title: Stocks Still Weak; Dow Off 4.52 Points
description: Stock prices continued to weaken yesterday, on trader fears that the Federal Reserve might not loosen its monetary policy further.

title: Mercedes Production
description: Daimler-Benz A.G., maker of Mercedes-Benz automobiles, expects to push its car output ''markedly above'' 500,000 vehicles in 1985, according to the company's spokesman, Bernd Gottschalk. In a statement on Thursday, he said that the company had planned to increase production to more than 500,000 units this year but that output would not exceed 480,000 cars because of the six- week strike by metalworkers in May and June.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about stock market trading on Thursday misstated the closing prices of R. H. Macy & Company and Sears, Roebuck & Company. Macy's closed at 42 5/8 and Sears at 31 1/8.

title: Books of The Times; Hope for the Retarded
description: THE WILLOWBROOK WARS: A Decade raveleof Struggle for Social Change. By David J. Rothman and Sheila M. Rothman. 405 pages. Harper & Row. $27.95.

title: ISRAEL TO ALLOW REVIEW OF FILES IN SHARON CASE
description: The Israeli Cabinet decided today to allow the retired president of the Israeli Supreme Court to examine classified documents pertaining to Ariel Sharon's libel suit against Time Inc. and to report on their contents to the Federal court in New York.

title: NURSING HOMES REACH CONTRACT IN 68-DAY STRIKE
description: A 68-day strike by unionized workers against 11 nursing homes in New York City was settled yesterday after a dispute over benefits was resolved.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14.

title: U.S. Trade Gap Above $100 Billion
description: The nation suffered a $9.2 billion foreign trade deficit in October, the Government said today, pushing the yearly total past $100 billion for the first time ever, with the figures from two more months still to be added.

title: PRINCE LOEWENSTIEN, HITLER FOE, DIES IN BONN AT 78
description: Prince Hubertus zu Loewenstein- Wertheim-Freudenberg, a German historian and political figure who was an early opponent of Hitler and, as a refugee, helped arouse Americans against Nazism, died Wednesday in Bonn of heart failure after suffering from peritonitis. He was 78 years old and lived in Bad Godesberg, a Bonn suburb.

title: UNDERSTANDING WHO IS HOMELESS IN NEW YORK CITY
description: With the return of cold weather, attention is turning to New York City's homeless people. Along with our outrage at their plight, and our frustration about what can be done for them, we need a new way of thinking about homelessness.

title: C.I.A. DISPUTE RAISES KNOTTY ISSUES
description: When the Central Intelligence Agency filed a complaint against ABC News this week, on the matter of a ''World News Tonight'' report concerning a reputed C.I.A. employee and his alleged illicit activities, it was utilizing a Federal Communications Commission regulation that says a licensee ''must have a policy of requiring honesty of its news staff and must take reasonable precautions to see that news is fairly handled.''

title: Temple Trounces Toledo Indoors
description: Lee Saltz threw two touchdown passes, including a 74-yarder, to lead Temple to a 35-6 rout over Toledo tonight in the first game played inside Convention Hall in 11 years.

title: MUSIC: ORFF 'CARMINA' BY BROOKLYN GROUP
description: The exceedingly curious production of ''Carmina Burana'' at Brooklyn's St. Ann's and the Holy Trinity Church on Thursday night began with the assumption that Carl Orff's simple, joyous barbarism is dramatically inept. Then it set about to right Orff's wrongs.

title: A European Is Killed In New Caledonia Clash
description: A European settler was killed today and six people were wounded when fighting broke out between whites and Melanesian militants demanding independence for New Caledonia, French officials reported.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGES

title: WESTERN STATES LIFE INS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including capital gains of $10,723 for the quarter and $42,533 for the 9 months. c-After a capital loss of $7,579 for the quarter and a capital gain of $120,207 for the 9 months.

title: New Year's Encore
description: Last year the District of Columbia

title: Victories for Voters in South America ; Uruguay's Slow Boat to Democracy
description: Uruguay's election last Sunday, its first in 13 years, proved to be a remembrance of things past. Most votes went to the Colorados and Blancos - the Reds and Whites - just as they did in voting before the military seized power in 1973. So Uruguay rejoins the democratic club in March under President-elect Julio Maria Sanguinetti of the centrist Colorados. The pity is that the transition took so long.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Dec. 1, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: DYNEER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
USACAFES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest year are for the 11 months since the company's inception to the end of its fiscal year, Sept. 30. USACafes became a separate company from Bonanza International on Oct. 31, 1983.

title: 200 SRI LANKA REBELS ARE SAID TO KILL AT LEAST 42 AT PRISON FARMS
description: The Government of this island nation off India said today that at least 42 people were killed when heavily armed Tamil guerrillas attacked two prison farms in the northern region.

title: East German Guards Remove Shrapnel Arms From Border
description: East German border guards today removed the last of some 60,000 shrapnel devices from the heavily guarded fenced frontier with West Germany, the Interior Ministry said.

title: THE WORKING POOR DESERVE A TAX BREAK
description: To the Editor:

title: 34 in Morristown HeldinDrugRaids
description: Morris County authorities arrested 34 people today in predawn raids on homes in this community and seized drugs, weapons, vehicles and cash, the County Prosecutor's office announced.

title: MAPLE LEAFS RALLY TO TIE RANGERS
description: The Rangers had one final flurry of shots. Barry Beck had a stab. So did Mike Rogers. And Chris Kontos had the best chance, but the puck trickled through the goalie's crease.

title: LIVING IN A FISHBOWL; One Man's Family
description: ''I've decided never to run for President,'' a friend says. ''Just think what it might trigger in my mother.'' Our friend was alluding to the logorrhea that overtakes those whose relatives suddenly find themselves in the Oval Office.

title: U.S. and Soviet Agree To Hold Regular Talks
description: The United States and the Soviet Union, expressing concern about the possible increase in the number of nations that may develop nuclear weapons, announced today that they will hold regular talks on preventing the spread of nuclear weapons twice a year.

title: Bridge:Teams With Only 4 PlayersDoing Well in Reisinger Play
description: Stamina is a factor in major national team championships, and conventional wisdom dictates that a team with five or six players has better prospects than a team of four, playing of necessity without rest. But recent evidence has pointed in the opposite direction.

title: PRESIDENTIAL STRATEGY: CONFRONTATION ON DEFICIT
description: For the start of his second term, President Reagan has set a course of confrontation with Democratic leaders, and possibly with some Republicans in Congress, by relying on large cuts in domestic spending to bring down the Federal budget deficit.

title: YOUTHFUL PACERS TROUNCED BY NETS
description: It wasn't long ago that the Nets were much like the Indiana Pacers are these days, a group of exuberant young players with little experience in the rough ways of the National Basketball Association. The Nets improved, however, as should the Pacers, who have four rookies on their roster and three other players who are in their second season.

title: BAYOU RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: IN ZAMIBIA, ISSUE IS NOT JUST DROUGHT
description: Zambia, a landlocked country in south-central Africa that is now in its third year of drought, could be a substantial food exporter. Instead, this nation of 6.5 million people has been spending its critically short foreign-exchange earnings for food imports even in good years.

title: U.S. INDIAN BUREAU ASSAILED IN REPORT
description: A Reagan Administration report on the status of Indian reservations sharply criticized the Bureau of Indian Affairs today and recommended that it be replaced by a new Federal agency.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Division in the life of the church is a contradiction of its very nature. The reasons for seeking unity among the churches are found in the Bible, in tradition and in the imperatives of witness and worldwide mission.'' - Statement by the Consultation on Church Union. (1:3.)

title: MAYFAIR SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
description: Results are for 13 and 52 weeks for the latest periods and 14 and 53 weeks for the year-ago periods.

title: Shakespeare Theater To Resolve Bankruptcy
description: A Federal judge confirmed a plan Thursday under which the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn., is to repay its creditors, to end bankruptcy proceedings against the once-renowned theater.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; 'Turbulent Sea of Adversity'
description: Agapito Aquino, brother of the assassinated Philippine opposition leader, Benigno Aquino, is in town from Manila for a week's activities in memory of his brother.

title: WEST BANK ARABS GIVE MIXED REVIEWS TO PALESTINIAN PARLEY
description: -Occupied West Bank, Nov. 30 - The meeting of the Palestine National Council in Amman earned mixed reviews today from the Arabs of Israel and the occupied territories, who were able to watch most of the proceedings live on television from the Jordanian capital.

title: Prices Farmers Get Fell 0.7% in Month
description: Prices that farmers get for raw products declined seven-tenths of 1 percent this month, averaging only 1.5 percent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: NATIONAL PESTICIDE POLICY IS DANGEROUS TO YOUR HEALTH
description: The village Board of Trustees of Wauconda, Ill., (pop. 5,688) last February unanimously adopted a ''right-to-know'' ordinance requiring pesticide-application firms to post signs on lawns and in yards, among other places, identifying the pesticides used and warning the public to stay off treated areas for 72 hours. This modest ordinance, which has become the target of a lawsuit filed by the pesticide industry, may well become a bellwether for the entire nation.

title: PLAN FOR TV BY SATELLITE FALLS APART OVER RISKS
description: A proposed joint venture that would broadcast television programs from satellites directly to home antennas fell apart yesterday, casting a cloud over the future of what once appeared to be a promising new technology.

title: 'Amahl' at Avery Fisher
description: The Little Orchestra Society's annual production of Gian Carlo Menotti's ''Amahl and the Night Visitors'' will be played at Avery Fisher Hall today at 11 A.m. and 1 P.M. Dino Anagnost will conduct. Mr. Menotti, who is staging the production, will introduce both programs. Tickets, from $16 to to $6, are available at the Avery Fisher box office (874-2424) or through Centercharge (874-6770).

title: Court Backs F.C.C. On Satellite TV Ruling
description: A United States Court of Appeals panel today affirmed a ruling by the Federal Communications Commission that local and state Governments may not regulate television programming distributed via satellite to private dwellings, including condominiums and apartment houses.

title: PUZZLING INSTRUCTION MANUALS
description: The stereo stand looks sleek and

title: IRATE HELMS ASSAILS THE PRESS
description: Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, on Thursday termed his re-election a victory over ''shoddy, biased and intellectually dishonest journalism'' because he succeeded in breaking a ''journalism curtain.''

title: RADICAL FUGITIVE IN BRINK'S ROBBERY ARRESTED
description: A Weather Underground fugitive who had been sought for two years in the $1.6 million Brink's robbery and murder case has been arrested in New Jersey by a police officer who became suspicious of her ill-fitting wig.

title: CONSUMER PANEL CHIEF RESIGNS HER POSITION
description: Nancy Harvey Steorts, a Republican who disagreed with the Reagan Administration on several issues, resigned today as chairman of the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title: A CHINESE DIPLOMAT AND JERSEY TEACHER
description: Dr. Kan Chieh-hou, an American- educated former Chinese diplomat who broke with Chiang Kai-shek after the Communist conquest of the mainland, died of a heart attack on Nov. 10 at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 87 years old and lived in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Chef's Death Ruled Homicide
description: The San Francisco coroner ruled Thursday after extensive tests that the death of Matsataka Kobayashi, a famous chef, was homicide. An earlier autopsy had left the cause unclear. Mr. Kobayashi, 45 years old, was last seen Nov. 11 when he walked from his restaurant, Masa's, to his Nob Hill apartment. His body was found the next day when his apartment was checked because he had failed to show up at the restaurant.

title: ASPIRATION, STRESS AND THE TRUE HENRY HIGGINS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Wrong Knee
description: Larry Collins , a 22-year-old defensive end for Cheyney State who hurt his right knee in a Nov. 10 loss to Shippensburg College, underwent a surgical procedure nine days later at Chester County Hospital in West Chester, Pa., on his good left knee. According to his aunt, Inez Rutland , Collins said, ''When I woke up, I found they operated on the wrong knee.''

title: New Interest in Army-Navy
description: Following more than a decade of declining interest in what was once the nation's most popular annual college football game, the 85th Army-Navy game, to be played here Saturday, has become a source of renewed fascination.

title: Two Refiners Cut Oil Prices By United Press International United States oil prices unraveled further yesterday as
description: Conoco Inc. cut its posted price

title: Hanukkah for the Young
description: As the holiday season approaches, the Smithsonian Institution is sponsoring a class to teach the young about Hanukkah, the Jewish Feast of Lights, a period for commemoration of the victory of the Maccabees' army over the Greco-Syrian king, Antiochus IV Epiphanes, who sought to eradicate Judaism in 165 B.C.

title: KAHANE'S CONSTITUENCY
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
New Video Telephone System
description: WASHINGTON A new two-way video phone that makes use of any single standard telephone line was patented this week. The device was conceived by Jerome H. Lemelson, a prolific inventor with more than 350 other patents, and Christian Grund, a research scientist at the University of Wisconsin.

title: TECHNALYSIS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bendix Purchase
description: The Allied Corporation's Bendix Aerospace sector has acquired Amex Systems Inc., according to the companies.

title: CHANGE OF LEADER WEIGHED IN UNESCO
description: Some Western delegates to Unesco say the possibility of replacing the agency's Director General, Amadou Mahtar M'Bow, is being discreetly discussed by several member governments.

title: Brotherly Rivalry
description: Eric and Scott Roth don't play football, but they will set a record of sorts for the student rooting sections when Army plays Navy today.

title: TURNBULL GAINS IN AUSTRALIA
description: Wendy Turnbull of Australia, Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia and unseeded Sophie Amiach of France advanced today to the quarterfinals of the $1.28 million Australian Open tennis championships at Kooyong.

title: BSD MEDICAL (CO) (O) reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
Aetna Names New Chairman
description: Aetna Life and Casualty today elected James T. Lynn chairman and chief executive officer, succeeding John H. Filer, who announced his retirement.

title: Vibes at Lush Life
description: The vibraphonist Bobby Hutcherson is leading his quartet tonight and tomorrow at Lush Life, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (228-3788). Sets are at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M. tonight 9 and 11 Sunday; there is a $12.50 cover ($10 Sunday) and a $6 minimum.

title: Ozawa Cancels in Boston Due to Death of Brother
description: Seiji Ozawa, music director of the Boston Symphony, will not appear with the orchestra tonight at Boston's Symphony Hall because of a death in his family. Mr. Ozawa's older brother Katsumi, a 56-year old sculptor and innkeeper, died of a stroke on Wednesday in Kyoto, Japan.

title: Virginia Electric
description: The Virginia Electric and Power Company, a unit of Dominion Resources Inc., said it had filed with the Virginia State Corporation Commission for a net increase in revenues of 4.7 percent, or $90 million. The increase is being requested to cover the costs of bringing into service a major new generating facility, the Bath County pumped storage station, and other costs created by new circumstances that are not being covered by current revenue.

title: CUOMO OPPOSES TESTING OF REACTOR AT SHOREHAM
description: Governor Cuomo said today that he opposed testing the Shoreham nuclear plant at very low power because of the lack of an emergency-evacuation plan.

title: THE BOOK TRAVELERS: 100 YEARS ON THE ROAD
description: The Association of Book Travelers - a hardy band of book salesmen with a shine on their scuffed shoes, a sincere smile and a 90-second summary for each of the books that they hope will include some of next season's best sellers - celebrated its 100th anniversary yesterday.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Portland Trail Blazers, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. New York fans get their first chance to see Sam Bowie as a pro. (Television - MSG Network, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WPAT, 930; WFAS, 1230; WGBB, 1240; all at 7:20 P.M.) Lapchick Memorial Tournament, at Alumni Hall, Utopia Parkway and Union Turnpike, Jamaica, Queens, consolation game at 7 P.M. and championship game at 9 P.M. The second and final evening of a tourney involving St. John's, Lafayette, St. Francis of Brooklyn and St. Bonaventure. (Radio - St John's game only, WCBS, 880; 7 P.M. or 9 P.M.)

title: MANY NEW YORKERS WOULD FACE HIGHER TAXES IN TREASURY'S PLAN
description: Middle- income residents of New York State who own property and itemize their deductions would owe much higher taxes under the Treasury Department's tax proposals than they do now, according to a preliminary analysis by an experienced accountant.

title: HOMER HOYT, EARLY PLANNER OF URBAN SHOPPING CENTERS
description: Dr. Homer Hoyt, a land economist and market analyst who pioneered in the planning and development of urban shopping centers, died of pnuemonia Thursday at Holy Cross Hospital in Siver Spring, Md. He was 89 years old and lived in Washington.

title: NUTRITION WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: DANCE: 'FRESH TRACKS,' YOUNG CHOREOGRAPHERS
description: The young choreographers who offered the fascinating program called ''Fresh Tracks'' on Tuesday night at the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater were all interested in unusual movement. However, their concern was not simply movement invention; they were also interested in movement as it expresses emotions.

title: Military Contracts
description: The Lockheed Corporation received Air Force contracts totaling $230.4 million for C-5B aircraft equipment and for training equipment, the Defense Department said. In addition, the General Electric Company got a $216.5 million order from the Navy for 1,549 gas turbine engines and the General Dynamics Corporation received contracts totaling $204.3 million for Navy missiles, Army tank production materials and Air Force aircraft equipment, the department said.

title: BRIGHAM YOUNG HAS ALL OF THE PROOF IT NEEDS THAT IT'S NO.1
description: Virtually all other issues have been pushed to the background in Provo and the entire Utah Valley as people play a game called ''We Beat, They Beat.''

title: COMMERCIAL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
JUDGE SETS NEW VON BULOW TRIAL BUT DECISION TO PROSECUTE WAITS
description: Claus von B"ulow's second trial on charges he tried to murder his wife has been tentatively set to begin Feb. 18.

title: SCOUTING ; Against the Grain
description: A demographic study undertaken by the New York Road Runners Club of the 14,590 finishers in this year's New York Marathon suggests that the typical participant was a married male New York educator, from 30 to 39 years old, who had been running for about five years.

title: DANCE: THE CITY BALLET
description: In ''Menuetto,'' Helgi Tomasson has choreographed a first-class ballet, as refined as its Mozart score and as attuned to 20th-century dynamics as its brilliant dancers.

title: THE HILLBILLIES' STORY, TOLD IN FILMS AT MODERN
description: Hillbillies are shiftless and backward, according to the pronouncements of generations of editorial writers and bureaucrats. Hillbillies are ignorant and foolish, according to decades of Hollywood movies and television programs. Hillbillies are so primitive their social organization is scarcely more sophisticated than that of savages, according to a succession of historians.

title: EAST SIDE, WEST SIDE: THE LIGHTS FANTASTIC
description: Thousands, hundreds of thousands, probably millions of lights are going on all over New York. Little ruby and emerald Christmas lights festooned over neighborhood streets. Red-ribboned wreaths twinkling in the windows of brownstones. Tree lights. Display lights. Candle lights.

title: Malta and Libya Sign Military-Training Pact
description: The Libyan military will train the Maltese armed forces under a mutual friendship and cooperation agreement signed earlier this month.

title: THE LOW TAX RATE OF MANY INDUSTRIES
description: The average income tax rate for large corporations last year was 16.7 percent, well below the nominal corporate tax rate of 46 percent, a Congressional study released today disclosed.

title: Dofasco to Spend $600 Million
description: Dofasco Inc. said it would spend $600 million (Canadian currency) on construction and renovations at its Hamilton operations. The company said it would install a slab casting unit for continuous steel casting, modify a steelmaking shop, and add slab heating equipment, two additional finishing stands and a coiler and coil conveyor.

title: Stennis's Leg Removed To Eliminate a Tumor
description: Surgeons today removed the left leg of Senator John C. Stennis to eliminate a malignant tumor in his upper thigh.

title: AUTHOR FOUND IN CONTEMPT
description: A Federal judge found the author of a controversial biography of Pope John Paul II in contempt of court yesterday for failing to comply with a court order to produce all notes, travel records, correspondence and photographs collected in the writing of the book. The biography, ''God's Broker'' was withdrawn from book stores after its publisher termed it ''fraudulent.''

title: ASPIRATION, STRESS AND THE TRUE HENRY HIGGINS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ONCE-TRENDY, NOW-PASSE KIWI IS STILL TASTY
description: Declaring myself a lover of kiwis is likely to lower my standing in the food world. Through overuse and misuse, kiwis have become pariahs among those who set the trends. Where once sparkling green little ovoid slices of kiwi graced every plate that came out of nouvelle cuisine kitchens, whether they were appropriate or not, kiwis are now relegated to sherbet, if they are used at all.

title: Small Miracle in Argentina
description: It had baffled mediators like the Vatican, Queen Elizabeth II and the World Court. It nettled five generations of politicians, diplomats, lawyers and editorialists.

title: Back on the Run
description: New Orleans is a big underdog to the Los Angeles Rams at Anaheim, Calif., tomorrow, but the Saints will have at least one thing going for them: Their leading yards-per-carry running back has recovered from a pulled calf muscle that sidelined him for the last two games.

title: YALE, AS STRIKERS RETURN, WEIGHS THE DAMAGE TO AN INTELLECTUAL COMMUNITY
description: As striking clerical and technical workers at Yale University planned to return to work next Tuesday without a settlement, many teachers and students expressed serious concerns about academic and intellectual life here after almost 10 weeks of the strike.

title:
PATENTS;
Flap-Type Heart Valve
description: A replacement heart valve of the flap type was patented this week by two medical researchers in Lyons, France.

title: Congressmen Held After Embassy Protest
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) Two Democratic Congressmen and a black labor official were arrested today at the South African Embassy, swelling to 16 the number of prominent people detained since Nov. 21 in demonstrations against that country's racial policies.

title: FRANKLIN RESOURCES reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
MCDERMOTT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
One-Woman Show
description: The comedian Beth Lapides will appear this weekend at Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street.

title: GOV. EDWARDS OF LOUISIANA SAYS HE IS TARGET OF U.S. FRAUD INQUIRY
description: Gov. Edwin Edwards said today that he was a target of a Federal grand jury investigation of his relationship with health-care organizations that paid him $1 million and then were exempted from his ban on new construction.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Interest Rates Rise for 2d Day
description: Reaction to Money Jump

title: TEKTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 10
Editors Group Bids India Drop Reporter Case
description: The Associated Press Managing Editors Association adopted a resolution today calling on the Government of India to ''cease all proceedings, under way and contemplated'' against an Associated Press correspondent.

title: Uruguayan Military Frees Jailed Politician
description: A Uruguayan opposition leader, Wilson Ferreira Aldunate, was released from prison today, five days after elections in which the military banned him from running for president, defense lawyers said.

title: JUDGE HALTS U.S. SWAP OF ISLAND IN ALASKA REFUGE
description: A Federal district judge today voided a Federal land exchange that would have allowed oil companies to use an island wildlife refuge as a base for drilling in the Bering Sea.

title: State Seat Belt Law Takes Effect Today
description: New York State's mandatory seat belt law - the first in the nation - went into effect today.

title: CARME INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
TRUMP SET TO BUT LINCOLN WEST SITE
description: Donald J. Trump said yesterday that he had an agreement to buy the site of the proposed $1 billion Lincoln West housing and office complex on the West Side and that he planned to redesign the project.

title: REAGAN AND KOHL URGE NONNUCLEAR ARMS BUILDUP
description: President Reagan and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany called today for a new effort by the Atlantic alliance to strengthen conventional forces in Western Europe to reduce the risk or need of nuclear weapons.

title: OTTAWA, PARIS IN TALKS
description: Canadian and French officials met this week to discuss increasing trade between the two countries, the president of Canada's Treasury Council said Thursday.

title: IDYLLS OF THE KID
description: J oe DiMaggio is 70. His birthday was

title: Kasparov Postpones Chess Game in Moscow
description: The 29th game of the world chess championship match was postponed today by Gary Kasparov, the challenger.

title: U.S.OfficialLauds Indian Point Drill
description: The state and county governments and the New York Power Authority received high marks for a full-scale drill of emergency procedures this week near the Indian Point nuclear- power plants, Federal officials said today.

title: New Minimum Bank Balances
description: Next Jan. 1, the minimum balance requirement for three types of accounts at banks and savings and loan associations will decline to $1,000 from the present minimum of $2,500. But not all banks and thrift institutions will drop their minimums, and some that do may establish a tiered interest rate system, whereby higher deposits will receive higher rates.

title: MULLIN AND BERRY LEAD ST. JOHN'S ROMP
description: After a month of tedious intra- squad srimmages, a lopsided exhibition victory over a weary Brazilian club team and the most intense preseason buildup in the school's recent history, St. John's officially opened its 1984-85 basketball campaign last night in thunderous fashion.

title: OLD ANDES LANGUAGE FINDS NICHE IN COMPUTER AGE
description: As a boy, Ivan Guzman de Rojas would roam among the alpaca herds and mud huts of the high Andes with his father, at the time Bolivia's best-known painter of the Indians known as the Aymaras.

title: FUNDS FOR HOUSING AND MEDICAID SEEN AS TARGET OF CUTS
description: President Reagan tentatively decided today on cuts in the projected budgets for Medicaid and Federal housing assistance, according to Administration officials.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1984

title: PART 1 OF SUMRIAN DICIONARY APPEARS
description: Amid much fanfare and erudite wit, the first volume of the first dictionary of the world's first written language, Sumerian, was officially published here today at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
THE BEAT GOES ON, INSIDE THEIR HOME
description: The big bass beat of Prince's ''Erotic City'' - powered by 14,500 watts through 130 speakers - pounds patrons of the Limelight dance club in the chest like so many paramedics trying to restart their hearts.

title: Washington Protests to Chile Over Expulsion of a Reporter
description: The United States said today that it sent a strong protest to Chile over its expulsion of United Press International's Santiago bureau chief for purportedly filing a false report.

title: BOB EVANS FARMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
SCOUTING ; Taking a Swing At a Boxer's Ego
description: Jose Torres, the new chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, was telling the story of his first payday in boxing. This was 1957, and Torres, then an amateur, received $40 for sparring with Sugar Ray Robinson.

title: U.S. Lets Heileman Make Its Pabst Bid
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it would not challenge the bid by the G. Heileman Brewing Company to acquire the Pabst Brewing Company for $63 million after Heileman said it would dispose of certain assets.

title: DEMOCRAT RECONSIDERS A CHALLENGE TO O'NEILL
description: Representative Charles W. Stenholm, Democrat of Texas, hinted today that he might abandon his bid to oust House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. after winning a promise from Mr. O'Neill to give conservative Democrats a greater voice in House decision-making.

title: WOOLFOLK ASSIGNED TO RETURN KICKOFFS
description: Lionel Manuel will return punts and Butch Woolfolk will return kickoffs for the Giants against the Jets at Giants Stadium Sunday, Coach Bill Parcells said today. Phil McConkey handled both assignments until last Sunday, when he broke three ribs and dislocated a fourth in a 28-27 victory over the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: 9 MAJOR CHURCHES APPROVE ACCORDS TO BRING A MERGER
description: Capping a 22-year effort, representatives of nine major Protestant denominations yesterday approved a set of accords intended to provide the theological basis for the eventual merger of the churches.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in Sports Pages on Nov. 7 about the race in the Eastern Division of the National Football Conference referred incorrectly to the newspaper method of listing tied teams in standings. The Associated Press says it lists such teams according to the National Football League's tie-breaking procedure.

title: H.R.A. AIDE JUDGED CHILDREN TO BE 'SAFE' BEFORE 2 WERE SLAIN
description: The Human Resources Administration said yesterday that a woman who killed her son and her nephew Thursday in a South Bronx apartment had been reported by the police to have neglected her children.

title: ASPIRATION, STRESS AND THE TRUE HENRY HIGGINS
description: To the Editor: While John Chancellor himself may prefer ''a'' to ''an'' before ''historic,'' his fuss over those who don't is exces

title: Oilers Win, 4-2, For 6th in Row
description: Mike Krushelnyski had two goals and Wayne Gretzky had two assists tonight as Edmonton extended its winning streak to six games by beating the Hartford Whalers, 4-2.

title: ASPIRATION, STRESS AND THE TRUE HENRY HIGGINS

title: Italian Prices Up

description: Supporters of an activist Lutheran pastor said today that they would not obey their synod's order to give up the keys and records of Trinity Church in nearby Clairton.

description: Australia is holding parliamentary elections today, and all signs point to a victory by the Labor Government of Prime Minister Bob Hawke.

description: Two senior police officers investigating the killing of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, the pro- Solidarity priest, were killed along with their driver today in a head-on collision with a truck, the Government reported.

title: NEW CITIZENS: A SENSE OF BELONGING SPICED WITH OPPORTUNITY
description: They met no gracious Lady Liberty at America's Pacific shore, no grim Ellis Island as a gateway to a brighter world. But by air and over land, from the nations of the globe, 2,000 immigrants who had come to California today claimed a place as new American citizens.

title: FLATLEY SCORES TWICE AS ISLANDERS TRIUMPH
description: Pat Flatley made his pro debut in the Winnipeg Arena on Feb. 29 last season and scored his first goal on his first shot. And tonight the Islander right wing achieved another personal first here, scoring twice for the first time in a regular-season game, leading a 5-2 victory over the Winnipeg Jets.

title: FOR MAZDA, A U.S. CAR PLANT
description: Detroit's hard- pressed auto workers, after years of chafing under Japanese competition, suddenly face a prospect of being employed by Japanese auto makers.

title: Starling Wars
description: Every morning, by the dawn's early light, thousands of starlings take off from their perches in the magnolia trees around the White House. They fly to Virginia and Maryland to spend the day on the job, which is mostly eating bugs and worms.

title:
PATENTS;
A Method to Purify Human Interferon
description: The Cetus Corporation, a biogenetic company in Emeryville, Calif., received a patent this week for a method it is using to purify human interferon, a protein used medically as an antiviral and anticancer agent.

description: The governing National Party retained three parliamentary seats in special elections, fending off challenges by far- right candidates who said the white-minority Government favored sharing power with blacks.

title: MEN'S GIFTS: CLASSICS REINTERPRETED
description: There are gifts and then there are Gifts. The former are what one might reasonably expect to receive; the latter come as a joyous surprise. These, in fact, don't have to come completely out of the blue. Some of the best-looking potential presents around town are, in fact, classics that have returned with just enough of a difference to make them look fresh once more. Nor does the offbeat and unexpected necessarily mean stratospheric prices tags.

description: The sales tax in Suffolk County will increase a quarter of a percentage point Saturday, from 7.25 percent to 7.5 percent.

title: Sutter Stands Firm
description: Bruce Sutter , a pitcher who likes to put down roots and keep them there, may not be stubborn, but when he says he won't sign a contract without a no-trade clause, he just may mean it. Sutter, a free agent who made $3.5 over the last four seasons, has turned down a $12.3 million offer to stay with the St. Louis Cardinals because the guaranteed, five-year, deferred-payment deal offered by the club didn't contain a no-trade clause.

The successful experiments could pave the way for a reasonably comfortable life for recipients of artificial hearts.

description: Soviet military capability continues to outpace that of the United States despite the Reagan Administration's substantial increasess in military spending, a private national security research group reported today.

title: LIVING IN A FISHBOWL; No MozartThe emphasis in the 60's was on educational ''relevance'' and in the 70's on jobs. Does that make the key word of the 80's ignorance? Yes, at least for a 31-member panel convened by the National Endowment for the Humanities. In a report on the decline of the humanities in higher education, it finds that students can easily obtain bachelor's degrees knowing FORTRAN but not French or world history or Mozart. ''Most of our college graduates remain shortchanged in the humanities,'' the report says, ''history, literature, philosophy and the ideals and practices of the past that have shaped the society they enter.''
description: Who's to blame? Mostly the universities. In the late 60's they too-eagerly abandoned course requirements.

description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1984 International A U.S. ship drifted into Cuban waters, prompting officials to order the aircraft carrier Nimitz to the area so quickly that 1,000 crewmen were left behind, Pentagon officials said. The ship, chartered by the Navy, had broken down before it started to drift. It was rescued by a Coast Guard cutter. (Page 1, Column 5.)

title: U.S. VOTER TURNOUT: NOW WORLD'S MOST WORST
description: A historical landmark of sorts was set in the Presidential election. The United States moved from its traditional position as the next-to-worst nation of the world in voter turnout to the absolute lowest, at 52.4 percent of eligible voters. Botswana, the traditional doormat, experienced a surge of voter participation this year and nosed just ahead.

title: BETA VERSUS VHS-LISTENING FOR DIFFERENCES IN STEREO SOUND
description: Many viewers dickering with Santa Claus about their first VCR this time of year are likely to opt for a basic model with a single monophonic sound track. This suffices for all ordinary purposes, such as recording television programs, both broadcast and cable, or playing pre- recorded cassettes. But veteran video fans who like to keep abreast of the latest developments and anticipate stereo TV broadcasts and a growing supply of pre-recorded stereo cassettes probably regard Christmas as a good excuse for trading in their basic VCR for one of the new hi-fi models. Now, for the first time, they have a choice between Beta and VHS in the hi-fi format.

title: Recalling Some Contested Cars
description: Safety on the highways begins on the car maker's drawing board. With the prodding of Government regulators, the Big Three auto companies last week announced that they would recall more than four million cars, the sixth biggest recall ever and the largest during the Reagan Administration.

title: LITTLE-KNOWN AGENCY'S WAR ON SEWAGE
description: Reporting to Emperor Napoleon 3d after a culinary inspection tour of the American eastern seaboard, a French lieutenant raved over the succulent shellfish taken from the region's waters. France had much to learn, the emissary, P. de Broca, wrote after his tour in 1862. ''The most highly esteemed oysters come from the bays of New York, New Haven and Providence; from different parts of Long Island Sound; from the shores of New Jersey,'' he said in his report.

title: CORRECTION

They were appointed by the Federal courts and have not been paid. They are seeking fees from the State of Missouri, the defendant in the case.

title: Health-Care Providers Barred From Medicare

title: FLORIDA CITRUS INDUSTRY BOUNCES BACK
description: Florida's citrus industry is proving resilient despite a devastating freeze last winter and the continuing spread of the virulent disease citrus canker. But growers have expressed renewed concern after the discovery of the first canker in a mature grove.

The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas D. Bowers, assisted by the Rev. Raymond Byrne, a Roman Catholic priest.

The Rev. Robert Romano, a Roman Catholic priest, and Cantor Robert Paul Abelson performed the ceremony at the Alpine (N.J.) Country Club. Mrs. Rosenberg is manager of marketing and office administration for Advanced Systems Concepts, a software engineering and consulting concern in Hoboken, N.J., of which Mr. Rosenberg is the founder and president.

title: HERB GROWERS FIND THAT BUSINESS BLOSSOMS, TOO
description: WITH rising interest in alternative medical care, holistic approaches and healing through natural means, herb businesses are flourishing throughout the state, each distinctive in its approach.

title: OPERA: THE CHICAGO LYRIC IN 'DIE FRAU' BY STRAUSS
description: The 30th anniversary season of the Chicago Lyric Opera is not just a months-long celebratory gala, with new productions of five operas (out of seven operas in total) never before given by the company. It is also, because of the advance planning necessary in the world of international opera, the first season entirely planned by the company's new general manager, Ardis Krainik, along with her artistic director, the conductor Bruno Bartoletti.

title: DANCE: WENDY OSSERMAN TROUPE
description: What is the difference between a wrestling hold and an embrace? As a choreographer, Wendy Osserman seems to play upon ambiguities inherent in body contact.

title: AMERICAN VICTIMS OF HIROSHIMA
description: Robert Karl Manoff is on leave as managing editor of Harper's to write a book on press coverage of nuclear weapons issues. By Robert Karl Manoff THERE MUST BE THOUSANDS like it in dens and scrapbooks all over America, one of those crew pictures from World War II, from the days when Vietnam was still in the future and boys from the heartland felt good about going off to war. Nine of them are gathered in this photograph, B-24 fliers who have just finished their training and are poised for their Pacific passage. Four crouch in the foreground. Blackie, their dog, holds steady for the camera between the tail gunner's legs. The fliers are fresh-faced and confident, their caps tilted at rakish angles and their flight-jacket collars turned up for maximum effect. Their picture is one of those images that makes you proud to be an American and shows you that they were, too. But this portrait, similar to so many of its vintage in so many ways, differs from them in one respect: Six months after it was taken, five of these men from the bomber called Lonesome Lady, plus a sixth who was not in the photo, died as prisoners of war when the United States dropped an atomic bomb on Hiroshima.

title: ; Explaining Liberation Theology
description: Pope John Paul II, rather than constructing ''a case against liberation theology,'' as Michael Novak states, has publicly endorsed several of its major tenets, including ''the preferential option for the poor,'' the priority of labor over capital and the social sinfulness of ''unfettered'' capitalism (''The Case Against Liberation Theology,'' Oct. 21).

title: MIDPRICED COMPONENTS GIVE THE MOST PLEASURE PER DOLLAR
description: The middle class is often regarded with unreasonable condescension. But then snobbery of all sorts is unreasonable. After all, in social hierarchies, the middle class is often a veritable hotbed of civic virtue and economic productivity. And in the hierarchy of industrial artifacts, it is often the midpriced goods that offer the best value. This certainly holds true among stereo components, where the middle class is solid in every way.

title: PRODUCTION OF GAS RISES IN NEW YORK
description: The production of natural gas in New York State rose to a record 20 billion cubic feet in 1983, enough to supply residents of the state for about 12 days, according to the State Environmental Conservation Department.

title: MR. REAGAN, GENEVA IS NOT APPOMATTOX
description: The meeting between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko scheduled for early January offers President Reagan a unique opportunity to get the arms control agreement he now describes as his first priority. The Soviet Union has agreed to talk, without conditions, about ''the entire complex of questions concerning nuclear and space weapons.'' In order to agree to meet for this purpose, the Soviet leaders have had to swallow a year's worth of verbiage. They walked out of the talks on intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe when deployment of United States Pershing 2 and ground- launched cruise missiles began last November. Then they refused to set a date for resumption of the strategic arms reductions talks on intercontinental ballistic missiles, submarine- launched ballistic missiles and strategic bombers. Until last week, they had insisted on removal of all United States missiles from Europe as the price for their return. Does the evident Soviet eagerness to get back to the bargaining table constitute a victory for President Reagan's policy of talking tough and presenting tough negotiating demands? It may - if he knows how to be a good winner. Konstantin U. Chernenko and his colleagues are clearly concerned about having to match United States technology in a competition in space weapons. Moreover, the stagnant Soviet economy will be hard put to bear the heavy costs of an uncontrolled arms race. But it would, in my opinion, be a sad mistake to conclude that these pressures will lead the Soviet Union now to accept the United States proposals on intermediate-range and intercontinental-range nuclear weapons presented in 1982 and 1983 - proposals that the former Secretary of State, Alexander M. Haig Jr., has characterized as ''absurd'' and ''non-negotiable.''

title: Where Colleges Fail
description: 'When students demanded a greater role in setting their own educational agendas, we eagerly responded by abandoning course requirements of any kind and with them the intellectual authority to say to students what the outcome of a college education ought to be. With intellectual authority relinquished, we found that we did not need to worry about what was worth knowing, worth defending, worth believing.

title: OUTSIDE AFRICA, FOOD PRODUCTION SHOWS BIG RISE
description: Ten years ago last month, when agricultural officials from every region of the globe met in Rome for the 1974 World Food Conference, famine was threatening in Asia and Africa.

title: LOOKING OVER THE SHOULDER OF NORTH AND SOUTH KOREA
description: Neither North Korea nor South Korea likes to admit it, but the fate of their divided peninsula continues to be shaped by the big powers, directly and otherwise, as events last week made clear. A young Russian, Vasily Yakovlevich Matuzok, had defected to the West on Nov. 23, choosing one of the world's more dangerous routes.

title: Ruckelshaus Ends a Return Engagement
description: The bottom line on William D. Ruckelshaus's resignation last week as head of the Environmental Protection Agency may have been the bottom lines - his and his agency's. To some Washington insiders, it was the prospect of a deep cut in the E.P.A. budget, which had been bolstered under his tenure but was still less than what he had sought, that led Mr. Ruckelshaus to step down. Others thought it was his $69,800-a-year Federal salary, on which he had to pay tuition for four college-aged children. He had been making more than $200,000 as an executive of the Weyerhaeuser Corporation. For his part, Mr. Ruckelshaus said he was leaving because of ''a whole lot of personal things'' and because ''I decided I had accomplished what I could accomplish.''
