title: CAFE CHAT AND BODY LANGUAGE
description: J. D. McClatchy teaches in the Creative Writing Program at Princeton University. His latest collection of poems is ''Scenes From Another Life.'' THE IDIOT PRINCESS OF THE LAST DYNASTY By Peter Klappert. 205 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $8.95. RAW HEAVEN By Molly Peacock. 54 pp. New York: Random House. Cloth, $12.95. Vintage. Paper, $6.95. THE LATE WISCONSIN SPRING By John Koethe. 51 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $6.95.

title: A Sergeant Gets His Man
description: A police sergeant headed to his home in the Bronx early yesterday, frustrated by an unsuccessful search for a missing 23-year-old retarded man. The sergeant, Carmine Tabacco of the 46th Precinct, had just parked his car at 12:50 A.M. near his home on Palisades Avenue when a man came up and asked for a quarter. The sergeant gave him the money and then realized he was the man he had been looking for. The man had been reported missing by his mother 10 miles away at 11:30 P.M.

title: THE SPACE PROGRAM'S UNSUNG HEROES STAR IN A MINI-SERIES
description: LOS ANGELES Like the architects of the space program itself, the creators of the 13-hour, $30 million mini-series called ''Space'' have had imposing logistical problems to solve before blast-off. Adapted from James Michener's best-selling novel, one of the author's typically sweeping sagas, ''Space'' is nothing less than a chronicle of the first three decades of the space program in America.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: GROUND has been broken for a $24 million office and research park in West Windsor Township that will be called the International Corporate Center at Princeton. The developer of the complex is the John E. Wiltshier Corporation, the United States subsidiary of Wiltshier Group Ltd. of London.

title: ECONOMICS CLASS TO BE TRIED IN YONKERS
description: FOR Dr. Joseph E. Donohue, the decision of the Yonkers public schools to cooperate with Junior Achievement of Westchester in a new economics program was based on a simple matter of supply and demand.

title: BASEBALL'S TALES OF DISTRESS
description: Once upon a time, when its fans were young and gay, baseball was considered a sport. In this enlightened and expensive age, in which innocence has given way to reality, baseball is called a business. The people who operate it wonder if it will live happily ever after.

title: CRIME
description: There's a nice variation on the standard Agatha Christie situation in CORPSE IN A GILDED CAGE by Robert Barnard (Scribners, $12.95). A new lord - an earl - and his lady have unexpectedly come into a tremendous estate. The Earl decides to have a family party. He also has made up his mind to sell the estate. All the members of the titled family gather for the festivities. There are those among them who do not take kindly to the Earl's decision, so he is murdered. In comes the portly, experienced Superintendent Hickory (no first name ever given), and he solves the case.

title: A SPECIAL FLAIR WITH SEAFOOD
description: WITH little fanfare, Stamford has acquired not just one, but several very good restaurants. One of those, La Parisienne on Hope Street, has opened a second establishment downtown, called Saint Tropez. It follows a similar format but has a different menu. Its chef, Roger Weissang, was formerly at Cinquante-Cinq in Greenwich.

title: ILLINOIS TURNS BACK OKLAHOMA BY 73-70
description: Efrem Winters tipped away an Oklahoma inbounds pass with 31 seconds to go today to help give Illinois a 73-70 victory over Oklahoma in a non-conference basketball game.

title:
ANTIQUES;
5 GRACIOUS HOMES IN BENEFIT TOURS
description: -room mansion built in neighboring Locust by United States Senator W. Warren Barbour in 1929-30 is one of five homes that will be open to the public Friday for the Holiday House Tour, an annual fund-raising event sponsored by MCOSS Nursing Services.

title: Dimmesdale Poisoned? Anna Pushed?
description: How many readers of ''The Scarlet Letter'' have passed right over the word ''apple-peru'' on the second page? All of them, we'll bet, but not anymore - not if they're also reading The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on last Sunday's Art page accompanying John Russell's essay about ''Content: A Contemporary Focus 1974-1984,'' an exhibit at the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington, inadvertently associated ''Labryrinth,''a work by Robert Morris, with a tableau vivant by Joseph Beuys. Although both works are in the exhibit, they are unrelated.

title: Autopsy Raises New Questions
description: The results of an autopsy on Eleanor Bumpurs, the Bronx woman shot to death by the police in an eviction dispute, raised additional questions last week about the propriety of the actions taken by police officers.

title: Blast Kills Filipino Student
description: A student passer- by was killed and 11 other people were injured in an explosion at a militia outpost in the heart of this southern Philippines city tonight, the police said.

title: RABBIS LEARN, AND TEACH, OF FAMILIES IN CRISIS
description: Social workers and psychologists met with a group of rabbis from the New York area last week to discuss ways of dealing with families in crisis.

title: WHAT WE REALLY KNOW ABOUT RUSSIA
description: A clarification is in order regarding Leslie Gelb's reference to the Soviet Interview Project in his article. The substantive comments about the Soviet economy that are attributed to me are accurate, but they were not based on interview data collected by the Soviet Interview Project.

title: THE LONG DIPLOMATIC HISTORY OF VENICE
description: To the Editor:

title: A BLUNT NEW TAX CHIEF TAKES OVERS IN THE SENATE
description: WASHINGTON SENATOR BOB PACKWOOD sat

title: MAKING BIG BUSINESS A THREAT IT CAN'T REFUSE
description: In the mid-1960's, the N.A.A.C.P. called a boycott of businesses in Port Gibson, Miss., to underscore its discontent with the lack of participation by the town's black majority in the white-dominated political and commercial life. From that experiment in the power of the unspent dollar sprang an effective strategy to persuade or force businesses to hire and promote blacks and invest in minority communities.

title: CONCERT: DAVID MASLANKA
description: We have grown accustomed to new- music programs featuring vastly different works by different composers, but on Wednesday night, David Maslanka, in a concert of his own music at Symphony Space, proved an esthetic one-man army. All three pieces on the program - ''Quintet for Winds,'' ''Concerto for Piano, Winds and Percussion'' and ''Lincoln Speaks at Gettysburg: A Musical Narrative,'' composed over a 10-year period, were markedly dissimilar in approach.

title: FLUTIE IS WINNER IN HEISMAN VOTE
description: A rain-soaked desperation pass - traveling 64 yards in the twilight in the Orange Bowl, with no time remaining on the clock - elevated Doug Flutie from a college football hero to a national celebrity. ''The Pass'' that enabled Boston College to defeat Miami the day after Thanksgiving was the essence of this daring undersized quarterback. It was a play worth more than any words to describe the qualities that have enabled Flutie to win the Heisman Trophy, which was awarded last night by the Downtown Athletic Club.

title: PARTI QUEBECOIS FACING A 'MOMENT OF TRUTH'
description: Premier Rene Levesque appears to have patched a growing breach in his governing Parti Quebecois this week, but the party's electoral prospects seem to have sunk further.

title: CANADIAN AUTO WORKERS THREATEN TO SPLIT UNION
description: The Canadian branch of the United Automobile Workers said today that it would ask this month for nearly complete autonomy from the union's United States-dominated leadership.

title: MAILBAG
description: DEBATING THE STATE OF TV DEBATES

title: COUNCIL SEEKS HOLIDAY FOOD FOR NEEDY
description: ''THIS is the first time the Westchester Corporate Volunteer Council is getting together on a project, and we're pooling all our resources to make it work,'' said Elaine Ostrowski, chairman of the newly formed council and a community-relations specialist at American Telephone & Telegraph.

title: WOMEN ON THE FIRING LINE
description: Hosannas to Betty Friedan and Elizabeth Holtzman. Theirs was a timely presentation of women's rights at the American Jewish Congress in Israel last August.

title: WHEN TERROR THREATENS: WHAT U.S. HAS LEARNED
description: Shortly before the Nov. 6 election, American intelligence detected what officials describe as hard evidence that Shiite Moslem terrorists planned to attack yet another American installation in Lebanon.

title: HILDA WEBER'S PLEASURE DOME
description: Nora Ephron's latest book is ''Heartburn,'' a novel. Y favorite story in ''The Estates of Beverly Hill'' - an insane, lavish, riveting book (which is not exactly a book, but I'll get to that) - is the one about plain, stocky Hilda Weber. Plain, stocky Hilda Weber was a nurse in New York in 1920 when she met an elderly Cincinnati glass manufacturer, recently widowed, who was recovering from a heart attack. She married him and he died, leaving her his fortune. She promptly married the chauffeur and spent $2 million to build one of the estates pictured in ''The Estates of Beverly Hills.'' It had 60 rooms, an 18- karat gold tea set made for the Czar of Russia, a marble-ceilinged bakery and walk-in silver, fur and wine vaults. Hilda hired 12 servants and 12 gardeners. She bought a silver service for 80. She threw four parties a week. But after 10 years, she was broke and was forced to sell her house for a humiliating $225,000 - including the furniture. She gambled the last of her money away and killed herself.

title: ALBURT FINISHES AT TOP OF BARCLAY
description: Lev Alburt of New York, the United States champion, won the second Barclay Gallery International Tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club. The 39-year-old former Russian grandmaster scored 8-1 (winning 7 games and drawing 2) and was awarded the $1,000 first prize in the 10-player round-robin.

title: Female Veteran Dies at 102
description: -SALEM, N.C., Dec. 1 (AP) - Laura M. Nell, the nation's second-oldest female military veteran, who once was a nurse for Gen. Douglas MacArthur, died here Thursday at the age of 102.

title: FARM PANEL FINDS TECHNOLOGY RISING
description: Greater numbers of big farms and small farms, but fewer moderate-size ones, are in the future for New York agriculture, according to a series of papers presented here this week at a conference on farming in the year 2000.

title: UNION IS VICTORIOUS
description: Union scored three touchdowns in the fourth quarter and defeated Montclair, 34-13, for the championship of the North Jersey Section 2 Group 4 state playoffs yesterday in Union.

title: Hunting with Muzzleloading Firearms
description: As one who hovers on the edge of being totally captivated by hunting with muzzleloading firearms, I am trying to comprehend the fascination.

title: 2 SOVIET DESERTERS, BACK HOME, DEPICTED AS HEROES
description: Two young soldiers who fought in Afghanistan and returned home last month from Britain were portrayed here today in a heroic light as having withstood pressures to betray the Soviet Union.

title: FRANKLIN ADVANCES
description: Franklin and Matawan, each unbeaten, advanced to next Saturday's final of Central Jersey Group 3 with semifinal-round victories. Franklin (11-0), paced by the passing of Darin Roberts, defeated Colonia (7-3), 28-8, in Colonia. Matawan (10-0) ended the state's current longest winning streak when it defeated Wall (10-1), 20-14, in Matawan.

title: RESERVOIR COST HAS RISEN 125%
description: HOWELL TOWNSHIP THE projected cost of the Manasquan River Reservoir, put at $40 million when the proposal was approved by voters in 1981, has now risen nearly 125 percent, to $89 million, and a state water-supply official says the final price will be even higher.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
NICKELODEON RINGS IN THE HOLIDAYS
description: Steve Schneider frequently reports on developments in cable.

title: WHY 'THE NUTCRACKER' HAS CONQUERED THE NATION
description: ''I have liked this ballet from the Sharon Basco is dance critic for The Boston Herald and Boston Magazine. first time I danced in it as a boy,'' George Balanchine wrote in his ''Complete Stories of the Great Ballets.'' When he set it on the New York City Ballet in 1954 ''The Nutcracker'' was still a ballet ''with which American audiences were not sufficiently familiar.''

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
OLD-FASHIONED NOTIONS ON THE FAMILY
description: SOME time ago while trying to make a date with a very old friend to catch up after months of not seeing one another, we found it difficult to arrive at a convenient time. Week followed week, because of one problem or another. Before we realized it, we were talking about the week of Thanksgiving. Naturally we shared our plans - who was coming home for dinner, when, where. I said that I had a lot to do as everyone was expected.

title: Reluctant Admiration
description: Eric Dickerson , the Los Angeles Rams' running back, needs only 372 yards in 3 games to break the National Football League's single-season rushing mark of 2,003 yards set by O. J. Simpson , and at least one football specialist thinks he's a cinch to do it - O. J. Simpson. ''He's got to be odds-on to get it,'' said Simpson, who set the record with the Buffalo Bills in 1973 and who is not necessarily rooting for Dickerson to break it.

title: THE MARKET FOR OCCUPIED APARTMENTS IS EXPANDING
description: INVESTORS in Texas find it hard to understand the prices of apartments in New York City. ''They can't comprehend paying $30,000 a room,'' says Gary H. Herman, an officer of D.G.B. Property Corporation, a real-estate syndicator that has bought several rental buildings in Manhattan, ''when in Texas you could pay $25,000 for an entire apartment with two bedrooms and two baths.''

title: CULINARY SHOWCASE: HOME-GROWN FEAST
description: MAYS LANDING

title: THE 10 VIRTUES OF WORKING WITH THE SOIL;
description: Raymond J. Duda is a teacher of composition and an avid gardener.

title: TAX, BUDGET PLANS REFLECT THE DEPTH OF FISCAL DISTRESS
description: LAST week the Administration started laying out plans for a radical change in the American fiscal system, and for completing the Reagan Revolution by further cuts in social spending.

title: Rude Awakening for Sleeper
description: Julian Hursey Jr., a 375- pound man with a physical affliction called Pickwickian Syndrome that causes him to fall asleep frequently, has pleaded no contest to violating a city ordinance against sleeping in public.

title: MEDICARE REVIEWS STIR CONCERN
description: A new Government program to cut Medicare expenses allows federally financed agencies in each state to dictate in advance whether surgical procedures proposed by doctors are really necessary.

title: TEACHER OF THE YEAR CHALLENGES PUPILS
description: IN the rural town of Deep River,

title: Award for Morrison
description: Joe Morrison , the unassuming former Giant back who coached South Carolina to a 10-1 record this season and a berth in the Gator Bowl, has been named coach of the year by the Walter Camp Foundation. The selection was announced in New Haven by the foundation's president, Vincent T. Farricielli , who described Morrison as ''a no-nonsense type of person who goes about his business in a quiet, professional manner.''

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
LATCHKEY MOTHERS HAVE A THOUGH LIFE
description: -suffering minority in our society that, until now, has been ignored. Its needs and rights, yet to be defined, have been sadly disregarded. This group, so discriminated against, is the minority of ''latchkey mothers.''

title: A VINE GROWS IN PARIS
description: WHAT BUSINESS ABOUT the 1984 vintage in France being mediocre? In Bordeaux, perhaps. Well, in Burgundy, too. And - O.K., if you insist - in the Loire, Champagne, Alsace and the Rh^one.

title: TRAIN IN ESSEX FILMED AS 'EXPRESS'
description: FOG swirled around the railroad station and a cold wind whistled down the platform as a headlight from the Orient Express rounded the turn. Passengers waited to board the train; a priest, a mink-swathed heiress, a gypsy and an American couple.

title:
ART;
SHOW LOOKS AT LINK BETWEEN DRAWINGS AND FINISHED WORK
description: UNOFFICIALLY the work of art to see at Herbert H. Lehman College in the Bronx is the new Art Building. Formerly a library designed by Marcel Breuer 25 years ago, the revamped building keeps Breuer's unique columns that splay delightfully like Chinese umbrellas. Accented with red, yellow and blue tiled walls, the new complex is beautifully light and airy.

title: THE TOUGH JOB OF SELLING TRACTORS
description: ALGONA, Iowa

title: CRIES FOR HELP IGNORED IN 15-MINUTE FATAL ATTACK
description: While neighbors ignored her screams for 15 or 20 minutes, a woman was beaten in the courtyard of a Brooklyn housing project early Friday, then dragged into a lobby and shot to death by two young assailants, the police said yesterday.

title: Carter Says He Kept Diary on Oval Office
description: Former President Jimmy Carter has disclosed that during his four years in office he kept a diary to record sensitive details about world leaders who passed through the Oval Office.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: NORMALLY, the Saw Mill River Tennis Club here is a hotbed of talk about John McEnroe 's amazing touch, Jimmy Connors 's relentless attack or Martina Navratilova 's record winning streak. One also hears speculation about the fortunes of Melissa Brown and Terry Phelps , county youngsters who recently invaded the professional ranks and are striving on the world circuit.

title: Texaco's Loss Without Tears
description: Those cynics who believe corporate bookkeeping is sometimes done with mirrors might find something to reflect on in an announcement last week by Texaco Inc. The company said it had decided to reduce its valuation of certain assets, creating a $765 million write-off to be charged against fourth quarter earnings.

title: 3 Top G.O.P. Officials Agree to Stay in Posts
description: Three top officials of the Republican Party have agreed to stay in their posts at the request of President Reagan, a spokesman said Friday.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
OH, THE JOY OF CHOOSING THOSE GIFTS
description: CHRISTMAS is coming. That is clear from the deluge of catalogues that pours forth from my mailbox each day, from the dusting of artificial snow on artificial trees that stand incongruously alongside cardboard turkeys and plastic pumpkins in store displays and from the rising panic I feel when I contemplate my gift list.

title: THE VIEW FROM THE TERRACE
description: NEW TROPICAL homes with lush surroundings have undergone as radical a transition as this former plantation in the Virgin Islands. Its ruins have been shaped into a rambling configuration reminiscent of a small castle perched at the edge of an Italian hill town. And, to complete the transformation, the property has been ringed with terraced gardens so that rich green leaves and brilliantly colored blossoms appear to cascade down the hillside, a hillside once covered with sugar cane.

title: RELICS OF WORLD WAR STILL EXPLODE IN EUROPE
description: Every once in a while, a bit of World War II explodes again in Europe. Lethal leftovers of unexploded wartime ordnance still go off and still kill people.

title: COMMISSION CALLS FOR MORE VOCATIONAL EDUCATION
description: A national obsession with raising academic standards is squeezing job preparation courses out of the high school curriculum, a vocational education commission says.

title: Katherine Frank, a Lawyer, Is Married
description: Katherine Lucile Frank, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John V. Frank of New York, and Jerome Foote Page 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Page Jr. of Columbus, Ohio, were married yesterday at the Lotos Club in Manhattan. Dr. Sheldon Ackley, a senior leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony.

title: QUARTERBACKS' POISE CRUCIAL IN TODAY'S BIG SHOWDOWN
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: HOMAGE TO CUMBRIA
description: NORMAN NICHOLSON is a poet and writer who has lived in the Lake District all his life.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: -depth study on the implementation of the State Supreme Court's Mount Laurel II decision has found that thousands of new housing units will be needlessly built over the next five years because of gross errors in calculating New Jersey's low- and moderate-income housing needs.

title: GETTING THE DROP ON THE MOB
description: For 50 years, whether it was called the mob, the syndicate, the Mafia or the Cosa Nostra, organized crime in America was largely invulnerable. In an abrupt turnabout, that invincibility has apparently been shattered. More than 100 defendants described as leaders and high-ranking figures in crime groups in New York and other big cities have been indicted in recent months by Federal and state grand juries.

title: 10 ON BANK BOARD ARE TOLD TO QUIT
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which saved the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company from bankruptcy this summer, is requiring 10 of its 16 directors to resign.

title: BELATED ATTENTION FOR BLOCH'S QUARTETS
description: The Portland String Quartet has been giving a series of concerts in Alice Tully Hall which included a retrospective of Ernest Bloch's five string quartets. This followed its recording of the works for a three- disk album on the Arabesque label (6511-3), a project that deserves belated attention.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ATHENS
description: HENRY KAMM is chief of the New York Times bureau in Athens.

title: MIDDLE TENNESSEE TRIUMPHS BY 42-41
description: The linebacker Mick Mathis tackled the fullback Jimmy Edwards to foil a 2-point conversion attempt and give Middle Tennessee a 42-41 victory over Indiana State after three overtime periods today.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
 HOLIDAY MUSIC
description: Holiday strings begin dominating the music scene this week. In Nassau, it all begins today with two performances of Handel's ''Messiah'': at 4 P.M., when Nassau Community College's chorus appears at the College Union Ballroom on the Garden City campus (for tickets: 222-7446); and then at 7:30 P.M., when the Bel Canto Chorale comes to Our Holy Redeemer Church on North Ocean Avenue in Freeport. The donation is $4.

title: DOCTORS BALK AT NEW RULES ON MEDICARE
description: MORE than a month after the new Medicare rules went into effect, the controversy and confusion that surrounded their enactment persist. Although physicians more than patients are likely to feel the initial impact, it remains unclear how both parties will fare in the long run.

title:
DEBATE OVER TAX REFORM;
THE PRIORITY IS STEMMING THE RED INK
description: IN the furor over tax reform, it

title: Chilean Leader Issues Order Subjecting Women to Draft
description: President Augusto Pinochet ordered women drafted into the armed services in a decree today that also called up an unspecified number of reservists to active duty to ''intensify the struggle against terrorism.''

title: EXPANDING ACCESS TO PREP SCHOOLS
description: Three years ago, Kevin Ortiz, 13 years old, gave up playing after school with his friends in the South Bronx for classwork that eventually led him to a selective private school.

title: Children's Books
description: THE BUTTER BATTLE BOOK. By Dr. Seuss. (Random House. $6.95.) (Ages 4 and up.) A bleak picture and verse vision of a mounting battle between the Yooks and the Zooks that resembles the international arms race.

title: STONE WHITE IS FIRST
description: For the second time in 14 days, Stone White won the Saturday feature race at Aqueduct - and this time it counted.

title: Paper in South Africa Prints Banned Speech
description: A South African newspaper today defied the authorities by publishing a speech by an anti-Government exile banned from being quoted in this country.

title: NEW LIBRARY CODE ISSUE IN ANN ARBOR
description: The Ann Arbor Public Library has adopted new rules for patrons that bar the sleepy and the extremely smelly, and a civil liberties group is worried that a result will be discrimination against homeless people.

title: Flyers Down Penguins, 3-1
description: Two third-period goals by Tim Kerr gave the Philadelphia Flyers a 3-1 hockey victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins this evening.

title: HIGH RETURNS FROM A VARIED PORTFOLIO
description: THIS past year has been a tough one for many

title: SOME GAINS AND LOSSES FOR SYRIA'S LEADERSHIP AMBITIONS
description: Only a few months ago, the Western countries and Syria were backing different sides in the conflict that raged in Lebanon. Syria was seen as striving to gain paramount influence and prevent genuine independence for that troubled country. But last week, Syria got direct word from one Western leader that its influence in Lebanon was acceptable.

title: AN ETHNIC JUBILEE AT OLD STATE HOUSE
description: TO ring in the holiday season and to pay tribute to the diverse ethnic backgrounds of Connecticut's residents, the Old State House at 800 Main Street in Hartford will sponsor a three-week- long holiday jubilee starting tomorrow.

title: RAJIV THE SON
description: Joseph Lelyveld, a New York Times correspondent in India from 1966 to 1969, is a staff writer for The Times Magazine. ON THE FIRST DAY FOLLOWING THE PERIOD OF official mourning for the murdered Prime Minister, her sole surviving son and dynastic heir struck what he plainly intended to be a keynote for his new-old regime. In a television talk that had been written for him by a friend who happened to be an advertising man, he said: ''Our administrative system must become more goal- oriented. A new work ethic, a new work culture must be evolved in which the government is result-bound and not procedure-bound. Reward and punishment must be related to performance.'' The next day, meeting senior civil servants, he decried the ''unnecessary politicization of administration.'' Then, having raised his sails, he immediately called a national election.

title: HOUSTON TOPS RICE, GAINS COTTON BOWL
description: The Houston Cougars, overcoming complacency against overmatched Rice, defeated the Owls, 38-26, behind Raymond Tate's three touchdown runs tonight to clinch their fourth Cotton Bowl berth since joining the Southwest Conference nine years ago.

title: ROCK: AT RITZ, LOS LOBOS FROM COAST
description: Good old rock-and-roll means something new in the hands of Los Lobos, the East Los Angeles band that played a triumphant show Thursday at the Ritz.

title: Alexandra S. Halsey Is Bride on Coast
description: Alexandra Simmons Halsey, the daughter of Stephen Simmons Halsey of New York and Wanda Philpott Halsey of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to William Powell Urschel Jr., a son of Dr. Urschel of Montecito, Calif,, and Mrs. Hugh Graham of Baltimore. The Rev. George F. Woodward Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the Mural Room of the Santa Barbara, Calif., Courthouse.

title: LEUKEMIA STRIKES A SMALL TOWN
description: Paula DiPerna is a New York-based freelance writer and editor.

title: ROBERT WILSON'S 'EINSTEIN' RETURNS TO THE STAGE
description: Robert T. Jones is a translator and critic who writes frequently about the arts.

title: PRINCE MYSHKIN, GIGI AND DR. JOHNSON
description: The Book Review asked a number of prominent people which character from a novel, or from a work of nonfiction, they would most like to be and why. Most respondents were sensitive to the difference between the character they would like to be

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE: THE BEST BOOKS OF 1984
description: Fifteen books have been chosen by the editors of The Book Review as the best of 1984 - six fiction, nine not. The fact that three of the six chosen as the best fiction were written by a South African, a Peruvian and a Czechoslovak emigre living in Paris makes a point. The editors agreed that the list of American (or, indeed, English) fiction from which nominees could be drawn was not as strong as the list of obvious nominees from works by foreign authors that were published this year in the United States.

title: STATE'S DANCE TROUPE GOES INTERNATIONAL
description: IF New Jersey ballet companies

title: Pastoral Letter
description: To the Editor:

title: COUNCIL IN NORWALK CUTS POWER OF MAYOR
description: ONE Norwalk Common Council member accused a colleague of ''making deals.'' Another accused the Mayor of calling an opponent ''nuts.'' A third complained a colleague was talking too much.

title: Schnellenberger Is Hired LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 1 (AP) - Howard Schnellenberger, who
description: coached Miami to a national football championship last year and then

title: Lottery Winner Wins Again
description: The man who claimed the biggest lottery jackpot in North America won again Friday when the Illinois Lottery Board agreed to alter the payout so that Michael Wittkowski could share his prize with his father, Frank; his brother, Daniel, and his sister, Eileen, without paying an estimated $5 million in gift taxes on the $40 million prize. The board agreed to change the name of the winner to ''the Wittkowski partnership.''

title: Danger Mouse
description: Children's Matinee: Cassette No. 1 Thorn EMI Video 60 minutes. $29.95

title: CHRISTMAS-TREE FARMS SET FOR THE RUSH
description: WHILE shoppers continue to count the days to Christmas and holiday lights begin to glow on front-lawn evergreens and porches, many families throughout the state are preparing traditional ornaments for Christmas trees.

title: DANCE: INNER CITY
description: The Inner City Ensemble Theater and Dance Company is a company of engaging young actor-dancers. But at present, the group, which performed on Friday at Theater of the Riverside Church, reverses the imbalance that is usual these days in dance companies.

title: SOCIAL ISSUES STILL FUEL THIS CHOREOGRAPHER'S WORK
description: Barry Laine writes frequently about the performing arts.

title: Appeal Seen in Land Dispute
description: Three corporations run by Alaskan natives say they will appeal a court ruling that blocked them from opening an island wildlife refuge to the oil industry.

title: Q&A
description: Changing Transfer Rules Question:

title: SCARSDALE CRECHE: THE DEBATE GOES ON
description: IN Scarsdale, the arrival of the

title: A PASSION FOR POTTERY
description: ''She put her hand up in an auction and I tried to pull it down,'' William Goodman recently recalled of a 1968 outdoor sale on a farm in upstate New York, where he and his wife, Marcia, began to collect American art pottery.

title: The Rich - and Edith Wharton
description: To the Editor:

title: In Name Only
description: Starring Cary Grant, Carole Lombard, Kay Francis, Charles Coburn, Katherine Alexander, Peggy Ann Garner; directed by John Cromwell, 1939 RKO Home Video 94 minutes. $34.95

title: CHANGING WITH SOCIETY
description: Francis A. Allen is the Edson R. Sunderland Professor of Law at the University of Michigan. AMERICAN LAW

title: SCINCE FACTS HELP PROPEL SCIENCE FICTION IN THE FILM '2010'
description: Science fiction has always had a prophetic side. In his 1914 story ''The World Set Free,'' H. G. Wells described a war in which the major cities of the world are destroyed by atom bombs the size of cannon balls. In the mid-1930's, after reading it, Leo Szilard became convinced that real atom bombs could be built and filed a secret patent on the idea. He later became a driving force behind the Manhattan Project.

title: THE IMAGES OF THE BUDDHA CONINUES TO ENTHRALL
description: Two things should be said about the Brooklyn Museum. One is that it is on the move in ways that can only delight us. The other is that there is an immediate and temporary reason to go there, in that through Feb. 10, 1985, the Brooklyn Museum has an exhibition called ''The Light of Asia'' that was previously shown with great success at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and the Art Institute of Chicago. Organized primarily by Pratapaditya Pal, senior curator at the Los Angeles County Museum, it traces the look of Buddha Sakyamuni, the founder of Buddhism, as it was imagined by sculptors and painters in India, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Tibet, Korea, China, Japan and elsewhere. It is a mark of the care and the diplomatic skills with which the choices were made that the 179 objects in the show come from more than 80 sources - the Brooklyn Museum itself not excluded - in France, Belgium, Germany, Switzerland, England, India, Japan, Thailand, Korea and the United States.

title: OFFICIALS SEEK TO PREVENT RUBELLA RECURRENCE
description: New York City health officials are trying to avert another outbreak of rubella among young office workers in Manhattan, a group that has been afflicted twice in the last two years.

title: NEW HOTELS BRING CHANGE TO CHINA
description: ORVILLE SCHELL is the author of the forthcoming book ''To Get Rich is Glorious: China in the 1980's'' (Pantheon).

title: 'BOIL WATER' ALERT LINGERS
description: MORE than a year after health-threatening levels of bacteria re-ju sulted in an eight-day ''boil water'' alert for customers of the South Farmingdale Water District, the Nassau County Health Department is still searching for the source of contamination within the system.

title: DEPENDENCE GROWS ON L.I. SALES TAXES
description: BOTH Nassau and Suffolk Counties are developing a growing dependence on sales tax revenues, taking some of the burden off property-tax payers.

title: MORE LOCAL CONTROL PROPOSED ON JERSEY LOW-COST HOUSING
description: A State Senate committee has released legislation that would give municipalities greater control in implementing the State Supreme Court's Mount Laurel decision requiring communities to provide a fair share of affordable housing.

title: China Deal
description: After a yearlong effort, Norman Dong of Bergenfield, N.J., managed to cut through red tape in China and sign a joint manufacturing agreement with the Tianjin Bicycle Industrial Corporation to produce bicycles for the United States market. Not bad for a lone American.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Let's not forget that part of Syria's territory - the Golan Heights - is occupied by Israel. Therefore its participation in the peace process is vital.'' - Osama el-Baz, chief foreign policy adviser to President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. (21:2.)

title: Inching Ahead On Cancer
description: Eight years after the war on cancer was supposed to have been won, the National Cancer Institute is still in the trenches. That much was apparent when the institute released its latest statistical profile of the nation's second leading killer last week.

title: After the Crash The only survivor of an Iowa auto accident was identified as Shawn Lake, the 14-year-old daughter of Colleen Lake. But in the two weeks Mrs. Lake sat at the hospital bedside of the comatose, bandage-swathed girl, she began to suspect otherwise. Last week, after the girl awakened, police confirmed her suspicion when a fingerprint check showed 16-year-old
description: Patricia Noonan was the survivor. While Patricia's mother, Karmen Noonan, expressed ''joy beyond words,'' Mrs. Lake faced the ordeal of reinterring Shawn, who was buried as Patricia.

title: Juried Show At the Parrish
description: Regarding the article ''Parrish Museum Beckons to Wider Area'' (Oct. 21) and the museum's 30th Juried Exhibition: Artists were invited to submit two works with an entry fee of $15 for each piece. The entry fee was waived for the first submission of members of the museum, but membership was not a requirement.

title: LYRICIST FOR MACLAINE SHOW
description: Christopher Edward Adler, who wrote the lyrics for Shirley MacLaine's revue on Broadway this year, died of cancer Friday at the Memorial Sloan- Kettering Cancer Center. He was 30 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: ELEGANCE IS AN elusive quality, also one that is immediately recognizable. Its manifestations are constantly changing, yet the basic elements are consistent.

Ferraro in hustings, hamlets and whole cities where people had apparently never heard anybody talk-that- way, and were charmed. Alas for the candidate, the listeners didn't stay all that charmed.

title: GANDHI IS CHEERED BY THOUSANDS AS HE OPENS HIS UNITY CAMPAIGN
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi opened his party's national election campaign today with a 14-hour swing through the state of Uttar Pradesh.

title: NICARAGUA THROWN TO THE LIONS
description: Nicaraguans feel like a Christian thrown to the lions by the Romans. After he overcame every lion, the Romans denounced him for fighting unfairly and executed him. His real crime was refusing to bow before the empire's gods and clinging to his own beliefs.

In the game, adult players outfitted in military fatigues pretend to kill opponents with air-powered guns.

description: Larry Bird scored 34 points and Danny Ainge made two foul shots to snap a late tie as the Boston Celtics gained their ninth consecutive victory, a 110-104 triumph over the Cleveland Cavaliers, tonight.

description: whether Brigham Young should be ranked No. 1 in college football drew

description: The San Francisco coroner ruled Thursday after extensive tests that the death of Matsataka Kobayashi, a famous chef, was homicide. An earlier autopsy had left the cause unclear.

WESTCHESTER OPINION;

title: SMALL HEART POWER UNIT USED 3 HOURS
description: As William J. Schroeder prepares to enter his second week with an artificial heart, his doctors switched him today to a portable power source for three hours, the maximum allowed by the Federal Food and Drug Administration for testing the device in one day.

title: BATTLING FOR A PRIZE: RADIO STATION LICENSE
description: IT started as a rumor. The word

title: 'OTHER' FLUTIE LEADS ROUT OF HOLY CROSS
description: It was the other Flutie, Darren, who made the key plays today for Boston College as the Eagles trounced Holy Cross, 45-10, at Fitton Field in the 80th game of this 88-year-old series.

title: Tamara K. Thomsen Is Wed to Thomas H. Bailey
description: Tamara Kaye Thomsen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman D. Thomsen of Providence Forge, Va., was married yesterday to Thomas Hanscom Bailey, a son of Mrs. Stephen R. Astle of Walpole, N.H., and Dr. James T. Bailey of Lyndon, Vt. The ceremony was performed at the Americas Society in New York by the Rev. Richard E. Leonard, a Unitarian minister.

title: PUTTING ANISE-FLAVORED LIQUERS TO TASTY USE
description: FOR MANY YEARS, and for several reasons, we have been intrigued with anise-flavored liqueurs. It seems that almost every European nation has one with which it identifies. In Italy, it is anisette; in France, Pernod or Ricard; in Greece, ouzo; in Turkey, arrack, and so on.

description: Years later, the memory was still chilling for the former New Jersey police officer.

title: The Comic-Book Caper
description: News item: The C.I.A. has published a comic book showing Nicaraguans how to make trouble for their Marxist government by using various sabotage techniques, including stopping up toilets with sponges.

description: Artifacts found in Guanabara Bay, near Rio de Janiero, raised the possibility in 1982 that Romans may have discovered Brazil 17 centuries before the Portuguese.

description: ALONG with the usual clippings, cartoons and notes taped on David and Katherine Gordy Levine's kitchen door is a list of rules: ''No hurting other people. No stealing. No carrying weapons - even pocket knives. No menacing or threatening other people.''

description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: PREPARING SNOW BLOWER FOR WINTER
description: HOMEOWNERS who do not take their snow throwers out of storage until the first time they actually see snow piled up in the driveway are taking a chance on being severely frustrated when they belatedly discover that the machine is not ready to do its work. The homeowner may find that the machine is very difficult (or even impossible) to get started, or it may be sadly in need of adjustments or repairs that will keep it from operating properly (or not at all).

title: GENTLEMEN IN TEMPERED STEEL
description: David Herlihy, the Henry Charles Lea Professor of Medieval History at Harvard University, is the co-author of the forthcoming ''Tuscans and Their Families.'' CHIVALRY

description: Catherine Diana Clare, the daughter of Dr. Gloria Clare Elias of New York and Hillsdale, N.Y., and the late Dr. Jack E. Clare, was married yesterday to Howard Mark Fifer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Fifer of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Dennis Math performed the ceremony at the Penthouse at 236 West 26th Street.

description: IF everyone from Connecticut is

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
LOVE IN BLOOM: ON THE L.I.R.R. OF ALL PLACES
