title: ZONING BY DEFAULT IN FEUD
description: CHARLES JOSEPH is going to get a certificate allowing him to build a 2,400-square- foot commercial building on Main Street in Jewett City. All he had to do was wait for it.

title: IN MALAYSIA, SPICY SATAY
description: MICHAEL SPECTER recently completed a year in Asia as a correspondent for the Far Eastern Economic Review on a Henry R. Luce Fellowship.

title: IT'S ALL IN THE CARDS
description: DID you know that in 1507 a Polish monk was accused of witchcraft because his children were learning so rapidly? When the matter was investigated, it turned out that the monk had put lessons on the playing cards he used in games with his children.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN PRODUCTS FOR THE AGED;
MARKETING WITH SENSITIVITY
description: MARKETING to older consumers is a Catch 22 situation. ''We're trying to say that older people are just like everybody else,'' said Dennis R. LaBuda, an executive with the American Association of Retired Persons. Yet older people often do have physical limitations. And non-age-related products - home appliances, dinnerware, even breakfast cereals - as well as items designed with older customers in mind can miss the mark for reasons other than intrinsic value.

title: College Quarrying
description: Casting about for innovative ways to raise money, Park College in Parkville, Mo., found it was sitting on a limestone mine.

title: SHORT ON TALK, BIG AT THE BOX OFFICE
description: Chuck Norris, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Charles Bronson: not everyone's idea of perfect party guests but nonetheless deserving of attention and even respect, since together they control such a formidable share of the movie market. Only last week, Mr. Norris's ''Missing in Action'' and Mr. Schwarzenegger's ''Terminator'' were being advertised as the nation's ''New no. 1 hit!'' and ''The N1 movie in the U.S.A.,'' respectively. And ''The Evil That Men Do,'' the latest from Mr. Bronson, made a comparable splash several months earlier.

title: OFFICE UNDER GLASS
description: Now you see it, now you don't. The Donald Art Building, a familiar structure at 90 South Ridge Street in Rye Brook, N.Y., is in the process of being rejuvenated, inside and out.

title: Julie Ann Hendrickson Marries Craig Whiting
description: At St. John's Lutheran Church in Stamford, Conn., yesterday Julie Ann Hendrickson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roland M. Hendrickson of Darien, Conn., was married to Craig Stephen Whiting, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawson M. Whiting of Delray Beach, Fla., and Darien. The Rev. Dennis Albrecht performed the ceremony.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: For every thing there is a season, and this season's thing in photography books is fashion. Among many others, the fashion photographers Louise Dahl-Wolfe, Horst P. Horst, Irving Penn and Francesco Scavullo are featured in publications ranging from the unassuming (Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe) to the sumptuously overblown (Mr. Scavullo). This isn't to say that more traditional fare - coffeetable books devoted to glorious views of American landscapes, photojournalistic reports on exotic peoples, monographic tributes to artists of the camera - is missing. It's just that these categories no longer seem . . . well, as fashionable. That fashion should surpass both art photography and socially concerned reporting on the current scene can be taken as one more sign of the times, which seem to favor the appearance of seriousness over the truly serious and the tried and true over the new and possibly disruptive. (Most of the pictures in the fashion books have been published before, in their original incarnations as images designed to move the goods of the garment industry.) Fashion also represents an arena in which photography's artistic capabilities collide with its uses as an instrument of mass-media persuasion - an interaction these days much on the mind of cultural critics, if not book publishers. In second place in the race for the holiday dollar are books that shout ''This is America'' in beautiful color pictures of beautiful scenery. These are, as a rule, lavishly produced, splendidly reproduced, oversize and expensive. Unfortunately, also as a rule, the photographs show us little we haven't seen before.

title: Great Salt Lake Still Rising
description: The Great Salt Lake, already at its highest level in more than a century, rose another 1.2 inches in the last half of November, the United States Geological Service says. Monitoring instruments at Saltair Resort on the lake's southern arm read 4,208.3 feet above sea level Friday, up from a reading taken Nov. 15.

title: TWO FOR THE ROAD
description: MARYLIN BENDER, whose most recent book is ''Nouveau Is Better Than No Riche at All'' (Putnam), writes on business from New York.

title: MANY CHANCES TO HEAR 'MESSIAH'
description: IT sometimes seems the Christmas season begins earlier

title: WHAT ONE ARTIST'S CAREER TELLS US OF TODAY'S WORLD
description: It's a mere half-dozen years since the controversial phenomenon known as Julian

title: PUPPETEER TROUPE MOVES TO STAMFORD
description: THEIR story inspired a recent television movie,''Special People,'' in which Brooke Adams starred as Diane Dupuy, founder of Famous People Players, a baker's dozen of puppeteers who have created the life-size likenesses of such celebrities as Michael Jackson, Barbra Streisand and Liberace.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Dance takes many forms, as this week's events tell us. Sunday evening at 8 at the Theater of the Riverside Church is the last time to see Morocco and the Casbah Dance Experience - a title that translates into Middle Eastern dancing as it is being creatively practiced by its American exponents. Morocco, incidentally, is not a place but the dancer who heads this company.

title: U.S. WEIGHS MOVES IN CZECH SPY CASSE
description: Justice Department officials are weighing how to proceed against the wife of a man accused of being a Czechoslovak spy who was described in court papers as joining her husband in espionage. The question the officials said they must decide was whether to charge the woman, too, or to seek to compel her to testify against her husband.

title: Some people think Adalberto Rosas Lopez is crazy.
description: It is not so much that the 42-year-old agricultural engineer has done things such as spend more than a month last year crossing the Mexican farming state of Sonora from one end to the other, ''on foot, like a nut,'' as he put it. It is more that Mr. Rosas, a member of an opposition political party, thinks he can become governor here.

title: CURBS PROPOSED ON BAR PROMOTIONS
description: WITH a practiced hand, Kathy Murray poured shots of rum into two glasses of cola, balanced them in one hand and delivered them to a customer at Katie's Cafe in Enfield. A rum and coke normally costs $1.95 there, but, during ''happy hour,'' the drinks are two-for-one.

title:
ART;
100 WORKS SELECTED OUT OF 500
description: THE annual juried exhibition at the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island in Hempstead is truly a pan-Island affair, attracting entries from Brooklyn and Queens as well as Nassau and Suffolk. Now in its second season, the show introduces some unfamiliar artists to area audiences and, because of its lack of size restrictions, allows a far greater number of submissions than other such offerings in the region.

title: SHALALA GIVES HER RESPONSE
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: RIFLE RANGE DRAWS HUNTERS
description: IT is a gray, drizzily Sunday

title: COURT TO CONSIDER NEW RULES ON CONSERVATORS
description: New York State's Chief Judge says he will present the Court of Appeals this week with stricter guidelines aimed at curbing favoritism and political influence in the appointment of guardians and conservators.

title: Elizabeth B. Bailey Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Briggs Bailey, a daughter of Richard Briggs Bailey of Boston and Mrs. Irving H. Chase of Lincoln, Mass., was married yesterday to Graham Stuart Beckel, a son of Cambridge Graham Beckel Jr. of Charlottesville, Va., and Ellen Gilliland Beckel of Lyme, Conn. The Rev. Norman Catir performed the ceremony at the Little Church Around the Corner (Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration) in New York.

title: CALIFORNIAN HAILS UPSETTING OF LAW
description: Willie Brown Jr., Speaker of the State Assembly, says the fight over a law that would have stripped him of much of his power was not ''a struggle between the Legislature and the will of the people'' but rather a dispute involving the ''primacy of the Constitution.''

title: Welfare Clients Down, Costs Up
description: While the number of New York City residents on public assistance has begun to decline, the city's welfare costs are still going up, the State Comptroller's Office reported last week. The explanation for that apparent contradiction: a higher proportion of the people receiving assistance are in desperate need, so the price of helping them is steeper.

title: RESERVING TOP TABLES
description: FLORENCE FABRICANT writes frequently about food and wine for The New York Times.

title: Margot E. Olshan To Marry April 6
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth S. Olshan of New York and Westport, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Margot Ellen Olshan, to John Clapps, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Clapps of Hackensack, N.J. The wedding is to be April 6.

title: CATALAN MAGIC
description: Gregory Rabassa teaches at Queens College and has most recently translated Jorge Amado's ''Sea of Death.'' MY CHRISTINA

title: Some Terrorists Thwarted, Some Reach Targets
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz's strategy for ''active prevention'' of terrorism seemed to produce results in Rome last week, but the worldwide threat was far from over. American embassies came under attack from leftist guerrillas in Lisbon and from drug traffickers in Bogota, Colombia.

title: IN NAPOLEON'S FOOTSTEPS
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: A WIDE VARIETY OF CHOICES
description: -giving have changed, so has the popularity of types of Christmas trees.

title: AFTER TWO CENTURIES, HEBDEN IS REDISCOVERED
description: Andrew L. Pincus writes extensively about music.

title: Tina R. Holman, E. S. Warfield 3d Plan to Be Wed
description: Tina Reid Holman and Edward Snowden Warfield 3d plan to be married Jan. 5 at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: RECITAL: BARBARA CADRANEL
description: The harpsichordist Barbara Cadranel presented what she called a ''tricentennial birthday party'' for Domenico Scarlatti, Johann Sebastian Bach and George Frederick Handel at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday night.

title: HEAR THR ROARING OF THE BIRDS
description: THE GARDENER'S YEAR

title: An Ex-Mayor's Guilt Former Mayor
description: Michael J. Matthews of Atlantic City apparently did not like his odds in Federal District Court in Newark, so last week he folded his hand. Mr. Matthews, who was turned out of office in a March referendum, admitted accepting a $10,000 bribe from an undercover Federal agent who said he represented companies seeking city business.

title: ARGUMENTS HEARD IN SCHOOL AID SUIT
description: Lawyers for 20 schoolchildren from the state's poorest districts asked the State Supreme Court this week to allow the courts to hear their suit charging that the state's formula for financing public education is unfair and illegal.

title: GIVING WORKERS A VOICE OF THEIR OWN
description: William Serrin is a correspondent for The Times who specializes in labor and the workplace. SOMETIMES A UNIVERSE CAN BE SUMMED UP IN a fragment. Late one afternoon, crammed into a conference room in a Ford Motor Company factory in Sharonville, Ohio, a dozen men in jeans and khakis and thick work shoes were talking about Steve Sandman's fan. The whine and throb of the lathes and drill presses could be heard through the walls. ''We can take an air-movement reading,'' John DeLucca, an engineer, was saying, ''but if it's adequate, then you'll have to see the plant engineer.'' Steve Sandman was not impressed. Factory work can be stifling, dreary, physically exhausting; a fan makes a difference. Sandman contended that the fan in his work area was too far away to provide any relief. ''Come down on one of the hot days,'' Sandman told DeLucca.

title: IS THE MADE-FOR-TV MOVIE IN AN IDENTITY CRISIS?
description: The TV movie doesn't have an easy time trying to define itself. On commercial television, the form generally has to survive within the boundaries of ''family entertainment,'' which, at its most obvious level, excludes the more permissive extremes of language and behavior found in what is euphemistically known as ''adult entertainment.'' This leaves the average TV-movie lineup with an inevitable glut of romantic comedies and inspirational stories featuring some kind of triumph over some kind of adversity.

title: AN UNADORNED SURVIVOR
description: BETSY WADE is an editor on the national desk of The New York Times.

title: RESTORED MALL DELIGHTS NEW HAVEN
description: CHRISTMAS came early to New Haven this year - in the form of a long-awaited bright new face for the Chapel Square Mall, its once-gloomy shopping center.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: -FOOD hamburgers and french fries appeal to young people all over America, but in Union County, one chain - McDonald's - is providing, through a national pilot program for high school dropouts, the meat and potatoes for some youngsters' futures.

title: NOTABLE BOOKS OF THE YEAR
description: This list has been selected from titles reviewed since the Christmas Issue of December 1983. It only suggests high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from The Book Review. Autobiography and Biography THE AMERICAN POPE: The Life and Times of Francis Cardinal Spellman. By John Cooney. (Times Books. $19.95.) ''A gossipy, iconoclastic and absorbing biography'' of the controversial prelate. AUDEN IN LOVE. By Dorothy J. Farnan. (Simon & Schuster. $17.95.) The story of the poet's ''marriage'' to Chester Kallman, which ''vividly evokes the world of bohemian New York in the 1940's.''

title: SHOREHAM RADIATION POTENTIAL CHALLENGED
description: WHEN Suffolk County concluded two years ago that the largest possible release of radiation from the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station would be too fast and too large to permit the evacuation of those in threatened areas, the county was using estimates made almost a decade earlier by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: Biotechnology
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 WIN HORWITZ PRIZE FOR CHOLESTOROL WORK
description: Two University of Texas scientists who studied how cholesterol accumulates in human arteries have been awarded the 1984 Louisa Gross Horwitz Prize by Columbia University.

title: FALLING PROFITS IMPERIL THE RECOVERY
description: WHEN top executives from General Electric's appliance division gathered in September for their monthly review meeting, the mood around the conference table was glum. Sales of ranges and refrigerators had retreated from the torrid pace of the previous several months and the parent company's profits had just begun to slip from the level of the previous quarter. Worse still, there was no improvement in sight.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
ROMANCE BY COMMUTE
description: John Tirman

title: CASINO OFFERS A HOUSING PLAN TO MEET REDEVELOPMENT RULE
description: On the eve of hearings to determine whether Caesars Boardwalk Regency Hotel and Casino has met its obligation to invest in Atlantic City's redevelopment, officials of the gambling hall have announced plans for two housing projects.

title: FIREFIGHTER DIES BATTLING A BLAZE One firefighter was killed and four others were injured yesterday night in a smoky fire that broke out in the unoccupied auditorium of an Episcopal School in Brooklyn Heights, authorities said.
description: The dead firefighter was missing inside the St. Ann's Holy Trinity School, an eight-story brick building for 14 minutes before his colleagues found him on the smoke-filled fourth floor, said Lieut. Frank Martinez, a department spokesman,

title:
NUMISMATICS;
THE GREAT INTERNATIONAL COIN GO-AROUND
description: Was the Susan B. Anthony dollar really such a terrible idea? Britain and Canada don't seem to think so. Despite the general view that the Anthony dollar was - and is - a fiasco, the British and Canadian governments are pushing ahead with new coinage programs that are, in many ways, similar.

title: 30 FEARED DEAD IN NEW CLASHES IN SRI LANKA
description: About 30 people were feared killed in separatist Tamil guerrilla attacks on three majority Sinhalese villages in northern Sri Lanka, a Government official said today.

title: Sarah A. Georgen to Wed Stephen P. Archer in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. W. Donald Georgen of Morris Township, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Sarah Andrea Georgen to Stephen Philip Archer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Archer of Norwalk, Conn. The wedding is planned for June.

title: GUIDE TO A VICTORIAN LAKELAND
description: DONALD GODDARD is a writer who lives in London.

title: Amy Laaksonen Wed in Trumbull
description: Amy Ann Laaksonen, a daughter of Walter A. Laaksonen of Darien, Conn., and the late Armida N. Laaksonen, was married yesterday to Blakeney DuBose Payson, a son of William Skiddy Payson of Stamford, Conn., and Mrs. Charles Hamilton Sanford of Southport, Conn. The Rev. Michael Tessman performed the ceremomy at Trinity Episcopal Church in Trumbull, Conn.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Recorded Dictionary For the Disabled Your publication of a photograph of Brad Greenspan, a Suffolk Cooperative Library System Coordinated Outreach Advisory Council member, demonstrating the first recorded dictionary for the blind and physically handicapped people (Long Island Journal, Nov. 11) brought to the public's attention one of the many special resources available to visually and physically disabled people on Long Island. Unfortunately, the brief caption did not note either the sophisticated technology that made this dictionary possible or, more importantly, how handicapped people on Long Island can obtain it.

title: More to Mull On Westway
description: Building Westway would have ''perceptible'' but ''minor'' effects on the striped bass that spend winters in the Hudson River and would not threaten their survival, the Army Corps of Engineers determined in an environmental review released last week. Whether that conclusion helps guarantee Westway's survival, however, remained uncertain.

title: Cosmos Dismiss Firmani
description: The Cosmos dismissed Coach Eddie Firmani last night immediately after the team surrendered five fourth-period goals and dropped a 7-4 Major Indoor Soccer League decision to the Cleveland Force at East Rutherford, N.J.

title: From Moscow and Washington, With Sincere Wishes
description: BOTH parties to next month's talks on arms control displayed enough good will last week to make almost a distant memory the sharp rhetoric the United States and Soviet Union were exchanging not so long ago.

title: EX-STATE AID NOW A BANKER
description: LAWRENCEVILLE KENNETH R. BIEDERMAN, who left the Kean administration - he was the State Treasurer - to open a savings bank here in October, said the time was ripe for the move because the economy promised to continue on the upswing.

title: CHAMBER: 'RAINFOREST' BY MCCABE
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has the British pianist and composer John McCabe as a guest this weekend, and is giving the first performances of a new piece he was invited to bring along (premiere, Friday evening at Tully Hall; deuxi eme, this afternoon there).

title: EXPAND TV COVERAGE ON L.I.: IT'S NOT BROADCAST, IT'S 'NARROWCAST'
description: ATELEVISION voice for Long Island has been stifled by Manhattan interests for the last 30 years. Although Long Island's population is 2.6 million - larger than that of 21 states - developments affecting Long Island politics, businesses, civic and cultural concerns are minimized in the vast New York market. In fact, although Long Island represents 12.9 percent of the New York market, no station, according to research conducted by the Long Island Coalition for Fair Broadcasting, has ever devoted more than 7 percent of news stories to Long Island events.

title: THE MASTERY OF ROBERT MOTHERWELL
description: AS HE OFTEN DOES, ROBERT MOTHerwell sits facing the south wall of his big studio - really a New York loft transplanted to suburban Connecticut - smoking and looking at his work. A nearby window offers a seductive view of a lawnscape, complete with pond, designed by a masterly English landscape architect at the turn of the century. But Motherwell is at this moment intent on what his own hand has wrought - three small canvases placed against the wall.

title: HOMELESS ARE WITH US
description: To the Editor:

title: Charlotte Reece Becomes a Bride
description: Charlotte Cameron Reece, a daughter of John Brooks Reece of Chestnut Hill and Marion, Mass., and Mrs. Jose Luis de Pedroso of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Northeast Harbor, Me., was married yesterday to Geoffrey Whitemore Disston Jr., a son of Mr. Disston of Bedford, N.Y., and Mrs. Robert Henry Larson of Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Donald E. Bitsberger performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill.

title:
STAGE VIEW;
PLAYWRIGHTS WHO TAKE A DIM VIEW OF BUSINESS
description: Arthur Holmberg, who teaches literature and drama at Harvard University, writes frequently about the arts.

title: Sexism?
description: To the Editor:

title: Women on the Firing Line
description: It was deeply moving to read Betty Friedan's article, ''Women on the Firing Line'' (Oct. 28), in which she combines her ''most basic values as woman, as Jew and as American. . . .'' She recalls, ''a national rabbinical organization held its convention in Arizona, a state that had refused to ratify the equal rights amendment, and the young women rabbis asked me to join in their outraged protest.''

title: Pakistani Leader to Hold Referendumn on Policies
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq said in a television broadcast today that a referendum on his Islamization policies would be held Dec. 19 and that he would stay in power for the next five years if he won.

title:
CAMERA;
ON THE ART OF MAKING SUCCESSFUL COPIES
description: Steve Simon, a freelance photographer, is a photography columnist for several Canadian newspapers. Success in the craft of producing high quality copy-photos is measured in getting an image as close to the original as possible. To do this, the photographer must be familiar with the techniques required.

title: LAW ON BIAS COULD LIMIT ROADWORK
description: HIGHWAY officials and major contractors, preparing to double road and bridge work next year under a $5.5 billion program, are saying they fear there will not be enough subcontractors owned by members of minority groups to meet the requirement that 10 percent of federally funded work go to such companies.

title: ROMANTIC BALLET BEGAN IN AN OPERA BY MEYERBEER
description: One of those seminal works that are always talked about but rarely seen promises to come back to life in some form when the Paris Opera revives ''Robert le Diable'' this spring in the French capital. ''Robert le Diable'' (Robert the Devil) is an opera by Giacomo Meyerbeer and not a ballet. But as any proper student of dance history knows, its premiere in 1831 at the Paris Opera caused a sensation - primarily because of its third act, in which Marie Taglioni led a band of spectral dancing nuns from their tombs in a moonlit cloister.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
NEW APPROACH TO DRUG CRISIS
description: UNDER our noses in our living rooms, classrooms and houses of worship is a whole other world in which our kids live, a world we do not notice or understand and of which we often are unaware.

title: TO PROTECT THE WORLD'S WEAK AGAINST THE STRONG
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa R. Jacobs Is Wed To W. Hunt Dumont
description: Lisa R. Jacobs, an office manager for the Newark law firm of Hannoch, Weisman, Stern, Besser, Berkowitz & Kinney, was married yesterday to W. Hunt Dumont, the United States Attorney for New Jersey. Judge Maryanne Trump Barry of the United States District Court in Trenton performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Philip D. Kaltenbacher in West Orange, N.J.

title: DAY-CARE LAGS AS HOUSING AMENITY
description: -CAREER families - once an anomaly,

title: IONA DOWNS MARIST IN OVERTIME, 86-78
description: Arnie Russell, admitting that he had a tough time accepting his role as a reserve center after being a starter last season, scored 6 of his 16 points in overtime as Iona sent Marist to its third straight defeat in basketball, 86-78, today at the winners' court.

title: Helen Hugo Has Nuptials
description: Helen Ann Hugo, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norman Hugo of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Capt. Michael Howard, U.S.A.F., a son of Mr. and Mr. and Mrs. John Howard of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Charles White performed the ceremony at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church.

title: CONSUMER RATES
REGAN INDIFFERENT IF CERTAIN STATES PAY MORE U.S. TAX
description: The concept of ''freezing'' the Federal budget apparently means different things to the White House and Congress. Page 38.

title: P.L.O. DOUBTS ROLE IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: A leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization says he does not think it would be possible for his organization to re-establish itself in southern Lebanon after an Israeli withdrawal.

title: Nuptials Are Planned by Miss Bowring
description: The engagement of Katharine Nash Bowring to Edwin Davis Coyle has been announced by Ann Street Bowring of New York and Lawrence, L.I., mother of the future bride, who is the daughter also of William Boyd Bowring of Chatham, Mass. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Temple Coyle of Christiansburg, Va.

title: NEW ROCHELLE TO LEASE ISLAND TO A DEVELOPER
description: The City Council has voted to lease Davids Island, an 80-acre abandoned Army base 1,500 feet off shore, to a Hawaii-based builder for a development that would include up to 2,000 luxury town houses and a marina.

title: Strip-Mining Appointment
description: President Reagan has named John D. Ward to be director of the Office of Surface Mining Reclamation and Enforcement. Mr. Ward has been acting director of the Interior Department agency since the summer. He assumes the post without Senate confirmation because Congress is not in session.

title:
CONTINGENT FEES-AN EVIL OF A BLESSING?;
LAWYERS OFTEN ARE GROSSLY OVERPAID
description: PRESIDENT LINCOLN said to lawyers: ''Discourage litigation. Persuade your neighbors to compromise whenever you can. Point out how the nominal winner is often a real loser in fees, expenses and waste of time. As a peacemaker, the lawyer has a superior opportunity of being a good man.'' This wise advice needs to be heeded in the mass personal injury litigation now flooding America's courts.

title: HIGH-RISE VISIBILITY FOR A.T.& T.
description: BEFORE divestiture, American Telephone and Telegraph had workers inside 17 million square feet of commercial space in New Jersey - but you would hardly have known it.

title: Surviving Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Weighing Time Against Life
description: It makes no sense to poke along at 55 miles an hour when there's no one else on the road, say drivers of the West's empty, smooth interstates who want to go faster than the speed limit. But it makes even less sense, say motorists whose nerves are tested on traffic-clogged and second- rate roads elsewhere, to argue that saving time is more important than saving lives.

title: FOLK: TRIONA NI DHOMHNAIL
description: Triona Ni Dhomhnaill's singing is one of the glories of current Irish folk music. Her voice stretches upward from a mezzo-soprano, and can be reedy as uileann pipes or clear as a pennywhistle, with a wisp of smoky melancholy now and then.

title: ARTISTS FIGHT DISMANTLING OF SCULPTURE
description: On a rectangular strip of city-owned property downtown, half of a sculpture called ''Green Lightning'' is still standing. The other half was dismantled two weeks ago by a city wrecking crew on the order of Mayor James D. Griffin, who deemed the artwork obscene only hours after it was unveiled.

title: FOR THE PRICE OF A T-SHIRT, CELEBRATIONS OF THE COUNTY
description: -SHIRT mania continues unabated with Westchester celebrating all manner of things on custom-designed shirts. Some silkscreen designs proclaim our history. The village of Port Chester sells one emblazoned with its new logo, a schooner, the type that made Port Chester a bustling port in the 1800's. The Dobbs Ferry Historical Society has a T-shirt commemorating William Dobbs, the first ferryman in the village.

title: Soviet Official Visits Block's Midwest Farm
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block welcomed his Soviet counterpart, Valentin K. Mesyats, to his 3,500-acre farm today, and said agriculture was the foundation of friendly relations between the two powers.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN PRODUCTS FOR THE AGED;
ITEMS THAT SELL IN A VENERABLE MARKET
description: IT is not easy to find products for

title: ARCHITECTURE AND DESIGN
description: By Peter Thornton. Illustrated. 408 pp. (Viking Penguin, $100; $125 after Dec. 31.)By Kenneth Frampton. Photographs by Yukio Futagawa. 465 pp. (Rizzoli, $65.)By Claude Mignot. Illustrated. 322 pp. (Rizzoli, $60.)By Jean d'Ormesson, David Watkin, Hugh Montgomery-Massingberd, Pierre-Jean Remy, Frederic Grendel and Marc Walter. Illustrated. 256 pp. (Vendome, $45.) By Fred Anderes and Ann Agranoff. Illustrated. 132 pp. (Abbeville, Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $16.) By Walter McQuade. Illustrated. 231 pp. (Abrams, $40.) By Elizabeth Gaynor. Photographs by Kari Haavisto. 252 pp. (Rizzoli, $35.) By Mills Lane. Illustrated. 258 pp. (Beehive Press, $75.)By Suzanne Slesin and Stafford Cliff. Photographs by Ken Kirkwood. 288 pp.

title:
MUSIC;
CHLDREN GET TASTE OF ANOTHER MUSIC
description: THROUGH their educational programs, the New Jersey State Opera and the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra prove to thousands of young people across the state every year that there is a musical world beyond rock 'n' roll. In the process, they assure themselves of future audiences.

title: COOKING
description: Now that home kitchens often look more professionally equipped than their restaurant counterparts, it is time to get down to the business of cooking. Cookbooks to keep the aficionado informed about the latest trends are flooding the market much as they did in the 1960's. This year's competition is so keen that many perfectly good books will never have a chance to prove their mettle because seasoned authors are at the top of their form.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The two dance events that highlight the television week are delectable signs that we have entered the holiday season, for both are balletic sweetmeats. In fact, one is that most popular of all terpsichorean treats, ''The Nutcracker.''

title: SENATE'S DOLE HAS HIS OWN BUDGET IDEAS
description: WASHINGTON WHEN Bob Dole won a hotly contested, five- man race last week to become the new Senate majority leader, the Kansas Republican captured one of the most powerful jobs in the capital, and got a running start toward 1988, when he is likely to bid for his party's Presidential nomination. But his selection also illustrates divisions within that party as President Reagan prepares for a second-term program of deficit reduction and economic resuscitation.

title: An Alternative To Methadone
description: There was new hope last week that at least some of the nation's estimated half million heroin addicts could be unhooked. Nearly 20 years after its discovery, the Food and Drug Administration approved naltrexone, a chemical capable of blocking the craving for heroin.

title: Mona Tinati Is Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Karim Tinati of Scarsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Mona Tinati to Michael Scott Settler, a son of Eugene B. Settler of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Phyllis Schlossberg of Rye, N.Y.

title: Abigail Ann Wender Becomes a Bride
description: Abigail Ann Wender, the daughter of Angelica Merrill Wender of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and Ira Tensard Wender of New York and Truro, Mass., was married yesterday to Rohan Seneka Weerasinghe, the son of Christobel Kotelawela Weerasinghe and the late Oliver Weerasinghe of Colombo, Sri Lanka. The Rev. Lee Hancock, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Georgian Suite, 1A East 77th Street.

title: NEW EFFORT TO KEEP BABIES FROM DYING
description: WHILE the infant mortality rate in Connecticut is on the decline, it continues to be higher in the largest cities, and health officials are seeking ways to educate mothers about prenatal and post natal care to reduce the number of infant deaths.

title: SCULPTORS FIND NEW WAYS WITH WOOD
description: One of the most unexpected developments in sculpture today is the sudden prevalence of wood. Wood occupies only a peripheral place in the history of Modernism. Twentieth-century giants like Brancusi, Picasso and Moore used wood, but it was not their primary sculpture material. During the wave of interest in direct carving in the United States between the wars, Herbert Ferber, Seymour Lipton and David Smith all worked in wood, but their major work came later, and the materials were metal and steel. After World War II, there was pioneering work in wood by Louise Nevelson, Louise Bourgeois and Mark di Suvero, but wood remained so much outside the late Modernist mainstream that, for example, their work was all but excluded from the new, but historically conceived painting and sculpture installation at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: FOREST SERVICE USES COMPUTERS TO DESIGN SKI SLOPES
description: The United States Forest Service is turning to computers to design new ski slopes that will blend with the rugged terrain of the Rocky Mountains.

title: AUBURN OUT OF THE SUGAR BOWL
description: Alabama finished its first losing season in 27 years by upsetting archrival Auburn, 17-15, today on two touchdown runs by Paul Ott Carruth and Van Tiffin's 52-yard field goal. The defeat knocked the Tigers out of the Sugar Bowl.

title: A Jeweler in Brooklyn Shot Dead by Robbers
description: A jeweler in Brooklyn was shot to death last night after he and two of his employees struggled with two masked robbers, the police said.

title: Pryor Signs for Fight
description: Aaron Pryor , the International Boxing Federation's undefeated, once-retired junior welterweight champion, said he had signed a $1 million agreement with Sylvester Stallone 's management group to defend his title against Gary Hinton of Philadelphia on Feb. 9. According to the promoter, Walter Alvarez , the bout will be held either in Miami or Atlantic City.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
MINING A SCHOOL REPORT FOR GOLD
description: IN THE last several weeks, there has been considerable discussion - most of it highly critical - of

title: WOMEN ON THE FIRING LINE
description: Betty Friedan's article provoked a mixed reaction from me. I am thankful that the women's movement has accomplished much in the United States in the recent past.

title: GOLF COURSE FILL-IN ASSAILED BY STATE
description: THE Village of Lawrence is in trouble with the State Department of Environmental Conservation for acting without a permit and filling in state tidal marshlands that fringe the municipal golf course, adjacent to Bannister Creek. Village officials say that the fill-in and an application to stabilize the surrounding shoreline of the golf course are all part of one comprehensive proposal to reclaim the golf course, some of which is steadily eroding.

title:
GARDENING;
SPECIAL BOOKS FOR THE GARDENER
description: WITH the holiday season fast approaching, finding gifts for everyone on your list can become a bewildering task. However, if there are gardeners, you are in luck. Any serious gardener will appreciate a garden-related gift more than any other, and there are so many from which to choose.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A PRIZED POSESSION THEN AND NOW
description: GOOD American antique pewter, of not much real interest to the average buyer until about 15 years ago, today is a major collecting category. As a result, ''there is now a very strong market for pewter, but not enough is being offered for sale to satisfy the demand,'' says John Carl Thomas, a collector and dealer from Hanover.

title: Susan O'Brien Married to George Thomas Myers
description: Leslie Susan O'Brien, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy O'Brien of Florence, N.J., was married in Princeton, N.J., yesterday to George Thomas Myers, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Myers of Penllyn, Pa. The Rev. John Long, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: KNICKS FALL TO BLAZERS, 115-93
description: Hubie Brown appears to be running out of ways to find some help, particularly a center. Last night, the Knick coach started the rookie Eddie Wilkins, a sixth-round draft choice who had played in only three pro games.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: How a Poet Plays

title: Claire C. Paquot Is Married to Robert W. Barney
description: Claire Christiane Paquot and Robert Weir Barney were married yesterday at the bridegroom's home in New York, where the Rev. Karl W. Gillmeister of the Presbyterian Church of the Covenant officiated at a nondenominational ceremony.

title: MORE SUBMARINE OFFICERS ARE STAYING IN NAVY, ADMIRAL SAYS
description: Better pay and more time ashore are reducing attrition in the Navy's corps of submarine officers, according to the commander of the Atlantic Fleet Submarine Force.

title: Talks Resume In El Salvador
description: Government officials and rebel representatives sat down to talk again last week in El Salvador but despite a lengthy session, the two sides remained far apart. In an apparent concession that helped keep the second round of discussions going for 12 hours, the insurgents offered to forgo immediate satisfaction of their demands for direct power-sharing.

title: POLITICS ; BUDGET: SURPLUS STILL ISSUE
description: TRENTON THE Legislature and Governor Kean have caught the Christmas spirit. Like most people faced this time of year with shopping lists that cannot be financed out of pocket, they are talking about spending money they do not have.

title: LAWN-CARE CONCERS FIGHT PESTICIDE SIGN RULE IN ILLINOIS CITY
description: Residents here who take pride in neatly manicured, pesticide-treated lawns are being forced to post signs warning of toxic chemicals, and commercial pesticide applicators are so upset they have gone to court.

title: Bataan
description: To the Editor:

title: DEVILS 3-GAME STREAK ENDS
description: In its 11-year history, the National Hockey League franchise now stationed in New Jersey has never put together a four-game winning streak - not as the Kansas City Scouts, the Colorado Rockies or the New Jersey Devils. The team had such an opportunity today, but failed again by losing, 5-3, to the Chicago Black Hawks at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: MAILBAG
description: DEBATING THE STATE OF TV DEBATES

title: Tax Inequities
description: To the Editor:

title: EQUAL PARTNERS IN THE VOCAL RECITAL
description: Jan DeGaetani and Gilbert Kalish will be making their Carnegie Hall debut Tuesday evening. Not that either is a stranger to the place: as soloists and chamber musicians, both the mezzo-soprano and the pianist have performed there often. But within the specialized community of the song recital, DeGaetani/Kalish is a celebrated duo like Britten/Pears, Souzay/Baldwin or Bolcom/Morris. The combination is a discrete artistic entity, and it's playing Carnegie for the first time.

title: THE SURE WAY TO PROTECT THE 'LITTLE GUY
description: THE contingent fee is perhaps the

title: 'EGO UNDER REIN'
description: Living in a historic Park Avenue dwelling may sound like a sybarite's dream, but the reality can be a bit of a nightmare if the plumbing and wiring are antiquated and the rooms look tired and gloomy. This accounts for the extensive work now under way at the Swedish Consulate, the four-building complex at 61-63 East 64th Street and 600, 604 and 608 Park Avenue.

title: THE LINE FOR AN ARTIFICIAL HEART STARTS IN LOUISVILLE
description: Today might have been William J. Schroeder's funeral. Before he was selected as the second recipient of a permanent artificial heart, his doctors had given him no more than a week to live. But the 52-year-old retired Federal worker has now survived on the experimental device for a week, and physicians say he is continuing to make ''slow and steady progress.''

title:
WINE;
SELECTING HOLIDAY GIFT BOTTLES
description: AREA residents planning to purchase wine for holiday gift giving should strongly consider aperitifs and postprandials, like cognac and port. Bottles are rarely completed at a single sitting, often allowing the good spirit to extend well into the new year. Moreover, a number of county shops stock wide selections at prices comparable to Manhattan retail outlets.

title: REPORT DEPICTS HUMAN TOLL OF 2 RECESSIONS
description: Calculating the human toll of two recessions over the last five years, the Government has reported that 5.1 million experienced workers lost their jobs because of plant shutdowns or staff cuts.

title: PIANO RECITAL: KAMITSUKA AT MERKIN
description: If musicality could be measured in exuberance alone, John Kamitsuka's piano recital at the Merkin Concert Hall Wednesday night would have been a great success. Mr. Kamitsuka pounced eagerly on his music, pounding cheerfully and indiscriminately at everything in sight. The playing unrolled in great sheets of legato; crescendo was hammered upon crescendo; there was little or no attempt to create coloristic differences between inner voices. Mr. Kamitsuka, in other words, not so much violated style as ignored it altogether.

title: Miss Clapp Weds John Connolly Jr.
description: Kimberly Jean Clapp, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur R. Clapp of New Providence, N.J., was married yesterday to John Francis Connolly Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Connolly of Spring Lake, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Tewell performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of New Providence, assisted by the Rev. Frank Hamill, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: EARTH AND AIR, FIRE AND WATER
description: THE FOURTH DIMENSION

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
HOW TO CULL THE CHRISTMAS-CARD LIST
description: THE annual writing of Christmas cards, unlike trimming the tree, stuffing the stockings or hanging the wreath, is not a cooperative effort at our house.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
A STREET WITH A DICKENS AIR
description: PHYLLIS LEE LEVIN is a writer who lives in New York.

title: BEST SELLERS Dec. 2, 1984
description: Fiction*1 16 THE TALISMAN, by Stephen King and Peter Straub. (Viking, $18.95.) Two parallel worlds and a young boy who can travel between them. *2 27 LOVE AND WAR, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) The Civil War rages in this saga of a Pennsylvania family and a South Carolina family, begun in ''North and South.'' *3

title: CONNECTICUT TO INSTALL CONCRETE DIVIDERS AT I-95 DANGER SPOTS
description: The State Department of Transportation says it will begin installing concrete median dividers at the areas along the Connecticut Turnpike where accidents are most likely to occur.

title: FOOD ; FAST WAYS TO BRIGHTEN A PLATE
description: WHEN it is dull and cold outside, there is nothing like bringing a little color to the dinner table. And as the holiday season approaches, nobody wants to fiddle around in the kitchen with longwinded recipes. What is needed are dishes that can be made with little fuss after a day's work or an afternoon of hectic Christmas shopping.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC IN SYMPHONY BY CARTER
description: The current New York Philharmonic subscription program, the final installment of which can be heard Tuesday night at 7:30 in Avery Fisher Hall, is a real grab bag, but orchestra spokesmen are quick to assure us that there are reasons. It seems that the first plan was for an all-French bill. Then Zubin Mehta's elbow surgery last spring forced the postponement of Elliott Carter's Symphony of Three Orchestras. When it was shoehorned into this program, something else had to be added to fill out the first half, and any notion of French coherency was long gone.

title: N. DAKOTA STATE WINS
description: James Molstre scored on runs of 19 and 20 yards and Todd DeBates recovered two fumbles as North Dakota State upended turnover-prone Nebraska-Omaha, 25-14, today in a Division II semifinal playoff game.

title: Double-Agent Defense Does the Central Intelligence Agency know something about
description: Karl F. Koecher that it isn't telling the Federal Bureau of Investigation? That's what Mr. Koecher's lawyer implied last week after the F.B.I. arrested his client on espionage charges. The F.B.I said that between 1973 and 1977, when Mr. Koecher worked as a translator for Central Intelligence, he passed C.I.A. secrets to the intelligence agency of Czechoslovakia, from which he emigrated in 1965. His lawyer said Mr. Koecher was actually ''a double agent in counter-espionage'' and that ''the F.B.I. double-crossed the C.I.A.'' After Mr. Koecher and his wife, Hana, were detained in New York City, prosecutors were undecided about charging Mrs. Koecher.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ; Belgium Delays Decision On Deploying Missiles
description: Belgium has delayed a decision on deploying 48 American cruise missiles until early next year.

title: JERSEY CITY: FEW SHOP SUNDAY
description: JERSEY CITY AS THE sun was setting on Nov. 25, the second Sunday in many years that most stores here finally could be open for business, there was, perhaps, only one thing missing amid the warm, late-autumn glow that lighted the Journal Square shopping district.

title: KIRKLAND STRESSES SOLIDARITY ON CANDIDATE ENDORSEMENT
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, says he is not committed to an early endorsement of a Democratic candidate in future Presidential campaigns.

title: ITALIANS COOK THE BOOKS AND TAX COLLECTORS SIMMER
description: It was a cause that all Italian small shopkeepers could believe in - opposing the Government's efforts to get them to start paying taxes, which seemed an outrageous notion in a land known for its mistrust of the state. So one day in October, tranquility descended on central Rome, giving the usually rambunctious place the feeling of a piazza in a country town at lunch time. Shop owners pulled their shutters down and joined in a nationwide strike. Immediately, there was talk of a Government crisis. The strike protested a proposal to raise $5.5 billion in tax revenues and to close a large budget deficit by imposing new rules designed to make evasion more difficult for shopkeepers. Last year, Finance Minister Bruno Visentini noted, one million shopkeepers declared average incomes of about $3,600. Their shop assistants declared incomes of about $5,700, 60 percent higher than the boss. Something was wrong, ''absolutely disgusting,'' Mr. Visentini said. His attempt to crack down threatens one of Italy's hallowed traditions. It also raises anew an issue that economists, businessmen and workers have debated for years: How large is Italy's ''black'' or illegal economy, and what should be done about it? The term ''black economy'' is often shunned here. In a land where consciousness of the Mafia is high, it has a sinister sound. In fact, the lawbreaking extends far more broadly, including shopkeepers and restaurant owners as well as small businesses in fields such as leather and clothing.

title: CHRISTMAS CAPER
description: Marilyn Stasio writes a syndicated newspaper column called ''Mystery Alley.'' A LIKELY STORY

title: December 2, 1954
description: Two days before, the Senate heard stern words from the man Joe McCarthy ridiculed as Senator Halfbright. J. William Fulbright, a Rhodes Scholar from Arkansas said, ''The junior Senator from Wisconsin, by his reckless charges, has so preyed upon the fears and hatreds and prejudices of the American people that he has started a prairie fire which neither he nor anyone else may be able to control.''

title: AROUND THE NATION ; Sale of Coat for $1 Ends a $675 Dream
description: A live-in housekeeper's dream of a Christmas trip to her homeland, El Salvador, evaporated when the old raincoat in which she had kept $675 was sold for $1 at a family garage sale.

title: NEW POLICY IS PROPOSED FOR RUTGERS
description: NEWARK SOME of the recommendations made by a committee of business, education and civic leaders to put Rutgers in the forefront of state research universities are not new, but others would be radical departures from current policies.

title: FARMERS' REVENUES FROM CROPS DIP
description: FARMERS in the state sold their crops for less money last year than in 1982, according to the New England Crop and Livestock Reporting Service.

title:
DINING OUT;
THE NOUVELLE CUISINE OF SPAIN
description: THOSE who think leaden rice, searing spiciness and a slick of olive oil characterize Spanish cuisine are in for a surprise. And those already familiar with the light- handed cocina de hoy, Spain's version of nouvelle cuisine, will approve of the mellow, artistically wrought and often indecipherably delicious dishes Jose Costa has been creating in La Camilia's kitchen since its opening only six weeks ago.

title: SIMPLIFIED MENU IN A FORMAL ROOM
description: -detailed main dining room in the Marriott Hotel in Uniondale, opened about two years ago, the menu was extremely complicated. A la carte entrees were available in different-size portions from separate listings, and there was a complete dinner selection as well. Ordering was more like negotiating.

title: CONCERT: DAVID JOLLEY, HORN PLAYER, AT TULLY HALL
description: David Jolley, one of the better horn players of the present day, came to Tully Hall on Wednesday night to give a concert supported by a Solo Recitalist Grant from the National Endowment for the Arts. His program offered works by Bach, Schumann.

title: ARCHITECT'S HOUSE TRIGGERS A TEMPEST ON EAST END
description: FEW places in the United States can equal the showcase that the South Fork offers architects, and few houses better exemplify the perils of performing in such a spotlight as the house that William F. White designed for himself last year in Water Mill.

title: Linda Sentner Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert V. Sentner Jr. of Port Washington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Linda Davy Sentner to Dr. Michael J. Fracchia, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred A. Fracchia of Plandome, L.I. The wedding is to be in April.

title: THE UNITED STATES HAS A BAD DAY IN WORLD COURT
description: Already a standard target of attacks in the United Nations General Assembly, the United States last week seemed to be on a collision course with another world forum, the International Court of Justice. Some legal experts see the conflict - over the Court's ruling that it has the power to judge Reagan Administration actions against Nicaragua - as the latest step in a gradual withering of the United States' commitment to the system of international institutions it helped set up after World War II. Administration officials, however, contend that they have operated effectively in these organizations.

title: DOING BUSINESS WITH DISTANT BANKS
description: TRADITIONALLY, most people have chosen

title: AN OLD LANE LEADS TO DISPUTE ON ACCESS
description: AWALK along Judge's Lane in the Village of the Branch, a Town of Smithtown historic district, is a walk back in time to an era when people lived out their lives on land settled centuries earlier by their ancestors.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: HUNTINGTON
description: FORTY miles east of Manhattan, on

title: Mismanaging Indian Affairs
description: If there ever was a need for the Bureau of Indian Affairs - many native Americans might argue there was not - there no longer is, according to a report issued last week by President Reagan's Commission on Indian Reservation Economies. The commission was sharply critical of the B.I.A. and recommended that it be replaced by a more competent and less meddlesome agency.

title: Earplugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Marianne Infante Is Bride of Eugene P. Conese Jr.
description: Marianne Elizabeth Infante, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Infante of Ridgewood, N.J., was married there yesterday to Eugene Paul Conese Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Conese of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Eugene Heyndricks performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church.

title: TEACHING AT HOME ON RISE IN STATE
description: FARMINGDALE WHEN Nancy Plent of this Monmouth County community began corresponding with other parents who taught their children at home, she soon found herself answering so many inquiries that she decided to write and distribute a newsletter, The Unschoolers Network.

title: CRAFT-BUYER'S HOLIDAY GUIDE
description: THE holiday crafts shopper has a wide range of options awaiting him all around the state, from Sussex County in the north to Camden County in the south.

title: Faith Glazier and Darioush Toraby Are Married
description: Faith Julie Glazier, a lawyer in New York, was married yesterday to Darioush Shater Toraby, a partner in Thompson, Robinson & Toraby, architects and engineers, also in New York. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: Page
description: Wins W.B.A. Crown

title: U.S. GROUPS HELPING GET OUT THE VOTE IN GRENADA
description: Two Washington groups, one closely associated with the Republican Party and the other with the A.F.L.-C.I.O., have contributed more than $25,000 for campaigns to encourage Grenadians to vote in elections Monday, according to group officials here and in Washington.

title: Sports of The Times; GIANTS-JETS: BONFIRE EMBERS
description: WHEN the Giants play the Jets today at Giants Stadium, those Jets' season- ticket holders who remember what the real rivalry was like 20 years ago will appreciate the irony. Under the National Football League schedule formula, the Giants will be the visiting team in their own home - the house that Sonny Werblin built for the Giants in the Meadowlands a decade after he built the Jets into the Super Bowl III champions.

title: A COLLECTION OF PARCELS BEHIND BARS
description: Direct mail sales specialists know that the use of a postage stamp on an envelope improves the chances of response from the the recipient. But just about all stamped direct- mail advertising pieces have two black bars over the stamp. Until a few years ago, and even sometimes today, within those two bars was the name of the city and state from which the item was mailed.

title: SEPARATISTS IN NEW CALEDONIA INSTALL A PROVISIONAL REGIME
description: Militant Melanesians seeking independence for New Caledonia hauled down the French tricolor today, hoisted their flag and installed their own provisional government in a ceremony in a Noumea suburb.

title: ; Buenos Aires
description: To the Editor:

title: MINNESOTA CASE SETS LIFE-SUPPORT PRECEDENT
description: Early on July 14, 1983, nurses at the Hennepin County Medical Center here found a 57- year-old patient choking in his bed, his neck caught in an improperly placed restraining strap.

title: AIR MEDICAL CARE SUBJECT OF 2 PLANS
description: TWO proposals for airborne medical care, intended to save crucial time or ease risky travel, are before Connecticut officials.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN PRODUCTS FOR THE AGED;
A PREMATURE TASTE OF OLD AGE
description: PATRICIA MOORE, head of the industrial design firm of Moore & Associates, is waging war against what she calls ''Darwinian Design'' - the prevalence of products that only the healthy and fit can use.

title: LEGGY LOOK, BIG TOPS COME OUT IN THE COLD
description: As an anchor to this distinctive silhouette, almost any kind of footwear works - soft ankle boots, high-topped sneakers that look like oversize marshmallows and straightforward flat shoes.

title: URUGUAY'S NEW LEADERS INHERIT A BAD CASH FLOW
description: As if to purge their memories of 11 years of heavy-handed military rule, Uruguayans marked last week's elections with a spontaneous carnival of dancing, singing and embracing. Rather than dwell on the past, they celebrated the recovery of hope. The change had come with dizzying speed. Only in late August did the dictatorship confirm the date of the elections, lift press censorship and allow political parties to begin campaigning. In just three months, a country that used to be a democratic model for the rest of Latin America cheerfully returned to normality. But like others who have recently switched from military to civilian rule, Uruguayans expect far more from democracy - and from the centrist Government of President-elect Julio Maria Sanguinetti that is due to take office March 1 - than it may be able to deliver. Last week, factory workers, who earn $50 per month and have seen real wages halved since 1969, spoke of their hopes for higher wages and more jobs. ''The dictatorship is killing us with hunger,'' a young woman remarked as she waited to vote. ''How can we live off what we earn? Things have to improve.'' But the economy is caught in a crisis that defies easy solution. Gross domestic product has fallen by 20 percent in three years, unemployment stands at 15 percent and inflation is running at 50 percent annually. Uruguay also has a $5.3 billion foreign debt which, for a country of three million inhabitants, is higher per capita than that of Brazil, the world's largest debtor.

title: LIVING & BOATING ON THE HUDSON
description: Imagine waking up in the morning to a spectacular view of the Hudson River and the New York skyline, then avoiding bridge or tunnel traffic en route to the city by hopping aboard a launch at your front door, one that nips across the river to 42d Street in a trim 10 minutes.

title:
DINING OUT;
A 'CONTINENTALLY ORIENTAL' MENU
description: STOREFRONT restaurants in shopping centers take many forms. One of the most creatively designed we have come across is the Cafe Look See in Fort Lee.

title: ST. JOHN'S HANGS ON TO CAPTURE FINAL
description: St. Bonaventure scratched and clawed and came close to ending St. John's perfect record in the Lapchick Memorial Tournament last night. But the Redmen ran out the final 32 seconds for a 58-57 victory and their 10th consecutive title.

title: SEARCHING OUT WRIGHT'S IMPRINT IN LOS ANGELES
description: CHARLES LOCKWOOD is the author of ''Guide to Hollywood and Beverly Hills'' (Crown) and ''The Estates of Beverly Hills'' (Margrant Publishing).

title: MORE TERROR, MORE SPEED; Guilt by Citizenship
description: Terrorism took an ominous turn in Vienna recently when Evner Ergun, a United Nations official since 1967, was killed by an Armenian gunman. Mr. Ergun's reputation was excellent, and his sole ''crime'' was his citizenship. He was a Turk.

title: Co-op Screening
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAVEL AND NATURE
description: What is striking about this year's travel and nature books is that so many are dominated by aerial shots, as if by common decree this were to be the Year of the Bird's-Eye View. Certainly it is not a year for readers who get giddy when they look down from heights.

title: 'COTTON CLUB' GOES TO ALBANY FOR ITS PREMIERE
description: New York's capital city will become a most unlikely movie capital today when it holds the premiere of ''The Cotton Club,'' a $47 million film about the famous Harlem nightclub of the 1920's and 30's.

title: TOURS DESIGNED FOR OLDER PEOPLE
description: For older travelers, the variety of opportunities seems almost limitless these days. All sorts of destinations and types of travel are beckoning: traditional escorted bus tours of Western Europe, safaris into the savannas of East Africa, cruises up the Orinoco River to the heart of Venezuela, extended vacations on the Costa del Sol of Spain, and educational programs on university campuses, to name just a few. Tour operators have learned that an ever-growing number of older travelers have the vacation time and flexibility that most younger adults lack, and that older people also frequently have renewed energy and curiosity.

title: MASTERING THE ART OF A MASTER CLASS
description: ALTHOUGH he has been studying the violin for four of his 12 years, Young Jin Lee was new to the master- class circuit. So new that on Monday, when he played for James Buswell, the noted violinist who capped a weekend appearing with the Long Island Philharmonic by conducting a master class for talented Long Island students at Huntington High School, the stocky seventh grader at Elwood Junior High School was noticeably nervous.

title: WEINBERGER'S WAR GUIDE: FOLLOW THE DIRECT ROUTE
description: Hardly a year has gone by since the end of World War II that Americans have not struggled with the issue of when and how to use military force. Last week, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger entered the fray, arguing that the standard should be: Be prepared to fight virtually everywhere, but then decide either to win or, failing that, to get out or stay out in the first place.

title: 3 HUMAN RIGHTS GROUPS URGE U.S. TO MOVE TO CURB ABUSES IN HAITI
description: Three human rights groups have asked the State Department to refuse to certify Haiti in the department's annual review of human rights unless violations there are ended.

title: MAILBAG
description: DEBATING THE STATE OF TV DEBATES

title: THE SERIOUS TASK OF MAKING TOYS
description: TOR the last 12 years, Elizabeth and Ronald Lanza of Simsbury have spent many hours considering what kind of toys are right for their three children. After all, said Mrs. Lanza, a 39-year-old former nursery school teacher, ''it's part of our job as parents.''

title: TESTIMONY TO START IN TRIAL OF SAN DIEGO MAYOR
description: Opening arguments are to begin Monday in the conspiracy and perjury trial of Mayor Roger Hedgecock, who was easily re- elected last month despite his indictment on 13 felony charges.

title: SKEPTICISM GREETS NEW TAX PLAN
description: Imports still exceed exports, and although the gap narrowed a little in October, the merchandise trade deficit remains at a record high. At more than $100 billion for the year so far, it may be double that of last year. In October, machinery and farm goods exports increased, and imports of manufactured goods decreased, but the gap was still $9.2 billion. Part of the problem is the continuing strength of the dollar, which surged again last week as interest rates in the United States dropped.

title: GLEN COVE PROJECT DRAWS CRITICISM
description: THE recent decision by the Glen Cove Community Development Agency to allow construction of a 120,000-square- foot office complex in the downtown business district has been criticized by some city leaders and merchants who say middle-income housing would do more to rejuvenate the city's sagging downtown economy.

title: Guard Is Reported to Confess In the Killing of Indira Gandhi
description: A security guard accused in the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has admitted his guilt and implicated two other men in a conspiracy, the United News of India reported today.

title: Polish Leader Meets the Press
description: It is rare for a national leader to admit publicly that things are not what they should be. It is even rarer for the leader of a Communist country to hold a news conference. Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski of Poland did both last week.

title: Irma Birnbaum of A.T.&T. To Be Bride of Leo Steiner
description: The engagement of Irma Birnbaum to Leo Steiner has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Max Birnbaum of Clifton, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance, who owns the Carnegie Delicatessen and Restaurant in New York and Atlantic City, is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ben Steiner of Elizabeth, N.J.

title: VETERANS OF LOS ANGELES ROCK STILL CHAMPION ITS JOYS
description: If any city and any sound dominated rock music during the 1970's, it was the folk-rock of Los Angeles. Bands like the Eagles and Fleetwood Mac and solo artists like Jackson Browne and Linda Ronstadt shaped a style based firmly on folk music - country, 60's folk, even soul - but unified as a genre of its own by its shared concerns, musical signatures and social linkages.

title: FLORIDA TRIUMPHS OVER FLORIDA STATE
description: Kerwin Bell threw two touchdown passes and Bobby Raymond kicked two field goals today to lead Florida to a 27-17 victory over Florida State.

title:
GARDENIING;
SPECIAL BOOKS FOR THE GARDENER

Any serious gardener will appreciate a garden-related gift more than any other, and there are so many from which to choose.

title: Perverse Flattery?
description: To the Editor:

title: SALVATION, DAMNATION AND THE RELIGIOUS NOVEL
description: IN a savagely witty review of one of Francois Mauriac's books some years ago Jean-Paul Sartre wrote, ''God is not a novelist. Neither is M. Mauriac.'' Sartre objected to the way he thought Mauriac curtailed his characters' freedom, confining them in the claustral atmosphere of a faith that dictated their choices; and this, or some variation of it, has been the traditional criticism of religious novelists, in particular Catholic ones. George Orwell wrote, ''The novel is a Protestant art form, requiring the free play of mind. There are few Catholic novelists who are any good, and most of them are bad Catholics.'' He was surely using ''Protestant'' in its historical or secular sense, not as a description of an active type of faith; from his own position of radical secularism, he was really indicting any novelistic stance of belief, however beleaguered, in transcendence and deity.

title: Hunter Is Shot by His Dog
description: A hunter reached down to pet his dog and was accidentally shot by the animal Thursday, the Union County sheriff's office said Friday.

title: Judge Tells Traffic Offenders That Charity Begins at Court
description: It will not get them reduced fines, but City Judge Peter Katic says traffic and misdemeanor offenders who go before him can help themselves by helping others in a food-for-the-needy drive. And the judge says all the violators are complying.

description: Clinging precariously to a hillside overlooking the mansions and apartment blocks of an elegant beach district, Rocinha seems like a typical Rio de Janeiro slum.

title: Sewage Ruling Bans Building in Boston
description: Few citizens distressed by a perception of legislative inactivity have the power to act on their frustrations immediately. But Judge Paul G. Garrity of Superior Court in Boston is one of them, and last week act he did. Wednesday evening, he watched local television interviews with state legislators about the Massachusetts House Ways and Means Committee's decision to postpone action on a bill that would create a new state water and sewer authority. Thursday, he imposed a moratorium, retroactive to June 1983, on permits for commercial connections to the antique sewer system through which the state capital and 42 neighboring cities and towns still dump tons of raw sewage into Boston Harbor.

description: WASHINGTON WALTER F. MONDALE barely had time to lick his wounds before political enthusiasts kicked off the 1988 Presidential campaign.

It includes autobiography, biography, letters, plays, novels, stories, diaries, memoirs, essays, history, social science and poetry. AND THEN WE HEARD THE THUNDER. By John Oliver Killens. (Howard University. $6.95.) An affecting novel about a black soldier and his outfit in World War II from Fort Dix, N.J., to the South Pacific. THE ARAB-ISRAELI WARS: War and Peace in the Middle East. By Chaim Herzog. (Vintage. $8.95.) A candid survey by the President of Israel of military conflicts from 1948 to the 1982 invasion of Lebanon.

title: DEMOCRATS LOOK TO THEIR DEMOGRAPHICS

''You can judge a candidate by the company he keeps,'' said the caption.

title: Florida's Worst Storm Was Not a Hurricane
description: The 1984 Atlantic hurricane season, which produced 11 major storms, ended this morning, leaving an odd legacy: Florida's most damaging storm was not a hurricane.

title: SALVADOR REJECTS REBELPEACE PLAN
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte today rejected an rebel plan presented Friday that called for the eventual formation of a new government, a new constitution and a new army. But he said negotiations would continue.

title: Jersey to Add Patrols For Drunken Driving
description: The state police will set up sobriety checkpoints during the Christmas and New Year's holidays to apprehend drunken drivers, Governor Kean announced this week.

title: WESTERN UNION SENDS OUT AN S O S
description: LATE in October, the Western Union Corporation rented a Manhattan hotel ballroom and filled it with potential customers, reporters, and beaming public relations men. The spread was impressive - oversized croissants, miniature Danish pastries, Brazilian coffee, and ther choice fare. And the accompanying sound-and-light show, dramatizing Western Union's undertakings in communications in general, and in electronic mail in particular, was dazzling. On the surface, it seemed a bash fiven by a company celebrating success.

title: MILITARY PLAN ON PRESS POOL BEING ALTERED
description: The Department of Defense has apparently backed away from a previously reported plan to create a standby press pool of 12 people to cover emergency military operations such as the invasion of Grenada, saying that there never was a formally approved plan for a pool of any specific size.

description: Mr. and Mrs. C. Barse Haff Jr. of Old Lyme, Conn., formerly of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Ely Haff, to Barry Graham Armstrong, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald G. Armstrong of White Plains.

Hamilton of Setauket, L.I. The Rev. Kenneth Swanson performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in New York.

description: Paul Revere's Birthday Party According to the Paul Revere Memorial Association, the patriot-silversmith was born in Boston in the last week of December 1734. To commemorate the 250th anniversary of his birth, the Paul Revere House, owned by Revere from 1770 to 1800 and the oldest house (about 1680) remaining from 17th-century colonial Boston, is offering a series of special events this month.

LONG ISLAND OPINION;

description: WE were told by friends who signed up for a whale-watching trip out of Montauk that they had actually seen a mother whale tending her calf.

title: ART
description: THE BIBLE AND ITS PAINTERS. By Bruce Bernard. Preface by Lawrence Gowing. Illustrated. 300 pp. (Macmillan, $24.95.) This is not a reassuring title. Can this be yet another mindless anthology, superior only in the quality of its reproductions to ''The Seasons in Art,'' ''The Dog in Art'' and ''Athletics in Art''? It could be. But stick with me, because this is in fact an exceptionally intelligent and wide-ranging survey, selected and annotated by someone who knows what he is doing, and accompanied in each case by the relevant passage from the Bible. Above all, Bruce Bernard's anthology is powered by curiosity as to what painters made of the Bible, in this period or that, and what their paintings have to tell us not only about the Bible or about the period in which the pictures were painted, but about ourselves. As to that, Lawrence Gowing in his preface has much that is rewarding to say about ''the unparalleled dual value that Western society and its painters have given both to the outward, perceptible world and at the same time, in the same picturing, to what is inward and invisible, either ideal or compulsive.'' Put more plainly, there are in this book 274 paintings, every one of them reproduced in very good color, by painters who range from the accepted great masters, from Raphael to Rembrandt and beyond, to people like Leon Bonnat, Simeon Solomon and Briton Riviere, who would have been sent round to the servants' entrance even 20 years ago.

title: STATES GAIN WIDER INFLUENCE ON SCHOOL POLICY
description: Hundreds of new laws enacted to improve the quality of elementary and secondary schools are giving states around the country increased control over public education.

title: Chris Evert Lloyd Wins Match No. 1,000
description: Chris Evert-Lloyd scored the 1,000th singles victory of her tennis career today, beating France's Pascale Paradis, 6-1, 6-7, 6-2, to advance to the quarterfinals of the Australian Open.

title: MORE TERROR, MORE SPEED; Dialogue There's plenty of gas, driving is back in style, and rural states are pressing to relax the Federal 55-mile- per-hour speed limit, at least on big interstates in rural areas. They deserve a hearing. A study of the nation's 10-year experience with the limit finds that increasing it could yield large benefits without ''proportional impact on safety.'' An increase to 65 m.p.h. might cause an additional 500 deaths per year. But for each death travelers would save 850,000 hours - nearly 96 years - in time.
description: To some rural lawmakers, that's an acceptable trade-off, and legislators from urban areas, which need the 55- mile limit, need not stand in the way.

title: KING HUSSEIN VISITS EQYPT, SEALING RECONCILIATION
description: King Hussein of Jordan arrived in Cairo today for a three-day state visit, the first official trip here by an Arab leader who politically shunned Egypt for making peace with Israel.

title: Viviana Pouget, Architecture Student, Is Wed to Jeffrey Wattenberg, Broker
description: Viviana B. Pouget, a daughter of Olga Rodriquez-Pouget of Coral Gables, Fla., and the late Dr. Rene Rodriquez-Pouget, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Wattenberg, a son of Beverly Thaler of Hicksville, L.I., and Stanley Wattenberg of Forest Hills, Queens. title: Kentucky Drops 2
description: Two Kentucky starters have been dismissed from the football team for disciplinary reasons by Coach Jerry Claiborne and will miss the Hall of Fame Bowl, the school announced. No details of the infractions were disclosed, but athletic officials said they would re-evaluate the case in the spring to determine if the two players, Tony Mayes , a sophomore defensive back, and Brian Williams , a junior defensive end, will be allowed to rejoin the team next season.

description: SUFFOLK County Executive Peter F. Cohalan and the County Legislature are coming under increasing pressure to change their adamant stance against the opening of the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station.

She comes, as usual, with a repertory of songs - funny songs, charming songs, wistful songs - that have become closely identified with her and with her very personal manner of delivery.

title: AN AGE-OLD (BUT STILL COMMON) HORROR

His captors also prodded his tongue with live electric wires, put him through mock executions and held his head under water in a game they called ''the submarine,'' he said. The prisoner was released several weeks ago after a judge and doctors intervened, corroborating much of his story. It happened not in some infamous dictatorship, but in democratic and generally enlightened Spain. The victim was a suspected Basque terrorist.
