title: ISRAELI MAJOR SAYS HE TOLD SHARON OF RISK OF A MASSACRE IN LEBANON
description: An Israeli Army reserve major testified today that, only four days before the 1982 Beirut massacre of Palestinians, he warned Ariel Sharon that civilians were liable to be slaughtered in Lebanon.

title: PLASTIC SURGERY TRANSCENDS AGE BARRIERS
description: When Lydia Salzano of Mt. Vernon, N.Y., announced that she was planning to have her nose done, friends and relatives said: ''At your age? Are you crazy?'' Mrs. Salzano, who underwent the surgery last month, is 42 years old.

title: Sports World Specials ; And No Greens Fees
description: There may be stables with better facilities, and there may be trainers with better racing records, but when a pacer or trotter needs some refresher training, it's a good bet that Tom Milici's Windsome Farms in Rising Sun, Md., is the horse's choice.

title: LENDL IS EXTENDED, GAINING 4TH ROUND
description: Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia advanced into the fourth round of the Australian Open tennis championships today with a victory over Tarik Benhabiles, an unheralded French teen-ager.

title: BOWLS SETTLED IN UPSETS
description: The final five college bowl slots were filled on the final day of the regular season Saturday, but not without some more of the unexpected results that have marked every weekend in this year of upsets.

title: LIBEL TRIALS ARE NOT WON BY GOOD FAITH ALONE
description: To the Editor:

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Among the college basketball teams in Division I, which one has gone the longest without a losing record for a season?

title: WHAT MOI MEANT WHEN HE ASKED KENYANS TO SING HIS TUNE
description: To the Editor:

title: Tackle Snares Bengal Pass
description: With their playoff chances hanging in the balance, the Cincinnati Bengals decided today to go to the receiver they could trust most: left tackle Anthony Munoz.

title: Wider Japan Payment Gap
description: Japan's balance of payments deficit widened to $274 million in October, from $172 million a year ago, the Finance Ministry said.

title: CONTINENTAL PURGE SEEN AS SIGNAL
description: Bankers, bank directors and bank analysts said today that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's decision to force out 10 directors of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company may encourage bank directors nationwide to take their jobs more seriously.

title: JESSE JACKSON SAYS HE IS PRESSING SOUTH AFRICA FOR TALKS ON POLICIES
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, praising recent demonstrations protesting South Africa's racial policies, said today that he would attempt to meet with South African leaders to discuss ''brutal, inhuman exploitation'' of blacks.

title: Brave Justice in Salvador
description: For years in El Salvador, an army officer's uniform conferred a blanket of immunity from prosecution for political crimes. Now President Jose Napoleon Duarte has taken a brave step to tear that blanket away. His decision to cashier Lieut. Isidro Lopez Sibrian without pension demonstrates what he thinks about the officer's involvement in the 1981 killing of two American labor advisers and a Salvadoran peasant leader.

title: Cube Is A Problem To CBS
description: Nobody has been more frustrated by Rubik's Cube than CBS Inc.

title: Minutes
description: The stenographer's machine ran

title: HUSSEIN, IN EGYPTIAN PARLIMENT, CONDEMNS CAMP DAVID ACCORDS
description: King Hussein of Jordan reiterated his criticism of the Camp David accords today in a speech to the Egyptian Parliament.

title: DIPLOMATS ON A WAR FOOTING TO GUARD AGAINST TERRORISM
description: Since the terrorist attack on the American Embassy in Lebanon in September, the State Department and its diplomats abroad have gone on what amounts to a war footing.

title: COLLEGES HELP TO 'INCUBATE' NEW INDUSTRY
description: In a cloistered gray brick building here that resembles a fraternity house for entrepreneurs, the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute is helping new companies go into business. Its example is being copied nationwide.

title: PURCHASERS, CITING ORDERS, SEE SLOWED ECONOMY
description: The economy continued to be sluggish in November, with the rate of new orders virtually at a standstill, the National Association of Purchasing Management concluded yesterday in its most recent report. It is likely that December will similarly see little or no growth, the association said.

title: Venezuelan Debt Talks
description: Venezuela's President, Jaime Lusinchi, said today he would discuss his country's private sector debt when he meets President Reagan and bankers on an official visit to Washington and San Francisco between Monday and Thursday. Mr. Lusinchi told reporters he plans to discuss the interest on Venezuela's estimated private debt of $6 billion to $7 billion. Interest arrears on the debt, estimated by bankers to be more than $1 billion, are a major stumbling block to the final renegotiation of nearly $21 billion of public debt.

title: CHICAGO SCHOOLS ORDERED CLOSED AFTER TEACHERS UNION SETS STRIKES
description: Negotiations broke off today between teachers and officials in the nation's third-largest school district, and the Board of Education ordered all public schools closed after the teachers' union said it would strike Monday morning. A strike would halt classes for 430,000 students and idle up to 28,000 teachers and 12,000 other school workers.

title: A Movable Hearing
description: Several politicians were more than

title: DEMOCRATS PREPARE TO ELECT SPEAKER
description: The Democrats in the House of Representatives begin this week to organize Congress for the next two years, and it appears they will commence on a note of reconciliation between House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. and some conservative Democrats.

title: SALVADOR VISITS HONORS 4 SLAIN CHURCHWOMEN
description: Thirty-four churchwomen from the United States have arrived here on a pilgrimage in honor of three American nuns and a Roman Catholic lay worker who were slain by National Guard soldiers four years ago today.

title: APRES RUCKELSHAUS LE DELUGE?
description: Perhaps the most telling commentary on William D. Ruckelshaus's 18-month tenure as Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency was the reaction of many environmental groups when the White House announced his resignation last week.

title: CITY BALLET: A NEW CAST FOR MARTINS'S 'SCHUBERTIAD'
description: Of the 10 dancers with solo roles in the New York City Ballet's production of ''A Schubertiad'' on Saturday night at the New York State Theater, only Stephanie Saland was a veteran member of the cast. The others were newcomers to Peter Martins's ballet about guests at a party in 19th-century Vienna. Dancing to pieces by Schubert for piano solo and piano duet, they proved to be attractive guests who would grace any party.

title: Six-Hour Standoff Ends With Two People Dead
description: A man who barricaded himself inside a house where a woman had been shot to death earlier today exchanged gunfire with the police in a six- hour siege before apparently takang his own life, the police said.

title: WHEN AIDE AND BOSS MUST PART
description: When her assistant resigned a few weeks ago, Marilyn Machlowitz, a New York psychologist and business consultant, felt sad.

title: MAGAZINE FOR YOUTH IN SPORTS
description: MANY an experienced magazine publisher has lost his way while seeking the holy grail of the youth market. So maybe what it takes is a relatively inexperienced publisher.

title: MOZAMBIQUE: INCONGRUITIES AMID HUNGER
description: The predicament of hunger, rebellion and economic collapse in which Mozambique is mired makes Maputo a capital of incongruities, some painful, others absurd.

title: A New Publication For Private Pilots
description: Another new magazine that is revving up is Take Off, a life-style publication aimed at the more affluent private airplane pilot.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Dec. 3, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ABOUT BOSTON
description: Here on the Boston Common, which breathes with the vapors of the earliest heroes of the republic, a young athlete touched a control tonight, and Christmas bulbs strung through the trees switched on, enchanting the dusk with light.

title: Prosit, Herr Reagan
description: T he West German Embassy was

title: Adina Kolatch Is the Bride of H. Steven Ehrenhalt
description: At Temple Beth Shalom in Lawrence, L.I., yesterday Adina Kolatch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Kolatch of Woodmere, L.I., was married to H. Steven Ehrenhalt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel M. Ehrenhalt of Brooklyn. Rabbi Ephraim Kolatch of Jerusalem, the bride's great-uncle, performed the ceremony.

title: STAGE: 'ISSUE,' SATIRICAL REVUE AT BALLROOM THEATER
description: One hundred percent of Americans are in show business. Ninety-nine out of a hundred are familiar with the terms ''enchilada'' and ''high heel,'' but only 1 percent recognize ''leftist guerrilla'' and ''nouvelle cuisine.'' And more people know the words to Michael Jackson's ''Beat It'' than to ''The Star-Spangled Banner.''

title: COMMON MARKET TO DISCUSS ENTRY OF NEW MEMBERS
description: Common Market leaders will try to resolve disagreements over wine, fish and fruit that are blocking the admission of Spain and Portugal to their 10-nation trading group at a two-day summit meeting scheduled to open here Monday.

title: Satellite Launching Put Off
description: The launching of a $56 million weather and rescue-aid satellite was postponed today for the ninth time, on this occasion because of a problem with the guidance system. The liftoff of the National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration satellite was rescheduled for 2:42 A.M. Dec. 9, said C. J. Fenrick, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Chairman Retires At Oak Industries
description: Oak Industries, the financially troubled electronic products and communications company, said that Everitt A. Carter, its 65-year-old chairman and chief executive, had retired.

title: King to Give the Saudis Voice in Government
description: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia was quoted today as having said that he plans to give his people a say in the Government, which is now an absolute monarchy.

title: CALLER REPORTED AN ATTACK DURING ASSAULT ON WOMAN
description: Police officials investigating the slaying of a woman in Brooklyn Friday said yesterday that they may have been notified of the attack while it was in progress, and not only after the victim had been shot.

title: FRANCE SENDS ENVOY TO TROUBLED ISLAND
description: The French Government sent a special commissioner to New Caledonia today to try to quell disturbances between whites and Melanesians in the troubled South Pacific island territory.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Allied Stores Corp. has elected to its board John Phillip Diesel, president and chief operating officer of Tenneco Inc.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: BOSTON In 1981 a Yugoslav named Milan

title: DOLE SAYS MEESE WILL BE APPROVED
description: Senator Bob Dole, the newly elected majority leader of the Senate, said today that ''one of the first orders of business'' when Congress reconvenes in January should be the confirmation of Edwin Meese 3d as Attorney General.

title: ARGUMENTS OF WESTMORELAND TRIAL RESEMBLE SOME KEY DISPUTES IN 1960'S
description: The key, and disputed, arguments in Gen. William C. Westmoreland's libel suit against CBS, in which the general may finish testifying today, bear a strong resemblance to some of the key disputes among American officials in the 1960's about how the Vietnam War could best be prosecuted. While those arguments are not easy to summarize briefly, one school of thought seemed to believe the war could be won by killing people and another school believed it would be more useful to influence people - as well as killing some of the most intractable enemy.

title: EXPERTS STUDY EXPLOSION IN CRASH TEST OF AIRLINER
description: Shaken and disappointed, Government engineers set out today to pin down what went wrong in the fiery destruction of an unmanned airliner in a test crash.

title: OPERA: STRAUSS'S 'ELEKTRA' AT MET
description: There was much to anticipate at the Metropolitan Opera's revival of ''Elektra'' on Saturday night, despite the absence of Klaus Tennstedt. Mr. Tennstedt was originally scheduled to conduct, but, complaining of nervous exhaustion after a recent cross-country orchestra tour, he gave way to James Levine, the Met's music director.

title: INDIAN POLICE ARREST 3d SIKH IN GANDHI SLAYING
description: A Sikh identified by the authorities as one of two men who killed Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has reportedly confessed and provided details of the plot. His statements were said to have led to the arrest of a third Sikh and a police search for two more people believed to be linked to the case.

title: FIRST TIME SINCE '76
description: The campaign for Grenada's first elections in eight years came to an end this evening in a flourish of small motorcades with loudspeakers blaring reggae and calypso music and political messages.

title: Dickerson Gets 149 As Rams Triumph
description: Eric Dickerson, continuing his assault on O. J. Simpson's season rushing record, ran for 149 yards today as the Los Angeles Rams built an early lead and went on to a 34-21 victory over the New Orleans Saints.

title: We Sell Oil. Why Not the Spectrum? You can't see, smell or touch it. But to economists, the radio spectrum is as much a scarce natural resource as petroleum or fresh water. Recent advances in communications technology and the prospect of more are forcing difficult choices on the Federal Communications Commission. Fortunately, the commission is now looking for ways to let markets rather than regulators make the decisions.
description: A half-century ago, Congress dumped onto the F.C.C. the responsibility for deciding who gets to use how much of the finite radio spectrum. Typically, the commission has chosen the path of least political resistance, awarding usage rights to whoever made the first claim.

title: Wide Recount Asked In Closest House Race
description: Representative Frank McCloskey, Democrat of Indiana, filed papers Friday for recounts in all 15 counties of the Eighth Congressional District, where the Republican candidate, Rick McIntyre, has challenged the incumbent's lead of 72 votes.

title: UNHEALTHY CURE FOR MEDICARE ILLS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Vance-Muskie Duo
description: In a city famous for type-casting,

title: HARD TIMES FOR PINOCHET
description: Despite extensive unhappiness here with President Augusto Pinochet and concern in Washington over his measures to thwart dissent, the 69-year-old military ruler seems to have defied his adversaries and to remain firmly entrenched. Last week a national protest, the 12th in a series that began in May 1983, failed so definitively that for the first time the Government did not bother to publicly proclaim it a failure.

title: A SUBDUED CONVENTION OF BROKERS
description: In contrast to last year's celebratory mood, leaders of the securities industry ended their annual convention here sobered by a year of depressed profits and major uncertainties in the months ahead.

title: Deborah Albright Is a Tarrytown Bride
description: The marriage of Deborah Veronique Albright, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Albright Jr. of Pocantico Hills, N.Y., to Joel Mercurio, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Mercurio of Holliswood, Queens, took place yesterday in the Butler Memorial Chapel at the Marymount Convent in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by the Rev. John D. Kirwin, assisted by the Rev. Louis Padavano.

title: ;  International
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1984 Quarrels over wine, fish and fruit that are blocking the admission of Spain and Portugal to the Common Market are hoped to be resolved in a two-day summit meeting scheduled to begin in Dublin today. In the background are such political questions as Spain's entry into NATO and an effort to help both former dictatorships strengthen democracy. In the foreground Dublin has undertaken the biggest security operation ever to protect Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britian against a possible attack by the Irish Republican Army. (Page 1, Column 4.)

title: CONTRIBUTORS TO NEEDIEST FOLLOW FAMILY TRADITION
description: Longtime contributors, many of them carrying on a family tradition, account for much of the response to the annual appeals of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Actions Defended In Bumpurs Case
description: A psychiatrist who examined Eleanor Bumpurs four days before she was shot to death by the police in an eviction dispute said yesterday that state law had prevented him from having her committed to a psychiatric hospital.

title: Mexican Conglomerate's Comeback
description: Grupo Industrial Alfa, the huge Mexican conglomerate, has returned to the Mexican stock exchange after a two-year suspension. The move was viewed by analysts here as a sign of confidence that the company was near a resolution of its problems with foreign creditors on its $2.5 billion foreign debt.

title: COWBOYS BEAT EAGLES, 26-10
description: An interception and touchdown run by the safety Dennis Thurman in the first quarter today gave Dallas a lead it never relinquished, and the Cowboys posted a 26-10 victory over the Eagles, maintaining their share of the lead in the National Conference East.

title: Chase Bank Seeking International Scope
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank is reviewing its relationship with Wells, Rich, Greene, at least as far as international wholesale banking is concerned, according to reliable Madison Avenue sources.

title: CITIBANK FLORISHES IN BRAZIL
description: Given all the recent talk about the third world's borrowing troubles, few people would expect a big American bank to be earning record profits in a Latin American country with a depressed economy and huge debts.

title: Letter: On Caribbean Policy ; In Puerto Rico, Economy Before Polity
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW RULE TURNS THE TIDE FOR THE GIANTS
description: The first touchdown of the Jets- Giants game today was made possible by an ''unsportsmanlike penalty'' against a Jet rookie, Kyle Clifton, who had been following his instincts: He leaped attempting to deflect a field-goal attempt.

title: CORRECTION
description: A season preview of local college basketball teams in Sportsmonday last week incorrectly identified the coach at Marist College. He is Matt Furjanic.

title: The Left, Aground in France The Mitterrand administration, which brought France its first left-of-center government in a generation, is reeling from blows that a healthier government might have shaken off. While its legislative majority is secure for another 18 months, it has slid so rapidly in the polls that a new mandate now seems unlikely.
description: The erosion of support began over economic austerity and religious education. Now foreign policy sideshows like Libya's duplicity over troops in Chad and a flare-up in tiny New Caledonia compound the sense of failure. Can the French left no longer govern?

title: Service at Sarah LawrenceFor the Artist Kurt Roesch
description: A memorial service will be held for the artist and teacher Kurt Roesch at the Sarah Lawrence Gallery at the college's Performing Arts Center in Bronxville, N.Y. on Wednesday at 4 P.M. Mr. Roesch, a painter and engraver who taught painting at Sarah Lawrence from 1934 to 1972, died Oct. 8 at his home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 79 years old.

title: Golf Swing Sequel
description: Jack Nicklaus, the resourceful golf champion, has come up with a resourceful solution to a problem that has plagued championship golfers for years - how to peddle a new how-to book when all your old how-to books have already told all there is to tell about your swing.

title: AN UPSURGE IN READINGS BY WRITERS
description: The art of reading poetry aloud has become so popular in New York that one poet, X. J. Kennedy, calls it ''po biz.''

title: CRITICAL PLAYS BY DEFENSE
description: The Giants' offense and special teams kept making mistakes today, and the defense kept bailing them out. Finally, the offense started moving the ball, the defense bent but did not break, and the Giants emerged with a hard-fought 20-10 victory over the Jets.

title: STUDY SAYS AGGRESSIVE CHILD IS FATHER TO AGGRASSIVE CHILD
description: Children who are highly aggressive are likely to remain aggressive in adulthood, and, in turn, to have children who are also highly aggressive, according to research published in the current issue of ''Developmental Psychology.''

title: GOOD MOVES BY GALBREATH
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. He is a third-down player, a specialist. Tony Galbreath is often called on when the Giants need an extra receiver coming out of the backfield, who can hold on to the football and dance his way to the first-down marker.

title: REBELS' PLAN WAS NOT DISCUSSED
description: Salvadoran Government and rebel officials spent most of a 12-hour negotiating session on Friday debating a Government peace proposal and the possibility of a Christmas cease-fire, according to two Government delegates to the talks.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: '' In this part of the world, we do not just think people will die of hunger. We assume it.''-Bougma Emile, a volunteer relief worker in Burkina Faso

title: By John Gross;
description: TALES OF A LONG NIGHT. A Novel. By

title: Arms and the Democrats
description: House Democrats who are anxious to give both their party and their branch of Congress a new voice in international affairs will press this week for creation of a House Select Committee on Arms Control. Representative Thomas J. Downey of Suffolk will ask, probably tomorrow, that the Democratic caucus create a 25-member panel, and his supporters say they have enough votes to put the idea over.

title: ONLY THE 'FUN' WARS
description: WASHINGTON In a carefully reasoned, timely and

title: EDUCATION DEPENDS ON FEDERAL PARTNER
description: To the Editor:

title: OUTDOORS ; A BAD DAY FOR DUCKS TURNS GOOD
description: GUILFORD, Conn. When I was too young to hunt by myself, the coughing of distant guns over the salt ponds and marshes on dark winter days filled me with a longing that I further nourished by listening to the graybeard waterfowlers gathered about the pot- bellied stove in Charlie Turner's general store in the evenings.

title: LIONEL K. LEVY, ARCHITECT OF NEW YORK COLISEUM Lionel K. Levy, the principal architect of the New York Coliseum and a designer of racetracks and sports arenas, died Thursday night of Parkinson's disease at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 82 years old.
description: Before he designed the Coliseum and office-tower complex for the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority in the mid-1950's, Mr. Levy was best known as the architect associated with Mike Jacobs, the sports promoter.

title: Paul W. Conner, 47, Is Dead; Founded Exchange Program
description: Paul W. Conner, who developed an international exchange program for undergraduate students, died Wednesday at New York Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: PREPARING THE WAY FOR ARMS TALKS
description: The announcement that Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko have agreed to hold arms discussions in Geneva in early January has raised hopes that United States- Soviet relations may finally get off dead center. These talks will have little chance of success, however, unless President Reagan takes steps to put his own house in order.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.04

title: NETS BATTLE BACK BUT LOSE TO 76ERS
description: ROY S. JOHNSON

title: FRIENDS ARE CHILDBIRTH 'COACHES' TO SINGLE MOTHERS
description: The woman who gave my Lamaze class would have to correct herself,'' Suzanne Miles recalled. ''She would say 'husbands' and then look at us and say 'coach.' ''

title: POP: KAMAHL AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: Kamahl, the Australian pop star who is known as that country's ''voice of romance,'' is a singer of exceptional talent who has opted to take the low road, artistically speaking. Born in Malaysia, and of Sri Lankan parentage, Kamahl possesses a commanding bass baritone voice whose heroic resonance recalls the late Paul Robeson.

title: Business Digest; MONDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1984
description: International

title: FIVE RECEIVE KENNEDY CENTER HONORS FOR 1984
description: President Reagan and the Kennedy Center tonight honored four Americans and an Italian for their contributions to culture in the United States.

title: Japan Plans Easier Trade GENEVA, Dec. 2 (Reuters)
description: Japan plans to announce a

title: Olympics Will Bar Officials in Boycotts
description: The International Olympic Committee rejected today proposals to exclude boycotting nations from subsequent Olympics. It said such action would punish athletes more than the governments initiating the boycotts.

title: Laura Jane Steigman Wed to B. C. Swaim Jr.
description: Laura Jane Steigman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Steigman of Whippany, N.J., was married yesterday to Benjamin Clayton Swaim Jr., the son of Lieutenant Colonel Swaim, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Swaim of Myrtle Beach, S.C. Rabbi Morrison Bial performed the ceremony at Mayfair Farms in West Orange, N.J.

title: Mayor Plans To Trim 1,200 Philadelphia Jobs
description: Saying city Government is ''simply too big,'' Mayor W. Wilson Goode has announced plans to trim Philadelphia's work force by at least 1,200 through attrition during the next 18 months.

title: 'CHILDREN' ON NBC TONIGHT
description: More than 10 years ago, Robert Northshield, then with NBC News, produced an unusually sensitive documentary titled ''Suffer the Little Children.'' It went to Northern Ireland and looked at how the children, both Roman Catholic and Protestant, were being caught up in the ideological hatreds of the conflict. Well, the ''troubles'' are still raging there, most of those children have grown up, some like the hunger striker Bobby Sands have died, and a new batch of youngsters now faces a tormented future as various political entities continue to wring their seemingly helpless hands. These young people are the subject of ''Children in the Crossfire,'' the television movie on NBC at 9 this evening. Once again, their plight is profoundly moving.

title: BIG INTEREST IN HENDERSON
description: Rick Sutcliffe and Bruce Sutter, remaining on the loose as free agents, will figure in some of the more intriguing talks at major league baseball's annual winter meetings here this week, but a not-quite-free Rickey Henderson could command even more titillating attention.

title: CHINA ENGAGES HOFSTRA U. TO ARRANGE DEALS WITH AMERICAN COMPANIES
description: In an unusual alliance of a world power and a university, Chinese officials signed a contract over the weekend that establishes Hofstra University as a deal maker for China.

title: NEO-CONSERVATIVES' FUTURE IS DIMMER
description: The future of the neo- conservatives, which seemed so bright four years ago, appears far less certain in the wake of the latest Reagan landslide.

title: Hartwick Tops Fairleigh, 1-0
description: Fairleigh Dickinson University's soccer team made one glaring defensive mistake in 90 minutes this afternoon and paid a high price for it.

title: BOSSY: NOT AFRAID TO SUCCEED
description: The trip was growing long and Pat LaFontaine, who somewhere on the road had picked up one more nickname, The Motor City Munchkin, was playing the dressing room for laughs. His Islander jersey tugged up over his helmet, walking trance-like, he bumped blindly into bewildered and amused teammates.

title: BUSINESS-SERVICES INDUSTRIES PACE GROWTH IN JOBS IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Advertising agencies, accounting concerns, public relations companies, photocopying shops and many other businesses that exist to serve other businesses have become the fastest- growing part of the New York City economy, according to a Federal report.

title: Experts Still See Fall in Rates
description: The move to lower interest rates was stalled late last week after a huge $6.7 billion increase in the nation's basic M-1 money supply measure led some traders to conclude that the Federal Reserve would be less willing to continue the easing of monetary policy that began in September.

title: Falcon Guest
description: On Aug. 4, 1983, the New York Yankee outfielder Dave Winfield killed a sea gull in Toronto with a warmup throw to the infield, an accident that became an international incident when he was arrested and charged with cruelty to animals.

title: STUDY SAYS THIRD OF CONVICTS GO BACK TO JAIL
description: WILLIAM E. FARRELL

title: TOUGHER TALK FROM S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON MOMENTUM is building at the Securities and Exchange Commission to bar repeat offenders of Federal securities laws from serving as officers or directors of public corporations.

title: JOHN W. BUCKLEY, PETROLEUM EXECUTIVE, DIES
description: John W. Buckley, a petroleum-industry executive who once headed the worldwide network of speculative oil, gas and mineral ventures founded by his father, William F. Buckley Sr., died of heart failure Saturday at Etobicoke General Hospital in Toronto. He was 64 years old and lived in Lakeville, Conn.

title: SOUTH OF SAHARA, THE INTRUSIVE POLITICS OF HUNGER
description: They came across the emptiness that hoofs had turned to dust, the women of a distant tribe, without men but with children, astride donkeys, 30 or 40 of them.

title: SCIENTISTS ENLISTED IN EFFORT TO MAKE EMBASSIES SECURE
description: The State Department has a contract with the National Academy of Sciences to design a model embassy that incorporates the latest safety features.

title: JET BRIGHT SPOT: O'BRIEN'S ARM
description: Early last week, Joe Walton snapped when he was asked who would be the Jets' quarterback against the Giants.

title: Elections in Singapore Scheduled for Dec. 22
description: The Singapore Government said today that general elections would be held on Dec. 22, a year ahead of schedule.

title: Glass Master's Windows
description: New York's most freshly discovered treasure may end up as the latest one to be lost.

title: World Press Review Is Planning Changes
description: Marilyn K. Ginsberg, publisher since October of World Press Review, announced a number of changes last week.

title: 2.3 Million Applied For Telecom Stock
description: The bankers managing the $4.7 billion British Telecom stock offering said today that 2.3 million people had applied for shares, forcing them to impose a maximum allocation of 800 shares per applicant.

title: THEATER: 'BING,' BY FARRELL
description: The Circle Repertory Company, long one of Off Broadway's most reliable purveyors of realistic American plays, has lately had a lot of trouble finding stageworthy new scripts. But even theatergoers who suffered through the company's weak offerings of last season, such as ''Full Hookup'' and ''Levitation,'' may be startled by the low estate to which the Circle Rep has fallen in its latest venture, James Paul Farrell's ''Bing and Walker.'' A formula work to start with, the play is executed with so little energy and conviction that one begins to wonder if the whole effort might be a put-on.

title: Argo Sets Deal With French The Argo Communications
description: Corporation, New Rochelle,

title: Bush Warns of Program Cuts
description: Vice President Bush told Republican governors today that the nation must ''face the fact'' that spending ceilings will be imposed on a ''tremendously wide spectrum'' of Federal programs to cut the deficit.

title: MOVES BY CBS ELICIT CAUTION
description: AFTER CBS Inc. agreed two weeks ago to buy 12 consumer magazines from the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company for $362.5 million, Susan V. Watson cut her next year's profit estimate for CBS to $9.20 a share, from $9.50. The analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company said the acquisition would dilute CBS earnings.

title: Banned Polish Priest Celebrates Mass
description: A Roman Catholic priest who was banned from preaching by the Primate of Poland because of his political views took part in a church service today on the outskirts of the capital.

title: AFGHAN WAR: THE RUSSIAN PUBLIC IS STILL A BELIEVER
description: When Pvt. Aleksandr Pankratov died last June in Afghanistan defending his Soviet comrades from an insurgent ambush, his father's grief was mixed with pride.

title: BRITAIN'S DIVERSIFIED BANKER
description: One of the best-kept secrets of the huge British Telecom share offering completed last week has been the total fees paid to Kleinwort Benson Ltd., the merchant bank that planned and ran the historic $4.7 billion sale for the British Government.

title: CHANGES WEIGHED IN FEDERAL RULES ON DISCRIMINATION
description: Federal officials have begun an extensive review of whether to change the guidelines used to detect patterns of discrimination in employment against blacks, women and Hispanic Americans.

title: Mexico Oil Price
description: Mexico, the top foreign oil supplier to the United States, is leaving its export prices unchanged in December, the Government-owned oil monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos, has announced. It will be the 23d consecutive month of a $29-a-barrel price for Mexico's light Isthmus crude oil.

title: People
description: * Kenneth J. Majka has rejoined Calet, Hirsch & Spector as executive vice president/creative director.

title: REAGAN URGED TO BLOCK COMPARABLE PAY EFFORT
description: An influential conservative organization is urging the Reagan Administration to make it ''a top priority'' to block efforts to apply a theory of evaluating the worth of different jobs to achieve pay equity for women.

title: PoliceCreditHoltzman With Aiding in Arrest
description: District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn was credited by the police with assisting in the arrest of a robbery suspect Saturday afternoon in Manhattan.

title: Hiatus in Some Treasury Offerings
description: Beginning this week, there will be a three-week hiatus in Treasury borrowings in the note and bond markets, although regular weekly sales of new three- and six-month bills will continue and may be increased in size.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; The Vicar as Author
description: As befits the subject of his book -

title: COLGATE STAR IMPRESSES PROS
description: By this time every year, scouts from the National Football League teams and the several scouting combines that service them are busy evaluating and analyzing the college players who will be available in the next draft.

title: Israeli Rate Information
description: Israel's Central Bureau of Statistics today announced that because of high inflation it would release figures on the skyrocketing cost-of-living twice a month instead of once, beginning later this month. With inflation now running at 800 percent a year, business and trade leaders need faster information, a spokesman for the bureau said.

title: U.S. News & Talent
description: Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the new owner of U.S. News & World Report, is contemplating injecting some new blood into the writing staff of the news magazine. He has asked Michael Kramer, a contributing editor of New York magazine, to conduct a talent search for journalists who might broaden and liven up the normally low-key, straight-away news format of the publication, which is sometimes affectionately referred to by its own reporters as ''U.S. Snooze.''

title: TAX CUT WON'T HELP NEW YORKERS MUCH
description: To the Editor:

title: If the Shoe Fits . . .
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan

title: Fight Protest Is Planned
description: The handlers of Gerrie Coetzee said today that his knockout loss to Greg Page Saturday in the World Boxing Association heavyweight title fight should be annulled because of a late bell in the eighth and final round.

title: NBC MINI-SERIES BASED ON 'THE SUN ALSO RISES'
description: A grieving Jake Barnes attends the funeral of a prostitute he had visited several times before being wounded and rendered impotent in World War I. Pedro Romero, the handsome young Spanish bull fighter, uses his sword to murder a vindictive count who has threatened the life of Lady Brett Ashley. Jake's best friend, Bill Gorton, takes an airplane, goes up on a daredevil flight and crashes to his death.

title: 'Drumming' at Museum
description: Steve Reich and Musicians will perform ''Drumming'' on Dec. 12 at 8:30 P.M. at the Titus I Theater of the Museum of Modern Art, where the piece had its premiere 13 years ago. Tickets are $7.50.

title: PHYLLIS GEORGE HIRED BY CBS NEWS
description: After more than a month of negotiations, CBS News announced yesterday that Phyllis George, a CBS sportscaster and former Miss America, will become co-anchor of ''The CBS Morning News'' with Bill Kurtis on Jan. 14.

title: CHICAGO TEACHERS ON STRIKE AS NEGOTIATIONS GO ON
description: While many of the city's teachers took to the picket line today, the Chicago Teachers Union and the Chicago Board of Education resumed negotiations in an effort to end a strike that began at 12:01 A.M.

title: TELECRAFTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including a gain of $55,000 for the quarter and a loss of $3,335,000 for the year from discontinued operations. c-Net loss after a loss of $177,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net income after a loss of $287,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Planning the Inaugural
description: The Committee for the 50th

title: JETS UPBEAT
description: As the Giants keep winning and improve their chances for a playoff berth, their running game has become respectable. The statistics are not dramatic, but the results are, and Rob Carpenter, Joe Morris and now Tony Galbreath are playing larger roles in offensive production.

title: Solidarity Activist Is Reported Killed
description: Sources in the banned Solidarity trade union said over the weekend that that one of their underground activists in Lublin died in a hospital after he was attacked and beaten on the night of Oct. 19, the night that a pro- Solidarity priest, the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, was abducted more than 100 miles away and then killed.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN APARTHEID FOE
description: Layton Slater, chairman of South Africa's largest newspaper group and a leading opponent of Government racial policies and restrictions on press freedoms in his country, died of heart failure Sunday at his home in Johannesburg. He was 68 years old.

title: 1,504 Interviewed For Poll on Arts
description: The poll, which was commissioned by Philip Morris Inc., a major corporate sponsor of arts institutions, was conducted by telephone interviews last March among 1,504 people chosen randomly across the United States. The statistical margin of error was 3 percent, meaning that one can say with 95 percent accuracy that the results are within plus or minus three percentage points of what they would have been had the entire population been polled.

title: THE MYTH OF THE PEACEFUL MARIJUANA FARMER
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.25-11.50 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Accounts
description: * Hearst Business Communications to Decker, Decker & Freas.

title: Collecting a Staff
description: It was only three days ago that Howard Schnellenberger was appointed the new football coach at Louisville, but his staff is already starting to fall into place. Chris Vagotis, the offensive line coach at Schnellenberger's former school, the University of Miami, resigned yesterday with the intention of rejoining his old boss.

title: REPORTS CITE LACK OF COORDINATION DURING U.S. INVASION OF GRENADA
description: The United States invasion of Grenada a year ago was hampered by disjointed planning and poor coordination among the different American military contingents, according to internal reports by two officers who commanded Navy air squadrons during the invasion.

title: DEBATE ON NEW YORK'S WETLANDS RETURNS TO ISSUE OF LOCAL CONTOL
description: Fifteen years ago, a student at the Columbia Law School drafted a law that the state eventually used to gain control over 800,000 acres of New York's fresh-water wetlands.

title: More Retirees Receive Private Pension Funds
description: The Government's first survey of new Social Security beneficiaries in more than a decade shows a dramatic increase in the number of retirees who also draw private pensions, according to the head of the Social Security Administration.

title: HARNISCHFEGER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a gain of $11,005,000, or 93 cents a share, from the effect of a change in accounting for depreciation. c-Net loss.

title: SMOKE DETECTOR VIOLATION IS SEEN
description: One woman was killed and two women and a child were injured yesterday evening when a fire raced through an apartment in a three-story Newark apartment house, fire officials said.

title: AGENCY RULES OUT ATOM WASTE BANS
description: The Federal Government ruled today that state and local officials have no authority to ban or severely restrict the transportation of radioactive materials.

title: The Worm and the Apple ; Readers' Services ; Word Power
description: A million and a half adult residents of New York City don't know how to read English. That frustrates and embarrasses them.

title: New Zealand Concert Clash
description: Thirty policemen were injured in clashes with some 2,000 bikers who tried to crash a weekend concert by the rock group Deep Purple. The police said today that 78 arrests were made when about 2,000 ''criminal and gang elements'' tried to storm into the stadium Sunday.

title: Q T & T INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $115,847.

title: 2 Funds, Crow Set Property Venture
description: The Equitable Real Estate Investment Management Company said it and Eastdil Realty Inc. had arranged for a joint venture to acquire a $315 million package of properties in the Pacific Northwest from the Jack A. Benaroya Company. The joint venture consists of two California pension funds and Trammel Crow & Company, Equitable said.

title: CHILEAN FAMILIES BEGIN COLONY ON ANTARCTICA
description: Seventy-three years after Roald Amundsen of Norway reached the South Pole by dogsled, pioneers at a Chilean outpost here are exploring the psychological and logistical frontiers of everyday community life in Antarctica.

title: 43 Salvadoran Troops Killed Battling Rebels
description: At least 43 Government troops and at least as many rebels have been killed in three days of fighting in El Salvador, military sources said today.

title: Required Reading; East or West
description: Paul H. Nitze, chief United States delegate to the Geneva talks on reducing medium-range missiles, speaking in Washington Nov. 15 at a dinner given by the Ethics and Public Policy Center:

title: MILLER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net losses. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Sept. 24.

title: REGAN FORESEES FINAL TAX PLAN LIKE TREASURY'S
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that he believes the tax legislation the President proposes to Congress next year will be quite similar to the sweeping plan the Treasury Department presented last week.

title: Allied Stock Up On Reports of Bid
description: The Allied Stores Corporation's stock jumped $7 a share on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, reflecting widespread takeover reports. The stock closed at $59.25 a share, on a volume of 819,500 shares.

title: College Basketball ; McIntosh's 26 Help Fordham Win, 82-65
description: Tom Penders used his entire 14- man squad as Fordham scored an 82- 65 victory over St. Francis College last night at the losers' Physical Fitness Center in Brooklyn.

title: CENTRIST PARTY SWEEPS TO VICTORY IN GRENADA VOTE
description: A centrist coalition party favored by the Reagan Administration swept to victory in elections here today, 13 months after a United States-led invasion put an end to revolutionary government on the island.

title: Seaway u8Reopening Planned Thursday
description: The reopening of the St. Lawrence Seaway is planned for Thursday after a jammed lift-bridge is freed.

title: People
description: * Helayne Spivak has been named senior vice president at Ally & Gargano.

title: WILTON ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
RAND INFORMATION SYSTEMS reports earnings for 12 wks to Aug 12
description: b-Including tax credit of $106,505 for the 12 weeks and $146,100 for the 24 weeks. c-Net income. d-Including a tax credit of $350.

title: Sikh-Hindu Fund Established For Victims of Indian Unrest
description: Sikhs and Hindus are being asked to help each other in an international fund-raising effort launched in New York yesterday for the victims of religious violence in India.

title: DETAILS OF SPENDING FREEZE OUTLINED
description: President Reagan has tentatively decided to accept a modified freeze on a large block of domestic spending, officials said today.

title: SUPPORT BUILDS FOR RETAINING TAX TO BENEFIT MASS TRANSIT
description: Negotiations over the future of a corporate tax surcharge that subsidizes mass transit in the metropolitan region shifted today from whether the tax should be continued to how long it should be continued.

title: HIGH COURT TO DECIDE ANTITRUST SKIING CASE
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the company that controls downhill skiing on three of the four mountains in Aspen, Colo., violated the Sherman Antitrust Act when it refused to cooperate with the owner of the fourth mountain.

title: GUARDIAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-There are no comparative year- ago figures available because the company began operations in late 1983.

title: Lodgings for the Homeless New York City has to do better by its homeless families: on cold nights many now are forced to bed down in welfare offices, surrender their privacy in mass shelters or purchase warmth and a place to sleep for 90 cents a person, on a subway train.
description: In fact the city already does much contracting for hotel space and renovating of apartments in abandoned buildings. But the number of families on the street continues to exceed supply. Another resource might be tapped quickly and cheaply: unused space in private homes.

title: Aerialist 'Critical' After a Fall
description: An aerialist with the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus was in critical condition today with a fractured skull after falling from a 20-foot-high bar during a practice session.

title: CHESS MATCH: ANOTHER DRAW
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov agreed to a draw today after 13 moves in the 29th game of the world chess championship match.

title: SUN'S ULTRAVIOLET RAYS INDUCE SHIFTS IN OZONE
description: A WEATHER satellite has obtained the strongest evidence yet to show that variations in the Sun's output of ultraviolet light have a direct and substantial effect on the Earth's protective ozone layer.

title: CHEMFIX TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: EAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TRIAL OF SAN DIEGO MAYOR OFF TO A BITTER START
description: The Mayor of San Diego, Roger Hedgecock, went on trial today on campaign finance charges, and the defense immediately contended the charges were linked to his having alienated the San Diego Republican establishment, including the District Attorney.

title: REPORTER CRITICIZES SHARON FOR STAYING IN GOVERNMENT
description: David Halevy, a Time magazine correspondent, declared yesterday that Ariel Sharon ''should have quit politics'' after being severely criticized over the 1982 Phalangist massacre of Palestinians in Lebanon.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Scouting column in Sports Pages on Friday misstated the number of players from Indiana University, Louisville and Notre Dame who started the season in the National Basketball Association. The number is seven from each school.

title: WINTER IN A BRITISH PIT VILLAGE: THE SPIRIT IS BITTER
description: The telephones have been turned off, and the savings have run out. The children depend on school lunches and the mercy of the milkman. There are no strike benefits.

title: RANGERS ROUTED
description: The Rangers exhausted themselves last night trying to keep up with the Philadelphia Flyers. They matched them knock for knock early but then lost their zest and lost the game, 6-2.

title: DYING STUDENT CALLED RESISTING RAPE A MISTAKE
description: Before dying from stab wounds, a 23-year-old drama student told doctors and nurses who were trying to save her life that she made a mistake in resisting the man who robbed her and tried to rape her in her Upper West Side apartment building, police officials said yesterday.

title: Police Press Hunt In Housing Killing
description: Detectives said yesterday that they thought they knew the identity of the second person wanted in the killing of a woman at a Brooklyn housing project. The victim was severely beaten in the courtyard of the project on Friday and then dragged inside a lobby and fatally shot.

title: Astros May Move Outfield Fences
description: The Houston Astros have reportedly decided to move in the outfield fences in the Astrodome next season, which should produce more home runs.

title: JANE'S SECRET ROLES AS RIVAL AND IDEAL
description: To the Editor:

title: MODERATE RISE IN FOOD PRICES SEEN NEXT YEAR
description: With large supplies of grain and meat expected to be available through most of 1985, consumer food prices should rise a moderate 2 to 5 percent next year while farmers' net income should improve only slightly, the Agriculture Department predicted today.

title: EUROPEAN WINE ACCORD SEEMS NEAR
description: The leaders of the European Economic Community were edging toward an agreement tonight on curbing surplus wine production that would open the door to Spain and Portugal joining the Common Market in a year's time.

title: Investor Defers Register Offer Fred Eyechaner, the president of a Chicago-based communications concern, said yesterday that he would not make
description: an acquisition bid for the Des

title: 2 SENATORS PRESS REAGAN ON ARMS
description: Two conservative Republican Senators warned today that they might vote against the deployment of 100 MX land-based missiles if President Reagan did not stop abiding by provisions of the 1979 strategic arms limitation agreement with the Soviet Union.

title: JANE'S SECRET ROLES AS RIVAL AND IDEAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Horner's Choice
description: A decision whether to undergo surgery on his right wrist has Bob Horner ''so confused I don't know what to think.'' The Atlanta Braves' third baseman must decide whether to begin rehabilitation to rebuild the wrist or have the operation, according to a Dallas orthopedic specialist, Peter Carter, who added that the success rate of the required surgery was 85 to 90 percent.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I feel like I got 10 years right now.'' - William J. Schroeder, artificial heart recipient. (C7:3.)

title: THE MYTH OF THE PEACEFUL MARIJUANA PLANT
description: To the Editor:

title: Poem Pleasing
description: Thanks to Peter Polakoff and Duffy the golfin' dolphin, Arnold Palmer has won yet another tournament.

title: Corruption Inquiry Set By Tampa Prosecutor
description: A former Federal prosecutor who defeated the incumbent Hillsborough County prosecutor by a decisive margin of votes says he will investigate possible corruption in the county government.

title: BUYING A FLOPPY DISK IS WORTH A LITTLE CARE
description: MOST floppy disks are created equal, but some can store far more information than others. One computer system allows a writer to cram a short novel onto a single floppy diskette, while another seems to flash a ''disk full'' message halfway through the Gettysburg Address.

title: Maria Grandy Named To Post at Joffrey II
description: Maria Grandy, associate director of the Joffrey II, has been named to succeed Sally Bliss as artistic director of the Joffrey II Dancers, the second company of the Joffrey Ballet.

title: I Cantori di New York Sings Gabrieli Work
description: Casa Italiana, a transplanted Florentine palazzo on upper Amsterdam Avenue, served as the setting for a Friday night performance of Andrea Gabrieli's ''Edippo Tiranno,'' a 16th-century musical setting of Sophocles for chorus and actors, presented by I Cantori di New York under the direction of Bart Folse.

title: ; Credibility Ratings For 750 'Personalities'
description: Would you like to know the type of person that Robert Redford appeals to? No, not just the information that it is likely to be a 25-year-old woman, but real demographic dope along with product-buying information.

title: Stable Yen Rate Urged
description: The head of Japan's central bank today called for efforts to stabilize the yen against the dollar, saying a stronger yen is in the interests of the country.

title: Federal Employees Told To Work Christmas Eve
description: The Reagan Administration, noting the huge Federal budget deficit, broke with tradition today and said Federal workers should report to work on Christmas Eve.

title: No Headline
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1984 International Toxic gas killed at least 410 Indians , many as they slept, according to officials. The lethal gas leaked from a pesticide plant owned by Union Carbide in central India. At least 12,000 people were reported sickened in the city of Bhopal, 2,000 of them seriously enough to be hospitalized. The death toll was expected to rise as more bodies were found and the critically injured died. (Page A1, Column 6.) A warning on the MX missile was issued by two conservative Republican Senators - Steven D. Symms of Idaho and John P. East of North Carolina. They said they might vote against deployment of 100 of the land- based missiles if President Reagan did not stop abiding by provisions of the 1979 arms limitation agreement with Moscow. (A1:5.)

title: Nora T. Dean, Herbalist, 77; Of Delaware Indian Heritage
description: Nora Thompson Dean, believed to be one of the last of the full-blooded Delaware Indians, died Thursday at the Jane Phillips Episcopal Memorial Medical Center, Bartlesville, Okla., after a long illness. She was 77 years old and lived in Dewey, Okla.

title: CAPTAIN DENIES SHIP WAS SPYING ON CUBANS
description: The captain of the Seaward Explorer, the Miami-based ship towed today into the Port of Miami after being incapacitated in Cuban waters last Thursday, said his 105-foot vessel had been out on a routine ocean mapping operation, not ''a secret mission.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Joe Barry Carroll, the former center of the Golden State Warriors, signed a one-year contract with Simac of Milan in the Italian basketball league. . . . The Denver Gold of the U.S.F.L. has reached an oral agreement to acquire the quarterback Vince Evans . First the Gold must negotiate a settlement of Evans's long-term contract with the Chicago Blitz, Evans's previous team, which will suspend operations next season and resume play in 1986.

title: RAGAN, BRAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
GAS LEAK IN INDIA KILLS AT LEAST 410 IN CITY OF BHOPAL
description: Toxic gas leaking from an American-owned insecticide plant in central India killed at least 410 people overnight, many as they slept, officials said today.

title: TREASURY FORECASTS STATE AND LOCAL BUDGET EXCESS
description: The Treasury issued a report today estimating that state and local governments would have a combined surplus of $86.5 billion in 1989 if current spending and tax policies continued unchanged.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: ODD COUPLE O. Winston Link is a photographer who focused on a vanishing American artifact, the steam engine, in the 1950's, and Harold E. Edgerton opened a new photographic frontier in the early 1930's as he developed stroboscopic lighting, a process that makes fast action seem to stand still. Their themes were totally at variance but their work makes for an interesting exhibition at Pace/MacGill Gallery, on the fifth floor of 11 East 57th Street (759-7999).

title: The Worm and the Apple ; Readers' Services ; Street DumbThe phone company urges people to ''Let your fingers do the walking.'' But in New York City, they can only do productive walking in a home or office. The white and yellow pages of the telephone directory, once available on every other street corner, have gone into hiding. On a recent walk up First Avenue from First Street to 53d, a caller in search of a number could find nary a phone book, either in a street booth or in a store.
description: New York Telephone does permit free calls to information from public phones.

title: Sindona Bank Fraud Trial Begins in Italy
description: Michele Sindona, the Sicilian financier who has been at the center of some of Italy's most spectacular political and financial scandals, went on trial here today on charges of bank fraud.

title: Iconoclasm and Actors
description: Peninsular protuberances were missing when three actors who have played Cyrano de Bergerac got together at the Players on Gramercy Park South.

title: U.S. Official to Visit Mideast To Aid Lebanon-Israel Talks
description: Assistant Secretary of State Richard W. Murphy will return to the Midle East this week to try to break a deadlock on an Israeli troop withdrawal from southern Lebanon, officials said today.

title: EX-OWNER OF L.I. ELECTRONICS PLANT INDICTED IN TOXIC DMPING CASE
description: The former owner of an East Farmingdale, L.I., electronics company was charged yesterday with illegally dumping millions of gallons of highly toxic wastes into the ground.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Alatenn Resources Inc. , Florence, Ala., a holding company involved in natural gas exploration, said that Jerry A. Howard had been named president, succeeding M.D. Prouty Jr., who has been appointed chairman and will continue as chief executive.

title: Lydia C. Kirk, Author AndFormerNavyAide
description: Lydia Chapin Kirk, an author and the widow of Adm. Alan G. Kirk, the commander of the United States naval forces during the invasion of Normandy in World War II, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan.

title: Mozambique Rebel Attack
description: Mozambican rebels have killed 13 civilians, raped women and wounded other peasants in two separate attacks 120 miles northeast of Maputo, a United Nations official said today. The official, Lindsay Hilsun, an information officer with the United Nations Children's Fund, said that when she arrived at the village of Laranjeira Saturday she saw the bodies of three men, one a Red Cross worker.

title: Norstar Acquisitions
description: Norstar Bancorp Inc., a $7.2 billion bank holding company, said today that it had bought Chapdelaine & Company, a government securities brokerage, and had completed the previously announced $9.2 million acquisition of the Bank of Long Island.

title: In the Nixonian Hand
description: On Vietnam: ''While negotiations are in progress with hope for success,'' the outline reads, ''will withhold comment as to how I would settle.''

title: Stennis Said to Gain Ground
description: Doctors are pleased with Senator John Stennis's recovery from a cancer operation that cost him his left leg, but no date has been set for him to return to the Senate, an aide to the Senator said today.

title: JORDAN'S FORMULA BACKED BY EGYPT
description: Egypt today officially endorsed King Hussein's formula for a peaceful resolution of the Arab-Israeli conflict and called on the Palestine Liberation Organization to support it.

title: SCIENTISTS CHART A RETURN TO MOON FOR NEW EXPLOITS
description: THE moon is beckoning again. Twelve years after the last Apollo astronauts walked on its barren surface, scientists, astronauts, engineers and space agency officials are calling for a return to the scene of the American space program's early glories.

title: PENNSYLVANIA MILL TOWN'S CHURCH MILITANTS DEFY SYNOD ANEW
description: Symbols of violence hung behind the glass church door here as the Rev. Mont O. Bowser approached today.

title: Sale Considered By Gifford-Hill
description: Gifford-Hill & Company said it was exploring various alternatives, including the possible sale of the company or the sale or other disposition of some assets.

title: Building Spending Is Up 1.7%
description: Construction spending rose in October for the first time in five months, climbing 1.7 percent, the Commerce Department said today.

description: The West's first modern energy boom was in uranium, an industry in deep recession nowadays that has left a legacy of hundreds of mounds of radioactive uranium mill tailings scattered from New Mexico to Wyoming.

TEACHER WARRANTIES IN THE OFFING
description: NEW teachers may soon come with a warranty: Like defective automobiles, if they do not perform satisfactorily in their first year, the university that trained them will ''recall'' them for repairs. And in another new move, at least one university will offer its teaching graduates a money-back guarantee that they will pass the state certification tests.

title: BANK OF NOVA SCOTIA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The Bank of Nova Scotia is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: ARAFAT OFFERS ISRAEL AN OPPORTUNITY
description: Yasir Arafat took an unprecedented risk in convening the Palestine National Council session in Amman last month. In doing so, he forced an open split with the pro-Syrian faction of the Palestinian movement. But he also presented the Israeli Government with a significant opportunity to move toward a workable Israel-Palestinian accord.

title: Marty Wayne, Host at WNYC OfProgramAboutthe Elderly
description: Marty Wayne, the host of ''Senior Edition,'' a daily radio program on WNYC-AM, and a former head of the Armed Forces Radio Service in Munich, West Germany, died of a heart attack Sunday morning at Albert Einstein Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived in the Bronx.
