title: TIME FOR AN ECONOMIC SHIFT
description: The cascade of economic news, including a cut in the discount rate and the Treasury Department's major tax reform proposal, suggests a dawning of the realization that it's time to change the unsustainable policy mix of the last three years. Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, still needs to reaffirm his commitment to allow money growth of about 4 percent. The Reagan Administration and Congress still need to respond with prompt, credible action to reduce deficits.

title: SALVADOR REBELS REMAIN WILLING TO DISCUSS A TRUCE, LEADER SAYS
description: A leader of El Salvador's left said today that the rebels remained willing to discuss the possibility of a cease-fire ''for whatever period'' with the Salvadoran Government.

title: Wassail and the Democrats
description: Some of the furniture is still to be

title: COST O WINNING A HOUSE SEAT ROSE IN '84, BUT AT A SLOWER RATE
description: The cost of winning a seat in the House of Representatives rose again in 1984, but only by about half as much as it has in recent elections, according to an analysis of campaign spending reports.

title: 'JAWS: THE TRUE STORY'
description: NO question about it - the great white shark is fearsome and scary and you don't want to have it around. But after ''Jaws: The True Story'' has said that, it pretty much just kills time. The documentary, on Channel 13 at 8 tonight, is part of ''Nova,'' the otherwise distinguished public-television series. Even ''Nova'' has its misses.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1984

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC NOT THEIR THING
description: AN indication of what schoolchildren think of classical music is reflected in the attitude of a sixth grader in Cincinnati, who feels that such music ''means long notes that are slow, and quite frankly boring.'' This attitude seems widespread among students in elementary and secondary schools, most of whom have had little exposure to classical music.

title: RICKY BELL, EX-U.S.C. STAR, MOURNED IN FUNERAL SERVICE
description: Mike Garrett, Marcus Allen, Lynn Swann and numerous other football players were among those who gathered today at the funeral of Ricky Bell, the former college and professional football player.

title: MUSIC: ENSEMBLES IN CONCERT
description: WHAT began last year as a recreation - even a therapy - for players in the Philharmonic blossomed into something more serious Sunday evening at the Asia House. The New York Philharmonic Ensembles - made up of members in the orchestra - joined two pianists and one singer in a well-rehearsed chamber program of Mozart, Beethoven and Schoenberg. This was not a semi-private entertainment with a few friends looking on, but a sold-out event held in an auditorium space that is ideal for chamber music and should be used more.

title: Alaska's Housing Bonds at 10.719%
description: The Alaska Housing Finance Corporation is offering $125 million of 10 1/2 percent collateralized home mortgage revenue bonds at a tentative price of 98 to yield 10.719 percent to maturity in 2019 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: INDIANA FINANCIAL INVESTOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PENN TRAFFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
Silverman to Make Movies for Disney
description: Fred Silverman, the former programming chief at ABC, CBS and NBC, is making his first foray into producing theatrical feature films for Walt Disney Pictures.

title: COMPANY HALTS OUTPUT AT SIMILAR PLANT IN U.S.
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, owner of the pesticide plant that leaked poisonous gas in India, said it was temporarily closing part of a nearly identical pesticide plant in West Virginia while it investigated the causes of the Indian disaster.

title: Deregulation For Utilities
description: State utility regulators believe that utilities will increasingly be deregulated in the coming years, according to a poll released yesterday by the Group Attitudes Corporation, a New York City research concern specializing in public policy issues.

title: CHRONAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hartwick Plays Indiana Sunday
description: Hartwick of Oneonta, N.Y., will play at Indiana and Clemson at U.C.L.A. Sunday in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I soccer tournament.

title: TRIMEDYNE INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Piedmont Power Unit In $689 Million Offering
description: The Piedmont Municipal Power Agency, based in South Carolina, made its debut in the long-term bond market yesterday with a $689 million financing. Shearson Lehman/American Express led the underwriters.

title: 'DELICATE TIME' FOR SEABROOK
description: At the on-again, off-again Seabrook nuclear project, a shrunken crew of workers on frozen or reduced wages pushes doggedly forward on Seabrook 1, now more than four-fifths complete, often glancing at the adjacent skeleton of the all-but-abandoned Seabrook 2, which was to have provided them with work for years to come.

title: FIRST AMERICAN FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DODGING THE ISSUES
description: JONATHAN F. FANTON, president of the New School for Social Research, attended a recent benefit dinner where the subject of small towns came up, as it sometimes does (particularly in connection with country weekending), and he was quick to comment. ''I find a progressive decline in my tolerance for them,'' he said.

title: Top Executives Named By Zapata Gulf Marine
description: The Zapata Gulf Marine Corporation, the product of a merger of the marine service units of the Zapata Corporation, Houston Natural Gas and the Halliburton Company, announced yesterday that consolidation of the marine service fleets had been completed and named officers to run the company.

title: Palau's President Leading a Challenger
description: Unofficial returns from the Palau election on Friday were released today, indicating that the President, who is seeking a second term, was being strongly challenged by a state Governor.

title: Advertising; Rumrill, City Opera: Teamwork
description: WHEN good agency people talk about a client, it is always ''we.'' That marketing partnership is very real to them.

title: GIANT VICTORIES CAN HELP SIMPLIFY RACE
description: It would be so simple for the Giants if they would just win their last two games, Sunday in St. Louis against the Cardinals and the following Saturday at the Meadowlands against the New Orleans Saints. By doing that, they would win the Eastern Division of the National Conference and leave the tie-breaking system to determine which two teams among the Cowboys, the Redskins, the Cardinals and the Rams make the playoffs as wild- card teams.

title: Accident in India Among the Worst
description: The poison gas leak today in the central Indian city of Bhopal is one of the worst industrial accidents on record.

title: ON THE NEW YORK BORDER, 'BAR HAVEN' FOR YOUTHS
description: It is midnight at the Cuckoo's Nest, a bar and disco on Route 303, five miles north of the New Jersey border, and the line of young faces is a dozen deep outside the door.

title: Blast Near Iraq Embassy Kills Greek Bomb-Disposal Expert
description: A police bomb- disposal expert was killed today while trying to defuse a bomb placed under the car of an Iraqi diplomat in Athens, the police said. Two other time bombs placed under the cars of Iraqi diplomats were found and detonated by the police.

title: Jurors Are Selected In Hustler Libel Trial
description: A jury was seated today to hear a $45 million libel suit the Rev. Jerry Falwell filed against Hustler magazine over a parady advertisement that portrayed the evangelist as an incestuous drunk.

title: ENTWISTLE CO reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $766,000.

title: Chicago Mayor Announces Plan to Curb Street Violence
description: Mayor Harold Washington today disclosed plans to step up efforts to combat gang- related violence by using Federal funds and more aggressive police raids.

title: Gershwin, Ellington, Terry on Pops Program
description: The New York Pops opened its second season at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening with a three-way split among George Gershwin, Duke Ellington and Clark Terry. Mr. Gershwin was represented by his compositions, Mr. Ellington by his compositions and the Ellington Orchestra conducted by his son, Mercer, and Mr. Terry by himself.

title: ADMINISTRATION DEFENDS ITS POLICY ON SOUTH AFRICA AS PROTESTS GROW
description: The Reagan Administration, reacting to domestic protests against its South African policies, said today that change had slowly been taking place in that country's racial situation as a result of American policies.

title: Documents Show U.S. Test of Germs in Public
description: Army agents secretly sprayed passengers at Washington's National Airport and a city bus terminal with harmless bacteria to test how a smallpox epidemic might be started by enemy forces, documents made public today reveal.

title: NOW, EVERY DESK TOP CAN BE A CONCERT HALL
description: MUSIC has been part of man's culture since primeval times. Yet the orchestra goes back a mere 300 years or so, originating with the 16th- and 17th-century Italian opera composers. Those early orchestras included such now-forgotten instruments as viols, flageolets and zinken.

title: Ashton-Tate Names Chief
description: Ashton-Tate, the microcomputer software publisher, said yesterday that Edward M. Esber Jr. had been named chief executive officer.

title: DIET THERAPY FOR BEHAVIOR IS CRITICIZED AS PREMATURE
description: IN thousands of homes, schools and institutions

title: KEMP IS CHALLENGED FOR SILENCE
description: No one asked him, but Governor Cuomo suggested today how Representative Jack F. Kemp could run ''the shortest campaign in history'' for President.

title: UNITED-OVERTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Net income The prior year included interest income on escrow funds distributed to stockholders in February 1984 and a loss from discontinued operations.

title: Let Them Eat Potpie
description: On Sunday night the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts attracted about 2,500 guests for the taping of a gala entertainment by five artists who earlier in the day attended a ceremony at the White House in which they received the Kennedy Center Honors for lifetime achievement in their fields.

title: DAIRY MART CONVENIENCE STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
VOTE BEGINS ON ACCOUNTING MERGER
description: Partners of Price Waterhouse and Deloitte Haskins & Sells, two of the Big Eight accounting firms. begin voting this week on a proposed merger that officials say provides for an ''essentially equal'' division of management positions and compensation in what would be the world's largest accounting firm.

title: BROKERAGE REVIEWER RESIGNS
description: A securities law expert appointed by a Federal court to review the business and sales practices of First Jersey Securities has resigned.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Prospecting
description: When Sheila Tighe, a 5-foot-9-inch guard, graduated from Manhattan College last June, she had scored 2,453 points, more than any other basketball player in the school's history, male or female. Naturally, that total attracted interest.

title: LONG LIVE THE NEVER-NEEDED CONTINGENCY PLAN
description: ''There is nothing so perishable,'' says a senior military officer, ''as a contingency plan.''

title: HOUSE ETHICS PANEL COMES TO A DECISION ON FERRARO FINANCES
description: A House committee on ethics reached a decision today in its preliminary investigation into financial disclosures of Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro of Queens, according to a member of the panel.

title: ISAAC STERN IS TOO BUSY TO RETIRE
description: Says Isaac Stern, who needs no introduction:

title: BRIEFS ;  Debt
description: * CBS Inc. is offering $100 million of eight-year 11 3/8 percent notes at a price of 99 1/2 to yield 11.47 percent and $:40 million of 10-year 10 7/8 percent notes in the Euromarket, through underwriters led by Swiss Bank Corp.

title: Court to Hear Appeal On Boston Sewer Freeze
description: The state Supreme Court agreed today to hear a request that it cancel a judge's order halting new sewer connections in Boston and its suburbs.

title: Lincoln National
description: The Lincoln National Corporation said it had sold its real estate unit, the Lincoln National Development Corporation, for $120 million in a leveraged buyout.

title: SFN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Trial to Be Moved In Houston Slaying
description: A state district judge ordered today that the trial of a teen-ager accused of killing a postal carrier be moved out of Houston because of the attention the case has been given by news organizations.

title: Olympic Star Retires
description: She won Olympic gold medals 12 years apart, and once held the world record, and now Ulrike Meyfarth , the West German high jumper, has announced her retirement from competition. In a letter to the German Track and Field Federation, the 28-year-old Miss Meyfarth said she would compete for the last time in the national indoor championships at Dortmund Feb. 15.

title: Friona in Talks
description: Friona Industries said it had entered into talks on its acquisition by Eller Enterprises Inc. for $17.25 a share. Based on Friona's nearly 2.2 million shares outstanding, the deal would be valued at nearly $38 million.

title: SUKOVA UPSETS SHRIVER IN QUARTERFINAL
description: Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia surprised third- seeded Pam Shriver of the United States, 6-2, 6-7, 6-1, today in the quarterfinals of the $1.28 million Australian Open tennis championships.

title: AIDE CONFIRMS ILLNESS OF MARCOS
description: A close political aide of Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that the President was ''in control but cannot take major initiatives at this time.''

title: THE DANCE: 'MOROCCO' AND CASBAH EXPERIENCE
description: THE dancer who calls herself Morocco is one of a growing number of American exponents of Middle Eastern and North African dance. And when Morocco burst onstage at the Theater of the Riverside Church Sunday night - every golden thread of her fringed costume flying out with every moving muscle - she looked like an angora cat aflame.

title: WORKING PROFILE: Gary Bauer; READING, WRIING, ROPING LIBERALS
description: Gary Bauer carries the title of Deputy Under Secretary of Education, which in normal Washington parlance would indicate that he is in charge of planning, budget and evaluation.

title: Afghanistan Replaces Its Defense Minister
description: The Defense Minister of Afghanistan, who had been considered the No. 2 man in the Soviet-backed Government of President Babrak Karmal, has been replaced, the state-run Kabul radio reported today.

title: PARIS'S PAST UNEARTHED IN DIGS AT LOUVRE
description: PARIS THE two main courtyards of the Louvre Museum have been converted into a maze of trenches and holes, sunken remains of walls and foundations and mounds of scrupulously sifted earth and centuries-old debris. Hundreds of workers armed with spades, brushes, cameras and microscopes are peering into the past of this city.

title: BRITISH TELECOM SHARES SOAR
description: Records were smashed in hectic dealing and recriminations sounded in the House of Commons as British Telecom shares began trading here today at a 90 percent markup on their sale price.

title: KMI CONTINENTAL PICKS NEW CHIEF
description: KMI Continental Inc., formerly the Continental Group, announced yesterday that Donald J. Donahue, currently vice chairman, had been named chairman and chief executive.

title: Northern Trust Elects Former Head at Jewel
description: The Northern Trust Corporation announced the election of Weston R. Christopherson as chairman and chief executive of the holding company and its subsidiary, the Northern Trust Company, Chicago's fourth- largest bank.

title: PIEDMONT NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
3 Held in Burglary At a Seafood Store
description: Three Brooklyn men were arrested Sunday night by police officers who watched them break into a store near the Fulton Fish Market and try to steal $200,000 worth of shrimp and lobsters, the authorities said.

title: DONORS' SPIRIT FOR HOLIDAYS AIDS NEEDIEST
description: For many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the holiday season evokes a sense of well- being that they would like to share with those around them who they know are less fortunate.

title: Sudanese Guerrillas Attack a Troop Ship
description: Separatist guerrillas ambushed a Nile River steamship carrying military personnel near the southern town of Bor Sunday night but were driven off by army reinforcements, a military spokesman said today.

title: MORE AMERICANS ATTEND THE ARTS
description: More Americans attended arts presentations last year than in 1980 in nearly every category of the arts - theater, dance, opera, and musical performances - while attendance at art museums declined slightly, according to a poll released yesterday by Louis Harris and Associates Inc.

title: Got a Spare Tentacle?
description: There is almost always something interesting in the window of the Citarella fish store on Broadway near 75th Street. Yesterday, there were octopuses, propped up on sticks and wearing name tags.

title: PLANT-DEPRECIATION PROPOSAL RELEASED
description: The Treasury today released its proposed schedule for writing off plant and equipment, and Secretary Donald T. Regan predicted it would pleasantly surprise business because of what he portrayed as its generosity.

title: SALVADOR RIGHTIST GRANTED U.S. VISA
description: The State Department announced today that it had approved a visa for Roberto d'Aubuisson, the Salvadoran rightist leader, to visit the United States this week.

title: PLASTIC BOTTLE REDUX
description: To the Editor:

title: Interest Keen Among Investors in U.S.
description: American investors joined in the enthusiasm for British Telecom shares yesterday, quickly bidding them up to nearly twice the offering price in the first day of their trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Nicaraguan Rebel Says He Is Seeking Alliance
description: Eden Pastora Gomez, the former Sandinista hero now fighting to topple his former comrades, said today that he had met unofficially with representatives of another Nicaraguan rebel group to seek an alliance.

title: AMERICAN SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
20 Rebels Killed in Sri Lanka In Escape Bid at Army Camp
description: Army guards killed 20 rebel prisoners trying to escape an army camp today, the Government said.

title: PHYSICAL AIDS reports earnings for Year to June 30
IRAQI ROCKET HITS TANKER IN GULF, FIRST IN 6 WEEKS
description: An Iraqi warplane made the first attack on a tanker in the Persian Gulf in six weeks today, firing a rocket into a Cypriot supertanker.

title: FED RULES IN UNDERWRITING DISPUTE
description: In the latest twist in a six-year controversy, the Federal Reserve Board ruled yesterday that at least until 1980 the Bankers Trust Company was ''underwriting'' corporate securities and thereby violating the Glass-Steagall Act. The issue involved the manner in which Bankers Trust was selling commercial paper for its corporate clients.

title: DeBakey Out of Hospital
description: Michael DeBakey, the 76-year-old heart transplant pioneer, who was hospitalized Nov. 17 for a bleeding intestinal ulcer, has been released from Methodist Hospital here after surgery to correct the problem.

title: Goldina-Loumbrozo, Duo-Piano Team
description: A week before Arianna Goldina and Remy Loumbrozo's Saturday evening concert at the Abraham Goodman House, they were awarded the first prize at the Seventh Valentino Bucchi International Duo Piano Competition of 20th-century music, in Rome. The judges listened well - Miss Goldina and Mr. Loumbrozo share an unusual synergy; their playing is typified not only by the hyperactive jangle that we expect from a duo-piano team, but also by lyricism that seems the product of a single imagination.

title: 'EXCLUDABLE' HAITIANS TO GET HEARING ON PLEA
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Haitian refugees seeking asylum in the United States could challenge the constitutionality of their confinement in Federal detention centers.

title: N.A.A.C.P. SUES OHIO CITY OVER SURVEILLANCE
description: The Columbus chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People filed a $12 million suit in Federal District Court today, alleging that city police used surveillance devices to spy on the civil rights group more than a decade ago.

title: Drop Dead, Again ''My heart will not break,'' says Treasury Secretary Donald Regan, if New Yorkers lose the right to deduct billions in state and local taxes from their taxable incomes. His remark was not as callous as it sounds; he was talking about upper-income taxpayers. But the policy he proposes is callous. Indeed, it would be far more devastating than Washington's refusal to help during the 1975 fiscal crisis, which prompted the famous Daily News headline ''Ford to City: Drop Dead.''
description: Mr. Regan and some other political figures, including Manhattan's Representative Charles Rangel, see the deduction as a tax break for the rich. To end it would not affect poor people who do not use it and would, presumably, raise enough revenue that they might actually pay less in taxes. Technically that's right. But look again. It's plain that the big losers would be the poor people who live in high-tax states like New York, California and Massachusetts.

title: JAYARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SUPERIOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Includes a charge of $450,000 from the modification of an acquisition contract for the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes a charge of $1,176,584 from the writeoff of goodwill associated with the purchase of the Podiatary Clinic Management unit. d-Net income after income from discontinued operations of $43,797 for the quarter and $138,256 for the 6 months.

title: HELEN BRAUN
description: Helen Braun, a soprano who under the name of Helen Donohoe played in musical comedy and light opera on Broadway in the early part of the century, died Saturday at Flushing Hospital in Queens. She was 92 years old and lived in Astoria.

title: JAPAN MAY EASE CURB ON ARMS SPENDING
description: The Japanese Government, frequently criticized for its military policies, is debating whether to abandon a fundamental principle that tightly limits military spending.

title: Caribbean Center Presents Jazz Concert
description: As part of its continuing effort to reunite the African diaspora, the Caribbean Cultural Center brought together African-tinged jazz and jazz- tinged salsa for a concert Sunday at Aaron Davis Hall at City College.

title: UNESCO AIDE SAYS U.S. EXIT WOULD BE 'DANGEROUS' ERROR
description: With the deadline approaching for a decision by the United States on whether to withdraw from Unesco, the director of the group's United Nations Liaison Office, Doudou Diene, said yesterday that it would be a ''dangerous miscalculation'' by the Administration to leave.

title: CBS Plans to Sell Instruments Unit
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that it planned to dispose of its musical instruments division and that it would report the disposition as losses from discontinued operations in the fourth quarter.

title: Michael Reagan Plans To Be at Inauguration
description: President Reagan's son Michael said today that he planned to attend his father's inauguration to a second term on Jan. 21 but would spend Christmas in Los Angeles with his own family.

title: Players Honored
description: Eleven former players and two former coaches will be inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame tonight when the National Football Foundation holds its annual awards dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The coaches to be inducted are Duffy Daugherty of Michigan State, and the late Jim Tatum of Oklahoma, Maryland and North Carolina. The players are Lance Alworth of Arkansas, Warren Amling of Ohio State, Sam Chapman of California, Holland Donan of Princeton, Bob Griese of Purdue, Joe Greene of North Texas State, Bill Hartman of Georgia, Doug Kenna of Mississippi and Army, Bobby Reynolds of Nebraska, Joe Romig of Colorado and Chuck Taylor of Stanford.

title: DOW FALLS 6.52
description: Stock prices fell yesterday for the fourth consecutive session as a multitude of problems continued to plague the market.

title: U.N. Approves a Plan To Ease Africa Crisis
description: The General Assembly unanimously approved a lengthy declaration tonight dealing with the critical economic situation in Africa that seemed unusually free of anti-Western polemics.

title: Carburetor Problems Lead Ford to Recall 91,000 Cars
description: The Ford Motor Company today recalled 91,000 cars and trucks for a problem with four-barrel carburetors that could cause the engines to accelerate uncontrollably, the company said.

title: WASHINGTON HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Stay of Execution In Jersey Is Sought
description: Attorney General Irwin I. Kimmelman asked the New Jersey Supreme Court today to stay the execution of James J. Koedatich until the court has ruled on the constitutionality of New Jersey's death penalty law.

title: BIO-TECHNOLOGY GENERAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-The company had no revenues in the year-ago third quarter.

title: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a pooling of interests related to restaurant acquisitions.

title: WITH TULLY OF MERRILL LYNCH
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.

title: FLUTIE'S FUTURE: GENERALS OR N.F.L.?
description: Even before Doug Flutie won the

title: The Iraqi Reconnection Change walks on cat's feet in the Middle East, and a hundred careful steps brought Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, to the White House the other day. But cumulatively, something significant is afoot. A stalemated war with Iran has impelled radical Iraq to befriend Arab moderates and somewhat to temper its hostility to Israel. Now Iraq and the United States are reopening embassies shut since 1967, acknowledging a new mutual interest.
description: Americans can welcome this reconnection without illusions - and without taking Iraq's side in the war it began. But neutrality is not indifference. The best outcome to a bad war would be a no-winner settlement. Iraq needs to abandon its territorial claims. Iran needs to abandon efforts to get Iraq's Shiites to overthrow their Sunni rulers and establish a second Islamic Republic in Baghdad.

title: THE STAGE: 'DESK SET,' AT EQUITY
description: ''DESK Set,'' the current offering at the Equity Library Theater, is not only a play about an electronic future that was only a glimmer in the public eye when William Marchant wrote it in the mid-1950's, but it is itself the sort of theater that was falling victim, even then, to another electronic development that was already keeping people home and away from box offices.

title: 'KNEW HE WAS DYING'
description: When William J. Schroeder and Dr. William C. DeVries talked about the informed consent form allowing the implant of an artificial heart, the patient said: ''I want to live to March to see my son married. Can you promise me that?''

title: Best Gets 3 Months
description: The former soccer star Georgie Best was sentenced to three months in jail after pleading guilty to drunken driving, assaulting a police officer and jumping bail in connection with an incident Nov. 3. The 38-year- old Best, who made his name with Manchester United in the English League and also played in the North American Soccer League, was also banned from driving for five years. He was released on bail after his lawyers filed an appeal.

title: UEBERROTH CALLING FOR BASEBALL UNITY
description: Peter Ueberroth said today that ''unity'' was his No. 1 priority as the new commissioner of baseball. He told the club owners that he would leave their business convention later this week to join the players at their union meeting in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: BIRTH CONTROL GROUP CUTS BUDGET
description: The world's largest independent family- planning organization said today that it was being forced to curtail its services drastically because of Reagan Administration policies on abortion.

title: CITY CRACKING DOWN ON 'GYPSY' CABS
description: The city's Taxi and Limousine Commission began a crackdown yesterday on the thousands of unregulated nonmedallion cabs cruising New York City streets, the commission chairman said.

title: Utility to Freeze Rates
description: Orange and Rockland Utilities announced today that it would freeze electric and gas rates until February 1986 for its 158,000 electric customers and 90,000 gas customers in New York State.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS CHOOSE O'NEILL TO SERVE AS SPEAKER FOR 5TH TIME
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. was chosen by House Democrats today to serve a fifth and final two-year term as Speaker of the House, but rumblings of discontent welled up from the ranks of younger Democrats who want to see the party move away from some of the New Deal ideas that have marked Mr. O'Neill's career.

title: LEGAL AID COUNSEL RESIGNS AFTER RIFT
description: Donald P. Bogard, president of the Federal Legal Service Corporation, disregarded his own general counsel's interpretation of the law in awarding some grants in September, according to corporation documents that were released today.

title: A HEISMAN WINNER IN A MORE INNOCENT TIME
description: Mr. Inside left his home in San Antonio yesterday morning to return to the Downtown Athletic Club, the place where he received a trophy nearly 39 years ago. Felix (Doc) Blanchard, the Army fullback who became the 11th recipient of the Heisman Memorial Trophy, planned to return to the 50th presentation on Thursday night. He will listen to Doug Flutie, the Boston College quarterback, become the owner of the same trophy that sits in a den in San Antonio.

title: Skipping Pros For Life's Work
description: When he was starring in high school basketball and football in Pana, Ill., Warren Amling had already decided that he wanted to be a veterinarian. But he would never lose his love of sports, and so, after enrolling at Ohio State in 1943, he decided to go out for the football team.

title: Military Contracts Received by G.E.
description: The General Electric Company received military contracts totaling $976.2 million, the Defense Department said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny Power Systems Inc. said its West Penn Power Co. subsidiary had filed with the Public Utility Commission of Pennsylvania for rate increases designed to produce $96.6 million in additional revenues on an annual basis.

title: Contempt Citation Against Writer Lifted
description: The Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia yesterday suspended both the contempt order and the $500-a-day fine directed against Antoni Gronowicz, author of ''God's Broker,'' the controversial biography of Pope John Paul II. The court granted a stay of the order and declared that the case would be heard on its merits during the week of Jan. 14.

title: 'REITH,' BBC FILM OF ITS 1ST DIRECTOR
description: ANY history of broadcasting must contend with the formidable figure of John Charles Reith, the first director general of the British Broadcasting Corporation. He was the visionary and uncompromising taskmaster who established standards that still distinguish the BBC as a model of integrity and quality for all other broadcasters and he is the subject of ''Reith,'' a BBC production being presented tonight at 9 on the Arts & Entertainment cable service.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE mice were out in unusual force this year, scampering through dozens of the children's picture books that were read for this column. And if anyone thinks the animals aren't right in step with this age of cardiovascular conditioning, there's ''Pooh's Workout Book'' and ''Albert the Running Bear's Exercise Book.'' But it was a stoat, a lion, a whale and a couple of hippopotamuses that really stood out, along with a monster, some motor vehicles and a bunch of humans.

title: SEX CHANGE IN FISH FOUND COMMON
description: WHEN a school of reef fish loses its single male, the largest female begins acting like a male within a few hours and will produce sperm within 10 days. Some other species repeatedly switch back and forth between the production of eggs and of sperm during a single mating. Among deep sea fish that only rarely encounter potential mates, reproduction is often possible only if one changes sex.

title: Political Calendar Conflict
description: Stay away from Gracie Mansion.

title: Coppertone Products Going to Della Femina
description: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners will be doing the creative work for Coppertone Suntan Products from Shering-Plough's U.S. Proprietary Drug and Toiletries division. The assignment was previously at Warwick Advertising, which will continue making ads for a number of other Shering-Plough products.

title: OFF THE CRITICAL LIST
description: William J. Schroeder was taken off the critical list today and said his artificial heart had already made a ''fantastic'' difference in his life.

title: A Monumental Anniversary
description: Exactly 100 years ago this Thursday, the Washington Monument was completed. The cornerstone of the 555-foot, 5 1/8-inch edifice was laid July 4, 1848.

title: 2 WITNESSES SAY DEFENDANT TRIED TO STOP SLAYING
description: An 18-year-old youth on trial for a murder in an Upper East Side video arcade last January was described by two prosecution witnesses yesterday as having intervened to try to save the victim and others from unprovoked clubbings by a bat-wielding co-defendant.

title: BELLAMY CALLING FOR EXPANDING ESTIMATE BOARD
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy proposed yesterday that New York City settle a longstanding lawsuit challenging the structure of the Board of Estimate by agreeing to expand its membership.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Dec. 4, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: YANKEES' BYSTROM HAD ARM OPERATION
description: Last June 30 the Yankees traded Shane Rawley to Philadelphia for Marty Bystrom. Today, according to Clyde King, the Yankees' general manager, an executive of another club met with him and said, ''We don't see Shane Rawley on your roster. What do you plan to do with him?''

title: DNA MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: IMMUNO NUCEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: COMMON MARKET URGED TO REORGANIZE
description: The leaders of the Common Market were told today that their community was in crisis and could not move significantly forward in political or economic integration without major changes.

title: TEXTRON RAISES BID FOR AVCO
description: After barely two days of negotiating, Textron Inc. agreed to pay the Avco Corporation $50 a share, $3 more than it had proposed last week, to take over the company. The agreement, valued at $1.4 billion in cash, also calls for Robert P. Bauman, Avco's 53-year-old chairman, to be named vice chairman of Textron.

title: CITIES HAVE FAILED AS CABLE REGULATORS
description: To the Editor:

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Denver Nuggets , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. More bad news for the Knicks: The Nuggets, a habitually high-scoring club, are now playing tightened defense as well. The combination has enabled them to post a 13-3 record and climb to the top of the Midwest Division. (Television - MSG Network, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WPAT, 930; WFAS, 1230; WGBB, 1240; all at 7:20 P.M.)

title: ALERT URGED ON DES LINK TO CANCERS
description: A public health activist today urged the Federal Government to alert about two million women that they face an increased risk of breast cancer because of a synthetic hormone they took more than two decades ago.

title: SCHOOL, AFTER FATAL FIRE, SEEKS TEMPORARY HOME
description: ST. Ann's School in Brooklyn Heights, where a firefighter died battling a blaze Saturday night, was closed to students yesterday as school officials scrambled to find another site for classes.

title: MITCHELL ENERGY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CORRECTION
description: An article in some late editions on Sunday about a fire at a private school in Brooklyn Heights described it incorrectly and gave a wrong address. The school, St. Ann's, has no religious affiliation and is at 129 Pierrepont Street. Later developments are reported today on page B7.

title: AT COSTUME INSTITUTE SHOW, EQUESTRIAN IS THE THEME
description: Four members of Virginia hunt clubs, in their red jackets and orange lapels, brought a note of holiday cheer to the gala party previewing the Metropolitan Museum of Art's newest exhibition last night. The women in their sequined designer dresses looked on admiringly. ''Aren't they smashing,'' they said to one another and their escorts.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THOSE who go out went out every

title: CHEMICAL, WIDELY USED, IS VERY TOXIC
description: The substance that escaped from a storage tank at Bhopal, India, with severe loss of life is widely used in preparing insecticides, such as Union Carbide's Sevin. It is known as methyl isocyanate, and in even small amounts it produces voluminous discharge from the eyes and is extremely irritating to skin and internal organs.

title: Danish Loan Interest
description: Denmark's interest payments on the nation's variable-interest dollar loans are up by about 25 percent from last year, the National Bank said today in its quarterly report. The bank attributed the increase to continuing external payments deficits, the strong dollar and higher United States interest rates. Denmark's payments deficit is expected to top 16 billion kroner, or about $1.43 billion, in 1984, up from 11 billion kroner in 1983.

title: Market Place; Chesebrough's Slowing Pace
description: -POND'S Inc., with products including such household names as Vaseline petroleum jelly, Ragu spaghetti sauce and Health-tex children's apparel, has forged an enviable record of 28 straight years of earnings growth.

ADVERTISING;
Entertainment Agency Set Up
description: creative team at Ash/DeLonne, an agency specializing

title: PAY-FONE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: FIRST COMMERCIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW LASER AMPLIFIER
description: TWO research teams have announced the creation of a new free-electron laser amplifier that can increase energy levels 250,000 percent, producing incredibly high-powered microwaves.

title: Service Time for Missionaries Increased by Mormon Chiefs
description: Concerned about a decline in the number of converts, Mormon leaders reversed a 1982 decision Friday and increased service for most missionaries to 24 months from 18 moths.

title: RATES MIXED; INVESTORS WARY
description: Rates were mixed in quiet trading yesterday, with the interest falling slightly for issues due in less than a year. Note and bond yields were little changed.

title: A BANQUET FOR FOOTBALL'S AUTUMN FINALE
description: Another college football season came to a close

title: AUTHOR ON SOVIET AND HAPSBURGS
description: Edward Crankshaw, one of the most respected authors on the Soviet Union and chronicler of the Hapsburgs, died last Thursday in his native Britain after what was described as a ''long and painful illness.'' He was 75 years old and lived in Hawkhurst, in rural Kent.

title: UNIVERSAL-RUNDLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,020,000 from the sale of a plant in California.

title: HEALTH EXTENSION SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LIL' CHAMP FOOD STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Including a net profit of $30,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: FARM PRICE SYSTEM MAY BE CURTAILED, WASHINGTON SAYS
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that to help cut Federal spending, the Reagan Administration would propose legislation to sharply curtail Government price supports for farmers.

title: COLLINS FOODS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted. Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed Nov. 16.

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PENGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,042,000 for the quarter and $19,688,000 for the year.

title: Illinois Offering Housing Bonds
description: The Illinois Housing Development Authority is offering $146 million of mortgage revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 10.68 percent for bonds due in 2008, according to tentative prices announced yesterday by the underwriters, led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: GOTT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WESTMORELAND TESTIFIES JOHNSON WANTED DATA
description: A. FARBER

title: Bridge:Grand National Team Event FeaturesaNumberofUpsets
description: There were some surprising results in the Grand National Team Championship played Sunday in Port Washington, L.I. Two rounds of knockout play cut the field of 32 teams, survivors from club and unit preliminaries in New York City and on Long Island, to 8. The eventual winners will advance to the national finals in Las Vegas, Nev., next August.

title: 50,000 DISPLACED PERSONS
description: I have been away traveling for

title: British Miners Vow to Stay On Strike and Defy the Courts
description: Coal miners vowed today to continue their strike despite being threatened with the loss of their union's $10 million of assets.

title: Continental Bank Departures
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company formally announced today that 10 of its 16 directors would be stepping down as part of what it called a ''substantial board restructuring'' required by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: 14 Indicted in Bid To Run Gambling
description: Fourteen New York and Massachusetts residents have been indicted in connection with an effort to take over illegal gambling and loan-shark operations in the Albany area, state authorities announced today.

title: ISRAEL TURNS TERROR BACK ON THE TERRORISTS, BUT FINDS NO POLITICAL SOLUTION
description: Before the state of Israel was founded, Jewish settlers used to prevent Arab attacks by surrounding themselves with sandbag walls and coils of barbed wire and shooting out from there. One day in the late 1930's, though, a Russian-born immigrant named Yitzhak Sadeh convinced the Haganah leaders that this was no way to go about things. The only way to deal effectively with guerrilla raids or terrorist attacks, he argued, was ''to go outside the fence.''

title: Doubling in Toronto
description: British Telecom nearly doubled in price today on the Toronto Stock Exchange, from $7.90 (Canadian) at the opening to $14.50 at the close. Each unit represented 10 British Telecom shares. One Toronto broker said that ''the demand was overwhelming.''

title: Happy Racegoer
description: Two men watched the television monitor waiting for the day's last race to begin. Neither knew the other's name.

title: Cellular Phones
description: The Federal Communications Commission, in a 3-to-2 decision that reversed an administrative law judge, granted the Los Angeles Cellular Telephone Company permission to build and operate a new cellular telephone system to serve metropolitan Los Angeles. The mobile phone franchise had also been sought by a joint venture of the MCI Communications Corporation and Metromedia's Industrial Communications Systems, with Cellular Mobile Systems holding a minority interest. The commission said that the competing parties were equal on most issues, but that Los Angeles Cellular ''deserved a slight preference'' because it proposed to serve an additional 17 square miles and 42,000 more people than the joint venture.

title: ALICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
MAN WHO HELPED LURE EX-AGENT TO TRIAL IS SHOT
description: Ernest Keiser, who helped lure Edwin P. Wilson, a former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency, from Libya to face trial and jail in the United States, was shot and wounded outside a suburban restaurant late Sunday.

title: Deere's Earnings Drop
description: Deere & Company today reported earnings for its fiscal fourth quarter of $34.2 million, or 51 cents a share, down 41 percent from $58 million, or 85 cents a share, in the period last year.

title: PERRY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Investor Buys 5% Of Harper & Row
description: Theodore L. Cross, an investor in Princeton, N.J., told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had purchased 154,900 common shares of Harper & Row Publishers Inc., or 5 percent of the shares outstanding, for about $3 million.

title: KARPOV REFUSES TO BUDGE
description: Gary Kasparov tried to entice Anatoly Karpov into enterprising play by choosing a provocative defense in the 29th game of their chess title match in Moscow on Monday, but the 33-year-old world champion would not be budged from his conservatism. The draw in 13 moves, the 24th draw of their series, was the shortest game of the match.

title: OKLAHOMA DRINKS RULED OUT
description: The State Attorney General ruled today that sale of liquor by the drink is illegal despite the repeal of a constitutional ban on open saloons.

title: Chile Sends 58 More Into Internal Exile
description: The Government sent 58 more people into internal exile today, but relaxed the nightly curfew by one hour.

title: Topics ; Cold Shoulders ; Odd Admissions
description: What Dickens called the Office of Circumlocution has apparently been recruited to explain Washington's whimsical visa policy.

title: Martinis and the Man
description: The latest set of tax proposals to

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: HOLIDAYS It is just two weeks until Hanukkah, the Jewish Feast of Lights, begins (Dec. 18), but the spirit of the holiday, indeed of all the Jewish holidays, is aglow in the Yeshiva University Museum, in Washington Heights, 2520 Amsterdam Avenue, at 185th Street (960-5390). The exhibition is ''The Art of Celebration,'' and to accommodate it the generous ground-floor museum space has been converted into a town square through which one strolls and gazes into windows to see how people observe religious occasions at home.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Barnett Banks of Florida Inc., Jacksonville, said it had agreed to acquire Cawthon State Bank of De Funiak Springs, Fla., which has assets of $16 million. Terms were not disclosed.

title: WICKES COMPANIES reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 27
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $803,000 for the quarter and $2,405,000 for the 39 weeks and tax credits of $5,059,000 and $7,686,000 for the quarter and 39 weeks, respectively. c-After income from discontinued operations of $700,000 for the quarter and $2,913,000 for the 39 weeks and tax credits of $9,585,000 and $10,154,000 for the quarter and 39 weeks, respectively. The company is listed on the Pacific, Midwest and Philadelphia stock exchanges.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Los Angeles Lakers at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. Since this is the only visit to the Meadowlands this season by Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who has declared that this is his final N.B.A. season, the Nets will honor the Laker center.

title: IN HOSPITALS OF BHOPAL, THE SUFFERING GOES ON
description: In the emergency room of the Government Medical College Hospital here, doctors and nurses struggled late tonight to save seven children.

title: FILM: MURPHY IN 'BEVERLY HILLS COP'
description: ''BEVERLY HILLS COP'' finds Eddie Murphy doing what he does best: playing the shrewdest, hippest, fastest-talking underdog in a rich man's world. An opening montage establishes the ghetto origins of Axel Foley, the Detroit policeman whom Mr. Murphy plays. But Axel turns out to be much more at home in the posh California settings where most of the film takes place. Cruising the streets of Beverly Hills in his jalopy, or strolling into hotels and restaurants in a well-worn sweatshirt, Axel maintains every bit of his cool. Far from being daunted, he enjoys the challenge. Axel's confidence never wavers, nor does his natural authority - and for that, audiences will love him.

title: CONGRESS AND THE 'NONBANK BANK'
description: To the Editor:

title: EATING HABITS ARE SURVEYED
description: American eating habits fall into five categories, from consumers of meat and potatoes to sophisticates who wash down such fare as quiches with lots of wine, according to a University of New Hampshire researcher.

title: Brock Hotel Sells Unprofitable Unit
description: The Brock Hotel Corporation said it had sold its unprofitable Unique Concepts Corporation unit to the Douglas Hotels Corporation, a closely held concern. Complete terms were not disclosed, but Brock said that as part of the deal it had granted Douglas 950,000 common shares of Brock and five-year warrants to buy up to 1.5 million more at $3.25 a share.

title: TELECREDIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain of $382,000, or 7 cents a share, on the sale of Telecredit's equity position in DMC Systems Inc. in June.

title: Happy Birthday, Dr. Clark
description: Harlem and Park Avenue celebrated together Monday night at Dr. Kenneth B. Clark's 70th-birthday party. The beloved psychologist, teacher, human-rights advocate, author and inspiration to several generations was characteristically modest.

title: ENVOY TO U.S. DURING 1950'S
description: Ahmed Hussein, Egypt's Ambassador to the United States in the tense years before and during the Suez crisis, died on Saturday in a Cairo hospital after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Pentagon Says Nicaraguans Have Chemical Warfare Suits
description: The Pentagon said today that Nicaragua had protective equipment against chemical weapons and that it did not know why such gear was needed.

title: PANTRY PRIDE' SHEATED BATTLE
description: When stockholders gather here Thursday for the annual meeting of Pantry Pride Inc., they will be voting to settle a messy proxy fight that pits the supermarket chain's current management and operating philosophy against a group of outsiders determined to point the once-troubled company in a new direction.

title: MUSIC: KHAN RAGA RECITAL
description: USTAD ASAD ALI KHAN is a master of a nearly extinct instrument - the rudra vina, a North Indian stringed instrument. It has a tangy tone, and plays in a lower, less penetrating register than its descendant, the sitar. Mr. Khan played a recital Sunday at the Alternative Museum of ragas in the reflective medieval dhrupad style.

title: MONDALE AGREES TO RETURN EXCESS DONATIONS
description: Walter F. Mondale's Presidential campaign has agreed to pay the Treasury $379,640 plus a civil fine of $18,500 for accepting excess labor donations through delegate committees in the Democratic primaries.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS REACH A FORK ON A FOGGY ROAD
description: After Democrats chose Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. on Monday to preside over the House of Representatives for a final two-year term, the 71-year-old Speaker told his colleagues, ''These will be years of transition for our party and for the leadership here in the House.''

title: TREASURE OF ARTIFACTS FOUND IN 3,400-YEAR-OLD SHIPWRECK
description: The earliest shipwreck ever excavated has yielded a treasure of Bronze Age artifacts - copper and tin ingots, medallions and beads, pottery and several gold objects - that archeologists believe will provide a revealing glimpse into shipbuilding and trade in the eastern Mediterranean 3,400 years ago.

title: MADEIRA, A WELL-KEPT SECRET, MAKES ITS YEARLY APPEARANCE
description: -kept secrets, has slipped into town quietly, as it usually does at this season, in time for the small coterie of Madeira aficionados who like to give it and add it to their own collections.

title: Iran to Replace Judges Who Assaulted Swede
description: Iran will replace two of its judges who assaulted a Swedish judge at a tribunal settling claims between Iran and the United States, the tribunal said today.

title: Dow Up 2.65, Ending Losing Streak
description: The stock market advanced slightly yesterday, ending a four-session losing streak. Trading was slower.

title: Witness Active as Public Servant
description: Paul Henry Nitze, who testified yesterday in the Westmoreland- CBS libel trial, is one of the most durable public servants in the history of the United States bureaucracy.

title: JOHN ROCK, DEVELOPER OF THE PILL AND AUTHORITY ON FERTILITY, DIES
description: Dr. John Rock, a pioneer in the study of human fertility who helped develop the birth control pill, died early yesterday of a heart attack in Peterborough, N.H. He was 94 years old and lived at Temple, N.H.

title: REHABILITATION IN THE GARMENT DISTRICT
description: To many people, the towers standing side by side on the corner of Seventh Avenue and 37th Street in the heart of New York's garment district were long known as the Bridal Buildings because they were occupied almost exclusively by wedding fashion showrooms.

title: Sri Lanka Troops Ambushed
description: Separatists ambushed an army convoy today in an attack that sparked fighting in the village of Murunkan and left as many as 53 people dead, officials and residents said. In the ambush, a mine exploded under an army jeep, killing the driver and injuring the six other soldiers riding in the vehicle, officials said.

title: Cable TV Issues Before F.C.C
description: The Federal Communications Commission today began the process of determining where state and local regulation of cable television subscription rates should continue when a Congressional deregulation order takes effect in 1987.

title: Le Monde's Editor Says He Will Quit
description: The editor in chief of Le Monde, France's most influential daily newspaper, indicated today that he would step down from his post after the editorial staff rejected an austerity program that he had proposed.

title: WINES: THE PICKING IS EASY
description: THERE is a little secret that wine enthusiasts tend to keep to themselves: Wine gifts are the easiest to choose, the easiest to buy and among the most eagerly received of Christmas presents. And you don't have to know a blessed thing about wine to buy them.

title: WHALE NAVIGATION LINKED TO MAGNETIC FIELDS
description: A team of scientists has found that whales seem to have a sensitive magnetic sense that may lead them to their death on the beach if they encounter magnetic anomalies near the shore.

title: RSI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said the year-ago quarter and previous year results include a charge of $203,000 from the settlement of litigation.

title: 3 YOUTHS IN CONEY I. ARE KILLED BY A CAR POLICE WERE CHASING
description: Two 14-year-old boys were killed yesterday and a third boy died early today after a stolen car being chased by the police mounted a curb in Coney Island and struck them, the police said.

title: BOBBY MCFERRIN AND ALVIN BATISTE CONCERTS
description: Two of the most distinctive new jazz talents to have emerged recently are on view this week in New York. Tomorrow night at 9 P.M. at the Ritz, the astonishing vocal improviser, Bobby McFerrin is giving a solo concert-his lungs, vocal chords and mouth are the accompanying band. Saturday at 8.30 P.M., Alvin Batiste, who is carrying on the grand tradition of New Orleans Clarinet playing in a decidely modern idiom, will lead a fine New York rhythm section in a program of his original music at Carnegie Recital Hall. Tickets are $10 for each show adn are on sale at the respective box offices.

title: KENNEDY CENTER'S CHIEF SEEKS WIDER AUDIENCE
description: One of the first things Peter Sellars noticed when he took over last summer as artistic director for theater at the Kennedy Center was that although Washington is predominantly black, there are few blacks in the audience on any night.

title: SPECIALITIES FROM BARBECUE TO TRUFFLES
description: IF you divide recipients of Christmas food gifts into two categories - cooks and eaters only -

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT was at 74th Street and Riverside Drive that

title: TIME WRITER AT LIBEL TRIAL, DESCRIBES GEMAYEL SLAYING
description: Testimony by David Halevy, a Time magazine correspondent, presented a vivid description yesterday of the assassination of a Lebanese leader that provoked a massacre in Lebanon.

title: The Economy
description: President Reagan completed his decisions on spending cuts in domestic programs for his 1986 budget, leaving him to decide whether to cut the military budget. That decision, which is not expected until next week, is central to the budget the President will send to Congress in January. Some top aides have said they expect him to accept a military slowdown. (Page A1.)

title: 2 HOLIDAY HEARTHS AS WARM AS HOME
description: AMONG the food memories most indelibly etched in the mind are those involving the Christmas holidays. It is one time of the year that home cooks, even those who normally shun time- consuming meals, put out their best efforts for families and friends. Christmas is a time when extended families get together, and throughout the centuries food has been a symbol of unity and welcome during this season.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''New York has a problem. But I submit New York's problem has always been they're a high-tax state.

title: MADRID AND LISBON FACE NEW HURDLE TO MARKET ENTRY
description: Greece today threatened to veto longstanding plans to admit Spain and Portugal as members of the European Economic Community unless the community agrees to pay poor southern European farmers up to $5 billion in special aid over the next five years.

title: ROHATYN ASSAILS TAX PLAN
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, yesterday assailed the Treasury's tax simplification proposal as ''lethal'' for New York and an invitation to regional conflict.

title: 5 Men Charged in Sale Of Unwholesome Meat
description: Thousands of schoolchildren, hospital patients and Air Force personnel in five states ate ''putrid and decomposed'' beef butchered from dying and diseased cows, a Federal grand jury concluded Monday.

title: California Issue In Big Demand
description: A $310 million issue of California general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 5.75 percent for bonds due in 1986, to 8.50 percent in 1994 and 9.80 percent in 2008 through 2010. Underwriters were led by the Bank of America.

title: Issue a First For District The District of Columbia
description: made its debut in the long-term

title: Pentagon Sets Up High Post For Purchasing Spare Parts
description: The Pentagon, buffeted by disclosures of huge overpayments for spare parts, announced today that it was centralizing purchasing under a new executive, the Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Spares Program Management.

title: G.M. DROPS MOST OF ITS DIESEL CARS
description: The diesel- powered passenger car, which not all that long ago seemed on its way to capturing a big chunk of the American car market, now seems headed toward a dead end.

title: EFFECT OF MOBIL NEWS BOYCOTT
description: While it is not unusual for corporations to withdraw their advertising from publications to protest news coverage, it is rare that a corporate fit of pique moves a corporation to declare a news boycott as well. But this is what the Mobil Corporation has done, canceling advertising and refusing to provide information about corporate developments to The Wall Street Journal, the daily business newspaper owned by Dow Jones & Company.

title: Provincetown-Boston Airline Says All Its Flights Are Back
description: Provincetown-Boston Airlines, cited by the Government for safety violations and grounded for more than two weeks, has resumed service to all 36 cities on its routes, the company said today.

title: TOP-SEEDED LENDL OUSTED IN AUSTRALIA
description: Kevin Curren knocked top-seeded Ivan Lendl out of the $1.28 million Australian Open Tennis Championships today and advanced to the quarterfinals.

title: FACTORY ORDERS OFF AGAIN IN OCTOBER
description: Orders received by factories dropped 2.5 percent in October, the third consecutivet monthly decline and the steepest since last April, the Commerce Department said today. New orders for manufactured goods totaled $185.1 billion in October, down $4.7 billion from September.

title: Experts Unsurprised By Pattern of Deaths
description: Specialists in respiratory illnesses said yesterday that they were not surprised at the high mortality among the very old and very young, as opposed to those of middle age, after a highly irritating gas was released from a plant in India on Monday.

title: U.S. COURT BARS EXCLUDING PEOPLE AS JURORS SOLELY BECAUSE OF RACE
description: A divided Federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled yesterday that prosecutors could not systematically exclude people from juries solely because of their race.

title: CEREAL AD PRAISED BY AN F.T.C. AIDE
description: The head of the Federal Trade Commission's consumer protection bureau today praised an advertising campaign by the Kellogg Company that seeks to associate its All-Bran cereal with a finding that a high-fiber, low- protein diet may reduce the risk of some kinds of cancer.

title: Friday Is Pearl Harbor Day
description: President Reagan today declared Friday, Dec. 7, as National Pearl Harbor Remembrance Day. He called on Americans ''to pledge eternal vigilance and strong resolve to defend this nation and its allies from further aggression.''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Brittania Ltd ., a Seattle-based sportswear concern, has named Christopher Regalia president and Jeffrey Qvale chairman of the board.

title: Jersey Votes to Keep Lindbergh Property
description: The State House Commission today rescinded its decision to sell 182 acres of an estate once owned by Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. and voted instead to turn the property over to the New Jersey Natural Lands Trust for development of trails for hiking and horseback riding.

title: FISCHBACH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $579,000 for the quarter and $2,723,000 for the year. c-Net income.

title: AMBULATORY MEDICAL CHAIR reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
YANKS SEND FONTENOT TO CUBS
description: The Yankees hit a snag today in their efforts to acquire Rickey Henderson, but managed to make the first trade of baseball's winter meetings. They sent Ray Fontenot and Brian Dayett to the Chicago Cubs for four players - Ron Hassey, a catcher, who had demanded a trade; Henry Cotto, a young outfielder from the Bronx, and two right-handed pitchers, Rich Bordi and Porfi Altamirano.

title: Homeless Asked to Quit Station and Use Shelters
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode, criticized for the way the city is dealing with homeless people staying at the main Amtrak rail station, has personally asked them to use available shelters.

title: Columbia Gas Leaves Group
description: The Columbia Gas System said it was withdrawing from the partnership formed to build the Alaskan segment of a natural gas pipeline system from Alaska's North Slope to the lower 48 states.

title: A Rosy Future
description: Physically, Janes United Methodist

title: FOR THE WELL-TEMPERED COOK
description: -forgotten kitchen utensils given as Christmas gifts with good intentions but a flawed sense of what home cooks really need. While kitchen fads, such as electric carving knives and fondue pots, are hard to pass up, the most appreciated gifts are those that will be used over and over for years. An explosion of kitchenware has made the choice more challenging, and comparison shopping more important, than ever before.

title: Fatally Beaten 4-Month-Old Had Been Raped, Police Say
description: A 4-month-old girl who was kidnapped from her home last month and bludgeoned to death had also been raped, the police said today.

title: U.S. DIPLOMAT WILL RENEW EFFORTS IN MIDEAST
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it would send a high-ranking official back to the Middle East in the next day or so to try to help end the stalemate in the negotiations on Israel's withdrawal from Lebanon.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FREEDOM WITH JUSTICE: Catholic Social Thought and Liberal Institutions. By Michael Novak. Harper & Row. 253 pages. $17.95.

description: largest carrier, said it would raise its discount coach fares

title: PAVEL KUTAKHOV, SOVIET MARSHAL
description: Chief Air Marshal Pavel S. Kutakhov, commander of the Soviet Air Force for the last 15 years, died Monday in Moscow after a long illness, the Soviet press agency Tass announced yesterday. He was 70 years old.

description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Viktor Ulyanov Dies in Soviet; Lenin Nephew Was Engineer
description: Viktor Dmitriyevich Ulyanov, a nephew of Lenin, died Nov. 22 in Moscow after a long illness, according to a Soviet newspaper received in the United States. He was 67 years old.

description: State and City income taxes is

Coach Praises Coach
description: The Cincinnati Bengals' coach, Sam Wyche , has praised his Cleveland counterpart, Marty Schottenheimer, for scolding two Brown players who taunted the Bengals' receiver Cris Collinsworth as he lay on the ground after a hard hit Sunday.

description: Scene on the street:

description: To the Editor:

title: PAUL NITZE TAKES A STAND IN CBS TRIAL
description: A. FARBER

title: NOV. 21-30 CAR SALES OFF 14.2%
description: New-car sales by the nation's major auto makers fell 14.2 percent in the last 10 days of November, surprising industry executives and analysts who were expecting the trend to continue upward from mid-November.

title: Cleanth Brooks Named A Jefferson Lecturer
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities has picked the Faulkner scholar Cleanth Brooks to deliver the 1985 Jefferson Lecture - the Government's top honor in the humanities.

title: Topics ; Cold Shoulders ; Wet ThreatWhen does it rain hardest in New York? By one friend's unscientific sample, the answer is: ''After I've started walking back to work from lunch and I don't have a raincoat or an umbrella, and naturally there's not an empty cab between me and Manhasset. Sometimes I even have a raincoat and an umbrella but it rains and blows so hard I get soaked anyway, which is what happened last Monday.''
description: He does not, he insists, bring up the matter to solicit sympathy or to add yet another variation of Murphy's Law that anything that can go wrong will. His purpose is sociolinguistic.

title: HIGH INTEREST RATES HELP SMALL SAVERS
description: To the Editor:

title: METS EXTEND JOHNSON'S PACT
description: Dave Johnson received a raise and a one-year extension on his contract today as a reward for leading the Mets from last place to second in his first season as manager.

title: PICKENS IN BID FOR PHILLIPS
description: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, said yesterday that he was planning to offer stockholders of the Phillips Petroleum Company $60 a share for at least 15 million shares, or 9.7 percent, of the nation's 12th-largest oil company.

title: WOOLRIDGE LEADS BULLS OVER NETS
description: The Nets, who have had to adjust to life without their big center, Darryl Dawkins, faced the muscular Chicago Bulls tonight without two more ailing players, Albert King and Mike O'Koren.

title: Horner Decides
description: After an agonizing week of indecision, Bob Horner, the Atlanta Braves' third baseman, said he had decided to undergo wrist surgery that could keep him out for all of next season. The alternative, he was told, was to risk a further fracture of the wrist that could end his career.

title: CORPORATE EXECUTIVES AIDING PUBLIC COLLEGES
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: 'DISTRICT LINE,' FROM NEGRO ENSEMBLE
description: JOSEPH A. WALKER has not been much heard from since his corrosive family drama, ''The River Niger,'' won the Tony Award for best play a decade ago. ''District Line,'' Mr. Walker's new work for the Negro Ensemble Company, may reflect the frustrations of that long silence. A potpourri of clashing theatrical styles, far- ranging political aper,cus and truncated emotional catharses, ''District Line'' seems a jam-packed anthology of a talented writer's false starts and half-developed projects. Even in Douglas Turner Ward's sleek, sensitive staging at the Theater Four, the evening is a mess - albeit a peppery, well-acted mess.

title: Lucrative Donaldson Linkup
description: Aside from the shareholders of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, the big winner in the planned acquisition of the Wall Street firm by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States is Dave H. Williams, the 52-year old chairman and chief executive officer of Alliance Capital Management, Donaldson's money management subsidiary.

title: MEMORABLE SELECTIONS FROM THE PAST AND PRESENT
description: Perhaps I am prejudiced, but it seems to me that the easiest of all gifts to select are those destined to be placed under the trees of dedicated cooks. If it is chosen with care, there is scarcely a kitchen item likely to be frowned upon, whether it is a well-designed rubber spatula, a no-nonsense apron, a solid- bottom saucepan or kettle, a heavy- duty electric mixer or an outdoor barbecue. And, happily for both gift giver and receiver, the kitchen is one of the few areas where there need be no fear of duplication. I have yet to meet a serious saucemaker, pastry chef or any other cook who felt that one wire whisk was enough, or a single food processor for that matter.

title: Watches for Santa
description: At the Tourneau shop on Madison Avenue yesterday, five homeless men in scarlet Santa suits and flowing white beards were given wristwatches.

title: Miami Official Waives Hearing on Discharge
description: City Manager Howard Gary, dismissed by the City Commissioners because of differences over the way he ran the government, has waived his right to a hearing and, in effect, accepted his dismissal.

title: Cronies In, Cronies Out New York's top judges are belatedly trying to clean out the state's sordid system of picking conservators for the assets of children and incapacitated adults. Their administrative board now urges random computer nominations from a larger pool of qualified candidates, which would be fine if the qualifications were also tightened.
description: Judges have been left mostly to their own sense of propriety and too often dish out this pork to personal and political favorites. They are not allowed to appoint relatives, but nothing bars the son or daughter of another judge.

title: Practice Pays Off
description: When Kevin Willis, a 7-foot, 235- pound center, played basketball at Michigan State, his statistical line was impressive except for one department - foul shooting.

title: IS NONPROFIT SCIENCE REALLY BETTER FOR YOU?
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Company Briefs column of Business Day yesterday misstated the price paid by the Fujisawa Pharmaceutical Company for Lymphomed Inc. It was $17.50 a share.

title: DEERE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Head of Marketing Unit Leaving Carter Hawley
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., the nation's 13th-largest retailing concern, said yesterday that Francis H. Arnone had decided to resign as president of its market services division.

title: Koch Asks Chamber To End Bias Lawsuit
description: Mayor Koch asked the city's Chamber of Commerce yesterday to drop its legal challenge to his executive order prohibiting discriminaton on the basis of race, sex, religion, age and other factors.

title: Harry Sukman, a Composer;Won Oscar for Film Score
description: Harry Sukman, an Oscar-winning composer who wrote the theme to the television show ''Dr. Kildare,'' collapsed and died of a heart attack Sunday on his 72d birthday at a benefit for a stroke center.

title: ONE REPORTED SLAIN
description: Arabic-speaking gunmen forced a Kuwaiti jetliner with at least 155 people on board to fly to Teheran today, airport security guards said. They were reported to have killed one of their hostages and later to have released 44 women and children.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Satellite Business In Another Change
description: Satellite Business Systems, the troubled communications company, yesterday named Marvin L. Mann as president and chief executive officer. It is the second leadership change in less than a year.

title: Indians Sign Thornton HOUSTON, Dec. 4 - The Cleveland Indians, who have steadily
description: fallen into disrepute with their fans, made a bold effort to regain their

title: YALE FEELS RELIEF AS STRIKING WORKERS RESUME JOBS
description: The sidewalks around Yale University were empty of pickets for the first time in 10 weeks today as striking clerical and technical workers resumed their jobs in offices and laboratories.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for 12wks to Oct 20
description: b-Including a tax credit of $449,000, or 10 cents a share, from the settlement of federal income tax assessments for 1971-75 fiscal years.

title: BUDGET CHAIRMAN MUST QUIT
description: In a close vote, House Democrats decided today to retain a party rule that would prevent Representative James R. Jones of Oklahoma from staying on as chairman of the Budget Committee in the new Congress.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: HANUKKAH TABLE: SEPHARDIC TREATS
description: THE idea of Hanukkah without latkes would be as unacceptable to many Jews as a bagel without lox. Latkes, or potato pancakes, have long been considered a traditional part of the holiday celebration.

title: F.A.A. HEAD SAYS FLIGHT DELAYS DROPPED 55% IN NOVEMBER
description: Flight delays dropped sharply in November because of improved weather and changes in airline schedules at six of the country's busiest airports, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: Norfolk Southern
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation said it would buy 100 high-efficiency locomotives next year for $129 million. Norfolk Southern said it would purchase 50 locomotives from the General Electric Company and 50 from the General Motors Corporation's Electro-Motive division for its operating subsidiaries, the Norfolk & Western Railway and the Southern Railway.

title: S. & P. BEARISH ON GOLD NOW
description: IN common with economists and Wall Street analysts, advisory services change their minds

title: A Jordanian Diplomat Is Killed in Bucharest
description: A top Jordanian diplomat was shot dead in Bucharest today as he was taking his child to school. The Palestinian terrorist group Black September took responsibility.

title: Mandate and the Sequel
description: Four years ago, when the Heritage

title: 'CRUEL GARDEN,' ON THE ARTS NETWORK
description: IN ''Cruel Garden,'' to be shown

title: Standoff at Coast Bank Ends With a Surrender
description: A gunman who apparently broke his leg trying to escape after a botched bank robbery surrendered today, ending a four-and-a-half-hour standoff in which 23 people took shelter inside a bank vault, the police said.

title: Anderson Resting for Giants
description: Ottis Anderson is worn down. The St. Louis Cardinals' running back spent yesterday, a day off, lying in his bed except for time in a Jacuzzi bath and a steam room. The object? ''Trying to get rid of the soreness in my body,'' he explained.

title: ND in Chapter 11
description: ND Resources Inc. said it had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The company said its subsidiaries are not a party to the Chapter 11 filing and continue to operate in southeastern Kentucky. ND explores for and develops a variety of natural resources in the Western United States, and produces low-sulfur steam coals in Kentucky.

title: Brown-Harris: Running Duel LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 (AP)
description: Jim Brown and Franco Harris will engage in a four-event

title: DUNES HOTELS & CASINOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $287,000 for the quarter and $687,000 for the 9 months and an extraordinary gain of $11,489,000 for the 9 months representing a gain on the exchange of stock for debt. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $18,000 for the quarter and $59,000 for the 9 months.

title: Canucks' Rota Retires
description: Darcy Rota, the Vancouver Canucks' high-scoring left wing who has not played since he suffered a severe neck injury last season, has retired after 11 seasons. Rota, who is 31 years old, scored 256 goals and 239 assists. . . . Guy Lafleur, who retired from the Montreal Canadiens last week, will be honored at the Forum on Feb. 16, when his No. 10 uniform is retired. . . . Wayne Gretzky of Edmonton was named by the league as the player of the month for November, the 16th time he had received the honor.

title: GRACE DOWNS
description: Grace Downs, the founder in 1927 of one of the first modeling and charm schools in New York, died of kidney failure Saturday at a nursing home in Cocoa Beach, Fla.

title: PEORIA SCHOOL BOARD RESTORES 3 JUDY BLUME BOOKS
description: Public school trustees voted 5 to 2 Monday night to return to library shelves three books by an award-winning children's writer that had been banned on the ground of sexual references and strong language.

title: Edwina T. Mackenzie, Who Survived Titanic
description: Edwina Troutt Mackenzie, the second-oldest survivor of the sinking of the Titanic in 1912, died Monday at the age of 100.

title: MUSIC: YOUTH SYMPHONY PERFORMS AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: IT was an ambitious program that

title: Lord & Taylor Keeping Chief Joseph E. Brooks, chairman
description: Lord & Taylor, has renewed his

title: NICHOLS, S.E. INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in The Living Section last Wednesday with an article on catered parties misidentified the caterer of a reception at the Banca Commerciale Italiana in New York. It was Sant Ambroeus.

title: FLOATING POINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Bridge: After Teammate Collapsed, The Dummy Became Player
description: In one sense dummy-play is normal, but in the literal sense, play by the dummy does not exist. However, the first dummy-play in 47 years of world championships occurred last month at the World Team Olympiad in Seattle.

title: ELECTROMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 4
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $36,588,000 for the quarter and $39,856,000 for the 9 months and a gain of $48,270,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the sale of the company's Van de Kamp frozen foods division. c-Net losses including income from discontinued operations of $649,000 for the quarter and $1,853,000 for the 9 months. Results for the latest periods include operations of Flower Time Inc. since the date of acquisition, March 2, 1984.
