title: ANTITERRORIST COMMAND POST: IT'S RIGHT OUT OF THE MOVIES
description: If there is ever a major terrorist attack in the United States, the Government's response will be coordinated from a windowless, three-room command post known as the Emergency Operations Center.

title: CHILD-CARE FINGERPRINT DATA DISPUTED
description: The City Investigation Commissioner said yesterday that as many as half of the 36 people cited by Mayor Koch as child-care center workers who had criminal records were not now working in such centers but were applicants for jobs in them.

title: WE HAVE A GREATER ROLE TO PLAY IN THE IRISH PEACE PROCESS
description: To the Editor:

title: 'REAL' RATES: TOO HIGH?
description: PRESTON MARTIN, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who was appointed to the board by President Reagan, is widely regarded as a possible successor to Paul A. Volcker, the board's chairman, when and if Mr. Volcker decides to resign. Mr. Volcker has in the past indicated he might not serve out his full four-year term as chairman, to which he was appointed by Mr. Reagan in mid-1983.

title: CUOMO-KEMP QUARREL CONTINUES
description: Governor Cuomo today continued his criticism of Representative Jack F. Kemp over the Treasury's tax proposal, saying the Buffalo Republican is ''selling out New York for the sake of a national image.''

title: Conagra Buys Hopkins
description: Conagra Inc. said today that its United Agri Products unit had acquired the Hopkins Agricultural Chemical Company of Madison, Wis. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: NEW-HOME SALES UP IN OCTOBER
description: Sales of new homes, spurred by lower interest rates and a surge of activity in the West, rose 2.1 percent in October, the Government reported today.

title: Wings 7, Leafs 6
description: John Ogrodnick scored three third-period goals, the last with 49 seconds remaining, to lift Detroit to victory. Ogrodnick beat the Maple Leafs' netminder, Ken Wregget, with a slapshot from the top of the face-off circle for his 14th goal of the season to cap a five-goal third-period outburst.

title: FCS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: photo of Royal Shakesphere Company; 'CYRANO' PLAYERS COOK UP NOSTALGIA
description: GEORGE PARSONS missed marmite on toast for breakfast. Brigid Larmour missed English beer. ''I do like a little bit of bitter from time to time,'' she said wistfully. Richard Clifford decided that he missed a real English Sunday dinner, so he invited six friends over and made roast beef and Yorkshire pudding.

title: Stefan Voitec Is Dead at 84; A Vice President of Rumania
description: Stefan Voitec, a Social Democrat who joined the Communists in 1948, died today ''after a long and severe illness,'' the press Agerpres said. He was 84 years old.

title: BLASTS NOT ON F.B.I. TERRORISM LIST
description: William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that he did not consider abortion clinic bombings to be acts of terrorism and therefore was not giving them the high priority accorded terrorist violence.

title: Interest Rates Fall Modestly
description: Short- and long-term interest rates fell modestly yesterday in quiet trading as many speculators and investors remained on the sidelines.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Dec. 5, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: 20,000 AT L.I. COLISEUM SEE 2 RABBIS' CHILDREN MARRY
description: Thousands of Hasidic Jews from around the world gathered at the Nassau Coliseum this evening for the wedding of two scions of the Satmar sect.

title: TRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $5,184,000 from settlement of a lawsuit.

title: WIFE IS HELD IN CONTEMPT OF COURT FOR REFUSING TO TESTIFY IN SPY INQUIRY
description: The wife of a former C.I.A. employee accused of spying for Czechoslovakia was found in civil contempt of court yesterday for refusing to testify before a Federal grand jury in Manhattan that is investigating her husband's activities.

title: VENEZUELAN CAUTIONS REAGAN ON USE OF MILITARY FORCE
description: President Jaime Lusinchi of Venezuela told President Reagan today that the use of military force would not solve the ''delicate and complex crisis of the Central American countries.''

title: BEWARE OF DRIVELATING HALLJOGGERS
description: Jim Boren calls them Borenwords, finely tuned phrases for practitioners of the bureaucratic arts.

title: SASSOON JUDAICA SOLD AT SOTHEBY'S
description: The fourth sale of manuscripts from the collection of David Solomon Sassoon, a Bombay-born British collector, last night established a record for a Judaica auction and for a Hebrew Bible purchased at public sale, Sotheby's said.

title: NATO TO SPEND $7.85 BILLION TO IMPROVE ITS GROUND POSTS
description: The Defense Ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today approved $7.85 billion in spending on military ground installations and vowed to remedy critical shortages of ammunition.

title: Accord Reached in Strike Of Coast Restaurants
description: A tentative agreement was reached today in a 13-week strike against 26 San Francisco restaurants, including some of the city's most famous.

title: Figure in Pennsylvania Crime Dies at 82 in His Bed at Home
description: John Sebastian Larocca, identified by the Pennsylvania Crime Commission as head of southwestern Pennsylvania's organized crime group, died Monday at his home in suburban McCandless Township.

title: VINCENT B. WELCH
description: Vincent B. Welch, former senior partner in the Washington law firm of Welch & Morgan and founder of Welch Enterprises, a business and investment company, died of cancer Monday in the Maine Medical Center, Portland. He was 67 years old. Mr. Welch was a lawyer in the Federal Communications Commission in the 1940's, and from 1946 to 1977 was the senior partner of Welch & Morgan. Born in Portland, he earned a bachelor's degree from Bowdoin College in 1938 and a Doctor of Jurisprudence at Harvard University in 1941.

title: Housing Bonds For Puerto Rico
description: The Puerto Rico Housing Bank and Finance Agency is offering $150 million of housing revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 10 3/8 percent for bonds due in 2015, according to tentative prices announced yesterday by underwriters led by E.F. Hutton & Company.

title: BRIEFS ;  Debt
description: * AMAX Inc. is offering $150 million of 14.5 percent notes due in 1994 at par, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman/American Express Inc.

title: Arms and the Traveler
description: Speaking of arms and the Russians, Senator-elect Gore took

title: ISLANDER DEMISE RECALLED
description: Denis Potvin was one of the last Islanders to leave the ice when the Islanders filed out of here last May. At one end of Northlands Coliseum, the Oilers were rejoicing in their first Stanley Cup. At the other, the Islanders quietly departed to their dressing room, many of them limping, their four-year cup reign finally ended.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Dublin on Nov. 23 incorrectly characterized the political status of the southern part of Ireland in 1922, when it was known as the Irish Free State. It was a British dominion, and was not proclaimed a fully independent republic until 1949.

title: JOBS AND RISKS ARE LINKED AT SISTER PLANT IN THE U.S.
description: The sprawling Union Carbide chemical factory here, a sister plant to the one that leaked toxic gas in India this week, is an uneasy neighbor to the middle-class houses and college classrooms nestled among the hills and riverbanks around the mile-long tangle of steel machinery.

title: HOUSE PANEL DECIDES FERRARO VIOLATED ETHICS LAW
description: The House ethics committee found today that Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro violated the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 by failing to report details of her husband's finances.

title: Ex-Solidarity Member Voted University Rector
description: Faculty and student representatives, whose rights of self-government are being threatened by proposed legislation, elected a former Solidarity member Monday to serve as rector of Warsaw University.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.25-11.50 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: REGAN DECLARES NEW YORK TAX COULD BE CUT
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said tonight that his proposal to revamp the Federal income tax system would provide greater tax revenues for New York State and that, therefore, the state could afford to reduce its own taxes.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE relatively high prices of wine in many restaurants was the subject of several articles in this space recently. Alas, those pieces did not lead to a nationwide cutback in wine prices. Consumers applauded, and some restaurant owners sent along their wine lists to show that there are places to eat where a bottle of wine need not cost more than the food. Most restaurateurs who reacted to the columns defended their price levels, citing the high cost of doing business these days and arguing, in so many words, that they have to make a profit somewhere.

title: GELCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SLAYING WAS ORDERED FROM TAIWAN, LAWYER SAYS
description: A lawyer for the family of a Chinese writer who was slain here asserted today that the identification of the killers as leaders of an underworld gang with good political connections in Taiwan showed the killing had been ''ordered and planned by powerful figures in Taiwan.''

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1984 International 1,000 Indians have been killed by poison gas leaking from a Union Carbide insecticide plant in the central India town of Bhopal. Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi said he would seek compensation for the disaster, which is one of the largest known industrial accidents in history. (Page A1, Col. 6.) There are no current regulations in the United States to control hazardous chemicals stored in underground tanks, such as the leaking facility in India, according to officials of the Environmental Protection Agency. Several said that a similar accident could occur in this country. (A13:1.)

title: A VARIETY SHOW ABOUT SURVIVING
description: ''S.O.S. - Secrets of Surviving'' is a melange, some of it sensible, even touching, much of it only confused. What do you make of a one-hour variety show for parents and children that has Erma Bombeck cracking jokes, Mr. T telling the kids to learn to fight (''and don't talk to no strangers'') and Dee Snider of Twisted Sister saying he's not satanic? The NBC program will be seen on Channel 4 at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: DOWSING FOR FUN, PROFIT AND COUNTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tomato Campaign
description: ONE could say without fear of contradiction that advertising of fresh tomatoes has been a rarity on television in the New York market. But that situation is about to change, courtesy of Agrexko (USA) and its new agency, J.J. Gross & Company.

title: 17 IN BROOKLYN SEIZED IN 'STING' ON CREDIT CARDS
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney's office announced yesterday that in an investigation of 85 Brooklyn businesses - ranging from national chain stores to small neighborhood shops - 25 percent of them were eager to accept credit cards they knew were stolen or fraudulent.

title: HARWOODFERRYMERRILL
description: Harwood Ferry Merrill, a former managing editor of Forbes Magazine and a writer and editor of business- management publications, died of a heart attack Nov. 23 at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 80 years old and lived in Clark Island, Me.

title: NICARAGUAN COUNCIL GIVES WAY TO NEW ASSEMBLY
description: Nicaragua's Council of State closed today to prepare the way for the inauguration next month of the recently elected National Assembly.

title: SERVICE CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in October.

title: UNIT FOR STORING CHEESE
description: BEFORE the age of home refrigeration in France my mother used to keep food provisions in the cool basement, secured in a makeshift cage called a garde-manger. Unlike today's consumers, we did not shop for large quantities of food only once or twice a week; rather, groceries were purchased daily, sometimes twice a day. What little leftovers we had were usually consumed the next day. The garde-manger was used to preserve meats, vegetables, cheeses and bread overnight.

title: Leaving City Government
description: After eight years of working in key city jobs, James R. Brigham Jr. is planning to leave his adopted city in the spring.

title: Touche Ross Deal
description: Touche Ross & Company, a Big Eight accounting firm, said it had acquired Braxton Inc., a management consulting company based in Boston.

title: U.S. MILITARY TRIES TO CATCH UP IN FIGHTING TERROR
description: A special Defense Department commission that investigated the October 1983 bombing of the Marine barracks in Lebanon said its ''most important message'' was that terrorism had become ''tantamount to an act of war,'' and that the United States military was ill-equipped to fight that kind of war.

title: Victim's Sacrifice Honored
description: The District of Columbia Council voted today to rename a bridge for the man who died saving others after a jetliner crash three years ago. The northbound span of the 14th Street Bridge will become the Arland D. Williams Memorial Bridge. After the Air Florida jet struck the bridge Jan. 13, 1982, Mr. Williams, a passenger, repeatedly passed a helicopter lifeline to others before drowning in the Potomac.

title: RETAIL SALES IN CITY EXPAND 6.6%
description: Retail sales in New York City rose by an average of 6.6 percent in November from the period a year earlier, aided by the beginning of the Christmas shopping season, a monthly spot-check found yesterday. Sales of the same stores and their suburban branches in the New York metropolitan area were up 7.4 percent in the month.

title: KNICKS WIN IN LAST :003
description: Darrell Walker, who had had a tough shooting night, hit a 9-foot baseline jumper with three seconds remaining last night to give the Knicks a 100-98 victory over the Denver Nuggets at Madison Square Garden.

title: Mugging a Network
description: For an impermissible two weeks, the Federal Communications Commission has been threatening the licenses of the American Broadcasting Companies because the network, as it acknowledged on the air, may have erred in reporting an assassination plot by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Jordan, Case Acquires Bloom & Gelb Agency
description: Jordan, Case & McGrath has acquired the Bloom & Gelb direct-response ad agency and is so excited about it that it will announce the fact in an ad in The New York Times and segments of the advertising trade press.

title: MOE: COACH WITH FREELANCE STYLE
description: Foster Park, the playground at the intersection of Foster and Nostrand Avenues in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, was once Doug Moe's concrete domain.

title: COMPANY SAYS INQUIRY IN INDIA MAY TAKE WEEKS
description: Senior executives of the Union Carbide Corporation, confronted with the worst industrial accident in the company's history, said today that it might take two to three weeks to determine the cause of the poisonous gas leak at their pesticide plant in Bhopal, India.

title: MUSIC: PACO PENA ON GUITAR
description: PACO PENA'S Sunday night program of flamenco guitar music at the Abraham Goodman House was extraordinary in several respects. Mr. Pena is a genuine virtuoso, capable of dazzling an audience with technical abilities beyond the frets of mortal man. He combines rapid-fire flourishes with a colorist's sense of shading; this listener cannot recall hearing any guitarist with a more assured mastery of his instrument.

title: Dance Premiere Canceled
description: Alvin Ailey's new ''For Bird-With Love,'' scheduled for a New York premiere during the current season of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at City Center, has been canceled due to injuries sustained in a taxi accident by the lead dancer, Gary DeLoatch. Billy Wilson's ''Concerto in F'' has also been canceled. The company will perform at City Center through Dec. 23.

title: Aoki Explains
description: Isao Aoki, the Japanese golf star, has been invited to play in the annual Sun City Million Dollar Challenge golf in the South African tribal homeland of Bophuthatswana each year since the tournament started four years ago.

title: A Friend at Times Square
description: Since 1941, when the U.S.O. was founded, American men and women in uniform have had a friend at Times Square. New York, the world's most popular leave and liberty port, can be a bewildering place for a young recruit in town for the first time.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1.*Warm and Fifty-ish

title: TOWN IN WYOMING REJECTS GUN BAN
description: The mayor and the town council have voted down a proposed ban of guns in this community's three bars, bowing to the sentiment of most of 250 people attending a town meeting.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
F.D.R., THE GHOST OF DEMOCRATS PAST
description: Franklin D. Roosevelt is the Democratic Party's Ghost of Christmas Past: he visits the nightmare conjured up by our most recent electoral debacle.

title: CHERNENKO MEETS ARMAND HAMMER
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, said today that Soviet and American officials should ''roll up their sleeves'' and start forging concrete agreements on limiting and reducing arms.

title: 371 HAITIANS ARE SEIZED AT SEA
description: United States officials seized 371 Haitians on two ships heading toward Florida on Sunday and Monday, and the Coast Guard sank one of the boats because the authorities said it was a health hazard.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Ameritech Forms Fund For Pension Benefits
description: American Information Technologies Inc., the Chicago-based phone company known as Ameritech, announced yesterday that it had created a $2.4 billion dedicated bond fund to pay retirement benefits for 43,000 current retirees.

title: EXERCISE PLANNED FOR HEART PATIENT
description: Nine days after receiving an artificial heart, William J. Schroeder is moving into the next phase of his recovery: exercise and rehabilitation.

title: TELESPHERE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After tax credits of $101,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $175,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: PUNCH LINE TO COME
description: Weird is the word for the tale of taxation being told from the swamps of Washington, but it is a weirdness suffused with mirth.

title: NAVY BACKS UP SHIP'S CAPTAIN ON ROLE OFF CUBA
description: The American vessel that broke down and drifted into Cuban waters last week, causing the aircraft carrier Nimitz to be dispatched to the area, was gathering hydrographic information along the coast of Haiti before developing engine trouble, Navy officials said today.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Croissants Worth a Wait

title: STATE PHONE RENTERS TO GET 2 BILLS
description: More than three million residences and businesses that rent their telephones in New York State will begin receiving an extra phone bill in January, for equipment rental.

title: UNITED STATES MUTUAL FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company has changed to a calendar year from one ending April 30, thereby reflecting results for the year-ago period for 8 months instead of 9 months. The year-ago 8 months' loss includes extraordinary charges of $625,291 and $1,961,617, both related to expenses incurred in the reorganization of the company.

title: People
description: * William D. Badger and Jo Anne McShane have been promoted to senior vice presidents at Benton & Bowles.

title: SCOUTING ; Not a Real Upset
description: The 83-51 loss by the highly ranked University of Louisville to Athletes in Action on Monday night at Freedom Hall in Louisville was not as stunning or as unexpected as some basketball fans might believe.

title: RUTGERS TOPS PRINCETON, 54-41
description: The thought that this may be his first losing season after 17 years as Princeton's basketball coach must have crossed Pete Carril's mind here tonight after Rutgers defeated the Tigers, 54-41, at the Rutgers Athletic Center,

title: EL CHICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 16
description: Year-ago results have been restated for reclassification of some non-sale items.

title: DYCOM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: A CENTRIST IN GRENADA
description: In the more than four and a half years that leftist revolutionaries ran Grenada, little was heard from Herbert A. Blaize, who was sworn in today as Prime Minister after his centrist, coalition party swept to victory in the elections Monday. Talking with reporters the other day, the 66-year-old lawyer and former civil servant said that when the revolutionaries dissolved Parliament he went home to his district and carried on with his legal practice.

title: Inco Plans to Alter U.S. Pension Plan
description: Inco Ltd. said it expected to restructure its United States pension plan and, as a result, generate $75 million to $100 million (Canadian), which would be used to reduce debt.

title: Arms and the Senate
description: Even before conservative Republicans threatened to vote against deployment of MX land-based missiles in the next Congress, the weapons system appeared to be in trouble. The Council for a Livable World, an antiwar organization, having tallied last month's election results, predicts that the new Senate will vote 51 to 49 against authorizing MX production.

title: Ted Page, 81, Found Slain;Former Negro League Star
description: Theodore R. (Ted) Page, who starred in the Negro Baseball League during the 1920's and 1930's, was found slain at his home here last Saturday.

title: Transactions
description: Extended contract of Dave Johnson, manager, through 1986 season and increased his salary for 1985.

title: Big Numbers, Even for Aaron
description: When he was breaking Babe Ruth's record 10 years ago, Henry Aaron always was dealing in big numbers: 756 home runs and a salary of $200,000 a year, which was considered high at the time. But now that he has retired from the field and become vice president of the Atlanta Braves, he is amazed at some of the big numbers in baseball.

title: Bill to Set Drinking Age at 21 In Massachusetts Is Signed
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today signed a bill raising the drinking age in Massachusetts from 20 to 21, effective June 1, or earlier if all other New England states and New York conform to that age.

title: TIP'S LAST HURRAH
description: WASHINGTON Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill, the

title: HIGH COURT WEIGHS SILENCE IN SCHOOL FOR PRAYER OR MEDITATION
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether a state law permitting public school teachers to open class with a minute of silence for ''meditation or voluntary prayer'' violates the constitutional separation of church and state.

title: PENELOPE PLATT LITTELL
description: Penelope Platt Littell, director of the junior school of the Hopkins Grammar School-Day Prospect Hill School in New Haven, died of cancer Saturday at her home in New Haven.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: In some faraway place, the mother and child might have been out for a stroll picking wildflowers. ''There's a red one!'' 5-year-old Mark Williams shrieked. He skipped to the curb, picked the red beer can from the gutter and handed it to his mother.

title: U.S. RULES ARE DUE ON TOXIC MATERIAL
description: Officials of the Environmental Protection Agency said today that there were no regulations so far to control underground storage of chemicals such as the leaking tanks that took a high toll of human life in India, Several officials said a similar accident in the United States was not unimaginable.

title: PEP BOYS-MANNY, MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SHARON'S 'BLOOD LIBEL'
description: There is something sinister happening in the New York courtroom where the former Israeli Defense Minister Ariel Sharon is suing Time magazine. Mr. Sharon's specific charge concerns the magazine's coverage of the Kahan Commission of inquiry's ruling that he was indirectly responsible for the massacres of Palestinian refugees at the Sabra and Shatila camps in Beirut - a ruling that eventually led to his resignation from the Defense Ministry. More generally, however, and much more alarming, he is charging Time Inc. with ''blood libel.''

title: SCHEIB, EARL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Including gains of $13,980,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the sale of Arizona supermarkets and losses of $4,485,000 for the quarter and $3,495,000 for the 9 months related to holdings in Jewel Companies.

title: LEGISLATORS PREPARE TO VOTE ON RAISES
description: Legislators began gathering here today for a lame- duck session in which they plan to vote themselves raises of 30 percent and to also give pay increases to judges and state commissioners.

title: BROADCASTS AND PRESS SHAPE MUSIC IN BRITAIN
description: AMERICAN visitors here who have been long-time fanciers of British rock are often shocked by the paucity of media outlets for pop music. A few pirate and commercial radio stations offer color and some programming for specialists' tastes, but driving through the countryside, away from the larger cities, one usually has to choose between whatever BBC's Radio One is playing and other stations devoted to the classics, news or talk. And if one misses the two weekly pop television shows, ''Top of the Pops'' and ''Whistle Test'' one isn't likely to see any other pop performances on television.

title: Sad Farewell
description: Pietro Mennea, the Italian sprint star who has held the world record in the 200 meters for five years, said in Rome yesterday that he was retiring from competition because he felt there was an increasing use of illicit drugs by his rivals. ''I am going because I have noticed that most performances are no longer the result of training alone, but need something else,'' he said.

title: HOMEMADE EDIBLES PROVIDE A TOUCH OF THE PERSONAL
description: CHRISTMAS gifts of homemade food are not always as happily received as given. Well do I remember being the uneasy recipient of a liter jar full of fresh pig's blood, and the assurance from my Tuscan neighbor, whose pig it had been, that it would be the basis of a wonderful sanguinaccio, whatever that might be. (It is, in fact, a blood pudding.) The following suggestions for gifts of food will be, one hopes, as happily offered as that jar was, and perhaps more graciously received.

title: CIRCUS CIRCUS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
HOMELESS STIRRING GIFTS TO NEEDIEST
description: As shoppers throng the streets and visitors arrive to savor the holiday festivities, many of those among them who are contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund become increasingly aware of the city's homeless people and ask that their gifts be directed toward them.

title: REAGAN COMPLETES PROPOSALS ON CUTS IN MANY PROGRAMS
description: President Reagan today finished deciding how to cut domestic spending in his 1986 budget, White House officials said, leaving him to decide whether he also wants to slow his military buildup to reach his deficit-reducing goal.

title: Dutchess County Sets an Offering
description: A $41.2 million issue of the Dutchess County, N.Y., Resource Recovery Agency was offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 10 5/8 percent for bonds due in 2008, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Alexander to Buy Canadian Broker
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., the world's second-largest insurance-brokering company, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Reed Stenhouse Companies Ltd., the Toronto-based insurance broker, for $15.83 a share, or about $263 million.

title:
CAREERS;
ACCOUNTING MANAGERS
description: WHENEVER a new career path develops, an association is sure to follow. The Association of Accounting Administrators, which was formed last January, now has 200 members, according to Clifford M. Brownstein, its executive director. He also heads Brownstein Associates, a public relations and marketing firm in Washington.

title: Flutie Big to Falcons
description: Doug Flutie, the Boston College quarterback who just won the Heisman Trophy, may considered too small by some scouts to make a top pro prospect, but at least one team will consider making him a high draft choice. Rankin Smith, the owner of the Atlanta Falcons, said his executives would take a good look at the 5-foot-9 3/4-inch Flutie, especially since Steve Bartowski, the team's longtime quarterback, is out with an injury that may cause him to retire. The Falcons, who are 3-11, could pick as early as third in next year's draft.

title: SHAD ASKS TIGHTENING BY NASDAQ AND AMEX
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers and the American Stock Exchange have been asked by the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission to consider raising the standards for companies whose stock trading they supervise, Gordon S. Macklin, the association's president, and Arthur Levitt Jr., the exchange's chairman, said yesterday.

title: SATELLITE OPERATORS HAIL COURT RULING
description: When a United States Court of Appeals panel last week affirmed a Federal Communications Commission ruling that local and state governments may not regulate television programming distributed via satellite to private dwellings such as apartment houses, the decision was hailed by satellite programmers as a victory for competition and free enterprise.

title: NEW OLYMPIC SANCTIONS
description: With the Olympic movement still suffering from the politically motivated absences in the last three Summer Games, officials tried last week to do something to discourage future absences.

title: PARIS SENDS AIDE TO MEDIATE NEW CALEDONIA EMERGENCY
description: A special envoy from Paris arrived here this afternoon to try to bring an end to the recent violent clashes between loyalists and Melanesian separatists seeking independence from France.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: AS if severe pain and embarrassing symptoms that do not respond to usual treatments are not bad enough, to be told that a devastating health problem is ''all in your head'' can make anyone frustrated and hostile. Trying to treat people with chronic debilitating symptoms that do not go away despite the best therapeutic efforts can be equally discouraging for doctors - enough so that they often turn their backs on such patients.

title: PROTESTS SPREADING IN U.S. AGAINST SOUTH AFRICA POLICY
description: Protests against South African racial policies spread to other cities today, with demonstrators marching at the South African Embassy here and at consulates in New York, Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles, Houston and Seattle.

title: LTV Plant Sale
description: The Justice Department said it had approved the sale of the LTV Corporation's stainless steel cold-rolled sheet plant in Massillon, Ohio, to CDH Metals Inc., a steel service-center company based in Wynnewood, Pa. Robert Newstat is the chief executive and main owner of CDH. LTV is divesting itself of the plant under an agreement with the Justice Department allowing the company to acquire the Republic Steel Corporation.

title: The Tragedy at Bhopal
description: A poisonous vapor crept at night through the city of Bhopal in central India, smothering people in their sleep or sending them running in agony. More than 1,000 are feared dead, many of them children or elderly who could not outrun the lethal cloud. Some 20,000 more may be rendered blind or sterile. It's among the worst industrial accidents ever.

title: N.H.L. ; Capitals Triumph Over Devils, 4-1
description: Bob Carpenter and Greg Adams scored goals 41 seconds apart in the first period and the Washington Capitals went on to defeat the Devils tonight, 4-1, extending their winning streak to six games.

title: DIOXIN DISPUTE CONTINUES AS INCINERATOR VOTE NEARS
description: The Board of Estimate is preparing to vote tomorrow on a resolution that would move New York toward construction of eight large garbage incinerators amid a dispute over whether they would produce unacceptably large amounts of dioxin.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ROCK Cornish game hens are, to my taste, one of the finest of all American foods. When I served them recently, a dinner guest was amused that these birds are still called game hens after all these years of being bred commercially. There has been talk for some time of dropping the word ''game'' from the name; certainly they do not taste at all gamy.

title: A SENATOR LEAVES OFFICE WITH REGRETS AND RELIEF
description: When H. Douglas Barclay took his seat in the State Senate 20 years ago, he was told legislative sessions lasted 3 months.

title: KURRI SCORES 3 AS OILERS BEAT ISLANDERS
description: The Islanders left Northlands Coliseum as losers last May, drummed out of the playoffs by the Edmonton Oilers. And tonight, after taking a 2-0 lead in the opening 41 seconds, they again left as losers, suffering a 6-4 defeat to the Oilers in the first meeting of the year between last season's Stanley Cup finalists.

title: CAVCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Royal Opera Appoints Tate as Top Conductor
description: The Royal Opera House at Covent Garden in London has announced that Jeffrey Tate, the British-born conductor who made his Metropolitan Opera debut four years ago with Berg's ''Lulu,'' has been appointed the company's principal conductor - the first in its history. Mr. Tate will assume his position at Covent Garden in September 1986, where he will spend 16 weeks of each season.

title: Robert H. Fleming, 72; A Johnson Press Aide
description: Robert H. Fleming, a longtime journalist who served as deputy press secretary to President Johnson, died of pneumonia Monday, a spokesman at George Washington University Hospital said today. He was 72 years old.

title: Systems and Computer Inquiry
description: The Systems and Computer Technology Corporation said its results would be reduced because of questions raised about its license fee income by its independent auditors, Ernst & Whinney. The company said it expected that the revenues and income recognized in each of the first three fiscal quarters and in the year ended Sept. 30 would be affected.

title: IN LOS ANGELES, A BIT OF 1880'S FANTASY
description: LOS ANGELES The tall and growing skyline of downtown Los Angeles is only a short view away, but the immediate scene along Carroll Avenue in Angeleno Heights is Victorian: The 1300 block has the highest concentration of Queen Anne Eastlake Victorian houses in southern California. The neighborhood, developed in the late 1880's, is much as it was at the turn of the century.

title: COMPANY DEFENDS PLANT SITE IN INDIA
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said today that it had been making chemicals in Bhopal, India, for more than 15 years and that the site of the gas leak Monday had been selected for its plant at a time when the surrounding area was much less densely populated.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report on Nov. 10 with an article about coastal erosion in New York incorrectly described a building protected by sandbags on Fire Island. It is part of the incinerator for the town of Saltaire.

title: GUEST SUPPLY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SPORTS OF THE TIMES ; 'The Opportunity to Walk'
description: He was introduced as ''the virtuoso of New York basketball,'' a 6-foot-8-inch former forward at Long Island University who had been ''smooth, quick,'' who ''could shoot from outside, rebound, dribble and fast-break.'' Sherman White, 55 years old, was selected for Madison Square Garden's all-time team as the Garden approached its 50th anniversary of college basketball. And with a soft smile, Sherman White, in a black suit with a gold ''W'' on his pink- white-and-black striped tie, walked up yesterday to accept his bronze trophy.

title: E.P.A. REJECTS PETITION TO CURB POLLUTION OF AIR
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today formally rejected a petition by New York, Pennsylvania and Maine to curb pollution from Middle Western and Border states.

title: DEMOCRATS GIVE UP ON LIMITING G.O.P. ON HOUSE SPEECHES FOR TV
description: House Democratic leaders bowed to heavy criticism from lawmakers in both parties today and abandoned plans to apply restrictions on a group of conservative Republicans who have been using the House rules to broadcast their political message on television over the last year.

title: R. W. LEE, ART HISTORIAN, DIES
description: Dr. Rensselaer W. Lee, an authority on Renaissance and Baroque painting and the theory of art, died Tuesday at Princeton (N.J.) Hospital of complications after surgery for an aneurism. He was 86 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: PIEDMONT NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
'GLITCHES' DELAY LEGISLATIVE SESSION
description: Last-minute haggling over raises for the State University chancellor and other officials today delayed the start of a lame-duck legislative session.

title: DISPUTE DELAYS U.S. HIGHWAY FUNDS FOR 43 STATES
description: As of today, 43 states are virtually out of Federal interstate highway money and there will be no more interstate grants until Congress approves a formula for distributing $7.2 billion from the highway trust fund.

title: India Is Said to Arrest Policeman in Slaying
description: The police have reportedly arrested a policeman they say ''guided the assassins'' who killed Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: REAGAN TO MEET WITH TUTU AS PROTESTS ON SOUTH AFRICA SPREAD
description: President Reagan will meet Friday with South African Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, a leading critic of Administration policies toward his country, White House sources said today.

title: Surgery for Fouts
description: Dan Fouts, the San Diego Chargers' quarterback, underwent arthroscopic surgery yesterday to repair slightly damaged cartilage in his left knee and will miss the game Sunday against the Denver Broncos. Fouts suffered the damage when he was sacked during a 52-24 loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers on Nov. 25.

title: BIGGEST ETHIOPIAN REFUGEE CAMP IS REPORTED ALMOST OUT OF FOOD
description: Korem, the site of Ethiopia's largest camp for victims of the drought and famine, is now ''critically short of food,'' according to a relief official.

title: SPECIAL PRECAUTIONS USED IN HANDLING TOXIC GAS
description: The chemical that leaked from a pesticide plant in India is subject to violent reactions when contaminated and requires special handling and safety precautions, according to experts.

title: Mrs. Ferraro's Refrigerators The House Ethics Committee correctly concludes that Geraldine Ferraro had no right to withhold information about her husband's finances when she filed annual disclosure statements during her three terms in Congress. It turns out that, contrary to her claims last fall, their assets, liabilities and business dealings were extensively mingled. Had the committee rendered any other judgment it would have torn a huge loophole in the Ethics in Government Act.
description: The committee made a second decision, also correct, to impose no penalty on her. For one thing, it observed, the ethical issue has been ''clouded with some amount of ambiguity.'' For another, the committee is itself remiss for failing in its overseer role since the act was passed in 1978. Closer attention would have meant fewer clouds.

title: NEW FEATURES IN A STEAM IRON
description: An iron recently introduced on the market, the VaporSimac by Simac, has a particularly unusual steam mechanism. The iron is connected to a clear plastic reservoir that holds a liter of standard tap water and allows for three hours of continuous steaming. The water is purified in the reservoir, preventing mineral deposits and eventual rust, which normally clog the steam canals on standard irons.

title: MANAGUA'S CENTRAL PROBLEM
description: The debate in the United States about the crisis in my country, Nicaragua, is dangerously distorted. I have recently traveled across the country, speaking to college students, international affairs experts, labor leaders, businessmen and journalists. I was encouraged to find that the American people seem at last to grasp the importance of what is taking place in Central America. But I was also deeply troubled.

title: JERSEY'S LOTTERY ESTIMATES PRIZE AT $13 MILLION
description: In bus terminals and railroad stations and in lines that snaked along wintry streets, hundreds of thousands of people yesterday bought a chance at winning a record first prize of $13 million in the New Jersey Pick-6 lottery.

title: STUDY CALLS FOR ADMINISTRATOR TO REPLACE NUCLEAR AGENCY
description: The Heritage Foundation has proposed that the independent Nuclear Regulatory Commission be replaced by a Presidentially appointed administrator to keep what it described as a sluggish bureaucracy from snuffing out the ''promise'' of nuclear power.

title: FURTHER EASING BY FED IS SUGGESTED
description: Martha R. Seger, the newest member of the Federal Reserve Board, suggested today that the central bank could move further to relax monetary policy and push down interest rates without undue risk of worsening inflation.

title: NITZE IS APPOINTED ADVISER TO SHULTZ IN GROMYKO TALKS
description: President Reagan announced today that Paul H. Nitze would serve as the adviser of Secretary of State George P. Shultz for next month's arms talks with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union.

title: Still a Knockout
description: The clock may have read 3:48 when Gerrie Coetzee was counted out in the eighth round of his heavyweight title defense against Greg Page at the Sun City resort in South Africa last Saturday night but, as far as the World Boxing Association is concerned, the knockout stands. In a message to South African boxing authorities, Elias Cordova, the chairman of the W.B.A.'s championships committee, said that the panel was satisfied that the fight had been conducted according to the rules, and that the W.B.A. recognized Page ''as a legitimate W.B.A. heavyweight champion.''

title: GIFFORD-HILL CHIEF PONDERING A SALE
description: At first John R. Hill Jr., the chairman and chief executive officer of Gifford-Hill & Company, did not like the idea of selling the cement producer or any part of it.

title: ILC TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ITT Up $2.75; Trading Heavy
description: Shares of the ITT Corporation rose sharply yesterday, apparently fueled by conjecture that the giant conglomerate might liquidate or sell additional assets. The stock jumped $2.75, to $30.25, on a turnover of more than three million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: O'NEILL REFLECTS DEMOCRATIC STRATEGY ON BUDGET CUTS AND TAX REVISIONS
description: In his most conciliatory remarks since the election campaign, House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. has set out the prospect of bipartisan cooperation on the budget and taxes but has insisted that President Reagan take the political risk of publicly initiating controversial policy changes.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1984
description: The Economy

title: 'CARMEN' OPENS SEASON AT LA SCALA TOMORROW
description: La Scala will open its season Friday night with a dark, melancholic version of ''Carmen,'' and the production may serve as something of an analogy for the famed opera house's continuing financial and production problems.

title: XII O'Clock, and All's Well
description: It was just before noon, in an odd and

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: BANKER'S NOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
ETHICS PANEL ORDERS INQUIRY ON REPORTS ON FERRARO CASE
description: The House ethics committee voted unanimously today to investigate how the findings of its report on Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro were disclosed to a Washington newspaper and a national news service before its official release.

title: BETTER WAYS FOR U.N. TO SPEND IN ETHIOPIA
description: To the Editor:

title: Bank Money Accounts
description: Money6-monthMarketC.D.'s(%)(%) Bankers Trust *9.50*9.45 Chase Manhattan *9.14*9.31 Chemical Bank *9.20*9.31 Citibank *8.82*9.03 Manufacturers Hanover *8.87*9.42 Bowery Savings *9.20*9.60 Dime Savings (N.Y.) *9.7010.00 Dollar Dry Dock Savings *9.00*9.76 Goldome 8.87*9.69 Metropolitan Savings *9.5310.24 City Federal (N.J.) 9.06*9.38 First Fidelity (N.J.) 8.57*9.00 Midlantic National (N.J.) 8.60*9.00 United Jersey Banks 8.89*9.47 Connecticut Bank & Trust 8.57*8.58 Connecticut National 8.57*9.33 People's Bank (Conn.) *8.84*9.47 Bank Rate Monitor Index* 9.01*9.44 **Annual effective yields offered by 50 large institutions in the five largest U.S. markets.

title: Smithfield Deal
description: Smithfield Foods Inc. said it had agreed to acquire substantially all of the assets and business, and to assume certain liabilities, of Patrick Cudahy Inc. for about $29 million. Patrick Cudahy, a subsidiary of the Prestige Foods Corporation, is a pork packer and processor based in Cudahy, Wis. Smithfield, which has headquarters in Arlington, Va., said Patrick Cudahy had sales of about $250 million in the last 12 months.

title: ALFIN FRAGRANCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DUQUESNE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MILSTEIN APPROACHES 80 WITH AGELESS ARTISTRY
description: Here is a quote from the kind of review performers dream about, and wait a lifetime to reap in the fullness of their artistic maturity: ''The faultlessness of technique which Mr. Milstein brought to the show-piece might have been anticipated in view of his former accomplishments. But now mechanics had become merely a means to an end with the artist, and he could seemingly forget that aspect so entirely as to rivet his attention solely on publishing the poetical ideas of the work.''

title: SAME CHEMICAL INJURED 31 PEOPLE IN UPSTATE SPILL
description: About 30 students and a teacher suffered eye irritation when the same chemical that killed more than 1,000 people in India spilled three weeks ago from an FMC Corporation plant in Middleport, a small town in western New York.

title: AN ANGUISHED INDIAN CITY MOURNS ITS DEAD
description: Thousands of men, women and children continued to flood the hospitals of this stricken city today two days after gas leaked from an American-owned insecticide plant, reportedly killing more than 1,000 people.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.25-11.50 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Suspect Gives Up in Slaying Of His Wife and Father-in-Law
description: A Bronx man accused of fatally stabbing his estranged wife and his father- in-law and wounding his mother-in-law Saturday surrendered last night at the 42d Precinct station house in the Bronx, the police said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Dialing for Dolor
description: New Yorkers spend a lot of time on

title: American Security WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (Reuters) - The American Security
description: Corporation said it would increase its loan loss provision by about $37 million in the fourth quarter, which would result in a loss for the period. The company said, however, that it expected a modest profit for the year.

title: NATIONWIDE POLICE SPYING IN 60'S DOCUMENTED
description: Scores of police agencies around the country joined the now-defunct Chicago Police Department's ''red squad'' in its efforts to spy on political, civic and antiwar groups in the 1960's, newly released records show.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Dallas Mavericks, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Knicks, fresh from the victory over the Denver Nuggets, meet the Mavericks for the second and final time this season.

title: HERITAGE BANCORP'S 2 NEW BIDS
description: The Heritage Bancorp announced yesterday that it had received two more unsolicited merger offers, this time from Midlantic Banks and the First National State Bancorporation.

title: Cash Infusion For Seabrook
description: A $425 million cash infusion for the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, described by brokers as the largest electric utility financing ever, is scheduled to close today.

title: THEATER MUSEUM DEPICTS STAGE-TO-FILM SUCCESSES
description: Smack in the middle of the Broadway theater district, there is a little museum where visitors can see the wasp-waisted costume Garbo wore in ''Camille,'' watch Bela Lugosi go for the jugular in ''Dracula'' and hear Katharine Hepburn talk about the time Ralph Richardson made an almost irresistible pass at her.

title: QUARTZ ENGINEERING & MAERIALS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $17,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $52,000.

title: TAX PLAN MAY AFFECT BANK RESERVES
description: The Treasury's tax simplification plan appears to conflict with a goal of Federal bank regulators - bigger bank reserves for bad loans.

title: EUROPE CURRENCY UNIT MAY PLAY BIGGER ROLE
description: A move to have the European Currency Unit replace the dollar in many international transactions is expected to gain impetus from decisions taken this week by European heads of government at their summit meeting here.

title: Burt Unlikely to Start
description: Jim Burt, the Giants' nose tackle, watched practice on crutches today.

title: OFFICIAL SAYS ABUSE PlAGUES NAVY SHIP CONTRACTS
description: The Navy officer in charge of fostering competition among contractors acknowledged today that military shipbuilding had been plagued by unrealistically low cost estimates and other contract abuses.

title: MANY PROGRAMS THAT FACE CUTS WIDELY POPULAR
description: The budget proposal that President Reagan presented to his Cabinet today identifies many popular programs for ''reforms, cuts and terminations'' intended to save $24 billion in the next fiscal year.

title: FLORIDA ROCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Msgr. Robert J. White Dead; Catholic U. Law School Dean
description: Msgr. Robert J. White, former dean of the Catholic University School of Law in Washington, died Monday at the Veteran's Administration Hospital in Togus, Me.

title: HOLIDAY SALES AND SHOWS
description: Handmade crafts, clothing and antiques are among the items to be offered at holiday shows and sales this month.

title: Pakistani Outlaws Call for Vote Boycott
description: Gen. Mohammad Zia ul- Haq, the Pakistani leader, issued a decree today making it a crime punishable by up to three years in jail to urge a boycott of elections or a referendum.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It seems to us an extraordinarily incongruous thing that we have a sport in which two people are literally paid to get into a ring and try to beat one another to death, or at least beat them into a state of senselessness, which will then leave them permanently brain-damaged.'' - Dr. Joseph R. Boyle, president of the American Medical Association. (B31:4.)

title: MORTGAGE LOAN RATES DIP AGAIN
description: Interest rates on new home loans dropped for a fourth consecutive month in November, hitting their lowest level since last spring, the Government reported today.

title: BRIEFING ; Suddenly, Secrecy Is 'In'
description: The Senate Select Committee on

title: GALILEO ELECTRO-OPTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $107,000 for the quarter and $708,000 for the year.

title: New York Philomusica
description: The New York Philomusica Chamber Ensemble will perform music by Beethoven, Dvorak and Ezra Laderman at Alice Tully Hall, Broadway and 65th Street, next Wednesday at 8. The concert is sponsored by Philomusica, a nonprofit organization that was formed 13 years ago to provide a forum for the performance and recording of contemporary chamber pieces that are rarely performed.

title: IN APARTMENT NO. 7, A TALE OF THE CITY
description: Several weeks ago Jeffrey Libman switched on his answering machine and left town. ''I knew what would happen when the ad ran,'' he said. ''I didn't want people calling in the middle of the night.''

title: 2 EXECUTIVES PROMOTED BY NEWMONT MINING
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation's board of directors promoted two of the company's top executives yesterday. Newmont said the moves were in contemplation of the ''eventual'' retirement of Plato Malozemoff, its 75-year-old chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Insider Trading Case Centers on Swiss Firm
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is in the midst of the largest insider trading investigation ever conducted by the agency, ''both in terms of the number of securities traded and the amount of possibly illegal profits involved,'' the agency has disclosed in a court filing.

title: NAVRATILOVA UPSET IN AUSTRALIAN OPEN
description: Helena Sukova, a teen-ager from Czechoslovakia, ended Martina Navratilova's hopes of winning a record seventh consecutive Grand Slam tournament today when she defeated the world's top-ranked player, 1-6, 6-3, 7-5, in the semifinals of the $1.28 million Australian Open championship at suburban Kooyong today.

title: POLITICS OF TAXATION MAKESSTRANGE BEDFELLOWS
description: Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, and Ralph Nader, who gained fame at the expense of G.M., are lined up behind the Treasury Department's plan to overhaul the nation's tax system. The National Association of Manufacturers and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. are against it.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Dec. 6, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: No Time to Waste on Solid Waste Today the New York City Board of Estimate must decide whether to authorize Sanitation Department planning for seven high-temperature incineration plants to be built over the next 12 years. Doing so in no way weds the city to specific sites or plant specifications. Not doing so condemns it to perilous delay.
description: The city's landfills are approaching capacity, and without additional disposal plants the prospect of drowning in garbage remains real. Mass burning at high temperature is the safest tested method.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: BY DESIGN The National Academy of Design lays claim to being the first art gallery in New York, having opened its doors in 1825 near City Hall. Since 1940, it has been in a stately and large townhouse gallery building at 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street (369- 4880).

title: 4 Authors Receive Awards at N.Y.U.
description: Four authors received the second annual Elmer Holmes Bobst awards in a ceremony held Tuesday in the Bobst Library at New York University.

title: Drummond Offer
description: The Drummond Coal Company and its Drummond Coals Sales Inc. unit said they would begin a joint tender offer of $75 a share for all shares outstanding of class A common stock and class B common stock of the Alabama By-Products Corporation. Drummond said it owned about 68 percent of the class A stock outstanding and 30.4 percent of the class B stock outstanding. Alabama By-Products, which has a total of about 1.7 million shares outstanding, is principally engaged in the production of coke, primarily foundry coke, and the mining of bituminous coal.

title: YANKS AND A'S COMPLETE DEAL FOR HENDERSON
description: Wheeling and dealing in a style unparalleled at baseball's winter meetings, the Yankees reached agreement with the Oakland A's today on a trade for Rickey Henderson, and sent Rick Cerone to the Atlanta Braves for a minor league pitcher.

title: CITY AND AGENCIES SUED BY GRUMMAN ON BUSES
description: The Grumman Corporation has sued New York City and two local transit agencies for $1 billion over the withdrawal of the company's Flxible buses from service.

title: CALLING ALL CARS
description: WASHINGTON A generation ago, working on a

title: HERS
description: Lately I've been reading about Rita Hayworth. Although she is quite unlike me and of another era, I feel oddly drawn to her. When overseas G.I.'s voted her ''No. 1 Back-Home Glamour Girl'' in 1945, she responded by saying she enjoyed being glamorous: ''After all, a girl is . . . well, a girl. It's nice to be told you're successful at it.''

title: Change Made In Peso Value
description: The daily downward adjustment of the Mexican peso against the United States dollar will increase to 17 centavos, from 13, effective Thursday, the Finance Ministry said.

title: Port Unit Sells Revenue Bonds
description: A $42.5 million issue of San Francisco Port Commission revenue bonds has been offered with a maximum yield of 10.20 percent for 9 1/2 percent bonds due in 2009 that are priced at 93 3/4 by underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: AS DEATH TOLL CLIMBS, INDIA NOW FEARS EPIDEMIC
description: The death toll from the gas leak at the American- owned insecticide plant in this central Indian city was reported today to have risen to at least 1,200 and possibly as high as 2,000.

title: Keep the Pressure on Unesco
description: There's been a distinct change in attitude at Unesco since last December, when the United States gave a year's notice that it was withdrawing. But the policies that provoked the threat have not really changed. Until they do, President Reagan ought to keep up the pressure by vacating America's seat and diverting its $50 million in dues to selected Unesco and other global projects.

title: 2 TEEN-AGERS SEIZED IN KILLING OF 3 BOYS IN STOLEN-CAR CRASH
description: Two Brooklyn teen-agers were arrested yesterday on charges that they struck and killed three teen-age boys while trying to evade the police in a stolen car.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Hospital Supply Corp., Evanston, Ill., said that it expected earnings to increase about 5 percent in 1985 and said again that it expected 1984 earnings to increase 5 percent to 10 percent. In 1983, it earned $211.9 million.

title: 90% Pass Tests In Jersey Schools
description: About 90 percent of the 135,000 third- and sixth-grade students who took standardized reading and mathematics tests during the last school year had passing scores, state education officials said today.

title: STAGE: THE BIG APPLE CIRCUS, AT LINCOLN CENTER
description: AT the Big Apple Circus, the show begins not with a hyperbolic fanfare or a lavish parade but with two riderless horses majestically tossing their heads and prancing around a single ring. Without benefit of rein, the horses dance a graceful equestrian pas de deux.

title: Election Panel Action On Mondale Assailed
description: The Federal Election Commission should have imposed a stiffer fine on Walter F. Mondale's Presidential campaign for the excess spending by its labor-financed delegate committees, one of the commissioners said today.

title: IN DEVASTATED MEXICAN AREA, THE ANGER PERSISTS
description: The fires at the San Juan Ixhuatepec gas storage plant were put out more than two weeks ago, but anger and suspicion continue to be expressed in the small working-class community north of the capital.

title: BRIEFING ; Snakes Fly? Birds Imbibe?
description: The denuding of the area's trees

title: Debt
description: * AMAX Inc.'s $150 million issue of 10-year notes through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman/American Express was given a 14 1/2 percent coupon and priced at par.

title: 'MAY'S MIRACLE,' TONIGHT ON PBS
description: hour film version of ''The Sun Also Rises,'' which begins Sunday at 9 P.M. on Channel 4 (and concludes Monday at 9), have been carefully releasing public explanations that certain liberties have been taken with the Ernest Hemingway novel. Their candor is admirable. Unfortunately, in just about every instance, the changes have been disastrous. Hemingway finally emerges as not only a macho blusterer but also a tedious bore.

title: Milwaukee Acting to Aid Dying Officer's Family
description: The bureaucracy is coming to the aid of a fatally ill police officer whose family could lose a big part of his pension if he dies before Dec. 24, an alderman said today.

title: HOUSE PANEL CALLS C.I.A. MANUAL ILLEGAL
description: The House Intelligence Committee concluded today that the Central Intelligence Agency's guerrilla warfare manual for Nicaraguan rebels violated the law because it advised the rebels on how to overthrow the Sandinista Government.

title: APARTMENT HOUSE FOR THE BLIND, OCCUPIED 4 YEARS, STILL UNFINISHED
description: Four years after the opening of a model, federally financed apartment building for 200 blind and handicapped tenants in Manhattan, some areas of the lobby floor are still under construction, the much-advertised library for the blind and bowling alley have yet to open and relations between the landlord and the tenants are barely civil.

title: NICARAGUA'S 'DREAM' RAILWAY: WILL IT EVER ROLL?
description: The Nicaraguan Government is looking for a donor willing to finance a project that Nicaraguans have dreamed about for more than a hundred years.

title: STALEMATE IN SALVADOR
description: Unless one side or the other changes its position, peace talks between the Government of President Jose Napoleon Duarte and Salvadoran leftist rebels may be stalemated. In two meetings each party has presented proposals that the other has rejected as a demand for surrender. In interviews this week, rebel and Government officials showed little willingness to budge from their initial stands.

title: Woman Allowed Back in U.S.
description: A pregnant woman who was deported to her native Philippines is being allowed to return to the United States after taking the required chest X-ray for tuberculosis, her husband said today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The huge and controversial surplus generated by the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee will probably surpass $170 million, according to Harry Usher , the committee's executive vice president and general manager. . . . The Arizona Wranglers and the Oklahoma Outlaws completed their merger and will now be known as the Arizona Outlaws. Ted Diethrich , who owned the Wranglers, said that he had retained a 25 percent interest in the new team and that the owners of the old Oklahoma club, Bill Tatham and his son Bill Jr, , had acquired the rest. . . . Brian Lawton , the first American-born player ever picked in the National Hockey League draft, was sent to the Minnesota North Stars' minor league team in Springfield, Mass., yesterday. The 19- year-old Lawton had only two goals and five assists in 24 games this season.

title: Rule Called 'Stupid'
description: A Federal judge in Philadelphia said yesterday that he was powerless to overturn a ''stupid'' athletic-eligibility rule even though it would cause ''irreparable harm'' to LaSalle by keeping the school's star center, Albert Butts, from playing his senior season. Accordingly, Judge John Fullam denied a request by Butts for an injunction that would have allowed him to play.

title: SHOP FOR 19TH-CENTURY COLLECTORS
description: What do Gloria Vanderbilt, Yves Saint Laurent and Andy Warhol have in common? All collect Victorian furniture, and they have for years.

title: THEATER: 'AMERICAN NOVEL'
description: THE prospect of a comic colloquy on ''A Good American Novel'' drew one to Performance Space 122 over the weekend to hear the performance artist Beth Lapides in a show of her own devising. Miss Lapides, a spritelike young woman, wears a man's oversize white suit that aspires to fit the wide shoulders of David Byrne. Before she has been properly introduced, she assumes the audience's affability and begins to improvise. In contrast to others of her genre, she presents herself apparently unadulterated by editing and wanders through what's on her mind at the moment.

title: Nagasaki Protests A-Test
description: The city of Nagasaki, which was hit by an American atomic bomb during World War II, protested to the Soviet Union today about a nuclear test in Siberia, a spokesman said. It was the city's 300th such protest since 1970.

title: Chicago Board Meeting School Unions in Strike
description: Raises and the length of the school year were the key obstacles in contract negotiations today, the third day of a strike that has shut the nation's third largest school system.

title: CALENDAR: HANDMADE TOYS AND GAMES
description: Artists' Toys, Vanderwoude Tananbaum Gallery, 24 East 81st Street,

title: FLOURISHING AGAIN: THE VICTORIAN STYLE
description: Never was a style so heartily embraced, later to be so much maligned, as the decorating of Queen Victoria's long reign - 1837 to 1901. It was an era of unabashedly opulent interiors. In both America and Europe the upper classes, and the newly affluent middle class, collected and displayed their possessions with abandon. High Victorian rooms were stuffed with furniture, draped with fabric,hung with a myriad of pictures, and ornamented with bibelots.

title: FINDING THE RIGHT PERIOD HARDWARE
description: Those restoring a Victorian house or creating a 19th-century decor will have decisions to make beyond choosing furniture, fabric or wall coverings - they will have to decide about details.

title: TELECRAFTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including a gain of $55,000 for the quarter and a loss of $3,335,000 for the year from discontinued operations. c-Net loss after a loss of $177,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net income after a loss of $287,000 from discontinued operations.

title: City Plans to Give Out Surplus Food to Needy
description: The city will distribute nearly nine million pounds of Federal surplus food to needy people in the next three weeks, Mayor Koch and the city's Human Resources Administration announced yesterday.

title: ABDUL-JABBAR TO PLAY IN '85-86
description: He has already scored more points, blocked more shots and been named the league's most valuable player more times than anyone else in National Basketball Association history. But tonight, Kareem Abdul- Jabbar said that it wasn't enough.

title: INVITATIONS TO TEEN-AGE SUICIDE IN MUSIC, BOOKS AND MOVIES
description: To the Editor:

title: BALANCHINE MUSINGS ON OTHER BALLETS
description: JUST as composers occasionally base scores upon other composers' themes, so George Balanchine choreographed ballets that were fantasias upon other ballets. He repeatedly created works inspired by ''Raymonda,'' and the New York City Ballet's first week of repertory at the New York State Theater included Balanchine's version of ''Swan Lake (Act II).'' And what a peculiar ''Swan Lake'' it is.

title: MESSAGE TO PRETORIA
description: BOSTON If the white rulers of South Africa

title: 2 A.M.A. OFFICIALS DEPLORE PUBLICITY IN HEART SURGERY EXPERIMENTS
description: As William J. Schroeder, who received an artificial heart 10 days ago, showed continued improvement and began a new phase of exercise today, officials of the American Medical Association added to the heat that has developed around this operation and others.

title: U.S. Bank Withdrawals That Lack Notice Barred
description: A Federal district judge today ordered the Reagan Administration to stop deducting Social Security overpayments from the bank accounts of thousands of elderly Californians without advance notice and a hearing. The Government said it would appeal.

title: REAGAN PROPOSES $34 BILLION SAVING AND PAY CUT OF 5%
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. and other Democrats warily offered cooperation. Page B20.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1984 International The death toll from the gas leak at the Union Carbide insecticide plant in Bhopal, India, was said to have risen to at least 1,200 and possibly as high as 2,000. Medical authorities said a growing concern was the threat of epidemics and unanticipated health problems for the more than 50,000 people believed to have been stricken. (Page A1, Column 1.) Thousands of Indians continued to flood the hospitals of the anguished city of Bhopal two days after the gas leak from the insectide plant. Dozens of infants and children are lying next to each other, crying as they make an effort to breathe. Many victims just sit or lie on the ground. Their eyes are closed in pain, for the gas has caused a burning sensation in the eyes and distorted vision. Some are temporarily blind. (A1:2-4.)

title: No Headline
description: After starting by photographing vanishing architectural ornaments in London and New York, Jessica Strang saw that many of the door knockers and lintel supports were representations of women.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Friday with an article about convertibles misstated the availability of the Ford Ghia Barchetta. It is on display as a prototype only.

title: AIDS BLOOD TEST SET FOR USE
description: One of the first blood tests to detect AIDS virus in humans will be used on as many as 10,000 samples next year, researchers say.

title: ALPINE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $200,000, or 5 cents a share, for the latest 6 months and $1,292,000, or 41 cents a share, for the year-ago period. The company was formerly the Alpine Geophysical Corp.

title: SEAGRAM CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes dividend income from E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company of $37,051,000 for the quarter and $104,100,000 for the 9 months and equity in unremitted earnings of Du Pont of $25,412,000 and $117,353,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After dividend income from Du Pont of $28,112,000 for the quarter and $84,335,000 for the 9 months and equity in unremitted earnings of Du Pont of $32,107,000 and $63,582,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Stay of Execution Ordered in Jersey
description: The State Supreme Court today stayed the execution of a convicted murderer and allowed the State Public Defender's office to pursue an appeal on his behalf.

title: Scali Chosen By Duffy-Mott
description: Cadbury Schweppes, Stamford, Conn., has assigned its

title: ROCK: THE IRISH QUARTET U2 AT RADIO CITY MUSIC HALL
description: -and- roll cathedral on Monday with the appearance of U2, the young Irish quartet whose Christian, antiwar anthems have earned them one of the most devoted followings in rock. That devotion is well- placed.

title: LONG-TERM FOREIGN INVESTMENT FOR MEXICO
description: To the Editor:

title: TINY ISLANDS OFF FLORIDA FEED STREAM OF ILLEGAL ALIENS INTO U.S.
description: The detention camp is on a desolate piece of ground on the edge of the Everglades, 9,000 miles from where Mohammad Ahamad began his journey to the United States.

title: HERMAN ACKMAN
description: Herman Ackman, a New York real- estate executive for 58 years, died of a brain tumor Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Bank Rates Continue Fall
description: Annual effective yields on money market accounts and six-month certificates of deposit continued to decline for the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported. The Monitor's national index of money market accounts fell to 9.01 percent, from 9.14 percent, the lowest level since last April 4.

title: Pipe Rupture at Dam Kills 4
description: A pipe ruptured at a remote hydroelectric power plant today, releasing water that swept four workers to their deaths in the frigid Bear River, utility officials said.

title: MCNEIL TO MISS FINAL GAMES
description: Freeman McNeil, who set a team record for yards gained rushing this year, was declared out for the rest of the season yesterday because of a broken rib. He will miss the Jets' last two games, against the Buffalo Bills Saturday and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers Dec. 16.

title: DANCE: 'COLLAGE,' BY AILEY COMPANY
description: ''COLLAGE,'' choreographed by Donald McKayle, is one of four premieres that the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater presented in October during an evidently fruitful two-week residency period in Kansas City, Mo.

title: GENISCO TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: AGENCY TO ASSESS GENE-SPLICING TEST IN FIELD
description: The National Institutes of Health, responding to a Federal court's injunction, have agreed to assess the probable environmental effects of the first outdoor release of genetically engineered organisms.

title: Korean Investment Off
description: Foreign investment in South Korea fell 36.8 percent, to $9.5 million, in November from a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said today. The ministry said all foreign investment went into seven business projects, mostly joint ventures with Korean interests. During the first 11 months of the year, foreign investment climbed threefold, to $386 million, from the period a year earlier.

title: Bridge:With Both Sides in Auction, ConfusionIsOftentheResult
description: When one partnership monopolizes the auction, almost every simple sequence has a standard meaning. But when both sides are in the act, it is another story: There are many situations that are not covered by the text- books, and even the experts are often groping uncertainly.

title: SHARES OF PHILLIPS SURGE
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company's stock jumped $5.50 a share yesterday, to $53.50, in the wake of Tuesday's offer by T. Boone Pickens and his partners to pay $60 a share for nearly 10 percent of the Oklahoma oil giant.

title: College Basketball ; Georgetown Defeats St. Leo
description: Bill Martin scored 15 points, 13 in the first half, to lead Georgetown to a 76- 56 victory over St. Leo tonight.

title: Blue Bell Closing Plants
description: Two months after Levi Strauss & Company closed its Belgian plant, Blue Bell Inc. said today that it would shut four Wrangler blue jean plants in Limburg province, partly because of shifts in fashion. Blue Bell will also close distribution centers in Belgium, France and the Netherlands, a company official said. Blue Bell employs about 1,000 people in Belgium.

title: A REPAIR SERVICE TO AID THE ELDERLY
description: Not long ago, Walter and Hermine Blume wouldn't have worried about a broken stoop, a burned-out light fixture or a leaky faucet. Mr. Blume could have repaired all those things himself, just as he had paneled the kitchen and the den of the small brick house in Queens the couple have owned for 27 years.

title: MATERIAL SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Rape Trial Is Moved After Victim Is Killed
description: A judge agreed Tuesday to move the trial of a man charged with raping a 14- year-old girl after he was also charged with the girl's murder.

title: Soldiers in Sri Lanka Are Reported to Kill 85
description: Soldiers killed at least 85 people, most of them Tamil civilians, in reprisal for a land mine explosion that killed one soldier and wounded six others, residents and hospital officials said today.

title: Jackson Deciding
description: A leg injury kept Bo Jackson from making a run at the Heisman Trophy this season, but the Auburn running back will have another chance next season. Or will he? Asked if he would be back for his senior season, Jackson told The Atlanta Constitution that he hadn't made a decision.

title: How Mesa Avoided Disclosure
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company, in partnership with the Wagner & Brown oil company, was able to secretly amass 8.8 million shares of the Phillips Petroleum Company - without getting approval from Federal regulators - because of a loophole in the antitrust laws.

title: MUSIC: JAN DEGAETANI IN CARNEGIE DEBUT
description: UNTIL Tuesday night, Jan DeGaetani had never sung a recital at Carnegie Hall. She had, however, done virtually everything else one would expect of a widely admired singer with an attractive voice, superlative musicianship, linguistic mastery, an interest in offbeat repertory and a particular gift for interpreting problematic contemporary vocal music.

title: 65 CHARGED IN SCHEME TO SELL MILITARY EQUIPMENT ON COAST
description: A Federal indictment unsealed Tuesday accused 65 people, most of them marines on active duty, of conspiring to steal and sell military equipment to surplus stores.

title: ESTIMATE BOARD DELAYS DECISION ON INCINERATORS
description: The Board of Estimate decided yesterday not to vote this week on a resolution committing the city to building a citywide network of huge garbage incinerators in the decades to come.

title: PLIGHT OF THE ELDERLY DRAWING CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: The elderly poor seem especially vulnerable and in need of help during the holiday season, and gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund often reflect concern for their plight.

title: WRONG SOLUTION TO WELFARE-PAYMENT PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil Exceeds Trade Targets BRASILIA, Dec. 5 (AP) -
description: Trade balance figures released

title: CHINESE CITY FINDS ITS PAST IS WORTH SAVING
description: During the Ming dynasty six centuries ago, the ancient city of Xian threw up massive earthen ramparts to protect itself from invaders.

title: GRANT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
EXECUTIVES
description: * Allegheny International, Pittsburgh, has named James R. Allen president of IPM Corp., a subsidiary that makes powder metal parts.

title:
MARKET PLACE;
ALLIED STORES' STOCK ACTIVITY
description: THE Allied Stores Corporation, generally considered a low-profile company and perhaps a

title: SEXUAL BIAS: ALICE IN COWBOY LAND
description: Nearly 90 percent of the secretaries and clerical personnel at the World Bank are women, but women occupy less than 3 percent of its ''senior level'' positions. At the Inter-American Development Bank there are 33 jobs in the ''Executive'' category. One is held by a woman.

title: RECOGNITION EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After tax credits of $134,000 for the quarter and $564,000 for the year. c-After a gain of $5,752,000. d-After a tax credit of $1,275,000. The year-ago quarter and year nets include a pre-tax gain of $1,554,000 from patent licensing.

title: 'CLEANING' GAS FROM GARBAGE
description: OREGON CITY IGNORING the mud on his wingtip shoes, John

title: See-Through Pantaloons, Circa 1919
description: Miss America was

title: THE ONLT GIFT HE COULD GIVE
description: THIS time last year Frank M.'s

title: GOLDWATER FOR ARMS BUDGET LID
description: Senator Barry M. Goldwater, the Arizona Republican who is expected to become the new chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, says President Reagan should freeze military spending for the 1986 fiscal year at the current year's level and should abandon efforts to win approval for continued production of the MX missile.

title: A SOVIET PRECEDENT FOR CHINA'S LATEST LEAP
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. Studying Yonkers Hanging
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it had opened an investigation into the hanging death of a suspected marijuana dealer in the Yonkers city jail.

title: 3d-Party Fees Spur Inquiries
