description: Both the Securities and Exchange Commission, which has jurisdiction over money management organizations, and the Labor Department, which oversees the nation's pension plan system, are investigating the use of brokerage commissions to pay for third-party services.

title: Iraq Repeats Vow to Attack Tankers Sailing to Iran Ports
description: Iraq today repeated its threat of air and sea attacks on tankers stopping at Iranian ports.

title: Turkey's Trade Deficit
description: Turkey's foreign trade deficit narrowed to $2.85 billion in the first 10 months of this year, down 4.6 percent from the period of 1983, the Statistics Institute said today. The agency said exports totaled $5.71 billion in the period, while imports totaled $8.43 billion.

title: BRITAIN IS FORCED TO RESCIND PROPOSALS TO CUT STUDENT AID
description: A protest by middle-class students and their parents over proposed cuts in student aid has handed Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher a major policy setback.

title: Seagram Profit Edges Up 1.7% By The Associated Press The Seagram Company Ltd.
description: said yesterday that net income

title: Anchor Hocking To Close Plant
description: The Anchor Hocking Corporation said it plans to close a Lancaster glassware plant by mid-1985. The shutdown would cause the company to lose about $23 million in the fourth quarter and affect 650 employees.

title: Canada's Trade Stance
description: Canada remains committed to the idea of freer trade with the United States, despite concern voiced by its trade partners, Canada's External Trade Minister, James Kelleher, said today. Mr. Kelleher, in Paris for trade talks with the French, said he had tried to reassure Canada's Japanese and Common Market trading partners by reaffirming the country's commitment to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the international trade forum based in Geneva.

title: PRESIDENT RESIGNING AT HOUGHTON MIFFLIN
description: Richard W. Young, the 58-year-old president of the Houghton Mifflin Company for the last two years, said yesterday that he would resign at the end of this year.

title: RECITAL: STEPHEN DICKSON
description: STEPHEN DICKSON is one of the more visible participants in Affiliate Artists' program for young performers. Mr. Dickson is not a beginner, and his operatic baritone has been welcomed in London, Santa Fe, Washington and New York. Sunday afternoon he sang a collection of songs at Carnegie Recital Hall with Levering Rothfuss as the pianist.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Commercial Mortgages Used to Back C.M.O.'s
description: The first issue of collateralized mortgage obligations backed by commercial mortgages was announced earlier this week by the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company and Salomon Brothers.

title: CABLE TV DELAYED TO '86 FOR THE OUTER BOUROUGHS
description: The long-delayed expansion of cable television to the boroughs outside Manhattan is now at least another year behind schedule, with service not expected to begin before 1986, city officials said yesterday.

title: CBS PRODUCER TESTIFIES AS A 'HOSTILE WITNESS'
description: Beginning a new phase of their case, lawyers for Gen. William C. Westmoreland called to the stand as a ''hostile witness'' yesterday the CBS producer who was chiefly responsible for the 1982 documentary on Vietnam that is the subject of the general's $120 million libel suit.

title: Zaire Leader Starts 3d Term
description: President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire was sworn in to a third seven-year term of office today.

title: 13.47 DROP PUTS DOW AT 1,171.60
description: The stock market plunged yesterday, with sharp price drops in some large-capitalization issues. Trading remained in the doldrums, although somewhat busier than on Tuesday.

title: RIGHTS COALITION SEEN AS REVIVING IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Organizers of the daily protests in front of the South African Consulate in Manhattan say they believe that the apartheid issue has suddenly unified the city's black community and revitalized an old coalition of civil-rights leaders, union activists and a variety of religious groups.

title: MATERIALS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Net losses.

title: Japanese Steel Curb
description: Japan has agreed to limit its shipments of carbon steel to the United States, David Demerest, a spokesman for Bill Brock, the United States Trade Representative, said today. Details were still being negotiated in Washington with Kadzuo Wakasuki, Japan's Vice Minister for Trade and Ministry, Mr. Demerest said.

title: AMERICAN REPORTED SLAIN ON JET FORCED TO IRAN By The Associated Press
description: Five hijackers holding a Kuwaiti airplane at the airport in Teheran said today that the hostage they had shot and killed was an American diplomat, the Iranian press agency reported. American officials said they could not confirm the report.

title: A.M.A., CITING DANGER, ASKS ABOLITION OF BOXING
description: The American Medical Association adopted a resolution today calling for the abolition of boxing, both amateur and professional, and urging medical groups throughout the country to lobby for state laws banning the sport because of ''the dangerous effects of boxing on the health of participants.''

title: THE RETAIL WORRIES IN MIAMI
description: More than a week into the Christmas season, this city's big retailers speak in glowing terms about their efforts to improve service and upgrade the quality - and prices - of the merchandise they are selling.

title: Penthouse Strikes Deal With French Publisher
description: Remember back in February 1979 when Daniel Filapacchi, the wonder man of French magazine publishing, tried to bring back the old Look over here and failed. Well, 18 months ago back home he started a magazine called Newlook, which is also photo journalism, but with plenty of pictures of nude females.

title: SUPREME COURT HEARS ARGUMENT ON AID TO PAROCHIAL SCHOOLS
description: The Supreme Court turned again to church- state issues today and explored the permissible limits of governmental aid to parochial schools.

title: STREET INCIDENT STUDIED AS LINK TO ROOF MURDER
description: Less than an hour before a 23-year- old drama student was fatally stabbed last Sunday on the roof of her Manhattan apartment building, a man fitting the general description of her killer approached another young woman on a street nearby, the police said yesterday.

title: AT 28, HE'S KING OF THE ROAD
description: The good ol' boys have finally

title: REAGAN RELEASES WHEAT FOR AFRICA
description: President Reagan, citing the existence of ''a major disaster,'' today directed the emergency release of 300,000 tons of wheat worth about $50 million from the country's food-security reserve for relief to victims of the drought in Ethiopia and elsewhere in sub-Saharan Africa.

title: ANGIOMEDICS INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-The company went public in August and revenue for the previous year was not available.

title: TOY MAKER TO REMOVE 'SCHIZOPHRENIC' LABEL
description: A toy manufacturer, saying it used ''poor judgment'' in marketing a new doll as a schizophrenic adversary of its G.I. Joe soldier doll, will try to make amends by donating money to mental-health research.

title: Hong Kong Pact Endorsed
description: The British Parliament early today approved without dissent a draft agreement on the return of Hong Kong to China when the lease on most of the colony expires in 1997.

title: E.P.A. PLANS POLLUTION TAX FOR HEAVY TRUCKS
description: Heavy trucks and engines that do not meet Federal exhaust emission standards would be faced with a pollution tax the Government is ready to propose with the support of industry and environmental groups.

title: Temple U. Student Dies Here In Apparent Suicide Plunge
description: A Temple University student from India, despondent over his expulsion from the school, plunged four stories to his death yesterday morning from a Hare Krishna temple in Brooklyn Heights, according to the police.

title: FRENCH ENVOY GIVES PLAN FOR ACCORD ON PACIFIC ISLE
description: A special French envoy, hoping to end two weeks of violent clashes between loyalists and independence-seeking Melanesians, announced a three-point program today for working out an accord between the two groups on this French island territory in the South Pacific.

title: Ford Sees Good Chance Tax Rise Will Be Asked
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford said today that there was ''at least a 50-50 chance'' President Reagan would seek a tax increase to reduce the Federal deficit adequately.

title: THE COURT AND THE SWITCH
description: Alpha O. Stephens, a black man who is a convicted murderer, may die in Georgia's electric chair next Wednesday even though the state's capital punishment law may unconstitutionally discriminate against blacks. His case is the latest abomination in the United States Supreme Court's relentless march to get on with the death penalty.

title: Beatrice Expands
description: The Beatrice Companies said it had acquired the Dr Pepper Bottling Company of Southern California from the parent Dr Pepper Company.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Teaching the Language
description: There was no universal language at

title: 30 Said to Die as Youths Battle in Madagascar
description: About 30 people were killed and several others were hurt Tuesday when kung fu devotees clashed with unemployed youths here, the Madagascar radio reported today.

title: WORKERS AT SITE OF LEAK DESCRIBED AS UNSKILLED
description: A top-level manager at the American-owned pesticide plant in central India where poison gas leaked out Monday said the accident had occurred while the outside of the storage tank was being cleaned by unskilled workers, an Indian newspaper reported today.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: Even though a house is properly heated, poor design or careless construction may have left some pipes susceptible to freezing. Pipes or fittings may crack and cause extensive damage when they thaw.

title: Cash Exchange Hires Korey, Kay & Partners
description: The New York Cash Exchange, made up of eight banks that have agreed to allow their depositors to have access to the automatic tellers of all the group's members, has hired Korey, Kay & Partners to promote the service. The ad budget for the first three months of the program beginning next March is set at about $1.5 million.

title: Employee at a Du Pont Lab Is Killed in Domestic Dispute
description: A gunman scaled a fence and burst into a Du Pont Company laboratory Tuesday, killing former companion the day after she had warned security guards to look out for the man, with whom she had quarreled, the authorities said.

title: UNITED STATES CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,139,000 from the sale of a unit and a loss of $343,000 from other operations. c-Net loss

title: A Glint From the Bronze Age Plunder, fire or earthquake have destroyed so many human habitations that almost nothing from far antiquity remains untouched. Robbers ancient and modern rifled all the Pharaohs' tombs except that of Tutankhamun, the least significant of early Egypt's rulers. Pyramids apart, the Seven Wonders of the ancient world are all rubble or, like the Colossus of Rhodes, so entirely vanished that even their sites are uncertain.
description: Amid this desolation, the shipwreck now discovered off the south coast of Turkey is a treasure trove. Protected by the sea's silt, it has lain undisturbed for more than three millennia, until excavated this summer by American and Turkish archeologists.

title: WRONG SOLUTIONS TO WELFARE-PAYMENTS PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: SHARON NOT A MURDERER, WRITER SAYS
description: David Halevy, a Time magazine correspondent, declared in a dramatic moment on the witness stand yesterday that he did not regard Ariel Sharon as a murderer.

title: Peres Visiting Paris To Seek French Support
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel arrived here today on a four-day visit aimed at enlisting French support.

title: LEGAL SERVICES CHIEF ELECTED
description: William Clark Durant 3d, a Detroit lawyer, was elected chairman of the Legal Services Corporation today and said in an interview that he hoped to end the ''breakdown in the relationship with Congress'' that has plagued the program.

title: Consumers Power Payout JACKSON, Mich., Dec. 5
description: Directors of the Consumers Power Company today

title: LONG-TERM EFFECTS OF GAS UNKNOWN
description: Without previously known cases of severe exposure to the gas released by an insecticide plant in India early Monday, specialists in industrial hygiene found it difficult yesterday to predict the long-term effects on tens of thousands of residents who survived inhalation of the gas.

title: Taiwan Mine Explosion Kills 2 and Traps 93
description: A coal mine explosion near Taipei killed two miners today and trapped 93 others deep underground, the police said. It was the third major mine accident in Taiwan in six months.

title: Georgia Federal
description: Georgia Federal Bank said it had signed an agreement to acquire all of the stock of First Family Financial Services H.C. Inc., a subsidiary of the First Atlanta Corporation, for $36 million. First Family, a consumer finance company, operates in nine states and has total assets of about $150 million. Georgia Federal said it expected to complete the transaction by Jan. 2.

title: CHILEAN JUDGE INDICTS POLICEMAN
description: A judge investigating the killing of a French Roman Catholic priest, the Rev. Andre Jarlan, during anti-Government protests in September indicted a policeman on charges of manslaughter today, the church's lawyer said.

title: CITY'S FIRST SNOWSTORM OF SEASON FORCES KOCH HELICOPTER TO LAND
description: The first snowstorm of the season dropped from one to four inches of heavy wet snow on the New York metropolitan area last night and forced an Army helicopter carrying Mayor Koch from a speaking engagement at West Point to make an emergency landing.

title: GULFSTREAM LAND & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WOMEN'S IMAGE ON TV IMPROVING
description: Women have begun to achieve a better image on network television, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Commission on Working Women. The report said women portrayed on television are no longer predominantly ''young, white, single, beautiful,'' but have begun to achieve what roles that show ''leadership, authority and courage.''

title: TESTIMONY DELAYED FOR CRITICS OF JERSEY HEALTH COST SYSTEM
description: After a top aide to Governor Kean called the chairman of an Assembly committee prior to a hearing last week examining the state's system of containing health care costs, testimony from critics of the state's system was delayed until after the first of the year.

title: PARLOR PALMS FROM TURN OF THE CENTURY
description: No 19th-century parlor was considered complete without house plants. It was a fashionable obsession to harbor greenery indoors. Victorians crowded their rooms with ornate ceramic jardinieres and filled them with pots contained the latest tropical treasures introduced by returning botanists and plant explorers.

title: BAN ON BOSTON SEWER HOOKUPS IS OVERTURNED
description: A Massachusetts Supreme Court justice today overturned a ban on new connections to the Boston area sewer system, but a Federal environmental official said he would ask a Federal judge to reimpose the ban.

title: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1.2 million. c-Including a gain of $25.6 million from the liquidation of the company's marketable securities portfolio and a gain of $4.6 million from discontinued operations.

title: Q & A
description: Q.

title: Reader's Digest
description: The Reader's Digest confirmed yesterday that it was switching its approximately $1 million trade advertising account to Henderson, Friedlich, Graf & Doyle, following James D. Parry, who had been chief creative man on the business at Posey, Parry & Quest in Greenwich, Conn. The biggest part of the Digest's promotion, which is for circulation, is at J. Walter Thompson.

title: First Words
description: It must have been quite a piece of apple pie, because when Ed Reinhardt had finished it, he said, ''I'm full.'' It was a routine enough comment except for one fact: Those were the first words that Reinhardt, the Colorado tight end, had spoken since he suffered a severe head injury in a game against Oregon on Sept. 15 and fell into a coma. According to Craig Hospital in Denver, the words were spoken during last week, as Reinhardt continued to improve on a program of rehabilitation that began last month.

title: SCOUTING ; Lesson for Lanier
description: Bob Lanier spent 14 seasons in the National Basketball Association, nine and a half of them with the Detroit Pistons. But it is the Milwaukee Bucks, the team for which he played the remaining four and a half, that is retiring his No. 16 tonight, at a game against Detroit.

title: MUSIC: RUDOLF SERKIN AND BEETHOVEN
description: RUDOLF SERKIN'S annual recital at Carnegie Hall has taken on a ritualistic tone. The pianist's approach to music and his instrument is devout, all but priestly, and his audience attends to him with the seriousness of a congregation that expects nothing less than high revelation.

title: Read It and Weep
description: Ralph Nader yesterday issued 5,000 copies of ''The General Motors Lemon Grover,'' which he described as a compilation, to be published annually, of letters from disgruntled owners of cars made by the General Motors Corporation.

title: JAZZ: RUBY BRAFF AT WEST END
description: NEW YORKERS who want to hear the distinctively dark colors and urgently singing lines of Ruby Braff's cornet usually have to go across the Hudson River to Struggles, the jazz club in Edgewater, N. J. But this week through Saturday his followers need go no farther than the West End Cafe, Broadway at 113th Street, where Mr. Braff is making one of his rare Manhattan appearances in the company of the Scott Hamilton Quintet.

title: VALTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $238,598 from the termination of a pension plan for the quarter and 6 months.

title: People
description: * Lewis G. Green named vice president-sales at Metropolitan Sunday Newspapers.

title: KULICKE & SOFFA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHESS: DRAW IN 20 MOVES
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov agreed to a draw today after 20 moves in the 30th game of their world chess championship match.

title: NOW MUSEUMS CHERISH 19TH-CENTURY OBJECTS
description: It was in the 1980's - so the historians

title: THE ATTRACTIONS OF PHILLIPS
description: In the past, T. Boone Pickens has laid out several criteria that energy companies would have to meet before he would try to take them over.

title: WIEBOLDT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A FLURRY OF CORPORATE ISSUES
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday as a lack of investor activity and an uncertain rate outlook combined to keep trading volume low in the Treasury market.

title: AMREP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a payment of 25 percent stock dividend in November 1984.

title: Oregon Judge Overturns Ban On South African Investment
description: A judge has overturned a 1977 decision by the Oregon Board of Higher Education not to invest in companies that do business in South Africa.

title: THE 'ANTIHUNTERS' TAKE TO THE CONNECTICUT WOODS
description: The woods are deep, and these are people with promises to keep.

title: CUCOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-The company said the comparable year-ago results are not meaningful because it adopted a new fiscal year.

title: ENGINEERING MEASUREMENTS COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FAMILIAR GROUND. By Elizabeth Cox. 220 pages. Atheneum. $14.95. SARAH PHILLIPS. By Andrea Lee. 117 pages. Random House. $12.95.

title: Tri-Star Offering Withdrawn
description: Tri-Star Pictures, a motion picture company backed by three giants in the entertainment business, announced yesterday that it had withdrawn an initial public offering of 4.5 million shares of common stock because of market conditions.

title: DEL ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: RANGERS, CALGARY PLAY TO A STANDOFF
description: The Rangers earned a point in the standings by gaining a 4-4 tie last night with the improved Calgary Flames at Madison Square Garden, and although it was not exactly a coming together for the team, it was one of their snappier showings in recent weeks.

title: Accounts
description: * Character Licensing, an ITT subsidiary, to Kolker & Gill to promote Raggedy Ann & Andy.

title: Mullin's Foul Shots Set Back Fordham
description: The fun-and-gun style that characterized St. John's first two games this season gave way last night to a conservative, almost snail-like contest against Fordham.

title: HOUSE OF FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Children's Holiday Program
description: Jacques d'Amboise will join with performers from the National Theater for the Deaf and the Broadway musical ''Cats'' on Dec. 20 at noon at the Vivian Beaumont Theater for Lincoln Center's ''Meet the Artist'' holiday children's program.

title: SCOUTING ; Commuter Coach
description: There could be no better illustration of the way the sports world has changed over the years than the story that Bob Davies told yesterday at a Madison Square Garden luncheon.

title: SCOUTING ; Orange Bowl Pair Bidding for No. 1
description: Danny Bradley, the Oklahoma quarterback, doesn't try to be diplomatic about it. He believes that the Sooners are the finest college football team in the United States, and never mind undefeated Brigham Young's top ranking in the news-agency polls, both of which place Oklahoma second.

title: VAIL ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CML GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
FIRSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $75,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Including extraordinary credits of $100,000 for the quarter and $500,000 for the 9 months.

title: Man Fails to Save 4 Children
description: A farmer who smelled smoke as he was milking his cows before down today rammed his pickup truck through a sliding-glass door in an unsuccessful attempt to rescue his four children from their burning house, the authorities said. The bodies of three boys and a girl ranging in age from 7 to 14 years old were found in their bedrooms, a coroner's spokesman said. The parents, Mr. and Mrs. Louis Chaves, were taken to a hospital for treatment of smoke inhalation, burns and shock.

title: BRIEFING ; As Conable Sees It
description: In a ''Hail and Farewell'' letter to

title: SYNTREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $526,000 for the quarter and $747,000 for the year. c-After an extraordinary credit of $552,000.

title: PHILLIPS BID IS BLOCKED BY COURT
description: A state district court judge in Oklahoma has granted the Phillips Petroleum Company a temporary restraining order blocking T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, from going ahead with plans to take over the company, Phillips said yesterday.

title: FIRESTONE TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $5 million for the quarter and $13 million for the year and a gain from discontinued operations of $26 million for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $5 million for the quarter and $12 million for the year and extraordinary credits of $8 million for the quarter and $11 million for the year.

title: American Can Bid
description: The American Can Company said it had agreed to acquire the Reliable Corporation, a direct marketer of office products.

title: DEAK & CO. FILES FOR CHAPTER 11
description: Deak & Company, the holding company for one of the country's oldest and largest foreign exchange and precious metal dealers with branches worldwide, surprised the investment community yesterday by filing to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code.

title: Military Chief in Pakistan
description: Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, arrived in Pakistan today to discuss the situation in Afghanistan with Government officials. He will be here for six days.

title: SUPREME EQUIPMENT & SYSEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $435,000.

title: Quick Goals Top Cosmos EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 6 (UPI) - Nathan Sacks and
description: Willie Molano scored third-period goals 18 seconds apart to break a 2-2

title: Apollo Stompers
description: The pianist Jaki Byard and his big band, the Apollo Stompers, will perform tonight and tomorrow at 10 P.M. and midnight at the Jazz Cultural Theatre, 368 Eighth Avenue above 28th Street (244-0997). Admission is $8.

title: REAGAN, CABINET SET JAPAN TRADE PARLEY
description: President Reagan will meet with his Cabinet next week to try to shape a comprehensive strategy for dealing with the record trade deficit with Japan, Administration officials said today.

title: REAGAN PROPOSALS TO CURB SPENDING WOULD AFFECT ALL
description: The domestic spending reductions President Reagan endorsed Wednesday would touch more than 100 types of programs and would fall on Americans in every walk of life.

title: '2010,' PURSUES THE MYSTERY OF '2001'
description: THE film ''2010'' is a perfectly adequate though not really comparable - sequel to Stanley Kubrick's witty, mind- bending science-fiction classic, ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' That film, a dazzling invention, was as much about the prepackaged, Musak-orchestrated, flash-frozen consumer society of 1968, and about our primordial past, as it was about our dreams of the future.

title: FOR CHILDREN TO LOOK AT AND JOIN IN
description: BIGGER than life, they loom in the main gallery of the Queens Museum - brides and bridegrooms, kings and drummers, even a woman in curlers. They stand, wooden and stoic, until the tug of a string sets a hand in motion, then a leg. Suddenly, the arcade is bubbling with the imagination of children, bringing the puppets to life.

title: Smucker Accord
description: The J.M. Smucker Company said it had agreed to acquire Knudsen & Sons Inc. The price was not disclosed. Knudsen, which is closely held, produces pure fruit juices distributed in health food stores and supermarkets. Smucker, which makes preserves, jellies and fruit syrups, said that when the deal was completed Knudsen would operate as a subsidiary under the direction of William R. Knudsen, president.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Weekend on Oct. 26, about celebrating Halloween, incorrectly described the captaincy of the sloop Clearwater. The captain was Peg Brandon. Pete Seeger, the folk singer, was aboard as a passenger only.

title: LEASING CONSULTANTS reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''Wasn't this just magic?'' said Donna Hentic as she held her 2 1/2-year-old son, Frank, in her arms and waltzed around the promenade of the New York State Theater. The occasion was the seventh annual Christmas ballet party to aid the Spence-Chapin Services to Families and Children and the School of American Ballet, and hundreds of children accompanied by their mothers and a few fathers arrived wearing their picture-postcard holiday best: Eton suits, knickers and ruffled shirts for boys; velvet dresses or smocked cottons for girls. The 750 guests feasted on sandwiches and brownies and watched excerpts from ''The Nutcracker'' performed by children and several adults, including Patricia McBride, Kyra Nichols and Christopher d'Amboise.

title: Marcos Daughter Calls The Palace a 'Snake Pit'
description: A daughter of President Ferdinand E. Marcos who represents her family's district in the National Assembly today called the presidential palace ''a snake pit'' and said abuses had been committed by people close to her family.

title: DANIEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a nonrecurring pretax charge of $8 million for a loss on disposition of certain assets. c-Net income.

title: West German Prices
description: West Germany's cost of living climbed two-tenths of 1 percent in November from October and 2.1 percent from November 1983, the Federal Statistics Office said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; A Midtown Beach
description: At a construction site on the northeast corner of Eighth Avenue and 50th Street, a pile of sand stood alongside a concrete mixer.

title: Dioxin Cleanup Process Reported a Success
description: Officials of a New Jersey concern said today that they had proved an electrical process could safely remove toxic dioxin from contaminated soil, but state officials expressed caution about its providing a quick solution to Missouri's dixion problems.

title: Advertising ; Ad Inserts A Concern Of Editors
description: A growing phenomenon in American magazine publishing circles is the so-called advertorial insert, and at a workshop at the Harvard Club yesterday it was obvious that while they may have become an important advertising revenue source, they are viewed with great suspicion by editors.

title: CITIZENS GROWTH PROPERTIES (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $171,000 for the quarter and $776,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $34,000 for the quarter and $199,000 for the 9 months.

title: 45-Year Sentence In Heroin Case
description: Rosario Gambino was sentenced today to 45 years for heroin trafficking amid prosecution charges that he had harbored Michele Sindona five years ago while the Italian banker was a fugitive in a $400 million fraud case.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If you could dream it, it's possible.'' - Doug Flutie, Boston College quarterback and winner of Heisman Trophy this year. (D28:4.)

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Milwaukee Bucks retired Bob Lanier 's uniform No. 16 during a halftime ceremony last night. Lanier ended his career last Sept. 24 after 14 seasons, the last four and a half with the Bucks. In last night's game, the Bucks beat Lanier's former team, the Detroit Pistons, 114-99, behind 27 points each by Sidney Moncrief and Terry Cummings . . . . Jerry Grote , former Met catcher, has been named manager of the Detroit Tigers farm club at Lakeland of the Florida State League, a Class A league.

title: Shapiro/Budrow
description: Globus-Gateway and Cosmos- Tourama, both tour operators that are subsidiaries of Group Voyagers of Lugano, Switzerland, have retained Shapiro/Budrow & Associates as their first ad agency.

title: FUND FOR ARMY BIOLOGICAL WARFARE UNIT APPROVED
description: A Senate subcommittee today approved funds to expand the Army's biological warfare research, circumventing the objections of a ranking Democrat.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.25-11.50 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Woman, 76, Slain in Home
description: A 76-year-old woman was found stabbed to death in her Washington Heights apartment last night by a neighbor after the woman failed to show up for a scheduled meeting, Sgt. Ed Burns, a police spokesman said.

title: FOR CHILDREN TO LOOK AT JOIN IN
description: THEATERS are filled with magic and mystery during this holiday season, from the magic of Avner, a wide-eyed, loveable character in a one-man show being presented at the Lamb's Theater, to the mysteries revealed to Amahl, the boy in Gian Carlo Menotti's opera about the brilliant star in the East and the three night visitors, which has become a Christmas favorite since it first appeared more than three decades ago.

title: BISHOPS CRITICIZE PRETORIA'S POLICE
description: South Africa's Roman Catholic bishops accused the country's policemen today of indiscriminately killing and beating civilians like ''an occupying foreign army controlling enemy territory'' in their efforts to quell unrest that has racked black townships since September.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Music From Japan
description: Today - of all days - Music From

title: BROADWAY
description: ALMOST anything can happen in the theater and most of the time it does. Still, it isn't too often that an infant acts like a full- fledged adult, which is just what the less than two-year-old Mirror Theater Company is doing.

title: AUSTRIA TO AUCTION ART CONFISCATED BY NAZIS
description: The Austrian Government will auction 3,900 paintings, sculptures and art objects that were confiscated by the Nazis during World War II, most of which have been kept by Austria in a monastery near Vienna since 1955, a Government official said yesterday.

title: On the Sidelines
description: A day after their starting center Kareem Abdul-Jabbar decided to play another season, the Los Angeles Lakers said that the 6-foot-11-inch rookie Earl Jones, their top draft choice last spring, has a fractured right ankle and could miss the rest of the season.

title: Taxi Policy in Low Gear
description: New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission seems to be trapped in traffic of its own design. Even as it moves in some right directions - to enforce safety rules on gypsy cabs and to ban radio service by yellow cabs - it proposes to crawl to its destination.

title: FIRE-GUTTED QUEENS HOUSING RESTORED WITH TAX AID
description: On the heels of a historic-district designation in Ridgewood, Queens, last year has come a housing rehabilitation that demonstrates the power of tax incentives to stimulate new investment in older neighborhoods.

title: SUTTER EXPECTED TO ACCEPT BRAVES' $9.6 MILLION OFFER
description: Bruce Sutter, the National League's No. 1 relief pitcher, is scheduled to meet Friday with Ted Turner, the owner of the Atlanta Braves, and is expected to sign the most lucrative contract ever given a pitcher.

title: 350 Nicaraguans in Protest Against U.S. Help for Rebels
description: More than 350 persons marched peacefully today in protest against the United States for its support of rebels who are said to have kidnapped several teachers last month.

title: BEST PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Net income.

title: WINDOWS THAT LIGHT UP THE HOLIDAYS
description: THEY'RE Off Broadway productions, mounted on some of the most expensive real estate in the world. But they have no stars, opening night doesn't mean a thing and nothing as crass as money or credit cards changes hands. As for the critics, let's just say that even a jaundiced eye can't kill these shows but, on the other hand, the most ecstatic reviews won't extend their limited runs.

title: DUARTE OFFERS A CHRISTMAS CEASE-FIRE
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador said today that he is prepared to suspend military operations at Christmas if guerrilla forces agree.

title: U.S. SAYS CITIES CAN PUT AN END TO BUSING PLANS
description: The Justice Department told a Federal appeals court for the first time today that a school board could eliminate a court-ordered busing plan and said the board was free to return to a neighborhood school system even if ''less racial balance'' resulted.

title: Appeals Court Upholds U.S. Meat Regulation
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Wednesday upheld a lower court's ruling in favor of a Federal regulation permitting the use of machines to separate bones from meat to make hot dogs, bologna and similar products.

description: LatestPreviousYearWeekWeekAgo Monetary Aggregates M-1*as of Nov. 26 217,100 R 216,200 n.a. Reserve Position, Eight New York Banks Daily averages for two weeks ended Dec. 5 Excess (Deficit) Reserves (Incl. carryover) 43 (36)n.a. Borrowings at Federal Reserve 264 187 n.a.
