title: Firestone's Net Slumps
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said today that earnings in its fiscal fourth quarter, ended Oct. 31, fell 52.8 percent because of competitive pricing, higher costs and a shortage of tires for passenger cars.

title: REAGAN'S WINTRY BUDGET TALK NUMBS CONGRESS
description: Back in the warmth of summer and early fall, President Reagan derided Walter F. Mondale as the prophet of ''defeatism, decline and despair'' and ridiculed the Democratic nominee as the leader of a ''pack of pessimists'' who were offering the American people a diet of bad news.

title: 10 MILITANTS DIE IN CLASH ON FRENCH ISLE
description: Ten Melanesian separatists were killed Wednesday in the worst case of violence in more than two weeks of strife in this French territory in the South Pacific, the police said today.

title: Bird Walk in Queens
description: Birdwatchers are invited to join an early morning bird walk sponsored by the Alley Pond Environmental Center, 228-06 Northern Boulevard, Douglaston, Queens, at 8:30 tomorrow.

title: Applied Data Insider Case
description: An executive of Applied Data Research Inc. of Princeton, N.J., has settled insider trading charges filed against him by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: MISSISSIPPI COLLECTS MEMORIES OF RIGHTS STRUGGLE IN A MUSEUM
description: They are memories of an era that many here would just as soon forget: the charred frame of a wooden cross that once burned at a Ku Klux Klan rally, shards of glass and nails recovered from the debris of Mississippi churches bombed more than 20 year ago.

title: Music Ensemble
description: The Ensemble for Early Music will present ''Daniel and the Lions,'' a reconstruction of a 12th-century church play, tomorrow and Sunday at 4 P.M., at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street. Tickets are $15 and $20, and may be purchased through Ticketron (977-9020), Teletron (947-5850) or the cathedral box office (662-2133). The performance will be repeated on Dec. 14, 15 and 16.

title: 'Women of Courage'
description: The lives of 71 outstanding black women are documented in ''Women of Courage,'' an exhibition of photographs and biographical sketches that opens today at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street.

title: MISSING GIRL, 16, IS FOUND STRANGLED IN L.I. WOODS
description: A teen-age girl has been found strangled in a wooded area of Long Island, and officials identified her today as 16-year- old Theresa Fusco, who had been missing from her Lynbrook home since Nov. 10.

title: 'OEDIPUS REX' IN NEW YORK PREMIERE
description: THROUGH the window on the second floor of a middle-class house, in a room dimly lit by electricity, a woman gives birth to a son. In a quick succession of brief scenes, we see how the baby, as it grows up to be able to totter around on its own, earns the jealousy of his handsome father, a member of Mussolini's militia, while his beautiful mother is torn between love for husband and child. On a night of national celebration, the small boy gets out of bed and makes his way to the window where he watches the fireworks that both enthrall and frighten him.

title: Foothills, ANR In U.S. Gas Deal
description: Foothills Pipe Lines Ltd., a Canadian natural gas transmission company, said it would join the ANR Pipeline Company and three other United States pipeline companies in co-sponsoring a project to transport additional Canadian natural gas to American markets. It said the Can-Am Pipeline Project involves use of the existing facilities of Foothills, the Northern Border Pipeline Company, ANR and a new system, the Ohio Interstate Pipeline Company.

title: Federal Parole Panel Meets With Williams
description: Former Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey, serving a three-year sentence at the Federal prison here for his Abscam conviction, went before a Parole Commission panel Wednesday to receive a tentative date for his release.

title: CONTRIBUTORS TO NEEDIEST CITE TRADGEDY
description: An awareness of tragedies that have touched millions of people around the globe is often cited by contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund as the reason for their giving.

title: The Dotted Line
description: Howard Schnellenberger had made it clear from the beginning that he wouldn't accept the Louisville coaching job unless the university was prepared to make a major commitment to football, and yesterday the faculty senate found out just how much of a commitment the school had to make. In a briefing, Louisville's president, Donald Swain, said Schnellenberger would receive $140,000 a year, plus $50,000 a year in deferred salary and accumulated interest to be paid at the end of his five-year contract. . . . Jerry Pettibone , long acknowledged as one of the nation's top college recruiters, has been named head football coach at Northern Illinois, his first such job after recruiter roles at Texas A & M, Oklahoma, Nebraska, Southern Methodist and Iowa.

title: COMMITTEE TO STEER SOUTH AFRICA PROTESTS IS NAMED
description: Several black leaders of the demonstrations against South Africa's racial policies today announced a steering committee to oversee future nonviolent protests.

title: PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for 12wks to Nov 3
description: b-After tax credits of $374,000 for the 12 weeks and $1,009,000 for the 40 weeks. c-After tax credits of $223,000 for the 13 weeks and $513,000 for the 39 weeks.

title: 9 Feared Killed in Spain
description: A bus carrying nine people hit a guard rail in heavy rain on a winding road today, flipped over and fell into the Bay of Biscay, apparently killing all those aboard, officials said. The high seas smashed the wrecked bus against the rocks and dragged it 300 feet out to sea, a spokesman for the Pesa Bus Company said.

title: AS BLACK, KARPOV STILL PLAYS FOR DRAW
description: In the 30th game of the world chess championship match in Moscow on Wednesday, Anatoly Karpov continued his policy of playing for a draw whenever he has Black - and once again the 33-year-old titleholder's defensive skill proved sufficient to the task at hand.

title: Curren, Wilander Gain Final
description: Kevin Curren of South Africa rallied to beat American Ben Testerman today and advance to the final of the million Australian Open tennis championships at Kooyong where he will meet the defending champion Mats Wilander of Sweden.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; INTEREST RATES RISE SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday, but the increases were held down by a late rally that lifted prices and reduced yields after the Federal Reserve announced a $2.2 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply.

title: Polaroid-Sage Tie
description: The Polaroid Corporation said it had acquired an approximately 20 percent equity interest in Sage Technology Inc. Terms were not announced. Sage, a closely held California concern, makes and markets chemistry and imaging products used in printing. Polaroid, based in Cambridge, Mass., said its purchase ''is an expression of our confidence in the company's products, technology and potential for growth.''

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Bulls, at Chicago. The first time the Knicks faced Michael Jordan this season, a sellout crowd showed up at Madison Square Garden and watched the sensational rookie score 33 points in a 121-106 Chicago victory.

title: An Offer to Take McGregor Private
description: The Rapid-American Corporation, which owns about 54 percent of the McGregor Corporation, said it had offered to take McGregor private for $23 a share.

title: 'Village' School Fair
description: The Greenwich Village Neighborhood School, 209 Sullivan Street, will have old its eighth Holiday Fair tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. in its auditorium.

title: EXXON OFFICER ELECTED PHILHARMONIC PRESIDENT
description: Stephen Stamas, a vice president of the Exxon Corporation, has been named president of the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Stamas was elected to the job at a meeting of the board of directors of the New York Philharmonic on Wednesday and the announcement was made yesterday by the board's chairman, Carlos Moseley.

title: Subbing for Subs
description: Jim McMahon, the Chicago Bear quarterback who has been sidelined for a month with a damaged kidney, will not return for the playoffs. The team's announcement yesterday came a day after the Bears signed the 37-year-old veteran Greg Landry to serve as a backup to Rusty Lisch, who became the Bears' No. 1 quarterback when McMahon's replacement, Steve Fuller, suffered a separated shoulder in Monday night's game against San Diego.

title: The Pentagon's Top Dissenters
description: In the heart of the Pentagon lurks a brave band of dissidents, isolated by adherence to a creed their organization spurns - free enterprise. The dissidents are highly placed, but don't be misled by their positions. Being on top in the Pentagon does not necessarily mean being in charge.

title: WAGNER AND BROWN: MESA'S PRIVATE PARTNERS
description: Until they made a big oil strike in the mid- 1970's, Cyril Wagner Jr. and Jack E. Brown were ''the kind of multimillionaires that are a dime a dozen'' around Midland, Tex., according to one source who knows both men well.

title: Cecil Taylor on Piano
description: The pianist Cecil Taylor will perform with a five-piece group tomorrow at 9 P.M. at the Inter-Media Art Center, 370 New York Avenue, Huntington, L.I. (516) 549-9666. Tickets are $10.

title: Encouraging Words
description: Doug Flutie, the 5-foot-9 3/4-inch Boston College quarterback who just won the Heisman Trophy and is expected to go on to bigger things, was in Washington yesterday.

title: SCOUTING ; Patience Pays Off
description: The Calder Cup, awarded to the best rookie in the National Hockey League, may well go to a Pittsburgh Penguin next spring - and no, not necessarily to Mario Lemieux.

title: HYTEK INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $55,000 for the quarter and $90,000 for the 6 months.

title: New York Telephone Bonds
description: The New York Telephone Company, a subsidiary of the Nynex Corporation, said yesterday that it had purchased $220.4 million of its 15 5/8 percent debentures due in 2012.

title: HOUSTON NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a gain of $4,624,000 from discontinued operations. c-Including a gain of $17,621,000 from discontinued operations.

title: DAVE MALONEY SENT TO SABRES
description: The Rangers joined the Yankees in the trading season yesterday, sending Dave Maloney, the emotional defenseman in his 10th full season as a Ranger, to the Buffalo Sabres in a four-player deal that broke up one pair of brothers for New York but united two other pairs of brothers.

title: MEDICAL WORKERS FACE ETHICAL DILEMMAS IN NEW TECHNOLOGY
description: ''She was standing there by her father's bed,'' said the nurse, ''stroking his arm and his cheek and crying and talking to him. He was in a coma, in a steady decline. The only thing keeping him going was the ventilator breathing for him. 'This isn't right,' she said. Then she looked across the bed at me, right in my eyes, and she said, 'If I could do this thing, I would.' Now, what would you do?''

title: Ray Assesses Demotion HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 6 - Darrol Ray did not quite say his career with the Jets appeared to be over. He just looked that way today as
description: he tried to put into perspective what his benching meant. ''Coach Walton told me he was putting Russell in at safety to get a

title: C.I.A. MANUAL SENT BY BALLOON?
description: The Central Intelligence Agency distributed some of its manuals for Nicaraguan rebels earlier this year by attaching them to balloons and floating them into the country, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: OFFICIALS FAULT PLANS TO BUILD 8 TRASH PLANTS
description: Members of the Board of Estimate yesterday objected to sites selected for huge incinerators as the board heard testimony on a plan to dispose of the city's garbage for decades to come.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Dec. 7, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Charlie Byrd to Appear
description: The guitarist Charlie Byrd will give two early-evening concerts this weekend.

title: Cantor Forms A London Link
description: The Cantor, Fitzgerald Securities Corporation, a New York-based broker of Treasury securities, announced an agreement with Charles Fulton Ltd., a London broker of money market instruments, to begin brokering Treasury securities in London next Feb. 1. The service will be offered over the Telrate System.

title: Goodrich Line To Be Dropped
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company said it will phase out its manufacturing of industrial rubber products here by early 1986, and as a result it will take a $12 million pretax charge against earnings for this year's fourth quarter.

title: ARMEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
AIRLINES WARNED OVER FOOD SAFETY
description: The Food and Drug Administration has notified all of the nation's passenger airlines that violations of regulations for handling food have been found on many airplanes. The agency urged the lines to improve their practices to avoid possible food poisoning.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Allied Corp.'s Industrial Fibers Group said it plans to expand its polyester plant in Moncure, N.C.; the move will add about 20 percent capacity.

title: CHALLENGE FOR CUOMO: PICKING JUDGES
description: NewsAnalysis

title: UNION CARBIDE SET FOR DAMAGE SUITS
description: Although stunned by a disaster whose human and financial toll is growing far beyond the scope of any previous industrial accident, the Union Carbide Corporation said today that it can cover all claims for compensation and damages resulting from the poisonous gas leak in Bhopal, India.

title: Houdini's Props
description: The props and paraphernalia used by Houdini and other magicians are among the items in a free exhibition called ''Magic: Past and Present'' in the main gallery of the Public Library's General Library and Museum for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center, 111 Amsterdam Avenue.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: LIKE a hot air balloon with a small puncture, Le Chantilly has been slowly drifting downward from the three-star stratosphere it reached in November 1978, shortly after it was launched, to two stars in January 1981, and now one. This bastion of classic French cooking used to be a reliable refuge for diners seeking an antidote to the nouvelle blues. Its food was soul- warming, honest and adamantly kiwiless - as comforting as a favorite old blanket.

title: MGF OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago revenues have been revised for accounting reclassifications.

title: Addenda
description: On Cable magazine is increasing its circulation rate base to 1.4 million, from 1.2 million, and its advertising rates by 16.7 percent with the February issue.

title: Old Skates on Display
description: ''Manhattan on Ice: Skating and Sleighing in Old New York,'' a free exhibition, opens today at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street.

title: HEART RECIPIENT TAKES WALK IN EXERCISE PROGRAM
description: William J. Schroeder took his longest walk today since receiving his artificial heart, from his bed to a window to look at the snowy woods outside and then back again. He bore his own weight as he took the dozen steps with a nurse at his side.

title: ACME PRECISION PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $67,994 for the quarter and year.

title: DOW DECLINES 1.11 IN ACTIVE TRADINGI
description: Stock prices ended with mostly minor changes yesterday in more active trading, with most of the interest focused on Union Carbide, which dropped sharply because of the disaster at its plant in India.

title: HALLWOOD GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings for the year-ago period is not meaningful because of the exchange and issuance of new shares in forming the Hallwood Group.

title:
Market Place ;
Mesa Stock's New Prospects
description: When T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, announced earlier this week that he would seek to take over the Phillips Petroleum Company, it created what one stockbroker described as ''an exciting development in a rather dull market.''

title: EXTENSION OF TAX TO RETAIN FARES VOTED IN ALBANY
description: After resolving last-minute disputes over a bill to raise their pay, state legislators convened today in a lame-duck session and quickly approved a two-year extension of the corporate tax surcharge that subsidizes mass transit in the metropolitan area.

title: Union Carbide Factory Attacked in Germany
description: One of two gasoline bombs planted inside a Union Carbide plant exploded, but no one was injured and there was no damage, the police said today.

title: Canada Trade Surplus
description: Canada's trade surplus widened to $2.3 billion (Canadian), or $1.74 billion, in October from $1.9 billion (Canadian) in September, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today.

title: War on Waste Herculean Job
description: The struggle to cut the budget deficit has

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: Thomas. 340 pages. Illustrated. St.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1984
description: The Economy

title: LAFAYETTE EDGES PRINCETON
description: Billy Hughes, a freshman forward, scored 14 points, including 12 in the second half, to lead Lafayette to a 45-43 victory over Princeton tonight.

title: YANKEES ARE CLOSE TO TRADING KEMP
description: As the Yankees tried to complete their deal with Oakland by signing Rickey Henderson at the winter baseball meetings today and moved closer to completing one that would bring Dale Berra from Pittsburgh for Steve Kemp, the Chicago White Sox actually completed a seven-player transaction tonight that sent the pitcher Lamarr Hoyt to the San Diego Padres.

title: SON HELD IN MOTHER'S DEATH
description: -A woman was slashed with a butcher knife and beaten to death by her 20-year-old son, who told the police he had killed her because she scolded him for getting drunk, the authorities said today. The police said the son, Bobby Cannon Jr., killed his mother, Emily Marie Cannon, 40, in their home.

title: ST. JOHN SEEKS CONSISTENCY
description: After opening the season with a 46- point rout of Lafayette in the opener of the Joe Lapchick Memorial Tournament last week, St. John's has been taken to the wire in each of its last two games by teams that were supposed to offer only mild resistance.

title: SL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $183,000. The company said 1983 figures were restated to reflect the disposal of its Printed Circuits division and B & S Screw Machine Products Inc. The share earnings are restated for a 6 percent stock dividend paid Nov. 21. The company was formerly SGL Industries.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday WBAI HOLIDAY CRAFTS FAIR

title: Olajuwon's 42 Go for Naught OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 6
description: Akeem Olajuwon

title: ADVERTISING ; Brouillard Gets New Account
description: based in White Plains and operating in five other countries,

title: Chicago Teachers Walk Freezing Picket Lines
description: Striking Chicago teachers today shivered on picket lines with temperatures in the teens and a wind-chill factor of 26 below zero Fahrenheit as their strike kept the nation's third-largest school district closed for the fourth day.

title: TAKING TO THE WOODS TO CHOOSE YOUR TREE
description: There is no better way for a family to get into the holiday spirit than an expedition to choose and cut its own Christmas tree at a farm rather than picking one in the city. So once again it's time to head for the woods in quest of the holiday tree.

title: PARKS NEED A NEW CONSERVATIVE CORPS
description: To the Editor:

title: FILIPINO SKEPTICISM
description: The mass demonstrations triggered by the assassination of the Philippine opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. have hardly subsided in the nearly 16 months since his death. But the nature of the political opposition to President Ferdinand E. Marcos's rule has changed profoundly in that period, raising troubling questions about the prospects for a democratic transition of power.

title: BRIEFING ; Darwin, Dole & Simpson
description: Senators Bob Dole of Kansas and

title: GAS LEAK TOUCHES A NERVE IN EUROPE
description: The mass deaths from gas released by an insecticide plant in India on Monday have spread a sense of nervousness in Western Europe, where large chemical concerns produce vast amounts of highly toxic substances at factories that are often in areas with dense populations.

title: Grace Won't Sell Petroleum Holdings
description: W.R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it would retain its remaining petroleum holdings rather than divest itself of them as it had announced last June. The company cited the lower market prices for oil.

title: Plea of Not Guilty In Fire Fatal to 14
description: A 44-year-old former handyman pleaded not guilty today to charges he set a fire in October that killed 14 people and injured 44 others at the Alexander Hamilton Hotel here.

title: CUOMO CALLS TAX PLAN BASICALLY A GOOD IDEA
description: Governor Cuomo said today that, except for the proposal to disallow deductions for state and local taxes, he believes the Treasury Department's plan for overhauling the Federal income tax system is a good idea.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: PUBLISHING: HELP FOR THE SMALL PRESS
description: THE life of the small publisher has always been risky, a fact underscored again by the financial collapse last summer of Network Inc., a consortium of 38 publishers on the West Coast. But help is on the way.

title: FED CAN CUT DEFICIT BY LOWERING INTEREST
description: To the Editor:

title: F.T.C. REPORT SEES LAWYER ADS AS BENEFICIAL
description: A Federal Trade Commission staff report said today that lawyers should be allowed to advertise in any medium, including radio, television, mail and telephone.

title: COMPACT VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday misstated the assets of the American Security Corporation. They were $3.7 billion as of March 31.

title: BRIEFING ; Justice at Any Price
description: The Department of Justice is

title: LEGISLATURE APPROVES RAISING SALES TAX TO 8% IN ERIE COUNTY
description: The sales tax in financially pressed Erie County will rise a percentage point to 8 percent next March 31 under legislation passed today by both houses of the Legislature.

title: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
Accounts
description: World Press Review to Grossich & Partners for its first national ad campaign.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued this week its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: REDPATH INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a writedown of $8,937,000 on an investment. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: BIG BLOW TO CITY TRANSIT SEEN IN BUDGET
description: Under President Reagan's budget proposal, the New York City transit system would suffer its biggest cutbacks in Federal assistance since Federal reductions made four years ago, officials said today.

title: 'THE SUN ALSO RISES,' EXPATRIATES IN EUROPE
description: Publicists for the new four-hour film version of ''The Sun Also Rises,'' which begins Sunday at 9 P.M. on Channel 4 (and concludes Monday at 9), have been carefully releasing public explanations that certain liberties have been taken with the Ernest Hemingway novel. Their candor is admirable. Unfortunately, in just about every instance, the changes have been disastrous. Hemingway finally emerges as not only a macho blusterer but also a tedious bore.

title: Bethlehem Plan
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it plans to spend $18 million so that its Steelton plant can make extra-long railroad rails.

title: CLARK CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
A HOEDOWN FROM BRITAIN MIXING FOLK AND CLASSICAL
description: THE freewheeling eclecticism that has been labeled world music comes in as many shapes and sizes as there are musicians who care to refine their favorite sounds into personal signatures. One of the most likable and eccentric cross-fertilizations of the last decade has been the blend of the folkloric and the classical created by the Penguin Cafe Orchestra. The English group, which makes its American debut tomorrow as part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival, is the brainchild of Simon Jeffes, a 35-year-old composer, arranger, conductor and musician.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: 19 Red Brigade Members Imprisoned for Life

title: Alexander Unit's Head To Lead Fred S. James
description: Fred S. James & Company, the New York-based insurance brokerage, said yesterday that Richard M. Page would become its president and chief executive in January. Mr. Page, 52, succeeds Charles A. O'Malley, 67, who will remain chairman until he retires in April.

title: VILLAGE SUPER MARKET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 20
UNITED STATES CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,139,000 from the sale of a unit and a loss of $343,000 from other operations. c-Net loss Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: DALLAS ROUTS KNICKS BY 112-83
description: Coach Hubie Brown started his postgame interview mildly last night, but before the Knick coach was finished he was using words like ''atrocious'' and ''leaderless'' to describe the play of his backcourt.

title: RAISES FOR STATE OFFICIALS GET APPROVAL IN ALBANY
description: State legislators voted today to make themselves the highest-paid such officials in the continental United States by approving a pay package that expanded as the special session here lengthened.

title: SUCH STUFF AS SPACE DREAMS ARE MADE ON
description: To the Editor: Your arguments against a manned station in ''The Wrong Stuff'' imply that manned versus unmanned is an either/or proposition. A manned sta

title: GOV. CUOMO'S CURIOUS REACTION TO JUDICIAL LIST
description: To the Editor:

title: MCNAMARA DISCUSSES WAR AT CBS LIBEL TRIAL
description: Robert S. McNamara, the former Secretary of Defense, broke a 16-year silence on the Vietnam War yesterday to testify at the CBS libel trial that, although he had major policy differences with Gen. William C. Westmoreland during the war, he did not believe the general had conspired to deceive him or President Johnson and could not have succeeded if he had tried.

title: CHEMICAL COMPANIES REVIEW SAFETY
description: Some chemical companies in the United States are reviewing their safety and spillage procedures to make sure they are adequate in view of the disaster that caused more than 1,000 deaths in India.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1984 International Hijackers killed two more passengers aboard a Kuwaiti jetliner at the Teheran airport, the official Iranian press agency reported. It said the victims included an American official who was forced out of the plane and shot six times. The State Department said two Americans, both officials of the Agency for International Development, had apparently been killed by the hijackers. (Page A1, Column 6.) The hijackers holding the Kuwaiti airliner at the Teheran airport are closely connected with the Iranian- backed Shiite terrorist group that is believed to have bombed the United States Embassy and the Marine barracks in Lebanon last year, according to American officials. (A1:4-5.)

title: CAR SERVICES INCREASE IN POPULARITY
description: They are used by frustrated riders who cannot find taxis and who are tired of waiting for buses and braving subways. They are supported largely by corporations who hire them to take home hundreds of employees who work late each night. They are registering with the city in greater numbers than ever before and are substituting luxury sedans for older, often untrustworthy vehicles. Car services, which cost much less than limousines but somewhat more than cabs, have become a presence on the streets of New York.

title: LONG LEGAL WRANGLING LIKELY OVER GAS LEAK
description: The Union Carbide Corporation is expected to face an onslaught of damage claims stemming from the gas leak at its plant in Bhopal, India, and most experts are expecting months - or even years - of legal wrangling.

title: Three Found Slain in Miami
description: The wife of Miami's honorary Lebanese Consul and an elderly couple she was visiting were found shot to death Tuesday night in the couple's apartment, the police said Wednesday. The victims were identified as Genevieve Abraham, about 60 years old, the wife of Anthony Abraham, a prominent businessman who was appointed honorary consul by the Lebanese Government in 1979; Sam Josephs, a retired builder in his 80's, and his wife, Bea, 76. A police spokesman said a motive had not been determined.

title: CITY MOVES TO PRESERVE A SYMBOL OF CORRUPTION
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday affirmed the designation of the Tweed Courthouse, a symbol of one of New York's most corrupt administrations, as a city landmark.

title: BRIEFING ; Why the Spy Isn't 006
description: Easing tensions between the United States and the Soviet Union, most authorities concede, will require dispelling a certain amount of suspicion in both countries. But even longtime Kremlinologists may be surprised at a belief that is reported to be prevalent among Soviet citizens who visit Washington from time to time.

title: N.H.L. TEAMS SIGN TV DEAL
description: The National Hockey League, which has been split by a rancorous squabble over television rights, announced yesterday that 19 of its 21 clubs had concluded a five-year agreement to pool and share broadcast revenues.

title: SUCH STUFF AS SPACE DREAMS ARE MADE ON
description: To the Editor: ''The Wrong Stuff'' suggests you have learned nothing about space since your notorious castigation of Prof. Robert Goddard in 1920 for his naive belief that rockets could work in a vacuum. To write now that ''The next phase of . . . exploiting space could almost certainly be undertaken more efficiently, and perhaps more spectacularly, with robots,'' in the very month when astronauts brilliantly improvised the salvage of two stray communications satellites, shows truly uncanny timing.

title: THE RESELLING OF GINNIE MAE
description: Wall Street thought it had a sure winner when it found a way to package Ginnie Maes - Government- guaranteed mortgage securities - to sell them to small investors. The securities offer both relatively high yields and the safety of a Government guarantee.

title: No Headline
description: The Legislature gave final approval tonight to a bill requiring casinos to reinvest a portion of their gross revenues each year in projects to redevelop Atlantic City and other blighted New Jersey cities.

title: Northwest Group Awaits Financing
description: Northwest Industries said an investor group that had agreed to buy the company had not yet completed required financing for the transaction, which is scheduled to close Dec. 31. But Northwest said Donald P. Kelly of Kelly, Briggs & Associates Inc., one of the purchasers, said the group expects to have firm financing commitments before that date.

title: 2 Quartets to Join
description: A jazz quartet and a string quartet will perform together as the Max Roach Double Quartet Sunday at 9 P.M. and midnight at the Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street near East Third Street (505-5660). The musicians include Mr. Roach on drums, Cecil Bridgewater on trumpet, Odean Pope on tenor saxophone and Tyrone Brown on bass, plus the Swedenborg String Quartet. Tickets are $10.

title: Drew Is Suspended
description: The Utah Jazz suspended John Drew , their high-scoring forward, for an indefinite period yesterday for violating team rules and said: ''The Jazz will have no other comment on the action.'' The suspension, announced after a morning practice, followed a meeting between the 30-year-old Drew and Frank Layden, coach and general manager.

title: PHILHARMONIC: CHRISTIAN ALTENBURGER, VIOLINIST
description: SINCE this is an Alban Berg season in the world's orchestra halls and opera houses, notice was taken by the New York Philharmonic last evening. The centennial of the Viennese composer's birth on Feb. 9, 1885, was celebrated by playing his most famous instrumental work and excerpts from his most accessible opera. Even so, the Philharmonic subscribers, renowned for their resistance to 20th- century music, could not bear to hear out Zubin Mehta's musicians as they offered this rather timid Berg sampler. Fully a third of the audience stampeded from Avery Fisher Hall before the program's final piece, fragments from ''Wozzeck,'' a 59- year-old opera that is one of this century's undeniable masterpieces.

title: ART: FROM MOTHERWELL, BIOGRAPHY AND HISTORY
description: ROBERT MOTHERWELL will be 70 next month, and he has been a substantial presence on the New York scene for 40 and some years. But in his retrospective exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum he shows no signs of flagging. In ''Dance'' (1981), he tackles one of the grand persistent subjects of 20th-century art and does it in such a way that the heavy-footed antics of the figure on the left make us rethink the meaning of dance. As for the huge painting (72 inches by 180 inches) of the same year called ''Face of the Night,'' it can be said that never has he managed black on black with more conspicuous success.

title: A LIBERAL TAX PLAN
description: The snowstorm outside my window is blowing no more gustily than the storm of criticism that greeted the Treasury Department's ''modified flat tax'' proposal. But liberals and Democrats, in particular, ought to grab and run with a plan that's in fact a child of the Bradley- Gephardt reform developed by two of their own.

title: Sohio Offering
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) is offering $150 million of 10 1/2 percent Euronotes at a price of 97 3/4 to yield 11.23 percent through underwriters led by Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd. Sohio is also offering 150,000 warrants at $25 each, which may be exercised during the next four years to buy seven-year noncallable bonds yielding 11 1/2 percent.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Former HBO Chief Hired by Coca-Cola
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that Frank J. Biondi Jr., who resigned in October as chairman and chief executive officer of Time Inc.'s Home Box Office, had been named executive vice president of Coke's Entertainment Business Sector, a new position.

title: BENJAMIN DIRECTS 'CITY HEAT'
description: OVERDRESSED and overplotted as it is, ''City Heat'' benefits greatly from the sardonic teamwork of Clint Eastwood and Burt Reynolds. Without them the film would be eminently forgettable, but their bantering gives it an enjoyable edge. Working together in very ''Sting''-like circumstances, they are cast, respectively, as a hard-boiled police lieutenant and a sharp-dressing private eye. Mr. Eastwood, in this Prohibition era setting, displays both his trademark steeliness and an underused talent for tongue-in-cheek comedy. For his part, Mr. Reynolds looks dashing and is back at the top of his wise-cracking form.

title: AUCTIONS
description: MARILYN MONROE and Mickey Mouse are the stars of two auctions scheduled for this weekend. The Statue of Liberty figures in a third and corkscrews dominate a fourth. The month is December, the mood is pre-holiday and the sales in which all but one of these offerings appear are classified as auctions of collectibles.

title: Berkeley Council Backs Friendship Benefits
description: Berkeley's new City Council convened for the first time Tuesday and passed an ordinance to grant live-in partners of city employees the same benefits as spouses. The vote was 8 to 0.

title: British Troops Ambush And Kill 2 I.R.A. Men
description: British soldiers lying in ambush shot and killed two members of the Irish Republican Army today as they rode a motorcycle into the grounds of a psychiatric hospital, the police and the I.R.A. said.

title: TAKEOVER OFFER IS DEFENDED
description: T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, asserted today that the primary aim of his bid for the Phillips Petroleum Company was to obtain the full value of Phillips stock for its shareholders.

title: Truffles
description: Are truffles the rich man's caviar? At Il Monello, an East Side restaurant, a table of diners was seduced by a tray of them brought for inspection by the waiter. Jane Safer, the museum specialist in the city's Cultural Affairs Department, ordered them with pasta.

title: ART: THE SCULPTURE OF THE NEW YORK SCHOOL
description: THE NEW YORK SCHOOL means painting to us, not sculpture. We think of its founding fathers as Pollock, Rothko, Still, de Kooning, Motherwell and company - Abstract Expressionists who achieved their revolution through the application of pigment to a flat canvas surface. Although there was also a substantial contingent of sculptors who, sharing the ambitions of the painters as well as their roots in European vanguard movements, made strong contributions, too, we don't have the same coherent sense of their work as a body. Except, in fact, for that created by the best-known of them - Alexander Calder, Louise Nevelson, Isamu Noguchi, David Smith - most of the sculpture of the period is today regarded as subsidiary to what the painters were doing.

title: WEINBERGER FIRM ON ARMS SPENDING
description: Officials in the Reagan Administration said today that Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger would return from an overseas trip this weekend ready to fight for a large increase in next year's military budget despite growing pressures against an increase.

title: RUCKELSHAUS SAYS E.P.A. IS IMPROVED
description: Bidding farewell to employees of the Environmental Protection Agency, William D. Ruckelshaus said today, ''The agency is no longer in trouble.''

title: Jazz at Carnegie
description: Alvin Batiste, a modern jazz clarinetist from New Orleans, will perform tomorrow at 8:30 at Carnegie Recital Hall, 154 West 57th Street (247-7800). His quartet will include Mulgrew Miller on piano, Rufus Reid on bass and Herman Jackson on drums. Tickets are $10.

title: SON OF CUSTODIAN IS CHARGED WITH KILLING WITH DRAMA STUDENT
description: A son of the superintendent of an Upper West Side apartment house was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder of a 23-year-old drama student who lived in the building.

title: SPIRITUALISM FLOWERS IN 'CHOSEN LAND' OF BRASILIA
description: As they lay face down on stone slabs, their entire bodies hidden by dark brown capes, the male mediums supposedly received interplanetary energy attracted by an ellipse placed in the middle of a star- shaped pond.

title: REAGAN PLAYING A ROLE IN ARMS CONTROL DEBATE
description: President Reagan has asked his arms control advisers to tell the Soviet Union next month that he seeks stability in Soviet- American relations, White House officials said today.

title: After 26 Years, Family Gets Payment for Brother's Death
description: The family of a man killed by a police officer 26 years ago received shares Thursday of a $1.6 million settlement of the killing.

title: Lucky Pick-6 Draw: 5, 8, 10, 14, 32, 37
description: The six numbers that would win New Jersey's $13 million Pick-6 Lotto jackpot are 5, 8, 10, 14, 32, 37.

title: RYMER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-After tax credits of $1,275,000 for the quarter and $3,300,000 for the year. c-Not available because the company changed to a fiscal year from a calendar year.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE Wine Spectator, a newspaper that covers the wine industry, has just published a ''Pocket Guide to the Greatest Wine Lists in America.'' Based on an inspection of wine lists by the newspaper's staff, the 35-page booklet lists more than 200 restaurants across the country that have received its Grand Award. In addition, there is a ''Top 100'' honor roll recognizing exemplary efforts by other restaurants.

title: XEROX OFFICIAL WILL JOIN POSTAL INSTANT PRESS
description: Thomas C. Marotto, 48, has been named president and chief operating officer of Postal Instant Press, a chain of nearly 1,000 outlets worldwide that offer printing services.

title: COONEY SEES ROOM FOR FUN
description: It is never easy now for Gerry Cooney, no matter the opponent. It is never easy when a fighter hears snickers where once he heard cheers.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: WHEN Columbia turned down ''E. T.'' and instead elected to make ''Starman,'' the latter was pure science fiction. And it had a good deal in common with ''E. T.,'' because both screenplays described visits to Earth by benign creatures from other planets. But now, having passed through the hands of such directors as Adrian Lyne (''Flashdance''), John Badham (''Saturday Night Fever'') and Ridley Scott (''Blade Runner'') before being taken over by John Carpenter (''Halloween''), ''Starman'' has changed its tone. ''I wanted to make a fairy tale rather than a sci-fi film,'' Mr. Carpenter said. ''I think it's much closer to 'The Wizard of Oz' than to 'Close Encounters.' Or you might say it's 'It Happened One Night' with a sci-fi premise.''

title: ANALYSTS STUDYING IMPACT ON WALL ST.
description: Wall Street securities analysts disagreed sharply yesterday about Union Carbide's prospects after the industrial accident in Bhopal, India. Although the price of Union Carbide shares has plummeted since Monday's disaster, some analysts said the market has overreacted.

title: THE CIRCUS STILL FEELS THE SHOCK
description: As the parents of a 23-year-old trapeze artist seriously injured in a fall last Sunday maintained a vigil at her hospital bedside here, friends recalled her last rehearsal and told of how it shocked performers at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: A 'Dear Ms. Bellamy' Letter
description: ''Dear Ms. Bellamy,'' the form letter began.

title: MUSIC: SERKIN IN BEETHOVEN PROGRAM AT CARNEGIE
description: Rudolf Serkin's annual recital at Carnegie Hall has taken on a ritualistic tone. The pianist's approach to music and his instrument is devout, all but priestly, and his audience attends to him with the seriousness of a congregation that expects nothing less than high revelation.

title: MORLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $177,800 from the settlement of litigation. c-Including a gain of $235,200 from the settlement of litigation.

title: PENTAGON'S WATCHDOG OFFICE TO MONITOR PARTS' PURCHASES
description: The Defense Department's new spare-parts watchdog office will have a staff of 15 people charged with monitoring about 15 million purchases a year, a Pentagon official said today.

title: PULASKI FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
THE ISSUE OF TRUST
description: As a new approach to Soviet-American negotiation nears, the question of trust comes up again. It is easy enough to shunt it aside with the reminder that agreements between adversaries can never depend on trust but only on mutual interest. If each side doesn't feel it is gaining at least as much as it concedes, there won't be any agreement.

title: Debt
description: * Avon Products Inc. is issuing a $130 million, 10-year, 5 3/8 percent bullet bond, through underwriters led by Union Bank of Switzerland.

title: Utah Bank Rescue
description: A Utah bank that had been closed by state officials will reopen under a new charter after receiving $4.1 million in cash advances from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the F.D.I.C. said. The Golden Spike State Bank in Tremonton was bought by a newly chartered state bank that will operate under the same name. The bank purchased 3,000 deposits totaling $6.8 million, of which $792,000 was placed by deposit brokers, the F.D.I.C. said.

title: SALLY GETS CHANCE TO START FOR GIANTS
description: FRANK LITSKY

title: SUSPECT IN BIRD RING IS SAID TO HAVE BEEN A NOTED MOB FIGURE
description: A former organized crime figure, given a new identity after testifying against other mob figures, was indicted by a Federal grand jury Wednesday on charges of smuggling hundreds of exotic birds and reptiles into the United States, the authorities say.

title: TELEPHONE SPECIALISTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ADVERTISING ; Leber Katz Assigned More Lenox Accounts
description: Leber Katz & Partners, already the agency for Lenox china, has now been additionally assigned the Lenox Collections for print and direct-mail advertising.

title: STAGE: 'THE BLOODLETTERS,' A COMEDY
description: NO one ever claimed it was all fun growing up middle- class Jewish on Long Island, but Corky Sutter has it harder than most. Corky, the awkward teen-age protagonist of Richard Greenberg's ''The Bloodletters,'' is not merely the victim of his oppressive, widowed mother and an overactive, if unfulfilled, sexual imagination. He also suffers from an incurable disease that leaves its victims with a single, but devastating, infirmity - a disgusting stench redolent of ''an old bathroom.''

title: Dining Out Guide: Middle European
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CSARDA, 1477 Second Avenue, at 77th

title: KEEPING THE PRESIDENT ON THE LINE
description: Harold Quann, with mock depreciation, calls it his ''garbage story.''

title: Bridge:Jacoby, in 1941, Walked Out OftheFallNationalTourney
description: A player who leaves in the middle of a bridge event for any reason other than illness is normally summoned before a committee and perhaps subjected to some disciplinary penalty. But for several reasons no action was taken about the most famous such departure.

title: Rare Tree Ornaments
description: The Gotham Book Mart and Gallery, 41 West 47th Street, is displaying its collection of rare and antique Christmas tree ornaments through Jan. 5. A glass pear with a face and a double-sided angel are among the hundreds of items featured. Hours are Monday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 6:30 P.M.; Sundays until Christmas, noon to 5 P.M. Information: 719-4476.

title: DAMSON OIL CO reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
CANADIAN IMPERIAL BANK OF COMMERCE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Italy's Output Rises
description: Italy's inflation-adjusted gross domestic product rose 1.1 percent, to the equivalent of $81 billion, in the third quarter from the second quarter, the State Economic Forecasting Institute said today. It said Italy's G.D.P. was up 3.2 percent from the third quarter of 1983. G.D.P. measures all of a country's output of goods and services, excluding exports.

title: BRIEFING ; Arms and the Superbowl
description: Diplomatic observers have been wondering why the meeting in Geneva between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko of the Soviet Union was scheduled for Jan. 7-8 rather than later in the month to leave a little breathing space after the holidays.

title: INDIA POLICE SEIZE FACTORY RECORDS OF UNION CARBIDE
description: In preparation for an investigation into the catastrophe caused by the release of poison gas, the police seized records Thursday from the Union Carbide plant here and guarded the hospital room of an employee on duty Monday when the accident occurred.

title: EGYPT BIDS U.S. ACCEPT P.L.O. IN PEACE TALKS
description: Egypt's Foreign Minister urged the United States today to become actively involved again in efforts to resolve the Arab-Israeli conflict and to accept the Palestine Liberation Organization as a participant in peace talks.

title: G.O.P. CHIEFS ADD TARGETS FOR PRESIDENT'S BUDGET CUTS
description: Republican leaders in Congress generally endorsed President Reagan's budget-cutting plans today. But they emphasized that the package should include smaller military spending increases, a 10 percent pay cut for Government leaders, and possibly a freeze on cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security recipients.

title: Required Reading; Diplomacy and Guts
description: A. Let me try to give you what I think are the important qualities as they would fit with a number of different definitions of success. The first is intelligence - not necesarily brilliance, but you've got to have a questioning mind. Second, you have to be able to express yourself well, both in writing and orally. You can know everything there is to know about a place, but if you can't say it or write it so that somebody else can use it, it's of no use. These attributes are essential to success, but they by no means guarantee it. Assuming that somebody can express himself well and is intelligent, the single most significant quality is guts. And if you don't have that, in the last analysis, I don't care if you get to be Secretary of State, you're not a success.

title: JOHNSON WANTS TRADE TO GAIN AN 'EDGE'
description: Dave Johnson conceded today that he was disappointed the Mets had not made a major trade at the winter meetings, and warned that one was necessary to give the Mets the ''edge'' they needed t' win their first pennant in 12 years.

title: APPEALS COURT BACKS COLUMNISTS IN LIBEL SUIT
description: The United States Court of Appeals here ruled 6-to-5 today that the syndicated columnists Rowland Evans and Robert Novak were not vulnerable to a libel judgment for a column six years ago that criticized a Marxist professor seeking a job at the University of Maryland.

title: SCOUTING ; Coming Home
description: A pair of relocated New Yorkers whose basketball careers have carried them to Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill., will return this weekend for games against old friends.

title: Fugitive Is Arrested After Year in Woods
description: Facing burglary charges and determined not to be caught, a 37-year-old man retreated to the woods where he lived in a lean-to for a year, only to be snared by two officers disguised as hunters, the police said today.

title: 31 More Bodies Found In Taiwan Coal Mine
description: Rescue crews found the bodies of 31 miners today, bringing the death toll from a coal mine explosion Wednesday to at least 33.

title: ART: ITALIAN MANUSCRIPT PAINTING
description: ''ITALIAN Manuscript Painting: 1300-1500'' is the first exhibition in 20 years of the great collection of Italian Renaissance manuscripts at the Morgan Library. Like all exceptional manuscript shows, these 60 miniatures, on display at the library through Feb. 17, give us both an overview of a period of art and slices of cultural history. The union of word and image also provides an unusual sense of well-being in this visually dominated culture, where word and image remain largely at war.

title: Stories for Children
description: Youngsters can experience a traditional Dutch St. Nicholas Day at the Ladies' Parlor of the Long Island Historical Society, 128 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn Heights, tomorrow at 3:30, 4:15 and 5 P.M. Children will listen to stories and receive treats. Admission is free. Reservations: (718) 624-0890.

title: TRIAL OF BELGRADE DISSIDENTS: MORE THAN A 'SPASM OF INDECISION'
description: To the Editor:

title: Beware of Pickpockets
description: Along with the cheery Christmas

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Business Products Inc. of Atlanta, a supplier of specialty paper products, elected Jeff Davidson, president and chief executive officer of the Gannett Broadcasting Group, to its board of directors.

title: U.S. LINKS IRANIAN-BACKED GROUP TO HIJACKING OF KUWAITI AIRLINER
description: American officials said today that the hijackers holding a jetliner at the Teheran airport were closely connected with the Iranian-backed Shiite terrorist group that is believed to have bombed the United States Embassy and the Marine barracks in Lebanon last year.

title: FERRARO LUNCHES WITH BUSH IN HIS OFFICE, HER LOST GOAL
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro and George Bush met over lunch today, with memories of tart language shelved for the moment and the Vice President suggesting that they be friends.

title: BILLS ARE INITIATED IN JERSEY TO GET BIG LEAGUE BASEBALL
description: New Jersey took a significant step today toward attracting a major league baseball team.

title: RISKS AND BNEFITS
description: An accident causing great loss of life in the third world has reached the consciousness of the industrialized world. Unlike other disasters, this one seems to speak to an amorphous dread that is the price humanity sometimes pays for the bounty of technology. The many hundreds of lives lost and those irreparably diminished in the Indian city of Bhopol were the result of a catastrophe that confirmed one's worst fears: that somewhere, perhaps everywhere, there are silent, invisible man-made killers, from radiation, to gas, to asbestos. Unlike the automobile accident that can be dismissed as unlikely to strike home, this kind of catastrophe somehow seems all too likely in a world that is ever more industrialized.

title: THE SUGAR INDUSTRY'S SLIDE
description: Americans are consuming sweeteners in near-record quantities - 133 pounds per person this year - but despite this vast craving for the taste of sugar, the sugar industry itself is languishing.

title: DIANE VON FURSTENBERG: COUTURE IN A NEW SHOP
description: Diane Von Furstenberg has had a lot of idols since she came to New York 15 years ago at the age of 22 and started a dress business. As the wife of Prince Egon Von Furstenberg, she was a decorative member of the social scene as well as part of the business community.

title: COAST LOTTERY HAS TROUBLE MEETING DEADLINE
description: The first deadline set by California's new lottery law passed today, but Gov. George Deukmejian did not meet it.

title: HEALTH CRISIS COULD LAST YEARS, EXPERTS SAY
description: Several American public health specialists expect a health care crisis of a severity unparalled in peacetime to persist in the Bhopal area of India for years to come.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds continued their climb, increasing $1.86 billion, to $209.90 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Court Told Coast Mayor Received Illegal Funds
description: Mayor Roger Hedgecock, beginning his new administration in court facing felony conspiracy and perjury charges, was accused today of setting up a brokerage concern to hide illegal campaign contributions.

title: Jersey High Court Disbars Ex-Judge
description: The State Supreme Court today disbarred former Judge Peter J. Coruzzi of Superior Court, who was convicted in 1982 of accepting $47,000 in bribes in return for lenient sentences.

title: Off-Duty Officer Kills a Burglar
description: An off-duty police officer yesterday shot and killed a burglar she found in the kitchen of her Brooklyn apartment, the police said.

title: Maine's Seabrook Decision
description: Maine's Public Utilities Commission tentatively agreed today to order three utilities to sell their 10 percent aggregate share of the Seabrook nuclear power plant or ''disengage'' from the long-delayed project. The decision, subject to further review, was disclosed by Peter Bradford, chairman of the commission.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Boston Agency Offers $69.6 Million of Bonds
description: The Boston Water and Sewer Commission is selling $69.6 million of revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 10.73 percent for 10 1/2 percent bonds due in 2009, which are tentatively offered at a price of 98 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS ; A Division Where Losers Can Thrive
description: The Central Division of the National Football League's American Conference has helped give rise to the notion that parody might now be more than a near-homonym for parity. It may also be a synonym.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Wednesday about plans to build garbage-burning incinerators in New York City omitted part of a statement by Dr. Barry Commoner on the possibility of building one to test how much dioxin would be produced. He said that while such a test would take 5 to 10 years, there would be no time to carry it out before the city's shortage of landfill space required a new system of disposal.

title: OUR TRADE BALANCE: A GROWING CRISIS
description: The debate over the budget deficit again virtually ignores a critical dimension of the problem: the stunning and historic deterioration of America's international trade and financial position.

title: Pantry Pride Uncertainty
description: Shareholders of Pantry Pride Inc. were told at a tumultuous annual meeting today that they may have to wait two weeks to discover who will control the supermarket chain.

title: THOUSANDS SAID TO HAVE FALSE MEDICAL DEGREES
description: A six- month Congressional investigation into bogus medical credentials has found that more than 10,000 people in the United States are suspected by law-enforcement agencies and professional groups of possessing fraudulent medical degrees.

title: G. HEILEMANN TO ACQUIRE PABST FOR $69.3 MILLION
description: The Pabst Brewing Company said today that it had agreed to be acquired by the G. Heileman Brewing Company for $11 a share, or $69.3 million.

title: Chrysler Will Buy Back Up to 20% of Its Shares
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it plans to purchase up to 25 million of its common shares, or about 20 percent of the total outstanding, over the next two years.

title: Big Board in a Dispute Over Jacobs ITT Order
description: On Wall Street, where the motto is ''your word is your bond,'' there was a major dispute yesterday over how much stock of the ITT Corporation the broker for Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, purchased on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Rome Airport Struck
description: A 12-hour strike today over a contract dispute by personnel at the Leonardo da Vinci airport in Rome forced the cancellation or postponement of flights to and from the airport, authorities said. Most domestic flights were canceled. Trans-Atlantic flights were delayed for 12 hours.

title: SUCH STUFF AS SPACE DREAMS ARE MADE ON
description: To the Editor:

title: SOPRANO LEONTYNE PRICE TO LEAVE THE OPERATIC STAGE
description: Leontyne Price, a Metropolitan opera star for nearly a quarter-century who is regarded as one of the great Verdi sopranos, will give her last operatic performance on Jan. 3 at the Met.

title: DANCE: PLAYERS' PROJECT
description: SINCE the 1930's, Anna Sokolow has been an uncompromising, even cantankerous choreographer who knows how to inspire dancers. She inspired dancers once again when the members of Anna Sokolow's Players' Project presented three works on Wednesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church. All the participants appeared to be totally committed to her choreography. Yet the choreography varied considerably in its effectiveness.

title: MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Including tax credits of $8.3 million for the quarter and $28 million for the 9 months and a gain on the exchange of securities of $2.2 million for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $62.3 million for the quarter and $250.4 million for the 9 months.

title: RAMAPO LOSES SEX-BIAS SUIT
description: A Federal jury here awarded $75,000 today in compensatory damages to a former associate professor at Ramapo College who had charged that she was denied tenure because she was a woman.

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
FLORIDA PLANE CRASH KILLS 13 ON AIRLINE PENALIZED BY F.A.A.
description: A Provincetown-Boston Airline plane crashed yesterday in a wooded area shortly after taking off from Jacksonville International Airport in Florida, killing all 13 people aboard, the authorities said.

title: GRAPHIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
7 States Appeal on Pollution
description: New York, six other Northeastern states and a New York Congressman today appealed a decision by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency refusing to order a reduction in sulfur emissions in seven states in the Middle West, Southern and Border areas.

title: No Place for Race in Picking Juries Too many lawyers in too many courtrooms get away with removing potential jurors on the basis of race. A 1965 Supreme Court decision condemned the practice but in a way that makes it nearly impossible to prove. Now the United States Court of Appeals in New York has ruled on the issue in a way that could lead to real reform.
description: Judges cannot disqualify potential jurors simply because of race. The Civil War and the 14th Amendment settled that. But lawyers can use a fixed number of ''peremptory'' challenges to remove jurors without having to state a reason. The peremptories permit lawyers to indulge their hunches about the partiality of a juror who, for example, has had a bad experience with the police or another who has recently been mugged.

description: b-Net losses after a loss of $235,000 for the quarter and a gain of $4,000 for the year from discontinued operations.

description: A Brooklyn rabbi was listed in critical condition at Maimonides Hospital yesterday as a result of a holdup Wednesday night in the driveway of his home.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES ; Boxer and Psychologist
description: When his counseling group is in session, Wilbert McClure seats his clients in a circle from which there is no easy escape. The members are urged to confront one another's defenses, not much differently from the way he gained his Olympic gold medal in a squared boxing ring in Rome in 1960.

title: BYRD IS FACING FIGHT BY CHILES FOR SENATE JOB
description: In a surprise move, Senator Lawton Chiles of Florida announced today that he would challenge Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia for the leadership of the Senate Democrats Wednesday when the party organizes itself for the new session of Congress that begins next month.

title: Some of the Parts Of Perfect Player
description: In his fourth annual College Basketball Handbook, 2.5 million copies of which are distributed free on college campuses by the Miller Brewing Company, Al McGuire, the former Marquette coach and current game analyst for NBC Sports, picks the nation's top 20 teams, suggests nine coaching candidates for the 1988 United States Olympic basketball team, selects a six-man all-America squad and assembles the ''perfect basketball body.''

title: The Editorial Notebook; The 'Order of Battle,' Then and Now
description: Testimony in the case of Gen. William C. Westmoreland against CBS gives unexpected prominence to a military intelligence branch known as the Order of Battle. It informs commanders of the size, location and nature of the opposing forces.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Sports People column in some copies yesterday incorrectly described Brian Lawton. He was the first American-born player to be the No. 1 choice in the National Hockey League's draft.

title: CORRESPONDENT'S MEMO ON SHARON IS DESCRIBED
description: A bureau chief for Time magazine testified yesterday that he had relied on a correspondent's information for a key part of the article that prompted Ariel Sharon to sue the magazine for libel.

description: The Reagan Administration, saying ''quality of life'' must play no role in deciding whether infants should live, proposed rules Friday requiring treatment of handicapped newborn babies except in extreme cases.

description: Federal officials announced the arrest yesterday of a Chicago man they said had threatened to kill Caroline Kennedy, the daughter of the former President. They said he had threatened to blow up the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, where she works.

title: U.S. SYSTEM IS IN PLACE FOR CURBING DISASTERS
description: A highly organized Federal emergency response network now in place across the country could contain, but not entirely prevent, disasters of the kind caused by the leak of lethal gas in India, Government officials said today.

title: THOSE WHO WOULD DEFEAT KOCH HAVE YET TO UNIFY
description: Months after they began planning for a challenge of Mayor Koch, the liberal, labor and minority-group opposition is still split between the factions and within the factions on whom to back and how to do it.

title: John Alsop Rand,70,IsDead; Ex-LegislatorinConnecticut
description: John Alsop Rand, a lawyer and former member of the Connecticut House of Representatives, died Thursday at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Salisbury, Conn.

description: Citing ''continued weakening of the worldwide semiconductor market,'' Texas Instruments Inc. said yesterday that it would lay off 2,000 workers in January.

description: The Library of Congress called today for an effort by the Government and private groups to eliminate illiteracy in the nation by 1989, the bicentennial of the United States Constitution.

description: The Florida state legislature today approved a $6.4 million plan to aid nursery growers whose young citrus trees were destroyed in the fight against citrus canker.

description: The man charged with fatally stabbing a 23-year-old drama student on the roof of her Upper West Side apartment house has confessed to the police and ''given a detailed and graphic description of the murder,'' a prosecutor said yesterday.

He must tiptoe delicately into an opponent's hand at the right moment, a move that is appropriately known as a steppingstone.

description: A car dealer today advertised a ''Pearl Harbor Day sale'' with a newspaper advertisement showing pictures of the Japanese attack 43 years ago. The advertisement urged customers to buy ''American cars built in America by Americans.''

There isn't a sense of crisis now.''

The firm did not sue the gallery, although such an action was considered by the project's private developer.

description: Anti-Ethiopian rebels charged today that Government planes bombed and strafed famine victims fleeing into the Sudan, killing as many as 18 people and wounding 56.
