description: St. Ambrose stared down from the ornate gold, red and blue tapestry, a whip in one hand and a bishop's staff in the other, as Milan's Mayor handed out honors to citizens of a city whose residents sometimes call themselves ''Ambrosiani.''

title: Son of Founder Drops Suit To Close MacArthur Charity
description: The son of the founder of the MacArthur Foundation has dropped a lawsuit that sought to liquidate the charitable organization best known for its ''genius awards,'' the foundation said Thursday.

title: ON 10TH STREET, SOME LIKE THEIR BATH VERY HOT
description: ''This is an Old World kinda place,'' explained Max, a customer, ''a place where men are men.'' Big, fat men, in large part; naked men who sweat profusely in the steam bath before going upstairs to puff stogies, argue a game of gin rummy, converse in full chorus, tell dirty jokes, toss back shots of vodka, consume steaks the size of sides of beef - both sides - and proclaim that they would not want to be anywhere else in the world.

title: New Zealand Scolds France
description: Prime Minister David Lange criticized France today for the detonation earlier in the day of a 70- kiloton nuclear device at the French Government's Mururoa Atoll testing site in the South Pacific. ''It does not matter whether the tests are large or small,'' he said. ''What is offensive to New Zealanders is that the French continue their testing at all - despite the unequivocal official and public opposition evident not only within New Zealand, but also throughout the South Pacific region.''

title: CHARITY BGINS AT THE MOVIES
description: Early in his first term, nearly four

title: DYSAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: b-After writeoffs of approximately $34 million related to the company's previously announced consolidation of facilities, cessation of certain affiliates and curtailment of certain operations. c-Net income.

title: HEART RECIPIENT SHOWS DRAMATIC IMPROVEMENT
description: William J. Schroeder, the artificial heart patient, was removed from intensive care and put in a private room today after dramatic improvement was observed in his general condition.

title: DIODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $162,480 for the quarter and $258,159 for the 6 months.

title: GIANTS' NELSON WANTS TO BE ANONYMOUS
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Books of The Times; A Life of Drama
description: AUGUST STRINDBERG. By Olof Lagercrantz. Translated by Anselm Hollo.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF NEWS CONFERENCE WITH PRESIDENT;
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: JORDAN HITS JUMPER TO DEFEAT KNICKS
description: Michael Jordan, the Chicago Bulls' rookie star, hit a 20-foot jumper with five seconds remaining tonight that defeated the Knicks, 95-93. With three defenders pressing him, Jordan rose out of the pile, and his off-balance shot ended a Knick comeback from a 15-point third-quarter deficit.

title: Military Contracts
description: CFM International, a joint venture of the General Electric Company and Snecma of France, received a $318.7 million Air Force contract for 149 engines for the KC-135 tanker aircraft, the Defense Department said.

title: A Hand for the U.S.I.A.
description: Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States Information Agency, has frequently been at the center of public criticism as well as private carping inside his agency.

title: 'CIVILIZATION AND JEWS' ENJOYS BROAD APPEAL
description: If producers of the public television series ''Heritage: Civilization and the Jews'' had any worry about their program, it was that its appeal might be too specialized to attract a large audience nationwide. But according to officials at WNET-TV, New York's major public television station, where the show was produced, those concerns have proved wrong.

title: KOCH AIDES WANT CHANCELLOR TO HIRE SPECIALIST ON BUDGET
description: The Koch administration, increasingly unhappy with the way the Board of Education spends its money, has recommended to Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones that he hire a budget specialist of City Hall's choosing.

title: CUOMO TO GAIN FROM DELBELLO RESIGNATION, POLITICIANS ASSERT
description: Lieut. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello's resignation, combined with Governor Cuomo's possible Presidential ambitions, has made an often routine nomination critically important, Democratic and Republican politicians agreed yesterday.

title: PROVIDENCE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm looking at this as a total commitment to private life, the private sector. I'm not anticipating running for office again.'' - Lieut. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello. (26:5.)

title: EMPLOYEE AT INDIAN PLANT REPORTS AN EARLIER LEAK IN STORAGE TANK
description: An employee at the Union Carbide factory here who worked about 50 feet from the site of the gas leak Monday said today that the faulty storage tank had leaked a few days before the accident but that the problem had been corrected.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1984
description: The Economy

title: HENDERSON-YANKEE TALKS GO ON
description: The Yankees and Rickey Henderson, who began contract negotiations $13 million apart, called a recess early this morning in their effort to reach an agreement that would complete the Yankees' seven-player trade with the Oakland A's.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Media Overview
description: Also at Columbia, at the School of

title: SWIFT'S GENRE SEEN IN EDITORIAL COLUMNS
description: To the Editor:

title: Marcos Calls for Changes In Election Schedule
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, recovering from lung disorders that required his isolation for 24 days, has called for changes in the schedule of forthcoming elections, including one that enables him to choose his possible successor.

title: THRIFT UNITS TO RECEIVE SHARES OF FREDDIE MAC
description: In a move to strengthen the financial underpinnings of the nation's savings and loan associations, the Government today announced ''a paper transfer'' to the associations of the ownership of what has been a Government corporation.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Going Out Guide on Wednesday gave an incorrect date for a Juilliard American Opera Center performance of ''Il Trittico.'' It will be tomorrow at 2 P.M.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE DECLINES TO 7%
description: In an unexpected decline, the nation's unemployment rate fell three-tenths of a percentage point in November, to 7 percent, the Labor Department reported today.

title: NORWEGIAN INTEREST IN PHILLIPS SEEN
description: Norsk Hydro A/S, the Norwegian industrial giant, has expressed interest in negotiating with the Phillips Petroleum Company, possibly to buy part of it, international investment bankers said yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Busy Corner for Towing
description: A street scene to warm the heart of

title: RESPONSIBLE ROLE FOR UNWED TEEN-AGE FATHERS
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS ;
Laboratory Antibody Utilized in Cancer Tests
description: Dr. Samuel Bogoch of New York, a physician and research professor, this week received the fourth in a series of patents on cancer detection.

title: SAATCHI & SAATCHI CO reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
BUREAU CHIEF CALLS ARTICLE ONSHARON 'VERY FAIR'
description: ARNOLD H. LUBASCH

title: Run Reconsidered
description: Eric Dickerson, the Los Angeles Ram back who is closing in on O. J. Simpson's single-season rushing record, has picked up 11 more yards, and he didn't even have to run with the ball. The gain, which brought Dickerson 211 yards short of Simpson's 2,003, came on a re-evaluation play by the National Football League, which found that he had been improperly charged with an 11-yard loss in last Sunday's game against New Orleans.

title: THE NEW SCHOOL MARKS ANNIVERSARY IN BERLIN
description: In 1947, Vera List remembers, she was bored with courses at Columbia University and decided to try the New School for Social Research. ''The professor I had spoke such broken English that we had to strain to hear him,'' she said, ''but he was absolutely fascinating.''

title: Polish Group Supports Jailed Lutheran Pastor
description: The Polish Ecumenical Council has expressed its support for the Rev. Douglas Roth, a Lutheran pastor who is in jail as a result of his battle with both the church and Pennsylvania authorities, the Lutheran Council U.S.A. said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: DOUBLE TAKES Back before home entertainment entered the parlor through an array of electronics, it was the stereoscope that titillated the family of a cozy evening. Stereographs, in those years from the mid-1800's to the century's turn, were those pictures, double images, that when viewed through the scope made a scene spring to three-dimensional depth before one's very eyes. They were all the rage.

title: Company Agrees to Ad Tests
description: General Nutrition Centers, the nation's largest distributor of health foods, has agreed not to mail or advertise 13 products that Federal prosecutors say do not live up to their billing, a prosecutor said Thursday.

title: DELBELLO QUITTING NO. 2 ALBANY POST FOR INDUSTRY JOB
description: Alfred B. DelBello today announced his resignation as Lieutenant Governor of New York.

title: Laos Says It Expelled A U.S. Diplomat
description: The second-ranking American diplomat in Laos was expelled Nov. 24 because he violated a curfew, the Foreign Ministry disclosed this week.

title: U.S. CRITICIZES IRAN'S HANDLING OF HIJACKERS AND PUBLICITY FOR THEM
description: President Reagan criticized the Iranian Government today for its handling of the hijacking case in Teheran. But he stopped short of accusing Iran of complicity in the hijacking, which so far has led to the death of two Americans and two Kuwaitis.

title: LFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-After a loss of $1,155,000 for the quarter and 6 months from discontinued operations. c-Net income.

title: BALDRIDGE CRITICAL OF TREASURY BID TO END BUSINESS TAX BREAK
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today that he had serious doubts about a central provision of Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan's tax plan that would take away an important business tax break.

title: DEVILS SETTLE FOR TIE AFTER 2-GOAL LEAD
description: The Devils relinquished a two- goal advantage, fell behind, then came back and settled for a 3-3 tie with the Calgary Flames tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Duarte Seeks Publisher
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte

title: WORKED FOR WOMEN'S RIGHTS
description: Former Representative Cecil Murray Harden, an early advocate of women's rights who served five terms in the United States House of Representatives, died of cancer Wednesday at a nursing home in Lafayette, Ind. She was 90 years old.

title: MGM Hotel Stake
description: Kirk Kerkorian said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had raised his stake in MGM Grand Hotels Inc. to 69.4 percent of the common shares outstanding, or 15,739,173 common shares. He had owned 50.5 percent. According to the filing, the Tracinda Corporation, of which Mr. Kerkorian is the principal executive officer, acquired 4,287,734 MGM shares in a $12-a-share tender offer completed on Oct. 31. On the New York Stock Exchange today, MGM closed at $11.75, up 12.5 cent s.

title: INDIANS ARREST AND THEN FREE U.S. EXECUTIVE
description: The chairman of the Union Carbide Corporation was arrested today as he arrived in Bhopal and was charged with criminal conspiracy in connection with the insecticide plant gas leak that killed an estimated 2,100 people and injured tens of thousands. He was released on bail six hours later.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ; Comings and Goings
description: Steve Scott, a two-time winner and the defending champion, has entered the Wanamaker Mile at the Millrose Games Jan. 25. . . Geoff Huston, the Cleveland Cavalier guard who had been feuding with Coach George Karl, was waived, and Lonnie Shel ton, the power forward who had been sidelined by a knee injury, was reactivated. . . . Woody Widenhofer, former coach of the Oklahoma Outlaws of the United States Football Leagur, John Cooper of Tulsa and Gene Murphy of Fullerton State are among candidates for the vacant head-coaching job at Missouri. The three are to meet with the Missouri athletic director, Dave Hart , today.

title: CAMPANELLI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Rockcor May Be Takeover Target
description: A group led by American Investment Partners, a California partnership, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was considering seeking control of Rockcor Inc. through a proxy fight.

title: Boxing Defended
description: Jose Sulaiman, the president of the World Boxing Council, charged yesterday that the resolution passed by the American Medical Association this week urging a ban on boxing was an ''irresponsible and demagogic'' action that lacked scientific justification and would deprive the poor of an important avenue to success. Poverty-stricken young men, he said, ''see boxing not only as a means to a decent life but as society's open door to snatch many of them from the jaws of vice and hunger.''

title: AM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,781,000 and a gain of $29,000. c-Including a tax credit of $1,302,000.

title:
PATENTS ;
Device Aids Disabled In Computer Operation
description: A device to enable quadriplegics to operate a computer, a video game or the like by movements of the jaw and eyebrows was patented this week by John E. Fetchko, a respiratory therapist at the Bayonne, N.J., Hospital.

title: Soviet Press Focusing On Negligence Charges
description: Soviet press reports on the poison gas leak in India have focused on allegations by Indian officials that the American company Union Carbide was negligent.

title: Frazier on Line In a New League
description: Oft-told tales of how many talented basketball players there are coming out of college every year and of how few spots there are for them on National Basketball Association rosters, have apparently helped spawn a new professional league. On Dec. 20, at a news conference in New York, the United States Basketball League plans to announce such details as franchise cities, team owners, the length of the playing season and draft dates.

title: Duke University Names Successor to Sanford
description: Duke University named Dr. H. Keith Brodie its seventh president today, ending a 10- month search for a successor to Terry Sanford.

title: INTERCOLE INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $731,000.

title: Instant Revenge
description: They call Marty Glickman ''coach'' because of his job at NBC-TV: After every National Football League game that the network televises, he phones the announcers and analyzes their work. Now the tables are about to be turned.

title: DONORS TO NEEDIEST CITE THEIR MEMORIES OF FAMILY MEMBERS
description: As the holiday season approaches, memories of departed family members and friends in festive times past, mixed with thoughts of those less fortunate today, are often cited as reasons for contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: The Chance in Chile Although Chile's Government has met a mounting protest with a persuasive show of force, the Reagan Administration is right to worry about that country's stability. General Pinochet's rigidity has had the unintended effect of radicalizing much of the opposition and enhancing the political weight of Marxists. The Administration seems ready to recognize that the time has come to resist this trend by combining pressure and mediation to move Chile toward a democratic future.
description: The movement toward democracy in Argentina, Brazil, Bolivia, Peru and Uruguay has rekindled the spirit of protest in recession-bound Chile. But if General Pinochet continues to use his military dominance to cling to power at any price, the price could be enormous. For Chile: violence, economic crisis and political extremism. For Chile's creditors: lower prospects for repayment. For Chile's neighborhood: instability.

title: GANDALF TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27

Jacobs Raises Stake in ITT MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 7 (AP) - Irwin L. Jacobs, the financier, said today that his stockbroker had been able to fill his order Thursday for 3.8 million shares of ITT stock despite an initial mixup on the New York Stock Exchange in handling part of the deal. That is about 3 percent of the ITT Corporation's common stock.
description: Jefferies & Company, Mr. Jacobs's broker, bought one block of 2 million ITT shares at 30 3/8 each Thursday, then a few minutes later thought it had purchased an additional 1.8 million shares at 30 1/2 each. That would have been a total purchase of about $115 million.

title: LOBBYIST WITH A TARGET: SOUTH AFRICA
description: Randall Robinson is spending more time organizing, coordinating and demonstrating these days than attending to his job as a foreign policy lobbyist.

title: Seymour Fogel Is Dead at 73; Artist Created Public Works
description: Seymour Fogel, who created murals and other public art works in the New York area for the past half century, died Tuesday at Norwalk Hospital in Norwalk, Conn., after suffering a heart attack. He was 73 years old and lived in Weston, Conn.

title: BRAEK IN TAIL IS CITED IN FATAL AIR CRASH
description: A Provincetown-Boston Airline plane crashed in Florida Thursday because part of its tail broke away in flight, a Federal safety official said yesterday.

title: HOUSE PANEL TOLD OF BOGUS DOCTOR WHO LEFT A PATIENT 'A VEGETABLE'
description: A bogus doctor botched an operation and left the patient ''a brainless vegetable'' at the Fort Dix hospital in New Jersey last year, a Congressional investigating panel was told today.

title: Man Is Accused of Enslaving A Woman for Sexual Torture
description: A mill worker has been ordered to stand trial on charges that he kidnapped a woman, then enslaved and tortured her for seven years.

title: A $340 MILLION COMPLEX ANNOUNCED FOR BROOKLYN
description: An agreement to build a $340 million office, retail and research complex in downtown Brooklyn was announced yesterday by city officials.

title: GROUPS PREPARING STRATEGY ON CUTS
description: The Reagan Administration's tentative budget proposals came under attack today from a wide range of interested parties, including supporters of child nutrition programs, farmers, city and county officials, veterans and Federal employees.

title: Chinaglia to Play
description: In an effort to generate enthusiasm on the field and to attract fans to the indoor games, Giorgio Chinaglia, the president and majority owner, came out of retirement yesterday and will play for the Cosmos again.

title: Victim of Shooting WinsSuitinJersey
description: A jury today awarded more than $3.5 million to the family of a California woman who was paralyzed in 1981 when she was struck in the back by a bullet fired by a deranged woman in Newark's Pennsylvania Station.

title: WHEN A LAWYER IS REMISS
description: Most purchases can be examined before they are paid for: clothes can be tried on, cars can be driven, stereos can be heard. Not so lawyers. It is difficult to judge a lawyer before hiring one, other than on the basis of experience and the advice of friends, and equally difficult to know where to turn when you believe that your lawyer is not acting in your best interests.

title: Relative of an InformerIs Killed Near Palermo
description: The brother-in-law of Tomasso Buscetta, the former Mafia chieftain whose dislosures led to one of Italy's biggest anti-crime operations, was killed tonight, the police said.

title: MAGNA INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.25-11.50 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ASSOCIATES OF BECKETT SEEK TO HALT PRODUCTION
description: Representatives of the playwright Samuel Beckett are seeking to halt the production of ''Endgame'' that began previews last night and will formally open on Dec. 12 at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass.

title: KIMONO INDUSTRY'S DISTRESS
description: For more than a thousand years, the Nishijin silk weavers of Kyoto have endured devastating fires, the wrath of austerity-minded shoguns, even an edict a century ago ordering all Government workers to wear Western clothes.

title: MODERN CONTROLS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CORRRECTIONS
description: An article in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday about the New York Knicks' loss to the Dallas Mavericks incorrectly described the crowd that remained when the Mavericks turned the game into a rout.

title: Cyanide Pill Stock Rejected
description: Washington University students, by a wide margin, have rejected a proposal to require the school to stock lethal cyanide pills to be available to students in the aftermath of a nuclear war. The proposal was defeated Thursday, 726 to 189, with the university's 4,500 undergraduate students eligible to vote. Supporters said the purpose of the proposal was to attract attention to the horrors of nuclear war.

title: WORDS OF LEAD
description: Not surprisingly, the television- besotted Reagan Administration has a very thin performance record when it comes to enriching the English language.

title: THE COMMON COLD IS GOOD FOR YOU
description: The common cold, according to recent reports, may be an endangered species. If medical scientists are to be believed, facial tissues treated with special virus-killing chemicals could prevent the spread of colds. Apparently, indiscriminate coughs and sneezes don't hold a candle to tissues when it comes to distributing cold germs.

title: Price-Deloitte Merger Backed
description: The British Government has given antitrust clearance to the proposed merger of Price Waterhouse and Deloitte Haskins & Sells, spokesmen for the two accounting firms said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1984 International Union Carbide's chairman was arrested as he arrived in Bhopal, India, and charged with criminal conspiracy in connection with the insecticide plant gas leak that killed an estimated 2,100 people and injured many thousands more. Warren M. Anderson, the chairman, was later freed on bail. Two senior officials of Union Carbide India Ltd. who were arrested with him remain in custody. (Page 1, Column 2.) Arab hijackers threatened to kill more of their hostages aboard a Kuwaiti airliner in Teheran and said that they had killed two American and two Kuwaiti passengers, the Iranian press agency reported. Reports from Teheran indicated that about 50 people, including the four or five hijackers, were still on the plane, and that passengers had been tied to their seats. (1:3.)

title: FOR CHRISTMAS, A ROUNDUP OF FASHIONS AND FANCIES
description: It would be nice to buy everyone a dirk for Christmas this year and call it a day. But we can't. Everyone does not need an agate pin to fasten his or her kilt.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Boston Celtics, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. The defending champions visit New Jersey for the first time this season. (Television - Sports Channel, 10:45 P.M., tape. Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:30 P.M.)

title:
PATENTS ;
Ultraviolet Rays Used On Telephone Bacteria
description: A Los Angeles inventor was granted a patent this week for a bacteria-destroying apparatus to be used with telephones.

title: AN EMBATTLED CHAIRMAN
description: Warren M. Anderson, the chairman of the Union Carbide Corporation, had said he wanted to visit the central Indian city of Bhopal to gauge how much aid was needed after a leak at a company-owned insecticide plant killed an estimated 2,100 people, his associates recalled.

title: PEABODY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $114,000 for the quarter and $58,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $9,526,000.

title: COMP-U-CARD INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $190,000 for the quarter and $368,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss.

title: Limited-Service Banks Are Barred in Florida
description: A moratorium on operations in Florida of limited-service, or ''non-bank,'' banks was overwhelmingly approved Thursday night by the State Legislature.

title: Helping the Symphony
description: Forty couples, most of them out-

title: Edelman Buys Into Datapoint Asher B. Edelman, a New
description: York investor, said he would

title: UNION CARBIDE DOWN
description: Stock prices finished moderately lower yesterday, with Union Carbide again holding the spotlight as its price continued to drop.

title: MAILER AND CALDWELL JOIN ACADEMY'S SELECT 50
description: The American Academy of Arts and Letters, which is limited to 50 members from the worlds of literature, art and music, elevated two authors - Norman Mailer and Erskine Caldwell - to its ranks yesterday.

title: HCW INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CITY'S PROGRAM ON CHILD ABUSE SEEN AS LAGGING
description: New York City's program to protect children from abuse is plagued by serious deficiencies and ''leaves much to be desired,'' according to a new study by the State Department of Social Services.

title: LEAVE THE RETIREMENT ACT ALONE
description: As the Administration looks for ways to narrow the budget deficit and to simplify our tax system, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, just 10 years old this year, is coming under attack.

title: CANADA TO EASE CURBS ON FOREIGN INVESTMENT
description: Canada's Progressive Conservative Government today proposed the abolition of many rules that set out to control the type and size of foreign investment in the nation.

title: PHYSICIANS INSURANCE COMPANY (OHIO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BLACKS STILL LOOKING FOR A CANDIDATE
description: The fragile alliance of black leaders that hopes to unseat Mayor Koch is struggling to find a single challenger behind whom it can unite. With the mayoral election year less than a month away, members of the alliance have been troubled by their failure to identify a candidate who is both viable and black.

title: THE SURGE IN HOLIDAY IMPORTS
description: Hasbro's G.I. Joe, advertised as ''a real American hero,'' and Mattel's Barbie and Ken, the quintessential teen-age American couple, are made in Hong Kong. And the new Michael Jackson doll, a vinyl lookalike of America's favorite pop idol, complete with glittering glove and microphone, is made in China.

title: METS TRADE TERRELL TO TIGERS
description: The Mets satisfied some of their craving for more power today when they traded Walt Terrell, one of their starting pitchers, to the Detroit Tigers for Howard Johnson, a switch-hitting third baseman with a strong bat but risky glove.

title: RANGERS LOSE IN OVERTIME
description: In the final two minutes, the Rangers wasted a 3-2 lead that had been built on superb goaltending and two goals by James Patrick. The Pittsburgh Penguins tied the game with 1 minute 32 seconds remaining and then Randy Hillier scored at 1:35 of overtime to beat the Rangers, 4-3, last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: ARMY IN SRI LANKA IS SAID TO KILL 102
description: More than 100 people were shot dead after a guerrilla attack on an army convoy in northwest Sri Lanka, official sources said today.

title: TORTURE WILL STOP WHEN THE TRUTH OF IT IS TOLD
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESLEY COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Polynice Disappears
description: Stung by public criticism that has followed his exoneration on a cheating charge, Olden Polynice, the center for Virginia's basketball team, has secluded himself and will miss the game against Duke tonight, the Cavaliers' first Atlantic Coast Conference matchup of the season. According to Coach Terry Holland, Polynice attended practice Thursday and then sent a note indicating that he would drop off the squad for a while.

title: THE DAY LOS ANGELES'S BUBBLE BURST
description: My pal Jerry P. just bought a condominium in Century City, in Beverly Hills, for 60 percent of what it sold for in 1980. Down the street from me here in the Hollywood hills, four houses have been on the market since 1981. The asking prices now are about one-third less than they were three years ago. Up and down Sunset Boulevard in West Hollywood, apartment houses that were converted to condos lie empty, boarded up, not one unit sold, in bankruptcy, with banks holding title.

title: 26TH CHESS DRAW SETS RECORD
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov agreed today to a draw in the 31st game of their world chess championship match, breaking the record for most draws in a title contest.

title: SURVIVORS OF GAS HUNT FOR MISSING
description: As shops reopened in Bhopal today and survivors returned home, many people were still searching for missing relatives, four days after poison gas escaped from a chemical plant here.

title: REAGAN HAILS PLAN ON TAX AND HINTS CUTS FOR MILITARY
description: Transcript of news session, page 10.

title: Ornery Missiles It is wholesome that nations tremble at the thought of nuclear war, but even that deadly subject can benefit from perspective. Nuclear strategists and politicians have speculated glibly about ''surgical first strikes,'' as if there were imminent danger of - or opportunity for - perfectly timed salvos of hundreds of missiles that destroy the other side's missiles in their underground silos.
description: Engineers know better, knowing how hard it is to launch a single missile on time.

title: AMF Funds
description: AMF Inc. said it expects to recover about $100 million in excess funds from its salaried employee pension plan.

title: FRANCE REPLACES FOREIGN MINISTER
description: Roland Dumas, a close friend of President Francois Mitterrand, was named Foreign Minister today, replacing Claude Cheysson.

title: Governor of Kentucky Is Home After Surgery
description: Gov. Martha Layne Collins arrived home in Kentucky today, 16 days after undergoing emergency surgery in Britain to remove a shard of glass from her intestines.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: Son Is Born to an Activist
description: Reve Walsh, who became active in the cause of missing children after her son, Adam, was kidnapped and beheaded in Florida three years ago, gave birth to a son Thursday, hospital officials said today. The infant, Callahan Walsh, weighed 6 pounds and 12 ounces. Mrs. Walsh and her husband, John, are temporarily living in Oakton, Va. They have a 2-year-old daughter, Meghan.

title: 2 Claim Prizes In Jersey Lottery
description: A 71- year-old woman and a man who cleans repossessed cars for a living cashed winning lottery tickets today worth $2.7 million each. Three others who will share in the record $13.9 million state jackpot remained unknown.

title: REAGAN REJECTS TUTU'S PLEA FOR TOUGH POLICY ON PRETORIA
description: President Reagan assured Bishop Desmond Tutu today that the Administration was opposed to apartheid in South Africa, but he rejected a plea for tougher actions in place of quiet American diplomacy.

title: David Merrick Seeks Control of His Estate
description: The Broadway producer David Merrick today asked a court to restore personal control of his $50 million theatrical empire, saying he is fully recovered from a 1983 stroke and tired of paying lawyers to handle his business.

title: Sutter Becomes a Brave ATLANTA, Dec. 7 (AP) - Bruce Sutter, a free-agent relief pitcher,
description: worth $9.6 million that includes a no-trade clause and deferred compensation. The announcement was made at a news conference at the headquarters of the Turner Broadcasting System, where Sutter, his agents

title: Murderer Commits Suicide
description: Charles Hatcher, who confessed he murdered 16 people in a 13-year nomadic tour of the country, was found hanged today in his cell at the Missouri penitentiary.

title: Avoiding Amputation In Cancer Is Evaluated
description: Many cancers in the arms and legs no longer require amputation if doctors use an aggressive combination of treatments, experts have concluded.

title: Lebanese Soldier Killed
description: A Lebanese soldier was killed and three other people were wounded in fighting between army units and gunmen in Beirut today, military sources said. Three other people were wounded south of Beirut in fighting between the mainly Druse Progressive Socialist Party and the Christian Lebanese Forces militia.

title: Czechs Refuse Visa Request Of Nobel Winner's Secretary
description: The daughter of the Czechoslovak poet Jaroslav Seifert said today that her father's secretary had been denied his request for an exit permit to collect the 1984 Nobel Literature Prize on behalf of her 83-year-old father.

title: Mr. DelBello Leaves an Empty Job To become lieutenant governor of New York, a candidate must win nomination on his own and then run in the general election coupled with the nominee for Governor. Since the official duties are only what governors want them to be, lieutenant governors not chosen by their running mates are not likely to have many responsibilities of interest. Unless they can see vistas of political advance, they become restive.
description: Lieut. Gov. Alfred DelBello could not become a member of Governor Cuomo's inner circle. Worse, he may have doubted his chances for renomination in 1986, when Mr. Cuomo would be tempted to balance his own name with that of someone not also of Italian heritage.

title: Stacy Keach Sentenced In British Cocaine Case
description: The American actor Stacy Keach pleaded guilty today to importing 1.3 ounces of cocaine into Britain and immediately started serving a nine- month prison sentence. He told the court he was ''terribly sorry'' and deeply humiliated.

And so when the little nutcracker chopped off the crown of the seven-headed mouse king and held it up in triumph, even the most uninitiated spectators in the State Theater Thursday night knew enough - as the music swelled - to applaud the victory of good over evil.

description: Moses Malone scored 35 points, 16 in a third-period spurt, as the Philadelphia 76ers beat the Los Angeles Lakers, 122-116, tonight.

description: Those infamous revolving doors leading to and from prison are spinning rather rapidly, a new Federal study suggested last week. Based on information from 14 states, the Justice Department found that nearly a third of all inmates were back behind bars within three years of their release, at least half of them for committing new crimes rather than violating parole.

description: ''GOOD MORNING, ladies and gentlemen, this is the first revenue run of the Housatonic Railroad. It's been a long time in coming. We're on our way to Falls Village.''

title: Compulsory Air
description: In the flurry of bills that Governor Cuomo signed into law before the Legislature adjourned earlier this year was one that required all gasoline stations with four or more fuel pumps to have a motor-driven air pump for customer use.

title: FLYNT CLEARED OF LIBEL BUT MUST PAY $200,000
description: A Federal jury tonight found Larry Flynt, publisher of Hustler magazine, not guilty of libeling the Rev. Jerry Falwell in a parody advertisement accusing the evangelist of drunkenness and incest but awarded him a total of $200,000 in damages.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
THERE ARE DANGERS IN THE USE OF POLLS
description: TOO much of a good thing can be harmful. The use of polls in the American electoral process is a case in point.

title: RAILROAD TO TEST SATELLITE SYSTEM
description: The Burlington Northern railroad plans to test a system that would track its trains with precision by using a satellite guidance network. The network could someday be used to find ships on voyages and trucks making deliveries.

title: 13 Die in Mozambique Clash
description: Thirteen people, including seven East Germans and one Yugoslav, were killed in a rebel ambush in northern Mozambique Wednesday, the Mozambican Government said today. The foreigners, who were described as technicians, and the five Mozambicans who died all worked at a state farm in northern Niassa Province, the Government said.

title: PLAN FOR FARM SITE DEBATED
description: ANEW ROCHELLE farm acquired in 1698 by one of the city's early Huguenot settlers, Pierre Bonnet, the site of a rambling low-ceilinged pre-Revolutionary farmhouse, a barn, chicken coop and pond, may be carved into five pieces under plans being considered by the New Rochelle Zoning Board of Appeals and Planning Board.

title: Margaretta Haines, Travel Agent, Wed
description: Margaretta Gibson Haines was married yesterday to G. Paull T. Sargent 2d at St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square, in Washington. The Rev. Dr. John C. Harper performed the ceremony.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: New & Noteworthy AMERICAN BEAUTY, By Lois W. Banner. (University of Chicago, $9.95.) A description of changes during the 19th and 20th centuries in the shapes of women, mainly in the size of their hips, breasts and waists - faces are ignored. Lois W. Banner identifies four types of beauty in the evolution of the American conception of the beautiful woman, including the buxom type (Lillian Russell) and the small, boyish type (Mary Pickford, Clara Bow). Our reviewer, Carl N. Degler, noting that all the types were ''drawn from the white upper class,'' called this 1983 book ''highly readable and broad ranging.'' THE PEGNITZ JUNCTION, by Mavis Gallant. (Graywolf, $6.) The novella and five short stories in ''The Peg nitz Junction'' are set in post- World War II Europe. William H. Pritchard wrote in The Book Review in 1973 that the stories were ''serious and crafted.'' In the final one, ''An Alien Flower,'' a refugee woman moves in with the narrator and the narrator's husband. Mr. Pritchard said the ''reader enters most fully into Mavis Gallant's imagination, artful and moral in 'An Alien Flower' to the extent that (the story) bears comparison with a Chekhov's or a Katherine Anne Porter's.''

title: A BATIK OF TEMPLES AND PALACES
description: The afternoon sunlight slants into the Jakarta Kota station, casting patterns of shadow and light on the commuters and travelers crowding the platforms, an intricate batik in motion. The stationmaster makes his last call for the 4 P.M. Bima express, the night train bound for the central Java cities of Jogjakarta and Solo, then east to Surabaya. Quickly, friends pass packages wrapped in brightly colored cloth and old newspapers up through windows to passengers already in their seats; farther down the platform, a straggler, struggling with a large basket containing a rooster - perhaps a fighting cock - jumps into the third-class car as the train slowly pulls out of the station, weaving its way through a tangle of tracks, creaking past old Dutch buildings with roofs of red tile and shanties with lacey roofs of tin.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: After a fling at Off Broadway theater that included ''She Stoops to Conquer'' and her one-woman show, ''Hey, Ma . . . Kaye Ballard,'' Miss Ballard returns to cabaret on Tuesday at Michael's Pub where, in a review called ''Here's to the Ladies,'' she will sing for the next five weeks the songs of three Broadway lyricists - Carolyn Leigh, who wrote the words to ''Hey, Look Me Over,'' ''Witchcraft,'' ''The Best Is Yet To Come,'' Dorothy Fields (''I Can't Give You Anything But Love,'' ''On the Sunny Side of the Street,'' ''If My Friends Could See Me Now'') and Nancy Hamilton (''How High the Moon'' and ''The Old Soft Shoe'').

title: WILL A WRINKLE IN TAX LAW BRING A VIRGIN ISLAND WINDFALL?
description: Virgin Islanders are hoping for a blizzard this winter. A paper blizzard, that is. With Friday's release by the United States Treasury Department of rules and regulations to guide American exporters setting up tax-saving foreign sales corporations, the United States Virgin Islands hopes to become home to thousands of new paper companies.

title: LOOKING TO THE LONG TERM
description: Compensation specialists are convinced that anything that makes managers think and behave like owners would be a good way to improve long-term corporate performance. Where they split, however, is on whether stock prices accurately reflect long- term executive performance, and if it is fair to tie a major portion of executive compensation to the vagaries of Wall Street.

title: POPULAR SONGS FORM A SMITHSONIAN HISTORY
description: When Martin Williams, the director of the Jazz Program at the Smithsonian Institution, created a six-disk survey of recorded jazz in 1973, ''The Smithsonian Collection of Classic Jazz,'' he not only broke through the barriers that had prevented recordings controlled by one company from being mingled with those controlled by other companies and thus made possible really representative record collections, but, by his choice of selections and his annotations, he established a model for such overviews of an area of recorded music.

title: SHULTZ, WEINBERGER NONDIFFERENCES
description: It has been widely taken as something of a paradox that Secretary of State George P. Shultz has emerged within the Reagan Administration as a vigorous advocate of the use of force, while the Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger advocates caution and discrimination in the application of American military power. In fact, there may be less to their apparent differences than meets the eye.

title: CREATIVITY BECALMED
description: ANY ACCURATE REPORT ON THE state of fashion, particularly at the middecade mark, demands commentary on the present paucity of genuine creativity. This is not to say that the current crop of clothes, as well as those for next spring, are not, in the main, appealing and attractive. They are. Nor would it be correct to say that these new fashions are totally devoid of novelty. They are not, as the surge of shorter hemlines - midknee or above - from all the fashion capitals demonstrates. This is certainly a demonstrable departure from the longer lengths that have so dominated fashionable clothing during the last several seasons. Then, too, there is the international use of fabrics in vivid colors or vibrant prints; they have not been stylishly employed for some time. And everywhere one looks, there are clothes deliberately shaped to define the body in dressmaking ways that were more familiar to the 1950's than today's more easygoing styles.

title: AFTER A YEAR OF GUIDING TRANSIT, KILEY IS A LITTLE OFF SCHEDULE
description: When he first announced plans to gain more control over the hiring and firing of supervisors of the city's subway and bus system, Robert R. Kiley said he felt as if he had revealed a ''deep dark secret.'' He said, ''I was advised that this sort of behavior simply wasn't acceptable in New York. Problems like these, it seems, were to be discussed behind closed doors.''

title: THE WORLD ; Marcos FightsIllness Rumors
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines bared his chest to his Cabinet and to a television audience yesterday to scotch rumors he was seriously ill and had undergone heart surgery. The rumors, which had contributed to the uncertainty surrounding Mr. Marcos's much-contested leadership, had been strengthened a few days earlier by a member of his cabinet, Blas Ople, the Labor Minister. Mr. Ople said Mr, Marcos was ''in control but cannot take major initiatives at this time.''

title: 'MESSIAH' IS SOUNDING DIFFERENT NOW
description: ''Messiah'' at Christmastide is an established amateur sport for choral groups everywhere, but this week, New York hears two fully professional choirs sing Handel's oratorio in performances that promise great differences but may end up having much in common.

title: HIJACKERS FREE 39 AT AIRPORT IN IRAN BUT STILL HOLD 18 By Reuters
description: Arab hijackers holding a Kuwaiti airliner at the airport here freed 39 more hostages today, but still retained 18, including two Americans and three Kuwaiti officials, diplomats and the Iranian press agency said.

title: Fan Treatment Is Called Unfair
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: L.I. OFFICIALS CALLED TO ALBANY ON TRASH CIRISIS
description: BY summoning Long Island's County Executives and several town officials to a meeting in Albany next week on solid-waste disposal problems, Governor Cuomo injected himself into one of the most troubling and far- reaching problems now facing the Island.

title: SLEEPLESS NIGHTS FOR PUCCINI'S GHOST
description: Linda Ronstadt's attempt to cross over into opera territory by singing Mimi in a Public Theater production of ''La Boh eme'' raises many questions. Most of them, unfortunately, can be answered in a word. Does she sing the part? No. Does she act it? No. Is Puccini's ghost having sleepless nights? Probably. Miss Ronstadt, a superstar of popular music, simply does not possess the vocal heft, the technique or the dramatic sense to satisfy anyone who knows the opera. Her colorless, unsupported soprano, even while amplified by body microphones, produces a sound startingly like Minnie Mouse in extremis, and she acts with all the expressive power of a damp dish cloth.

title: YES, HEALTH CARE MUST BE PAID FOR
description: AS the county's first self-contained Ambulatory Surgery Center was dedicated last week at the White Plains Hospital Medical Center, we recognized one of the many changing trends in health care today; the delivery of a cost-effective alternative to in-patient hospital care. A patient, receiving the same operation that once required two, three or even four days of hospitalization, can now be admitted, operated on and released from the hospital, all in the same day.

title: AMBULANCE SERVICE DEBATED
description: -half months pregnant, began to hemorrhage. Her daughter called 911 and requested an ambulance.

title: U.S. to Test Cruise Missiles Over Canadian Terrain in '85
description: The United States and Canada have reached an agreement to conduct the first live-fire tests of the cruise missile over Canadian territory early next year.

title:
ART ;
INDIVIDUALISM AT THE KATONAH GALLERY
description: EVERY artist knows he is an artist, but the group now showing at the Katonah Gallery seems especially innocent and self-effacing. They can't help but hoe their own rows outside of any collective tradition. This individuality is what sets today's folk artist apart from his predecessors.

title: IONA RETAINS ITS TITLE
description: Rory Grimes scored four free throws and a basket in the final 1 minute 36 seconds as Iona held off Idaho State, 74-69, to win the seventh Manufacturers Hanover Classic tonight.

title: MENTAL HOSPITAL TO ALTER DISCHARGE PRACTICES
description: The practice of driving patients who have been discharged from a mental hospital in Austin to Houston and dropping them off at a bus depot will stop, state officials have said after learning that many of them ended up wandering the streets.

title: NORTH'S FIRST EQUITY CABARET
description: SECAUCUS WHO killed Dixie Braddock, a nasty rhythm- and-blues singer who took over an orphanage so that she could start her own record company - Orphan Records - and then threw out the children and the nuns in charge.

title: Tanker Overturns in Oregon
description: A major highway was reopened and dozens of people who had been evacuated were allowed to return home early today after crews emptied 1,000 gallons of explosive acetone from an overturned tank truck. The highway, Interstate 5, was reopened at 3:05 A.M., about an hour after those evacuated were allowed to return, the police said. Traffic had been diverted to secondary roads for nine and a half hours.

title: TREASURES SEIZED BY NAZIS ARE COMING OUT OF THE CLOSET
description: When the Austrian Government announced last week that it would auction off 3,900 works of art that had been confiscated by the Nazis in World War II, the spokesman was asked why it had taken 30 years to decide what to do with the works. Saying it was a ''very good question,'' he replied that the delay was caused by red tape in sorting out the claims to the art, and in reaching a consensus on what to do with unclaimed works.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO USE EVERGREENS IN DECORATION
description: EVERGREEN boughs have been used in the celebration of winter festivals and holidays at least as long as there has been a recorded history. Not only do they brighten up our homes, businesses and places of worship during dreary winter days, but they represent the promise of spring to come and the continuation of life, as well. As a result, their use has often been tied in with religious symbolism. This is especially true of their use during Christmas.

title: TEEN-AGE SUICIDE EXPLORED
description: ''NO one really knows why three times more teenagers are committing suicide today than they did in the Eisenhower years,'' said the psychiatrist Alvin Rosenfeld at a recent workshop on adolescent suicide. ''Under circumstances where answers really aren't available, perhaps the best thing we can do is to ask the right questions.''

title: 8-Hour Fire Damages Connecticut Complex
description: A fire gutted a supermarket, a three- story office building and seven other stores in a shopping complex here yesterday. Officials said it took firefighters eight hours to bring the blaze under control.

title: AN ABC STRATEGY GOES WRONG
description: This year had all the makings of the

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in the Personal Investing section on Nov. 18 incorrectly stated as fact an allegation in a pending case against Thomas C. Reed, a former national security adviser in the Reagan Administration. The government charges that Mr. Reed traded illegally in shares of Amax Inc. on the basis of information obtained from his father, an Amax director, but both Mr. Reed and his father deny that they exchanged information.

title: ; ROBOTS ARE MORE EQUAL THAN HUMANS
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran Takeover Stamp Is Being Sold for $45
description: Investors who acquired Iranian postage stamps commemorating the takeover of the United States Embassy in Teheran are offering them as Christmas gifts and are getting customers, although some dealers say the stamps, at $45 each, are overpriced.

title: PAGANINI'S MUSIC TESTS VIRTUOSITY
description: K. Robert Schwarz writes frequently about music.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
SHAPING A GOBLET TO SUIT A WINE
description: Our tongues have no fewer than five ''taste zones'': salty, tart, sweet at the edge of the tongue, carbon- acidic at the tip and salty bitter at the back. This is why, according to a family of Tyrolean glassmakers that has practiced its art for 10 generations, every wine should have its specially shaped glass, to enable the liquid to flow onto the right area of the tongue at the right time. The 14 ''Sommelier'' glasses - of which the largest, a 37-ounce size intended for vintage Burgundy, was a favorite of both Winston Churchill and Aristotle Onassis - were developed for this purpose by Prof. Claus Josef Riedel of Kufstein in the Austrian Tyrol. They are only one of his innovations in glass.

title: BUYING WOOD? KNOW A CORD
description: THROUGHOUT Connecticut, owners of fireplaces and wood stoves are stocking up on fuel for their holiday fires as well as for heating their homes over the cold weeks to follow.

title: A BUSY TIME FOR YOUTH ORCHESTRAS
description: THE seats are arranged in proper orchestral fashion, with dozens of sneakered feet dangling beneath them. As the conductor steps up to the podium, 25 violins are taken out of rest position and planted firmly under small chins. Backs are straight, eyes raised as the conductor lowers her baton. Orchestra rehearsal has begun.

title: Schiro and Fry Winners Of Cross-Country Runs
description: Cathy Schiro of Dover, N.H., and Scott Fry of Sandusky, Ohio, ran away from the nation's best high school cross-country runners today to win the boy's and girl's titles in the sixth annual Kinney Cross-Country Championships at Balboa Park.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: Secure saplings with guy wires....Spray anti-desiccants on evergreens....Spray rosebushes once again with fungicide for disease control and cover each crown with a mound of soil....Clean and store power and hand tools, houses and watering cans. More Books Good gardens design seems to be the theme for this years's gift editions. Although many books are imports and written for English gardeners, can inspire Americans in a way that only the English can do. Graham Stuart Thomas, who is consultant to the National Trust in Great Britain, is a well-known plantsman. His latest book to appear ''The Art of Planting'' ($24.95, David Godine) is the outcome of the first Fraser lecture given to the Royal Horticultural Society. It should become a well-worn treasure. Mr. Thomas has analyzed trees, shrubs, perennials and bulbous plants for incorporate them in plantings. There are generous lists and as the author claims ''Colour, form, light and shade, grouping, all have to be studied in the composition of one of those living pictures which the gardener paints with living marterials.''

title: Data Update
description: * Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: HOSPITALS TO BE BUILT IN DOBBS FERRY
description: GROUNDBREAKING ceremonies last weekend for a $14 million, 50 acute-bed hospital in Dobbs Ferry capped a 13- year fight to persuade state and Federal officials to allow residents of the village to replace its 91-year-old facility.

title: THE SEDUCTION OF THE COLTS
description: Jeffrey Kluger is an editor at Family Circle magazine.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CONCERT AT UCONN

title: SCHOOL CASE BACKS AN ANCIENT RITUAL
description: A school board attorney has ruled that a third- grade student who missed school for a month so she could become a priestess of a centuries-old African religion was legitimately absent under the constitutional guarantees of religious freedom.

title: HEALTHY MALONE A THREAT
description: Clemon Johnson is the Philadelphia 76ers' backup center, which means he gets to play when Moses Malone needs a rest or is injured or the score is one-sided.

title: AFTER A BUYING SPREE, CAN HE MOVE THE COMPANY AHEAD?
description: VEVEY, Switzerland

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
4 'NUTCRACKERS' SPIN THEIR MAGIC
description: LONG ISLAND is ''Nutcracker'' country this year, as an unprecedented number of holiday performances by four area ballet companies take to local stages. Snowflakes, bonbons and a dozen young Claras will make their debuts, and seasoned professionals, be they choreographers or dancers, will breathe new life into the full- length classical ballet, with its beloved Tchaikovsky score.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR On Self-Motivation And Teen-Agers
description: According to Kay S. Long (''When College Is Not a Good Option,'' Nov. 11), college is not a good choice for a young person who lacks motivation. Parents should regard such children as they would a business venture, as a kind of stock option not to be taken.

title: VETERANS SHARE A VIEW OF VIETNAM
description: THERE are two Jerry Krawczyks at the Michaelian County Office Building in White Plains. One, a 37-year-old, 200-pound bearded Eastchester resident in jacket and tie, works on the first floor as a program analyst for the Office of Employment and Training. The other, a 19-year-old, 170-pound, beardless Port Chester resident in combat fatigues, is a portrait hanging on the wall of the second-floor Bridge Gallery. The younger Jerry Krawczyk fought in a war in a tiny Southeast Asian country, a conflict that, 18 years later, the other Jerry Krawczyk can't forget.

title: TWO PRINT SHOWS TESTIFY TO THE VITALITY OF THE PRINT
description: Aside from the fact that they're both print shows, they don't have too much in common. ''Goya: The Disasters of War and Selected Prints From the Collection of the Arthur Ross Foundation,'' uptown at the Spanish Institute, 684 Park Avenue at 68th Street, presents etchings (and one lithograph) of the 18th-century Spanish master. ''Intuition and the Block Print, A New York Obsession,'' downtown at John Nichols Printmakers and Publishers, 83 Grand Street, deals with the use of wood and linoleum block by current New York artists. Yet in their poles- apartness, the two serve as reminders that even in print shows, there is an enormous range available in New York at any given moment, a marvelous melange of centuries, styles, mediums.

title: WHY CAIN WAS MURDERED
description: To the Editor:

title: B.Y.U. Is a Narrow Winner
description: Football fans join sportswriters and coaches in ranking Brigham Young University as the nation's best college football team, but by such a narrow margin over Boston College that the lead is statistically insignificant, a New York Times/CBS Sports Poll shows.

title: LeeRoy Yarbrough, 46, Dies;Leading Racing Driver in '69
description: LeeRoy Yarbrough, stock car racing's top driver in 1969, died Friday at University Hospital from internal bleeding in the brain. He was 46 years old.

title: MEETINGS EXPLORE STUDENT VOLUNTEERISM
description: REFLECTING the growing number of high school students involved in community service, two separate conferences in recent weeks have provided forums for students in the county to share their experiences while learning more about the benefits - from personal satisfaction to sampling a career field - of volunteer programs.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: -boggling experience for most families, no matter what their tax bracket. Interest rates are high and mandatory deposits are astronomical, but the state's Department of Transportation is offering relief of sorts.

title: THE NATION ; U.S. Joins SuitTo End Busing
description: In a move that civil rights leaders say could significantly undermine progress toward school desegregation, the Justice Department argued in Federal court last week that de facto segregation of public schools was no sin as long as it wasn't intentional. The department joined the Norfolk, Va., school board in asking the court to abolish that city's 13- year-old busing plan for elementary students.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Eliot Teltscher , who recently won a $300,000 tennis tournament in South Africa, has qualified for the $400,000 Masters tournament in New York next month. . . . Willie Mays is returning to action, and so, for that matter, are Hank Aaron , Sandy Koufax , Willie McCovey , Don Drysdale , Lou Brock , Ernie Banks and Frank Robinson . They are among 22 retired baseball greats who will team against former Japanese stars in a goodwill game on the island of Maui in Hawaii Dec. 20. . . . Jo Jo Starbuck and her figuring skating partner, Ken Shelley , will be making their final competitive appearance together today at the Pro Skate Championships at Madison Square Garden. . . . As it had threatened, the World Boxing Council will not rank Greg Page among its top 10 heavyweight contenders for December because Page fought in ''racist'' South Africa last week.

title: QUEBEC ABBEY: SERENE RETREAT
description: There may be more beautiful spots, places where the lake glimmers like a jeweled brooch, where the surrounding spruce and cedar forests stand lofty and lush, where the tree- lined mountains in the distance look more heroic. Still, the Benedictine Abbey of St.-Beno^it-du-Lac, set beside southern Quebec's 30-mile long, sliver-thin Lake Memphremagog, is sublime enough.

title: WOMEN WARRIORS
description: Elizabeth Lyttleton Sturz directs Argus Community, a residential center for troubled youth in the South Bronx, and is author of ''Widening Circles.'' THE GIRLS IN THE GANG

title: REKINDLING MEMORIES OF JAKARTA
description: BERNARD KALB, who was a correspondent for The Times in Indonesia 25 years ago, wrote this article after he returned from a visit in July, and before he was nominated to be Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs.

title: STUDY FINDS 10 MILLION LIVE IN MOBILE HOMES
description: The Census Bureau says more than 10 million Americans lived in mobile homes at the time of the 1980 census, and these homes accounted for 5.3 percent of the nation's housing stock.

title: A WATERFRONT CLUB OF S.I. Staten Island's Great Kills Harbor will be getting a $15 million waterfront restaurant, private club and marina that its developers hope to open by the time boats are back in the water late next spring.
description: The recreational project, to be known as Port Regalle, will occupy part of a 20-acre site between Nelson and Wiman Avenues less than a mile from the Gateway National Recreational Area and Great Kills Park. It is being built by the Great Kill Development Company, whose owner, Michael Miley, bought the waterfront property last year for $1.7 million.

title: Sarah A. Michels Becomes a Bride
description: Sarah Ann Michels, a daughter of Presiding Judge Herman Douglas Michels of the Appellate Division of the Superior Court of New Jersey and Mrs. Michels of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Harlan Lynn Strader Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Strader of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by the Rev. Parkman D. Howe Jr., assisted by the Rev. David Earnest, at Christ Church of Short Hills.

title: U.S. EXECUTIVE SEES A HIGH INDIAN AIDE
description: Warren M. Anderson, the chairman of Union Carbide, met with India's Foreign Minister today, but there was no word on the substance of their talks.

title: IN SHORT
description: Never having been the kind of fan who wanted to emulate a star, I've had some difficulty with the Michael Jackson craze. I probably had no problems with the Elvis Presley phenomenon because I was a teen-ager then, and it seemed perfectly natural for boys to adopt Presley's mannerisms and dress. Reading William McCranor Henderson's ''Stark Raving Elvis,'' then, brought back some memories. It's an entertaining novel about a teen-ager who has little going for him except his excellent, lifelike impression of Elvis. While his peers remember football games or the homecoming dance, ''Prince'' (since Elvis is the King) Byron Bluford of Portland, Maine, remembers the night in 1958 he stopped the Elks Club talent contest with his Presley imitation. Although he thinks he is doomed to spend the rest of his life on the assembly line at the local factory, Bluford so obsessively identifies with Elvis that he writes the singer's manager to say that he's ready when the King retires. After Presley dies, Bluford advances from local amateur shows to the big Elvis shoot-out in Las Vegas where he wins and receives one of the King's jump suits as well as a stint at a night club there. Dreams, however, when they become reality, are not always what we expect. The jump suit is too tight and soon Bluford is gaining even more weight, doing more drugs and surrounding himself with people who care only about his image. At this point, his face begins to ''show the kind of strain that comes from pushing too hard on the edge of youth,'' and he becomes involved in a struggle to discover who he really is. Mr. McCranor has written a funny, revealing novel that shows what happens to those who refuse to let youth go.

title: CONCERT: JUPITER SYMPHONY
description: Jens Nygaard brought his Jupiter Symphony to Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night for a concert that - with one exception - featured music familiar to most devotees of standard orchestral works. Bach was represented by the Suite No. 1 in C, Mozart by the Piano Concerto No. 17 in G (with Richard Goode as soloist) and Schubert by the Symphony No. 5 in B Flat. Tucked in among these, and seeming a bit foreign in the company, was Virgil Thomson's ''Stabat Mater,'' a five-minute-long setting for soprano and strings of a poem in French by Max Jacob. Nan Nall was the soloist.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ''WE'RE just trying to do the best thing that we can do,'' Kathleen Mulvey, a spokesman for the Diocese of Rockville Centre, said of the effort by Long Islanders to ease the famine that has killed thousands in Ethiopia.

title: THEY BRAKE FOR UNICORNS
description: John House is an associate editor of Vanity Fair. JITTERBUG PERFUME

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM MANET TO GRAND OPERA
description: Edouard Manet: Painter of Modern Life Produced and directed by Judith Wechsler Metropolitan Museum of Art 27 minutes. $49.95

title: HOME-STYLE OFFICES
description: It was more than a matter of a developer's taste that lead to a distinctly residential flavor for the design of an office complex to be built next year in Westport, Conn. The building site at 1089 Post Road East is within Westport's Business Preservation District, where the zoning code requires that homes demolished for commercial construction projects be replaced with residential-looking structures.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: FAVORITE authors never lack for readers, and bookstores these gift-giving days are filled with works about or by the old charmers - with a New Jersey connection never too far off. ''Plymouth Rock & The Pilgrims: And Other Salutary Platform Opinions,'' by Mark Twain, selected and edited by Charles Neider (Harper & Row, New York, $19.95), is proof enough that Twain's reputation as one of the great comic speakers of the 19th century was well deserved.

title: NASSAU BUDGET APPROVAL SEEN
description: -controlled Nassau County Board of Supervisors appears ready to approve the $1.28 billion budget for 1985 as proposed by County Executive Francis T. Purcell, with little or no change.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; Court Will HearHaitians' Case
description: Though they landed on the shores of south Florida years ago, thousands of Haitian ''boat people'' have remained legally at sea. Last week, the United States Supreme Court agreed to hear a case that may eventually lead to a clarification of their status, and the status of those who may follow them.

title: MATHEMATICIAN IS HONORED
description: PRINCETON ALTHOUGH Dr. Elias M. Stein works in the sparsely inhabited world of pure mathematics, he and his colleagues at Princeton University know that theory can feed into application and from there into science and technology.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO USE EVERGREENS IN DECORATION
description: EVERGREEN boughs have been used in the celebration of winter festivals and holidays at least as long as there has been a recorded history. Not only do they brighten up our homes, businesses and places of worship during dreary winter days, but they represent the promise of spring to come and the continuation of life, as well. As a result, their use has often been tied in with religious symbolism. This is especially true of their use during Christmas.

title: Jody Isselbacher Plans a June Wedding
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Kurt J. Isselbacher of Newton and Woods Hole, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter Jody Isselbacher to Stephen Coukos, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Coukos of Watertown, Mass. The wedding is planned for June.

title: CONVERSION CLASH
description: A plan to convert a former utility structure in a residential section of Ridgewood, N.J., into condominium apartments has lead to a bitter dispute between the local developer and nearby residents who hold that the project violates zoning laws and would irrevocably alter their single- family neighborhood.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR On Women's League In New Rochelle
description: The Oct. 28 Westchester Section carried an article (''Changes for League of Women Voters'') filled with doom and gloom about the future of the League of Women Voters in Westchester. The New Rochelle League, however, is well and thriving.

title: ; Tip of the Hat To Mr. Broun
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; Heart RecipientRaring to Go
description: With the unnatural thump of the polyurethane and aluminum pump within his chest and an unaccustomed strength flowing through his body, William J. Schroeder left the critical list and the coronary care unit last week and, in his mind's eye at least, prepared to leave Louisville's Humana Heart Institute International. ''I could go out fishing and watch ball games,'' the 52-year-old retired Federal worker said before he was wheeled to a private hospital room. ''I feel like I got 10 years.''

title: CONCERT IS HISTORIC FOR PIANO VIRTUOSO
description: THE University of Connecticut is calling it a historic event, and so it is: when Eugene List plays Shostakovich's Piano Concerto No. 1 with the UConn Symphony this Wednesday at 8:15 P.M., it will be 50 years to the day since the renowned virtuoso gave the work its American premiere.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:

title: Beth Isham To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan Trumbull Isham of Newport, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Chittenden Isham to Foster Nichols Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nichols of Brookville, L.I.

title: PRESSING ISSUES POLITELY DEBATED
description: How can television join in the great debates of our time? It is no easy matter. How, for example, can television bring us the Catholic bishops' recent pastoral letter on the economy? Whether we agree with the letter or not, it is an important statement. It touches on God, mammon and social thought, and it is both an exhortation and an indictment. Often it cites specific cases: The United States is insufficiently supportive of the International Development Association; unemployment is acceptable only at 3 or 4 percent; job-training programs should be expanded. Specifics, however, can be boring on television, although if we lose them, we lose much of the substance of the discussion. ''The Bishops and the Economy,'' an NBC News program on Channel 4 at 5 this afternoon, takes something like a middle way; it doesn't give us many specifics, but instead uses panelists to talk about what they mean. The result is only middling successful.

title: PIANO RECORDINGS SHED LIGHT ON MODERN FRANCE
description: A series of piano recordings from France on the Pianissime label offer a wonderful - if unintentional - sociological study of one country's tentative confrontations with the world of music.

title: Sibyl Peyer Is Engaged TAW
description: Announcement has been made by Hans C. Peyer of Bronxville, N.Y., and Sylvia M. Peyer of Branford, Conn., and Zurich of the engagement of their daughter Sibyl Claudia Peyer to Andrew John Wertheim, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Wertheim of Easton, Conn. An April wedding is planned.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: It's Luciano Pavarotti week on Channel

title: On Language; THE LINEAR CAMEL
description: NORA EPHRON, THE novelist, underlines a couple of curious usages in a story by Jane Gross of The New York Times about Fred Lebow, the marathon runner and promoter.

title: JOURNALISM, HISTORY AND JOURNALISTIC HISTORY
description: Theodore Draper's most recent book is ''Present History,'' a collection of essays and reviews.

title: Correction
description: A chart accompanying an article on Nov. 18 about the American dependence on foreign funds incorrectly labeled the amounts invested in this country from different parts of the world. The correct amounts were Western Europe, $367.1 billion in 1983 and $226 billion in 1979; Latin America, $167.6 billion in 1983 and $63.6 billion in 1979; Canada, $50.3 billion in 1983 and $26.7 billion in 1979; Japan, $50.1 billion in 1983 and $28 billion in 1979; other areas, $133.8 billion in 1983 and $64.6 billion in 1979.

title: WOMAN BILKING POOR WHO SEEK APARTMENTS
description: The Housing Authority police are seeking a confidence artist who they say is preying on poor people seeking low-rent apartments in New York City housing projects.

title: JERSEY HIGH COURT REVIVES LAWSUIT ON DRUG
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court has reinstated for technical reasons the lawsuit of a woman who sued five New Jersey pharmaceutical concerns and numerous unnamed companies for damages she said had been caused by a drug her mother took during pregnancy.

title: DEALING WITH PROBLEMS OF SOME GIFTED CHILDREN
description: Nine parents of intellectually gifted children gathered here recently in a basement room, and when they spoke of their children on that raw autumn night, they did not brag.

title: THREE WHO LOST EYE WHAT'S NEXT
description: THREE Long Island Democrats sat in their comfortable swivel chairs in the State Senate and Assembly for possibly the last time last week as the Legislature met in special session to vote on an extension of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority tax surcharge.

title: TV CAPTURES NEWPORT'S 30TH JAZZ FESTIVAL
description: After 30 years, television has finally recorded a jazz festival at Newport, R. I. The hour-long program, ''Jazz Comes Home to Newport,'' will be broadcast Friday evening at 10:30 on Channel 13, with a stereo simulcast on WBGO-FM.

title: INDONESIANS SEEK A CARBIDE PLEDGE
description: An Indonesian environmental lobbying group said today that it would seek assurances from the Indonesian Government and Union Carbide Indonesia that the company's factories in this country posed no danger to public health.

title: Gold Coins for Sale 'Cheap'
description: A collection of 170 rare gold coins, most of them privately minted in California's Gold Rush, is for sale at a ''cut- rate'' price of $3.5 million, the owners say.

title: Catholics and Morality
description: Elaine Sciolino's article, ''American Catholics: A Time for Challenge'' (Nov. 4), gives a much-needed voice to an area of concern to many Catholics. The Roman Catholic Church needs to open itself to the realization that human sexuality is not a theological issue at all, and in only a very limited area are there moral issues involved.

title: HUCKLEBERRY FINN, ALIVE AT 100
description: Is there a sweeter tonic for the doldrums than old reviews of

title: Basketball's Memory Lane
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: STUDIES SHOW A DRAMATIC RISE IN STERILIZATION
description: With the recent decline in the popularity of the pill, sterilization has become the nation's most common form of birth control, particularly among married couples who consider their families complete, according to new statistics.

title: INQUIRY REQUESTED IN MT. KISCO CASE
description: MOUNT KISCO officials have asked the State Commission on Investigation to conduct an inquiry into the trial and subsequent sentencing of Sergeant Robert Cercena, a 17-year-veteran of the village police force who was found guilty last month by the Village Board of Trustees of violating department rules.

title: THE REGION ; Tightening UpOn Gypsy Cabs
description: Agents from New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission were on the streets last week in an urban roundup, trying to identify and register so-called gypsy cabs. To prod the reluctant, the agents were armed for the first time with the authority to issue $250 summonses to drivers of unregistered taxis.

title: Damaging Lawsuits
description: Football is a dangerous sport, but because of high-impact modern helmets and other protective equipment, it is considered far safer than it once was. Now, according a lawyer for one leading manufacturer, the supply of such equipment has been threatened by a barrage of damage suits filed against manufacturers as a result of football injuries.

title: SING-ALONGS TO MARK HOLIDAY MUSIC
description: THAT Handel's ''Messiah'' will dominate the holiday music season on Long Island is a foregone conclusion. And it will, with more than a dozen performances scheduled over the next two weeks. This year, however, those who enjoy singing along will have yet another opportunity to add their voices to the celebrated oratorio, as the C. W. Post Center joins such traditional sing sponsors as the State University of New York at Stony Brook and the Long Island Singers Society in staging a really big ''Messiah Open Sing.''

title: FOR HIGHER CORPORATE TAXES
description: In the discussions of deficit reduction and tax simplification, a consensus seems to be developing on a critical point: because so many corporations currently pay so little in taxes, it is almost impossible to produce a serious tax reform or budget proposal without a major increase in corporate taxes.

title: CHEMICAL USED AT INDIAN PLANT WAS NOT VITAL
description: The chemical that leaked from a Union Carbide insecticide plant in India, killing and injuring thousands of people, is not essential to the production of the main product of the plant, a Union Carbide spokesman has acknowledged.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Big Markdowns On Women's Wear Levine's Factory Showroom in Bridgeport, Conn., is closing out its retail sale of women's clothing, belts and handbags at the present location after 50 years, with warehouse and showroom relocation plans unresolved. The ''everything must go'' prices apply through December, with larger selections to the earliest arrivals. Prices are marked down with stickers: red at 40, green or yellow each 10 percent lower, with the blue sticker representing 70 percent off the manufacturer's suggested retail price. All is first quality, current merchandise and labeled; any summerware is at the highest markdown.

title: CATHOLICS AND MORALITY
description: The Catholic Church is and always will be a society of patriarchs administering to Catholic women as dutiful mothers and wives, but seldom as intelligent individuals trying to deal with a changing culture while staying within the boundaries of church teaching. Doctrines concerning contraception, abortion and divorce are seldom addressed in women's terms, and yet these are essentially women's issues.

title: BOXERS NEED A DEFENSE AGAINST THE A.M.A.'S BLOWS
description: AWAY back in 1916, Jess Willard fought Frank Moran in the old-old Madison Square Garden for what was billed as ''The Heavyweight Championship of the World.'' This, despite the fact that in those days the bout would go to a ''no decision'' if one of the two participants had not scored a knockout within the prescribed 10 rounds.

title: 2 EXPERTS, SCIENTIFIC AND WRY, STUDY LAUGHTER
description: Smiles, giggles and belly laughs may be good for what ails you, a medical journal reports in an article, but an accompanying editorial asserts, tongue in cheek, that a lot of research would be needed before the Government would allow laughter in large doses.

title: FOES OF S.I. NAVY BASE PROPOSAL AIR CONCERNS
description: In two days of hearings last week, residents and local community groups opposed to the Navy's proposal to base a seven-ship group on Staten Island argued that their fears of a nuclear accident outweighed the potential benefits of the base.

title: STUDENTS GET CREDIT FOR COMMUNITY AID
description: ''MY parents always said, 'You could become a Candy Striper,' but I never really thought of doing it seriously until my school said I had to do something. Then I began it right away.''

title: FOR FLATBUSH, A 'DEVELOPER OF LAST RESORT'
description: IT is hard to find a developer willing to restore crumbling, rent-regulated buildings
