title: RULING LETS CONNECTICUT G.O.P. OPEN ITS PRIMARIES
description: A Federal judge has ruled that the Republican Party in Connecticut can allow the state's 600,000 unaffiliated voters to vote in its major primary elections.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; Nation's DoctorsCall for a FullBan on Boxing
description: For several years now the American Medical Association has been telegraphing its concern. Last week it delivered the blow - a resolution calling for the abolition of boxing, both amateur and professional.

title: Belcher: Smart and Steady
description: Last winter, when many of the Giants went home to try to forget their 3-12-1 season, Kevin Belcher stayed in New Jersey and worked out daily at Giants Stadium.

title: A COLLAPSED BED, A DEAD CHILD AND ONE FAMILY'S CAMPAIGN
description: Ed Sheils, middle-aged, quiet and baldish, does not look like a crusader. But a three-inch stack of correspondence beside the typewriter on which he slowly pecks out his letters offers testimony that he well may be.

title: Legal Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: RELICS OF WAR IN BASTOGNE
description: One the shelf of a wall niche in the lobby of Bastogne's 27- room Hotel Lebrun is a head-and-shoulders photograph of an American soldier and his wife. Inscribed across it is, ''To Mrs. Lebrun and family, with sincere thanks for many kindnesses to us during our wonderful return to Bastogne,'' and it is signed ''Anthony C. McAuliffe'' and ''Helen McAuliffe.''

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
DIANE ARBUS'S CHILDLIKE VIEW OF OTHERS
description: One of the most striking photographs the late Diane Arbus ever took was done on assignment for Harper's Bazaar. It is a formal portrait of a rich old womans, and up to a point it is reminiscent of Goya.

title: RECITAL: KURT OLLMANN OFFERS SONGS
description: Kurt Ollmann's song recital at the Merkin Concert Hall Thursday night offered quiet encouragement to friends of French vocal style that their music will survive, indeed flourish, into the next generation. Mr. Ollmann, a baritone who has divided his young life between Wisconsin and France, covered three centuries and a variety of styles - ranging from Rameau's cantata ''Thetis'' through songs by Gounod, Aubert and Caplet to Roussel, Debussy, Poulenc and Duparc.

title: THE DEVELOPMENT POTENTIAL ATOP MANHATTAN BUILDINGS
description: ONE of the more difficult ways to get an apartment in Manhattan is to build it on someone else's roof. But Ken and Gerry Greengrass have done it at 470 Park Avenue, a 12-story cooperative on the southwest corner of 58th Street, and now a great many other people are staring upwards and wondering.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM MANET TO GRAND OPERA
description: Hester Street Starring Carol Kane, Steve Keats and Mel Howard; directed by Joan Micklin Silver, 1975 Vestron Video 89 minutes. $59.95

title: PARLEY EXPLORES THE FATHER'S ROLE
description: ''I treat my children completely equally - oh, I say that to people all the time,'' said Ron Fox, sitting to the right of his son and the left of his daughter. ''But there is a certain part of me that may have felt more

title: PANELS TACKLING THE STATE'S PROBLEMS
description: TRENTON THERE may not be an easy answer to each pressing social problem, but chances are there is a study group, commission, committee or task force assigned to look for one.

title:
DINING OUT;
NEW LINK IN A CHINESE MINI-CHAIN
description: THERE is a new wave in Chinese restaurants. Lately, they have taken on a sophisticated air. Instead of red lanterns and plastic table tops, restaurateurs are hiring interior decorators to give their dining rooms a stylish look.

title: SCHOOLS' USE OF COMPUTERS DISAPPOINTING
description: After investing heavily in microcomputers, public schools in the New York metropolitan area are finding that they are still far from achieving the academic revolution expected from the new technology.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
YOUNG PIANIST 'MAKING IT' IN THE STATES
description: VLADIMIR ZAITSEV says it takes ''talent, personality and brains'' to become a successful pianist, but his solo recital at the Huntington Public Library today shows that events less predictable than the world of competitions and performances can also mold a young musician's career.

title: A Fish Wins in Hawaii, 2-1
description: The humuhumu-nukunuku-a-pua'a has won the popular vote to become Hawaii's state fish, it was announced Wednesday. About 55,000 people, Hawaii residents, visitors and out-of-state voters, cast ballots this fall that elected the fish over seven other candidates.

title: 'CYCLICAL' STOCKS ARE BACK IN VOGUE
description: Although it does not yet constitute a groundswell of activity, increasing numbers of investors are looking at and buying some of the basic industry stocks. Included are groups such as steels, metals, paper and forest products and chemical companies.

title: Acid Rain
description: To the Editor:

title: EAST HAMPTON DEBATES ZONING CHARGES
description: ZONING changes that curb development and codify ecological precepts into town law are near a vote in East Hampton, where environmentally minded officials hold the reins of local government.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
ISN'T GETTING IT ALL THERE HALF THE FUN?
description: IHAVE often wondered why, when people

title: A MIXED BAG OF OPTION TYPES
description: While most employees prefer I.S.O.'s, three related methods of delivering long-term compensation complement I.S.O.'s or provide comparable benefits. Non-qualified stock options, stock appreciation rights (S.A.R.'s) and ''phantom stock'' promise some of the profits of I.S.O.'s with far fewer restrictions.

title: Title to Augustana With 24th in a Row
description: Ron Nelson rushed for 155 yards and 3 touchdowns to lead Augustana to a record second-consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III championship with a 21- 12 victory today over Central of Iowa (10-1). It was Augustana's 24th consecutive victory since losing the 1982 title game to West Georgia, 14-0.

title: A TROUBLED TIME FOR UNION CARBIDE
description: Union Carbide faces a severe financial test in the wake of the catastrophe at its Bhopal, India, plant, where more than 1,500 people have died from exposure to poisonous gas. In addition to the reparations that are likely to be demanded by India and the Indian criminal charges facing its officers, Carbide faces investor uncertainty over its ability to withstand the financial drain from the expected private lawsuits and the loss of confidence in the company. Its stock already is suffering, and Standard & Poor's is watching it closely for ''potentially negative implications'' for its debt ratings.

title: United States Names Radio Marti Director
description: The United States Information Agency Friday named Paul Drew, a broadcast consultant and former RKO Radio network executive, as director of the Voice of America's Radio Marti Program.

title: PACIFIC ISLANDERS SEEK TO VOID PACT ON U.S. BASE
description: Landowners of Kwajalein atoll, the site of key installations for testing United States antimissile defenses, have brought suit in a Federal court to void the agreement allowing the Department of Defense to continue using the billion-dollar base.

title:
DINING OUT;
NEW ADDITION FROM MEXICO
description: THIS newcomer to the county's Mexican culinary scene serves the usual dishes purported to have come from south of the border, but although the menu has a familiar ring some items were superior, explaining the crowds on weekend evenings. Early evening finds men and women in business dress at many of the tables, dipping fresh tacos into Hacienda Don Emilio's mildly spicy salsa. The later, the bar area builds up with a convivial younger set. On weekends, a strolling duo sings of the old country, music preferable to the canned Mexican tunes played too loudly on weekday evenings.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
A CALL FOR NATIONAL DISASTER GUIDELINES
description: As the mind-numbing figures from

title: AROUND THE NATION ; Company Pays Millions In 1981 Sewer Explosion
description: The Ralston Purina Company has paid $8.9 million to more than 16,000 people in a suit stemming from explosions that ripped up two miles of city streets and sewers in 1981, the authorities say.

title: PROJECT BLOCKED TO SPARE FERN
description: The New Jersey Pinelands Commission has blocked construction of a 15- year-old road project that could endanger a fern that grows in just two places in the state, and Burlington County intends to contest the decision.

title: Vibrations Baffle Coast
description: Baffled officials and scientists say they have no idea what caused vibrations that shook buildings and rattled windows Friday throughout Orange and San Diego counties. There were no reports of damage or injuries, but the authorities reported hundreds of telephone calls from residents who felt the vibrations and heard a roar.

title: COONEY GETS A REAL FIGHT AND WINS
description: Gerry Cooney was in a fight tonight, his first in two and a half years, but only briefly.

title: G. B. Hall 3d, Miss Weyher Are Married
description: Laura Carter Weyher, a daughter of Mrs. Alan Kenneth Gage and Harry Frederick Weyher, both of New York, was married yesterday to Gordon Bennett Hall 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hall Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York, assisted by the Rev. Kevin Madigan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: THEATER ; DOUBLE-HEADER IN BRIDGEPORT
description: IN its eight-year existence, the

title: How the Poll Was Taken
description: The New York Times/CBS Sports Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Dec. 2-4 with 1,340 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii, of whom 910 said they were interested in sports and 774 said they were interested in football.

title: WASTE GAS IS USED TO GENERATE POWER
description: ELEVEN municipalities in Essex and Union Counties that own and operate joint sewage-treatment facilities here have added to the complex a power plant that converts methane gas - a waste product from the biological decomposition of sludge - to electricity.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Jennifer Jones won an Oscar as the young peasant heroine in ''The Song of Bernadette,'' and this 1943 drama about the spiritual vision at Lourdes remains one of the better films of this kind. Its real strength and dramatic spine is the expert supporting cast - Charles Bickford as a rugged priest, Gladys Cooper as an acerbic nun, Anne Revere and Roman Bohnen as Bernadette's bewildered parents, and Lee J. Cobb and Vincent Price. Welcome back, after a long absence from the home screen. (Cinemax on Sunday at 9 A.M., later at 3 A.M., and on Thursday at 7 A.M. and 8 P.M.)

title: 'HEROES': A POWERFUL PREMIERE
description: -year-old British playwright, writes passionate, intense plays about the class system and the breakdown of society that are also engrossingly entertaining. He writes in a naturalistic manner, but his characters and the events that propel them into action are surrealistic. His is an original and powerful dramatic voice that is not heard often enough in this country.

title: TOWNS DISPUTE DISTRIBUTION OF AID
description: NORMAN G. ST. PIERRE, Waterbury's Deputy Comptroller, expected a check for $11 million on Nov. 1 as the first installment of the state's aid to education to the city.

title: The Plight of Peruvians
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Tests Approved
description: Ever since stewards at Hollywood Park asked the jockey Kenny Black to submit to a drug test and it was found that he has used cocaine, other jockeys at the track have been concerned about their image. Now they have moved to do something about it.

title: THE WORLD ; Trouble Flares onA French IslandIn the Pacific
description: Frenchmen who may have thought they had shed the white man's burden more than 20 years ago have been disagreeably reminded in the past few weeks that bits and pieces remain of a once formidable empire.

title: Miss Birk to Wed T.J. Colas in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roger E. Birk of Red Bank, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Elizabeth Birk to Timothy Joseph Colas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Colas of Manassas, Va. The wedding is to take place in June.

title: Data Bank; December 9, 1984
THE NATION ; G.M. Faces FactsOn Diesel Cars
description: In the 1970's, when the price of gasoline began soaring, many analysts thought diesel-powered cars were certain to capture a sizable portion of the American market. Last week, after years of poor sales and widespread complaints about performance, General Motors said that after the current model year it would offer the diesel option on just one of its many car lines.

title: German Film Festival
description: A monthlong series of screenings of recent works by German film makers opened this weekend at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street.

title: Article 138064 -- No Title
description: The advertisement said, ''Send $34.95 and we will send you a Cabbage Patch,'' and that is exactly what the customers got: a cabbage patch but no doll.

title: FIRST SKI VICTORY FOR HAECHER
description: Traudl Haecher of West Germany, whose skiing career almost ended with a bad fall in 1982, emerged from the 54th starting position to score a stunning victory in a women's World Cup supergiant slalom race today.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
POP CULTURE: DOES IT RULE OR REFLECT OUR LIVES?
description: CARL LADENSACK'S ''Society Should Accept the Blame for the Way Schools Are'' was published in these pages on Oct. 7. Unlike the author, I am not, in the formal sense, a teacher. But I am a parent and, like Mr. Ladensack, heartily concerned with the education of our children - the manners, morals and technical skills of daily living they should be acquiring both in and out of the classroom, and so often aren't.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR Of Comfortableness And Challenge
description: I felt honored to be one of those who was interviewed for your article on activist clergy (''Activist Clergy Defines Its Role,'' Nov. 18). I know that there were others who were more deserving of this attention than I.

title: IS NO DANCE FIGURE LEFT WHO MERITS NATIONAL HONOR?
description: For the first time since they were established in 1978, the annual Kennedy Center Honors have excluded a dance figure. Past recipients of the award in dance have been George Balanchine, Martha Graham, Agnes de Mille, Jerome Robbins, Gene Kelly and Katherine Dunham.

title: Tracy Brod, an Appraiser, Engaged to Paul Taylor 3d
description: Tracy Lynn Brod and Paul Edward Taylor 3d plan to be married Jan. 12.

title: AMERICA GOES CHICKEN CRAZY
description: Behold the modern chicken.It's seven weeks old, weighs about 4.1 pounds, has a plump body and skinny legs, and is fast becoming one of America's most popular animals.

title: IS BROADWAY IN TROUBLE OR IN CLOVER?
description: Six months into the Broadway season, how is Broadway doing? There are at least two answers to that question, and they are polar. Not very well, a skeptic would mutter. Eleven plays have opened since June 1, which the League of New York Theaters and Producers considers the beginning of a season. Even if one omits the summer, when few plays ever premiere, Broadway has seen only nine new shows in the 14 weeks since Labor Day. Twenty-one of Broadway's 37 theaters are now occupied. Those figures are almost identical to last season's - but last season had the fewest new shows in years.

title: PUTTING UP STRINGS OF HOLIDAY LIGHTS
description: F OR many homeowners, decorating the house for the Christmas holidays also means hanging strings of decorative lights around the inside and outside of the house - and possibly adding some white or colored floodlights to illuminate an outdoor display on the front lawn or on the house itself.

title: HEART PATIENT IN NEW ROOM AND PUMP WORKING 'FLAWLESSLY'
description: William J. Schroeder spent time with his family and rested today, his first full day in a private room since leaving the coronary care unit with his artificial heart.

title: SOVIET BLAMES CAPITALIST GREED FOR INDIAN DISASTER
description: The Soviet press said today that the disastrous leak of poisonous gas in Bhopal, India, proves that capitalist ''big business'' is ready to sacrifice even human life in the chase for profit.

title: BIG BEND ADVENTURE
description: Let it be said at the outset that this diary is not for travelers who prefer a soft bed and room service. Neither is it for those who may be squeamish about snakes or scorpions. It is intended for those willing to put in the hard work needed to backpack through the wilderness of Big Bend National Park in Texas, an extraordinarily varied landscape, ranging from scorching desert to cool moist canyons full of oaks and maples reminiscent, as colors change, of autumnal Vermont. Day One: After a cushy night at the Chisos Mountain Lodge in the so-called basin of the mountains that rise dramatically in the middle of the park, my friend Charlie Johnson of Austin and I awoke to a glorious morning, ideal for hiking: cool, crisp, cloudless, dry. A soft light was beginning to paint the steep crenulated slopes. It was fall, the beginning of the Big Bend ''season,'' when the furnace-like summer temperatures had finally abated.

title: VOTES AT SPECIAL SESSION
description: Following are the votes by which the Legislature on Thursday extended the tax to subsidize mass transit and raised the pay of various officials. (Y - ''yea''; N - ''nay''; A - absent; * - abstain; d - not voting):

title: Bowman Ties N.H.L. Mark BOSTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -
description: Scotty Bowman moved into a

title: THE EDUCATED GAME PLAN
description: WEDNESDAY is the heaviest day in pro football, the day coaches reveal the next game plan and players practice it, violently, on the scrimmage field. At the end of that day, the temptation is to collapse in the nearest corner, but for 14 New England Patriots Wednesday has been extended by two hours this season, for a college course, with an exam facing them at the end.

title: Waivers Asked On Jazz's Drew SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 8
description: The Utah Jazz announced today that the veteran

title: CATHOLICS AND MORALITY
description: Too many Catholics want it both ways; they want the standards of the world and the comfort of the church. If the Pope were to put down his torch and say, ''Go ahead, do your thing,'' who would hold up the ideal, the Gospel values? As St. Augustine said, ''Wrong is wrong, even if everyone is doing it, and right is right, even if no one is doing it.'' KATE MILLER

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
 VIVALDI IN FARMINGDALE
description: To usher in their second ''Baroque 'N Mozart Festival'' at the State University at Farmingdale, the Sea Cliff Chamber Players today are featuring the works of Vivaldi. With Kenneth Cooper, the acclaimed harpsichordist, as soloist, the Players perform an all-Vivaldi concert featuring the Baroque composer's most popular concertos and sonatas. The concert is at 3 P.M. at the Little Theater of Roosevelt Hall, and tickets are $8, or $4 for students. For subscription information about the remaining four performances in the series, which will feature Bach and Handel, call 671- 6263. AMERICAN MUSIC

title: INQUIRY SEEN AT LANCE'S BANK
description: The Comptroller of the Currency is investigating allegations of ''irregular transactions'' at the Calhoun First National Bank, which is headed by Bert Lance, President Carter's first budget director, people familiar with the investigation say.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: DAFFODILS IN THE SNOW

title: Walkout at Nuclear Plant
description: About 360 construction workers walked off the job at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant Friday to protest a new contract that would cut wages by 15 percent next year. The walkout did not affect operations at the plant, where testing of a reactor is under way.

title: D.H. Rule Backed By Wide Margin
description: Baseball fans and sports fans in general approve the designated-hitter rule by a margin of almost two to one, according to a New York Times/CBS Sports poll.

title: COLUMBIA DEAN FINDS TIME FOR CANCER RESEARCH
description: The other day, the dean of Columbia College met with the provost about building a new chemistry lab, arranged to have the bathrooms in Hamilton Hall painted, gave a lecture on Galileo and Descartes, wrote letters to alumni and, in the evening, went to hear a seminar at the Faculty House.

title: FULL EXTENT OF RELIEF SUPPLIES IN ETHIOPIA APPEARS IN DISPUTE
description: A question has arisen over the amount of food available in Ethiopia.

title: BLITHE PAST, CLOUDY FUTURE TROUBLE THE CHICAGO SCHOOLS
description: New York, which has the nation's largest public school system, has not had a teacher strike since 1975. Los Angeles, which is No. 2, has not had one since 1969, and Miami, No. 4, has been free of strikes since 1968. But the walkout that shut down the third largest school system last week was the seventh in Chicago since 1969 and the second in as many years.

title: THE QUEST FOR A PERFECT TREE
description: GUY D. COCKBURN is known as ''Mr. Christmas Tree,'' but getting hold of one of his balsam firs at Yuletime is like trying to find an apartment in Manhattan.

title: Louise D. White To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Louise Dawson White to Charles L. Marburg Jr., the son of Mrs. Marburg of Lutherville, Md., and the late Mr. Marburg, has been announced by S. Bonsal White Jr. of Monkton, Md., and Mrs. Benjamin F. Lucas of Baltimore, parents of the future bride. A May wedding is planned.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ; Suriname to Create A National Assembly
description: Suriname's Cabinet, apparently seeking restoration of $90 million in annual development money from the Netherlands, approved a proposal Friday to create a national assembly.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO USE EVERGREENS IN DECORATION
description: EVERGREEN boughs have been used in the celebration of winter festivals and holidays at least as long as there has been a recorded history. Not only do they brighten up our homes, businesses and places of worship during dreary winter days, but they represent the promise of spring to come and the continuation of life, as well. As a result, their use has often been tied in with religious symbolism. This is especially true of their use during Christmas.

title: NEAR WEST VIRGINIA PLANT, THE TALK IS OF ESCAPE
description: A vague sense of uneasiness has often gnawed inside many of the people who live here among the chemical plants of the Kanawha Valley, a feeling often no stronger than the faint sulphurous scent that hung in the snow-dampened air today.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN EXECUTIVE STOCK PLANS
description: As January approaches, corporations are

title: DRUMMERS LEAD THE WAY THROUGH JAZZ HISTORY
description: Drummers don't usually lead jazz bands. In the normal scheme of things, drummers provide essential but self-effacing support for other, more melodic instruments. But when drummers do take charge, they forge a strong identity for their groups, as if all those years of listening to music from the rhythm upwards have made them knowing and decisive. A few drummers steamroller their bands, turning every tune into a drum solo; others, such as Art Blakey, Max Roach, Mel Lewis, Andrew Cyrille, Dannie Richmond, Philly Joe Jones and Paul Motian, pay attention to every architectural nuance of a piece.

title: RIDING A FLOOD TIDE
description: NORTH(D) S 4 2 H K J 5 D A 10 6 3 C A 9 6 4 WEST S A 9 7 H 9 6 4 D Q 7 C K J 8 7 3 EAST S Q 5 3 H Q 3 2 D J 9 8 5 2 C 5 2 SOUTH S K J 10 8 6 H A 10 8 7 D K 4 C Q 10

title: Military Demolition Pay
description: President Reagan signed an executive order Friday to clarify the right of all military demolition experts to receive extra pay. The Army, Air Force and Navy have been paying demolition teams a supplement for the hazardous work. But in February an old executive order authorizing such pay was found to refer only to ''underwater'' demolition. Mr. Reagan's order removes the reference to underwater work.

title: CORRECTION
description: In assembling the list of Notable Books of the Year, ''Margaret Mead: A Life'' by Jane Howard (Simon & Schuster, $17.95) was inadvertently omitted in the Christmas Books issue Dec. 2. The biography is ''an excellent journalistic account'' of the life of the anthropologist, gathered not only from the record, but more important, from perceptive interviews of a large number of people who knew Mead in many different surroundings.

title: Bruce Breimer Is Wed To Lorna Ruth Doran
description: Lorna Ruth Doran, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. James R. Doran of New York, and Bruce John Breimer, a son of Anne Breimer of New York and the late Dr. Charles W. Breimer, were married yesterday on their birthday. The Rev. Kenneth Gorsuch, assisted by his wife, the Rev. Judith Gorsuch, the Dutch Reformed ministers of the West End Collegiate Church, and the Rev. Charles B. Houghtlin, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew in Manhattan.

title:
The Editorial Notebook;
'Putting Up With the Russians'
description: Edward Crankshaw, who died last week, was Britain's most sober, and witty, analyst of the Soviet Union. For 40 years, he probed its mysteries and hostilities and set standards for journalism, looking past the games of Kremlinology to the central issues of coexistence.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: DANCE IN WEST ORANGE

title: Clash Over Coin
description: Skaneateles, N.Y., 20 miles south of Syracuse, likes tourists, because it depends heavily on their spending. But, earlier this year, some residents said that the tourist buses run by the Mid-Lakes Navigation Company were creating noise and fumes while parked for hours with engines idling at idyllyic Skaneateles Lake.

title: HEADLINERS ; Church Dispute Heats UpIt apparently is going to take a higher authority than the Lutheran Church of America to make the
description: Rev. D. Douglas Roth follow orders. As pastor of the Trinity Lutheran Church in Clairton, Pa., Mr. Roth recently joined with other activist clergymen and a group of militant unemployed workers in trying to pressure the Mellon Bank and the United States Steel Corporation to do something to ease unemployment in the depressed region.

title: INNOCENT IN PAKISTAN
description: Garrick Utley is the chief foreign correspondent of NBC News. PASSAGE TO PESHAWAR

title: OFFICIALS IN YONKERS ANALYZE CHATTER ISSUE'S NARROW LOSS
description: FOR the fourth time in 12 years, Yonkers voters last month rejected a proposal that would have eliminated the current City Manager-City Council form of government and replaced it with a system giving greater power to the city's mayor. But unlike previous elections in which similar proposals were resoundingly defeated, the proposition put before voters in November came within 363 votes, out of 54,571 cast, of passing. The closest vote previously had come in 1980, when the proposal was defeated by a 6,000-vote margin.

title: SLAVIC DIVAS CREATE A VOCAL RENAISSANCE
description: There is an exciting group of relatively new singers around, singers who promise much for the kind of medium-to-heavyweight soprano role that most often goes begging today between pushed-up mezzos and lighter sopranos out of their depth. New record releases and recent New York appearances make them newsworthy at the moment, and they have something interesting - namely Slavic heritage - in common. National trends and traditions are important in opera; a brief glimpse of history is in order here.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM MANET TO GRAND OPERA
description: Jimi Hendrix Warner Home Video 103 minutes. $39.98

title: BALLET: OHIO COMPANY IN WORK BY BALANCHINE
description: The Ohio Ballet, the admirable little group that danced last Sunday afternoon at Brooklyn College, is celebrating its 10th anniversary as a professional company. It hails from Akron, but because it often tours, it is a credit not only to its hometown but to the entire American dance community.

title: Striped Bass: The Big Question
description: By the titles alone of two recent articles, ''Striped Bass to Get Help'' and ''Bass Fishermen Await Relief,'' it is clear that there are two very distinct versions of the striped bass story, told from very different points of view. The question is: How do both the bass fishermen and the striped bass get help and relief?

title: A BIG HELPING OF BACH
description: How many organ works did Johann Sebastian Bach compose? It is unlikely that he himself kept count, and the exact number remains in doubt as the 300th anniversary of his birth in 1685 approaches. At least 200 are thought at the present time to be authentic, but many others attributed to him in the past are in the doubtful column nowadays.

title: Cuomo, in Summer, To Be a Grandfather
description: Governor Cuomo will become a grandfather next year.

title: LARCHMONT ACTRESS TO OPEN IN PLAY
description: -old problem, particularly, perhaps, for actresses. But how does one deal with what appears to be a natural law in reverse? Elizabeth Berridge fears she is ''youthening.''

title: ; Orvieto
description: To the Editor: I read Olivier Berni

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. 76ers , at Philadelphia. This is the Knicks' first meeting of the season with a team they beat only twice in six games last season. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.) College : St. Francis vs. Monmouth, noon; Long Island vs. Fairleigh Dickinson, 2 P.M., and St. John's vs. Rutgers, 4 P.M., at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. (Television - MSG Network, 7 P.M., tapes of last two games only; USA Network will show the St. John's game at 1:30 A.M., Monday. Radio - WCBS, 880, 4 P.M., live, last game only.); Lincoln (Pa.) at Upsala, 3 P.M. Figure Skating

title: Huckleberry Finn, Alive at 100
description: Is there a sweeter tonic for the doldrums than old reviews of great novels? In 19th-century Russia, ''Anna Karenina'' was received with the following: ''Vronsky's passion for his horse runs parallel to his passion for Anna'' . . . ''Sentimental rubbish'' . . . ''Show me one page,'' says The Odessa Courier, ''that contains an idea.'' ''Moby-Dick'' was incinerated: ''Graphic descriptions of a dreariness such as we do not remember to have met with before in marine literature'' . . . ''Sheer moonstruck lunacy'' . . . ''Sad stuff. Mr. Melville's Quakers are wretched dolts and drivellers and his mad captain is a monstrous bore.''

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM MANET TO GRAND OPERA
description: A Charlie Brown Christmas; You're Not Elected, Charlie Brown Media Home Entertainment 50 minutes. $39.95

title: Official in Labor Department Quits Post as Chief of Staff
description: The chief of staff of the Labor Department, Daniel K. Benjamin, has resigned to return to private industry, a department spokesman said Friday.

title: Federal Pay Is Reported Trailing Private Sector
description: Pay and benefits for Federal employees on the average are 7.2 percent behind those of workers in the private sector, although retirement benefits for Federal workers is better, a House subcommittee report says.

title: A Mother's Complaint
description: In ''A Mother's Son'' (About Men, Nov. 4), I was delighted (relieved, amazed) to see Thomas Simmons recognizing his mother's discomfort: ''She knew that the balance of power in the family - the very structure of the family itself - was vastly unequal, and that all the pleasant cliches she had learned about love and marriage and child rearing had deceived her intolerably.''

title: COMPANY'S PROOF IS IN THE PUDDING
description: IN their tiny kitchen in Redding, Lee and Shippen Swift have

title: U.S. AIDES REPORTED DEADLOCKED OVER NICRAGUA
description: The Reagan Administration is deadlocked over the development of new approaches for dealing with Nicaragua, according to senior national security officials.

title: EMIGRE ARTISTS AND GREAT EXPECTATIONS: ONE VIOLINIST'S TALE
description: Nina Beilina, the prize-winning Soviet violinist who immigrated to the United States eight years ago, will give what Omus Hirshbein, the performing arts director of the 92d Street Y, calls her ''comeback performance'' there at 3 this afternoon.

title: MORE HOPEFUL OUTLOOK SEEN
description: The number of deaths occurring each day at Bhopal's major hospital has dropped for the first time since the escape of lethal gas from the Union Carbide insecticide plant here last Monday, the hospital's superintendent said today. At the same time there were signs that medical consequences for survivors might not be so devastating or widespread as had been predicted.

title: DISABLED TO HELP STATUE OF LIBERTY
description: A veterans group has promised to donate $1 million to help make the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island more accessible to the disabled.

title: 'DIAL M FOR MURDER' RETAINS THRILLS
description: FREDERICK KNOTT'S ''Dial M For Murder'' began its public life 32 years ago as a 90- minute BBC television special. It became a long-running stage hit on both the West End and on Broadway, and Alfred Hitchcock made a film version starring Grace Kelly. The play has since been in almost continuous worldwide production and, as the current production at the Nassau Repertory Theater proves, this thriller is as effective today as it was at its 1952 debut.

title: COOPERATION HAILED IN GROWTH OF TOWN
description: RANDOLPH TOWNSHIP ' 'THIS was a sleepy little town 20 years ago, when my father started building houses here,'' said Andrew B. Abramson, president of the Hedy Heights Construction Company in Clifton. ''People said he was crazy to take a chance on it.''

title: WINNOWING OF 9 NUCLEAR WASTE SITES TO START
description: The Government will soon begin winnowing the list of nine prospective sites for burying thousands of tons of highly radioactive waste from nuclear power plants.

title: A SELECTION OF NEW BOOKS FOR THE HOLIDAY SEASON
description: New photography books range from one-volume encyclopedias to soft-cover treatises on specialized subjects. The books listed here contain good, practical advice for all photographers, as well as such information about photography, photographers and the processes they use.

title: PUPILS 'DESIGN' GREETINGS FOR PATIENTS
description: NEARLY 1,500 kindergarten and elementary school students in three Nassau County school districts will surely get special recognition from Santa Claus this Christmas for their help in bringing Yuletide joy to patients at Community Hospital in Glen Cove.

title: CELTICS DEFEAT NETS BY 9
description: Earlier this week, Micheal Ray Richardson, after surveying the hobbled bodies around him in the Nets' locker room, said that ''things couldn't get any worse.''

title: FOR THE CONNOISSEUR OF TOYS
description: Alexander Acevedo is about to share with the public the toys in his attic - 19th- and early 20th-century tin windups, electric trains, pull and push toys, Teddy bears, automatons and Mickey Mouse figures. These vintage playthings - some faded and chipped, but most in near- mint condition - fill a transformed storeroom and two closets, a second- floor hideout adjoining his Alexander Gallery, 996 Madison Avenue, at 77th Street. Mr. Acevedo calls the new venture, which opens Thursday, the Collector's Gallery. He says it is a permanent addition.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Period rooms are notoriously difficult to bring off. If many people find them a bore, it is because by their very nature they look lifeless.

title: FAMILIAR PIECES SHOWCASE TALENT
description: Paul Turok writes frequently about recorded music.

title: 'FALLING IN LOVE' MAKES THE MOST OF THE MUNDANE
description: Few things are less easily represented on the screen than ordinary life. The illusion of realism can be disrupted by the slightest false move, and anyhow, ordinary life is something audiences presumably get at home free of charge. Even films that successfully simulate day-to-day activity run the risk of losing the viewer to sheer monotony, since such material may not provide much occasion for thought. On the other hand, when an ordinary-life film does strike the right chord, it can affect an audience overpoweringly. Such films, when they work, contain few obstacles to direct identification with the characters and to pure, uncomplicated emotional response.

title: The Versatile Beret
description: That was a very interesting article about men's hats, but Barrymore Laurence Scherer never mentioned the beret, my favorite (''A Crowning Touch,'' Nov. 4).

title: BOARDS CAN EASE PROCEDURE
description: SOMETIMES it's the heat that's not coming through, or a window that needs fixing. Perhaps the snow is not being removed quickly enough from the parking lot.

title: LaRouche's Holdings Are Called Insufficient
description: A lawyer for Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., a former independent Presidential candidate, said in Federal court Friday that his client was almost penniless and was unable to pay NBC television a $3 million judgment levied against him last month.

title: LEGISLATURE SAW ITS AGENDA GROW
description: MAURICE CARROLL

title: USE OF MARIJUANA FOR PAIN ACCEPTED AS DEFENSE IN JERSEY CASE
description: A New Jersey appeals court has ruled that medical necessity may be used as a defense by a man charged with marijuana possession.

title: FUTURE OF 2 SOUTHERN INDUSTRIES RAISES CONCERN
description: Concern is growing in the South over the declining fortunes of textiles and tobacco, traditional pillars of the region's economy.

title: THE TEST OF TIME
description: ARCHITECTS seem to be designing everything from teapots and dishes to standing lamps and chairs, and thus it is only natural to wonder how many of these pieces will outlast their time. Is the Swiss architect Mario Botta's metal chair, for instance, destined to become as much a classic as Mies van der Rohe's Barcelona chair? Or will Robert Venturi's molded plywood furniture be as visible tomorrow as Alvar Aalto's stacking tables are today?

title: Recent Sales
description: Annandale $178,000 *2*3 Westminster Drive, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*year-old Colonial; center-island kitchen with skylight, *2*central air-conditioning; taxes $2,700. Dunellen $93,000 *2*744 First Street, 4-bedroom, 3-bath, *2*older two-family; slate roof, 2-car garage, *2*porch; taxes $2,194. Mahwah $212,000 *2*62 Bayberry Drive, 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*18-year-old ranch; wall-to-wall carpeting, *2*wet bar, pool; taxes $2,600. Teaneck $230,000 *2*321 Rutland Avenue, 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*13-year-old colonial; 3 fireplaces, 2-car garage, *2*study; taxes $3,745. Tenafly $325,000 *2*125 A & B Hickory Avenue, 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*new duplex; skylight in baths and halls, *2*1-car garage on each side; taxes $5,300. Wyckoff $250,000 *2*675 Highview Drive, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*30-year-old colonial; entrance hall, living room *2*with fireplace; taxes $3,108. OTHER AREAS Scarsdale, N.Y. $289,000 *2*949 Post Road, 5-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*24-year-old frame colonial; dining room, *2*Florida room, den; taxes $6,317. Norwalk, Conn. $238,500 *2*James Street, 6-bedroom, 3-bath, *2*59-year-old converted mill; 0.75 acre; *2*taxes not available. Hauppauge, L.I. $95,000 *2*44 Robin Drive, 3-bedroom, 1-bath, *2*27-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement, *2*1-car garage; taxes $2,200.

title: INDIA
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NATION ; Airline DelaysCut By Half
description: The long-suffering airline passengers of the land began getting a few breaks last month, according to the Government's reckoning.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Regan as Scrooge

title: WASTE PLANT EYED
description: AGAINST a volley of criticism, the Town of Hempstead's Sanitary Garbage District One - which serves the Five Towns - has decided to forge ahead with plans to build a small $20 million garbage-burning plant off Rockaway Turnpike in North Lawrence.

title: FOREIGNERS MAKE MARK IN AN AMERICAN GAME
description: THEIR travels take them to the cities and outposts in Africa, Western Europe, the Communist bloc, South America, Arctic belt and even the land down under. Some college basketball coaches and recruiters have become modern-day Stanleys looking for Dr. Livingstone, or rather another Dr. J. And recently, some of the young men they have found tending herds of cattle, serving their country in the military or on the national team, are having an impact on the made-in-America game.

title: Anna Maria Garcia Is Dr. F. R. LaBarbera's Bride
description: Anna Maria Garcia, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lisardo Garcia of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. Frank Raymond LaBarbera, a son of Aurora LaBarbera of Whitestone, Queens, and the late Frank John LaBarbera. Msgr. George Bardes performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: SWEET SWAN OF OXFORD?
description: THE MYSTERIOUS WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE

title: 3 ARE HONORED FOR DEFENDING RIGHTS OF JEWS
description: Three people have been named this year's winners of the Jabotinsky Prize for ''outstanding service in defense of the rights of the Jewish people.''

title: JON B. HIGGINS, EXPERT IN SOUTH INDIAN MUSIC
description: Dr. Jon B. Higgens, an internationally acclaimed singer of South Indian music and a professor of music at Wesleyan University, died Friday night after he was struck by a hit-and-run driver near his home in Middletown, Conn., according to the police. He was 45 years old.

title: A CORRECTION
description: The Perspectives column last Sunday incorrectly reported the address of a 10-unit town house in which several apartments have been sold to an investment group. The correct address is 111 East 78th Street.

title: AT 75, DEACON AWAITS HER ORDINATION
description: SUCCASUNNA IN 1977, when the Episcopal

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: IT is beginning to look a lot like Christmas in

title: DAVID LEAN FILMS A FAMED NOVEL
description: When ''A Passage to India'' opens at the Ziegfeld Theater in New York on Friday, the signature of David Lean will once more be written on celluloid - after an absence of 14 years.

title: DOES QUIET TALK HELP?
description: PROTESTS against apartheid and the Reagan Administration's policy of ''constructive engagement'' in South Africa reached the White House last week in the person of Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, the black South African bishop who recently won the Nobel Peace Prize. For the past three weeks, there have been demonstrations against South African offices in several American cities but the Administration appeared particularly sensitive to Bishop Tutu's testimony before a Congressional committee in which he called the effort at quiet diplomacy ''immoral, evil and totally un-Christian.''

title: ARABS READ THE CARDS, FIND U.S. HOLDS STRONG HAND
description: Arab leaders continued to stress the theme of unity last week but they have begun to adjust their goals and tactics to the world as it is rather than as they would like it to be.

title: COLUMBIA RECEIVES $1 MILLION IN GIFTS
description: Donations totaling $1 million to Columbia University's School of Engineering and Applied Sciences will be used to establish a professorship in geophysics, the university has announced.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: POLITICAL pressure was brought to bear last week in an effort to get the Department of the Navy to hold a hearing in New Jersey on its plan to establish a port in the Stapleton section of Staten Island for its nuclear- armed Surface Action Group.

title: Article 138831 -- No Title
description: Six Democratic Representatives said today that they would ask Congress next month to approve a $1 billion famine relief package for Africa.

title: A 1693 'MEDEE' NOW ON DISKS
description: -Antoine Charpentier's opera, ''Medee'' (HMC 1139.41, three disks, with compact disks forthcoming), is the second of three stages (so far) in the recent rediscovery of this masterpiece of the French Baroque. The score was composed in 1693 and may or may not have received a second production in Lille after its premiere in Paris. But then it seems to have fallen into musty neglect, the victim first of the Lully cabal at the French court, and subsequently of sheer ignorance of its many beauties.

title: Another Injury
description: Dino Ciccarelli played three straight seasons in the National Hockey League without an injury, but although the current season is still young, there are indications that this is not going to be his year. In the opening weeks of the season, the Minnesota North Star right wing has successively suffered torn shoulder ligaments, a sprained ankle and an eye injury, which together caused him to miss 15 of the first 19 games.

title: DOCTOR RECALLS HIS BROTHER, A SUSPECT IN ROOFTOP SLAYING
description: Dr. Alfredo Torres, a brother of the man accused of slaying a drama student on the Upper West Side, sought yesterday to explain how the brothers' lives could have taken such different paths.

title: FOR SOME EMPLOYEES, YALE IS A COLLEGE OF HARD KNOCKS
description: After 10 weeks of picketing on the ivy-covered campus, 1,500 striking clerical and technical workers went back to work without a contract at Yale University last week. Union officials insisted that the return was temporary. If an agreement is not reached by next month, they said, union members will once more shoulder cardboard signs and hit the streets.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN DAN DIEGO
description: It may be hard to think of Christmas in a landscape in which colored lights among the palm trees herald the season. But San Diego (average December temperature: 65.1) makes the most of the holiday, with tree lightings and carol singing and parades on land and sea. And since this is a city that looks to Mexico for some of its most dearly held traditions, with processions and pinatas as well.

title: DANCE: ZE'EVA COHEN AT RIVERSIDE CHURCH
description: In several works presented by Ze'eva Cohen and Dancers on Thursday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church, clusters of people would break apart and individuals would scatter, only to form a new cluster. Miss Cohen's choreography was often all comings and goings.

title: WRITER FEELS WRATH OF COMPUTER BUFFS ANGERED BY ARTICLE
description: A Newsweek reporter says someone tried to charge $1,100 on his credit card after he wrote an article about how amateur computer buffs can illegally enter various computer systems.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Michael Lewin's New York debut piano recital last Sunday at Tully Hall was a different sort of concert from that usually reviewed in this space: Mr. Lewin is a prominent contest winner, whose list of concert successes is already impressive and whose career is under way. His technique and ability qualify him eminently for success. Let that be said and got out of the way, because by the stiffer standards according to which his work demands to be judged the recital was in large part disappointing.

title: INCREASE IN POWER SOUGHT AT NIAGARA
description: Plans for a $583 million expansion of the Niagara Power Project, already the largest electricity-generating plant in New York State, were announced this week by the State Power Authority.

title: C.I.A. HAS A RIGHT TO COMPLAIN AGAINST ABC
description: To the Editor: The complaint against ABC that the C.I.A. has filed with the F.C.C. raises important constitutional and other legal questions. However, in view of the relief asked by the C.I.A. in its complaint, it appears to me that much of the discussion has been wide of the mark, particularly since primary at

title: THE NATION ; Ferraro Erred Unintentionally, Panel Decides
description: In a world where any investigation that doesn't result in a fine or jail sentence is marked as a victory for the investigatee, Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro quite reasonably claimed last week that she had been ''completely vindicated'' by the ''key finding'' of a House ethics committee inquiry into her financial disclosure practices.

title:
About Men;
HIS SON, THE ARTIST
description: Gene Light

title: YANKEES' PITCHING WEAKENED BY DEALS
description: When the Yankees arrived in Houston for the winter meetings, they established their primary targets as a center fielder and two starting pitchers. They left with the center fielder, Rickey Henderson, but Rich Bordi and Porfi Altamirano weren't what they had in mind as the pitchers.

title: STORIES PERCHED IN THE SKY
description: David Evanier is the author of ''The One-Star Jew,'' a novel, and ''The Lost Pigeon of East Broadway,'' a play. A MAN JUMPS OUT OF AN AIRPLANE

title: GRENADIANS GET NEW LEADERS AND A PIPELINE TO U.S. AID
description: Crowds of young people skipped through the streets of the capital long after midnight, tooting conch horns and cheering. At the seaside inn that houses the United States Embassy, American officials smiled broadly. Thirteen months after President Reagan sent troops that brought down the island's teetering Government, democracy returned last week.

title: Plimsolls in the Cupboard
description: Cathleen Schine, author of ''Alice in Bed,'' is working on a new novel. Russell Baker is on vacation.

title: SOCIAL WORKERS URGED TO WEIGH ETHICAL ISSUES
description: About 600 social workers heard themselves criticized last week for ''self-interest,'' too narrow a concentration on clinical procedures, and an ''assumption of their own benevolence.''

title: CORRECITONS
description: Because of a misplaced line of type in Marian Burros's review of cookboodk (Dec. 2), it was not made clear that all the recipes were tested by Frances Patterson.

title: JUST WHAT IS A PRIMARY RESIDENCE?
description: A tenant whose apartment has just been converted to cooperative ownership, a foreigner investing in American real estate, a couple selling their vacation home, a farmer selling most of the land around his house, someone living in a home provided by his employer - even Vice President Bush - would all like to know if their homes are principal residences for purposes of deferring taxes on the gain. Although the Internal Revenue Service has never ruled on exactly what makes a principal residence, it recently answered these questions on the subject:

title: Presidential Trivia
description: In his article, ''Presidential Trivia'' (Oct. 28), Harold Faber might have listed the following items: John Tyler later was elected to the House of Representatives of the Confederacy and the impeached Andrew Johnson later sat in the United States Senate. JEROME AGEL

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption on the Recordings page last week misstated the professional background of the rock musician, John David Souther. Mr. Souther is not a former member of the Eagles.

title:
ART ;
VARIETY MARKS HUNTINGTONSHOW
description: ALONE among arts organizations on the Island, the Huntington Township Art League annually sponsors both a juried and an open exhibition for its membership. Now in its 30th year of service, the league holds its juried show at the Heckscher Museum, with a spunky salon des refuses at its headquarters on Little Plains Road, where the open show is now on view through Dec. 20.

title: Julia Anne Rivkin Is a Bride in Chicago
description: Julia Anne Rivkin, a daughter of Mrs. John Sterry Long of Chicago and the late John Edward Dreyfus, was married yesterday to Daniel Harding Wheeler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wheeler of New Boston, N.H. Judge Seymour Simon of the Illinois Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Fortnightly of Chicago club.

title: THIS IS THE WINTER OF THE DRAWING
description: Ever since the Chatsworth sale at Christie's, just a few months ago, people have been talking about drawings who never talked about them before. That drawings could cost real money was a surprise to them. Furthermore, those prices in the high six figures were attached to names that are universally familiar - Raphael, Rubens and Rembrandt, among others.

title: GROUP URGES USE OF LOVE TO HEAL MIND
description: Recently a salesman, a data processing consultant, an interior designer and an expert in the technique of training oneself to control emotional or physical states, or biofeedback, met in Manhattan, with soft music playing in the background.

title: AROUND THE NATION ; New Orleans Fair Lost $121 Million
description: The 1984 world's fair lost about $121 million in its six-month run, closing Nov. 11 with $81 million in debts, court records show.

title: Verbatim: ; Classifying Violence
description: Conflicting opinions on the nature of the 20 bombing and arson incidents at abortion and family planning clinics this year.

title: THE GIFTS OF 1984: ROBOTS AND ELECTRONICS
description: TIES, scarfs and gloves are giving way this holiday shopping season to gift items that sound as if they were a part of the world envisioned in George Orwell's novel, Nineteen Eighty-Four.

title:
ANTIQUES;
TRAINS: MODELS AND MEMORABILIA
description: TRENTON ABRIGHT and energetic holiday exhibition devoted to the young and old alike - ''Model Trains: 1890-1940'' - will be on view at the State Museum through Jan. 13.

title: GEORGETOWN ROUTS LAS VEGAS BY 82-46
description: Georgetown, coming off a weak early schedule, faced its first major opponent this afternoon and responded with its most lopsided victory of the season.

title: Alexandra Garland Spofford Engaged
description: The engagement of Alexandra Garland Spofford to Edwin McClellan Johnston 3d, the son of Mr. Johnston Jr. of Buffalo and the late Sarah Montgomery, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. C. Nicholas Spofford of Bedford, N.Y., parents of the bride to be. A June wedding is planned.

title: Patricia O'Leary Engaged to Wed A Fellow Lawyer
description: The engagement of Patricia Ann O'Leary to Robert Brian McLaughlin has been announced by Robert L. O'Leary of Oakton, Va., and Barbara B. O'Leary of McLean, Va., parents of the future bride. Mr. McLaughlin is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James P. McLaughlin of Greenwich, Conn., and Williamstown, Mass. A February wedding is planned.

title: Cary Chapin to Be Bride
description: Cary Neil Chapin, a kindergarten teacher at the Rye (N.Y.) Country Day School, and James Charles Stanley, associate principal for development and alumni affairs at the Fairfield College Preparatory School, plan to be married Feb. 9. The future bride is a daughter of Mrs. Lincoln Stevenson of Rye, who has announced her engagement, and Neil Chapin Jr. of Sarasota, Fla. Her fiance's parents are Mr. and Mrs. George Stanley of East Norwalk, Conn.

title: DESPITE INTENSE, SHARP PLAY, KARPOV AND KASPAROV DRAW
description: The 31st game of the world championship chess match in Moscow was sharply played and full of tension, yet it still produced a draw. In agreeing to it on Friday, the 33-year-old champion, Anatoly Karpov, and his 21-year-old challenger, Gary Kasparov, set a new record of 26 draws in a title match.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday about ballet productions of ''The Nutcracker'' misidentified the theater at which the New York City Ballet will perform. It is the New York State Theater.

title: WHY MOST PEOPLE LIKE I.S.O.'S THE BEST
description: While plans may offer I.S.O.'s or non-qualified options or both, I.S.O.'s are the first choice of most employees. Created by Congress in the 1981 tax act, I.S.O.'s offer distinct tax advantages. First, an executive does not face a stiff tax when the options are exercised. And second, the gain at eventual sale may qualify for capital gains treatment. In sum, ''an I.S.O. is good from an executive's point of view,'' noted George E. Hagerty, a principal with Arthur Young & Company, the accounting firm.

title: USING BASKETBALL TO LURE COLLEGE STUDENTS
description: FOR years, most college administrators have justified their schools' entry into big- time sports by saying that it would afford better competition for the athletes and added revenues needed to improve athletic facilities.

title: SOME LIBERALS REALLY CONSERVATIVES
description: To the Editor:

title: BISHOPS STUDYING PASTORAL LETTER
description: THE Bishops of New Jersey's five Roman Catholic dioceses are responding in a variety of ways to a call for the study and discussion of the document ''Catholic Social Teaching and the U.S. Economy.''

title: TEACHERS' TEACHER A HITWITH CHLDREN
description: -faced man strides into a classroom of first-graders. ''You know my name,'' he says. ''Anybody here named Jane?''

title: STAR OF 'FIDDLER' ON BROADWAY
description: Luther Adler, a stage and screen actor who starred in ''Fiddler on the Roof'' on Broadway, died yesterday at his home in Kutztown, Pa., after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Joyce in Monosyllables

title: BARLEY SHOULD BE TAKEN WITH MORE THAN A GRAIN OF SALT
description: BARLEY, a staple in other parts of the world, is a grain that is underappreciated in this country. Yet its marvelously delicate nut-like flavor, its texture - which has a slight appealing chewiness - and its ability to absorb the flavors with which it cooks makes it a superb choice as a side dish, to add to soups and to thicken and enhance stews.

title: Risk and Blame at Bhopal In Bhopal, technology has showed its grimmest face. The pesticide ingredient that burst from its storage tank in the central Indian town is feared to have killed some 2,000 people. Many thousands more may be blinded or debilitated, perhaps for life. The wounded still wander the streets under the pall of funeral pyres. As the catastrophe bears witness, pesticide ingredients can be more deadly than the kindred agents of chemical warfare.
description: The detailed causes of the accident are still unknown, but a tragedy of such dimension prompts broader questions. Is the risk of such accidents too high a price to pay? Has technology outrun the capacity to control it?

title: INDOOR PLANT HOBBYISTS CAN PROFIT FROM REVIEWING THE SIMPLE BASICS;
description: House plants please. They are decorative. They satisfy. They provide generous rewards. Landless gardeners tend their collections of pot plants with special affection, while outdoor gardeners give them more care now that the land is on its own. A survey conducted by a nationally circulated home magazine revealed that 60 percent of its respondents owned anywhere from 6 to 15 house plants and they added as many as five new plants each year. A poll taken by The Gallup Organization and sponsored by Gardens For All showed that 46 percent or 39 million households have indoor plants.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
OLYMPIC COIN PROGRAM CLOSES THIS MONTH
description: The United State Treasury is nearing the finish line in its marathon promotion of three los Angeles Olympic advertising campaign will end on Dec. 31. The coins - two silver dollars and a $10 gold piece - will be available for purchase from the Treasury only until Jan. 18, 1985.

title: CHRISTMAS BRINGS A BOUNTY OF MUSIC
description: CHRISTMAS is a time of celebration, and every December brings a rich musical harvest to New Jersey. Hardly a day will pass without a musical celebration of some aspect of the holiday.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO USE EVERGREENS IN DECORATION
description: EVERGREEN boughs have been used in the celebration of winter festivals and holidays at least as long as there has been a recorded history. Not only do they brighten up our homes, businesses and places of worship during dreary winter days, but they represent the promise of spring to come and the continuation of life, as well. As a result, their use has often been tied in with religious symbolism. This is especially true of their use during Christmas.

title: COMPUTING SKIN CARE
description: COMPUTER TECHnology entered the world of cosmetics this year, and it certainly doesn't plan to leave during the next one. In August, Elizabeth Arden introduced its beauty computer, rather coyly named Elizabeth, at Macy's New York store. Shortly after, two of Japan's leading cosmetics companies, Shiseido and Intelligent Skincare Inc., began their own computer programs at Bloomingdale's.

title: HENDERSON SIGNED FOR $8.6 MILLION
description: Rickey Henderson, after protracted and sometimes intensive negotiations, reached agreement with the Yankees today on a five-year contract worth $8.6 million that makes him the fifth-highest paid player in baseball.

title: STAGE: 'LITTLE BIRDS FLY,'FAMILY TALE
description: In his 1971 memoir, ''Inside, Looking Out,'' Harding Lemay wrote with great sensitivity about the deprivations of his childhood, growing up in a large, emotionally desolate farm family. ''Little Birds Fly'' deals less persuasively with the same autobiographical material. Written before the memoir and once optioned for Broadway, the play can now be seen at the Neighborhood Group Theater.

title: Peter Miller to Marry Amy Elizabeth Faust
description: Amy Elizabeth Faust, a doctoral candidate in organizational behavior at the New York University Graduate School of Business Administration, and Peter A. Miller, an associate in the real-estate department at the New York law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, plan to be married in February.

title: CHRYSLER BIDS FOR YUPPIES
description: WITH all those young urban professionals out there, it had to happen. The Yuppymobile has arrived. It showed up in Fort Lee, N.J., on Wednesday in the form of twins - the Dodge Lancer and Chrysler LeBaron GTS - and Chrysler says that they are aimed squarely at the upwardly mobile segment of the Baby Boom.

title: THE MENTAL DEFICIT
description: WASHINGTON The conversation of a great capital is important, and here in

title: WICKED NOVELS AND PLAINTIVE DRUMMERS
