description: Ronald Hingley's books include biographies of Dostoyevsky, Chekhov, Stalin and Pasternak. BULGAKOV

title: JETS TOP BILLS, 21-17, TO END LOSS STREAK
description: In their staggering march toward the .500 plateau, the Jets hurdled the ineffective Buffalo Bills today to break a six-game losing streak and record a 21-17 victory.

title:
ART ;
WINSLOW HOMER AND THE NEW ENGLAND COAST
description: ALTHOUGH he painted many paintings set on dry land, Winslow Homer is practically synonymous with the sea. ''Winslow Homer and the New England Coast,'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art in Stamford through Jan. 9, is quite a substantial and engrossing account of that identification.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
FOR A HAPPY AND PEACEFUL CHRISTMAS, BUY DAD A TOY
description: IF you want to insure your children a safe and happy Christmas, buy your husband a toy. Of

title: SUPPORT OFFERED DIVORCED WOMEN
description: IN a classroom at Westchester

title: 'ANGEL DUST' USE IN CAPITAL SAID TO REACH EPIDEMIC PROPORTIONS
description: It is late Friday night at a city intersection less than a mile from the broad boulevards of Washington's Federal District. In the narrow streets young men scurry from car to car, murmuring ''love'' and lovely.''

title: 19TH-CENTURY GRILL IMPRESSIONS
description: From time to time persons have been arrested for attempting to reuse postage stamps and vast quantities of items prepared for reuse are seized. Such problems for the postal service date back more than 100 years. Steps taken to offset these illegal actions have led to items of considerable interest to collectors.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: I'M sitting here wanting a cigarette.

title: DISKS MARK THE MET'S 100TH
description: The Metropolitan Opera and others are making the most of the Met's centennial year, with a rush of recordings - audio and video - paying homage to the company's glamorous and distinguished past as well as its present. Recordings of various origins, all carrying the Met name, have become ubiquitous items in catalogues and in record shops, not to mention mail order.

title: CORRECTION
description: The publisher of ''In Her Own Right: The Life of Elizabeth Cady Stanton'' by Elisabeth Griffith was omitted from The Book Review's list of the best books of 1984 (Dec. 2). It is Oxford University Press.

title: LONG ISLAND IN A BIND AS LANDFILL SPACE AND PATIENCE GROW SHORT
description: The environmental challenge that hovers over Long Island's future is evident in the man-made mountains that tower over its predominately flat terrain.

title: U.N. WORKERS PLAN STRIKE OVER BUDGET CUTS
description: Thousands of United Nations employees here and abroad plan to walk off their jobs for part of the day Wednesday in a ''worldwide day of solidarity'' against budget-cutting efforts that threaten a cost-of-living increase.

title: A PREMIERE FOR 'PIPER' OPERA
description: THE children who were lured by the mesmerizing, magic flute of the Pied Piper were never heard from again, or so the Robert Browning poem would have us believe.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: THE Lockheed Electronics Company has dedicated an $8 million, 3-story building that will add 100,000 square feet of engineering and office space to its headquarters in the Somerset County community of Watchung. Occupancy is scheduled next month.

title: DelBello Is Bowing Out As No. 2
description: By law, the Lieutenant Governor of New York serves as a standby, should the Governor need to be replaced because he leaves office or leaves the state temporarily. Apparently frustrated by that limited mandate - he once described the job as ''sort of fun'' - Lieut. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello said last week that he himself would vacate his office.

title: Students Punished for Protest
description: Brown University announced today that it would discipline 57 of 68 students accused of disrupting a recruiting session of the Central Intelligence Agency on the campus Nov. 26.

title: Shelley Bochner Bride Of Richard W. Boylan
description: Shelley Rise Bochner and Richard Wade Boylan, both of Holliston, Mass., were married yesterday at the First Parish Unitarian Universalist Church in Framingham, Mass. The Rev. Raymond J. Baughan officiated.

title: THE STAGGERING COST OF A BABY FAE
description: While the plight of infants such as Baby Fae has focused attention on new types of medical treatment designed to help children with birth defects, it has also raised questions about the ability of parents to pay for such treatment. Loma Linda University Medical Center offered to pick up the costs of transplanting a baboon heart into Baby Fae, but few parents can rely on finding an institutional benefactor when their infant requires expensive medical treatment.

title: Sydney Plants Threatened
description: Threats were made to bomb two Union Carbide plants in Sydney, apparently because of the gas leak from the company's factory in Bhopal, India, that killed more than 2,000 people, the police said today. A police spokesman said the threats Friday night were against the plants in the industrial suburbs of Rhodes and Rosebery. No details were available.

title: DELBELLO STESSES NEED FOR CHANGE
description: After 20 years in public office, Alfred B. DelBello, who announced his resignation Friday as Lieutenant Governor of New York, says he has simply grown tired of working when everyone else is off, speaking at dinners, shaking hands at holiday parades and attending luncheons on the weekend.

title: BEST SELLERS Dec. 9, 1984Fiction*1
description: 17 THE TALISMAN, by Stephen King and Peter Straub. (Viking, $18.95.) Two parallel worlds and a young boy who can travel between them. *2 34 THE SICILIAN, by Mario Puzo. (Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) A fictionalized life of Salvatore Giuliano, the Sicilian bandit-hero of the 1940's. *3 2 8 LOVE AND WAR, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) The Civil War rages in this saga of a Pennsylvania family and a South Carolina family, begun in ''North and South.'' *4

title: BARRY TUCKWELL PLAYS MOZART
description: Edward Schneider writes frequently about recorded music.

title: 21 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 21 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: HEADLINERS ; The Trials of CleaverIt must sometimes be frustrating to
description: Eldridge Cleaver that ever since he was politically born again as a conservative, folks just don't seem to want to hear what he has to say. Not long ago, Mr. Cleaver, who achieved some prominence in the late 1960's as a leader of the revolutionary Black Panther Party, was booed by a college audience as he expounded on his newfound anti-Communist views.

title: COMMON MARKET STILL CAN'T GET ITS MIND OFF THE GROCERY LIST
description: At 12:50 P.M. on Tuesday, deep in the gloomy halls of Dublin Castle, the presidents and prime ministers of the European Common Market countries were discussing IMP's - in Eurospeak, the community jargon, the acronym for agricultural subsidies known as Integrated Mediterranean Programs. It was the 30th summit meeting of the organization, the repository of Western Europe's hopes for its political and economic future. Ten minutes before the scheduled end of two days of discussion, it had come to this: nine men and a woman,representing a community carrying much of the world's history and distinction, bargaining about price supports for items such as olive oil and sponges.

title: CATHOLICS AND MORALITY
description: The primary role of the church is not ''meeting the needs of the faithful,'' at least not in the sense suggested in Elaine Sciolino's article. Rather, it is to provide a Christian witness that includes promulgating the truths of the Gospel and administering the sacramental life of believers.

title: TAX PLAN WOULD PUT STATES ON THE SAME FOOTING
description: To the Editor:

title: BIG WHEEL AMONG SMALL BIKES
description: DAN BEHRMAN is the author of ''The Man Who Loves Bicycles'' (Harper's Magazine Press).

title: STANDOUTS IN AUDIO'S ARISTOCRACY
description: In the field of audio, where class lines are fuzzy and

title: HE PROMOTES A 'CASHLESS SOCIETY'
description: ''ALL of the companies started from a telephone and a credit card and a computer,'' said Richard A. J. Williams . ''So when you think about the whole fabric, just about all of them use a telephone to make a transaction, a credit card or a check to pay for it, and they are fully computerized.''

title: Added Resource
description: To the Editor:

title: Cause of Derailment Sought
description: A boxcar toppled from an overpass onto Cambridge Street here in a freight train derailment Friday. The accident is being investigated by the railroad and state and Federal transportation and railroad officials, according to Allan Kaulbach, vice president of the Providence and Worcester Railroad. The authorities said no one was hurt.

title: Lisa Emily Ogren To Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Theodore Ogren of Ridgewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Emily Ogren to William Fuller Gadsden, a son of Mrs. Henry W. Gadsden of Gladwyne, Pa., and Lake Wales, Fla., and the late Mr. Gadsden. The wedding is planned for July.

title: BRAVURA ACTRESSES ARE LIGHTING UP LONDON
description: It used to be said that, by some quirk of island biology, British actresses consisted of mellifluous heads and nothing much else. They were exquisite from the neck up, and they barely existed from the neck down. Give a long Shakespearean role to one with a round, resonant voice, complained the critic Kenneth Tynan back in 1952, ''and she'll have to enter smoking a pipe to avoid being acclaimed.'' But in recent years that slur has got harder and harder to sustain. You couldn't sanely accuse Diana Rigg of not having arms or Vanessa Redgrave of lacking heart and stomach. Still less could you patronize Glenda Jackson, Maggie Smith and Judi Dench as beguiling songbirds, warbling their way through the great parts.

title: C.I.A. HAS A RIGHT TO COMPLAIN AGAINST ABC
description: To the Editor:

title: FLORIDA PHOSPHATE MINING PROCESS STIRS DISPUTE
description: A mining company has dammed two small streams near here, removed phosphate lying under the stream beds, and has attempted to recreate the streams near their original paths.

title: LOVE IN THE PUNJAB
description: Sheila Solomon Klass teaches English at Manhattan Community College and is the author of ''A Perpetual Surprise,'' a novel of India. AN INDIAN ATTACHMENT

title: OUTBACK SAGA
description: Craig McGregor is an Australian writer and critic. His latest book is ''Soundtrack for the 'Eighties,'' a collection of essays. THE BUSH SOLDIERS

title: E. J. Junior Thrives In Second Chance
description: ST. LOUIS IT was cold here last Thursday, with

title: HEADSMAN, HOLD THAT MEAT AX
description: ROCHESTER, Vt.

title: THE NEW WAVE STARTS TO CREST ON CAPITAL HILL
description: ''I grew up watching television,'' Representative Richard A. Gephardt remarked recently, ''I watched Howdy Doody.'' Last week, the lawmaker from Missouri was chosen as chairman of the House Democratic caucus for the 99th Congress, the No. 4 job in the party leadership.

title: Physician Is Wed To Dr. Merriman
description: At the Second Presbyterian Church in Baltimore yesterday Dr. M. Suzanne Merriam, the daughter of Catherine Evering Merriam of Towson, Md., and the late Henry Wilson Merriam, was married to Dr. George Rennell Merriam 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Merriam Jr. of Tenafly, N.J. The Rev. Ernest Smart performed the ceremony.

title: MALL COMPUTERS AID STYMIED SHOPPERS
description: DON'T know what to get that special someone? A computer may have a suggestion. In several shopping centers in the state, people are consulting computers for ideas on what to buy their loved ones for Christmas.

title: BRITON BREAKS A FISCHER RECORD
description: Michael Adams, a 12-year-old from Truro, Comwall, England, became the world's youngest international player last month when he qualified for the International Chess Federation's rating list.

title: AFTER 35 YEARS, 'COOKIES' STILL AN EASY A AT CORNELL
description: For the last 35 years, one course in Cornell University's School of Hotel Administration has had the reputation of being one of the easier A's in the Ivy League.

title: LOAN INCREASE LIFTS STUDENT AID OVER $18 MILLION
description: Financial aid for college students, which fell precipitously two years ago, has risen beyond $18 billion again, the College Board has reported.

title: A Designer Is Engaged To Amy C. Edmondson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Edmondson of New York and Prouts Neck, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Claire Edmondson to Mark Dunbar Carpenter, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. James A. Carpenter of New York and Greensboro, Vt. The wedding is planned for February.

title: AROUND THE NATION ; Lewis Heads Americans For Democratic Action
description: Ann F. Lewis, political director of the Democratic National Committee, was appointed today as national director of Americans for Democratic Action.

title: F.A.A. GROUNDS COMMUTER AIRLINE IN MIDWEST FOR VIOLATIONS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday ordered the immediate emergency grounding of a commuter airline, American Central, charging falsification of records and numerous other safety violations.

title: NEWARK: WHIMSICAL HOUSES
description: NEWARK THE houses that Anne Seelbach builds are not ranch homes, split-levels or bungalows. They have, in fact, nothing to do with the houses one might see in city or suburbs.

title: THE REGION ; Holding FaresAnd Raising Pay
description: Freed from short-term political considerations, a lame-duck session of the New York State Legislature got down to some serious, if potentially risky, business last week. The lawmakers voted themselves a pay raise that would make them the highest-paid state legislators in the continental United States.

title:
ART;
WINSLOW HOMER ON THE NEW ENGLAND COAST
description: ALTHOUGH he painted many paintings set on dry land, Winslow Homer is practically synonymous with the sea. ''Winslow Homer and the New England Coast,'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art in Stamford through Jan. 9, is quite a substantial and engrossing account of that identification.

title: Ruth Levine To Be Bride
description: Ruth Ellen Levine, an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, and Leonard R. Sussman, an associate in the New York law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, plan to be married in March, her parents, Justice and Mrs. Howard A. Levine of Schenectady, have announced.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF GENERAL JARUSZELSKI
description: Michael T. Kaufman is chief of The Times's bureau in Warsaw. THE MEAL WAS PLAIN, AND, outside, a chill November wind blew through Warsaw's dark and empty streets. But, as befits a Polish get- together, the conversation at the dinner table was lavish and extravagant, mixing politics and history, religion and literature. The point under debate, raised by one of the Polish guests, a writer, was whether Poland's austere and aloof current leader, the army general and Communist Party chieftain Wojciech Jaruzelski, was a janizary or a Wallenrod.

title: Dorsett Is Rising Above His Problems
description: At his current rate, Tony Dorsett should finish the season with more than 1,200 rushing yards. Statistically, that would not be the best of his eight seasons with the Dallas Cowboys. Nor his worst. From a different perspective, however, this may be his greatest season ever.

title: ALASKA IS SEEKING TO END SALE OF BEAR PARTS
description: Fearful that poaching could wipe out the Alaska bear population, the State Game Board has made it illegal to sell the animals' gallbladders and paws.

title: Q&A
description: My neighbor, a piano teacher, has been playing a piano and several electric instruments for hours every day. Occasionally, groups hold rock concerts in the apartment. She says there are no restrictions before 11 P.M. Do I have recourse? . . . R. K., Manhattan

title: YALE STRIKE ALSO TAKES A REAK
description: EVERY December a quiet descends on Yale University as students and employees leave campus for the winter recess.

title: NORWALK HOSPITAL RESUMES WORKLOAD
description: IN the wake of the 65-day nurses'

title: CONGRESS HOLDS ITS FIRE ON REAGAN'S DEEP CUTS
description: WASHINGTON WITH the unveiling of his budget proposals last week, Ronald Reagan provided another of those surprises that have come to be a trademark of his Presidency. The budget he and his spokesmen outlined is an extraordinary package of spending freezes, outright reductions and eliminations of entire programs. Its promise is large: If Congress goes along with his proposals, spending will be cut by $34 billion in 1986, $60 billion in 1987 and $75 billion in 1988. Reaching such targets would require drastic measures because the President doesn't want to touch Social Security and, so far, has not agreed to slow down the pace of his military buildup.

title: Food View ; A YEASTY PLATEAU
description: THE QUESTION WAS DOUBTLESS ASKED long before the time of Saint Peter:

title: PRO FOOTBALL FANS LIKE GAME AS IT IS
description: Despite a recent decline in television ratings and constant suggestions that the game needs an overhaul, professional football, by a wide margin, is still the sport a majority of fans most enjoy watching, a New York Times/CBS Sports Poll shows.

title: The Big Farmers and the Little Folks According to leaked reports, President Reagan will propose a big cut in farm subsidies as one way to reduce the deficit. While it's not yet known just what he has in mind, virtually any such reduction would be welcome. There is no good economic or social reason to keep America's enormously productive farm sector permanently on welfare.
description: Agriculture support programs responded to the great suffering of the Depression, when a quarter of the population lived on family farms. Now the number is 3 percent and many of those farmers are big businessmen.

title: NICARAGUA WARNS U.S. OVER PARLEY
description: A Foreign Ministry official said Friday that Nicaragua would have to re-evaluate its participation in talks with the United States if there was no progress in meetings next week.

title: THE MAN BEHIND MANY OF THOSE BRITISH GEMS
description: Peter Cowie, a British film critic, is executive director of the International TV and Video Guide.

title: THE PAIN OF PROGRESS RACKS THE THIRD WORLD
description: THE death of more than 2,000 people in India last week from a leak of poison gas at a Union Carbide chemical plant had an uncomfortably familiar ring to many who study the growing threat of technology gone wrong. It recalled Seveso, where a dioxin cloud poisoned an entire Italian town in 1976. It recalled Mexico City, where last month a fiery gas explosion killed almost 400 people.

title: JERSEY TESTS LOOK FOR DIOXIN EFFECT
description: Vietnam War veterans started checking into a hospital here this week to begin what researchers said was the first scientific study in the country to determine if the dioxin in the defoliant Agent Orange was responsible for medical problems suffered by veterans.

title: CAREER DETAILED ON BOGUS DOCTOR
description: A man who posed as a doctor for almost a decade before being caught and convicted had received commendations from the Army for his work and was hired by the National Institutes of Health as a medical fellow, according to documents that have been released by a Congressional subcommittee.

title: STING: A ROCK STAR TRANSCENDS THE FORM
description: John Duka is a reporter for the Style section of The New York Times.

title: I.C.C.-A HOUSE DIVIDED AND UNDER FIRE
description: WASHINGTONAlmost 100 years after the Government created its first regulatory agency, the Interstate Commerce Commission, and charged it with ending the abusive policies of railroads, the I.C.C. now finds itself enmeshed in bitter ideological battles reminiscent of those that led to its creation.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: WHEN it comes to New Jersey's cities, David C. Schwartz dreams big dreams.

title: NEW TOXICITY TEST FINDS POTENTIAL PERIL
description: RESEARCH scientists with the state's Department of Environmental Protection said last week that a new broad-based toxicity test on industrial discharges into rivers and the Atlantic Ocean indicated potential irreversible damage to fish and other aquatic life.

title: OPERA: VINEYARD TROUPE IN 'LOVE'
description: At a time when Italy, France and even the backward German principalities were producing major operas, England and its American colonies contented themselves with Italian imports or naive ''ballad operas.'' There were simple strings of airs, usually composed by or borrowed from a potpourri of composers and dotted through a farcical story. And yet, as the Opera Shop of the Vineyard is proving just now, such works could have considerable charm.

title: Lucy Gregg, State Department Aide, Weds Christopher Buckley, an Editor
description: At St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Washington yesterday Lucy Steuart Gregg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Phinney Gregg of Bethesda, Md., and Westminster West, Vt., was married to Christopher Taylor Buckley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Buckley Jr. of New York and Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Julien Stead, a Benedictine monk, performed the ceremony.

title: JERSEY WOMAN FACING NIGERIA TRIAL TUESDAY
description: A 59-year-old businesswoman from Jersey City is scheduled to be tried Tuesday in a Nigerian military tribunal on charges that she illegally exported petroleum products. If found guilty, she could be put to death by firing squad.

title: WOMEN'S NETWORK THRIVING
description: WHEN a new member attends a meeting of the New Jersey Women's Network, one of the first things she is likely to do is exchange business cards with other members.

title: Rent Hardship
description: To the Editor:

title: HENDERSON: BREAK DANCER AT THE BALLET
description: NOW that the Yankees have finally succeeded in negotiating an $8.65 million contract with Rickey Henderson, they must negotiate a new philosophy at Yankee Stadium - allowing a base-stealer to steal bases.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR Centers for Peace: Other Perspectives
description: I cannot believe the na"ivete of the people at the so- called centers for peace (''Centers for Peace Find Homes in the County,'' Nov. 18).

title: THEATER IN FRANCE: FRON CORNEILLE TO POLITICAL SATIRE
description: In Paris these days, one hears that

title: BRAZILIAN STATE OUTLAWS GAS USED AT INDIAN PLANT
description: The state government of Rio de Janeiro has prohibited the unloading of a shipment of methyl isocyanate and decreed that the lethal gas, the same kind responsible for the disaster in Bhopal, India, can no longer be used in the state.

title: U.S. Envoy Arrives In Sri Lanka
description: A special United States envoy, Gen. Vernon Walters, arrived in Sri Lanka today, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said.

title: IN SOUTHERN AFRICA, TOO, FOOD CRISIS GROWS
description: While the famine in Ethiopia has aroused the compassion of the world, a quiet drama of comparable dimensions is in the making in southern Africa.

title: WILANDER WINS FINAL IN 4 SETS
description: Mats Wilander, formerly known as a clay-court specialist, wore down Kevin Curren, 6-7, 6-4, 7-6, 6-2, today and retained the men's singles title at the Australian Open tennis championships on grass at Kooyong. It was the Swede's third Grand Slam tournament title over all.

title: Market Place; Wall St. Wary Of Oil Stocks
description: SLIGHTLY more than four years ago, in November 1980, shares of domestic oil companies reached record heights. That spectacular runup reflected steadily rising prices of crude oil, along with the expectation that crude prices would keep climbing in the current decade.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 10, 1984: MONAY Bunker Hill Inc Sec Illinois Power Dayco Corp

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on Nov. 24 with an article about rabbis' use of computers to interpret the Talmud misidentified some symbols shown below Hebrew characters on a screen. They included both vowels and cantillation signs, which denote tones for chanting.

title: A Look Back at Grenada
description: Critics of the Grenada invasion - this page among them - need to acknowledge its constructive sequel. A year and a month after the intervention, Grenada has held its first election since 1976. The victory of former Prime Minister Herbert Blaize restores the status quo ante. After a terrible decade of first right-wing, then left-wing misrule, Grenadians have been helped back to the center under a leader congenial to the United States.

title: TOY SALES: CHANGING SCENE
description: The old toy department, with half an acre of toys and the kids lined up to see Santa, is becoming the ghost of Christmas past at department stores across the land.

title: COONEY'S POWER IMPRESSIVE, BUT QUESTIONS REMAIN
description: Gerry Cooney is back, and so are the questions.

title: AS FISHING INDUSTRY CHANGES, RISK AND LOSS SEEM TO GROW
description: In the Gloucester harbor north of here, where fishermen have brought their catch to dock for more than 350 years, the curved hulls and rigging of the fishing trawlers make a pretty sight. But some of the oldest boats, and some of the newest, are not at dock, nor will they be again.

title: WORKING AT HOME IS A BLOW FOR FREEDOM
description: To the Editor:

title: ETHIOPIAN JEWS ARE FIGHTING TO HANG ON AMID DROUGHT
description: When he knew that he would be visiting Ethiopia, said David Bedein, an Israeli social worker, he got in touch with many of the Ethiopian Jews in his hometown of Safad.

title: Seat Belt Laws Preferred To Airbags, A.A.A. Says
description: The American Automobile Association said today it would prefer state laws requiring use of safety belts over proposed Federal requirements that airbags be installed in new automobiles.

title: 'Economic Security Council Urged
description: A Presidential task force has recommended the establishment of a White House Economic Security Council to coordinate international economic policy - reviving heated arguments over the splitting up of economic power within the Administration.

title: BROADENED POWER GIVE FEDERAL BUDGET OFFICE CONTROLS OVER RULES
description: The Reagan Administration, moving to consolidate its power over the Federal bureaucracy, has significantly enlarged the scope and authority of the Office of Management and Budget in the last four years.

title: Doyle Dane Acquires San Francisco Agency
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach has acquired the Michael-Sellers Company, a 28- year-old San Francisco agency billing some $21 million, and it will merge it into D.D.B./San Francisco, billing about $17 million.

title: Newly Formed HCM Gets Its First Account
description: The New York office of HCM - which stands for Havas Conseil Marsteller - has its first account since assuming its new identity.

title: RIZZOLI ACUIRES BOOKSTORES OF SCRIBNER
description: Rizzoli International Bookstores, a New York-based company owned by Italian and Swiss interests, has bought Scribner Book Stores, which has been owned independently by members of the Scribner book publishing family in Manhattan for 135 years. The new owners said the famous Scribner Book Store on Fifth Avenue and 48th Street will stay in place - as a bookstore.

title: Senator Rosalynn Carter?
description: Speaking of First Ladies, word

title: Athletes, Beware
description: On the basketball court, the kid showed promise as a freshman, but college is a long, four-year haul and many student-athletes who start strong are gone by senior year.

title: ADLER: QUEEN OF THE METHOD
description: Wearing bed sheet cloaks and foam rubber crowns, the students assembled in a room three floors above West 56th Street. They had come to acting class to learn how to play royalty. Their instructor, Stella Adler, need not pretend at the role.

title: CHALLENGE AIR'S EXPANSION PLANS
description: Bill F. Spohrer is no stranger to fledgling passenger airlines or to Latin America.

title: Broncos 16 Chargers 13
description: Rich Karlis, atoning for failures in two previous games, had three field goals, including a 28-yarder with 2:08 left, as Denver snapped a two-game losing streak and got back into first place in the American Conference West.

title: Alphabatim Wins Coast Turf Race
description: Alphabatim held off Raami in the stretch to score a 1 3/4-length victory today in the $500,000 Hollywood Turf Cup.

title: U.S. ORDERS INSPECTIONS OF PLANES LIKE ONE IN FATAL FLORIDA CRASH
description: The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday ordered an emergency inspection of the tail sections of Bandeirante airliners.

title: NO CONDUIT TO AFGHANS
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1984

title: COMPANIES FIND SPORTS GOOD FOR BUSINESS
description: At E. F. Hutton & Company, salesmen are rewarded for brisk business with tickets to the Super Bowl, employees are buoyed by motivational lectures from the Knicks' coach, and investment bankers cozy up to clients by chronicling their progress on the tennis court or the ski slopes.

title: WNYC IN TV PACT FOR SHOWS IN GREEK AS WELL AS JAPANESE
description: -TV, the New York City- owned television station, has reached tentative agreements to lease a substantial portion of its air time to three private, foreign-language broadcasting companies. Two of them would broadcast in Japanese, the other in Greek.

title: Diseased Animals Removed From Coast Research Center
description: Two rabbits injected with oral herpes and numerous dogs with cancer were among more than 100 animals stolen from a research center, apparently by animal rights activists who scrawled slogans on walls with paint and tar, officials said today.

title: GIANTS' FATE NOW UNCLEAR
description: ST. LOUISThe Giants' locker room immediately after the game against the Cardinals yesterday afternoon was very quiet. At first, the only sound was that of soiled uniforms plopping into laundry baskets. The players sat silently and grimly on stools in front of their cubicles, removed their jerseys and pants and socks, and tossed them into one of several cloth baskets in the room.

title: Washington Watch; Differing View On the Elderly
description: WASHINGTON

title: U.S. OFFICIALS 'VERY PLEASED' AT END OF HIJACKING IN TEHERAN
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they were ''very pleased'' by the apparent resolution of the Kuwaiti airliner crisis in Iran.

title: TEHERAN REPORTS ITS MEN TAKE JET AND FREE CAPTIVES
description: Iranian security men stormed the hijacked Kuwaiti airliner at the Teheran airport shortly before midnight Sunday and freed the last nine hostages, the Iranian press agency reported. The four Arabic-speaking hijackers surrendered, the agency said.

title: Midway Turns To Campbell
description: Campbell-Mithun of Minneapolis and Chicago, a subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide, announced Friday that it would be taking over the account of Midway Airlines of Chicago, replacing two agencies that quit.

title: Guignard Records First Cup Victory
description: Corrine Guignard of France overtook Erika Hess with a powerful second-heat charge today to score her first World Cup victory by winning the slalom race.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: YULE TIDE

title: SEAWAY IS SET TO REOPEN AFTER BRIDGE BREAKDOWN
description: Canadian officials said today that they had repaired a malfunctioning bridge that had blocked the St. Lawrence Seaway for more than three weeks, stranding 160 ships west of Montreal and halting shipments of grain and steel.

title: HEADLINES BLARING, CITY'S TABLOIDS STEP UP BATTLE
description: A new, rough and head-to-head form of competition has flared in New York City's long and bitter tabloid newspaper war between The Daily News and The New York Post.

title: Common Market Fills Posts
description: The former Finance Minister of Belgium, Willie de Clerq, this weekend was named Europe's chief trade negotiator with the United States, Japan and other industrialized countries, a key post in the Common Market's new executive commission that takes office next month.

title: HONDURAS MAKES NEW DEMANDS ON U.S.
description: As part of an effort to obtain increased aid and diplomatic concessions from the United States, Honduras has recently presented a new series of demands to the Reagan Administration, according to Honduran and American officials.

title: Taiwanese Miner Is Rescued And Tells of His Cannibalism
description: A miner who was rescued today from a coal mine where he was trapped for four days after an explosion said ate a dead miner's flesh, believing he had to do so to survive.

title: Freed Solidarity Activist Seeks a Political Role
description: Bogdan Lis, a Solidarity activist who was freed Saturday, said today that he wanted a political role in Poland's future and would resume contacts with other leaders of Solidarity, the banned free trade union.

title: Where's the Cake?
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel,

title: Up the Stairs to Arms Control
description: The big news in arms control is that Paul Nitze has moved from the fifth to the seventh floor of the State Department. That gives Secretary of State Shultz easy access to some of the weapons expertise and bureaucratic skill he needs to take charge of nuclear diplomacy - if only the President will now guard the Secretary's other flanks.

title: NICARAGUAN REBEL IN APPEAL FOR AID
description: An anti-Sandinista leader told a rally of some 1,500 Nicaraguan exiles at a park in this township north of Miami today that the Reagan Administration had a ''duty to find a formula'' for supporting Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Grenadian Opposition Party Accuses U.S. of Rigging Vote
description: Grenada's main opposition party accused United States officials today of rigging elections that returned the Caribbean island to democracy 13 months after an American-led invasion.

title: BRAZIL'S RULERS AWAIT DEFEAT IN VOTE
description: Five weeks before Brazil's indirect presidential election, the departing military Government seems to have accepted the anticipated defeat of its candidate and has begun working to insure a smooth transition to opposition civilian rule.

title: BACKERS OF NUCLEAR FREEZE SEEK TO BROADEN BASE
description: Advocates of a nuclear weapons freeze, holding what organizers said was the movement's largest national gathering ever, have voted to focus their efforts on long-term strategies and redouble attempts to attract broader support.

title: Samsung Electronics Chooses David Deutsch
description: Samsung Electronics America, the marketing arm of a Korean manufacturer that recently opened a New Jersey plant, is taking its $4 million in advertising billings to David Deutsch Associates.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Campaignland, U.S.A.
description: In Washington, they're hauling the Inaugural out of the attic and putting away the crate marked Campaign, the one containing the primaries, conventions, debates, Electoral College, exit polls - all the artifacts needed for the candidates to take to the stump. Except one: the stump. It has disappeared.

title: ; PUBLIC OFFICIALS DON'T BELONG ON JURIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Capitol Sells Majority Stake
description: Capitol Air, which suspended operations Nov. 25 because of financial problems, said it had sold a majority interest in the airline to a group of investors who plan to resume service before Christmas.

title: IRAQI MISSILE HITS TANKER IN GULF
description: An Iraqi warplane fired an Exocet missile into a Bahamian-registered oil tanker in the Persian Gulf today, Iraq and marine salvage executives said. No casualties were reported.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT BY COMPANY ON GAS LEAK
description: Following is the text of the statement issued in New Delhi today by Union Carbide India Ltd. on the gas leak in Bhopal, India:

title: POLICEMAN ARRESTED
description: A 56-year-old police sergeant was arrested last night and charged with the shooting death of a woman in Queens early yesterday morning in a dispute over an auto accident, the police said.

title: Lucas Takes Leave
description: John Lucas, the Houston Rocket guard, has taken an indefinite leave of absence after testing positively for drug use, a spokesman for the National Basketball Association team said today.

title: Eagles Eliminate Patriots
description: The Eagles, who scored three running touchdowns all season, picked up three against New England today as they defeated the Patriots, 27-17.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Allied Corp. plans to issue 10 billion yen of Euroyen bonds, the equivalent of $41 million, with a 6 3/4 percent coupon and a maturity of seven years, through underwriters led by Nomura International.

title: HOMOSEXUAL COUPLES FIND A QUIET PRIDE
description: After 40 years together, Marvin and Murray decided an anniversary party was in order. So they booked the Pool Club of the United Nations Plaza Hotel and sent out formal invitations to friends and relatives. Among the 130 guests at the party, held last month, were Marvin's aunt from New Orleans, his sister from Las Vegas and Murray's nieces and nephews, who call his partner ''Uncle Marvin.''

title: FRIENDS AND ACCESSORIES JOIN CABBAGE PATCH DOLL
description: The Cabbage Patch Kids, America's popular pudgy playmates, are a hit again this Christmas. This year, however, there's a whole patch full of Cabbage Patch goods, including children's clothes, diapers, sleeping bags, sewing machines and playhouses. This year the Kids have younger siblings, called Preemies, and pets, called Koosas. Next year, twins will arrive to the Cabbage Patch family.

title: COMPUTER MAKERS FIND RICH MARKET IN SCHOOLS
description: The education sales manager for Apple Computer Inc. has a word he sometimes uses to describe the seemingly endless demand for microcomputers in the nation's public schools: mania.

title: Philippine Inflation
description: The Philippines' inflation rate slowed to 60.57 percent last month, from 63.8 percent in October, and is expected to continue to decline, Economic Planning Minister Vicente Valdepenas said today.

title: STARRETT CITY: 20,000 TENANTS, FEW COMPLAINTS
description: Florida?'' said Nat Abramowitz, waving his cigar. ''We've got everything Florida has but the weather.''

title: Nelson Takes Title
description: Azumah Nelson of Ghana knocked out Wilfredo Gomez with one second remaining in the 11th round Saturday night to take away his opponent's World Boxing Council featherweight title.

title: DANCE: 'PORTRAIT OF BILLIE' GIVEN BY AILEY COMPANY
description: The life and death of the singer Billie Holiday make up the subject of ''Portrait of Billie,'' John Butler's powerful choreographic treatment of private angst behind show-biz success. It is Mr. Butler's finest dance work and, fortunately, has been kept alive in the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's repertory. On Wednesday night at its first performance of the season at the City Center, Donna Wood was the tragic heroine and Rodney Nugent was her man, nameless and unfeeling.

title: JEWISH FEDERATION SHIFTS POLICY ON HOSPITAL GIFTS
description: The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York has made a ''major change'' in its annual contributions to its seven affiliated hospitals to insure that the money ''more clearly reflects'' the hospitals' Jewish sponsorship.

title: AVERAGE PAY DOWN FOR YANKEES, METS
description: The Yankees and the Mets were among five teams whose average player salaries went down last season, but the Yankees retained their No. 1 spot while the Mets plummeted from 10th to 20th.

title: Traditional Toys Sell Well
description: Toys have made a strong showing this year in large part because the public is turning away from video games and toward traditional toys, according to merchants and analysts concerned with the industry.

title: Suspect F.B.I. Hunted Believed Dead in Siege
description: A body believed to be that of a neo- Nazi wanted for shooting an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was found today in the charred rubble of an island house.

title: A Gender Gap
description: Francis Gordon Brown was quite a man, and so, by Brown's standard at least, is Mindy Rosenbaum. Brown was a 6-foot-3-inch guard and captain of the great Yale football team of 1900 that compiled a 12-0 record and scored 336 points while holding its opponents to only 10 - a touchdown and extra point by Columbia and a field goal by Princeton.

title: AT A RELIEF CENTER IN CHAD, THE FOOD IS GONE
description: MOUSSORO, Chad, Dec. 6 - At the edge of the grid of squat and square mud houses in this market town in western Chad, a second town has sprung up, about as populous.

title: OPERA: MET IN 'ELECKTRA'
description: Two sopranos who probably shouldn't have took over the leading roles in Strauss's ''Elektra'' at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday evening.

title: OUTSIDE DIRECTORS CLEAR GRAY
description: The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that its outside board members had cleared Harry J. Gray, the conglomerate's chairman, and other officers of illegal or improper conduct.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Dolphins 35, Colts 17
description: Behind four second-half touchdown passes by Dan Marino, Miami (13-2) overcame a 17-7 halftime deficit.

title: ST. JOHN'S ROUTS RUTGERS, 77-61
description: After escaping with two 1-point victories over teams it was supposed to defeat handily, St. John's turned in its best performance of the season tonight in beating Rutgers, 77-61.

title: ETHICS AND TELEVISION DISCUSSED BY BROADCASTERS
description: When broadcasters meet to discuss ethics and television, there is often a lot of blame meted out, and not very much responsibility taken.

title: Bangladesh Lawyers Back National Strike
description: The Bangladesh Supreme Court Bar Association announced today that it had extended its ''support and solidarity'' to a national strike on Dec. 22 and 23 called by major opposition parties to force President H. M. Ershad to restore democracy.

title: Article 140861 -- No Title
description: Union Carbide India Ltd. announced today that it would contribute $830,000 to a special relief fund for the disabled survivors of the deadly gas leak from it pesticide plant in Bhopal.

title: No Losers Here
description: Careful selection of nomenclature can sometimes make your batting average seem higher. The National Chamber Litigation Center, the legal arm of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, has only two classifications on its case list: ''Victories'' for proceedings it has won and ''Ongoing Cases'' for those being appealed to a higher court.

title: FOR DEMOCRATS, THE MEDIUM'S A MESS
description: In a candid post-mortem after his defeat in November, Walter F. Mondale offered Democrats the advice that any future Presidential nominee should be a television politician, someone at home with the medium that has become the central battleground of American campaigns.

title: RANGEL PLANS TAX BILL BASED ON TREASURY PLAN
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, said today he would submit a bill in Congress modeled on the Treasury Department's draft proposal for tax simplification.

title: McNamara, Clausen and Loans
description: The Bank of America is among the banks where directors are now engaged in reviewing loans to the third world.

title: Saving Some of Manhattan For the Less-Than-Rich
description: Is Manhattan becoming an enclave

title: JEANETTE H. ROBISON
description: Jeanette Hoffman Robison, former chairman of the board of the Mountain Trust Company of Stowe, Vt., died Saturday at the University of Vermont Medical Center in Burlington, Vt., of a brain hemmorrhage.

title: BBDO Client
description: Did you know that BBDO has a special Business-to-Business Group? Well, it does, and it has just got a new client with a budget of $1 million.

title: SLUMS ALONGSIDE FACTORIES INEVITABLE, EXPERTS SAY
description: The industrial accidents in the third world in recent months, highlighted by the poison gas tragedy in India last week, point to the difficulty in isolating industrial plants from densely populated residential areas in third world countries, according to some development specialists.

title: W.S. LASDON, PHILANTHROPIST AND A DRUG EXECUTIVE, DIES
description: William S. Lasdon, a pharmaceutical executive and philanthropist, died yesterday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 88 years old and also had a home in Somers, N.Y.

title: PITY THE APOLOGIST FOR SOUTH AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: DICKERSON TOPS SIMPSON MARK
description: Just when everything was going right for the Giants, just when they seemed about to move one step away from a playoff berth, everything fell apart today.

title: Norsk Cites Phillips Talks
description: Norsk Hydro A/S confirmed in Oslo today that it had told the Phillips Petroleum Company it was interested in the possibility of acquiring the Phillips share of Ekofisk, the oilfield in the Norwegian sector of the North Sea.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the European Currency Unit, or ECU, misstated the number of separate currencies it represents.

title: Blaze at Bellevue Is Confined ToOneFloor,WithNoInjuries
description: A one-alarm fire yesterday swept through an unoccupied floor of a new building at Bellevue Hospital Center, authorities said.

title: 3 GERMAN CAR MAKERS BATTLE IN U.S. MARKET
description: West Germany's three largest manufacturers of luxury performance cars are locked in a fierce battle for the loyalty of affluent Americans.

title: GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST HELPING TO EASE BURDENS OF CHILDREN
description: Dear N.Y. Times,

title: Carol Finkelstein Wed
description: At Temple Gates of Prayer in Flushing, Queens, yesterday Carol Ann Finkelstein, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Murray Finkelstein of Bayside, Queens, was married to Morris Shoretz, the son of Rabbi and Mrs. Osher Shoretz of Brooklyn.

title: Kuwaitis Try a New Exchange
description: Kuwait's new stock exchange, an imposing marble and tinted black glass emporium, is situated across the street from the State Mosque.

title: RANGERS MYSTIFIED BY UNLUCKY STRETCH
description: The Rangers, as a team, are like a video game character. They resemble the fellow trying to rescue the damsel from the gorilla. He carries a sledgehammer to stamp out rolling balls of fire as he tries to hop from one station to the next. But when he missteps, he drops through a crack and lands with a splat.

title: MICKEY MOUSE ON NBC
description: ''Mickey's Christmas Carol'' is about as good as you expect it to be, which means it is a vaguely felt, but ineluctable, disappointment. Walt Disney Productions has, as always, the talent and the means; it is its sensibilities that fall short. Why should it mug Charles Dickens? The animated feature, Mickey Mouse's first since 1953, will be seen on NBC at 8 tonight.

title: THE PUNITIVE LIBEL TRIALS
description: Irrespective of their merits, the two giant libel trials going on in New York City should be immediately dismissed because of their chilling effect on the press. In addition, Federal steps should be taken to insure that no such trials are ever permitted again.

title: SOUTH AFRICA DEMONSTRATORS TO FIGHT SALE OF KRUGERRANDS
description: Leaders of the movement in the United States against the South African policy of racial segregation decided today to expand their protests to dealers selling South Africa's gold Krugerrand.

title: REDSKINS TRIUMPH, TAKE FIRST ALONE
description: For the first time in eight weeks, one team, the Washington Redskins, has first place to itself in the Eastern Division of the National Conference.

title: Tass Joins Yule Tour
description: Are there signs of a thaw in United States-Soviet relations? Well, when Nancy Reagan conducts her annual press tour of the White House and its Christmas decorations this morning, joining the usual newspaper and news agency reporters and television cameras for the first time will be a representative of Tass, the Soviet press agency, which asked and was granted permission to cover the tour.

title: From Student to Dean At Columbia Law
description: The civil rights lawyer, Prof.

title: Swedish Daily Calls on Palme To Resign as Prime Minister
description: A leading Swedish newspaper called today for Prime Minister Olof Palme to resign because of remarks that left doubt over whether he thought a Conservative Government would preserve the nation's neutrality.

title: DELOREAN TRIAL JURORS TELL WHY THEY VOTED TO ACQUIT
description: Jurors who acquitted John Z. DeLorean of drug conspiracy charges said in a series of interviews published today that they did not mean their verdict to be a message in opposition to Government undercover operations.

title: PLAYOFF ASPIRANTS IN JUMBLED FINISH
description: The San Francisco 49ers have won the Western Division of the National Football Conference. The Chicago Bears have won the Central Division.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Last month, Columbia completed a football season in which it lost all its games for only the second time in its history, the other year being 1943. Have any other teams in the Ivy League gone through the same thing?

title: COMING ARMS TALKS: BONN WAITS WARILY
description: The approaching renewal of preliminary talks between Washington and Moscow over nuclear weapons holds out both possibilities and pitfalls for the Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl, which is badly in need of foreign policy breakthroughs to offset difficulties at home. On the positive side, the resumption of Soviet- American arms talks could vindicate the Kohl Government's championing of American medium- range missiles in West Germany, soften the overall East-West climate and permit Bonn to revive its stalled diplomatic openings to East Berlin and other Warsaw Pact capitals.

title: Dr. Gabrielle Marshall Married to Radiologist
description: The marriage of Dr. Gabrielle Marshall, a resident in psychiatry at St. Vincent's Hospital, and Dr. Amir Salomon, a resident in radiology at Mount Sinai Hospital, took place yesterday.

title: Advertising; 3 Agencies Contribute To 1 Spot
description: TO some advertising aficionados,

title: Chase Receives Prize
description: Joan Chase, author of ''During the Reign of the Queen of Persia,'' published by Harper & Row last year and by Ballantine Books in paperback this year, has been named the winner of the Janet Heidinger Kafka prize for fiction. The $1,000 prize is given exclusively to women writers by the English department and the writers workshop of the University of Rochester.

title: Intelsat Softens on Competition
description: Intelsat, the cooperative of governments that runs the world's main international satellite communications system, has softened its opposition to competition by private companies. Two weeks ago, President Reagan said he supported competition with Intelsat only in the areas of intra-office video, data and voice transmissions, a position that would protect 85 percent of Intelsat's business.

title: MALONE AND 76ERS OVERPOWER KNICKS
description: The Philadelphia 76ers extended their winning streak to seven games tonight by defeating the Knicks, 110-94, at the Spectrum. That the talent- laden 76ers, who own the second-best record in the National Basketball Association (16-4), would beat the undermanned and injury-riddled Knicks could be expected. The strange aspect of New York's third straight loss, which dropped its season mark to 9-15, was what they did to make it even easier for the 76ers.

title: NORDIQUES AND SABRES PLAY TO 4-4 TIE
description: Mario Marois, the Quebec defenseman, scored with 1 minute 4 seconds remaining in regulation to lift the Nordiques into a 4-4 overtime tie with Buffalo today.

title: HE FEELS 'SUPER'
description: William J. Schroeder, saying he felt ''super,'' tonight declared the experiment in which he received an artificial heart a success.

title: BAN SPACE-WEAPONS TESTS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz leaves today to consult the NATO allies on his Jan. 7-8 space and nuclear arms control talks in Geneva with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko. But agreement is not in sight, either with the allies or the Russians.

title: MUSIC: SONGS BY CHARNIN
description: Martin Charnin, who wrote the lyrics for the musical, ''Annie,'' is by no means a giant among Broadway songwriters. A clever writer of revue songs, as well as of sentimental ballads like ''Tomorrow,'' he is a polished craftsman of easygoing, homey verses that use topical references and broad puns.

title: RISING TREND FOR BOND YIELDS
description: While securities dealers wait for new economic data and a fresh supply of Treasury issues to revive interest among speculators and investors, the trend has been for higher note and bond yields over the past two weeks.

title: Nets Acquire Kevin McKenna
description: In an effort to shore up their depleted forces, the Nets signed Kevin McKenna, a 6-foot-7-inch, 210-pound forward yesterday.

title: MAYOR SAYS OPPONENTS POLARIZE CITY
description: While black politicians searched for a mayoral candidate of their own, Mayor Koch went to a black church in Harlem yesterday and accused his opponents of polarizing the city.

title: U.S. and Britain Conduct Test of Nuclear Device
description: The United States and Britain detonated a high-yield nuclear device today in an underground test beneath the desert at the Nevada test site.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Dec. 10, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: BIPARTISAN REPORT
description: The most fascinating finding in The New York Times/CBS Sports Poll, reported in these pages yesterday, was that Republicans tend to favor high-scoring football games, while Democrats tend to prefer low-scoring games.

title: Champion Spark Plug Appoints 3d President
description: Robert J. Brotje Jr. has been named president and chief operating officer of the Champion Spark Plug Company.

title: INDIANA, CLEMSON IN FINAL
description: Indiana earned a chance to win its third straight soccer championship by beating Hartwick, 2-1, today in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. The triumph was Indiana's 38th straight at home.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Football
description: Detroit Lions vs. Los Angeles Raiders , at Pontiac, Mich. The Raiders, the defending league champions, again appear to be on a late-season roll into the playoffs as they were last season when they won six of their last seven games after stumbling early in the season.

title: OPEC UNIT BACKS PRICE CHANGES
description: Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said that a key OPEC committee has agreed on changes in the group's pricing policy, but its $29-a-barrel benchmark price would remain untouched.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''One way or another, the law-abiding nations of the world will put an end to terrorism and to this barbarism that threatens the very foundations of civilized life.

title: SPEAKING FOR THE TREES
description: ''He was shortish. And oldish. And brownish. And mossy. And he spoke with a voice that was sharpish and bossy.''

title: 30 YEARS OF CARING: THE P.A.L.'S ONE-WOMAN SHOW
description: The prevailing image of the Police Athletic League is one of organized street sports and games, of young boys and girls in police-shield T-shirts bouncing balls, swinging bats and leaping hurdles. As accurate as that is in this 70th anniversary year of the P.A.L., it is incomplete, for it does not include the P.A.L. world of Kitty Kirby, who has young people singing, dancing and acting.

title: ACTIVISM AFFIRMED BY CATHOLIC ORDER
description: The governing councils of Roman Catholic Maryknoll missionaries have given strong backing to the order's social justice aims, despite criticism of its policy of political activism.

title: A TIME TO REMEMBER SLAIN DRAMA STUDENT
description: A week had been time enough for the body of Caroline Isenberg to be brought home to Brookline, Mass., for her parents to tear their clothes in the Jewish tradition of mourning and to bury their child.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SOMETHING TO BE DESIRED. By Thomas McGuane. 173 pages. Random House. $14.95. OTHER WOMEN. By Lisa Alther. 336 pages. Knopf. $15.95.

title: Futures/Options; Automation In Trading
description: Is the ''electronic outcry'' system of futures trading the answer to the increasing congestion on exchange floors, the costly rise in errors in order executions and the industry's shrinking profitability?

title: LAWYER'S FEE CUT ON APPEAL
description: Four years after a prominent Boston lawyer was awarded $176,000 in fees for winning a civil rights case in the United States Supreme Court, an appeals court has cut those fees in half.

title: INDIA AND PAKISTAN MUST RUN OR RUIN THEMSELVES
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1984 International Iranian security men freed the last nine hostages in a hijacked Kuwaiti airliner at the Teheran airport, and the four Arabic-speaking hijackers surrendered, the Iran press agency reported. The hostages were two Americans, the British pilot and four Arabs, and two Kuwaiti men, who previously were reported to have been killed, the press agency said. (Page A1, Column 6.) Bhopal ''became a big gas chamber'' the night that a lethal gas escaped from a Union Carbide insecticide plant, one of the survivors of the biggest chemical accident in history said. In contributing to a reconstruction of that night, a police official in the Indian city, said anyone who was left alive ran away blindly. ''Mothers didn't know their children had died. Children didn't know their mothers had died. Men didn't know their whole families had died.'' (A1:1.)

title: THE CROTTYS: CLOSE FAMILY OF 7 LAWYERS
description: Peter J. Crotty has said more than once that his children have displayed ''no imagination'' in their choice of careers.

title: Theater Art Created To Go on the Road
description: Picasso and Chagall did it. David

title: Agency-of-Record Plan For A.T.&T. on TV
description: The American Telegraph and Telephone Company will adopt the agency-of-record approach to network television buying on Jan. 1.

title: Lori Beth Silberberg Weds Howard Levine in Queens
description: Lori Beth Silberberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Silberberg of Merrick, L.I., was married yesterday to Howard Mark Levine, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David Levine of Englewood, N.J. Rabbi Morton Gordon performed the ceremony at Temple Torah in Little Neck, Queens.

title: FREEDOM, NOT COMFORT
description: BOSTON The Mobil Corporation has for

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Atlantic Gulf Airlines of St. Petersburg, Fla., which recently filed for Chapter 11 protection, has named Fred E. Luhm chairman and president as part of a reorganization.

title: IN BHOPAL, SIGNS OF TRAGEDY ARE EVERYWHERE
description: The mosques, the temples and the schools have reopened, and fruit vendors and shopkeepers are back, peddling their wares. But everywhere there are signs and reminders of the tragedy that has scarred this central Indian city of 900,000.

title: CHIEFS TURN BACK SEAHAWKS BY 34-7
description: The rookie linebacker Scott Radecic returned an interception 19 yards for a touchdown to highlight a 17-point second-quarter that carried the Kansas City Chiefs to a 34-7 upset of the Seattle Seahawks (12-3) today.

title: CARTER'S PLAY GIVES JETS HOPE FOR '85
description: In this what-might-have-been season for the 7-8 Jets, the most nagging speculation on defense has centered on the club's first-round draft picks - Russell Carter and Ron Faurot.

title: Houston Natural Gas Names Shell Oil Officer
description: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation, which is in the midst of a major restructuring program, said that Keith D. Kern, a longtime financial official at the Shell Oil Company, had been named chief financial officer. The appointment is effective Jan. 1.

title: A Democratic Success
description: When prizes are awarded for little-noticed achievements of the 1984 political campaign, there ought to be something in the envelope for the Democratic Senate Campaign Committee. For the first time, that group raised more money through its direct-mail appeals to contributors than the program cost in stamps, stationery and mailing lists, raising, in fact, $500,000 for candidates.

title: Large Gaudi Exhibition Being Held in Barcelona
description: The largest-ever exhibition of the works of Antonio Gaudi, Spain's most eccentric architect, opened in Barcelona last week, 58 years after his death.

title: Walter M. Ciszek, 80; Jesuit Held by Soviet
description: The Rev. Walter M. Ciszek, a Jesuit missionary who spent 23 years in Soviet detention until his release in 1963, died Saturday morning at the John XXIII Ecumenical Center on the Bronx campus of Fordham University. He was 80 years old and had been assigned as a priest to the center since regaining his freedom.

title: GREATEST LEAP FORWARD
description: Put yourself at the turn of the millennium, and look back 15 years: What event in 1984 most affected the history of the world?

title: Days of Wine and Labels
description: In honor of the exhibition of Mouton

title: SOME SEE THREAT IN NON-LIBEL VERDICT IN FALWELL PARODY CASE
description: A jury's decision awarding damages to the Rev. Jerry Falwell for emotional distress caused by a magazine parody, if allowed to stand, could discourage free speech, several lawyers and legal scholars asserted yesterday.

title: COLLAPSE OF DEAK & COMPANY
description: In the world of foreign exchange and precious metals, no name glitters like Deak-Perera.

title: MEAT WORKERS BATTLE HORMEL ON WAGE CUTS
description: About 3,000 people today attended a boisterous rally here to press an unusually vigorous drive against wage cuts made by one of the nation's largest meatpackers.

title: SLAYINGS SHORTEN THE FUSE ON A TENSE PACIFIC ISLE
description: At the end of a dirt road, past the French troops guarding the way, 10 Melanesians killed last week received their funeral rites Saturday on a palm- and pine-covered tribal burial ground,

title: PAYTON IN QUARTERBACK DEBUT
description: Walter Payton, the star rusher for the Chicago Bears, made his National Football League debut at quarterback today, then said he would just as soon stay a halfback.

title: Bishop Assails Arrests Of Sanctuary Activists
description: The Roman Catholic Bishop of Brownsville today accused the Government of singling out for prosecution two activists he said were following Jesus' mandates by helping Salvadoran refugees.

title: Child Counselor in Brooklyn Is Charged With Abusing Boy
description: A Brooklyn man who runs a child- counseling practice from his home is being sought on charges he sexually abused a 10-year-old boy, authorities said last night.

title: 'CARMEN' AT LA SCALA
description: Briefly, it was like the old days at La Scala - not the time of Verdi, but the rough- -and-tumble era of the late 1960's.

title: DICKERSON'S RUSH TO GLORY: YARDS COME AUTOMATICALLY
description: ANAHEIM, Calif. The vigil had been going on all last week at the Los Angeles Rams practice field. News people were everywhere, as if by letting Eric Dickerson out of their sights for one second, he might slip on his goggles, steal away and break the big record behind everyone's backs.

title: PAVAROTTI IN CONCERT, TONIGHT ON PBS
description: As befitting a performer of his enormous stature and imposing girth, Luciano Pavarotti thinks big. Last August, he took his pop-classical act to New York's Madison Square Garden and left 20,000 fans exhausted from having to clamber to their feet for standing ovations. Seizing the flashy moment, WNET/Channel 13 was there with its cameras, under the always accomplished direction of Kirk Browning. So, tonight at 9:30, the event can be seen - and heard in stereo over WNCN-FM - by millions of the Italian tenor's admirers. ''Luciano Pavarotti in Concert at Madison Square Garden'' is being used as a centerpiece for the station's current on-air membership drive. The performance runs about 85 minutes. The ''package,'' complete with pitches for donations, runs two hours.

title: Bridge ; Bridge Federation Relocates Another World Title Match
description: For the second time in two years, the World Bridge Federation has moved a world championship because the intended host country could not provide a guarantee that all countries that might qualify to compete would be admitted.

title: Chicago Teacher Talks Recess Without a Pact
description: Talks that began shortly before noon Saturday ended tonight with no settlement in a teachers strike that has shut down the nation's third largest school system and idled 431,000 students.

title: Bodies of Three Men Found in Cape Cod Bay
description: The bodies of three men who disappeared after setting out to ferry a fishing boat across Cape Cod Bay were found today after a 12-hour Coast Guard search, but there was no sign of the boat.

title: INDIA DISASTER: CHRONICLE OF A NIGHTMARE
description: It began without warning in the dead of night, while the vast and crowded slums of Bhopal, India, lay in slumber, dreaming the troubled dreams of want and hope, heedless of the danger in the wind scything over the silent metropolis.

title: THEATER: 'HUSBANDRY,' PLAY BY PLAY BY PATRICK TOVATT
description: In a new play titled ''Husbandry,'' 1984's most ubiquitous pop-

title: MARIJUANA HAZARDS, ESPECIALLY FOR THE YOUNG
description: To the Editor:

title: Briefcases
description: - Department of Congressional perquisites: Representative Jack F. Kemp, the upstate New York Republican who sees the Federal Reserve and its chairman, Paul A. Volcker, as the chief obstacles to the success of supply-side economics, mailed out copies of an anti-Volcker magazine article earlier this month - at taxpayer expense.

title: FAMILIES AND SUICIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. MUST BE READY TO USE ITS POWER, SHULTZ DECLARES
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said yesterday that it was ''the burden of statesmanship'' for the United States to be ready to use military force even when it had no guarantee of public support for such action.

title: Chilean Economy Faltering
description: While President Augusto Pinochet has moved with apparent assurance to solidify his political support, the Chilean economy has begun to falter. The hard-line measures accompanying the state of siege that the 69-year-old commander imposed last Nov. 6 seem only to have worsened an already difficult economic situation.

title: STRESS SIGNS IN YOUTHS: OVEREATING
description: When a son or daughter becomes seriously overweight, conscientious parents often try to tackle the problem by putting the child on a diet. They assume they are doing their best to help. But are they?

title: Page on Apartheid
description: Greg Page, criticized by anti-apartheid groups for fighting in South Africa, would be glad to go there again, at least to box. He is not sure that he would like to live there, although he said he was offered a home by the Government of Bophuthatswana, one of the black homelands set up by the South African Government. Page captured the World Boxing Association heavyweight title there Dec. 1 with an eighth-round knockout of Gerrie Coetzee.

title: JEANNE CAGNEY
description: Jeanne Cagney Morrison, the actress and sister of actor James Cagney, died Friday at her home in Newport Beach, Calif. The cause of death was not disclosed.

title: Michele Bush Wins Metropolitan Mile
description: Michele Bush, last year's women's collegiate 1,500-meter champion, is attending the Columbia School of Nursing. Yesterday, she took time off from studying for examinations and won a mile race in 4 minutes 53 seconds at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: Outdoors ; Advice for Safe Hunting
description: Whether you have been pursuing game for a long time or are a recent graduate of a hunter-safety course, you should realize that handling firearms properly is something like quaffing strong spirits - you must remain forever alert to the endeavor's dangers.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: A Heavy Slate of Corporate Issues
description: The only Treasury financings scheduled this week are today's regular auctions of new bills due in three and six months. Late Friday, outstanding three-month bills were bid at 8.33 percent, while the six-month issue was 8.60 percent.

title: Hobart Freeman Dies; Indicted Head of a Sect
description: The Rev. Dr. Hobart Freeman, the leader of the Faith Assembly, died Saturday night at his home. He was 64 years old and had been ill for a month.

title: CHRISTINE ALEXANDER MARRIES DR. NORMAN ERNST JR.
description: At the Manhattanville College Chapel in Purchase, N.Y., yesterday Christine Ann Alexander, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Alexander of North Bellmore, L.I., was married to Dr. Norman A. Ernst Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ernst of Garden City, L.I. Msgr. Patrick Sheridan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: 2 Australians in Gas Scare At a Union Carbide Factory
description: Two security guards at a Union Carbide factory in Sydney were rushed to the hospital early today after it was suspected they had inhaled toxic ammonia gas.

title: Trouble at Armory
description: For the last three decades, the Bishop Loughlin track and field games at the 102d Engineers Armory at Fort Washington Avenue and 168th Street has been the largest indoor meet for high school athletes in the country, drawing as many as 4,000 competitors from 300 schools in a 10-state area.

title: Midtown Offices Are Rated Tops
description: In the high-priced-office stakes,

title: Paper Says Wholesalers Steal Gasoline Taxes
description: Dishonest petroleum wholesalers in Florida stole millions of dollars in gasoline tax revenues, The Fort Lauderdale News/Sun-Sentinel reported today.

title: BANK BOARD PLANS EXPANSION CURBS
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board plans to restrict state-chartered savings institutions from moving into the new lines of business recently permitted by regulators in some states.

title: Britain Said to Turn Over Antarctic Base to Chile
description: Britain handed over one of its Antarctic bases to Chile in an unpublicized agreement with the Chilean Ambassador in London early this year, The Observer reported.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY SHULTZ
description: Following are excerpts from Secretary of State George P. Shultz's address Saturday to a Yeshiva University convocation at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in Manhattan:

title: ISRAELIS ASK DEADLINE IN TALKS
description: Israel pressed today for a two-week deadline to break the impasse with Lebanon over an Israeli withdrawal from the south.

title: FENCES SHORTENED IN 'DEATH VALLEY'
description: For the first time since Yankee Stadium was renovated for the 1976 season, the Yankees are bringing in the fences in left-center and center field. The primary reason, George Steinbrenner said yesterday, is to build a walkway so fans can visit the monument area in left-center field before games.

title: Denver Tree Choppers Cause Big Traffic Jam
description: Christmas tree hunters chopped down more than 10,000 trees in the mountains last weekend and caused traffic jams equal to any rush hour crush in the Denver area.

title: POWERTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
10 CHARGED WITH PARTICIPATION IN MILLION-DOLLAR HEROIN RING
description: Ten men were arrested in New York City and three other cities Sunday night and yesterday and were charged with being members of a drug ring that had conspired to distribute tens of millions of dollars worth of Lebanese-made heroin in the United States.

title: Accounts
description: * Schering-Plough's U.S. Pharmaceutical Products division to Ogilvy & Mather for Chlor-Trimeton, an allergy treatment medication, and an unnamed new product.

title: 'BUNNY'S TALE' DEPICTS STEINEM'S PLAYBOY DAYS
description: Gloria Steinem stood in front of a replica of New York's now-defunct Playboy Club and felt as if she had been transported back in time. ''It looks exactly the way I remember it,'' Miss Steinem said. ''I feel as if I'm on 59th Street in New York.''

title: WHAT WE CAN DO TO HALT FAMINES IN AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Officer Quits At Miniscribe Corp.
description: The Miniscribe Corporation, a disk- drive maker that absorbed a sharp blow earlier this year when the International Business Machines Corporation reduced its orders for data storage devices, announced yesterday that Terry Johnson had resigned as chief executive. Mr. Johnson, who is 49 years old, had founded Miniscribe.

title: INDICTED AGENT'S ATTORNEYS SAY F.B.I. SINGLED HIM OUT
description: An attorney for Richard W. Miller, the first F.B.I. agent ever to be charged with espionage, said at least three bureau agents had earlier had ''romantic affairs'' with women who had links to Soviet intelligence officials, according to a court statement.

title: 4 INDICTED IN SCHEME TO BILK NEW YORK ON AIDS RESEARCH
description: A former State Assemblyman and three other men have been indicted on charges that they tried to steal at least $250,000 from the state by inflating the cost of an AIDS research project, authorities said today.

title: RANGERS HOLD OFF KING RALLY
description: The Rangers could be forgiven if for a moment last night they thought a complete collapse was impending. ''I couldn't help it,'' said Willie Huber. ''No matter we had played really well. I felt a bad thing coming.''

title: JOSEPH LOMBARDI
description: Detective Sgt. Joseph Lombardi, a member of the Transit Police Department for 35 years, died of cancer Thursday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 60 years old and lived in Massapequa, L.I.

title: Karpov Postpones Chess Game in Moscow
description: Anatoly Karpov postponed the 32d game of the world chess championship match today against Gary Kasparov, the Soviet press agency Tass announced.

title: Sri Lanka Army Says It Killed 15
description: Army troops killed 15 people and rounded up 750 during a weekend drive against separatist Tamil guerrillas in northern Sri Lanka, the authorities said today.

title: SOUTH BOSTON SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: South Boston Savings said it converted to stock ownership in November 1983.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: Securities dealers in the tax-exempt bond market expect to offer more than $1.6 billion of resource recovery revenue bonds during the next few weeks to finance plants that burn garbage and produce electricity.

title: U.S. AND HAVANA IN TENTATIVE PACT ON RETURN OF 2,500
description: United States and Cuban negotiators have reached an agreement in principle on the terms for repatriation to Cuba of some 2,500 criminals and mental patients, Administration officials said today.

title: Fun Spots and Monuments
description: The other night, as the last shuttle flight from New York prepared to land at National Airport, the view was exceptionally clear and the city's landmarks - the Capitol, the White House, the Lincoln Memorial and others - were brilliantly etched against the night sky.

title: Anti-Falwell Protesters Are Ejected From Hall
description: About 50 demonstrators who were booing the Rev. Jerry Falwell, president of the Moral Majority, were ejected by security guards from Town Hall last night where Mr. Falwell appeared on stage in a public discussion with a New York rabbi.

title: DATA ACCESS SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Including a tax credit $1,670,000. c-Net loss. Share earnings were not reported because of changes in the company's organization, including a new capital structure, when it emerged from Chapter 11 proceedings in November 1984.

title: Moore Is Disqualified PARIS, Dec. 10 (AP) - Louis Acaries of France beat Davey Moore
description: tonight on a controversial disqualification after the ninth round of their

title: COSMOS HIRE KLIVECKA AS INDOOR COACH
description: The Cosmos today named Ray Klivecka, an assistant coach with the team during its peak years in 1978 and 1979, as the head coach for the remainder of the indoor season.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results for the latest quarter include a gain from the sale of an idle facility in Prosperity, N. C., and a charge from the writedown of certain machinery and equipment in the non- fabricated segment of the company, the net effect of which was to increase net income by 2 cents a share.

title: Bridge: Relocation of Title Match: Speculation About Reason
description: The announcement Friday by the World Bridge Federation that the 1985 world team championships would be staged in Sao Paulo, Brazil, instead of New Delhi has given rise to speculation about the underlying reasons for the change.

title: Slalom Victory Lifts Zurbriggen
description: The defending World Cup champion, Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland, moved to the top of this season's overall standing today with the first slalom victory he had ever scored on the circuit.
