description: Association is offering $250 million of floating-rate notes due

title: Mapco Will Sell Some Assets
description: Mapco Inc. said today that it was selling most of the assets of its Mapco Oil and Gas Company subsidiary for about $290 million.

title: FIRST DEFENDANT TO TESTIFY
description: George Crile, the first of the defendants to take the stand in Gen. William C. Westmoreland's $120 million libel suit against CBS, is a 39-year-old film producer with a taste for politically controversial journalism.

title: TIED-UP SEAWAY SHIPPING BEGINS TO MOVE AGAIN
description: A three-week- old traffic jam of more than 160 cargo ships, stalled by a broken bridge that blocked the St. Lawrence Seaway, began to break up today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.25-11.50 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 2 Coaches Suspended
description: Two Clemson track coaches, Stan Narewski for men and Sam Colson for women, have been suspended by the school without pay while South Carolina law-enforcement officials investigate the possibility that someone unauthorized to do so has been giving prescription drugs to student athletes. The inquiry was prompted by an autopsy on Augustinius Jaspers , a 23-year-old cross-country runner from the Netherlands who had competed for Clemson and the Dutch Olympic team.

title: Policeman's Death Costs Family Pension
description: A 43- year-old city police officer died today of leukemia, 14 days too soon for his wife and two children to receive his pension.

title: METS GET EXPO'S CARTER FOR BROOKS AND 3 OTHERS
description: In one of the blockbuster trades of recent years, the Mets sent four players last night to the Montreal Expos for Gary Carter, the all-star, $1.8 million-a-year catcher and one of the top power hitters in baseball.

title: Mellon's New Heritage Offer PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10 (AP)
description: Mellon Bank N.A., barred by

title: Good Taco Closes
description: The Good Taco Corporation said its board had voted to suspend operations at all of its restaurants and to lay off all of its staff immediately. The company said the suspension is intended to preserve working capital and to provide time for management to re-evaluate long- range plans and to explore alternatives. Good Taco said that it had significantly increased its number of restaurants lately and that while some of them had had encouraging sales, over all they had failed to maintain adequate levels of volume.

title: NEW CHIEF LOOKS AHEAD
description: P. Michael Timpane, a former director of the National Institute of Education, was inaugurated Friday as the eighth president of the Teachers College of Columbia University. In an interview, the 50-year old educator, who had been dean of the college since 1981, discussed his views on the state of teaching and teacher education. Following are excerpts from the interview.

title: A New Raid by Iraqis Is Reported in the Gulf
description: Iraq said its planes successfully attacked a ''large naval target'' in the Persian Gulf today.

title: LEE PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includng a tax credit of $200,000. c-Net loss.

title: Virgin Islands Disaster Area
description: President Reagan issued a major disaster declaration today for the Virgin Islands as a result of the tropical storm Klaus and flooding that caused extensive property damage last month. The action permits use of Federal funds in relief and recovery efforts in areas to be designated.

title: The Message From Iran
description: Secretary of State Shultz was surely not including Iran among the law-abiding nations he summoned last Sunday to help put an end to terrorism. Iran has usually appeared high on Washington's list of nations thought to be supporting terror. Yet Iran has now spoken the right words and, however tardily, apparently done some right things in storming a hijacked Kuwaiti airliner in Teheran.

title: SUBURBAN STORES STRUGGLE TO FIND HOLIDAY WORKERS
description: Jobs in many suburban stores are going unfilled during the holiday shopping rush, forcing employers to find new ways to attract part-time and seasonal help.

title: DON'T RESIST ROBBERY, CHICAGO STUDY WARNS
description: Resisting an armed robber drastically increases the risk of death to the victim, according to results from a new study done at the University of Chicago.

title: Transactions
description: Placed Michael Young, guard-forward, on waivers. COLLEGES EAST CAROLINA - Dismissed Ed Emory, football coach.

title: Canada Dance Festival
description: Five Canadian dance companies have been selected for the Metropolitan Life Foundation Dance Canada Festival at Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College in 1985-86. The companies range from classical ballet to experimentalist dance. They include the Toronto Dance Theater, directed by Kenny Pearl, which will perform at the Brooklyn theater from April 18 to 21; Theater Ballet of Canada, directed by Lawrence Gradus, and the Anna Wyman Dance Theater, which will make their New York debuts in October; Robert Desrosiers's Desrosiers Dance Theater, to perform in November, and Les Ballets Jazz de Montreal, under the direction of Genevieve Salbaing, which will be seen in January 1986.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: LAW AND LETTERS IN AMERICAN

title: NORTH HILLS ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MARKETING HALLEY'S COMET
description: OWEN RYAN is not your run -of- the-mill ad man and that's apparent even before he starts to talk about the progress of General Comet Industries, which he started to prepare the world of commerce for the coming of Halley's comet.

title: SANDINISTA CLERIC DEFENDS HIS STAND
description: The Rev. Fernando Cardenal, the Nicaraguan priest expelled by the Jesuit order, said today that as ''an objection of conscience,'' he could not comply with demands from Rome that he resign as Minister of Education.

title: SCHOOL COMPUTERS: VISION AND REALITY
description: ''When you are dealing with computers in the schools,'' said Al Suttles, a high school English teacher, ''you've got to be both a dreamer and a hard-nosed realist.''

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: GRENADA GIVES THANKS
description: In the last few days, since the avalanche election victory of a new, moderate Parliament and a Prime Minister committed to peace and stability, Grenadians have been in an especially cheerful and festive mood.

title: Allis, Massey Holding Talks
description: The Allis- Chalmers Corporation, the troubled Milwaukee-based farm equipment company, has been negotiating with Massey-Ferguson Ltd. about some ''supply-type'' or other arrangement, company officials said today.

title: BISHOP TUTU GIVEN NOBEL PRIZE IN OSLO CEREMONY
description: Bishop Desmond Tutu, a leading opponent of apartheid in South Africa, accepted the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize today after a bomb scare interrupted the ceremony for an hour and 20 minutes.

title: ARES-SERONO INTERNATIONAL HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HYDROELECTRIC DAMS GENERATE DEBATE
description: When city engineers here devised a plan four years ago to divert water from the Savannah River through a small, city-run hydroelectric plant, local officials expected compliments, not controversy.

title: EX-HOSTAGES ON KUWAIT JET TELL OF 6 DAYS OF 'SHEER HELL'
description: Hostages freed Sunday from the Kuwaiti airliner that was hijacked to Teheran said today they had gone through six days of ''sheer hell'' in which their four Arab captors shot two Americans, beat and tortured the captives with lighted cigarette butts and, in a hoax, poured ketchup on two Kuwaitis to make it appear they had been killed.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: ONLY NATURAL The American Museum of Natural History, at Central Park West and 79th Street (873-1300), is an unparalleled repository that tells of nature and man's place in it. Much of its store is always there, but some exhibitions come and go, and three now there should be visited before they leave.

title: DONORS TO NEEDIEST EXPRESS CONCERN FOR LESS FORTUNATE
description: A refrain running through many of the letters and notes sent with donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund expresses the contributors' concern for ''the less fortunate'' of their neighbors and fellow citizens.

title: TOO MANY WHAT IFS
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: SCIENCE DEPARTMENT IN CABINET IS URGED
description: The status of the President's science advisory office is in a state of flux that may leave it greatly strengthened or perhaps weak ened. The most dramatic proposal is to create a Cabinet-level Department of Science and Technology that would take over much research now being administered by other departments.

title: 'HAPPY HOUR' BAN STARTS IN MASSACHUSETTS BARS
description: A regulation banning ''happy hours'' at bars and restaurants went into effect throughout Massachusetts today amid hopes that the elimination of promotions that offer special low-priced alcoholic drinks would reduce the incidence of drunken driving.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in SportsMonday yesterday about the New York Giants' loss to the St. Louis Cardinals misstated the length of Ali-Haji Sheikh's field- goal attempt in the third quarter.

title: Raising Voices Against Apartheid
description: President Reagan may finally have recognized that quiet diplomacy is not the most effective way to persuade South Africa to abandon the contemptible system of apartheid. His proclamation for International Human Rights Day declares that Americans ''strongly object to and seek to end such affronts to the human conscience as . . . the manifest injustices of the apartheid system.''

title: 3 Companies Fined For Price Fixing
description: A Federal judge fined three paving- materials companies and their presidents a total of $550,000 today for bid rigging and price fixing in the sale of asphalt supplies to New Jersey communities.

title: DOCTORS OFFERED AID IN HANDLING DRUG PROBLEMS
description: Doctors in New York State with drug or alcohol-abuse problems will face disciplinary action unless they agree to undergo treatment, under a program announced yesterday by the Department of Health and the state medical society.

description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL IN BEIRUT FOR TALKS ON ISRAELI EXIT
description: Assistant Secretary of State Richard W. Murphy, met here today with Lebanese officials to discuss the talks on ending the Israeli occupation of southern Lebanon.

title: Standard's Bid for ICL
description: Standard Telephone and Cables P.L.C. said today that it had increased its stake in ICL, the British computer group, to 97.6 percent under its acquisition offer. Standard Telephone said it would force holders of the remaining shares to sell them under provisions of the 1948 Companies Act.

title: A FLOPPY LITTLE CHRISTMAS
description: THE first floppy disk Christmas card of the season - or ever, as far as we can recall - arrived at the office recently, bringing with it a glimpse of Christmases Future and, as a result, wistful longings for Christmases Past. Random House Software, the division of the publishing company that concentrates on computer programs instead of novels, mailed the disks to its dealers and friends.

title: Japan, E.E.C. In Video Pact TOKYO, Dec. 10 (AP) -
description: Japan and the European Economic Community agreed today on a sharp reduction in the

title: NAVY FINDS THAT ENGINES DON'T MATCH GEARS
description: The Navy has discovered that the engines and main gears for its first two modern minesweepers do not match.

title: Dr. Alfred Richman, 92, Dies; Founded Hospital in the City
description: Dr. Alfred A. Richman, an orthopedic surgeon and an honorary trustee of Beth Israel Hospital, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home on Bay Harbor Islands, Fla. He was 92 years old.

title: Another Suit Filed On Times Sq. Plan
description: The Brandt Organization, which operates seven movie theaters on 42d Street that often feature martial-arts and X-rated movies, has filed suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan asking that the nearly $2 billion Times Square redevelopment project be declared in violation of the organization's First Amendment rights.

title: ANALYSTS WARY OF SHIFT IN TAX INCENTIVE POLICY
description: When President Reagan took office, he championed an approach to tax policy that greatly expanded incentives for specific types of business investment. This program has been credited with helping spur a recent surge in capital investment.

title: CAN SUBMARINES STAY HIDDEN?
description: A RACE is on between those seeking to make the oceans transparent and those who want to keep them opaque.

title: SIGHT RESTORED FOR THOUSANDS YEARLY
description: THE cornea of the eye, one of the first human tissues to be transplanted successfully, is being used more widely today than ever before to restore sight to the blind.

title: REAGAN ATTACKS SOVIET AND SOUTH AFRICA ON RIGHTS
description: President Reagan said today that the Soviet Union was committing ''brutal affronts to the human conscience'' by suppressing freedom at home and waging a ''barbaric war'' in Afghanistan.

title: CUOMO REPORTEDLY PICKS UPSTATE DEMOCRAT TO LEAD PARTY
description: Governor Cuomo has selected Laurence J. Kirwan of Rochester to be the new Democratic state chairman, administration and party officials said yesterday.

title: Moleculon Wins
description: The Moleculon Research Corporation said it had won a decision in its case against CBS Inc.'s Ideal Toy division regarding Moleculon's assertion that one of its research scientists had invented Rubik's Cube. It said Judge Walter Stapleton of the Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del., issued his final order establishing that the puzzle cube was invented by Larry D. Nichols, a Moleculon scientist. It said CBS has 30 days in which to appeal the case.

title: ELECTRONIC MODULES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29

description: * Allegheny Power System Inc. has elected Thomas J. Kloc treasurer.

title: POSSIBLE PLANET FOUND BEYOND SOLAR SYSTEM
description: American astronomers have discovered what they believe is the first planet to be detected outside the solar system, it was announced yesterday.

title: BYRD-CHILES FIGHT IN SENATE WEIGHED
description: Supporters of Senator Lawton Chiles, who is challenging Senator Robert C. Byrd for the job of Senate minority leader, said today they believed Mr. Chiles could win in the vote scheduled for Wednesday.

title: BOMBARDIER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CALLS TO SPLIT UP H.R.A. OPPOSED BY ITS NEW CHIEF
description: The new Commissioner of the city's troubled Human Resources Administration said yesterday that dividing the agency into smaller, independent offices, as some city officials have recommended, would not solve its problems.

title: Yankees Seek 2d Pirate Deal
description: The Yankees and the Pittsburgh Pirates, intent on swapping Steve Kemp and Dale Berra, are working on a second, separate deal that would enable the Pirates to receive additional money from the Yankees, thus making the acquisition of Kemp's expensive contract more palatable.

title: HOMELAND BINGO IS SOUGHT BY TRIBE
description: It has been nearly a century since the Miami Indians fled their homeland in the Wabash country of Ohio. Now they want a small parcel of their aboriginal land there, so they can build a reservation, re-establish tradition and open a high-stakes bingo parlor.

title: FOR KELLER, JOAN OF ARC IS HER ROLE
description: Marthe Keller has played Shakespeare's Juliet and Goethe's Margaret in ''Faust'' and Pinter's faithless wife in ''Betrayal'' on European stages. On the screen she has portrayed everything from ''Sunshine Girls, healthy and romantic,'' as she calls them, to international terrorists who ''wear black and get killed in the end.'' Now the Swiss actress has embarked on something entirely new in her crowded career - the spoken role of Joan in the Swiss composer Arthur Honegger's oratorio-drama ''Joan of Arc at the Stake.''

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Interest Rates Drop Slightly
description: Short- and long-term interest rates declined slightly yesterday in quiet, lackluster trading.

description: Bernard King went back to work yesterday.

description: Governor Cuomo, in the nation's capital today to press his views on taxes and budget-cutting, said he told Senator Bob Dole, the new Senate majority leader, that part of the Treasury's plan for overhauling the tax system would be ''devastating'' to New York.

title: Rock Band Singer Arrested In Traffic Death of Drummer
description: The lead singer of the heavy- metal rock band Motley Crue is free on $2,500 bail after being arrested in connection with a traffic accident that killed the drummer for the punk band Hanoi Rocks.

title: Earle Bower Named Agency for Elkay
description: Earle Bower Associates has been named agency for Elkay Industries, an apparel manufacturer with plans for a multimillion-dollar advertising expenditure.

description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger today presented President Reagan and other Administration officials what was termed a ''firm defense'' of his 1986 budget request, which some Presidential advisers want trimmed by $8 billion.

title: WHAT WE CAN DO TO HALT FAMINES IN AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

description: It gets hard to believe some of the stuff you read in the papers.

title: ECONOMIC DRAG SEEN IN TAX PLAN
description: Some Reagan Administration economists and many of the nation's leading economic forecasters find that the Treasury's new tax plan would be more likely to retard the nation's economic growth than to accelerate it, at least during the rest of the 1980's.

description: IN a period of investor uncertainty over the outlook for stock prices, the retail and wholesale

title: Back on Sidelines
description: For the first time in 17 years, Fred Lewis is back pacing the basketball sidelines, shouting instructions to players and ''constructive criticism'' at referees. ''Some things never change,'' he said the other day. ''Officials are as bad as ever.''

title: AILEY TROUPE HONORING A DANCER'S PERFECT SCORE
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater usually dances as if it's celebrating something. And the company will be celebrating tonight at City Center, when it throws a birthday party for Dudley Williams in honor of his 20th year as an Ailey dancer.

title: LUCAS RETIRES, CITES PRESSURE
description: John Lucas, placed on leave of absence Sunday by the Houston Rockets because of renewed cocaine use, says he is retiring from professional basketball after eight and a half years because he cannot take the pressure anymore.

title: Texaco Sells Unit
description: Texaco Inc. said it had completed the previously announced sale of Skelgas Inc. to a unit of the Synergy Gas Corporation.

title: BANK BOARD EASES THRIFT UNIT PROPOSAL
description: Yielding to industry opposition, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board today weakened a proposed rule that would restrict expansion by state-chartered savings and loan associations into new lines of business.

title: STAGE: 'A PLAY OF GIANTS' BY SOYINKA
description: Political satire hardly exists in the American theater anymore, and when it does, it's so mild that audiences need never run for cover. That's why it's uncommonly bracing to encounter ''A Play of Giants,'' the lethal Wole Soyinka comedy now having its world premiere at the Yale Repertory Theater. Mr. Soyinka, the Nigerian playwright, poet, novelist and essayist, spares no one in this farcical fantasy about African dictators at loose in New York. The first, second and third worlds, eastern and western divisions, are all mowed down in the relentless comic barrage.

title: SCIENCE WATCH ; NEW EFFORTS EXPECTED TO PLACE CELLS IN BRAIN
description: SWEDISH researchers who in 1982 and 1983 sought to relieve two severe cases of Parkinson's disease by transplanting tissue from the patients' own adrenal glands into their brains expect to make two more attempts early in the coming year.

title: Reagan the Author
description: The Times of London has just

title: WELDOTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Kansas State Acts
description: Kansas State announced yesterday that Athletic Director Richard Towers would be dropped from his post as of June 30. The school's president, Duane Acker , said that Towers would be allowed to stay on in some other job if he chose, but the president would not point to a specific reason for Towers's being replaced.

title: Judges Refuse to Bar Murderer's Execution
description: Judges in two courts today rejected efforts to stop the execution of Alpha Otis Stephens. State officials set his electrocution for 12:15 A.M. Wednesday.

title: JEWS BACK BLACKS IN RACISM PROTEST
description: Three leaders of the American Jewish Congress were arrested at the South African Embassy here today as they engaged in a protest against racial segregation.

title: Grappling With Graffiti
description: Washington's sleek new subway system has prided itself on the absence of spray-can vandalism that has become so rampant in some cities that efforts to efface it have been futile. The capital's subway stations are quite unsullied, partly because their vaulted walls were designed to thwart graffiti addicts.

title: WHY THE WORLD CARES ABOUT WILLIAM SCHROEDER
description: William J. Schroeder is a unique man. No other human lives with an artificial heart, although if future experiments go well there may be many others in decades to come.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST TUESDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1984
description: The Economy

title: LAWYERS VOLUNTEER TO HELP ARTISTS
description: What can a sculptor do if one of his regular customers starts to reproduce his work and sell it?

title: DRESS BARN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
'CAMILLE': A NEW VERSION OF THE DUMAS STORY
description: THERE once was a young aristocrat who fell in love with a young courtesan. When the affair became serious, the young man's father convinced the woman that she should leave the youth for the sake of honor and the family title. The crushed young man, not knowing about his father's intervention, swore revenge on his lover. She eventually died of consumption and, it was rumored, a broken heart.

title: 2 Key Giants May Miss Finale
description: The Giants, hoping to qualify for the playoffs Saturday in their final game of the regular season, will almost surely have to do it without Mark Haynes and Billy Ard, two key starters.

title: David Dietz, Pulitzer Winner; Longtime Writer on Science
description: David Dietz, who won a Pulitzer Prize for reporting in 1937 and was a longtime science writer for the Scripps-Howard Newspapers, died Sunday at the age of 87. He had suffered from Parkinson's disease.

title: Jailed Minister Vows To Press Jobless Fight
description: Saying he must ''obey God rather than man,'' a jailed Lutheran minister, the Rev. D. Douglas Roth, vowed today to continue fighting for unemployed steelworkers and to defend his mill town church, with violence if necessary.

title: Kaiser Plans Sale
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it had agreed to sell most of its refractory- manufacturing assets in Australia to Morganite Australia Pty. Ltd., a subsidiary of the Morgan Crucible Company of London.

title: SLAYING OVER CAR ACCIDENT BEWILDERS NEIGHBORS
description: Relatives and neighbors of Sharon Walker clustered in front of her aging row house in Jamaica, Queens, yesterday, their tears dried and their anger rising, trying to understand why the young mother of three was shot to death over a minor traffic accident.

title: New Caledonia Farmer Surrenders to Police
description: A farmer of mixed race wanted in connection with the killing of 10 Melanesians gave himself up today after four days in the bush.

title: BRIEFS ;  Debt
description: * CBI Industries filed an offering of $100 million in notes due in 1996, through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers.

title: ANDY URAM
description: Andy Uram, an all-America fullback at the University of Minnesota who went on to play for the Green Bay Packers, died at a nursing home here Sunday at age 69.

title: NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
JUSTICES TO RULE ON CIVIL WAR LAW TO AID VETERAN
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a 120-year-old Federal law enacted to protect Civil War veterans from unscrupulous lawyers is depriving modern-day veterans of their constitutional rights.

title: Fighting Horse
description: Any horse owned by a chap named John Sullivan has a right to be pugnacious, and so maybe there should have been little cause for surprise at what happened Sunday in the third race at Aqueduct.

title: INDIAN JOURNALIST OFFERED WARNING
description: Before the gas leak at the Union Carbide insecticide plant here last week, an Indian journalist had asserted in several articles over the last two years that safety standards at the plant were inadequate and that a catastrophic leak could result.

title: Secretary of Senate Named
description: Jo- Anne L. Coe was named today to be the incoming secretary of the Senate, the first woman to hold the job. Mrs. Coe, 51 years old, is a longtime aide to Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, the incoming majority leader, who named her to the new post as the Senate's chief administrative officer.

title: PHILLIPS BID IS DELAYED BY PICKENS
description: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman attempting to take over the Phillips Petroleum Company, announced yesterday that he was delaying the official start of a $1.38 billion offer to buy nearly 15 percent of the Oklahoma- based oil company because of legal uncertainties. The offer had been scheduled to begin yesterday.

title: Canada-U.S. Trade Tie
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada declared last night that ''Canada is open for business again'' and called for closer ties and more trade with the United States.

title: Cease-Fire Eludes Nicaragua In Talks With Indian Leader
description: Nicaragua's Deputy Interior Minister said today that weekend talks with a Miskito Indian leader had failed to win a cease-fire but that the two sides would meet again in Bogota on Jan. 19 and 20.

title: OVERSTATED THREAT OF PRIVATE AIRCRAFT
description: To the Editor:

title: ADS BY GRACE BACK CUTS IN U.S. BUDGET
description: W. R. Grace & Company is paying for $2.6 million in television advertising that shows a crying baby in an effort to rally public support for the boss's ideas to trim Federal spending.

title: CUBIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
People
description: * Gordon Fenton and Forrest Long, senior vice presidents at Ted Bates Advertising, have been appointed executive creative officers.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: CALVIN KLEIN presented his first shoe collection last week and did what clothing designers seldom do: create a decent shoe. His are more than decent; they're a subtle application of men's shoe styles to the female foot.

title: GERMAN GREEN PARTY: A FORK IN THE NATURE PATH
description: Buoyed by a string of electoral triumphs, the five-year-old Green Party gathered here this weekend with the proclaimed goal of resolving one of the central questions of West Germany's unsettled politics: whether or not to forge regional coalitions with the Social Democrats.

title: WEAK SALES IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: In the fashionable Union Square area, this city's premier shopping section, five flagship stores of the nation's largest retail chains are elbowing one another in an effort to keep from losing position in what is normally the year's biggest and most profitable season.

title: Protesters at Yale Withhold Tuition
description: One hundred and fifteen Yale students are withholding their spring tuition and fees to protest Yale University's ''failure to sign a contract'' with clerical and technical workers who recently returned to work after a strike, according to a spokesman for the group. The payments were due Nov. 30.

title: OPERA: 'COSI FAN TUTTE'
description: ''COSI FAN TUTTE'' is an opera that has always tempted directors to tinker with it. For some reason, it is often assumed that its dramatic situation will not be grasped by modern audiences unless it is lifted out of its 18th-century milieu and dragged by the nape of the neck into our time. But, as is demonstrated in any reasonably faithful staging and well- sung performance, this of all Mozart operas needs no updating or other directorial cleverness. It speaks to us today, wittily and wisely, in exactly the way it must have spoken to the audiences of Mozart and his librettist, Lorenzo da Ponte. It is not a foolproof work, because it demands ensemble acting and singing of a high polish, but the only help it needs is plenty of talent onstage and backstage.

title: E-H INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: DANCE: BALLETAP USA
description: BALLETAP USA, a new company directed by Maurice Hines and Mercedes Ellington, made its New York debut Saturday night with Carmen de Lavallade as guest artist at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts.

title: INDIANS WORRY OVER POISON CHEMICAL STILL IN PLANT
description: Officials in this central Indian city expressed mounting concern today over how to deal with 30 metric tons of poisonous chemical stored at the American- owned insecticide plant, the site of the disastrous gas leak last week.

title: 1982 REPORT CITED SAFETY PROBLEMS AT PLANT IN INDIA
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said today that a 1982 inspection of its pesticide plant in Bhopal, India, revealed serious equipment and safety problems but that its Indian subsidiary had rectified most of the problems by June.

title: Where to Complain About Bad Gasoline
description: Motorists who pay for unleaded or high-octane gasoline cannot tell at the pump whether the fuel is in fact unleaded or high-octane, but officials of several agencies will investigate the complaints of customers who say their cars' performance has suffered.

title: CHINA CORRECTS A SLIP IN IDEOLOGY
description: Senior Chinese officials today criticized a recent newspaper editorial that suggested that rigid adherence to Marxism could not solve China's problems.

title: Fruit Concern Suing Florida On Loss in Canker Campaign
description: A Lake County fruit company is suing the state's Department of Agriculture over what it contends were negligent actions that led to the department's burning of 10,700 citrus trees owned by the company and believed to be infested with citrus canker.

title: DREXEL GETS AWARD IN MERRILL DISPUTE
description: A New York Stock Exchange arbitration panel has ordered Merrill Lynch, Pierce Fenner & Smith Inc. to pay $600,000 in damages to Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in a dispute over the hiring of stockbrokers, Drexel announced yesterday.

title: IN THIS STREET CRIME CASE, FEW STONES GO UNTURNED
description: The police are used to investigating ''street crime,'' but the term took on a new meaning when they arrested two men for stealing a 100-year- old street.

title: Amling in Hospital
description: Warren Amling, a two-time all-America lineman at Ohio State who was inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame last week, was admitted to a hospital here today after suffering a heart attack. The 59-year-old Amling was listed in critical but stable condition.

title: Rexnord Offer
description: Rexnord Inc. said it had reached an agreement to acquire the Electronic Modules Corporation and would begin a tender offer for 2.5 million, or 48 percent, of Electronic Modules' shares outstanding at $18.50 each.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Saturday about Alfred B. DelBello's resignation as Lieutenant Governor of New York misstated the circumstances under which Nelson A. Rockefeller left office as Governor. He resigned in 1973 to pursue what he called a new national role. He became Vice President in December 1974.

60 Planes Grounded by Navy And Marine Corps Over Flaws
description: The Navy and the Marine Corps have grounded about 60 A-6 and A-4 bombers and AE-6 electronic-jamming planes because of cracked rivets found in an engine of one A-6, Navy officers said today.

title: LANGLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
POP MUSIC: DONOVAN
description: PROBABLY more than any other pop music figure, the English folk-rock singer and songwriter Donovan symbolizes the headiest lotus blossom atmosphere of the late 1960's hippie culture. And on Saturday night, the former apostle of peace, love and flower power made his first Carnegie Hall appearance in more than a decade before an audience made up largely of grown-up hippies.

title: WRITING THE BOOK ON BOOKSHOPS
description: Ask this city's old-timers to name their most beloved institutions and the Francis Scott Key Book Shop surely would make the list.

title: AT WESTMORELAND TRIAL, PRODUCER TELLS OF RATIONALE ON INTERVIEWS
description: A. FARBER

title: Prudential Issue Is Eurobond Record
description: A subsidiary of the Prudential Insurance Company of America is issuing $1.3 billion of securities in the largest fixed-rate debt financing ever made in the Eurobond market.

title: GENERAL AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Net income including extraordinary income of $130,000.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Dec. 11, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: IRVINE SENSORS CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $92,700 on the settlement of trade accounts payable. c-Including a gain of $133,200 on the settlement of trade accounts payable.

title: LIES NOT PROTECTED BY FIRST AMENDMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: FROM SEPARATES TO BALL GOWNS, A CHOICE FOR FESTIVE EVENINGS
description: It's party time from now through New Year's Day. Even the most organized woman can suddenly discover she doesn't have a thing to wear as she accepts still another invitation where she may see the same group of people. Or suddenly, after several evenings out, a pressing need for something new suddenly arises.

title: MAN DIES IN PLUNGE FROM 31ST FLOOR
description: A 30-year-old salesman for a brokerage concern jumped to his death yesterday afternoon from the 31st-floor office where he worked at 1 Rockefeller Plaza, the police reported.

title: ADVISORY COUNCIL MAY END
description: The White House said today that President Reagan was considering abolishing the Council of Economic Advisers, the small but influential staff of economists that has drifted to the sidelines of policy making with the departure of its last chairman, Martin S. Feldstein, five months ago.

title: U.S. Near Steel Pacts
description: The United States is close to concluding pacts with South Africa and Australia to limit steel shipments from those nations to the United States, Administration sources said today.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Philadelphia 76ers , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. Just what the Knicks needed: a second game in 48 hours against the 76ers, who beat them by 16 points Sunday night at the Spectrum. (Television - MSG Network, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WPAT, 930; WFAS, 1230; WGBB, 1240; all at 7:30 P.M.) Nets vs. Boston Celtics , at Hartford. The Nets have only eight healthy players with whom to meet the defending champions. (Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:30 P.M.)

title: MUSIC: RARE SILK, VOCALISTS
description: WHEN Rare Silk made its New York debut almost five years ago at Carnegie Hall with Benny Goodman's septet, it was a female trio and it specialized in tight, precisely harmonized versions of Swing Era hits that drew on the vocal styles of the Boswell Sisters and of Lambert, Hendricks and Ross.

title: SCIENCE AND TV'S FORGOTTEN CHILD
description: IN this age of science and technology, most American children show little interest in

title: LA GUARDIA AS A ONE-MAN SHOW
description: ''Hizzoner!'' is a one-character show about the life and times of Fiorello H. La Guardia. Tony Lo Bianco impersonates him, so to speak, telling anecdotes, reflecting on life and speaking to unseen newspaper reporters. Mr. Lo Bianco, never dull, emphasizes the comic, the energetic and the ebullient; his La Guardia is a folksy, populist crusader. The one-hour program will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 tonight.

title: Judge Prepares Ban On Boston Sewer Links
description: Superior Court Judge Paul G. Garrity said today he has prepared an order banning metropolitan area sewer hookups for proposed buildings. He said he would not impose it, however, while the legislature is considering whether to create an agency to deal with pollution in Boston Harbor.

title: SHULTZ-WEINBERGER DISCORD SEEN IN NEARLY ALL FOREIGN POLICY ISSUES
description: As President Reagan prepares for a second term, his two top foreign policy advisers, Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, are reported at odds on virtually all foreign policy issues, often to the frustration and concern of the White House.

title: A Genetics Project
description: In a new program, ''Family Tree

title: QUESTIONING WAS STOPPED IN WEST SIDE MURDER CASE
description: Detectives had to stop questioning the man who is accused of stabbing a 23-year-old drama student to death, after they discovered that there was an unresolved charge against him in an unrelated criminal case, a police official said yesterday.

title: 12 RELEASED BY SOUTH AFRICA, THEN 6 OF THEM ARE ARRESTED
description: Under pressure at home and abroad, South Africa lifted detention orders against 12 activist opponents of apartheid today but immediately charged 6 of them with treason and violating security laws.

title: Edelman Acquires 8% of Datapoint
description: A group of investors led by Asher Edelman, a New York investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had purchased 1,599,500 common shares, or 8 percent, of the Datapoint Corporation. Mr. Edelman said in the filing that he ''intends to seek to maximize the value of the company to all shareholders by seeking to influence management policies or by obtaining control of the company.'' He said he reserved the right to seek board representation by proxy contest or to influence management through a tender offer.

title: MARGARET J. HITTLE
description: Margaret J. Hittle, a former teacher who was active in Michigan educational affairs, died Friday in a retirement home in East Lansing, Mich. She was 97 years old.

title: Hawks Defeat Pacers, 104-98
description: Dominique Wilkins scored 27 points and Mike Glenn, a reserve, got 12 of his season-high 17 in the second half as the Atlanta Hawks turned back a late rally tonight and defeated the Indiana Pacers, 104-98.

title: AIRLIFT TO ISRAEL IS REPORTED TAKING THOUSANDS OF JEWS FROM ETHIOPIA
description: Many thousands of Ethiopian Jews have been taken to Israel in recent months as a result of the famine in Ethiopia, diplomatic, Government and Jewish organization sources said today.

title: NEWPORT PHARMACEUTICALS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: OFFERS CALLED INADEQUATE
description: The board of the Des Moines Register and Tribune Company voted today to seek offers from ''high-quality newspaper companies'' to buy the company, according to David Kruidenier, its chairman. He cited pressure from family stockholders as the major reason for the decision.

title: CARBIDE HAS HAD RECENT BUSINESS SETBACKS
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, which is reeling from the accident at its plant in Bhopal, India, has been struggling for some time to overcome declines in some of its key businesses.

title: NOMINEES FOR BOOK CRITICS AWARD
description: Three first novels, including one by an author in her 70's, and a first collection of stories by a 23-year-old graduate of Yale, were among the five books nominated yesterday as the best works of fiction in 1984 by the National Book Critics Circle. The books were selected by the 24 board members of the 10-year-old organization comprised of 380 book reviewers and critics.

title: NEW YORK STATE ACTS TO COUNTER EVASION OF TAX ON GASOLINE
description: Unscrupulous gasoline distributors are cheating New York State out of tens of millions of dollars in tax revenues each year and gaining unfair advantage over their honest competitors by ''bootlegging'' gasoline, state officials said yesterday.

title: U.S. EXPECTS IRAN TO RELEASE 2 HIJACKING SURVIVORS TODAY
description: The United States said today that it expected Iran to release on Tuesday the two Americans who were freed from the hijacked airliner at Teheran airport and to prosecute the captured hijackers promptly.

title: Harlem Dance Troupe Wins Olivier Award
description: The 1984 Laurence Olivier Award for the outstanding new dance production of the year in London was presented to the Dance Theater of Harlem last night at a ceremony at the Theater Royal.

title: LATE RALLY SENDS DOW UP BY 9.05
description: Stock prices yesterday made their biggest advance since the day after Thanksgiving, when they moved up on a cut in the discount rate.

title: Poppe Tyson Gets Port Authority Account
description: Poppe Tyson, an industrial advertising agency that is a division of D'Arcy MacManus Masius, has become agency for the Economic Development Department of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: RICHTON INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $86,000 from discontinued operations. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $2,693,000. d-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,325,000.

title: Korean Car Exports Up
description: South Korea's exports of cars and trucks climbed 47.6 percent in October from a year earlier, the Korea Auto Industries Cooperative said today. The 4,850 vehicles were worth $18 million, it said. For the first 10 months of the year, exports more than doubled from the year before.

title: DWI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
TOM WOLFE ON SHIFTING TASTES IN ART
description: YOUNG, upwardly mobile professionals are the new buyers of art these days, and they jammed the Asia Society auditorium the other night to hear Tom Wolfe, writer, critic and intellectual scamp, add another lush chapter to his ongoing history of artistic taste.

title: A PRIMER ON N.F.C. PLAYOFF POSSIBILITIES
description: The National Conference playoff picture is such a crazy-quilt of possibilities that the Giants can lose to the New Orleans Saints Saturday and get in, and they can defeat the Saints and be eliminated.

title: GLOSSER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
CURB ON 'ABUSIVE' TAX SHELTER
description: The Internal Revenue Service will begin freezing tax refunds of those taxpayers whose claims are based on an investment in a suspected ''abusive'' tax shelter, Roscoe Egger Jr., commissioner of the I.R.S., said today.

title: HOUSE UNIT'S CHIEF IS SEEN AS SECURE
description: Representative Melvin Price, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee for 10 years, has come under fire as being too infirm to continue in the post, some committee members said today. But the man who is first in line to succeed him said he expected Mr. Price to stay on for another two years.

title: BERTRAM SCHWARTZ
description: Bertram Schwartz, executive vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company, died of leukemia Saturday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: INSURANCE PARLEY GETS SMOKER PLAN
description: People who smoke, have high blood pressure or are overweight would pay more for health insurance under a recommendation being debated this week by state insurance regulators.

title: YOUNGER BROTHER FINDS HIS NICHE
description: There was once a time, Derrick

title: ARMOUR-DIAL HAS PAID $4 MILLION IN BACK WAGES, UNION SAYS
description: A private arbitrator's ruling that Armour-Dial Inc. had illegally reduced the pay and benefits of 800 workers at two plants has resulted in the company's paying more than $4.1 million in back wages, the employees' labor union said today.

title: SCHIZOPHRENIA: EARLY SIGNS FOUND
description: THROUGH a major new approach to fighting the disorder, an international research group has begun to identify signs in children that may predict which of them will eventually fall victim to schizophrenia, the most severe form of mental illness.

title: OWNER OF 'GENIUS' SPERM BANK PLEASED BY RESULTS
description: Robert Graham still gets some negative reaction to his sperm bank, but his list of genius donors is slowly growing and 15 children have been born to women chosen as recipients.

title: ATECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
More Speculation On Ray Knight
description: In retrospect, it certainly appears that they were setting the stage for yesterday's big trade that brought Gary Carter to New York. But even before then, the Mets had insisted that they were not giving up on Ray Knight's throwing arm when they dealt a starting pitcher to the Detroit Tigers last week for yet another third baseman, one of many in their 22- year history.

title: Group Buys 7.4% Of Pioneer Corp.
description: An investment group led by Irwin L. Jacobs of Minneapolis told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had acquired 7.4 percent of the common shares of the Pioneer Corporation. The group said it had bought the stock to ''obtain an equity position'' in Pioneer, but ''might under certain circumstances consider seeking control.''

title: SALVADOR REBELS SAID TO KILL 9
description: Military authorities said today that Salvadoran guerrillas had ambushed Government forces north of the capital, killing 9 soldiers and wounding 6, and that in a separate battle the army had killed 13 rebels.

title: Frederick Daniels, 86, Ex-Social Service Chief
description: Frederick Daniels, a former director of the Brooklyn Bureau of Social Service and the Children's Aid Society, died of cancer Nov. 28 at the Doylestown (Pa.) Memorial Hospital.

title: Commuter Airlines Held Safe
description: The administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration said today that commuter airlines remain ''a safe segment of the transportation system'' despite the recent discovery of widespread safety violations at two airlines and the crash last week of a commuter plane in Florida.

title: Greece Rejects Protest By American Embassy
description: The Greek Socialist Government tonight rejected an American protest over a Greek Communist Party charge that the United States was involved in recent bomb attacks in Athens. The Government said the American protest was ''unjustified and unacceptable.''

title: 8 ROOKIES TO START IN JETS' FINAL GAME
description: They say the handwriting on the wall isn't for them. They don't hear a bell tolling, the veteran Jets insist.

title: AVERY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Net loss.

title: JANITOR IS HELD
description: The body of a 12-year-old girl was found Sunday in a clump of shrubs near a heavily traveled highway here, and hours later a 29-year-old janitor was arrested and charged with her murder, the Suffolk County police said.

title: INSURING SURVIVAL OF NICARAGUA'S INDIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: Party at St. John the Divine
description: Almost exactly a year ago - six days before Christmas - she returned to her Long Island home to find that marshals had thrown her property into the street. Now she lives with her disabled husband and their 3-year-old son in one room at a boarding house in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Article 141826 -- No Title
description: In 12 days President Reagan's inaugural committee has raised the $9 million in private money needed to finance the four-day gala, Michael K. Deaver, chairman of the committee, said today. The actual cost may be double that, but tickets and television rights take care of much of the cost.

title: Center of Speculation
description: Speculation on the future of Frank Kush , head coach of the Indianapolis Colts, continues unabated, spurred by the recent merger that produced the Arizona Outlaws from the United States Football League's old Arizona and Oklahoma franchises. The latest flurry of talk resulted from an article in The Arizona Republic over the weekend that said Kush, who has two option years remaining on his contract with the Colts, had agreed in principle to a five-year, multimillion- dollar deal to begin coaching the Outlaws next spring.

title: TIME EMPLOYEE TELLS HOW HE WROTE SHARON ARTICLE
description: A writer for Time magazine told a jury yesterday how he wrote the article that led Ariel Sharon to sue the magazine for $50 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1984 International A U.S.-Cuban accord has been reached in principle on the terms for repatriation to Cuba of about 2,500 criminals and mental patients, Reagan Administration officials said. In return, they said, Washington will resume the processing of regular emigration from Cuba to the United States. (Page A1, Column 6.) A 1982 inspection of the Indian plant of the Union Carbide Corporation revealed serious safety and equipment problems, but its Indian subsidiary rectified most of the problems by last June, according to the company. Among the problems remaining in June, the company said, was a question of the adequacy of a relief valve on a methyl isocyanate storage tank to relieve ''a runaway reaction.'' The highly toxic gas was released from the Bhopal plant last week, killing more than 2,000 people. (A1:3.)

title: Fingerprints and Child Safety
description: A child molester can be a parent, a neighbor or the stranger in the corner store. So it's not surprising that a molester may show up on the staff of a New York City day-care center.

title: DAYCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $335,000 for the quarter and year from the early retirement of debt.

title: Trilogy Gets New Chief As Founder Steps Aside
description: Trilogy Ltd. yesterday elevated its new president, Henry C. Montgomery, to the additional position of chief executive. The action means that Gene M. Amdahl, who had been Trilogy's chief executive as well as chairman, will remove himself from the daily responsibilities of the company.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on Saturday with the New York Day by Day column misidentified a professor at Teachers College of Columbia University. He is A. Harry Passow. B6

title: OIL COMPANIES LOSE BID TO BAR RELEASE OF DATA
description: The Supreme Court cleared the way today for the release on Friday of sealed court documents filed by major oil companies charged with illegal price-fixing.

title: Renewal in the Library
description: Serge Gleboff was the first student to step into the peach, pink and mauve interior of the renovated Rare Book and Manuscript Library at Columbia University when it reopened yesterday on the top two floors of Butler Library.

title: PUNITIVE COSTS: INSURANCE ISSUE
description: UNION CARBIDE, the owner of the plant in Bhopal, India, whose gas leak last week killed 2,000 or more people and injured thousands of others, has said that it has adequate insurance to compensate all the victims. But the company still faces a serious financial threat - huge punitive damage awards.

title: WEBCOR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: MUSIC: PIANO CONCERTO
description: THE highlight of the Queens College Orchestral Society's Saturday evening concert at Alice Tully Hall was the New York premiere of Karol Rathaus's Piano Concerto (Op. 45).

title: THE REAL CONTRIBUTION OF NEO-CONSERVATIVES
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Promoted by Higbee To Office of President
description: The Higbee Company has created a four-man Office of the President, following the resignation of the company's president and chief merchandising officer.

title: CANADIANS BREAK FROM AUTO UNION
description: Leaders of the United Automobile Workers union agreed tonight to split the union into separate Canadian and American organizations as a result of disputes over differences in bargaining in the two countries.

title: FINDING A GOOD BOOK IN A SEA OF MEDIOCRITY
description: FAR too many mediocre books about computers are hogging space on bookstore shelves this season, for publishers are still jumping on the silicon bandwagon.

title: HEINZ, H.J. CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
New Barriers for Pentagon
description: New barriers are being installed outside the Pentagon to stop unauthorized vehicles from approaching the main entrances. The manned crossing gates going up at the building are part of a series of new security measures taken at the White House and elsewhere in Washington after a bombing at the Capitol a year ago. Once the new gates are in, only authorized vehicles will be permitted to approach, the officials said.

title: Hawkeye Deal Off
description: The Hawkeye Bancorporation said a proposed merger with United Central Bancshares Inc. had been terminated by mutual consent.

title: CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a gain of $708,000 from insurance proceeds.

title: PEKING'S GOOD NEWS
description: WEST BERLIN China's official attack on Marxist orthodoxy as outdated and a hindrance to needed reform was such a surprise to Soviet-bloc Communists that it left them speechless. It is a historic watershed that can have far- reaching, dramatic consequences.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Bootleggers don't have the highest ethical standards, and they're not beyond putting leaded fuel in unleaded storage tanks or putting regular unleaded in super unleaded tanks.'' - Karl E. Felsen of the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance. (B9:1.)

title: Thanks From a Vermonter
description: Madeleine M. Kunin, the Democratic Governor-elect of Vermont, went to speak at the annual dinner of the American Jewish Committee at the Pierre.

title: OKLAHOMA WINS AS TISDALE GETS 55
description: Kevin McHale's tip-in at the buzzer extended Boston's home winning streak to 10 games and lifted the Celtics to a 128-127 victory over the Atlanta Hawks Sunday night.

title: Snowflake on 5th Ave.
description: More glitter will radiate from the already incandescent intersection of Fifth Avenue and 57th Street, when 6,000 bulbs are turned on tonight, lighting a huge snowflake and sending 60,000 watts of light into the sky.

title: Topics For Shame
description: Netting RunawaysWhen a parent is unable to support a child it's sad. When he or she can but won't it's cruel.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Applied Data Communications Inc., Tustin, Calif., said it expected to report a loss for the third quarter, ending Dec. 31, but foresaw a return to profitability in the fourth quarter.

title: Lawyer to Head Financial Agency
description: Mayor Kock yesterday appointed a 34-year-old lawyer and former insurance company executive chairman of the city's Financial Services Corporation, which provides incentives for small businesses to expand in New York.

title: MANAGEMENT ASSISTANCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $300,000 for the quarter and year and a gain of $1,063,000 for the year from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting. c-Including a tax credit of $254,000. d-Net income including a tax credit of $1,004,000.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: JESUIT ORDER DISMISSES PRIEST IN NICARAGUAN CABINET
description: The Jesuit order of the Roman Catholic Church announced today that it had dismissed Nicaragua's Education Minister, the Rev. Fernando Cardenal, from the order for his refusal to leave the Sandinista Government.

title: QED EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PUTTING THEIR WORDS WHERE THE MIKE IS
description: The finalists were assembled for the last time,

title: State Suspends Bronx Surgeon
description: The State Commissioner of Health has suspended the medical license of a Bronx surgeon who is charged with leaving a surgical clamp inside a patient in 1980 and then using deceit in getting the unknowing patient to submit to a second operation whose only purpose was to remove the clamp.

title: CLUBS AT HARVARD VOTE TO END TIES
description: The nine all-male, private ''final clubs'' at Harvard College decided today to break their ties with the school rather than accept women members and break a 200-year-old tradition, Harvard officials said.

title: WORLCO DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Safety First
description: Responding to rowdiness and fighting among fans at recent high school basketball games, Rochester's School Superintendent, Laval Wilson , issued an order banning all spectators from games. Mr. Wilson also moved the basketball games to be played before Dec 21 from the Community War Memorial in downtown Rochester to school gymnasiums and rescheduled evening games for the afternoon. ''We want to make sure that the safety of our team members and the safety of the people who come to our games are protected,'' he said. Mr. Wilson said the ban would be in effect at least until Dec. 21, when Christmas recess begins. . . . The coach for the Plattsburgh State hockey team says his team will not play in this season's State University of New York Athletic Conference championship tournament at Oswego State because of the abuse his players were subjected to by Oswego fans after a game there last week. ''We're not going back,'' Coach Steve Hoar said.

title: Milwaukee Firm Fined
description: Blunt, Ellis & Loewi Inc., a Milwaukee-based securities firm owned by the Kemper Corporation, has been fined $10,000 by the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Polish Parents Stage Sit-In In a Dispute Over Crucifixes
description: Parents of more than 100 Polish students staging a sit-in to protest the removal of crucifixes from a school held talks with the authorities today, a provincial official said.

title: SENATOR BAKER AND THE ART OF MAKING RAIN
description: Howard H. Baker Jr.'s earned income will increase at least tenfold on Jan. 3. That is the day he will officially stop being Senate majority leader and start being a Washington lawyer.

title: RUCKELSHAUS, THWARTED
description: When William D. Ruckelshaus resigned as Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, he claimed that he had ''accomplished everything I came here to do.'' I disagree. Opposed within the Administration at virtually every turn, Mr. Ruckelshaus never had a chance.

title: TOP PASTRY CHEFS PICK FAVORITES OF THE SEASON
description: AT this time of year, when the American love affair with dessert seems to reach its zenith, the pastry chef becomes the most important person in the kitchen. To keep up with the demand for fruit cake, croquembouche, plum pudding, decorative butter cookies - all the treats associated with the holiday season - bakers are stoking their ovens full time.

title: 'A Christmas Carol'
description: The South Street Seaport Museum will present Eli Wallach, Anne Jackson and Zoe Caldwell in a reading of ''A Christmas Carol'' by Charles Dickens, on Monday at 7:30 P.M., at the Trans-Lux Theater, 210 Front Street. Tickets are $5; $3 for the elderly, children and museum members, and includes a party. The number for reservations is 669-9416.

title: COMPACT WINE RACKS
description: A fine bottle of Burgundy or Bordeaux, or maybe a case of a relatively unknown wine that you find particularly exciting, is a gift that is always appreciated. However, if the recipient lives in a small New York apartment, your thoughtfulness might only add to his or her storage problems.

title: LOUIS J. MARION, FORMER HEAD OF THE PARKE-BERNET GALLERIES
description: Louis J. Marion, auctioneer, art appraiser and former president of Parke- Bernet Galleries, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Gardiner, N.Y. He was 75 years old.

title: BLACK AND JEWISH LEADERS TRYING TO REVITALIZE COALITION OF THE 60'S
description: Late last month, a representative of the National Conference of Black Lawyers was reported to have pledged the organization's ''undying support for the Palestinian revolution.'' But, sensitive to what that meant to American Jews, David N. Dinkins - a leading black New York City politician who is a member of the group - publicly disavowed the pledge.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Milwaukee Bucks, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. Just after playing a second game in 72 hours against Boston, the Atlantic Division leader, the Nets have to lock horns with the powers of the Central Division. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:30 P.M.) St. John's at Davidson. Chris Mullin and Walter Berry take their show on the road. (Radio - WCBS, 880; 7:30 P.M.)

title: Mini-Programming With A Female Focus
description: For several years the Consumer Products division of the American Cyanamid Company fought the advertising clutter problem on television by supplying mini-programming of its own to run with its ads.

title: Bridge:Signaling Codes May Take Years to Gain Acceptance
description: New methods of signaling, however sensible, take a long time to gain acceptance.

title: WALTER UHL
description: Walter Uhl, a home builder on Long Island since the 1930's, died Friday after surgery at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan.

title: H.R.A. SEES 25% OF PEOPLE IN CITY BELOW POVERTY LINE
description: The number of New York City residents living in poverty has grown 20 percent since 1979 to a figure that now represents nearly a quarter of the city's population, according to the city's Human Resources Administration.

FORDHAM HOLDS OFF SETON HALL BY 74-70
description: Steve Samuels scored 8 of Fordham's final 13 points and finished with a game-high 25 as the Rams held off Seton Hall, 74-70, last night at Rose Hill Gymnasium in the Bronx.

title: Increase Seen In '85 Spending
description: of 1985 domestic advertising

title: BRITISH PUT OFF DECISION ON SHIFT IN PRICING OF OIL
description: The British Government, despite pressure from oil companies, today put off a decision on changing its method of pricing North Sea oil.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Metropolitan Savings Selling Housing Bonds
description: The Metropolitan Savings Bank is selling about $104.4 million of old 6 1/2 percent New York City Housing Development Corporation bonds from its portfolio as part of an unusual financing where investors will be able to ''put,'' or redeem, the bonds after two or four years.

title: CLASH OF CULTURES AFFECTS RANGERS
description: Jan Erixon, skating along the left wing, had an idea. But for the idea to work in the rush of the moment, precision timing would be necessary and there could be no pause for thought.
