description: Dec. 12, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: GCI INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After unrealized losses of $250,000 for the quarter and $575,000 for the 9 months on marketable securities.

title: No Prancer, No Dancer
description: What will Sweetie Pea, Lushie Peach, Snappie Bean, Cobbie Corn, Reddie Tomato and Juicie Pineapple be doing over at the White House today? Who, you may well ask, are Sweetie Pea, Lushie Peach and the rest anyway? Well, they turn out to be stuffed toys representing vegetables and fruits that the advertising people for the Del Monte Corporation concocted to symbolize various nutritional elements and named collectively, in a marketing masterstroke, Country Yumkins.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''An awful lot of people did not grow up marching together.'' - R. Peter Straus, on the tension between blacks and Jews. (B2:2.)

title: JUDICIAL PANEL SEEKS INCREASE IN JUROR POOL
description: A panel of New York trial judges and legal experts called yesterday for the elimination of nearly all exemptions from jury service as part of an effort to cut in half the number of days jurors must serve in court.

title: ECONOMISTS MISSING THE MARK
description: Economists are on the defensive. The most recent victim is the Council of Economic Advisers, which President Reagan is considering abolishing. But while the council's possible demise appears to be more for political than economic reasons, economists everywhere have been carrying a heavy burden as their forecasts seem to stray further and further from the mark.

title: TREASURY CALLS PLAN SOUNDLY BASED
description: The chief architect of the Treasury's tax simplification plan, responding to concern voiced by tax accountants at a meeting here today, acknowledged that it was beyond the scope of economic science to accurately assess the plan's impact on the economy. Nonetheless, he said, he is confident that the proposal does not represent a risky step into the unknown.

title: Stake in Avco
description: A group of companies contolled by Ivan Boesky, a New York investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had acquired 1,875,100 common shares, or 8 percent, of the Avco Corporation. The group said it had acquired the stock for risk arbitrage and other investment purposes and had no plans to seek control of Avco, which is based in Greenwich, Conn.

title: New Rules Accelerate Review of New Drugs
description: Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human Services, announced new regulations today designed to accelerate the review of new drugs and bolster safety monitoring of existing medications.

title: FORWARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: Bills High on Flutie
description: Some scouts have suggested that, at 5 feet 9 3/4 inches, Doug Flutie is too short to make a top professional quarterback. But Ralph Wilson , the owner of the Buffalo Bills, apparently hasn't been listening.

title: AMERICAN RESTAURANTS CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $321,000.

title: DANCE: JOYCE TRISLER DANSCOMPANY
description: THE Joyce Trisler Danscompany gave a consistently interesting performance last night when it opened a week's engagement at the Joyce Theater, at 19th Street and Eighth Avenue. And because it did, one is tempted to breathe a sigh of relief and shout, ''Hurray!''

title: ESTERLINE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $273,000 for the quarter and $1,229,000 for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $235,000 for the quarter and $1,598,000 for the year.

title: Vienna Choir Boys Concert
description: The Vienna Choir Boys, one of the world's most beloved choirs, will present a gala Christmas program at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday.

title: MUSIC: BACH ORGAN RETROSPECTIVE
description: IN the case of Bach's organ

title: TIME WRITER TERMS SHARON A 'VICTIM OF AN OBSESSION'
description: A Time magazine writer testified yesterday that Ariel Sharon was ''the victim of an obsession'' about Palestinian forces in Lebanon.

title: Pope Badly Informed, Ousted Jesuit Asserts
description: The Nicaraguan priest removed from the Jesuit order said today that Pope John Paul II was ''badly informed'' about Nicaragua's revolution.

title: Wrather Port Account
description: The Los Angeles office of Ogilvy & Mather is going to be doing advertising for Wrather Port Properties, which is expected to spend $3 million to promote its tourist facility. The properties, in Long Beach, Calif., include the liner Queen Mary, Howard Hughes's giant seaplane known as the Spruce Goose, and a segment of Olde England called Londontowne.

title: ELECTION PANEL REJECTS BID FOR NEW FERRARO INQUIRY
description: A divided Federal Election Commission, rejecting the advice of its staff lawyers, voted late last month against subpoenaing Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro's husband and conducting a new inquiry into real estate transactions used to pay off her illegal campaign contributions in 1978.

title: GOVERNMENT MISCONDUCT CHARGED IN SPY CASE INVOLVING F.B.I. AGENT
description: A lawyer who used to work for Svetlana Ogorodnikov, the Soviet woman accused of an espionage scheme with a Federal agent, told Government investigators of an earlier love affair she had with another agent, her new attorneys say in documents made public today.

title: Lions Roar For Another
description: At first, only a handful of students were watching the Detroit Lions-Los Angeles Raiders game Monday night on a television set in the recreation room of Columbia University's Furnald Hall. Little was at stake in that mismatch, a circumstance that contributed to a kind of drowsy atmosphere.

title: U.S. Studies Oil Stockpile
description: The Government is considering an early halt to building the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve, which would leave it at only two-thirds of the current goal, Energy Secretary Donald P. Hodel said today.

title: SEASONAL MELODIES AND ORNAMENTS
description: 1.*Ornament That Sings

title: MAKER OF VACCINE QUITS THE MARKET
description: Connaught Laboratories Inc. has stopped selling whooping cough vaccine, a company official said today. Health experts said the move would worsen shortages of the vaccine, which is used to protect nearly every infant in the country against the potentially fatal disease.

title: MURDERER IS EXECUTED IN GEORGIA AFTER FIVE APPEALS ARE REJECTED
description: Alpha Otis Stephens, convicted of murdering a man who had interrupted a burglary, was executed in Georgia's electric chair early today. He was the 20th person to be put to death in the United States this year, and the third in Georgia.

title: Equity Group
description: Equity Group Holdings, an investment partnership based in Washington, D.C., told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had acquired 9.2 percent of the Easco Corporation's common shares.

title: INACOMP COMPUTER CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
Separatists Still Offering Talks on New Caledonia
description: Jean-Marie Tjibaou, leader of the separatists, said today that, despite the slaying of 10 Melanesians last week, including two of his brothers, he was willing to negotiate with the French.

title: Medical Imaging Unit At Raytheon Gets Head
description: Apparently, the Raytheon Company sees something in the X-ray business that others cannot. The Lexingron, Mass., company has named John C. Kingery, 38, president of a new division of Raytheon, a leading manufacturer of electronic equipment and components.

title: WILSON FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Net loss.

title: 2-CENT RISE IN FIRST-CLASS MAIL SAID TO BE APPROVED
description: The board of the United States Postal Service voted in a closed meeting today to increase the price of a first-class stamp to 22 cents next year, according to Postal Service sources.

title: BROWN, ROBERT C. & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INDIANS PLAN TO DISPOSE OF REMAINING POISON GAS
description: The Madhya Pradesh Government said today that scientists were ''confident of working out a zero-risk method'' of neutralizing and disposing of the remaining poison chemicals at the Union Carbide insecticide plant.

title: Diversifoods Net
description: Diversifoods Inc. said that it expected a sharp decline in earnings for the fourth quarter and that a tentative agreement for a $525 million leveraged buy out of the company had been terminated.

title: Seaborg Considers A Buyout of Soya
description: Seaborg Inc., a California-based real estate and investment concern, said today that it held 5.1 percent of the Central Soya Company and was considering proposing a leveraged buyout, or a similar transaction.

title: U.S. AND ISRAELIS IN WAR GAMES
description: Ships and aircraft of the United States and Israeli navies began a joint antisubmarine warfare exercise in the Eastern Mediterranean today, the Defense Department said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in Business Day on Dec. 1 with an article about the third-quarter results of savings banks in the New York area misstated the performance of the Southold Savings Bank. It had a net operating profit of $1.1 million.

title: SYNCOR INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: GRIFFIN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
JAZZ: AT RITZ, MCFERRIN
description: ANYTHING a human voice can do, Bobby McFerrin is game to try. His solo sets Thursday at the Ritz included songs, wordless tunes, impressions, even a recitation - in an upper-class British accent - of the lyrics to the Beatles' ''Blackbird.''

title: BRAZIL'S LONG, COMPLEX RACIAL HISTORY
description: To the Editor:

title: WHY VOTERS HAVE GROWN INDEPENDENT
description: The combination of the Reagan landslide on the national level and a strong Democratic showing on the Congressional level has baffled political experts. For the historian, however, the results were not unexpected because they have been more than a quarter century in the making.

title: LEVITT STARTS $2 BILLION PROJECT
description: William J. Levitt, the developer whose name came to symbolize inexpensive tract housing in the postwar years, announced yesterday that he would build a $2 billion planned community of at least 26,000 residential units in the Orlando, Fla., metropolitan area.

title: BOSTON FIVE CENTS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Wildwood Mayor Recalled
description: Residents of this resort in Cape May County voted tonight to recall Mayor Earl B. Ostrander and replace him with City Council President Victor DiSylvester. Mr. Ostrander's opponents had accused him of failing to cooperate on issues before the governmental body and of trying to wield too much authority. The vote to recall was 1,075 to 613.

title: BISHOP TUTU CALLS FOR WORLD JUSTICE
description: Bishop Desmond Tutu, the winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize for his nonviolent campaign to end South Africa's policy of apartheid, delivered a Nobel lecture today that called on those who would be peacemakers to work for justice throughout the world.

title: TREASURE-LADEN HANGOUTS FOR HOBBYISTS
description: IN hundreds of tiny nooks around

title: Five Plead Guilty To Hunting Violations
description: Five of the people charged in a Federal investigation into illegal hunting for big game animals and the sale of parts of animals illegally killed have entered guilty pleas in Federal District Court.

title: Pictures at an Exhibition
description: The camera had captured more

title: PREPARING FOR GROMYKO
description: WASHINGTON The Reagan Administration is

title: 'NUCLEAR WINTER' IS SEEN AS POSSIBLE
description: A panel of scientists told the Federal Government today that despite great uncertainties there was a ''clear possibility'' that a major nuclear war would generate enough smoke and dust to blot out the sun in the Northern Hemisphere, causing severe drops in temperature.

title: Marathon Cuts Price For Crude
description: The Marathon Oil Company yesterday cut the price it will pay for the most common kind of American crude oil by 50 cents, to $28.50 a barrel. Although several small oil companies already post that price for West Texas Intermediate, most majors, like Marathon, have remained at $29 for the key grade.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: CANDLELIGHT Candles on the table are practically a community cliche on the Upper East Side, where the dimmer the lights, the higher the tab. But there is one establishment where the candles are entirely authentic and preceded the electric light - and, what's more, where there will be taper illumination in nine of its rooms from tonight through Friday.

title: County Denies Funds For Liver Transplant
description: County commissioners have decided not to pay for a second liver transplant for a 5-year-old girl who is a ward of the county.

title: Off and Running
description: Wearing a red scarf, a blue tie and

title: ITT SUSPENDS PUBLIC RELATIONS CHIEF
description: Edward J. Gerrity Jr., an executive vice president of the ITT Corporation and its most senior public relations official, said yesterday that he had been suspended ''because of an internal perception that I have been in disagreement with certain policies of top management.''

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1984 International The White House accused Iran of taking actions that encouraged the Arab terrorists who hijacked a Kuwaiti airliner last week and killed two American officials. The Reagan Administration also demanded that Iran either prosecute the hijackers or turn them over to another country for trial. (Page A1, Column 6.) Earlier, two American ex-hostages of the hijacked airliner arrived in Kuwait with other freed passengers and said they had seen no evidence of Iranian complicity in their six-day ordeal. But there were reports from Karachi that two Pakistani passengers said on arriving there that the Iranian authorities had supplied the hijackers with weapons, ropes and handcuffs. (A1:5.)

title: JETRONIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid on July 2, 1984.

title: U.S. LAWYERS ARE ARRIVING TO PREPARE BIG DAMAGE SUITS
description: Right behind the stream of scientists, executives, officials, aid givers and others who have come to this central Indian city after the gas leak last week are American lawyers, members of a breed of legal specialists seen by some as ambulance chasers and by others as champions of the individual against the corporation and of industrial safety and consumer protection.

title: Economic Scene; Advising The President
description: THE White House has made known that President Reagan is seriously considering abolishing the Council of of Economic Advisers. But does the President have the right to do this?

title: Woman Arrested In Housing Fraud
description: The Housing Authority police have arrested a 38-year-old woman who they say defrauded more than 250 people who were seeking low-rent apartments in a city housing project.

title: XTRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,025,000 for the quarter and $3,010,000 for the year and losses from provisions for the disposal of discontinued operations of $3,783,000 for the quarter and $4,264,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $532,000 for the quarter and $2,247,000 for the year.

title: U.S. JUDGE RULES E.P.A. IN CONTEMPT
description: A Federal district judge found the Environmental Protection Agency and its Administrator, William D. Ruckelshaus, in contempt of court today for failing to comply with a court-imposed deadline for issuing standards on airborne emissions of radioactive materials.

title: CHINA MAY PERMIT ATOMIC INSPECTION
description: China for the first time may be willing to allow international inspection of its nuclear installations, according to authoritative United States Government sources.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1984

title: REISSUES BY POLYGRAM UNCOVER RARE MATERIAL
description: AT a time when most reissue albums of classic American rhythm and blues, soul and country music are either independent productions or high-priced imports from Europe or Japan, it's heartening to see one major United States label, Polygram, assembling and releasing thoughtful compilations of material from its vaults. In recent months, Polygram reissues have made available rare and worthy material by artists ranging from Hank Williams and George Jones to James Brown and Parliament to Joao Gilberto and Stan Getz.

title: Colorado National
description: Colorado National Bankshares Inc. said its lead bank, Colorado National Bank of Denver, had made a special, additional provision of $5 million to its loan loss reserve, which would hurt fourth-quarter earnings.

title: PICKENS IS SUED BY PHILLIPS
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company yesterday accused T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company of Amarillo, Tex., of tipping friends, Mesa officers and members of the Amarillo Country Club of his plans to acquire stock in major oil companies.

title: Rights Group Says Albanians Curb Dissent
description: Albanians who practice their religion or who criticize the Government are serving long sentences in labor camps, Amnesty International said today.

title: Revco Expecting To See Net Drop
description: Revco D.S. Inc. said it expected to report a 45 percent drop in earnings for its fiscal second quarter, which ended Nov. 17. Revco, which operates a drugstore chain, attributed the drop on a number of factors, including the costs of opening new stores and the unexpected poor performance by the Odd Lot Trading Company.

title: 3 FISHERMEN ADMIT CHEATING
description: Four Louisiana men admitted today that they had cheated to win more than $200,000 in bass fishing tournaments in East Texas.

title: KEAN HOPEFUL OF GETTING MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL
description: New Jersey's growing professional sports industry is ''one of the jewels of the state,'' Governor Kean said today, adding that he was looking forward to putting another gem in the collection.

title: HINTS AND INTRIGUE IN TALE OF A TRADE
description: The Mets and the Montreal Expos said yesterday that it had taken 14 months of hints, overtures, intrigue and finally intensive discussions in four cities to fashion the trade that sent Gary Carter to New York.

title: WARSAW INDICTS 4 FOR MURDER
description: The Government indicted four security officers today in the kidnapping and killing of a pro-Solidarity priest. It also criticized a student sit-in protesting removal of crucifixes from schools.

title: The Long Walk
description: Rob Sweetgall, a 37-year-old chemical engineer from Newark, Del., who is a quarter of the way through his one-year, 11,600-mile walk through 50 states to help demonstrate the physiological effects of long-distance walking, crossed the Continental Divide on Thursday near Helena, Mont., at an elevation of 6,300 feet.

title: TRUMP PROPOSES 'CO-OP' STADIUM FOR QUEENS SITE
description: The developer Donald J. Trump proposed yesterday to build an 80,000- to 85,000-seat sports stadium, probably in Flushing, Queens, which he said he would finance by selling or leasing most of the seats.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.25-11.50 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estima .25-1tes for bellwether issues

title: 6 Blasts Hit NATO Pipelines; Far Left Takes Responsibility
description: Six explosions damaged emergency fuel pipelines of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization around Belgium today, setting off at least two fires but causing no injuries.

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
U.S. Library Rebuffed For Employee Inquiry
description: A Federal appeals court opened the way today for a former clerk at the Library of Congress to sue the Government for a wide-ranging investigation of his political activities.

title: Talks Resume On Contract Representatives of major
description: league baseball's owners and

title: IS EXTENDED FAMILY AN ADOPTION ASSET?
description: To the Editor:

title: CASEY'S GENERAL STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PLAYWRIGHTS AND ACTORS IN DISPUTE OVER RULE
description: The production of new American plays in low-cost showcases - the method used to develop more than 150 plays in New York each year - is being disrupted by a dispute between playwrights and Actors Equity.

title: ENERGY ASSETS INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: B&B Unit Is Planning Ads for Folio Society
description: Britain's 37-year-old Folio Society, which prints special editions of hard- to-find literary and historic titles, has a new management that has set North American conquest as a short- term goal.

title: NEW OFFICE BUILDINGS FOR MT. PLEASANT'S 'GOLDEN MILE'
description: Some officials in Mount Pleasant, N.Y., refer to the town's major commercial throughfare, Columbus Avenue, as Westchester County's ''Golden Mile.'' This obvious allusion to the corporation-rich strip of Route 287 known as the ''Platinum Mile,'' just north of White Plains, may have seemed a bit hyperbolic until now.

title: CHINATOWN EXHIBIT HONORS THE HARD LOT OF THE LAUNDRYMAN
description: Eight pound iron, twelve hour day, Seven Day week, just to make it pay, Sort and wash, press and fold, Bitter rice on a mountain of gold William (Charlie) Chin's song, ''Eight Pound Livelihood''

title: MUSIC: ZEITLIN, VIOLINIST
description: ZVI ZEITLIN'S admirable Tully Hall recital Sunday contained substantial violin sonatas by Beethoven (the 10th, elegantly done) and Prokofiev, but it was most interesting for student works by Bartok and Jacob Druckman, and most fun in a virtuoso fantasy on Rossini themes by Heinrich Wilhelm Ernst.

title: CHUCK, A TASTY BARGAIN IN BEEF FOR PLAIN OR FANCY COOKING
description: OF all the cuts of beef, none can match the chuck when it comes to combining versatility, economy and flavor. Rib, loin, sirloin and round may provide more elegant steaks and nobler- looking roasts, but for good cooking - plain or fancy - chuck easily holds its own as a delicious bargain.

title: Eagles Studying Move to Phoenix
description: The Philadelphia Eagles confirmed today that they were considering a move to Phoenix, an action that their owner, Leonard Tose, had recently said would be taken ''over my dead body.''

title: A TIME FOR BARKERS
description: There was an entertaining dust-up

title: SUN CITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
Not So Highbrow
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: HOUSE UNIT ASKS F.C.C. TO DROP $6 PHONE FEE
description: The House Small Business Committee asked the Federal Communications Commission today to remove the $6 monthly fee it allows local telephone companies to charge multiline businesses for access to the telephone network.

title: Legal Services Still the Stepchild President Reagan's fifth annual proposal to eliminate funds for the Legal Services Corporation is not to be confused with most of his other budget austerities. This is a vengeful attack on a program Mr. Reagan has sought to abolish since he was Governor of California, an attack that continues despite Congress's repeated renewal of subsidized legal help for the poor.
description: Besides offering little to deficit reduction, the corporation's $320 million budget deserves to survive because it delivers high-class legal work at bargain rates, mostly from idealistic young lawyers. Occasionally a zealous attorney has indulged in excessive lobbying or filed a suit that alarmed a state official.

title: ON STATE SUPREME
description: Justice Albert H. Buschmann of State Supreme Court in Jamaica, Queens, died of heart failure Sunday at a daughter's home in Westbury, L.I. He was 71 years old and lived in Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Nate Bowman Is Dead;Former Knicks Center
description: Nate Bowman, the center who was a backup to Willis Reed on the New York Knick team that won the National Basketball Association's championship in 1970, died of cardiac arrest at Roosevelt-St. Luke's Hospital yesterday.

title: HARVEY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-After a loss of $50,000 for the quarter and 9 months from discontinued operations.

title: Godard Retrospective Opens at Film Forum
description: A Jean-Luc Godard retrospective begins the winter season today at the Film Forum, 57 Watts Street. Opening the series are the films ''Le Gai Savoir'' (1968) and ''See You at Mao'' (1969.) The retrospective will run through Jan. 1 and will be followed by a three-week festival devoted to the Japanese film maker Nagisa Oshima.

title: Portec's Plans
description: Portec Inc., a maker of railcar and construction equipment, said it was considering a variety of actions to ''maximize value'' of its stock to shareholders, including the sale of some or all of its businesses, a leveraged buyout or a combination of alternatives. The company said it was working with its investment bankers, Kidder, Peabody & Company, to review its course of action. On the New York Stock Exchange today, Portec, which has about 3.7 million shares outstanding, jumped $2.50, to $17.75.

title: Advertising; Marketing Products From Italy
description: FRANK DiGIACOMO may have

title: SIMCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Including a net gain of $367,567 on the sale of real estate.

title: Circus Aerialist, 23, Dies
description: Cindy Dodge, the 23-year-old aerialist with the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus who was severely injured in a fall Dec. 2 at a rehearsal at the Nassau Coliseum, died Monday night after being removed from a respirator at Nassau County Medical Center. Electroencephalograms had indicated her brain had ceased to function.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: ''There is no one here,'' Merry Clark said, quickly surveying the nightclub crowd with a practiced eye. ''These guys are all from out of town. Where are the men? Where are they?''

title: T.W.A. TO BEGIN NONSTOP FLIGHTS OF TWO-ENGINE JETS OVER ATLANTIC
description: Trans World Airlines said today that it would begin this country's first nonstop twin- engine airline flights across the Atlantic in April, joining the three- and four- engine jet service that now takes people across the ocean.

title: FALWELL, BOOED AND HECKLED, HOLDS A TOWN HALL DIALOGUE
description: Before a crowd that heckled and booed him at Town Hall, the Rev. Jerry Falwell was asked if he was an ''optimist or a pessimist'' about the future of America.

title: Greece Says It's Free To Ignore NATO Policy
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou says Greece no longer follows NATO policies as a matter of course because that means ''continual subservience.''

title: Salvadoran Insurgents Declare Holiday Truce
description: A statement issued here today by the Salvadoran insurgents declared a cease-fire for the Christmas and New Year's holidays.

title: BRIEFS
description: Applied Biosystems Inc., Foster City, Calif., said it had completed the acquisition of Brownlee Labs Inc., a closely held company, for about 130,000 shares.

title: MOVEMENT SEEKS TO ADVANCE RIGHTS OF DYING
description: Every day several sacks of mail arrive at the front door of a small rented house in suburban Los Angeles and in two crowded offices on West 57th Street in Manhattan. From the quarters of these three little-known organizations a continent apart comes much of the current impetus for a better-known movement advocating the ''right to die.''

title: LAB WORKER GETS IMMUNE DISORDER
description: Epidemiologists are investigating a case of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS. contracted by a medical laboratory worker in Boston.

title: Market Place; Union Carbide And Insurance
description: SHARES of the Union Carbide Corporation have come under heavy selling pressure since the middle of last week. In three trading days ended Monday, the stock plunged a total of 9 1/4 points, to 35 1/4, as apprehension mounted that the company could incur staggering claims for damages from the lethal gas leak at its plant in Bhopal, India. More than 2,000 people, it is estimated, died as a result of the leak.

title: WHEN IS A TERRORIST NOT NECESSARILY A TERRORIST?
description: The antinuclear activist who drove up to the Washington Monument two years ago in a truck that he pretended was loaded with explosives was a ''terrorist,'' but those responsible for firebombing abortion clinics are not.

title: COMTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income including an extraordinary gain of $1.5 million from the sale of stock in Electronic Mail Corp.

title: COMGEN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Letter: On Taxi Service ; Some Yellow Cabs Need Radios To the Editor:
description: In your editorial ''Radio Cabs Needn't Be Yellow'' (Nov. 25), you asked the Taxi and Limousine Commission to require that yellow cabs with radios be replaced by non-yellow radio cabs. Unfortunately, such action would hurt both the individual cab owner/operator and the City of New York.

title: Financial Corp. Cuts Dividend
description: The Financial Corporation of America said today that it had reduced the quarterly dividend on its common shares to 5 cents from 17 cents, the first dividend reduction since the company's near-collapse last August.

title: CRILE TESTIFIES ON PROGRAM'S ACCRACY
description: George Crile, the producer of a disputed CBS documentary on Vietnam, vigorously defended its accuracy in court yesterday as lawyers for Gen. William C. Westmoreland continued their 10-week assault on the broadcast.

title: MOTHER TERESA CARRIES HER MESSAGE TO BHOPAL
description: Mother Teresa came to Bhopal today to comfort victims of the gas disaster, visiting them in hospitals and homes and kneeling in prayer at a special evening mass for those who died and others who are still suffering.

title: UNION CARBIDE OF INDIA: IMAGE IS SHATTERED
description: For nearly half a century, Union Carbide grew and prospered in this vast and densely populated subcontinent, managing to survive in a country where anti-American statements are often heard from Indian officials and in the press.

title: Man Killed in Siege Is Identified as Fugitive
description: A man killed in a fire after a 35-hour standoff with agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been tentatively identified as Robert J. Mathews, a white supremacist wanted in the shooting of a bureau agent and a $500,000 robbery, the authorities say.

title: Suit Against Novelist Is Settled Out of Court
description: An out-of-court settlement was reached Monday between the author Robert Ludlum and a former friend who accused the spy novelist of stealing his idea for the popular novel, ''The Road to Gandolfo.''

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: THE SEASON'S GLOBAL GLITTER ON MADISON
description: IT was the antique wristwatch with red stones

title: Man Injured in Crash Left for Dead 5 Hours
description: A taxi driver believed killed in an automobile accident lay unaided near the wreckage for almost five hours today before a medical examiner's investigator discovered he was alive.

title: WE'LL TAKE A PEACE WITH PEPPERONI
description: Having tried privately and failed to persuade Secretary of State George P. Shultz to take a small step in the new negotiations w ith the Russians, my friend and I have decided to go public. My friend is James Symington, former ambassador and Congressman, and a Washington lawyer skilled in diplomatic maneuver. I am a former journalist, White House assistant under Lyndon B. Johnson and, more recently, head of a small liberal arts college on Maryland's eastern shore. My involvement in this episode arises from a keen desire to educate my students in world affairs. Alas, I little reckoned the difficulties.

title: STATE DELAYS FUNDS FOR CITY'S PROGRAM ON ABUSIVE PARENTS
description: New York State announced yesterday that it was withholding $1 million for city programs that protect children from abusive parents because the city had failed to provide adequate services.

title: MOST SUFFOLK LAWMAKERS STILL OPPOSE SHOREHAM
description: A substantial majority of the Suffolk County Legislature is unwavering in its opposition to opening the Shoreham nuclear power plant despite recent statements by a senior county official about the possibility of a change in the county's position.

title: KEITHLEY INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Slower Taiwan Growth
description: Taiwan's economic growth rate is expected to slow to 8.5 percent in 1985 from this year's projected 10.9 percent, the Council for Economic Planning and Development said today. The agency blamed declining exports, a result of weakening United States demand.

title: ALL SEASONS RESORTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ETHIOPIANS BLAME WEST FOR FAMINE
description: Senior Ethiopian officials said today that the Western nations involved in emergency relief efforts here were largely to blame for the extent of the famine devastating the people of this nation.

title: Chiat/Day the Agency For Nynex Directories
description: Chiat/Day's New York office has become the agency for the Nynex Information Resources Company, publisher of 260 telephone directories for the New York and New England Telephone Companies.

title: NETS WASTE 42 BY BIRDSONG
description: Bernard King, sidelined for 13 days and seven games with a pulled groin muscle, returned to action last night, and the Knicks' fortunes changed. In an inspirational comeback, the Knick captain and the National Basketball Association's leading scorer, with a 31.9 point average, scored 34 points in a 110-106 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers at Madison Square Garden.

title: FREED HOSTAGES AT ODDS ON ROLE IRANIANS PLAYED
description: The two surviving American hostages of the hijacked Kuwaiti airliner arrived here tonight with other freed passengers and said they had seen no evidence of Iranian complicity in their six-day ordeal.

description: Representative Dante B. Fascell, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said today that a Yugoslav decision to bar a Congressional observer at a dissident trial this month might affect Yugoslav-United States relations.

description: A coalition of civil-rights groups and State Attorney General Robert Abrams have urged an appeals court to uphold Mayor Koch's authority to prohibit city contractors from practicing discrimination.

description: The Muse Air Corporation said its directors had authorized management to pursue the sale or other disposition of the company. The board deemed the action necessary in light of the company's recent losses and its current financial position, Muse said.

title: Changing Sides

Before the game, Knight, a 6-foot-6-inch swingman who had been with the Kings for two seasons, was traded for McNamara, a 6-foot-11-inch center with the Spurs. . . . Sam Battistone , the owner of the Utah Jazz, said that his efforts to build an alternate following for the team in Las Vegas, Nev., had failed and that four home games that had been scheduled for the gambling capital were being switched back to Salt Lake City. . . . The Houston Rockets have signed Allen Leavell , a free-agent guard, to a two-year contract. The 6-foot 2-inch Leavell takes the spot left open by John Lucas , who was waived Mondayafter a drug test over the weekend showed traces of cocaine in his system.

title: How Much Less Deficit, How to Get It Though first elected President on a pledge to wipe out the budget deficit, Ronald Reagan promptly made it three times larger. Heading now into his second term, he proposes only to cut it by half by 1988. Under the circumstances, that objective is probably sound. But Mr. Reagan's strategy for achieving it is not.
description: A dramatic reduction in the deficit is essential. It's grown since 1981 from $58 billion to more than $200 billion, dangerously draining savings from other investment - abroad as well as at home. What is needed most urgently now is credible evidence that the United States is bringing its fiscal affairs under control.

title: Jake Butcher in Plea

Mr. Butcher and Jesse A. Barr, an associate, appeared before Federal District Judge Eugene Siler Jr. on Monday to answer the fourth indictment against them in connection with the 1983 collapse of the $1.5 billion Butcher banking empire. Mr. Butcher and Mr. Barr were charged here Nov. 28 with conspiracy, bank fraud and falsifying records of United American Banks in Lexington and Somerset.

title: IMAGINATION AND IBSEN CELEBRATE MAGIC OF STAGE
description: The stage was bare and dark, except for a line of chairs. The actors filed out and sat down, books in their laps. It was left to the audience to conjure up the setting - a richly furnished study with green-shaded lamps casting a soft light, a glowing fire in the fireplace and servants in livery moving about quietly under the glittering candelabra in the elegant salon beyond.

title: THE WINE LABEL AS A WORK OF ART
description: GRAPES and wine have long inspired artistic creation. Now a number of wine makers have become involved with art - and not just as collectors. ''There is something very legitimate about it, that art is relevant to wine and that wine is a work of art,'' said Alex Hargrave, owner of Hargrave Vineyard in Cutchogue, L.I., and one of several wine makers who have the works of modern artists reproduced on their labels.

description: The chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Charles L. Brown, said yesterday that A.T.&T. was rethinking its dividend policy because of growing competition and higher-than-expected costs.

title: J. M. SWING, WARTIME AIRBORNE COMMANDER
description: Lieut. Gen. Joseph May Swing, commanding officer of the 11th Airborne Division in World War II and later Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, died of pnuemonia Sunday in San Francisco, where he resided. He was 90 years old.

title: SENSE OF SHARING INSPIRES DONORS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: For many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the satisfaction of feeling that they may be making a holiday cheerier for the cheerless and more bountiful for the needy is ample reward for the act of giving.

title: A LOOK AT CONSTITUIONAL CONFLICTS
description: STAY with tomorrow night's edition of ''The Constitution: That Delicate Balance'' past the first 15 or 20 minutes; eventually, it gets down to business. What is the proper relationship between the Federal Government and the states? The program doesn't answer the question, but it does let you know there is an argument. The one- hour conclusion of the fine 13-part series will be seen on Channel 13 at 10 P.M.

title: Perversity on Abortion
description: At current growth rates, the population of the world will nearly double in the next 40 years. Most of the increase will be in poorer countries: they're adding a million people every five days. Then why is the United States weakening its support for family planning that can make for smaller families and longer lives the world over?

title: Crew Blamed for Train Crash
description: Errors by the engineer and conductor aboard a crowded commuter train that collided with another train last month led to the accident, a report on the incident said today. The report, prepared by the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority, also said slippery rails contributed to the Nov. 21 accident, which injured 150 people when the trains collided at the Narberth station in Montgomery County.

title: Dutch Military Jet Crashes
description: A Dutch Air Force F-16 jet crashed into a wooded hillside north of Frankfurt today, killing one crew member, a police spokesman said. Police sifting the wreckage of the fighter found the dead pilot. The co-pilot is missing but must be presumed dead, the spokesman said.

title: No-Shows Chided
description: Bobby Knight of Indiana University and Bill Frieder of Michigan have been reprimanded by the Big Ten Conference for failing to appear at a basketball coaches' clinic on officiating on Oct 7. In letters to the two coaches, Paul Gikas , a Michigan professor who serves as chairman of the conference, and Wayne Duke , the commissioner, said that the absence violated Big Ten rules and that it was ''the professional responsibility of all conference personnel to attend meetings scheduled by their group.''

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of the most famous poems about food is William Makepeace Thackeray's ''Ballad of Bouillabaisse.'' In it he speculates that the dish is either ''a sort of soup, or broth, or brew.''

title: OPERA: 'COSI FAN TUTTE' BY MOZART
description: ''COSI FAN TUTTE'' is an opera that has always tempted directors to tinker with it. For some reason, it is often assumed that its dramatic situation will not be grasped by modern audiences unless it is lifted out of its 18th-century milieu and dragged by the nape of the neck into our time. But, as is demonstrated in any reasonably faithful staging and well- sung performance, this of all Mozart operas needs no updating or other directorial cleverness. It speaks to us today, wittily and wisely, in exactly the way it must have spoken to the audiences of Mozart and his librettist, Lorenzo da Ponte. It is not a foolproof work, because it demands ensemble acting and singing of a high polish, but the only help it needs is plenty of talent onstage and backstage.

title: DEVILS TRIUMPH FOR FIRST TIME AT COLISEUM
description: Coach Al Arbour, without effort from many of his Islanders for most of the night, found himself without words following a 7-5 loss to the New Jersey Devils tonight - the first victory at Nassau Coliseum in the 11-year history of the Kansas City-Colorado-New Jersey franchise.

title: 2 Resign at Clemson
description: Clemson officials accepted the resignations of two track coaches, Stan Narewski and Sam Colson , who were suspended without pay pending an investigation by South Carolina law-enforcement officials of possible drug use by athletes. Narewski, the men's track coach, and Colson, the women's coach, were suspended Saturday.

description: They form a duet of striking contrasts: Micheal Ray Richardson, the high-strung and effervescent point guard, and Otis Birdsong, his usually soft-spoken running mate in the Nets backcourt. But they have emerged as an almost unstoppable one, too.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Broward County Offers $535 Million of Bonds
description: Broward County, Fla., is offering about $535 million of resource recovery revenue bonds that will eventually be used to finance a plant that will process garbage and produce electricity.

title: Control Data Executive Going to New Venture
description: Thomas G. Kamp Sr. said yesterday that he will retire as vice chairman of the Control Data Corporation at the end of the year and form a floppy disk repair company with his son.

title: More Jurors, Less Duty
description: How is an embalmer like a minister? A physician like a firefighter? A lawyer like a homemaker caring for children? In New York State, these and 13 other occupations all qualify for exemption from jury duty because they are legally deemed too essential to interrupt.

title: Ho, Ho, Ho
description: Once again John M. Snyder of the Citizens Committee for the Right to Keep and Bear Arms has stirred controversy with his Christmas greeting.

title: JETS PREFER MCNEIL OVER GASTINEAU
description: It was a bittersweet day for two Jets, both honored by their opponents but only one by his teammates.

title: U.S. AIDES SHUN HOUSE PANEL
description: The Federal Government's top disaster relief officials today were threatened with contempt charges for boycotting a House hearing at which new charges were made of fraud and abuse in their agency.

title: Ali Goes to Court
description: Muhammad Ali , who was stripped of his heavyweight title and not allowed to fight for three years after being convicted of draft evasion during the Vietnam War, filed suit against the Federal Government and the World Boxing Association yesterday.

title: ; A.T.& T. REACHES OUT FOR NEW MONOPOLY
description: To the Editor:

title: Pickens Backed In Phillips Move
description: The United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., refused to grant the Phillips Petroleum Company a temporary restraining order to prevent T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, from trying to take over the big oil company.

title: BRENNER COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Letters
description: A pile of 13,000 letters, written by American children, were dumped onto a table at the Soviet Mission on East 67th Street. Around the table, eight of the writers read their letters, then talked with Soviet children about the future of the world.

title: RISE IN MARIJUANA ON U.S. LAND CITED
description: Despite stepped-up enforcement efforts, marijuana cultivation is increasing on Federal lands as the farmers use booby traps, camouflage and violence to protect their illegal crop, a new study reports.

title: 32D CHESS GAME AJOURNED
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov adjourned the 32d game of their world chess championship match today after 40 moves.

title: ASHTON-TATE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $1 million, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Mozambique Reports Killing 1,131 Rebels Over 6 Months
description: The Mozambican Army has reported killing 1,131 rebels in the last six months, the official news agency said today.

title: Old Garden Site Sold to Developers
description: Gulf and Western Industries said yesterday that it had signed a contract to sell the full-block site of the old Madison Square Garden for $100 million to three developers, including the Zeckendorf Company.

title: Helen S. Mitchell Dies; Nutritionist and Writer
description: Helen Swift Mitchell, a biochemist, nutritionist and author, died as a result of a stroke yesterday in a nursing home at Uplands Retirement Village, Pleasant Hill, Tenn. She was 89 years old.

title: 'ENDGAME' OPENS IN WAKE OF PACT
description: Lawyers for Samuel Beckett and the American Repertory Theater reached an out-of-court settlement late yesterday allowing the theater's revival of ''Endgame'' to proceed. The opening-night curtain rose on the production only hours after the agreement was signed.

title: Court Backs Utility Panel
description: The Montana Public Service Commission acted properly when it denied the Montana Power Company authority to charge its customers $96 million for a new coal-fired power plant, the state's Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Coast School Is Closed For Alleged Child Abuse
description: A Manhattan Beach preschool facility searched last week by sheriff's deputies was ordered closed today because of allegations that a 3-year-old pupil had been sexually assaulted there.

title: CHASE WOODHOUSE, EX-REPRESENTATIVE FROM CONNECTICUT
description: Chase Going Woodhouse, a former United States Representative and Connecticut Secretary of the State, died yesterday at the Waveny Care Center in New Canaan, Conn. She was 94 years old and was a former resident of Sprague, Conn.

title: Guilt in Abducting Reporter
description: Dennis Lee Higgins pleaded guilty today to kidnapping and robbing Tim Carlson, a reporter from The Los Angeles Herald Examiner who was covering a triple shooting in the city. Mr. Higgins, 26 years old, pleaded guilty before Judge Edward Davenport in Municipal Court in a plea bargain with the District Attorney's Office.

title: Relative of Six Victims Files A $50 Billion Suit in Chicago
description: An American relative of six victims of the gas leak in Bhopal filed a class-action lawsuit today seeking $50 billion in damages from the Union Carbide.

title: Key Soviet Official Off to China Soon
description: China announced today that Ivan V. Arkhipov, a Soviet First Deputy Prime Minister, would visit China for official talks beginning Dec. 21.

title: STUDY FINDS HISPANIC STUDENTS ARE 'WASTED'
description: Hispanic students around the country are getting an inadequate education, a national report released yesterday contends. It says that 45 percent of the youths never complete high school and that 4 of 10 of those who drop out do so before reaching the 10th grade.

title: Accounts
description: * Warner Computer Systems to AC&R Advertising.

title: U.S. PRODS BELGIUM AND NETHERLANDS TO ACCEPT MISSILES
description: The United States told Belgium and the Netherlands today that the chances for progress in forthcoming negotiations with the Soviet Union would be set back if they did not carry out commitments to deploy American cruise missiles.

title: HERS
description: The Hers column is currently being written by Anne Farrer Scott, a writer and former lawyer who lives in Minneapolis.

title: Mystic Museum Gets Yacht Photo Collection
description: The Mystic Seaport Museum acquired yesterday the largest single collection of maritime photographs in the world. It is the Rosenfeld Collection and consists of more than one million images, including 10,000 glass-plate negatives dating back to the 1890's.

title: Volunteers
description: Twenty-seven million American adults can't read. To combat this illiteracy, the Coalition for Literacy was formed to organize volunteers to teach reading and writing.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: THIS week, as occasionally in the past, the Home Improvement column will be devoted to questions and answers about some of the problems most frequently encountered by do-it-yourselfers.

title: WESTERN MICROWAVE LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RULING ON DISABILITY IS UPSET
description: A Federal appeals court has overturned a district judge's ruling that restored benefits to thousands of people across the country who had been dropped from the Social Security disability rolls.

title: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 13, 1984
description: The Economy

title: Inflation Slows, O.E.C.D. Finds PARIS, Dec. 12 (AP) - The
description: average rate of consumer price

title: ROCKET PIONEER AND PHYSICIST
description: Krafft A. Ehricke, a German-born rocket specialist who became an innovative engineer in the American space program, died Tuesday at his home in La Jolla, Calif., after a long illness. He was 67 years old.

title: CELTICS AND 76ERS K.O. ANIMOSITY
description: Whatever animosity remained was put aside when Julius Erving and Larry Bird met at midcourt during the pregame warm-up tonight and shook hands to scattered applause. Of course, boxers are known to shake hands and come out fighting, so the capacity crowd of 17,921 at the Spectrum was prepared for the kind of physical basketball game that has typified the Philadelphia-Boston rivalry in recent seasons and inspired a suggestion that the quarters should be called rounds instead.

title: F.A.A. INSPECTIONS CURB 16 AIRLINES
description: Sixteen of the nation's 327 airlines had their operations suspended or curtailed or withdrew some pilots from service as a result of an intensive national inspection program by the Federal Aviation Administration last spring, according to the agency's final report on the program issued today.

title: ON TV, BRAZIL IS GETTING A CLEARER PICTURE OF ITSELF
description: More than four centuries after the sword and the cross first started shaping this vast land into a nation, the silvery blue logo of Brazil's main television network is emerging as the country's new symbol of integration.

title: HEART DIET: LEANER FOODS
description: The panel convened by the National Institutes of Health recommended that all Americans, especially those considered to have a high cholesterol level, adopt a diet that derives at most 30 percent of its calories from fat, with no more than 10 percent from saturated fat and a maximum of 300 milligrams of cholesterol a day. To achieve this, the American Heart Association and nutrition specialists suggest these dietary measures as a general pattern.

title: THE MAYOR EXPRESSES HIS CONCERN WITH TRUMP'S PLAN FOR A STADIUM
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would probably oppose a developer's plan for a cooperatively owned sports stadium in Queens if it did not set aside enough seats at football games for the general public.

title: PACT WITH CUBANS TROUBLES FLORIDA
description: Florida officials have called on the Federal Government to take financial responsibility for an expected influx of tens of thousands of of Cubans to the Miami area as a result of an agreement in principal on emigration reached by American and Cuban negotiators this week.

title: 2 MIAMI BANKERS AMONG 6 LINKED TO DRUG RING
description: Two Miami bankers were among six men arrested by Federal agents today on charges of smuggling more than 600,000 pounds of marijuana into the United States. The authorities said the six had used some of the proceeds to invest in legitimate businesses.

title: BRIEFS$95LONDON,
description: * Compucade International Inc. said it had agreed to acquire Domestic Satellite Network Inc., which operates long-distance telephone systems. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Books: A Gould Fugue
description: THE GLENN GOULD READER. Edited

title: Required Reading; Power and BB Guns
description: The House majority leader, Jim Wright of Texas, recently published ''Reflections of a Public Man,'' a collection of short essays and speeches. Here is one, ''Raw Power'':

title: MUSIC: HONEGGER'S 'JEANNE D' ARC'
description: AT least two dozen composers have attempted operatic or quasi-operatic versions of the Joan of Arc story, the best-known among them being Verdi and Tchaikovsky. Perhaps the most dramatically shrewd of these essays is Arthur Honegger's ''Jeanne d'Arc au B^ucher'' (''Joan of Arc at the Stake''), a 1938 work that the composer called an ''oratorio dramatique'' but that can be treated as a one-act opera. The Boston Symphony under Seiji Ozawa treated it just that way Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall, on a raised stage behind the orchestra, with costumes, masks, atmospheric lighting and brilliantly simple direction by Georges Wilson. It all made for gripping theater of a melodramatic sort that the French handle with special panache. Berlioz's ''Damnation of Faust,'' also an Ozawa specialty, is perhaps the finest example of this hybrid type.

title: 4 U.S. MEDICAL EXPERTS ARRIVE IN INDIA ON INVITATION
description: Four leading American experts in environmental threats have arrived here to advise Indian medical authorities on how to assess and handle the long-term consequences of the poison-gas leak at Bhopal last week.

title: Car Bomb Kills 3 At Beirut Druse Site
description: A car bomb exploded outside the Druse religious center in West Beirut today as artillery duels raged in the mountains east and southeast of here between Druse and Christian militiamen for a second day.

title: POISON DISPOSAL IS AGREED UPON
description: The poisonous methyl isocyanate that remains in storage at the Union Carbide Corporation plant here is to be neutralized by converting it into a pesticide, as happened routinely when the factory was operating normally, the Government said today.

title: CALIFORNIA'S FIRST EXECUTION IN 17 YEARS BLOCKED BY STAY
description: The California Supreme Court today blocked an execution that would have been the first in the state in 17 years.

title: COOPERBIOMEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
REGAN CRITICIZES FEDERAL RESERVE ON TIGHT CREDIT
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan charged today that Paul A. Volcker's ''remarkably tight'' management of the money supply was slowing economic growth and hurting the Christmas shopping season.

title: FAHTERS' ROLE AND INCEST
description: Fathers who take an active role in holding, feeding and diapering their daughters in their first three years of life are less likely to abuse the girls sexually later, researchers say.

title: THE IRISH QUESTION
description: To the Editor:

title: HIDING PLACES
description: MANY clever places to hide jewelry and other valuables and extra house keys are on the market. Some of them are available from the Brookstone stores, which sell a variety of clever devices for home security. One is in the form of an imitation Old Spice deodorant can ($19.95) or a Quaker State motor oil can ($14.95) that is weighted so it feels right when lifted and has a screw-on cap that reveals a hollow interior.

title: Creusot-Loire Liquidation
description: A French court today approved the liquidation of Creusot-Loire, a giant engineering company, and authorized a plan by two state-controlled concerns to take over part of its assets.

title: Leveraged Bid For Conair
description: The Conacq Corporation, a newly formed concern owned by Leandro P. Rizzuto, chairman and president of the Conair Corporation, said it had submitted a leveraged buyout merger proposal to Conair of $24.50 a share.

title: Crossroads
description: The Sheraton Centre - a favorite watering hole for politicians - is even more of a crossroads than usual this week.

title: Jokes
description: With furrowed brow and a ''there you-go-again'' smile, Jim Morris slipped effortlessly into his President Reagan impersonation to explain why the Professional Comedians Association was necessary.

title: NEW PRODUCTS, BUT HOW NEW?
description: Remember flavored ketchup? Frozen cookie dough? Liquid brown sugar, toaster pizza, low calorie cake mix? Probably not. They were among the new products that have come tumbling onto the market in record numbers in recent years. And they, like all but a few of the rest, tumbled right off again.

title: Dome Debt Pact Revision Sought
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. asked its 54 lenders to drop a requirement that it raise $265 million in new equity by Feb. 5. The requirement is part of a $3.9 billion debt restructuring agreement between the company and its lenders.

title: Priests' Group Urges Equality for Women
description: An independent group of Roman Catholic priests called Tuesday for full equality for women in the church and urged the authorities to consider the possibility of ordaining women to the priesthood.

title: IN FROM THE COLD
description: WASHINGTON Gary Hart, Democrat of Colorado, and William Cohen, Republican of Maine, were sitting around the Senate Armed Services Committee a few years ago and decided to write a spy novel.

title: BUTLER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Saluting the Troops
description: Has a computer run amok? Or are the Democrats handing out battlefield commissions to supporters of the Mondale-Ferraro ticket?

title: MURDERER ELECTROCUTED IN GEORGIA AFTER APPEALS FAIL
description: The first charge of electricity administered today to Alpha Otis Stephens in Georgia's electric chair failed to kill him, and he struggled to breathe for eight minutes before a second charge carried out his death sentence for murdering a man who interrupted a burglary.

title: THE DANCE: AILEY TRIBUTE TO DUDLEY WILLIAMS
description: THE curtain fell and then the real show began. On Tuesday night at the City Center, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater paid tribute to its leading male dancer, Dudley Williams, on the 20th anniversary of his career with the company.

title: Hendrick Is Traded
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 12 (UPI) The St. Louis Cardinals traded the outfielder George Hendrick and a minor league player to the Pittsburgh Pirates today for John Tudor, a left-handed pitcher, and Brian Harper, an outfielder-catcher.

title: Spain, U.S. Near Pact On Steel
description: Negotiations with Spain to reduce its steel exports to the United States made progress today, but talks with South Korea failed to reach agreement, a spokesman for the United States Trade Representative's Office said.

title: CRILE, ON STAND, ACCUSED OF SUBVERTING THE TRUTH
description: Comparing what was shown on the air to what was not, lawyers for Gen. William C. Westmoreland yesterday accused George Crile, the producer of a disputed CBS documentary on the Vietnam war, of using the editorial process to subvert the truth.

description: * Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. is offering $100 million of 15- year mortgage participation certificates with a 12 percent certificate rate at 99 14/32 to yield 11.79 percent, assuming payment in seven years of the underlying securities.

title: British Back Citibank Bid
description: The 10-member committee of London clearing banks has agreed that Citibank's application to become the first foreign- owned member of the group be granted as soon as possible.

title: No Immunity for Doctors' Fees
description: Should Washington regulate doctors' fees? In the Reagan Administration the issue is no longer whether but how, and that's as it should be. Physicians strenuously object, but the medical cost problem is urgent and doctors have no legitimate claim to immunity from attempts to solve it.

title: Estimate Raised On Millstone Plant
description: The estimated cost of building the Millstone III nuclear power plant has again been raised by Northeast Utilities, this time to $3.825 billion by its completion in May 1986.

title: KOCH RAISES $1.5 MILLION AT PARTY ON 60TH BIRTHDAY
description: Mayor Koch celebrated his 60th birthday yesterday with some philosophizing, lots of politicking and about $1.5 million in birthday donations from members of the city's legal, real-estate, business, financial and political establishments.

title: LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR: DOES NEW YORK NEED ONE?
description: The remarkable thing about the resignation last week of Lieut. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello was how little anyone running the state government seemed to care.

title: TOSHIBA AND WESTINGHOUSE IN VENTURE
description: The Toshiba Corporation and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation will form a venture to produce tubes for computer monitors and color televisions in a plant in New York State, officials said today.

title: Bank Rates Continue To Decline
description: Annual effective yields on money market accounts and six-month certificates of deposit continued their ninth consecutive week of decline, in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported. The Monitor's national index of money market accounts fell to 8.88 percent, from 9.01 percent, the first time the yield has been this low since last Feb. 22. The index of six-month C.D.'s declined to 9.31 percent, from 9.44 percent.

description: Sixteen subway fires broke out across the city yesterday, sending out smoke, leaving jammed trains stuck in tunnels and delaying thousands of rush-hour riders.

SIMMONS AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SURVIVAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: ESTIMATE OF ITT'S LIQUIDATION VALUE
description: When the price of shares in the ITT Corporation slumped last summer, professional investors began to circle the conglomerate and Wall Street analysts began to calculate what the company might fetch if it were liquidated.

title: CHILE WILL GET $48 MILLION LOAN
description: The Inter-American Development Bank has approved a $48 million loan for Chile to finance oil and gas exploration, improve refineries and build a gas pipeline.

title: Milwaukee Delays Pension for Widow
description: City officials declined today to take immediate action to guarantee pension benefits to the widow of a policeman who died of leukemia 14 days before she would have been entitled to the money.

title: Kenyon & Eckhardt Gets Consolidated Cigar
description: According to smoke signals received here, Kenyon & Eckhardt/ New York has become agency for what it describes as the $5 million account of Consolidated Cigar, whose major brands are Dutch Masters, El Producto and Muriel cigars, and a number of other tobacco products.

title: Save Boxing From Barbarism
description: Sugar Ray Leonard earned more than $40 million in just over four years of professional boxing. And he won 23 out of 33 victories by knockouts. Big- time boxing is about money, fame, training, technique - and brain damage. To the sport's enduring shame, the last ingredient is avoidable.

description: * Split rate, 11.25-11.50 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: RELIEF OFFICIAL ACCUSES ETHIOPIA OF 'BITING THE HAND' THAT FEEDS IT
description: The head of the United States food relief program said today that Ethiopia was ''biting the hand'' that feeds it by blaming Western nations for the extent of the famine devastating it.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, DECEMBER 13, 1984
description: International Iran indicated adamance against extradicting four men who hijacked a Kuwaiti airliner to Teheran last week and killed two Americans, according to an Iranian press account. It said the position was suggested by Prime Minister Mir Hussein Moussavi. (Page A1, Column 1.) Ethiopia is ''biting the hand'' that feeds it by blaming Western countries for the extent of the famine devastating the country, according to M. Peter McPherson, the head of the United States food relief program. Mr. McPherson defended the American relief effort, calling it the largest in the world, and charged that Ethiopian officials were not cooperating with American efforts to have huge amounts of food unloaded at ports, preferring to use their limited harbor facilities to unload cement. (A1:2-3.)

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Interest Rates Off Modestly
description: Interest rates declined modestly yesterday, with Treasury bill rates falling by about a tenth of a percentage point, while yields on notes and bonds dropped by smaller amounts.

title: Cypriot Adversaries To Meet Jan. 17
description: The United Nations announced tonight that Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot leaders had agreed after three months of indirect talks to a meeting next month to resolve their longstanding political differences.

title: Article 145824 -- No Title
description: REALITY dictates that it would be nearly impossible to renovate and decorate a Manhattan studio apartment - floor to ceiling, door to windows - for only $2,000.

title: EAGLES' MOVE BELIEVED NEAR
description: Although the Philadelphia Eagles continued to insist that no final decision had been made, there were strengthened indications yesterday that Leonard Tose, their owner, was prepared to move them to Phoenix, perhaps in less than a week.

title: State Gets U.S. Aid to Ease L.I. Expressway Congestion
description: The Federal Government has given New York State $12.5 million to help halt traffic congestion on a section of the Long Island Expressway in Queens, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said today.

title: Patent Office Chief Resigns
description: Gerald J. Mossinghoff submitted his resignation today as Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks and Assistant Secretary of Commerce, effective Jan. 19. He is to become president of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, which is based in Washington.

title: BELL PETROLEUM SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ADVERTISING ; Addendum
description: * The Caldwell/Reingold Group has been named Reingold Advertising after the resignation of Wallace Caldwell.

title: POSTAL SERVICE TO INCREASE RATE FOR LETTER TO 22/
description: The chairman of the Postal Service board of governors announced today that the postage on a first-class domestic letter would rise to 22 cents on Feb. 17 and said that future increases might be necessary because labor costs ''are now completely beyond our control.''

title: Chicago Mayor Returns Cr eche to City Hall
description: The Nativity scene that was removed from City Hall after several non-Christian religious groups objected to it will be back on display this week, the Mayor's office announced Tuesday.

title: Heaps of Important People
description: Sir Oliver and Lady Wright are

title: CRAFT EXHIBITIONS FOR HOLIDAY GIFTS
description: -DESIGNED fabrics, glass, toys and handmade books are among the offerings at a selection of craft shows and sales around New York City, Westchester County and Connecticut.

title: BIG STAKE IN CROWN IS SOUGHT
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation, a large paper and forest products concern, last night said it had been notified by Sir James Goldsmith, the British industrialist, that an investment company he heads intends to buy enough stock to give it 15 to 25 percent of Crown's outstanding shares.

title: Commuter Air Crash Hurts Three at Miami
description: A small commuter plane crashed tonight as it approached Miami International Airport for a landing, injuring the three people aboard, officials said.

title: QUOTATIONS OF THE DAY
description: ''I filed March of 1984 for Social Security and I'm just getting a run-around-I'm not getting anything at all.

title: ELEGANT GLASS MADE BY MASTERS
description: An exhibition by the Japanese glass artist Fujita and the American glass artist Michael Glancy at the Heller Gallery offers an example of glass techniques put to different uses. This is Fujita's first show in New York, but for some years now his elegant glass boxes have been widely known.

title: BYRD RE-ELECTED MINORITY LEADER
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia easily brushed aside the challenge of Senator Lawton Chiles of Florida today and was re-elected as the Democratic leader in the Senate.

title: Dr.J.J.Panzarella Jr., L. I. Hospital Official
description: Dr. Joseph J. Panzarella Jr., director of physical medicine and rehabilitation at the Brunswick Hospital Center in Amityville, L.I., died of a heart attack Sunday at St. Charles Hospital in Port Jefferson, L.I. He was 65 years old and lived in Setauket, L.I.

title: EAGLE FANS VENT RAGE AT A MOVE
description: For Philadelphians, The Daily News said it all. A giant-size ''Boooo!'' dominated the top half of the newspaper's front page.

title: OFFICIALS TELL A HOUSE HEARING THAT PLANT IN WEST VIRGINIA IS SAFE
description: The Union Carbide site in Insitute, W. Va., that makes the same chemical as the one that killed 2,000 people in India is a ''safe plant,'' the head of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration said in Congressional testimony today.

title: Colombia Unit Of G.M. Ailing BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 12
description: The General Motors

title:
GARDENING;
SIGNS THAT INDOOR PLANTS ARE AILING
description: AILING plants send clear distress signals that can help indoor gardeners detect problems early. Key signposts are the newest leaves, the oldest leaves and the soil's surface.

title: PACE OF EXECUTIONS IN U.S. QUICKENS
description: When Alpha Otis Stephens went to the electric chair in Georgia yesterday, he became the 22d prisoner executed in this country in the last 12 months. Since Dec. 14, 1983, more than twice as many Americans have paid the death penalty as in in the previous 20 years.

title: Gen. Vessey to Visit China
description: Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has accepted an invitation to visit China early next year. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger was in Peking in 1983. General Vessey's trip is believed to be the first by a chairman of the Joint Chiefs to China.

title: CARTWRIGHT TO UNDERGO SURGERY ON FOOT
description: Bill Cartwright, the Knick center who has yet to play this season because of a broken bone in his left foot, will undergo a surgical procedure tomorrow that will probably force him to miss the rest of the season.

title: Margeotes Additions
description: Three new accounts have arrived within the last few days at Margeotes, Fertitta & Weiss. They are Oxford Industries' Merona Sport, makers of apparel for the whole family, whose former agency was Don Wise Advertising; Hearst's Harper's Bazaar magazine, formerly with Geers Gross Advertising, and Villeroy & Boch for both its tabletop division and bathroom fixture and tile division, formerly handled by the William B. Johns agency and the Siesel Company, respectively.

title: PENTAGON OFFERS A LIMITED SAVING IN 1986 SPENDING
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger proposed limited savings in military spending today as pressure grew within the Reagan Administration for a one-year delay in the military buildup.

title: CHRISTMAS COOKIES? CASH? OR A MINK? THE ANNUAL TIP
description: DALE BURG would love to know something about her neighbors, something she says she would never dare to ask. She drops oblique hints, hoping they will volunteer a fact or two. She wonders about them when they're not around and glances at them as they walk by. But she doesn't say a thing.

title: Greater Role Asked for Ex-Im Bank
description: A Presidential task force today called for a sharp expansion in activity of the Export-Import Bank, even though President Reagan's budgetary marching orders seek retrenchment.

title: Drive Against Illiteracy
description: RARELY does a public service advertising campaign come along that the media, ad agencies and advertisers can support with as much enlightened self-interest as the one introduced yesterday by the Advertising Council.

title: HANDLING 'GROWTH RECESSION'
description: Fourteen years ago, as the American economy dawdled, an economics professor, Solomon Fabricant, coined the term ''growth recession'' to describe a period in which the economy slows dramatically but keeps sputtering forward. While the economy was still growing, he suggested, the decline in the rate of expansion could seem almostas traumatic as an outright contraction.

title: RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including an extratordinary credit of $1,898,000, or 29 cents a share.

title: DIXICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
N.C.A.A. Meeting
description: A select group of university presidents, in hopes of reversing what one of them calls a ''worsening and unacceptable'' level of academic and recruitment cheating in college athletic programs, is calling a special meeting of N.C.A.A. schools for next summer. John Ryan , president of Indiana University and chairman of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 44-member Presidents Commission, said the meeting was scheduled for June 20-21 in New Orleans and would deal with finances and institutional integrity.

title: ITT INQUIRY ON LIQUIDATION REPORTS
description: The ITT Corporation is investigating a series of events in recent weeks that may have been orchestrated from within the company to promote the notion that disgruntled shareholders and board members were seeking to liquidate the company, according to sources close to the inquiry.

title: Product Introductions
description: Product introductions in the areas of grocery products and health and beauty aids continued strong in November after a lusty comeback in October, the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News has reported.

title: HOW TO SPOT A FAKE BEHIND A STETHOSCOPE
description: To the Editor:

title: Datapoint Seeks To Thwart Bid
description: The Datapoint Corporation notified its 8,500 employees that it had hired an investment banking firm to come up with ways to avoid a takeover bid by Asher Edelman, a New York investor. Datapoint's chief executive officer, Harold O'Kelley, and president, Edward Gistaro, sent out a letter to the workers explaining Datapoint's move to thwart Mr. Edelman.

title: RAPPAPORT'S PLOY IRKS HOLMES
description: ''Get the smeller.''

title: OUR TOWNS
description: Hello? What's this? A fan?

title: Craft Lofted After 13 Delays
description: A weather and search-and-rescue satellite was rocketed into space today after 13 postponements. Since the first attempt on Nov. 8, high winds forced cancellation of eight launching attempts.

title: ONLY THE HIGHEST CHALLENGES
description: The place on the tax return where

title: American Healthcare Notes
description: American Healthcare Management is offering $80 million of 15 percent subordinated debentures due in 2004 at a price of 100 through Drexel Burnham Lambert.

title: Thrift Unit Backed On Tie to K Mart
description: A savings and loan association broke no Florida banking law by offering money market accounts and certificates of deposit through the K Mart Corporation department stores, a state appeal court said. The First District Court of Appeal's opinion went against the State of Florida, the Department of Banking and Finance and State Comptroller Gerald Lewis.

title: CALIFORNIA PIONEERS: ADVENTUROUS NEW HOUSES
description: LOS ANGELES EVEN the avid roller skaters pulsing their way to music down the nearby skate path stop and take off their earphones to look at the unusual lifeguard tower. Unlike the other towers on the beach in Venice, Calif., this one is part of a private beach house designed by the Los Angeles architect Frank Gehry. With exposed steel struts, unpainted plywood, wood panels and outrigging, the room is a type of pop sculpture that sums up the casualness of the chic but scruffy beach town.

title: SCORING MARK FOR MULLIN
description: Chris Mullin, one of the most celebrated athletes in St. John's history, became the school's career leading scorer tonight when he had 20 points in a 77-51 victory over Davidson.

title: FOREST CITY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including net gains on the sale of properties of $715,000 for the quarter and $1,104,000 for the 9 months. c-After a loss of $603,000 for the quarter and a gain of $2,189,000 for the 9 months from the sale of properties.

title: Husband Shoots Man at Service
description: A jealous husband entered a Jehovah's Witness service Tuesday at 9:15 P.M. and shot a man who he believed was having an affair with his wife, the police said.

title: ART CARNEY AS SANTA IN ABC HOLIDAY SPECIAL
description: WHAT, their fans might wonder, are Art Carney and Jaclyn Smith doing in an odd little television movie entitled ''The Night They Saved Christmas''? Well, holiday specials can sometimes become what the trade likes to call classics. One can always hope, of course, but the longevity potential for this particular bit of whimsy, on ABC at 8 tonight, would seem limited.

title: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $881,000 for the quarter and $3,343,000 for the 9 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $377,000 and a gain of $23.5 million on the disposal of County Seat Stores Inc.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: INSIDER STORY If you have wondered what goes on in the White House, forget those dreary tomes and documents and hurry over to the Dog Museum of America, off the lobby in 51 Madison Avenue, at 26th Street (696-8350). The museum's exhibition, ''Presidential Pets: Finny, Feathered and Furry Friends in the White House,'' is waiting to give you the inside story.

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $33,210,000. c-After a loss of $53 million from discontinued operations.

title: GOLDWATER IS URGED BY REAGAN TO BACK MX MISSILE PROGRAM
description: President Reagan met today with Senator Barry Goldwater and urged the Arizona Republican who is expected to become the new Armed Services Committee chairman to support funds for the MX missile.

title: SURTAX BURDENS BANKS
description: To the Editor:

title: VIDEO SCREEN FOR DASHBOARD
