description: COMPUTER technology in automobiles has come a long way, sparked by the need for fuel efficiency through precise engine controls. Those under-the-hood electronics are of interest primarily to engineers, but now the microchip is being pressed into service in new ways that are liable to excite even the sometime driver.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Barber-Greene Co., Aurora, Ill., has named Robert C. Johnson, president and chief executive, to the additional post of chairman.

title: SLEEP-AWAY SKI CAMPS FOR YOUNGSTERS
description: FOR children who want to ski but parents who do not, one solution can be a winter ski camp where youngsters from novice to expert can go during school vacations to learn or improve skills.

title: CUTTING REGULATORY TAPE
description: The regulatory maze must be reduced, and there is a handy way to do so.

title: Wilson's Appeal Is Denied
description: The Supreme Court has refused to hear the appeal of Edwin P. Wilson, a former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency, who contended he had been unfairly convicted of illegally selling 20 tons of plastic explosives to the Government of Libya. The Justices, without comment, let stand the conviction Tuesday, along with its 20-year sentence and $145,000 fine. Mr. Wilson had contended he was denied a fair trial because he was blocked from introducing two witnesses.

title: U.S. COMPANIES BOLSTER ANTI-APARTHEID CODE
description: About 120 American companies that operate in South Africa agreed yesterday to press for broad changes in South African society, including the repeal of all apartheid laws.

title: A SNOWFLAKE WEIGHS HEAVILY ON FIFITH AVENUE
description: THE problem with the ''snowflake'' of lights suspended at the intersection of Fifth Avenue and 57th Street is not that it is not pretty, although it is true that you have to move a block or so away before its ugly web of supporting wires disappears and the array of 6,000 tiny bulbs seems to be floating magically in midair. But even when you do step back and see it properly, the snowflake has an odd grossness to it; it is big enough to fill the intersection, but that is big indeed for a snowflake, or for an arrangement of lights intended to suggest delicacy, precision and grace.

title: U.S. REFUSES TO GIVE PLANNED PARENTHOOD A $17 MILLION GRANT
description: The Agency for International Development refused today to renew funding of $17 million a year for the private International Planned Parenthood Federation, citing the group's financing of abortion- related services overseas.

title: DISPLAY OF ANCIENT ART AT MET
description: In the 19th century, the Ancient Near East was thought to be something of a promised land. Western archeologists, artists and even private collectors were lured there in the hope of finding information about Biblical figures like Abraham, who was known to have come from Ur, in ancient Mesopotamia. But while their aim was to document biblical truth, they discovered instead one of the world's great cultures.

title: INTRODUCING, THE PENNANT
description: He had been down on the field at Shea Stadium, wearing a uniform shirt with 8 on the back for the photographers. But now, wearing a brown pin-striped, three- piece suit and a brown tie with thin white stripes, The Pennant strolled into the Diamond Club for his introduction and inquisition as the Mets' new catcher. At first, the temptation had been to identify Gary Carter as The World Series Ring, but the Detroit Tigers deserve more respect than that. For starters, The Pennant is enough of an alias, especially since he agrees that the National League pennant is possible, if not likely.

title: Head of Muse Air Plans Drive Despite Sale Sign
description: Sam Coats does not sound like the president and chief operating officer of a beleaguered company that has just been put up for sale.

title: COOPER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $2,222,000 for the quarter and a gain of $2,265,000 for the year from discontinued operations and gains of $4.7 million for the quarter and $84.5 million for the year from the sale of discontinued operations. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $9,860,000 for the quarter and $27,387,000 for the year.

title: Holders Back Bid For Security Life
description: Shareholders of the Security Life Insurance Company of Georgia approved the $51.3 million acquisition of the company by an insurance affiliate of Tenneco Inc., both companies said.

title: DIGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $340,000.

title: SAM LOPRESTI
description: Sam LoPresti, a former Chicago Black Hawk goalie who once made a record 80 saves in a game, died Tuesday at the age of 67.

title: SOME CENTERS IN THE NORTHEAST
Sindona's Trial Is in Absentia
description: Michele Sindona, the Italian financier, agreed today to be tried in absentia after he did not show up in court for the second day of his fraud trial.

title: BILLS ON JERSEY STADIUM ARE BACKED AT HEARING
description: Legislation that would pave the way for bringing major-league baseball to New Jersey moved closer to passage by the Legislature today following a public hearing that produced no major obstacles to enactment.

title: EVENTS: ARTISTRY IN TIN
description: Marriage Milestones: 10th Wedding

title: PLANT HAD TO BE LOCALLY DESIGNED AND OPERATED
description: The Union Carbide Corporation was required by Indian law to design, engineer, build and operate its Bhopal chemical plant with local labor, materials, machines and staff unless the company could prove to the Indian authorities that local resources were unavailable, trade and legal sources said yesterday.

title: DIRECT ACTION MARKETING reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SOME ATTRACTIVE NEW VOLUMES LOOK FORWARD, OTHERS BACK
description: IN the last few years, decorating

title: ANIXTER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a gain of $69,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Vanguard Plans New Mutual Fund
description: The Vanguard Group, a manager of mutual funds, expects to offer a new $200 million closed-end common stock mutual fund that will be divided into separate classes of income shares and capital shares.

title: Dr. Frank A. Geldard, ProfessorofPsychology
description: Dr. Frank A. Geldard, professor emeritus of psychology at Princeton University and a former adviser to the North Atlantic Treaty Orgnization, died Saturday at his home in Princeton. He was 80 years old.

title: PRIVATE AID TO LATIN REBELS AT ISSUE
description: There is mounting concern at the State Department and the Central Intelligence Agency about the involvement of private American citizens in Nicaraguan rebel operations, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: The Quickest Knockout
description: At the instant the bell sounded for the first round of a cruiserweight bout in Atlantic City on Tuesday night, Rickey Parkey stepped swiftly across the ring. Then, while his opponent, Broderick Mason , was beginning to set himself to ward off an opening jab, Parkey unleashed a single, overhand right that sent Mason sprawling face-down onto the canvas and put Parkey in the record books.

title: CAUTIOUS VIEW ON FAST FOOD
description: MICHAEL CULP, the restaurant analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities, believes in on-the-spot research. He eats, on average, five meals a week at fast-food outlets, which gives him a chance to compare menu pricing, talk to store managers and, of course, sample the hamburgers, fried chicken, codfish cakes and other items on the bill of fare. ''It's fun,'' he said, ''although I could stand to lose a little weight.''

title: KOCH CRITICIZES CUOMO'S LOGIC OVER ABORTION
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the logic behind Governor Cuomo's support for legalized abortion and opposition to the death penalty was ''flawed'' and inconsistent.

title: Edwards Food Stores To Hill, Holliday
description: The New York office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, a Boston agency, is going to be doing advertising for the Edwards Food Warehouse Connecticut division of First National Supermarkets.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: ISLANDERS LOSE
description: The Islanders, short on fortune the last eight days, were best tonight when they were short-handed. But despite two short-handed goals by Mike Bossy, they suffered a 4-3 loss to the Pittsburgh Penguins - their fourth straight and second in two nights.

title: BARRY FARRELL
description: Barry Farrell, a former columnist at Life magazine, died Monday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in West Los Angeles, Calif. He was 49 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: South Africa Steel Curb
description: South Africa may extend its voluntary restraint on steel exports to the United States to five years from three years, a Government spokesman said today. Under American pressure, South Africa has cut such exports by 22 percent, to 5.5 million tons, for the year ending next March 31.

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NANKIN EXPRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
WEST POINT-PEPPERELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
FARMERS' LAND REALLY THEIRS AS TITLE TROUBLE IS RESOLVED
description: Twenty-five people who had bought and settled on farmland in northwest Ohio received clear deeds today to the land, which was owned by the Federal Government but mistakenly sold by the state in 1834.

title: Offer by Strategic Mortgage Priced
description: The initial public offering of Strategic Mortgage Investments was announced yesterday at a price of $20 a share through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: VIOLATION OF RIGHTS CHARGED
description: Holding a copy of the New Testament, Emmanuel Torres stood before a judge yesterday and was told he had been indicted on charges that he stabbed to death a drama student, Caroline Isenberg, on the roof of her West End Avenue building.

title: Land Fraud Of $2 Billion
description: Two men have pleaded guilty to bilking thousands of investors in the Netherlands out of as much as $2 billion in what the prosecutor called the largest land fraud in United States history.

title: OIL PRICES CONTINUE DROPPING
description: Oil prices dropped again yesterday, some to their lowest level of the year, as speculation mounted that oil- producing nations would be forced to lower their prices again.

title: A LEGAL EAGLE'S LEGAL EAGLE
description: William C. Bryson decribes himself as a man who spends his time ''putting pieces of paper between red covers.'' But to his superiors at the Justice Department, who have selected him as this year's recipient of the top departmental employee honor, Mr. Bryson is actually a one-man appellate section.

title: Bach Series at Carnegie
description: Three major choral works by Bach - the St. John Passion, the St. Matthew Passion and the B minor Mass - will be presented in April during the Easter holiday season at Carnegie Hall. The series begins with the St. John Passion on April 3, followed by the St. Matthew Passion on April 6 and the B minor Mass on April 7. Soloists are Chris Merritt, Jorma Hynninen, Elly Ameling, Paul Esswood, John Aler, John Cheek, Sylvia McNair and Kathryn Bouleyn.

title: UNBEATEN IONA POSTS SIXTH VICTORY, 72-60
description: Iona, after squandering a 14-point first-half lead, overtook St. Francis of Brooklyn and scored a 72-60 victory tonight. It was the sixth victory for the unbeaten Gaels. The loss was the sixth for the Terriers since they won their opener.

title: PARENTS FAULTED ON DISCIPLINE
description: A failure to discipline children is seen as the major fault of parents today, and child neglect is the next most serious failing, according to a recent poll of American adults by the Gallup Organization.

title: Topics ; Endangered Species ; Plain Miracles
description: ''Trying to preserve the California condor,'' we observed a few years ago, ''is like trying to reform the unrepentant.'' At the time the number of condors, big, ungainly birds, was down to about 20.

title: U.N. CHIEF WARNS NUCLEAR POWERS
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, in a major address to the General Assembly, criticized the nuclear superpowers today for allowing an ''ideological confrontation'' to ''jeopardize the future of humanity.''

title: A.T.& T. REACHES OUT FOR A NEW MONOPOLY
description: To the Editor:

title: Singer Contract
description: The Singer Company received a $133 million Navy contract for six simulator devices for Apache helicopters, the Defense Department said. In addition, the Martin Marietta Corporation was given a $56.5 million contract from the Air Force to provide ground support equipment for space shuttle launch facilities.

title: STRANGE ENCOUNTERS OF THE POST-ELECTION KIND
description: The fallout from the Nov. 6 election, which still lingers over this city, has had a strange effect on political behavior here. Democrats' efforts to repair the damage to their party is as baffling to some as the way Republicans are reacting to President Reagan's landslide victory.

title: 2d Union at Yale To Open Talks
description: Yale University's blue-collar workers, who for 10 weeks honored the picket lines of the school's striking clerical and technical workers, will begin talks Thursday on their own new contract. The two-year pact expires Jan. 19.

title: U.S. Frees Brothel Owner
description: Joe Conforte, owner of the Mustang Ranch brothel, was released from Federal prison Monday after serving a reduced sentence under the Federal witness protection program for tax evasion. He had a five- year sentence shortened to 15 months in exchange for testimony in the bribery trial of Federal District Judge Harry Claiborne of Las Vegas, Nev., who was found guilty at a second trial of two counts of income tax cheating.

title: SINATRA TO COLLABORATE ON TV PROJECT
description: Frank Sinatra will collaborate on the production of a six-hour television mini- series chronicling his rise from the streets of Hoboken, N.J., to the top rungs of show business, Warner Brothers Television said today.

title: 1,800 U.N. Employees Strike For an Hour Over Pay Issue
description: About 1,800 United Nations civil servants left their jobs for an hour today to protest a budget-cutting move, backed by the United States and the Soviet Union, that would suspend a scheduled cost-of-living allowance.

title: Verdict for the Defense
description: When they were recruiting the outstanding defensive lineman Bruce Smith , Virginia Tech coaches brought him to the Blacksburg campus more times than the rules allow and gave his father a load of firewood to take back home to Norfolk. When the National Collegiate Athletic Association uncovered those and other recruiting infractions in May, 1983, Virginia Tech was placed on a year's probation, and Smith, along with seven teammates, was banned from postseason play.

title: Salvador Troops to Join in Truce
description: The Government said today that it would join a holiday cease-fire announced by leftist guerrillas.

title: Ex-Officer at K.&E. Signs On at Warwick
description: Late last month when Kenyon & Eckhardt was announcing a bit of a corporate reorganization, Robert Fiore, who had been executive vice president and deputy director of creative services worldwide, said he was moving elsewhere, but did not disclose where.

title: JUDGE RULES OUT ISRAELI PROPOSAL FOR TRIAL DATA
description: A Federal judge informed the Israeli Government yesterday that he could not accept its proposal to provide some key information for Ariel Sharon's libel case against Time magazine.

title: KOCH SEES 'CABAL'
description: After a year of meetings, a coalition of black and Jewish leaders in New York City outlined its ''common human agenda'' yesterday. Mayor Koch immediately said the coalition's members were ''being used'' by ''a cabal'' whose primary mission was to opppose his re-election.

title: Topics ; Endangered Species ; Same Old Prague
description: ''Our greatest living poet'' is how Czechoslovakia describes the Nobel laureate Jaroslav Seifert. Prague's diplomats are amazed that Americans would swallow lurid stories about his works being unobtainable in Prague.

title: Qawi a Winner As Cruiserweight
description: Dwight Muhammad Qawi, a former World Boxing Council light-heavyweight champion fighting for the first time as a cruiserweight, scored a unanimous 10-round decision tonight over Stanley Ross.

title: MAURITANIA COUP OUSTS PRESIDENT
description: The army chief of staff of Mauritania, in northwest Africa, seized power in a bloodless coup today while the President was out of the country.

title: PANEL SAYS CHOLESTEROL LEVEL IN MANY IS DANGEROUSLY HIGH
description: In the most far-reaching public health recommendation yet made on cholesterol and heart disease, an expert panel yesterday advised dietary and other treatment for millions of Americans whose cholesterol levels have until now been considered normal by many physicians.

title: MAGNETIC TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Beatrice to Sell Three More Units
description: The Beatrice Companies said it had agreed to sell its graphic arts, agri-products and leather operations to separate buyers for a total of about $117 million.

title: George F. Murray Dies at 55; NBCandCBSNewsProducer
description: George F. Murray, a former producer for NBC News and a former senior producer of special events for CBS News, died Saturday at his home in Mexico City, where he had lived and worked on freelance television projects since 1983. He was 55 years old.

title: SEARCH FOR A NAME NEW YORK'S NEW CONVENTION CENTER ENDS IN 'JAVITS'
description: The organization that is building New York City's convention center voted yesterday to name it for former Senator Jacob K. Javits.

title: OFFICERS' UNION RUNS ADS BACKING ACTION OF POLICE IN BUMPURS CASE
description: The union that represents the city's police officers has started an advertising campaign to counteract what it says is unfair criticism of the police action that led to the fatal shooting of a Bronx woman during an eviction dispute.

title: PALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
CHINESE OFFICIAL ON VISIT TO U.S. IS FOUND HANGED
description: The body of a Chinese official on a brief working visit to New York was found hanging yesterday morning from a cable on the roof of the Chinese Consulate General in Manhattan, the police said.

title: DIAGNOSIS-RELATED SYSTEM WILL CUT COSTS
description: To the Editor:

title: TET OF PANEL'S AGENDA
description: Following is the text of a statement by the coalition of blacks and Jews on its efforts to repair the split between the two groups:

title: Dream Scenario Fades for Todd
description: The scenario could have been almost dreamlike: Richard Todd, in his first return to the New York area since the Jets traded him to New Orleans after last season, arrives at the Meadowlands this Saturday and quarterbacks the Saints to a victory that helps to knock the Giants out of the playoff picture.

title: Jet's Landing Gear Fails on Taxiway
description: The landing gear of an American Airlines DC-10 jetliner with 209 people aboard collapsed before takeoff yesterday at Kennedy International Airport. There were no injuries.

title: FEWER VICTIMS APPEAR AT BHOPAL'S HOSPITALS
description: Fewer victims of the leak of toxic gas last week are appearing at the city's hospitals, but officials and physicians, having settled a brief strike by junior doctors and medical students, expressed renewed concern today about continuing respiratory problems.

title: CORRECTION
description: -series ''Fatal Vision'' misstated the title of another mini-series based on a Herman Wouk novel. It was ''The Winds of War.''

title: Wyoming Conviction Upheld
description: The Wyoming Supreme Court, by a vote of 3 to 2, today upheld the conviction of Deborah Jahnke, 19 years old, who helped her brother kill their father for what the two children said was a lifetime of abuse.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: DEATH OF A UNICORN. By Peter Dickinson. 206 pages. Pantheon. $13.95.

title: BERTHA CASE
description: Bertha Case, who was the literary representative of the estates of Kurt Weill and of Bertolt Brecht, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. She was 75 years old and lived in New York.

title: MORGUARD BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
F.C.C. TO RECONSIDER TV STATION OWNERSHIP
description: The Federal Communications Commission announced yesterday that next Wednesday it will reconsider its regulation governing the number of television stations that can be owned by a single company. The result of this deliberation is already widely anticipated. A new ruling is expected, that will allow a single company to own television stations that reach a total of no more than 25 percent of the nation's viewers, Congressional sources said.

title: Borg Unit to Shut
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation said its Borg-Warner Ltd. transmission division will close its plant at Kenfig, South Wales, by March 1986. The plant, which makes automatic transmissions for auto makers in Europe, has about 750 employees. Borg-Warner, which is based in Chicago, attributed the planned closing to shrinking demand for transmissions as auto producers build their own plants in France and Germany.

title: Norway Trade Surplus
description: Norway's foreign trade surplus grew to $420 million in November, up 17.3 percent from a year earlier, the Government said today. Exports were $1.64 billion, imports $1.22 billion.

title: CORRECTION
description: A news analysis article in Metropolitan Report last Friday, about the choice of a Chief Judge of the New York State Court of Appeals, incompletely described the history of the competition. Until 1978, when the office was changed from elective to appointive, it was largelyuncontested, with one notable exception. In 1973, Charles D. Breitel defeated Jacob D. Fuchsberg in a hard-fought contest.

title: IOWANS FEAR LOSS OF STATE'S 'VOICE'
description: Bill Reichardt, the owner of a local clothing store, is outspokenly worried about the pending sale of The Des Moines Register, a newspaper Mr. Reichardt and many others here call a state resource almost as important as Iowa's fertile soil.

title: OUT-OF-TOWNERS CITE CONCERN ABOUT POOR IN HELPING NEEDIEST
description: Among the contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund each year are many out-of-towners who have never lived in New York but feel that they know the city and its problems through an occasional visit.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1984 International Masses of Indians fled Bhopal after an announcement that the Union Carbide plant there would be started up again Sunday to neutralize what remains of a toxic chemical that leaked Dec. 3 and killed at least 2,000 people. By the tens of thousands and using any vehicle available, the residents left, abandoning jobs and homes, crippling many services and activities. (Page A1, Column 1.) Masses of Ethiopians were carried from the famine-stricken northern areas to more fertile lands in the west and south. An armada of buses, trucks and Soviet helicopters and troop transport planes is carrying tens of thousands of hungry, destitute peasants at the start of a huge resettlement program. (A12:3-6.)

title: African Suffering Seen In Population Fund Cut
description: A former official of the International Planned Parenthood Federation said yesterday that the Reagan Administration's refusal to grant $17 million to the federation would hurt efforts to control population throughout Africa, particularly in such famine-stricken areas as Ethiopia.

title: Smith in Dispute
description: Bruce Smith, Virginia Tech's star lineman, was in Shreveport, La., yesterday preparing for tomorrow's Independence Bowl game against Air Force, but lawyers for the National Collegiate Athletic Association were trying to find a way around a Virginia court order that has cleared Smith to play in the game. He was banned from postseason play when the N.C.A.A. determined in 1983 that Virginia Tech coaches violated recruiting rules in inducing him to enroll there as a freshman four years ago.

title: OIL SHARING'S ADVERSE MARKET IMPACT
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Messiah,' Other Oratorios Today
description: Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West 57th

title: CALIBRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the discontinuance of the G. D. Ritzy's Restaurant business.

title: DEAD YOUTH'S LOVE OF GAME REMEMBERED
description: The family and friends of a teen-ager who died Wednesday night of a hockey injury gathered today to remember a young man whose life, they said, revolved around the game.

title: Friday GAMES AND FANCIFUL TIN
description: Game boards hang on the walls and whimsical objects of tin are on view in two shows that open Friday and run through March 3 at the Museum of American Folk Art, 125 West 55th Street. The game boards - more than 100 painted with dazzling colors - were handmade, mostly in the 19th century, in the United States or Canada. There's a parcheesi board with a painting of the Vermont craftsman's own home, trompe l'oeil paintings and a ''Trip Around the World'' game whose decorations include a mermaid, a sea serpent and a dungeon. The tin show consists of 19th- century gifts for 10th wedding anniversaries - some 50 lighthearted shapes, including a witch's hat, a huge pocket watch, a two-foot-tall saltshaker and a life-size ladder-back chair. Admission: $2 ($1 for students and over- 65's). Information: 581-2474. HOLIDAY ORIGAMI

title: Money Funds Up $1.6 Billion Assets of the nation's money
description: market mutual funds are continuing to rise, climbing $1.62

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: Red and green may be the colors of the season, but the ties were strictly black on the party circuit this week. At Sotheby's, the Irvington House Institute for Medical Research held its 29th annual art and antiques auction. The evening raised $250,000 to support research on diseases involving the body's immune system at Rockefeller University and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

title: Mellon Ends 83 Bank Deal
description: Officials of the Mellon Bank Corporation have agreed to terminate a 1983 agreement to acquire the Heritage Bancorporation.

title: REAGAN INDICATES PENTAGON SAVINGS WILL BE NARROWED
description: A senior Administration official said this evening that President Reagan has indicated he will accept only limited savings in the military budget.

title: Museum by Candlelight
description: A candlelight tour is planned tonight from 5:30 to 8 P.M. at the Abigail Adams Smith Museum, 421 East 61st Street.

title: VALUE LINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BEATRICE CHEMICAL UNIT TO I.C.I. FOR $750 MILLION
description: As part of its effort to return to its roots as a food and consumer products company, the Beatrice Companies announced today that it had signed a definitive agreement to sell its chemical operations to Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. of London for $750 million in cash.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: NEW restaurants in New York City generally fall into one of two categories: those where the owner can be seen loitering at the front door for the first few weeks, wistfully scanning the street for customers; and the rarer species, where patrons storm the dining room the minute the door opens as if the restaurant were giving away Cabbage Patch Dolls. Indochine, recently opened near Astor Place in Greenwich Village, falls into the latter category, despite the absence of even a sign outside. Rather than dolls, however, Indochine offers a cheerful, smart decor, the chance to rub napkins with the city's rakish art crowd and some invigorating food from Southeast Asia.

title: Judge Bars Loan Plan Of Storage Technology
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge today rejected a $140 million loan deal aimed at keeping the Storage Technology Corporation in business, but left the door open for lawyers to return with a similar plan.

title: MAYOR IS HOPEFUL ON KEEPING EAGLES
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode said his cabinet members met with Leonard Tose today, and the Mayor was hopeful that Tose, the owner of the Philadelphia Eagles, would accept one of two city-arranged loan packages to keep the team from moving to Phoenix.

title: NOVEMBER RETAIL SALES ROSE 1.8%
description: Early Christmas shoppers helped push retail sales up 1.8 percent in November for the sharpest gain in seven months, the Government reported today.

title: Thon Is Back
description: Dickie Thon of the Houston Astros, making his first appearance since being struck in the head by a pitch last April, hit a three-run homer last night in a Puerto Rican Winter League game in San Juan. Thon, a 26- year-old shortstop, knocked a fastball over the left-field fence more that 350 feet away at Hiram Bithhorn Stadium to lead the San Juan Metros to a 6-2 victory over the Ponce Lions.

title: CORRESPONDENT IS UNDER ATTACK AT SHARON TRIAL
description: Time magazine's chief of correspondents testified yesterday that a correspondent who worked on a disputed article about Ariel Sharon had previously been put on probation.

title: Intel Foresees Drop in Earnings
description: The Intel Corporation said its fourth-quarter earnings would probably be about half the 40 cents a share that it earned in the period a year earlier. The company, which makes memory and microprocessor parts and systems, said its near-term business outlook ''has continued to deteriorate.''

title: NEW SHELLS COULD DOUBLE AS NEUTRON BOMBS
description: The Army's new nuclear artillery shells could be converted into neutron bombs, according to sources in Congress and the Pentagon.

title: ARCO PAYS $22.5 MILLION TO SETTLE SUIT
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company today agreed to pay $22.5 million to settle charges brought against it by the State of California and the City of Long Beach.

title: Centennial for a Library On the Lower East Side
description: ''Freie Bibliothek u. Lesenhalle'' is

title: LEAVES FOR CHILD CARE STUDIED
description: The problem of families in which both parents hold jobs and care for young children, a situation increasing nationwide, has brought together some of the most eminent authorities on child care in a new panel called the Yale Bush Center Advisory Committee on Infant Care Leave. The group held its first meeting in New York earlier this week.

title: FREE BELIZE HOLDS FIRST VOTE TODAY
description: This tiny nation, a haven of calm amid the turmoil of Central America, holds general elections Friday, the first since independence three years ago. By regional standards, it has been an uneventful campaign.

title: Counterattack
description: Bob Arum, the boxing promoter, referring to last week's attack on the sport by the American Medical Association, ridiculed the A.M.A.'s call for the abolition of boxing. ''It's a very safe issue, it diverts people's attention from how few people can afford medical care and from how few doctors there are in this country,'' said Arum. ''There'll be more fatalities in Harlem in one day because of inadequate medical care than there are in 20 years of boxing.''

title: EUGENE F. LAYDEN
description: Eugene F. Layden, an outfielder who played three games for the New York Yankees in 1915 and is believed to have been among the oldest former members of the team, died here Wednesday. Mr. Layden was 90 years old. With the Yankees, he went to bat seven times and had two hits. Mr. Layden never played for any other major league team. He was later employed as a supervisor for a Pittsburgh city park until his retirement.

title: 'Winnie Ille Pu', in Latin, Is Reprinted Yet Again
description: Another book went back for reprinting this week: ''Winnie Ille Pu,'' a Latin version of A. A. Milne's ''Winnie the Pooh.'' E. P. Dutton ordered 2,500 additional copies, bringing the total to 12,500 since the book was reprinted in September. All this comes 24 years after ''Pu'' was originally published in the United States, then became probably the only book in any foreign language to land on The Times best seller list.

title: Article 150568 -- No Title
description: The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today proposed fining the owner of the Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant $80,000 because of an Aug. 21 accident that allowed 200,000 gallons of water to leak onto the floor of the building that contains the reactor.

title: 4 Army Men Killed in Crash Near Foggy Field in Virginia
description: All four servicemen aboard an Army airplane died Wednesday when it crashed in woods near Washington while trying to land at an airfield shrouded in fog, the authorities said.

title: ADDING TO HOMELESS
description: To the Editor:

title: E.P.A. RAISES DUMP ESTIMATE
description: The program to clean up toxic waste dumps could eventually cost $11.7 billion in its present form and possibly twice that much, the Environmental Protection Agency told Congress Wednesday.

title: NU-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MAVERICK BRITON CUTTING A SWATH IN U.S. DEALINGS
description: Just what is Sir James Goldsmith, the secretive British millionaire, up to now?

title: IN-HOSPITAL SURGERY TO BE REDUCED BY CONTRACTS TO SAVE ON MEDICARE
description: Over the next two years, according to a new Federal estimate, 1.4 million Americans will be treated in doctors' offices, or not at all, for medical problems that until now would have meant admission to a hospital.

title: North Castle Partners Wins Additional Clients
description: North Castle Partners of Greenwich, Conn., a subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc., announced yesterday that it had won three new clients, who it will be billing between $8 million and $10 million.

title: OUR CONSTRUCTIVE ENGAGEMENT WITH MOSCOW
description: To the Editor:

title: STEWART & STEVENSON SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net losses. Results for the latest periods include recoverable income taxes of $3,779,000, or 82 cents a share, relating to the company's domestic international sales corporation.

title: Quintet at Sweet Basil
description: The saxophonists Frank Foster and Frank Wess are leading a quintet tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.. There is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: CHINESE OFFICIAL SAYS DEAD MAN SOUGHT ASYLUM
description: An official at the Chinese Consulate General in Manhattan said yesterday that the Chinese citizen who was found dead on the consulate's roof had sought asylum in the United States, but that he had come to regret his decision in the hours before he committed suicide.

title: THE SCREEN: 'PASSAGE TO INDIA,' BY DAVID LEAN
description: AFTER watching the first public performance of Santha Rama Rau's dramatization of his ''Passage to India'' at Oxford in 1960, E. M. Forster, then 81 years old, walked onto the stage to express his pleasure with the performance.

title: ART: WHISTLER PAINTINGS ON DISPLAY AT KNOEDLER
description: WITH the recent Whistler shows at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Freer Gallery in Washington, and now with ''Notes, Harmonies and Nocturnes'' at Knoedler, 19 East 70 Street, there is no excuse for not knowing almost everything there is to know about this artist. Everything, of course, includes the fact that he was born 150 years ago in Lowell, Mass., failed to graduate from West Point, worked briefly for the United States Coastal Survey and, upon inheriting money from his father, went to Paris never to return, living most of his life in London.

title: ETHIOPIA MOVING 1.5 MILLION PEOPLE FROM FAMINE
description: An armada of battered buses and trucks and modern Soviet helicopters and troop transport planes is carrying tens of thousands of hungry, destitute peasants from the famine-stricken areas of northern Ethiopia to more fertile lands in the west and south.

title: COMMERCIAL ALLIANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company became a subsidiary of First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles on Dec. 3 and therefore no share earnings figures were reported.

title: MORRIS COUNTY VOTES APPROVAL OF NEW LANDFILL
description: Morris County officials today bowed to pressure from the state and approved opening a landfill in Rockaway Township.

title: The Dollar's Strength Is Weakness The meaning of having a ''strong'' dollar is clearer now. It means directly weakening the nation's economic recovery. Though most analysts do not yet foresee another recession, they're agreed about three necessary precautions: Cut the Federal budget deficit, bring down interest rates and beware of protectionism.
description: The economy slowed sharply this fall and hasn't perked up yet. The third quarter's gross national product grew in real terms at an annual rate of only 1.9 percent, compared with 7.1 percent last summer. The slowdown highlights the effect of a growing foreign trade deficit, due mostly to the high- priced dollar. Without that trade erosion, third- quarter growth would have been 5.7 percent.

title: TOFU TIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Dr.AlanB.Rothballer, Surgeon and Educator
description: Dr. Alan Burns Rothballer, chairman of the department of neurosurgery at the New York Medical College in Manhattan, died of cancer Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan and Oxford, Conn.

title: Jazz Trio
description: The saxophonist Ken McIntyre, the pianist Richard Harper and the drummer Andre Strobert will perform Sunday at 3 P.M. at the fourth- floor loft of 109 West Broadway, above Chambers Street (619-4879). Admission is $5.

title: Topics ; Unusual Warmth ; Robin WeatherA New Yorker who, like all New Yorkers, has had no occasion to button up her overcoat this December complained of just that the other day. It seemed
description: funny , she said, not to be freezing. It felt

title: Smoking Bills Advance
description: The New Jersey Assembly today approved a six-bill package that would regulate smoking in government buildings, restaurants, theaters, supermarkets, department stores, other places of business and industrial plants and on public transportation.

title: THE BIG LAWSUITS: WILL THEY BE TRIED IN U.S.?
description: The American personal-injury lawyers who have flocked to Bhopal, India, to sign up clients injured in the gas leak last week at a Union Carbide Corporation plant say the claims will be heard in the United States.

title: OPPENHEIMER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Penn Square Official Settles
description: A Federal judge today approved a settlement in which John R. Preston, Penn Square Bank's former corporate secretary and general counsel, will pay $70,000 to satisfy the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's claims against him in a $138 million lawsuit. The agreement also calls for Mr. Preston to repay a $58,300 note at Penn Square.

title: Bridge:In Memory of Dan O'Neill, Who Helped Many Players
description: The fact that bridge is thriving on Long Island owes much to the dedicated efforts of Dan O'Neill, who died recently at the age of 74.

title: Celebrating With Restraint
description: Jack Stroud, the offensive tackle who in 12 seasons with the New York Giants played on six conference championship teams, including the one that captured the National Football League's 1956 title, sees a change in pro football these days, and he doesn't like it a bit.

title: WILLIAMS TIES STEALS MARK
description: Gus Williams of the Bullets had five steals tonight, enough to equal a National Basketball Association career record but not enough to give Coach Gene Shue his 700th victory.

title: PUBLISHING: 'IACOCCA' REACHES MILLIONTH COPY
description: LEE IACOCCA'S autobiography went on sale Oct. 15 and three weeks later it soared to No. 1 on The New York Times best seller list. ''Iacocca'' has held that position for six weeks, and this week Bantam Books printed the millionth copy.

title: SPANISH POET WON '77 NOBEL
description: Vicente Aleixandre, the Spanish poet who won the 1977 Nobel Prize for literature and whose cadenced free verse explored the mysteries of death, love and the unconscious, died yesterday of kidney failure at his home in Madrid. He was 86 years old.

title: IN INDIAN CITY, FEAR EMPTIES HOSPITAL BEDS
description: The emergency room at the Hamidia Hospital was locked this evening, and admissions were down to a trickle as scores of patients deserted the institution and joined a swelling exodus of fearful residents leaving the city.

title: PETROLEUM HELICOPTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: WHEN LOSING ISN'T BAD
description: Not all rewards come from winning. In fact, the Buffalo Bills are confronted by a situation in which they would be rewarded by losing. If the Bengals beat them Sunday in Cincinnati, the Bills will have assured themselves the first pick in the college draft next year. And, because one of the Bills' priorities may be to find a new quarterback, Doug Flutie's mailing address next year could be Orchard Park, N.Y.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1984

title: SAN DIEGO AREA BANS NONESSENTIAL LIGHT TO AID ASTRONOMERS
description: A law forbidding all nonessential lighting after 11 P.M. in San Diego County's unincorporated areas has been approved by the county supervisors in response to pleas by astronomers who have to work in the dark.

title: Australia Wool Output
description: Australian wool output should rise 6.1 percent in the 12 months ending March 31, the Government said today. Production of greasy wool is expected to reach 773,308 metric tons, up from 729,052 tons a year earlier.

title: Jobless Benefit Claims Jumped in November
description: Jobless Americans' new applications for unemployment compensation jumped to 455,000 in the last week of November, marking the highest level since the spring of 1983, the Government reported today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Dec. 14, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: RELEASE ORDERED FOR TRANSCRIPTS ABOUT DONOVAN
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered the Bronx District Attorney's office to turn over to defense lawyers testimony used by a grand jury to indict Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan on fraud and larceny charges.

title: LET'S GIVE UNESCO A YEAR TO CONTINUE REFORM
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Firemen Hurt In Arson Blaze
description: A man poured a flammable liquid into the entrance of an occupied Bronx grocery last night and started a fire that injured three firefighters, according to the police.

title: JUDGE RULES CBS STUDY NOT ADMISSIBLE IN TRIAL
description: The presiding judge in Gen. William C. Westmoreland's $120 million libel suit ruled inadmissible as evidence yesterday a CBS internal report that found the network had violated its news standards in the preparation of a disputed documentary on Vietnam.

title: ; THE LAKE THE RUSSIANS EVAPORATED
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE THEATER OF ESSENCE AND

title: Three Giants In Pro Bowl Three Giants - Lawrence
description: Taylor, Mark Haynes and

title: SOUTH AFRICAN LEADER DENIES U.S. WON RELEASE OF JAILED DISSIDENTS
description: Without mentioning President Reagan by name, South Africa's President, P. W. Botha, today rejected suggestions that United States Government pressure had forced Pretoria to release detained labor unionists and black community leaders.

title: UAL Buildings
description: UAL Inc., the parent of United Airlines, has been discussing the possible sale of its headquarters complex to the investment company Paine Webber Inc., a UAL spokesman said.

title: PHILHARMONIC: A ROCHBERG PREMIERE
description: THE New York Philharmonic dedicated last night's performance to the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, which is celebrating its 25th anniversary season. Since the Philharmonic is a constituent of Lincoln Center, this is something like one arm saluting its own body. Still, great occasions are rare enough so that allowances must be made for ceremonial observances of this sort. Illness prevented Martin E. Segal, Lincoln Center's board chairman, from showing up to make the appropriate remarks, but Carlos Moseley, the Philharmonic's board chairman, jumped into the breach.

title: Lack of Fuel Is Linked To Miami Plane Crash
description: Investigators said today that a twin-engine commuter plane that crash-landed a quarter-mile short of Miami International Airport may have run out of fuel and was not using its auxiliary tanks.

title: COMPUTONE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
G.E.-Apple Deal
description: The General Electric Information Services Company and Apple Computer Inc. have reached an agreement under which the General Electric unit would resell Apple's products.

title: Diner's Journal
description: BARKING FISH, the tiny Cajun and Creole carryout on Eighth Avenue near 43d Street, has packed its chili powder and moved up the street to larger quarters, taking over the 40-year-old Downey's Steak House on Eighth Avenue between 44th and 45th Streets. Called the Barking Fish Cafe, the new 200-seat restaurant is a far cry from its predecessor.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report on Wednesday with an article about a proposal to reduce exemptions from jury service in New York misidentified a Housing Court judge. He is Antonio Brandveen.

title: Cubs Keep Sutcliffe On $1.8 Million Bid
description: Two months after he faltered in the deciding game of the National League championship series and one month after he became a free agent, Rick Sutcliffe decided yesterday to re-sign with the Chicago Cubs.

title: SEX ALLEGATIONS PROMPT CHARGES AGAINST OFFICERS
description: A special grand jury in Queens has indicted three New York City police officers in a case involving a 16-year- old girl's charges that she was compelled to perform sexual acts with two of the officers.

title: A CALENDAR OF MUSIC FOR THE CHRISTMAS SEASON Today
description: Church of St. Francis Xavier (Roman Catholic), West 16th Street, east of Avenue of

title: Benefits Follow Reagan's Call
description: The Federal Government today awarded Social Security disability benefits to William J. Schroeder, the artificial heart recipient, a day after his complaint to President Reagan that the claim had been delayed for nearly nine months.

title: BRIEFING ; Merry Hotel
description: Briefing got a Christmas card the other day from a hotel that is not even scheduled to open until next October. So fierce is potential future competition in the latest high- style Washington hotel district, the West End, that the nonexistent hotel, the Westin, has also begun publishing a newsletter, complete with a lead article on the forthcoming Presidential inaugural, notes on other local happenings and a discreet plug for the 400-room hostelry now under construction.

title: Hutcheson & Shutze?
description: Virgil Shutze, 40, executive vice president and director of creative services at McDonald & Little, the Ted Bates Worldwide subsidiary in Atlanta, is leaving the agency to join Hutcheson & Anderson, also in Atlanta. The agency has promised to change its name to Hutcheson & Shutze and give Mr. Shutze the titles of vice chairman and director of creative services. Don Hutcheson last month bought out his partner, William Anderson.

title: EXCALIBUR TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Accounts
description: * Amfesco Industries Corporation to Wyse Advertising.

title: INTERSTATE BAKERIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 17
description: b-Including tax credits of $869,000 for the quarter and $1,308,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $375,000 for the quarter and $692,000 for the 6 months.

title: Asian-American Video
description: The third Asian-American International Video Festival, featuring a variety of documentaries, experimental features and installations, will be held on Sunday at Danceteria, 30 West 21st Street.

title: House Asked to Drop Subpoena of Reporter
description: The Authors League of America said today that it had asked leaders of the House of Representatives to withdraw a subpoena served last week on a reporter for The Washington Times who had written about the ethics committee's investigation of the financial reports filed by Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro.

title: Eastern Gas
description: Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates said it would take a nonrecurring charge against net income of about $36 million in the fourth quarter because of a write-down of assets held by its coal and oil and gas exploration subsidiaries. The company said the write- down of the coal assets had stemmed from weak demand for Western coal, while the oil and gas units had been re-evaluated as a result of declines in energy prices. In last year's fourth quarter, Eastern Gas earned $37.5 million on revenues of $1.19 billion.

title: DANGER FOR EUROPE
description: BRUSSELS The European Community has established a new administration

title: Still at Odds
description: Jim Rice, the Boston Red Sox slugger, has a year to go on his contract, but the Red Sox have been hoping to sign him to a new pact before the start of the 1985 season, the deadline Rice has set for deciding whether to become a free agent at the end of the season. The negotiations, however, have not been going well.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; No Slaughter on 10th Ave.
description: A cabby wheeled his taxi in and out

title: JAZZ HARPIST BLENDS BLUES WITH SONGS OF CHRISTMAS
description: AT a ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' concert at the 92d Street Y in May, Corky Hale was doing what she had been doing with great success for the last 30 years - playing piano and harp. She's been an accompanist to such singers as Frank Sinatra, Billie Holiday, Tony Bennett and a multitude of others, a member of the bands of Harry James and Russ Morgan and on radio and television commercials. During those years, Miss Hale's versatility and particularly her unusual talent as a jazz harpist made her a legend among musicians although she was virtually unknown to the public.

title: ALEXANDER & BALDWIN NAMES NEW PRESIDENT
description: Michael S. Wasacz was named president and chief operating officer of Alexander & Baldwin Inc., a Honolulu-based transportation, sugar and real estate company.

title: RAINS AND MUDSLIDES HIT ETHIOPIA FAMINE CAMPS
description: Violent rains and mudslides have caused increased hardship and damage in Alamata and Korem, the sites of a major concentration of refugees from Ethiopia's famine, aid officials say.

title: Stein Beats Green - In Spending
description: While Representative Bill Green

title: SUCCEEDING FLUTIE
description: With Doug Flutie about to conclude his fabled college football career in the Cotton Bowl on New Year's Day, Boston College will be looking for a new quarterback when the Eagles assemble for spring practice.

title: U.S. SEEN NEARING A UNESCO PULLOUT
description: President Reagan is expected to announce next week that the United States has formally decided to leave Unesco, Administration officials said today.

title: ZELLERBACK STOCK UP AFTER BID
description: The stock of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation jumped $5.25, to $34, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, a day after the company said that Sir James Goldsmith had notified it of his intent to acquire 15 to 25 percent of the company's stock.

title: MONY MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including gains from the sale of investments of $2,219,000 for the quarter and $2,261,000 for the 6 months. c-Including gains from the sale of investments of $459,000 for the quarter and $463,000 for the 6 months.

title: People
description: * Peter Serchuk and Allen Gilburne appointed senior vice presidents and creative directors at William Esty.

title: TOP SOVIET AIDE TALKS OF ARMS CUTS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who is widely regarded as second-in-command in the Soviet Union, had his first substantive conversation with Americans two weeks ago and told them that Moscow was ready for reciprocal cuts in military spending with the United States.

title: Mauritania's President Arrested by Coup Leader
description: The deposed President of Mauritania, Col. Mohamed Khouna Ould Haidalla, returned home today and was arrested by forces loyal to his rival for power, radio reports said.

title: ICE DANCERS HAVE NO TIME FOR SITTING
description: Like most good ice dancing duos, Suzanne Murphy of Montclair, N.J., and Andrew Niedler of Warren, N.J., act as one on the ice, but are total opposites off it. While Miss Murphy does most of the talking during interviews, Niedler is content to nod agreement.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Chicago Bulls, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. The injury-hobbled Nets meet Michael Jordan, who scored 20 points when the teams played in Chicago earlier this month.

title: Kohde-Kilsch Gains in Tennis
description: Top- seeded Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany and second-seeded Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria breezed past their opponents today to advance to the singles quarterfinals of the $300,000 Pan Pacific Women's Tennis Tournament.

title: BRIEFING ; Attention: Outside World
description: Two of the best-informed and

title: CRILE DENIES HE 'MADE UP' SEQUENCE IN CBS FILM
description: George Crile, the producer of a disputed CBS documentary on the Vietnam War, was accused in court yesterday of fabricating a part of the program that dealt with a supposed ''cover-up'' of enemy strength statistics after the Tet offensive of January 1968.

title: ANALOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Thrift Unit Repayment
description: The Financial Corporation of America today said it had repaid $375 million in Federal borrowings in the last two weeks, while raising its liquid reserves of cash and securities to the minimum industry standard.

title: Union Oil Price
description: The Union Oil Company of California, a unit of the Unocal Corporation, cut the price it would pay for West Texas Intermediate crude oil by 50 cents a barrel, to $28.50.

title: STOP SUPPORTING PINOCHET
description: The Reagan Administration faces a great opportunity to repair its reputation in Latin America. It could identify itself with the movement toward democracy that is sweeping the hemisphere by making it clear that it supports the Chilean people in their desire to rid themselves of the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: NIPPON TELEGRAPH SALE TO PUBLIC IS BACKED
description: A far-reaching package of bills to reshape Japan's telecommunications industry cleared a key parliamentary committee tonight, guaranteeing its evenutal passage by the full Parliament.

title: U.S.-Cuba Talks Resume
description: The United States and Cuba resumed immigration talks today, seeking to reach final agreement on the return of about 2,500 ''undesirable'' Cuban refugees who came to this country in the 1980 boatlift. In return, Cuba is seeking a restoration of normal immigration flows to the United States. The talks resumed at a location in New York that was kept secret for security reasons.

title: BIG HOMES ARE BACK IN NORTH HILLS, L.I.
description: History will never repeat itself here: The great estates and palatial homes that once lined the wooded drives of this North Shore Nassau County community are all but gone. Most have been redeveloped in the last 15 years into condominiums and private homes on small plots.

title: Brazilian Nights
description: Brazilian music and dance will be performed this weekend at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street (864- 5400).

title: U.S. SERIOUS ON ARMS TALKS, SHULTZ SAYS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told the NATO foreign ministers today that the United States was approaching the new negotiations on arms control with the Soviet Union in ''a positive, extremely serious and open-minded way,'' a senior American diplomat said.

title: SICILIAN CITY, U.S. BASE, DISCOVERS MISSILE POLITICS
description: It was a local political fight, the sort of clash over personalities and management that characterizes city politics just about everywhere.

title: IN ISRAEL, EVEN SHARON'S WORST ENEMIES AREN'T FRIENDS OF TIME
description: As his libel case against Time magazine unfolds in a courtroom in the United States, some of Ariel Sharon's countrymen find themselves caught between two impulses.

title: Dining Out Guide: Classic Brunch
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAFE LUXEMBOURG, 200 West 70th Street

title: GIANTS ARE UPBEAT AND LOOSE
description: As the Giants prepare for Saturday's game here against the New Orleans Saints, a game that may put them in the playoffs, the locker-room excitement is at a fever pitch. Well, maybe just a slight fever.

title: Advertising; Merger Set Of Mower And Gore
description: FOR the two years that his Sycracuse-based agency has had a New York office, Eric A. Mower, 40 years old, has been looking to connect with a New York shop to supply him with a larger base of operations.

title: FAMILY IN ARCADE SLAYING FINDS GRIEF IS SLOW TO EBB
description: The blows that killed 18-year-old Jonny Habib in a video arcade last January left his mother, too, a murder victim. ''I wanted to die,'' said Suzanne Habib. ''I wanted to go to Jonny. I felt Jonny was calling me. He wouldn't rest until I got there.''

title: Harvester Has Profit In Quarter
description: The International Harvester Company said today that it had earned $7 million in its fourth fiscal quarter, the first quarterly profit by the ailing agricultural equipment manufacturer in four years.

title: Chileans Admit Mixup In Deporting Reporter
description: The military Government has acknowledged deporting the wrong correspondent for what it called an erroneous story, and it has allowed him to return.

title: LUBY'S CAFETERIAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid in August.

title: 40-Car Pileup in Georgia Kills 3 and Injures 17
description: Three people were killed and at least 17 injured today in a fiery, chain-reaction pileup involving six semitrailer trucks and about 40 automobiles on a fog- shrouded bridge of Interstate 95.

title: CAMBEX CORP.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $28,000. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $47,000. d-Net loss.

title: DON'T COME, BUT DO BUY A SOUVENIR
description: Invitations to the 1985 Reagan-Bush inaugural are out, but, to be frank, they will not really get you into much of anything.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report last Friday about a plan to build eight large incinerators in New York City misreported the position of the Staten Island Borough President, Ralph J. Lamberti. He has not objected to any site proposed for an incinerator.

title: Nicor Write-Down
description: Nicor Inc. said that because of the depressed energy markets it serves, the company expected ''significant asset write-downs'' to be included in its full-year 1984 results.

title: Charles P. BuchananIsDead;RanSavoyBallroom 32 Years
description: Charles P. Buchanan, who managed the Savoy Ballroom in Harlem for 32 years, died of a stroke Tuesday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 86 years old.

title: AN EXPERIMENT IN WORKER OWNERSHIP FACES A CRUCIAL TEST AT JERSEY PLANT
description: An important experiment in employee ownership of a company is in serious trouble here.

title: Beatles' Apple Records Sues Capital EMI
description: Apple Records, the company representing the former Beatles, sued Capital EMI Records for $45 million yesterday, charging millions of dollars in royalty payment fraud over a 10-year period.

title: SHORTAGE OF WHOOPING COUGH VACCINE IS SEEN
description: The Federal Centers for Disease Control, citing a shortage of whooping cough vaccine, today recommended that doctors delay booster shots for children more than a year old.

title: Pageants and Puppets
description: Today American Museum of Natural History ,

title: STAGE: 'TOTAL ECLIPSE,' AT THE WESTSIDE ARTS
description: THE two ethereal bodies that merge in ''Total Eclipse'' belong not to the solar system but to a steamy chapter in the history of Symbolist literature. Christopher Hampton's play, now in revival at the Westside Arts Theater, charts the tumultuous liaison of the French poets Paul Verlaine and Arthur Rimbaud - a violent, erotic, creative fusion that led to Rimbaud's masterwork and swansong, ''Une Saison en Enfer'' (1873), as well as to a scandalous shooting incident and the eventual flameout of both men.

title: DOLE TURNS TO A TRUSTED AIDE TO HEAD NEW TEAM
description: When Senator Bob Dole was marrying Elizabeth Hanford in 1975, Jo-Anne L. Coe was working at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. But when the Senator from Kansas asked her to come in on a volunteer basis and organize the guest list for the wedding, she readily agreed.

title: 'Geography Illiteracy' Is Assailed by 2 Groups
description: Test results that show about 20 percent of American students cannot find the United States on a world map means the nation is producing ''widespread geography illiteracy,'' two education groups said today.

title: DRUG MAKER PLEADS GUILTY OVER LETHAL SIDE EFFECTS
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation has pleaded guilty and two of its medical officials have pleaded no contest to charges of failing to report to the Food and Drug Administration the lethal side effects of the blood-pressure drug Selacryn.

title: MISSING EXPLANATIONS IN MISKITO PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: Widows and Children Of the Finest
description: Their husbands or fathers were

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.25-11.50 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Garden State to Hold $1 Million Race
description: Garden State Park, which opens April 1 for the first time since fire destroyed the track in 1977, announced today that it would hold a $1 million race for 3-year-olds, the Jersey Derby, between the running of the Preakness Stakes and the Belmont Stakes, the final two races of the Triple Crown series.

title: PERJURY CASE GOES TO NEBRASKA JURY
description: Jurors began deliberations today in the trial of State Attorney General Paul Douglas, who is accused of lying about his business dealings with a savings company and one of its officers.

title: 2 PROGRAMS OF AVANT-GARDE DANCE
description: ''I thought I was going to do a piece called 'Art,' '' Daniel Nagrin, a representative of the grand old establishment of modern dance, said mischievously. ''But I don't know. Mostly I want to look good and let the ideology take care of itself.'' The emphasis will be on entertainment at St. Mark's Church's Danspace tonight and tomorrow at 8, when 12 dancers and companies will perform in a benefit for Movement Research Inc., an association of postmodernist dancers, artists, choreographers and teachers of ''body work'' or techniques of natural movement.

title: FOR POLAND, A LOOK BACK
description: Three years ago today, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski declared martial law, breaking up the Solidarity trade union movement, ordering the detention of thousands and sending tanks into the streets. Now on the anniversary of that event, both the Government and its opponents are taking stock, defining the positions of state and society in very different terms.

title: Japan Steel Production
description: Japan's production of crude steel fell 4 percent in November from October but was up 4.3 percent from a year before, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said today. Output totaled 8.82 million metric tons last month.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Key Senator Opposes U.S. Latin Troop Role
description: The new chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today opposed the use of United States combat troops in Central America in the near future and predicted that Congress would not soon change its mind on banning United States aid to Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Spare the Rod in New York Schools About 60 percent of New York State's public- school children risk a severe spanking or paddling when they sass a teacher or break a rule. At a meeting today, the State Board of Regents has an opportunity to limit such corporal punishment.
description: New York's penal law permits local school districts to set their own policy on physical discipline. Nobody knows for sure how much of it actually occurs, but state legislators and regents receive a few complaints of abuse each year.

title: AUCTIONS
description: THE largest and most important selection of Frank Lloyd Wright's designs ever to be auctioned - stained-glass windows, home and office furniture, lighting fixtures, a rare copper urn and architectural drawings - will be sold today at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street.

title: Market Place; Behind Revco's Profits Setback
description: REVCO D.S. INC., operator of the nation's largest drugstore chain, may be suffering from too much diversification. The company announced on Tuesday that the earnings prognosis for its second fiscal quarter was indeed unhealthy.

title: Challengers Lose At Pantry Pride
description: Pantry Pride Inc.'s board has been re-elected, receiving almost 61 percent of the shares voted, according to preliminary figures released by the supermarket and specialty retailing company.

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $376,000.

title: SEARCHERS CATCH 2 'MOUNTAIN MEN'
description: Two men who eluded intensive mountain searches since July, when they were suspected of kidnapping a member of the American biathlon team and killing one of her rescuers, were captured today.

title: Economic Scene; Battle Revives On Fed Status
description: TREASURY Secretary Donald T. Regan made

title: Swiss Parliament Endorses United Nations Membership
description: The Swiss Parliament voted today in favor of Switzerland's membership in the United Nations but left the final decision to the Swiss people in a nationwide referendum.

title: MONEY SUPPLY PLUNGES $7.1 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday announced a $7.1 billion drop in the nation's money supply. The decline was much larger than expected, helping keep alive conjecture that the Fed might encourage lower interest rates to stimulate money supply growth and the economy.

title: INDIANS FLEE CITY AS CHEMICAL PLANT PLANS TO RESTART
description: By the tens of thousands, Bhopal residents fled the city today after an announcement that the Union Carbide plant here would be started up again Sunday to neutralize what remains of a toxic chemical that killed at least 2,000 people.

title: SCREEN: TOM SELLECK IN 'RUNAWAY'
description: ROBOTS are all the rage this Christmas, and Michael Crichton's ''Runaway,'' which opens today at the National and other theaters, has more of them than any toy store. ''Runaway'' is about a police sergeant named Ramsay, whose job it is to dismantle things that look like very smart vacuum cleaners should any of them run amok. Tom Selleck, as Ramsay, takes this seriously and makes an affable hero, but he's at a big disadvantage. Mr. Crichton has a much better feel for the film's gadgets than for its human players.

title: SCREEN: COPPOLA'S 'COTTON CLUB'
description: ''THE COTTON CLUB'' may well be a tap-dancing ''Cleopatra'' for the 1980's, a period movie whose time and - apparently - script had not come when principal photography began in New York a couple of years ago. It obviously cost a bundle but, considering the rate of inflation since the early 60's, ''The Cotton Club'' probably didn't cost as much as ''Cleopatra,'' best remembered now for some of the post-production comments made by its exhausted writer- director, Joseph L. Mankiewicz, in his war with 20th Century-Fox: ''They could cut it into banjo picks if they want.''

title: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ART PEOPLE
description: JUST the way he has always done, Paul Cadmus slipped quietly into town recently and proceeded to amaze a few people. Now 80 years old, the artist has shunned abstract painting all his life, producing instead in the painstakingly slow ''egg-tempera'' medium realistic works that are charged with symbolic, violent and often homoerotic imagery.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
RADIANT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHOCK FULL O'NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,000 for the latest first quarter and $191,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: Article 150542 -- No Title
description: Nearly one-fifth, or $6.1 billion, of President Reagan's $34 billion in proposed domestic budget cuts for the next fiscal year would come from programs for the poor, according to the findings of a study made public today.

title: BRIEFING ; A Leg Man
description: Among many other attributes, the Corcoran Gallery tells us, Louis XIV was a leg man. One of the more familiar paintings of the 17th-century French monarch in an exhibition called ''The Sun King'' opening at the gallery tomorrow carries this caption: ''Like other royal portraits, this one flatters Louis' figure and strong legs, of which he was proud.''

title: AMERICAN HOME PATIENT CENERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: DANCE: JOFFREY IN CRANKO'S 'ROMEO AND JULIET'
description: John Cranko's ''Romeo and Juliet'' is arguably the best dance treatment of Prokofiev's celebrated ballet score. And for the first time it has been presented - with blazingly splendid results - by an American company, the Joffrey Ballet.

title: Times National Edition Gets Business Director
description: The New York Times Company yesterday named Richard W. Stockton to the new position of business director of the national edition of The Times.

title: COMPUCORP APPOINTS TROUBLESHOOTER AS CHIEF
description: William M. Duke was named president and chief executive officer yesterday of troubled Compucorp, a maker of office automation systems.

title: BROADWAY
description: CYNICS who think the name ''Three Guys Naked From the Waist Down'' was chosen merely to titillate are at least partly wrong. The phrase ''naked from the waist down'' is apparently how vaudeville's stand-up comics often referred to their stage appearances.

title: A Change in the Program
description: Fragments from Alban Berg's

title: The Redskins: Still Shining
description: The Washington Redskins needed

title: I.M.F. Plan Denounced
description: Foreign Minister Arturo Tolentino said today that the conditions placed on a loan package by the International Monetary Fund would drive the Philippines deeper into debt.

title: PARADE OF HOLIDAY FARE
description: There are a number of special presentations this weekend, most of them connected with the holiday season. Tomorrow night at 8, Channel 5 has ''It Came Upon the Midnight Clear,'' a television movie in which Mickey Rooney plays a former New York policeman who, with the help of assorted angels, gets to show his Los Angeles grandson a real snowy Christmas in the Big Apple. As might be suspected, the film is designed to be family entertainment. Meanwhile, over on Channel 7 at 10 P.M. tomorrow, Perry Como is back in one of his holiday travelogues. ''Christmas in London,'' with Ann-Margret as guest star, visits Shepherd's Market, Leeds Castle and a 19th-century pub, with many breaks for songs and carols.

title: ABC Pulls Diet Coke Commercial Off the Air
description: The ABC-TV network has pulled a Diet Coke commercial off the air over the question of whether its new drink formulation - with all aspartame and no saccharin - is available nationally, a network source confirmed yesterday.

title: Dec. 1-10 Car Sales Rebound by 19.9%
description: Sales of new cars bounced back in the first 10 days of December with the nation's six major manufacturers today reporting sales of 184,470 units, up 19.9 percent from the period last year, on a daily rate basis.

title: TRADING IS SLOW
description: Stock prices finished lower yesterday in continued slow trading, reflecting the moderate rise in interest rates in the credit markets.

title: CHRYSLER REBUFFS UNION'S PLEA TO CANCEL CONTRACT
description: The Chrysler Corporation today refused a request by the United Automobile Workers to cancel the current labor contract and begin negotiations on a new one. The company did, however, express a willingness to discuss pay increases and other modifications of the existing agreement.

title: 2 U.S. Navy Men Die In Honduras Accident
description: Two members of the United States Navy's special forces team died in Honduras Wednesday in a demolition accident while trying to help Honduran villagers, the Pentagon said today.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: HIS accent in ''Beverly Hills Cop'' will send linguists reeling, but Bronson Pinchot, who has a small role as an assistant in an art gallery, was originally not supposed to speak with one. Mr. Pinchot was cast as a non- Frenchman named Jacques, and all he had to do was look snobbish, answer a few of Eddie Murphy's questions and offer the star a drink. However, Mr. Pinchot, a 25-year-old English major from Yale whose natural speaking voice is nothing out of the ordinary, had his own ideas about how to handle the role.

title: BLUES STAGE LATE RALLY AND TIE DEVILS
description: The Devils started well, taking a two-goal lead in the first period, but were outplayed after that and had to settle for a 4-4 with the St. Louis Blues at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight.

title: Mother and Son to Seek Counseling for Incest
description: A mother and son who married each other today pleaded no contest to incest, conceding that they knew of their relationship when they married and agreeing to seek counseling in return for staying out of jail.

title: LEAVE INTACT TAX, CHARITY DEDUCTIONS
description: While the Reagan Administration should be commended for making a serious first step toward tax reform, the Treasury Department's recent proposals leave a lot to be desired. In the name of closing tax ''loopholes,'' the Treasury would eliminate deductions - for state and local income taxes and charitable contributions - that are not actually loopholes. Moreover, the proposed elimination of the deduction for state and local income taxes may violate the Constitution.

title: Illinois Governor Gets Mandatory Seat-Belt Bill
description: The Illinois Senate has approved legislation requiring drivers and front- seat passengers to buckle their seat belts or face a $25 fine.

title: 5 HOUSING AIDES CHARGED BY U.S. WITH EXTORTION
description: Three supervisors and two inspectors with the New York City Housing Authority were arrested yesterday and charged with extorting a total of $100,000 from four contractors doing repair work on public housing projects.

title: NICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DON KING, AIDE INDICTED ON TAX EVASION CHARGES
description: Don King, boxing's leading promoter, and an aide were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Manhattan yesterday on a total of 23 counts of income-tax evasion, filing false and fraudulent tax returns and conspiracy.

title: COPPOLA'S 'COTTON CLUB'
description: ''THE COTTON CLUB'' may well be a tap-dancing ''Cleopatra'' for the 1980's, a period movie whose time and - apparently - script had not come when principal photography began in New York a couple of years ago. It obviously cost a bundle but, considering the rate of inflation since the early 60's, ''The Cotton Club'' probably didn't cost as much as ''Cleopatra,'' best remembered now for some of the post-production comments made by its exhausted writer- director, Joseph L. Mankiewicz, in his war with 20th Century-Fox: ''They could cut it into banjo picks if they want.''

title: SCREEN: SCIENCE-FICTION EPIC, 'DUNE'
description: SEVERAL of the characters in ''Dune'' are psychic, which puts them in the unique position of being able to understand what goes on in the movie. The plot of ''Dune'' is perilously overloaded, as is virtually everything else about it. As the first king-sized, Italian-produced science-fiction epic, ''Dune'' is an ornate affair, awash in the kind of marble, mosaics, wood paneling, leather tufting and gilt trim more suitable to moguls' offices than to far-flung planets in the year 10191. Not all of the overkill is narrative or decorative. Even the villain, a flying, pustule-covered creature, has more facial sores than he absolutely needs.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The Mayor doesn't know this: We have been examining how we would provide precisely the same services without any city, state or Federal support at all.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Yankees announced that Ken Griffey underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right knee Wednesday. Joe Safety, a club spokesman, said Dr. John Bonamo removed some floating objects from the knee at New York University Medical Center. Griffey was released from the hospital yesterday and will able to begin running in two weeks. . . . The Nets cut the guard Foots Walker, who was on the injured list.

title: UNICEF: NOT SAME AS UNESCO
description: One of the casualties of the dispute between Unesco and the United States is another international organization that shares some of the letters in the Unesco acronym but none of its responsibilities or staff.

title: Production in Sweden
description: Sweden's gross domestic product fell five-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter from the second quarter but was up 2.5 percent from a year earlier, the Government said today.

title: ISRAEL REPORTED DISENCHANTED WITH LEBANON PULLOUT TALKS
description: Israel is becoming increasingly convinced that its withdrawal talks with the Lebanese Government are a waste of time, and it is now seriously considering a redeployment of Israeli troops in southern Lebanon on its own, official Israeli political sources said today.

title: Athens Judge Delays Wiretapping Trial
description: The publisher and editor of a leading Greek newspaper won a one-month delay today in their trial on charges of tapping the telephones of The New York Times bureau here.

title: Feeling Left Out
description: The Denver Broncos have a 12-3 record, are tied for first place in the American Football Conference and have given up fewer points than any other team in the National Football League. So it might be supposed that the team would be well represented on the conference's Pro Bowl squad.

title: METROCARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a gain of $284,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the sale of land.

title: MUSICAL ABOUT RAGGEDY ANN OPENS AT 'THE EGG' IN ALBANY
