description: A new play by William Gibson, a musical version of the children's stories about ''Raggedy Ann'' with music and lyrics by Joe Raposo, opens tonight in Albany. It will be performed in the oval-shaped theater called ''The Egg'' in the Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller Empire State Plaza through Dec. 19.

title: O'CONNOR SAYS HE MIGHT REJECT CITY'S FINANCING
description: The Archbishop of New York startled Mayor Koch yesterday by suggesting that he might consider operating the archdiocese's social programs without government funds rather than comply with a city policy banning discrimination against homosexuals.

title: BALLY PLANS $150 MILLION WRITE-OFF
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation said yesterday that it would take a $150 million pretax charge in the fourth quarter to consolidate its troubled video arcade game business. Bally is the major manufacturer and distributor of coin-operated video games. It also operates about 440 video arcades.

title: DAVID GILLESPIE JR., ADVERTISING LEADER, AT AGE 69 IN FLORIDA
description: David J. Gillespie Jr., chairman emeritus of Kenyon & Eckhardt, a New York advertising agency, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Indian River Memorial Hospital, Vero Beach, Fla. He was 69 years old and had lived in Vero Beach since he retired.

title: Quarter at West End
description: The trumpeter Clark Terry is leading a quartet this weekend at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway at 114th Street (666-9160). Sets begin at 9 and 10:30 P.M., midnight and 1:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow; there is no 1:30 set on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: ART: PAT STEIR'S 'BRUEGHEL SERIES'
description: ''THE BRUEGHEL SERIES (A Vanitas of Style)'' is the culmination of Pat Steir's career to this point. Steir has been painting flowers since 1981, she has used panels almost from the beginning and she has consistently painted paintings about painting. This two-part, 80-panel, floor-to ceiling work, at the Brooklyn Museum through Feb. 18, also seems to be a realization of a lifelong ambition, expressed last year to the art critic Frederick Ted Castle, to produce a notebook from which others could learn.

title: DUPLEX PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
Burglar Cuts Phones To 2,000 in Brooklyn
description: A burglar left 2,000 Brooklyn homes without phone service yesterday when he cut a main telephone cable outside a discount store to disconnect the store's alarm system.

title: RENE KLOPFENSTEIN
description: Rene Klopfenstein, one of Switzerland's best-known conductors and the former director of the Montreux International Music Festival, died while on a flight from the United States to Switzerland, his family announced today.

title: Stein Bids City Take Over Transit
description: Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan, criticizing the bus and subway systems, proposed yesterday that the city take control of transit by invoking a clause in a 1953 agreement that created the Transit Authority.

title: OPTICAL COATING LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $70,000 for the quarter and $722,000 for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $275,000 for the quarter and $1,274,000 for the year and a gain of $4,643,000 for the year on the disposition of discontinued operations.

title: ENNIS BUSINESS FORMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
TEXSCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago results reflect charges of $88,000 for the quarter and $1,715,000 for the 6 months due mostly to the correction of the purchase price allocation of acquisitions and revision of the company's effective tax rate.

title: TAMBORA'S LESSON
description: On July 4, 1816, thick layers of ice formed in New England, New York and Pennsylvania. In June, snow had fallen from 7 to 10 inches deep in Massachusetts, Vermont and New York. But the worst was yet to come; in August, according to one account, ''ice formed nearly an inch in thickness and killed every green thing in the United States.''

title: WALKER'S STEALS PACE KNICKS
description: Darrell Walker used his quick, long arms to strip the ball from Adrian Dantley twice in the final stages last night and pave the way for the Knicks' 119-115 overtime victory over the Utah Jazz at the Garden.

title: Caterpillar Plans To Cut 1,360 More
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said 1,360 employees would soon be laid off or take early retirement. The world's leading maker of off-road construction equipment said the cuts would come atop the layoff of 2,450 workers announced in October.

title: ROYAL PALM BEACH COLONY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
KASPAROV WINS A GAME FOR FIRST TIME IN MATCH
description: Gary Kasparov won his first victory in the world championship chess match in Moscow when 33-year-old Anatoly Karpov, the titleholder, resigned the 32d game yesterday. Although the score is now 1-5 against the 21-year-old challenger, he has spoiled Karpov's hopes for a shutout.

title: U.S. JUDGE REJECTS BID FOR EXTRADITION OF I.R.A. MURDERER
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday refused to extradite a member of the Irish Republican Army convicted of the murder of a British soldier, ruling that the slaying was a political act.

title: Court Assays Sprint Accord
description: A Federal judge told the GTE Corporation and the Justice Department today what changes they must make in their antitrust agreement to let GTE complete its purchase of the Southern Pacific Communications Company.

title: JEWELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $30,000 for the quarter and $81,000 for the 9 months.

title: 4 Escape Crash of Navy Jet
description: Four Navy officers parachuted to safety moments before their jet exploded and crashed today in a heavily wooded area along the coast of Puget Sound. A helicopter team rescued three of the crew members from Discovery Bay, and the other was picked up from land. One man who saw the crash said it appeared the EA-6B Prowler jet, an electronic jamming aircraft, ''broke up into 27,000 pieces, give or take a few.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary in some editions on Sunday of a professor of music at Wesleyan University misidentified him. He was Dr. Jon B. Higgins.

title: Turner Censured by Owners
description: National League club owners voted at their meeting in Houston last week to censure Ted Turner for his contract offer to Bruce Sutter. The owners' action, instigated primarily by the St. Louis Cardinals, prompted the Atlanta owner to restructure the offer to the free-agent relief pitcher, a move that actually raised the value of the contract from $9 million for six years to $10 million.

title: APPEALS COURT UPHOLDS DETROIT HIRING PLAN FOR FIREFIGHTERS
description: The Detroit Fire Department's affirmative action hiring plan is legal and necessary to remedy more than a century of racial discrimination, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit ruled today.

title: THE MANY SOUNDS OF CHRISTMAS
description: The day after Thanksgiving, it begins, Piano benches and music cabinets are opened and searched; a year of dust is blown off the old ''Messiah'' score. Rusty amateur voices start practicing up for a round of hallelujahs and fa-la-las. Rock musicians study Phil Spector's Christmas album one more time; jazz players brush up on the chords of Thad Jones's ''Child Is Born'' and any carols susceptible to swing. Country and folk musicians look for well-known tunes that can use a twang. It's the annual, musical Christmas rush - and one thing to be glad of is that there's so much music appropriate to the season. This weekend, just in time to prevent overexposure to ''White Christas,'' the city's musical organizations will start cutting loose with the full range of Christmas repertory. As always, Handel's ''Messiah'' can be heard almost continuously from now through New Year's Day. One ''Messiah'' with a long-established reputation is the massive production by the Oratorio Society of New York, which gave its first ''Messiah'' in Andrew Carnegie's living room, and will appear Thursday at Carnegie Hall. The St. Thomas Choir's production, Tuesday at St. Thomas Church, will use Baroque instruments and male sopranos and countenors.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Waste Recovery Bonds Lead Tax-Free Market
description: Financings for waste resource recovery plants continued to dominate the tax-exempt bond market yesterday as issuers and securities dealers scrambled to complete their offerings before the end of the year.

title: ACCIDENT LINKED TO IMMUNE DISEASE
description: British doctors say a nurse developed an infection from the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome after she stuck her finger with a needle on a syringe that contained blood from an AIDS patient.

title: STANG HYDRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: IN-DEPTH VIEW OF LEGER AT THE JANIS
description: -century art - right up there with Picasso, Braque, Matisse and Gris - is that of Fernand Leger (1881-1955). Of the Cubist generation and the first painter to deal with our industrial civilization - as pointed out by the late art historian Douglas Cooper - Leger is most appreciated for his syncopated compositions of strong, boldly colored images that convey the mechanized dynamism of ''modern'' life. But there were other phases of his painting as well, and we get a run- through in the admirable anthology of Leger canvases and drawings mounted by the Sidney Janis Gallery, 110 West 57th Street, through Jan. 5.

title: UNHAPPY LANDINGS
description: To the Editor:

title: ECONOMY TURNS RANCH INTO A HUNTERS' PARADISE
description: The century-old YO Ranch, sprawling like a sleeping lion over a vast stretch of the dun-colored Texas hills, is one of the West's legendary ranching empires.

title: CONAGRA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,735,000 for the quarter and $3,442,000 for the 6 months. Share earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on Dec. 1.

title: F.T.C. Reviews Bid by Pickens
description: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it had begun a preliminary review of the bid by T. Boone Pickens Jr. to acquire the Phillips Petroleum Company.

title: Nuclear Winter, Star Wars Discussions of the nuclear balance have been much enlivened by two novel and far-reaching complexities. One is President Reagan's espousal of a defensive shield to protect America against Soviet missiles. The other is the thesis that a large exchange of nuclear explosions would create sooty clouds that would blot out the sun, and thus human survival. On closer inspection both ideas, of a ''Star Wars'' defense and of a ''nuclear winter,'' appear increasingly uncertain.
description: Even the supporters of Star Wars now emphasize the objective of defending missile silos, not cities, from Soviet attack. But defense of silos is nothing new, and it has seemed so destabilizing that both superpowers agreed to deny themselves the option in 1972. Technologies to defend cities are still science fiction, and the most promising seem barely viable even if the Russians took none of the obvious countermeasures.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Chapman Energy Inc., Dallas, said it had completed the previously announced plan for it and two other companies to buy the assets of Bunker Exploration Co., a closely held oil and gas concern.

title: PLAN FOR BIG LEAGUE BASEBALL IS APPROVED BY JERSEY SENATE
description: The state Senate early today approved legislation that paves the way for the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority to build a stadium to attract a major league baseball team to the state.

title: Topics ; Unusual Warmth ; Bureaucratic Heart
description: The Reagan Administration, heretofore grimly determined to deny Social Security payments to the disabled, has just managed to provide 24-hour service for a notable claim handled by a notable clerk.

title: FILM: JEFF BRIDGES PLAYS INGRATIATING 'STARMAN'
description: IF ''Starman'' doesn't make a

title: 3 in Seabrook Told to Sell
description: Maine regulators, as expected, ordered three utilities today to obtain ''credible firm offers'' for the sale of their shares in the Seabrook nuclear plant by Jan. 11, or face being ordered ''unequivocally'' to pull out of the financially troubled project.

title: Gas Blast Kills 16 Pakistanis
description: At least 16 people were killed by an explosion at a natural-gas pipeline in Pakistan's Punjab Province today. The police said the blast in Rahim Yar Khan district was caused by pressure in the pipeline. Eleven people were injured.

title: OFFICIALS CAN'T TIE IRAN TO HIJACKING
description: United States intelligence officials said today that they had no hard evidence indicating Iranian complicity in the hijacking of a Kuwaiti airliner to Iran last week.

title: BRIEFING ; Rank? Did You Say Rank?
description: No one is more sensitive about rank and its subtle gradations than Washington bureaucrats.

title: YOUTH CONVICTED IN KILLING AT EAST SIDE VIDEO ARCADE
description: A jury convicted an 18-year-old youth of manslaughter yesterday in the random clubbing death of a student in an East Side video game arcade last New Year's Day.

title: MANY DONORS MAKE HELPING THE NEEDIEST A TRADITIONAL EVENT
description: Joining the many new contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund every year are those regular donors whose tradition of giving to the poor and unfortunate of New York City may go back many years, even decades.

title: SPACE WEAPONS PROJECT FACES FIGHT IN CONGRESS
description: President Reagan's campaign to develop a space- based defense against ballistic missiles faces serious trouble next year as Congress tries to cut the military budget, according to the chairman of the House subcommittee that handles military appropriations.

title: SPANIARD URGES NEW OUTLOOK ON THE ECONOMY AND NATO
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, citing the realities of a changing world, urged his governing Socialist Party today to make what would be historic changes on economic ideology and NATO membership.

title: Debt
description: * A.E. Staley Manufacturing Co. filed a shelf registration to sell as much as $300 million of debt securities, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Braintech Inc., South Plainfield, N.J., has named Raymond Tsao chairman and chief financial officer, Barry Kass chief executive officer and William Stewart chief operating officer.

title: Cuomo Plan to Enroll New Voters Is Upheld
description: A state appeals court today upheld Governor Cuomo's plan to have state employees distribute voter registration forms.

title: GATES LEARJET PICKS 2-DIVISION MANAGER
description: In an effort to broaden its product base, the Gates Learjet Corporation has placed Ronald D. Neal in charge of its two major divisions, aircraft and aerospace, naming him general manager.

title: HAGLER-HEARNS SET FOR APRIL 15
description: The Fight. With immodest understatement and opulent surroundings, it was announced yesterday that Marvelous Marvin Hagler would defend the world middleweight championship against Thomas Hearns and everyone concerned is happy that it did not happen, as planned, two years ago, when it would have been Just Another Fight.

title: DOCTOR REPORTS PARTIAL RECOVERY
description: William J. Schroeder, the world's second recipient of a permanent artificial heart, suffered a stroke at 6 P.M. today and was partly paralyzed, one of his doctors announced tonight.

title: THE COMPUTER SEARCH FOR FLUTIE'S AGENT
description: The future of Doug Flutie is being monitored not only by teams in the rival pro football leagues, but also by his father and a computer.

title: ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PAY EQUITY ISSUE MOVING TO FOREFRONT

description: Frank Kush ended two weeks of speculation today by announcing that he had resigned as head coach of the Indianapolis Colts to accept a five- year contract in the same position with the Arizona Outlaws of the United States Football League.

description: To some people, they are ''the new therapists.'' To others, they are one of the status symbols of the 80's. But to most people who employ them, they are the prime motivators for whipping a flabby body into shape.

title: Margaret Mead Hall At American Museum
description: The Margaret Mead Hall of Pacific Peoples, a permanent exhibition dedicated to the late anthropologist, opens today at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street. The exhibition contains over 1,400 artifacts relating to the culture of the peoples of Australia, Indonesia, the Philippines, Melanesia, Micronesia and Polynesia.

title: CRISIS MANAGEMENT AT CARBIDE
description: The other day one of the dozens of reporters who have flocked here asked Warren M. Anderson, the Union Carbide Corporation's beleaguered chairman, whether he really cared about anything besides profit and loss. Mr. Anderson sighed a weary sigh.

description: A Federal judge today approved requests by six of the seven regional telephone companies to enter a broad range of businesses beyond local telephone service.

title: Bard of the Beats
description: It was in 1961 that Allen Ginsberg's book of poems, ''Kaddish,'' established him as a major talent. ''Howl'' some five years earlier had brought him fame, but fame as a spokesman for the Beats. The poem had brilliance but there was something glitzy about it, sensational, or so it seemed to many critics at the time. Could you take seriously a poet who began a poem by announcing: ''I saw the best minds of my generation destroyed by madness, starving hysterical naked''? Changing The Hands On a Robot
description: WASHINGTON A robot system in which the robots have interchangeable hands was patented this week for the Zymark Corporation of Hopkinton, Mass. The inventors are Burleigh M. Hutchins, one of the founders of the company, and Louis Abrahams, a staff engineer.

description: The Government put 21 men on trial today on charges of trying to overthrow the Communist regime through espionage, sabotage and guerrilla warfare.

description: Representative Harold E. Ford, Democrat of Tennessee, and two college professors were arrested in front of the South African Embassy today as they protested the racial separation policies of the South African Government.

title: DANCE: THE 1923 NIJINSKA-STRAVINSKY 'LES NOCES'
description: An event that is a must for dancego ers in the New York area is the staging of ''Les Noces,'' in the 1923 version created by Bronislava Nijinska and Igor Stravinsky, that will be performed tonight and tomorrow at 3 P.M. at the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: REGAINS SPEECH AFTER STROKE
description: William J. Schroeder, the artificial heart patient, regained his speech as well as strength in his right arm and leg today as his doctors said he appeared to be recovering ''brilliantly'' from the stroke he suffered while eating dinner Thursday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: CAMPUS ARTS The only art museum in Queens with its own permanent collection, more than 1,800 pieces, is on the campus of Queens College, at Long Island Expressway and Kissena Boulevard. It is a modern gallery on the second floor of the Paul Klapper Library.

title: Blue Note Modern-Jazz
description: The drummer Jack DeJohnette with his group Special Edition, and the pianist Cecil Taylor with his quintet are sharing a modern-jazz double bill at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets tonight are 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M., and tomorrow at 9 and 11 P.M. There is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, and a $7.50 cover and one-drink minimum at the bar.

title: REGULATING NEW YORK RENTS
description: Sometimes it seems that every New Yorker has a friend who is unable to find even a studio apartment for less than $500. In fact, these stories are quite misleading. According to the 1984 New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey, even in Manhattan most occupied apartments rent for well under $500. In the other boroughs, average rents are even lower. It is vacant apartments that command high rents. So people looking for a new apartment face scarcity and high rents, while incumbent tenants are often blessed with housing bargains. This is not a perverse accident. It is an inevitable consequence of regulating rents.

title: Group Halts Bid For Wackenhut
description: The Wackenhut Corporation, which provides investigative and security systems and services, said a leveraged buyout offer of $24 a share, or $93 million, had been withdrawn. The offer had been made by an investment group that included Merrill Lynch Capital markets; George Wackenhut, the company's chairman; his wife, and others.

title: DOW UP 7.07, TO 1,175.91, BUOYED BY RATE HOPES
description: The stock market advanced moderately yesterday after two sessions of losses, buoyed by the belief that interest rates will decline and that the economy is improving.

title: BAN ON NAMING THEATER FOR TENNESSE WILLIAMS IS UPHELD
description: An appeals court ruled Thursday that the estate of Tennessee Williams owns all rights to the playwright's name and that a New York theater owner may not name a theater after the dramatist without permission.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATING HIJACKING TO IRAN
description: The United States has begun an investigation to piece together the details of the hijacking of a Kuwaiti airliner to Iran last week, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Smith's Legal Tangle

The big question was whether Virgina Tech's star defensive lineman and Outland Trophy winner, Bruce Smith, would be allowed to play and, if not, who would stop him.

title: 70 Arrested in Jersey Raids
description: About 350 law enforcement officers swept through three Cumberland County communities early today and arrested 70 people on drug charges. The raids resulted from a five-month undercover operation by an Atlantic City police detective who posed as a drug dealer and bought more than $15,000 worth of drugs from the suspects, said Terri Miller, a spokesman for the Cumberland County Prosecutor, Kenneth A. Pagliughi.

title: Namibia Police Detain Freelance Journalist
description: The police in South-West Africa detained a freelance journalist today and said she would probably be charged under two laws, including the Official Secrets Act. The journalist may be held for 48 hours without being charged.

title: Reagan Names Ex-Senator
description: Former Senator Nicholas F. Brady of New Jersey was named Thursday by President Reagan as chairman of the Commission on Executive, Legislative and Judicial Salaries. Mr. Brady, a 54- year-old Republican who is an investment banker, served the unexpired term of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., a Democrat, after Mr. Williams resigned in 1982 because of his conviction on bribery charges.

title: VACCINE GAP: 3 ISSUES CLOUD FUTURE
description: Public fears, industry reluctance to risk damage suits and a longstanding failure of Government to draft an effective policy have all come together abruptly to contribute to the most serious national shortage of a major vaccine in modern American history. Experts say they do not recall anything in the past quite comparable with the recommendation earlier this week to delay final booster shots of whooping cough vaccine to conserve supplies in the face of a looming nationwide shortage.

title: MUSIC: 'SATYAVAN' PREMIERE
description: Clouds of incense wafted through the Guggenheim Museum Thursday night. Six young musicians, clad in psychedelic pink pajamas, sat solemnly on the stage, cross-legged, in what used to be called ''Indian style,'' rattling a variety of percussion instruments, blowing and tooting on little flutes, chanting syllables and banging gongs.

title: Israeli Prices Up by 19.5%
description: The Israeli Government said today that prices last month rose by an average of 19.5 percent, keeping Israel's annual inflation rate in the 800 percent range.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Johan Kriek was fined $500 for using bad language during a bad moment in a quarterfinal victory over Marty Davis at the New South Wales Open tennis tournament in Sydney, Australia. . . . Jan Stenerud , the Minnesota Vikings' 42-year-old place- kicker, said that being selected for the Pro Bowl had persuaded him not to go through his annual ritual of deciding whether he is good enough to play another season. ''This indicates I am,'' said Stenerud, who is the oldest player ever selected for the bowl.

title: Sorry, Rabbi (er, Judge)
description: Computer trouble sent out 5,000 thank-you letters from the Democratic National Committee that conferred upon the recipients judicial, military and religious titles that had no connection with their professions.

title: THEATER: DOUG HENNING OFFERS 'WORLD OF MAGIC'
description: Doug Henning only seems to dema terialize - and re-materialize - and levitation is a mechanical rather than a natural wonder. But it is beyond the ken of nonmagicians to understand how he performs his illusionary feats. As we know from his first two Broadway shows and his frequent television appearances, he is a genial grand master of a magician.

title: 'ENCOURAGING PROGNOSIS' IS SEEN FOR GAS VICTIMS

title: Oklahoma Bank Robber Kills 4 and Wounds 3
description: A gunman herded seven adults and an infant into the back room of a small bank today and opened fire, killing four and wounding three before he fled in a car, the authorities said.

description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it had extended to Monday the deadline for an employee-owned roller-bearing company to settle a labor dispute. The bearing company said losing G.M.'s $300 million in business would force it to go bankrupt.

We're looking for deeds rather than words on the part of the Cubans because their conduct in Central America is totally unsatisfactory in the eyes of the United States.'' - Larry Speakes, White House spokesman. (1:5.)

title: SCOUTING ; Yet Another Goal For Chris Mullin
description: Chris Mullin's climb up the St. John's career scoring ladder has lifted him past the greatest stars in the Redmen's basketball history. And the final step up that ladder - at least in terms of a new school record - was seemingly taken last Wednesday night, when, with a 20-point performance against Davidson, he achieved a total of 1,836, smashing a 32-year-old mark of 1,827, held by Bob Zawoluk.

title: Gun in Denver Killing Leads to a Suspect
description: The gun used in the slaying of a radio talk show host in June was found in a search of an Idaho house used by a member of a group accused of plotting to overthrow the Government, the police said today.

title: INTEREST RATES OFF MODESTLY
description: While traders and economists debated whether or not the Federal Reserve was easing monetary policy another notch, interest rates fluctuated in a wider-than-normal range yesterday before ending the day with modest declines.

title: WHISTLE BLOWERS' STRESS EASED HERE
description: Bureaucracies, whether of the corporate or government variety, are known mashers of individualiy. And if a venturesome soul also accuses those above him or her with breaking the law, the trouble really begins.

title: Recount Shows G.O.P. Winning Indiana Seat
description: The Republican challenger in Indiana's Eighth Congressional District race was certified yesterday as the winner by 34 votes.

title: The Unfriendly Skies of Iran On the available evidence, the Scottish verdict of ''not proven'' still applies to the Reagan Administration's dark suspicions about what happened at Teheran's airport in recent days. But our initial faith in Iran's responsibility has been shaken. The worst doubts will be confirmed if Iran refuses to extradite or punish the four hijackers who killed two Americans aboard a Kuwaiti airliner.
description: Iran's weird hint that it wants to swap the captives for Iranian exiles is of a piece with Prime Minister Moussavi's arrogant declaration that ''Iran explains nothing to anyone but God.'' If he won't see to the punishment of murderous hijackers, the appropriate response is to organize an international boycott of Iranian aviation.

title: I.M.F. Loan to Manila
description: The International Monetary Fund said today that it would lend $615 million to the hard-pressed Philippine Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos. Interest on the three- to five-year loan will vary with the market, but at current rates the burden would work out to about 8.5 percent a year.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report last Saturday about opposition to Mayor Koch's re-election incorrectly reported the date of a New Democratic Coalition dinner and the guest of honor. Victor Gotbaum, the labor leader, will be honored at the dinner, on Feb. 10.

A Process to Convert Cellulose to Glucose
description: Two faculty members at Louisiana State University in Baton Rouge have invented an economical method of converting cellulose in the form of wood, waste paper and agricultural products to glucose. The glucose could be used in food or converted to alcohol and other chemicals.

title: Cavaliers Make Trade
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers traded a forward-center, Jeff Cook, to the San Antonio Spurs for the center Edgar Jones and an undisclosed amount of money, and waived Mike Wilson, a second-year guard.

title: HOUSE PANEL NOT REASSURED BY CARBIDE OFFICIALS
description: A Congressional subcommittee pressed Union Carbide officials today for assurance that the chemical disaster that struck Bhopal, India, was unlikely here, but its members appeared to find little comfort.

title: METRO AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: NATO TALKS END ON NOTE OF HARMONY
description: The Western allies declared today that they welcomed the planned resumption of Soviet-American negotiations next month and would do their part ''to bring about an improved East-West relationship and increased cooperation.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Lists for Santa
description: Astrid Schultz of Queens made two

title: IACOCCA EXPECTS U.A.W. CONTRACT TALKS TO BEGIN EARLY NEXT YEAR
description: Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, expects to begin discussions on a new contract with the United Automobile Workers early next year despite the company's rejection of the union's first proposal.

title: U.S. SAID TO DROP ITS BAR TO POLAND IN MONETARY FUND
description: The United States has lifted its objections to Polish membership in the International Monetary Fund in response to the freeing of political prisoners in Poland, a senior Reagan Administration official said today.

title: Navy Decides Sailors May Not Have Beards
description: Beards, which have been allowed in the Navy since the 1970's, will be banned under an order to be issued by the Chief of Naval Operations, Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. said today.

title: REAGAN HOLDS FIRM ON CUTS TO HALVE THE DEFICIT BY '88
description: President Reagan said today that he was still committed to proposing spending reductions next year that would bring the Federal deficit down to about $100 billion by 1988.

title: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION UP SLIGHTLY IN NOVEMBER AFTER 2-MONTH DROP
description: Industrial production in the United States turned modestly higher in November after a two-month slump, prompting economists to strengthen their forecasts for the economy.

title: Hanukkah Festival Preview
description: A concert on Sunday at 5 P.M. featuring David Amram and Friends and the Klez-meydlekh, a klezmer band, will highlight a Hanukkah Arts Festival at Ansche Chesed, 251 West 100th Street.

title: EXPERTS DESCRIBE 'EPIDEMIC' OF TEEN-AGE SUICIDES
description: A program to prevent teen-age suicides should be developed and introduced into high schools around the nation, psychiatrists and others agreed at a conference here.

title: Europe-U.S. Steel Impasse
description: The United States and the European Economic Community failed today to resolve a dispute over an American ban of imports of Common Market steel pipes and tubes for the rest of this year.

title: APPEALS COURT INTERRUPTS SAN DIEGO MAYOR'S TRIAL
description: The trial of Mayor Roger Hedgecock was interrupted today for at least two and a half weeks while a state appeals court considers whether the Mayor was improperly charged.

title: SURGE OF PREPAID HEALTH PLANS
description: Until recently, the prepaid medical plans known as H.M.O.'s were dismissed as relatively expensive aberrations that flourished mainly in California and among government employees. But they have expanded greatly of late, as major employers have become much more conscious of worker health costs.

title: DOING JUSTICE TO CUOMO'S REMARKS ON JUDGESHIP NOMINATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: CELTICS' HOME MARK NOW 11-0
description: Larry Bird started a run of 17 unanswered points by making a 20-foot jump shot as the Boston Celtics broke out of a tie in the third period tonight, extending their unbeaten home record to 11 games this season, with a 117-106 victory over the Utah Jazz.

title: U.S. AND CUBA GAIN AN ACCORD ON REPATRIATION
description: The United States and Cuba announced an agreement today for the repatriation of 2,746 Cuban criminals and mental patients who came here in the 1980 boatlift from the port of Mariel.

title: HOTEL INVESTORS TRUST/CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
QUINONES SEEKS BUDGET INCREASE OF $476 MILLION
description: In his first formal budget request since becoming City Schools Chancellor, Nathan Quinones yesterday asked for an increase of $476 million over the Board of Education's current $3.9 billion budget.

title: ARCHEOLOGISTS FIND INTACT BRAINS 7,000 YEARS OLD STILL CONTAINING DNA
description: Archeologists in Florida have found two human skulls, estimated to be 7,000 years old, containing brains that were largely intact.

title: Names, Names
description: On Thursday, while announcing to a news conference that he was leaving the Indianapolis Colts to become the head coach of the United States Football League's franchise in Phoenix, Frank Kush identified the team that he would be joining as the ''Arizona Bandits.''

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: MEASURING VIOLENCE IN ROCK 'N' ROLL VIDEOS
description: The National Coalition on Television Violence has monitored violence in rock-and-roll videos for the last year, viewing more than 900 productions. It has found, it says, 17.9 instances of violence for each hour viewed.

title: Consumer Debt Increase Is Largest in 3 Months
description: Americans took on $6.28 billion more in installment debt than they paid off in October, with the big increase coming in automobile and personal loans, the Government reported today.

title: MILLER TECHNOLOGY & COMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,977,993.

title: RICHARD McMURRAY
description: Richard McMurray, a stage, screen and television actor, died of lung cancer Tuesday at St. Joseph Hospital in Burbank, Calif. He was 68 years old.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ; North Stars Strike Deal
description: The slow-starting Minnesota North Stars traded a defenseman, Brad Maxwell, and a forward, Brent Ashton, to the Quebec Nordiques for Tony McKegney and Bo Berglund, two wings. ''The idea is to add speed and scoring ability up front,'' said Lou Nanne, the North Stars' general manager. McKegney will move into the lineup right away, but Berglund, who is recovering from a shoulder separation, will miss a few games.

title: THREAT BY VATICAN REPORTED BY NUNS
description: The Vatican has reportedly threatened to expel from their orders nuns who signed a statement asserting that Roman Catholics hold diverse views on abortion.

title: 'Sweet Honey' in Jersey
description: The vocal group Sweet Honey in the Rock will sing gospel songs, work songs and protest songs tomorrow night at 7:30 at Montclair High School, 100 Chestnut Street, Montclair, N.J. The concert is a benefit for the New Jersey Committee for Occupational Safety and Health. Call (201) 623-4751 for information and directions. Tickets are $10 and are tax-deductible.

title: 'Gator Was No Bargain
description: The other day on K Street a

title: BRIEFS
description: Abbott Laboratories , North Chicago, said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 1 million shares of its common stock on the open market or in private transactions during the next 19 months. The company has about 120 million shares oustanding.

title: IN JERSEY, OFFICIALS HURRY TO APPROVE LEGISLATION TO GET BASEBALL TEAM
description: Late in the afternoon eight days ago, Governor Kean's office announced that he and legislative leaders had reached agreement on legislation designed to bring major league baseball to New Jersey. Since then, the legislation has been introduced and approved by the State Senate with extraordinary speed. The Assembly is expected to give final approval to the bill on Monday, and the Governor has said he would sign it quickly.

title: Dickerson Seeks A New Contract
description: Eric Dickerson, the National Football League's season rushing record holder, will ask the Los Angeles Rams to renegotiate his contract and pay him at least $1 million a season, it was reported today.

title: A City-Church Dispute Enlarged
description: New York's Archbishop, John O'Connor, suggests that he may forgo public subsidy for Catholic social agencies if he loses his court battle about discrimination against homosexuals. The threat magnifies a conflict that should have been avoided from the beginning. The poor, and epecially children, will be the losers if the issues are not settled soon. So will all who yearn for better group relations in a city that needs no more divisive quarrels.

title: PEDAL POWER GIVES WAY TO THE PISTON IN INDONESIA
description: Jakarta, capital of the world's fifth most populous nation, is a sprawling city of seven and a half million people, and some days it seems that all of them are out on the roads, riding in an assortment of vehicles. There are the trucks of industry and commerce, the chauffeur-driven cars of the rich and privileged, hundreds of rattletrap taxis and a fleet of double-decker buses.

title: Mavericks 119, Spurs 102
description: Rolando Blackman's 27 points led five Mavericks in double figures. Dallas took control in the third quarter, limiting the Spurs to 3 field goals in 12 minutes, and led by 95-71 after three quarters.

title:
PATENTS ;
Driver Breath Test Speeded by New Device
description: A breath control testing device for drivers who are suspected of being drunk was patented this week by Karl Wolf, president of Alcotek Inc., in Webster Groves, Mo.

title: Extension for Switzer
description: Barry Switzer had his problems this year, but the Oklahoma football coach got his eye back on the ball and put the Sooners on a 9-1-1 pace to the Orange Bowl. And now he has earned the contract extension that was denied him last spring.

title: COMPUTER DEPOT reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net income. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $68,000, or 3 cents a share. d-Net loss.

title: Fuels Post
description: The Synthetic Fuels Corporation put one of its new directors, Representative Tom Corcoran, on the payroll today at $83,300 a year by appointing him acting vice chairman, a new post.

title: CHRISTMAS TREE SALES SCENE
description: Every year after Thanksgiving, an army of hundreds of thousands of Douglas fir, Scotch pine and balsam trees starts pouring over the borders of New York City. By the time the first shock has been absorbed and individual trees have been dispersed to individual homes, tens of millions of dollars have changed hands.

title: CENSORSHIP IS NOT A CURE FOR TEEN-AGE SUICIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: 32 ARRESTED IN INVESTIGATION OF 3 HEROIN NETWORKS
description: In a series of raids that began before dawn yesterday, Federal agents, New York City detectives and state troopers arrested 32 people described as members of three interrelated heroin and cocaine rings here. Seven other people were still being sought last night.

title: REGENTS ACT TO BAR HITTING OF STUDENTS
description: The State Board of Regents moved today toward banning physical punishment in public schools.

title: MONARCH AVALON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: IN NEW YORK, TRUMP PLAN HINGES UPON THE SALE OF RIGHTS TO ITS SEATS
description: It is about 3 feet high, 22 inches wide, and people sit on it.

title: Bronx Youth Accused In Slaying of Woman
description: A 16-year-old Bronx youth was being held in the fatal shooting of a 33-year- old Bronx woman yesterday and the critical wounding of her 13-year-old daughter, the police said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Erin Remembered
description: Straying far from City Hall, the

title: ALL THAT SCHMALTZ
description: Professional sport is a world of restless men constantly moving in search of a few more bucks, so I was not startled to learn that the Philadelphia Eagles, a football team, might move out of Pennsylvania.

title: HOLIDAY SALES PACE PICKS UP
description: The nation's Christmas shopping season, more than two-thirds over, has been sluggish until this week, when sales rose to a much higher pitch, a spot-check of retailers in several major cities has found.

title: British M.P.'s Criticize Ruling on Extradition
description: The refusal of a Federal judge in Manhattan to extradite a member of the Provisional Irish Republican Army convicted of the murder of a British soldier was greeted with fury here by several Conservative Members of Parliament.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ; Sutcliffe's Debt
description: Rick Sutcliffe, the free-agent pitcher who turned down multimillion-dollar offers from three other teams, signed a contract yesterday that will keep him with the Chicago Cubs for five years and reportedly give him $9 million. ''I woke up this morning feeling like the world was off my shoulders,'' said Sutcliffe, who had been furiously courted by the Atlanta Braves, the Kansas City Royals and the San Diego Padres, all of whom, he said, had offered ''basically the same'' compensation package as the Cubs. Sutcliffe said he re- signed with the Cubs because he ''owed it to Chicago'' to stay with the team and try to make it all the way to the World Series next year.

title: DOING JUSTICE TO CUOMO'S REMARKS ON JUDGESHIP NOMINATIONS
description: To the Editor: I noted to my chagrin that in my let

title: Nicaraguan Dissident Denies Plan for Exile
description: Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, the director of a Nicaraguan opposition newspaper, said today that censorship was stifling the paper but that he had no intention of going into exile in protest.

title: BALANCE COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $187,545 for the quarter and $229,160 for the 6 months.

title:
PATENTS;
Inventors Exposition
description: Fifty inventors and 20 companies have applied for space to display their newly patented inventions at the annual National Inventors Exposition, to be held Feb. 9 and 10 at the Patent and Trademark Office in Arlington, Va. More than 140 early patent models will also be exhibited. Six inventors, whose names have not been announced, will be inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame on Feb. 10.

title: NUTRI/SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $519,000 from discontinued operations.

title: MGM/UA Plans Merger of Unit
description: The MGM/UA Entertainment Company, which already owns 85 percent of the common stock of MGM/UA Home Entertainment Group Inc., announced plans to acquire the remainder for an aggregate of $126 million in notes. Under the proposal, a new company to be formed by MGM/UA would be merged with MGM/UA Home Entertainment, said Frank Rothman, chairman and chief executive officer of MGM/UA.

title: MEDICAL MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-No comparable results are available for the year-ago periods because the company began operations on Nov. 1, 1983.

title: Truth in Advertising
description: A rare bit of capital candor is on a shop sign on the road to Middleburg, Va. ''We Buy Junk and We Sell Antiques,'' it says.

title: FAKE CABBAGE PATCH DOLLS ARE SEIZED
description: Customs agents seized 20,000 counterfeit Cabbage Patch dolls yesterday at three locations in Manhattan and found that the dolls might contain hazardous substances.

title: 40 EAST GERMANS ON HUNGER STRIKE
description: Forty East Germans who have occupied the West German Embassy in Prague for several months began a hunger strike today to dramatize their demand to be allowed to emigrate to the West.

title: Inventories Rose 0.8% In October
description: Business inventories climbed by eight-tenths of 1 percent in October, apparently because of retailers' efforts to get ready for Christmas sales, the Government reported today.

title: A FILMIC BOUQUET OF LAUREL AND HARDY RARITIES
description: On his deathbed, a famous actor - many say it was Edmund Gwenn, some Edmund Kean - was asked how he felt. ''Dying is easy,'' he replied. ''Comedy is hard.''

title: VACCINE COMPANY TO EASE SHORTAGE
description: Wyeth Laboratories said today that it would produce 8.4 million doses of whooping cough vaccine in 1985, a move that a Federal official said would significantly ease a projected shortage of the vaccine.

title: WHAT U.S. GRANT CAN TEACH REAGAN
description: In a recent speech, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger told us that the ''President will not allow our military forces to creep - or be drawn gradually - into a combat role in Central America.'' This is good news, but the Administration's provocative actions - such as the planned military maneuvers in the region - seem to belie the Secretary's words.

title: Walton Chased Jets From Field
description: Coach Joe Walton, who has been critical of many of his players this season and not shy about benching them, took his dissatisfaction to new lengths at the Jets' final extended practice - he kicked the whole team off the practice field.

title: Jersey Turnpike Is Closed by Spill
description: The New Jersey Turnpike was closed for more than six hours Friday night and early today after a tanker truck carrying liquid oxygen overturned, officials said. One person was hurt.

title: U.S. AEROSPACE EXHIBIT HOPEFUL OF CHINA GAINS
description: United States aerospace companies are mounting their most concerted effort yet to secure a dominant position in China's growing aviation market, and Chinese officials are responding with a speed that has surprised and reassured the American businessmen involved in the effort.

title: COMCOA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SMITHSONIAN TO SHOW A VANISHED FRONTIER
description: An unlikely pair, a Prussian prince and a Swiss painter, spent 13 months in the 1830's living and traveling among the Indians of the upper Middle West and Plains and brought back to Europe a great record of a people whose era was, unknown to them, perilously near its end.

title: GUERRILLA WAR, OR PARKING ON THE WEST SIDE
description: In the 70's, my wife and I parked our car in the Belnord Garage, on West 87th Street between Broadway and West End Avenue, but that proved too expensive. In 1978, we left the garage owing $800, which we paid off over the next year. We still appreciate their patience with us.

title: Sri Lanka Unveils Plan For Some Autonomy
description: President J. R. Jayewardene, trying to end Sri Lanka's ethnic violence, introduced draft legislation today by which his Government would share some of its powers with districts and provinces.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15.

title: Your Money ; Zero Coupon Generic Issues
description: A popular category of zero coupon bonds has been long-term Treasury issues whose coupons were stripped and sold separately from the actual security. But most have been proprietary products of different investment firms - popularly called by such feline designations as ''cats,'' ''tigers'' and ''lions'' - that maintained a secondary market in their own offerings.

title: Man Given Year in Jail For Burning U.S. Flag
description: A six- member jury convicted a Georgia man Thursday of burning a United States flag while the Republican National Convention was here last summer and sentenced him to a year in jail and a $2,000 fine, the maximum punishment.

title: REAGAN AIDE'S SON IS FINED
description: -John C. Baker, son of James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, has pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor in a two-year-old marijuana case and paid a $2,000 fine and court costs, the assistant district attorney's office said Thursday.

title: Margery D. McMullin Of Home Service Unit
description: Margery D. McMullin, founder and director of the Handicapped Children's Home Service, died Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. She was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: b-Net loss.

description: With the Nets' season evolving into one of attrition, it was only a matter of time before things came to this.

title: ATLANTA'S RAPID TRANSIT SYSTEM TO REACH OUT TODAY FOR SUBURBAN RIDERS
description: Atlanta's five- year-old rapid rail transit network will open five new stations here Saturday, marking the first extension of the system into the city's populous and affluent northern suburbs.

title: WESTERN STEER-MON 'N' POP'S reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
GIANTS' GREY TO FACE SAINTS
description: The Giants, fighting to make the playoffs, end their regular season at Giants Stadium Saturday against the New Orleans Saints with two major weapons lost and one regained.

title: WILLIAM F. MILLER
description: William F. Miller, Connecticut's Director of Parks and Recreation, died of cancer Thursday at his home here.

title: Books of The Times; Bard of the Beats
description: -1980. By Allen

title: Judge Refuses to Curb Comment on Spy Case
description: A Federal district judge refused today to issue an order limiting comment about the spy case against a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and two people charged as Soviet intelligence agents. But he warned defense attorneys to stop their criticism in the news media of the Government's investigation of the case.

description: James Broad, the North American Boxing Federation heavyweight champion, stopped Sterling Benjamin of Trinidad at 1 minute .01 second of the second round of a scheduled 10- rounder last night at Felt Forum.

title: Antuofermo Wins
description: Vito Antuofermo, the former undisputed middleweight champion, made his second start since coming out of a three-year retirement and stopped Marcus Starks at 1:46 of the fourth round of a scheduled 10- rounder tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

Deficit Expected By Castle & Cooke
description: Castle & Cooke Inc., a producer and distributor of fresh products and packaged goods, said yesterday that it expected to report a net operating loss of about $35 million for its quarter ending Dec. 29.

title: ABC IS PUTTING KING BOUTS ON HOLD
description: Don King, the flamboyant promoter, sold the television rights for a boxing match to CBS soon after being indicted Thursday on Federal tax charges. But he will not be selling any bouts to ABC ''at the present time,'' according to an official from that television network.

title: BGS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

Yes, Declaim Against Torture Torture is universally denounced - often most loudly by governments that employ it. So there was no dissent last week when the United Nations approved a Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment. Though such declarations are routinely flouted, they nonetheless set norms by which surviving victims may shame their tormentors. For that reason alone, the United States Senate should favorably consider ratifying this convention.
description: Torture is increasing. Amnesty International has compiled evidence that indicts a third of the world's governments. Its catalogue of horrors ranges from alleged use of heated skewers in Syria to Turkey's

title: JAEGER OF CANADA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
