title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1984 International The U.S. cleared the way for Polish membership in the International Monetary Fund by lifting its objections to Polish membership in response to Warsaw's release of political prisoners, a senior Reagan Administration official said. American opposition to Poland's attempts to join the I.M.F. started after the Solidarity trade union movement was repressed. (Page 1, Column 6.) An agreement to return 2,746 Cubans to their homeland from the United States was announced. The Cubans are criminals and mental patients who came to the United States in the 1980 boatlift from the Cuban port of Mariel. White House officials said the agreement opened the way for the resumption of normal emigration from Cuba, which has, in effect, been suspended since 1980. (1:5.)

title: POLITICAL TRIAL IN YUGOSLAVIA: PUTTING OPENNESS TO THE TEST
description: In a dimly lit courtroom whose aisles are crowded with members of an interested public, a political trial is under way that many regard as the most significant in this country in a decade.

title: WESTERN UNION IN PACT ON PAY CUTS
description: The Western Union Corporation reached an agreement with its 8,000 unionized employees yesterday calling for a 10 percent pay cut and possible worker ownership of a stake in the company in the future.

title: M.T.A. VOTES TO EXTEND 63RD ST. LINE
description: After years of building the 63d Street subway line without knowing where to end it, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority decided yesterday to connect it to local tracks in Queens.

title: FEDERAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Bridge:Temptation to Join Bidding Caused the Perils of Nadine
description: Some Americans know about the Perils of Pauline. Some French, in the bridge world, know about the Perils of Nadine.

title: Wisconsin 90 Dartmouth 70
description: Scott Roth scored 20 of his 28 points in the first half to lead Wisconsin. Roth scored 18 of Wisconsin's first 37 points. Dartmouth (1-4) scored the first basket, but the Badgers (6-1) ran off 6 straight points on two layups by Roth and an 18-footer by Rick Olson to grab the lead.

title: MUSIC CELEBRATING A SEASON
description: ONE of the rarer joys of Christmas is the clear, floating sound of a boys' choir performing old English carols.

title: Gretzky's 5 Goals Pace Oilers, 8-2
description: Wayne Gretzky scored five goals and assisted on two others to lead the Edmonton Oilers to an 8-2 victory over the St. Louis Blues tonight. The 23- year-old center, who had recorded only 2 points in two previous games, now has 999 for his career and his next point will make him the youngest player ever to score 1,000 points, a level reached by only 17 other National Hockey League players.

title: NERVE DISEASE DISABLES GIRL, 9, IN A FAMILY OF LITTLE MEANS
description: NiNE-year-old Dolores B remains playful and lively despite a neurological disease that has left her unable to control her limbs or walk without support. She laughs off her embarrassment when an unintentional movement brings the stack of blocks a brother has built tumbling down.

title: HOSPITALS COMPETING FOR PATIENTS
description: DO hospitals make you nervous? Do you put off surgical or medical treatment that might require an overnight stay because your family needs you at home? If so, Greenwich Hospital's All in a Day Program might be the answer.

title: No Headline
description: Play 'Coming of Age' Delayed for Rewriting

title: 24 Food Outlets Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 24 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: REID TO REVIEW OPERATION OF PEEKSKILL GARBAGE PLANT
description: WHITE PLAINS A SERIES of nagging questions about the planning and operation of the Charles Point resource-recovery plant has prompted a county ''review'' two months after the $243 million facility opened in Peekskill.

title: PRINCIPAL AIDS HUNGARY YOUTHS OF 'MOTEL ROW'
description: They are not like other students at North Shoreview Elementary School. They live in motels or automobiles, and they have little to eat and not much to wear. But someone is watching out for them: their principal.

title: HEADLINERS ; Ali Seeks DamagesIt will be billed as
description: Muhammad Ali vs. United States and it has the makings of a grudge match.

title: REIGN OF 2 JETS ENDING
description: The Jets' season ends today and so does the reign of two of their most consistently dominating players on offense and defense.

title: THE DANCE: RICHARD BULL AND PARTNERS
description: Richard Bull, Peentz Dubble and Cynthia Novack, who have been working together for six years, exude an air of gentle camaraderie that is enhanced by the intimacy of the pretty little Warren Street Performance Loft in which they perform, as well as by the attentive, respectful audiences they draw. To watch them perform there is a pleasant experience, and their lively ''talk'' pieces can be witty and provocative.

title: WHERE WAS CHRISTIAN CONCERN?
description: When David S. Wyman, the author of ''The Abandonment of the Jews,'' began to write his fourth chapter, which deals with how some American publications discredited reports about the Nazi concentration camps in World War II, he was moved to tears. ''I don't cry easily but all my life I had been taught to believe in the good Samaritan, yet here were Christians killing Jews in Europe,'' he said.

title: PAUL COX'S FILMS EXPLORE THE INNER MAN
description: ''Isolation and loneliness in modern society has always puzzled

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: A Festival of Gifts At Discount Prices The John Rossi Company, the exclusive distributor of desk accessories designed and made in Italy by Nava Milano, has opened a retail shop in Ossining with 20 percent off retail prices. There are also samples and discontinued holiday and gift items from other sources at steeper reductions, some first quality, some seconds.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: MANFRED J. STROHMEIR, president and owner of European Tours Travel Service in East Rutherford, will begin publication in February of a magazine for travel agents that will offer advice on packaging group tours.

title: CELTICS HOLD OFF HAWK RALLY
description: Dennis Johnson hit three free throws in the final minute tonight as the Boston Celtics held off a late rally by the Atlanta Hawks and won, 101-94.

title: AIR FORCE TOPS VA. TECH, 23-7
description: The court-mandated presence of Bruce Smith did little to help Virginia Tech tonight as Bart Weiss's running and passing sparked Air Force to a 23-7 victory in the Independence Bowl.

title: Meeting Recesses in Sweden After Russian Berates West
description: The 35-nation Stockholm conference on European security recessed for the year Friday after the Soviet delegate accused the United States and NATO of preparing for war.

title: Q&A
description: Our co-op is in the process of rewriting its proprietary lease. We want to allow shareholders the right to sublet, but do not want to encourage turning apartments into a profit-making business. What have other co-ops done? . . . A. S., Manhattan

title: GIANTS LOSE TO SAINTS, 10-3, AND END WITH 9-7 MARK
description: The Giants were fortunate their game against the New Orleans Saints today could not affect their chances to make the playoffs. They played ineffectively on offense and erratically on defense, committed too many penalties and allowed too many sacks, and they lost, 10-3.

title: HOME CLINIC ;  Answering the Mail
description: Q . When I bought my house, there was an old asphalt patio out back that was covered with green fungus. I ripped this out and put down a new concrete patio, but now after a few months the same green fungus is back.

title: JUST WHAT GERMS WOULD THE ARMY GROW IN UTAH?
description: Since the days when bodies of cholera and plague victims were tossed over the walls of beleaguered cities, biological weapons have created a horror all their own. Last week, the Governor of Utah joined an effort to halt the Army's latest attempt to expand its germ warfare research laboratories.

title: AL HOLBERT TAKES OVER PORSCHE RACING
description: Motor sports competition has always been important to Porsche. More than any other auto manufacturer, except perhaps Ferrari, Porsche uses the rub-off from its competition activities to sell its road cars.

title: AMERICA REDISCOVERS ITS BLACK ACTORS
description: It's still too early to tell what the long-range effects will be, but one of the more encouraging

title: Valerie A. McDermott To Marry J. R. Cooper
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. McDermott of Tinton Falls, N.J., and Ludlow, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Valerie Ann McDermott to Jonathan Ross Cooper, a son of Mrs. Joseph S. Cooper of Mentor, Ohio, and Saxtons River, Vt. and the late Mr. Cooper. A May wedding is planned.

title: DISASTER DOMINATES A PARLEY
description: The deaths of more than 2,000 people from gas poisoning in the Indian city of Bhopal dominated the unofficial agenda at the International Organization of Consumers Unions conference here this week.

title: Anti-ApartheidProtests Grow
description: South Africa last week insisted anew that it would not be swayed by international criticism. But as the anti-apartheid chorus grew louder in Washington, New York and Stockholm, President P.W. Botha seemed more than a little on the defensive. ''No quiet diplomacy or hard shouting will keep us from seeking the road of justice,'' Mr. Botha said, rebutting President Reagan's assertion that the American policy of quiet pressure had pushed South Africa to release 11 nonwhite dissidents.

title: A SEASON OF RECEPTIONS BUT NO PARTY FOR REDSKINS' ART MONK
description: ART MONK never imagined he could have this kind of season. The way the Washington Redskins run their offense, with heavy reliance on the one running back, the passes are usually spread around among the receivers. Once in a while, one of them will have a quirky season, like Charlie Brown did a year ago, when he set a club record with 78 catches.

title: TO SUFFER A PROLONGED ILLNESS OR ELECT TO DIE: A CASE STUDY
description: When Robert Bauer made his regular visit to his wife's hospital bedside one morning last year, he had no inkling what was about to happen, how it would change his life forever and end his wife's.

title: A JEWEL OF MANY A CROWN
description: ONCE IN A RARE while, a book dedicated to food appears that is literary, informative and written with an enthusiasm bordering on the poetic. Of all the cookbooks we have scanned this year - and they can be counted by the score - only one comes close to that description. It is a book about what has been called ''the most tender and delicate of seafoods,'' the oyster. ''Oysters: A Culinary Celebration,'' published by Parnassus Imprints, Orleans, Mass., was written by Joan Reardon and Ruth Ebling.

title: THE INDUSTRY IS CHEERED BY RISING POSTAL COSTS
description: While there was the predictable grousing last week following the Postal Service's announcement that the price of mailing a first-class letter will soon rise to 22 cents, the news could not have been better for the providers of electronic mail. For years, companies involved in electronic mail - letters that are written on personal computers or word processors, then transmitted electronically over phone lines to another terminal - have been unprofitable. Part of the problem has been cost: the price of sending correspondence electronically has been more than triple that of messages sent with a stamp. With each postage rise, however, the price gap has narrowed, and electronic mail providers believe the most recent increase could give them a needed boost.

title: Anne Lantzius Is to Be Married in May
description: The engagement of Anne Maria Lantzius to Edward M. Strauss 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Strauss Jr. of New York, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John L. Lantzius of Vancouver, British Columbia, parents of the bride to be. A May wedding is planned.

title: AUSTRIAN IS DOWNHILL WINNER
description: Helmut Hoeflehner of Austria, who did not expect to be in top form for the first men's downhill race of the season, nonetheless posted an imposing margin in winning the World Cup event today.

title: A TEACHING DEGREE AT SARAH LAWRENCE
description: NEXT fall Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers will join the list of private liberal arts colleges offering teacher-preparation programs to their students.

title: JOURNALISM, HISTORY AND JOURNALISTIC HISTORY -AN EXCHANGE
description: The following letters were received in connection with Theodore Draper's article ''Journalism, History and Journalistic History'' in The New York Times Book Review Dec. 9. The letter from Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and both letters from the arms negotiator Paul H. Nitze were replies to Mr. Draper's earlier letters of inquiry about ''Deadly Gambits'' by Strobe Talbott. Their letters, together with Mr. Draper's original article, were sent to Mr. Talbott for his comments. Mr. Talbott's letter was then sent to Mr. Draper for reply. Two other letters of inquiry by Mr. Draper, to Assistant Secretary of Defense Richard N. Perle and to Assistant Secretary of State Richard R. Burt, were not answered.

title: FILM: 'MAN OF FLOWERS' AT LINCOLN PLAZA
description: ''Man of Flowers'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 9. The film opens today at the Lincoln Plaza Cinema 2, Broadway between 62d and 63d Streets. The leading character in Paul Cox's ''Man of Flowers'' is Charles Bremer (Norman Kaye), a wealthy Australian esthete who lives alone, studies drawing and flower arrangement, and writes frequent letters to his dead mother. His contact with others is rare, remote and more than a little ghoulish, as when he stands naked in his mirrored bathroom, speaking to a radio evangelist on his cordless telephone. He is asking if the evangelist doesn't share his feeling that flowers have a sensual allure.

title: AN EMBLEM OF MODERNISM
description: Perhaps no one need honor T. S. Eliot's wish for his life to remain unwritten; still, given the difficulty of proceeding without the help of his estate, why try? For Peter Ackroyd, it began when he wrote his critical study, ''Ezra Pound and His World'' - after which, Mr. Ackroyd said, ''Eliot seemed the one person I wanted to tackle. At one level he was emblematic of modernism, and after Pound he seemed a natural choice.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday on the engagement of Ruth Ellen Levine identified her fiance incorrectly. He is David William Sussman, the son of Leonard R. Sussman of New York and the late Mrs. Charles M. Buchholtz.

title: WORKERS WITH THE HOMELESS CALL SHELTERS A 'POOR STOPGAP'
description: RALPH ACOSTA JR. can tell when winter has arrived - not by the calendar, not by the weather but by the heightened public interest in the homeless. ''It's almost as though the season makes the problem,'' said Dr. Acosta, who is program director at the county-sponsored shelter for homeless men and women, run by the Volunteers of America at the Westchester County Airport,

title: ASBURY PARK CHANGING ITS RESORT IMAGE
description: FOR more than 100 years, Asbury Park

title: Tracy Budd to Marry John Baxter on Jan. 19
description: Tracy Ann Budd and John Baxter Day, principals in J. L. Baker & Associates, a theatrical properties company in Wallingford, Conn., plan to be married Jan. 19 in the chapel at Trinity College in Hartford.

title: SHULTZ IS WRONG ON TERRORISM
description: In three recent speeches, Secretary of State George P. Shultz has permitted his obsession with terrorism to distort his normally judicious view of the world.

title: MODERN PESTICIDES AID IN INSURING MORE FOOD FOR POOREST COUNTRIES
description: The accident at the pesticide plant in Bhopal that killed at least 2,000 people has obscured the fact that pesticides have also brought better health to millions of people in India and other third world countries, according to international food and health officials here.

title: CANOE CAVEAT
description: To the Editor:

title: COUNCIL PANEL BACKS BAN ON FISHING FROM SOME CITY BRIDGES
description: Fishermen have become a menace to boaters, joggers and motorists in New York City and should be barred from some bridges, a City Council committee has concluded.

title: STAGE DESIGNER WITH A POET'S PALETTE
description: Michael Billington reports regularly on British theater.

title: FREE-AGENT PACTS PUT HOLE IN THEORY
description: THE owner of a National League club noted the contracts that free agents have signed in the past couple of weeks and remarked, ''It's a good thing the owners are conspiring to keep down salaries.''

title: Plans for Title Bout
description: David Solerwitz and Lenard Leeds, attorneys from Mineola, L.I., who are incorporated as Lightning Bolt Productions, may have lost money in promoting the first boxing program in four years at Nassau Coliseum Friday night, but there is a silver lining: They have the negotiating rights for a world light-heavyweight championship fight between Michael Spinks, the champion, and David Sears of Howard Beach, Queens. ''Feb. 23 is a date we are looking at,'' Leeds said. ''Naturally, there would be nationwide TV, and I am hoping to have Vito Antuofermo and Howard Davis on the card, too.''

title: SEEKING TO AVERT A SMALL COLONIAL WAR
description: Edgard Pisani, the special envoy sent in haste by an alarmed French Government to this troubled Pacific territory to restore order and seek a political solution, was able to declare last week that the first part of his mandate had been fulfilled. The killings have stopped and the roadblocks manned by Melanesian separatists since mid-November have been lifted in most areas. Mr. Pisani seemed a long way from a political solution, however.

title: CHRISTMAS ISN'T MY HOLIDAY, AFTER ALL
description: IT'S that time of year again. The music,

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Hoboken has never been a pop-music mecca, despite having given the world Frank Sinatra and later serving as home base for various rock bands. But Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, continues to be the most comfortably informal rock club in the vicinity of New York City, and the amiably eccentric garage-pop one most frequently encounters there has found a home on Hoboken's own Coyote label.

title: Pamela Thompson to Wed Joseph Bauernfeind 3d
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Owen Edward Thompson of Pelham Manor, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Pamela Lynn Thompson to Joseph Bauernfeind 3d, a son of Mrs. Bauernfeind Jr. of Willard, Wis., and the late Mr. Bauernfeind. The wedding is to be in May.

title: THE NATION ; Georgia ThrowsThe Switch
description: Lawyers for Alpha Otis Stephens had been fighting his death sentence for almost a decade, but last week state and Federal appeals courts refused to delay his execution any longer. Mr. Stephens, a convicted murderer, became the third person put to death in a Georgia prison in the past 12 months.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
description: HAPPY HANUKKAH

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: GIFTS FOR CHILDREN

title: DEFROSTING LIBEL CHILL
description: To the Editor:

title: SUFFOLK UNION TALLYING VOTE
description: A BITTER struggle within the Civil Service Employees Association in Suffolk County that has ramifications beyond the union will come to a head tomorrow.

title: DEAN OF ENGINEERS, SHE'S A TRAILBLAZER
description: '' TOO many people think of engineers only as designers and manufacturers of instruments of death and destruction, and that's not really the case at all,'' said Eleanor Baum of Great Neck. ''I see the role of the engineer as making society a better place for all of us.''

title: Floppy Disks For A Merry Christmas
description: THERE'S something quite unprecedented for children in bookstores this Christmas. Computer software - ''floppy disks'' that, when inserted in a home computer, cause graphics and color to appear on the screen and make sounds emerge from the computer's sound box - are on sale in more than 1,000 stores across the country. These include members of the Waldenbooks and Barnes & Noble chains and independent bookstores services by Ingram Book Company, the Nashville-based wholesaler.

title: PRESERVATION LAW SAVED FARMERS $13 MILLION ON TAXES IN '82
description: A 13-year-old state law passed to help preserve farms by reducing their taxes resulted in a savings of $13 million for farmers in 1982, according to a new study by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment.

title: FAIRNESS, COMMON SENSE AND THE SUPERSTATION ISSUE
description: BRUCE SUTTER to Atlanta. Gary Carter to New York. Rick Sutcliffe back with the Cubs.

title: JERSEY COURT RULES AN INSURER MUST WARN IF A POLICY LAPSES
description: A state appeals court has ruled that insurance companies are obliged to notify policyholders of the expiration of a fire insurance policy and that they must automatically renew policies if they fail to give notice.

title: THIS IS RICKY HENDERSON: SPEED THAT TERRORIZES
description: THIS is Rickey Henderson: 'He took off from second base with the pitch,'' Butch Wynegar related, recalling his most vivid memory of a Henderson escapade. ''It was a fastball right down the middle that the hitter took. When I caught the ball, he was barely reaching halfway between second and third. When I came up to throw, I remember thinking to myself, 'I got him, I got him.' I made a perfect, chest- high throw to Nettles, but by the time the ball got there, he was sliding in safe. I swear he accelerated like I have never seen anyone accelerate. I stood there bewildered. I was in awe.''

title: ;  The Water Mill In Water Mill
description: We are writing to correct a statement in ''Saving the Great 'Sails' of Long Island'' (Nov. 25). The article said that the South Fork's ''first mill was a water mill built on a stream five miles from the center of East Hampton in 1648.''

title: OPERETTA STAR STILL LIVELY AT 88
description: EATONTOWN SIXTY years ago, on Dec. 2, 1924, Sigmund Romberg's classic operetta ''The Student Prince'' opened in New York, introducing a new star to the Broadway stage, Ilse Marvenga.

title: Penguins 5, Maple Leafs 2
description: Pittsburgh got goals from Andy Brickley, Mark Taylor and Kevin McCarthy to snap a 2-2 tie and defeat Toronto for its fifth straight victory. Moe Mantha and Warren Young also scored for the Penguins, who moved to within one game of the club record for consecutive victories. John Anderson and Walt Poddubny scored for the Leafs, who outshot the Penguins 37-24.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article about the contestants for the license for radio station WLIR that appeared in the Long Island Weekly on Dec. 2, one of the applicants, North Shore Broadcasting, was incorrectly described as a corporation. It is a general partnership.

title: GAMBLING ADDICTS SEEK AID AT CLINIC
description: Not long after her first trip to Atlantic City, the 50-year- old businesswoman had become addicted to gambling, she recalled.

title:
DINING OUT;
OFF THE BEATEN TRACK IN SUSSEX
description: RESTAURANT gems sometimes pop up in the most unlikely places. Middleville, for instance, is a long way from practically everywhere. Yet, that rural Sussex County community is the site of a charming old inn that serves some of the most interesting meals we have had in a long time.

title: Flicker of Hope
description: It was just a flicker of movement in his left foot, but it was the first flicker William Andrews, the Atlanta Falcons' running back, had seen in the foot since training camp, and it was a welcome sight. ''It's the first encouraging flicker,'' said the Falcons' orthopedic surgeon, Dr. John Garrett, noting that Andrews had not been able to move the foot since a training-camp injury to his knee tore three ligaments and stretched the nerve that controls the foot's upward movement.

title: THE REGION ; Poorer QuarterLeft Behind byNew York Boom
description: More and more, the story of New York's economic resurgence is becoming a tale of two cities. Since January 1983, more than 140,000 new jobs have been created by the booming service and financial industries.

title: 7.1 Million in Grants Made to Small Colleges
description: Education Secretary T. H. Bell has announced the award of $7.1 million in matching grants to help 33 colleges with large concentrations of poor students build up their endowments.

title: HARRIMAN FOUNDATION DONATES 560-ACRE ESTATE TO COLUMBIA
description: Columbia University has been given a 560-acre estate in the Ramapo Mountains at Arden, N.Y., by the Gladys and Roland Harriman Foundation, university has announced.

title: Who Needs Economic Advisers?
description: The President's Council of Economic Advisers seems to have made the White House hit list. Abolish it, some Reagan aides urge. The Government has enough economists without those three who mostly tell the President things he doesn't want to hear. Who needs them?

title: A MOOD OF RESENTMENT SPREADS OUT OF BHOPAL
description: Beyond the grievous human toll at Bhopal is an economic and political question: Will India slow its headlong rush to acquire Western technology and pull in a welcome mat only recently put out for American and other foreign investors?

title: ANNE HARTWELL, A.R. HIRSCHFELD EXCHANGE VOWS
description: Anne Colby Hartwell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Adams Hartwell of New York, was married yesterday to A. Robert Hirschfeld, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Hirschfeld of Cheshire, Conn. The Rev. Henry Ashe Tilghman, rector of St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Norwich, Vt., performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in Woodstock, Vt.

title:
A CHRISTMAS APPEAL: HELP THE NEEDIEST CASES;
HOW THOSE WITH CAN HELP THOSE WITHOUT
description: Federation of Jewish Philanthropies Of New York

title: A COOK'S TOUR OF EARLY AMERICAN RECIPES
description: UNTIL the year 1796, cooks in the new United States of America had to rely on recipes printed in England. Then came the first cookbook native to this country, written and published by an enterprising Connecticut woman named Amelia Simmons.

title: Risk Forces OutVaccine Maker
description: Whooping cough vaccine, like many other medical blessings, can have severe side effects for a minority of users. Last week, in what could be viewed as a side effect of the side effects, the vaccine was in short supply in some parts of the United States.

title: THE HIGHLY PAID JOB SHOPPERS
description: ROSE CIRESI, armed with a marketing degree and more than a decade of business experience, is a job shopper. Her two- week assignment with a New Jersey telecommunications company has already stretched beyond a year.

title: HOLIDAY DISPLAYS IN SCHOOLS QUESTIONED
description: IT'S going to take Solomonic wisdom on the part of Long Island

title: Ronnie Sussman to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Sussmann of Harrington Park, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ronnie Ann Sussmann to Matthew Howard Powell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald W. Powell of Englewood, N.J. A June wedding is planned. Miss Sussmann, an associate in the New York law firm of Ballon, Stoll & Itzler, graduated from Vassar College and the Boston University School of Law. Mr. Powell, a senior accountant at Hoberman, Miller & Company in New York, graduated from the University of Bridgeport.

title: KOCH'S OPPONENTS SEEK A WINNING COMBINATION
description: Criticizing Mayor Koch was easy. So was agreeing that the best way to defeat him was to rally around one opponent. But that's where the consensus ended last week as three prospective mayoral challengers opened the new political season with the first of what will undoubtedly be many forums over the next 11 months.

title: THE DANCE: MARGIE GILLIS IN CONCERT
description: Margie Gillis's dancing was always vivid and usually bizarre in the solos she offered on Wednesday night at Playhouse 46.

title: A MAN FOR ALL PEOPLE
description: ''IN his 16 years as owner and president of the Philadelphia Eagles, Leonard Tose has been a man for all people - whether it's meeting Mayor Wilson Goode at City Hall, mingling with Eagles fans at places like the Red Lantern Inn near the Vet, or personally calling season ticket holders.''

title: 'Affordable Rents'
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan E. Kessler Exchanges Vows With John Hess
description: Susan Elizabeth Kessler, the daughter of Debra Kessler of New York and Los Angeles and the late Bernard Kessler, was married in New York yesterday to John Barnett Hess, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Hess of New York and Deal, N.J. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Senator ByrdHolds the Helm
description: Democrats on the Senate side gave their dissatisfactions about party personalities and party policies an airing last week. As with last month's challenge to House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the frustration had little issue. Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the party's leader in the Senate for the past eight years, easily won re-election. Lawton Chiles of Florida, who had mounted a late campaign against Mr. Byrd, took only 11 of the 47 votes cast.

title: AT LAST, A SCHOOL BOOK ON STATE HISTORY
description: IN years past, when Connecticut

title: Bearing a Child in Medical School
description: I enjoyed reading Perri Klass's article, ''Bearing a Child in Medical School'' (Nov. 11). Her experience reminds me of my first two years of medical school, when I felt threatened by each new disease I studied.

title: VERSATILE PORTABLE EQUIPMENT USHERS IN VIDEO-ON-THE-GO
description: Video fans eager to make their own tapes often see themselves as producers of the biggest show of all: The Life and Times of Yours Truly - the video documentation of their children and family, friends, homes, pets, travels, sports and various adventures. They share the universal urge to immortalize themselves, and video cassettes have become the latest means to this immemorial end.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:

title: ENCOURAGED AWARDS FOR 'GENIUS'
description: J. Roderick MacArthur, a Chicago businessman and philanthropist who sought to encourage the spark of genius through no-strings cash awards to ''exceptionally gifted individuals,'' died yesterday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. Mr. MacArthur was 63 years old.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: MIDDLE VILLAGE
description: TRADITIONAL values are taken

title: U.S. PANEL SEES FIRE PERIL IN CITY'S SUBWAYS FROM PILES OF GARBAGE
description: Federal inspectors conducting a weeklong investigation of fires in New York City's subway system have found piles of garbage in dangerous areas and a lack of fire extinguishers, according to the head of the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: BEARING A CHILD IN MEDICAL SCHOOL
description: As a first-year medical student at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, I read Perri Klass's article with interest.

title: RAPE 'HELP-LINE'
description: Rape victims in the county who choose not to report the crime will soon be able to telephone a 24- hour Rape Crisis Help-Line for support and assistance.

title: RETAILERS HOPING FOR LATE RUSH IN SALES
description: With their busiest days of the year immediately ahead of them, retailers at shopping centers around the Island are poised for a strong sales finish to the Christmas shopping season.

title: NIAGARA STUNS ST. JOHN'S, 62-59
description: What was expected to be a mere tuneup for No. 4-ranked St. John's turned into a general breakdown tonight as the Redmen were upset by Niagara, 62-59. It was the first loss in six games this season for the Redmen.

title:
ANTIQUES;
PROPS AS QUIET LURES TO SHOPPERS
description: WHAT many shops have in common is their generous and astutely selective use of antiques as a display device.

title: Martha Cargill Planning June Marriage
description: Announcement has been made by William S. Cargill of Marbella, Spain, and Mrs. Harris E. Russell of Southport, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Martha Lyons Cargill to Reeve Kelsey Biggers Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Biggers of Redding, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: GEORGETOWN OVERPOWERS DEPAUL, 77-57
description: The task at Georgetown University is no longer to establish its basketball supremacy. The control that was achieved last April was overwhelmingly reinforced this afternoon.

title: ROLE OF UNIVERSITIES IN FOREIGN CONTRACTS
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE EVE OF DISPOSAL, INDIAN CITY LIES SILENT
description: The once-bustling slum of Jayaprakash Nagar outside the Union Carbide plant here was empty, silent and shuttered hours before the scheduled start of the disposal of the chemical that was responsible for killing more than 2,000 people last week.

title: BEARING A CHILD IN MEDICAL SCHOOL Perri Klass criticizes her medical education in obstet
description: rics for focusing too much on the disorders of pregnancy and not enough on the normal pregnancy. I am one of her classmates, and I sat through the same lectures last December at Harvard.

title: NEWARK PUPILS GET JOB BRIEFING
description: NEWARK THE architectural lines and archways that few commuters take time to notice at Pennsylvania Station here did not escape the eyes of some local eighth-grade pupils on a recent tour of the 47-year-old building.

title: POLISH TV CALLS U.S. SANCTIONS A FIASCO
description: Polish television said tonight that the withdrawal of United States objections to Polish membership in the International Monetary Fund was ''another proof of the fiasco of the American policy of sanctions.''

title: On Language; Free World, So-Called
description: -wing Presidential aide after I had given an essay about the use of color for political classification the daring title of ''Wave of the Fuchsia.'' The message was brief and pointed - ''Your friends are worried'' - but the note paper caught my attention. Instead of the simple blue-on-white ''The White House, Washington,'' there was a yellow stick-on paper with the printed heading ''If This Gets Into the Hands of the Russians, It's Curtains for the Free World.''

title: Kimberly Idler Bride Of Myles D. Gillespie
description: Kimberly Ann Idler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John N. Idler of Fort Washington, Pa., was married yesterday to Myles D. Gillespie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Gillespie 3d of Harrison, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas J. Kelly performed the ceremony at St. Alphonsus Roman Catholic Church in Maple Glen, Pa.

title: EILEEN LAMBERT WEDS F.L. NEWBAUER
description: Eileen Frances Lambert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Lambert of Greenwich, Conn., and Conway, N.H., was married to Frank Lewis Newbauer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Newbauer of Lima, Ohio. The Rev. Douglas Tufaro performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; New Families forBell Offspring
description: Under the original court guidelines for the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company into separate, independent components, new local telephone companies were not allowed to be anything but local. Under a new ruling last week, however, the breakup of Ma Bell could take on aspects of a cloning, with local phone companies growing into little A.T.&T.'s.

title: CHANGE COEXISTS WITH TRADITION AT THE CLEVELAND
description: There are signs of change at the Cleveland Museum of Art. A year and a half after Sherman E. Lee retired and Evan H. Turner replaced him as director, there is clear evidence of a different style and taste. But there is also every indication that the museum will remain fundamentally in accord with Mr. Lee's philosophy, which, together with the comprehensiveness of its collection and its strong financial base, was instrumental in developing the institution into one of the handful of great American museums.

title: Overdue Books Bring A Criminal Sentence
description: Constance Moore, 29 years old, had to report to the Santa Rita jail Friday for booking and fingerprinting because she had failed to return 13 library books.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; The Ill WindsOf Nuclear War
description: It was the most harrowing weather forecast since the Ice Age, and one of the most controversial: swirling clouds of dust and smoke would blot out the sun, producing a frigid season of darkness and devastation that could be even worse than the nuclear war that triggered it. Although some have dismissed the idea as more propaganda than science, a panel from the National Academy of Scientists concluded last week that despite great uncertainties a ''nuclear winter'' was a ''clear possibility.''

title: Lize Mifflin, Sculptor, Wed on Shelter Island
description: Elizabeth Parker Mifflin and Kaspar Schmid were married yesterday at the Shelter Island (L.I.) Justice Hall by Town Justice Edward J. Hannabury.

title: LATE IN LIFE, A FIRST NOVEL
description: HARRIET SEGAL, a Hartsdale resident and author of the recently published novel, ''Susquehanna,'' says she grew up thinking that she would write a novel at some point in her life. That it took her so many years to get started remains something of a mystery to her.

title: REOPENED BRIDGE REVIVES PHILADELPHIA MALL
description: Out of habit, Claire Diolazo got off her train today at Suburban Station and prepared to walk the half-mile to Center City to the Gallery II shopping mall on Market Street.

title: HARD-PRESSED STEEL TOWN BUYS A CHANCE WITH LOTTERY PLAY
description: This old steelworkers' community, with immense financial difficulties but no lack of imagination, has adopted an unusual tactic for addressing its economic needs.

title:
THE ACRES FAMILY SONS PLAY WELL FOR THEIR FATHER, THE COACH;
FAMILY THAT PLAYS TOGETHER
description: AMONG college basketball teams that have been coached by men with sons on their own rosters, Oral Roberts University has the rarest and most unplanned combination.

title: MANDATE RENEWED FOR CYPRUS FORCE
description: The Security Council extended the mandate of the United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus for six months today, acting against a backdrop of apparently successful negotiations between Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot leaders.

title: SUBTEEN TROUPERS ENTERTAIN THE AGED
description: MONTCLAIR '' MANY years ago,'' the letter said, ''I was a first-grade teacher in the Montclair schools for 40 years. Now I am an old lady 91 years old, but I remember a number of my pupils.

title: Carla Mayer Plans a Winter Wedding
description: Carla Mayer, director of advertising and promotion for Villard Books, a division of Random House, and David Glasser, an associate in the New York law firm of Pavia & Harcourt, plan to be married in a private ceremony Dec. 27.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
STAR IS BORN
description: WHEN Jason Kingsley of Chappaqua was born with Down's syndrome, a doctor told his parents, Charles and Emily , to institutionalize him immediately and tell relatives that the baby had died at birth. Today, 10 years later, Jason is reading, writing, doing arithmetic - and acting. On Wednesday, he stars with Lee Majors in an episode of ''The Fall Guy'' (Channel 7 at 8 P.M.) in which he plays a mentally retarded youngster caught up in a dangerous adventure.

title: OPTIMISM AMID DEFEAT
description: In or out of the playoffs, and despite their dreary 10-3

title: ;  Writer of Article Chided as 'Thankless'
description: Vanessa Levy (Speaking Personally, Nov. 25), how many friends and relatives do you think your parents (proudly, of course) telephoned and said, ''Have you read our daughter's essay about us ('When a Star Border Returns') in The Times?''

title:
THE TREASURY'S TAX PLAN-- BOOM OR BUST?;
A VIABLE PROGRAM TO FIX THE SYSTEM
description: THE Federal tax system is widely

title: HEADLINERS ; Goodbye to estAs far as
description: Werner Erhard is concerned, est isn't where it's at any more. Mr. Erhard, who in 1971 founded Erhard Seminar Training (est) and through it peddled his brand of personal transformation to an estimated half million people, said last week he was ending the program and replacing it with something called ''The Forum.'' A spokesman said the decision had nothing to do with a recent decline in est enrollment or the fact that Mr. Erhard's wife is divorcing him and demanding a piece of the est action.

title: LESSON FROM BHOPAL
description: To the Editor:

title: A BIT OF YANKEE FLAVOR IN OHIO
description: ABE ZAIDAN is the senior editor of The Akron Beacon Journal.

title: HEATING-OIL SUPPLY RISES
description: -heating oil in Connecticut, which dropped to ''dangerously low levels'' two months ago, is now above the levels of last year, the energy office of the State Office of Policy and Management reported last week.

title: RECITAL: 3 PIECES BY MARSHALL
description: Ingram Marshall, a composer from San Francisco, brought three of his pieces to Carnegie Recital Hall Wednesday night. Mr. Marshall's music offers, in its earnest and amiable way, a supermarket of familiar musical products. He himself plays the piano and an Asian wooden flute, and he sings and mouths sound effects - and all of the above are played against prerecorded tapes and transformed by electronically induced delayed responses.

title: Sober Ending forThe Happy Hour
description: For many bars and restaurants, offering customers alcoholic drinks at sharply reduced prices during the unwinding hours of the early evening has come to be a tradition. Because of mounting concern about accidents caused by customers who have knocked down one cheap drink too many, Massachusetts last week banned the ''happy hours.''

title: FLEDGING THEATER STRIVES IN FAIRFIELD
description: '' THERE'S nothing around like us,'' said Rob LaGamba, the artistic director of the Boston Post Road Stage Company in Fairfield.

title: DRAMA: BECKETT PIECES
description: Samuel Beckett's ''Fizzles,'' a collection of brief prose pieces written over a period of 15 years, are the narrative equivalent of what the author calls dramaticules - spasms of imagery and memory that assert themselves as night thoughts. Fizzle, fourade in French, means both ''sputtering'' and ''fiasco.''

title: NEW TECHNIQUES FOR BIG CATCHES
description: TWO New England big-game anglers, Bob Mayo and Steve Moreton, have developed a highly effective technique for catching giant bluefin tuna and other pelagic species with artificial lures.

title: Under a Blood Red Sky
description: Featuring U2 MCA Home Video 55 minutes. $29.95

title: 'LION IN WINTER': ROYAL STRUGGLES
description: THE holiday season is a time of family gatherings, and in James Goldman's historical drama, ''The Lion in Winter,'' the royal family of King Henry II is gathering for the Christmas court. The time is 1180, the place is Henry's castle at Chinon, France, and the purpose is not so much a celebration as it is a medieval power struggle for the throne of England.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
WAITING FOR NEXT TIME
description: Mark Kramer,

title: MORE CHELSEA CHIC
description: Chelsea's growing chic has put a premium on brownstones in the neighborhood just above Greenwich Village.

title: CORPORATION FORCED TO REASSESS RISKS AND TO REVIEW SAFETY RULES
description: The escape of poison gas from a chemical plant in India on Dec. 3 has raised broad ethical, legal, social and technical questions for multinational corporations.

title: Beatrice A. Reed Is Married
description: Beatrice A. Reed, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Pryor Reed of New York, and Roger A. Morrison, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Roger Morrison of London, were married yesterday. Bishop Theodore E. McCarrick of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Metuchen, N.J., performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: MUSIC OF THE SEASON FILLS COUNTY
description: ONE of the rarer joys of Christmas is the clear, floating sound of a live boys' choir performing the old English carols, invoking Dickensian tableaus of steaming roast goose served in candlelighted rooms cheerful with holly and smiling revelers.

title: Virginia Hinrichs Is to Be Married To Stephen Miller
description: Mr. and Mrs. John R. Hinrichs of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Lee Hinrichs, to Stephen Wilcox Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Thompson Miller of Roswell, Ga., formerly of Summit, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Blacks, Jews and Mayor Koch
description: A hundred New Yorkers, blacks and Jews, have been meeting for a year to explore their differences and this week they set out to try to revive some political collaborations. Mayor Koch, a Jew who has had his difficulties with blacks, swiftly branded the group a ''cabal'' being exploited by people who want to defeat him for re-election next year.

title: TOP JERSEY COURT EXTENDS THE LIABILITY OF HOME CONTRACTORS
description: Homeowners can bring lawsuits for shoddy workmanship against contractors that were hired to do improvements by the previous homeowners, according to a ruling by the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: JEWETT ZONING PANEL RESUMES FUNCTIONS
description: THE Jewett City zoning commission got back to business as usual last week, for the first time in more than two months, as it approved plans for expansion of the Jewett City Pharmacy and the State Theater.

title: CHILDREN OF BRONX HEAR AN APPEAL ON COAST
description: On a rainy weeknight nearly 3,000 miles from the Bronx, Jeffrey Silber and more than 275 guests gathered at a house in the Brentwood area to celebrate their old borough by starting an association to involve Bronx youth in the arts.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
IN 'NUTCRACKER'S' PIVOTAL ROLES
description: IT'S coming down to the wire.

title: MUSIC: CONJUNTO CLASSICO
description: Conjunto Clasico is a young band building on an old-fashioned style. In Cuba in the 1940's, Arsenio Rodriguez led conjunto dance bands featuring three trumpets over a rhythm section of bass, guitar, piano and percussion.

title: Shultz gets NATOBacking ForSoviet Talks
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz got some important business out of the way last week before his meeting on arms control with Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko in Geneva Jan. 7 and 8. Mr. Shultz's colleagues at the annual winter meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization gave him their full backing, including a pledge to continue the deployment of Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in Western Europe pending an agreement with Moscow to limit or eliminate medium-range missiles on both sides of the continent.

title: FOR CUBANS EXCLUDED, A WAY OUT-OR IN
description: Until last week about 2,700 Cubans, a small part of the more than 125,000 refugees who sailed the ''freedom flotilla'' to Florida four years ago from the Cuban fishing village of Mariel, had been trapped in a kind of legal limbo.

title: THE WORLD ; Britain FailsIn Extradition Bid
description: Joseph P.T. Doherty, a member of the extremist provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army, escaped from a Belfast prison in 1981, two days before his conviction for the murder of a British captain during the ambush of a British Army patrol in Northern Ireland the previous year. He found clandestine refuge in New York until his arrest last year in a Manhattan bar.

title: F.C.C. SILENCES RADIO STATION
description: IF you ask Alan Weiner about

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
DEVELOPMENT AND DRINKING WATER: THE DANGERS OF THE MIX
description: THE need to protect watersheds surrounding surface reservoirs from the contaminating effects of commercial or residential development is well understood. Millions of acres of upstate forests have been precluded from large-scale development to assure clean water in the public supply reservoirs owned by New York City. Unfortunately, Long Island's aquifers, or underground reservoirs, are not as well protected.

title: STATE TO KEEP MONITORING THE CASINO UNION
description: ATLANTIC CITY SHORTLY after resigning last week as president of this resort city's largest hotel- casino union, Frank Gerace became a $48,000-a-year ''consultant'' to the union.

title: BEREAVED OFFERED PLACES TO TURN TO
description: '' I DON'T believe you ever recover from bereavement or stop missing a person you love very much, but happily you do change and grow,'' said Lynn Caine, author of the book ''Widow'' and keynote speaker at a recent conference, ''New Options for the Widowed.'' The conference, planned by the county's Department of Community Mental Health, Westchester Community College and the Westchester Self-Help Clearinghouse, was co-sponsored by a number of other agencies working with the bereaved in the county.

title: JACKO THE HEX
description: Valerie Miner is a novelist whose latest work is ''Winter's Edge.'' A WORLD MADE OF FIRE

title: FAMINE SHARPENS QUESTIONS ON THE NATURE OF AFRICAN AID
description: On barren-seeming land in Burkina Faso, a robed man with a hoe carves a slender furrow from red and stony dirt. The line follows a route marked by plastic piping filled with water. The idea, brought by a foreigner, is to find the contour of the land and create terraces that will save the soil and bring fertility. Elsewhere, other images prevail: highways built across wastelands that do not connect with other highways; flour mills rising up in places that cannot produce wheat; aid translated into suites of offices and fleets of cars. The conflicting pictures pose their own question: What do needy people really need? And, increasingly in this time of widening starvation in Africa, a further question arises: Who, ultimately, is responsible for answering those needs?Last week, an acrimonious dispute erupted between Ethiopia, which blamed the West for the extent of its crippling famine, and the United States Agency for International Development. The agency's administrator, M. Peter McPherson, accused Ethiopia of ''biting the hand'' that feeds it. To some, Mr. McPherson had a point. Ethiopia, arguably Africa's most rigid Marxist state, led by a regime that came to power in a series of blood-stained ''terrors,'' seems to spend more on the guns to fight its rebellious peoples in Eritrea and Tigre than it does on promoting the growth of food.

title: THE RUNAWAY SLEIGH RIDE
description: ASTRID LINDGREN'S near-classic children's book, ''Pippi Longstocking,'' was published in this country in 1950, a little late for my childhood; I also missed it during my reading-to- children years, an omission I happily rectified recently. Pippi proved to be a delightfully naughty 6- or 7-year- old who lives all by herself in a big house. She spends her time outwitting grown-ups who want to provide her with more suitable accommodations, and corrupting two young neighbors, stout-hearted Tommy, who follows Pippi anywhere, e.g., down hollow tree trunks, and timid Annika, who glumly tags along.

title: Miss Shrewsbury, Artist, Married to Adrian Lopez
description: The marriage of Marcie Shrewsbury, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Shrewsbury of Mantoloking, N.J., and Adrian Bernard Lopez, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Eugenio Lopez of Montclair, N.J., took place yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Church in New York.

title: ON THE HEIGHTS
description: When Alfred T. White, the Brooklyn philanthropist, built the Riverside Buildings in the late 1880's, he aimed to show that comfortable, well- designed housing could be built for the working poor as a profit-making venture.

title: Everton Retains Lead By Beating Nottingham
description: Everton retained first place in the First Division of the English Soccer League today, trouncing Nottingham Forest, 5-0.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
description: VIENNA CHOIR BOYS

title: HOW 'THE RIVER' CAME TO THE SCREEN
description: The trees of Central Park were alternating shades of maize and red, and the stream of yellow taxis along Fifth Avenue blended into the autumn palette. Mark Rydell stood at the window of his 24th-floor hotel suite and smiled at the bold landscape, fraught with contrasts - of golds and grays, of nature and construction, of people and machines.

title: Jane Davis Plans To Marry Feb. 16
description: Elizabeth Jane Davis, an account executive for Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, the New York advertising agency, plans to be married Feb. 16 to Robert G. Hottensen Jr., a vice president of and securities analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York.

title: BEHIND THE 1985 CROP OF GUIDEBOOKS
description: Suddenly it is 1985 - in the travel sections of bookstores, anyway. Their shelves are brimming with 1985 editions of popular ''meat and potatoes'' guidebooks that list what they regard as the best hotels, restaurants, entertainment, shops and sightseeing attractions. Many such books have just become available - right before Christmas and Hanukkah - and make fine last- minute gifts.

title: PIANISTS AND A VIOLINIST AMONG PLAYERS
description: Last Monday night, the young American pianist Julie Bees presented a concert at the Abraham Goodman House that was a model of gracious and intelligent music-making. This marked Miss Bees's solo debut here, although she is not unknown to local audiences, having appeared at Carnegie Hall as soloist with the Youth Symphony Orchestra of New York three seasons ago. Miss Bees studied at the University of Colorao, and later served on the faculty of Peabody Conservatory of Music. She was recently a semifinalist in the Clara Haskil International Piano Competition in Switzerland.

title: EX-CUBAN SETS SIGHTS ON SKY AND BEYOND
description: PALISADES PARK FRIENDS and business acquaintances call 49-year-old Carlos Hernandez determined, energetic and stubborn. Some think he is a bit crazy.

title: SIGHTS AND REFLECTIONS
description: DOUBLE VISION

title: IDEAS & TRENDS;
description: Legal fees, however costly, are usually a byproduct of litigation. They were at the center, however, of an unusual case the United States Supreme Court agreed to resolve last week that pits veterans groups against the Government.

title: HOSPITAL PRODUCES WEEKLY TV SHOW
description: '' A HOSPITAL today is expected to do much more than just cure illness - it's expected to be a 'wellness' center and do patient education and some community education,'' said Ruth Kitchen, director of public relations and development at the New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center. In an effort to fulfill that objective, the hospital has developed an unusual television series, ''Closeup,'' that is shown on cable television to 20 communities countywide.

title: FIGHTING AND INFIGHTING IN THE PACIFIC
description: Donald M. Goldstein is the co-author with K. V. Dillon and the late Gordon W. Prange of ''At Dawn We Slept,'' ''Miracle at Midway,'' ''Target Tokyo'' and the forthcoming ''Verdict of History.'' EAGLE AGAINST THE SUN

title: CD PLAYERS MAKE IDEAL GIFTS
description: Santa Claus is usually portrayed as a happily unneurotic type with nary a worry. But I suspect his ostentatious jollity is deceptive and that he really suffers multiple stress-related syndromes, agonizing about what to bring people for Christmas.

title: ADVOCATES FOR THE RIGHT TO LIFE
description: Marcia Chambers is a legal affairs reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday on the troubled outlook for tobacco and textiles in the South misstated an estimate of sales for American textile and apparel manufacturers this year. The American Textile Manufacturers Institute estimated sales of $50 billion, which it said was about 20 percent below the figure that would have applied in the absence of competition from imports.

title: Battling Graffiti
description: With Mayor Koch exclaiming ''Eureka!'' amid much rejoicing, the New York Sanitation Department demonstrated in August a product it called the answer to graffiti: GP-66. The Mayor applied the liquid to graffiti and - eureka - no more graffiti.

title: Jeanne M. FitzGibbons Plans to Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. William A. FitzGibbons of Great River, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jeanne Marie FitzGibbons to Thomas John Herrmann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Herrmann of Plainview, L.I., and Palm Harbor, Fla. The wedding is planned for July.

title: ON PIERO'S OWN GROUND
description: Each generation makes its own list of the greatest artists of the past; it is not uncommon for someone who was little known in his own lifetime, like Vermeer, to be judged a paragon hundreds of years later. In our own day, perhaps the most dramatic example of the upgrading of a painter's reputation is that of Piero della Francesca, that mysterious genius of the quattrocento from the Tuscan backwater of Sansepolcro. Almost ignored in the 19th century (Ruskin barely mentions him), Piero is acknowledged today to be one of the greatest artists who ever lived, worthy of comparison with Leonardo or Van Eyck.

title: RARE PIANO PIECES GET A HEARING
description: The Romantic Revival has been taking a look at Anton Rubinstein, the 19th-century Russian pianist who, in the latter half of the century, was considered the only serious rival to Franz Liszt. Four of his five piano concertos have been recorded. By far the most popular through the decades has been No. 4 in D minor, and it is still heard every once in a while. The other Rubinstein concertos have vanished. Listening to No. 1, as played by Michael Fardink and the Royal Philharmonic conducted by Paul Freeeman on an Orion cassette (OC 657), it is easy to understand why this concerto's neglect is, by and large, deserved.

title: THEY GO SHOPPING, BROWSING, AND SPLURGING
description: -age girls in twos, threes and sometimes tens are swarming like bees to sweet honey to places like Great Neck, Woodbury, Cedarhurst, Merrick and other pockets throughout the Island where ''name'' clothing shops abound. Many go just to browse or to be seen; others to fill in their wardrobes with one or two items and bring their mothers back for the big buys. But some as young as 8 years old, store owners say, drop a few hundred dollars on casual clothes without batting an eye and then head back shortly for another round.

title: WINTERING IN TUSCANY
description: WILLIAM WEAVER is the author of ''Duse'' (Harcourt, Brace Jovanovich).

title: POVERTY WORSENING IN CITY, STUDY FINDS
description: The poor of New York City have not been helped by the city's recent economic resurgence and are unlikely to be touched by future improvements, according to a sweeping study sponsored by the Community Service Society of Greater New York.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on page 3 of the Arts and Leisure section today, giving the opening date for Albert Innaurato's play ''Coming of Age in SoHo'' at the Public Theater, has become outdated. The play will close after tonight's performance, and a new opening date will be announced later this month.

title: USE OF AGED IN CHILD CARE URGED IN BILL
description: TRENTON THE Offices on Aging in the state's 21 counties would act as matchmakers under the provisions of a bill awaiting Governor Kean's signature.

title: The Chinese Correction
description: The newspaper of China's Communist Party has now apologized for one of the printing errors of the century. A major editorial was wrong, The People's Daily said, to state that ''One cannot expect the works of Marx and Lenin . . . to solve today's problems.'' It should have said ''to solve

title: ;  'Who Wants to Be Paid for Just Sitting?'
description: Obviously Larry McCoy (''Who Wants to Be Paid for Just Sitting?,'' Opinion Page, Nov. 18) has not had any personal need or experience that has caused him to rely on the judicial system to protect him or his family on their constitutional rights, else he would not have written so derogatory an article about jury duty.

title: FOR A HARTFORD DEVELOPER, A CHALLENGE IN THE BRONX
description: THOSE with long memories in the Bronx

title: DEVILS TROUNCE NORDIQUES, 8-3
description: The Devils trounced the Quebec Nordiques, 8-3, in one of their better performances of the season at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight, setting two significant records and several insignificant ones along the way.

title: TIME TO HEED A.M.A.'s STAND
description: BOXERS Need a defense against boxing as it is now structured, and the recent American Medical Association study should be seen as the medical foundation upon which some changes, not all, should be based.

title: THE COLLISION OF BULLS AND BEARS
description: IN a report issued early this month, Joseph C.

title: Linda K. Simons And Bank Officer To Wed in Spring
description: Linda Kathryn Simons and Daniel Crosby de Menocal Jr. plan to be married in May, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Dolph C. Simons Jr. of Lawrence, Kan., have announced.

title:
COMPUTERLAND'S 26-YEAR-OLD CHIEF: BARBARA J. MILLARD;
A DAUGHTER'S QUICK RISE TO THE TOP

title: Zhou Enlai Works Published
description: China issued a second volume of writings by former Prime Minister Zhou Enlai today. The book contains 56 speeches, articles and telegrams written after 1949, including 35 that were unpublished before Zhou died in 1976.

title: FOR MARIELITOS, A NEW SIGN OF HOPE
description: WEST NEW YORK FOR MOST of the tens of thousands of Cuban refugees who came to the United States in the 1980 boatlift, the last several years have been especially hard.

title: QUILTS FOR COLLECTORS
description: SARA EVANS, who writes frequently on antiques and crafts, lives in New York.

title: BEARING A CHILD IN MEDICAL SCHOOL
description: I teach childbirth classes of the kind that Perri Klass refers to as teaching people to be ''bad patients'' rather than to be cooperative and submissive, with no questions asked. Having attended a similar course herself, Miss Klass can understand that these ''bad patients'' are the ones who are making the changes that the major medical schools seem unable to undertake. They are good medical consumers who choose their birth attendants and location carefully and are much better caretakers of their own health. ELENA DE KARPLUS

title: THE YANKIFICATION OF THE METS
description: WELL, the Mets, that young hardscrabble club that prides itself on bringing up babies, have gone and succumbed to a Yankee-type trade. This was the sort of trade they used to purse their Calvinist lips and look smug at when their across-town neighbors got slaphappy with the checkbook. ''They are mortgaging their future,'' I believe it was reported Davey Johnson said of the Rickey Henderson trade. And what, pray, have the Mets just done?

title: A THREE MILE ISLAND FOR CHEMICALS
description: FOR about a week after a cloud of toxic gas killed

title: SPAIN'S SOCIALISTS RATIFY NATO ROLE
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, after a tough fight, won approval from his governing Socialist Party tonight to keep Spain in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: SUSPECT IS SOUGHT IN BANK KILLINGS
description: Law-enforcement officials searched muddy back roads in foggy rain today for a bank robber who killed four people, including a pregnant woman, and wounded three others Friday.

title: STAGE: COMIC 'SULLIVAN'
description: Kenneth Ludwig's affable comedy with music, ''Sullivan and Gilbert,'' takes place in 1890, behind the scenes at the Savoy Theater in London, where final preparations are under way for a Gilbert & Sullivan revue. The backstage hysteria is unusally feverish since the show is a command performance for Queen Victoria, and unbeknownst to his collaborator, William S. Gilbert, Sir Arthur Sullivan, the more socially exalted of the pair, has agreed to let the Queen's son, Alfred, appear onstage.

title: HEALTH AND MEDICINE
description: AMID charges that he did not allow critics of the state's hospital rate-setting system to testify at a recent hearing by the Assembly's Corrections, Health and Human Services Committee, the chairman of that committee, Assemblyman George J. Otlowski, has called a second hearing for Thursday.

title: 2AmbulanceOfficers Held in Sale of Drugs
description: Two lieutenants in the Emergency Medical Service have been arrested on charges of selling cocaine at the city hospitals where they worked, according to the police.

title: DISMANTLING THE INNOVATIVE D.R.I.
description: LEXINGTON, Mass.

title:
A CHRISTMAS APPEAL: HELP THE NEEDIEST CASES;
NEW HOPE IN A LIFE OF POVERTY, LONELINESS, AND FEAR
description: MANUEL G had never known loneliness or fear. As a young man, when captured and threatened by anti-Semites in his South American country during the Nazi period, he repeatedly shouted at them: ''Death to Hitler! Death to Hitler!''

title: Sarah Ann Dana Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marshall A. Dana of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and Quechee, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Ann Dana to John Post, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Post of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens. The wedding is to be in April. Miss Dana is an assistant manager at and Mr. Post an assistant vice president of Citibank's Bankcard division in New York.

title: STUDENTS RUN RESTAURANTS AND LEARN
description: GEORGE ALLEN, a school bus driver, has breakfast at the same restaurant in Higganum every day. A couple of days a week, he buys a fresh baked pie to take home.

title: TALKS WILL RESUME ON 6 HELD BY SUDANESE REBELS
description: Negotiations for the release of six hostages being held by Sudanese rebels are to resume here next week, Western diplomats say.

title: PROMISE AND FEAR OF HOBOKEN'S FUTURE
description: A few words at the back of the old hiring hall, where 200 longshoremen had come as usual to ''shape up'' for work, were the only acknowledgement of the passing of an era. ''Adios, Finidi,'' someone had scratched on a chalkboard. ''It's all over.''

title: STUDENTS FIGHT DRUNK DRIVING
description: MEMBERS of the newly formed chapter of Students Against Drunk Driving at Mount Vernon High School have been working overtime recently. ''I'm very proud of them,'' said Kim Owens, the students' adviser. ''They've been working on S.A.D.D. activities during school hours and in meetings after school, especially in the weeks before the holidays.''

title: A WOMAN NAMED LIFE
description: Thomas Mallon is the author of ''A Book of One's Own: People and Their Diaries.'' THE LETTERS OF VITA SACKVILLE-WEST TO VIRGINIA WOOLF

title: HELLO, SANTA? WRONG NUMBER
description: VERY few children or adults are able to wait until Christmas Eve to have their first contact with Santa Claus. Children write letters to Santa at the North Pole weeks and even months before the holidays, and parents annually take their young children to department stores in malls all over the Island for a chance to sit on Santa's lap.

title: GA. TECH BEATS N.C. STATE IN FINAL :002
description: Mark Price hit a 20-foot jumper with 2 seconds left to give Georgia Tech a 66- 64 Atlantic Coast Conference victory over North Carolina State tonight.

title: STRIKING RECORDS OF AN ART IN MOTION
description: The relationship between dance and photography comes to mind everytime we see a photograph of a dancer - even more so when a photographer issues a book of his work in the dance field. It is worth noting that many photographers have wrestled with the inherent opposition between the essential qualities of dance and of their own endeavor. Dance is concerned with movement but the camera, by necessity, provides a fixed image.

title: ARTIST REPAIRING WORK VANDALIZED ON STONY BROOK CAMPUS
description: VANDALS have struck again at Bernard Aptekar's sculptural painting, ''The Defeat of the City of Plutonium,'' which is on exhibit in the Lab Office building at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. The incident marked the fourth time that the work has been damaged since it was lent to the university by the artist last March.

title: A THOUGHT-PROVOKING 'AGNES OF GOD'
description: JOHN PIELMEIER'S philosophical drama, ''Agnes of God,'' was a long-running hit on Broadway. Now that this play about a young nun accused of murdering her baby has closed in New York, other theaters have been able to acquire the production rights, which is why a plethora of ''Agnes of Gods'' have recently appeared. The most recent production is at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst, through Jan. 6, and it is almost flawless in its execution.

title: PRACTICAL TOGS FOR CHILDREN
description: The shop is called Peter Elliot's Whimsy, and there is a certain amount of whimsy - stuffed clown mobiles hanging from the ceiling, for example - but mostly there are good, practical clothes for children.

title: NEW EFFORT TO KEEP STUDENTS IN STATE
description: ELABORATE brochures, improved financial aid and aggressive promotion are among the actions being planned by private and public colleges in an effort to persuade Connecticut students to stay in the state for their higher educations.

title: NETS FALL TO PACERS, 112-100
description: The fog that settled over this city just hours before tip-off was so thick that the Indianapolis International Airport was closed to all traffic early this evening. Unfortunately for the Nets, they had already arrived.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Slow, But No Recession

title: HOME CLINIC ;  Answering the Mail
description: Q . When I bought my house, there was an old asphalt patio out back that was covered with green fungus. I ripped this out and put down a new concrete patio, but now after a few months the same green fungus is back.

title:
ART;
AT YALE, AN EXHIBIT OF MODERN SCREENS
description: SCREENED from view since October, when the strike at Yale University precluded its announced opening, ''The Folding Image'' opened at the Yale Art Gallery on Dec. 4 and will remain through Jan. 6.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN NAIROBI
description: SHEILA RULE is the Nairobi bureau chief of The New York Times.

title: THE REGION ; Hidden CostsOf Bootleg Gas
description: New York officials acted last week to plug some expensive leaks at the gasoline pumps. After a two-year investigation, officials disclosed that between $100 million and $200 million in state taxes are evaded each year with ''bootlegged'' gasoline.

title: A MYTH THAT WILL NOT LET US GO
description: David Grene is a professor of Greek literature in the Committee on Social Thought at the University of Chicago. He has translated various Greek authors, including Sophocles. ANTIGONES

title: KOCH CHALLENGERS AGREE AT FORUM ON NEED FOR UNIFIED FRONT
description: In their first joint discussion of mayoral campaign issues, three potential challengers to Mayor Koch agreed that only one of them should run, to insure a united front.

title: Grace Carley to Wed Douglas L. Kennedy
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Carley of Cork and West Cork, Ireland, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Grace Patricia Carley, to Douglas Lawrence Kennedy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Kennedy of New York. The wedding is to be in April.

title: OLD JAPANESE ART LIVES ANEW ON L.I.
description: THE ancient Japanese art of joinery, which created structures that have withstood 1,000 years of hurricanes, earthquakes and typhoons, may be dying out in its ancestral home. It's alive and well, though, on eastern Long Island - if not necessarily as a ''new'' method of mass-producing houses, then as a monumental sculpture of beams and posts that provide the framework for a home being built deep in the woods of Southampton.

title: OPERA: 'NIGHTINGALE'
description: At the border between opera and musical comedy, the barbed wire is obviously down. Stephen Sondheim has crossed over into the New York City Opera and operates easily there, and Thursday night at the Golden Fleece theater, a Broadway composer brought his work to what is really a proving ground for operatic composers.

title: 'FAIR LADY' BESTS BROADWAY REVIVALS
description: DARIEN

title: FAMILY FEUDS
description: WASHINGTON WHEN President Reagan took office nearly four years ago, the simplicity of his agenda and his leadership style were vital assets. He gave orders to cut the growth of Government and had loyal lieutenants work out the strategy. An enthusiastic circle of Administration conservatives proudly used its unity to overpower Democratic disarray.

A HANUKKAH PARTY WITH I.B. SINGER

title: THE PLEASURES OF POETRY
description: David Lehman, a poet and critic, is the editor of ''Beyond Amazement: New Essays on John Ashbery'' and co-editor of ''James Merrill: Essays in Criticism.''

title: LONGTIME LEADER OF BELIZE OUSTED IN CRUSHING DEFEAT
description: The conservative opposition in this Central American democracy scored a sweeping election upset Friday, toppling the center-left Government of Prime Minister George Price.

title: GRIM IMAGES: HOW ETHIOPIA BECAME NEWS
description: Most Americans became aware of the famine in Ethiopia many months after it began, through television pictures.

title: Miss Bauman Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. William A. Bauman of South Salem, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Joan Bauman, to Bruce B. Zutler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Zutler of Plainview, L.I.

title: Dames
description: With Joan Blondell, Dick Powell, Ruby Keeler, Guy Kibbee, Hugh Herbert and ZaSu Pitts; directed by Ray Enright, 1934 Key Video 90 minutes. $59.98

title: ISLANDERS EASILY DEFEAT FLYERS
description: The Islanders met their chief rival in the Patrick Division tonight, the Philadelphia Flyers, and broke a four- game losing streak with an impressive 6-2 victory at Nassau Coliseum.
