NEW JERSEY OPINION;
THE HOMEOWNER MUST PROTECT HIS PROPERTY'S VALUE
description: IT IS not an automatic mark of

title: GORBACHEV STARTS A VISIT TO BRITAIN WITH SOVIET GROUP
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, widely regarded as second in command in the Soviet Union, arrived here today to meet British officials and said he hoped for a slowdown in the arms race and an improvement in East-West relations.

title: SOUTH AFRICA PROTESTERS TAKE PART IN DAILY DRAMA
description: Like clockwork, American protesters opposed to South Africa's policy of racial separation gather at 3:30 P.M. each weekday to march in a circle near Pretoria's embassy and court arrest.

title: A FESTIVE FIFTH AVENUE CHRISTMAS
description: CHRISTMAS time, more than any other season of the year, gives the nation's retailers reason to cheer. And on Fifth Avenue, the nation's premier shopping stretch, merchants drawing well- heeled customers into their shops with dazzling displays usually cheer the loudest.

title: Bruce Charnov to Wed Gail Schlesinger in Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome A. Schlesinger of New York, Delray Beach, Fla., and Woodstock, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail Schlesinger, to Bruce Charnov, a son of Winona Charnov of West Palm Beach, Fla., and Abraham Charnov of Clearwater, Fla. The wedding is to take place in May.

title: ; A PROSPEROUS AMERICA AT PLAY IN THE ARTS
description: To the Editor:

title: ORNAMENTS FROM CHRISTMAS PAST
description: They shimmer and glow in the light - a thousand tiny Santas, birds, boats and balloons. Andreas Brown's Christmas tree is up and decorated in the gallery of his shop, the Gotham Book Mart, 41 West 47th Street. For the eighth year in a row, Mr. Brown is sharing his magical view of Christmas - and the ornaments he and his friends collect - in a dazzling display of feather-light paper and glass fantasies. The show remains on view through Jan. 5.

title: THE ISLAND GRAPE
description: LONG ISLAND'S recent success as a wine region has surprised a lot of people, but what's all the fuss about? There are a few islands that have been makding good wine for a couple of millennia or more. Sicily, for instance, and Sardinia and Corsica.

title:
ART;
FIBER INVENTIVELY DESIGNED
description: TODAY ''fiber art'' carries little of the reassurance of grandmother's old quilt. Aggressive, highly inventive work has radically changed perceptions of this medium and has infused it with considerable vitality.

title: TOULOUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Philadelphia 76ers traded Mark Iavaroni, a forward, to the San Antonio Spurs for a third-round pick in the 1986 draft and also signed the veteran George Johnson, a free agent. . . . Billy Olson , the two-time defending champion, and Earl Bell, a four-time winner who captured a bronze medal at the Olympics, have entered the Fred Schmertz Pole Vault at the 78th annual Wannamaker Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden Jan. 25. The field will also include Doug Lytle, who placed sixth in the Olympics; Jeff Buckingham, who was the second-best American indoor vaulter this year, and Dan Ripley, the 1979 Millrose winner who shares the Garden record of 18 feet 8 3/4 inches with Olson. . . . The man who made the Olympics such a resounding success financially this summer, Peter Ueberroth, has been named man of the year by The Sporting News. . . . James Stotter, 12 times club champion of Sunningdale in Westchester, is the new president of the Metropolitan Golf Association. . . . The Baltimore Orioles officially named Frank Robinson a coach.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Cable TV

title: LUCIEN ALONE IN DEADROCK
description: Robert Roper is the author of ''Royo County Tales'' and ''On Spider Creek.'' SOMETHING TO BE DESIRED

title: GAME BIRDS CAN BE A TENDER DISH
description: DURING this busy season a quiet evening at home can be a blissful experience. In keeping with the holiday spirit, what better dish to serve for dinner than a small game bird, enough for one or two people?

title: Eloise Zeeman Bride of David Scharff
description: Eloise Lincoln Zeeman, a daughter of John Huibert Zeeman 3d and Joan Javits Zeeman, both of New York, Larchmont, N.Y., and Waitsfield, Vt., was married yesterday to David Alan Scharff, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Matthew Scharff of Larchmont and Tolland, Mass. The Rev. Elwood P. Graves, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Palm Beach, Fla., home of the bride's grandmother, Mrs. Benjamin A. Javits.

title: TRAVEL ADVISIORY: AFLOAT IN THE CARIBBEAN, ON FOOT IN LONDON
description: Island Hopping By Small Ship As ships go, the Vacationer is a small vessel, so perhaps it is only fitting that it visit small islands.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Talking to Gertrude Stein

title: Data Update
description: * Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: BLACKS IN COLLEGE DECLINE IN JERSEY
description: The number of black students enrolled in New Jersey colleges and universities has declined, primarily because high school graduates are getting jobs instead of continuing their education, and the trend is expected to continue, according to a state study released today.

title: GOOD SEAFOOD WITH RIVER VIEW
description: KEEP in mind that things aren't always what they seem as you enter Harbor Park, the large, white ship-like building on the Connecticut River in Middletown. The singles scene at the bar on the ground floor and the pulsating, exploding music might deter you from climbing the stairs to the restaurant. But don't let it, for upstairs, in three quiet dining areas, you can rise above it, so to speak, and in doing so you are in for pleasant surprises.

title: LIBRARY EXPANDING
description: Another milestone in the continuing development of the Mamaroneck Free Library and Theater Center is about to be recorded. Today, at noon, the library's board of trustees and members of the Emelin Theater's executive committee, as well as the public, are to gather for a groundbreaking ceremony on Library Lane. There the stage will be set for a $852,000 expansion program to provide a new addition for the library-theater center.

title: EXOTIC VISITORS MAKE THEMSELVES AT HOME;
description: Eric Rosenthal is a freelance writer.

title: HOW PLEASANT TO MEET MR. ELIOT
description: IT was 1946, in London, and I was going to lunch to meet Mr. Eliot. I had dressed very carefully, in my only good suit and my last nylons, and I carried in my pocket a telegram, an invitation from Morley Kennerly, one of the editors at Faber & Faber. I had no telephone. Phones were hard to come by that year in London - phones and food and enough sleep and sweets and nylons and enough money to live. Austerity was the catchword for those years after the war. I remember it as dry and tired and quiet. Its color was gray.

title: Texas Agrees to Pay for Part Of 17-Year-Old's Transplants
description: Officials of the Medicaid program in Texas have changed their minds and agreed to pay part of the cost of a heart-liver transplant for a teen-ager who doctors say would live only two months without the operation.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
A GIANT STEP FOR CONSTRUCTION
description: SUCCESSFUL passage of the $3.3 billion Transportation Trust Fund Authority Act last August and public approval on Nov. 6 of a Constitutional amendment to dedicate part of the existing gasoline tax for transportation aid represent a giant step forward for New Jersey's construction industry.

title: Scare Trims Field At Loughlin Games
description: The 31st annual Bishop Loughlin Games, the oldest continuous major high school indoor track meet in the country, were held yesterday at the 102d Engineers Armory on West 168th Street and Fort Washington Avenue. But not everybody showed up.

title: THE OPULENCE OF SINGAPORE
description: Barbara Crossette is chief of The New York Times's bureau in Bangkok. By Barbara Crossette YOU KNOW,'' SAYS FRAN cis Siah Ooi Choe, smiling, ''we still get Americans over here thinking we live under mosquito nets and ill-treat the workers.'' At his new plant in Singapore's Kallang Bahru industrial complex, Mr. Siah controls what has become a multimillion-dollar empire built on plastic bags. On the rooftop of the plant are a swimming pool, squash courts, sauna, massage rooms, game rooms, bar and cafeteria - all at the disposal of Mr. Siah's factory workers.

title: Emily Bailen Weds Jonathan McKeage
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York yesterday Emily Thompson Bailen, a daughter of Eliot Bailen of New York and Sherman, Conn., and the late Elise Thompson Bailen, was married to Jonathan Fleming McKeage, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John Fleming McKeage of North Pender Island, British Columbia. The Rev. Beatrice Blair and the Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: UNIONS EMBATTLED DESPITE BUILDING BOOM
description: ALTHOUGH the New Jersey Department of Labor says that the state's construction industry is having its best year in more than a decade, the 15,000-member State Council of Carpenters is voting on a new contract that calls for a wage freeze and other concessions.

title: THEATER: 'AN OCCASION OF SIN'
description: Set in a prison cell, Deborah Lundy's ''An Occasion of Sin'' isn't so much a play as a shrill debate among stick-figure characters about the issue of mercy killing. Its protagonist, Robert Hayden (Keith Michl), is an idealistic young Roman Catholic doctor serving 15 years for having killed his terminally ill wife. In abrupt blackout scenes, we learn that he concealed from his lawyer the fact that he had a mistress. What his attorney had hoped would be a signficant test case was successfully prosecuted as the trial of an adulterous murder.

title: TIME EXPOSURES
description: Small wonder that the 74 veteran screen actresses photographed by Horst in James Watters's RETURN ENGAGEMENT: Faces to Remember Then & Now (Clarkson N. Potter/ Crown, $24.95) could not resist the famed photographer, whose warm, glamorous portraits are as flattering to octogenarians as to ingenues. Many of his subjects here were captured by him at both stages in their lives and now look friendly, intelligent and direct, in contrast with the coquettish studio portraits the book also includes.

title: THE 'SHULTZ DOCTRINE' IS RENDERED MOOT IN IRAN
description: For months, Secretary of State George P. Shultz has been arguing that the time has come for the United States to use military force to either pre- empt or retaliate against international terrorism. The alternative, he has said, is for the United States to become the ''Hamlet of nations,'' endlessly wringing its hands over whether and how to respond.

title: CONGRESSMAN REPORTS TOUGH TALK FROM PINOCHET
description: A United States Congressman who met with President Augusto Pinochet of Chile this week said today that the military ruler showed no interest in negotiating with the opposition, lifting the state of seige or relaxing press censorship.

title: EMPLOYEE BENEFIT PLANS UNDER FIRE
description: IF the Treasury Department has its way, some

title: AT 4-6 E. 65TH ST., A RENT STRIKE
description: THE two adjoining former town houses just off

title: ;  E.P.A. Approach To Lead Clarified
description: The Nov. 18 Environmental News column confused two separate Environmental Protection Agency approaches to environmental lead. (1) - The E.P.A. has proposed the phase-down of lead from gasoline.

title: Miss Johnson Has Nuptials In Tarrytown
description: The marriage of Marjory Stuart Johnson, a service assistant in Chemical Bank's world insurance group in New York, to Joseph Anthony Reagan Jr., an architect with the Phillips Janson Group in New York, took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Boniface Hanley performed the ceremony.

title: PROBLEMS FOUND IN MINERAL RIGHTS
description: The Federal Government is losing millions of dollars because of inefficient management of the nation's mineral resources, a Congressional report said today.

title: EX-GENERAL BURIED IN MOSCOW
description: The disgraced former Soviet Interior Minister, Nikolai A. Shchelokov, who was believed to be about to go to trial on corruption charges, was buried in a quiet ceremony today.

title: IBIZA: ITS BLITHE SPIRIT CARRIES ON
description: JACK BEECHING lives in Paris and spends part of the year in Spain. His most recent book is ''The Galleys at Lepanto'' (Scribners).

title: REAWAKENING MEMORIES OF CHINA'S TASTES
description: -FEI LO, the author of ''The Dim Sum Book: Classic Recipes From the Chinese Teahouse'' and ''The Chinese Banquet Cookbook'' (Crown), teaches regional Chinese cooking and nutrition at the China Institute in America, in New York City.

title: COMPUTER NETWORKS SEEN AS NEW TOOL
description: HASBROUCK HEIGHTS THE personal computer, which is no longer a novelty in the workplace, no longer represents the latest in office automation, either.

title: CONVICTED WORKER RULED ENTITLED TO CITY PENSION
description: A former New York City sanitation superintendent who was convicted and dismissed from his job for allowing the illegal dumping of toxic wastes is entitled to his pension, the state's highest court ruled this week.

title: OVERLOOKED OPTION
description: The oldest rule in games of the bridge family has been under attack for many years. Among serious players in North America the attack seems to have succeeded in part.

title: IN SHORT
description: M. Kaye. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) The time is 1947, just before India's independence; the place is ''beautiful mountain-locked Kashmir''; the agenda is mystery and romance. Our heroine is Sarah Parrish, a young, pretty, red-haired, no-nonsense Englishwoman and veteran of World War II. While on holiday with the Ski Club of India (the departing colonial masters are enjoying the countryside while they may), she meets Janet Rushton, an agent for the British Secret Service who confides that she has unearthed an international plot of monstrous proportions - a plot that no one else in British intelligence knows about. When Janet dies under questionable circumstances, Sarah finds herself left with a lapful of cryptic clues and unsought responsibilities. Love for Mother England and concern for the thousands whose destinies may be at stake lead her deeper into the intrigue, despite her conviction that ''people one knew did not do these things - plot and spy and lend themselves to murder.'' What Sarah learns is that some people one knows

title: Western Union
description: To the Editor:

title: KNICKS LOSE, 102-97
description: With the worst record in the National Baseketball Association and pressure mounting for a victory, George Karl, the Cleveland Cavaliers' rookie coach changed the starting lineup tonight for the seventh time this season.

title: CAROL TAYLOR HAS NUPTIALS
description: Clayland Boyden Gray, counsel to and deputy chief of staff for Vice President Bush, and Carol Elizabeth Taylor, a ceramist, were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Georgetown. The Rev. Sanford Garner officiated.

title: BUSINESS IN FLAGS VARIABLE
description: CONTRADICTORY reports indicate that New Jersey's flag-selling business defies generalization.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
WEARING IT, EATING IT, HAVING IT ALL -- RIGHT NOW
description: OUR parents were always patient. They spent their lives working, saving and waiting. They had a strong belief in the future, and looked forward to the day when they would enjoy the multiplicity of benefits that awaited the provident.

title: 'WEST SIDE STORY' STATES ITS CASE AS A SPLENDID OPERA
description: The release of Deutsche Grammophon's new ''West Side Story,'' sung by stars and conducted (for the first time!) by Leonard Bernstein, is above all an occasion for celebrating one of the great operas of our century. Number after number, Mr. Bernstein's 1950's ''Romeo and Juliet'' answers the standards of variety, melodic richness, seriousness of intent and musical sweep that the major operatic composers have taught us to set.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''While New York remains a city of gold for those at the top of the economic ladder, it has become a city of despair for many elderly, for the homeless, for women and children barely subsisting on public welfare.'' - ''The Changing Face of Poverty,'' a report sponsored by the Community Service Society of Greater New York. (42:1.)

title: DAVID MCLAIN, 51, CINCINNATI BALLET'S DIRECTOR
description: David McLain, artistic director of the Cincinnati/New Orleans City Ballet and head of the dance division of the University of Cincinnati College Conservatory of Music, died of cancer in Cincinnati yesterday. He was 51 years old and lived in Cincinnati.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY ; Extrasolar PlanetFound - Perhaps
description: The long search for a planet outside our solar system may have ended 21 light years away, between Scorpio and Sagittarius in the constellation Ophiuchus. There, a research team at the University of Arizona reported last week that it had found a huge, gaseous sphere nine- tenths the size of Jupiter, the largest planet circling our sun, and 30 to 80 times as dense. They believe the object, named Van Biesbroeck 8B after the dim star it is orbiting, is also a planet, though of a much different sort than ours.

title: Cynthia T. Cline Is Wed in Jersey
description: The marriage of Cynthia Todd Cline, who is a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at the University of Chicago, to Philip Nicholas Kadinsky-Cade, a floor broker for and account executive at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Futures in Chicago,, took place yesterday at the Presbyterian Church in Basking Ridge, N.J. The Rev. Dr. J. Calvin K. Jackson performed the ceremony.

title: MINORITY REPORTS Class UprisingAs every college senior knows, there's nothing so lowly as a freshman. That was true in Congress, too, where some seniors hung on for decades. Things changed with the ''Watergate Babies'' of 1974. That year's 57 new Democratic representatives - the largest freshman class of recent times - united in a revolt that stripped several startled seniors of their committee chairmanships. Ever since, the seniors of both parties have kept a wary eye on newcomers.
description: Well, now the class of '84 has spoken. The 34 new Republicans elected to the House have chosen Ben Blaz, a native of Guam and now its nonvoting delegate, as their president; the 12 new Democrats picked Albert Bustamante of Texas.

title: FOR THE HEARTY, IT'S TIME TO PICK A TREE
description: BUSINESS was so good at the Jones Tree Farm in Shelton last Sunday that by midafternoon the thousands of cookies, brownies and Swedish coffee breads that had been baked by the owner's wife, Elisabeth Jones, had all been sold.

title: STAGE: 'COLD STORAGE'
description: The revival of Ronald Ribman's ''Cold Storage'' by the Jewish Repertory Theater brings to the stage an earful of good dialogue delivered by actors worth going to see. It has no real plot but always seems to be going somewhere and, even though it never does, it achieves its own sort of dynamic and makes for a lively theatrical experience.

title: UNEASY HEADQUARTERS IN CARBIDE ACCIDENT
description: DANBURY THE disaster at the Union Carbide Corporation's pesticide plant in Bhopal, India, has been sending shock waves through Danbury, Bethel, Ridgefield, New Fairfield and other towns where the company's employees live.

title: RUNNING DRY AT THE OLD-STYLE AGENCIES
description: IT is almost ironic: Temporary employment agencies started up as a

title:
ART;
CLARENCE CARTER: ENIGMA
description: NEWARK AT THE age of 80, Clarence Carter is one of the great standbys of the New Jersey art scene. But despite this familiarity, he remains an enigma.

title: POP: PENGUIN CAFE GROUP
description: Modesty is becoming to the Penguin Cafe Orchestra, which performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last weekend.

title:
GARDENING;
TREES TO ENHANCE SEASONAL DECORATIONS
description: OUTDOOR Christmas displays have become increasingly popular in recent years. Some are done in an understated way with one or more trees lighted. Others are a bit overdone with everything in sight, including house, plantings and a myriad of figurines, covered with multicolored lights.

title: IMPROVING QUALITY OF LIFE IS FIRST PRIORITY IN PEKING
description: A startling announcement in the official press the other day reminded Chinese how serious their leader, Deng Xiaoping, was about his crusade to modernize China.

title: WRITERS RECEIVE GRANTS
description: ALMOST 30 years ago, Adrienne Wolfert of Fairfield wrote a story about a foster child growing up in rural Connecticut during the Depression. She could not get the story published at the time, and put it away.

title: LURING SUPER BABIES, COMMINGLERS AND EMPTY-NESTERS
description: IF you ask a developer who all the new condominiums are designed for, the most

title: MILES TRIUMPHS AT THE INTERPOLIS
description: The British grandmaster Anthony Miles achieved the greatest success of his career by winning the elite all- grandmaster Interpolis International Tournament in Tilburg, the Netherlands. His 8-3 score put him 1 1/2 points in front of the field.

title: THE CHURCH CUTS OFF A SANDINISTA PRIEST
description: The four-year conflict between the Sandinista Government and the Roman Catholic Church reached a new level of bitterness last week after the Jesuit order in Rome announced it had dismissed the Rev. Fernando Cardenal. He is one of four priests in high Government positions who have disobeyed an edict of Pope John Paul II that bars priests and nuns from holding public office. Coming after Vatican interrogation in September of Leonardo Boff, a Brazilian Franciscan friar and proponent of ''liberation theology,'' the Jesuit measure was a new rebuke to Latin American Catholics who have embraced concepts of economic struggle. In a related action last week, John Paul condemned class struggle as a social evil and declared that responsibility for sin ''lies with individuals.''

title: SINGLES SHOW LESS SUPPORT FOR REAGAN
description: On Election Day, while President Reagan was closing the oft-analyzed difference in voting preferences between men and women, another gap was opening for postelection attention from political analysts.

title: EXIT STALLONE, ENTER EDDIE MURPHY
description: A fortnight before shooting on Paramount's principal Christmas offering was scheduled to begin last spring, Sylvester Stallone decided that he didn't like the comedic theme and pulled out.

title: HEALTH EXPERTS START CAMPAIGN ON HEPATITIS
description: Hepatitis B, an infectious viral disease that can lead to death from liver cancer or cirrhosis, is on the rise in the United States despite the availability of a safe, effective vaccine to prevent it, medical experts say.

title: AROUND THE NATION ; Crashes of 3 Light Planes In California Take 7 Lives
description: The bodies of seven people were found Friday in the wreckage of three small planes that crashed in mountains in Riverside and Kern counties, apparently because of high winds and poor visibility.

title: THE REGION ; A New Stadium,The Trump Way
description: Are there 85,000 armchair quarterbacks willing to pay thousands of dollars for some new furniture? Donald Trump is willing to bet there are. The developer proposed last week to build a $300 million football stadium in New York City to be financed primarily by fans, who would buy their seats much as one would purchase a condominium apartment.

title: THE DANCE: BEBE MILLER
description: For eager young people who move to the world's big cities from farms or small towns, urban bustle can be endlessly stimulating. But for the jaded it is only nervewracking.

title: TOY CONCERN'S PLAN TO CLOSE ANGERS CHICAGO
description: Hasbro Bradley Inc., one of the nation's largest toy companies, is accustomed to bringing happiness to people this time of year. But this December it has brought shock and anger to the West Side of Chicago by announcing that it would close a factory with 700 employees around Christmas Day.

title: THE RIDDLE OF TUKHACHEVSKY
description: Colette Shulman, a specialist in Soviet affairs, is a senior staff associate at the School for International Affairs of Columbia University. THE TSAR'S LIEUTENANT

title: SHANGHAI REGIONAL COOKING
description: AT the top of its one-star category, recently opened Shanghai City has several things going for it. For one, it has brought an interesting regional cuisine to the county, which suffers from a glut of Sichuan-Hunanese places. Dishes here have some of the characteristics that mark Shanghai regional cooking, such as expertly made seafood dishes; liberal use of bamboo shoots; rich, sweet sauces well laced with soy sauce and oil; exceptionally fine frying techniques. For another, the prices are close to Manhattan's Chinatown bargains. This value is hard to pass up. Finally, the fact that Shanghai City has settled in a restaurant-poor area of the county makes it particularly welcome.

title: COLIN STOKES OF R.J. REYNOLDS
description: -SALEM, N.C., Dec. 15 (AP) - Colin Stokes, retired chairman and chief executive officer of R. J. Reynolds Industries Inc., died Friday at North Carolina Baptist Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: Castle & Cooke Names A New Chief Executive
description: The board of directors of Castle & Cooke Inc. named Robert D. Cook as president and chief executive officer of the company Friday after accepting the resignation of Ian R. Wilson.

title: The Roots of Revolution
description: In her important article, ''The Roots of Revolution'' (Nov. 11), Flora Lewis seems to suggest that there is essentially one truth about third- world revolutionaries, namely, that they are indigenous idealists who get some revolutionary activity going and then seek help from outsiders, ''the enemies of their local enemy.'' My observation of reality, however, is that there are apt to be many truths. Moreover, in any given third-world ''revolutionary'' situation, several of these truths probably exist at the same time. In particular, I don't think we can accept that there is a standard scenario for the effects of United States policies, if any, and the degree, timing, motivation and initiation of involvement with the Soviet Union and its surrogates.

title: No Governors' Endorsement
description: A bid by Democratic governors to endorse their own candidate for party chairman has apparently collapsed, a spokesman for the head of their caucus said Friday.

title: PANEL NAMED TO STUDY ISSUE OF CHILD-SUPPORT PAYMENTS
description: Many children of broken families are not getting the financial support that they are entitled to, Governor Cuomo said in announcing the formation recently of a state commission to study the problem.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
COORDINATOR, ANALYSYT, AND OTHER NOBLES OF CORPORATE SOCIETY
description: ON a typical workday in Connecticut, during the morning or afternoon rush hour, a thousand vice presidents have their hands tight around the steering wheel. They're in executive control of their cars and their lives. They're the boss.

title: V.A. ACTS ON MIAMI HOSPITAL
description: The Veterans Administration has ordered its hospital here to halt all heart surgery until a team of medical experts can investigate allegations that an excessive number of its cardiac surgery patients die.

title:
GARDENING;
TREES TO ENHANCE SEASONAL DECORATIONS
description: OUTDOOR Christmas displays have become increasingly popular in recent years. Some are done in an understated way with one or more trees lighted. Others are a bit overdone with everything in sight, including house, plantings and a myriad of figurines, covered with multicolored lights.

title: DAKOTA WATER PROJECT IS CUT BY REAGAN PANEL
description: The Garrison Diverson water project, once one of the largest and most expensive single projects ever authorized by Congress, was sharply cut back in scope and cost here late last night by a special advisory panel appointed by the Reagan Administration.

title: A TENOR WHO JUST GOES ON SINGING
description: The entry for Hugues Cuenod (b. 1902) in the New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, sums up the Swiss tenor's art as follows: ''He was a fine interpreter of lieder and French song, and used his high, light tenor with exquisite taste in all the music he performed. On stage his interpretations were full of humour, where that was called for, and he was also a master of the grotesque.''

title: THE NATION ; Fiscal Concerns
description: While Secretary Regan worried the monetary side, private analysts were concerned with fiscal policy, and specifically the Treasury Department's proposal for tax simplification.

title: ELECTIONS PANEL RULES LOANS TO CONGRESSMAN WERE ILLEGAL
description: The Federal Election Commission has ruled that Representative Edolphus Towns, a Brooklyn Democrat, received $20,000 in illegal personal loans from two Brooklyn businessmen during his 1982 primary campaign.

title:
ANTIQUES;
LOVELY ECHOES OF CHRISTMAS PAST
description: THE setting is the week before Christmas and all through the Butler-McCook Homestead, the last 18th-century residence on Main Street in Hartford, there are lovely echoes of Christmas past.

title: 2 NEW MEXICO OFFICIALS INDICTED ON U.S. CHARGES
description: A Federal grand jury here has indicted two state officials on charges that they conspired to extort a political contribution from a New York bank. The brother of Gov. Toney Anaya was indicted on a perjury charge in the case.

title: WESTERN UNION
description: To the Editor:

title: Barbara Walsh Becomes a Bride
description: Barbara Lynn Walsh, a daughter of Joanne Eastman Walsh and Richard Owen Walsh, both of Lakeville, Conn., was married yesterday to Amos Barr Hostetter Jr., a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hostetter of Short Hills, N.J., and Delray Beach, Fla. The Rev. Peter Warren Sipple, headmaster of the Salisbury School, performed the Episcopal ceremony at the First Church of Christ in Sharon, Conn.

title: BRONCOS TAKE A.F.C. WEST
description: The Denver Broncos did it the way they had all season, wrestling away a 31-14 victory over the Seattle Seahawks for the American Conference's Western Division championship here today.

title: TORIES BARELY WIN A VOTE ON WHO'LL RULE LONDON
description: Fresh from a large-scale Conservative Party revolt on cutbacks in aid to university students, the Government squeaked through another in-house rebellion this week on a bill that would do away with London's elected government.

title: Family Murder
description: Shortly after attending church on July 12, 1981, William A. Keeler, president of the Arco Oil and Gas Company, was slain, and his wife, Anita, was fatally wounded at their home in Dallas. A daughter who found them told the police that her mother had said, ''David did it.''

title: THE INVISIBLE POET BEGINS TO APPEAR
description: T. S. ELIOT

title: Any Which WayOut of Bhopal
description: They pushed their way onto trains and planes, clung to the roofs of buses and queued up at gas stations, rode two-wheeled tongas and pushed flat carts piled high with relatives and belongings - anything to get out of town. ''All the public has gone to the village,'' said a white-haired man last week in Bhopal, and it seemed only a slight exaggeration. By the Government's estimate, 70,000 had left; others put it several times higher. But there was no disputing what caused the exodus: the announcement that the Union Carbide chemical plant would start up once again, this time to neutralize the remants of the chemical that had killed more than 2,000.

title: FAIRLEIGH DICKINSON PLANS CUTBACKS TO STEM DEFICIT
description: The board of trustees of Fairleigh Dickinson University, New Jersey's largest private university, has approved a program to eliminate a projected $3.5 million budget deficit.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
MOON WITH A VIEW
description: RYE

title: Karen Losco Is the Bride of Dr. William Kutcher
description: At the Great Neck Synagogue last night Karen Palma Losco, a nursing instructor at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, was married to Dr. William Lee Kutcher, an internist affiliated with New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital and the Regent Hospital. Rabbis Ephraim R. Wolf and Herbert Bomzer officiated.

title: MONASTERY SHOP OFFERS CRAFTS
description: A VISITOR would not expect to find, at the crossroads of Georgetown, a place that reaches out to people in the third world and tries to build bridges between the haves and the have-nots.

title: Nonalcoholic Drinks Urged To Reduce Drunken Driving
description: Groups seeking to reduce drunken driving have opened a drive to promote nonalcoholic beverages, ranging from fruit punches to immitation beers.

title: SANDINISTA-INDIAN TALKS ARE SAID TO FOUNDER
description: A meeting between the Nicaraguan Government and representatives of Miskito Indians foundered over demands for political autonomy in the Indians' Atlantic Coast homelands, a Sandinista official says.

title: TEST FOR TEACHERS CAUSES DISCONTENT
description: Starting next spring, all prospective teachers in New Jersey will have to pass a battery of standardized tests before they can get the certificates that entitle them to lead a classroom.

title: TRUCK CRASH ON TURNPIKE CLOGS JERSEY TRAFFIC
description: A 14-mile stretch of the New Jersey Turnpike, sealed off Friday night after the crash of a tanker truck carrying liquid oxygen, remained closed until 8 P.M. yesterday, causing long traffic backups all day.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The week's TV film fare holds some memorable moments and vignettes, starting with the 1962 ''Lawrence of Arabia'' (Sunday at 2 P.M. on ABC). Who could ever forget David Lean's split-second introduction to the Sahara? The director cuts from a flaring match, struck in an Army officers' club in London, to a huge, rising sun that saturates the desert sand.

title: Inferior Teams In the Lapchick
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BROKERS CREATING A MARKET
description: A GRADUAL increase in owners eager to sell their time-shares interest in resorts has precipitated the development of services geared specifically to this market. These new services can also afford a way to buy time-shares at a more favorable rate than buying directly from the developer.

title:
A CHRISTMAS APPEAL: HELP THE NEEDIEST CASES;
HOW THOSE WITH CAN HELP THOSE WITHOUT
description: Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn

title: Award in Death of Prize Bull
description: A jury awarded a rancher $8.5 million for the death of a prize bull that had been sprayed with insecticide. A district court jury on Monday ordered Diamond Shamrock and Medina Valley Artificial Insemination Inc. to pay the award to Dan Wendt for the death of his purebred bull, Superman 1024. The 4-year- old, 2,700-pound animal died in 1981 after herders at the insemination laboratory sprayed it with an insecticide manufactured by Diamond Shamrock.

title: BEARING A CHILD IN MEDICAL SCHOOL
description: I agree with Perri Klass that it can be difficult to find an obstetrician who views pregnancy as something other than ''a perilous, if not pathological state.''

title: SELECTING A BOOK ON ART
description: ASIDE from the tree at Rockefeller Center, carols coming out of loudspeakers and brightly festooned stores, there is another sure sign of Christmas: A proliferation of art books.

title: POLITICS AND TAXES
description: WASHINGTON Christmas came early to Washington this year, mainly for the lobbyists who are against the Treasury Department's tax reform plan. The slush fund to drown this reform must be wider and deeper than the Potomac, and by all accounts the effort seems to be succeeding.

title: AN INDEFENSIBLE DEFENSE
description: Would President Reagan's proposal for a space-based ballistic missile defense - his Strategic Defense Initiative - ''strengthen deterrence and reduce the threat of nuclear war'' even though it cannot fulfill Mr. Reagan's promise that it would make nuclear weapons ''impotent and obsolete''?

title: ;  The Baldwin Library: Historical Footnote
description: The Baldwin community was delighted with Fred McMorrow's article on Nov. 4 (About Long Island). The information on Baldwin's early years, especially the focus on the library, was accurate and written with Mr. McMorrow's flair for making history vibrant.

title: Jackie Shapiro Is Engaged; June Wedding Is Planned
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth L. Shapiro of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jackie Shapiro, to Gary Spector, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Spector of East Rockaway, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE PLAYER: A Profile of an Art, by Lillian Ross and Helen Ross. (Limelight, $10.95.) The 22 actresses and 33 actors profiled in ''The Player'' were interviewed between 1956 and 1962. Almost all the profiles, 21 of which were published in the New Yorker, are preceded by unflattering photographs taken by Lillian Ross. Among the subjects are Ingrid Bergman, Sophia Loren, Henry and Jane Fonda, Sidney Poitier, Paul Newman, Michael Redgrave and John Gielgud. In 1962 our reviewer, Alex Szogyi, called the collection ''a deeply moving experience. All essential facts are given; the interviews ring remarkably true; one is continually amazed at the hardiness of the breed.'' Another film-related classic by Lillian Ross is PICTURE (Limelight, $6.95), the story of John Huston's and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's making of ''The Red Badge of Courage'' (1951). Budd Schulberg observed a year later in these pages that ''Picture'' presents ''Hollywood's more heroic attitudes as well as its more foolish and familiar ones. . . . It plays back with an unfailing ear some of the wise things that are said in that keyed-up, pent-up industrial town.''

title: Purported Dodge Heir Loses Bid on Estate
description: A woman who says she may be a Siamese twin of one of John F. Dodge's daughters lost Friday in her effort to halt distribution of the automobile maker's $40 million fortune.

title: THE REGION ; The Archbishop'sCity Hall Surprise
description: The price of principle, Archbishop John J. O'Connor suggested last week, may be tens of millions of dollars. That's how much the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York might be willing to forgo in government support for its social programs, rather than comply with a New York City policy banning discrimination against homosexuals.

title: CORPS TRAINS OFFICERS FOR U.S. OCEANIC ADMINISTRATION
description: The ensigns' black uniforms disappeared beneath yellow slickers as the morning mist turned into rain. The officers moved quickly, carting crates of food to the galley below.

title: RANGERS DEFEATED BY CAPITALS, 4-2
description: The Rangers' slump dropped them to a new low tonight. They lost to the Washington Capitals here, 4-2, showing a touch of everything that has brought them down in the first stages of the season.

title: Five Killed in St. Louis Fire
description: Five people were killed and six others injured early Friday in a fire that roared through their three-story home on the city's north side. The police said four men and a woman were killed and several of the injured were taken to Barnes Hospital in critical condition. No identifications were immediately available.

title: Miss Vodra Is Married
description: Victoria Anne Vodra , the daughter of Mrs. Edward H. Heinemann of Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., and Richard J. Vodra of Pensacola, Fla., was married yesterday to Barrye Langhorne Wall, a son of Mrs. J. Barrye Wall Jr. and the late Mr. Wall of Farmville, Va. The Rev. Susan Harriss performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: PESTICIDE FACTORY RESTARTED IN INDIA
description: Scientists began an operation this morning to convert into a pesticide 15 metric tons of deadly methyl isocyanate still stored at the Bhopal plant of Union Carbide.

title: MORALE REMAINS PROBLEM FOR F.A.A.
description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration, acknowledging persisting morale problems among air traffic controllers, said yesterday that he had set a goal of ending abnormal overtime duty by next June.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
HOW THE PATTERNS OF COMMUTING PROVIDE A SUBTLE STRUCTURE TO OUR LIVES
description: WHETHER we travel to and from work by car or train, to a city, town or village, our commute is a routine, a world unto itself that lends rhythm and pace to our days. And though commuting styles vary, each provides us with comforting and unnerving experiences, rich in detail, that etch their way into our remembrance.

title: Grasshoppers Ruin Holiday
description: Kevin Massie, who has the largest Christmas tree farm in Illinois, says a plague of grasshoppers stole his Christmas this year. Grasshoppers gobbled up 50,000 Scotch and white pines in the summer on the 350-acre tree farm along the banks of the Illinois River, Mr. Massie said Wednesday. ''It's kind of hard to get in the jolly 'Ho, Ho' spirit when you're down that many trees,'' he said.

title: ADVISERS BID STATE PREPARE FOR SLOWDOWN
description: TRENTON GOVERNOR KEAN'S economic advisers had some good news, tempered with a large dose of caution, for New Jersey residents last week.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY CUTS WOULD NOT REDUCE DEFICIT
description: To the Editor:

title: SKI RESORT SEEKS A CEMETERY SITE
description: When this ski resort was established 22 years ago, a cemetery was not in the plans for a fledgling town full of young people seeking recreation.

title:
THE ECONOMICS OF CAR QUOTAS ;
THEY'RE MERELY A SUBSIDY FOR DETROIT
description: AFTER its remarkable rebound,

description: Clinton $85,000 *2*4 Glenside, 1-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*3-year-old town-house condominium; 2 decks, wall-to-wall *2*carpeting, $115 monthly maintenance; taxes $1,330. Convent Station $207,900 *2*22 Bennington Road, 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*18-year-old colonial; new roof and driveway; *2*taxes $2,954. Hazlet $87,900 *2*48 Virginia Avenue, 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*24-year-old bilevel; 1-car garage, eat-in kitchen; *2*taxes $1,850. title: HIGH SCHOOL TO TEST U.S. FARM COURSE
description: LYMAN Memorial High School in Lebanon has been chosen by the Federal Education Department as the only school in the East to test a new business course aimed at giving farmers the techniques of corporate managers.

title: CITY'S SETTLEMENT HOUSES SEEK NEW SUPPORT
description: Faced with a reduction in public aid, New York's settlement houses, part of a movement born in the slums of East London 100 years ago, are searching for new sources of money to continue their work among the city's poor, officials say.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN TEMPORARY EMPLOYMENT
description: FOR years, companies have recognized

title: Elizabeth Blair Cowley Weds Bradford Barker
description: Elizabeth Blair Cowley, a daughter of Blair Phillips Resika and Robert W. Cowley, both of New York, was married yesterday to Bradford Alan Barker, a son of Dorothy M. Barker of Sacramento, Calif., and Frederic N. Barker of Jeffersonville, Vt. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: TRIBES OF DARNBY, N. H.
description: Tom LeClair teaches at the University of Cincinnati and is co-editor of ''Anything Can Happen: Interviews with Contemporary American Novelists.'' WHISPER MY NAME

title: BRIDGE PLAN STIRS SAG HARBOR
description: THE bridge over the culvert on Main Street in Sag Harbor was built in 1792. It has been patched, repaired and rebuilt so many times in the intervening two centuries that there is nothing picturesque or historic about it. It is just serviceable.

title: THE COMET OF BELIZE
description: For Manuel Esquivel, the 44-year-old physics teacher who will soon become Belize's second Prime Minister, his upset election victory this weekend seemed to defy the laws of political motion here. Belize, the only English- speaking country in Central America, had long been associated with only one man: George Price, the tall, scripture-quoting former seminarian of Scottish and Mayan ancestry who began working for independence 30 years ago and ushered it in as Prime Minister in 1981. His international stature is unquestioned.

title: CHILDREN'S PROGRAMMING REMAINS TV'S POOR RELATION
description: In a sunny classroom at the Cathedral School in Manhattan, a dozen

title: THEATER: 'OLIVER OLIVER,' COMEDY AT LONG WHARF
description: Vivian Matalon, who staged a blissful Broadway revival of Paul Osborn's ''Morning's at Seven,'' has turned his directorial insights on another, lesser known comedy by Mr. Osborn, ''Oliver Oliver.'' Though ''Oliver Oliver'' is, admittedly, a play of lighter substance, audiences are rewarded with an evening of effervescence, a fact that directly derives from a sparkling cast headed by two holdovers from ''Morning's at Seven,'' Charlotte Moore and Nancy Marchand.

title: Correction
description: In the list of Notable Books of the Year in The Book Review of Dec. 2, the citation of ''Paula Modersohn-Becker: The Letters and Journals'' omitted the names of the editors and translators of the American edition. They are Arthur S. Wensinger and Carole Clew Hoey.

title: DANCE: ROBERT KOVICH
description: Segolene Colin Poirier wore a stylish red dress and Robert Kovich wore a dark suit in ''Technicolor Tarantella,'' on Thursday night at the Paula Cooper Gallery. Yet, despite his respectable attire, Mr. Kovich often looked like a big bug. And before his delightfully weird 50-minute dance was over, one started wondering about Miss Poirier's identity.

title: VOICES FROM BEHIND THE SCREEN
description: Kenneth Turan is the film critic for California magazine and for National Public Radio's ''All Things Considered.'' A KISS IS STILL A KISS

title: A FOUNDER OF BIRCH SOCIETY
description: Robert Waring Stoddard, chairman of the Worcester Telegram and Gazette Inc., former chairman of the Wyman-Gordon Company and one of the founders of the John Birch Society, died at his home Friday at the age of 78.

title: State Panel to Conduct Voting-Machine Study
description: A bipartisan commission has been named by Governor Cuomo to explore possible changes to New York voting machines.

title: A POET FOR THE BALLET
description: Looking at the picture of the impressive ballet figures on the cover of the issue that featured the New York City Ballet, I was intrigued to see that both Jerome Robbins and Peter Martins were wearing jogging shoes, the kind that old ladies, like me, wear for museumgoing.

title: HOLIDAY PROGRAMS IN OPERA, BALLET
description: PERHAPS the most ambitious holiday event on the music scene is today's full-scale production - with soloists, orchestra, chorus and ballet - of Gian Carlo Menotti's ''Amahl and the Night Visitors,'' the first opera commissioned for television, in 1951.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY ; Iran FreesHostages, DeniesAiding TerroristsEven Iranians agreed that last week's hijacking and hostage-holding incident at Teheran airport was ''a strange event,'' as Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, Iran's Speaker of Parliament, called it. After a six- day orgy of threats and beatings broadcast over Iranian radio, and the killing of two American aid agency employees, four Arabic- speaking terrorists emerged, hands in the air.
description: The terrorists first announced that they had said their final prayers and planned to blow themselves up along with the remaining nine hostages in the Kuwaiti Airbus they had seized. Then, inexplicably, they summoned a cleaning crew. Iranian security men, some disguised as cleaners, stormed the plane and ended the seige. The passengers, including two surviving Americans, were freed.

title: EASING EDISON'S SQUEEZE
description: The spurt of office construction in Edison, N.J., over the last decade, which has brightened that town's economy and created thousands of jobs for its residents, has also put a squeeze on the availability of affordable housing.

title: A VARIED MENU AT BARGAIN PRICES
description: THE Harbor View in Stony Brook is something of a find, a restaurant that provides an attractive setting for dining and has an interesting, varied menu of creditably prepared specialties, a well-balanced wine list and bargain prices. Where's the catch? Only that the portions are quite modest in size.

title: North and South Korea Agree to Resume Talks
description: North and South Korea have agreed to resume trade talks in Panmunjom and hold Red Cross talks in Seoul next month, a South Korean Government spokesman said today.

title: DELBELLO, LEAVING JOB, SEEKS TO EMPTY CAMPAIGN CHEST
description: Alfred B. DelBello, who has announced that he is resigning as Lieutenant Governor, says he is looking for ideas from the public on how best to spend an estimated $75,000 remaining in his campaign chest.

title: SONGS AND COMEDY TAKE THEIR TURN
description: LAST week, in a crowded comedy club in Manhattan, while accompanying himself on guitar, Dennis Blair of Port Jefferson, who also plays bass, drums and piano, was singing ''Hollywood.''

title: AROUND THE WORLD ; Vietnam Arrests 119 As 'Traitors and Spies'
description: Vietnam announced today that 119 people accused of being ''traitors and spies'' had been arrested in connection with a purported plot to overthrow the Communist Government.

title: SAND-MINING RULES DEBATED
description: SEVERAL Suffolk towns have agreed to join forces with the State Attorney General to file an appeal of a decision concerning a Smithtown sand-mining case, a decision they believe interferes with their home rule prerogative.

title: Big Turnout for Free Rides
description: An estimated 300,000 people turned out today for a free train ride as the Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority added five stations and nine miles of rail to its commuter service. The rail system now has 25 stations on 25 miles of track. The fare is 60 cents.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
A MIX OF LATKES AND CANDY CANES
description: card stores. In addition to all the Hello Kitty trinkets, scented pencils and smelly stickers my daughters require, I also buy cards for Christmas and Hanukkah, chocolate ''Hanukkah gelt,'' peppermint candy canes, dreidels, Santa Claus cupcake sticks, blue wrapping paper with menorahs, red wrapping paper with holly, Hanukkah candles, Christmas tree ornaments, and presents, presents, presents.

title: COUNTRY VETERINARIAN: MAKING ROUNDS TO FARMS AND STABLES
description: DR. JOHN V. STEINER was barreling down the narrow, bumpy country lane in his midnight blue pickup truck.

title: COMPANY SELLS EXCLUSIVE HOMES
description: A 54-ACRE horse farm in Ridgefield, a Georgian mansion on Long Island Sound in Darien, a block of shops in Essex and a 919-acre farm in Burlington are a few of the Connecticut properties being sold by Previews Inc., a Greenwich-based international real-estate marketing service that specializes in the sale of unusual, high-priced properties.

title: GRADUATES FACING GOOD JOB OUTLOOK
description: For the second consecutive year college seniors will have an easier time finding jobs than did the previous year's graduates, according to the three major annual reports on college employment.

title: Christina Hoyt and H. N. Vanderlip, An Investment Banker, Are Married
description: Christina Hoyt and Henrik Nils Vanderlip were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Church in New York. The Rev. Richardson Schell, assisted by the Rev. Thomas D. Bowers, performed the ceremony.

title: NEW MAGAZINE OFFERING OUTLET FOR TALENTS OF POLISH EMIGRES
description: In the living room of a modest, gray-shingled house in Queens, amid tidy stacks of mailing labels and bottles of glue, New York's first Polish- language magazine has been taking shape.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: WHEN the holiday season comes, Rabbi Yosef Z. Carlebach of Ocean Township goes to prison.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
JAZZ FINDS A NEW SHOWCASE
description: Steve Schneider frequently reports on developments in cable.

title: BUFORD PETERSON, COUNSELOR
description: Buford G. Peterson, a former prisoner who founded the Fellowship Center Inc., an alchoholism treatment center for released prisoners, died of heart failure Friday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. Mr. Peterson was 69 years old and a resident of Long Island City, Queens.

title: THE CHANGE WOULD HURT INVESTMENT
description: IT may be bad form to dump on the

title: 'JEWEL IN THE CROWN'- SUPERB DRAMA
description: There are those of us who have long been insisting that television is not just a convenient conduit for carrying old films, that the medium has its own distinctive artistic and esthetic forms. Still another outstanding example of the kind of undertaking that would be impossible in the traditional settings of film or theater is getting underway tonight at 9 on Masterpiece Theater, public television's enduring showcase for largely British imports. Produced by Christopher Morahan for Granada TV, ''The Jewel in the Crown'' is based on four Paul Scott novels known as ''The Raj Quartet.''

title: London Theater
description: To the Editor: Upon reading Benedict Nightingale's tribute to London's theater tradition, ''Afoot in London's Theaterland'' (Travel, Oct. 28), I am reminded of an incident that reveals a generous side of the London theater world, something that rarely occurs elsewhere in the theater business.

title: HEADLINERS ; Kasparov on the BoardFor weeks, perhaps the most suspenseful element in the world championship chess match between
description: Gary Kasparov and the title-holder, Anatoly Karpov, has been the question of whether Mr. Kasparov would ever get on the scoreboard.

title: 'BLACK NATIVITY'
description: IN LAST year's review of ''Black Nativity,'' a musical celebration based loosely on a work by Langston Hughes, and performed at the Theater of Universal Images here, this critic had the temerity to suggest that the piece, a rousing and uplifting paean to peace, become an annual event.

title: BUDGET POLITICS TURNS TO MIDDLE-CLASS ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON THE ''fairness issue,'' which Democrats had counted on in the 1984 election, was assumed by many people to have been buried along with Walter F. Mondale in the Reagan landslide of Nov. 6. But the issue has suddenly reappeared, showing definite signs of life.

title: Dickerson Sidesteps
description: Eric Dickerson said he was upset by a report that he would ask the Los Angeles Rams to renegotiate his contract and pay him at least $1 million a season, but he didn't quite deny it. Dickerson told The Los Angeles Times that the report, which appeared in The Los Angeles Herald Examiner on Friday before the Rams' loss that night to the San Francisco 49ers, was based on a ''lackadaisical conversation'' with a reporter. ''The guy asked me about my contract, and I said it was a good contract but we may have to talk about it after the season,'' Dickerson told the Los Angeles paper. ''That was all that was said.'' Dickerson, who has two seasons to go on a four-year, $2.2 million contract, was quoted in The Herald Examiner as having said: ''I don't like saying this, because I like it here, I'm treated right, and I love playing for John Robinson . But the Rams got me cheap, and everyone knows it. I need to get the money now while I'm still healthy, while I'm whole. But I'll settle for a million.'' He told The Times he felt ''sick'' about the report. ''It makes me seem like I'm money-hungry, and I'm not a money-hungry person. I'm just looking for the best deal that I can get. But right now, that's not in my future. I just want to finish the season.'' Dickerson's lawyer,

title:
NUMISMATICS;
THE INAUGURAL MEDAL
description: President Ronald Reagan's second inauguration will be marked by issuance of an impressive new medal. While traditional, it is also unconventional, a combination that hobbyists may find intriguing.

title: AN INVASION RESULT: GRENADA SCHOOL PROSPERS
description: The American medical school here, the evacuation of which President Reagan said was one of his main reasons for sending troops to Grenada, has been riding a groundswell of publicity and enjoying new prosperity since the invasion more than 13 months ago.

title: Tchaikovsky's 'Nutcracker'
description: A production by the American Ballet Theater and Mikhail Baryshnikov MGM/UA 78 minutes. $49.95

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE checks were in the mail, directors of Connecticut's six smallest public transportation systems found out last week, though the checks were five months late.

title: IRAN: OBSESSED WITH MARTYRDOM
description: John Kifner is chief of The Times's bureau in Beirut.

title: LOTTERY PROPOSED FOR NEW ENGLAND
description: Heads of lotteries in the six New England states are in favor of creating a regional lottery that would have the nation's second-largest player pool after New York, according to the director of the Connecticut Lottery.

title: Front-Running Puntivo Wins the Gallant Fox
description: Puntivo, the favorite of the crowd of 13,170, withstood a strong challenge from Moro to take the $87,000 Gallant Fox Handicap at Aqueduct by a neck yesterday.

title: U.S. FACING DECISION ON SPACE ARMS
description: American officials said today that President Reagan would have to decide how forthcoming the United States should be in discussing space weapons with the Soviet Union next month.

title: AUSTRALIA CELEBRATES ITS BICENTENNIAL
description: Australia Post has issued the first in a major series of stamps honoring the nation's bicentennial. The stamp-issuing program, known as the Australian Bicentennial Collection follows a chronological approach. Design subjects range from the period prior to European contact to the present day.

title: NEGOTIATED DEATH: AN OPEN SECRET
description: ''Doctors want to do the right thing,'' said Dr. Eric Cassell, ''Families want to do the right thing. But nobody knows exactly what the right thing is. So a very human, dynamic interaction is emerging, negotiation.''

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE number of female prison inmates in New Jersey increased by 110 percent from 1978 to 1983, according to a survey completed by the Department of Justice in Washington. It was termed the third largest increase in the nation, behind the District of Columbia and Virginia. T. Gary Mitchell , director of the state's Office of Inmate Advocacy, an arm of the Department of the Public Advocate, said that much of the rise was ''probably because of a lot of lesser offenses that now carry mandatory time in New Jersey.''

title: ENDOWMENT SETS GRANTS OF $14.9 MILLION
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities announced $14.9 million in grants last week to a broad range of educational and cultural organizations, including public libraries, historical societies, colleges and public television stations.

title: NEARBY URBAN AREAS DRAW HOME BUYERS
description: ''IN the 1960's, everything was suburbs -

title: IRISH COMFORT AND ANTIQUITY
description: BARBARA DUBIVSKY is an editor on The New York Times Magazine.

title: SEIZED WITH PASSION IN BAVARIA
description: From "Mr. Noon." So Gilbert, in the midst of Bavaria, was seized with the strange passion for the place. He went with Alfred across the levels, where the snow lay only in pieces here and there: over the rushing little streams, towards the nestling village of Genbach, whose white farms with their great roofs and low balconies clustered round the toy-looking church.

title: Salaries for the Yankees and Mets in 1984
description: The total, where applicable, also includes earned bonuses and prorated share of signing bonus. Salaries have been determined from management and player sources with access to contract information. YANKEES

title: PLAN TO MOVE PAUPERS' GRAVES STIRS PROTEST IN CAROLINA TOWN
description: Years ago, the old residents in the Spartanburg County home liked to visit Ralph and Lois Cothran in the summers. They sat in the sun in the front yard and talked.

title: HOME CLINIC ;  Answering the Mail
description: Q . When I bought my house, there was an old asphalt patio out back that was covered with green fungus. I ripped this out and put down a new concrete patio, but now after a few months the same green fungus is back.

title: SCHOOL PRINCIPLES OUGHT TO TEACH
description: PROPOSALS of all kinds are being offered as ways to bolster the lagging public schools. Most prevalent is the idea that money is the ultimate solution to all the problems and can bring excellence in education.

title: Time AgainFor a LittleFed-Bashing
description: In good times and bad, but especially when times are uncertain, the Federal Reserve Board turns target of opportunity for officeholders who, no matter how confident they sound about a positive outcome of their policies, are just a bit concerned about a negative potential. Last week, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan was at it again.

title: CORRUPTION, MEXICAN STYLE
description: On weekends, families come on outing to gawk at the neo-Gothic mansion with reflecting windows that dominates a wooded hillside overlooking Mexico City. They pass through its 25-foot-high wrought-iron gates cautiously, as if trespassing on a property guarded by 50 armed police - until recently, the case. Then they gain confidence, climbing on chairs to peep at the marble columns and nymphet-covered murals inside and raising their voices in indignation. ''Here,'' one man informs his children, brothers and parents, ''here is our foreign debt.''

title: ANOREXIA THERAPY USES FEEDING DEVICE
description: STANDING slightly over 5 feet 4 inches tall and weighing 69 pounds, an anoretic woman entered an innovative therapy program at Four Winds Hospital in Lewisboro last February. During her stay, a feeding device pumped up to 2,000 calories a day into her body, slowly altering her near-skeletal frame. The pump became an almost constant companion in the initial phase of her therapy program.

title: WELFARE: MORE HARM THAN GOOD?
description: Lawrence M. Mead, an associate professor of politics at New York University, is the author of ''Beyond Entitlement: Obligation in Federal Social Policy,'' which will be published next year. LOSING GROUND

title: MUSIC: POEMS IN CHORAL SETTINGS
description: Vincent Persichetti has made some attractive choral settings of poems about flowers by E.E. Cummings, and they were given first New York performances in the Music Project- Goodman Chamber Choir concert at Goodman House on Wednesday night. Scored for mixed chorus and string ensemble, these choral songs are - like Cummings's poems - gentle, airy and clear.

title: NOBLE DETECTIVE WORK IN ART
description: The next time someone asks you what you want for Christmas, take a deep breath and say ''I'd like a catalogue raisonne.'' As a conversation stopper, that sentence has few equals. Then you take another deep breath and say ''The catalogue raisonne can be one of the noblest works of man. Through it, and better than in almost any other way, we can study a work of a great artist in its every detail. It has in it something of biography, something of the detective story, something of the laboratory and something of ecstasy.''

title: Rep. Perkins Left No Will
description: Representative Carl D. Perkins, the Kentucky Democrat who died Aug. 3 after 36 years in Congress, did not leave a will but had an estate valued at $390,000, including real estate in Kentucky and Virginia, court documents show.

title: ROCKERS WITH LITERARY ASPIRATIONS MAKE THEIR MARK
description: John Giorno, the New York poet who performs his work in an intensely personal, sometimes confrontational manner, hasn't always appreciated rock and roll. A decade or so ago, he turned down the opportunity to open shows for a world famous rock singer, not because he didn't want or need the exposure but because he had never heard of the singer and assumed he was simply another struggling unknown. Mr. Giorno would not make the same mistake today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An entry today in the Photography listing of The Guide, section 2A, omits the location of the Edward S. Curtis exhibition. It is on view through Jan. 13 at Ledel, 168 Mercer Street. The listing also carries an outdated entry for an Andre Kertesz photography exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum; it has been postponed until next year.

title: Kriek Loses in Upset To Unseeded Player
description: Unseeded Sammy Giammalva of Houston scored the biggest triumph of his tennis career today when he eliminated top-seeded Johan Kriek from the $125,000 New South Wales Open, 5-7, 6-4, 6-3, in a 117-minute semifinal.

title: ANOTHER WESTMORELAND
description: To the Editor:

title: CUTTING THE COSTS OF HEATING
description: ALTHOUGH fuel costs are pretty stable this year and there seems to be no danger of any fuel shortages in this area, most homeowners still find that paying the bills for keeping warm consumes a large part of the family budget during the winter. That's why most homeowners feel they are engaged in an ongoing battle to do everything possible to keep heating costs from climbing any higher than absolutely necessary, and to insure getting as much heat as they can out of every dollar spent for fuel or energy.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Dec. 16, 1984Fiction*1 COME LOVE A STRANGER, by Kathleen E. Woodiwiss. (Avon, $8.95.) The bride of a planter is haunted by what may be the return of a love she has all but forgotten. *2

title: BEST SELLERS Dec. 16, 1984Fiction*1
description: 18 THE TALISMAN, by Stephen King and Peter Straub. (Viking, $18.95.) Two parallel worlds and a young boy who can travel between them. *2 25 THE SICILIAN, by Mario Puzo. (Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) A fictionalized life of Salvatore Giuliano, the Sicilian bandit-hero of the 1940's. *3 39 LOVE AND WAR, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) The Civil War rages in this saga of a Pennsylvania family and a South Carolina family, begun in ''North and South.'' *4

title:
GARDENING;
TREES TO ENHANCE SEASONAL DECORATIONS
description: OUTDOOR Christmas displays have become increasingly popular in recent years. Some are done in an understated way with one or more trees lighted. Others are a bit overdone with everything in sight, including house, plantings and a myriad of figurines, covered with multicolored lights.

title: Villanova Captures 5th in Row
description: Ed Pinckney and Harold Pressley each scored 19 points as Villanova (5-0) rolled to an 80-67 victory tonight over its Big Five rival Penn (0-4).

title: Seven Young Children Killed In Fire in Texas Mobile Home
description: Seven children, ranging from 3 to 8 years old, died today in an early-morning fire that swept through a two-bedroom mobile home in rural Fort Bend County, the authorities said.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; Postal RatesAre on theRise Again
description: After a lull of almost three years, the cost of a first-class stamp is going up again in mid-February, this time to 22 cents from 20 cents. John R. McKean, the chairman of the Postal Service's board of governors, last week announced a batch of rate increases intended to raise an estimated $1.8 billion.

title: Cutting Fuel Bills
description: With a $331,000 grant from the Federal Department of Energy, Maryville College in Tennessee set out last year to heat its buildings by burning only wood. The liberal-arts college, 15 miles south of Knoxville, expected to save $100,000 a year in this way.

title: On the Death Of a 'Hero'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A ROMANTIC IN ITALY
description: W. SOMERSET MAUGHAM wrote this piece for the Printer's Pie Annual, 1909. It is here reprinted from ''A Traveller in Romance: Uncollected Writings, 1901-1964,'' a Maugham anthology to be published next month by Clarkson N. Potter.

title: HOME CLINIC ;  Answering the Mail
description: Q . When I bought my house, there was an old asphalt patio out back that was covered with green fungus. I ripped this out and put down a new concrete patio, but now after a few months the same green fungus is back.

title: MANY VIRGIN ISLANDERS OUTRAGED OVER PLANS FOR RESORT AT A PRISTINE BEACH
description: Three decades ago, a wealthy New York financier bestowed on the people of the Virgin Islands a precious gift. It was Magens Bay on the north coast of St. Thomas, considered one of the most beautiful and unspoiled beaches in the world.

title: GIANTS MISS ON A BIG CHANCE
description: The Saints were ahead, 7-3, and half of the second quarter had been played. Phil Simms had just completed a 31-yard pass to Zeke Mowatt and the Giants had a first down at the New Orleans' 3-yard line. The crowd was on its feet.

title: ACUPUNCTURE'S RISE EXPECTED
description: WHEN it comes to acupuncture, New Jersey is 5,000 years behind the Orient. But the ancient healing art is now being officially embraced in the state and is available to the public for the first time.

title: PRODUCER PRICES UP, BUT FEW WORRY
description: The first surge in producer prices in four months was led by rapidly rising food and energy prices. The five- tenths of 1 percent increase in November meant that inflation at the producer level was running at an annual rate of 1.9 percent, three times last year's rate. Although the increase is expected to show up at the consumer level in the months ahead, few economists predicted renewed inflation. Indeed, most saw the surge as a sign that the economy was moving ahead again after several months of limited growth. One surprise was in energy costs, which continued to rise as oil prices fell.

title: IS A 'DOUBLE WHAMMY' AHEAD FOR NEW YORK?

A few, including Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, whose state has lowered its own tax rates in recent years, and Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona, which has always had low taxes, are supporting the plan. Their states, they calculate, would benefit.

title: 'SHARON, GET LOST,' THEY SAY. I WON'T
description: While the jury sits in judgment on my libel suit in Foley Square, any number of critics sit in judgment on my case. This judgment has thus far been singularly harsh. I was naive enough to believe that when a case is sub judice, particularly when a jury is sitting, responsible commentators would refrain from editorial comment until the verdict is in. But I do not complain; indeed, I welcome the opportunity to set the record straight.

Now America's premier tenor and America's premier opera company are back together, and on Friday night, Mr. McCracken will sing Radames to Leontyne Price's Aida at the Met.

description: Sheriff Johnny France , who had been tracking two fugitive mountain men through the wilds of Montana for five months, brought the armed pair out of the woods single-handedly last week. The men, Don Nichols and his 20-year-old son Dan, were accused of kidnapping and shooting Kari Swenson, a member of the United States biathlon team, and with killing a man who tried to come to her rescue.

title: Film Premiere Aids Albany

On Friday, William Kennedy, a Pulitzer Prize-winning writer from Albany, presented checks for $18,300 each to the Trinity Institution and the McKinney Library of the Albany Institute of History and Art. Mr. Kennedy was a coauthor of the screenplay. The showing took place here Dec. 2, a week before the film's New York City premiere.

title: READING ABOUT MUSIC OFFERS ITS OWN REWARDS
description: Let's be cynical about this, shall we? It is the gift- giving time of year once more, a time when we seek to seal the affection of friends or lovers by bestowing on them exactly the flabbergastingly right item that they would least expect to receive. Giving presents may be, of course, an expression of pure, selfless love - ''The Gift of the Magi,'' and all that - but there also is an element of bribery involved. Everyone knows love cannot be bought, but each year we ignore that truism. The most idealistic among us will tour the stores with an eye out for the perfect extravagant present, the ''Oh, dear, you shouldn't have!'' item. What the giver wants in return is the recipient's eternal gratitude and unswerving love, no more than that. Deep down, shoppers are all the same.

title: Dr. Celestia Higano Wed to Oncologist
description: Dr. Celestia Savoye Higano, an instructor in medicine and a staff physician at the Seattle Veterans Administration Hospital, and Dr. Jack Wolfe Singer, chief of oncology at the hospital and associate professor of medicine at the University of Washington, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. A. Foerster performed the ceremony at the University Unitarian Church in Seattle.

title: STROKE IS LINKED TO CLOT FORMED IN ARTIFICIAL HEART
description: Dr. William C. DeVries said today it was very likely that a blood clot formed in William J. Schroeder's artificial heart and then broke off to lodge in his brain and cause the stroke Mr. Schroeder suffered Thursday night.

Hans Van Manen's ''Songs Without Words'' is a delicate, yearning and playful evocation of the Mendelssohn score of the same name, spun against a backdrop that looks like a huge sheet of graph paper.

Unfortunately, the author overlooked the driving force behind the library - Janet Collins, children's librarian. Mrs. Collins, with her professional expertise and knowledge of her community, has developed and conducted successful programs at the library, several of which were enumerated in the article.

title: THE AVANT-GARDE IS BIG BOX OFFICE
description: Eight years ago, when ''Einstein on the Beach'' was presented at the Metropolitan Opera for two performances, it was a sensational one- of-a-kind event in which the downtown art world occupied a temple of uptown establishment culture for one brief moment. So great was the excitement that even as performances of the four-and- one-half hour opera by Philip Glass and Robert Wilson were in progress, art world aficionados who were unable to get in waited patiently outside in hopes of confiscating the ticket stubs of walkouts who had grown impatient with its length or mystified by its hallucinatory vision of Albert Einstein's life and times.

title: Israel HardensLebanon Stand
description: Israel has had rough going in its withdrawal talks with Lebanon as well as in its relations with Moslems in the southern areas it occupies. On both counts, the Israelis got tough last week.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: MY friend the former Great Necker mentioned the other day that he had been back to the old neighborhood not long ago for the first time since he had left it for Manhattan five years ago. He had moved out here in what are probably now looked at as the pioneering days after World War II when New Yorkers, seeking better lives and housing that New York denied them, erupted into the environs, and he had been a steadfast Long Islander all those years, father of children who called Nassau their native land, and a city man who had willingly converted to communion with sun, stars and the lawn mower.

The move reportedly will not come until President Reagan completes a visit to the West German capital early in May for the annual economic summit meeting.

title: Washington Watch; Freddie Mac Plan Opposed
description: WASHINGTON EDWIN J. GRAY'S plan to shift ownership of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, the quasi-public Government agency, to the nation's savings and loan industry, has hit heavy opposition from an unexpected Administration source: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan.

title: Oxford Dons Are Assets To Nixon-Era 'Plumber'

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It will probably be a tie between our riders and the Park Avenue traffic on which is most inconvenienced.'' - William Aston, a vice president of Metro-North. (A1:6.)

title: FOR MORE TRADE WITH THE RUSSIANS
description: At a time when United States-Soviet relations are improving, increased trade could draw the two superpowers even closer together.

title: MCKENNA GIVES NETS A LIFT
description: In a sport dominated by muscular men who can run, jump, dunk and almost fly with grace and strength, Kevin McKenna is an anomaly. He isn't muscular, and he can't do any of those things with flair. In fact, he says he can't dunk at all.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by the Associated Press on November 25 about competition for a Navy base to be situated on theGulf Coast misstated the number of cities competing and listed several incorrectly. Nineteen cities are under consideration, including Lake Charles, La., and Gulfport, Miss., Baton Rouge, La., is not under consideration.

title: Paper Says U.S. Army Went Into Nicaragua

description: The first problem was the distance, 50 yards between Neil O'Donoghue, the St. Louis Cardinal kicker, and the goalposts.

title: U.S. NEARS PACTS TO CUT STEEL IMPORTS
description: The United States is close to agreement with steel-exporting nations on a system of quotas to curb their shipments here to less than 20 percent of the market.

description: Harry Carson said he was going to church yesterday. In fact, he said with a weary smile on Saturday, ''I think everybody should go to church.''

title: 'AREA SPECIALISTS' HELP IN RECRUITING

The targets of corporate recruiting efforts begin to fret not only about Minnesota's low temperatures and high taxes but also about schools for their kids and career opportunities for their spouses.

description: John F. Cowell 3d, creative director of Albert Frank- Guenther Law, has been named president of that 112- year-old Wall Street institution. He replaces Michael A. Taylor, 46, who becomes vice chairman, while Stephen J. Witt remains chairman and chief executive officer.

description: Phi Beta Kappa, the national academic honorary organization, has named its 1984 book awards. Each carries a $2,500 prize.

description: Didn't quacks and snake oil salesmen vanish when medicine became a self-regulating profession? No, because medical self-regulation is a mockery, even though doctors' tolerance of failure damages public health and invites heavy malpractice awards.

title: No Headline
description: Pro-Life Terrorism and What to Call It What's the difference between the antinuclear activist who said he could blow up the Washington Monument and the anti-abortion activists who have been blowing up family-planning clinics? One answer is easy. The former had no explosives; the latter most certainly do.

title: RIGHT NUMBERS ON 11 TICKETS IN $20 MILLION LOTTO DRAWING

description: Scientists and engineers began converting methyl isocyanate into pesticide here today in an effort to prevent another deadly leak of the substance.

At Meridian House, a home away from home for many of Washington's diplomats, the windows are festooned with Victorian Christmas wreaths and the 12-foot blue spruce in the solarium is decorated with handmade nosegays and golden bells.

title: AID INQUIRY AT EVERS COLLEGE SAID TO FIND NO WRONGDOING
description: An investigation into charges of financial-aid irregularities at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn has found no reason for bringing action against anyone at the school, according to the Chancellor of the City University.

title: Charles Jay Oppenheim Dies; Former Executive at CBS-TV

title: THE LAST-NAME GAME: A BALANCING ACT

There are women who use their maiden names in professional life and their husbands' names in private life. There are women who hyphenate and women who separate last names. There are also a lot of men getting unnerved by all these options in the new last-name game.

title: MANY STATES LIMIT MEDICAID PROGRAM
