description: States across the country are limiting the coverage of hospital care for poor people under Medicaid in an effort to control the costs of the program.

title: METRO-NORTH SAYS PARK AVE. TUNNEL MUST BE REPAIRED
description: The train tunnels under Park Avenue - some more than 110 years old - are rotting, and long stretches of the avenue will have to be ripped up to fix them, rail officials say.

title: IN POWERFUL NEW JOB, SHE OVERCOMES THE SKEPTICS
description: Last May the 16 members of the board of governors of the New York Mercantile Exchange closeted themselves in their headquarters in the World Trade Center to elect a new president. When they emerged about an hour later they had come up not only with a new president but also with an important breakthrough for women in the work force.

title: ; CREDITING GIDEON'S LAWYER FOR COURAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: 32 IN U.S. NAMED RHODES SCHOLARS
description: A national collegiate pistol champion, a scientist who studies sea turtles and a former night watchman for Amtrak are among the 32 Americans who have won Rhodes Scholarships for study at Oxford University in England.

title: FED POLICY MAKERS' CHALLENGE
description: The Federal Reserve's senior policy-making body meets this week to set money- supply targets for the next eight weeks against a backdrop of renewed prodding by the Reagan Administration to drive interest rates down.

title: A PINCH OF PARTY PSYCHOLOGY
description: IT is 30 minutes and counting, and Michael Hollingsworth is briefing his troops. ''No noshing,'' he says.

title: Cosmos Lose
description: A Cosmos defender, Dan Canter, deflected the ball into his own goal in overtime tonight, giving the Pittsburgh Spirit a 7-6 victory.

title: ROAD TO THE FUTURE IS PAVED WITH GUACAMOLE AND GOAT CHEESE
description: The largest-selling automobile in America last year was the Oldsmobile. But in the 13 Western states, the hottest seller was the Honda Accord, followed by three other Japanese models.

title: DON'T TAX EDUCATION BENEFITS
description: As the debate over the Federal income tax begins in earnest, increasing attention is being given to the idea of taxing a variety of fringe benefits, including those related to the continuing education of employees. Making such educational benefits taxable at a time when America badly needs to put more dollars into human capital would be folly.

title: Rewards Spurring Poaching Arrests
description: Two dozen arrests have been made in the first weeks of a new program offering rewards to people who inform the state of wildlife poaching, officials said.

title: 5 Women Escape From State Prison
description: Five female inmates apparently squeezed between steel bars on a window to escape Saturday night from a maximum-security section of the Niantic Correctional Institution, the state's only prison for women, officials said.

title: U.S. TRAILS IN CUP FINAL, 2-0
description: Sweden grabbed an unexpected 2-0 lead over the United States in the 1984 Davis Cup tennis final today as Mats Wilander crushed Jimmy Connors and Henrik Sundstrom followed with a straight-set upset of John McEnroe, the world's top-ranked player.

title: NINA SAVIN IS BRIDE OF WILLIAM W. SCOTT
description: Nina E. Savin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter M. Savin of Bloomfield, Conn., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to William W. Scott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Scott of West Hartford, Conn. Judge Jon O. Newman of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit performed the ceremony at the Tumble Brook Country Club in Bloomfield.

title: Wanted: A Sponsor
description: He was among Poland's top junior tennis players, and when unrest gripped his country, he decided to come to the United States to find his future. But for Darek Hrynkiewicz, a sturdy 6-footer with an arsenal of shots, the promised land has not been all it promised to be.

title: BALLET: 'THE NUTCRACKER'
description: Kaleria Fedicheva was a leading ballerina in the Kirov Ballet, and American audiences saw her perform with the company from Leningrad when it last toured the United States in 1964.

title: 16-Year-Old Is Held in Killing
description: A 16-year-old high school student has been accused of stabbing a classmate to death, possibly because of teen-age rivalry, the authorities said.

title: THATCHER AND RUSSIAN DISCUSS ARMS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, considered the second-ranking leader in the Soviet Union, and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher met today for nearly five and a half hours and discussed the state of East-West relations and new efforts to reduce the risk of nuclear war.

title: Officer Resigns At Tri-Star LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16 -
description: Gary Hendler, the president

title: AFGHANISTAN'S FIVE-YEAR ORDEAL: GRIM OUTLINES OF A FEROCIOUS WAR
description: Five years after its troops swept into Afghanistan, the Soviet Union is fighting a ferocious and largely secret war to subdue a fiercely resistant population.

title: Denmark Ends Search For Submarine in Fiord
description: The Danish Navy called off a hunt today for what may have been a submarine in a fiord after three days of searching by helicopters and warships.

title: HOW TV COVERS WESTMORELAND SUIT
description: The court battle between CBS and Gen. William C. Westmoreland almost certainly is, as ABC told its viewers, ''one of the most important libel trials in modern American history.'' It has everything, including the Vietnam War. Moreover, as CBS reported, it raises ''questions for a judge and jury that could not be more important.'' As an ongoing story for television, however, it has been deficient. History may be in the making in Federal Court in Manhattan, but not much of it has been seen on the evening news.

title: Actor Delivers Sermon To Dissident Lutherans
description: The television actor David Soul preached to the defiant followers of a jailed pastor at Trinity Lutheran Church today, calling for discussions with business leaders in an effort to ease the problems of blue-collar unemployment in this depressed steel valley.

title: IN THE HANDS OF RECEIVERS
description: WASHINGTONOn the previous play, Joe Theismann had been sacked for a 9-yard loss by Elois Grooms and now the Washington Redskins were confronted with a third-and-19 situation at the St. Louis Cardinals' 47-yard line. Third-and-19, behind by 27-26, only 2 minutes 45 seconds remaining, the National Conference East title at stake. Turning out of the huddle, Art Monk, a wide receiver who now holds the National Football League season record with 106 receptions, lined up at tight end.

title: SEEING IT SIMPLE
description: BOSTON Defenders of the racial system in South Africa often speak of the complexity of the country's problems. To the contrary, the first thing to learn about South Africa is that its problem is starkly simple.

title: Accounts
description: * Mobil Chemical Co. to Isidore & Paulson for new products.

title: RISING STAR IN KREMLIN
description: Though Mikhail S. Gorbachev is no stranger to foreign travel, his visit to London is giving the West its first extensive chance to take his measure since his ascendancy in the Soviet hierarchy became evident. Though formally he is leading a relatively low-level delegation of Soviet legislators on a visit to the House of Commons, Mr. Gorbachev, who visited Italy and Bulgaria earlier this year, came to Britain as the Russian widely believed to be next in line to lead the Kremlin.

title: KEMP TRADE APPROVAL SEEN
description: The Yankees expect to receive word in the next day or so that Commissioner Peter Ueberroth has approved their deals with the Pittsburgh Pirates in which Steve Kemp would join the Pirates and Dale Berra would join his father with the Yankees.

title: CAPITALS TROUNCE RANGERS, 6-3
description: The Rangers matched the Capitals last night blow for blow but not goal for goal. And so in a game filled with fistfights and stick jabs, they lost, 6-3, to Washington at the Garden.

title: THEATER: 'DIAMONDS,' A REVUE ABOUT BASEBALL
description: An all-star team takes the field in ''Diamonds,'' the new musical revue about baseball at the Circle in the Square Downtown. The roster of songwriters reads like a hall of fame of the present-day musical theater; the sketches are by such literary sluggers as Roy Blount Jr. and John Lahr; the veteran director is Harold Prince, who, in an early season of his career, co-produced the all-time champ of baseball musicals, ''Damn Yankees.'' So go figure why ''Diamonds'' proves too often a minor league affair. Even by generous estimate, the revue connects in only 10 of its 35 segments. Check my arithmetic, but I think that makes for a lowly winning percentage of .286.

title: U.S. FINDS FISH IN RIVERS HOLDING THEIR OWN
description: The fish life in the rivers and streams of the United States is holding its own despite increased pressures from the growth of human population and ''man-caused limiting factors that adversely affect fish,'' the Department of the Interior says.

title: An Indian Is Named Cape Town's Archbishop
description: Bishop Stephen Naidoo became the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Cape Town today.

title: MITTERRAND DEFENDS HIS POLICY ON CHAD
description: President Francois Mitterrand, defending his foreign policies, said tonight that Libya had lost ground in black Africa because of the French intervention in Chad.

title: America West Air To Consider Offer
description: America West Airlines, a commuter airline based in Phoenix, has received an unsolicited takeover bid that it will consider at a regularly scheduled board meeting tomorrow, the airline said.

title: A PERMANENT CURE IS DIFFICULT FOR ATHLETE-ADDICTS
description: Before the Utah Jazz waived John Drew on Dec. 8 because of renewed cocaine usage, the 30-year-old forward met with Frank Layden, the coach and general manager who had encouraged him to admit his addiction in 1982, enter a residential treatment center and continue group counseling after his discharge.

title: THE UNWITTING ALLIANCE
description: WASHINGTON People in their natural state are free. Why do we form governments, anyway?

title: JACK LEMMON IN 'MASS APPEAL'
description: ''Mass Appeal'' is this season's ''Educating Rita,'' which is not to say that it isn't likable, merely that it's blunt. Like ''Educating Rita,'' Bill C. Davis's two-character play (which he has adapted and expanded as a screenplay) takes the form of an extended, snappily paced ideological debate. In drama of this sort, a mature and somewhat jaded father figure finds his ideas challenged and eventually revitalized by a brash young protege. The process is described in big, bold, simple terms no audience could fail to understand.

title: Continental Illinois Officer Joins Southeast
description: In a move from the hot seat to the Sun Belt, William D. Plechaty today will become executive vice president and chief financial officer of the Southeast Banking Corporation and its subsidiary, Southeast Bank N.A. Both are based in Miami.

title: MUSIC: 'EINSTEIN' RETURNS BRIEFLY
description: The question, both for those who had seen ''Einstein on the Beach'' in 1976 and for those who hadn't seen it and regretted their loss, was: Would the 1984 revival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music be as good as the original? The answer is no, it's better.

title: DIVERSION OF FOOD IN ETHIOPIA DENIED
description: Members of a Canadian fact-finding mission said today that they had found no evidence to substantiate reports that famine relief aid was being sold commercially or was being misused.

title: GROUP RECOMMENDS CITY USE SURPLUSES FOR CAPITAL PROJECTS
description: New York City should consider using some of its budget surplus to finance the building of roads, bridges and other capital projects, instead of paying for them by selling bonds that command high interest rates, a civic group has recommended.

title: BEARS ESTABLISH SACK MARK
description: Greg Landry, playing his first National Football League game in almost three years, passed for one touchdown and ran for another and the Chicago defense set an N.F.L. season record for sacks as the playoff-bound Bears beat the Detroit Lions today, 30-13.

title: THE DANCE: 2 WORKS BY AILEY
description: ''Blues Suite'' and ''Cry,'' two of Alvin Ailey's best- known choreographic works, were on the program that the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater offered Saturday night at the City Center Theater. The result was an evening of lively dancing. Yet it was also an evening of sensitive dancing, for energy was invested with dramatic meaning.

title: Party's Paper Betrays Confusion in Ideology
description: The extent of confusion over China's ideology was highlighted inadvertently by People's Daily a short time ago.

title: MARYKNOLL USES LAITY IN MISSIONS
description: Leading their two small daughters by the hand, Patricia McKenna-Lee and her husband, Gerry, stepped to the altar of the Maryknoll chapel here today to begin a journey of faith among the poor.

title: LAFONTAINE'S PROGRESS SLOW
description: Things have cooled for Pat LaFontaine. He is no longer the midget- hockey scoring sensation, the junior hockey record-setter, or the hope of the United States Olympic hockey team.

title: BLAME WASHINGTON AND KEEP ON HELPING THE HOMELESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Full Agenda for F.C.C.
description: The agenda for the Federal Communications Commission's meeting this Wednesday is packed full of benefits for the communications industry.

title: HANDSHAKE ENDS TOSE THREAT
description: After five days of intense negotiations, Mayor W. Wilson Goode and a team of four city negotiators were feeling secure today in a promise that the Philadelphia Eagles will remain here.

title: No Headline
description: Kill Him, 5-4 It took two separate 2,000-volt charges of electricity to execute Alpha Stephens the other day. ''He was just not a conductor'' of electricity, a Georgia prison official said. The first, two-minute surge left him struggling to breathe. The doctors waited six minutes for his body to cool. When they pronounced him still alive, the executioners threw the switch again. In two more minutes, he was dead.

title: BROTHERS FEUD OVER NEW ORLEANS NEWSPAPER
description: As a major voice for New Orleans blacks, the 59-year-old Louisiana Weekly is accustomed to reporting news, its front pages telling of lynchings in the 1920's, civil rights marches in the 1960's, and its back pages detailing accounts of social events.

title: Caral Firestone Gets New Entree Account
description: Kent Kitchens, a recently formed company in Philadelphia, is moving beyond the test market with Chef de Royale, a heat-five-minutes-and- serve non-frozen entree.

title: JETS ROUTED IN STORMY FINISH
description: In the confusion of a season-ending 41-21 loss to the Buccaneers, the Jets were humbled and embarrassed today. And so were the National Football League and the Buccaneers.

title: States Repeal Unitary Tax Some four decades ago, California legislators, looking for a
description: way to raise revenues, put in

title: Tribute to Yiddish Poet
description: An evening of Yiddish poetry and song will be presented by Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival at 7:30 P.M. today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, in honor of Wolf Yunin, the Yiddish poet and folklorist who recently died.

title: Boiler, Left Outside Building, Falls on Boy, 8, and Kills Him
description: An 8-year-old boy was crushed to death yesterday when an old boiler outside his brother's Greenwich Village apartment building accidentally fell on him, according to the police.

title: No Headline
description: An Awful Reason to Love New York Ask New Jersey and Connecticut young people home for the holidays why they love New York, and they're likely to talk about the stimulation of socializing in another state. But the stimulation they seek is likely to be alcohol.

title: Dalai Lama Drops Tibet Trip
description: The Dalai Lama announced today that he had canceled a plan to visit his Chinese- controlled homeland next year. ''As long as the Tibetan people are not fully satisfied, the question of my return does not arise at all,'' the 49-year-old Buddhist leader said in a statement.

title: New Agency Forming: Angotti Thomas Hedge
description: Angotti Thomas Hedge could well be New York's first ad agency of the new year when it opens next month in temporary space at 10 East 21st Street. ''That's trendy midtown south,'' said Thomas C. Thomas, who is the writer in the threesome.

title: Trying to Avert a 'Vietnam'
description: Abbie Hoffman, the Yippie protester of the Vietnam War era, will lead 68 journalists, teachers, students, executives and professionals on an eight-day tour to Nicaragua beginning Friday. Mr. Hoffman said he had spent half the six years when he was a fugitive from justice, charged with selling cocaine, in Central America and that he had spent 10 days this summer in Nicaragua, so the project is ''very natural.''

title: Productive Season
description: Another basketball season has ended for the Webb Institute of Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering on Long Island, and again the team from Glen Cove will not go to a postseason tournament, even though it came through with one of its best records in years. It won a game.

title: Advertising; Modifying Claims for Crisco Oil
description: MIGHTY Procter & Gamble, the country's largest national advertiser, is changing its superiority claims for Crisco Oil because of an investigation by the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus.

title: CUBAN ORGANIZING A GUERRILLA UNIT
description: A Cuban exile leader says he has begun organizing a permanent Cuban exile detachment to fight alongside Nicaraguan rebels seeking the overthrow of the Sandinista Government.

title: Futures/Options; Tracking Trends by Computer
description: REGARDLESS of the technical and fundamental supply-demand factors commonly cited for moving futures prices, the three main influences are the interactions between traders, the cash price of the underlying commodity and the flow of economic news.

title: THE TANGLED LIFE AND MIND OF JUDY, WHOSE HOME IS THE STREET
description: This is the story of Judy, a homeless woman who sits at the corner of 64th Street and Lexington Avenue.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Football
description: Dolphins vs. Dallas Cowboys , at Miami. The Giants and their fans have reason to stay up till the end of this game: A Cowboy loss eliminates them and puts the Giants in the playoffs. The Dolphins, although they have clinched their division title, have some incentive to win, since a victory will give them the home-field advantage throughout the American Conference playoffs. There are some other noteworthy aspects to this game. Dan Marino, the Dolphin quarterback who has already set a standard for touchdown passes in one season, needs only 58 yards to surpass Dan Fouts's season record of 4,801 yards passing. Mark Clayton has 15 touchdown catches, 2 short of the record of 17 shared by Don Hutson, Elroy (Crazy Legs) Hirsch and Bill Groman. (Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 9 P.M.) Hockey

title: REDSKINS HOLD OFF CARDS BY 29-27 AND WIN TITLE ON
description: MOSELY'S KICK

title: Ban on Nerve Gas Is Upheld
description: A judge ruled Friday that the Cambridge Health Department's order banning laboratory tests on nerve gas for the Defense Department was constitutional. Judge Robert J. Hallisey of Superior Court set Dec. 27 for a pretrial conference in a legal battle between the city and Arthur D. Little Inc., a research and development company. The company contends that city regulations cannot apply to the tests because the project, authorized and financed by the Defense Department, is answerable only to Federal law.

title: HEART RECIPIENT LOSES ENTHUSIASM, DOCTOR REPORTS
description: William J. Schroeder, the second patient to receive an artificial heart, got out of bed today with assistance for the first time since he suffered a stroke Thursday night. But his doctors said he appeared withdrawn and they were concerned that if he did not snap out of a psychological slump, he might lose his will to live.

title: Deborah Jane Gardner Is Wed to Robert Lee Gray
description: Deborah Jane Gardner, the daughter of Dr. Milton M. Gardner of Garden City and Water Mill, L.I., and the late Madeleine Murphy Gardner, was married yesterday to Robert Lee Gray, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leroy Gray of Corinth, Miss. Judge Leslie C. Snyder of the Manhattan Criminal Court performed the ceremony at the Parker Meridien Hotel in New York.

title: Groups Want Budget Freeze
description: A coalition of business organizations will add its voice to the call for an across-the-budget freeze Monday. The idea of a freeze, including the military budget and cost-of-living increases for Social Security and other pension and benefit programs, is one that is being talked about on Capitol Hill by some Republicans.

title: Gretzky vs. Devils: Going for a Record
description: Wayne Gretzky and the defending champion Edmonton Oilers visit New Jersey tonight, and the Devils are perhaps more prepared than ever before to face them.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1984

title: FRANK SPEDDING, KEY FIGURE IN ATOM BOMB DEVELOPMENT
description: Frank H. Spedding, a developer of the atomic bomb and a founder of the Ames Laboratory for atomic research, died here Saturday. He was 82 years old.

title: STEELERS TRIUMPH, TAKE CENTRAL TITLE
description: Walter Abercrombie rushed for 111 yards on 28 carries and Pittsburgh's defense stymied the Los Angeles Raiders as the Steelers won, 13-7, today to take the American Conference Central Division title and earn a berth in the playoffs.

title: EARLIER SCHOOLING IS PRESSED
description: Educators and political leaders across the country are showing a growing interest in the instruction of 3- to 5-year-olds in light of mounting evidence that it results in better-adjusted children and reduced public spending over the long run.

title: Navy Indicates Cause Of 1968 Sub Sinking
description: An accidental torpedo explosion was the most likely cause of the loss in 1968 of the submarine Scorpion and her crew of 99 men, according to recently declassified Navy documents.

title: CONTINUING ECONOMIC DRAG SEEN
description: Recent statistics have shown a foggy picture of the economy's current health, but there is a growing view among forecasters that when the Commerce Department announces its ''flash'' estimate of economic growth for the fourth quarter, it will show little change from the third quarter's sluggish 1.9 percent rate. The figure is to be released Wednesday morning.

title: Increased Treasury Activity Likely
description: Activity in the Treasury securities market, which has been subdued in recent weeks from the lack of new issues and uncertainty about the interest rate outlook, may increase this week as the Treasury starts an end- of-the-year flurry of financings.

title: No Headline
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1984 International A ferocious and largely secret war is being fought by the Soviet Union in Afghanistan five years after its troops swept into the country. In an effort to subdue fierce resistance, high-altitude saturation bombing has demolished many villages in several regions of the country. Nearly every day, Soviet fighter bombers and helicopter gunships are on the lookout for guerrilla warriors who dominate the mountains and deserts. (Page 1, Column 1.) Polish policemen broke up a march organized in Gdansk by supporters of the banned Solidarity trade union in memory of Poles killed while protesting food price increases 14 years ago. Lech Walesa, the outlawed union's founder, led the memorial demonstration, which turned into the worst violence in Gdansk in months. At least two people were reported arrested. (A1:3.)

title: B.A.T In Pact for Hambro
description: B.A.T Industries, the British conglomerate that is the world's largest tobacco company as well as the owner of retail chains on both sides of the Atlantic, has offered to acquire Hambro Life Assurance P.L.C. for the equivalent of $800 million.

title: WOMAN SAYS ISRAEL CAUSED HER DISMISSAL
description: The New York City Commission on Human Rights has determined there is probable cause to believe that a 45- year-old Israeli-born American citizen was dismissed from her job at the World Zionist Organization as a result of a policy of discouraging the emigration of Israelis to other countries.

title: Israeli Philanthropist In Ethiopia With Aid
description: Abie Nathan, an Israeli philanthropist and self-styled campaigner for peace, arrived in this famine-struck country today with a planeload of relief supplies that he said were donated by Jewish communities around the world.

title: Civil War Shell Is Returned
description: A Civil War shell stolen Thursday night from Fort Zachary Taylor was returned after officials warned there was a small chance it could explode. The 100-pound shell turned up Saturday morning propped against the old fort's outside fence, said Cullen Chambers, chief ranger at Fort Zachary. The building from which the shell was stolen is accesible only from the Harry S. Truman Annex, a Navy base.

title: INVESTMENT IN OREGON SPURRED BY TAX REPEAL
description: Only eight years ago, Oregon's newly elected Secretary of State jokingly proposed that Oregonians line up on the southern border and hurl rocks at incoming cars with California license plates.

title: SICKLE-CELL ANEMIA TEST REPORTED
description: By aiming a laser beam at the arms of sickle- cell anemia victims, doctors say they have discovered that they can determine the severity of the disease and possibly test experimental treatments.

title: DISPLAYING AFFECTION IN PUBLIC
description: WHEN it comes to public displays of affection there seems to be very little middle ground. Some couples do it, others never do it. Onlookers either abhor it or adore it.

title: Signs of Finals At Barnard
description: That Columbia University and Barnard College students are deep into finals is immediately visible on both campuses.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline Dec. 9 on an article about a College Board report on financial aid to college students misstated the approximate total. Grants, loans, subsidized jobs and other forms of aid for the 1984-85 school year total more than $18 billion.

title: FORT WORTH ORDERS UP A POST-COWPOKE IMAGE
description: Fort Worth was once second only to Chicago among the nation's leading meat packers. Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid used to hang out there, between bank robberies, along with the odd cattle rustler, and the city still calls itself ''Cowtown U.S.A.''

title: 21 MEDALS FOR HEROISM AWARDED BY CARNEGIE FUND
description: When the Rev. John J. Sholly leaped into a chilly Iowa river to save a 76- year-old man from drowning last year, he said his first thought was: ''Well, dummy, you've done it now. You're going to die.''

title: Packers 38, Vikings 14
description: Lynn Dickey, playing only the first half, completed 16 of 20 passes for 198 yards and threw for 2 touchdowns and ran for another and gave Green Bay a 31-0 halftime lead. The cornerback Mark Lee set up scores with an interception and a fumble as the Packers (8-8) finished in second place in the Central Division. James Lofton caught 5 passes for 91 yards to set a Packer receiving yardage record for a single season with 1,361 yards in 62 catches.

title: RATTLING THE PENTAGON'S COFFEE CUPS
description: An old aviator named Barry M. Goldwater recently rattled the breakfast coffee cups in the suburbs surrounding the Pentagon. Military officials opened their morning paper to read that Mr. Goldwater, the next chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, favored a freeze on their budget and wanted the Reagan Administration to abandon the MX missile.

title: AN INDIAN UNION LEADER BLAMES BOTH STATE AND MANAGERS FOR LEAK
description: An Indian trade-union leader said today that both local officials and the management of the Union Carbide plant here were responsible for what he called a failure of safety measures at the plant.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: How many players from schools in the Atlantic Coast Conference have played pro basketball with the Knicks? How many with the Nets? Have any played for both teams?

title: JAZZ: 'HIGHLIGHTS' SERIES BRINGS ON THE SAXOPHONE
description: A ''Saxophone Spectacular'' presented Thursday evening at the Loeb Auditorium as part of the ''Highlights in Jazz'' series was only marginally ''spectacular'' and even then it was not entirely due to the saxophonists on the bill.

title: DONORS TO NEEDIEST MENTION GRATITUDE FOR THEIR BLESSINGS
description: The holiday season evokes a variety of responses from those who are able to enjoy it, and many supporters of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund express gratitude for their own blessings by sharing good fortune with others.

title: GIANTS WATCH AND WAIT
description: The Giants needed help from the Washington Redskins today, and from the Miami Dolphins Monday night, to qualify for the National Football League playoffs. So far, so good. Three Giants who watched the Redskins-Cardinals game together - Casey Merrill, Brad Benson and Perry Williams - confessed that they had many anxious moments before the Redskins eked out a 29-27 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: MONUMENTAL MISTAKE
description: To the Editor:

title: BAHAMAS INQUIRY ON PREMIER REPORTED TO BE INCONCLUSIVE
description: A report to be issued Monday on Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling says that after an investigation of more than a year, a three-member panel has been unable to determine whether he took bribes from drug smugglers trying to elude United States authorities in the Bahamas, according to prominent Bahamians who have seen excerpts.

title: REPORT CITES CAMPAIGN OF TERROR SINCE SOVIET ENTERED AFGHANISTAN
description: A report on human rights violations in Afghanistan asserts that a campaign of organized terror, torture, imprisonment and execution has been under way since Soviet troops entered the country five years ago.

title: Bridge:ClubWillSetAside2Nights Each Week for Nonsmokers
description: All tournaments make provision, in varying degree, for those who do not smoke and wish to play in a smoke- free environment. At the club level, however, with small numbers involved, the problem is more difficult. Many clubs attempt compromises by barring smoking at specific tables or on specific rounds of play.

title: Ex-British Official Promoted at Lazard
description: Sir John Nott, a former British Secretary for Defense, has been appointed chairman and chief executive of Lazard Brothers & Company, the London merchant bank subsidiary of Lazard Partners, which also has investment banking operations in New York and Paris.

title: Badillo Urges Gun Use Be Barred in Evictions
description: Former Deputy Mayor Herman Badillo said yesterday that police officers should be barred from using guns when called in for assistance during eviction proceedings.

title: WHY WE'LL POUND ON THE WORLD COURT'S TABLE
description: To the Editor:

title: IN BHOPAL REFUGEE CAMPS, NO HURRY TO RETURN HOME
description: Sayed Jaffer, one of 1,000 residents of Bhopal who moved to a large tent at the edge of a sports stadium to wait out the detoxification process at the Union Carbide plant, listened to Government broadcasts over the state-run radio throughout the day.

title: POLISH POLICE BREAK UP A PROTEST MARKING 1970 GDANSK FOOD RIOTS
description: The police used tear gas, riot sticks and smoke bombs today in Gdansk to disperse supporters of the banned Solidarity trade union who tried to memorialize Poles killed while protesting food price increases 14 years ago. At least 12 people were reported detained.

title: ANTHEM CHIEF ADDS POSITION OF CHAIRMAN
description: Anthem Electronics Inc., the semiconductor distribution company, has elected Robert S. Throop, 47, its president and chief executive officer since 1972, to be chairman. Mr. Throop, who replaces Charles R. Scott as chairman, will continue as chief executive and a member of the board.

title: Clemson Dethrones Indiana in Soccer
description: John Lee's 6-yard goal on a header with 1 minute 42 seconds left tonight gave Clemson a 2-1 victory over Indiana and kept the Hoosiers from becoming the first taam to win three consecutive Division I soccer titles.

title: Miss Meyer Wed To Joshua Sacks
description: At the Park East Synagogue in New York yesterday Emily Ione Meyer, a daughter of Arlene Meyer Cohen of New York and Greensboro, N.C., and the late John H. Meyer, was married to Joshua Mark Sacks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David G. Sacks of Larchmont, N.Y. Rabbis Arthur Schneier, Hillel Friedman and Marshall T. Meyer, the bride's uncle, officiated. They were assisted by Cantor Moshe Geffen.

title: Mitsubishi Motors
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, Japan's fifth-largest auto maker, said it had agreed to supply the Chrysler Corporation with its newly developed fuel- injected V-6 engines.

title: Film Showing Aids Festival of India
description: Recent events have not slowed the

title: The U.N. Today
description: Dec. 17, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 17, 1984: MONDAY Horizon BancorpPrimark CorpLilly (Eli) & CoRochester TelNBD BancorpSterchi Bros StrsPHH Group Inc

title: OUTDOORS ; BIRDS OF OUTER BANKS
description: KILL DEVIL HILLS, N.C.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, has named Alan H. Anderson, Timothy L. Guzzle and Oliver S. Travers Jr. executive vice presidents.

title: '30 Bentley Sets Record In a Sale to American
description: An American collector paid a world record price last week for a 1930 Bentley automobile that made history by beating an express train from Monte Carlo to London.

title: CABARET: KAYE BALLARD
description: Kaye Ballard is an engaging anomaly - a musical comedy veteran who is still a starstruck fan, an urban sophisticate with a self-deprecating clownish sense of herself. In ''Here's to the Ladies,'' her salute to three women lyricists that plays at Michael's Pub through Jan. 12, she and Arthur Siegel, the pianist, singer and songwriter, have put together a zestful living room entertainment in which Miss Ballard's earthy sense of fun and Mr. Siegel's arch, lemony wit ricochet amusingly.

title: The Budget World According to La Guardia
description: It was a meeting of city agency

title: Wrestling Galore
description: There is no accounting for the appeal of the expressive grimace or the well-turned grunt, but to those who savor the spectacle of massive men with menacing names bouncing off the ropes to squash a squalid opponent with a flying leg drop, nothing is quite so appealing as a well-choreographed wrestling match.

title: Barbara Kur Is Wed
description: The marriage of Barbara Jean Kur and Mark David Berger, 1980 graduates of Pennsylvania State University, took place yesterday at the Chanticler in Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Reuben R. Levine officiated. The bride, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Kur of of Springfield, N.J., is a graduate also of New York University's paralegal gram. Mr. Berger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Berger of Fairview, Pa., is a marketing and sales sentative for the Himolene Sales Corporation, a plastics manufacturer in King of Prussia, Pa.

title: North Koreans In New Warning
description: North Korea said today that it had sent an urgent request to the International Olympic Committee to cancel the choice of Seoul, capital of South Korea, as the site for the 1988 Summer Olympics. It warned that South Korea was unstable, facing constant danger of war because of the presence of 40,000 United States troops.

title: Yugoslav Takes Cup Slalom Race
description: Bojan Krizaj of Yugoslavia, despite being bothered by an aching leg, turned in two strong runs today and led a sweep by veterans in a men's World Cup slalom race.

title: SMALL PARTY SAYS IT'S QUITTING ISRAELI CABINET
description: Israel's Cabinet of national unity was confronted today with its first serious political crisis when a member of the Orthodox Shas Party resigned in a dispute over who would get to control religious affairs in the country.

title: May I Take Your Pie, Sir?
description: Those with $250 tickets to the

title: Toasting the City Council
description: To enable Washington merchants and consumers from

title: KNICKS ASSESS COLLEGE TALENT
description: Soon after the regular season ends April 14, the National Basketball Association will introduce its version of a lottery game. The drawing will be confined to the seven teams that fail to make the playoffs. The top prize will be Pat Ewing, the 7-foot Georgetown center, who is expected to be the first player selected in the draft.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section yesterday about avant-garde events misstated the availability of tickets for ''Einstein on the Beach'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Seats may still be available for some performances.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: BRANCH OFFICE Every December, a tree bears the fruit of creative hands on the second floor of the building at 41 West 47th Street, which houses the Gotham Book Market & Gallery (719-4476). It is a Christmas tree laden with treats for the eye in a block that otherwise sparkles only with the wares of the diamond dealers who do most of the other business on this street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas.

title: ROCHESTER FANS BARRED AFTER VIOLENCE AT GAMES
description: The bleachers are empty when the players arrive and start running through their pregame drills on the basketball court - layups, weaves, rebounds. The cheerleaders stand on the sidelines and practice their routines - ''Dee- Fense,'' ''Give me a C,'' ''Yea, Team.''

title: AFTER NINE YEARS, GODZILLA RETURNS TO THE SCREEN
description: His appeal may be a bit hard for some people to understand. Basically, he is an outsized, outdated lizard in dire need of a good orthodontist, with a vocabulary limited to a grating ''Aaarrgh!''

title: CHINA REPORTS DISCOVERY OF 1,100 ANCIENT FIGURINES
description: The official New China News Agency said today that 1,100 terra cotta figurines from the Han dynasty had been unearthed in the ancient city of Xuzhou and compared the find to the discovery of an army of life- size terra cotta figures in Xian 10 years ago.

title: GEORGE SCOTT IN 'A CHRISTMAS CAROL'
description: The very first scenes of the new adaptation of ''A Christmas Carol,'' on CBS at 8 this evening, are reassuring for those of us who love and treasure the Charles Dickens classic. Filmed in the English town of Shrewsbury, on the Welsh border, the production beautifully evokes a sense of period and place, washed in misty pastel colorings. Care has obviously been taken. The story is clearly in good hands.

title: Market Place; Stock Sages Look to 1985
description: THIS is the season on Wall Street for making

title: DANCE: MOVEMENT RESEARCH BENEFIT
description: Movement Resarch presented a two-performance benefit on Friday and Saturday that was a model of its kind. Dances flew by in the congenial Danspace at St. Mark's Church in expertly paced programs that offered suggestions of history and current trends, as befits an organization that serves, in part, as a forum for postmodernist dance and dancers. At the same time, most of the dances also offered succinct and engaging views of their makers' perspectives and concerns, with an unexploded rocket or two to enhance the charms of the nonfizzlers.

title: LONG SHOPPING LIST FOR JETS
description: In a quiet time on the Jets' practice

title: ASIMOV IS CELEBRATING 300TH BOOK'S PUBLICATION
description: Isaac Asimov expects to be up at 6 o'clock this morning, and as usual he expects to be at his typewriter by 7:30 A.M. But instead of working until 10 P.M., tonight he will attend a dinner party - in celebration of the publication today of his 300th book.

title: TENOR SANG AT MET 27 YEARS
description: Jan Peerce, the American tenor who was one of the favorite singers of Arturo Toscanini, died at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged here on Saturday night after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: JAZZ: JANET LAWSON SINGS
description: In an unusual and imaginative

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: OIL PARLEY FACES BIG OBSTACLES
description: As the OPEC oil ministers gather this week in Geneva, they face three formidable challenges to their increasingly battered pricing system.

title: Man Jailed for Alleging Santa Doesn't Exist
description: A man was jailed on trespassing charges after he was reported to have harassed a shopping center Santa Claus and to have told children there is no Santa Claus.

title: IN TUNNEL, A DRILL FOR DISASTER
description: In the dim light of a tunnel beneath Park Avenue, rescue units yesterday conducted a drill to test procedures for evacuating Metro-North Commuter Railroad trains during a fire.

title: Possible Iran Sanction Proposed by Moynihan
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said yesterday that if Iran fails to prosecute the Arab terrorists who hijacked a Kuwaiti airliner, the United States and European nations should cease all air travel to and from Iran.

title: FRENCH WARN SPANISH ON FISHING VIOLATIONS
description: France is ready to step up naval action against illegal fishing by Spanish trawlers in French waters after recording 1,195 violations by Spanish vessels last year, the External Relations Ministry said today.

title: Shultz Picks an Envoy
description: Secretary of State George P.

title: Harcourt Brace
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. said it would terminate its pension plan as of Dec. 31, but maintain all benefits and current choices of payments through annuities bought from a major insurance company.

title: An Anti-Meese Effort
description: Common Cause, the private Washington-based citizens' lobbying group, says it will actively oppose President Reagan's nomination of Edwin Meese 3d as United States Attorney General.

title: ACTION ON DONOVAN DEFENDED
description: A Bronx prosecutor, defending the indictment by a state grand jury of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan, testified yesterday that the action was taken only after a special Federal prosecutor decided against investigating similar charges.

title: Mending Fences
description: Using his own form of a diplomatic

title: O.&M. Added Billings Of $485 Million in 1984
description: At the annual festive pre-Christmas get-together of the staff of Ogilvy & Mather held yesterday, William E. Phillips, chairman and chief executive, announced in his own merry fashion that the worldwide company this year had pulled in a total of $485 million in new billings.

title: Boy Is Hit and Killed By a Police Car on S.I.
description: A 12-year-old boy trying to walk a bicycle across a Staten Island highway died last evening when he was struck by a police car involved in ''some kind of chase,'' the police reported.

title: 17 States Are Chosen As Possible Dump Sites
description: The Energy Department has listed 17 states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, as having the right kind of rock to make an underground home for the nation's second industrial nuclear waste dump.

title: Sweden Beats U.S. in Doubles and Wins Davis Cup
description: Sweden clinched the 1984 Davis Cup tennis title before an ecstatic home crowd tonight as Anders Jarryd and Stefan Edberg handed John McEnroe and Peter Fleming their first doubles loss in 15 cup matches.

title: ALL BRANCHES OF JUDAISM CAN OPPOSE APARTHEID
description: To the Editor:

title: ANDRE LAUG, STYLIST OF CONSERVATIVE LINE OF FASHION IN ROME
description: Andre Laug, the Rome couturier who also had a thriving ready-to-wear business, died of a heart attack Sunday in Rome, where he was working on his next collection. He was 53 years old.

title: SWANTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $193,000 for the quarter and $499,000 for the 9 months. c-After a loss of $1,155,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net income after a loss of $1,356,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Electronic Therapy
description: ''I wish I came up with the idea,''

title: SPORTO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: ATLANTIC FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN(FT. LAUDRDALE) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Toyota Sports Car
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation announced a suggested retail price of $11,000 for a new two-seat sports car it will begin importing from Japan next month.

title: AGAIN, MIDEAST TERROR
description: The hijacking of a Kuwaiti airliner to Iran this month in which two Americans were killed is but one terrorist episode in a series that reflects new tension in the Middle East, diplomats and Government officials say.

title: VIETNAM TO KILL 5 ACCUSED IN PLOT
description: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 18 (Reuters) - Five people today were sentenced to death by firing squad after being found guilty of plotting to overthrow the Vietnamese Government with the help of China, Thailand and the United States.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: WRITER AND POLITICAL ACTIVIST
description: Sidney Hertzberg, a writer, editor and political activist, died of lung cancer Friday at the Rockland County Medical Center in Pomona, N.Y. He was 74 years old and lived in Palisades, N.Y.

title: PENRIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results for the latest first quarter include revenue of approximately $8.4 million from the Triplett Corp., acquired on Oct. 18 and Concord Systems Inc., acquired on Dec. 31, 1983.

title: RIO GRANDE DRILLING reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
THE THEATER: PETER WHELAN'S 'ACCRINGTON PALS'
description: IF there's one story the English

title: A TOWN HELPS ITSELF TO A NEW SCHOOL
description: After six years of trying and failing to get the county, the state and even the Federal Government to give them money to build a new elementary school, people in this rural town decided the traditional approach to school financing was not worth the wait.

title: DEVILS SLOW OILERS, GRETZKY
description: With solid performances by several players, the Devils defeated the defending champion Edmonton Oilers, 5-2, tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena and prevented Wayne Gretzky from reaching a milestone.

title: 'TRAP' SPRINGS ROOKIE
description: For the majority of the National

title: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: AGENCY REPORTS GENETIC THERAPY IS NEAR
description: THE policy question concerning human gene therapy is no longer whether to attempt such treatments, but when trials in patients should begin, according to a report released yesterday by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment.

title: AT WESTMORELAND TRIAL, A JUDGE IN FIRM CONTROL
description: There are judges garrulous or grave, imperious or benign, formidable or folksy, who preside over and often set the tone for a trial. Pierre Nelson Leval is all of these but the first: He is not a gabby judge. But he is firmly in command, every minute, of the historic libel trial pitting Gen. William C. Westmoreland against CBS, now in its 11th week.

title: Shue Leads in Losses
description: Coach Gene Shue of the Washington Bullets knew that one more victory would give him 700 for his career, but he did not realize that one more defeat would make him the first coach in the history of the National Basketball Association to have 700 losses. He found out Sunday night, when the Bullets were beaten by the Los Angeles Lakers, 109-101.

title: SPEED-LIMIT REPORT CAUTIOUS ON CHANGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Fails to Settle Dispute in Cabinet
description: Israeli Government leaders tried without success tonight to settle a dispute between two religious parties in the unity Government.

title: LOUISIANA HOSPITAL INQUIRY FOCUSES ON GOVERNOR'S ROLE
description: At first glance the subject of Louisiana's latest scandal appears less than riveting and more than a little murky.

title: Tarkett Seeks Agency For Combined Work
description: Tarkett Inc. of Parsippany, N.J., vinyl-making United States subsidiary of Swedish Match, is looking for an agency to handle all of its consumer and trade advertising.

title: '84 POLL RESULTS DISPUTED BY JEWS
description: In something more than an academic exercise, some Jewish supporters of President Reagan are challenging the results of election polls that show the Jewish vote for the Republican candidate was smaller in 1984 than it was in 1980.

title: STAMP IN SERIES HONORS ELIOT
description: -born poet who became a British citizen, was honored in New York last night with the unveiling of a T. S. Eliot postage stamp scheduled to go on sale in 1986.

title: IRISH ARREST 3 FROM U.S. AFTER PACT IS SIGNED
description: Three fugitives from the United States, including a former executive of the General Dynamics Corporation who is wanted in a kickback scandal, were arrested today under a new extradition treaty quietly signed by Washington and Dublin.

title: No Headline
description: Walter Gilbert, a Nobel Prize-winning biochemist, resigned yesterday as chairman and chief executive of Biogen N.V., one of the companies in the forefront of the search for an anticancer drug. Biogen has been reporting sizable losses, and analysts speculated that Mr. Gilbert may have been under pressure to resign.

title: Toronto Board, Amex Plan Tie The American Stock Exchange and the Toronto Stock
description: Exchange are scheduled to disclose plans this morning to develop an electronic link between their two trading floors. In announcing the news conference, the two exchanges

title: Aldermen Uncertain On Pension for Widow
description: ''Serious policy implications'' may jeopardize the award of a pension to the wife of a police sergeant who died of cancer two weeks before he was eligible for it, an alderman said today.

title: A BROKER'S DRIVE FOR NEW IMAGE
description: Now that years of sparring with the Securities and Exchange Commission over his business practices are behind him, Robert E. Brennan, founder and chairman of First Jersey Securities Inc., is remaking his image and that of his firm.

title: TALKS BREAK OFF BETWEEN CITY AND NONUNIFORMED WORKERS
description: Talks between New York City and unions representing 200,000 nonuniformed city workers broke off yesterday, after an independent mediator concluded that his efforts to bring the sides together had failed.

title: Louisiana Parish Sells 'Put' Bonds
description: St. Charles Parish of Louisiana yesterday offered $105 million of adjustable/fixed rate pollution control revenue bonds for the Louisiana Power and Light Company.

title: Dana to Acquire Warner Electic
description: The Dana Corporation said it had executed a definitive agreement to acquire the Warner Electric Brake and Clutch Company for $30 a share, or about $157.5 million. Dana, which makes parts for trucks and, to a lesser extent, for cars, said it had entered into an agreement with Warner shareholders owning 2,579,630 shares, or about 49 percent of those outstanding, to buy their shares at $30 each.

title: Wage Pact Keeps A Company Open
description: An agreement early today giving blue- collar workers raises of $20 a week kept the employee-owned Hyatt Clark Industries from closing its doors.

title: LITTLE PRINCE PRODUCTIONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: LEBANESE MILITIAS EXCHANGE FIRE
description: Druse militiamen fired dozens of rockets into Christian residential areas in Beirut today, and Christian and Druse militias fought artillery battles in southern Lebanon, the police and radio reported.

title: New Bulgarian Plot? It May Be Fake Scotch
description: A British business organization said today that fake Scotch whisky was being produced in Bulgaria and exported by a Government-run company.

title: Posey & Quest
description: Chester L. Posey, 61, chairman of Posey, Pary & Quest, has passed his chief executive's title along to James H. Quest, 50, the president. The agency has also been renamed Posey & Quest, reflecting the fact that James D. Parry recently left to join Henderson Friedlich Graf & Doyle.

title: MASTERING THE ART OF HEAD-KNOCKING
description: WASHINGTON He has carried a football 57 times in his four-year career, but that is not important. He has caught two passes in those four seasons - none in the last two - but that is not how Otis Wonsley's value to the Washington Redskins is measured. The truth is that, for all the attention that rushes and receptions may receive, much of Wonsley's considerable worth is hidden in obscure statistics that assistant coaches keep.

title: AMERICAN MOTOR INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
COGENIC ENERGY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Church Rejects Minister It Thinks Is Homosexual
description: A Southern Baptist Church congregation has revoked a minister's ordination because it believes he may be a homosexual.

title: Felec Contracts
description: Felec Services Inc. received two Air Force contracts totaling $278.8 million to operate early warning facilities, the Defense Department said. It said the company got $167.1 million for taking care of distant early warning facilities in Greenland, Canada and Alaska, and $111.7 million for ballistic missile early warning system facilities in Greenland, Alaska and Colorado. The department also said the Army had given the Thiokol Corporation $29 million to maintain a Government facility.

title: TO REDUCE CRIME, LEGALIZE MARIJUANA
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE COUNCIL ON ARTS STAFF COMPLAINS ABOUT CUTS
description: Staff members of the New York State Council on the Arts have sent an 8-page letter to the members of the board of that organization, claiming that recent staff cuts and policy shifts have put the agency into a state of ''deep confusion.''

title: PANEL PASSES BILL ON BOSTON HARBOR CLEANUP
description: A conference committee of the Massachusetts Legislature today approved a bill designed to reduce pollution in Boston Harbor by creating an independent agency to raise money for improving sewage treatment facilities.

title: Healing, Not Stealing, for the Disabled The young woman had held her job as a librarian for four years before it became clear in 1978 that her depression wasn't getting better. That year she was hospitalized - the first of many admissions until she attempted suicide in 1980. Then she was placed in a supervised residence. According to court documents, ''Her thoughts are disordered and the slightest stress causes intense anxiety and psychotic disturbance in mood and thinking.''
description: Going back to work at the library was out of the question, and the woman easily qualified for the Social Security program that supports people too disabled to hold a job. Yet in 1982 the Reagan Administration suddenly cut her off. Though her condition seemed worse, she was pronounced fit to work.

title: Steckel Dismissed
description: Les Steckel , whose strict coaching techniques had been a constant source of friction between himself and his Minnesota Viking players, was dismissed yesterday after he refused General Manager Mike Lynn 's request that he resign. Lynn said he had based his decision, in which all the assistant coaches were also let go, on three criteria: ''image, control of the team and maintenance of the football team.''

title: Thon Is Dropped
description: Dickie Thon was dropped from the San Juan Metros baseball roster yesterday by the team's general manager after the Astros' shortstop, who is recovering from an eye injury, missed a meeting.

title: SAL COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
THE REVIEW OF BOOKS IS SOLD FOR $5 MILLION
description: The New York Review of Books, the influential journal created in 1963, has been sold to Rea Hederman, former executive editor of The Jackson (Miss.) Clarion-Ledger.

title: 'NOVA' VISITS WITH STEPHEN JAY GOULD OF HARVARD
description: ''NOVA'' visits tonight with a paleontologist, examining both the man and his works. He is Stephen Jay Gould of Harvard, popular lecturer, dinosaur expert and, ''Nova'' says, ''one of the liveliest voices in science today.'' He is also a regular fellow. The one-hour program will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 P.M.

title: Man Asks Military Trial Rather Than Extradition
description: A retired automobile worker whom Israel wants to extradite on charges of World War II crimes argued today that a military court, not a Federal court, should try those charged with war crimes.

title: MICRON TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BSL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Year to Sept 30

Topics ; Wondering Eyes ; DasherUsually it is an older sibling who brings the bad news about Santa Claus - and he in turn got it from the same kid who told him the unvarnished truth about where babies come from. The latter revelation, being greeted with a disbelief that can last well into adolescence, is easier to accept.
description: Imagine, then, the wails of the toddlers in a Burlington, Vt., shopping mall who got the message from a grownup driven by stringent religious conviction.

title: KEMP OPPOSES SAVINGS ON ARMS TO CUT DEFICIT
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp took issue with many fellow Republicans in Congress today, opposing sizable reductions in projected military spending as a way to slice the Federal deficit.

title: NO ACCORD ON DEMOCRATIC LEADER
description: Democratic governors and state party leaders failed Sunday to agree on their own candidate for national party chairman, but called for the creation of a national policy council to strengthen Democrats' performances in Presidential elections.

title: TAKE EAGLES FROM TOSE
description: For whatever his promise is

title: SELLING OF A LACKLUSTER FOOTBALL GAME
description: The Giants played a football game Saturday,

title: INQUIRY FINDS SMUGGLING HAS HURT BAHAMAS
description: The smuggling of large amounts of drugs through the Bahamas to the United States has damaged ''almost all strata of Bahamian society,'' corrupting policemen and Cabinet ministers and creating countless young addicts, according to a royal commission report issued to members of Parliament today.

title: Injury List
description: Glen Hanlon, the Ranger goalie, suffered a slight concussion, the team said yesterday, when Bobby Carpenter of Washington crashed into him during a game Sunday.

title: 2 Restaurateurs Refused Blacks, U.S. Charges
description: The Justice Department filed criminal and civil charges today against a Virginia couple, accusing them of refusing to serve blacks in their restaurant.

title: HANOVER BANK SETS 10 3/4% PRIME
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company cut its prime lending rate yesterday by half a percentage point, to 10 3/4 percent, the lowest level since August 1983, when it stood at 10 1/2 percent. Although no other major banks immediately followed the move, it was widely believed most would do so shortly, probably today. Some predicted that the prime rate would soon drop even lower.

title: No Headline
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1984 International China's new ''responsibility system,'' which lets peasants who produce more earn more, has been a general success. Since the policy change was announced in late 1978, China's output of grain and potatoes has increased nearly 5 percent a year to reach a record 387 million tons last year. Now that the 800 million peasants are no longer forbidden to find ways to earn money on the side, their average income has more than doubled since 1978 to reach 310 yuan, equivalent to about $117, a person in 1983. However, some regions are still gripped by poverty. (Page A1, Columns 3-4.) Mikhail S. Gorbachev told Sir Geoffrey Howe, the British Foreign Secretary, that the Soviet leadership considers it ''especially important to avert the transfer of the arms race to outer space.'' Mr. Gorbachev, the Kremlin's second in commmand, said, ''If it is done, then it would be unreal to hope to stop the nuclear arms race.'' (A3:1-3.)

title: Six Flags Aides Are Spared Trial
description: Two amusement-park executives charged with manslaughter in the fire at Six Flags Great Adventure that killed eight teen-agers were spared a criminal trial today when a judge allowed them into a pretrial program.

title: Merrill Seeks Seat in Tokyo
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said it was seeking permission to buy a seat on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. Merrill, which would be the first foreign brokerage firm to own a seat on the exchange, said it made the request on Friday to the Securities Dealers Association of Japan.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Friday about the manslaughter conviction of Joseph Brennan for a killing at a Manhattan video arcade gave his address incorrectly. He lives at 227 East 57th Street.

title: ROZELLE MAY ASK OWNERS TO HELP TOSE
description: Pete Rozelle, the National Football League commissioner, will meet with the club owners here today to review the situation involving the Philadelphia Eagles, and he may ask them for a favor on behalf of Leonard Tose.

title: Rich's Aide Gets Probation By The Associated Press A business associate of the
description: fugitive financier Marc Rich

title: SEARCH FOR 'NEMESIS' INTENSIFIES DEBATE
description: WITH bounding curiosity and a theory to establish, astronomers are searching the northern skies for a star they call Nemesis, a small, dim companion of the Sun. Nemesis may or may not exist, but the quest goes on and soon will expand to the southern skies.

title: Bird vs. Erving: A Lasting Photo
description: The Faneuil Hall market in Boston was chockablock with shoppers over the weekend, many of them elbowing for room near the racks of prints at a photographic gallery called At the Negative Side.

title: ALL THE PRESIDENTS' DOGS
description: Franklin D. Roosevelt had his Fala. Lyndon B. Johnson had Him and Her. Now comes Lucky, the latest in a long line of Top Dogs at the White House.

title: Final Approval Given Baseball Bill in Jersey
description: The Assembly today gave final approval to a bill that expands the power of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority so it can try to lure a professional baseball team to the state.

title: IT'S OFFICIAL: REAGAN SWEEPS NEW YORK
description: The ballots bore only the names of Ronald Reagan and George Bush. The voters dutifully followed a script that told them not only what to say but even when to applaud.

title: ISRAEL ARRIVES IN ETHIOPIA ON RELIEF MISSION
description: Citing an ancient connection between the Jewish and Ethiopian peoples, an Israeli philanthropist and fund-raiser has come here to build a fully equipped camp for famine refugees.

title: Saudi Imports Down
description: Saudi Arabian imports totaled the equivalent of $17.8 billion in the first six months of this year, down 11.2 percent from a year earlier, according to the Government. The Ministry of Finance said on Sunday that the appreciation of the country's currency, the riyal, against major currencies had contributed to the decline.

title: Walton Lashes Out At Last Jet Meeting
description: This was not just another day for the New York Jets. It was their last day. But the way they were scolded by Coach Joe Walton, and then underwent the unusual routine of watching films, reminded some players of his other tirades this season.

title: Financial Corp. Restructuring LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17
description: (Reuters) - The Financial

title: SOCIAL ANXIETY: NEW FOCUS LEADS TO INSIGHTS AND THERAPY
description: SOCIAL anxiety, in its many forms, is epidemic. About 40 percent of Americans think of themselves as shy, while only 20 percent say they have never suffered from shyness at some point in their lives. Nearly one in four men and one in eight women report high anxiety when going out on a date, while a third of men and almost a half of women report such feelings at dances and discoth eques. And the most frequent fear in one survey of 3,000 adults was found to be speaking before a group.

title: MIDLANTIC TO ACQUIRE HERITAGE
description: The Heritage Bancorporation and Midlantic Banks Inc. said yesterday that they had reached a definitive agreement under which Midlantic would acquire Heritage for $47 a share in a deal worth more than $200 million.

title: In Perspective
description: During the weeks that ABC vied for his services, and in the days since he decided to remain the star broadcaster for CBS Sports, Brent Musburger has tasted both the pleasures and the pains of free-agent celebrity.

title: KOCH FACES SHARP QUESTIONS FOR HIGH SCHOOL AUDIENCE
description: It showed every sign of being a friendly encounter: Mayor Koch speaking to a group of high school students in the quiet Midwood section of Brooklyn.

title: 2 'Revolutionaries' Held Without Bail
description: Two self-proclaimed revolutionaries, including a woman who had been sought in connection with the Brink's armored-car robbery in Nanuet, N.Y., in 1981, were ordered held without bail today at a Federal Court hearing.

title: NO FREE LUNCH IN THE NEW SATELLITE-DISH LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: Prime Cut Lifts Stocks; Dow Up 0.88
description: A late rally enabled the stock market to finish higher yesterday after being in the minus column until shortly before the close of trading.

title: OILMEN LOBBY ON TAX PLAN
description: A number of President Reagan's top financial backers, some of them independent oil producers, are upset over the business provisions in the Treasury's tax simplification proposal, but they say they are confident that the White House will significantly alter the plan in response to pressure from corporate lobbyists.

title: Poison-Gas Scare in Peru
description: A poison gas leak forced the evacuation of 3,000 residents from a shantytown district of the Peruvian capital over the weekend but caused no casualties.

title: Cheers and Jeers
description: Groans and cries of ''foul'' have been heard from many Federal employees who have been told by budget-conscious Reagan Administration officials that they cannot automatically have time off on Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve. In the past when these days fell on a Monday, as they do this year, Presidents have added to holiday cheer by closing Government offices.

title: ARTS LEADERS TO LOBBY FOR INCREASED STATE AID
description: Nearly 20 of New York's most powerful cultural figures have banded together to lobby for an $11 million increase - 28 percent - in annual state aid to the arts. The current budget is $39 million.

title: MARITAL RAPE: LAW'S CRITICS JOIN AN APPEAL
description: A little more than a year ago, a Buffalo jury gave Mario Liberta a dubious distinction. He became the first man in New York State to be convicted of raping his wife.

title: GREAT AMERICAN MANAGEMENT & INVESTMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Murder Trial Ends In a Hung Jury
description: A jury was dismissed today after failing to reach a verdict in the 13-week trial of a Mayor's wife accused of killing her 3 1/2-year-old adopted son by repeated physical abuse.

title: PUT UP YOUR DUKES
description: One is continually puzzled by New York's Archbishop, John O'Connor. He seems to relish street-brawling with politicians and government officials who don't agree absolutely with one or another of his principles. He says he's a reasonable man but he's always telling someone to put up his dukes.

title: POWER TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss. Year-ago share earnings adjusted to reflect 5 percent stock dividends in April 1984 and October 1984.

title: ISRAEL BARS A MEMBER OF GERMAN GREEN PARTY
description: A West German member of the European Parliament was denied permission today to enter Israel with five other representatives of the Green Party because of her conviction four years ago on terrorist charges.

title: Jewel Thief to Leave Prison
description: Jack (Murf the Surf) Murphy, a celebrated jewel thief and murderer who a judge once said should never be freed, will be transferred from prison to join a program of working outside it Thursday, the officials said today.

title: FEDERAL OFFICIALS CITE FIRE HAZARDS AND TRACK PROBLEMS IN SUBWAYS
description: Federal inspectors yesterday ended a weeklong investigation of fires in the city's subway system, describing their findings but refusing to draw conclusions.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: TO HORSE! It's a garment show, and more, for the horsey set that opens today in the downstairs Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, 81st Street and Fifth Avenue (879-5500). ''Man and the Horse'' traces the fashions people have worn since they first dressed specially for going out astride hayburners.

title: Steel Output Falls by 1.7% By The Associated Press Steel production fell to 1.445
description: million tons in the week ended

title: Bond Prices Increase Sharply
description: Bond prices rose sharply in active trading yesterday, buoyed by further evidence of an easing in monetary policy by the Federal Reserve.

title: KEY PORTIONS OF DISCUSSION ON TAXES
description: Following are excerpts from a discussion yesterday at The New York Times between Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Representative Charles B. Rangel, New York Democrats, on the Treasury Department's proposal for revising Federal income taxes.

title: UNITED EDUCATION & SOFTARE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: N.F.L. Weighs Penalty
description: The National Football League may take action against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers for not attempting to stop the Jets from scoring late in the game.

title: SIBONEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $83,794 for the quarter and $282,159 for the 9 months. The 1984 results reflect chages of approximately $1 million to provide for potential adjustments to the cost of video purchases in the Siboney Communications subsidiary.

title: CRILE TESTIFIES ON ADVICE TO WALLACE
description: A. FARBER

title: HIJACKING SURVIVOR SEEKS TRIAL
description: One of the two Americans who survived the hijacking to Iran of a Kuwaiti airliner said today that he did not know if there was any Iranian complicity in the incident. But he said the Teheran Government could dispel any notions of collusion by trying the four hijackers for slaying two other Americans on the craft.

title: INCONSISTENT GIANTS SHOWING PROGRESS
description: The Giants' final regular-season record of 9-7 seems just right. Anything less, such as 8-8, would not reflect the team's vast improvement. Anything more, such as 10-6 or 11-5, might create a false illusion.

title: REPORTER WAS WARNED TO STAY OUT OF POLITICS, SHARON JURY IS TOLD
description: Time magazine's chief of correspondents testified yesterday that he had once cautioned his Jerusalem correspondent to stay out of politics.

title: Kelly-Johnston
description: Kelly-Johnston Enterprises Inc., which recently reported a loss of $8.9 million for its second quarter ended Sept. 30, said independent accountants believe the company needs additional funds to survive. The company, which operates and franchises restaurants, said it was currently negotiating with one of its banks for additional capital and renewal of about $6.5 million of debt that came due last Saturday.

title: Market Place; A Strategy For Airlines
description: ''AIRLINE convertibles'' may sound like a contradiction in terms to an automobile buff. But Julius Maldutis, who tracks the airlines for Salomon Brothers, suggests that certain securities of these carriers that are convertible into common stocks are worthy of consideration by investors.

title: CRAFT HOUSE CASUALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in the financial year of a subsidiary.

title: REAGAN APPROVES 1986 ARMS BUILDUP
description: White House officials said today that President Reagan had given final approval to a military budget proposal that they described as a victory for the Pentagon.

title: Gunfight in Ulster
description: A police patrol killed a man suspected of being a guerrilla in the Irish National Liberation Army, a Marxist offshoot of the largely Roman Catholic Irish Republican Army, in a gun battle today after seven soldiers were wounded in a land-mine ambush near Armagh, the police reported.

title: To Cuba, With Justice A multitude of decent Cubans have paid for an indecent act by Fidel Castro in 1980. He opened his jails and dumped thousands of criminals into boats loaded with 127,000 Cubans fleeing his rule from the port of Mariel. Stuck with ''excludables'' ineligible for asylum, the United States retaliated by halting the lawful admission of Cubans, including some 3,000 political prisoners who had been promised American haven.
description: That door will be reopened now that Cuba has finally agreed to take back up to 2,700 excludables. When normal emigration resumes, about 20,000 Cubans may be able to qualify for the regular annual quota.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. has appointed Mark E. Oleksik vice president, controller and chief accounting officer, and Jayne D. Maas vice president and director of taxes.

title: NEWS REPORTS ON SHUTTLE ARE WITHHELD
description: SPOKESMEN for NBC News, The Associated Press and Aviation Week & Space Technology confirmed yesterday that the news organizations would honor requests from the Department of Defense that they not release information regarding the the nation's first classified manned space mission for reasons of national security.

title: British Plan Bank Review
description: The British Government today announced a full review of banking supervisory arrangements following the collapse of Johnson Matthey Bankers and its subsequent rescue by the Bank of England.

title: DESPITE RURAL CHINA'S GAINS, POVERTY GRIPS SOME REGIONS
description: chen Qingfan, a husky middle-aged farmer, sat in his whitewashed adobe house with a pounded earthen floor and recalled the years of poverty before the water came.

title: SCOUTING ; Point Scramble
description: As the Volvo Masters tennis tournament at Madison Square Garden approaches, John McEnroe, the defending champion, can shudder at the prospect of a second-round meeting with Henrik Sundstrom of Sweden, who upset the world's No. 1 player in the Davis Cup on Sunday. The lesser lights, however, have a more pressing concern: how to qualify for the final two spots in the January event, which allows room for only the 12 men who earned the most points on the 1984 Grand Prix circuit.

title: DOLPHINS WIN, 28-21, TO PUT GIANTS IN PLAYOFFS
description: A long weekend of wishful thinking and crossed fingers ended on a stunning note for the Giants tonight when the Miami Dolphins scored two touchdowns in the closing minutes to beat the Dallas Cowboys, 28-21, a victory that put the Giants in the playoffs.

title: Houston Men Convicted In Abduction at Tourney
description: Two Houston men were convicted today of kidnapping Edith Rosenkranz from a hotel during an international bridge tournament in July.

title: SOUTHEASTERN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: JAN PEERCE IS REMEMBERED BY HIS COLLEAGUES
description: Mourners overflowed the main chapel and crowded into anterooms, the balcony, the hallways. ''Jan always had full houses,'' said Martin Bookspan in a eulogy that was carried by public- address system to all who packed the Riverside Memorial Chapel on West 76th Street yesterday to remember Jan Peerce, the Metropolitan Opera tenor who died Saturday night at the age of 80.

title: U.S. CRITICISM OF CHILE ON HUMAN RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Edelman Group's Datapoint Stake
description: A group of investors, led by Asher B. Edelman, a New York investor, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its stake in the Datapoint Corporation to 1,953,800 common shares, or 9.8 percent of those outstanding, from 8.6 percent. The group said that between Dec. 11 and Dec. 13, it had purchased 322,900 shares.

title: UPHILL PUSH FOR 'MASTER TEACHERS'
description: -TROY HILLS, N.J.

title: BROKERS MAY ACT ON C.D. IMPASSE
description: The Securities Industry Association said yesterday that it might soon take legal steps to break an impasse that has developed over the sale of bank certificates of deposit on Wall Street. Since early November, major brokerage firms have reluctantly ceased buying hundreds of millions of dollars of large certificates of United States commercial banks and reissuing them in small denominations to retail customers for fear that Government insurance coverage might not apply.

title: DONORS TO NEEDIEST POINT TO TRADITIONS FORMED BY FAMILIES
description: For many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the annual tradition of giving began a generation ago with their parents or other loved ones. Today's donors often give in memory of those who, through their own compassion and generosity, taught them to help others less fortunate.

title: CONSERVATION CORPS WOULD HURT WORKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
AVANT-GARDE COMPUTING reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $48,000.

title: THE BRITISH ARE COMING
description: A RECENT survey by a British computer supplier reported that computer sales in Britain are highest in the world. While the claim strains the usual British understatement, there is no doubt that the country is mad about microcomputers. More than a million of them are expected to be sold there in 1985, and a large number of these will be made by Acorn Computers Ltd. of Cambridge, England.

title: Shearson Planning Jersey Complex
description: Shearson Lehman/American Express is considering building an office complex on a 16-acre platform in the Hudson River here, officials said today.

title: Calibrating Rewards for Poland Put aside for the moment the ugly news from Poland about police violence against Solidarity demonstrators and suspicions of Government complicity in the murder of an outspoken priest. The Reagan Administration is right to ease further United States sanctions against Poland and to end its opposition to Polish membership in the International Monetary Fund.
description: Sanctions sometimes must be invoked for moral purposes, without real hope of influencing conduct. But at other times they can in fact function as limited incentives.

title: Montagu-Cordura
description: An investment group led by Montagu Investment Management Ltd., a London-based investment adviser, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had acquired 6.2 percent of the common shares of the Cordura Corporation for investment.

title: Topics ; Wondering Eyes ; Star-Crossed
description: Something in the constellation of Ophiuchus has left earthbound astronomers in a prickly contretemps.

title: FAMINE IN ETHIOPIA: BARREN HILLS, EXHAUSTED PEOPLE; A LAND OF WANT
