description: The photographs on these pages wre taken in northen Ethiopia. The palces are called Karem and Bati and Harbu, where thousands of famine victims have flocked from the drought-stricken countryside to food distribution centers set up by relief workers.

title: CAMPUSES FEAR U.S. INTRUSION INTO RESEARCH
description: A report circulating at the nation's top research universities asserts that Federal agencies have greatly expanded their demands to review academic research before it is published.

title: DOCTORS SAY HEART PATIENT'S MEMORY IMPAIRED BY 3 STROKES
description: William J. Schroeder's doctors now believe that the artificial heart patient has suffered three strokes and some loss of memory. Mr. Schroeder is ''very slow to recognize'' members of his family and believes today is Friday, but he is aware that he is in a hospital, Dr. Gary Fox, a neurologist, said at a news conference. Dr. Allan M. Lansing, the chief medical spokesman for the Humana Hospital-Audubon implant team, said Mr. Schroeder ''looks completely normal,'' though he is not normal and ''looks better than he has at any time'' since he received the mechanical heart. He said the patient was more alert than he was Sunday. News that Mr. Schroeder had apparently suffered several strokes rather than just the one last Thursday, as originally thought, resulted from a series of new tests and Dr. Fox's review of old ones.

title: CHESS GAME ENDS IN DRAW
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov played to a draw today in the 33d game of their world chess championship match.

title: Talking Businesswith Laidig of Great Northern Nekoosa ; Timberlands' Value Slumps
description: In the early 1980's, timberlands were considered an excellent investment because it was thought that their value would always go up relative to inflation.

title: SKIN CARE FOR MEN SURGING
description: Many men may wince at the thought of smoothing on a skin moisturizer or under-eye cream, but cosmetics for men are enjoying a surge in sales.

title: BUELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
A SOVIET DESERTER IN AFGHANISTAN, LIVING IN U.S., WILL RETURN
description: A young Soviet soldier who defected in Afghanistan 18 months ago has decided to return to the Soviet Union from the United States. The State Department said today that it was satisfied he made the decision voluntarily.

title: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: SMALL STEPS IN ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM When Israel's national unity Government was formed after last summer's inconclusive elections, a cartoonist pictured it as a horse with a head at each end. One head was that of Shimon Peres of the Labor Alignment, the other Yitzhak Shamir of the Likud coalition. Between them were a lot of little riders shouting ''giddyap.''

title: 2 LEGISLATORS HAVE PRAISE FOR TAX PLAN
description: Two of New York's leading lawmakers got together yesterday to praise the bulk of the Federal Treasury Department's proposal to overhaul the tax system, while at the same time, in different ways, they tried to bury a key part of it.

title: INTERFERON SIDE EFFECT: LONG LASHES
description: THE natural antiviral substance interferon has been promoted for all manner of medical uses from treatment of cancer to cure of the common cold. It has also been blamed for adverse side effects of many kinds, including fever, fatigue, chills and abnormalities in the central nevous system.

title: TRANSACT INTERNATIONAL, DIVISION OF GRAM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $102,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: Joint Venture For McDonnell LONG BEACH, Calif., Dec.
description: 17 (Reuters) - The McDonnell

title: REAGAN CONFERS ON ARMS TALKS
description: President Reagan conferred with his senior advisers again today on what the United States position will be at Soviet-American talks next month on arms control, White House officials said.

title: Iraqi Planes Damage Another Cargo Ship
description: Iraq said its warplanes bombed another naval target in the Persian Gulf today. Marine shipping and salvage sources identified the ship as the Greek bulk carrier Aegis Cosmic.

title: FREE RIDES ON BUS AID PRISON VISITS
description: Four years after their last face-to-face meeting, Mary Brooks has seen her imprisoned son again, thanks to a new program providing free rides to state prisons aboard a battered yellow vehicle called ''The Love Bus.''

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; First Chicago Picks Leader of New Unit
description: The First Chicago Corporation, the parent of the First National Bank of Chicago, announced that George L. Davis, an executive vice president, would head a newly created Corporate Banking Department, consolidating formerly separate domestic and international commercial loan divisions.

title: MERCHANTS CO-OPERATIVE BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After nonrecurring charges of $410,000 for the quarter and $631,000 for the 6 months from merger expenses. c-Net loss. d-Including a nonrecurring gain of $7,369,000 on the sale of mortgage loans. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a pooling of interests due to the merger with Fort Hill Investors Management Co. in September.

title: Pioneer Considers Financial Choices
description: The Pioneer Corporation said yesterday that its directors had retained Kidder, Peabody & Company to begin looking for financial alternatives for the oil and gas exploration and production company, including a sale of part or all of its assets.

title: CITY SHOPPERS TURN OUT IN TWEEDS, FURS, JACKETS
description: As the days before Christmas dwindle, holiday shoppers in the 57th Street and Fifth Avenue area juggle their tote bags and packages. Some are reasonably serene as they huddle into fur coats, even though the weather has been reasonably mild, or wear short coats or toppers so as not to inhibit their movements.

title: POISON'S DISPOSAL IS HALF COMPLETED
description: More than half the deadly methyl isocyanate remaining at the Union Carbide plant here has been neutralized by Indian engineers and scientists since the plant began operating again Monday and a top official said the detoxification process should be completed by Wednesday.

title: Louisville Orchestra Votes to End Strike
description: The Louisville Orchestra - one of the country's most important ensembles for fostering new music - has voted to end a two-month-long strike that had threatened its existence. The strike, which began Oct. 8, forced the orchestra to cancel a number of performances and intensified its already difficult financial problems.

title: THE FRAILITIES OF PARTY TALK
description: PETER G. PETERSON, banker and a former Secretary of Commerce, thanked his hostess for ''a wonderful evening,'' collected his wife, Joan Ganz Cooney, and left a formal dinner party highly amused. ''I don't know where those people get their information,'' he said. ''Is it always like this?''

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a loss of $127,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You won't know the specific launch time until engines ignite.'' - Brig. Gen. Richard Abel. (C2:2.)

title: State of Emergency Is Extended in Chile
description: Chile's military Government extended a state of emergency for 90 days today.

title: WASHINGTON SCIENTIFIC CO reports earnings for 12 wks to Nov 18
description: Results for the latest first quarter reflect a provision for a possible loss associated with the Storage Technology Corp., which had filed for Chapter 11 protection.

title: CAROL VANESS: A SOPRANO ON THE RISE
description: Carol Vaness, the radiant Fiordiligi in the Metropolitan Opera's current ''Cos i Fan Tutte,'' continues to build her reputation on Mozart, but as the American soprano passes into her early 30's, she also is looking forward to bigger Italian roles. ''My spirit is with Verdi,'' she said the other day, and her technique may be closing in on him as well.

title: DONAHUE FINALLY MAKES THE MOVE
description: In Chicago, total strangers have accosted Marlo Thomas on the street, asking her not to take Phil Donahue away. In New York, on the other hand, a 1982 lecture by Mr. Donahue at the 2,700-seat Beacon Theater had to be canceled when only 250 tickets were sold.

title: 38 Babies' Deaths Linked to Solution
description: Doctors in at least four hospitals around the country have linked the deaths of 38 babies to intravenous feedings of E-Ferol Aqueous Solution, a new vitamin E preparation, The St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported Sunday.

title: ABOUT PHILADELPHIA: ALLEYS MUCH TREASURED FOR THEIR TINY HOUSES
description: Some of them, not surprisingly, still fit a shadowy-souled philosopher's view of human existence: They are solitary, poor, nasty, brutish and short, not to mention narrow.

title: Blues 3, Maple Leafs 2
description: Greg Paslawski scored the tying and winning goals to lift St. Louis to its first victory in seven games. Paslawski delivered the winner at 10:34 of the third period, when he skirted the Leaf defense and backhanded a shot that caught the left post and banked behind the goalie, Rick St. Croix.

title: Objections on Times Sq.
description: Under state law, yesterday was the

description: For many years Alfred L. Atherton Jr., a career diplomat,

description: b-Net income.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; First 'Junk' Bond Sold In Eurobond Market
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which acted as sole underwriter for the first foreign ''junk'' bond sold in the United States late last year, yesterday became the first underwriter of a less-than-investment-grade offering in the Eurobond market, traditionally the home for blue-chip issuers.

title: USE OF CAPACITY UP A BIT AFTER 3 MONTHLY DROPS
description: The operating rate at the nation's factories, mines and utilities edged up slightly in November, bolstered by a rebound in auto production, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Transactions
description: Put Howard Carter, guard, on waivers. COLLEGES OHIO UNIVERSITY - Named Cleve Bryant, an assistant with the New England Patriots for the last two years, as head football coach.

title: Helping Save Babies
description: That Roberto Maldonado could

title: E.E.C. Fines John Deere
description: The European Economic Community commission said today that it had fined John Deere & Company, the United States maker of farm machinery, $1.44 million for violating the Common Market's antitrust rules.

title: Marcos Sees Recovery
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos has predicted an ''economic turnaround'' next year, when the International Monetary Fund approves a $615 million loan to the Philippines, the Presidential Palace said today. Mr. Marcos said the anticipated $3 billion in foreign bank trade credits and $5.8 billion in foreign bank maturing loans following the I.M.F. action would help improve the 1985 economy by ''at least 1.5 percent.''

title: Group Names 'Passage' Best '84 Film
description: David Lean's ''Passage to India'' has been chosen the best film of 1984 by the National Board of Review, a private group that has been giving its film awards since 1920. The group named Mr. Lean best director and also voted awards to two of his film's stars - Victor Banerjee and Peggy Ashcroft, who were named best actor and best actress for ''A Passage to India.''

title: Weyerhaeuser Plans Charge Of $82 Million
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company, the forest products company based in Tacoma, Wash., said yesterday that it expected to have an $82 million pretax nonrecurring charge against earnings in the fourth quarter.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: WHEN last heard from, Billy Boy, a 23-year-old American fashion designer who collects Schiaparelli designs in his spare time, was heading off into the sunrise in the general direction of Paris. Last week, he returned to deposit his first collection of jewelry on the coffee table of Geraldine Stutz's office at Henri Bendel.

title: Delay of Execution Ordered
description: Justice Byron R. White today ordered Texas officials to wait before setting an execution date for John Michael Lamb to give the convicted murderer time to file an appeal with the United States Supreme Court. The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals upheld a jury's verdict of death in October and refused to issue a stay of execution while Mr. Lamb filed an appeal with the Supreme Court.

title: Super Rite Foods
description: Super Rite Foods Inc. said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Food-a-Rama Companies, a closely held operator of 48 supermarkets that is based in Baltimore.

title: West German Bankers Held
description: The three former managing partners of Schr"oder, M"unchmeyer, Hengst, the private bank that nearly collapsed last year because of excessive loans made to a failed construction machine group, have been detained by the police on suspicion of bankruptcy fraud, officials said today.

title: Christmas Is Coming, But the Thermometer Didn't Get the Hint
description: Calvin Coolidge was President and the first all-talking picture, ''The Lights of New York,'' had opened at the Strand when last it was warm enough to break a record on a Dec. 17. It happened again yesterday.

title: SEISCOM DELTA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Deduction for Taxes: The Issue Is Fairness
description: The Treasury proposal to simplify taxes would eliminate or sharply restrict most deductions, credits and exemptions in order to reduce personal tax rates to three brackets: 15 percent, 25 percent and 35 percent.

title: 3 Hurt by Grenade in Tel Aviv
description: Three people were wounded in a grenade attack near the main produce market here today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Dec. 10 about West German luxury cars misidentified G"unter Kramer.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.25-11.50 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HISPANIC FERTILITY IN U.S. FOUND ABOVE NORM
description: Fertility among Hispanic women in the United States is nearly 50 percent greater than among other Americans, and females of Mexican descent have the highest fertility rate, a Government study reported today.

title: 'HE'S FIRED, SHE'S HIRED,' CBS MOVIE
description: LABORING under the dreadful title of ''He's Fired, She's Hired,'' tonight's television movie on CBS at 9 uses a silly plot to fire off a scattering of satiric barbs. The targets include credit card survival in suburbia and chic hustling on Madison Avenue. Bob Shanks, the writer, knows the territory. His past credits include administration roles at ABC-TV in the making of ''Good Morning, America'' and the memorably disastrous debut of ''20/20.'' In this latest effort, his perhaps understandable cynicism unfortunately takes off in too many directions and is too often frittered away in one-line jokes.

title: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1984
description: Markets

title: 2 'LIVING IT UP' IN SAN FRANCISCO HELD IN KILLINGS
description: Two suspects in a bank robbery in which four people were shot dead were arrested today at a San Francisco hotel where they were ''living it up,'' the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: A CHANCE TO USE LEVERAGE ON IRAN
description: The confused events surrounding the hijacking of a Kuwaiti airliner to Teheran showed that while Iran continues its efforts to the spread of Islamic revolution and anti-Americanism in the Middle East, both its determination and chances of success are eroding.

title: HANDY DEVICE RE-INKS WORN-OUT PRINTER RIBBONS
description: A PERSONAL computer, like a child's electric train set of yore, is just the beginning. There are always countless useful little accessories to be added to the basic layout.

description: Corporation yesterday issued

title: IN MOSCOW, OPEN ARMS TO WAYWARD
description: For Turgenev, a Russian away from his homeland was like a slice cut off from the loaf.

title: INITIO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $800,000 for the quarter and 9 months from discontinued operations and an expense of $130,000 for the quarter for litigation. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $78,191 for the quarter and $139,130 for the 9 months.

title: ANTITRUST CHIEF WARY OF TRIPLE-PENALTY RULE
description: The Government's antitrust chief, J. Paul McGrath, believes the treble-damage penalty in private antitrust suits should be re-evaluated to determine whether it unfairly inhibits legal and efficient business conduct.

title: TOP-LEVEL PAPER URGES TOUGH STANCE ON JAPAN
description: A working paper prepared for a Cabinet- level meeting forecasts further deterioration in the United States trade position with Japan next year and says that Japan must ''rectify the situation before we make it equal by taking negative action.''

title: Grubb & Ellis Names 6 Regional Presidents
description: The Grubb & Ellis Company, the largest publicly held independent real estate services company in the nation, yesterday announced a major reorganization, naming six regional presidents.

title: Unbeaten Duke Routs Davidson, 82-65
description: Jay Bilas scored 10 points in the first five minutes of the second half tonight as sluggish Duke scored an 82-65 basketball victory over Davidson.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Boston Celtics , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. In their only earlier meeting with the defending champions this season, the Knicks held a 6-point lead in the third quarter before succumbing to a 115-99 Boston rout that featured 29 points by Larry Bird and 25 by Kevin McHale.

title: HURCO MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
RUSSIAN DENOUNCES SPACE WEAPONS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev today told Sir Geoffrey Howe, the British Foreign Secretary, that the Soviet leadership considers it ''especially important to avert the transfer of the arms race to outer space.''

title: Greece May Shift Troops To Face the Turks
description: Greece said today that it might transfer part of its armed forces away from its northern border with Communist nations to confront Turkey, a NATO ally with whom it has historically been at odds.

title: 30 YEARS OF SHOES BY VIVIER
description: Fashion may or may not be art, but shoes are architecture, according to Christian Duvernois, director of the Fa,cade Gallery. So the gallery, which specializes in architecture and painting, is exhibiting three decades of shoes by Roger Vivier of Paris.

title: BHOPAL'S DOCTORS GIVEN HIGH PRAISE
description: In the fateful early morning hours of Dec. 3, as clouds of toxic gas began to escape from the Union Carbide pesticide plant here, the medical community of Bho pal faced an emergency of staggering proportions.

title: ABUNDANCE OF ADVISERS IN BATTLE TO BUY CONRAIL
description: The major parties in the battle to buy the Government's 85 percent stake in the Consolidated Rail Corporation will bring their campaigns here to the railroad's non-management directors on Tuesday.

title: HE-MAN, A PRINCELY HERO, CONQUERS THE TOY MARKET
description: At the toy department of Macy's one day last week, a dozen anxious parents became upset and some berated the clerks when 6-inch plastic dolls known as He-Man were put on the shelves and quickly recalled because they had been priced incorrectly.

title: INMAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-After losses from operations of units to be discontinued of $319,790 for the quarter and $698,221 for the 9 months and an estimated loss on the disposal of assets of units to be discontinued of $541,941 for the quarter and 9 months. c-After losses from operations of units to be discontinued of $150,531 for the quarter and $282,041 for the 9 months.

title: Bridge:A Game Can Help to Build Bridges at the Great Wall
description: Bridge is not a requirement for business and investment executives traveling to China nowadays but it is an asset: It is always possible that Deng Xiaoping or some other Chinese leaders will invite them to take part in a social game.

title: PIERCE, S.S. CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
People
description: * Rod W. Underhill promoted to executive vice president of Tracy-Locke, Dallas.

title: AUTO FRAUD 'STING' TRAPS 122 IN CITY
description: A banker, a restaurant owner, a police officer and other ''ordinary citizens'' were among 122 people in New York City accused yesterday of automobile insurance fraud in a six-month ''sting'' operation.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ALBERT SPEER. The End of a Myth. By Matthias Schmidt. Translated From the German by Joachim Neugroschel. 276 pages. Document Illustrations. St. Martin's Press. $14.95.

title: ETHIOPIAN MEETS WITH CHERNENKO IN MOSCOW
description: The leader of Ethiopia, in Moscow on an unannounced visit, met today with Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, apparently to discuss Soviet assistance for its drought-stricken African ally.

title: AN ARCHIVE PUTS FACES ON NAZIS' YOUNG VICTIMS
description: It was just over 40 years ago, on the brilliant spring morning of April 6, 1944, that two trucks and two cars belonging to the Gestapo in Nazi-occupied France arrived unexpectedly at a children's home in the mountain village of Izieu, a few miles east of Lyons.

title: SPEED-LIMIT REPORT CAUTIOUS ON CHANGE
description: To the Editor:

title: PROLER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Publisher Is Appointed For Elle's U.S. Edition
description: -year-old ad director of Conde Nast's Glamour magazine, has been named publisher of the American version of Elle magazine, the English-language rendition of the French favorite that is scheduled to begin monthly publications here next September.

title: PAYING BHOPAL VICTIMS
description: The rush of American lawyers who descended on Bhopal last week was both insulting and inappropriate. The accident at the Union Carbide insecticide plant was a tragedy. There's a danger, however, that a further tragedy will be worked unless more thought goes into the effort to compensate the victims and their families.

title: CHEEZEM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: ONE THING IS CERTAIN ABOUT TAXES: DISAGREEMENT
description: The very first law adopted by the very first Congress in 1789 prescribed the oath of office to be taken by Government officials. The second law was a tax law that, among other provisions, placed a tariff of 10 cents a gallon on imported rum. Its purpose was not to discourage the citizens of the new country from drinking the demon rum. Rather, it was to give a competitive edge to Americans who made corn whisky.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Champion International Corp., a wood and paper products concern based in Stamford, Conn., said it had sold its Associated Weavers Europe Belgian Carpet Producing unit to a group of Belgian investors for $6.4 million in cash and $1.6 million in notes.

title: PRISON TERM CUT IN FATHER'S DEATH
description: Gov. Ed Herschler today commuted the prison sentence of a teen-ager found guilty of helping her brother kill their abusive father, only a week after the state's highest court upheld her conviction.

title: MILITARY MISSION OF SPACE SHUTTLE TO BE KEPT SECRET
description: Extraordinary measures will be taken to protect the secrecy of the next space shuttle mission, scheduled for launching Jan. 23, the Defense Department announced yesterday. The shuttle flight will be the first devoted exclusively to military operations.

title: ARA Buyout Set
description: ARA Services Inc. said shareholders had overwhelmingly approved the leveraged buyout of the $3 billion international food, health care and transportation concern by a group of management-led investors.

title: MusicNoted in Brief; Orpheus Plays Music By Mozart and Dvorak
description: With 16 strings and 10 wind players from which to draw, Orpheus enjoys its pick of the chamber repertory. Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall, most of its string players stayed home, leaving a dozen of the group's winds to play music by Mozart, Enesco, Dvorak and Bruce Adolphe.

title: BID TO FIND A BLACK CANDIDATE TO OPPOSE KOCH ABANDONED
description: Leaders of the black Democratic coalition agreed yesterday that they would not advance a black candidate for mayor and instead would begin talks with labor and liberal Democrats to try to find an opponent for Mayor Koch.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Dec. 18, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Emergency Exit
description: A tired but relieved East Tennessee State University basketball team arrived home by bus last night to champagne and balloons honoring their narrow escape from a fiery crash landing in Alabama. ''We're celebrating New Year's tonight,'' said Tammy Lowry, wife of Vincent Lowry, an assistant coach, who was unhurt when the plane crashed Sunday near Jasper, Ala., and injured 12 players.

title: SPAN-AMERICA MEDICAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Advertising; Creative Troika At W.R.G.
description: speaking world, Wells, Rich, Greene has selected a Briton as its third creative director.

title: DR. HOWARD W. POTTER
description: Dr. Howard W. Potter, former chairman of the psychiatry department and dean of the medical school at the Downstate Medical Center of the State University of New York, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in Fredonia, N.Y. He was 92 years old.

title: TEMCO SERVICE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $3,906,000 for the quarter and $16,956,000 for the year.

title: Sheila Schonbrun At Merkin Concert Hall
description: New York concertgoers are used to hearing Sheila Schonbrun sing music that is either very old or very new. But Saturday night at Merkin Concert Hall, Miss Schonbrun explored the historical middle of the soprano repertory.

title: CRITICS OF BASAL READERS SAY LOOK AT MCGUFFEY
description: -ROOTS rebellion is slowly growing against the use of dull books to teach children to read. Educators still debate whether the so-called ''basal readers,'' with their carefully controlled vocabularies, should be replaced with real books.

title: COMPANIES SHARED OIL-PRICING DATA, DOCUMENTS SHOW
description: Several large oil companies operating on the West Coast routinely exchanged confidential pricing data from the late 1950's to the early 1970's, according to thousands of pages of industry documents made public today by a Federal judge.

title: Gillespie Agency Starts Division for Magazines
description: Gillespie Advertising in Princeton, N.J., has taken a number of its publishing clients and formed a new division called the Magazine Marketing Group.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IN this era of heroic therapies for

title: TRAK AUTO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FILM: FARMERS' PLIGHT IN 'THE RIVER'
description: ''THE RIVER,'' which has absolutely nothing to do with Jean Renoir's 1951 classic set in India, is about Tom and Mae Garvey (Mel Gibson and Sissy Spacek), their two children and their attempts to hang on to their farm in spite of mounting bank debts, big business interests and, of course, the river.

title: No Headline
description: How the Trade and Budget Deficits Have Soared

title: WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
'No One Was Following Orders'
description: By their splendid, immediate response, the doctors of Bhopal very likely prevented the poison gas disaster of Dec. 3 from causing thousands more deaths and permanent injuries. As Philip Boffey reported in The Times the other day, their performance reflected the quality of the city's medical system and state medical school hospital.

title: GORBACHEV VOWS SOVIET READINESS FOR BIG ARMS CUT
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev told members of Parliament today that his nation was ready to negotiate radical reductions in nuclear arms, but he repeated Moscow's position that the United States had to act first.

title: Gregorio Prestopino, 77;Painter of Different Styles
description: Gregorio Prestopino, a painter whose style ranged from social realism to impressionist landscapes filled with nudes, died Sunday at the Princeton Medical Center of cancer. He was 77 years old, and lived in Roosevelt, N.J., his home of 35 years.

title: FEDERAL WORKERS TERMED OVERPAID
description: A Government study, released as a defense of a proposal to cut the pay of Federal workers by 5 percent, has concluded that Federal employees are overpaid.

title: Iraq Reports New Air Strike Against Ship in Persian Gulf
description: Iraq said its planes hit another merchant ship in the Persian Gulf today, and it vowed to turn a war zone around the Iranian oil terminal at Kharg Island into ''a graveyard'' for any vessels entering the area.

title: Letter: On the U.N. 'Let's Remain in Unesco'
description: To the Editor:

title: DUNKIN' DONUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
CURRENCY MARKETS ; Gold's Fall Accelerates; Price Off $4.90 in U.S.
description: Gold prices tumbled again yesterday in hectic trading, accelerating a month-old trend and pushing prices to their lowest levels in two and a half years.

title: PROVIGO INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Nov 3
Life Sets Trade Ad Campaign
description: In the Time Inc. organziation, Time may be the weekly news magazine, Money America's financial adviser, Fortune for members of the business class and Sports Illustrated just what it says it is, but what is Life?

title: SKYLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including a gain of $175,000 on the sale of an idle plant.

title: 31 STATES GAIN IN TESTS
description: In the last two years high school students improved their scores on college entrance tests in 31 states and the District of Columbia, while declines were recorded in 10 states, the Department of Education reported today.

title: HOME BUILDING DOWN, BUT PERMITS INCREASE
description: New-home construction fell seven- tenths of 1 percent in November to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.53 million units, the lowest level since December 1982, the Commerce Department reported today. But, in a hint of better days ahead, applications for building permits rose for the first time in five months.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY GORBACHEV
description: Following are excerpts from a speech today by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, a key member of the Soviet Politburo, to the House of Commons Select Committee on Foreign Affairs, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: 4 Klansmen Sentenced In Beating Incidents
description: A Federal judge today sentenced four Ku Klux Klansmen in connection with two beating incidents.

title: Good News for Horner
description: Bob Horner , the Atlanta Braves' slugging third baseman, underwent surgery in Dallas to repair the slow- healing fracture of his right wrist, and afterward his surgeon told club officials that he expected Horner to be swinging a bat within three months. According to a team spokesman, the surgeon, Dr. Peter Carter , said the results of the operation ''couldn't have been better.''

title: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 19, 1984
description: Markets

title: PRICE WATERHOUSE TALKS WITH DELOITTE ENDED
description: Price Waterhouse and Deloitte Haskins & Sells terminated merger negotiations yesterday aimed at creating the world's largest accounting firm after partners in Britain reportedly voted down the proposal.

title: OFFICE BUILDERS IN JERSEY ARE LOCATING NEAR MALLS
description: Lunch in the burgeoning corporate suburbs can often bring the workday's most trying moments. Isolated in sprawling new buildings surrounded by nothing but grass, trees and highways, many office workers search for something to do during their lunch periods. To travel to eat, and perhaps shop, means traffic and a hunt for a parking space. Staying in the building means the cafeteria again.

title: LANGER BIOMECHANICS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: UNIVERSITY PATENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TREASURY HELATH PLAN BLAMES THE VICTIM
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER: 'KING STAG'
description: BOSTON ANDREI SERBAN has opened the season at the American Repertory Theater with a vivid production of Carlo Gozzi's Orientalized fairy tale, ''The King Stag.'' Filled with the marvelous costumes, masks and puppetry of Julie Taymor, this 18th-century charade should appeal to the fanciful at heart as well as the young in age.

title: CURTAINS FOR OLD RED
description: I'm saying in three, four, five years

title: Trustee Bank Sale in Britain LONDON, Dec. 18 - The
description: British Government announced

title: BERRAS ARE HOPING THEY'LL JOIN FORCES
description: The Berras, Yogi and Dale, were talking recently about the pending trade between the Yankees and the Pittsburgh Pirates that would unite the two on a baseball team for the first time.

title: Charity Rents Animals Out for Commercials
description: Because charitable organizations are always in need of funds and since commercials frequently need animals in their casts, Green Chimneys, a treatment center for troubled children that is also a working farm, has gone into the rent-a-pig business.

title: PRINCETON IN LAST-MINUTE LOSS
description: Anthony Robinson, a freshman center, scored 14 points, including Bowling Green's first go-ahead points with a minute left, as the Falcons edged Princeton tonight, 60-59.

title: DWG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,049,000 for the quarter and 6 months from discontinued operations. c-Including a tax credit of $934,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Former Georgia Official Gets 30-Month Sentence
description: A former Georgia Labor Commissioner was sentenced today to 30 months in Federal prison for mail and insurance fraud.

title: W. 114th St. Provides Its Own Light and Cheer
description: The children of 114th Street still talk about the beautiful Christmas tree on the block two years ago.

title: Sweet Pact for Toney
description: The Philadelphia 76ers, who like to stay out of the free-agent market and fish for talent in their home pool, have signed the sharp-shooting guard Andrew Toney to a contract that will reportedly bring him $6 million over seven years, starting next season. General Manager Pat Williams declined to disclose terms of the contract but said he was glad to have re- signed the 27-year-old Toney, only months before he could have become a free agent. Toney, the team's chief outside shooting threat, is in the final season of a five-year contract that pays him about $200,000 annually.

title: STOCKS AND BONDS SURGE ON DECLINES IN INTEREST RATES
description: Spurred by visions of lower interest rates and faster economic growth, the stock and bond markets surged yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average soared 34.78 points, its biggest gain since Aug. 3, while interest rates continued to plummet and bond prices rose.

title: STORES REOPEN IN INDIAN CITY AS POISON DISPOSAL PROCEEDS
description: The stores and markets of this city began reopening today as residents returned to work and started shopping in greater numbers. Vendors pushed carts filled with fruits and vegetables, and restaurants, cigarette kiosks and even a few barber shops opened for business.

title: Panel to Study Eagle Aid Ways to help Leonard Tose find refinancing for the Philadelphia
description: Eagles will be taken up by a committee of other owners in the National

title: South Korea to Limit Steel Exports to U.S.
description: South Korea today became the last of the major suppliers of steel to the United States to conclude an export restraint arrangement, apparently assuring the achievement of President Reagan's plan to limit steel imports so that they account for less than 20 percent of domestic consumption.

title: ENZO BIOCHEM, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Leader Federal
description: The Leader Federal Savings and Loan Association of Memphis said yesterday that one day this week it would offer $100 million worth of six-year notes that are secured by pledged securities. The notes, which mature on Dec. 15, 1991, carry a one- time put on Dec. 15, 1988. Goldman, Sachs & Company is acting as lead underwriter.

title: Driver Shot Dead By Officer in Bronx
description: A police officer shot and killed a man in the Bronx Monday night when the officer's gun accidentally discharged, the police said.

title: TRADING IS 6TH HEAVIEST
description: The stock market, after weeks of steady declines, exploded upward yesterday in the sixth-heaviest trading ever, fueled by a sharp drop in interest rates.

title: LD BRINKMAN CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $284,000 from discontinued operations. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $224,000.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Goat's-Milk Yogurt

title: CONVERSION RULES ARE BLAMED FOR APARTMENT 'WAREHOUSING'
description: Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan said yesterday that the soaring purchase prices of cooperatives and condominiums and the rules governing conversions had led to the unreported ''warehousing'' of rental apartments and the harassment of tenants in buildings where conversion plans have been filed.

title: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
United Way Sees Threat In Reagan's Tax Plan
description: Contributors have given an estimated $2.1 billion to the United Way in 1984, a 10 percent increase over last year, but its chairman says the Reagan Administration's tax proposal could cut contributions by 20 percent.

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 19, 1984 International Mikhail S. Gorbachev told the British that the Soviet Union was ready to negotiate radical reductions in nuclear armaments, but he repeated Moscow's position that Washington had to act first. Addressing a committee of Parliament, the Kremlin's second in command put particular stress on the Soviet desire for an end to American efforts to develop weapons in space. (Page A1, Column 3.) A major Soviet military reaction was touched off several days ago by two American aircraft carriers operating near Soviet naval and air bases around Vladivostok, Reagan Administration officials confirmed. They said the unusual Soviet reaction involved at least 100 Soviet jet fighters, bombers and reconnaissance planes as well as surface vessels. A civilian official quoted experienced military officials as describing it as ''the most vigorous Soviet reaction'' to any American military movement of its kind since World War II. (A1:2.)

title: A WARM TOUCH OF GLITTER
description: THE voltage generated by myriad sequins, metallic embroideries and beads on fashions worn during this holiday season may not be surpassed.

title: NIXONS' GIFT FOR NEEDIEST CITES A FRIEND
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon and his wife, Pat, have donated $1,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in memory of Helen Clay Frick, art archivist and daughter of Henry Clay Frick, who established the Frick Museum and the Frick Collection on Fifth Avenue. Miss Frick died last month at the age of 96.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1.*Unicef Cards

description: VICTOR HUGO AND THE VISIONARY

title: CAMBODIA RETURNS FROM POL POT TERRORS
description: To the Editor:

title: 'BUZZ WORDS' BY THE NUMBERS
description: Donald G. Groves, a staff scientist with the National Materials Advisory Board, has devised a foolproof system for those wishing to appear more learned than they are.

title: HUNDREDS FLEE LEAK OF AMMONIA FUMES AT A CITY IN MEXICO
description: Hundreds of residents near the border city of Matamoros were evacuated Monday night when a ruptured hose at a fertilizer company spewed ammonia fumes into the air, police officials reported today. Two people were seriously injured.

title: Officer Slain With Own Gun
description: A police officer stopped a man for not paying a restaurant bill today and was shot to death, apparently with his own gun, the police said.

title: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT was three days before Christmas last year

title: Guards Lose Suit On L.I. Prison
description: The Court of Appeals, New York's highest court, today rejected a claim by correction officers that closing the Long Island Correctional Facility would make their work more hazardous.

title: Grayer Than Acid Rain
description: From blue skies fell a brief shower that splattered dozens of passers- by, some vehicles and the entire intersection of Broadway and 45th Street yesterday.

title: Lawrence Schacht, Ex-Head Of Steel Concern and Charity
description: Lawrence Schacht, former president and chairman of Schacht Steel Construction Inc., of Hillside, N.J., died Sunday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. He was 79 years old and lived in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Rangers Eye Trades
description: News-agency articles from Toronto yesterday speculated that Craig Patrick's presence there Monday meant an impending Rangers-Leafs deal. ''I'm pursuing trades at my normal pace,'' said Patrick, the Rangers' general manager, who also denied an earlier rumor that had the Ranger captain, Barry Beck , headed to Toronto for Rick Vaive, the high-scoring wing.

title: Poland Says It Wants Better Ties With U.S.
description: The Polish Government said today that it was interested in improving relations with the United States and that the Reagan Administration's decision to end its opposition to Poland's membership in the International Monetary Fund was ''a step in the right direction.''

title: Last-Minute Emergency At City Hall Park
description: ''The question is will we have lights for Christmas?'' asked Lieut.

title: U.S. SHIPS MET BY SOVIET ALERT OFF MAJOR BASE
description: Two American aircraft carriers operating near Soviet bases around Vladivostok touched off a major Soviet military reaction several days ago, raising concern in the Japanese Government, Administration officials said today.

title: U.S. LONE DISSENTER IN U.N. VOTE ON LISTING OF RESTRICTED PRODUCTS
description: Over the sole objection of the United States, the United Nations General Assembly voted today to continue to publish and to expand a directory listing 500 potentially dangerous products that are banned, restricted or have failed to win approval in any one of 60 countries.

title: DR. HOWARD W. POTTER
description: Dr. Howard W. Potter, former chairman of the psychiatry department and dean of the medical school at the Downstate Medical Center of the State University of New York, died of heart failure Monday at his home in Fredonia, N.Y. He was 92 years old.

title: KEAN SIGNS BILL INTENDED TO GET BASEBALL TEAM
description: Governor Kean today signed into law a bill designed to enable the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority to bring a major league baseball team to the state.

title: RULING ALLOWS NATIVITY SCENE IN CENTRAL PARK
description: A ruling by the city's Corporation Counsel has cleared the way for the display of the first Christmas scene in Central Park since the 1920's, city officials said yesterday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: STAGE AND SCREEN Almost from the time the movie camera started grinding out fare for the millions, it has drawn from the great plays of the stage (as time has gone on, the situation has occasionally reversed itself, too). The role of theater as a seedbed for films is the theme of the exhibition now at the midtown Theater Museum of the Museum of the City of New York, in the Minskoff Theater Arcade at 1515 Broadway, between 44th and 44th Streets near Shubert Alley (944-7161).

title: The Dolphins Make Their Mark
description: Text not available

title: GREYLORD JUDGE GETS 15 YEARS
description: A former Cook County judge was sentenced today to 15 years in prison for accepting bribes, a crime that the sentencing judge described as ''despicable.''

title: SHUTTLE CAN'T BE KEPT FULLY SECRET BUT OFFICIALS SAY IT'S WORTH EFFORT
description: Defense Department officials acknowledged today that little information about space shuttles with military cargo could be kept from the Russians, even if secrecy is imposed. But the officials, explaining a policy announced Monday, said such secrecy was worth the effort.

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 10.75-11.50 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FIGHT SEEN ON PLAN BY SHULTZ TO DROP POLITICAL APPOINTEES
description: White House and State Department officials are locked in a dispute over plans by Secretary of State George P. Shultz to replace ranking officials and diplomats who are political appointees with Foreign Service officers, according to Administration officials.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Washington Bullets , at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. The powerful Ruland-Ballard-Mahorn front line comes into the Meadowlands for the second game of a home-and-home series.

title: HRT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Including gains of $5,036,000 for the quarter and $4,445,000 for the 9 months on the disposal of businesses. c-Net loss. d-After a loss of $5.5 million for the quarter and 9 months on the disposal of businesses.

title: Escapee Gives Up; 2 Are Still Sought
description: A third inmate among five who had escaped from the Niantic prison for women on Saturday surrendered here today, while two other inmates were still at large.

title: NEW YORK FILM CRITICS VOTE 'PASSAGE TO INDIA' BEST FILM
description: The New York Film Critics Circle yesterday voted its 50th annual best- film award to ''A Passage to India,'' David Lean's sweeping adaptation of E. M. Forster's novel. Mr. Lean was voted best director, and Peggy Ashcroft, who plays the dowager Mrs. Moore in the film, was voted best actress. Although the group seldom cites comedy performances in the best-acting categories, it named Steve Martin best actor for ''All of Me.''

title: SEMICONDUCTOR OPINION MIXED
description: WHEN it comes to market volatility, it is hard to top semiconductor stocks. This group enjoyed a spectacular run from early 1982 to early 1984. Then the stocks of major chip makers suddenly weakened in January and later recouped much of their losses, only to sink lower through July.

title: CNN RAISING ITS IDENTITY QUOTIENT
description: In an era when Dan Rather, Tom Brokaw and Peter Jennings are accorded superstar status as network news anchors, the philosopy of Cable News Network, the round-the-clock news service, has seemed quaintly anomalous. Since the channel was founded four years ago by Ted Turner, the Atlanta entrepreneur, CNN has emphasized that the news, not the anchor, is the star.

title: EDWARD S. DAVIS
description: Edward S. Davis, retired chairman of the New York City printing concern Davis-Delaney-Arrow Inc., died of leukemia Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan and Boothbay Harbor, Me.

title: HOUSE PANEL DROPS SUBPOENA OF A REPORTER
description: The House ethics committee today dropped its attempt to question a reporter to learn the source of articles about its deliberations on Geraldine A. Ferraro's financial disclosures.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: SCREEN: 'BREAKIN' 2'
description: THE kids in ''Breakin' 2: Electric Boogaloo'' like break- dancing so much that they prefer it to drug-taking and larceny. This, they argue, is the reason a community center called Miracles, which they have covered with blinding graffiti, should not be razed to make way for a mall. One kindly adult in the area understands the kids and their need to dance; the others are steadfastly in favor of the shopping center. And there you have it: A plot no teen-movie enthusiast could fail to recognize. Be it break-dancing or drag-racing or surfing, some things never change.

title: Ex-Im Bank in Budget-Cut Fight
description: The chairman of the Export-Import Bank said today that he was fighting White House budget-cutters to retain some direct lending authority for his agency and forecast that even if the Administration tried to eliminate the program Congress might restore it.

title: Cosmos Defeated By Americans, 4-2
description: Julie Veee scored three goals to lead the Las Vegas Americans to a 4-2 Major Indoor Soccer League victory over the Cosmos tonight.

title: Greece Eases Stand On Enlarging Market
description: Greece lifted its objections today to European Economic Community terms of entry for Spain and Portugal, clearing the way for final negotiations.

title: Behind-the-Wheel Analyst
description: The cabdriver weaved and swerved through traffic, trying to avoid cars running lights and pedestrians playing chicken with his fenders. ''New York is the world's biggest hospital,'' he noted. ''Everyone here is sick.''

title: Armco President Adds Chief Executive's Title
description: Armco Inc., a producer of carbon and specialty steel products, has elected its president, Robert E. Boni, to the additional post of chief executive officer. Mr. Boni, 56, succeeds Harry Holiday, who continues as chairman.

title: Northeastern
description: Northeastern International Airways said it had laid off about 300 workers after a judge stopped the airline from renting five planes from Braniff Inc. Northeastern said the laid-off employees included pilots, flight attendants, mechanics and ticket agents. The layoffs reduced the airline's work force to 747, from a high of 1,444 in August, said a Northeastern spokesman, Wally Knief.

title: American Express Credit's Notes
description: The American Express Credit Corporation offered $100 million worth of five-year notes.

title: Brown Disc Sale
description: Brown Disc Manufacturing said it had signed an agreement to sell virtually all of its stock outstanding to a subsidiary of Rh^one- Poulenc S.A. of Paris.

title: WELL-STOCKED BUTCHER SHOPS
description: MANY butcher shops in New York City carry game during the holiday season. What follows is a selection of those that will have game on hand on a regular basis. The items are fresh unless otherwise indicated. Since some are not necessarily available every day, it is advisable to order three days in advance.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Alaska Housing Issue Worth $302.5 Million
description: For the second time in less than a month, the Alaska Housing Finance Corporation has tapped the municipal bond market for long-term financing.

title: GUIDELINES ISSUED ON SILENT PRAYERS
description: An amendment to the State Constitution providing public school students 20 to 60 seconds daily for ''contemplation, meditation or prayer'' was certified Monday by A. James Manchin, the West Virginia Secretary of State.

title: MUSIC: BACHIAN PRELUDES
description: OF the 33 newly discovered chorale preludes attributed to J. S. Bach, one is described by the finder, Christoph Wolff, as ''an extraordinary setting'' of the chorale and ''perhaps the most striking'' of the group. Based on ''Jesu, meine Freude,'' a well-known chorale on which Bach composed a motet in 1723, this prelude is in the key of D minor and consists of 18 measures of music.

title: Percy and New Delhi
description: Senator Charles H. Percy of Illinois has told friends that he will

title: Canada Hails Cyprus Talks
description: Canada, which has had peacekeeping forces in Cyprus for 20 years, urged Cypriot leaders today to make a success of their first high-level talks in five years. External Affairs Minister Joe Clark said Canada had ''learned with great satisfaction of the announcement by U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar that the leaders of the two Cypriot communities have agreed to meet in January.''

title: BURN'S VIEW OF EUROPEANS
description: ARTHUR F. BURNS, the distinguished economist who serves as President Reagan's Ambassador to West Germany, was back in Washington this week for consultations. Mr. Burns, who is 80 years old, is reportedly thinking of retiring after the Bonn economic summit meeting in May.

title: South Korean Dissident Repeats Vow to Return
description: Kim Dae Jung, the South Korean opposition leader, said today that he would return home around the end of January despite a renewed warning from the Government that he will be imprisoned on his arrival.

title: Reagan With Eyes Closed
description: Robert Orben, the comedy writer who once worked on the White House staff of President Ford, has capsulized the political history of the year now closing. ''1984,'' he says, ''was the year they said Ronald Reagan could beat Walter Mondale with his eyes closed - and did.''

title: OFFICIAL EXPLAINS GAFFE ON VACCINE SHORTAGE
description: A senior Federal health official said today that the Government had overstated the severity of a shortage in whooping cough vaccine when it said supplies could be tight through next year.

title: CBS PRODUCER SAYS GENERAL PLAYED 'SHELL GAME'
description: George Crile, the producer of a disputed CBS documentary on the Vietnam War, yesterday described the calculation of enemy strength by Gen. William C. Westmoreland's command in 1967 as ''akin to an intelligence atrocity.''

title: A CUP OF KINDNESS FOR HOLIDAY DRIVES
description: A national commission held a more or less typical reception the other day. There were invitations from the White House. The Reagan Administration provided an ornate setting, the Indian Treaty Room of the Old Executive Office Building, whose arched windows overlook the West Wing of the White House next door.

title: KNICKS BEATEN IN A RUNAWAY
description: The Knicks' only consistent offensive weapon, exclusive of Bernard King's postup game, is outside shooting. When that shooting fails, their chances for victory become slim.

title: Woman, 24, Fatally Stabbed; Apartment Neighbor Is Held
description: A 24-year-old Brooklyn woman was stabbed to death and thrown out of a window after being lured to a neighbor's apartment to discuss a babysitting job, the police said.

description: After weeks of careful diplomatic planning to clear his schedule for Super Bowl Sunday, Secretary of State George P. Shultz is going to have to miss attending the professional football championship after all.

title: OSTRICHES? ARABIAN HORSES? IT MUST BE A KIBBUTZ
description: There was a time not long ago when the word kibbutz was synonymous with farming. Eventually, though, farming gave way to industry, and lately industry has given way to, well, ''imagination.''

title: 10 'STAR WARS' CONTRACTS LET
description: The Defense Department announced Monday that it had awarded its first 10 ''study contracts'' as part of President Reagan's plan for a space-based antimissile system.

title: Beecham to Buy Cosmetic Units
description: Beecham Group P.L.C., a holding company with pharmaceutical, food and cosmetics interests, said it would acquire the cosmetics units of B.A.T Industries P.L.C. for about $:125 million, or about $105 million.

title: FOUNDER OF PHOTO COMPANY
description: Benjamin Berkey, who founded Berkey Photo Inc. and made it second only to the Eastman Kodak Company in the photofinishing industry, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 73 years old.

title: AEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 23
description: b-Including tax credits of $524,000 for the quarter and $2,160,000 for the 9 months. c-Including a gain of $34,950,000 on the sale of discontinued operations.

title: JOSEPH S. STRAUSS
description: Joseph S. Strauss, a New York City attorney specializing in corporate law, died Saturday at his home after a long illness. He was 49 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: ETHIOPIAN PROJECT APPROVED BY U.N.
description: The General Assembly, on the final day of a session dominated by famine in Africa, approved $73.5 million today for a new conference center in Addis Ababa, the Ethiopian capital.

description: b-Including tax credits of $410,000 for the quarter and $590,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $200,000 for the quarter and $347,000 for the 6 months.

title: Finks Leaves Cubs
description: Jim Finks , a longtime football executive who took over as president and chief executive officer of the Chicago Cubs a year ago, has abruptly resigned to pursue what is described as other interests, and General Manager Dallas Green has been named to take his place. The announcement by the club's owner, the Tribune Company, did not say what Finks's plans were, and he was not commenting yesterday. But there was speculation that he might be returning to the National Football League, where he had been general manager of the Minnesota Vikings and the Chicago Bears before joining the Cubs.

title: PANEL ON NOMINATION OF JUDGES IS CRITICIZED
description: A State Senator said yesterday that he would try to change the way in which judges for the state's highest court are nominated.

title: Financial Corp. In Stock Sale Loss
description: The Financial Corporation of America said today that it had sold its stock in Walt Disney Productions back to Disney at a loss of $6.27 million.

title: Ethics Act Conviction Is Appealed by Hansen
description: Congress did not intend to have House and Senate members prosecuted on criminal charges for violations of the 1978 Ethics in Government Act, an attorney for Representative George V. Hansen, Republican of Idaho, told an appeals court today.

Hodes, a partner and co-chairman of the New York law firm of Willkie Farr & Gallagher. Justice of the Peace Marcelle Sherwood performed the ceremony at the Town Hall in Greenwich, Conn.

title: 4 Samaritans in Concert
description: Four Samaritans, members of a small and ancient sect, have arrived in New York from Israel to participate in a concert at 8 P.M. tomorrow at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. The four will sing the unique liturgical music of their people - only 500 of whom still exist, mostly in the city of Nablus - who are considered to be descendants of the ancient Israelites although their religion diverged from Judaism 2,000 years ago. The program, ''Folk Music and 20th- Century Composers,'' is one of the ''Israel Music Spectrum'' series, and a wide range of selections will also be performed by other instrumentalists and singers.

title: Jews Are Celebrating Festival of Hanukkah
description: The Jewish festival of Hanukkah, which commemorates the successful fight for freedom of Judah Maccabee, began at sundown last night with the lighting of the first candle.

title: Rebels Kill 8 in Peru
description: Maoist rebels killed eight people in northeastern Peru over the weekend, breaking a monthlong lull in guerrilla violence in the coca-growing region.

description: Albert Shanker, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, has joined Mayor Koch in calling for an unpaid, restructured Board of Education.

description: The K Mart Corporation yesterday announced a restructuring of top management, eliminating the chief operating officer title and appointing three executives to head the company's three operating units - K Mart Stores, Specialty Retailing and Administration.

title: WEINBERGER SAYS HE WINS ON BUDGET WITH LESSER CUTS
description: President Reagan has approved military budget levels that would trim projected spending by $8.7 billion in the 1986 fiscal year, but would leave the Administration's military buildup essentially uninterrupted, the White House said today.

description: Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend payable Jan. 2, 1985.

description: Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turk sentenced to life imprisonment for shooting Pope John Paul II in 1981, was quoted today as asking Italy to grant him a pardon.

description: A fire underneath a PATH commuter train today injured 21 people, including 7 rail employees and 14 passengers who were hurt when they pushed one another to get off the train, the authorities said.

About 35 years ago Mr. Cohn gained fame of sorts as chief counsel to the Senate investigating subcommittee headed by Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin.

description: Some numbers lie. Some deceive. In this case, however, they are forthright, honest and conclusive: In 1984, the Miami Dolphins were the No. 1 offensive team in National Football League history.

description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher arrived here today to sign the agreement to return sovereignty over Hong Kong to China on July 1, 1997.

description: Continental Illinois Corporation and its banking subsidiary,

description: $175.5 million of guaranteed obligation bonds yesterday. The bonds, which were rated

description: Austrian Kontrollbank said yesterday that one day this week it intended to offer $100 million of five-year guaranteed notes.

description: In the corporate market, Citicorp offered $300 million worth of two-year extendible notes with a final maturity of Dec. 15, 1994. The notes carry a 10 1/4 percent coupon and were priced at par.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of my favorite dishes for several decades has been something called boeuf a la ficelle, or beef tied in string. I thought of it recently after a column on the uses of fillet of beef brought numerous requests from readers for another recipe using this cut of meat.

title: VARI-CARE INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
WINE TALK
description: SWISS bankers, French businessmen, Hollywood comedians, Japanese whisky makers and teddy bears: what do they have in common? They all make wine in California.

title: Smiling Through
description: Reporters who cover the Islanders swear that they rarely see Al Arbour smile, but certain fans of the team have documentary evidence that the coach is, in fact, enough of a ham to qualify for a gig in the Catskills.

title: One Airline Sale, One Refusal
description: America West Airlines said today that its directors rejected an unsolicited offer to acquire the regional airline. The suitor and terms of the proposal were not disclosed.

title: SIX YOUNGSTERS SERIOUSLY HURT IN QUEENS FIRE
description: Six young children and their baby sitter were severely injured yesterday by heavy smoke as a fire swept through the lower floors of an apartment house in Flushing, Queens.

title: CBI Industries
description: A $100 million issue of 10-year notes from CBI Industries was priced for offering today. The notes, which mature Dec. 15, 1996, carry a coupon of 12 1/8 percent at a price of 99.52 to yield 12.20 percent. The issue, which is led by underwriters from Lehman Brothers, has been rated A-3 by Moody's and BBB-plus by Standard & Poor's.

title: Arbitrator Sought For Wage Dispute
description: The city yesterday requested that an arbitrator be appointed to draw up a contract with unions representing 200,000 nonuniformed city workers. The unions said they would oppose the move.

title: VIKINGS HIRE GRANT
description: The Minnesota Vikings, who suffered through their worst season ever this year, said tonight that Bud Grant would return to the coaching job he held for 17 years.

title: THE STAR AND 'STAR WARS'
description: WASHINGTON Christmas being the time of the guiding star, symbolizing peace and good will on earth, the Reagan Administration has chosen this, of all weeks, to dramatize its ''Star Wars'' policy in outer space.

title: Injured Queens Dancer Sues South Africa Over Treatment
description: Barry Martin, a dancer from the Cambria Heights section of Queens, filed a $130-million lawsuit yesterday against the South African Government and Transvaal Hospital Services, a provincial agency, charging that he received discriminatory medical treatment that left him quadriplegic after he suffered fractured vertebrae in an automobile accident in that country Sept. 26, 1983.

title: SECRECY IN SPACE
description: The secrecy measures for the military space shuttle mission in January appear to be another major round in the sparring that goes on constantly between the superpowers regarding their increasing military and intelligence- gathering operations in space. Sometimes the secrecy is maintained long after many of the facts are widely known. Not until 1978, almost two decades after the flights began, did President Carter acknowledge officially what nearly everyone already knew: that the United States operates photo-reconnaissance satellites in orbits passing over the Soviet Union. The capabilities of these and other ''spy'' satellites remain official secrets, although they are discussed frequently in technical journals and the press.

title: NEUTROGENA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings do not reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective Jan. 17, 1985.

description: Daily close of the Dow Jones industrial average vs. the effective daily average Federal funds rate (in percent) Dow Jones Industrials Left scale 1,150 1,175 1,200 1,225 1,250 Dec. 18 1,211.57 x34.78 Federal Funds Rate Right scale 6.5 7.0 7.5 8.0 8.5 9.0 9.5 10.0 10.5% Dec. 18 6.65% Est. cf39,8 Nov.Dec.

title: MCENROE RESCUES U.S. FROM SHUTOUT
description: Sweden was brought halfway back to earth tonight as John McEnroe beat Mats Wilander and Jimmy Arias almost upset Henrik Sundstrom in the last two singles of the Davis Cup tennis final, which the Swedes clinched yesterday. Thus, the final score was 4-1.

title: 4 Killed in Crash Of Plane Upstate
description: All four people aboard were killed Monday night when a twin-engine plane slammed into a 600-foot hill near the airport here, authorities said today.

title: DEPOSITORS IN LIMBO IN CALIFORNIA CASE
description: Nearly eight months after state officials seized the assets of California's fifth- largest thrift and loan association, the Western Community Money Center, 12,500 depositors are still unsure when they will recover their money or even how much they will receive.

title: IN THE DELAWARE VALLEY, CHRISTMAS IS AT GINGER'S
description: The children came from the river towns, from Hankins and Callicoon, from Equinunk and Stalker. In twos and threes, tugging parents, they came to Ginger's restaurant and Santa's Workshop, where toy trains, bright yellow trucks and Raggedy Ann dolls, brown stuffed bears, electric hockey games and striped candy canes awaited.

title: Transactions
description: Jim Finks, president and chief executive officer resigned and will be succeeded by Dallas Green, who will retain his post as general manager. CHICAGO (AL) - Signed Britt Burns, pitcher, to two-year contract.

title: PITTSBURGH STORE YIELDS TO PROTEST
description: Pittsburghers Against Apartheid, which has been demonstrating against local businesses that sell gold coins minted by South Africa, won an agreement today from Kaufmann's Department Store to halt sale of the Krugerrands.

title: ON SETTINGF A NICE TABLE AND THE UNFAIRNESS OF LIFE
description: -school students of my small town were taught to read music in the second grade and I didn't join them until the third, I can sing only what I have heard many times before. Because I had a fight with the boyfriend who was teaching me how to drive (it was his father's car, and the license plate is written on my heart), I never completed the course. Because I was buried in mystery fiction during adolescence, which is said to be the only possible time to read Thomas Wolfe, I know no more of him than one great book title. And because I was married, quite inconspicuously, 200 miles from home, I was not enrolled in the local department-store bridal registry.

title: PAY 'N PAK STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ENGINEER IS HELD IN SCHEME TO SELL SECRETS TO RUSSIANS
description: A 40-year- old engineer for the Northrop Corporation was arrested today on charges that he stole secret Stealth airplane technology and tried to sell it to the Soviet Union.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Tom Mazzola held up a spindly spruce. ''Where,'' asked a customer, ''are all the branches? It's so scrawny.''

description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $325,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $3,506,000 for the year.

title: COFFEE GRINDER-BREWER
description: COFFEE making has come a long way from the old iron or aluminum drip pot. Today coffee fanciers choose from dozens of blends. And, they blend their coffees with the precision of a chemist. The beans are often ground at home to meet individual tastes, and electric coffee machines come in more models than Fords do.

title: UNITED STATES SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
S.I. GAS STORAGE PLAN DROPPED
description: Public Service Electric and Gas Company announced today that it had abandoned plans to store liquefied natural gas at a Staten Island terminal, near a site where 40 people died in 1973 when similar gas tanks exploded.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a technical error, an article yesterday about Judge Pierre N. Leval, who is presiding over the CBS libel trial, omitted two lines. It should have read: ''What the six women and six men in the jury box are living through is a crash course in the law and in the fundamental democratic process of trial by jury. Judge Leval is the teacher: patient, reassuring and never patronizing.''

title: LIPPER LINKS PLANS TO BELLAMY
description: Deputy Mayor Kenneth Lipper said yesterday that if Carol Bellamy did not run for re-election as City Council President, he would resign and seek the job.

title: European Venture For Tandy, A.C.T.
description: The Tandy Corporation and Applied Computer Techniques (Holdings) P.L.C. said they plan to form a jointly owned computer distribution company with 70 retail stores in Europe. Ed Juge, Tandy's director of marketing planning, said the venture, TA Computerworld Ltd., would combine 49 Tandy computer centers in Europe with 21 of Applied Computer's Computerworld centers.

title: ORGAN PRELUDES ATTRIBUTED TO BACH FOUND AT YALE
description: A group of 33 organ chorale preludes, attributed to J. S. Bach but unknown to modern Bach scholarship, has been found and authenticated by Christoph Wolff, a Harvard professor and Bach authority. The pieces had lain overlooked for nearly 120 years in a collection of hundreds of 18-century manuscripts at Yale University.

title: INTRIGUE IN 'BLADE OF THE FEATHER'
description: THE setting is a rather grand English country home on the Isle of Wight. Two women are bickering as they play lawn tennis. An elderly man reading beneath a tree spots a fly on his hand and begins having an odd attack. A young stranger suddenly appears and gives the man mouth-to-mouth resuscitation or, so to speak, a kiss of life. Later, the victim will thank him for having braved not only the garlic on his breath but ''an old man's slack mouth.''

title: CROWN BOOKS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
EFFORTLESS DRAW FOR KASPAROV AS BLACK IN THE 33D GAME
description: Gary Kasparov revealed an improved counterattack that brought him an effortless draw with the black pieces in the 33d game of his world chess championship match with Anatoly Karpov in Moscow on Monday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We all agree that ours is a vulnerable, fragile yet interdependent world where we must coexist, whether we want this or not.

title: LTV Disposing Of Facilities
description: The LTV Corporation said it would take a $50 million pretax write-down in the fourth quarter for estimated losses on the disposal of certain drilling-related assets, including inventories and facilities.
