title: Attendance Is Up At N.F.L. Games
description: The National Football League reported yesterday that its regular-season paid attendance this year was 13,397,712, an average of 59,811 a game, the second-highest figures in the league's 65 years.

title: EDITOR SAYS HE DOUBTS SHARON INSTIGATED MASSACRE
description: Richard L. Duncan, Time magazine's chief of correspondents, told a jury yesterday that he did not believe that Ariel Sharon had ''instigated'' a massacre of Palestinians in Lebanon.

title: THE ESSENCE OF THE DESSERT MAKER'S ART
description: THIS may be the year you finally decide to celebrate New Year's Eve by baking a croquembouche, a towering pyramid of caramelized cream puffs. Or perhaps for Christmas you might try your hand at a rich mincemeat pie and make the mincemeat from scratch. An elegant holiday cake fashioned with layers of dacquoise and butter cream and tied with a golden satin ribbon might be another inspiration, and a gingerbread Santa in his sleigh could be the centerpiece at this festive time.

title: REAGAN MILITARY BUDGET PLAN DRAWS PROTESTS IN CONGRESS
description: Congressional leaders said today that President Reagan's proposals for savings in his military budget were too small and would jeopardize chances for passage of his deficit reduction package.

title: FOR AFGHAN REBELS, A HOLY WAR 'TO THE LAST MAN'
description: Ahmed Rasool, a steely eyed giant of a man wearing a huge floppy turban and a billowy brown pajama suit, walked in from Afghanistan the other day to visit his family and take a break from making war against the Russians.

title: OEA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
A Hint of Trump's Vision Of the West Side's Future
description: The castles in the air that Donald J. Trump may build over the old Penn Central rail yards on the Hudson River may be of the skyscraping variety. The new developer of the Lincoln West site sketched a vague picture of its future for more than 100 West Siders.

title: BULLETS GET 700TH FOR SHUE
description: The Nets finally met their match tonight: a team that was also playing without its starting center.

title: VATICAN THREAT ON ABORTION AD WENT TO SIGNERS
description: The Vatican announced yesterday that members of religious orders faced dismissal from their orders unless they renounced their support of a statement that Roman Catholics could rightly differ on abortion.

title: MORRISON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $24,961 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $255,355 for the 6 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $182,283 for the quarter and $400,176 for the 6 months.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ROCK performers who write their own songs and have put in time mastering their craft often find themselves bored and short on ideas after spending 5 or 10 years making records, touring, making another record, and going off on another tour, in an apparently endless and often numbing cycle. Tom Verlaine, who has made only four albums since the breakup of his pioneering New Wave Band Television in 1978, doesn't have this problem.

title: EGYPT TAKES SEAT IN ISLAMIC CONFERENCE
description: After a five-year absence, Egypt took its place again today at the opening of the 15th annual meeting of the Foreign Ministers of the Islamic Conference Organization.

title: BOWNE & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $747,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Xebec Expects Quarterly Loss
description: Xebec said it expected to report an operating loss in the fourth quarter, which ended Sept. 30, and a break-even or marginally profitable year. The results for the year will reflect new accounting adjustments that will hurt second and third quarter results.

title: STERCHI BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Next Round of the School Debate
description: How much will it cost to improve New York City's schools? Chancellor Nathan Quinones seeks $476 million to augment the school system's present $4 billion budget. That's more than the city can afford in any case. But it's especially extravagant given the Board of Education's recent record in managing plans for improvement.

title: THE TAX PROPOSAL BENEFITS NEW YORK
description: In the fall of 1787 one of my predecessors, Alexander Hamilton, took the case for New York's ratification of the Constitution to the court of public opinion through a series of newspaper articles. These articles, which became part of the ''Federalist Papers,'' stressed the promise of growth and prosperity under a ''bundle of compromises'' that served the majority.

title: HOW WILL ISOLATION CHANGE SOUTH AFRICA?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Names New Head Of Diversified Products
description: The Ford Motor Company today promoted its top car salesman to head its nonautomotive activities.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: A.T.& E. Corp., San Francisco, a company involved in computer, telecommunications and radio transmission and reception technology, has named Philip S. Hayman executive vice president.

title: 'EXCLUSIVELY WASHINGTON TRIVIA'
description: So you think you know all there is to know about Washington? A new book might convince you otherwise.

title: It's a Hot Ticket
description: At the time of year when workers are sneaking out of offices to buy Christmas presents, the folks at Shea Stadium have no time for such holiday hooky. Since the acquisition of Gary Carter last week, requests for Met season-tickets have poured in, prospective customers have visited the ball park to choose their seats for the coming season, and Bill Ianniciello, the ticket manager, has recruited ''people from around the building, secretaries from other departments'' to help with the traffic.

title: No Headline
description: By finishing second in their division, the Giants will play a 1985 schedule against nondivision opponents with an overall record this year of 56- 72. Of those eight opponents, only the Los Angeles Rams and the Pittsburgh Steelers had winning records.

title: Keach Appeal Rejected On Cocaine Sentence
description: A judge today rejected the actor Stacy Keach's appeal of a nine-month prison sentence imposed for taking cocaine into Britain.

title: IT'S NOT KITTY GENOVESE AGAIN
description: The murder of Barbara Miller Purvis during the early hours of Nov. 30 in Brooklyn's Gowanus Houses has excited a certain amount of commentary likening it to the 1963 death of Kitty Genovese, a 28-year-old bar manager who was knifed to death in Queens while her middle-class neighbors looked on. Before I explain why the comparison is entirely spurious, it might be well to examine the facts (such as they are) of the present case.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS;
description: Air Cargo Equipment, an aircraft cargo concern based in Long Beach, Calif., said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Transequip Inc., a defense products company, for about $3.5 million in cash, notes and securities.

title: FUNDS RATE FALLS SHARPLY
description: Bond prices continued to surge in active trading yesterday, as pressures for a cut in the Federal Reserve's discount rate, the rate that Federal Reserve banks charge on loans to financial institutions, continued to mount.

title: MOTHER SEES FUTURE FOR CHILDREN SPARED SENTENCE IN SLAYING
description: Gov. Ed Herschler commuted the prison sentence Monday of a teen-ager found guilty of helping her brother kill their abusive father, only a week after the state's highest court upheld her conviction.

title: Missouri Picks Coach
description: Woody Widenhofer , the former Missouri linebacker who spent 11 years as an assistant with the Pittsburgh Steelers before taking over last season as head coach of the Oklahoma Outlaws, has been named head coach at Missouri.

title: EAGLE CLOTHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $119,000. c-Including a tax credit of $535,000 and a nonrecurring loss of $1,003,000 on the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Income and Spending Show Rise
description: Americans enjoyed a healthy gain in personal income last month, while spending increased even more, in what the Reagan Administration and private analysts said were signs of a rebounding economy.

title: Times Mirror Unit
description: The Times Mirror Company said it had agreed in principle to sell its Art and Graphic Products group to Brentwood Associates, a Los Angeles- based investment firm, for about $55 million.

title: ROCKETS RALLY TO DEFEAT BULLS
description: Akeem Olajuwon scored 13 of his 24 points in the final quarter tonight to help the Houston Rockets overcome a 16-point deficit and defeat the Chicago Bulls, 104-96.

title: A FAIRER SHARE IN THE MARSHALL ISLANDS
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ; Comings and Goings
description: Doug Flutie , the Boston College quarterback who won the Heisman Trophy, has won another top college football honor, the Maxwell Award given by the Maxwell Football Club of Philadelphia. . . . Amr Aly , the star midfielder for Columbia, won the Hermann Trophy as the nation's best college soccer player. . . . Carl Lewis , who captured four gold medals at the Los Angeles Olympics but disappointed many fans when he did not try for a world record in the long jump, has entered the event in the Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden next month. . . . Two other stars of the Olympics, the hurdler Edwin Moses and the gymnast Mary Lou Retton , were honored as sportsman and sportswoman of the year by Sports Illustrated magazine. . . . Phil Ford was waived by the Houston Rockets but will remain with the club in a front-office position, a team official said. . . . Dave Kingman could re-sign with the Oakland A's as early as Friday, says his agent, Jack Childers . ''It's just a question of getting it all in writing'' Childers said.

title: SHUTTLE SECRECY TROUBLES PRESS
description: The military's stamp of secrecy on its space shuttle program has shaken the balance that news organizations try to strike between not disclosing vital military secrets and keeping readers fully informed, according to some leading journalists.

title: ECHLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Hunters Rescued By Coast Guard
description: Stranded overnight on a small island in Great South Bay off Fire Island after their boat was disabled, two duck hunters were rescued today by the Coast Guard.

title: TONELLI'S GOALS PACE ISLANDERS
description: As ineffective as they looked in the early stages, the Islanders played with inspiration for the last 30 minutes tonight and trounced the Winnipeg Jets, 7-4, with John Tonelli getting three of the goals for the winners.

title: OPEC Panel to Ask Differential Shift
description: A group of OPEC oil ministers will recommend a revision of the group's complex system of price differentials to the organization's 13 oil ministers, who will meet here on Wednesday to discuss ways to avert a price war.

title: JUMPING-JACKS SHOES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
A 'DEAL' FOR DICKERSON
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: MACGREGOR SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $280,800 for the latest first quarter and $161,800 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: DART GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $2,481,000 for the quarter and $7,433,000 for the 9 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $76,010,000.

title: AGREEMENT REACHED ON PLAN TO DEVELOP BROOKLYN WATERFRONT
description: Governor Cuomo announced an agreement yesterday that he said would allow a long-stalled Brooklyn waterfront project to move ahead while saving the jobs of 1,200 manufacturing workers on the site.

title: Richard Giliberty, 71, Surgeon and Inventor
description: Dr. Richard P. Giliberty, an orthopedic surgeon and the inventor in the 1970's of the bipolar prosthesis, an artificial hip joint widely used in operations, died of a stroke Saturday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhasset, L.I.

title: COUNTY THREATENS TO CUT TIMBER IN NATIONAL PARK
description: Around the turn of the century, North Manitou Island, about 15 miles out in Lake Michigan from here, had a thriving community of more than 300 people. They logged the rich virgin forests that covered the 14,000-acre island, hauling the logs to waterfront docks on miniature railroads that ran down the east and west shores.

title: VACCINE: ASSESSING RISKS AND BENEFITS
description: It is a scene colored with the sentimental overtones of a Norman Rockwell painting. A rosy-cheeked child, trying to be brave, bites her lip as the needle jabs her arm. The tear wiped from her eye, she steps forth to announce that shots don't really hurt.

title: FLOATING CURRENCY RATES AND THE U.S. ECONOMY
description: Some economists think they have found a troubling explanation for why inflation has remained so low this year, or why the economy wilted so fast. Increasingly, they look back to decisions taken more than a decade ago, when the financial world abandoned the system of fixed exchange rates and permitted currency values to float.

title: GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA (A&P) (N) reports earnings for 12 wks to Dec 1
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $10,920,000 for the 12 weeks and $23,850,000 for the 40 weeks and an extraordinary pension credit of $135 million for the 40 weeks. c-Including extraordinary tax credits of $2,650,000 for the 12 weeks and $10,650,000 for the 40 weeks.

title: U.S. AIDE FAULTS JUDGE'S I.R.A. EXTRADITION RULING
description: A high- ranking Justice Department official assailed as ''outrageous'' today a judge's refusal last week to extradite an Irish Republican Army fugitive convicted of murder in Britain.

title: Significant Moves
description: Even when the new year does not signal a change of administration or Cabinet officers, it often brings important shifts in Government assignments at the operating level, just out of the public spotlight. Two such significant moves are now in progress within the Washington foreign policy apparatus.

title: First Defection Takes Place From Israel's Unity Cabinet
description: The first defection from Israel's national unity Cabinet went into effect this morning as a Minister Without Portfolio, Rabbi Yitzhak Peretz, took his four-man Shas Party into opposition.

title: WITH GAME, RESOLUTE AND STURDY WINES
description: IN choosing a compatible wine

title: MICROSEMI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Resignation at Macy's
description: Philip Schlein, the chairman and chief executive of Macy's California and a corporate director of R.H. Macy & Company, has resigned in what the company is calling ''an amicable parting.''

title: FEDERATED GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Edward Mabley, 78, Is Dead;Playwright and TV Director
description: Edward Mabley, a playwright and a former director for CBS-TV, died Sunday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SPEX GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-There are no year-ago results because the company went public in February 1984.

title: REMARK ABOUT 'GAYS' MAY HAVE LED TO 4 SLAYINGS
description: The killing of four people during a bank robbery may have been touched off when a bank employee suggested that the robbers were homosexual, a prosecutor said today.

title: Hennepin County
description: Hennepin County of Minnesota yesterday offered $134.5 million worth of general obligation bonds for solid waste recovery. The bonds, which mature in 1987, carry a 7.35 percent coupon to yield 6.45 percent. They have been rated AAA by Moody's and carry a 1-plus rating from the Standard & Poor's.

title: Long Weekend for Giants
description: At this time a year ago, the Giants had just completed a disastrous 3-12-1 season, and the players were saying their goodbyes for another year. Today, the 1984 Giants, having just completed a surprisingly good 9-7 regular season, began preparing for Sunday's playoff game against the Los Angeles Rams in Anaheim, Calif.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Before the people of Deaf Smith County will glow in the dark, sparks will fly.'' - Gov. Mark White of Texas, on possibility the state might be chosen for a nuclear waste dump. (A24:1.)

title: Prosecutor Clears Police in Hanging
description: The Westchester County District Attorney said today that his investigation of the hanging of an inmate in the Yonkers jail had uncovered no evidence of wrongdoing by the police.

title: WHY JUDGES ACT
description: BOSTON Courts all over the country in recent years have stepped into the running of prisons, hospitals and other public facilities. The cases have raised hard questions of legal and political philosophy: Are judges right to intervene, and if so when? What advantages do they bring to the solution of what are often policy problems?

title: Pirates Say No
description: Donald Trump , the real estate man who owns the Generals, has been looking for a major league baseball team to play in the stadium just authorized by the New Jersey Legislature. But he has been told that the Pittsburgh Pirates are not available for such a move, even though the Galbreath family has placed the club up for sale.

title: CPT CORP reports earnings for 16 wks to Nov 10
Kean Signs Bill On Casino Income
description: Governor Kean signed legislation today requiring Atlantic City casinos to reinvest more than $1.6 billion in the resort city and northern and southern New Jersey over the next 25 years.

title: Danube Dam Protested
description: More than 14,000 people took to the streets of Vienna today to protest construction of a dam on the Danube that they say will destroy one of Europe's last primeval forests, the Auwald.

title: Peter Lawford in Coma; Condition Called Critical
description: Peter Lawford went into a coma today and was listed in critical condition at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, according to a hospital spokesman.

title: TOP OFFICIALS JOIN IN ATTACK ON TAX PLAN
description: Abolishing Federal income-tax deductions for local and state taxes would cost New Yorkers $6 billion a year by 1986, the state's top officials said yesterday in bipartisan denunciation of the proposal by the Treasury.

title: STAGE: DISPUTED 'ENDGAME' IN DEBUT
description: BOSTON

title: Ted Hughes Is Poet Laureate
description: LONDON, Dec. 19--Ted Hughes was named England's new poet laureate today. The son of a Yorkshire carpenter, Mr. Hughes succeeds Sir John Betjeman who died earlier this year.

title: RESTAURANT MANAGEMENT SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
KELLY JOHNSTON ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After nonrecurring charges of $8.6 million for the quarter and $13.4 million for the 6 months. c-Net income.

title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
Rates Are Mostly Unchanged
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday, after falling sharply during the previous two trading sessions. Compared with the last few days, activity was light, money market participants said.

title: NEIGHBORS IN AFFLUENT SUBURB KNEW LITTLE OF SPY SUSPECT
description: The neighborhood where Thomas Patrick Cavanagh lived with his wife and two teen-age sons is a handsome suburban refuge of four- to six-bedroom homes where most households sent both spouses out to work, like the Cavanaghs, to pay for their share of the California dream.

title: FERRARO AND SPOUSE OFFICIALLY ABSOLVED OF ELECTION CHARGES
description: The Federal Election Commission formally announced today that Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro and her husband, John A. Zaccaro, had been cleared of allegations that they violated Federal election laws in her 1978 Congressional campaign.

title: Amfac Sees Loss; Payout Dropped
description: Amfac Inc. said it expects to take a one-time charge against earnings of $20 million in the fourth quarter and expects to report a loss for 1984 because of a reorganization.

title: Dow Falls by 3.53 as Trading Slows
description: After surging Tuesday, the stock market lost most of its vigor yesterday, as prices ended mixed. Volume continued very heavy.

title: U.S. EXPORT AID FOR CENTRAL AMERICA
description: The Government announced a $300 million loan guarantee program today for Central American countries regarded as friendly. The program would help the countries finance imports from the United States and stabilize their economies.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: GRAB BAG OF HISTORY When it comes to pulling history out of the past, particularly that with a New York touch, few can do it as neatly as the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Streeet (873-3400). As a museum, the society juggles in its exhibition halls up to a dozen shows at a time and they represent the most kaleidoscopic range of interests.

title: FERRARO SELLS BOOK RIGHTS AT AUCTION
description: An 11-hour auction among 10 publishers competing for the rights to Geraldine A. Ferraro's proposed book about the 1984 Presidential campaign ended shortly before 9 o'clock last night with a winning bid that was reportedly in excess of $1 million. The identity of the winning publishing house, however, was withheld so its officials could notify employees today.

title: NUNS, EXPRESSING DISMAY, PONDER VATICAN THREAT
description: Nuns who have been threatened by the Vatican with expulsion from their orders for their stand on abortion expressed ''surprise and anguish'' today and indicated they were still pondering their individual responses.

title: 2 Shot at Pittsburgh U.; Man With Rifle Seized
description: A man fired a semiautomatic rifle at an apartment building on the University of Pittsburgh's urban campus today, wounding two students, then shot at emergency vehicles before being arrested as he fled, the police said.

title: A Clarinet Recital By Charles Neidich
description: Charles Neidich is a clarinetist who stands out in a crowd. In the various chamber and orchestral groups with which he has played during the last few years in New York, it has been impossible not to notice the verve of his physical presence and the handsome tone and lively phrasing that go with it.

title: Election Panel Picks Chief
description: John W. McGarry, a Democrat, was chosen Tuesday by his fellow members of the Federal Election Commission to serve a one-year term as chairman. Joan D. Aikens, a Republican, was elected vice chairman of the six-member panel. The post customarily changes hands between parties each year, and by statute the two officers must be members of different parties.

title: Four Votes for Bird
description: Viewed up close or from the

title: OPEC'S OPENING TALKS YIELD LITTLE PROGRESS
description: Ministers of the 13 OPEC countries adjourned a first round of formal talks on pricing today that has thus far yielded only a stern admonition to North Sea oil producers not to undermine OPEC prices.

title: Four Named by MONY To Head New Divisions
description: The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, which will restructure itself into five core business units on Jan. 1, named four senior officers to head those units yesterday and said it would appoint the fifth next year.

title: HEINICKE INSTRUMENTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TOWELS: GUESTS, PLEASE USE
description: EACH holiday season hope swells that this year will be different. Once again I permit myself to hope that those who honor my home will also honor my guest towels, a vintage collection dating back to the 1940's.

title: FUTURE
description: High stratosphere winds with their juvenile whistle.

title: Dr. Kirkpatrick on Sexism
description: ''Sexism is alive,'' declared Dr.

title: Addendum
description: * Cohn & Wolfe, an Atlanta-based public relations company, is opening a New York office at One Madison Avenue.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Vince Dooley , Georgia's football coach and athletic director, said that the National Collegiate Athletic Association was investigating the university's football and women's basketball programs. The announcement by Dooley, who gave no details, came just two weeks after he had disclosed that the N.C.A.A. was investigating possible violations in the recruitment of a top basketball player, Cedric Henderson . . . . Livingstone Bramble , who won the World Boxing Association's lightweight title in June by stopping Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini , will fight Mancini again on Feb. 16, according to Bramble's manager, Lou Duva .

title: A PUBLIC CALL FOR SECRECY
description: The Reagan Administration's effort to impose tight secrecy on the next mission of the space shuttle reflects both an urge to protect national security and what some intelligence specialists see as a broader, long-term drive to curb the flow of information on such issues to the public.

title: Bridge2 Experts to Discuss GameOn Radio Show Tomorrow
description: In recent years several television series showing bridge experts at work have received surprisingly high ratings in Britain. Two such series consisted of matches between London and New York and could be popular here, but there has been some lethargy from the BBC, which owns the rights.

title: Bank Rates Fall Again
description: Annual effective yields on money market accounts and six-month certificates of deposit plunged for the 10th consecutive week, in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported. Average yields on money market deposit accounts have fallen more than a point since August.

title: S.E.C. Censure Of Publisher WASHINGTON, Dec. 19
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today censured the publisher of Penny

title: STALKING WHITE-TAILED DEER WITH BOW, ARROW AND YO-YO
description: Dressed in camouflage, their faces covered with masks and nets, Ken Petersen, Bob Krontilik and Mark Strauss moved silently across the barren landscape with their bows and arrows.

title: THE WRITER'S SKILL IN ADAPTING TO THE COLLOQUIAL
description: EXCEPT that almost no one in America had heard of him - and even this didn't come as too much of a surprise - the announcement that the Czech poet Jaroslav Seifert had won the 1984 Nobel Prize for Literature was mostly business as usual. That the Nobel committee praised Mr. Seifert for being loved and respected in his own country; that his work was cited for providing ''a liberating image of the indomitable spirit and versatility of man'' - this provoked a yawn so huge that one nearly broke one's jawbone.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: VESTAUR SECURITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Net income figures represent net investment income.

title: ANDERSEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Accused Murderer Brought to Jersey
description: A suspected terrorist was transported in secrecy from Ohio to the maximum- security state prison here to face murder charges in the shooting of a state trooper.

title: AVANT-GARDE RUSSIAN WRITER
description: Viktor Borisovich Shklovsky, a versatile Russian writer whose career of 70 years ranged from early opposition to the Bolsheviks to being an honored member of the Soviet literary establishment, died last week, according to Soviet press reports. He was 91 years old.

title: Don't Fiddle; Burn New York's Trash
description: Why drown in garbage when you can burn it to generate steam for electricity? New York City's Board of Estimate, meeting today, will either endorse a bold new garbage-burning plan by the Sanitation Department or, by ducking a decision, take New York another step toward suffocating in its own trash.

title: U.S. Trade Unit Reports On Prison-Good Imports
description: A Government report asserted today that about 1 million prison laborers in China and 1.2 million to 1.5 million prisoners in the Soviet Union manufacture goods that might be imported by the United States illegally.

title: Jazz Keep Paultz
description: Yet another day of reckoning has passed for Billy Paultz, the durable 36-year-old center who has been with 14 playoff teams in his 14-year professional career. Cuts were made throughout the National Basketball Association this week because of a deadline requiring players still on the roster to be paid for the remainder of the season, but the Utah Jazz made no move to rid themselves of the good- natured man known as the Whopper.

title: DECORATIONS IN THE HOUSES OF CHRISTMAS PAST
description: WASHINGTON IRVING, serving as the American Minister to Spain, wrote in 1843 to his niece Sara Irving in Tarrytown, N.Y.: ''I thought of you all at dear little Sunnyside on Christmas Day, and heartily wished myself there to eat my Christmas dinner among you. I hope you kept up Christmas in the usual style, and that the cottage was decked with evergreens. You must not let my absence cause any relaxations in the old rules and customs of the cottage: everything must go on the same as it did when I was there.''

title: Secret T-shirts
description: The Secret Service is understandably committed to keeping a low, preferably nonexistent, profile in carrying out its protective duties.

title: KEMP FOR BERRA IS CALLED FINAL
description: Commissioner Peter Ueberroth has approved the trade between the Yankees and the Pittsburgh Pirates involving Steve Kemp and Dale Berra, a source familiar with the matter said yesterday.

title: Strong Friendship
description: Some people who watch one of the

title: Pakistanis Said to Back Leader in Referendum
description: Pakistanis voted in a referendum Wednesday on whether they supported the rule of President Mohammad Zia-ul-Haq and today the election commission announced that incomplete results indicated that 96 percent of those who voted approved.

title: FROST & SULLIVAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
GORBACHEV MEETS LABORITE LEADERS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev met today with British Labor Party leaders and reiterated Moscow's concern about the issue of space weapons.

title: Earnings Rise in Britain
description: Britain's average seasonally adjusted earnings rose 2.7 percent in October from September and 8.2 percent from October 1983, the Department of Employment said today. A spokesman said back pay for civil servants, teachers and some health workers, who settled a wage dispute during the month, inflated earnings by more than two percentage points. But the coal strike depressed average earnings by about one and a quarter points.

title: TIME'S CHIEF PRAISES SHARON ARTICLE
description: Henry A. Grunwald, the editor in chief of Time Inc., expressed praise yesterday for the article that prompted Ariel Sharon to sue the magazine for $50 million.

title: Button Up
description: Weather or not, winter begins

title: End the Auto Quotas It's time to end the quotas restricting imports of Japanese automobiles. President Reagan's meeting with Prime Minister Nakasone in two weeks presents the ideal opportunity. This was to be a temporary restraint - a tax, really, on American consumers - to give America's automakers time and capital to adjust to new market conditions. They've had four years. From here on, protection will only make them inefficient again.
description: Unfortunately, both Governments see the issue as a bargaining chip. Auto quotas are not for bargaining. Even if once justified, their task is done.

title: JUDY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ONE DISTRICT KNOWN FOR ITS PRESIDENTS
description: Kalorama means ''beautiful view'' in Greek. To five Presidents of the United States, it also meant home or former home.

title: Poll Finds Churchgoing Holds Steady in 1984
description: The percentage of churchgoing Americans remained unchanged in 1984, with four of every 10 adults attending a church or a synagogue, the same percentage as in 1983, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

title: Muse Air Stake
description: The Muse Air Corporation said Harold C. Simmons, a Dallas investor, had agreed to invest $16 million in Muse in return for a 30 percent interest. The announcement came one week after the airline put itself up for sale because of mounting losses. On the American Stock Exchange today, Muse plunged $1.125, to $5.625.

title: OLYMPIC SURPLUS PUT AT $215 MILLION
description: The Olympic Games last summer generated a surplus of at least $215 million, about $65 million more than the original estimate in September, the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee said today.

title: CONVENTION PROJECT TO BRING BENEFITS, BUT ITS UNMET GOALS LEAVE QUESTIONS
description: The first event ever held in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center of New York - yesterday's topping-out ceremony - turned into a celebration of the project itself, and, considering the possibilities, who could be surprised? Mayor Koch, casting a glance across a four-block-long lobby, told a crowd of several hundred that he looked forward to all the events he would be attending in the giant structure and to the ''millions of dollars'' it would bring to the coffers of the city and the state.

title: HERS
description: MY husband Steve says he enjoys living in Minnesota because here he can truly experience what he likes to call ''the theater of the seasons.'' As I write this, the wind chill is 37 degrees below zero, and I am thinking about preparing for winter (I am never prepared for these winters), wishing I had stored up more nuts. I need to stock up on staples and canned goods in case we're snowed in, and I need to get jumper cables for the car.

title: Hogeboom Said To Seek Trade
description: Gary Hogeboom was said to have urged today that the Dallas Cowboys trade him or Danny White, his rival at quarterback.

title: HOW TO CALCULATE EFFECT OF TREASURY'S TAX PLAN
description: Without much difficulty, it is possible for taxpayers to compute roughly how much they would owe in Federal income taxes under the Treasury Department's proposal to overhaul the tax system and to compare that with what they are paying under the existing law.

title: Carol Burnett Settles With Enquirer in Suit
description: Carol Burnett said today that her legal battle against The National Enquirer stemming from a 1976 article about her has been settled with the payment of an undisclosed sum by the tabloid.

title: DANCE: KUHNKE AND GOSHEN GROUPS
description: TWO dance groups, Martha Goshen's Earthworks and Kuhnke and Company, offered 10 works on Sunday night at the Emanu-El Midtown Y. The mixed bill proved a mixed blessing. The sheer quantity of dances came close to wearying the eyes. Yet if nothing else, the pieces represented more than one choreographic style.

title: ABORTION-CLINIC BOMBINGS ARE TERRORISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Debt
description: * Chrysler Financial Corp. filed for a shelf registration for the proposed offering of up to $1 billion of debt securites, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Some Steps Forward At Della Femina
description: James D. Travis, who directed the efforts of the Tuesday Team, the one- client ad agency that helped the winning Reagan-Bush ticket, is returning to Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, his regular agency, on Jan. 1 and that is no surprise.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: THE news last month that B. Altman is to be sold to a consortium consisting of one retailer and several real-estate investors whose intention is to condense the Fifth Avenue flagship store drastically, making half of its building into rentable real estate, suggests that this will be the last Christmas for Altman's as New Yorkers have known it for most of this century.

title: SOFTWARE THAT AIDS IN CRAFT DESIGN
description: CAROL BECKETT came across the afghan in a book on antique bed coverings. She liked the way it looked in the picture and decided that the coverlet would be perfect for her daughter's bedroom. But before the Dallas-based weaver sat down at her loom to begin work, she popped a software disk into her personal computer and received a complete analysis of the afghan's pattern.

title: Murray Perahia Plays Concert of Piano Works
description: The pianist Murray Perahia is a brilliant musical storyteller. Such is his sense of linear continuity that he is able to cohere the most sprawling and diversified compositions of the Romantic era into supremely logical unities.

title: TIRELESS FRIEND OF THE POOR
description: For Unicef's executive director, James P. Grant, the dramatic success of the organization's child survival program comes as the culmination of a lifetime spent in the service of the third world's poor. But it also represents the continuation of a family tradition. Since becoming Unicef director in 1980, Mr. Grant has labored tirelessly on behalf of the simple but effective health care program that has saved the lives of so many children. He has traveled around the globe, lobbying governments and drumming up private support for the program.

title: Husband Is Held In Parkway Killing
description: The husband of a 42-year-old woman who was shot dead in a rest area along the Garden State Parkway was arrested today and accused of arranging the murder, the Ocean County Prosecutor, Edward J. Turnbach, announced.

title: IN THE MATTER OF THE UNITED STATES V. LEVITY
description: After a moment in the sun as a campaign issue this fall, the Supreme Court has now slid into its winter of invisibility.

title: CITY-BUILT SINGLE-FAMILY HOMES CAN END HOUSING
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; A 2-Part Tandy Issue To Yield 10.3 to 11.10%
description: The Tandy Corporation yesterday $300 million worth of senior notes yesterday in two increments of $150 million each.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Communications Satellite Corp. said it had completed the previously announced sale of its one-third stake in Satellite Business System to its partners in the venture, Aetna Life and Casualty Co. and International Business Machines Corp.

title: BIG DROP FORESEEN IN INFANT DEATHS
description: Unicef reported today that its effort to revolutionize children's health care, begun two years ago, was starting to save lives in dramatic numbers.

title: PENTAGON CHIEF ASSAILS ARTICLE ON SHUTTLE TRIP
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger yesterday denounced as ''the height of journalistic irresponsibility'' a report in The Washington Post yesterday giving details about the Pentagon's classified Jan. 23 space shuttle mission.

title: Leo Burnett to Get More Procter Business
description: Procter & Gamble, the country's largest national advertiser, which rarely switches brands among its agencies, announced yesterday that it would be giving even more business to the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago, which has served it since 1951.

title: CORRECTION
description: A article in Business Day on Tuesday about Conrail incorrectly described Colin Pease. He is a lobbyist for Guilford Industries but is not a lawyer.

title: Market Place; Better Future Seen for Dayco
description: THE Dayco Corporation, the highly diversified

title: PAKISTAN CAMPS NOW HOLD A FIFTH OF ALL AFGHANS
description: Naseeb, an 8-year-old Afghan boy, lost both his legs this fall when he stepped on a Soviet land mine. He is getting better now, and lately he even smiles as his hands make little cutting gestures above his knees, to explain the amputation.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 10.75-11.25 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Storage Technology Can Get Financing
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge yesterday approved a critical $140 million financing plan for the Storage Technology Corporation, prompting the troubled maker of computer memory devices to say that it would continue operating at least through the first quarter of 1985.

title: Nassau County Bonds Insured
description: In the municipal bond market, Nassau County issued $34.3 million of general obligation bonds.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: pages. Holt, Rinehart & Winston.

title: Citibank, Some Others Reduce Prime to 10 3/4%
description: Several more major banks yesterday cut their prime lending rates to 10 3/4 percent, as short-term interest rates continued to hold at lower levels. Other banks, however, refused to budge from their 11 1/4 percent prime rates, pending clearer indications that rates would stay down.

title: Article 163614 -- No Title
description: A captain of the University of Rochester's 1969 football squad and his brother donated $1 million to the Division III school today and earmarked part of the money for the head

title: DECADE OF FABRICS
description: BECAUSE he felt that ''a retrospective sounded very pompous,'' Jay Yang, above, a fabrics designer who was born in Taiwan, titled a show of his work ''The First 10 Years.'' Included in the informative exhibition are original artworks and finished hand-screened and machine-printed fabrics as well as wallpaper and sheet patterns. Mr. Yang's vein has been inspired by museum documents and by places and objects he has seen in his travels.

title: YEARNINGS OF A RANGER ON THE SIDELINES
description: RYE, N.Y.

title: RECITAL: BEVERLY MORGAN, SOPRANO
description: AT the center of Beverly Morgan's song recital Monday at Merkin Concert Hall came a brilliant theatrical success with ''Northeast Reservation Lines,'' commissioned for the occasion from the composer Hayes Biggs. The text, by Jane Shore, is one of those recorded messages asking the caller to wait for the next available agent, repeated three times ''straight'' and then four times with mounting, hilarious perversion.

title: U.S. Aide and Gemayel Discuss Israeli Troops
description: In hopes of breaking the deadlock between Lebanon and Israel over the proposed withdrawal of Israeli troops from southern Lebanon, Assistant Secretary of State Richard W. Murphy States met today with President Amin Gemayel.

title: Smith Expects Loss for the Year
description: Smith International Inc. said that it expects to report a loss for the year as a result of a one-time charge in the fourth quarter and that it had reduced its quarterly dividend on common stock to 8 cents a share, from 24 cents.

COMPANY OFFERS VACCINE, BUT ADDS CONDITION
description: A major drug company offered today to provide enough whooping cough vaccine to avert a shortage projected for early next year, but only if the Government assumed liability for lawsuits.

description: Following are highlights of the agreement on Hong Kong:

title: Revco Profit Off 43.2%
description: Revco D.S. Inc., owner of the nation's largest retail drugstore chain, today reported a 43.2 percent drop in second-quarter earnings compared with the 1983 quarter.

title: SHUTTLE MAY CARRY INTELLIGENCE SATELLITE
description: Despite the cloak of official secrecy placed around the military space shuttle mission next month, information available from Pentagon statements, Congressional testimony and technical publications suggests that it will carry a satellite able to pick up communications on earth for intelligence purposes.

title: Libyan Leader Meets With Spanish Premier
description: The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, and Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain met for five hours today on the Mediterranean island of Majorca and discussed North Africa and relations between the two nations.

title: JEWISH GROUPS CRITICIZE CITY FOR ALLOWING CRECHE IN PARK
description: Several Jewish organizations yesterday criticized the Parks Department's decision to allow a Nativity scene in Central Park this Christmas for the first time in many years.

title: BAYLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: MIXED MARRIAGE AND A DILEMMA OF THE HOLIDAYS
description: IN one synagogue, the workshop was called ''The December

title: Legal Group Attacks A Judicial Nominee
description: The State Trial Lawyers Association said today that a New York University Law School professor was ''not qualified'' for appointment to the state's highest court,

title: W. MICHIGAN UPSETS DEPAUL
description: Western Michigan's Pete Hansen sank a pair of free throws with 16 seconds remaining and then the Broncos held off a furious DePaul charge at the other end of the court to upset the Blue Demons, 65-64, tonight.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Cleveland Cavaliers, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Knicks have won two of their three games this season against the hapless Cavaliers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1984

title: HONG KONG ACCORD IS SIGNED IN PEKING
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today signed the agreement formally committing Britain to surrender Hong Kong to China in 1997 in return for terms guaranteeing a 50-year extension of its capitalist economic system.

title: Women Seeking Place in the Hall
description: The chapter of the National Organization for Women in Springfield, Mass., is vigorously lobbying for the inclusion of women in the Basketball Hall of Fame, which is building a new home in that city at a cost of $11.3 million, 70 percent of which is coming from the state government.

title: BULLETS ARE TOPPLED BY NETS
description: With injuries forcing the Nets to face their opponents with only eight healthy players these days, there will be many nights when they just don't have enough energy to power them through a complete game. Tonight was not one of them.

title: ROSS COSMETICS DISTRICT CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
U.S. AFFIRMS PLAN TO LEAVE UNESCO AT END OF MONTH
description: The United States announced today that it would withdraw from Unesco at the end of this month. It said the agency had largely failed to meet American demands that it rid itself of mismanagement, politicization and ''endemic hostility'' toward a free press, free markets and individual human rights.

title: WEINBERGER CALLS U.S. SPACE-ARMS EFFORT 'VITAL'
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that it was ''vital'' that the United States pursue its program of research into a new generation of defensive space weapons.

title: DIXON TICONDEROGA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income of $1,977,809 from the sale of a factory property in Jersey City and a loss of $483,477 from discontinued operations.

title: Austrian Notes
description: Austrian Kontrollbank offered $100 million of five-year guaranteed notes. The notes, which carry a guarantee by the Republic of Austria, carry an 11 1/4 percent coupon and were priced at par. Dillon, Read & Company and Salomon Brothers acted as lead underwriters for the offering, which carries a AAA rating from both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.

title: ACOMPUTERCRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
A Jewish Christmas Vigil
description: For several weeks there have

title: The Vienna Choir Boys At Avery Fisher Hall
description: The Vienna Choir Boys' Sunday afternoon recital at Avery Fisher Hall was prime family entertainment and, like most such events, probably had strongest appeal for the younger members of the family.

title: Return of Avi Pazner
description: Avi Pazner for many years was the Israeli press attache in Washington before going back to Jerusalem to become spokesman for the Israeli Foreign Ministry and eventually for Yitzhak Shamir when he was Prime Minister. Now, according to diplomatic sources, Mr. Pazner will return next year to head up his Government's sizable information effort in Washington.

title: Article 163432 -- No Title
description: The Federal Communications Commission today unanimously authorized the nation's 1,400 local telephone companies to add a $1 monthly charge to the phone bills of residential and single- line business telephone customers starting June 1, 1985. The fee will increase to $2 a month on June 1, 1986.

title: U.S. MOVE PRAISED BY CONSERVATIVES
description: The announcement that the United States would withdraw from Unesco on Jan. 1 drew a favorable reaction from conservative and middle-of-the road American groups, but was criticized by United Nations officials and the Soviet Union.

title: U.S. NAMES 3 SITES FOR ATOMIC STUDY
description: The Government chose three areas in Texas, Nevada and Washington today as the leading candidates to become a permanent site for disposing highly radioactive nuclear wastes.

title: U.S. FOUND TO BREED MANY SPIES, BUT EVEN MORE AREN'T PROSECUTED
description: With a record number of people facing spying charges, Federal investigators say that an even larger number of Americans committed acts of espionage in the last year but were not prosecuted.

title: Transactions
description: Reached agreement with Dave Kingman, designated hitter, on a one-year contract. METS (NL) - Named Bud Harrelson manager of Columbia affiliate in South Atlantic League.

title: REHNQUIST DEFENDS THE COURT
description: Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court, in his first interview on network television, says it would be ''a recipe for anarchy'' if the Supreme Court automatically supported civil liberties claims.

title: Washington Firefighter Killed In Blaze in Red Light District
description: Fire swept through three businesses in the capital's red light district three blocks from the White House today, sending a firefighter plunging to his death through a theater marquee.

title: TELCO SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $121,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: Reducing Red Ink
description: Back in 1982, the Democratic National Committee sponsored a telethon hoping to bring in donations of $6 million to $8 million. Some of the more ebullient backers talked of raising as much as $20 million.

title: Gretzky Gains 1,000th Point EDMONTON, Alberta, Dec.
description: 19 (AP) - Wayne Gretzky of

title: FREEDOM PROPOSED FOR SLAYER
description: The Louisiana Pardon Board voted unanimously today to recommend that the state free Wilbert Rideau, a murderer who became an award-winning prison journalist.

title: CUBS GO TO COURT TO INSTALL LIGHTS
description: The Chicago Cubs filed a lawsuit today against the City of Chicago and the Governor of Illinois, James R. Thompson, seeking, in effect, to allow the team to end a decades-old tradition and play night baseball at home.

title: 3 Held in South Africa Protest
description: The police arrested three people, including the author Gloria Steinem, at the South African Embassy today in the latest protest against that Government's nation's policy of racial separation, or apartheid.

title: THEATER: ARCHBISHOP REMEMBERED
description: THE BREAD AND PUPPET THEATER'S Christmas show, ''The Nativity, Crucifixion and Resurrection of Archbishop Oscar Romero of El Salvador,'' is a heartfelt tribute to the Central American Roman Catholic prelate who was assassinated while celebrating mass in a hospital chapel in March 1980. As is usual with Peter Schumann's troupe - for 20 years a theatrical sentinel of political and moral concern - the musical pageant is both somber and jubilant, as the hero, in death, is able to unite his people.

title: MX Power Overstated, Jane's Yearbook Says
description: The American MX missile, designed to destroy Soviet weapons on the ground, is not likely to be any more effective than existing weapons because the Soviet Union has reinforced its missile silos, according to a new Jane's yearbook published Thursday.

title: Castle & Cooke Bank Debt Delay
description: Castle & Cooke Inc., which has been hard pressed for cash, said its bankers had agreed to a delay in the payment of $100 million in principal and interest due in the next three months. The agreement came five days after the resignation of the company's president and chief executive, Ian R. Wilson. Mr. Wilson had planned to raise $120 million this year by selling several units of the company, but only one unit has been sold.

title: Lions Dismiss Clark
description: The postseason suspense about his future with the Detroit Lions came to an end for Coach Monte Clark yesterday when William Clay Ford , the club's owner, dismissed him and his assistants. Ford, who said he was acting with ''deep regret,'' called Clark ''a fine person'' but added that he felt a change was necessary ''in order to pursue our goal of a championship.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1984 International The U.S. will withdraw from Unesco at the end of this month, the Government announced. It said the United Nations agency had failed to meet American demands that it rid itself of mismanagement, politicization and ''endemic hostility'' to a free press, free markets and individual human rights. (Page A1, Column 6.) Key benefits will be lost to American scientists, scholars and cultural groups because of a United States withdrawal from Unesco, according to many experts who have worked through the organization's agencies and related programs. They generally contend the Reagan Administration did not take the adverse effect of withdrawal for Americans sufficiently into account. (A11:1.)

title: GIANTS NEED A SPECIAL GAME
description: When the Giants meet the Rams in the wild-card playoff game in Anaheim, Calif., on Sunday, their special teams will have to be special. They were atrocious in the fifth week of the season when the Rams routed the Giants, 33-12.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: TODAY'S resilient flooring materials are made of vinyl and are more durable and more varied in pattern, texture and color than ever before. Resilient flooring comes in two forms: sheet vinyl and square tiles that are usually 12 by 12 inches.

title: Man May Discern Talk With New Ear Implant
description: An artificial ear more advanced than one recently given Government approval has been implanted into a deaf man and is expected to enable him to understand speech once again, doctors said today.

title: 8 Die in Sri Lanka Clash
description: Four soldiers and four Tamil separatist guerrillas were killed today in a clash in Sri Lanka's northeastern region, a Government spokesman said. The spokesman said the gunfight broke out after guerrillas land mines blasted two trucks carrying 27 soldiers near the town of Padaviya.

title: MUSIC: BEETHOVEN
description: BEETHOVEN'S last three piano sonatas are hardly a set. And given their extraordinary variety of mood and musical device, hearing one after the other can numb the listener with a surfeit of experience as much as it can enlighten him. Jacob Lateiner brought these pieces to the Juilliard Theater Sunday night, and whatever one might think of his playing, he did make us listen to it with care and intensity.

title: A City Paramedic Is Charged With Abusing Injured Woman
description: A paramedic with the Emergency Medical Service was charged yesterday with sexually abusing an injured woman being taken to Bellevue Hospital in an ambulance, the police said.

title: North Castle Partners Promotes Executive
description: North Castle Partners, a Greenwich, Conn., subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding, has promoted Lynn A. Rotando, 41, to president and chief operating officer.

title: COMPUCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Guardian President Gets 2 Top Posts
description: The Guardian Life Insurance Company of America said yesterday that its president for the last four years, John C. Angle, had been elected chairman and chief executive.

title: NEWHALL LAND & FARMING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including a net gain of $4.8 million from the sale of land.

title: Correction:
description: Because of a typographical error, a letter yesterday from Robert P. Neuschel on Conrail gave an incorrect figure for the 1972-83 rise in the Consumer Price Index. It should have read 137 percent,

title: Samuel Mammel Gives A Piano Recital
description: Samuel Mammel's program of piano music at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday afternoon balanced less- known contemporary pieces with standard familiarities by Chopin and Liszt.

title: SOME VETERANS MAY FACE CURB ON HEALTH CARE
description: New rules being drafted by the Reagan Administration would establish a rigorous test of financial need for health benefits for veterans less that 65 years old and would deny services to those judged able to afford private medical care.

title: Cooke Buys Elmendorf
description: He already has a Super Bowl championship to his credit and is currently trying for another.

title: A SYMBOL OF PEACE, A SYMBOL OF CONFLICT
description: Behold the season of symbols: a Yule log and goose, a holly branch with berries, eight candles on a silver menorah, mistletoe and a mythical sleigh.

title: FEW LASTING HEALTH EFFECTS FOUND AMONG INDIA GAS-LEAK SURVIVORS
description: The gas that escaped from a Union Carbide Corporation plant here Dec. 3 killed at least 2,000 people and injured perhaps 150,000 more, but it has thus far caused remarkably little lasting damage to the stunned survivors.

title: 4TH-QUARTER G.N.P. RISE PUT AT 2.8%
description: The economy is expanding at a 2.8 percent annual rate in the current quarter, somewhat faster than most analysts have been expecting, the Commerce Department's ''flash'' estimate of gross national product showed today.

title: U.S. EXPERTS CITE UNESCO BENEFITS
description: American scientists, scholars and cultural organizations stand to lose significant benefits through the abandonment of Unesco membership, according to many experts in cultural and scientific fields and others who have worked through the organization's agencies and related programs.

title: COURT SAYS THE STATE'S JUDGES CAN'T BE FORCED TO QUIT AT 70
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan has ruled that the state provision forcing judges to retire at 70 violates the United States Constitution. The ruling has raised troubling questions among state officials.

title: Celtic Home Streak Ends
description: Terry Cummings scored 10 of his game-

title: TEST-TUBE METHODS SPEEDING OUTPUT OF DISEASE-FREE STOCK
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla.

title: KOCH BACKS A NEW SITE FOR A BRONX TRASH PLANT
description: Mayor Koch, in an effort to win Board of Estimate approval for a new citywide garbage disposal plan, agreed yesterday to shift the site of a proposed incinerator in the Bronx.

title: ANALYSTS CUT RETAIL PROFIT ESTIMATES
description: Several of Wall Street's top brokerages yesterday lowered their earlier estimates of fourth-quarter earnings for the nation's largest retailers because of disappointing Christmas sales.

title: A SANTA FOR DEAF YOUNGSTERS
description: A college student who said he learned sign language to cheat in high school is now putting his skills to good use: communicating with deaf children as a Santa Claus at a shopping mall.

title: RULE EASED ON OWNING TV STATIONS
description: The Federal Communications Commission voted today to permit a single company to own as many as 12 television stations, provided that the stations do not collectively reach more than 25 percent of the nation's viewing audience.

title: A Diner Owner Anticipates
description: If the Jacob K. Javits Convention

title: Plastics Plant Charged With Polluting Delaware
description: Delaware's air pollution regulations face their first court test after a lawsuit filed Tuesday by the state against the Formosa Plastics Corporation for releasing a toxic and flammable gas into the atmosphere.

title: Fire Shuts Down Indian Point Plant
description: Leaking hydrogen gas burst into flames last night at the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant, forcing a shutdown of the plant for several days, Con Edison officials said.

title: 34TH CHESS GAME IS DRAWN
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov played to a draw today in the 34th game of their championship match.

title: Man, Tired of Rejection, Shoots Three, Police Say
description: A man described by the police as a drifter ''tired of being rejected by women'' opened fire with a revolver in a public library today, killing one woman and wounding two others, the authorities said.

title: MANY CONTRIBUTIONS FOR NEEDIEST CASES HONOR LOVED ONES
description: Many gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are inspired by fond memories of family members whose lives and actions reflected love for others and expressed the virtue of concern for the unfortunate.

title: New Jersey's Fine Free Ride In most places, on New Year's Eve, responsible partygoers will agree on who's driving - who will nobly stick to diet soda for the evening so as to stay sober and be able to drive others home safely. New Jersey has demonstrated that though responsibility and nobility may falter, there's another way.
description: Last year, New Jersey Transit pioneered the idea of giving free service on all buses and trains from 6 P.M. New Year's Eve to 6 A.M. the next morning. The program included extra trains and transit officers to keep order.

title: ISRAEL ASKS FOR $4.85 BILLION IN U.S. AID, A RECORD
description: Israel today submitted its largest aid request ever to the United States, asking for $4.05 billion in economic and military assistance for 1986 and an additional $800 million in emergency financing for 1985.

title: Plunkett Gets Call
description: Jim Plunkett , who has played less than three quarters of a game since being injured Oct. 7, will start at quarterback for the Los Angeles Raiders in the American Football Conference wild-card playoff game at Seattle on Saturday. ''I feel Jim's experience is vital,'' Coach Tom Flores said yesterday.

title: BRAKES ON LEVERAGED BUYOUTS
description: Republicbank Dallas used to be one of the most active Southwest banks funneling money into the leveraged buyouts of corporations. But nowadays, when John R. Bunten, vice chairman of the bank, listens to deal makers present him with such written proposals he said he usually has the same reaction: ''I throw the piece of paper in the air and say, 'No way; adios, boys.' ''

title: 2 FOUNDATIONS GIVE $25 MILLION TO AID HOMELESS
description: Thousands of the nation's homeless people will soon receive free health care and social services through a $25 million grant from two charitable foundations.

title: PAULEY PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-The company broke even in the latest fourth quarter. c-After an extraordinary charge of $2,694,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $266,000 for the year.

title: Kosher Food at Ordination
description: It is a specially ecumenical season

title: FARM SUPPORTS HELP CONSUMERS
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Clifton B. McFeely promoted to senior vice president at Dancer Fitzgerald Sample.

title: McDonnell Unit
description: A subsidiary of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation received a $145.2 million contract for 60 Navy and 48 Air Force cruise missiles, the Defense Department said. In addition, the Navy gave the same unit $9.7 million for engineering services for cruise missile guidance sets.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT BY U.S. ON ITS WITHDRAWAL FROM UNESCO
description: Following is the text of a statement on the United States withdrawal from Unesco that was read today by Assistant Secretary of State Gregory J. Newell at the State Department:

title: GULTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $16,000 for the quarter and $463,000 for the 9 months. c-After a loss of $674,000 from discontinued operations and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $2,172,000.

title: :'COTTON CLUB' IS NEITHER A SMASH NOR A DISASTER
description: After five years of the sort of behind-the-scenes pyrotechnics that are normally confined to celluloid, ''The Cotton Club'' made a debut last week that was almost startlingly calm. The movie, which received mixed reviews, took in $2.9 million over the weekend, a respectable if unspectacular box-office revenue that placed it fourth after ''Beverly Hills Cop,'' ''Dune'' and ''2010.''

title: CONCEPT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $49,000 and a tax credit of $45,000.

title: UNCERTAINTY IS OLDEST RAM'S NEWEST FOE
description: In 1971, Richard M. Nixon was the President, Eric Dickerson was a fifth- grader in Sealy, Tex., and Jack Youngblood, a defensive lineman from the University of Florida, arrived in California feeling ''completely lost'' as the first-round draft choice of the Los Angeles Rams.

title: Technology; Computer's Aid In Gas Alert
description: LAST March 14 a chemical spill occurred at a

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECHES IN PEKING
description: Following are excerpts from speeches today by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, as recorded by The Associated Press, and by Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang, as provided in official translation, at the signing of the agreement on the future of Hong Kong.

title: Mexico Cuts Debt Payment Because of delays in completing a complicated debt rescheduling package, Mexico's top finance official said yesterday that the nation would not keep a pledge to prepay foreign creditor banks $1 billion of a $5 billion loan by the end of the year.
description: But Finance Minister Jesus Silva- Herzog said that as a sign of good faith the Mexicans would pay the banks $250 million by Jan. 3.

title: NATPAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: DEVILS WIN, TIE 2 CLUB MARKS
description: The Devils tied two club records tonight - longest winning streak and longest unbeaten streak - in a 3-2 victory over the Penguins. The triumph moved New Jersey over Pittsburgh and the Rangers into fourth place in the Patrick Division.

title: Polynice Returns
description: Olden Polynice , the center who left Virginia's basketball team two weeks ago, has rejoined the squad and is expected to be in uniform tonight when the Cavaliers play Randolph Macon. Polynice withdrew from the team and went into seclusion because of heavy public criticism after his exoneration by the university's student honor committee on an academic-cheating charge.

title: Rare Parrot Stolen in Poland
description: A rare parrot from Borneo, worth more than $3,000, has been stolen from the zoo in Wroclaw in southwestern Poland, a zoo official said today. ''It is the only parrot of its kind in Poland and is so rare that we fear it may be smuggled out of the country,'' the official said. Zoo officals said two youths broke into an aviary to steal the bird.

title: EXPENSIVE EMPTY JOB
description: To the Editor:

title: Gould to Take A Write-Down CHICAGO, Dec. 19 - Gould
description: Inc. said it intends to take a

title: PENTAGON BUDGET POLITICS
description: The intramural struggle that regularly opens the Reagan Administration's annual budget process has produced still another victory by Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger in winning the President's protection against deep cuts. The vanquished ''pragmatists'' within the Administration, however, are hardly seething and are, in fact, quietly claiming some comfort in the sheer predictability of the process.

title: 7 NATIONS AGREE TO STEEL CURBS
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that it had concluded pacts with seven leading steel exporting countries calling for reduction in their shipments to the United States by 30 percent next year.

title: TREATMENT OF KIDNEY STONE WITHOUT SURGERY APPROVED
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved the use of a device that crumbles kidney stones with shock waves and permits them to be passed without surgery.

title: CHICANO ART AND ARTISTS
description: THE ostensible subject of ''The Mask of El Zarco'' is El Zarco Guerrero, an Arizona artist who makes masks. The actual subject, and not a bad one either, is Chicano art in the Southwest. What is it, and what makes it Chicano? The documentary will be seen on Channel 13 at 10 tonight.

title: CITY SPACE FOR A NATURALIST'S COLLECTIONS
description: IN the space of a few minutes,

title: Competition For Intelsat
description: The Federal Communications Commission today began exploring the merits of allowing private companies to compete with the nonprofit cooperative Intelsat in offering international satellite communications.

title: BROKERS' HOLIDAY SPIRITS RALLY
description: On Wall Street, the spirit of Christmas had to wait for a stock market rally.

title: VALSPAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
PHOTON SOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PLACES FOR VIEWING ALL THE TRIMMINGS
description: FOLLOWING are some of the historic houses in the New York area with period Christmas decorations.

title: FAMILY HEALTH SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-including a tax credit of $35,000.

title: SOVIET DESERTER IS CALLED UNWILLING TO WORK
description: Nikolai Ryzhkov, a Soviet Army deserter who asked to go home after a year in the United States, was described today by friends as a homesick and undisciplined youth who showed little interest in working or in learning English.

title: GUARD AT NAZI DEATH CAMP LOSES LATE APPEAL TO HALT DEPORTATION
description: Two Justices of the Supreme Court refused today to prevent the deportation of a former German Nazi death camp guard, Feodor Fedorenko, who has lived in the United States for 35 years.

title: Bowman Tops Record
description: Scotty Bowman became the National Hockey League's career leader in victories tonight, guiding the Buffalo Sabres past the Chicago Black Hawks, 6-3. The victory was his 691st, eclipsing the mark of Dick Irvin, who coached from 1940-1955.

title: Books: Merton Portraits
description: THE SEVEN MOUNTAINS OF THOMAS

title: COSOPOLITAN CARE reports earnings for Qtr tO Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $95,172 for the quarter and $182,571 for the 9 months.

title: First City Bid For Scovill
description: The FCP Acquisition Corporation, a subsidiary of First City Properties Inc., offered yesterday to buy all the outstanding common shares of Scovill Inc. for $35 a share in a deal that would be worth $427 million.

title: SUPERPOWER VIEWS ON COMING TALKS
description: Recent visits to Moscow and then to Washington reveal quite different attitudes regarding the upcoming talks between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko.

title: Kidnapped Bronx Boy Is Returned Unharmed
description: A 7-year-old epileptic boy who was kidnapped from a Bronx school on Monday was returned unharmed to his mother yesterday by the woman's estranged boyfriend, the police said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bank of New York has elected G.H. Denniston a senior vice president.

title: Ted Hughes Is Named English Poet Laureate
description: Ted Hughes was named England's new poet laureate today. The son of a Yorkshire carpenter, Mr. Hughes succeeds Sir John Betjeman who died earlier this year.

title: THE CITY ; Landlords Indicted For Harassment
description: Two landlords were indicted yesterday on charges of conspiring to terrorize tenants and force them out of 17 Manhattan apartment buildings.

title: Kingman Stays
description: After testing the free-agent market, Dave Kingman , the former Met slugger who rejuvenated his career last season as the designated hitter for the A's, has decided to stay with Oakland and has come to an agreement on a one-year contract, according to his agent, Jack Childers . Kingman, who earned $715,000 last season, will reportedly get $850,000 under the new accord. . . . Bud Harrelson, the former shortstop for the Mets who managed their Little Falls (N.Y.) farm club to a New York-Penn League championship in his rookie season as a manager this year, has been named to manage their club at Columbia, S.C., in the South Atlantic League.

title: CAMPS FOR BHOPAL EVACUEES TO CLOSE TODAY
description: As the process of converting lethal methyl isocyanate into a pesticide approached its final stages today, the Madhya Pradesh government announced that it would close refugee camps set up for thousands of Bhopal residents who were evacuated from their homes after some of the gas escaped from a nearby plant earlier this month.

title: A 'DEEPLY MOVED' JAVITS ATTENDS CONVENTION CENTER'S TOPPING OUT
description: After two years of construction delays and political fights, New York City's convention center celebrated a construction milestone yesterday as it was renamed for former Senator Jacob K. Javits.

title: FUTURES/OPTIONS ; Uncertainty on OPEC Sends Oil Prices Down
description: Prices of crude oil, heating oil and gasoline fell to new contract lows in trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange today, reflecting anticipation that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will be unable to regain control of the oil pricing system at its year-end meeting in Geneva. In related developments, the British pound fell to new lows at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and precious metals were flat.

title: 'ADJOURNED' SUBPOENA
description: WASHINGTON The House Ethics Committee was

title: GANDHI LANDSLIDE IS FORECAST IN INDIAN VOTING NEXT WEEK
description: With India's election five days away, indications are that Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party will win a landslide victory at the polls and a commanding majority in Parliament.

title: A NOTE TO READERS
description: On Nov. 15, this page published an article by Donald Carroll, titled ''Truly Inspired Gibberish,'' making light of the malapropisms, or fractured English, that could be found abroad - a sign in a Jordanian tailor's shop, for example, reading: ''Order your summers suit. Because is big rush we will execute customers in strict rotation.'' On Nov. 26, The New York Times received a complaint from Bill Bryson, a British editor and writer, asking it to compare its article ''with an article of mine from which Mr. Carroll would appear to have drawn considerable - not to say literal - inspiration.''

title: A Popular Appointment
description: Career Foreign Service workers are enthusiastic over reports that the new director general of the Foreign Service is to be George S. Vest, a popular career diplomat. The official announcement of Mr. Vest's appointment is expected soon.

title: Rolf Tietgens Is Dead at 73;German-Born Photographer
description: Rolf Tietgens, a photographer whose work is represented in the permanent photography collection of the Museum of Modern Art, died Dec. 11 at the Beekman-Downtown Hospital in Manhattan. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: NORDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $756,000 for the quarter and $2,066,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $2,082,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Advertising; McCann's Orderly Transition
description: CONSIDERING the major crises that have plagued the management careers of Willard C. Mackey Jr. and Robert L. James, when the latter replaces the former as chief executive of McCann-Erickson on March 1 it will be the epitome of orderly transitions.

title: PLAN TO CLEAN BOSTON HARBOR IS ADOPTED IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: Under a deadline imposed by a State Superior Court judge, the Massachusetts Legislature today approved the creation of a new agency to clean up Boston Harbor.

title: YARDNEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
AIRLINE GROUNDS FLIGHTS AFTER ACCIDENT IN SOUTH
description: The charter airline that had an airplane crash Sunday while carrying a college basketball team told the Government yesterday that it was halting all operations pending an official inquiry into possible rules violations, a Government spokesman said.

title: TALKS ADJOURNED
description: Negotiators for major league baseball's owners and players finished exchanging ideas today on a basic agreement to replace the one that expires Dec. 31. The two sides ended two days of meetings and are scheduled to meet again on Jan. 9 in New York.

title: Milwaukee Rejects Bid For Widow's Pension
description: The Milwaukee Common Council has rejected a bid to give full pension benefits to the widow of a police officer who died of leukemia last week. The officer lost his fight to stay alive until Christmas Eve, when he would have qualified for the pension automatically.

title: Questions for Mr. Meese
description: To be cleared of criminal suspicion is a relief but not a qualification for high office. Yet when a court-appointed independent counsel found no basis for indicting Edwin Meese in September, President Reagan saw the judgment as ''vindication'' of his nomination to be Attorney General. Now Robert Dole, the new Senate majority leader, says Mr. Meese, having endured Judiciary Committee grilling and a six-month special investigation, merits swift confirmation next month.

title: COMPUSCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $217,000 for the quarter and $470,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $325,000 for the quarter and $518,000 for the 6 months.

title: Officer Is Killed In Gun Incident
description: A rookie Housing Authority police officer who graduated first in his class Monday fatally shot himself in the head last night with his service revolver, apparently accidentally, the police said.

title: SERVOMATIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SOVIET UNION LOFTS A SHUTTLE MODEL IN AMBITIOUS PLAN
description: The Soviet Union yesterday launched a scale model of what American experts called a small, re-usable, winged spaceplane. It orbited the earth once, glided back into the atmosphere and splashed down in the Black Sea like a bottom-heavy speedboat.

title: Really Rocking
description: The British rock group Duran Duran has come up with an idea that could excite the sailing world in much the same way that its new releases stir the recording business.

title: U.S. EXTENSION OF HEALTH PLAN IN JERSEY SEEN
description: The Reagan Administration has agreed to continue New Jersey's pioneering hospital rate system, despite strong misgivings among some of its health financing and budget officials, Federal and state health officials said yesterday.

title: FOR MISKITOS, PROBLEM IS 'CONTRA' ATTACKS
description: To the Editor:

title: MULLEN HELPS PUT RANGERS IN LAST PLACE
description: The return of Ron Greschner after a 20-game absence and Barry Beck after missing two games helped the Rangers perform better than in recent games last night at Madison Square Garden, but not well enough to avoid another defeat, this time by 5-4 to the Winnipeg Jets.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ROOM FOR CHILDREN
description: If the baby boomers want to take the

title: PROJECT TO HELP YOUTHS AND SPRUCE UP 125TH STREET IS BEGUN
description: Keith Hogan, a 21-year-old high school dropout from Queens, joined Mayor Koch and David Rockefeller yesterday in marking the start of a $150,000 pilot project to educate and employ 20 young New Yorkers and to clean up Harlem's 125th Street commercial strip.

title: EXTRADITION: HOT TOPIC IN CRUSADE ON TERRORISM
description: The Reagan Administration, trying to rally the community of nations against international terrorists, is increasingly frustrated by some judicial rulings on the homefront that stand in the way of its crusade.

title: 2 RELIGIOUS PARTIES IN ISRAEL'S COALITION RESOLVE THEIR FIGHT
description: A dispute that threatened to break up Israel's three- month-old national unity Government was resolved early today.

title: SINGAPORE ELECTION TO TEST OPPOSITION'S ROLE
