description: A million and a half Singaporeans are expected to vote Saturday in a national election in which the major question is whether Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew and his Peoples Action Party will again win every seat in Parliament.

title: GREAT AMERICAN MANAGEMENT & INVESTMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: NAHAMA & WEAGANT ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: AT NEW MEAD HALL, A BYGONE WORLD
description: Margaret Mead came to the American Museum of Natural History as an assistant curator in 1925, after the Pacific sojourn that was to form the basis of her book ''Coming of Age in Samoa,'' and remained associated with the museum for 52 years, until her death in 1978.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press on Monday from Jasper, Ala., about the crash landing of a plane, misidentified its owner and operator. It was owned by Air Resorts, a California- based charter airline, and chartered by Tennessee Valley Airways of Nashville.

title: QADDAFI HAS 'AMICABLE' TALKS IN SPAIN
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, said today that his meeting with Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez on Wednesday night had been amicable and had dealt mostly with developments in northwest Africa.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1984 International American flexibility on arms control was stressed by a senior Reagan Administration official. He said Washington would be willing to negotiate its long-term missile defense plan along with seeking cuts in offensive weapons systems when talks resume with Moscow early next month. (Page A1, Column 6.) A rare U.S.-Soviet cooperative effort arranged quietly between American and Soviet scientists was reported by a psysicist at the University of Chicago. He said that an American comet-dust detector was aboard the Soviet Vega spacecraft and had been tested successfully as the craft headed toward a rendezvous with Halley's comet in 1986. (A1:3.)

title: THREE KILLED IN EXPLOSION IN OHIO AT A GARBAGE-FUELED POWER PLANT
description: An explosion and fire ripped apart a tower today at a power plant fueled by recycled garbage, killing at least three workers and badly burning six, the authorities said.

title: HOLIDAY SURPRISES AND HAPPENINGS
description: Almost nothing is impossible in New York, but some things are more unlikely than others. The modern-day equivalent of the true love celebrated in traditional song isn't likely, even at this season, to be presented with partridges in pear trees and other such delights that filled the 12 days of Christmas. But it matters not a whit. There are urban pleasures and surprises equally pleasing to the eye and, in some cases, almost as esoteric that unfold only for the holiday season. All that's required is a stout heart, sturdy shoes and a nudge in the right direction.

title: Non-drinker Who Had Stroke Arrested as Drunken Driver
description: A 70- year-old man was arrested for drunken driving and held for three hours until his wife arrived at the police station and it was discovered that he had suffered a cerebral hemorrhage.

title: Paiute Oil Filing
description: The Paiute Oil and Mining Corporation said it had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: CHINA EASES RULES ON VISITORS' ENTRY
description: China has adopted a new visa policy that will allow at least some businessmen and tourists to fly to China and apply for visas on arrival at the Peking airport, but it remains unclear how freely the new policy will be applied.

title: Yemen Reports Large Oil Discovery
description: President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen said today that his country had discovered ''large'' quantities of oil that could be exported through the Red Sea in two years or less.

title: MacTavish Tells Students Of a Lethal Combination
description: On other wintry days, in other years, he spent his mornings gliding along a hockey rink in workouts, preparing for the evenings, when he wore the black and gold of the Boston Bruins.

title: GIANT WREATH AT CLOISTERS
description: They're not strictly medieval, but we do need varieties like baby's breath and German statice,'' Susan Leach said as she discussed some of the dozens of subtly hued flowers and leaves that grace an eight-foot-diameter wreath now suspended in the main rotunda of the Cloisters Museum.

title: THE SWEET SMELL OF SUCCESS AT BLOOMINGDALE'S
description: ''HOW can I help you with Giorgio today?'' With $150-an-ounce perfume and $40 cologne and a pair of $47.50 perfumed candles, that's how. It is difficult this week to walk across the main floor of Bloomingdale's and not be confronted with those opportunities by Diana Romanello, the store's enthusiastic ''fragrance representative'' for Giorgio, the Rodeo Drive boutique.

title: ABS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $115,000 for the quarter and year and tax credits of $356,000 for the quarter and $981,000 for the year. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $2,367,000 for the quarter and $4,218,000 for the year.

title: STRUGGLING KNICKS ROMP OVER HAPLESS CAVALIERS
description: The crowd was sparse, the shooting was poor and the fouls were numerous last night at Madison Square Garden, where the Knicks proved in a 112- 97 victory over Cleveland that a struggling team in the National Basketball Association is considerably better than the worst one.

title: RICKY ROSENTHAL
description: Ricky Rosenthal, a correspondent for National Public Radio at the United Nations, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 54 years old.

title: U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS IN ECONOMIC SLUMP
description: At a time when winter tourism figures are delighting resort owners, residents of the United States Virgin Islands are complaining of mounting government financial problems and a slumping industrial base.

title: CONOLOG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
9 More Bahais Dead in Iran
description: The State Department said today that it had received reports from Iran that nine more members of the Bahai sect have died in prison. A Department spokesman said Wednesday that six people were executed in Teheran on Dec. 9 and that three others died in Tabriz in November. Nineteen others were reportedly under death sentences.

title: CALNY INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Nov 3
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect an acquisition in January 1984 which was accounted for on a pooling-of-interests basis. Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 50 percent stock dividend paid in November 1983.

title: DOWN ON THE MALL
description: Despite the contentions of political activists, grass is not growing in the foyer of the White House. But today sheep were grazing on the Mall.

title: Texaco Unit Gets a Chief
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it had named Roland M. Routhier to succeed James W. Kinnear as president of Houston-based Texaco U.S.A., its largest division, effective Jan. 1.

title: RHODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
PUBLISHING: REVIVING HIMES NOVELS
description: CHESTER HIMES'S death in Spain in November came only a few months before the expatriate black writer was to enjoy a modest revival in the United States. For example, Schocken Books will soon distribute ''The Crazy Kill'' and ''Cotton Comes to Harlem,'' two of some 20 novels written by Mr. Himes, and next month Howard University Press will publish ''A Case of Rape,'' the most controversial of them.

title: 'MURPH THE SURF' ENDS PRISON TERM
description: Jack (Murph the Surf) Murphy, the former surfing champion who stole the Star of India sapphire from the American Museum of Natural History and was sentenced to life for killing a young woman, walked out of prison today, taking his first steps to parole.

title: 'NOSY ECONOMISTS' PRYING INTO POLAND
description: Poland's impending membership in the International Monetary Fund may have the one disadvantage of legitimizing the disdained Jaruzelski regime. But Washington should take comfort in knowing that economists can now get busy undermining Soviet influence in Poland - something that the Poles themselves have been unable to do.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 10.75-11.25 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PENWEST LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding figures are not available because the company was spun off from Univar Corp. in March 1984.

title: Bumpurs's Family ToSeek$10Million
description: The family of Eleanor Bumpurs, the elderly woman who was shot to death by the police during eviction proceedings at her Bronx housing project, filed a $10 million wrongful death claim yesterday against the city and the Housing Authority.

title: Rabbi's Quick Hop
description: Q. How can you light a candle on the

title: CENTER APPROVED FOR HARLEM, DESPITE CRITICS
description: WILLIAM R. GREER

title: Bronx Bird-Hunt
description: The yellow-bellied sapsucker will be sought, along with the brown creeper, the brown thrasher and other species during a bird count on Sunday at Wave Hill, Independence Avenue and 249th Street, the Bronx.

title: LORD ST. OSWALD
description: Lord St. Oswald, a journalist who escaped a death sentence in the Spanish Civil War and later served in the British Government, died Wednesday.

title: THE REAL MEETS THE PLASTIC AT ART THEATER'S SATIRICAL BALL
description: Whatever the New York Art Theater Institute's Waltz Evening lacked in formality the other night was more than compensated for with high good humor, a carefree style and a most engaging sort of throwaway elegance.

title: Mayda C. Lannik Is Wed To Dr. Milton M. Gardner
description: -relations consultant known professionally as Marsha Lane, was married yesterday to Dr. Milton M. Gardner, an obstetrician and gynecologist practicing in Merrick and Levittown, L.I. Justice Arthur D. Spatt of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony in his chambers in Garden City, L.I.

title: Milwaukee Road Rulings by I.C.C.
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission made decisions that favored each of the two companies bidding for the bankrupt Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad. At the request of a Federal judge in Chicago, the I.C.C. had been asked to rule on a sweetened $780 million proposal by the Chicago and North Western Transportation Company for the Milwaukee Road.

title: PRESS FREEDOM WITHERS, REPORT SAYS
description: The International Press Institute said today that press freedom continued to wither in 1984 as dozens of countries intimidated journalists with threats of expulsion, imprisonment and murder.

title: Suspect in Slaying Pleads Not Guilty
description: A 22-year-old Bronx man pleaded not guilty yesterday at his arraignment on charges of murdering Caroline Isenberg on the roof of her Upper West Side apartment building Dec. 2.

title: THE SCREEN: ALAN PARKER'S 'BIRDY'
description: THE most unusual thing about ''Birdy,'' Willam Wharton's novel about a boy who develops an overwhelming erotic fascination with avian life, is its lack of allegorical implications. The story of Birdy, who actually reaches the point of imagining that he has fathered a family of canaries, can be taken at face value. So can the parallel tale of Al, the boyhood friend who years later, after suffering grave wartime injuries, returns to coax the adult Birdy out of his madness.

title: FLORAFAX INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
LEBANON ARMY ASSUMES CONTROL IN PORT CITY
description: The Lebanese Army, in an effort to end months of factional fighting, took over control of the northern port of Tripoli today from private militias.

title: ASTRONOMERS SEE A GALAXY FORMING
description: Optical and radio astronomers say tens of thousands of new stars may be bursting into existence in the formation of a new galaxy.

title: Farewell at the Fed
description: The city's bankers said farewell

title: SENATOR 30 YEARS
description: Lister Hill, a United States Senator from Alabama for three decades who authored some of most important health and education legislation in the years following World War II, died of pneumonia yesterday at the Jackson Hospital in Montgomery, Ala. He He was 89 years old.

title: Bridge:CScopeforDefenders
description: When the final tournament of the 1984 New York bridge calendar begins today at the Sheraton Centre, 53d Street and Seventh Avenue, most of the top-ranked players will have their sights set on the Knockout Team event that begins tonight at 8and ends Sunday night. But there are plenty of shorter events at the Winter Regional of the Greater New York Bridge Association for players of all tastes and levels of experience.

title: Teachers Approve Contract
description: Chicago teachers voted by a 3-to-1 margin today to approve the contract that ended their two-week strike against the nation's third-largest school system. Classes for the city's 430,000 public school students resumed Monday, the day after the Chicago Teachers Union and the city's school board reached an agreement calling for a 4.5 percent pay raise and a one-time 2.5 percent bonus to be paid in March.

title: SCOUTING ; Working Holiday
description: Kelly Case thought she was coming to New York for a vacation last week when the harness-racing season ended on the Scarborough-Lewiston minor-league circuit in Maine. Instead, the 22-year-old Miss Case, whose 146 triumphs make her the leading female driver in the country this year, has been adding to her victory total at Yonkers Raceway.

title: FILM: EDWARDS'S 'MICKI AND MAUDE'
description: ''MICKI AND MAUDE,'' Blake Edwards's blithe new farce written by Jonathan Reynolds, is the kind of movie that dares to ask timely questions:

title: Underestimating Santa
description: What is the most famous newspaper editorial ever written? A.: ''Yes, Virginia . . .,'' and if you doubt it, try naming another famous editorial.

title: SCOU
description: The years since Walt Frazier's retirement in 1980 have been both chastening and enlightening, a time of learning how to live and work in a world that doesn't applaud his every move, as Madison Square Garden fans did when he was the one and only Clyde.

title: Gov. Dukakis Signs Into Law Bill for Cleaning Up Harbor
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis signed legislation Wednesday night creating an independent board to clean up Boston Harbor.

title: RAMS ON OFFENSE: SEE DICKERSON RUN
description: In a game against the St. Louis Cardinals this season, the Los Angeles Rams had a third down and needed 35 yards for a first down. Most teams in that situation would pass.

title: FLYERS END DEVILS' STREAK
description: The Devils had their five-game unbeaten streak stopped tonight by the Philadelphia Flyers, 8-4. The Devils, who had won three straight to equal a club record, have beaten the Flyers at the Spectrum only once in 11 years, on Nov. 29.

title: And Now, Duane
description: Among the six declared candidates for the post of Democratic national chairman, Duane Garrett, a San Francisco lawyer, has at least two distinctions. (1) As the owner of an art dealership specializing in 19th-century American works, he has pledged to ''use my experience and contacts in the arts to build an inventory of paintings, prints, photos and sculpture to be auctioned or sold'' to provide party campaign funds for 1988. (2) He has the only campaign biography that, after an initial identification in full, refers to its subject solely by first name: ''Duane served as a member . . . Duane's political activities date back . . .''

title: NEW YORK AREA COSTS RISE BY 0.5% IN MONTH
description: Driven by sharply higher housing and utility costs, the Consumer Price Index for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose one-half of 1 percent in November, a far steeper increase than the nationwide figure of two-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Ethiopians Reported To Attack Somali Towns
description: Somalia said Ethiopian troops, backed by tanks, artillery and jets, attacked several Somali towns and villages this morning before being driven back.

title: Transactions BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Named Jim Napier to the newly created position of field director of player development. TEXAS (AL) - Signed Luis Pujols, catcher, to a one-year contract and assigned him to Oklahoma City of the American Association. COLLEGE COLUMBIA - Named Jim Gossett head trainer. FOOTBALL DENVER (AFC) - Received a 1985 second-round draft pick from Tampa Bay to complete the deal for Steve DeBerg, quarterback. HOCKEY DEVILS (NHL) - Recalled Hannu Kampuri, goalie, from the Maine Mariners of the A.H.L.
description: Transactions

title: CHIRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MARSHALL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
INTERMOUNTAIN LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
U.S. WON'T BAR BRITISH FARE CUTS
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it would not challenge a proposal by British Airways to cut its fares between New York and London.

title: Pakistani Leader Gets 98% of Referendum Vote
description: Pakistan's President, Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, won 98 percent of the vote Wednesday in a nationwide referendum endorsing a five-year extension of his presidency and his plan to apply Islamic law strictly, election officials said today.

title: STATE 'SURPLUS' CAN FEED HUNGARY CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Slowing to Save Energy
description: The course of development for most National Basketball Association teams usually goes something like this: They spend the first few weeks of the season re-acquainting themselves with each other and their playing habits. Then they fine-tune their running game, using the fast break at every opportunity in an effort gain easy baskets. Finally, they hone their half-court offense, a strategy that requires precision passing and screening, as well as deliberate and efficient execution.

title: THE REGION ; Auditors Report Abuses in Hiring
description: State auditors said Wednesday that hundreds of state employees had got their jobs without taking competitive tests, a violation of Connecticut's merit hiring laws.

title: BACH AND AN IRISH CHRISTMAS
description: ON the weekend before Christmas, television is getting into the holiday spirit with a fanfare of appropriate music specials. The most ambitious and rewarding is a two-part presentation on public television's ''Great Performances'' series of Johann Sebastian Bach's ''Christmas Oratorio.'' Tonight from 9 to 10:30, Channel 13 will carry ''Part I: The Nativity,'' with the first three of the oratorio's six cantatas. ''Part II: The Epiphany'' will be broadcast next Friday at 9.

title: ALBERT G. REDPATH
description: Albert G. Redpath, a lawyer and investment broker, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88 years old.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
U.S. DEVICE RIDING SOVIET SPACECRAFT
description: In a rare cooperative effort arranged quietly between American and Soviet scientists, an American comet-dust detector is aboard the Soviet Vega spacecraft heading toward a rendezvous with Halley's comet in 1986, a University of Chicago physicist announced yesterday.

title: CHESS TITLE MATCH TO BECOME LONGEST ONE IN MODERN ERA
description: After 34 games, the current world championship chess match in Moscow now shares with the 1927 series between Alexander Alekhine and Jose Raul Capablanca in Buenos Aires the distinction of being the longest such contest in the modern era.

title: A POWERFUL NEW CHIP REPORTED BY BELL LABS
description: In what could be a breakthrough in the manufacture of computer memory, scientists at Bell Laboratories said last night they had perfected a 1-million-bit memory circuit that could be mass-produced in about a year.

title: Bantam Gets Ferraro Book
description: Bantam Books won the auction to publish Geraldine A. Ferraro's proposed book about the 1984 Presidential campaign.

title: UNESCO HEAD SEES NO FINANCIAL HURT
description: The head of Unesco said in Yemen today that the American withdrawal from the agency would not harm its operations.

title: A WORLD CONCERN
description: George Shultz, the Secretary of State, assured the NATO allies at recent meetings in Brussels that in arms control talks with the Soviet Union the United States would be honestly in search of agreement and was therefore prepared to be flexible and fair in its demands.

title: Reason to Smile
description: Burt Hooton 's nickname, Happy, stems from irony, of course, because the veteran right-hander's expression is almost invariably somber. And last season he had even more reason than usual not to crack a smile.

title: The Whooping Cough Crisis Whooping cough once killed 7,000 American children a year and infected 265,000 more. It may again become a major killer if the problems now swirling around the vaccine are not speedily resolved.
description: Whooping cough vaccine is effective and quite safe. But not safe enough: It causes 1 or 2 deaths and about 32 cases of brain damage among every 10 million children immunized. As a result, parents in Britain lost confidence in the vaccine, and the proportion of children vaccinated steadily dropped through the mid-70's. The inevitable result was the return of whooping cough epidemics, with 100,000 cases and 28 deaths in three years. Japan has had a similar experience, losing 32 children a year for lack of immunity.

title: BIPARTISANSHIP'S USES IN A CONSTITUTIONAL SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: British Production Up
description: Britain's seasonally adjusted gross domestic product rose 1.9 percent in the third quarter from the second quarter and 5.4 percent from the third quarter of 1983, the Central Statistics Office said today.

title: WESTWOOD ONE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
PUNK ROCKERS KNOW MORE ABOUT FLAGS
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO IS URGED TO AVOID A RISE IN TUITION LEVEL
description: City University students gave Governor Cuomo a report card yesterday with an ''F'' on the subject of tuition policy crossed out and replaced by an ''incomplete.''

title: Jazz Center Benefit
description: The nonprofit Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street near East Third Street (505-5660), will hold its annual benefit for the center tonight from 9 to midnight.

title: People
description: * Paul Marcus was promoted to executive vice president, and Marc Rodgers and Leslie Amozig to senior vice presidents at Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson.

title: SAN JOSE CHOSEN FOR MUSEUM OF MODERN-DAY TECHNOLOGY
description: Planners have selected downtown San Jose as the site of a $95 million showcase for computer-age applied sciences and have hired the chief scientist of the Ontario Science Center as the executive director.

title: Chief Finance Officer At Best Products Quits
description: Robert M. Quinn, who was named senior vice president and chief financial officer last month of the Best Products Company, resigned suddenly this week. He is the second financial officer in seven months to leave the catalogue showroom retailer, which is based in Richmond.

title: FILM: 'PROTOCOL,' GOLDIE HAWN AT THE STATE DEPT.
description: ''PROTOCOL'' is a breezy, not entirely unpredictable comedy that was made to order for the gifted Goldie Hawn by Buck Henry, the writer, Herb Ross, the director, and Miss Hawn herself, who is the film's executive producer.

title: ART: EXPLANATIONS FOR 'SUCCESS OF FAILURE'
description: ''The Success of Failure'' brings to mind the ''bad painting'' show at the New Museum some years back and has a touch of the same disingenuousness. Still, the two events are quite different, for the bad paintings were deliberate. The failures, on view at Diane Brown Gallery, 100 Greene Street, are not.

title: TIMES CO. MAGAZINE PROMOTIONS
description: Several executives are being promoted in the magazine group of The New York Times Company, effective Jan. 1, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman of the company, announced yesterday.

title: AVONDALE MILLS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
description: b-Including a gain of $2,209,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: NEW PLAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SPORTS PEOPLE ; Davis Fueding Again
description: The feud between Commissioner Pete Rozelle and Al Davis , the Los Angeles Raiders' managing general partner, flared again yesterday when Davis charged that his team's opening playoff game against Seattle had been switched arbitrarily from Sunday to Saturday became of Rozelle's ''vehemence toward the Raiders.'' Davis said there was ''no conscionable reason, certainly no logical competitive reason, to have changed our wild card game . . . when the A.F.C. wild card game had been scheduled for Sunday for over a year.''

title: Butter Tainted, Giveaway Halted
description: New Jersey officials today indefinitely suspended the distribution of 2.9 million pounds of Federal surplus butter to 250,000 needy families around the state until they determine why some of the dairy product stored in a Newark warehouse became rancid.

title: U.S. ENDS INQUIRY IN FLORIDA INTO SOURCE OF CITRUS CANKER
description: Federal experts say they are ending their search for the source of tree-killing canker in Florida's citrus industry because it was like ''looking for a needle on Miami Beach.''

title: EDWARDS, A.G. & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ENGAGING NICARAGUA
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIGHAM YOUNG'S HIGH HOPES FACE TEST
description: PETER ALFANO

title: LEGISLATORS PASS BUDGET INCREASE FOR WESTCHESTER
description: FRANKLIN WHITEHOUSE

title: Farmers, in Protest, Apply for Food Stamps
description: Several hundred farmers lined up to apply for food stamps today in three Iowa cities in a protest to show the farm crisis is so severe some farmers can no longer afford to feed their families.

title: COMPUSHOP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: EVEN JUSTER JURIES
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''New York is the greatest city in the world, but cleanliness is not one of its greatest virtues - a fact that increasingly frustrates and angers all New Yorkers.'' - David Rockefeller. (B3:6.)

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday WINTER ON WINTER

title: U.S. SET TO DEPORT FORMER GUARD AT DEATH CAMP TO SOVIET UNION
description: A Nazi death camp guard from the Ukraine who came to the United States in 1949 is about to become the first war crimes suspect deported to the Soviet Union, a destination he himself selected, a Justice Department official said yesterday.

title: BROADWAY
description: A brand new musical, based on a good old classic, is going into workshop Dec. 31 and rehearsal March 11, and when it opens May 1, the name on the marquee will be ''Grover's Corners.'' So now you know that the classic is Thornton Wilder's ''Our Town,'' but you don't know that it's taken R. Tyler Gatchell Jr. and Peter Neufeld, the executive producers, two years to bring the project to fruition. Marge Champion is slated to do the choreography.

title: U.C.L.A.'S HAZZARD STAYS COOL IN A PRESSURE JOB
description: At Overbrook High School in Philadelphia, Walt Hazzard idolized Jackie Robinson. The Brooklyn Dodger star had not only integrated baseball, but also had played sports at U.C.L.A.

title: WHAT FUTURE FOR COMPUTERS IN SCHOOLS?
description: To the Editor:

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Prices Up on Money Report
description: The Federal Reserve Board announced yesterday that the nation's basic money supply rose by $3.8 billion in the week ended Dec. 10.

title: China-Japan Nuclear Talks
description: Japan and China ended five days of talks today on a long-term nuclear cooperation accord.

title: Study Links Anorexia To Thin, Weak Bones
description: Young women with anorexia nervosa, an obsessive fear of being fat that leads to self-starvation, often have thin, weak bones, but exercise appears to offset the loss of bone mass, a study says.

title: M.T.A. APPROVES AGREEMENT WITH CITY TO PERMIT SALE OF COLISEUM
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday approved an agreement with the city that will permit the sale of the New York Coliseum. Proceeds from the sale - an estimated $200 million - will be used to improve the city's transit system.

title: O.E.C.D. OPTIMISTIC ON ECONOMY IN '85
description: The economies of the world's industrialized countries are doing better than expected and overall prospects are the best in a decade, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Moscow dispatch Tuesday, about Russians who leave their homeland and later return, misidentified the operatic bass who died in Paris in 1938 and whose body was returned to Moscow this fall for reburial. He was Fyodor Chaliapin.

title: Economic Scene; Hopeful Signs, With Caveats
description: AS 1984 draws to a close, the economy is looking much better than it did in the dismal third quarter. Many economists had begun to worry that we had already entered a recession, but it now looks as though the economy will continue to advance at a moderate rate through 1985.

title: YOUTHS ON L.I. SPREADING CHEER TO LESS FORTUNATE
description: With the holidays nearing, 17-year-old Ingrid Skadberg began preparing for her family's annual Christmas reunion and searching for a way to spread cheer among less fortunate children.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD OFF 8.5 MILLION SHARES
description: The following Big Board companies show large changes:

title: MILITARY' ROLE IN SPACE
description: Next month's space shuttle mission, the first devoted entirely to Pentagon activities, culminates a decadelong shift in the nation's space program toward dominance by the military. The history of the American space program is replete with tension between those who would preserve space as a frontier for scientific exploration and those who would seize it as a soldier's ultimate high ground. But the shuttle project has gradually left the National Aeronautics and Space Administration a junior partner to the Defense Department in budgetary, technological and political strength.

title: Facing Realities in Cyprus Before his election as Secretary General of the United Nations, Javier Perez de Cuellar toiled for years as its mediator on Cyprus. He now believes that Greek and Turkish Cypriots have edged near enough to a compromise to justify a meeting between their leaders next month. If he has judged right, Cyprus could be removed from diplomacy's intensive care unit. The U.N. needs such a victory. May the force be with him.
description: It's been 20 years since the U.N. sent a peacekeeping unit to Cyprus, and a decade since Turkey invaded to protect a Turkish minority under siege. Everything about that intervention is in dispute but the results are not. The Turkish community, comprising 18 percent of Cyprus's 650,000 people, holds 37 percent of the land. A swap of populations completed the division of the island into the Greek-led Republic of Cyprus and the self-proclaimed Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus.

title: Datapoint Holding
description: An investment group led by Asher Edelman, a New York investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it holds 10.8 percent of the Datapoint Corporation.

title: Tanker Train Fire in Britain
description: An oil tanker train exploded today in a tunnel 200 feet under the Pennine Hills in central England, creating a series of fireballs and forcing firemen to run for their lives. Hundred-foot-high pillars of flame shot up from the tunnel through ventilator shafts as firemen sprayed thousands of gallons of foam into the 2,800-yard tunnel between Manchester and West Yorkshire. The explosions ripped through the tunnel after the 14- car freight train, carrying 100 tons of fuel, derailed in the tunnel, the police said.

title: TOPIC IN THE SEIZIEME: LES MISERABLES AT THE DOOR
description: Avenue Victor- Hugo runs from the Arc de Triomphe to the Bois de Boulogne. It is a straight, affluent mile and the main thoroughfare of the 16th Arrondissement, the city's borough of domesticized cash. Made elsewhere, money in Paris has a way of coming home to the seizi eme. The street is full of convenience stores - St. Laurent Rive Gauche, Courr eges, Daniel Hechter, Charles Jourdan, Guy Laroche, Celine. Convenience in the sense of being nearby: Avenue Victor-Hugo's branch boutiques are really Gold Coast lighters anchored just off the rich residential shore.

title: CITY INQUIRY INTO ZACCARO DEALINGS SAID TO BE NEAR CONCLUSION
description: The Manhattan District Attorney appears to be close to concluding a three- month investigation into financial dealings involving John A. Zaccaro, a lawyer for Mr. Zaccaro said yesterday.

title: THEATER: 'THE INCREDIBLY FAMOUS WILLY RIVERS'
description: IS it possible to write a play that

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP 0.2% IN MONTH, LEAST SINCE JUNE
description: The O.E.C.D. says economic prospects for the industrial countries are the best in a decade. Page D5.

title: Market Place; Military Stock Uncertainties
description: QUESTIONS about cuts in military spending are clouding the outlook for military-related stocks.

title: Consolidation Of Macy Units
description: The Macy Midwest division of R.H. Macy & Company will be consolidated with the company's Davison's division in Atlanta, effective Feb. 1., under the name of Macy's-Atlanta, Edward S. Finkelstein, chairman and chief executive officer of R.H. Macy, said yesterday.

title: Semiconductor Net Falls 35.6% SANTA CLARA, Calif., Dec.
description: 20 (AP) - The National Semiconductor Corporation said today that its profits fell 35.6 percent, to $8.5 million, or 10 cents

title: ART: 'FORCED SENTIMENT,' EXHIBITION BY 7 ARTISTS
description: ''FORCED SENTIMENT,'' an exhibition at Artists Space, 223 West Broadway, through Jan. 12, could also be called: ''Who's Afraid of Sentimentality?'' Robert Longo, the guest curator, has selected work by seven artists, all of them under 30, almost all of them, like him, involved with mixing media and appropriating images from popular culture. There are now generations of artists who seem to believe that popular culture is

title: FOR MIKE WALLACE, A WELCOME PAUSE FROM TRIAL
description: Mike Wallace said he was feeling better yesterday. His flu was nearly over. He didn't have to go downtown to the courtroom where Gen. William C. Westmoreland was suing CBS for $120 million. And he learned that the general's attorney would not be calling him as a witness.

title: THE EVENING HOUR
description: This was the week for Christmas

title: IF YOU BELIEVE IN SANTA, R.S.V.P.
description: The capital city comes close to party gridlock at this time of the year. But except for the decorations, there is little to distinguish most of these holiday affairs from the year-round social events built around politics and public relations.

title: 3 Arrested at Embassy In Protest of Apartheid
description: Three demonstrators were arrested today outside the South African Embassy in another of a series of protests against South Africa's policy of apartheid, or racial segregation.

title: PENTAGON TO SEEK INCREASED SECRECY
description: The Defense Department's chief spokesman, Michael I. Burch, said today that the Pentagon would seek tighter controls over the flow of military information through more vigorous use of existing regulations and possibly by seeking new laws.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. San Antonio Spurs, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. Artis Gilmore and George Gervin pay their only visit of the season to New Jersey.

title: CIRCUIT CITY STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
U.S. SEES PRIVATE SCHOOL ENROLLMENT SURGE IN 80'S
description: Private school enrollment has surged in the 1980's, with one in every eight American children now attending schools outside the public system, the United States Department of Education reported today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; American Natural Elects a Chairman
description: William T. McCormick Jr. has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the American Natural Resources Company, a Detroit-based energy concern. He replaces Arthur R. Seder Jr. who is retiring, the company said yesterday.

title: Polynice Returns
description: Olden Polynice, who left Virginia's basketball team after a controversy involving the school's honor code, returned tonight in a 69-53 victory over Randolph Macon.

title: BOARD OF ESTIMATE APPROVES PLAN FOR 5 INCINERATORS IN CITY
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday narrowly approved a plan to build a series of huge garbage-burning incinerators in the five boroughs to ease the burden on New York City's rapidly dwindling landfill space.

title: Some British Miners Vote to Ignore Union
description: Union leaders in Nottinghamshire, the center of opposition to the nine-month-old strike by British coal miners, voted today to put themselves beyond the national union's authority to make rules.

title: Latin-Jazz Quintet
description: The flutist Dave Valentin will lead his Latin-jazz quintet at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475- 8592), through Sunday. Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, and a $5 cover and one-drink minimum at the bar.

title: G.E. to Use Rock Video To Sell Tape Recorders
description: Not too long ago, about the only way to spread a message to the masses of teen-age consumers was through their kind of radio stations.

title: Military Contracts
description: The Lockheed-Georgia Company, a unit of the Lockheed Corporation, received a $1.3 billion Air Force contract to build eight C-5B aircraft, the Defense Department said.

title: ASA LTD reports earnings for As of Nov 30
AT THE MOVIES
description: AT least on the face of it, ''Dune'' doesn't seem to be the ideal movie for merchandising tie-ins. The science- fiction plot isn't easily followed, not even by children. The hero is on the dull side, the villain is a boil-covered fat man, and the film's most memorable creatures are gigantic worms. No matter. A complete line of ''Dune'' paraphernalia has hit the toy stores, with more expected if the movie catches on. If the film becomes popular enough, there may even be the ultimate tie-ins, ''Dune 2,'' ''Dune 3'' and so on. 1 ''A film needs to have a certain number of characters, creatures and vehicles, because a toy company needs that kind of variety to make it worthwhile,'' said Michael Levett, vice president of marketing for the Dino De Laurentiis Corporation. And ''Dune'' has had enough of these to make for approximately 30 lines of licensed ''Dune'' products. There are sheets, pillowcases, posters, books, a soundtrack album, a view-master and a board game, just for openers.

title: KEY GENE PURIFIED BY RESEARCHERS
description: Scientists have detected, purified and reproduced in the laboratory a human gene that is believed to be vital to the body's internal defenses against disease.

title: Hedberg Eye Injury Could End Career
description: The Rangers, who had been fervently waiting for the day when all their disabled players would return, received yesterday what may be the worst news yet: Another veteran was hurt, this time with an injury that could jeopardize his career.

title: MCRAE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: b-After a writedown of $56,000 from a loss in an affiliate. c-Net loss. Results are for 14 weeks for the latest first quarter and 13 weeks for the year-ago first quarter.

title: SUPER FOOD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 17
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid Dec. 15, 1984.

title: Some Troops Are Leaving
description: Vice President Bush will be losing two top aides: Daniel Murphy, his chief of staff, and Peter Teeley, press secretary. The moves are viewed by some as paving the way for the Vice President to put in place a new team in anticipation of his expected run for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1988.

title: Advertising; Ustinov, For Money Magazine
description: ''WITH most commercials for magazines on radio sounding the same, we felt we had to get a soloist who sounded like an orchestra,'' said Michael B. Rich, promotion director of the highly successful Money magazine. That explains the presence of the talented Peter Ustinov on the first extended radio advertising campaign ever undertaken by the 11-year-old Time Inc. publication.

title: English, He Said
description: The Secretary of the Treasury,

title: Texas Eastern
description: The Texas Eastern Corporation said it would take a pretax provision against income of about $80 million relating to its Tyler, Tex., crude oil refinery. It said the provison would equal the carrying value of the refinery, which is owned by the company's La Gloria Oil and Gas unit. Texas Eastern said the write-off had been necessary because of continuing uncertainity about the profitability of crude oil refineries, excess domestic refining capacity and increasing competition from imports of refined petroleum products.

title: THE SCREEN: MATT DILLON STARS IN 'FLAMINGO KID'
description: GARRY MARSHALL'S ''Flamingo Kid'' is an ebullient, unsentimental ''Summer of '42,'' updated to the summer of 1963, about Jeffrey Willis (Matt Dillon), an upwardly mobile Brooklyn teen-ager whose father is a plumber and proud of it.

title: BOGERT OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Books: Earth's Features
description: LANDPRINTS. On the Magnificent American Landscape. By Walter Sullivan. Illustrated. 384 pages. Times Books.$22.50. WALTER SULLIVAN, science editor of The New York Times, was one of the first journalists to popularize plate tectonics, the theory that the continents and other earthly features originated in the motion of land masses that over the eons collided, crunched, slid atop one another and shifted into their present forms and positions.

title: '2010' TO 'BREAKIN' 2' TO 'DUNE'
description: THE good news for school vacation is that most parents will not have to battle with their kids about going to see Santa as an ax murderer in ''Silent Night, Deadly Night.'' The maker has pulled this seasonal horror almost entirely off the market.

title: Diner's Journal
description: NEW DEAL, a restaurant at 152 Spring Street in SoHo that held a game festival last fall featuring all the conventional animals and fowl as well as some exotica such as hippopotamus, rattlesnake and lion, is holding a Winter Shellfish Festival through January. While there is no Loch Ness Monster or Flipper on the menu, there are a few noteworthy dishes: medallions of abalone with sea urchin sauce, oysters and periwinkles in a champagne beurre blanc, Hawaiian blue prawns, and an interpretation of the traditional Japanese Yosenabe, in which the chef combines green mussels from New Zealand, clams and blue prawns in a rice-vinegar- and-soy sauce.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1984

title: SECOND RECALL VOTE OUSTS COUNCILMAN IN CALIFORNIA TOWN
description: A city councilman who survived a recall election in May in which his race was the major issue lost his council seat this week in yet another recall election. The vacancy was filled Wednesday by the man he had defeated for the council seat last year.

title: Scientology Papers Opened And Then Resealed by Court
description: Hours after thousands of personal records and writings of the founder of the Church of Scientology, L. Ron Hubbard, were released by a court to day, a judge ordered the papers resealed.

title: TENS OF THOUSANDS HAVE DIED IN MINES
description: The coal mine fire in Utah, in which the mine operator reported 27 workers trapped, is potentially the worst such disaster in the United States since 91 miners died 12 years ago in a fire in the nation's deepest and richest silver mine.

title: SELIGMAN & ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
AUCTIONS
description: EXTRAORDINARY competition continues at auctions offering major designs by Louis Comfort Tiffany, Frank Lloyd Wright, Greene and Greene and Emile-Jacques Ruhlmann. Last weekend, four records were set in a sale of late 19th- and early 20th-century decorative arts at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street.

title: KEMP-BERRA DEAL OPENS A LOOPHOLE
description: For the Berras, the trade is welcome because it unites father Yogi and son Dale for the first time on the same team. For the Yankees, the deal is important because it gives them a player they can platoon at third base and enables them to trade a player, Steve Kemp, they have no place for.

title: SCOUTING ; New on the Court
description: Frazier's visit to New York was prompted by a news conference at the Plaza Hotel to announce the formation of the United States Basketball League, the latest entry in the crowded arena of professional sports. Frazier is one of the franchise owners in the league, founded by Daniel T. Meisenheimer 3d, a Connecticut venture capitalist with modest plans for the 1985 summer season.

title: BHOPAL CHEMICAL STILL NOT USED UP
description: The Indian scientist supervising the conversion of deadly methyl isocyanate into a pesticide at the Union Carbide plant here said today that more of the chemical was at the factory than had been believed and that the conversion process would take a day or two longer than expected.

title: SOUTHERN GOVERNORS TO MEET ON DRUG TRAFFICKING
description: A group of Southern governors, concerned that their states have become the new targets of international drug smugglers, plans to meet in New Orleans next month to urge the Federal Government to deal with the problem.

title: Coaching Sweepstakes
description: Coach Kay Stephenson hasn't even lost his job jet, but Sam Rutigliano has already turned it down - at least for the present. Rutigliano, who was dismissed in October as the coach of the Cleveland Browns, has been talking with the Buffalo Bills recently about taking over from Stephenson.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: OPENING an ambitious restaurant like Cafe 43 in the heart of Times Square took more than a bit of courage. Such a gesture, however, offers hope that this tawdry neighborhood still has a pulse, and that in time it could be restored to its former grandeur.

title: Panel Head Urges Ban On Folding Baby Gates
description: Folding baby gates are deadly products that should be outlawed because of the potential harm they pose to children, the chairman of the Consumer Products Safety Commission said today.

title: Inaugural Parade Tickets
description: The Presidential Inaugural Committee announced Wednesday that tickets for reserved seats for the Presidential inaugural parade route would be sold for $12.50, $75 and $100. The parade, to be held on the afternoon of Monday, Jan. 21, is to begin at the Capitol and proceed down Pennsylvania Avenue past the White House. The $75 and $100 seats will be on Pennsylvania Avenue across the street from the White House and the Presidential reviewing stand.

title: Guard and Officer Shot in Newark
description: A city police officer answering a burglary call today exchanged gunfire with an off-duty prison guard who lived in the building and both were seriously wounded in what the city police director described as a ''case of mistaken identity.''

title: DIXON TICONDEROGA CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $483,477 and a net gain of $1,269,026 from the sale of a property in Jersey City.

title: A SMALLER OFFICE TOWER IS PLANNED BY ST. BART'S
description: St. Bartholomew's Church, rebuffed last summer by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission, yesterday offered a scaled-down version of the office tower it is seeking permission to build on the site of its community house.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
HAMILTON TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After non-cash charges of $1,007,000 for the quarter and $3,031,000 for the 9 months related to the writedown of good will and fixed assets as a result of Clabir Corporation's acquisition of Hamilton Technology in October 1983.

title: HOW TO HAVE DONATIONS AND A DEDUCTABILITY LIMIT
description: To the Editor:

title: 27 ARE MISSING AS BLAZE RAGES IN A UTAH MINE
description: Twenty-seven people remained trapped today by a fire a mile deep in a coal mine near here, the mine's operator reported.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LETTERS OF DELMORE SCHWARTZ. Selected and Edited by Robert Phillips. Foreword by Karl Shapiro. 384 pages. Illustrated. Ontario Review Press. $24.95.

title: Kansas vs. the Bronx
description: Four years ago, when the Farberware Corporation was considering moving its factory on Bruckner Boulevard in the South Bronx to the Southwest, the city and state arranged for more than $8 million to make sure it stayed put.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Atlantic Capital Corp., an investment banking affiliate of Deutsche Bank A.G., said it will change its name to Deutsche Bank Capital Corp. on Jan. 1.

title: HOW TO HAVE DONATIONS AND A DEDUCTABILTY LIMIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mark Breland, the Olympic boxing champion who recently made his professional debut, will meet Marlon Palmer in a six-round welterweight bout in Atlantic City on Jan. 5. And Evander Holyfield, the Olympic champion who made his pro debut on the same card with Breland, will meet Eric Winbush in a six-round light-heavyweight bout on Jan. 20, Super Bowl Sunday, also in Atlantic City. . . . Kevin McHale , a forward- center for the Boston Celtic who hasn't missed a game in his five-year National Basketball Association career, is expected to be sidelined for at least two contests with partially torn left ankle ligaments he incurred in the third quarter of Wednesday night's loss to Milwaukee. McHale has played in 413 consecutive regular-season and playoff games. . . Gary Hogeboom , starting quarterback with Dallas early in the season before Danny White reclaimed the job, has signed a three-year contract with the Cowboys.

title: ADVANCED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
C.W. Post 64, N.Y. Tech 63
description: Glen McMillan scored on a tip-in at the buzzer, giving C.W. Post (6-3) the victory.

title: Castle & Cooke Stake of Basses
description: Bass Brothers Enterprises said it had purchased 153,200 convertible exchangeable depository certificates of Castle & Cooke Inc., or 7 percent of its shares outstanding. According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the transactions are ''in the nature of arbitrage transactions,'' and the Fort Worth-based investors said they might purchase additional shares, depending upon market conditions.

title: The China Lobby Lives
description: The network of American supporters of Chiang Kai-shek,

title: Walter G. Davis Dies; A.F.L.-C.I.O. Official
description: Walter G. Davis, who was director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s department of community services and a longtime civil rights leader, died Tuesday while undergoing cancer treatment at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring, Md. He was 64 years old.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: Middle South Energy Inc., whose sole asset is the long-delayed Grand Gulf I nuclear power plant in Claiborne County, Miss., issued $300 million of first-mortgage bonds yesterday to finish construction on the plant and to reduce bank debt. The company is a subsidiary of Middle South Utilities Inc., based in New Orleans.

title: CONDOMINIUMS GOING UP AT FIFTH AVE. AND 107TH ST..
description: Driving south on Fifth Avenue one day last spring, Philip E. Aarons spotted a ''For Sale'' sign on the building at the northern corner of East 107th Street.

title: BUSINESSES WILL EASE SPENDING
description: American businesses plan to hold 1985 increases in capital spending to about half the size of this year's big gains, the Government said today.

title: New Hampshire Public Service
description: An international group of investors, led by Morgens, Waterfall, Vintiadis & Company, a New York investment advising firm, said it had purchased the equivalent of 2,029,175 common shares, or 5.2 percent of the shares outstanding, of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire.

title: THE SEASON OF PEACE BRINGS NEW BATTLES OVER NATIVITY SCENES
description: As Christmas draws near, courts, local officials, religious groups and civil liberties organizations around the country are contesting the legality and propriety of Nativity scenes on public property. There have been sudden decisions and overnight reversals, injunctions and appeals and dissonant emotions amid the season's jingles.

title: Japan Passes Phone Laws
description: Japan's Parliament gave final approval today to three bills that the Government said would give foreign companies a greater chance to enter the Japanese telecommunications market.

title: VISITS TO HUDSON MANSION
description: One of the most distinctive Hudson River mansions, Wilderstein, in Rhinebeck, N.Y., opens to the public this month for the first time since it was built in 1853.

title: CONSERVATIVES ASSERT STATE DEPT. CHANGES IMPERIL LATIN POLICY
description: President Reagan has been warned by some of his conservative advisers of a potential softening of the Administration's policies in Central America if plans by Secretary of State George P. Shultz for sweeping diplomatic changes in Latin America take effect.

title: Waste Concern Agrees To Remove Chemicals
description: One of the nation's largest hazardous waste storage companies has agreed to pay $600,000 in fines and remove 2.8 million gallons of toxic chemicals from a giant Alabama storage site, according to officials of the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: U.S. SEEMS WILLING TO OFFER A TRADE AT THE ARMS TALKS
description: A senior Reagan Administration official said today that the United States would be willing to negotiate its long-range missile defense plan along with seeking cuts in offensive weapons systems when arms

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the Financial Corporation of America incorrectly described the company's sale of stock in Walt Disney Productions.

title: TOP STATE COURT RULES HUSBANDS CAN BE CHARGED IN RAPE OF WIVES
description: New York's highest court ruled today that married men may be prosecuted for raping their wives.

title: THE ANTIABORTION VIGILANTES
description: Two dozen abortion clinics or offices have been bombed, burned or otherwise attacked this year. Some have been destroyed. In previous years, other clinics have been bombed or burned. One physician was kidnapped with his wife and held hostage for a week. Another was threatened at gunpoint and released. Another doctor's wife and child narrowly escaped injury when rifle bullets riddled their house.

title: EXPERTS SEE SLOWING IN 1985
description: This year's schizophrenic economy, which paired a blistering first half with a lethargic second half, will give way to more even, but substantially lower, growth in the coming year, according to many economists. Most look for growth, after inflation, of about 3 percent - close to what traditionally has been viewed as the long-term growth potential for the American economy.

title: Topics ; Relative Terms ; Old Granddad
description: Twenty-nine states must raise their legal drinking age to 21 by Oct. 1, 1986, or risk losing Federal highway funds until they do. Some will have to raise the limit more than others.

title: JIFFY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Financing Set By Colorado-UTE
description: In the first financing ever in the taxable market for an electric cooperative, the Colorado-UTE Electric Association Inc. issued $240 million of serial facility bonds.

title: Note Offering By Leader Federal
description: Leader Federal Savings and Loan Association, a Memphis thrift unit, offered $100 million of seven-year secured notes.

title: MICROPRO INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a nonrecurring net charge of $400,000. c-Net income.

title: REVCO DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 17
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: Kollmorgen Picks Chief
description: Kollmorgen Corporation, a high-technology company based in Stamford, Conn., said yesterday that it had elected James E. Swiggett, 52 years old, president and chief executive officer.

title: Koss in Chapter 11
description: The Koss Corporation, a maker of electronic equipment, said it had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Koss also said it would take a $1.4 million charge against earnings during its second quarter, ending Dec. 31, to cover the closing of its European operation. The company cited an excessive amount of short-term debt for its filing.

title: Sanford Rules Out Party Job
description: Terry Sanford, president of Duke University, today ruled out seeking the chairmanship of the Democratic National Committee, saying that wrangling over the post made rebuilding the party ''all but impossible.'' The former North Carolina Governor said, ''I should say that I am not going to be a candidate for the chairmanship of the Democratic Party.''

title: BURT DELAYS CALLING 2 DEFENDANTS IN CBS CASE
description: Dan M. Burt, the lawyer for Gen. William C. Westmoreland in his libel trial against CBS, decided yesterday not to call two defendants - Mike Wallace and Samuel A. Adams, a CBS consultant - as part of the plaintiff's case.

title: DOW OFF 4.75, TO 1,203.29
description: The stock market ended moderately lower yesterday in much slower trading, despite some encouraging inflation news.

title: ART: LEE KRASNER FINDS HER PLACE IN RETROSPECTIVE AR MODERN
description: FOR years, the name Lee Krasner didn't mean a lot in the art world. A dedicated painter herself, she was much better known as Mrs. Jackson Pollock, and for too long after his death, as Lee Krasner Pollock, the artist's widow. There were even those who said that she couldn't get a show were it not for the Pollock connection, a whispering campaign of which Krasner was bitterly aware. Yet she kept on painting, as she had always done, and gradually her work - and her name - emerged from the background to which her husband's fame had consigned it.

title: SCHAAK ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
CHEMLAWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
CORRECTION
description: An article in Sports Pages on Wednesday about the New York Giants misstated the possibilities for the playoff round after their wild- card game next Sunday. If the Giants win, they will play the San Francisco 49ers. But if the Los Angeles Rams win, the Rams will play the Washington Redskins.

title: Fire at Texas Oil Well Is Out
description: An oil well fire that burned for three days was extinguished Wednesday with high pressure water guns by Paul (Red) Adair and his crew. Five people were hospitalized Monday when pressure on the well caused an explosion. Four were in satisfactory condition and a fifth was in stable condition.

title: FAMILIES AND CONCERNS USING GIFT MONEY TO HELP NEEDIEST
description: With the festivities of the holiday season under way, many families and businesses are abandoning the customary exchange of gifts and greeting cards and donating the savings to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: ACAPULCO Y LOS ARCOS RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Including tax credits of $230,000 for the quarter and $508,000 for the year. c-Net losses.

title: State Dept. Aide Sees No End to Afghan War
description: A high- level State Department official said today that he saw no end to the stalemate between guerrillas and Soviet forces in Afghanistan unless the Soviet Union agreed to negotiate a withdrawal.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, has named John A. Bloxcidge, Thomas J. Albani and Anthony J. McCann vice presidents.

title: ISRAELI AIDE GIVES OPTIONS TO BEIRUT
description: Israel told the Lebanese Government today either to agree to the expanded deployment of United Nations troops in southern Lebanon or run the risk of Israel's quitting the withdrawal talks and taking independent actions.

title: Bogart Revisited On Channel 13
description: For Bogart fans, there's never too much of a good thing. So, in the spirit of Casablanca's Cafe Americain, where romance is forever ripe for a reprise, Channel 13 is bringing back the hourlong 1967 documentary ''Bogart'' tomorrow night at 9.

title: TIME, CALLING NO WITNESSES, RESTS ITS CASE IN SHARON TRIAL
description: Time magazine abruptly rested its case yesterday without calling any witnesses, surprising Ariel Sharon's lawyers in their libel trial in Manhattan.

title: PILLSBURY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
THE SCREEN: 'JOHNNY'
description: ''JOHNNY DANGEROUSLY,'' which opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, starts off with all the ingredients of an ''Airplane''-like spoof of gangster movies and their attendant cliches, from a crowded prison cafeteria (even a pet parrot wears stripes)to the bad-boy gangster who really loves his ma. But it also has a 90-minute running time, which is more than an extended skit can really sustain.

title: WNYC Allowed To Sell TV Time
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday unanimously approved plans by WNYC-TV to lease air time to three foreign-language broadcasting companies - two broadcasting in Japanese and the third in Greek.

title: Arbitraging Fears Ease
description: Fears of especially frenzied selling in the final hours of stock market trading today - the day when various stock- index futures and options expire - have eased.

title: Scovil Stock Soars on Bid Scovil Inc.'s stock soared
description: $5.625, to $37.50, on the New

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds climbed for the 15th consecutive week, increasing $1.82 billion, to $213.31 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: 6 Plaques of the Americas

title: BORGE BIRTHDAY CONCERTS CELEBRATE HIS 75TH YEAR
description: Victor Borge, whose musical antics have brought tears to the eyes of generations, will celebrate his 75th birthday with a dozen performances at Carnegie Hall. Starting tonight at 8, the Danish pianist, whose white hair and bearing give him a distinguished air, will stride on stage in black tie, acknowledge applause with an urbane nod and exhale smoke.

title: A Brooklyn Aide To Quit in Inquiry
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney's office said yesterday that the borough's first deputy county clerk had agreed to resign and pay $4,060 as double restitution of salary for days she falsely claimed to have worked.

title: ANSWERS TO KEY QUERIES ON TAX PLAN'S IMPACT ON NEW YORKERS
description: In the three weeks since the Treasury Department presented its sweeping proposal for overhauling the nation's tax system, there has been a dispute between Treasury officials and New York politicians over the effect the plan would have on New York taxpayers.

title: TITLE GAME IS PROPOSED
description: Richie Phillips, the Philadelphian who is perhaps best known as the general counsel of the Major League Umpires Association, said yesterday that he had filed an application with the National Collegiate Athletic Association to create a football game that would determine a national champion.

title: Boy Hurt in Plane Crash Leads Rescuers to Site
description: A 13-year-old boy hiked three miles in the dark with a broken arm to get help for his mother and a pilot when their small airplane crashed.

title: Ketchum Campaign For the Potato Board
description: With an eye toward increasing the average American annual consumption of 120 pounds of spuds, the Potato Board, a Government agency, will undertake a $1.3 million national advertising campaign.

title: Dining Out Guide: Uncommon Brunches
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CABANA CARIOCA, 123 West 45th Street

title: FavoritisminTimes Square Plan
description: A losing bidder on the Times Square redevelopment project has filed suit against New York City, charging that developers were selected with ''obvious favoritism'' and that officials have ''fraudulently'' represented the economic return of the project.

title: Some Troops Are Restless
description: When an appointive official begins muttering about how he or she can no longer afford to stay in Government, it may only indicate restlessness with the job. Take James C. Miller 3d, the economist who has been chairman of the Federal Trade Commission for three and a half years.

title: Reactor's License Is Upheld
description: A Nuclear Regulatory Commission appeals board upheld today the licensing of the Byron nuclear power station in northern Illinois, ruling against local groups that questioned the plant's safety.

title: Topics ; Relative Terms ; EspousalLast spring, well before the conventions, Congress took up a bill to consolidate laws concerning Secret Service protection of the President, Vice President, major candidates for those offices and their families. It was a routine bill, actually, pulling together bits and pieces. But it made one change that proved to be clairvoyant.
description: Previous law used wording like ''the President (and) his immediate family,'' and ''a former President and his wife'' or ''widow.''

title: PEACE IS WANTED, BUT...
description: AMMAN, Jordan

title: Debt Issues
description: * Appalachian Power Co. will redeem $800,000 of its 14 5/8 percent bonds due 1992 on March 1.

title: A.T.&T. to Abolish Investor Discount
description: Ending a decade-old practice, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would eliminate the 5 percent discount offered to stockholders when they reinvest their dividends to buy more A.T.&T. shares. However, A.T.&T. said it would continue its practice of not charging shareholders brokerage fees when they reinvest dividends.

title: CANADIENS TIE CAPITALS, 2-2
description: Guy Carbonneau scored at 12 minutes 16 seconds of the third period to lift the Montreal Canadiens (18-9-5) into a 2-2 tie with the Washington Capitals (17-9-7) tonight.

HAROLD NICOLAS: TIME OFF FROM TAPPING TO SING
description: HAROLD NICHOLAS, who has been dancing professionally for 53 years, most of the time with his brother Fayard as half of the celebrated Nicholas Brothers, is appearing in a different light at Freddy's through next week. Mr. Nicholas is performing without his brother and as a singer rather than a dancer.

title: OPEC SEEKS PLAN TO MONITOR OUTPUT
description: OPEC oil ministers agreed today to propose to their governments a strict enforcement mechanism in a desperate attempt to coerce members to adhere to quotas under OPEC's overall production ceiling.

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 9
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1.1 million.

title: Steel Pact Seen Near
description: The European Economic Community is close to settling a dispute with the United States about European steel tube and pipe exports to the United States market in 1985, Etienne Davignon, the Common Market's Industry Commissioner, said today.

title: TAX PROTESTERS IN MINNESOTA CHARGED IN PLOT ON U.S. AGENT
description: A group of Minnesota tax protesters was meeting on Sundays for what they called Bible study but what Federal agents said were sessions espousing violence against Federal agents as a means of fighting the Federal income tax, according to court records opened Wednesday.

title: New Era for Army
description: Jim Gentile could feel the difference in West Point football. It

title: Ornette Coleman Band
description: The saxophonist-composer Ornette Coleman and his band, Prime Time, will appear in ''Celestial Navigation,'' a theater work with music, tonight and tomorrow night at 8 at the Tower Gallery, 45 West 18th Street (297-0645). Tickets are $12.

title: HISTORIAN OF EASTERN EUROPE
description: Hugh Seton-Watson, one of Britain's foremost historians and a leading expert on East European affairs, died Wednesday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington, where he had been taken five weeks ago with a pulmonary illness. He was 68 years old.

title: CLOAK AND DOLLAR
description: Remember those days of yesteryear when only a Commie rat would betray America's secrets to Moscow? It isn't like that any more, as I learned the first time I dropped in at the New York office of the Soviet spymaster, Ovichovich.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bail Denied to Engineer Arrested on Spy Charges
description: An engineer charged with trying to sell technical secrets about the Stealth bomber to Federal agents posing as Soviet spies was ordered held without bail today by a Federal magistrate.

title: HOUSING LOANS TO BE PROVIDED BY ARCHDIOCESE
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York said yesterday that it would make $1 million available for loans to low- and moderate-income families to rehabilitate and purchase apartments in abandoned, city-owned buildings in Manhattan and the Bronx.

title: Court Says No
description: The Federal appeals court in Philadelphia turned down Albert Butts's request for an order that would have allowed him to rejoin the LaSalle basketball team. The National Collegiate Athletic Association has ruled that Butts has exhausted his eligibility because he played a season of high school basketball after age 20.

title: 3 STORE WORKERS ARRESTED IN SALE OF FAKE JEWELRY
description: A jewelry store manager and two employees were arrested yesterday and charged with selling thousands of pieces of phony gold jewelry to street dealers.

title: LETTERS
description: THE VOICE THAT SPOKE FROM A DARK ROOFTOP

title: CORRECTION
description: A film review in Weekend yesterday, of ''Micki and Maude,'' incorrectly quoted a line of dialogue. The line, referring to the character played by Dudley Moore, should have read, ''When it comes to value judgments, he is right up there with Custer and Nixon.''

title: Count Basie Orchestra Moving to Kansas City
description: The Count Basie Orchestra will move its headquarters to Kansas City, and a collection of the late musician's memorabilia will go to the proposed International Jazz Hall of Fame, his adopted son, Aaron Woodward, said this week.

title: Perjury Counts Remain Against Coast Mayor
description: A state appellate court today refused to reduce 12 felony counts of perjury against Mayor Roger Hedgecock.

title: A Late Blue-Chip Rally Cuts Dow's Loss to 4.31
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in heavier trading, as year-end factors apparently outweighed favorable economic news.

title: JAZZ: REINHARDT TRIBUTE
description: ''A tribute to Django Reinhardt,'' at Fat Tuesdays through tomorrow, is one of those rare events in which the tributee is outdone by the tributors.

title: Israel Is Said to Hold 6 For Plot on Americans
description: An American diplomat said Thursday that six people had been arrested for plotting to attack the United States Embassy in Tel Aviv.

title: A SECRET SESSION HELD TO ARRAIGN MAFIA TURNCOAT
description: A turncoat Mafia leader who gave Italian officials extensive information about organized crime was spirited into the country early yesterday by Federal authorities hoping to gain information that could lead to prosecutions in the United States.

title: BETTER COMPENSATION FOR TEACHERS
description: Unless teachers are adequately paid, the quality of classroom instruction will sink further, aggravating the crisis in education. Attractive, innovative financial packages are long overdue.

title: BRIEFING ; Of Brotherhood
description: Bernard Kalb, who will soon be Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs and State Department spokesman, was asked how his new post would affect his relations with his brother Marvin, senior diplomatic correspondent for NBC News. He paused, then replied: ''Folks, I've decided to put Marvin into a blind trust.''

title: Austrians Sweep Downhill Skiing
description: Elisabeth Kirchler led a 1-2-3 sweep by Austrian skiers in a women's World Cup downhill race today.

title: Bonn Says Standoff At Embassy Is Easing
description: West Germany said today that the three-month- old standoff in its embassy in Prague was ''easing'' and that more East Germans seeking asylum had abandoned their sit-in.

title: SALES REFLECT A POSITIVE U.S. MOOD
description: This is the Christmas when a toy maker is offering a new doll called Ruth, to help teach children to build a relationship with God.

title: KOCH AND THE BLACK-JEWISH COALITION
description: Shortly after black and Jewish leaders began drafting their ''common human agenda'' a year ago, they decided, in denouncing divisiveness, not to criticize either Mayor Koch or the Rev. Jesse Jackson by name. Instead, the leaders issued a general statement of purpose last week to which even the Mayor said he did not object. But Mr. Koch did complain that some of the coalition's members may have also been motivated by another agenda - to unseat him in the mayoral race next year.

title: AND IF YOU CAN'T AFFORD TREATMENT...
description: A few years ago, something started to go wrong with my tennis game. My forehand drives began to take on the trajectory of semi-lobs. As for serving, I couldn't seem to toss the ball in the same place twice. And after playing for an hour or so, I noticed that my right arm, in repose, would occasionally develop a case of the slight shakes.

title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
description: b-Including interest income of $541,000 for the latest first quarter and $549,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE CUTS ITS LOAN RATE TO 8%, 6-YEAR LOW
description: The Federal Reserve Board, in another move to ease credit, today cut the rate it charges on loans to financial institutions by half a point, to 8 percent.

title: REAGAN'S MARGIN IS 16,876,932 VOTES
description: President Reagan won re-election by almost 16.8 million votes, double his 1980 margin and the second-largest Presidential victory in United States history, according to official results from all 50 states.

title: Wang Outlook
description: Wang Labs Inc. said it expects earnings and sales to grow 20 percent in the second quarter, ending Dec. 31, a reduction from its earlier goal of 30 percent.

description: ALAN TRUSCOTT

title: LISTER HILL, LONGTIME SENATOR FROM ALABAMA
description: Lister Hill, a United States Senator from Alabama for three decades who sponsored some of most important health and education legislation in the years after World War II, died of pneumonia Thursday at the Jackson Hospital in Montgomery, Ala. He was 89 years old.

title: Chinese Nuclear Test
description: The Swedish Defense Ministry reported today that China had detonated a relatively weak nuclear device underground on Thursday. The ministry's observatory at Hagfors said the device was detonated at the Lop Nor testing ground in Xinjiang. China carried out a similar test last October.

title: UPSTATE VILLAGE GETS TO KEEP LONG-SOUGHT DOCTOR
description: With no warning, the old ache in Myrtle Rabatoy's back erupted into a fireball of pain. She rushed to the doctor down the street, who discovered an abscess and drained it.

title: Senator Weicker Weds Claudia Ingram
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut, and Claudia T. Ingram, until recently the chief of staff of the subcommittee on labor, health, human services and education of the Senate Appropriations Committee, were married yesterday. The Rev. Richard Van Wely performed the ceremony at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: ARMY'S WISHBONE FACES BIGGEST TEST
description: Army's first bowl appearance in its 95 seasons of football will take place Saturday against a team that is likely to present the strongest defense this season to the wishbone offense that brought the Cadets here.

title: ELECTRONIC YULE LOG WARMS THE HEARTHLESS
description: Long ago, when John V. Lindsay was Mayor, a Yule log burned and a cameraman trained his lens on it. The year was 1966. WPIX-TV telecast the burning log, and it caused a sensation. Thus, for the last 18 years, one of the rituals of Christmas for many chimneyless New Yorkers has been the watching of the Yule log.

title: DISMISSED PASTOR'S BACKERS ORDERED OUT OF CHURCH
description: A county judge today ordered supporters of the Rev. D. Douglas Roth to end their occupation of Trinity Lutheran Church, where he was once pastor.

title: Commonwealth Edison Plants
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company said costs for completing two nuclear power plant stations would rise by about $946 million following a move to extend the completion dates for units at the plants. Commonwealth said that the total cost of its Byron Station had been increased $415 million, to $4.18 billion from $3.77 billion, and that the cost of the Braidwood Station had been raised $531 million, to $4.11 billion from $3.58 billion.

title: STUDIED OBEDIENCE TO AUTHORITY
description: Dr. Stanley Milgram, a psychologist widely known for his experiments on obedience to authority, died of a heart attack Thursday night at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 51 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: PENTAGON SCIENTIST BACKTRACKED AT SECRET HEARING ON SPACE ARMS
description: The Pentagon's chief of advanced research told a Senate panel last spring that the Soviet Union did not hold a significant lead in space-based weapons technology, according to testimony released this week.

title: Ed Sneed Quits
description: After turning in his worst season ever and working himself into a ''mental rut,'' Ed Sneed says he has decided to drop out as a regular on the PGA Tour. The 40-year-old Sneed, who made the cut just four times in 18 tournaments and earned just over $4,000 this year, said he might enter as many as 10 tournaments in 1985 but needed to get away from full-time golf.

title: Who Judges Which Judges Are Too Old?
description: Justice Bruce Wright has bewildered New York's officials in and out of the judicial system by ruling that state judges are not required to retire at age 70. The decision is likely to be reversed but in the meantime is creating vast uncertainty.
