description: ''This will be the saddest Christmas, and not just this Christmas, all the Christmases will be sad now. From now on for these people, Christmas will always be the day that their son died, it will always be the day that Daddy died.'' - Francy Handly of Huntington, Utah. (10:1.)

title: Pabst-Heileman Link Advanced
description: A Federal judge refused a request to block the $70 million purchase of the Pabst Brewing Company by the G. Heileman Brewing Company and scheduled another hearing for next week. The Stroh Brewery Company had asked Judge John Feikens to issue a temporary restraining order, contending the takeover would violate Federal laws aimed at protecting competition.

title: PEKING AGAIN CHALLENGES THE UNIVERSAL VALIDITY OF MARXIST DOGMA
description: The Communist Party newspaper People's Daily today published its second front-page editorial in two weeks challenging the universal validity of Marxist dogma.

description: Iraq said its jet fighters attacked two ''large naval targets'' in the Persian Gulf today, and shipping sources confirmed that a Norwegian supertanker and Liberian tanker were hit.

description: The attorney for a former Nazi death camp guard facing deportation to the Soviet Union said yesterday that a last-ditch effort to get Canada to accept him had failed and that the deportation appeared imminent.

title: Steel Accord Eludes E.E.C.
description: The nations of the European Economic Community failed today to agree among themselves about a proposed accord with the United States that would limit exports of community -produced steel tubes and pipes, a spokesman for the community said.

title: 2 Judges to Retire As Scheduled
description: Chief Judge Lawrence H. Cooke and Associate Judge Hugh R. Jones of the State Court of Appeals said today that they would retire as scheduled on Dec. 31, allowing Governor Cuomo to replace them in January.

title: STAGE: 'HAMLETMACHINE' IN AMERICAN PREMIERE
description: Heiner M"uller's ''Hamletmachine'' is a brief paroxysm of a play. In shards of dialogue and description, some of it reworkings of Shakespeare (''Something is rotten in this age of hope''), it confronts the ghosts of Hamlet, Ophelia and Western civilization. Mr. M"uller has called his work ''the shrunken head of the Hamlet tragedy,'' an appropriately macabre summary.

description: Neither of these teams planned to be here for the American Conference wild-card game Saturday.

title: No Headline
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 22, 1984 International Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, the Soviet Union's Defense Minister, died Thursday after a two-month illness, the official Soviet press agency Tass announced. He was a designer of the Soviet Union's military machine and one of the most powerful officials in its hierarchy. (Page 1, Column 6.) Marshal Ustinov's successor as Defense Minister could be Grigory V. Romanov, the former Leningrad party leader, United States Government officials believe. They said Mr. Romanov appears to be the leading candidate and that if the Kremlin follows its usual practice, his appointment as Defense Minister would remove him from consideration as the successor to Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, and leave Mikhail S. Gorbachev as the seemingly undisputed heir apparent. (1:5.)

title: MUSEUM CLOSING ART SCHOOL
description: The Brooklyn Museum Art School, which has taught painting and sculpture to thousands of students since 1941, will close and transfer its teachers and courses to the Pratt Institute at the end of January, the museum announced yesterday.

title: HEART RECIPIENT EXERCISES TO SPEED RECOVERY
description: William J. Schroeder, the recipient of an artificial heart who suffered a series of strokes eight days ago, walked small distances in his room today, exercised with weights to build up his strength and tossed a small balloon to improve his coordination, hospital officials said.

title: MORE GAS IS FOUND AT PLANT IN INDIA
description: Technicians trying to eliminate the remaining lethal gas at the Union Carbide plant here found more of the gas today, and it appeared their task would not be completed until Saturday.

title: TRADING UP IN COMPUTER GIFTS
description: Most of the computers that turned up under the Christmas tree last holiday season were best suited for battling intergalactic invaders. This year, a surprising number of Santa's computers are versatile enough to teach the children conversational Chinese, as well as grapple with the family budget.

title: BULLETS BEAT KNICKS
description: Coach Hubie Brown of the Knicks, in his continuing search for a legitimate center who would allow Pat Cummings to return to power forward, started 7-foot- 1-inch Ron Cavenall against Jeff Ruland of the Washington Bullets tonight.

title: RESCUE WORKERS FIND 13 BODIES IN MINE IN UTAH
description: Battling a persistent coal fire a mile into a mountain, rescue workers today found the bodies of 13 miners, victims of the smoke and flames that trapped them Wednesday night.

description: After coaching Kentucky to two bowl games in a row, Jerry Claiborne has been rewarded with a five-year contract extension.

description: The State Department said today that the United States would not meet Israel's request for an emergency grant of $800 million until Israel adopted a much tougher economic austerity program.

description: The Saks Fifth Avenue flagship store, long a symbol of stylish shopping on the most elegant commercial avenue in New York City, has been designated a landmark by the city.

description: When she came to the United Nations in 1981, says Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, who has announced that she intends to resign as chief American delegate at the end of the year, ''the radical nations within the third world had achieved a dominant voice in the debates and decisions.''

title: A CENTER OF SOVIET POWER
description: In the Soviet Union, where the Communist Party holds ultimate authority, the party's Politburo is the nation's effective Cabinet, the arena in which final decisions are made.

title: WEST GERMANY WARNS IT MAY LEAVE UNESCO
description: Foreign Ministry officials said today that the Government had told Unesco that West Germany might withdraw from the United Nations agency if changes were not made.

title: No Headline
description: Representative Martin Frost of Texas said Thursday that he would not seek his fellow Democrats' votes to become chairman of the House Budget Committee, leaving Representative William H. Gray 3d of Pennsylvania the only active candidate. ''Bill has my support for chairman,'' Mr. Frost said.

title: STUDIES WEIGH HAZARD OF LEGAL DRUGS AND DRIVING
description: There is another hazard on the road, scientists say, one less publicized and less researched than the problem of drinking and driving, but not necessarily less serious. Although researchers have assumed for years that people drive regularly under the influence of over-the-counter and prescription drugs, they have only recently begun to study the percentage of drivers who do so and the number of accidents they cause.

title:
PATENTS ;
Variation Is Devised For Insulin Conversion
description: A variation of a previously patented method of converting porcine insulin into human insulin was patented this week for a Danish company.

PATENTS;
Pure Culture of Fungus Fights Plant Diseases
description: An invention in agricultural biotechnology was patented this week for the Department of Agriculture by George C. Papavizas, a laboratory chief in the agency's research center at Beltsville, Md.

title: REAGAN IS SAID TO SEEK LIMITS ON STUDENT AID
description: The Administration's proposed budget for next year would deny guaranteed student loans and certain education grants to any family with an income of more than $30,000 a year, Administration officials said today.

description: United States Government officials said today that Grigory V. Romanov, the former Leningrad party leader, is the leading candidate to replace Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov as Defense Minister of the Soviet Union.

Shows begin at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $8.50 for adults and $6.50 for those under 13, who must be accompanied by an adult.

title: CALENDARS TO HELP RING IN THE NEW YEAR
description: In an electronic age, when clocks and watches are losing their faces, the trusty old wall calendar is still hanging in there. People still rely on pages of paper to illustrate the passage of time, still prefer a two- dimensional peek into the fourth dimension.

title: No Headline
description: Five inmates were injured, one critically, in a half-hour fight Thursday at a yard at Southern Michigan Prison, said Thomas G. Phillips, a prison spokesman. Prison guards at posts above the yard fired two warning shots to break up the fight. He said he did not know what had led to the incident.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about Wilderstein, the Hudson River mansion at Rhinebeck, N.Y., was written for use earlier and thus gave outdated information on public access. The mansion was open for visits Dec. 8 and 9 but is now closed again.

description: The OPEC oil ministers adjourned today after agreeing in principle to a production and price monitoring system intended to enforce the group's production ceiling and bolster sagging oil prices.

title: TOWN BUILT BY TEXTILE MILL FACES FUTURE WITHOUT IT
description: For nearly 80 years the lives and fortunes of people in this small community have been inextricably bound to the mill. Without it, the saying here goes, the only thing running in Ware Shoals would be the Saluda River.

description: Gov. Edwin Edwards refused today to free a prisoner who became an award-winning journalist after spending 11 years on death row for murder.

description: Aware of the distress of the city's poor amid the prevailing cheer of the holiday season, many business and professional establishments and their employees are contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

description: Three and a half months after taking charge, T. Roland Berner resigned suddenly yesterday as chairman and chief executive of the troubled Western Union Corporation. The company named Robert S. Leventhal, a board member, to replace him.

title: 64 FIGHTER PLANES GROUNDED BY NAVY
description: The Navy announced today that one-fifth of its force of A-6E attack jets would have to be grounded because their wings might last only half as long as had been expected.

title: MUSIC: 3 VIERK PIECES SHOW JAPAN'S INFLUENCE
description: Concerts by little-known composers in Manhattan's downtown avant- garde spaces can be pretty chancy: some are terrible, many are mediocre, but occasionally, one is genuinely exciting. The first formal New York concert of Lois V. Vierk, Tuesday night at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation, fell into this last category: It gave great pleasure in itself, and promised even more for the future.

title: CLASH ON DISCLOSURES: REAGAN TACTICS
description: While the Reagan Administration has increased its pressure on news organizations not to publish classified information, it has also been moving more quietly to build a legal basis for imprisoning Government employees who give reporters such information. This Administration, even more than earlier ones, has been frustrated by the publication of Government secrets and its inability to stop the disclosures. Congress last year blocked its plan to subject more Government employees to polygraph, or lie-detector, tests and lifelong censorship, and it is unclear whether a new overall strategy has been developed to curb disclosure of official secrets.

title: LETTERS
description: SHOULD NO.1 COMPANY TOWN BE A STATE?

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Dec. 15 about the departure of Sidney Schwartz as inspector general of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority misstated his plans. He will open a business as a financial and management consultant at 1500 Broadway, operating independently from the offices of Hecht & Company there.

title: Chile Forces 21 Exiles Back into Argentina
description: The Chilean police forced 21 exiles back into Argentina after they tried to enter Chile, a spokesman for the exiles said today.

title: ANTI-SANDINISTA EDITOR DECIDES ON EXILE
description: The editor of the opposition daily newspaper, La Prensa, said today that he had gone into exile and would make his home in neighboring Costa Rica until press censorship was lifted in Nicaragua.

title: GTE Accepts

title: U.S. and Britain In Air Fare Accord
description: The State Department said yesterday that the United States and British Governments had formally agreed to approve lower fares on trans-Atlantic routes, ending a long legal and diplomatic dispute.

title: BOND PRICES LITTLE CHANGED
description: Bond prices were virtually unchanged in lethargic but erratic pre- holiday trading yesterday.

title: Broken Hill Profit Up
description: The Broken Hill Proprietary Company Ltd., Australia's largest publicly held company, said today that its profits climbed 24 percent in the six months ended Nov. 30 from the period a year earlier.

title: BOSCO PASSES LIFT B.Y.U.
description: Robbie Bosco, limping for most of the game on an injured left ankle and knee, threw a 13-yard touchdown pass to his tight end, Kelly Smith, with 1 minute 23 seconds remaining tonight to give Brigham Young University a come- from-behind 24-17 victory against Michigan in the Holiday Bowl that solidified the Cougars' claim to their first national championship.

description: At midseason William Roberts was starting at left tackle on offense for the Giants and enjoying his rookie season. Then he sprained his right foot, lost his starting job and stayed on the bench until someone else became injured.

title: DEBATE ON SECURITY: EDUCATED VIEWS
description: The debate on national security versus freedom of information, long a staple in Washington, dominated discussion in the capital this week. It was prompted by The Washington Post's publication of details of the secret payload of the space shuttle mission scheduled for next month, and the condemnation of the newspaper's article by Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger.

title: MERGER OF 2 ACCOUNTING FIRMS SET
description: Top partners of Alexander Grant & Company, the nation's 11th-largest accounting firm, and Fox & Company, the 13th-largest, said yesterday that they had reached agreement on a merger proposal and intended to put it to a vote by their respective boards and partnerships next month.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Raymond Berry, who took over as coach of the New England Patriots in midseason with a ready-made staff, yesterday dismissed seven of his eight assistants, retaining only Rod Rust, the defensive coordinator. . . . Milton McCrory will defend the World Boxing Council's welterweight crown against Pedro Vilella in Paris on March 9. . . . Ed Reinhardt, the Colorado tight end who has been undergoing a painstaking rehabilitation after a severe head injury suffered in a game last September, will spend the Christmas holidays at home with his family. According to officials of Craig Hospital in Denver, where he will return after the holidays, Reinhardt is still paralyzed on his right side but has regained limited use of the left side of his body, and has added to his vocabulary since speaking his first words two weeks ago.

title: Washburn Dropped
description: Chris Washburn , the North Carolina State freshman who had been one of the most intensively recruited high school basketball players in the country, was dismissed from the squad yesterday after he was arrested and charged with burglary. The police said Washburn broke into the dormitory room of another player Wednesday and stole stereo equipment belonging to that player's roommate.

title: THE COMMUTER CAR WITH CAMARADERIE
description: This week, the riders of Car No. 8657 of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad had themselves a Christmas party.

title: REAGAN COUNTERS CRITICISM OF SPACE WEAPONS
description: President Reagan today defended his space weapons program and said hewould be able to convince Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and other Western allies of the importance of the proposed missile defense system in outer space.

title: BRIEFING ; Black Tie, Boots and Beer
description: All sorts of events involving the official festivities arranged by the Committee for the 50th American Presidential Inaugural are emerging, The latest is the ''Lone Star-Studded Texas-Style Inaugural'' to be given Jan. 19 in honor of Vice President Bush and his wife, Barbara, by the Texas State Society and members of the Texas Congressional delegation.

title: GEORGIA TRIES TO HALT PROCESSING AT CARBIDE PLANT
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, which is planning to process thousands of gallons of its poisonous methyl isocyanate into finished pesticide products, hit a snag today when the Governor of Georgia asked Federal authorities to order the company to stop processing the chemical at its plant in Georgia.

title: Mayor in a Hurry
description: The rules are clear: The legislature

title: Data Tell of Deaths By Legion Disease
description: Five people died of Legionnaires' disease at St. Vincent's Medical Center here between 1980 and 1982, and as many as 31 others contracted the illness at the hospital, according to the Federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta.

title: Union Approves Hyatt Clark Pact
description: Union members at Hyatt Clark Industries Inc., an employee-owned business, voted overwhelmingly today to accept a new contract.

title: NEW SOVIET CRAFT HEADING TO VENUS
description: The Soviet Union today launched the second of two spacecraft that will pass by the planet Venus and rendezvous with Halley's comet in 1986. The liftoff of Vega 2 followed by six days that of its companion, Vega 1.

title: OPERA: LEONTYNE PRICE IN METROPOLITAN'S 'AIDA'
description: Verdi's ''A"ida'' has been a touchstone opera for the ''new Met.'' A mainstay at the Metropolitan Opera during previous regimes, it was given a bargain-basement new production by John Dexter in 1976. But it hasn't been revived since 1979-80, and the explanation was that there simply weren't the singers for it. Instead, we were told, the future of the Met lay in ensemble casts, fresh repertory and imaginative productions.

title: LETTERS
description: FOR A HIGH SCHOOL OF PUBLIC SERVICE

title: DEFENSE MINISTER OF SOVIET UNION IS DEAD AT AGE 76
description: Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, a designer of the Soviet Union's modern military machine and Defense Minister since 1976, died Thursday after a two-month illness, the official Soviet press agency Tass announced today.

title: 35th Chess Game Postponed in Moscow
description: The 35th game of the world chess championship match between Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov has been postponed until Wednesday, the official news agency Tass said today.

title: NOT YOUR USUAL HOCKEY PLAYER
description: The name Alex raised no eyebrows when I submitted our hockey team's roster - just another skater, one who wouldn't be around until midseason. Formalities are not rampant in the Southeastern Connecticut Men's Hockey League, but I put her name on the official list anyway, in case we needed another player. When Alexandra called, the squad was indeed undermanned.

title: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Idaho Legislator Challenging Loss of Congressional Seat
description: Representative George Hansen, contesting the loss of his Idaho Congressional seat Nov. 6 to Richard Stallings, a Democrat, asked the House today to declare that he was the real winner.

title: OTB Face Lift
description: The OTB shop on Second Avenue and 53d Street may be getting a face lift this spring as part of a quiet experiment in ''club concept'' wagering. Plans are in the works to join the ground-floor shop to an adjacent two- story restaurant called Goodfellows, creating a second-level lounge where bettors could eat, drink, watch simulcast races on television monitors and gamble, all at the same time.

title: TREASURY'S OBJECTIONS TO A SALES TAX
description: The Treasury said today that a new national sales tax would have some advantages but would be too burdensome to introduce simply as a means to reduce reliance on the income tax.

title: Reckitt Purchase Of Airwick Set
description: The London-based Reckitt & Coleman Group has agreed to buy the Airwick Group from Ciba-Geigy Ltd. of Basel, Switzerland's largest chemical company, for about $200 million, the two companies said. The agreement is conditional on approval by the Reckitt & Coleman shareholders.

title: REDS ARE BOUGHT BY CINCINNATIAN
description: Marge Schott, a Cincinnati automobile dealer who had been a minority partner in ownership of the Cincinnati Reds, has purchased a majority share of the team, the Reds announced today.

title: Your Money ; Medigap Policy Costs, Benefits
description: On Jan. 1, 1985, the price of participating in the Federal Medicare program will rise because of higher deductibles and co-insurance for hospital insurance and greater premiums for medical insurance. It will become even more important, therefore, to consider a private supplementary policy known as Medigap insurance to help pay for the health care costs not covered by Medicare.

title: LETTER
description: THE VOICE THAT SPOKE FROM A DARK ROOFTOP

title: Judaica on Sale
description: A variety of Jewish texts will be on sale tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. at the Central Queens Y.M.- Y.W.H.A., 67-09 108th Street, Forest Hills. The books are in English, Hebrew and Yiddish and cover history, culture and language. The sale is sponsored by the Rabbi Simon Hevesi Jewish Heritage Library at the Y; proceeds will be used to buy children's books.

title: Holiday Hustlers
description: Seasonal custom often spreads beyond customary boundaries.

title: The Shultz Reshuffle at State We take it that Secretary of State Shultz wants to promote competence in reshuffling ambassadors and assistant secretaries, with the full support of President Reagan. But the intimation that political credentials may count for less in the Administration's second term has caused an uproar on its right flank. Edwin Feulner of the Heritage Foundation, thunders: ''This is the first roundup leading to a Christmas massacre that would fundamentally change the political commitments of Ronald Reagan's State Department.'' It's no such thing.
description: No one would invest a dime in a multinational corporation that auctioned the appointment of its overseas plant managers. Yet in the apt phrase of William Macomber, the former diplomat who now heads New York's Metropolitan Museum, a tradition of ''bought commissions'' prevails in the naming of ambassadors. Under Mr. Reagan, it's been a buyer's market: 40 percent of ambassadors are political appointees, compared with 27 percent under President Carter.

title: TAKEOUT FOOD SHOPS CAN ADD JOY TO THE HOLIDAYS
description: As much as I prefer home-cooked food, there comes a time when the supermom syndrome has to give way to common sense. Now is the time.

title: Transit Ban on Ad Is Judged Unfair
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the Transit Authority had violated the First Amendment by barring a Penthouse magazine advertisement that portrayed a caricature of former Vice President Walter F. Mondale virtually nude.

title: JUDITH RASKIN, LYRIC SOPRANO ACCLAIMED FOR MUSICIANSHIP
description: Judith Raskin, the American lyric soprano famed for her voice and musicianship, died of cancer yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital. She was 56 years old and lived in New York City.

title: USTINOV HAD KEY ROLES IN MILITARY AND POLITICS
description: Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, the Soviet Defense Minister, oversaw a military buildup and played a key role in internal Kremlin politics.

title: Rape Is Rape Marital rape: the very words have long evoked a leer or conjured up a drunk and disappointed Rhett Butler carrying Scarlett O'Hara up a red-carpeted staircase - and her satisfied smile the next morning. Closer to reality is Mario Liberta, accused of beating his wife, Denise, within the first year of their marriage. Three years later, in 1981, after being ordered by a court to live apart from her, he forcibly raped and sodomized her in front of their young son.
description: A lower court denied him the marital exemption from rape in state law and he became the only husband in New York's history to be convicted of raping his wife. Now a unanimous panel of the New York Court of Appeals has upheld his conviction.

title: Computer Ad Inquiry
description: Fifteen local computer retailers have received complaints from the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York after the bureau investigated the advertising claims of 30 computer outlets.

title: Danish Prices Higher
description: Danish consumer prices rose seven- tenths of 1 percent in November from October and climbed 5.9 percent from November 1983, the Bureau of Statistics said today.

title: E.P.A. EXPANDS RULES TO COVER ALL 75 DIOXINS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today announced new rules that it said would prevent such environmental disasters as the contamination of an entire town with hazardous dioxin compounds.

title: DURABLES ORDERS SURGE 8.3%

title: Reporter Seeks Diary for Trial
description: R. Foster Winans, a former reporter for The Wall Street Journal, has subpoenaed his calendar and office diary, as part of his defense against criminal charges that he engaged in insider trading, lawyers for Mr. Winans and The Journal said yesterday. The Journal is resisting the subpoena on the ground of a First Amendment privilege to protect its confidential sources.

description: In the waning seconds of the game tonight, Stan Albeck, the Nets' coach, juggled his players. The move backfired.

title: At Least 100 Reported Killed In Soviet Georgian Gas Blast
description: At least 100 people were killed in a gas explosion that ripped through a nine-story apartment building in Tbilisi, the capital of Soviet Georgia, earlier this month, witnesses told Western journalists who were visiting the republic.

But it hasn't been revived since 1979-80, and the explanation was that there simply weren't the singers for it. Instead, we were told, the future of the Met lay in ensemble casts, fresh repertory and imaginative productions.

description: AS A MAN NAMED KIM Dae Jung sets out on a planned 7,000-mile journey home to South Korea next month, he will undoubtedly be thinking about Benigno Aquino. Kim did not know Aquino well. Indeed, they met only once, on March 10, 1983, in Cambridge, Mass.

description: JOB possibilities on the Island for toolmakers and machinists would appear to be unlimited, as companies try to keep pace with rapidly changing technology and the thriving economy of the region. Yet a training program set up by the industry to turn out skilled workers can barely find enough students to keep the classes open.

title: AVOIDING THE 'OCTOPUS' AND OTHER FIRE HAZARDS
description: RESIDENTIAL fires are a constant threat all during the year, but the danger is even greater at this time, when everyone's mind is on holiday festivities and when there is often a great increase in the number of potential fire hazards around the hoese. Statistics have long shown that residential fires cost thousands of lives each year, in addition to millions of dollars worth of property.

description: For more than 70 years, seamen from all over the world have found lodging, reasonably priced meals and companionship at the Seamen's Church Institute in lower Manhattan.

title: PLANE ENGINEER ACCUSED AS SPY
description: Employing a little stealth of their own, Federal agents in California last week arrested an aircraft engineer who, they said, had handed over preliminary plans for making United States bombers invisible to radar.

title: A NOSTALGIA FOR ROMANCE
description: LEFT TO THEIR OWN DEvices, many decorators prefer to create nostalgic environments based on fantasy rather than to cope with more practical design considerations. According to three firms that showed their work at the Southampton Designer Show House, romance - a yearning for settings from the past - has become a prevailing design trend.

title: LIFE SEIZED ON THE FLY
description: Even before his death last spring at the age of 56, Garry Winogrand had become a legendary figure. Of all the photographers of his generation - Diane Arbus and Lee Friedlander among them - Winogrand acquired the greatest following, and the greatest number of imitators. His idiosyncratic style of ''street photography'' (a term he disowned, with customary irascibility) was so innovative and radical that it was at first perceived as amateurish. But it quickly became the magnet for a coterie of younger photographers, who took to stalking the sidewalks of New York with Leicas strapped to their wrists, ready to pounce.

description: A CABLE television system that eventually will serve 16 northeast Connecticut towns began serving customers last week in the rural town of Ashford.

title: CITY SEEKS HELP FOR A HOMELESS SHIP
description: Up in Massachusetts, the bow of an 18th-century cargo ship lies in a huge tank of brine, waiting for someone, anyone, who will preserve and display in New York this piece of Manhattan history.

title: A Case of Wounded Pride

My reactions, including the flowers, the questioning of friends and the fruitless attempts to win my lover back, were also the same.

title: GETTING THE MESSAGE
description: MEXICO CITY Even in the democracies, powerful national leaders seldom suffer direct, face-to-face criticisms of their governments and policies, leveled at them in public by respected private citizens.

title: AS GOLD NEARS $300, DOLLAR STILL POPULAR
description: Gold prices have been falling for months as the dollar has surged, and last week gold traded briefly under $300 an ounce in Sydney, its lowest since a cyclical dip in mid-1982. Few traders predict that gold will fall to the $100 mark last seen in 1976, but the precipitous drop from 1980's $825 level has raised concerns about whether gold will retain its reputation as a safe harbor during times of uncertainty. Indeed, more traders seem to be wanting dollars as the hedge, especially since the American inflation rate is staying so unexpectedly low. The relationship between the dollar and gold shifts occasionally as the world economy changes, and some investors apparently have greater faith in the continuing strength of the dollar than they do in gold. And traders note that gold is still high, both historically and when adjusted for inflation.

description: DOES she always arrive at work this early? ''I usually arrive at 8:30 A.M.,'' Bluma Chwatsky replied. ''I'm here 59 years, and I was never late yet. If the store is open, I'm here.''

title: WEINBERGER WINS A ROUND ON THE BUDGET In the Administration's intramural battling over the budget for fiscal year 1986, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has won a preliminary skirmish. The White House announced last week that President Reagan, who has tentatively approved domestic spending cuts of $34 billion, had decided the Pentagon should have to make do with a mere $8.7 billion less.
description: If the President has his way, the Pentagon's uniformed troops will get a smaller-than-hoped-for raise and its civilian hands will, like other Federal employees, take a 5 percent pay cut. Trims will be made in purchases of certain weapons and ammunition, but big-ticket programs like the MX missile and B-1 bomber won't be touched.

But Krawczyk didn't hint at what the ''something different'' might be in the first Cherry Bowl, in which Army defeated Michigan State, 10-6, today.

title: SEASON'S QUANDRIES
description: In New York City, in Washington, D.C., in Barrington, R.I., and in many other cities last week, public officials struggled over how, where and whether to display the symbols of the season. In Scarsdale, N.Y., a 6-by-9-foot cr eche was locked away - as it's been since 1981 - awaiting a decision by the United State Supreme Court on whether placing the privately owned religious display in a small public park violates the separation of church and state.

title: SEEN IN 1984, THE FUTURE LOOKS BLEAK
description: The other Saturday afternoon at Movieland theater on Broadway, where I saw ''Dune'' with what was clearly a crowd of aficionados of the Frank Herbert sci-fi novels, the letters on the screen spelling out the film's title were so widely spaced that the left side of the ''D'' and the right side of the ''e'' were cut off. This may have been the fault of the projection, but I prefer to think it was a conscious comment on the things that were about to come.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: TUCKED away in a quiet little store off Main Street in Port Washington, Benita Albert tends to her knitting.

title: NASSAU AT CHRISTMASTIME: SANTA'S IN THE SOUP KITCHEN
description: NEARLY 1,000 Nassau County residents will be eating Christmas dinner at soup kitchens and community centers this Tuesday, while hundreds more will receive food donations to feed their families. Although the county is in many ways one of the most affluent in the nation, soup kitchens and community pantries report a dramatic increase in requests for food in the last few years.

title: TOXIC LEAK: LIMITED POLITICAL EFFECTS
description: Last Sunday morning, while scientists in Bhopal were waiting to begin converting into pesticide the remaining stores of poisonous methyl isocyanate at the Union Carbide plant there, Chief Minister Arjun Singh of Madhya Pradesh was late.

title: BUSINESS THROUGH THE GENERATIONS
description: WHEN Bill Wilkinson, a fourth-generation builder on Long Island, reads a computer printout estimating the costs for a new construction job, he is invariably reminded of the ledger kept by his great-grandfather, who started the family business a century and a half ago. ''Horse, wagon and laborer for a day . . . $3,'' was one entry.

title: DANCER, DASHER, PRANCER AND VIXEN: WHOSE REINDEER ARE THEY?
description: Donald Hall is the editor of The Oxford Book of Children's Verse in America. His most recent children's book is ''The Man Who Lived Alone.''

title: ; A FEDERAL BOXING COMMISSION WOULD MAKE FIGHT GAME SAFER
description: To the Editor:

title: CAPITOL OPENING WITH CHRISTMAS SHOW
description: ONCE, Port Chester's Capitol Theater was a symbol of splendor, with a facade recalling the Italian Renaissance. Inside, vaudeville acts abounded during the era of ''two- a-day,'' when two live performances were held daily. That was in the 1920's.

title: NEW JERSEY OUT SCOUTING FOR MAJOR LEAGUE TEAM
description: In recent days, New Jersey officials have been donning baseball caps and boasting gleefully about the state's prospects for adding a major league baseball team to its already impressive collection of professional sports teams. Is their behavior an expression of blind optimism or do they know something no one else does?

title: Helen A. Ix To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edward Ix of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Helen Adele Ix to Daniel Manning FitzPatrick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Anthony FitzPatrick of Plattsburgh, N.Y.

title: THE SPIRIT OF GIVING
description: THIS IS NOT EXACTLY A Christmas story; it's not really a wine story, either, although wine is central to it. It's a story about living and dying and the occasionally surprising nobility of the human spirit. No, it's not exactly a Christmas story but - for me - it evokes the spirit of Christmas more profoundly than a hundred recorded carols or a forest of lighted trees.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: A NEW WATCHDOG FOR THOSE WHO FLY
description: In just over a week, the consumer-

title: 7 MORE MINERS FOUND DEAD, AND HOPE OF SURVIVORS ABANDONED
description: All hope that there might yet be survivors of a persistent coal mine fire ended tonight when rescue workers reaching the end of a long smoky tunnel found seven more bodies and concluded that none of the seven miners still unaccounted for could still be alive.

title: CAMBODIAN FAMILY FINDS A HOME IN GREENWICH
description: The ''Made in U.S.A.'' tag still dangled from the zipper on the green ski jacket Thong Tha wore inside the house. Cool air from a stream of visitors coming through the front door chilled the room, but Miss Thong wore her jacket more out of pride than for warmth.

title: TRYING ARMS CONTROL AT HIGH SCHOOL LEVEL
description: When the first-period bell rang at Detroit's Southeastern High School one morning recently, all 3,200 students lined up in a corridor. For the next 45 minutes, while they slouched against lockers, a team of security officers walked slowly through the hallway. The officers were carrying portable metal detectors that scanned each student for knives or guns. The team had arrived at the school unannounced, to conduct the first search under a new program designed to keep students from bringing weapons to school.

title: A GAME AS REAL AS LIFE
description: Robert Mills, one-time managing editor of Ellery Queen's Mystery Magazine, is a freelance reviewer and short-story writer who lives in New York. THE DUNGEON MASTER

title: THE STORY-TELLING ANIMAL
description: HUMAN supremacy may be the product of technology, but technology is, in turn, the product of man's fancy, for the story of mankind is the story of Story itself. It was not the thumb, erect posture or the ability to make tools that gave man his start. Apes make tools, as Jane Goodall discovered. I once had a capuchin monkey who had four thumbs as well as a prehensile tail, and could walk as straight as she pleased. She invented the lever and the net, modifying a stick for one and my sweater for the other. A lower primate, she was happy eating flies and had a brain the size of a radish. What got people out of the trees was something besides thumbs and gadgets. What did it, I am convinced, was a warp in the simian brain that made us insatiable for patterns - patterns of sequence, of behavior, of feeling - connections, reasons, causes: stories.

title: HOLIDAY PROJECT: SEASONAL FAMILY FOR THE FORGOTTEN
description: For the 94 residents of the Bialystoker Home for the Aged on the Lower East Side, it was an unusual day. The afternoon was spent talking, laughing and singing songs with volunteer visitors who had come to help them celebrate Hanukkah.

title: DESIGNATION AS A LANDMARK: A BURDEN OR A BENEFIT?
description: When a building receives historic designation from the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, are its owners and residents better off as a result?

title: 'WRONG KIND OF PEOPLE' THREATEN PALM BEACH
description: The Talk of Palm Beach

title: NEW TRACK HEADS FOR OPENING
description: THE $125 million-plus Garden State Park race track, rising from the ashes of a 1977 fire that destroyed what was New Jersey's first parimutuel racecourse, is heading for completion by the April 1 opening of a thoroughbred- and harness-racing program.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
A FAIRY GODMOTHER LENDS A HAND FOR THE CHRISTMAS OF 1943
description: TWO days before Christmas, 1943, I was in the grocery store thumbing through my ration coupons and looking in vain for delicacies such as canned pineapple, baking chocolate and ketchup, when I saw Mrs. Gambrel again. We had met when I was apartment hunting a few days earlier, and she told me regretfully that all her rooms were taken.

title: BEST SELLERS Dec. 23, 1984
description: Fiction*1 19 THE TALISMAN, by Stephen King and Peter Straub. (Viking, $18.95.) Two parallel worlds and a young boy who can travel between them. *2 26 THE SICILIAN, by Mario Puzo. (Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) A fictionalized life of Salvatore Giuliano, the Sicilian bandit-hero of the 1940's. *3 310 LOVE AND WAR, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) The Civil War rages in this saga of a Pennsylvania family and a South Carolina family, begun in ''North and South.'' *4

title: FOR ELDERLY, A WAY TO USE HOME EQUITY
description: FOR the first time, elderly homeowners in the state are able to transform the equities in their houses into income while continuing to live in their homes.

title:
MEGAATRENDS OF '85;
REINVENTING THE AMERICAN CORPORATION
description: -five will be the year in which

title: Melissa Franklin Is Married to James Allen Keyte
description: Melissa Franklin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Ward Franklin of New York and Watch Hill, R.I., was married yesterday to James Allen Keyte, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Robertson Keyte of Los Angeles. The Rev. Phillip Pelikan, the bridegroom's brother-in-law and a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents in New York.

title: REDUCED GOAL SET ON REAGAN'S PLAN FOR SPACE DEFENSE
description: Scientists in charge of research for the Administration's proposal for a defensive shield in space say the immediate plan has been substantially scaled back - from trying to create an impenetrable defense of the nation to protecting the nation's land-based nuclear arsenal.

title: ; Bellagio
description: To the Editor:

title: A PURPOSE TO LIFE IN THE FAST LANE
description: KINGMAN, Ariz.

title: SHARON SUIT: IN THE WRONG PLACE, AGAINST THE WRONG DEFENDANT
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Mulroy Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Mulroy of Oceanside, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Mary Mulroy to John Michael Gettler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Gettler, also of Oceanside.

title: USTINOV'S FUNERAL RITES ADHERE TO FIXED PATTERN
description: For the fifth time in three years, a Politburo member lay in state today in Moscow's black-draped Hall of Columns, his medals ranged on red satin cushions at his feet and a row of his aging colleagues from the leadership standing by the bier to pay their respects.

title: Abigail Cairns to Wed James B. Sperry
description: Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Clifton Cairns of Montreal and Prouts Neck, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Abigail Clifton Cairns, to James Baldwin Sperry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leavenworth Porter Sperry Jr. of Middlebury, Conn. The wedding is planned for June 15.

title: MEETING THE NEED FOR COCKTAIL PARTIES AND THE UNEXPECTED
description: IT is heavy entertaining time. Is

title: TOP SUFFOLK PLANNER RECOMMENDS A RISE IN SALES TAX TO 8-1/4%
description: The Suffolk County planning director has recommended raising the sales tax in the county to 8 1/4 percent, from the current 7 1/2 percent, to finance the purchase of park land, stabilize school taxes and help the county's 10 towns treat solid waste.

title: SPECIAL PROBLEMS FOR BUYERS
description: Ornately carved bannisters, stained- glass windows and fine wall moldings may add to the allure of older houses, but are they really better built? And are there problems and limitations that are not readily apparent to buyers?

title: Tara Buck Bride Of Jack Kester Jr.
description: Tara Killingsworth Buck, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Buck of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Jack Bevel Kester Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kester of Salisbury, N.C. The Rev. David Hoffelt performed the ceremony at the University Presbyterian Church in Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: 76ER'S ROUT PLACES NETS IN LAST PLACE
description: It was once quite easy for the Nets to look past their string of misfortune to a time when all their injured players would be healed and they would be able to recapture the zeal that carried them to a surprisingly successful playoff last spring. But that vision is growing dim.

title: Cristina Hunter Lahey Wed to David Kepner
description: Cristina Hunter Lahey, executive vice president of Invemed Associates, an investment banking concern in New York, was married yesterday to David Jonathan Kepner, a real-estate investor in Eastport, L.I. The Rev. George W. Busler performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title:
FASHION/BEAUTY;
PRIVATE PLACES
description: BETWEEN AWAKING and sleeping, dressing and undressing, there are precious few moments for private time - time for collecting thoughts, planning the day ahead and actually putting oneself together for it. One of the places where a woman can steal such solitude is at the dressing table. The dressing table is among the most intimate of personal furniture. It is where a face, and the individual behind it, prepares to greet the day. The table can be a collage of pretty pink flowers, pomanders and silver-backed hairbrushes. It can be a simple bureau top and mirror. Or perhaps just a bathroom cabinet shelf, even a corner of a table. More than just a surface containing beauty aids, a dressing table, whatever and wherever it is, can also rekindle pleasant memories when arrayed with mementos.

title: 78 Young Women Bow at the Debutante Cotillion
description: Seventy-eight young women made their formal bows to society last night at the 49th Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Rush H. Kress was honorary chairman of the event, an annual benefit for the New York Infirmary- Beekman Downtown Hospital.

title: COURT OVERTURNS L.I. TOWN's CURB ON SHARING SINGLE FAMILY HOMES
description: A New York State appeals court has declared illegal a Long Island town's provision that restricts the occupancy of most single-family houses to people related by blood, marriage or legal adoption.

title: GENERALS OPEN ON FEB.24
description: The New Jersey Generals will open their 1985 United States Football League season Feb. 24, when they play the Birmingham Stallions in Birmingham, Ala., the first of 18-regular season games for both teams in the revised 14-team league.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
description: YULETIDE OFFERINGS

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: EVEN 208 years later, it's never too late to repair damage to military reputations. And that is one of the surprises of a new account of the Battle of Trenton, which began with Washington's army crossing the Delaware River on Christmas Day in 1776.

title: GIFT OF LEARNING
description: As Christmas and Hanukkah approached, Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond suggested a gift ''in a class by itself: a continuing- education gift certificate.''

title: AUTHOR: IACOCCA: INSTANT BEST SELLER
description: ''We're still waiting for the Reagan economic recovery in Michigan, but the 'Iacocca' recovery has been great for booksellers,'' said Candice Eaton, manager of Volume One, a small bookstore in Petoskey, Mich., on the shore of Lake Michigan. She was commenting on this season's blockbuster best seller.

title: POLICE REVIEW AUTO-CHASE RULES
description: The New York City Police Department says it is taking steps to reduce the chance of harm to officers and the public during high-speed auto chases.

title: SOUNDING OFF
description: THE CARTER TRADE It Makes Sense

title: Fastest Ram Waits in Wings
description: ''We just don't pass the ball enough here.''

title: Jewish Italians
description: To the Editor:

title: VOTE TALLY POINTS TO L.I.'S KEY ROLE
description: ALTHOUGH it numbers third in voter registration among New York's 62 counties, Nassau County produced the largest total vote and the largest vote for the Reagan-Bush Republican ticket of any county in the state last month.

title: EDITOR GIVES UP ON SANDINISTAS
description: Pedro Joaquin Chamorro Barrios was named for his father, the courageous Nicaraguan editor, whose assassination in 1978 helped to galvanize the Sandinista revolt that brought down the right-wing Somoza dictatorship the next year. Last week, the younger Mr. Chamorro said he was weary of battling heavy Sandinista censorship and would live in exile until it is lifted.

title: Roger Gorham Fiance Of Ann E. Zacharchuk
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wallace V. Zacharchuk of Cherry Hill, N.J., and Columbia, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ann Elizabeth Zacharchuk to Roger Bryce Gorham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Gorham of Upper Saddle River, N.J. A July wedding is planned.

title: SOUNDING OFF
description: THE CARTER TRADE Right Formula

title: No Headline
description: MAXINE A. HENRY came to the United States to learn how to help her native country, Jamaica. The 32-year-old Miss Henry, now a resident of Voorhees, in Camden County, grew up in Kingston, Jamaica's capital, as a member of a politically conscious family.

title: No Headline
description: Lieut. Gen. Thomas A. Wornham of the Marine Corps, retired, who was decorated for leading his troops in the assault on Iwo Jimain World War II, died at his home Monday.

title: MAMMAL LIST APPEARS
description: A RECENTLY published list of mammals indicates that nothing has been done in New Jersey to protect or even monitor more than a dozen species of whales, dolphins and porpoises that migrate along the Atlantic Coast, often lingering here or becoming stranded along the way.

title: WHOSE NOSE KNOWS WHAT
description: Among the senses, smell may be the least understood. Conflicting scientific studies over the years haven't helped matters. But last week researchers at the University of Pennsylvania's Clinical Smell and Taste Research Center released the results of the biggest investigation yet into olfactory abilities.

title: ISLANDERS DOWN PENGUINS, 5-2
description: Slowly, with defense the key, the Islanders have reshaped their game. They raced to their fourth straight victory tonight, 5-2, over the Pittsburgh Penguins at Nassau Coliseum. They now haven't allowed an even- strength goal in two games. And they rallied back from a 2-1 deficit in the third period, with the tying goal by Bryan Trottier and the winner from Mike Bossy.

title: A HOUSE ALL DRESSED UP FOR THE HOLIDAYS
description: IN the front yard of Hardy and Gladys Horan's Terryville home, snowmen and reindeer stand vigil around the stable. A tin soldier stands at attention off to the side. A bearded man in a red flannel suit guides his team of reindeer through the trees above. And, oh yes, the music - Christmas carols play on through the day and the night, piped through a speaker mounted over the door..

title: BRONZE IN THE HANDS OF AMERICAN SCULPTORS
description: There is nothing flash in the pan about bronze. From antiquity, it's been regarded as a serious, monumental metal, a metaphor for permanence, employed for art and ritual objects, weapons and statues of achievers. But in this young country, it didn't come into widespread use for sculpture until the middle of the 19th century, when we had developed enough sense of history to want more lasting monuments, and achieved the bronze technology to make them. Turning from carving in wood and marble, American sculptors learned to model in this durable alloy of copper and tin, and were eventually able to realize as skillfully as their European counterparts its richly expressive potential.

title: DESIGN FLAWS CITED IN B-1 CRASH
description: Faulty placement of a warning light and other design flaws contributed to the crash August 28 of a $325 million prototype B-1 bomber, according to aeronautics experts who disputed an Air Force's report that human error was to blame.

title: SENATOR WORRIED ON PAKISTANI ARMS
description: The senior Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee warned today that any major American arms sale to Pakistan would undermine prospects for improved relations between the United States and India.

title: THE IMPACT OF THE EXOTIC
description: Bernard Lewis, the Cleveland E. Dodge Professor of Near Eastern studies at Princeton University and a member of the Institute for Advanced Study, is the author of ''The Muslim Discovery of Europe.'' THE ORIENTAL RENAISSANCE

title: THE ECONOMIC NEWS IS GOOD; HOWEVER...
description: President Truman so despaired of getting definite opinions from his economic advisers that he mournfully called for a one-handed economist. Ordinary citizens might well have felt that way last week, as experts greeted with caveats what looked like quite positive economic developments.

title: That 'Trolley' Plan For the L.I.R.R.
description: The Nov. 25 article about the Oyster Bay line of the Long Island Rail Road worries me (''L.I.R.R. Eyes a 'Trolley' Line for Oyster Bay''). I am a senior citizen who does not like to drive much any more, and the Oyster Bay line has given me a way to escape to the city once in a while.

title: ARE MAJOR MUSEUMS SLIGHTING TODAY'S ART?
description: This is a good time in the New York art world. There is a sense now that anything can happen. Unlike the 1950's and 60's, when artists were unlikely to be taken seriously if their work did not reflect Abstract Expressionism, Pop Art, Minimal Art, or other currents in the artistic mainstream, artists can now work in almost any style and material and have a chance to receive appropriate critical and public attention. The variety and the amount of convincing work in the galleries and public spaces of New York City - painting that is expressive, naturalistic, conceptual or abstract, sculpture made with industrial materials, found objects, bronze or wood - has probably never been greater.

title: THE RIGHT TRIM
description: tion to boast that I tell you

title: Member of the Cast Bites Pageant Actor
description: A man acting in a Christmas pageant was bitten by another member of the cast, a 1,100-pound camel, and required nine stiches.

title: AVOIDING THE 'OCTOPUS' AND OTHER FIRE HAZARDS
description: RESIDENTIAL fires are a constant threat all during the year, but the danger is even greater at this time, when everyone's mind is on holiday festivities and when there is often a great increase in the number of potential fire hazards around the hoese. Statistics have long shown that residential fires cost thousands of lives each year, in addition to millions of dollars worth of property.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Chanticleer is a 13-member male a cappella choral group from San Francisco that made an ingratiating New York debut Thursday night in Alice Tully Hall. The group's singing was fresh yet admirably precise, and it gave almost unalloyed pleasure in a repertory from Gregorian chant through all manner of Renaissance music to piquant contemporary selections to spirituals and folk songs.

title: RONALD PERELMAN WILL BE MARRIED TO CLAUDIA COHEN
description: Claudia Cohen, an entertainment reporter on WABC-TV's ''Morning Show'' and a former ''Page Six'' columnist for The New York Post, plans to be married Jan. 11 to Ronald O. Perelman, chairman of the McAndrews & Forbes Group, a holding company in New York Whose subsidiaries include Technicolor and the Consolidated Cigar Company.

title: Sarah Richards Is Married To Johann Thalheim 4th
description: The marriage of Sarah Jackson Richards, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Richards of Far Hills, N.J., to Johann Friedrich Ernst Thalheim 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hans G. Thalheim of Old Greenwich, Conn., took place yesterday.

title: REDEEMED BY LOVE AT 75
description: Nancy Forbes is a short-story writer and critic. THE LAST GOOD TIME

title: Queens Man, 37, Dies AfterFightWithPolice
description: A 37-year-old Queens man died early yesterday after he struggled with two police officers who tried to take him into custody for drunken driving, the police said.

title:
GARDENING;
POINSETTIA: QUEEN OF THE HOLIDAY PLANTS
description: THE poinsettia has become so closely associated with Christmas that any attempt to omit it from the seasonal decor will most certainly result in a noticeable void. The plants also make great gifts.

title: VOTERS IN SINGAPORE GIVE PARTY IN POWER A SWEEPING VICTORY
description: The People's Action Party of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew won a sweeping victory in parliamentary elections today.

title: NIGERIA SUFFERS ECONOMIC PAINS OF PETROLEUM WITHDRAWAL
description: In a supermarket here, many shelves are bare except for a coat of dust. Others hold bicarbonate of soda from Greece, canned lentils from Italy, fruit punch from the United States and salad dressing from Belgium. Only a few items - cornflakes and yam flour, for example - are made in Nigeria.

title: CRECHE FIGURES FROM ITALY
description: ANNE MARSHALL ZWACK is a writer who lives in Florence.

title: LAST-MINUTE WRAPPER REGRETS IT ALL
description: SOME people really relish wrapping gifts. They lavish loving attention on the most minute details and revel in the challenge of transforming a bunch of bulky, contrary parcels into something suitably festive for holiday gift giving. Their packages fairly shriek the season's greetings, be they headed for Christmas tree or Hanukkah bush.

title: Foreign Exchange
description: To the Editor:

title: An Early Christmas
description: THE stock market seems to have given investment managers an early Christmas present

title: MAILBAG
description: 'MUCH ADO,' PULITZERS AND TRUFFAUT

title: ALISON A. MANNY TO MARRY IN MAY
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James Craven Manny of New Canaan, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Alison Adams Manny, to Richard Brown Samuelson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Wesley Samuelson of Fairfield, Conn. The wedding is planned for May.

title: MOSCOW RETURNS DEFENSE MINISTRY TO CAREER OFFICER
description: Marshal Sergei L. Sokolov, a 73-year-old Soviet career officer and a First Deputy Minister of Defense for the last 17 years, was named today to replace the late Dmitri F. Ustinov as Defense Minister.

title: 'CHILLING EFFECT; OR FRESH AIR?
description: A ''chilling effect,'' a phrase invoked with numbing regularity these days, is the shibboleth that civil libertarians have brandished for a couple of decades against actions that could deter the press from exercising its constitutional freedom. Today, the big chill is presumably the megamillion-dollar libel suit. But there it strikes me that the old metaphor aptly describes a reasonable remedy for journalism's overheated excesses: this particular chilling effect may really be a breath of fresh air.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN BERNARDSVILLE
description: BERNARDSVILLE, all history and charm, is a community kissed by good fortune. Already an established hamlet inexplicably known as Vealtown by the time Washington and his army tramped through on their way to their Jockey Hollow encampment near Morristown, it has managed by dint of its resolve and a good bit of luck to survive booms and busts over the last 200 years and still retain its unique character.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
NATURE WATCH
description: HERMIT THRUSH

title: Rifka Levy Is Married
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., yesterday Rifka Levy, a doctoral candidate in organizational psychology at Columbia University, was married to Robert Reichman, who is studying for a master's degree in Middle Eastern affairs at George Washington University. Rabbi William Berman, assisted by Cantor David Abikzar, performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Shelomo Levy of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and Dr. and Mrs. Irwin Reichman of Dix Hills, L.I., and Jerusalem.

title: Indians and Taxes
description: After her husband died, Mildred Skinner, a 78-year-old retired schoolteacher in Woodville, N.Y., decided to do ''the right thing.'' She gave her 66- acre farm to the original owners, the Onondaga Indians.

title: Fastest Draft in the East In the course of writing probably more books than the average person has read,
description: Isaac Asimov has demonstrated not only remarkable stamina, but also a kick. Like a marathon runner accelerating in the final mile, the 64- year-old Mr. Asimov, who last week celebrated the publication of his 300th title, ''Opus 300,'' has been writing faster than ever in recent years.

title: No Headline
description: Exodus: Walter B. Wriston, the nation's most influential banker, gave the Citicorp baton to John S. Reed, a boyish-looking 45-year-old. The iron hand of the legendary Dr. Armand Hammer, 86, struck again at Occidental Petroleum, ousting one critic, A. Robert Abboud, president, and unseating director David Murdock, whose large stock block was repurchased by the company. On Wall Street, Roger E. Birk stepped down as the head of Merrill Lynch; John C. Whitehead retired as co-chairman of Goldman Sachs; John Phelan stepped up to the chairmanship of the New York Stock Exchange,and David Tendler was elbowed out as co-chief executive of Phibro-Salomon while John H. Gutfreund took sole control.

title: 'HIS 'BRIDGES' CROSS 40 DIFFERENT CULTURES
description: ''WHEN we introduce two different cultures, something rare happens,'' said Stanley H. Barkan. He should know. As editor and publisher of Cross-Cultural Communications, a small press in Merrick, Mr. Barkan spends much of his time making introductions.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You know, people accuse us of playing God when we turn off machines. But nobody makes that accusation when we interfere with death by turning on the machines.'' - Dr. William A. Greene, psychiatrist at University of Rochester Medical Center. (18:4.)

title: HERALDING THE GOOD LIFE
description: WHEN IT COMES TO REMEMbrances of Christmas past, food, curiously enough, seems only a tangential factor. The things that I recall in

title: WORD OF CAUTION FROM SENATOR NUNN MAY SIGNAL TROUBLE FOR MX
description: Senator Sam Nunn, the senior Democrat on the Armed Services Committee, says his vote on the MX missile next year will depend in part on how seriously the Reagan Adminstration attempts to negotiate limits on new defensive weapons in space.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
OF GRAND GOLD PANDAS AND PENNY BOARDS
description: The People's Republic of China has issued a new proof coin containing a full troy pound (12 troy ounces) of .999-fine gold. The coin has a denomination of 1,000 yuan and is being marketed under the name ''Grand Gold Panda.'' Its obverse design depicts a giant panda in a bamboo forest. The coin's reverse portrays the 500-year-old Temple of Heaven in Beijing which is considered one of China's architectural wonders.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: MASSACHUSETTS CELEBRATION, SWISS TAXATION
description: Cultural Events Flood Boston At Year's End

title: Data Update
description: * Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic.

title: A BEAR BOOM THAT'S NOT JUST FOR KIDS
description: JUDGING from Allison Squire's shopping

title: Jays Get Burroughs
description: If the Toronto Blue Jays become a more solid pennant contender by way of offseason acquisitions, they will have the Oakland A's to thank. First, the Blue Jays acquired Oakland's ace reliever, Bill Caudill , in a trade, and yesterday they purchased the contract of the A's designated hitter Jeff Burroughs.

title: PARK AVENUE IN FOR A DIN
description: Along Park Avenue, behind graceful, anonymous building facades, are the homes of some of the nation's wealthiest people. Beneath the fabled thoroughfare, though, are rotting railroad tunnels, ravaged by water, salt, sewage and time.

title: BRITISH TAKE TO GORBACHEV IN A BIG WAY
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, widely regarded as the likeliest heir-apparent to Konstantin U. Chernenko as the Soviet leader, impressed his British hosts this week as a man of power, intelligence and enough self-confidence to indulge his sense of humor in public.

title: UNIVERSITY ARREST STIRS CONTROVERSY
description: ALMOST two months after an incident involving the arrest of a staff member of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, officers in the public safety department are seeking a ''clarification'' of the administration's policy regarding the arrest of university employees.

title: U.S. PARTS WAYS WITH UNESCO
description: When Unesco was founded in 1946, its first leader, the British biologist Julian Huxley, hoped it would clear the way for international intellectual cooperation free from international politics. Instead, Western leaders have argued, the United Nations agency has ended up in a blind alley, captive to leftist demagoguery and a bloated bureaucracy.

title: Wall Street Blues
description: The Dow Jones industrial average began the year at around 1,250 and is winding up at around 1,200 - which is part of the problem. Small investors deserted the market in droves, squeezing earnings at the big retail houses.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Football
description: Giants vs. Los Angeles Rams, National Conference wild-card playoff game, at Anaheim, Calif. If the Giants lose, the players go home.

title: Barbara Mulle, Bank Aide, Wed to Thomas P. Clerkin

Clerkin, a son of Ellen Clerkin of La Jolla, Calif., and the late Patrick Clerkin. The Rev. William Larkin performed the ceremony at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

Dillon of Greenwich, Conn., to Stevens Langley Shea 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stevens Langley Shea of Franconia, N.H., took place yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Westerly, R.I. The Rev. title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday on the marriage of Eloise Lincoln Zeeman and David Alan Scharff misidentified the clergyman who performed the ceremony. He is Rabbi H. Leonard Poller.

title: A House Fire in Jersey Kills 4 Small Children
description: Four children who were left alone in a house without electricity were killed tonight after a candle they were using for light ignited a fire in the bedroom of their house here, officials said.

title: Cold Eyes On a walk recently, a friend saw a man training his Seeing Eye dog, anticipating its learning processes with great good humor. Then on the bus he saw a child lying on a seat twitching a white shoelace across the floor as if a fish were nibbling at it. ''He fishes a lot,'' his mother said, but didn't know whether he had a trout or shark or goldfish in mind. Perhaps he visualizes a fish, goggle-eyed and bulgy- headed, that has yet to exist.
description: And what do fish themselves envision? That seems easier to imagine with dogs or even frogs. Frogs are shaped rather like us and we know that they mate after a songfest; that indeed all vertebrate music can be assumed to have originated from the croaking and peeping of ancestral frogs. From frogs to birds to flutes to divas. Or consider turtles: A male box turtle has red eyes, the female brown, so when he walks toward her she sees his sparks. Male painted turtles have long nails on their forefeet with which to tickle the throats of the females whom they swim to court.

title: CUOMO SAYS PUBLICITY KILLED CONCEPT OF DEPUTY GOVENOR
description: It is ''very unlikely'' that the job of deputy governor will ever be created, because of adverse publicity surrounding the idea, according to Governor Cuomo.

title: CUOMO APPOINTS 23 TO STUDY ISSUES IN MEDICAL TECHNOLOGY
description: Governor Cuomo has appointed 23 people to a commission on ''life and the law'' that will review and make recommendations on a wide range of issues associated with new medical technologies.

title: HUMOR: VICTOR BORGE
description: Victor Borge is back at Carnegie Hall, and the audience loves him. That was clear from the start: enough laughs to float a good ''Barber of Seville'' had been laughed before he even told any jokes. The amiable humorist's admirers knew just what they were going to get, got it, and were happy.

title: THE SHAME OF THE HOUSE OF MONTBOURG
description: MARTHE

title: CAN ELECTRONICS SOLVE ALL ACOUSTICAL PROBLEMS?
description: The specter of concert-hall electronics continues to haunt those who believe that God intended concert halls to be made of wood and plaster, unsullied by loudspeakers, transistors and delay systems. Acoustic fundamentalists see in modern acoustic technology the death of pure sound, murdered by the devils who tamper with natural law. And the chief American devil in their eyes is a cherubic-looking gentleman named Christopher Jaffe, the head of Christopher Jaffe Associates in Norwalk, Conn., who already has electronified about a dozen halls and is planning more.

title: 'HOT COLLEGES'
description: I am a high-school senior who is involved in the ''application rush.'' I feel that the application and admission process has gotten out of control.

title: 'PETER PAN' MAKES FINE HOLIDAY FARE
description: ONE look into toy store windows spilling out their cornucopia of wondrous, brightly colored holiday gifts is almost enough magic to transport even the most fuddy-duddy adult into Never-Never Land, where childhood is forever. For those who have to work or go to school, the next best thing to living in Never-Never Land is seeing a production of ''Peter Pan'' and living vicariously via Peter, Wendy, Tinkerbell, the Lost Boys and the nefarious Captain Hook.

description: Bucks 101, Spurs 90

'I WAS SICK AND YOU VISITED': A SPIRIT IS FELT
description: AT the entrance to the nursing home there are gold and white chrysanthemums slightly brownish from the frost. They are carefully placed in large buckets that surround yellow tables and attached unbrellas. There are fringes of autumn that suggest the onset of winter.

title: G.O.P. CHOOSES BRADY TO HEAD COUNTY'S BOARD
description: EDWARD J. BRADY of Thornwood, majority leader of the Board of Legislators, last week was chosen by its Republican caucus to be the Board's next Chairman, replacing Andrew A. Albanese of Scarsdale.

Chichester of Midland, Mich. The Rev. Almus M. Thorp Jr. performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church Cranbrook.

title: THE DANCE: LINDA GOLD
description: Linda Gold was always a strong dramatic presence in her solo dances on Wednesday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio. Miss Gold, director of the dance department at Santa Monica Community College, choreographically acknowledged the mysteries of nature in several fascinating works.

description: American efforts to punish Colonel Qaddafi received a setback last week when the Libyan leader visited the Spanish island of Majorca and met with the Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez.

title: PEEKSKILL MAYOR LOOKS TO GROWTH
description: -ELECT George Pataki, the outgoing Republican Mayor of this city, poked his head into his former office at City Hall the other day. Sitting behind his old desk was his successor, Richard E. Jackson. Mr. Pataki couldn't let the encounter pass without ribbing his childhood buddy.

title: Jacqueline Haber Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rudolf Haber of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jacqueline Haber, to Dr. Erno Grunstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mor Grunstein of Rego Park, Queens.

title: AN ANNUAL REPORT ON 1984
description: NO other year was born with the burdens of 1984. Famed in literature, it was feared by many as a time when Big Brother - chillingly portrayed in George Orwell's novel and reviled in Apple Computer's popular commercial - would smother individuality.

title: WHEN IDEAS BECOME MAJOR BREAKTHROUGHS
description: When an idea captures the imagination of an epoch, there is no setting limits to its possible application. But it has to be a big idea, not a nuance or a tactical improvement, no matter how critical to the feasibility of a key opening variation.

title: UNUSUAL SONG AND DANCE EVENTS WILL FILL OUT THE SEASON
description: WERE you so busy with preholiday activities that you missed the many fine concerts around the county? All is not yet lost - some of the most unusual Christmas programs are yet to come.

title: DELAYS ARE FOUND IN SCHOOL REPAIRS
description: An audit by the City Comptroller has found that inadequate attention by the Board of Education to minor repairs at school buildings has often resulted in unsafe and uncomfortable conditions.

title: ARMY WINS, 10-6, IN ITS BOWL DEBUT
description: Army's quarterback, Nate Sassaman, rushed for 136 yards today in guiding the team's magnificent wishbone offense, and the Cadet defense came up with five turnovers as the Black Knights made their bowl debut a success by beating Michigan State, 10-6, in the inaugural Cherry Bowl.

CHRISTMAS GIFT;
LIVING WITH MY VCR
description: Nora Ephron is the author of ''Heartburn'' and the co-author of the screenplay of ''Silkwood.''

description: With one of their best defensive performances of the year, the Seattle Seahawks today ended any thoughts of the Los Angeles Raiders repeating as Super Bowl champions.

description: THE lament about there being ''no decent place to eat in Stamford'' is fast becoming passe. While new restaurants may not be opening constantly, there are enough to sustain one's interest.

Statistics have long shown that such fires cost thousands of lives each year, in addition to millions of dollars worth of property.

The Rev. David Wayne performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. George Como. The bride, the daughter of Elizabeth Bell of New York and the late Calvin Bell, graduated from the University of California at Los Angeles. Mr. Roker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roker of New York, graduated from the State University of New York College at Oswego.

title: 'DEAR SANTA'-AND HERE'S YOUR ANSWER
description: THIS is the most important time of year for Evelyn Bloomer of Westbury, a retired postal worker. She may not be well-known to many Long Island residents, but every December she touches the lives of thousands of Nassau and Suffolk County families.

title: ...ON A RETURN TO OLD DELIGHTS
description: I SIT in my apartment at the foot of the Rocky Mountains and watch the light dance on a gold-plated snowflake, my year- round reminder of Christmas at home. Five years ago I left New York to live in Denver, but every year at Christmas my heart returns and takes up residence in Northport, my hometown.

They range from an off-price shopping mall in Secacus to a movie theater complex in the Meadowlands to Harmon Cove, a 1,200-unit housing development in Hudson County.

description: SELLING postcards of gigantic nuts and graves of early colonists is not what Jonathan Buller usually does for a living.

GARDENING;
POINSETTIA: QUEEN OF THE HOLIDAY PLANTS
description: THE poinsettia has become so closely associated with Christmas that any attempt to omit it from the seasonal decor will most certainly result in a noticeable void. The plants also make great gifts.

title: SCIENTIST CHARTS CHRISTMAS STAR
description: WHILE Christmas is celebrated on Dec. 25, an astronomer at Central Connecticut State University in New Britain has calculated that Jesus Christ was born on April 6, 6 B.C. and that the Christmas star was actually an unusual conjunction of planets.

LIVING AMID THE MARKETS

description: THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN is chief of the Jerusalem bureau of The New York Times.

Norton Company in Chicago, and Michael Dain Searle, president of Renaissance Ventures, a Chicago investment concern, plan to be married Jan. 26. Mr. and Mrs. Allan Kline of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Crow Searle of Winnetka, Ill.

title: B.Y.U. Led by Gimpy Bosco
description: It would have been fitting for Robbie Bosco to be accompanied to the interview room by a fife and drum instead of the television cameramen and photographers recording every step of the procession that Bosco led with the aid of crutches. For three quarters, Brigham Young's national championship aspirations had made the quarterback ignore the pain in his ribs, left knee and ankle; now, he was being comforted by a victory that was more soothing than the warm shower he had just taken.

title: ISLAMIC PARLEY ENDS IN DISCORD ON IRAN-IRAQ WAR
description: A five-day meeting of foreign ministers from 45 Islamic countries ended tonight amid discord over how to bring an end to the Iran-Iraq war.

description: The Rev. Dr. Ben Mohr Herbster, the first president of the United Church of Christ after it formed in 1961, died at Kettering Memorial Hospital in Dayton, Ohio, on Dec. 16. after surgery. He was 80 years old and lived in Dayton.

title: Cable TV
description: With Christmas carols pervasive now, cable film buffs may want to seek out a little more variety on the home screen this week. Sunday alone offers a mini-harvest. Take Max Steiner's background score for ''Since You Went Away'' (1944), a moving if somewhat glistening drama of America's home front in World War II.

title: Free Lunches
description: It was an offbeat tax-evasion case in which two restaurant partners found out, in effect, that there is no free lunch, but a mission learned that there is indeed.

title: GIANTS' DREAM ON LINE
description: Down the street from Disneyland, where fantasies are fulfilled, the Giants start living out a fantasy of their own Sunday. At 3:30 P.M., New York time, they play the Los Angeles Rams in a wild-card game at Anaheim Stadium on the opening weekend of the National Football League playoffs.

title: Seton Hall 58, St. Peter's 57
description: Andre McCloud a game-high 21 points as Seton Hall held off St. Peter's. McCloud was carried off the floor on a stretcher late in the game after suffering a hip injury, but he is expected to be ready for the San Juan Classic, which starts Dec. 28 in Puerto Rico.

title: YOUNG DIABETICS LEARN TO COPE
description: IT was last summer, during modeling auditions, when 6-year-old Troy Newsom of Garden City Park, an active boy with a mop of blond hair and blue eyes, complained constantly of thirst. His mother, Barbara, also noticed that he urinated a lot.

title: Chinese Being Urged To Eat Western Style
description: China's Communist Party chief, Hu Yaobang, said today that eating Chinese style from a common plate was unsanitary.

title: DRUG TRADE IN BAHAMAS IS CREEPING INTO POLITICS
description: The unit of currency here, the Bahamian dollar, is precisely equal to the American dollar but bears a picture of Queen Elizabeth II. That combination neatly symbolizes the two influences that dominate life in these islands: 325 years of British colonial tradition, reflected in the parliamentary political system, and the overwhelming economic power of 20th century America just 55 miles away.

title: Art
description: Last year the Vanderwoude Tananbaum Gallery, 24 East 81st Street, asked artists to create toys for a Christmas benefit exhibition. This year, the gallery has done it again, and there is every sign that it will become a tradition.

description: Marco Portales , an associate editor of the literary magazine MELUS, teaches English at the University of Houston, Clear Lake. LOVE MEDICINE

title: GLORY DAYS ARE FADING FOR CHAVEZ AND U.F.W.
description: A figure that seemed out of the past appeared on the nightly news in California last week - Cesar Chavez, waving a picket sign and doing what he perhaps does best, attracting the attention of television cameramen as a spokesman for farm workers.

title: DEPAUL RALLIES TO DEAFEAT NORTHWESTERN
description: DePaul rallied from a 10-point halftime deficit to defeat Northwestern today, 61-56, as Tony Jackson led the comeback with 13 points.

title: 'Hot' Colleges
description: When I first saw Michael Winerip's article, ''Hot Colleges and How They Get That Way'' (Nov. 18), I braced myself for a list of hot colleges, ranked, I supposed, by ratios of applications to spaces, quality of campus life and maybe SAT scores. As a graduate of and admissions interviewer for Brown, and also a graduate of Stanford, I commend Michael Winerip for what was

title: SCULPTURE ADORNS HOFSTRA CAMPUS
description: ART

title: ONOMATOPOETIC JUSTICE
description: To the Editor:

title: MUNICIPALITIES PLAN MT. LAUREL CHALLENGE
