description: AT LEAST 22, and possibly 40 or more, municipalities are planning to take their grievances over application of the Mount Laurel II zoning decision to the United States Supreme Court.

title: COLLECTIONS CHRONICLE THE TALENTS OF BILL EVANS AND CHARLIE PARKER
description: Multiple-record boxed sets have long been the most appropriate format for marketing complete operas, Beethoven's string quartets, J. S. Bach's collected keyboard studies and similar bodies of work. Commercial factors play a part in determining whose performances and which works are accorded lavish boxed set treatment, but generally these collections have to make some sort of musical sense. For example, one would not expect to find a boxed set of albums containing every piece written by a celebrated Baroque composer for one of his several patrons.

title: Talk Tough; Then Blame Congress
description: Defense Secretary Weinberger won a famous victory last week. Despite heavy opposition from Cabinet colleagues and Congressional leaders and despite the huge, overhanging Federal budget deficit, he persuaded President Reagan that defense spending must remain sacred. Though conscientious conservatives see the need for serious reductions, the President agreed to trivial cuts. Boy, does that make him look tough!

title: Broadcast TV
description: ''Shall I tell you a story?'' Those most magical of words in the English are intoned by Peter Ustinov at the start of ''John Curry Skates Peter and the Wolf,'' which was produced by WGBH-TV in Boston and will be rebroadcast on Channel 13 Sunday night from 7 to 8. But the ''big green meadow'' of Peter's adventures is, however, a skating rink, and no amount of charm succeeds in giving it the intimacy of a children's story.

title: 122 STUNG BY 'STOLEN' CARS
description: When a car is reported stolen in New York City - something that happens 90,000 times a year - the victim is not always the owner. In about one case in four, it's the insurance company, according to Raymond J. Dearie, the United States Attorney in Brooklyn.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
IN GOOD OLD DAYS, THE CHRISTMAS TREE WAS JUST A TREE
description: MY family's tree-trimming style was rather casual. A day or two before Christmas someone was asked to go to Woolworth's to buy two boxes of tinsel, a box or two of balls, some candy canes. We never needed an angel or star for the top of the tree. One of our cats was usually perched there.

title: Music
description: The down home Arkansas twang has never left Bob Dorough's voice although Mr. Dorough left Arkansas almost 40 years ago. He is a singer, pianist and songwriter with a highly individual manner that has led him to be categorized with, among others, Blossom Dearie, Johnny Mercer, Dave Frishberg and Hoagy Carmichael largely because none of them are conveniently categorizable although they hover around similar areas.

title: WILLIAM WOLFMAN
description: William Wolfman, an attorney and an authority on real-estate law, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Elmhurst General Hospital in Queens. He was 83 years old and lived in New York City.

title:
ANTIQUES;
VESSELS FOR MERRY HOLIDAY WASSAILING
description: SOME of the particularly fine, small antiques prized by collectors today were, to their original owners, symbols of the celebrations held at Christmas, New Year's and on Twelfth Night, or Epiphany. These were the occasions when a special spiced punch, wassail, was served from handsome bowls, drunk from tankards or the family's best glasses.

title: Anne Lombard,Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Anne Spencer Lombard, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Lombard of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Mark E. Cammack, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elwin F. Cammack of Madison, Wis., were married yesterday. The Rev. Eleanor S. Meyers performed the Protestant ceremony at the Gates of Heaven, a historic landmark building in Madison.

title: THE JEWISH WRITER
description: To the Editor:

title: TOY MAKERS FROLIC IN FANTASY LAND
description: In a classic battle of good against evil, the villain Cy-Kill flees from the planet GoBotron and allies himself on Earth with a brilliant but greedy scientist. Together they plot to take control of the Earth, but Leader-1, the hero, rushes in to save the day.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
GAWKY, YES BUT STILL A FINE TREE
description: '' STREW on her roses, roses. And never a spray of yew,'' wrote Matthew Arnold. It is a lament, and the yew symbolizes his sorrow.

title: THE TAX PLAN-AN EXCITING POLICY
description: The Treasury Department's simplified tax proposal is intriguing - but not half as intriguing as the reaction it has provoked.

title: GIFT FOR A SCHOOL
description: Christmas has arrived early at The Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, where last Monday, an unsolicited check for $400,000 arrived.

title: The Ghosts of Christmas Many of the ghosts of Christmas are all too visible - the homeless who haunt us from park benches and in rail and bus terminals. But many more of those pitiful ghosts are not visible at all; their misery, hunger, pain and loneliness are all too easily overlooked. Will they remain hidden from conscience as well? Or will they be pointedly remembered as we rejoice in the season and seek the warmth of family and home?
description: The jobless, the ill, the fragile old, the neglected young - they can be helped.

title: VERBATIM: COX ON MEESE
description: 'The office of Attorney General requires a person who can symbolize the highest standards of honor, integrity, and freedom from favoritism or other self-interest in the performance of public office. Only such a person can build the confidence in the integrity and even-handedness of law and law enforcement that is essential to democracy.

title: Institutional Buying
description: Nothing frustrates stock investors more than a price ''spike,'' the trade jargon for a sharp one-day market rise or decline, such as the one last Tuesday that sent the Dow Jones industrial average soaring 34.78 points, to 1,211.57. Many small investors rushed into the market the next day only to find themselves swamped by professional traders taking profits.

title: BIG PULLOVERS, BOLD PATTERNS
description: Big dots and big roses on big sweaters are turning up all over town. The prices of the wool pullovers with their giant patterns aren't minuscule, but the tentlike, Japanese-influenced sweaters seemed to be just the thing to wear during the recent mild weather.

title: CURBING THE COPYING OF SCORES
description: In a case that may have significance for conservatories and

title: RETIREMENT RULE FOR JUDGES UPSET
description: The ruling came in a suit by five judges and threatened to throw the state's court system into confusion. Four of the plaintiffs turned 70 this year and are due to be replaced in January by judges elected in November.

title: Yokohama
description: To the Editor:

title: CynthiaCoggeshallBecomestheBride Of Richard Ten Broeck Trask, Banker
description: Cynthia Coggeshall, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bayard Coggeshall of Mendham, N.J., and Richard Ten Broeck Trask, a son of Mrs. John J. Trask of New York and the late Mr. Trask, were married yesterday. The Rev. Albert Niesse performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. John on the Mountain in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: Memphis St. 76, Iona 62
description: The senior forward Keith Lee scored 20 points and grabbed 11 rebounds as Memphis State collected its eighth straight victory.

title: HOLIDAY REFLECTIONS: ON THE MATTER OF GREETINGS...
description: TO paraphrase Keats's lament that another English winter would put an end to him, I sometimes think another Long Island winter will put an end to me - at least, if it's like several I can recall. Certainly, I'm not dreaming of a white Christmas; I'm hoping it won't be. The delicate symmetry of snowflakes may be one of nature's most perfect designs, but I prefer looking elsewhere for evidence of The Source, thank you.

title: SCHOOL BOARDS FACE FIGHT INQUIRIES
description: A STEP taken by the New Jersey School Boards Association to avoid child-molestation incidents has drawn the ire of the teachers' union, which has called it an unfair and degrading invasion of privacy.

title: Another First
description: Here's a new first. According to the sports information department of West Virginia University, Georgeann Wells , a 6-foot-7 junior, made what is believed to be college basketball's first dunk by a woman.

title: PLAN TO BUILD INCINERATORS WINS BY A VOTE
description: The Board of Estimate last week disposed of one of the thorniest problems it had faced in a long while. By a 6-to-5 majority, obtained after weeks of negotiations, it reached agreement on what to do with New York City's garbage: five modern incinerators will be built by 1991, one in each borough. If necessary, three more incinerators - called resource recovery plants because the energy created by burning the garbage would be used to make electricity - would be built later.

title: Trouble in the Magic Kingdom
description: In January, the biggest worry at Walt Disney Productions was whether nudity in its hit movie ''Splash'' would tarnish the company's squeaky- clean image. But the March resignation of Roy E. Disney, son of Roy O. Disney, one of the co- founders, spelled trouble for the Magic Kingdom.

title: OFFICES & HOTEL
description: Among the last major projects planned for the 20-year- old, 130-acre urban-renewal program now drawing to a close in White Plains is a hotel and office complex to be built at the corner of Main and Bank Streets directly accross the street from the railroad station.

title: 'HOT COLLEGES'
description: Michael Winerip's report on hot colleges was flawed by his failure to report on students attending schools other than those in the most elite categories: expensive suburban high schools, boarding schools and highly competitive urban secondary schools. Thus, his story is one of an expensive commodity being packaged and sold to a privileged and/or gifted group of students. The majority of young Americans do not fit into either category, and it would be interesting to know what they are doing in this overheated commercial climate. MARION HUNT

title: Ukrainians Who Resisted
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese Military Aide Faults Army on Economic Grounds
description: A senior military official has complained that China's Army does not contribute enough to the Chinese economy, wastes resources and saps the state budget.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
NOTIONS ABOUT 30'S COME TO PASS AT 40
description: WHEN I was in my 20's and newly married, I once flippantly announced at a cocktail party that I would not at all mind being 40 years old; it was 30 that I dreaded. I associated being 30 with all the cliches of suburban living, while 40, on the other hand, meant being sophisticated, ''established.''

title: Confounding Futures
description: Commodity prices - cash and futures - have long been dependable economic indicators that usually project general economic activity trends six months ahead. Usually, if the Commodity Research Bureau's index of future prices is down, the economy will be down six months later - and vice versa.

title: IN INDIA, A WAVE CRESTS FOR GANDHI AND HIS PARTY
description: If the opinion polls and other soundings are right, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and his Congress Party are heading for an easy victory, perhaps even a landslide of historic dimensions, in this week's general election.

title: Bits and Pieces
description: The Good News: You didn't have to buy a ticket to win the lottery at U.S. News & World Report, the Washington newsweekly. Long-time employees reaped a sudden windfall when the magazine was sold to Mortimer Zuckerman, a real estate developer and owner of The Atlantic. Some 20 to 40 people at the publication became overnight millionaires, prompting a new men's room graffiti: ''For millionaires only.''

title: 'The Chicago School'
description: The once-clubby European foreign exchange markets are undergoing radical changes today as a result of what traders call ''the Chicago School.''

title: Pennsylvania Measure Outlaws Rape of Spouse
description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh signed a bill Friday making it a crime to rape a spouse, but also making it a less serious offense than other rapes.

title:
ANTIQUES;
SUGARPLUMS AND PERIOD STYLES ON HOLIDAY VIEW IN PRINCETON
description: -design talents and ''sugarplum'' artistry of John and Cile Bellefleur Burbridge of Danvers, Mass., can be seen through Feb. 15 in a holiday exhibition jointly sponsored by LaVake Jewelers and Silversmiths, 54 Nassau Street, and the New Jersey Historical Society at Morven, the former Executive Mansion on Stockton Street.

title: The Jewish Writer
description: To the Editor:

title: 'EINSTEIN' BECKONS US TO THE FOURTH DIMENSION
description: The last time Robert Wilson was in New York with a major theater piece the stage at the Metropolitan Opera House seemed to levitate. The revival of ''Einstein on the Beach'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, a careful reproduction of the historic original, is a homecoming for this seminal American performance artist after eight years of working primarily in European theaters and opera houses. It also acts as a reminder that Wilson is an innovator who daringly alters our perception of the possibilities of the theatrical experience. His is a theater of images - visual, aural, sculptural and architectural. In synchronization with Philip Glass as composer and Lucinda Childs as choreographer, he has created a cosmos of the arts.

title: BANK SEEKS TO OFFER VARIED SERVICES
description: CUSTOMERS at the Society for Savings on Pratt Street in Hartford can now buy insurance or book an ocean cruise without leaving the bank's lobby.

title: CAPPY THE TALKER
description: WASHINGTON Secretary of Defense Weinberger

title: Bonds
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: PLAYS FOR THE DEAF

title: DO WE BUY OR ARE WE SOLD?
description: Stephen Fox's most recent book is ''The Mirror Makers: A History of American Advertising and Its Creators.'' ADVERTISING, THE UNEASY PERSUASION

title: CONFIDENT REVIVAL OF 'FAIR LADY'
description: IF you haven't heard of Meg Bussert, it is high time you did.

title: Giants' Morris Excited by Rejuvenation
description: Joe Morris is excited. The Giants' 5-foot- 7-inch running back, whose even manner does not betray whether he has just run for 100 yards a game or only 2 yards, was smiling as he headed for the final workout for Sunday's playoff game against the Los Angeles Rams.

title: ACCOUNTS OF RUSSIAN'S CHINA VISIT SUGGEST EXPECTATIONS ARE LIMITED
description: Official accounts today of the visit to China by a senior Soviet official offered new indications of the limited expectations both Governments appear to have for the occasion.

title: The Patou Revival
description: Although many top perfume lines such as Chanel No. 5 and Joy have been around for generations, special fragrances to commemorate particular events have long played important - albeit brief - roles in the French perfume industry. Usually the lines are dropped shortly after the event.

title: THE WORLD ; IRANIANS SAY FOUR HIJACKERS WILL BE TRIED
description: The ways of justice seem as arcane as many other features of life in Iran, so the State Department last week was restrained in its praise when Iran announced that the four hijackers who were captured at Teheran airport on Dec. 9 would be tried under ''the penal law of the Islamic Republic.''

title: RICHARD OTTINGER, PRIVATE CITIZEN
description: NEW ROCHELLE QUITE soon, Richard L. Ottinger will have to turn in the New York license plate on his cream-colored Ford station wagon. It reads: ''U.S. Congress 20-2.''

title: CITICORP SAVINGS: SOARING AS COMPETITORS WINCE
description: ACROSS the country, the name

title: THE AIRLINE THAT SHOOK THE INDUSTRY
description: Sara Rimer is a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times.

title: WHY A.M.A. MUST OPPOSE MEDICARE-FEE FREEZE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW TREASURES FROM THE NORMANDIE
description: For some steamship buffs, the Normandie still sails the seas and may never reach final port. The legend of the French superliner, described at its launching in 1935 as the world's most magnificent ship, has to date had more to do with its extraordinary decoration and art works than what happened to passengers in the late 1930's, the heyday of trans-Atlantic travel. Given time, however, the saga of the Normandie may swell with stories of human dramas.

title: A QUARREL OVER WEIMAR BOOK
description: Over the past two years, a dispute involving charges of scholarly fraud has grown so bitter that historians are urging a reassessment of the ethics of academic debate and the standards of scholarship.

title: Leesa Conley Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Conley of Merchantville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leesa Jane Conley, to Mitchell Paul Harding, a son of Genevieve Harding of Waynesburg, Pa., and David Harding of Baltimore.

title: ATHENEUM PUBLISHERS CELEBRATES ITS 25TH YEAR
description: Atheneum Publishers is observing its 25th anniversary this season. More than most, the middle sized trade book house symbolizes the constants and changes in the modern world of publishing: the effort to remain independent, the different means of survival within larger companies, and the chancy game of briging books before the American reader in the electronic age.

title: Oh Dad, Poor Dad
description: Starring Rosalind Russell, Robert Morse and Barbara Harris; directed by Richard Quine, 1967 Paramount 86 minutes. $49.95

title: 'HOT COLLEGES'
description: Two years ago, as a college- bound senior, I witnessed many of my classmates rejoice or cry over acceptance or rejection at a ''hot'' college.

title: MORE BACH, JUST IN TIME FOR HIS BIRTHDAY
description: Music scholars and music lovers had reason to celebrate last week. There is a brand new batch of Bach to listen to.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: PATCHWORK TALES

title: AMERICA'S RETURN TO PRAYER
description: It is no accident that the prayer revival in America has coincided with the increasing efforts on the part of the Roman Catholic hierarchy to pressure Catholic public officials into forwarding the moral views of the church, and with the maneuvers of the fundamentalist religious right to expand its political power in Washington. For the underlying assumption of those who pray is that they can make direct contact with the ultimate moral authority - God - and that they will thereby learn the right way for human beings to behave. It is not very many steps along the road from that to the fanatical convictions of a Khomeini: for if one knows

title: ...ON A SPECIAL KIND OF GIVING
description: AT a Thanksgiving table burdened with bounty, the conversation eased into a predictable discussion of Christmas gifts. As I looked at my three children, I knew that this would be one year I wouldn't say, ''Oh, I don't know - surprise me.''

title: Crew of Fishing Boat Saved
description: Fifteen commercial fishermen were rescued unharmed after they abandoned their burning boat six miles off the coast of southern Oregon, the Coast Guard said today.

title: THE RELICS OF BYZANTIUM
description: FERGUS M. BORDEWICH is a writer who lives in Greece and New York.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Chanticleer is a 13-member male a cappella choral group from San Francisco that made an ingratiating New York debut Thursday night in Alice Tully Hall. The group's singing was fresh yet admirably precise, and it gave almost unalloyed pleasure in a repertory from Gregorian chant through all manner of Renaissance music to piquant contemporary selections to spirituals and folk songs.

title: COUNTERFEIT CABBAGE PATCH DOLL OFFERS AN ACRID CHRISTMAS OPTION
description: While parents have been standing in long lines to buy the popular, pudgy Cabbage Patch Kid dolls as Christmas presents for their children, the authorities in at least six states have been investigating the sales of counterfeit look-a-likes that carry a strong chemical odor.

title: FOR DOCTORS AND PATIENTS, DECISIONS ON DEATH
description: ''You've told me I have a year or two to live,'' the 54-year-old patient said to the doctor in the examining room. ''Now I'm telling you that when the time comes, I don't want to be on prolonged life-support machines. I just don't see the point.''

title: LAWRIE AND BETSEY MOTT WILL BE BRIDES
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Mott of New York and Quogue, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughters, Dorothy Lawrence Mott and Betsey Wittmer Mott, to Marc Peter Reisner and Matthew Joseph St. Onge, respectively. Mr. Reisner is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Konrad Reisner of Dayton, Ohio. Mr. St. Onge is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John St. Onge of Brunswick, Me.

title: Ellen Maria Bruzelius to Be the Bride Of William Neville Tifft in the Spring
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harmar Brereton of Redding, Conn., of the engagement of her daughter Ellen Maria Bruzelius to William Neville Tifft, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry N. Tifft of New Canaan, Conn., and Marion, Mass. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Oil Pricing
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S NEW IN SELLING TO SINGLES
description: The 80's may yet go down in the annals as the era of the single person. Divorce rates are at record highs, and more and more people are postponing marriage until later years.

title: MEETING THE NEED FOR COCKTAIL PARTIES AND THE UNEXPECTED
description: IT is heavy entertaining time. Is

title:
HOW TO CORRECT FED POLICY;
OPEN UP THE MONEY SUPPLY SPIGOT
description: HOW does the Federal Reserve Board do it? While Congress blames the White House for the red ink and the White House blames the Congress for too little spending cuts, the Federal Reserve escapes any culpability time and again. Few, with the notable exception of Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, have pointed out that a cooperative Federal Reserve would be able to eliminate much of the nation's budgetary red ink and that a bull-headed Fed will lead us to disastrous, irreparable troubles.

title: FACTORY OUTLETS REPORT A BRISK BUSINESS
description: THEY come out of the reconditioned factory building carrying crammed plastic shopping bags under their arms, bearing the satisfied, if tired look of holiday shoppers who have completed theirchores, at least for the time being.

title: NOTING A TREND: LIGHTER DRINKS
description: ''I LIKED the idea of selling a consumer product, of marketing a consumer product - being able to use one's creativity with respect to marketing, packaging or distribution,'' said Alfred Y. Morgan Jr. of Manhattan and East Hampton.

title: FINDING ROOM; Subway SpreadOld ways of testing for overweight include the pinch test, the see-if-it- buttons test and the present-profile- to-mirror test. Now, just in time for the holidays, there's a new way: the subway-seat test.
description: Because of complaints that the seats on new Japanese subway cars present a tight squeeze, Councilwoman Carol Greitzer measured 23 New York backsides. She found it no wonder that riders were restless.

title: PAGAN RITUALS LIVE ON IN BRITISH FOLK DANCE
description: ''The Christmas Revels'' from Boston, one of the merriest of all entertainments, has just made its annual boisterous visit to New York and, in passing, provided some of the most interesting dancing seen all year. Determined to celebrate the winter solstice upon our urban moors, ''The Christmas Revels'' is anything but your usual early- music group. True, its singers engage the audience in many a medieval or Renaissance carol from the British Isles. But in their carefully researched festivities, the ''Revels'' programs dig even deeper in time - into ancient British pagan rituals that have been preserved in dance form.

title: Stealing History
description: Massachusetts lost part of its charter Aug. 8 when a thief opened a display case at the Statehouse Archive in Boston and tore out the first page. The four-page charter was the original granted by King Charles I in 1629.
T reactionary when the movie

title: TRACING THE CRAFTS MOVEMENT AND ITS AIM OF 'JOY'
description: ''BLESSED Is That Man Who Has Found His Work,'' reads the handsomely lettered motto from the Roycroft Print Shop of East Aurora, N.Y. The words neatly summarize the philosophy of the arts and crafts movement, which flourished in this country from the 1890's through the early 1920's.

title: TOPICS
description: TO own a piece of land! This was the dream my grandparents shared from the day they married in 1879. And through the Homestead Act passed by Congress, their chance came that year to move from a rented home in Cutchogue to Clay County in Nebraska, where they were assigned a parcel of land in the tiny settlement of Edgar.

title: Basques Elect Premier
description: The Basque Parliament elected Jose Antonio Ardanza as premier of its regional government on Friday night to replace Carlos Garaicoetxea, who resigned Wednesday in a rift with party leaders, an official spokesman said today.

title: AN ENGLISH HOLY DAY
description: Wilfrid Sheed is a novelist who was born in England. He is currently at work on a memoir of his parents.

title: NICHOLAS FERRARO, A FORMER JUDGE AND DISTRICT ATTORNEY, DIES AT 56
description: Nicholas Ferraro, a former State Senator, District Attorney and State Supreme Court justice, died Friday at the City Hospital Center in Elmhurst, Queens, shortly after suffering a heart attack at his home. He was 56 years old and lived in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: ;  International
description: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1984 A Soviet career military officer was appointed to succeed the late Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov as Defense Minister of the Soviet Union. He is Marshal Sergei L. Sokolov, who had been a First Deputy Minister of Defense for the last 17 years. (Page 1, Column 1.)

title: HOLIDAY SPIRIT IN 2 PRODUCTIONS
description: THE spirits of Christmases past, present and future permeate two of the state's plays scheduled for the holiday season, but only one is the expected, venerable ''A Christmas Carol.''

title: 2 Sides in Salvador Start Holiday Truce
description: Leftist guerrillas and Government soldiers in El Salvador began a 13-day holiday truce today and early reports indicated both sides were observing the cease-fire.

title: Body of Union Official Found in Car in Chicago
description: The business manager of a union local whose national group has been the target of a Senate investigation for months, was found dead Friday in a car parked in a garage on the Loop.

title: Joyce Brendle Is Wed
description: Joyce Lynn Brendle, the senior documentation writer for PowerBase Systems Inc. in New York, was married yesterday to Daniel Asher Margulies, a public-affairs consultant and author in New York. Acting Justice Martin Schneier of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Fiorella Ristorante. The bride is a daughter of Joseph D. Brendle of Tonawanda, N.Y., and the late Betty J. Brendle. Mr. Margulies is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ariel Margulies of New York.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Economy Flight

title: U.S.C. Defeats Utah
description: Cheryl Miller poured in 37 points and grabbed 23 rebounds today to lead Southern Cal to a 78-62 victory over Utah in a non-conference women's college basketball game.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORTS;
THE HERO IN SPORTS: TEEN-AGERS CAST THEIR VOTES
description: WHEN I was growing up in New York, my sports hero was Duke Snider. Thinking about it now, he was probably responsible for some of the attitudes I hold today. I suspect that my focus on individuals rather than the organizations they served may date back to my rooting for Snider even after the Dodgers deserted Brooklyn. My respect for achievement without public acclaim may stem from my Hall of Fame hero who was outshown by Mickey Mantle and Willie Mays.

title: Anne Steer Is Engaged To Ralph S. Sheridan
description: The engagement of Anne Eileen Steer to Ralph Stephen Sheridan has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Charles M. Steer of Bronxville, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert R. Sheridan of Cincinnati.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Prep School of Excellence
description: In 1904 Emmanuel Montee McDuffie migrated here from Snow Hill, Ala., to open a school that would educate

title: BUSINESS THROUGH THE GENERATIONS
description: WHEN Thomas Esposito talks, people in Hauppauge listen - 51 employees, his three sons, his wife, his sons' wives and his grandchildren.

title: RICHARD W. GARBETT
description: Richard W. Garbett, vice president of public affairs for Conrail, died Wednesday at Bryn Mawr Hospital, the company announced Friday.

title: AMERICA'S RETURN TO PRAYER
description: Isn't it marvelous that something as ageless, profound and healthful as prayer has finally achieved the status of a trend?

title: DENG'S ROAD TO HONG KONG IS PAVED WITH PRAGMITISM
description: He was only a small figure in the crowd that filed into the hall behind Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and Premier Zhao Ziyang of China. But there was no doubt that Deng Xiaoping was the star of the show.

title: 32 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY CITY
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 32 food establishments last week for violating the city's health code.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES/THE 73D APPEAL ; WITH HELP, A YOUNG COUPLE LEARN TO MAKE MARRIAGE WORK
description: They can look back now at the fights they had and analyze what went wrong, but Thomas and Sharon G said horrible words to each other, vicious words, the kind divorces are made of, words they did not mean and never meant to say.

title: Recnet Sales
AVOIDING THE 'OCTOPUS' AND OTHER FIRE HAZARDS
description: RESIDENTIAL fires are a constant threat all during the year, but the danger is even greater at this time, when everyone's mind is on holiday festivities and when there is often a great increase in the number of potential fire hazards around the hoese. Statistics have long shown that residential fires cost thousands of lives each year, in addition to millions of dollars worth of property.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: Choosing reference books for children is a daunting and expensive task. The Reference Books Bulletin of the American Library Association recently evaluated several encyclopedias and recommended the following titles.

title: FLORAL CALENDARS CAN WARM THE MONTHS OF WINTER
description: Megan Fulweiler is a writer and home gardener.

title: ONE OF THE JEWELS IN TV'S 'CROWN'
description: ''The Jewel in the Crown'' has changed many people's lives. But none more so than that of Art Malik, who plays the soulful Anglo-Indian Hari Kumar falsely accused of raping a young Englishwoman in the Bibighar Gardens of Mayapore.

title: Fordham 83, Siena 69
description: Tony McIntosh scored a career-high 35 points to lead Fordham (5-2). Fordham's Steve Samuels scored 15 points and reserve Joe Franco had 10. Doug Poetzsch netted 18 points for Siena, backed by Art Tooles with 16, Eric Banks with 15, and Dave Carlisle with 14.

title: THE DOMESTIC ALUMINUM INDUSTRY FIGHTS FOR PROFITS
description: ALCOA, Tenn.

title: U.S. LIFTS A POLISH SANCTION
description: The United States last week lifted an important sanction against Poland, which promptly did its best not to appear appreciative. The Reagan Administration said it would no longer oppose Poland's attempt to rejoin the International Monetary Fund, thus opening the way for the Government to seek new help for its economy and to ease its $35 billion foreign debt.

title: STATE GROUP TO AID VICTIMS IN BHOPAL
description: MEMBERS of Indian communities throughout the state, as well as others wishing to help the victims of the chemical gas leak from a Union Carbide plant in Bhopal, India, have formed a group to speed medical help to the area.

title: NIPPER - HE'S STILL ALL EARS AT THE AGE OF 100
description: Letting somebody's birthday slip by without appropriate fuss can be embarrassing, especially if it's the 100th anniversary and the celebrator is unquestionably the most famous personage - if that's the proper word - in the history of recorded sound. It has been argued to the contrary that it is best to let sleeping dogs lie, but in this case due notice should be taken that Nipper, the little fox terrier, has been sitting in front of that brass-horned phonograph for nearly a century now, listening to His Master's Voice. At any rate, he was born, of uncertain parentage, in 1884, and his centennial should not go unremarked.

title: A SUBDUED BUT ELEGANT SETTING
description: ABOUT two months ago a new restaurant, Eugen's (pronounced Eugene's), was opened in Westbury by the former chef of the Galleria restaurant just up the street. Meanwhile, Galleria, where there had been a fire, has reopened, making Westbury the current focus of new restaurant activity in the area.

title: BAD TIMES BENEFIT MEXICAN OPPOSITION
description: Relations between Mexico's north and the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party in the capital have never been warm but in recent months they seem to have become downright hostile.

title: CABARET: SCHLAMME, EPSTEIN, AND WEILL
description: Martha Schlamme and Alvin Epstein have been performing the music of Kurt Weill together for so many years that onstage these two superb actor-singers are like an old married couple who know each other's tiniest eccentricities. Actors this familiar with one another often run the risk of settling into cozy, crowd-pleasing schtick. But in ''A Kurt Weill Cabaret,'' the ''farewell'' production of a show they've performed intermittently for 15 years, Miss Schlamme and Mr. Epstein use their intimacy in interestingly subversive ways.

title: BRINGING WORDS OUT OF SILENCE
description: THE SEVEN MOUNTAINS OF THOMAS MERTON

title: Defector Reconsiders The message from Mother Russia apparently was clear: ''Come home, all is forgiven.'' So
description: Nikolai Ryzhkov packed his bags last week. The 20-year-old Soviet soldier, who defected in Afghanistan 18 months ago and denounced his country's involvement in a ''dirty war,'' satisfied the State Department that he was leaving of his volition and seemed to have been promised a warm welcome in Moscow.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
HOLIDAY CONCERT
description: Con Edison will be dimming the lights at Lincoln Center in Manhattan next Sunday afternoon in order to brighten the holidays for 1,200 Westchester residents.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT DEVILS BY 5-3
description: The Rangers viewed their 5-3 victory over the Devils here tonight as the end of a bad streak.

title: SURROGATE FAMILY FOR LONELY AGED
description: HACKENSACK ELIZABETH BOWLES has a routine: She rises early, gets ready, then waits for a mini- van to take her to the Bergen County Senior Citizens Center here.

title: A SANTA'S SANTA
description: From White Plains to the White House, in towns large and small, this is Santa Claus's hour. At stores and malls and at events of all kinds, the sheer number of his incarnations - clad in overstuffed red and white fabric, and various wisps of beard - threatens to tarnish the ageless legend.

title: Contenders For Radio License
description: I am the attorney for North Shore Broadcasting, an applicant to be awarded a license to operate the radio station now known as WLIR 92.7 FM. I have been asked by my clients to express their chagrin at your failure to publish a fair and balanced report on the administrative trial being held in awarding the license (''Battling for a Prize: Radio Station License,'' Dec. 2).

title:
DINING OUT;
BEFORE OR AFTER THE GAME
description: -residential section of Lyndhurst, is an engaging spot for a hearty meal before or after some strenuous rooting at the sports arenas in the nearby Meadowlands. Linebackers' portions of robust, reasonably priced Italian-American fare are offered by this comfortable, dimly lighted ristorante.

title: MARYLAND RALLIES TO WIN SUN BOWL
description: Maryland came back from a 21-0 halftime deficit to defeat Tennessee, 28-27, in the Sun Bowl today.

title: THE JEWISH WRITER
description: To the Editor:

title: KREMLIN SUCCESSION UNDERLINES ENIGMAS FOR U.S. INTELLIGENCE
description: United States Government officials said today that the naming of Marshal Sergei L. Sokolov as the new Soviet Defense Minister underscored the difficulty of forecasting the highly secret decisions of the Soviet leadership.

title: WHO'S TO SAY WHETHER A PLAYWRIGHT IS WRONGED?
description: Whatever audiences may have thought of the production of ''Endgame'' last week at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., they must have found the playbill entertaining. There, stapled next to an advertisement for Oriental rugs, was a statement by the playwright Samuel Beckett denouncing the production as ''a complete parody'' and suggesting that ''anybody who cares for the work couldn't fail to be disgusted by this.'' On the other side of the page was a rejoinder from Robert Brustein, the artistic director of the theater. ''Normal rights of interpretation,'' he wrote, ''are essential in order to free the full energy and meaning of the play.''

title: A TANK DRIVER TURNED TOP MARSHAL: SERGEI LEONIDOVICH SOKOLOV
description: The new Soviet Defense Minister may be little known to the world, but it is a world Marshal Sergei Leonidovich Sokolov knows in some detail.

title: BRINGING ORDER TO RECORDS
description: The International Game Fish

title: Bangladesh Police Fire on Protesters
description: The police fired on demonstrators during the first hours of a planned 48- hour nationwide strike today, and local sources said three people, including a student leader, were killed.

title:
DINING OUT;
LIGHT TOUCH, OFF THE BEATEN TRACK
description: LONG POND INN is hard to find. Some secondary roads lead to a poorly lighted sign marking a sprawling parking lot at the far end of which, perched on the edge of a lake, is the rustic log cabin restaurant. At the entrance to the dining room, a cheery winter fire warms guests waiting to be seated at wood-topped tables aglow with elegant little candle lamps. Light pine paneling, metal candle sconces and shirred curtains give the room a cozy country look. The bare wood floor, while in keeping with this theme, nevertheless magnifies noise, which can be considerable when the room is full.

title: RATCHFORD'S AIDES SCRAMBLE FOR JOBS
description: HOFF had two ''To Do'' lists on her desk on Capitol Hill last week.

title: TESTING YOUR FINANCIAL SAVVY
description: THE quiz that follows is a quick test of your

title: FREE LOANS TO LURE TEACHERS
description: '' GIVE us your pledge to teach, and we'll give you a loan you may never have to pay,'' a new state program is telling high school and college students.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Detroit Red Wings have acquired Dave Silk , on waivers from the Boston Bruins. Silk, one of the heroes of the 1980 United States Olympic gold medal hockey team, had 15 goals and 20 assists for the Rangers two seasons ago and was traded to the Bruins in October 1983. . . . Abilene Christian's new football coach, John Payne , hired four assistants on Friday, including the school's former head coach, Ted Sitton, who had asked that his contract not be renewed. Payne said that he asked Sitton to stay on. . . . Joe Avezzano, Oregon State's head football coach for the last five years, has been named offensive line coach at Texas A&M, under Jackie Sherrill . . . . Ed Martin, basketball coach at Tennessee State University for the last 17 years, has resigned the post, citing lack of support from the administration and a 25 percent cut in his budget. . . . The Italian soccer star, Paulo Roberto Falcao, who underwent arthroscopic surgery Friday on his left knee, is expected to heal in time for the European Soccer Championships in May, according to Dr. James Andrews , who performed the surgery in Columbus, Ga.

title: FINE ACTORS LEAVE A RECORDED LEGACY
description: The voices of several of the most distinguished performers of our age have been silenced forever by death in the past year or so, yet a number of them are still able to reach our ears through the recorded legacy they bequeathed to us.

title: GIGI ROONEY PLANS TO WED L.J. WEIL JR.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis C. Rooney Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Clare Rooney, to Leon Jerome Weil Jr., the son of Ambassador and Mrs. Weil of New York and Katmandu, Nepal. A June wedding is planned.

title: DEVELOPERS QUICKEN PACE IN ROCKLAND
description: Martin Bernstein was one of the early arrivals. In 1955, as traffic started to flow across the new Tappan Zee Bridge and subdivisions began to transform the apple orchards of Rockland County, he moved his family from Washington Heights in Manhattan into a $15,750 split-level in New City.

title: THE GOTHCHA! GANG STRIKES
description: THE GOTCHA! GANG is that shock troop of Lexicographic Irregulars who specialize in correcting other language mavens. Their delight is catching grammarians with their syntax down; their symbol is the hoist petard, and their patron saint goes by the name of U. Ofallpeople.

title: CHICAGO ENDS SCHOOL STRIKE
description: Classroom doors swung open again last week for Chicago's 431,000 public school students.

title: PILGRIMAGE TO BETHLEHEM
description: LUCINDA FRANKS, winner of a Pulitzer Prize for national reporting, writes frequently about the Middle East.

title: OPERA-LOVERS RELISH DRAMA IN SINGING
description: In 1956, the American musicologist Joseph Kerman

title: BHOPAL PLANT USES UP LAST OF CHEMICAL
description: Local officials said today that all the remaining methyl isocyanate at the Union Carbide plant here had been converted into pesticide and that the city was safe again.

title: EX-NAZI, IN U.S. SINCE 1949, IS DEPORTED TO SOVIET UNION
description: Fyodor Fedorenko, a former Nazi death camp guard who had been living in the United States since 1949, was deported Friday night to the Soviet Union, ending seven years of litigation, the Justice Department announced yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: In The Book Review of Dec. 2, the name of the author of ''The Drawings of Milton Avery'' was given incorrectly. It is Burt Chernow.

title: A CONTINUING SERIES ON MAPS AND NAVIGATION
description: The Republic of the Marshall Islands has issued four additional values of definitive stamps. They cover the most popular postage rates used by the islands' residents. The new stamps, issued last Tuesday, make up the second part of the Maps and Navigation Series.

title: A
description: n Editor Redeemed Journalists are perhaps not thought of as a particularly virtuous lot, but every now and then comes one whose experience suggests that the craft may have redemptive qualities. Take Wilbert Rideau , a convicted murderer who learned the trade while serving a life sentence at Angola State Prison in Louisiana. Mr. Rideau spent the last eight of his 23 years there as an editor of the prison magazine, The Angolite, which he helped turn into an award-winning publication.

title: AFTERMATH OF BLAST: REPAIRS AND MYSTERY
description: YONKERS THE sounds of The Twelve Days of Christmas were floating over Main Street, courtesy of the Discount Radio-Rama, mixing with the rat-tat- tat of jackhammers down the block. Inside the Wonder-Bilt men's and boys' clothing store, Philip Marucci, the proprietor, was venting his anger at city officials.

title: Gladys Knight and the Pips With Ray Charles
description: Vestron Musicvideo 78 minutes. $29.95

title: America's Return to Prayer
description: Congratulations to Kenneth A. Briggs from the city to which Paul wrote his ''Letters to the Thessalonians'' (''America's Return to Prayer,'' Nov. 18). It was a joy to find that so many share our delight in old ''favorites,'' like Thomas Merton, Metropolitan Anthony Bloom and Dr. Scott M. Peck. We especially recommend ''Reach ing Out'' and ''The Way of the Heart'' by Henri Nouwen. TAD AND BRUCE LANSDALE American Farm School

title: MEETING THE NEED FOR COCKTAIL PARTIES AND THE UNEXPECTED
description: It is heavy entertaining time. Is there eough white wine or champagne (or both) in the refrigerator, sufficient ice in the freezer, a well-stocked bar and plenty of lemons, limes, sparkling mixers, nonalcoholic quenchers, cocktail napkins and glasses on hand?

title: CAMPAIGN FUNDS: VETO DRAWS FIRE
description: TRENTON GOVERNOR KEAN had a Christmas surprise for some of his potential opponents in next year's gubernatorial race. A few days ago, he conditionally vetoed a campaign-financing bill and recommended changes that, if followed, would make it more difficult for candidates to get public money for their campaigns.

title: Humor From Holtz
description: In his 14 years as a college football coach, Lou Holtz has not lost his sense of humor.

title: BLACK CHALLENGER UNLIKELY IN '85
description: Despite the record turnout of black voters in the Democratic Presidential primary and the general election in New York City this year, it appears unlikely that Mayor Koch will be challenged by a black candidate when he seeks re-election to a third term in 1985.

title: Time Appointment
description: Lawrence W. Crutcher, formerly vice president of financial planning for Time Inc., has been appointed president and chief operating officer. Mr. Crutcher, 42 years old, was vice president of Time magazine and has been a director of Time-Life Books.

title: MARE JOINS BRIDGEPORT'S POLICE FORCE
description: SGT. ANGELO FIORINI, head of Bridgeport's mounted police unit, says he has never been ribbed about whether Bridgeport is a one-horse town. But strictly speaking, Bridgeport qualifies. Presently the unit consists of one 9-year-old mare, though city officials plan to expand the mounted police division to a dozen horses.

title: Bauer and Fitzgerald Are Upset in Australia
description: Unseeded Huub Van Boeckel of the Netherlands upset top-seeded Mike Bauer of the United States, 2-6, 6-4, 6-4, today in the semifinals of the $75,000 South Australian Open tennis championships.

title: Q AND A
description: Sponsor's Cut of Profits Question:

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
CAN LIBERALS ESPOUSE 'RIGHT TO LIFE?'
description: I WAS talking with two college juniors recently, and one of the young women

title: New & Noteworthy
description: STALINGRAD, by Theodore Plievier. (Carroll & Graf, $8.95.) This is a German World War II novel, translated by Richard and Clara Winston, about German soldiers of all kinds and ranks fighting in Russia. Robert Gorham Davis wrote in The Book Review in 1948 that ''Stalingrad'' was ''the most impressive novel of the Second World War.'' He said that if Theodore Plievier's work ''is as widely read in this country (as it was in Europe), it should have a profound imaginative effect, deepening our sense of war's meaning and the great dangers and hopes of our present world role.'' There is ''none of the sexuality that obsesses American war fiction, no pretty nurses.'' OVERDRIVE: A Personal Documentary, by William F. Buckley Jr. (Little, Brown & Co., $8.95.) In ''Over drive'' William F. Buckley Jr. describes eight typical days during which he wrote, lectured, taped two television shows, attended entertainments, talked to the President, sailed, went to church and sat in his Jacuzzi with David Niven. Nora Ephron wrote in these pages last year that some might think ''Overdrive'' should have been called ''a week in the life of a rich man'' but declared it ''an astonishing glimpse of a life of privilege in America today.''

title: EFFORTS OF A SOCIAL WORKER BOLSTER A WIDOW'S STRONG SPIRIT
description: Nina keeps her television set on all day for the warmth of voices it adds to her small Staten Island home, but she says her favorite entertainment is seeing ''old people zip around.''

title: Rosamond Phelps Wed in Pittsburgh
description: Rosamond Lea Phelps, a daughter of Olive Perry Phelps of Pittsburgh and the late William Walter Phelps Jr., was married in Pittsburgh yesterday to Christian Frederick Baiz 3d, a son of Mary Batterman Lang Baiz of Ligonier, Pa., and Southold, L.I., and the late Rev. Dr. John Baiz. The Rev. William Coates performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church, of which the bridegroom's father was rector.

title: ST. JOHN'S TROUNCES U.C.L.A.
description: Two weeks ago, after watching St. John's struggle past teams it should have easily handled, Coach Lou Carnesecca repeatedly warned his players that their lack of intensity would eventually hurt them.

title: 5 Japanese Crewmen Lost
description: Five Japanese crewmen were missing after their vessel collided with an Indian- registered cargo ship in rough seas off central Japan today, the Maritime Safety Agency said. Agency officials said a helicopter had rescued one of the crew of six Japanese aboard the 496-ton Tensho Maru after the ship sank off Izu Peninsula, southwest of Tokyo. All 49 Indians aboard the 14,261-ton Andhra Pradesh were safe, they said.

title: Topics ; Finding Room ; Missing Persons
description: Whoever drew up the White House guest list for celebrating International Human Rights Day this month had highly selective vision. All the foreign guests at this important occasion were victims of regimes hostile to the United States.

title: WHEN AN ACTOR IS TAKEN CAPTIVE BY A SINGLE ROLE
description: In 1884, the famous American actor James O'Neill

title: FORMER JUDGE GETS 15 YEARS
description: Operation Greylord, the continuing undercover investigation of Chicago's municipal court system, has produced the indictments of five current or former Cook County judges, among other high and low officials of the law, and months of argument about the legality and propriety of entrapment. Last week, it produced what a Federal prosecutor characterized as an object lesson - a 15- year prison term for accepting bribes for John J. Devine, now a manager of a downtown tavern but in the period in question, 1977 to 1983, an associate judge.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS Dec. 23, 1984
description: Fiction*1 COME LOVE A STRANGER, by Kathleen E. Woodiwiss. (Avon, $8.95.) A planter's bride is haunted by what may be the return of a love she has all but forgotten. *2 CHANGES, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $3.95.) The crises that arise when a television anchorwoman and a glamorous physician fall in love. *3

title: BOONE'S PICKINGS
description: T. Boone Pickens, a distant relative of pioneer Daniel Boone, dominated the year as did no other single businessman. The wily chairman of Texas's Mesa Pertroleum terrorized the oil patch from the start of 1984 until the end, striking fear in the board rooms of the oil giants.

title: SHARI WEITMAN IS MARRIED
description: Shari Lynne Weitman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Weitman of Cliffside Park, N.J., was married yesterday to Jeff Robert Harrison, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Harrison of North Bergen, N.J. Rabbi Reuben Siegel officiated at the Tammybrook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J.

title:
GARDENING;
POINSETTIA-QUEEN OF THE HOLIDAY PLANTS
description: The poinsettia has become so closely associated with Christmas that any attempt to omit it from the seasonal decor will most certainly result in a noticeable void. The plants also make great gifts.

title: Flutie Suffers Loss
description: Now that Doug Flutie is a hot item, so is all his equipment. Six times thieves have made off with the Heisman Trophy winner's gym bag with T-shirt, socks, and shorts.

title: PLANETARIUMS SEEK GREATER ATTENDANCE
description: THE wonder of watching planets gyrate magically overhead in a planetarium was an experience prized by many for decades, until space exploration uncovered secrets of the stars and the real world overtook the simulated one.

title: Personal Problems
description: Some court documents filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission in 1984 read like potboiler novels. Deputy Defense Secretary Paul Thayer was charged with passing inside information to friends who then traded on it while he was chairman of the LTV Corporation.

title:
ART;
AN 'ETCHING 'CRAZE' AT HUDSON MUSEUM
description: IT is hard to imagine anything as

title: WEDDING IS HELD FOR MISS GIURGIU
description: Alexandra Maria Giurgiu, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Mircea Anthony Giurgiu of New York and Westhampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Alessandro Piol, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elserino Piol of Milan, Italy. The Rev. Gerard J. DiSenso performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: BAY HEAD THE SINKING winter sun cast a violet, pink and orange reflection on the still waters of the lake here and on the sinuous, brackish tidal stream that links it with Barnegat Bay.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
HOW CAN 'MESSIAH' LEAD TO FAMILY TROUBLE?
description: IT IS almost one year to the day

title: BUYING WHAT COUPLES BUY
description: ''While a great many manufacturers have realized that in fact there is a singles market,'' said Julian Tomshin, Bloomingdale's fashion director for the home, ''when the question is raised of 'Do we have to adapt to it?' the answer is, 'Not really.' ''

title: TAX-BENEFIT CUTS TO LIMIT NEW MANHATTAN RENTALS
description: In a sense, the city's two major tax-incentive programs for stimulating multifamily housing production have become victims of their own success. The 421a program for new construction and the J-51 program as applied to gut rehabilitations of older buildings have been curtailed in recent months, partly on the assumption that in most of Manhattan at least, they are no longer needed to generate housing.

title: BILL SIGNED TO COVER INSURERS' PAYMENTS TO SOCIAL WORKERS
description: Governor Cuomo has signed a bill requiring mental-health insurance plans to cover the costs of services provided by clinical social workers. Most such plans now only cover care provided by psychiatrists and psychologists.

title: Elizabeth Cleary Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Frances Cleary, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malachy F. Cleary of New Rochelle, N.Y., and New York, was married yesterday to Daniel Randal McCarthy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David McCarthy of Portsmouth, R.I. Msgr. Thomas P. Leonard performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
SANTAS IN NORTHPORT
description: What's better than one Santa Claus? A whole collection, probably. So for its holiday exhibition, the Northport Historical Society Museum has opened its doors (and, undoubtedly, its chimney) to a batch of antique and collectible Santas amassed over the years by a local resident, Brian Moran. There are European Father Christmas creatures, turn-of-the-century American figures and Santas in the form of an old English teapot, lantern covers and candy holders. In addition to the Santas, the exhibition features an 1880's pony cart originally built for the Brush family of Northport, and now on display for the first time. The show runs through Jan. 6 at the museum on Main Street and can be seen from 1 to 4:30 P.M. Tuesdays through Sundays, except, of course, Christmas and New Year's Days. Admission is by donation.CAROL CARAVAN

title: Short Stories or a Novel?
description: To the Editor:

title: A GUNMAN WOUNDS 4 ON IRT TRAIN, THEN ESCAPES
description: A middle-aged man with a silver-colored pistol strode into a subway car rolling through lower Manhattan yesterday and shot four young men he had apparently singled out from among the passengers, the Transit Authority police reported.

title: TRADE GAP'S EFFECTS CAUSING FEAR FOR AMERICAN ECONOMY
description: The growing trade deficit has not played well for some time in Peoria, or in scores of other heartland industrial towns where manufacturing jobs have been cut sharply by foreign competition.

title: THATCHER SEES NO DIFFERENCES ON 'STAR WARS'
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher met with President Reagan today and said there were ''no differences'' between Britain and the United States over the Reagan Administration's space-based missile- defense plan.

title: What Price Freedom?
description: Howls of protest rose in Congress over the practice of ''greenmail,'' a play on the word ''blackmail,'' in which companies pay a premium to get rid of hostile raiders. The Disney-Steinberg deal, perhaps because of America's love affair with the Disney characters, touched a deep chord.

title: CITY LIMITING S.R.O. CONVERSIONS
description: Four years after Martin Alter, an advertising consultant, bought a four-story brownstone at 143 St. Felix Street in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, he bought an empty rooming house next door.

title: EARL BLAIK IS PROUD
description: PONTIAC, Mich.

title: Marilyn Coats to Marry
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Walter R. Coats of Pennington, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Marilyn Ann Coats to Christopher Geoffrey Brian Thomas, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Trevor E. G. Thomas of West Orange, N.J., and Shelter Harbor, R.I. An April wedding is planned.

title: BONDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Apple, Polished
description: Apple Computer Inc. kicked off the year with a spectacular Orwellian commercial in which a vigorous female athlete smashes a Big Brother image and declares that the real 1984 will not be like the novel's 1984.

title: A DISARMING RUSSIAN STEALS THE SCENE ON WEAPON TALKS
description: WASHINGTON AS President Reagan and his senior aides looked ahead to next month's talks with the Russians in Geneva, they were distracted by developments in Europe, where British and French leaders last week offered unsolicited suggestions for the agenda of the long-stalled dialogue on arms control.

title:
ANTIQUES;
SUGARPLUMS AND PERIOD STYLES ON HOLIDAY VIEW IN PRINCETON
description: -design talents and ''sugarplum'' artistry of John and Cile Bellefleur Burbridge of Danvers, Mass., can be seen through Feb. 15 in a holiday exhibition jointly sponsored by LaVake Jewelers and Silversmiths, 54 Nassau Street, and the New Jersey Historical Society at Morven, the former Executive Mansion on Stockton Street.

title: Lori C. Goodman Wed To a Jewelry Designer
description: The marriage of Lori C. Goodman and Laurence Seegers took place yesterday in the chapel of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, where the Rev. Richard Leonard performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Anne Goodman of Los Angeles and David Goodman.

title: REAGAN AID REQUESTED ON WESTWAY
description: New York State's top officials have appealed directly to President Reagan for a prompt Federal decision on Westway, the long-debated superhighway proposed for the Hudson River shore of lower and mid-Manhattan.

title: Halfway Out
description: Jack (Murph the Surf) Murphy , who hasn't been near a beach in nearly two decades, may soon be waxing his board again. Mr. Murphy, a champion surfer who had a varied criminal career, was perhaps best known as the man who broke into the American Museum of Natural History and made off with the 535-carat Star of India sapphire. After doing time in New York for that bit of business, he was sentenced to life in prison for murder in Florida.

title: ELEMENTS OF A LIFE
description: THE PERIODIC TABLE

title: FANCY FEET AND FAMOUS FACES
description: NIVEN'S HOLLYWOOD By Tom Hutchinson. Introduction by Peter Ustinov. Afterword by David Niven Jr. Illustrated. 192 pp. Salem, N.H.: Salem House. $17.95.

title: DEMYSTIFYING MONEY MATTERS
description: Since early September, ''Adam Smith's Money World'' has been coming to us over public television on Sunday nights, enlightening, entertaining and, on occasion, baffling and even frustrating viewers. Sex, politics and religion may be the most civilized topics for a dinner party, but many people find money fascinating, too. At the same time, the money world, as George J. W. Goodman, or Adam Smith, as he is pseudonymously known, explained on the first program, ''is a subject that intimidates some people, which is too bad, because it can be a world of drama, intrigue and adventure.''

title: FISHER'S MONTAUK LEGACY GETTING A NEW LOOK
description: MEMORIES of Carl Fisher's 1920's dream resort in Montauk have been stirred by the recently begun renovation of his 200-room hotel, the Montauk Manor. The oversized buildings that Fisher built for his ill-fated development on the East End give distinction to the village and in the eyes of many are what helped set it apart from the carefully preserved historical elegance for which most of the South Fork's other villages are known.

title: MAILBOX
description: Doug Moe Style Is Applauded

title: DEVICE THAT ZAPS KIDNEY STONES
description: For sufferers of kidney stones, anything that relieves the intense pain is akin to a miracle. That is what many doctors are calling the lithotripter, a device that crushes the stones with shock waves and permits them to be passed without surgery.

title: WARSAW DISMISSES PARTY AIDE IN CHARGE OF POLICE
description: A two-day meeting of the Communist Party's Central Committee ended today with a change in the party's inner sanctum that diplomats believe is linked to the slaying of a pro- Solidarity priest.

title:
GARDENING;
POINSETTIA: QUEEN OF THE HOLIDAY PLANTS
description: THE poinsettia has become so closely associated with Christmas that any attempt to omit it from the seasonal decor will most certainly result in a noticeable void. The plants also make great gifts.

title:
CAMERA;
HOW TO IDENTIFY THE PHOTO MARKETS
description: Sandy Sorlien is a freelance photographer and writer. Many markets are open to photographers interested in selling their work. But the competition is fierce so the first step should be to identify where the pictures can be sold.

title: 14,000 SMALL PRESSES: SOMETHING MORE THAN THE SUM OF THIER PARTS
description: There have long been well-regarded small presses, of course, and some have earned heroic stature. New Directions, for example, began as a small press that introduced the work of Ezra Pound, William Carlos Williams and other modern literary giants. But such shining exceptions simply proved the rules; today, those rules have changed.

title: A GIANT WHO STAYS BEHIND
description: THE other Giants were packing their equipment

title: CHRISTMAS IN SEAFARING STYLE
description: TODAY the Mystic Seaport Museum, on the banks of the Mystic River, is expected to be the host to more than 2,000 Christmas visitors, many of whom will gather in Anchor Circle at 4 P.M. to hear and sing traditional Christmas music with the Seaport Carolers.

title: ISLAMIC MEETING SEATS EGYPT
description: The ''enemy of mine enemy'' is often the best friend a Middle Eastern leader can find. Working at least partly on that principle, Egypt has gathered support from King Hussein of Jordan, Yasir Arafat, and other Arabs who are at odds with Egypt's principal adversaries in the region - Syria, Libya and Iran.

title: TO BROWSE, TO MEET, PERCHANCE TO SHOP
description: ABOUT 200 booths were jammed

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday on teacher examinations in New Jersey gave an incorrect schedule and misstated the maximum possible score. The test on general knowledge, communications and professional skills is given in October and March; tests in specific disciplines are given in November and April. The top score is 690.

title: Pitcher Can Hit Unlikely Jackpot
description: TONY GWYNN should have it and doesn't. LaMarr Hoyt has it, and there's no reason why he should, except that he and his agent must have wild imaginations.

title: NEW RENTAL RATES
description: THE Division of Housing and

title: Florida Will Search 4 Counties for Canker
description: Inspectorsfighting citrus canker say they will search every yard in four southern Florida counties for the disease, and Gov. Bob Graham has signed a bill providing $6.4 million for the canker battle.

title: A MIND OF HER OWN
description: The structure of tournament bridge in North America may be headed for a revolution thanks to the efforts of one determined young woman. At issue is the traditional identification of some events according to sex: men's, women's and mixed competitions for pairs and teams. These account for about one- third of the schedule in tournaments at every level.

title: Darien Wedding For Miss Brown, A Photographer
description: Josephine Johanson Brown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Allen Brown of Darien, Conn., and Roy Lars Magnus Boe Jr., a son of Deon Woolfolk Boe of Darien and Mr. Boe of New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Douglass Ray performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien.

title: YULETIDE TREES GO ON DISPLAY
description: FOR centuries, artists have tried to capture the wonders of one of nature's great sculptural works - the tree - but have never quite measured up to the original.

title: 'HOT' COLLEGES
description: As the parent of a high- school senior in the throes of the college-application process, I found Michael Winerip's article somewhat distressing. I had hoped there was room in the ''good'' colleges for children who have attended a public high school, achieved excellent grades, good test scores, perhaps worked at an after-school job as well, but who, at age 17, have not yet been published, are not in their own businesses, have not invented anything and are not outstanding athletes.

title: U.S. Office to Study Fish
description: The new Estuarine Programs Office, under John B. Pearce, will organize research on how pollution affects fish and shellfish, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced Thursday. It will be part of the National Marine Fisheries Service.

title: GILBERT REVIVES ON KID LINE
description: No matter how well things are going, or how poorly, Greg Gilbert can never quite forget the company he keeps when he is on the same line with Bryan Trottier and Mike Bossy.

title: President of Milton Roy Named Chief Executive
description: Richard E. Schmidt has been elected chief executive of the Milton Roy Company, a maker of fluid control and laboratory analytical equipment. His appointment is effective Jan. 2.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1984
description: Companies

title: PERMANENCE OF G.O.P.'S NEW STRENGTH IS DEBATED
description: The Republican Party gained public support throughout 1984 and is ending the year with about as many adherents as the Democrats, according to New York Times/CBS News Polls. Political professionals disagree, however, on whether the party's gains signal the beginning of a political realignment.

title: NORTH CAROLINA, 7-0, WINS JAPAN FINAL
description: North Carolina won the Suntory Ball basketball tournament today, beating Arizona State, 85-66, in the last of the three games played here.

title: Flutie's Helmet Is Returned
description: Doug Flutie's helmet, which was stolen from his locker at Boston College last Thursday, has been returned to him.

title: Illusions on Fifth Avenue On one of last week's spring days, some pink and red balloons, refugees from a Manhattan office party perhaps, headed for the empyrean, only to be snagged in sleet. The sleet surrounds a huge snowflake, and together they are poised over Fifth Avenue and 57th Street. True, this heavy weather is made of light bulbs, but never mind: For the first time in the history of weather, a runaway balloon is known to have been stranded by a storm.
description: Forty feet or so beneath the snowflake, a fire was burning brightly in a fireplace in the window of a shoe store. The environs, however, were safe.

title: MASSACHUSETTS SPURNS HIGH-TAX-STATE LABEL
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: APRILE MILLO IN 'BOCCANEGRA'
description: A fine new Verdi soprano has arrived at the Metropolitan. Aprile Millo, who sang ''Ernani'' in the parks last summer and who stepped into a ''Simon Boccanegra'' performance on short notice earlier this month, made her originally scheduled house debut Saturday night in the latter opera. She is reportedly still in her 20's. The audience that cheered her at the Met will be expecting much from her in the future. The guess from this corner is that she will deliver.

title: F.D.I.C. POSTS: BANKS' CHOICES
description: WASHINGTON

title: Coast Nuclear Plant Tested at Half Power
description: Engineers began control rod tests today at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant, which has been cranked up to half its rated 1.1 million kilowatt capacity.

title: In Re Christmas
description: The Georgetown University Law

title: What Israel Needs, Before Money
description: After 100 days of coalition government, bankrupt Israel has concluded that the boldest way out of crisis is to bank on the sympathy and treasury of the United States. Its two-party Government has so far cut $400 million, or 1.6 percent, from the national budget while preparing to ask for 12 times that amount in new American aid. It's no favor to Israel for the United States to endorse such a ratio of self- help to welfare.

title: HAJI-SHEIKH'S FOOT ERASES A MEMORY
description: No one would have been very surprised if Ali Haji-Sheikh revealed that he changed his daily routine in preparation for his first playoff game, or trotted on the field at Anaheim Stadium for practice Saturday spreading incense and thinking positive thoughts about the faraway uprights. The nature and demands of being a place- kicker can make an eccentric of the most level-headed athlete.

title: OF HORROR AND MISCHIEF: RARE CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: I must not ugly faces scrawl With charcoal on a white-wash'd wall; Or, as from room to room I walk, Adorn them with designs in chalk. . . . The things my parents bid me do, Let me attentively pursue; The things they bid me leave undone, Let me essay as much to shun.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Dec. 14 about the Union Carbide Corporation misidentified a public relations firm that specializes in crisis management and misnamed its senior partner. It is Chester Burger & Company; the senior partner is Chester Burger.

title: Stephen Kates Plays Unusual Cello Material
description: The cherished Stephen Kates graced the Abraham Goodman House with expert performances of some unusual material last Tuesday afternoon. Accompanied by the pianist Margot Garrett - an unfailingly attentive partner - Mr. Kates presented eloquent interpretations of Luigi Boccherini's Sonata in C, Bruch's ''Kol Midrei,'' Chopin's shamefully neglected Sonata in G minor (Op. 65) - the composer's last major work and perhaps his only masterpiece for any medium other than solo piano - Gregor Piatigorsky's ''Fourteen Variations on a Paganini Theme for Cello and Piano'' and the world premiere of Ezra Laderman's Duo for Violoncello and Piano.

title: WORLD BANK MORE CAUTIOUS ON LOANS
description: The central African country of Burkina Faso, formerly Upper Volta, wants the World Bank to finance construction of a 300-mile railroad in its parched northern reaches to develop manganese deposits and get beef herds to markets more rapidly.

title: THE STRANGE CASE OF KARL MARX IN CHINA
description: To the Editor:

title: CENTRAL AMERICA IS ONLY TWO DAY'S DRIVING TIME FROM TEXAS
description: To the Editor:

title: Elegant Life First In the Gravesend
description: Elegant Life, the only New York- bred in the field of eight, prevailed in a driving finish to win the Gravesend Handicap by a nose yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Reagan and Re-Reagan
description: In politics as in physics, every action produces a reaction, although

title: Foss and Babbitt To Present New Works
description: New York premieres by the composers Lukas Foss and Milton Babbitt will be featured in a two-part ''Meet the Composers'' series beginning March 5 at the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue at 92d Street. Mr. Foss will introduce the March 5 performance of his work ''De Profundis'' by the Gregg Smith Singers. The concert will also feature Mr. Foss's ''Behold I Build an House.''

title: Giant Panda Mauls Keeper
description: Ling-Ling, the giant panda, mauled her new chief keeper today in her enclosure at the National Zoo, leaving the man with deep cuts but in good condition, officials said. The keeper, Edwin R. Jacobs, 52 years old, suffered cuts on his back, arms, neck, chest and right leg. Officials said they did not know what had prompted the attack, or whether any action would be taken against the panda.

title: Power Failure Ruled Out In 2 Hospital Deaths
description: A power failure at a public hospital did not cause the deaths Thursday of two cancer patients who were on life-support machines, the Cook County coronor said today.

title: Rhonda R. Schneider Wed to Mark Popkin
description: Rhonda Ruth Schneider, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Schneider of West Orange, N.J., was married there yesterday to Mark David Popkin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Popkin of the Bronx. Cantor Theodore Aronson performed the ceremony at The Manor.

title: Mother Is Charged After 4 Die in Fire
description: A 26-year-old woman whose four children died in a fire here while she was out Saturday night was charged today with child endangerment, the police said.

title: 'Normals' Pass Up Shot at Trendiness
description: The usual Saturday-night crowd of

title: SENIORS LED ARMY TO SUCCESS
description: Army's football fortunes languished so long that three consecutive classes of Cadets never enjoyed the pride of one winning season during their undergraduate years. This year's senior players, however, were a determined group that refused to become the fourth consecutive class without a winning season.

title: DEVELOPERS HAVE A DUTY TO POOR, O'CONNOR SAYS
description: Morality should motivate real-estate developers to provide low-income housing for the poor, but if moral suasion fails, then ''maybe government intervention would be the way to go,'' according to Archbishop John J. O'Connor.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Tennis Eighth Annual Rolex International Junior Championships, at Port Washington Tennis Academy, 100 Harbor Road, Port Washington, L.I. 9 A.M. Runs through Sunday.

title: DEATH IN THE FAMILY
description: -year-old American doctor who has worked for the past year in Nicaragua. Back here on a holiday visit, she talked with me about work and life in Managua. Her experience, described in homely detail, brought the large political abstractions of the debate about U.S. policy into human focus.

title: INDIANS BEGIN VOTING IN TEST FOR GANDHI
description: Voters in all but six of India's 22 states began casting ballots today in the first stage of a general election in which Rajiv Gandhi hopes to achieve a parliamentary majority that will solidify his hold as Prime Minister.

title: PLIGHT OF NEEDIEST TOUCHES THOSE FAR AWAY
description: ''Several times a year, for both business and pleasure, my husband and I travel to New York City,'' wrote Alda

title: Words of Encouragement
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants has often called Jim Burt, his nose tackle, ''my kind of player,'' one whose toughness and emotions make him that much better. Today, Burt demonstrated his character.

title: UNCOMMON SCHOLAR STUDIES FATE OF JEWS
description: David S. Wyman is an unusual historian. A devoted Christian, he has spent his entire academic career investigating the fate of Europe's Jews during World War II. An old-fashioned sort of American who loves baseball and dislikes Communism intensely, he has written a painful book, which was published in November, about the failure of this country's most cherished institutions and influential leaders to take actions during the war that might have saved the lives of hundreds of thousands of Jews.

title: Filipino Debt Accord Cited
description: The Philippines has agreed with Western creditor nations on a major restructuring of its official debts, the French Finance Ministry said.

title: Monday
description: Federal workers who have to report to work today, instead of spending what they had hoped would be a pre-Christmas holiday, may take comfort in the knowledge that President Reagan will be at his desk, too. The President and his wife plan to have Christmas Eve dinner at the home of Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States Information Agency.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: BELIZE' POLITICAL HURRICANE
description: Most times, especially when the molten Caribbean sun beats down, it can be downright somnolent in this British-style democracy, the only country in Central America with a Privy Council. But the speed with which Belize's political landscape was rearranged recently was something else again.

title: V.W. LIPPARD, EX-YALE DEAN
description: Dr. Vernon W. Lippard, dean emeritus of the Yale School of Medicine, which he led during an era of vigorous growth in the 1950's, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in New Haven. He was 79 years old.

title: Putnam Man, 21, Is Found Hanged
description: A 21-year-old Putnam County man hanged himself from a basement staircase Saturday, the police said.

title: Coffee Export Fall Reported
description: Exports by producer members of the International Coffee Organization to importing members in October and November were the lowest for at least five years, according to statistics the organization has released.

title: JOSEPHINE C. FABIAN
description: Josephine Cunningham Fabian, a conservationist and writer, died Thursday at a Salt Lake City nursing home.

title: Card Sharks
description: As a private school with tough academic standards, New York University was always at something of a disadvantage when it came to recruiting basketball players. Many top prospects could not meet the strict N.Y.U. admissions requirements.

title: INTEGRATED CAST TELLS CHICAGOANS 'GOD BLESS US EVERY ONE'
description: As sure as parents and children risk the biting cold to visit Santa Claus at Marshall Field's on State Street, so they turn out by the thousands each year for the Goodman Theater's production of ''A Christmas Carol.''

title: St. Cecilia Chorus Sings 'Maccabaeus'
description: The St. Cecilia Chorus and Orchestra's Wednesday evening presentation of ''Judas Maccabaeus'' at Carnegie Hall was a good, solid example of a Handel performance in the Victorian manner. Most 19th-century Britons esteemed Handel even above Bach and had a near-insatiable passion for oratorios - whether classics such as ''Judas Maccabaeus'' or more recent if less distinguished products by Stainer and Parry.

title: RAIDERS FACE A MAJOR REBUILDING JOB
description: Success in football doesn't always breed success. Nobody knew that better than the Los Angeles Raiders. The season after they won Super Bowl XV, they finished with a 7-9 record.

title: LAVISH MURAL AT CITY HALL IS MADE NEW
description: Up the freestanding staircase at City Hall, past the fluted columns, down the marble corridor and through the double doors of the City Council chamber, is the painting that Taber did. Taber Sears (1870-1950).

title: Required Reading; Morals and Martinis
description: Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota, who now lives in Virginia near the eastern slope of the Blue Ridge Mountains, recently published a book, ''The View from Rappahannock'' (EPM Books, McLean, Va.). Excerpts from one of his essays, ''The Free Lunch Under Fire'':

title: Storage Technology
description: Zoltan L. Herger, one of the founders of Storage Technology Inc., resigned as executive vice president, the company said.

title: Frontier Air In Union Pact
