description: Frontier Airlines said over the weekend that its employees and their unions had tentatively agreed to an investment package that could lead to an employee buyout of the company's parent, Frontier Holdings Inc.

title: UNJOYOUS TRADITION: CHRISTMAS SHOPPERS IN LASTMINUTE RUSH
description: It was the weekend before Christmas and people were mobbing store counters, grabbing scarves that were the wrong color and sweaters that were the wrong size.

title: MusicNoted in Brief; Akbar Ali in Debut With Black Swan
description: The violinist Akbar Ali's Black Swan, a jazz string quartet, made its debut last weekend at the Alternative Museum. Mr. Ali, Reggie Workman on bass and Abdul Wadud and Deirdre Murray on cellos are first-rate improvisers who can also play ensembles in tune. And Mr. Ali's better compositions take into account both the modal, African-influenced jazz he has played in other groups and the distinctive sound of a string quartet.

title: The Junior League Today
description: For many people, the mention of

title: FACE 49ERS ON SATURDAY
description: The scenario for the Giants-Rams wild- card playoff game today was simple. It was Eric Dickerson, the record- breaking running back of the Rams, against a Giants' defense that wins games when it makes big plays.

title: A Hunter's Christmas Tale
description: Children of my children wild among your peers

title: Crews Cleaning Up Puget Sound Beach
description: Coast Guard crews worked today to clean up a five-mile stretch of beach on a large island in Puget Sound, after gallons of marine fuel dumped at sea began to wash ashore.

title: MAXWELL NURNBERG, TEACHER AND WRITER ON ETYMOLOGY, DIES
description: Maxwell Nurnberg, who brought his passion for the English language to generations of students at Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn, died Saturday night at the Downstate Medical Center. He was 87 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BAII Banking Corp. has elected to its board Charles William Carson Jr., managing director and a senior partner at William Sword & Co. in Princeton, N.J.

title: DEVILS ARE STRUGGLING TO SHAKE OFF A LOSING SPIRIT
description: Losers had been in this room, feeling less than right about themselves, each one wearing like a long tail the feeling that he did not belong - not in a professional hockey clubhouse, not in his own body.

title: VALVANO IS FIRM ON WASHBURN CASE
description: ''Before this happened, we were a legitimate top 10 team; we were good and improving dramatically,'' said Jim Valvano, the head basketball coach at North Carolina State. He then paused and sighed resignedly.

title: Magazine Ad Pages Up
description: Advertising revenues for magazine members of the Publishers Information Bureau have exceeded $4 billion this year. And that is just through November, so there is still a month to go. Total ad pages for members of the bureau were up 2.2 percent in November, from the same month last year, to 15,631, while revenues climbed 12 percent, to $503.7 million.

title: A PANEL EXPLORES GAMBLING AMONG JEWS
description: The clergyman stood before the audience and described how he had become a gambler, so obsessed with winning that he didn't care whether there was milk in the refrigerator for his children or money in the bank to pay for their education.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''To eat out of the one bowl is important to communal spirit of the family.

title: Mighty Dog Campaign Set to Spoof Superman
description: With a brand name like Mighty Dog, what is more natural for a commercial than a Superman spoof?

title: Canisius 77 Duquesne 74
description: Ray Hall scored 21 points and Chris Heinold added 16 for Canisius (4-4). Canisius led by 38-36 at halftime but fell behind, 59-54, with six and a half minutes to play, Hall sank a layup with 4:47 to play to put Canisius ahead for good.

title: REPORT DISPUTES PENTAGON ON READINESS
description: A Pentagon staff officer has cautioned senior officials that without drastic changes in patterns of military spending, the readiness of the armed forces for sustained combat will decline rather than improve.

title: Police Seek Leads In Jersey Slayings
description: The police continued their search today for the killer of two Rockland County, N.Y., men who were found shot Friday outside a bar in this Bergen County community.

title: CUMMINGS MAKES SACRIFICES FOR KNICKS
description: Hubie Brown's first professional coaching position was as an assistant with the Milwaukee Bucks at the time Lew Alcindor, now Kareem Abdul- Jabbar, was the dominating figure. Since then, Brown, who stresses strength and power, has always surrounded himself with big centers - Artis Gilmore with Kentucky in the American Basketball Association; Wayne (Tree) Rollins in Atlanta, and Bill Cartwright and Marvin Webster with the Knicks.

title: Flyers Stymie Capitals
description: Tim Kerr scored his fourth career hat trick and Murray Craven added two goals in leading the Philadelphia Flyers to a 7-4 victory tonight that snapped the Washington Capitals' eight-game unbeaten hockey streak.

title: DIRECTING 'A.D.' FOR TV: TURMOIL IN TUNISIA
description: Last summer, Stuart Cooper found himself in the desert in Tunisia in 120-degree heat, directing some 1,500 extras in scenes re-creating the turmoil of the Roman Empire under Claudius and Nero.

title: Bridge:Becker Team Leading Final OftheWinterRegionalMeet
description: Teams led by B. Jay Becker and Matt Granovetter, both of New York, clashed in the Knockout Final at the Greater New York Bridge Association's Winter Regional Championship at the Sheraton Centre hotel yesterday after surviving desperately close semifinal matches. At the halfway mark, with 28 of 56 deals completed, the Becker team led the Granovetter team by 41 international match points.

title: SCIENTISTS HOPE TO CREATE A CHRISTMAS COMET
description: If skies are clear early tomorrow morning, residents throughout much of western North America should be able to see the creation of the first artificial comet. Because of its timing, scientists have dubbed it the Christmas Comet.

title: GAS IN MINE HALTS ATTEMPTS TO REMOVE WORKERS' BODIES
description: Because of a buildup of volatile methane gas, crews had to interrupt efforts today to seal off the Wilberg Mine, where rescuers had found the bodies of 25 of the 27 miners trapped four days ago.

title: The Hawk Is Back
description: ''When I was learning baseball,'' Ken Harrelson said the other day, ''all those other guys were learning golf.''

title: RANGERS TIE, 3-3, AFTER 2-GOAL DEFICIT
description: On a 10-point scale for theatrical value, last night's game at the Garden between the Rangers and the Montreal Canadiens was a flat zero for about 50 minutes and then abruptly, the level of drama rose. Trailing by 3-1 midway through the third period, the Rangers scored twice and the game ended in a 3-3 tie.

title: Box-Office Gust
description: At the Metropolitan Opera box office, a man had just finished signing a check when a great gust of air blew through the ticket window, scattering tickets, pen and papers onto the floor.

title: Czechoslovaks Defeat U.S. Team
description: The United States lost to Czechoslovakia, 9-1, today in an opening game of the World Junior ice hockey championships.

title: NOEL, LA NAVIDAD, WEIHNACHT-HAPPY TIMES FOR RETAILERS
description: The trees glisten with lights along the Champs Elysees. ''Jingle Bells,'' Muzak-style, reverberates in Tokyo. And in Warsaw, for the first time in 20 years, holiday decorations liven the main shopping areas.

title: Olympic Yacht Class Opens for Women
description: Competitive sailing at the Olympic level turns out to be mostly a competition among men, in part because races are sailed in boats that require the crew to be hefty and muscular as well as skillful.

title: Indians Get Ruhle
description: The Cleveland Indians signed the veteran right-handed pitcher, Vern Ruhle, to a one-year Class AAA contract on Saturday. He will be on the roster of the Indians' minor league affiliate, the Maine Guides, but will be invited to the club's major league spring training camp.

title: INMATE RELEASE HITS A SNAG IN HANOI
description: Vietnam may not agree to release inmates of ''re- education'' camps for resettlement in the United States unless Washington promises to curtail what Hanoi describes as anti-Vietnamese activities among exiles in America, officials here told two American Congressmen this weekend.

title: 7-ELEVEN STORES FIND FAVOR WITH JAPANESE
description: One measure of the success of 7-Eleven in Japan is that most Japanese are surprised to learn that the chain of convenience stores was made in America.

title: No Headline
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1984 International Chinese-Soviet cooperation pacts have been agreed on by Peking and Moscow, China announced. The four agreements include the first long- term trade pact that the two Communist powers have negotiated since their break a quarter of a century ago. (Page 1, Column 6.) Knives and forks for China, instead of the chopsticks that have been used for 3,500 years, have been urged by one of China's leaders. (1:5.)

title: Mourners of Ustinov File Past His Bier
description: Thousands of mourners stood in line in bitter cold today to view the body of Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov as preparations were made for a Red Square funeral Monday.

title: JAKE MILFORD
description: Jake Milford, the senior vice president of the Vancouver Canucks and a member of the National Hockey League Hockey Hall of Fame, died today at Shaughnessy Hospital.

title: LESSONS ON HOW TO BUILD POWER ON POWER
description: Several of this city's most powerful men have found a new way to increase their already considerable influence over public policy issues: They have formed foundations financed by tax- deductible contributions.

title: CITY STRENGTHENS SUBWAY PATROLS
description: At Mayor Koch's request, police patrols were sharply increased on the city's subway system for the holiday crowds yesterday as detectives hunted a gunman who shot four teen-agers on a subway train in lower Manhattan Saturday.

title: FOR SMALL BUSINESSES, A RENT-PRESERVATION LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: No More Excuses on Child Abuse
description: Ever since the spring of 1983 the New York State Department of Social Services has been pressuring New York City's Human Resources Administration to shape up its procedures for responding to child abuse. A new report finds that progress hasn't amounted to much in 18 months, while city officials continue to offer apologies and excuses. The city's families deserve better.

title: MAGGIE LIKES MIKE
description: WASHINGTON ''I like Old Joe Stalin,'' said Harry

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Including the recently completed regular season, against how many franchises have the Giants won more games than they have lost in their history? How about the Jets?

title: Benefactor Bails Out Inmates for Holidays
description: Robert Josephs, an inmate at the Nassau County Jail, got a Christmas present today from a Manhasset real-estate developer he did not even know. Mr. Josephs, 46 years old, and eight others awaiting trial for nonviolent crimes were bailed out so they could spend the holidays at home. The developer, Sal Miglio, posted $5,800 bail for the nine inmates. Mr. Miglio, 45, said in a telephone interview that he started his bail-out program 15 years ago to ''show God's love to some of those in jail.'' Mr. Josephs, reached by telephone just after his release, called it ''a very, very happy day.''

title: BRIEFS ;  Debt
description: * Chock Full o'Nuts opened a $20 million credit with National Westminster Bank U.S.A.

title: A Potpourri Of Christmas Cards
description: Christmas cards fluttered much

title: A Hayride Down 5th Avenue
description: Before the night before Christmas,

title: 'STAR WARS' IS NOT A BARGAINING CHIP, U.S. SAYS
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that President Reagan would not agree to trading away the Administration's long-range space defense plan in the new round of arms-control talks with the Soviet Union.

title: JAZZ: BIRDLAND WEST OPENS WITH CHARLI PERSIN AND BAND
description: A new club bearing an old jazz room name, Birdland West, opened on Thursday at 225 West Broadway with Charli Persip and his 17-piece Superband as the opening attraction. Birdland West takes its name from Birdland, a jazz club on Broadway in the 1950's and 60's that was named for the saxophonist Charlie Parker, who was known as Yardbird or Bird.

title: GOLD'S DECADE OF TURBULENCE
description: NEXT Monday will mark the 10th anniversary of the end of the Government's 40-year prohibition on public ownership and trading of gold bullion. In the decade since, the bullion market has changed from a highly personal affair between seller and buyer into one continuous global bazaar.

title: Time Is Running Out On Candidates' Funds
description: Time is running out for Senators Gary Hart and John Glenn and their fellow candidates for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination to get Federal matching funds to retire millions of dollars in debts.

title: TV: WILDER'S 'SKIN OF OUR TEETH'
description: In an appropriate gesture for the holiday season, public television's American Playhouse is offering, tonight at 9 on WNET/13, Thornton Wilder's ''Skin of Our Teeth.'' It is actually a rebroadcast of a production that was transmitted live from the stage of San Diego's Old Globe Theater in January 1983. The play's message of hope for the human race, that we are likely to survive by the skin of our teeth no matter what disasters befall us, assumes a special poignancy on Christmas Eve.

title: Jaruzelski Sees No Taint On Agency After Killing
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, said Saturday that the four officers charged with killing a pro-Solidarity priest were aberrations in the Interior Ministry.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: STRINGS ATTACHED At the stroke of midnight tonight, as Christmas makes its 1984 debut, the gift of great music will be unwrapped, appropriately at Carnegie Hall, 57th Street and Seventh Avenue (247-7800)

title: 14-YEAR-OLD EXCELS IN THE 600-YARD RUN
description: Diane Dixon won two events, and Sydney Maree took the 3,000-meter run. But a 14-year-old high school freshman from Philadelphia stole the spotlight today in the Metropolitan Athletic Congress Track and Field Meet at Princeton's Jadwin Gym.

title: A STRATEGIC SHIFT FOR AD INSERTS
description: DALE LANG thinks that his magazine, Working Woman, and another magazine, American Health, have discovered an answer to the troubling question of ''advertorials'' - do it yourself.

title: THE ASCENDANCY OF REAGAN
description: Donald T. Regan seemed contented Friday before his weekend departure for his vacation retreat in Florida. He sat in one of the wing chairs of his Treasury Department office, the portrait of Alexander Hamilton peering down from above the fireplace, a glass elephant filled with jelly beans on the coffee table. He looked crisp in a navy blue suit, polished black shoes and a navy blue tie emblazoned with little Santa Clauses.

title: Sharing the Wealth
description: Dick Barnett was known as a brainy sort during his 13 seasons in the National Basketball Association, and now, a decade after he retired from the Knicks, he is out to share some of his insights with those he believes could use them most - his fellow professional athletes.

title: I.R.A. Funeral in Ulster Turns Into a Riot
description: The police clashed today with Roman Catholic mourners at the funeral of an Irish Republican Army guerrilla. Seventeen people were reported hurt and four were arrested.

title: REAGAN'S PLANS FOR BUDGET CUTS ANGERING STATES
description: Treasury Department experts envision some changes in the Administration's tax revision plan. Page 33.

title: FORGED PAPERS MEAN CUSTODY FOR 77 CUBANS
description: After more than four years of trying to join their relatives in the United States, 77 Cubans have found themselves under detention by American immigration authorities - without a country to call their own and, they say, victims of a scheme to defraud them.

title: BIG LEONARD'S BIG TACKLES
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.

title: DR. BRADFORD H. EATON
description: Dr. Bradford H. Eaton, a resident surgeon at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, died Friday night after he was hit by a truck when he slipped on West 59th Street near the hospital. He was 27 years old.

title: Hand to Hand
description: The Smithsonian magazine, normally the most circumspect of

title: WE NEED MORE THAN SEAT BELTS FOR ROAD SAFETY
description: To the Editor:

title: Addendum
description: * The Mortimer Berkowitz Company is changing its name to the Berkowitz-Van Ingen Company.

title: GRIM HOLIDAY SPIRITS IN A STEEL TOWN
description: Something seems amiss on Lloyd Pas smore's Christmas tree lot.

title: Few Offerings This Week With corporate and tax-exempt calendars empty, the
description: Treasury Department is the

title: Maureen McGovern Sings in Many Idioms
description: Maureen McGovern is one of the most technically proficient singers in all of pop. With a vocal range that soars to an F above high C, a control of pitch that allows her to execute flawless two-part duets with an array of reeds and woodwinds and a musical intelligence that finds her equally comfortable with show tunes, rock- and-roll and jazz, Miss McGovern is physically capable of sounding like just about anyone.

title: POLICE AUGMENT HIGHWAY EFFORT AGAINST DRUNKS
description: The police in the New York metropolitan region have announced expanded efforts to keep drunken drivers off the roads during the holidays.

title: Chairman Will Leave Puerto Rican Cement
description: The Puerto Rican Cement Company said that Antonio Luis Ferre had resigned as chairman of the San Juan-based company, effective March 31. He will continue as a director and a shareholder of Puerto Rico's largest cement maker.

title: Bruins 4, Stars 3
description: Ken Linseman, set up by Terry O'Reilly, scored at 2:15 of overtime for the Bruins. Linseman took a pass from O'Reilly, kept behind the Boston captain and, after feinting the goalie Gilles Meloche, slid the puck into the empty net for his ninth goal of the season.

title: JAZZ: DUKE'S MEN PLAYS IN ELLINGTON'S STYLE
description: Between the Broadway musical, ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' and the current film, ''The Cotton Club,'' the late Duke Ellington's name and music are in the public awareness more than they often were even during his lifetime. One consequence is the appearance of groups, built around a few authentic Ellingtonians, that play the Duke's music.

title: FRANCE'S LEFTIST LEADERS VEER FROM CHARTERED PATH
description: The French voted in 1981 for a Socialist program of jobs, growth, nationalizations and the redistribution of wealth. They elected politicians talking of a new era of creativity and fairness, a time of generosity, of human warmth and solidarity.

title: TAMBRANDS' MYSTERY ITEM
description: THERE'S nothing like a corporate secret to

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about interfaith couples' means of dealing with the holiday season misstated data on intermarriage. Of Jews who have married in the last 10 years, 40 percent have married people of other religions.

title: Books of The Times; Hackers as Heroes
description: HACKERS: Heroes of the Computer Revolution. By Steven Levy. 458 pages. Anchor/Doubleday. $17.95. There was the great chess showdown of 1965, when MacHack won a chess game against a critic of artificial intelligence named Herbert Dreyfus, who had bluntly asserted that no computer program would ever be able to beat even a 10-year- old. None of the computer specialists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology cheered when the program won, because they

title: Humanities Grants Given
description: Four institutions will receive grants under a new program to improve the preparation of teachers in the humanties in elementary and secondary schools, the National Endowment for the Humanities announced Friday. The grants were to the University of Kentucky, $142,967; Kenyon College, Gambier, Ohio, $62,334; Middlebury College, in Vermont, $72,285, and the University of Virginia, $175,000.

title: PACT ENDS MESA'A BID FOR PHILLIPS
description: T. Boone Pickens and his Mesa Partners agreed late last night to end their bitterly fought attempt to acquire the Phillips Petroleum Company.

title: DIFFICULT CHILDREN AT HOLIDAY
description: CHRISTMAS is a special time for all youngsters, but there are some who, while not disturbed, have problems that may be heightened by holiday tensions. Dr. Stanley Turecki, a child and family psychiatrist, terms these children difficult, and he heads a year-old program at Beth Israel Medical Center that tries to help families learn better ways of dealing with them.

title: Gasoline Prices Dip Below $1 LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23
description: For the first time since

title: JAZZ: SPILKA PLAYS DIXIELAND
description: Followers of Dixieland jazz have relatively little to follow in New York clubs these days, particularly since Jimmy Ryan's closed a year ago. So the arrival of Bill Spilka and the Rowdy Rooters early last week at the West End Cafe, Broadway at 114th Street, normally a venue for swing and be-bop groups, is a small breakthrough.

title: JOB LOSSES CHALLENGE A SOCIALIST PREMISE
description: In the last four years, Le Creusot has elected a Socialist Mayor, a Socialist City Council, a Socialist regional council and a Socialist member of the National Assembly. The list represents a clean sweep, but the problem is that these Socialist officials have been unable to do what they promised as candidates.

title: Chris Stamey Leads Showcase for 3 Bands
description: Coyote Records, a record label in Hoboken, N.J., that is devoted to eccentric pop, gave three of its bands a showcase Wednesday at the Bottom Line.

title: POP: KINKS SING 'LOLA' IN A BENEFIT
description: No other rock group has a following quite like the Kinks, the venerable English band led by the indomitably young-spirited singer-song writer Ray Davies. Kinks concerts draw an unusually gentle and intellectual- looking type of rock audience that identifies closely with Mr. Davies's impersonation of embattled but smiling Everyman.

title: Kings 4, Jets 4
description: Brian MacLellan's goal at 18:25 of the third period pulled Los Angeles into the tie.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Top Official Resigns At Helionetics Inc.
description: Charles W. Missler, chairman, president and chief executive of Helionetics Inc., resigned Friday, citing ''personal reasons.'' The 50-year- old executive had held those positions since Nov. 1, 1983.

title: JEWS, AT CHRISTMAS
description: It was a family ritual. Each year, we took a ride to look at the lights. One evening, sometime between Dec. 23 and Jan. 1 (but never on the day), we would bundle into our coats and galoshes and climb into the Dodge. The tire chains would thud through the snow as we drove slowly along the holiday-hushed neighborhood streets. Inevitably, someone would begin to hum the melody of a carol, others would join in and, before long, the noise of the chains would be drowned out by our tentative harmony (but never the words): ''O come let us adore him.''

title: Korab Is Asked To Rejoin Sabres
description: Jerry Korab, a 36-year-old defenseman who has not played this season, is returning to Buffalo to play for the Sabres.

title: CONCERT: EDWARD AUER PLAYS SONATAS
description: Edward Auer, a pianist on the faculty of the University of California at Los Angeles, came to Tully Hall last Sunday to celebrate Beethoven's birthday by playing the ''Waldstein'' and two other sonatas. He is a thoughtful and accomplished player; the concert gave pleasure even if it rarely took fire.

title: THE MYSTERIOUS MOVES OF BERNARD KING
description: ON good authority, Bernard King is the stuff of a conundrum. No less a basketball personage than Larry Bird, the winged Celt, says: ''I don't understand how Bernard does it. He's in heavy traffic - guys all over banging him and waving their arms - and he gets the shot off, not just any shot, but the shot he wants, and he cans it. Time after time. He's the best scorer I've ever seen or played against.''

title: JAPANESE CAR IMPORTS: A LOBBYISTS' BATTLE ROYAL
description: If quotas on Japanese car imports are not extended, Japanese makers could get 40 percent of the United States market and add at least $61 billion to their earnings in the United States through 1988, says a Chrysler lobbyist, Robert A. Perkins.

title: Nancy Sue Levin Weds
description: The marriage of Nancy Sue Levin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Al Levin of Oceanside, L.I., to Ray Nathan Greenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Greenberg of Bridgeport, Conn., took place yesterday at the Oceanside Country Club. Rabbi Amos Miller officiated. The bride, a speech pathologist with the Norwalk (Conn.) school system, graduated from the State University of New York College at Plattsburgh and received a master's degree from Hofstra University. Mr. Greenberg, who graduated from the University of Connecticut, is a contractor and real-estate developer in Bridgeport.

title: HOW 'MESSIAH' SINGING BEGAN
description: When I was a boy, we did a lot of singing, but we never sang the ''Messiah.'' It was regarded as an awesome, formidable piece of music requiring hours of practice, and who had the facilities or time for that? Instead, we sang camp songs and spirituals, and carols at Christmas. Somehow we learned to sing in harmony and on Christmas Eve we would roam Morningside Heights - high school and college kids and people who joined us along the way. It was good music.

title: Wendy Kotler Weds Dr. Steven Herzberg
description: Wendy P. Kotler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Kotler of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Steven M. Herzberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arno Herzberg of Union, N.J. Rabbi Daniel Isaak performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: PEKING HAS SEEN THE FUTURE-AND IT LACKS CHOPSTICKS
description: Nearly 3,500 years after Chinese first took up chopsticks to eat their rice, they have been urged by one of the country's leaders to consider switching to Western- style knives and forks.

title: JERSEY DIVERS FIND DOZENS OF STOLEN CARS IN THE HUDSON
description: Police divers looking for a car in the Hudson River have discovered much more than they expected - the burial ground for dozens of stolen cars.

title: Hicks & Greist to Get Family Circle Account
description: As his first official act, Arthur Hettich, who becomes president of Family Circle Jan. 1, will bring in Hicks & Greist as the new ad agency for the magazine's trade and consumer advertising.

title: COSTUME JEWELRY GAINS STATUS
description: Flip through the pages of any fashion magazine. The slinky dresses, the androgynous men's coats and jackets, the simplest and the most elaborate designs are all shown off with large, dramatic jewelry, pounds and pounds of it.

title: HOLIDAY SALES OFF AT STORES
description: With one shopping day left, the year's Christmas season is concluding a generally disappointing run, according to retailers in various cities.

title: Illusions on Fifth Avenue
description: On one of last week's spring days, some pink and red balloons, refugees from a Manhattan office party perhaps, headed for the empyrean, only to be snagged in sleet. The sleet surrounds a huge snowflake, and together they are poised over Fifth Avenue and 57th Street.

title: JAZZ: CARAVAN OF DREAMS IN A PLAY
description: Sound outweighed sense in ''Celestial Navigation,'' a play presented at the Tower Gallery by the Caravan of Dreams touring theater company and co-produced by Kathelin Hoffman and Ornette Coleman. It drew an eager audience because its score was written and played onstage by Mr. Coleman and Prime Time, a trailblazing seven-piece electric jazz band that rarely performs in New York.

title: Brazil Soccer Star Killed in Air Crash
description: Figueiredo, 24-year-old soccer star with Brazil's Flamengo team, was among four people killed when their single-engine plane crashed into a mountain on Thursday, officials said today.

title: DEPRECIATION PLAN WORRIES OFFICIALS
description: Treasury Department tax experts are coming to the conclusion that some aspects of the Treasury's plan to revise the tax system will have to be changed because they would be so disadvantageous to business as to inhibit economic growth, according to Administration officials.

title: DEVOTION TO COMPUTERS GROWN OLD
description: I must not ugly faces scrawl With charcoal on a white-wash'd wall; Or, as from room to room I walk, Adorn them with designs in chalk. . . . The things my parents bid me do, Let me attentively pursue; The things they bid me leave undone, Let me essay as much to shun.

title: Iceman Gervin, 32, Begins to Cool Off
description: Whether he was lounging around at home in Detroit or gliding his spindly body through a sea of burly defenders, George Gervin was always cool. But getting old isn't cool, even for the Iceman.

title: Reason for Crash Of Copter Sought
description: Federal investigators today examined the wreckage of a small helicopter that crashed Saturday in dense fog near Ellington Airport, killing the pilot and his passenger.

title: Public Less Optimistic On Finance, Poll Finds
description: The American people were less optimistic in their financial outlook at the start of this month than they were in September, but optimists still outnumbered pessimists by a wide margin, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Typical Comeback
description: Maryland overcame a 21-0 deficit with a 22-point third quarter on the way to a 28-27 victory Saturday over Tennessee in the Sun Bowl. Maryland finished with a 9-3 record and Tennessee was 7-4-1.

title: LA SALLE STAR BITTER OVER BEING BARRED
description: Albert (Truck) Butts, the 6-foot- 9-inch center who was considered one of the best collegiate rebounders in the country, spoke with bitterness and disbelief Saturday about a rule that will keep him benched throughout his senior year this season.

title: Sarah Gould Becomes the Bride of Stewart Kagan
description: At the Park Avenue Synagogue yesterday, Sarah Elinor Gould, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce J. Gould of New York, was married to Stewart Alexander Kagan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kagan of Roslyn, L.I., and Old Lyme, Conn. Rabbi Judah Nadich and Cantor David Tilman performed the ceremony.

title: THAT PEACE ON EARTH MAY BEGIN IN ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Monopoly Is Blamed For Blast in Mexico
description: The Mexican attorney general's office has blamed the state-owned oil company Pemex for the explosion that killed at least 490 people last month and has ordered the company to pay damages.

title: Joseph C. Nichols, 79;Sportswriter for Times
description: Joseph C. Nichols, a sportswriter for The New York Times for 50 years until his retirement in 1975, died yesterday morning of a heart attack at his home in Rego Park, Queens. He was 79 years old.

title: A Scepter Recovered
description: As unexpectedly as it disappeared

title: THE STRANGE CASE OF KARL MARX IN CHINA
description: To the Editor:

title: TEST INDICATES THE ARTIFICIAL HEART HEART DID NOT CAUSE SCHROEDER'S STROKES
description: A highly specialized test has found no evidence that William J. Schroeder's artificial heart was the cause of the strokes he suffered 10 days ago, Dr. Allan M. Lansing, the chief medical spokesman for the artificial heart team, said today.

title: A Caucus on Soviet Jewry
description: Leaders of both parties in the Senate

title: BRIEF RISE IN RATES SEEN BY ANALYSTS
description: Short-term interest rates, which have been sliding steadily since August, may be in for a short-lived blip up this week, according to some money market economists.

title: CHINA AND SOVIET AGREE TO DEVELOP TRADE AND SCIENCE
description: China announced today that it would sign four new cooperation agreements with the Soviet Union, including the first long- term trade pact that the two Communist powers have negotiated since their break a quarter of a century ago.

title: THEATER: SHERMAN'S 'MESSIAH'
description: In ''Messiah,'' his first play since ''Bent,'' the writer Martin Sherman once again wonders how history's martyrs can find salvation when all the available signs say that God is dead. ''Bent,'' as you may recall, posed this question at a Dachau rock pile where two doomed Nazi prisoners found a fleeting moment of spiritual grace in an exchange of homosexual love. The new play's setting is the 17th-century village of Yultishk, Poland, on the Ukrainian border, where a traumatized Jewish community, decimated by Cossack slaughters, finds transitory hope in an outburst of mass hysteria: The villagers convince themselves that Sabbatai Sevi, a mysterious Sephardic rabbi in Asia Minor, is the messiah who will at last deliver them to redemption in Jerusalem.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Chic of Love Burger Ice Cream
description: A first visit to Japan uncovers some puzzles. For instance, virtually every consumer product, from whiskey to snow tires, has an English-language name. That's usually attributed to snob appeal. For the Japanese, American is chic.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;  Operation Bruin
description: The entrance fee was one teddy

title: Bridge:Winner at Winter Regional HadtoComeFromFarBack
description: A remarkable turnabout ended the Knockout Team Championship at the Greater New York Bridge Association's Winter Regional at the Sheraton Centre Sunday night. A New York quintet led by B. Jay Becker, and including Michael Becker, Ron Rubin, Edgar Kaplan and Brian Glubok, seemed to be coasting to victory at the halfway stage, when they led by 41 international match points. But their opponents had other ideas.

title: Debt
description: * Maryland National Corp. filed a statement for the proposed offering of $40 million of medium-term notes with maturities ranging from nine months to 10 years.

title: SINGLE MOTHERS JOIN SUIT TO ENLIST IN THE MILITARY
description: A 32-year-old Bronx woman, dismissed by the Army Reserve when it learned she was a single mother with custody of her child, has taken the country's largest employer, the American military establishment, to court.

title: Comings and Goings
description: A three-time Olympian, Brent Rushlaw, won his seventh national title when he teamed with Ed Card , the brakeman, to win the United States two-man bobsled championship at the Olympic run at Lake Placid, N.Y. Rushlaw, 33, of Saranac Lake, N.Y., and Card of Claverback, N.Y., piloted their sled to a four-heat total time of 4:08.94. Two heats were raced Sunday, with the two final trips held yesterday over the mile-long track.

title: HOLIDAY AWAY IS FINE FOR GIANTS
description: Like many other people, the Giants will spend the Christmas holiday away from home. Unlike most people who do that, they are delighted.

title: HOLIDAY SAMPLER: SERMONS INTERPRET THE CHRISTMAS MESSAGE
description: The church is full, the choir falls silent and the preacher approaches the lectern. By most accounts, the Christmas sermon is the most important and most difficult of the year.

title: Books of The Times; Silver Spoons
description: THE RAINBOW PEOPLE. A Gaudy

title: CHERNENKO FAILS TO ATTEND RITES FOR DEFENSE CHIEF
description: The ashes of Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov were lodged in the Kremlin wall today in a bitterly cold ceremony marked by the absence of the Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko.

title: ALLNET COMMUNICATIONS SERVICES reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
CALLERS SUPPORT SUBWAY GUNMAN
description: The New York City police were flooded with telephone calls yesterday from people expressing support for a man who shot four teen-agers who investigators said had tried to get $5 from him on a subway car last Saturday.

title: MICRO D INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After extraordinary net writedowns of $1.4 million for inventory and $1.1 million for accounts receivable. c-Net income. d-After lsosses from discontinued operations of $217,000 for the quarter and $410,000 for the year and a charge of $139,000 for the quarter and year related to the phase-out of discontinued operations.

title: SCOUTING ; Shopping List
description: One place where Slippery Rock's name holds no sway is Herman's World of Sporting Goods, where satin team jackets, manufactured by Starter, were the hottest item this holiday season. According to Kevin McCarthy, the manager of the Times Square branch, the local professional teams are the biggest sellers, followed by a handful of colleges, among them Georgetown University, the University of North Carolina and Notre Dame. ''They're very trendy now,'' Mr. McCarthy said, standing beneath a banner promoting ''The Sport of Giving'' as he explained that jacket prices range from $60 to $80, with pro football the most expensive because of the National Football League's licensing fees.

title: Deak-Perera Unit
description: The Government said it was freezing the Hong Kong assets of the financially beleaguered Deak-Perera Far East Ltd., a foreign-exchange and gold- dealing affiliate of the New York- based Deak & Company.

title: TAX THE REAL ESTATE, NOT WHAT'S BUILT ON IT
description: To the Editor:

title: ITALY BLAMES TERRORISTS FOR TRAIN BLAST
description: The police said today that they were convinced that an explosion aboard a train packed with holiday travelers was caused by a bomb planted by terrorists.

title: Agca Calls Himself 'Extraordinary Man'
description: Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turkish gunman who wounded Pope John Paul II, was quoted today as having said that he was picked to assassinate the Pontiff ''because I am a really extraordinary man.''

title: KEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $538,000 for the quarter and a gain of $1,904,000 for the year. c-Net income after a loss of $46,000 from discontinued operations. d-Including a gain of $214,000 from discontinued operations.

title: 49ERS RESPECTFUL OF GIANTS
description: For the most part, the San Francisco 49ers did not expect to be playing the Giants in the divisional round of the National Conference playoffs Saturday in San Francisco.

title: 'OF BLOOD AND HOPE' TOLD IN YIDDISH
description: Samuel Pisar, an international lawyer whose life now is a first-class commute between clients whose problems affect influence and affluence in America and Western Europe, has finally been able to see the story of his life told in the language in which it began. His autobiography, ''Of Blood and Power,'' has been translated into Yiddish.

title: TRANSTECTOR SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; A Voice of Cheer
description: It's Christmas. So today, for a

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: DO we care about the last year in fashion? Well, we do and we don't. We don't, because it's over, because who wants to hear another word about English youth, Boy George, androgyny, club culture and T-shirts that say ''Save the Whales''? By the same token, who wants to hear anything about ball gowns and the socialites who make them?

title: NO GLOW FROM DAMASCUS
description: DAMASCUS Christmas is also a holiday in this predominantly Moslem capital. There aren't many decorations and the trees tend to be scraggly. But there is an air of festivity.

title: Two Foreign Priests Are Arrested in Chile
description: The police arrested two foreign Roman Catholic priests and three Chileans for distributing holiday greeting cards that wished Chileans a new year ''without torture,'' church officials said today.

title: ORIENTATIONU; PanderingThere are certain creatures whose role it is to provide reading matter for the subway trip, the commuter train, the dentist's waiting room. Certain movie stars . . . a few princesses and the occasional prince . . . and a panda named Ling-Ling.
description: During Ling-Ling's 12-year stay at Washington's National Zoo, she has had, like her partners in fame, several unfortunate, and highly publicized, affairs. Her two pregnancies have aroused national interest; their tragic endings, national sorrow.

title: SPACE SLEAUTH KEEPS EYE ON SOVIET
description: Although he has no security clearance, no Government job and no access to clues gathered by American spy satellites, Charles P. Vick has become an international authority on the Russian space program. His detailed drawings of the Soviet Union's secret rockets and space shuttles have been used in Congressional studies and by aerospace experts around the world.

title: Argentina Interest Payment
description: Argentina has agreed to pay an additional $100 million in past-due interest it owes on its foreign debt, Citibank said yesterday. Argentina had already agreed in early December to pay $750 million in back interest it owed creditor banks.

title: WESTERN INTERNATIONAL COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BRIEFS
description: * American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., said it had completed the previously announced sale of the stock of its ACC Chemical subsidiary for $76 million to a subsidiary of Texaco Inc.

title: ROBOTIC VISION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Followers of the Star
description: When Jesus was born in Bethlehem, reported Matthew in his gospel, magi came from the east to Jerusalem. ''We have seen his star in the east and have come to worship him,'' they told Herod. The magi stepped into history and stepped out again, their journey of faith recorded in a few brief lines.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Continental Corp. Fills Agency Post
description: The Continental Corporation has named Walter H. Hallowell president of its agency group and executive vice president of the corporation, which is the nation's eighth-largest property and casualty insurance company.

title: Comets Coach Resigns
description: Pat McBride , one of five coaches to win 100 or more games in the Major Indoor Soccer League, resigned as coach of the struggling Kansas City Comets. The resignation came one day after the Comets were overwhelmed by the St. Louis Steamers, 10-1. Rick Benben , the assistant coach, will take over the 3-10 Comets, who had been one of the preseason favorites to win Western Division honors. ''I feel this is better for the team,'' said the 41-year-old McBride, who will remain with the team in an advisory capacity,

title: VERTIPILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
description: b-After a charge of $1.2 million from a plant shutdown. c-Net income.

title: CONCERT: Y ENSEMBLE
description: Gerard Schwarz is a tireless quester after the unexamined. At Mostly Mozart, at the Waterloo Festival, in the Music Today series at Merkin Hall, and at the 92d Street Y, whose Chamber Symphony he conducted Sunday afternoon, he has revived music forgotten, remembered in name only, rearranged, dismissed, neglected or mislaid. It is surely a rare member of the audience at a Schwarz concert who is not hearing at least one piece for the first time; the public owes him a vote of thanks for that, and so do the composers (and their shades), for allowing so many of their works an unexpected bid for reconsideration.

title: SCOUTING ; Your Car, Sir
description: Phil Simms, the Giants' quarterback, was besieged by the media after Sunday's 16-13 playoff victory over the Los Angeles Rams in Anaheim, Calif. It seemed that everyone in California knew him or wanted to know him.

title: LOW AIR FARES IN EAST CHANGING TRAVEL HABITS AND BUSINESS PLANS
description: The competition for low fares between Boston, New York and Washington is changing traveling and shopping patterns up and down the East Coast and is blurring the boundaries between the three metropolitan areas.

title: SOFTWARE AG SYSTEMS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DID ALZHEIMER'S AFFLICT RAVEL?
description: -mortems'' of which

title: BITTER TIME FOR QUAD CITIES
description: For 114 Christmas seasons, McCabe's Department Store has anchored the downtown of this farm equipment center along the Mississippi.

title: MINNESOTA FABRICS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: b-Net income.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Mayor on 'Mayor'
description: The Last Word. Getting it is practically Edward I. Koch's credo. It is also the title of a new final chapter in ''Mayor,'' added to the just-published paperback version of his political autobiography.

title: PARK PROTESTING BOMBER TEST PLAN
description: Plans by the Air Force to test guidance systems on B-52 bombers in low flights over Glacier National Park have drawn criticism from park officials, members of Congress and several environmental groups.

title: PHILLIPS'S SHARES FALL BY $9.625
description: The shares of the Phillips Petroleum Company plunged in tumultuous trading yesterday as investors expressed dismay about a plan that would restructure Phillips to save it from a takeover by T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman.

title: SOUTHERN HOSPITALITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
STUDIED NEONATAL DRUG ADDICTION
description: Dr. Carl Zelson, a pediatrician known for his work on neonatal drug addiction, died of a heart attack Sunday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Stratford, Conn.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Coca-Cola Co., Atlanta, has elected to its board James T. Laney, president of Emory University in Atlanta.

title: VICORP RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for 14 wks to Oct 28
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in August 1983. Shares outst 6,641,148 6,620,000 Yr rev 242,294,000 95,611,000 Net inc 8,735,000 4,784,000 Share earns 1.32 .85 Shares outst 6,634,936 5,652,968 Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in August 1983.

title: Jacobs Group's Pioneer Stake Up
description: A group of investors led by Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis financier, said it had increased its stake in the Pioneer Corporation to 3,845,200 common shares, or 11.7 percent of the shares outstanding. According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group purchased 759,000 shares on the open market between last Tuesday and Thursday at prices ranging from $31.96 to $32.80 a share.

title: TOY MAKER'S HOLIDAY SURGE
description: Each year, Christmas begins in the summertime in this small town on the moors of Jutland.

title: Sun Savings Unit
description: The Sun Savings and Loan Association said that Greenfield Partners had terminated an agreement to invest $10 million in capital in the association. Sun Savings said it had received other proposals that would assist it in raising additional capital and it would continue to explore these and other alternatives. The association said Greenfield Partners had indicated that its withdrawal was based on a determination that results of an examination of Sun Savings' condition - ''financial and otherwise'' - made it inadvisable.

title: ROCK: TOM VERLAINE
description: Tom Verlaine has been acclaimed as one of rock's finest guitarists since he led the band Television in the late 1970's. Now, he has decided to make a case for his songwriting. On his new album, ''Cover,'' his tunes are stripped down to guitar riffs, drumbeats and short lines of lyrics. Mr. Verlaine kept those songs terse and percussive when he brought his band to the Ritz last weekend.

title: SCOUTING ; Spirit Is Bright At Aqueduct
description: In this ecumenical city, each public lobby that sprouts a Christmas tree usually has an electric Hanukkah menorah close at hand.

title: HOW TO RETSORE AFRICA'S ECOLOGY
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITE HOUSE CHRISTMAS CHEER
description: Those who feel a bit guilty about overeating on Christmas Day might take solace from knowing that the nation's early Presidents and their families were far more gluttonous.

title: MEDIFLEX SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
A Picture of Loyalty
description: Last minute shoppers at The Tiny

title: FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DOOMED WILD BURROS FIND HAVEN AT TEXAS RANCH
description: Texans have firm opinions about burros.

title: Peruvian Insurgents Raid a Mining Center
description: In an attack Sunday night, Maoist guerrillas took over an Andean mining center for more than an hour and blew up the police station, wounding at least five officers, the authorities said today.

title: 350 in Houston Protest South African Policies
description: About 350 marching, chanting people led by ministers filled downtown streets today to protest the racist policies of the South African Government and draw attention to the famine in Ethiopia.

title: Air New Zealand Strike Ends
description: Air New Zealand resumed flights from Los Angeles today after the settlement late Sunday of a strike by flight attendants. About 500 passengers, many of them New Zealanders going home for the holidays, had been housed in a hotel by the Government-owned airline since the strike began Dec. 19.

title: Festival of Dance At Brooklyn Academy
description: ''New Traditions,'' a festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, will present five programs of classical, contemporary and popular dance from January to May.

title: Realty Refund Bid
description: An investment group that includes Eastgroup Properties and Eastpark Realty Trust told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it would seek ''a significant influence over the management and policies'' of Realty Refund Trust.

title: CHRIS CRAFT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
PSYCHOLOGY ANALYZES HUMBUG-SAYERS
description: Ebenezer Scrooge might have benefited from a little therapy. At least, the modern-day Scrooge might.

title: Merrill Sets Robbery Loss
description: Merrill Lynch Canada Inc. said today that the face value of securities stolen from two company messengers last week was $52 million in United States dollars at current exchange rates.

title: MINE MAY BE TOMB OF 27 UTAH MINERS
description: A fire-ravaged mine containing the bodies of 27 miners may become their permanent tomb once crews are able to seal off the persistent blaze that trapped them inside, a mining company spokesman said today.

title: Edward F. Prichard Jr.; Prominent in New Deal
description: Edward F. Prichard Jr., a New Deal activist who later championed educational change in Kentucky, died Sunday at the Veterans Administration Medical Center here. He was 69 years old.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES OFF SLIGHTLY
description: Short-term interest rates fell slightly in quiet pre-holiday trading yesterday, while long-term bond yields were little changed.

title: GUATEMALA FIGHTS ITS BAD-GUY IMAGE
description: Confronted with a moribund economy at home and a trend toward democratization among its neighbors, Guatemala is engaged in a major effort to improve its international image and strengthen its ties with other countries.

title: Caravaggio Show at the Met
description: ''The Age of Caravaggio,'' an exhibition of works by the 17th-century Italian painter and his contemporaries, will open Feb. 9 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The show will include almost 40 paintings by Caravaggio, among them ''Bacchus'' from the Uffizi Gallery in Florence, 14 paintings by Caravaggio's North Italian precursors and 45 by such contemporaries as Rubens, Carracci and Barocci. It will run through April 14.

title: AT CHRISTMAS, CAMARADERIE AMONG THE JOBLESS
description: I would like to send Christmas greetings to the legions of America's unemployed. In doing so, I am writing a card to myself. I am one of them.

title: POSTAL CONTACT INCLUDES A RAISE AND CONCESSIONS
description: Arbitrators today handed down terms for a new contract for postal workers that includes modest wage increases but sharply lower starting pay for new employees.

title: JOHN LOCKE'S LIBERTY WAS FOR WHITES ONLY
description: To the Editor:

title: STROKES FOIL HEART PATIENT'S GOAL: TO BE HOME BY CHRISTMAS
description: uf812

title: LAWYERS ARE ESSENTIAL IN JURY SELECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Aquascutum of London Gets New U.S. Head
description: E.T. Dick Catlett was appointed president of the American operations of Aquascutum of London, the 113- year-old maker of raincoats and coats.

title: Ex-Jewel Leader's Jobs Study
description: Donald S. Perkins makes it clear he is not looking for ink for himself.

title: PERES, SUDDENLY POPULAR, EMERGES AS THE DOMINANT FIGURE IN ISRAEL
description: A few weeks ago, Prime Minister Shimon Peres was visiting a school in Ashkelon, a town known politically as Ariel Sharon country and a place where, in the past, Mr. Peres ran the risk of being pelted with tomatoes.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Knicks, at Madison Square Garden, 8:05 P.M. The teams, struggling with injuries, are tied for last place in the Atlantic Division.

title: Key Rates
description: Split rate, 10.75-11.25 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: U.S. PLANNING A ROUNDUP
description: Congress appropriated $17 million just before it adjourned in October to round up 25,000 wild horses on Government land in the West, according to Cleveland Amory, president of the Fund for Animals.

title: A Timely Custom
description: 'Twas the day before Chistmas

title: THIEVES IN JERSEY TAKE $3 MILLION FROM AN ARMORED-CAR COMPANY
description: Burglars broke into the vault of an armored-car company in Perth Amboy, N.J., and made off with $3 million to $4 million in cash and checks from large retail stores, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Ethnic Issue Brings A Dismissal in Sri Lanka
description: President J. R. Jayewardene today dismissed a senior Cabinet member who opposed his proposals for a political solution to Sri Lanka's ethnic unrest.

title: Petro-Lewis Reduces Value of Planned Trust
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation, just days before it was to tally votes on its proposal to create a royalty trust for its limited partners, has notified investors that it has reduced the appraised value of the trust by 5 percent to 8 percent.

title: HOLIDAY CLEMENCY OFFERED TO SEVEN
description: Governor Cuomo offered holiday clemency today to seven people who were convicted of selling drugs in New York City during the 1970s under a sentencing law that has since been eased.

title: Train Kills 2 Asleep on Track
description: Two aliens sleeping on a railroad track were killed when they were hit by an Amtrak train about 50 miles north of the Mexican border late Saturday, a spokesman for the San Diego County Sheriff's Department said Sunday. Three other aliens sleeping near the track were not injured and were turned over to the Border Patrol, the spokesman said.

title: 20 YEARS OF MAYHEM BY P.D.Q. BACH
description: Opera fans should be warned that parts of ''The Abduction of Figaro'' will be sung at Avery Fisher Hall Thursday through Sunday as works by P.D.Q. Bach, that ''last and least'' of Bach's many offspring, are let loose for the 20th year.

title: DOWSING: UNDERUSED TECHNIQUE OR DISCREDITED SUPERSTITION?
description: To the Editor:

title: Salvadoran Says Rebels Broke Christmas Truce
description: Left-wing guerrillas attacked a town in northern El Salvador today, breaking their Christmas truce, an army commander said.

title: DOWSING: UNDERUSED TECHNIQUE OR DISCREDITED SUPERSTITION?
description: To the Editor:

title: Salvadoran Guerrillas Called Rigid in Talks
description: The State Department said today that El Salvador's rebels had adopted an inflexible position in peace talks with the Government, possibly reflecting ''an emerging dominance'' of the leftist military command over the more moderate political leaders.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: CHRISTMAS BELLS The most resonant Christmas bells in town will reverberate over much of the Upper West Side at noon today when the carillon of Riverside Church rings out in a concert of music appropriate to the day. For those who are not content to listen from ground level in the area, there is room for a limited number on the platform amidst the bells themselves outside the carillonneur's room atop the church at 120th Street and Riverside Drive (222- 5900).

title: THE LIMITS OF DESCRIPTION
description: Christian Babani of Queens stretching to demonstrate the height of his Christmas tree during a conversation with a Santa's helper. His bearded listener was collecting donations for the Volunteers of America yesterday on the corner of Broadway and 34th Street.

title: Get a New Board of Education
description: The seven members of New York City's Board of Education have a lot in common with comedian Rodney Dangerfield: they don't get any respect. Mayor Koch is rightly dissatisfied with their management of a $4 billion budget. Albert Shanker, president of the teachers union, rightly finds them without educational vision. The State Legislature should heed these cries for reform.

title: MARY LOUISE ASWELL
description: Mary Louise Aswell, an editor and writer, died yesterday in Sante Fe, N.M. She was 82 years old.

title: Bird Inc. to Sell Some of Its Assets
description: Bird Inc. said it had agreed to sell certain roofing assets to the Genstar Corporation for about $50 million. Bird said the proposed sale would involve plants in Charleston, S.C., Shreveport, La., Portland, Ore., Glenwood, Ark. and Martinez, Cordova and Wilmington, Calif.

title: RISING INSURGENCY STRAINS ANGOLAN ECONOMY
description: Nine years after Angola's independence, pro- Western guerrillas have greatly increased their attacks on the Marxist central Government here, crippling the economy and forcing the Angolans to rely more and more on Cuban troops and East bloc arms for survival.

title: STAODYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
description: Results for the year-ago quarter and 9 months include a charge of 231,480 from the revaluation of intangible assets.

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Columbia, S.C., Arrests 5 For Defying Blue Laws
description: A man opened his clothing store here dressed in a Santa Claus suit and thus became one of five local merchants arrested for breaking South Carolina's laws forbidding certain sales on Sundays.

title: 4 People Are Killed in Crash Of Plane in Fog in Louisiana
description: A light airplane diverted by fog from its intended destination struck some power lines and crashed into a field three and a half miles from the Lake Charles airport Sunday night, killing all four people aboard.

title: PACT ON PERU'S DEBT NOT EXPECTED SOON
description: With Peru's lame-duck Government seemingly unwilling to adopt new austerity measures before next April's general elections, hopes are fading for an early agreement with the country's foreign creditors to settle more than $300 million in interest arrears.

title: NEW RANGER HITS IN A RUGGED STYLE
description: What did Stephen Patrick do to bring this upon himself? Slip on a banana peel and walk into a cement wall?

title: RATE CUT SPURS 11.16 DOW RISE
description: The stock market celebrated Christmas a day early yesterday as prices advanced sharply, propelled by the Federal Reserve's cut in the discount rate late Friday.

title: THE VOTE ON INCINERATORS: POLITICS AND A CITY BOARD
description: Last week, as the Board of Estimate made one of its most important decisions in years - what to do with the city's garbage when there is no place left to bury it - Mayor Koch found himself at odds with New York City's two other citywide elected officials. Both City Council President Carol Bellamy and City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin supported, in theory, a plan to burn the garbage in huge incinerators to produce steam or electricity.

title: MUSIC: SAMARITAN SONGS
description: Music Spectrum's Thursday night concert at the Abraham Goodman House, in cooperation with the Yale University School of Music, was most notable for the opportunity it afforded to hear some rare traditional Samaritan liturgical music.

title: VALUE OF WINDOWING IS QUESTIONED
description: Does anyone do windows any more? I don't mean the clear panes of glass in our homes, long the object of the punch line of abject-housekeeper jokes, but the on-screen ''Now you can run half a dozen programs at once'' variety. The answer is, not really.

title: DEADLY TIDE OF PLASTIC WASTE THREATENS WORLD'S OCEANS AND AQUATIC LIFE
description: The world's seas and oceans, already polluted with spilled oil, toxic chemicals and radioactive waste, are now being fouled by a new and insidious form of pollution - plastic waste.

title: POOR FARMERS NEED SUBSIDIES TO EXIST
description: To the Editor:

title: Whittaker's Marine Group LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24
description: (Reuters) - The Whittaker

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The gift of life is the best present of all.'' - Margaret Schroeder. (36:3.)

title: SOFTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: SMOKING DEPICTED AS AN ADDICTION WITH MANY LURES
description: Despite mounting evidence that cigarette smoking is a colossal threat to personal health, this year a third of American adults will persist in puffing away on 593 billion cigarettes. Four out of five of these smokers say they want to quit but, after numerous attempts, most find that they cannot.

title: INJURIES FORCE NETS TO RELY ON THREE
description: The wear and tear a player endures during the season usually doesn't show until the playoffs. But, with barely a third of the season gone, fatigue has already become an issue for the Nets.

title: YANKEES REPORTED SET TO GET WHITSON
description: Ed Whitson, the free-agent pitcher whom George Steinbrenner designated as his No. 1 priority, has decided to sign with the Yankees, a source said yesterday.

title: Boeing Contracts
description: The Boeing Military Airplane Company, a subsidiary of the Boeing Company, received two Air Force contracts totaling $46.1 million, the Defense Department said. One was $41 million for environmental control systems and the other was $5.1 million for temperature control systems.

title: SEAHAWKS COPIED FROM FOE'S PLAYBOOK
description: Lester Hayes, the Raiders' left cornerback, had nothing but high praise for Chuck Knox, the Seahawks' coach, after the Raiders lost to them Saturday in the American Conference wild-card game.

title: A RESORT SEEKS END TO TURMOIL
description: Miles of motels standing side by side on the Atlantic Ocean here are boarded up for the winter, but it has not been a dull December for Wildwood's 4,900 residents.

title: TV: FIVE ARE HONORED AT THE KENNEDY CLUB
description: The annual broadcast of ''The Kennedy Center Honors: A Celebration of the Performing Arts,'' having reached its seventh season on CBS, has now evolved into a smoothly running format. Only the recipients of the awards change from year to year. For 1984, the ceremonies held on Dec. 2 honored Lena Horne, Isaac Stern, Gian Carlo Menotti, Arthur Miller and Danny Kaye. Taped portions of the event can be seen tonight from 9 to 11 P.M.

title: 'ALL THE CHRISTMAS MORNINGS'
description: When the Giants woke up this Christmas morning, they were just where they wanted to be, even though most of them had never been there before - in Fresno, Calif.

title: MIKE MOSES TAKES ROUNDABOUT ROUTE
description: The basketball team from St.

title: DESPITE POLITICAL CHILL, U.S.-SOVIET COOPERATION CONTINUES IN SCIENCES
description: Last July, an order for 218 pizzas was radioed to a makeshift Pizza Hut on the dock at Dutch Harbor, Alaska. The pizzas were presented to the full complement of the Soviet research vessel Akademik Korolev: 30 Russian scientists, 100 crew members and 16 American participants in the Second Soviet-American Expedition in the Bering Sea.

title: CHRISTMAS MEMORIES INSPIRE GIFTS TO NEEDIEST
description: It is through memories of childhood that many people think of Christmas.

title: BRAILLE MUSIC SURVEYED
description: John Henry, a blind, 39-year-old American harpsichordist, has devoted the last four years to compiling the first international survey of Braille music. For many years, he said, he felt the need for such a survey, which he describes as a practical reference work, not a comprehensive catalogue.

title: U.N. SETS UP A SPECIAL OFFICE TO COORDINATE AFRICAN RELIEF
description: A year ago Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar sought to draw the world's attention to what he saw as an impending economic and social disaster in Africa. The response, diplomats and United Nations officials say, was inadequate.

title: Pott Industries
description: Pott Industries, a unit of the Houston Natural Gas Corporation, said it was negotiating the sale of some of its shipyards and related operations in St. Louis and Caruthersville, Mo., to the shipyard's management.

title: Back in the Race
description: Sam Bogosian , an assistant coach with the Los Angeles Raiders, remains in the running to succeed Joe Avezzano, dismissed after the season as the Oregon State coach.

title: AN AFRICAN MENU GEARED TO THE FLIGHT SCHEDULE
description: It was Friday evening, so the man and the woman from France came to Le Safari restaurant, ordered a carafe of wine and then settled at their table, below the trees, relaxed and wafted by benevolent zephyrs.

title: UNION ISN'T SUPPORTING ITS LOCAL HORMEL FIGHT
description: Leaders of the United Food and Commercial Workers are refusing to support members of the union's local in Austin, Minn., who are contesting their employer, George A. Hormel & Company, over 23 percent wage cuts.

title: FEDERAL OFFICIALS PREDICT CITYCAID PROGRAMS'S END
description: An experimental program originally intended to keep Metropolitan Hospital open is expected to end next year as scheduled, Federal health officials said yesterday. But a city official said the hospital would not be closed.

title: LEFTIST RULE HAS BROUGHT LITTLE CHANGE IN FRANCE
description: After carrying out social policies ranging from low-cost housing to cheaper false teeth to the abolition of secret security courts - after attempting to model a more equitable society - many French Socialists express a sense of partial failure.

title: Boy, 3, Is Killed in Fire AtApartmentinBronx
description: A 3-year-old boy was killed and his 5-year-old sister was seriously burned in a blaze yesterday in a Bronx apartment next-door to a firehouse.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST TUESDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1984
description: Companies

title: Topics ; Orientation ; Greener Chopsticks
description: There's a moment in teenage life when tolerant worldliness first conquers mindless ethnocentrism - and Hu Yaobang, general secretary of China's Communist Party, has just betrayed it.

title: MOVIELAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept. 29
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $673,632 for the quarter and $410,084 for the 9 months. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $316,679 for the quarter and $1,060,768 and tax credits of $212,000 for the quarter and $467,000 for the 9 months.

title: Topics Orientation
description: Greener Chopsticks

title: CHOICE OF LAST-MINUTE GLITTER TO SHINE ON NEW YEAR'S EVE
description: Rhinestones or diamonds. Sequins or bugle beads. Metallic brocades and embroideries. Dressing up this winter has been awash with glitter. The simplest way to get in a festive mood is to add a bit of sparkle. It can be applied in small doses, like a pair of earrings or a necklace on a black velvet dress, or it can take the form of a T-shirt or tank top entirely paved in sequins. The sparkling outfit is a natural for the week of parties starting with Christmas.

title: Ohio State Bank
description: The National City Corporation said it had reached a preliminary agreement to sell its Columbus-based Ohio State Bank to the First National City Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. It said the sale of the bank, with assets of $230 million and 18 offices in the Columbus area, would require regulatory approval.

title: Smith May Call Off Its Bid for Gearhart
description: Smith International Inc., which has been pursuing Gearhart Industries since last spring, said that it was conducting negotiations with the concern that could lead to ending its bid.

title: Unicef's Salts of Life
description: Within the fat United Nations bureaucracy there are lean and effective agencies struggling to be heard. An outstanding example is the United Nations Children's Fund.

title: STILL IN TOUCH WITH SANTA
description: Santa Claus has been sketched by Thomas Nast. Norman Rockwell painted his portrait. And sometime today, a television station will undoubtedly illustrate its news account of his harrowing, late-night flight around the world by showing a silhouette of his reindeer-drawn sleigh whizzing through the sky.

title: 'Extra Attention'
description: After Mario Lemieux signed the richest rookie contract in National Hockey League history last summer, Bob Berry , coach of the Pittsburgh Penguins, predicted that the center would be subjected to an unusual amount of physical play by opposing teams seeking to determine his tolerance for contact. After 23 N.H.L. games, in which the 19-year-old Lemieux had 8 goals and 27 assists, Berry said yesterday that his prediction had come true.

title: TV SPORTS
description: On Saturday, ABC-TV presented a two-hour sports retrospective for 1984. An advertisement in Friday's sports section suggested it be watched in order for us to share ''the best'' of this disappearing year. It was, in other words, a celebration, and at this juncture of the calendar, what better thing to do than man's achievements, whether they be in an arena smelling of sweat or anywhere else?

title: LA QUINTA MOTOR INNS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: PHELPS DODGE TO SHUT STRUCK ARIZONA SMELTER
description: Union members in a bitter 17-month strike against the Phelps Dodge Corporation say they are delighted that the company's Morenci smelter will close next Monday. But the workers who replaced the strikers are shocked.

title: LESTER E. WATERBURY
description: Lester E. Waterbury, a lawyer and former vice president and general counsel of the General Foods Corporation, died of leukemia Sunday in St. Augustine, Fla., where he lived. He was 89 years old.

title: DECK THE HOTLINE WITH BOUGHS OF HOLLY
description: Through one of those horrendous leaks in Washington, we are able to bring you the transcript of President Reagan's pre-Christmas Cabinet meeting, including his first talk on the hotline with Konstantin Chernenko and a fortuitous intervention by the Ghost of Christmas Past.

title: KIT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $14,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $98,000 for the year. c-Net losses.

title: Ailing Arafat Cancels Talks
description: Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, canceled a second day of talks with Jordanian leaders today, complaining that he was suffering from influenza, a spokesman for the P.L.O. leader said. The spokesman said Mr. Arafat would remain at the state guest house but would not meet with Jordanian or P.L.O. officials because he was ''not feeling well.''

title: THE CAMPAIGN TO REVERSE CIVIL-RIGHTS LAWS
description: To the Editor:

Rescuer Finds Five Boys Lost in Oregon Wilds
description: A volunteer searcher went out alone to find five boys who were missing in the rugged Eagle Creek Wilderness Area, and he fired gunshots to attract rescuers because he could not lead them out in the deep snow and darkness, the authorities said today.

title: RIPLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CONCERT: BEETHOVEN
description: Beethoven did not find the way to his innermost heart in song as he did in the piano sonata or the string quartet. It was left to Schubert to mold the musical setting of a poem into a comparable instrument of intimate expression for 19th-century composers. Still, Beethoven played a part in showing the way - a larger part than one would have guessed from Johanna Meier's Beethoven Society recital Saturday at Tully Hall.

title: PETER LAWFORD, ACTOR, IS DEAD AT 61
description: Peter Lawford, the debonair British movie actor whose youthful charm brightened ''Good News,'' ''Easter Parade,'' ''The White Cliffs of Dover'' and others of his more than 30 films, died yesterday. He was 61 years old and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

description: The Rev. John F. Steinbruck has

title: SCOVILL BOARD REJECTS BELZBERG BID
description: Scovill Inc. yesterday rejected a $35-a-share tender offer from a company controlled by the Belzberg family, but Scovill said it would explore ''all available alternatives,'' including the sale of the company.

description: -Net income.

title: Glitter and Grates
description: Within a few minutes' walk of the National Christmas Tree, behind the White House on the Ellipse, and not far from the glitter of the lights and evergreen displays of the downtown shops and offices, is perhaps Washington's humblest holiday display of ornament.

title: HOMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $265,000 for the quarter and $3,647,000 for the year. c-Including extraordinary gains of $95,000 for the quarter and $2,819,000 for the year.

title: South African Offers Blacks 'Constitutional Development'
description: President P. W. Botha of South Africa said in a Christmas and New Year's message today that his Government was committed to the advancement and ''constitutional development'' of blacks.

title: McGraw Sought Chase Unit
description: Chase Econometrics confirmed yesterday that its owner, the Chase Manhattan Bank, had talked to McGraw-Hill Inc. about a possible sale of the economic forecasting unit. But Lawrence Chimerine, chairman and chief economist of Chase Econometrics, said the talks were no longer taking place.

title: COMPETITION AND LAWYERS
description: WASHINGTON

title: IN INDONESIA, A WILDERNESS IS NOW HOME
description: It has been called the largest organized peacetime relocation of people in recorded history. But to a 42-year-old farmer named Sukardji, Indonesia's ''transmigration'' program has a more concrete definition: his own home, on his own piece of land; a kerosene lamp, a radio and a new life.

title: ABOUT TOWN: ONCE AGAIN, THE BOWLER
description: There is something new in the usually unexciting world of men's hats.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Merry Hair
