title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1984 International Immurement rites in Moscow for the ashes of Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov were marked by the absence of the Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko. It was not clear whether Mr. Chernenko had stayed away because of ill health or because of temperatures that dropped to just below zero Fahrenheit. Mr. Chernenko had looked pale and unsteady on a visit to the bier of the late Defense Minister. (Page 1, Column 6. ) Shimon Peres appears to be on top in Israeli politics 100 days after taking office as Prime Minister, having outmaneuvered his political rival and coalition partner, Yitzhak Shamir. He was recently greeted warmly in a town where he had often been scorned in the past, and in a public poll his popularity has risen sharply. (1:4.)

title: Followers of the Star When Jesus was born in Bethlehem, reported Matthew in his gospel, magi came from the east to Jerusalem. ''We have seen his star in the east and have come to worship him,'' they told Herod. The magi stepped into history and stepped out again, their journey of faith recorded in a few brief lines.
description: Like other historians, the four evangelists often complement one another with different perspectives on the same event. But Matthew got an exclusive on the magi story. Calibration has to come from elsewhere, such as from the magi's descendants. With their belief that great human events are marked in the heavens, the magi were what we would call astrologers, an ancient tradition from which astronomy was born.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Now That's Service
description: Fifteen hundred cold latkes. And no

title: END OF U.S. CONTROL SOUGHT FOR CAPITAL'S AIRPORTS
description: A Federal advisory commission has recommended that the Federal Government relinquish ownership and control of Washington National and Dulles International airports and turn them over to an independent public authority.

title: ALPHA MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
A WARNING TO GOVERNORS
description: In the last two years, many of the nation's governors have staked their political reputations on their support of

title: NO ROOM IN THE CITY
description: One of the enduring themes of Christmas is that of finding shelter for those in need. A roof, at least, if not a hearth.

title: MIDTOWN BAR OWNER AND MAN ON STREET BY GNMAN
description: A young man shot the owner of a bar and grill on Ninth Avenue and moments later shot a Christmas shopper outside, wounding both of them seriously, the police said.

title: Mailing Early
description: At a time when mo1t of us were sending Christmas greetings, the folks at Slippery Rock University in Pennsylvania launched a mailing of a different sort: post cards touting Chuck Sanders as ''Your First Official Heisman Trophy Candidate For '85.'' The cards, 400 in all, arrived at newspapers and television stations this week, less than a month after Doug Flutie of Boston College was presented with the 1984 award.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: WHEN the tall man leaned over to open the subway car window in back of her, Catherine Stock really didn't pay much attention. The subway - it was the Lexington Avenue IRT heading downtown - was warm, after all, and most of the winter coat- wearing passengers seemed to appreciate the additional rush of air. When the train pulled into the 149th Street-Grand Concourse station many of the riders got off, the tall window-opener included. When the doors closed, and just as the train started moving once more, the tall man's hand darted in, and just as quickly out of the open window whisking the fur hat off the head of the man sitting beside Miss Stock. The victim was understandably upset; his fellow passengers were at the same time dismayed and amazed at the swiftness of the action. They looked at the hatless man with sympathetic smiles. No one spoke. Then, from across the aisle, a young man reached into his pocket, leaned forward and silently offered his comb. It was accepted, used and returned with a gentle ''Thank you.''

title: Israeli Measure Limits Immunity for Kahane
description: The Israeli Parliament voted today to limit the immunity of one of its members, Rabbi Meir Kahane.

title: JURORS WITH JUDGEMENT AND LIFE EXPERIENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHOPS, STREETS AND CHURCHES, THE SPIRIT OF CHRISTMAS EMERGES
description: Christmas came in simple ways yesterday. In gusty winds that blew tinsel down empty streets. In children clutching toys barely unwrapped. In prayers sung in kitchens laden with food, and whispered at tables where meals had been a gift.

title: 2 CLINTON RESIDENTS SUE TO HALT TIMES SQ. PROJECT
description: Two Clinton residents have sued the sponsors of the Times Square redevelopment project, seeking to block the project until its effects on nearby poor and elderly residents are better evaluated. They contend the project could have a ''traumatic and even life-threatening effect.''

title: TAX-PLAN ADVANTAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR AGING PARENTS ALONE IN NEW YORK
description: WHEN traditional family roles are reversed and parents begin looking to sons and daughters for help and care, many concerned children find themselves too far away to provide such support. By dialing 800-435-7666 - the last seven digits spell HELP MOM - grown children outside New York can insure that aging parents in the five boroughs are cared for through Elderlink, a new program run by the nonprofit social- care agency Selfhelp. For a fee Elderlink will provide aged New Yorkers with help that ranges from weekly phone calls to the coordination of hospital visits and vacations.

title: DEVELOPERS PAY INTO A FUND TO AID NEIGHBORHOODS, BUT LITTLE RESULTS
description: New York City has required housing developers using Federal subsidies to pay millions of dollars since 1979 into a program meant to restore poor neighborhoods. But an examination of city records shows that the program has paid out only a fraction of the money and that little legitimate neighborhood improvement has been accomplished.

title: VOICE OF AMERICA REACHES ACCORDS WITH 5 COUNTRIES
description: The Voice of America has signed agreements with five countries to improve its transmitting ability and is also pressing Israel for permission to set up equipment there to broadcast to Soviet Central Asia and Afghanistan, Administration officials said today.

title: WOMAN WHO USES PEYOTE WANTS JOB BACK
description: A woman who says she uses the hallucinogen peyote for religious purposes has overcome criminal drug charges but now is fighting to win back her job, which included counseling children on the dangers of drug and alcohol abuse.

title: BLACKS TO CELEBRATE AFRICAN HERITAGE HOLIDAY
description: For the Walker family, holiday time begins the day after Christmas. Their house is decorated with African artifacts: a straw mat, a candle holder, an ear of corn to represent each of their children, and handmade gifts. The holiday is known as Kwanzaa, and the Walker family is celebrating it for the 10th consecutive year.

title: CHAMINADE IN UPSET
description: Keith Whitney hit a 20-foot shot with no time remaining today as Chaminade upset Southern Methodist University, 71-70, in the final of the Western Airlines Chaminade Classic.

title: 'The Great Thoughts' Will Appear in April
description: A one-volume reference work titled ''The Great Thoughts,'' in preparation for 25 years and with some research going back 50 years, will be brought out in April by Ballantine Books. The author, George Seldes, a journalist who has written 20 books, is 94 years old.

title: A NIGHT FOR FALLING APART AND GETTING TOGETHER
description: Nora Sayre, a former film critic for The New York Times and the author of ''Running Time: Films of the Cold War'' and ''Sixties Going on Seventies'' is working on a book about the 1950's.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Knox Goes 2 for 2
description: In his 12 seasons as a head coach in the National Football League, Chuck Knox has directed teams to the playoffs nine times and is the only coach in league history to reach the playoffs with three different teams. He has coached the Seattle Seahawks the last two seasons, and both times they have reached the playoffs.

title: PHILLIPS'S NOVEL DEFENSE PACT
description: At the beginning of last week, top executives of the Phillips Petroleum Company convened their investment bankers and lawyers in New York to find a way to fend off T. Boone Pickens, the Texas corporate raider who was attempting to wrest control of the company.

title: KING SCORES KNICK-RECORD 60 POINTS IN LOSS TO NETS
description: Bernard King scored 60 points last night, more than any player in the National Basketball Association in more than six seasons, more than any Knick in any season and more than any player in the history of the current Madison Square Garden. But the personal glory was not enough to prevent a 120-114 loss to the Nets.

title: Jumping the Gun On the '88 Season
description: What may be the city's first public

title: ; U.S. ECONOMY IS A RELATIVE PILLAR OF STRENGTH
description: -Ed article, ''Our Trade Balance: A Growing Crisis,'' reiterates the alarmist views Mr. Bergsten has forcefully expressed in previous articles in The Times and elsewhere. His familiar stance, while not entirely wrong, is exaggerated and misleading because it ignores that there is another and brighter side to the strong dollar and the trade deficit, besides the dreary one that preoccupies him.

title: TO THE CAPITAL'S NAYSAYERS: TOUCHE
description: Francois de Laboulaye is not a member of the D.C. Board of Trade or local Chamber of Commerce. But he was born here, went to school here and served here from 1977 to 1982 as French Ambassador to the United States.

title: JOHN H. LIMPERT
description: John H. Limpert, a founder and former chairman of Limpert Brothers, a New Jersey food-processing company, died Saturday at the Cabrini Medical Center.

title: 'ROCKET SLED' RIDER OF '54 GRATIFIED BY RESULTS
description: Thirty years ago this month, Col. John Paul Stapp took part in an experiment.

title: No Headline
description: An Acid Test for Acid Rain The Environmental Protection Agency has rejected a petition by New York and other states to curb acid rain. The Administration is not convinced that gases from the coal-fired power plants of the Ohio Valley are the cause of the acid rain that falls hundreds of miles away in the Northeast and Canada. Those power plants can't be shut down to provide definitive proof. But now a different kind of experiment, in the Rocky Mountain states, has at last provided a clear link between the cause and effect of acid rain.

title: GRISLY DEEDS LEAVE ARGENTINE ARMY UNABASHED
description: In one corner is a model of the bombed-out bedroom of the Buenos Aires police chief who died in 1976 when his daughter's rebel friend placed a bomb under his mattress. In another corner is a ''people's jail'' complete with a hooded hostage and his rebel guard.

title: RESURGENCE OF INFLATION STILL FEARED
description: As the Labor Department announced its latest figures on inflation - consumer prices rising at a skimpy two-tenths of 1 percent in November - White House spokesman Larry Speakes said flatly: ''We have nailed inflation.''

title: BEETHOVEN LETTER TO BE SOLD
description: A letter from Ludwig van Beethoven to a woman believed to have been his mysterious ''Immortal Beloved'' will be sold at auction in London in May, Sotheby's announced today.

title: DISTILLING THE YEAR INTO TV MOMENTS
description: The networks are now melting down the hundreds of hours of videotape they have shot into year-end summaries - a few minutes of television memory that will run on the nightly news programs on Dec. 31. The task of creating a video time capsule of the year has become, say the producers and editors working on them, increasingly Herculean as the number of video images created in America and around the world grows exponentially.

title: Textile Import Rules Changed WASHINGTON, Dec. 25
description: (Reuters) - The Commerce

title: TAX-EXEMPT ISSUERS IN RUSH
description: The Palm Beach County Solid Waste Authority was about to plunge into the bond market with a $320 million financing for a trash incinerator when the deal fell apart.

title: RIOT ERUPTS AT BEIRUT RACE TRACK
description: Against the background of civil war, riots broke out at Beirut's race track today when the four favorite horses tripped and fell at the start of a race.

title: Frederick Rella Is Dead at 64; Town Supervisor in Ramapo
description: Frederick Rella, a two-term supervisor of the Town of Ramapo. died early this morning at Good Samaritan Hospital. He was 64 years old.

title: HENRY Z. WALCK
description: Henry Z. Walck, a publisher of scholarly and children's books, died Monday in Plandome, N.Y., where he had lived since 1941.

title: Suriname Cabinet Resigns
description: Prime Minister Wim Udenhout and his Cabinet have submitted their resignations, effective Dec. 31, to Commander-in-Chief Desi Bouterse. The Cabinet will be replaced in January by a National Assembly, an interim step toward restoring representative democracy to the former Dutch colony.

title: Careers; Strong '85 Is Seen for Executives
description: Survey takers are especially busy at this time of year attempting to determine the career outlook for top and middle managers in 1985 and getting a final fix on 1984 results.

title: HOMEOWNERS' INSURANCE IS REVISED
description: Insurance companies have begun to introduce a new homeowners' insurance policy nationwide, the first major revision in the standard policy in eight years.

title: THE FOOTBALL PRESENT
description: A couple of weeks ago, while having coffee in the press room before the Giants' football game in St. Louis, a reporter found himself in conversation with two other sportswriters and a third man. The third man wore a cowboy hat and a genial manner. His name is Harry Gilmer, and he is now a scout for the Cardinals.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Detroit Pistons , at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. The first meeting of the season between the teams. Detroit is challenging Milwaukee for supremacy in the Central Division. (Television - SportsChannel 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.)

title: 76ers 109, Pistons 108
description: Andrew Toney made two free throws with 30 seconds left to insure Philadelphia's 13th victory in its last 15 games. The 76ers (22-6) were led by 28 points from Moses Malone.

description: From the files of the 94th Precinct,

description: The Welsh poet Dylan Thomas

title: CREATION OF ARTIFICIAL COMET IS OFF TILL TOMORROW
description: A ''miserable'' cloud cover over the Southwest and Hawaii scrubbed plans for release today of an artificial comet that would have been visible from the ground. Disappointed scientists said they would try again Thursday.

title: Irish Nationalist Gets a Life Sentence
description: Dominic McGlinchey, once the most wanted man on both sides of the Irish border, was sentenced Monday to life in prison for the murder of a policeman's mother.

title: Markets Closed Stock and commodity markets were closed yesterday in
description: observance of the Christmas

title: Peking Returns Relics Seized From Tibetans
description: Two hundred tons of Tibetan Buddhist relics seized during the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution have been returned to their monasteries for restoration, the official New China News Agency reported today.

title: Tank Burns at Oil Refinery
description: Homes near an Amoco oil refinery were evacuated for about two hours Christmas Eve when a fire erupted at a storage tank.

title: MIND OVER MERCURY IN NORTH DAKOTA: THE COLD 'KEEPS THE RIFFRAFF OUT'
description: The day would be ''warm,'' the KMOT-TV weatherman said cheerfully, ''with a high of 40 degrees.'' And, sure enough, it was - 8 degrees above freezing, quite balmy. Even a short-time visitor to this northernmost city on the Northern Plains gets used to the relativity of warm and cold and learns to practice the kind of mind over mercury that, people here boast, allows Minotans to make a mild thaw feel tropical and the usual daytime high of 1 below zero merely normal.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE: CORPORATE NEWSMAKERS OF 1984 ; Smith Emphasizing Technology at G.M.
description: When Roger B. Smith took over as chairman and chief executive officer of the General Motors Corporation in January 1981, he was just in time to report the first annual loss in the company's modern history. Four years later, G.M.'s profits are healthy again and Mr. Smith is waging an aggressive campaign to streamline the auto giant and accelerate the installation of the latest technology in its factories.

title: CHILE UNDERSTANDS OUT GO-AHEAD SIGNAL
description: To the Editor:

title: THE POP LIFE
description: MASSED brass instruments make a lot of noise; if they are voiced and played sensitively, they can make music that is rich as well as powerful. During the past year, brass instruments have enjoyed a modest revival, providing a welcome contrast to the advances in synthesizer technology that have increasingly colored our popular music.

title: Ryokichi Minobe, 80; Ex-Governor of Tokyo
description: Ryokichi Minobe, an economics scholar who served three consecutive terms as Governor of Tokyo from 1967 to 1979, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Japan, according to reports from Tokyo. He was 80 years old.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: LESLIE STEPHEN. The Godless Victorian. By Noel Annan. 432 pages. Random House. $25. LESLIE STEPHEN is most remembered now for his literary criticism, but Noel Annan is right in saying Stephen regarded his relentless assaults on theology, and his insistence that man can be moral without religion, as his life's great work. He taught at Cambridge University until he was 30, became the editor of Cornhill magazine at 40 and the editor of the great Dictionary of National Biography at 50, and he wrote hundreds of articles and more than 20 books. He had been a clergyman but found a few years after his ordination that he was no longer a believer and set out to knock down the intellectual foundations of belief. When he thought he had cleared the field of theologians he searched for the moral impulse among novelists and used his wit and critical penetration to make writers a moral force. But at last he said, ''Literature is, in all cases, a demoralising occupation, though some people can resist its evil influences.''

title: INDICTMENT OF 3 SHAKE NEW MEXICO
description: New Mexico's Democratic political establishment has been shaken by the Federal indictments this month of two state officials and the brother of Gov. Toney Anaya.

title: 'DROPPING OUT,' REPORT ON CITY'S HIGH SCHOOLS
description: ''DROPPING OUT'' won't tell you much you don't already know, but it will do it in an awfully attractive fashion. The half-hour report, produced by WNBC-TV, looks at the high-school dropout rate in New York and finds it appalling. Meanwhile, everything is artfully filmed and pleasingly presented. ''Dropping Out'' will be seen on Channel 4 at 8 tonight.

description: Fire destroyed part of the South Norwalk railroad station early Tuesday morning, disrupting eastbound rail service for about an hour but causing no serious injuries, officials said.

title: Aqueduct Floods Freeway

The shutdown posed no threat to Los Angeles's water supply, a spokesman said.

title: Tennis Nerves

Miss Navratilova, who recently sprained an ankle playing basketball, went skiing in Colorado, reacquainting herself with a sport she enjoyed as a child in Czechoslovakia. ''She's due to play in Washington the second week in January,'' said a Virginia Slims spokesman, ''and she's making us all very nervous.''

title: DELOREAN HOPING AD WILL PAY DEBT
description: When John Z. DeLorean ran a newspaper advertisement last month on the West Coast to solicit money to help him pay his lawyer, he planned to run a similar ad on the East Coast. But the second ad has yet to run and how much he raised from the first one is a secret between Mr. DeLorean and a few others.

description: Brad Benson said it was different. Bill Currier called it strange. Jim Burt shrugged his shoulders. Kenny Daniel just smiled.

title: REPORT BACKS EXPANDING NEVADA NAVY BASE
description: Accidents, adverse health effects and some property damage will probably result if a Navy facility here from which supersonic jets are flown is expanded, a Navy report has said.

title: Bridge:The Pursuit of Overtricks Is Never-Ending Challenge

He returned to the battle, however, last weekend at the Winter Regional Championships at the Sheraton Centre. With his New York teammates, Edgar Kaplan, Brian Glubok and Ron Rubin and his son Michael, he reached the final of the Knockout Teams but just failed to win the title.

description: The recent flurry of American concern about South African aparthied has focused, and rightly so, on Washington's special political and economic ties with Pretoria. So far, however, very little has come to light about the unusal ties between the two countries' intelligence establishments.

title: Mother and Son Are Reunited As Kidnapping Plot Is Foiled
description: An 8-month-old boy allegedly kidnapped by his Syrian father and held in England to lure his mother there flew home with his mother Monday night after the police foiled the man's plot to take them to Syria, the authorities said.

title: FRENCH WILDLIFE DOCUMENTARY
description: ''THE CLAW AND THE TOOTH'' is a phenomenal wildlife documentary, one that's as brutal as it is beautiful. It has no narration, nor does it require any. It consists entirely of footage in which African animals perform their ordinary rituals. They graze, bathe, nap and copulate; they stalk, kill and eat one another. This French documentary, which opens today at the Film Forum, records all of this in mesmerizing detail.

title: Quotation of the Day

title: COAST JUDGE TO WEIGH POSTHUMOUS SENTENCE
description: A state judge has scheduled a hearing for next month to decide whether a man who died after he was convicted of murdering his wife and son should be given a life sentence so that his heirs from a previous marriage will not inherit nearly $1 million in insurance money. In September 1983, Clifforn Lee Morgan, a former trucking company sales manager, was convicted by a jury in Superior Court of ordering the slayings of his wife, Nancy, 44 years old, and son, Mitchell, 8. He was also convicted of lying in wait, multiple murders and murder for financial gain, special circumstances under state law that could have brought the death penalty. In addition, he was convicted of conspiracy to commit murder for the purpose of defrauding an insurance company and solicitation to commit murder.

description: The State Assembly is to vote Thursday on a bill increasing the size of the Racing Commission to seven members from four, completing legislation empowering the Sports and Exposition Authority to build a baseball stadium and to buy or run a baseball team or racetracks.

If I hadn't been wearing a seat belt, I'm sure I would have been severely injured, even killed. As it was, I walked away from the accident shaken but without much more than a few cuts, even though my car was totaled.''

The Yankees, though, have been the most active team this offseason, and they will not slow their activity this week. They haven't set a time officially, but plan to hold a news conference tomorrow to announce the signing of Ed Whitson, the free-agent pitcher, who earlier in the week decided to accept George Steinbrenner's offer of close to $4.5 million for five years.

Before Britten died in 1976, he had written six works for Mr. Rostropovich, the first performed at Aldeburgh, in the Suffolk countryside.

description: The Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, will present free lectures on the artist Robert Motherwell on Jan. 8 and 29 at 6:30 P.M., in conjunction with an exhibition of his works at the museum.

description: Kano Anoai-Gillard had five cartons of books he wanted to get rid of. The Strand Book Store, one of New York City's largest secondhand dealers, offered him $20 for the lot, an offer he decided to refuse.

title: GRAY WINNER BY 33-6
description: Jerry Rice of Mississippi Valley caught two touchdown passes, and Fuad Reveiz of Tennessee kicked four field goals today to lead the South team to a 33-6 victory in the 47th Blue- Gray Classic.

title: HUNT IS PRESSED FOR THE ROBBERS IN JERSEY THEFT
description: Federal and local authorities continued their hunt yesterday for the thieves who made off with an estimated $3 million to $4 million in cash and checks from an armored-car company's vault Sunday night or Monday morning in Perth Amboy, N.J.

title: SEEKING OUT THE FINEST IN IMPORTED FRESH CAVIARS

His remark seems particularly apt now because New Year's is a time many of us like to dress up, culinarily as well as sartorially, and no food has the festive sparkle of caviar, the tiny sturgeon eggs known as the black gold of the Caspian Sea.

title: POPE SPEAKS OUT FOR POOR AND STARVING

title: A DAILY OTTAWA RITUAL TESTS PRIME MINISTER
description: Imagine President Reagan and his Cabinet going to Congress every day to defend the Administration's record for 45 minutes before an array of hostile Democrats.

title: SHULTZ SAID TO WARN ISRAELIS ON AID
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres said today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz had sent him a letter warning that Israel needed to take urgent measures for economic recovery and asking Israelis to show some restraint in consumption.

title: BROWN WINS TITLE IN TENNIS
description: Argentina won its first title in the girls' 18 division, and Ricky Brown of Brentwood, Tenn., took the boys' 18 title today at the Orange Bowl International junior tennis championships.

description: Pittsburgh meets Denver Sunday in the other A.F.C. playoff game, and a key factor for the Broncos could be the way their cornerbacks cover the Steeler wide receivers.

title: No Headline
description: Opening the Brooklyn Option On their way to jobs in the Manhattan financial district each morning, thousands of Brooklyn residents pass block after block of marginal stores, parking lots and virtually empty tenements in their own borough. All this underdeveloped real estate is just a couple of subway stops, or a walk across the Brooklyn Bridge, from Wall Street.

title: Supertanker From India Is Attacked in Gulf
description: An Indian supertanker was attacked today and set afire by warplanes in the Persian Gulf.

title: MERRILL BID FOR TOKYO SEAT LOST
description: Merrill Lynch Capital Markets has lost out to a Japanese securities company in its effort to become the first foreign member of the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

title: CHINA'S CHRISTIANS GET SOME BREATHING ROOM
description: An hour before midnight mass it took shoving to get out of the frigid courtyard into the vestibule of Nantang Cathedral, the centerpiece of Christmas in China.

title: DR. PAUL D. SHAFER
description: Dr. Paul D. Shafer, president of the Packer Collegiate Institute in Brooklyn Heights for 31 years, died Dec. 14 in Bath, Me. He was 82 years old.

title: Gift for a Fan
description: An early Christmas gift arrived last weekend at Humana Hospital in Louisville, tagged for William J. Schroeder from Bobby Knight and offering encouragement from the Indiana University basketball team to the ailing patient who had suffered a series of strokes after receiving an artificial heart. Mr. Schroeder, a native of Jasper, Ind., is an avid Indiana University fan and was thrilled, a hospital spokesman said, to receive an autographed basketball, a team T-shirt and a videotaped message of inspiration from the coach, who also directed the team that won a gold medal in the Olympics.

title: Arms Protesters Curb Diet
description: Nine protesters jailed on contempt of court for demonstrating outside a plant that makes cruise missile engines began restricting their diet today to protest the arms race. The nine were consuming fruit, orange juice and vitamin pills, a sheriff's spokesman said.

title: WOMAN ACCUSED IN A DRUG CASE IS BARRED FROM RETURNING TO U.S.
description: Jeffrey Mendler does not think the United States is being fair in forcing him to travel to Mexico or Iceland to see his wife. So he has written President Reagan to tell about his problem.

title: MERRILL LYNCH OFFERING 'SUBSTANTIAL' REWARD IN $51.3 MILLION THEFT
description: Merrill Lynch Canada Inc. has offered a ''substantial'' reward for information leading to the arrest of five suspects wanted in the theft of $51.3 million in securities, a company spokesman said today.

title: MCGOOHAN TO STAR IN 'PACK OF LIES'
description: Twenty-five years ago, Patrick McGoohan became famous - first in England, and then in the United States - as the quintessentially cool and resourceful British intelligence agent in the television series ''Secret Agent.''

title: DISASTER CHANGES COURSE FOR TYLER
description: A drainage ditch lined one side of the road, and next to the ditch was a mountain wall. On the other side was the edge of a cliff overlooking who knows what.

title: TIDE OF TROUBLE ROBS PERUVIANS OF THEIR HOPES
description: Less than five years after Peru's armed forces left power, the hopes raised by the country's return to democracy seem to have been lost in a rising tide of economic and political troubles.

title: SANCTUARY FOR BIRDS OF PREY MARKING 50 YEARS
description: Once it was used as a shooting gallery with migrating hawks, eagles and falcons as the targets, but now it is observing its 50th anniversary as the world's first sanctuary for birds of prey.

title: Guardian May Get Aid For 2 Adopted Children
description: Two children sold by their mother five years ago may get a belated Christmas gift from officials seeking a way to allow their guardian to qualify for welfare, officials said today.

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 26, 1984 International The Voice of America has signed pacts with five countries for modernizing its broadcast equipment and is pressing Israel for permission to set up facilities there to broadcast to parts of the Soviet Union and to Soviet troops in Afghanistan. Reagan Administration officials said the agreements and discussions with Israel and other countries in the Middle East, Africa and the Far East are part of a $1.5 billion modernization program. (Page A1, Column 6.) Vietnamese forces attacked at least four Cambodian resistance camps along the Thai-Cambodian border, using tanks and artillery barrages. Thai military officers and international relief officials estimated that 63,000 civilians fled across the frontier into Thailand. (A1:4.)

title: Required Reading In Other Words, Bid High
description: 1984 may be remembered by some top American military corporations as a year when Congress, the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission sank their teeth into Navy warship contracts and refused to let go. Coincidentally, perhaps, this warning appeared in the Navy's solicitation to the industry for a new multibillion-dollar class of destroyers:

title: EXPANDING LOS ANGELES FACES TRAFFIC BOTTLENECK
description: This city has long been regarded as the quintessential urban expression of the automobile, a seemingly endless conglomeration of housing tracts, shopping centers and freeways that radiate from a undistinguished central business district with only a few tall buildings.

title: WINE TALK
description: CHAMPAGNE is a festive drink and this is a festive time of year. More champagne is bought in the weeks leading up to Christmas than at any other time, and some merchants report that they sell more on New Year's Eve than during the rest of the year. All this makes the time right to talk about champagne, especially since many people have it on their minds and may well be receptive to a little advice.

description: A woman was killed and four people were injured in Queens yesterday when a car jumped a road divider and collided with another car.

description: They are also apparently starting to adopt the Russian custom of drinking their vodka straight. Last year, according to a survey by Heublein, Inc., producers of Smirnoff and other brands, 15 percent of vodka in the United States was consumed straight, either neat or on the rocks, up from 13 percent the year before.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: KID STUFF Years ago, and perhaps to some extent today, stories for children were often cautionary tales, some in dead earnest and many in good fun. Both are in evidence in a colorful exhibition at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street (685-0008).

title: SAFETY CONCERN AFTER AIR CRASHES
description: After four consecutive years of dramatic improvement in the safety record of commuter airlines, several accidents have brought a surge of questions about the adequacy of Government monitoring of these carriers.

title: Back to Basic Red
description: It is startling to see Engine 65 wailing through midtown these days. The pumper truck is red.

title: I.B.M. Contracts

It also said that I.B.M.'s Federal Systems division had been given $33.5 million for sonar system improvements. Texas Instruments Inc. received a $109.6 million contract from the Air Force to produce laser-guided bombs, the department said.

title: Turkey, Soviet In Trade Pacts ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 26 -
description: The two-day visit to Turkey by

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: THE DARK BRAIN OF PIRANESI AND

title: THE MARKETPLACE IS A.T.&T.'S TRUE REGULATOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Chrysler Plant Adding 2d Shift
description: The Chrysler Corporaton said it would add a second shift at its Sterling Heights assembly plant early next year, enabling the company to recall about 1,000 laid-off workers and to hire up to 700 new workers as well.

title: Witnesses Describe Backfire Before Crash of a Helicopter
description: Witnesses said they heard a helicopter's engine backfire and then saw something fall from the chopper before it crashed into a field Tuesday afternoon, killing two people on board, Madison County sheriff's deputies said.

title: Those Looting Lotteries
description: Voters in four more states approved government lotteries by big margins last month, and the directors of lotteries in the six New England states tout a joint raffle for the region. Lotteries are catching on and people like them. But they remain a dreadful way to raise revenues.

title: LEXICON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: F.B.I. AGENT KILLS MAN AFTER BREAK-IN AT CAR
description: An off-duty F.B.I. agent saw two men breaking into a car outside his apartment house on the Upper West Side and shot one of them dead when the man appeared to reach for a weapon, the police said yesterday.

title: GEMTEC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
HANOI IS FAULTED ON CAMBODIA WAR
description: A Congressional delegation that completed a tour of Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos today has concluded that Vietnam has not yet demonstrated a willingness to begin serious talks to end the civil war in Cambodia.

title: The Nasty Truth Beneath Park Avenue There's an unpleasant problem hidden under Park Avenue: The 100-year-old tunnel that links Grand Central's rail tracks to the nation is badly decayed and requires expensive repair.
description: Even more unpleasant is the fact that neither the Metropolitan Transportation Authority nor its predecessors established reserves to pay for such deterioration or scheduled maintenance to avoid the disruption the repairs will cause. Besides fixing the tunnel, the agency needs to avoid repeating those mistakes.

title: MACHINE TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SCUFFLING ERUPTS IN ISAREL CHAMBER
description: A fracas broke out briefly today when a six-member delegation from the West German Green Party visited Parliament in Jerusalem.

title: MAN WITHOUT HOME WHO FROZE TO DEATH WAS A HERO IN WAR
description: A homeless man who froze to death in a park across the street from the White House three weeks ago was a decorated World War II hero who is to be buried Friday at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Sumatra Mine Delayed
description: A World Bank-financed project to expand the Bukit Asam coal mine in south Sumatra will be delayed by more than a year because of rail construction problems, a mining executive said today. The project will be finished in late 1986, he said.

title: No Arson Seen in Fatal Fire
description: Arson was ruled out today as the cause of a Christmas morning blaze that killed eight residents of a hotel for the elderly and left 40 others homeless, the authorities said. They said an electrical malfunction may have caused the fire at the Karcher Hotel for Active Seniors, which was undergoing renovation. Smoke inhalation killed five men and three women.

title: Chemical Safety Rule Relaxed
description: A Government agency said today that it had decided not to limit brief on-the-job exposures to ethylene oxide, a sterilizing chemical believed to be a cause of cancer and genetic damage.

title: INTERTRANS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Letter: On Medical Care
description: -Efficiency To the Editor:

title: 2 Letters Are Released In Sharon's Libel Case
description: Two letters were released yesterday concerning continued efforts to obtain Israeli evidence for the trial of Ariel Sharon's libel suit against Time magazine.

title: HELP WITH THE TRASH
description: TAKING out the trash is simplified by two products: new drawstring plastic bags and a tape gun that seals bags in one motion. Hefty Cinch Sak trash bags are available with heavy yellow drawstrings, making garbage bags easier to close and carry and eliminating the need for wire ties.

title: Westmoreland Coal Write-Off
description: The Westmoreland Coal Company said yesterday that it would take $57 million in fourth-quarter write-offs, consisting of certain metallurgical coal properties in West Virginia and the costs related to their disposition.

title: 49ERS HALTING RUN WITH 3 NOSE TACKLES
description: The way to beat most teams is to stop them from running. The San Francisco 49ers stopped most teams from running, and they won more regular-season games, 15, than any other club in National Football League history.

title: WORLD ALMANAC FACT: IT'S A NO. 1 BEST SELLER
description: It has taken more than a century, but The World Almanac and Book of Facts, the reference book that has been called on to settle innumerable disputes, is indisputably a No. 1 best seller: the 928-page potpourri of facts and figures is in first place in the category of paperback Advice, How- To and Miscellaneous books.

title: Baker Oil Tools
description: Baker Oil Tools Inc., a subsidiary of the Baker International Corporation, said it had entered into a definitive agreement to acquire the Torqmaster product line from the CMI Corporation for about $30 million. Baker said the transaction, expected to be completed by Feb. 1, would require Government review and approval by the boards of both parent companies. Torqmaster is a unit for lifting oil from producing wells.

title: KING SCORES 36
description: Dominique Wilkins scored 34 points to offset a 36-point effort by Bernard King as the Atlanta Hawks easily defeated the Knicks 117-105.

title: Jim Burt: A Survivor Gains Recognition
description: Many people have dismissed Jim Burt as too short, too injury-prone, too much of a risk at a vital position. Through it all, the Giants' nose tackle has survived and then some.

title: Jellyfish Sting 1,500 Bathers
description: Invading swarms of poisonous Portuguese man-of-war jellyfish stung nearly 1,500 bathers in south Florida on Christmas Day, the authorities reported. None of the injuries were serious, but all were painful, officials said.

title: HARD YEAR FOR U.S. BANKING
description: This has been a sobering year for the nation's banking system as more banks failed than in any year since the Great Depression. With the collapse last weekend of a small bank in Sandwich, Ill., the number of failures in 1984 rose to 79, the highest since 81 banks failed in 1938.

title: MARCOS FOES ANNOUNCE UNITY PLATFORM
description: Twelve Philippine opposition leaders today signed a declaration of unity on which to oppose President Ferdinand E. Marcos or his successors.

title: THE FLOWERS OF GRASSE FADE AS PERFUME-MAKING CHANGES
description: GRASSE, France

title: THE NEW YORK LOOK Why do so many who live in Manhattan boggle at crossing the river to Brooklyn, especially when, at the end of the short hop, there is that magnificent Brooklyn Museum, near the north end of Prospect Park and the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, at 200 Eastern Parkway (638-5000)? It is a magnificent and large institution, worthy of a borough that was once one of the nation's largest cities and that now offers some of the best views of New York in a small but significant show: 25 photographs tucked away among many other bigger ones that can lay claim to attention.
description: In ''New York by Forss: The Photographs of a Street Peddler,'' are pictures taken by George Forss, who is already a legendary figure in the body of New York photographers that includes Lewis Hine and Berenice Abbott. Mr. Forss, who was born in the South Bronx and lives in Brooklyn, grew up poor and made his living peddling the pictures he took on the street. In 1980 his work was spotted and appreciated by David Duncan, the photographer, and Mr. Forss's talent became a quickly-recognized matter in the field (the two have recently done a book of Forss works,''New York/New York,'' published by McGraw-Hill).

title: Bank Rates Fall 11th Week in Row
description: Annual effective yields on money market accounts and six-month certificates of deposit plunged for the 11th consecutive week yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.

title: Dim Cyclical Outlook for Paring Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Big Drum Inc., Columbus, Ohio, to Fahlgren & Swink for its Drumstick and Push-up frozen ice cream brands.

title: FILM SOCIETY TO HONOR FELLINI
description: Federico Fellini, the Italian film director whose career spans more than 30 years, will be honored on June 10 at Avery Fisher Hall by the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

title: FOR INDOOR COLOR, A KALANCHOE PLANTZ
description: Scalloped soft green leaves. Foot-high umbrellas of perky orange, red or yellow flowers. These two unmistakable qualities quickly identify one of the season's most interesting plants: kalanchoes. Their unusual appearance has set them apart from usual holiday offerings and they are rapidly gaining appeal. Besides, they are easy keepers.

title: ANIMAL AGENCIES TRYING TO END ADOPTION FAILURES
description: Of the seven million dogs in animal shelters across the country in 1983, over 60 percent had been returned by owners who had adopted them just six to eight months before. The pets, adopted by people who had planned to give them a permanent home, were once again homeless.

title: Long Sets Records As Iowa Triumphs
description: Chuck Long passed for 461 yards and six touchdowns as Iowa overwhelmed Texas, 55-17, tonight in the inaugural Freedom Bowl football game at Anaheim Stadium.

title: HOMELESS IN CITY STREETS STIR GIFTS TO NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: For many New Yorkers and visitors alike, the most compelling reason for contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is the homeless people shuffling along the streets or huddling in doorways against the winter's cold.

title: AT VOTING TIME, ACROSS INDIA, CASTE STILL COUNTS
description: On a hazy morning early in the Indian election campaign, about 12 male residents of this village in eastern Uttar Pradesh gathered beside a dusty street, talking politics.

title: Bank Failures in 1984
description: Chronological summary of 1984 failures of banks insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation BankLocationDepositsDateAction Taken * Data are approximate total assets. Source: Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation

title: Jellybean Scoops
description: On the day after Christmas, the first tourists to go through the White House received some inside information from their Secret Service guide. The guide, with handcuffs visible under his jacket and a tiny radio receiver in his ear, disclosed that there was something different about the gingerbread house on display in the State Dining Room.

title: TO SAVE JOBS, UNION URGES NEW USE OF PLANT
description: When the General Electric Company announced in June that it would close its steam turbine plant in Ladson, 20 miles north of here, the workers and their union decided to fight to keep it open. So far, they have had no success.

title: PHILLIPS CUTS THE PRICE IT PAYS FOR CRUDE BY $1
description: In a move that industry analysts said could spur other companies to lower oil prices, the Phillips Petroleum Company yesterday cut the price it will pay for the most common grade of crude oil in the United States by $1, to $28 a barrel.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: NEW HOSPITAL UNITS SEEN AS BOON TO ELDERLY
description: New hospital units designed to make elderly patients well enough to live on their own could keep 200,000 people a year out of nursing homes and prevent many needless deaths, a Veterans Administration report says.

title: GERULAITIS IN MASTERS
description: Johan Kriek and Vitas Gerulaitis have captured the final two spots in the 12-player, $400,000 Volvo Masters tennis championships starting Jan. 8 at Madison Square Garden, Ray Benton, the tournament director, said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Nynex Executive To Head New Unit
description: The Nynex Corporation announced yesterday that it had appointed A. Theodore Engkvist as the president of a new company that would plan and develop additional business ventures for Nynex, the parent of New York Telephone and New England Telephone.

title: TO END YALTA'S LEGACY
description: Next year will mark the 40th anniversary of Yalta - the fateful Crimean meeting of Feb. 4-11, 1945, when the Allied Big Three completed the process of conceding Eastern Europe to Stalin. Yalta continues to symbolize the unfinished struggle for Europe's future. By now it should be clear that this struggle is unlikely to be resolved unless an active role is assumed by Europe itself.

title: ONE YEAR LATER, THE DEBATE OVER BELL BREAKUP CONTINUES
description: The telephone industry has undergone sweeping changes since last Jan. 1, when the American Telephone and Telegraph Company divested itself of its 22 Bell operating companies. But as the first year comes to a close, Americans cannot agree whether the breakup of the Bell System was a good idea.

title: Japan Output Up in Month
description: Japan's industrial output and car exports climbed in November, but steel shipments fell, the latter due to United States-Japan talks on voluntary restraints for steel exports, the Government and industry groups said today.

title: HERS
description: EACH night as I was reading Arlene Blum's ''Annapurna, a Woman's Place,'' I dreamed I was climbing with the American Women's Himalayan Expedition - trekking to base camp, sitting out a storm at Camp 3. The avalanches were awful. I would awake in the morning, dark circles under my eyes, exhausted after my long night on one of the world's highest mountains. I was a wreck by the time we reached the summit and placed there a cluster of flags - one Nepalese, one United States and one declaring ''A woman's place is on top,'' held together by a ''Save the Whales'' pin.

title: Gloomy Forecast
description: New player and television contracts, due to be negotiated in 1987, may result in heavy financial losses for the National Football League, according to Dan Rooney , president of the Pittsburgh Steelers. ''Suppose the worst happens in both: we don't get any increase in television revenue and the players' union comes in and makes every demand they can make, financial and otherwise,'' Rooney said in a interview with The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette.

title: Alpha and Omega
description: Ted Turner , the Atlanta Braves' owner, charmed them, but George Steinbrenner , the Yankee owner, enraged them, according to the agent Barry Axelrod , whose diary of reminisces on the chase for Rick Sutcliffe this fall was published in yesterday's Kansas City Star. On Nov. 2, Axelrod says, six days before the free-agent draft, he received ''an interesting call from someone from the Yankees - I can't reveal who - saying they had a great deal of interest in Rick and how they'd draft him if he didn't sign with the Cubs.

title: 2 Indicted in Bank Robbery
description: A Federal grand jury returned indictments today against two men charged in a bank robbery in which four people were killed and three others were wounded. Jay Wesley Neill, 19 years old, and Robert Grady Johnson, 22, were both charged with killing a person in the commission of a robbery, according to John Green, an assistant United States attorney. Mr. Neill was also charged with bank robbery with a dangerous weapon and Mr. Johnson with aiding and abetting in the robbery, Mr. Green said.

title: Wallet Returned Posthaste
description: Brigid Brown of East Brunswick, N.J., was shopping in Manhattan on Christmas Eve when she had her wallet stolen.

title: Riverside to Celebrate Its 10th Anniversary
description: The Riverside Dance Festival will celebrate its 10th anniversary on Jan. 8 with a gala benefit at 8 P.M. at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: MAYOR IS 'SHOCKED' BY NEWS OF MISUSE OF A HOUSING FUND
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he was ''shocked'' by a news article documenting the misuse of private developer funds in a program supervised by the city, and he directed his aides to investigate the problem.

title: CLOSING OF NEWSPAPER IN MANILA IS REVERSED
description: The Philippine Supreme Court today condemned the 1982 closing of an opposition newspaper and ordered the military to return all seized items to the publisher.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Crossed Wires
description: The Rev. Richard L. May, Vicar of

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Dec. 8 about imported gift products misnamed the countries in which Charles Jourdan products are manufactured. They are France and Italy.

title: PAYCHEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $114,000 for the quarter and $138,000 for the 6 months.

title: National Can Schedules Meeting
description: The National Can Corporation said it would hold its long-delayed annual meeting in late April even though its proposed merger with the NVF Company was still pending. The New York Stock Exchange had requested that a date for the shareholders meeting be set.

title: ELTON JOHN PERFORMS ON SHOWTIME CABLE
description: IN the gallery of rock superstars

title: NEW WRINKLES IN FINANCING
description: Put bonds. Springing warrants. Superstock. Money-market preferred shares.

title: LINKS OF ANTI-SEMITIC BAND PROVOKE 6-STATE PARLEY
description: The roughly half dozen members of a heavily armed anti-Semitic group that has ''declared war'' on the United States appear to be part of a larger racist alliance with adherents in half a dozen Western and Southern states, according to Federal investigators and others monitoring the ultraright.

title: THE MAYOR AND THE ARCHBISHOP: AN OUTSPOKEN BUT FRIENDLY RIVALRY
description: It was, by any measure, one of the more unusual events in the recent history of City Hall: the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York turning to the Mayor of New York and announcing that the archdiocese might forfeit public financing rather than comply with a city policy barring job discrimination against homosexuals. Such an unexpected pronouncement, at a mayoral news conference set up for another purpose - to announce a housing plan - was nothing short of startling for Mayor Koch, who generally knows what to expect at his news conferences the way courtroom lawyers know the answers to questions before they ask them.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Dec. 11 about ''A Bunny's Tale,'' a television mini-series based on a story by Gloria Steinem, misidentified the studio that produced a ''Laverne and Shirley'' episode drawn in part from the same story. It was Paramount Studios.

title: TOLL NOW 25 IN INDIAN VIOLENCE
description: A member of the Andhra Pradesh assembly was shot dead today, bringing the number of people killed in India's election violence to at least 25, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: Peru Rebels Said to Kill 15
description: Maoist guerrillas have killed 15 Indian farmers in a southeastern village, raising to 82 the number of deaths in rebel violence this month, the police said today. They said the Shining Path guerrillas burned the local school and several homes Sunday before shooting 15 people in Ayahuanco, 215 miles southeast of Lima.

title: FINDING OLD MARKERS OF BOSTON POST ROAD
description: Howard Drake likes to think that he has found a hobby that is a little off the beaten path. Mr. Drake, who is 80 years old, and his family have spent nearly 20 years locating - but leaving in place - the surviving stone mile markers on the northern route of the Old Boston Post Road, which connected New York with Boston.

title: Deficit Rises $28.5 Billion
description: The Government spent $28.5 billion more than it collected in November, making the deficit in the first two months of the 1985 fiscal year 24 percent worse than last year, the Treasury Department said today.

title: WAVE OF FUTURE HERE FROM SOVIET
description: On New Year's Eve, when the Grandfather of the Cold - Ded Moroz, the Russians call him - delivers holiday gifts to Soviet children, four teen-agers who are 4,600 miles from home will be exchanging presents in a Long Island motel room.

title: BOOKS: ECONOMIC TOUR
description: ECONOMICS IN THE REAL WORLD. By Leonard Silk. Simon & Schuster, 289 pages. $16.95.

title: Hernandez Finds Delay May Hurt
description: Eight baseball players exercised their rights after the season and demanded trades. Three of the eight - Tim Foli, Ron Hassey and Ray Burris - have been traded. One, Dane Iorg, withdrew his demand. That leaves Willie Hernandez, Shane Rawley, Jim Sundberg and Tom Herr.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: St. John's vs. Old Dominion, 7 P.M., and North Carolina State vs. Rutgers, 9 P.M. Holiday Festival, opening round, at Madison Square Garden. Victories by both the Redmen and the Wolfpack would create an interesting final Saturday for the referees: Imagine having to enforce the new coaches'-box rule against both Lou Carnesecca and Jim Valvano in the same game. Meanwhile, North Carolina State has more- critical things to be concerned about. The squad will be arriving without its heralded freshman center, Chris Washburn, who has been dismissed from the team pending a court hearing Jan. 8 on a burglary charge. (Television - MSG Network, 7 P.M. Radio - St. John's game only, WCBS, 880; 7 P.M.)

title: INDIANS AS 'NEW CAPITALISTS,' ON PBS
description: ''THE NEW CAPITALISTS: ECONOMICS IN INDIAN COUNTRY'' is a hymn to capitalism on the American Indian reservation, suggesting that tribal custom and entrepreneurship can, and should, march hand in hand. History considered, it is a hard proposition to rebut. The one-hour documentary, with Eric Sevareid as host, will be seen on Channel 13 at 10 tonight.

title: Workers Queried In Jersey Burglary
description: Fifty F.B.I. agents and local law officers are questioning current and former employees of an armored car company from which burglars stole $3 million to $4 million after circumventing three alarm systems, the authorities said today.

title: Yet Another Draw in Chess
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov today drew the 35th game of their world chess championship match.

title: EVEN MARXISTS ARE PROTECTED BY THE RULE OF LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 27, 1984

title: 100 CANTORS MEET AND MAKE HISTORY
description: The gathering yesterday began with a song of praise for what they called a historic event - the first meeting between the professional bodies of Conservative and Reform Jewish cantors.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Dresser Industries, Dallas, has appointed Michael J. Kammerer president of its Dresser manufacturing division.

title: Student Who Was Hit By Goal Post Sues Yale
description: A Harvard student who was struck in the head by a falling goal post at the 1983 Harvard-Yale football game filed a $50 million suit today charging Yale, the city of New Haven and other defendants with negligence in allowing the accident to occur.

title: FRANCIS COPPOLA SALLIES INTO TV ON A FAIRY TALE
description: LOS ANGELESEarlier this month, when ''The Cotton Club'' was opening in movie theaters across the country, the film's director was not attending premieres or out hustling on the promotional circuit. Instead, Francis Coppola was on a sound stage in Hollywood at work on ''Rip Van Winkle,'' an hourlong video film for Shelley Duvall's ''Faerie Tale Theater,'' which will be shown on the Showtime cable service sometime next year.

title: FINE CERAMICS FOR METAL JOBS
description: DETROIT

title: Nixon Tapes on the Move
description: Unnoticed by the vast majority of Washingtonians, 31 Nixon Watergate tapes have been removed from the National Archives on Pennsylvania Avenue. Plumbers were conceivably involved, but not burglars or stonewallers.

title: NAKASONE REJECTS SPECIFIC TARGETS FOR U.S. PRODUCTS
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone said today that he did not want to commit Japan to importing specific amounts of American goods as a way to reduce its huge trade surplus with the United States.

title: FRAMING A POSTER: ITS VALUE CAN DETERMINE THE METHOD USED
description: LARGE in size, printed in multiple editions and bold enough to catch the attention of the casual passer-by, posters are also an attractive form of home decoration. While 19th-century posters are now considered valuable works of art and are sought by collectors, contemporary posters with sophisticated graphics can cost as little as $10.

title: California Lets Tents Remain For a Week to Aid Homeless
description: In a gesture of holiday spirit, the state gave permission today for a one-week extension of a downtown ''tent city'' shelter for hundreds of homeless here.

title: ROYALTY TRUST PLAN IS BACKED
description: Limited partners in the Petro- Lewis Corporation voted overwhelmingly yesterday in favor of the establishment of a royalty trust in which they would receive shares, in exchange for dropping lawsuits against the company.

title: LET'S LOOK AT MITTERRAND'S SUCCESSES AS WELL AS HIS DILEMMAS
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * William D. Wells elected an executive vice president of Needham Harper Worldwide.

title: MOREHOUSE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FORTEPIANO, OR A WELL-MEANT CLAVIER
description: THE fortepiano revival, and with it the emphasis on playing old music on authentic instruments, has taken hold with a vengeance. The concert halls are full of groups devoted to the ideal of trying to reproduce music exactly as it came from the composer's pen. Recordings by the dozens are being issued. Listeners' ears are becoming reoriented to the subtle, delicate sounds of Baroque and Classic music played on long-vanished instruments. The performance of a Mozart concerto these days is looked upon with suspicion by those in the know unless the orchestra is using violins with gut strings and no chin rests; unless the pitch is about a halftone down; unless the horns are valveless; unless the solo instrument is an approximation of Mozart's own clavier. And so on.

title: MAN ALLOWED TO DIE AS HOSPITAL FOLLOWS ORDER BY L.I. JUDGE
description: A brain-dead Long Island man was removed from life-support systems today after a judge granted the request of the man's family to let him die.

title: Sri Lanka Abandons Plan for Ethnic Peace
description: The Government dropped a plan today that was meant to give the Tamil minority more political power and ease ethnic tensions between the Hindus and the country's majority, who are Buddhist Sinhalese.

title: ART IN EARLY SOVIET CERAMICS: FROM FOLKLORE TO LENINISM
description: OXFORD, England

title: Divided House Told To Share That Horse
description: Ruling in a horse custody showdown between the rodeo celebrities Montie and Elly Montana, a judge said today that the couple must share their black- and-white pinto until a divorce hearing next spring.

title: BIG PHILLIPS ARBITRAGE LOSS SEEN
description: Wall Street's arbitrage trading community stands to lose at much as $100 million if the stock of the Phillips Petroleum Company does not recover from the plunge it took on Monday, arbitragers said yesterday. Most heavily exposed, they added, is the investment management company headed by Ivan F. Boesky, the most active professional arbitrager.

title: 13 CUBAN REFUGEES WITH FAKE PAPERS FLEE FROM CUSTODY
description: Thirteen of the 77 Cubans detained by immigration authorities at Kennedy International Airport last week have ''absconded'' from the Queens hotel where they were being held, immigration officials said yesterday.

title: DEPRESSION GLASS FANS SPECIALIZE IN QUANTITY
description: STEVE ATHA has 40 complete place settings in seven patterns. Richard Blons has 600 pieces in a pattern called Manhattan. In two years of collecting Nancy Brown found enough plates, bowls, cups and saucers in Patrician Amber to assemble a service for 14.

title: ABC STATION REJECTS A '20/20' REPORT
description: ABC News will broadcast a report on sexual abuse of children on its magazine series ''20/20'' next Thursday, but the network's Los Angeles station has refused to present the report to its viewers.

title: SAN JUAN RACING ASSN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Excludes an extraordinary gain of $12,869 from the sale of land. c-Excludes extraordinary gains of $286,803, or 7 cents a share, for the latest 6 months and $767,580, or 18 cents a share, for the year-earlier 6 months.

title: Far From Home
description: Three New York hockey mavens - Frank Anzalone, Bob Mancini and Keith Martin - have found a new home in Sault St. Marie, on the icy northern reaches of Michigan's Upper Peninsula. The coach from Brooklyn, the assistant coach from Seaford, L.I., and the goal-scorer from Jericho, L.I., now pursue their careers at Lake Superior State College, where they are reversing the fortunes of a hockey team that had lost so consistently it earned the school the nickname of Lake Inferior State.

title: COMPUTER FACTORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: The Moon and the Mirage In his ''Star Wars'' speech of March 1983, President Reagan challenged scientists to devise a defensive shield capable of ''eliminating the threat posed by strategic nuclear missiles.'' The overwhelming response of scientists and defense experts, after 18 months of reflection, is that it can't be done. But Mr. Reagan won't take no for an answer.
description: His own senior officials regard the immediate purpose of the Star Wars program as the defense of American missile silos and military targets, not cities. That's far different from the total shield Mr. Reagan called for. Yet when our colleague William Broad reported the change of purpose this week, Mr. Reagan reiterated the program's original goal: ''It's not going to protect missiles. It's going to destroy missiles.''

title: MEASUREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
description: b-After a tax credit of $1,661,000 for the quarter and year.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday about the New Jersey Nets' victory, despite the scoring of 60 points by Bernard King of the New York Knicks, incorrectly described the last previous time that players in the National Basketball Association scored so many points. David Thompson of the Denver Nuggets scored 73 and George Gervin of the San Antonio Spurs 63 on the same day - April 9, 1978 - but in different games.

title: ROYAL BUSINESS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NICARAGUA REBELS ACCUSED OF ABUSES
description: Members of Congress and other Government officials say many reports of abuses by Nicaraguan rebels against civilians have come to their attention recently as a result of Congressional investigations of the C.I.A.'s manual on guerrilla warfare.

title: Sports of The Times; IT'S A GAME OF ANSWERS
description: A fledgling sportswriter, armed with the cliches of his

title: Dismissal of Mailman Reversed After Clamor
description: A rural mailman who had been dismissed for delivering his own unstamped Christmas cards to more than 500 people on his route was reinstated today, after his wife, his union and the public complained.

title: AFGHAN AID IS LOST, SENATOR SAYS WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) - Senator Gordon J. Humphrey charged today that covert American aid to anti- Soviet guerrillas in Afghanistan was being lost because of ''serious mismanagement of our aid program, perhaps of scandalous proportions.''
description: ''As a result, the Afghan freedom fighters are taking unnecessary casualties and losing battles they might have won,'' Senator Humphrey, a Republican from New Hampshire, said at a gathering marking five years since the Russians joined the fighting in Afghanistan.

title: DISAPPOINTMENTS FOR SOME STUDIOS
description: With the Paramount Pictures Corporation's ''Beverly Hills Cop'' taking in about one of every three tickets sold to moviegoers this December, the rest of the motion picture industry is facing a disappointing Christmas season.

title: V-E DAY 1985: KOHL LOBBIES FOR AN INVITATION
description: Making elaborate diplomatic and domestic soundings, Chancellor Helmut Kohl and his closest aides are striving to insure that West Germany is conspicuously included in the 40th anniversary ceremonies next May marking the Nazi surrender and the end of the war in Europe.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: Second of two columns on resilient flooring materials.

title: PASSING THE SHEKEL
description: WASHINGTON ''If you can keep your head while all

title: BESICORP GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income including an extraordinary tax credit of $86,000.

title: MEMORIAL SERVICE HELD FOR MINERS
description: Friends and families of 27 miners killed in a mine fire gathered today for a memorial service and heard a Mormon Church official pray for ''a divine balm'' to heal their hearts.

title: PHYSICIANS RADIO SETS GROWTH
description: THE Physicians Radio Network,

title: Margaret R. Manning,Book Editor in Boston
description: Margaret Raymond Manning, book editor of The Boston Globe for the past 10 years, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Boston. She was 63 years old.

title: THE STAGE: 'HAMLETTE' AT P.S. 122
description: IN her years as the leading lady

title: Air Force to Pay Less to Lockheed
description: The Air Force said it had negotiated a $439 million reduction in a 1982 contract originally set at $7.8 billion for the purchase of 50 C-5B jet transport planes from the Lockheed Corporation. Delivery of the first of the new models, an improved version of the huge C-5A, is set for December 1985, with all 50 planes scheduled for delivery by early 1989.

title: DEVILS LOSE THIRD STRAIGHT
description: Sylvain Turgeon scored two goals and assisted on another tonight as the Hartford Whalers defeated the Devils, 5-3, at the Civic Center Coliseum.

title: RANGERS BEATEN
description: Parity may not yet be the byword in the National Hockey League, but this season in the Patrick Division there have been more games like tonight's, in which the once-lowly Penguins tagged a 6-5 defeat on the once- mighty Islanders.

title: Sally Silvers Program
description: Sally Silvers will appear with 16 dancers and 10 musicians in ''No Best Better Way'' on Jan. 4, 5 and 6 at 9 P.M. at the Merce Cunningham Studio, 55 Bethune Street.

title: Panel Dismisses Action Against Federal Judge
description: A judicial panel dismissed disciplinary proceedings today against a judge who had rebuked three officers of the A. H. Robins Company, the maker of the defective Dalkon Shield intrauterine birth control device.

title: Inquiry Team Forms On Antiabortion Blasts
description: A team of Federal explosives experts was assembled today to investigate the bombings of three clinics where abortions were performed.

title: Long Weeks
description: The foremost reason the 49ers are solid favorites over the Giants in Saturday's playoff game in San Francisco is evident. The 49ers (15-1) had the best regular-season record in the National Football League, while the Giants (9-7) barely made the playoffs.

title: Kahane Turned Back At Israeli Arab Village
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane, a militant rightist member of Parliament, tried to enter this Israeli Arab village today but was turned back by the police.

title: DR. KENNETH B. CLARK: BEWILDERMENT REPLACES 'WISHFUL THINKING' ON RACE
description: If you look at my record,'' said Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, with a melancholy smile, ''you can see I'm no prophet.''

title: YEMEN'S RECENT OIL FIND MAT BECOME A BOON
description: Arab and Western officials here said today that the recent discovery of oil in Yemen was likely to revolutionize its backward economy, strengthen the Government, and alter its diplomatic position.

title: The Search for Intrinsic Value
description: THERE are countless methods of investing in

title: DOCTORS OFFICENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: MSI ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
CUOMO WRITING POLITICAL CREDO
description: Governor Cuomo said today that he was writing a statement of principles for the Democratic Party to help attract middle-class voters.

title: THE UNLOVABLE PRESS (1)
description: BOSTON No reporter or editor needs to be told these days that the press is not a universally beloved institution. Write a piece about the new phenomenon of huge libel suits brought by public officials, and you will get letters expressing the hope that the plaintiffs get their millions - and some arrogant media blood, too.

title: TAX GASOLINE A DOLLAR A GALLON
description: Is there another malaise brewing in Washington? That is what one senses, watching from the bleachers here in the desert. Just as a consensus grows that something must be done right away about the gargantuan deficit, a counter-consensus emerges among the political pundits that Congress and the President will perform their usual slow waltz and maybe produce some modest budget cuts sometime next summer.

title: No Headline
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 27, 1984 International Many Cambodian civilian casualties were reported after Vietnamese troops overran the largest rebel camp in Cambodia. Officials in neighboring Thailand said there were scores of casualties, many among civilians. Vietnamese artillery and tank guns focused on Rithisen, a day after Vietnam mounted an offensive on at least four Cambodian rebel camps, including Rithisen. An estimated 63,000 Cambodian civilians fled into Thailand. (Page A1, Column 6.) Japan's huge U.S. trade surplus was discussed with American reporters by Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone in Tokyo. Mr. Nakasone, who is preparing for a meeting with President Reagan in Los Angeles next Wednesday, said he did not want to commit Japan to importing specific amounts of American goods as a way to reduce the surplus. He said that recent suggesitons that Japan establish import targets were ''not realistic and not advisable.'' (A1:2.)

title: BIG-STAKES BINGO BRINGS THEM INTO OKLAHOMA BY THE BUSLOAD
description: On Friday evenings, Edith Alexsevitz of a suburb of St. Louis and thousands of others like her from Michigan to Texas often board chartered buses heading for a weekend in Red Rock, Okla.

title: Use of Steroids Linked To AIDS Case on L.I.
description: Body builders who use steroids to make their muscles bigger may risk contracting acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, from shared needles used to inject the drugs, a group of New York doctors warned today.

title: NEW APPROACH USED TO TEACH ILLITERATE ADULTS
description: The image is a familiar one: a benevolent volunteer tutor working patiently one on one, week after week, teaching a proud but illiterate adult how to read.

title: 5th Prison Escapee Turns Herself In
description: The last of five inmates who escaped from the state prison for women in Niantic on Dec. 15 turned herself in today, a spokesman for the state police, Adam Berluti, said.

title: HUNGRY CHAD CHILDREN SIFT THE DIRT
description: In this desert town on the route of pilgrim caravans from West Africa to Mecca, swarms of young children in rags, their unwashed faces white with the sand of the Sahara, descend on the vast central market when the sun is setting and the cold winds rise.

title: TIME TO GET FISHING AND BEACH PERMITS
description: Although it seems audacious to begin planning next year's angling with Christmas just past, the Long Island State Parks and Recreation Commission will begin issuing fishing and beach vehicle permits for 1985 next Wednesday.

title: BASSETT FURNITURE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Bridge: How Three Stars Supplied Name for Astro Convention
description: For every 100 players who are familiar with the Astro convention against opposing one no-trump openings there is perhaps one who could correctly identify the derivation of the name. It was conceived more than two decades ago by three players who have virtually retired from tournament play: Paul Allinger, Roger Stern and Larry Rosler. The beginnings of their names were used to name the device.

title: Explosion and Fire Hit Los Angeles Refinery
description: About 160 firefighters were called in to fight a fire that broke out at an oil refinery after an explosion today at a Texaco oil refinery in Wilmington.

title: Voice From the Past
description: Booker Brown ,a former offensive lineman at Southern California and in the National Football League, has accused the Nebraska coach, Tom Osborne , of violating at least six major National Collegiate Athletic Associastion rules more than a decade ago in an effort to recruit him. Brown said recent statements by Osborne against alleged N.C.A.A. rule-breakers had prompted his written statement.

title: A PORNOGRAPHY BATTLE LOST DOESN'T END THE WAR
description: The topic is pornography. In other words, there will be talk here of the corruption of youth, the exploitation of women and children, freedom of speech, art and obscenity, the Supreme Court, politics and public morality and even the devil.

title: Spanish Supertanker Set Afire in Gulf
description: Warplanes bombed a Spanish supertanker in the Persian Gulf today, setting it afire. Shipping sources said that the planes were Iranian and that it was the second Iranian raid in the same area in two days.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Interest Rates Rise Sharply
description: Interest rates jumped yesterday as some bond market investors apparently took profits following the recent rally and girded themselves for a heavy schedule of Treasury auctions in the coming week.

title: INMATE COST IS PUT AT $40,000 A YEAR
description: The ''real cost'' of keeping an inmate in jail in New York City last year was $40,000, significantly higher than the city's estimate, according to a new private study.

title: SAFETY AGENCY ASKS COURT TO RULE ON WORKPLACE NOISE CASE
description: Is a steel company responsible for the hearing loss of an employee exposed to 90 decibels of noise near a blast furnace when he is working if he also listens to 90 decibels of rock music at home on his stereo?

title: Great Western
description: The Hunt International Resources Corporation said it was offering for sale the stock and assets of its Great Western Sugar Company, either as one package or in pieces. Great Western, which is owned jointly by trusts of Nelson Bunker Hunt and W. Herbert Hunt, has the following subsidiaries: the Godchaux-Henderson Sugar Company, the Northern Ohio Sugar Company and the Great Western Railway Company. Hunt International said it is requesting that sealed bids be submitted by Jan. 31.

title: FROM THE FARM, IN CLAY
description: THEY are made by a concern called Animals & Company, a group whose members live and labor on a farm in a village called La Clenega, just south of Santa Fe, N.M. Jenny Lind, a potter who has worked with clay for 17 years, designed the original peices, which are now being produced in small quantities. The cast animals have hand carved eyes, noses and beaks, and they are fired and glazed.

title: WHEN FACING THE RAPIST: IS RESISTANCE A STRATEGY?
description: IF young Caroline Isenberg died senselessly, her

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There's going to be a total examination of this whole program.

title: Schlumberger Ltd.
description: Schlumberger Ltd.'s acquisition of Sedco Inc. has been completed, the companies said.

title: SUFFOLK OFFICIALS VOTE DOWN BILL ON PORNOGRAPHY
description: A bill to discourage depictions of sexual violence against women in photographs and movies was defeated 9 to 8 today in the Suffolk County Legislature.

title: Some Shuffling at Top At American Express
description: The American Express Company has allocated additional power to Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the head of its charge card and traveler's check division, as part of some shuffling of responsibilities among its top three officers.

title: THE TAX NEW YORK PUTS ON TAXES
description: To the Editor:

title: Stock Trading Slows; Dow Off 1.22
description: Stock prices closed with minor losses yesterday in the second lightest trading of 1984. Year-end tax selling prevented the market from continuing its pre-Christmas rally.

title: ISRAEL ALIGNS ITSELF WITH UNESCO'S CRITICS
description: To the Editor:

title: New Musical Archives For Harvard University
description: A major collection of musical manuscripts, scores and letters from the writings and estates of leading 20th-century American composers has been acquired by Harvard University. The composers all were born in the United States or emigrated from Europe.

title: SOURCES FOR VARIOUS TYPES OF FRAMES
description: Following is a sampling of shops where posters can be framed:

title: NETS WIN 2D STRAIGHT AND FEEL UPBEAT
description: As a basis for comparison, consider this: At this time last season, the Nets were struggling and depressed under Stan Albeck, their new coach. They had a record of 13-17 and showed no signs of the play that would eventually turn their season into a surprising success.

title: Rose-Tinted Outlook
description: John Sullivan , the Ohio State reserve defensive tackle who is recovering from a stabbing during an attempted robbery near his family's home in Chicago last weekend, is hoping to be able to play in the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif., next Tuesday with a little help from some extra padding. The knife left an inch-and- a-half gash in his lower right back and a slash on his right arm and has kept Sullivan idle since early Saturday morning.

title: ACTIVISM SAID TO SWELL RANKS OF LATIN CATHOLIC PRIESTHOOD
