description: The number of young Latin Americans choosing to become priests is growing rapidly as a result of the Roman Catholic Church's increased involvement in social problems, according to the church authorities here.

title: Advisory to Runners: Beware the Buzzards
description: Buzzards have joined shin splints and stray dogs as a bane to joggers, a group of Swiss doctors reported today.

title: Negligence Is Charged
description: Margaret Cimino , the Harvard student from North Tarrytown, N.Y., who was struck on the head by a falling goal post at the 1983 Harvard-Yale football game, has sued Yale, the City of New Haven, the Ogden Security Company of New Haven and 60 members the New Haven Police Department who were working at Yale. She charged they were all negligent in not providing adequate protection on the field to guard the goal post.

title: LTV Asset Sale
description: The LTV Corporation said an agreement had been signed under which certain assets of its Republic Buildings Corporation would be sold to the AMCA International Corporation of Hanover, N.H. Terms were not disclosed. LTV said it acquired Republic Buildings, which makes pre-engineered metal buildings, as part of its purchase of the Republic Steel Corporation in June.

title: OF SURROGATE WHITE HOUSES
description: There are no signs proclaiming ''Temporary White House.'' Yet three mansions in downtown Washington have housed Presidential families in times of White House repairs.

title: Debt
description: * Citicorp sold $100 million of 91-day commercial paper at 8.189 percent, down from 8.199 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at 8.361 percent, up from 8.314. percent.

title: DOORNINK GEARS FOR 'OPERATION DOLPHINS'
description: Sometimes they call him Dr. Opie, and it's easy to see why. Dan Doornink looks a lot like an adult version of Opie Taylor, the little kid on the old ''Andy of Mayberry'' television series. He has the same blond hair, the Huck Finn grin and a soft, easy, friendly manner.

title: American Healthcare Appoints a President
description: David A. Huff, 40, a certified public accountant, has been named president and chief operating officer of American Healthcare Management Inc., a fast-growing company that he co-founded in 1978. Previously, he served as executive vice president and before that he was senior vice president.

title: African Healing
description: A living embodiment of the statues

title: Michigan Mother Held In Drowning of Infant
description: A woman who had said that her 2-month- old son was kidnapped from a shopping cart in a store was charged today with murdering the infant by drowning him in a river.

title: INCREASE IN U.S.-CHINA TRADE IS SEEN
description: An organization of more than 400 American companies forecast today that trade with China would increase by $1 billion next year from the $6 billion estimated for 1984.

title: Holiday Challenges at Garden
description: Although St. John's and North Carolina State bring nationally- ranked teams into tonight's first round of the Eastern College Athletic Association Holiday Festival, their opponents could provide stiffer challenges than expected.

title: IN BORDER COUNTRY, NATIONALITY SEEMS TO BLUR
description: Just over the border, in Canada, Paul-Maurice Patenaude chalked up the tip of his cue. Then, with the elan of a seasoned pool player, he stretched his arms and poked the white cue ball into the United States.

title: A LOOK AT 10 DESIGN TRENDS THAT MADE THEIR MARKS IN 1984
description: FOR design trend setters as well as trend watchers, 1984 was a particularly interesting year. The all-white modernist interior and the rigidly furnished minimalist space were both upstaged by nostalgic, cozy rooms, dense with 19th-century revival furniture, curtained with exuberant draperies of gold-flecked fabrics or extravagant chintzes.

title: ANCIENT ETHIOPIAN HOLY CITY STARVES
description: At night, the mountain slopes surrounding this ancient and holy city flicker with the light of tiny fires.

title: 'SATANIC RITUAL' IS NOW RULED OUT IN JUNE SLAYING OF YOUTH IN L.I. WOODS
description: When the decomposed body of a 17- year-old youth was found in the woods here last June, the police said he was killed as part of a ''Satanic ritual,'' a sacrificial slaughter witnessed by a throng of chanting cultists.

title: A PUBLISHER AND A WAR PILOT
description: Charles M. Kinsolving, a former publishing executive and one of the American pilots who flew with the Lafayette Escadrille in France early in World War I, died Monday at his home in Carmel, Calif. He was 91 years old.

title: NUNS SAY VATICAN THREAT IMPERILS CATHOLICS' RIGHTS TO SPEAK FREELY
description: Nuns threatened with expulsion over their stance on abortion show no willingness to retract their position and say the Vatican reacted too harshly, in a way that imperils the rights of all Roman Catholics to speak freely within the church.

title: Futurists See Growth In Robot Population
description: The population of robots in the United States is growing by 30 percent a year, compared to a human population growth rate of only 2 percent annually, according to the World Future Society. The society said there will be 35,000 robots in the United States by 1990.

title: Brooklyn Victor On Return Home
description: Brooklyn College, which will travel to 11 states for 13 games this season, returned home last night and routed Tufts, 73-51, behind Marvin Richardson's 29 points.

title: FOR SOME, IT LOOKS LIKE AN UNHAPPY NEW YEAR
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission, one of the smallest and newest of Federal agencies, heads toward the new year in anticipation of a new chairman, in anxiety over its very existence and, of all things, in search of a mole who may have divulged the substance of some private deliberations.

title: Qaddafi Says Britain Wages A Campaign Against Libyans
description: Col.Muammar el-Qaddafi. the Libyan leader, in talks with a Church of England envoy, accused Britain of conducting a ''campaign of hatred and harassment'' against Libyans, the Libyan radio said today.

title: Guerrillas in Chile Free Captive Journalist
description: A Chilean journalist kidnapped a week ago by leftist guerrillas was freed unharmed Tuesday night after Christmas appeals for his release.

title: January Jazz Festival Set at the Vineyard
description: A performance by the jazz trumpeter Doc Cheatham on Jan. 6 at 3 P.M. opens a month-long music festival at the Vineyard, 309 East 26th Street. Titled ''Five-Century Jazz Series,'' the program also features classical and Sephardic music.

title: Taiwan G.N.P. Outlook
description: Taiwan's per-capita gross national product will climb to $3,370 in 1985 from this year's estimated $3,000, because of rising exports, Prime Minister Yu Kuo-hwa said. But exports will grow at a slower pace in 1985, he said Monday. He also predicted that Taiwan's inflation rate will double to 2 percent in 1985 from 1 percent this year because of Taiwan's growing foreign exchange reserves.

title: SKI RESORTS USING BACTERIA FOR MAKING SNOW
description: A snow-inducing bacterium is being tested by at least four Colorado ski resorts to determine whether it would augment standard snow-making methods on the slopes.

title: FROM BAYSIDE HIGH TO 49ERS
description: The education of Derrick Harmon

title: Tesoro Reports Deal for Funk SAN ANTONIO, Dec. 26
description: (Reuters) - The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said it had

title: MAGNETIC CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a gain of $457,000 for the quarter and year from the reversal of a previously funded reserve for discontinued operations. c-Net loss after a reserve of $3,950,000. d-After a reserve of $3,950,000 for discontinued operations and a nonrecurring loss of $1,152,000 on the sale of a division.

title: Scovill Exploring Several Options
description: Scovill Inc. disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was considering various options in the wake of its board's rejection of a $35-a-share bid from First City Properties Inc., which is controlled by the Belzberg brothers of Canada. Scovill, based in Waterbury, Conn., makes household products.

title: Cr eche Figure Missing In Rhode Island Dispute
description: A statue of the infant Jesus is missing from a cr eche across the street from Town Hall, and the police say they have no clues concerning who is responsible.

title: KING MEETS STOPPER
description: If great minds think alike, then Coach Stan Albeck and George Johnson, the Nets' third-string center, could have been considered geniuses on Tuesday night.

title: COMPANY B
description: * Altos Computer Systems Inc., San Jose, Calif., said its board had authorized the company to buy up to 500,000 shares of its approximately 15 million shares outstanding.

title: ART: 'GRANDE PARADE,' AT THE STEDELIJK
description: AMSTERDAM AMSTERDAM has almost as many museums as it has fillets of herring, and not one of them deserves to be thrown back into the sea. It has the Rijksmuseum, one of the great repositories of Old Master painting and the decorative arts. Among its other resources is a first-rate theater museum, powered by videotape at its most vivacious and buried deep in the stuccoed interior of one of the grandest canal- side town houses.

title: 'The Festival of India'
description: When Indira Gandhi visited Washington in 1982, she and President Reagan agreed to the idea of an Indian festival in the United States. The Smithsonian Institution took over the planning, and the result is ''The Festival of India'' to be held in Washington and New York in 1985 and 1986.

title: 2 Suits Allowed On Imprisonment
description: Two men imprisoned for manslaughter convictions - one in 1933 and the other in 1959 - won the right today to sue the state for millions of dollars for being wrongly convicted.

title: Day-Care Prints Show Fewer Crime Records
description: The percentage of current and prospective day-care center employees in New York City with criminal records has dropped sharply with the recent receipt of criminal record checks on 721 people, officials said yesterday.

title: Columbia To Name Garrett As Coach
description: Jim Garrett, a 54-year-old assistant coach for the Cleveland Browns, will be appointed today as head football coach at Columbia University, where one of his sons is a wide receiver.

title: Two Children Survive Plane Crash in Texas
description: Two children who survived a small plane crash that killed three adults spent Christmas night huddled under a tree in rugged country near the Mexican border until rescuers reached them today.

title: SOURCES OF PATTERNS AND PRICE GUIDANCE
description: ANTIQUE shows, household and estate auctions, flea markets and yard sales are all good places to find Depression glass. Glass clubs often sponsor shows.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 10.75-11.25 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MEDICAL STERILIZATION reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Times Names Ad Directors
description: The New York Times yesterday named directors of national, classified and retail advertising. Lance R. Primis, senior vice president for advertising, made the announcement and said the appointments are effective Jan. 7.

title: Z&Z FASHIONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gemayel and Assad Confer on Security
description: President Amin Gemayel held talks in Damascus today with President Hafez al- Assad of Syria on security problems in Lebanon and the deadlocked negotiations with Israel, the Lebanese state radio reported.

title: ST. BART'S: NEW PLAN THAT FACES OLD ISSUES
description: AnAppraisal

title: WAGNER REPORT STATES MERRICK HAS RECOVERED
description: -appointed guardian for producer David Merrick, said yesterday he has told the State Supreme Court that Mr. Merrick is sufficiently recovered from a February 1983 stroke to resume control of his financial affairs.

title: Europe's Unleaded Gas
description: The state-owned Kuwait Petroleum Company has begun selling the first unleaded gasoline in Europe at 30 gas stations in five countries, a company spokesman said today. The unleaded gas went on sale Wednesday, in anticipation that the European Economic Community would adopt an antipollution standard calling for substantially lower levels of lead in gasoline by 1989, a company spokesman, Jan van Veen, said.

title: Firearms Conspiracy Charge Is Denied by Omega 7 Leader
description: Eduardo Arocena, the imprisoned leader of the Omega 7 anti-Castro group, pleaded not guilty today to an indictment charging him with conspiracy to possess illegal firearms and to four new counts involving machine guns.

title: Further Nerve Gas Tests Permitted in Cambridge
description: A Superior Court judge refused today to lift an injunction that temporarily permits Arthur D. Little Inc. to keep testing deadly nerve gas in a Cambridge laboratory despite the city's objection.

title: WATCHDOG OVER U.S. SPENDING ACCUSED OF WASTE
description: The General Accounting Office, the Congressional agency that investigates waste in the executive branch, has itself been accused of spending almost $13 million in developing a computer system that never was completed.

title: ART: THE SHOWMANSHIP OF JONATHAN BOFSKY IN A WHITNEY RETROSPECTIVE
description: WE knew that Jonathan Borofsky was coming to town; we had fair warning from Philadelphia, where his ''midcareer retrospective'' played its previous stand. Even so, we weren't quite prepared for his current blitz at the Whitney Museum, in whose fourth-floor galleries he seems to have unpacked the entire contents of his busy head.

title: Irene Segal Wed To Bennie Lauve
description: Irene Jane Segal, a daughter of Dr. Alvin Segal of Pomona, N.Y., and the late Nanette Greenberg Segal, was married yesterday to Bennie Edward Lauve, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Lauve of Groves, Tex. Judge Kenneth M. Pacetti of the Harris County Precinct Court performed the ceremony in his chambers at the Harris County Courthouse in Houston.

title: BLACKS AND THE REAGAN AGENDA
description: Recently, when the Department of Education awarded $7.1 million in grants to colleges, the press release announcing the Federal assistance made a significant point: The institutions to receive most of the funds included many black colleges whose financial solvency has long been a problem.

title: A SURPRISE SNOWSTORM BLANKETS REGION
description: The winter's first snowfall blanketed the New York metropolitan region yesterday, baffling forecasters with its severity and tying up traffic on roads and rail lines and at airports.

title: PAUL DAVIDOFF, 54: PLANNER CHALLENGED SUBURBS' ZONE RULES
description: Paul Davidoff, an influential planner who was instrumental in challenging suburban zoning regulations that exclude low-income people, died yesterday at the Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center of complications resulting from treatment for cancer. He was 54 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;  Through to the Governor
description: ''Mario?'' ''Yes.''

title: FREE NEW YEAR'S EVE FARE SET ON SUBWAYS AND BUSES
description: Rides on New York City's subways and buses will be free on New Year's Eve and early New Year's Day, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday.

title: Dow Declines 6.40; Toy Group Plunges
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday as trading quickened from the minuscule volume in the preceding session.

title: DANCE: 'NUTCRACKER'
description: ''THE NUTCRACKER'' bursts forth from every cranny, it seems, over the winter holiday season. And so it was unsurprising, perhaps, that Balletfore should hurl itself into the fray.

title: Michigan City Is Urged To Boil Drinking Water
description: Residents were urged to keep boiling their drinking water as a precaution today, even though initial tests showed no contamination of the city's water supply after an equipment malfunction allowed it to run dry Tuesday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;  Circadian Parking
description: When biological clocks go awry in

title: STAGE: ANN REINKING AT THE JOYCE
description: -person show needs in order to come alive is a strong, vivid personality. And in ''Music Moves Me,'' Ann Reinking's third attempt at a Broadway-styled one-woman show, personal electricity is in desperately short supply.

title: Taiwan Auto Tariffs
description: A Government agency has proposed a gradual reduction of import tariffs on compact cars, components and supplies to auto makers, an official said today. The Council for Economic Planning and Development proposed to the Cabinet that the tariff on imported compact cars be lowered to 55 percent, from 65 percent, in July 1985 and gradually to 30 percent over the next six years. Officials said the reduction would help make Taiwan's automobile industry more competitive.

title: TRYING TO RECONCILE SECRECY AND COMPUTER USE IN RUSSIA
description: For anyone feeling threatened by the spread of little computers into businesses, schools and homes, there is still a sanctuary in the developed world where the abacus is king and floppy disks are badly manufactured phonograph records.

title: PARKCHESTER'S LABORED CONVERSION A TESTING GROUND
description: Parkchester, once the largest housing development in the country, has been a testing ground since its construction in the late 1930's and early 1940's.

title: SOME SUBTLE POINTS MAY AFFECT PLAYOFFS
description: Teams seldom change their style once they get into the playoffs. Unless injuries dictate otherwise or a coach is struck by an odd notion - such as Dwayne Crutchfield's being a better runner on a particular play than Eric Dickerson - form pretty well holds.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The right of a competent adult patient to refuse medical treatment constitutionally guaranteed right which must not be abridged.'' - The California Court of Appeal for the Second District (A1:1.)

title: Welfare Increase Is Asked for State
description: The state's Social Services Commissioner has requested a 15 percent increase in New York's basic welfare grant, Governor Cuomo said today.

title: CORPORATIONS SEE GAINS IN AIR TICKET DECONTROL
description: With deregulation of the travel- agent industry taking effect Jan. 1, some of the nation's biggest companies are considering going into the airline-ticket sales business themselves, a change that could save them millions of dollars and even generate income, at the expense of the travel agencies.

title: Leading by Doing
description: Mel Stottlemyre, the Mets' pitching coach, is worried that ''we'll never hear the end of it.'' Jay Horwitz, the team's director of public relations, wonders if he'll have to rewrite the manager's biography in the 1985 press guide.

title: Wags-Clubmart
description: Wags Stores Inc. said it had agreed to acquire Clubmart of New York Inc. from Clubmart of America Inc. for $500,000 in cash and $700,000 in notes, subject to the approval of Clubmart shareholders. Wags said the closing is expected about March 15. Clubmart of New York operates an 18,000-square-foot store in midtown Manhattan.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Nets, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. When these two teams last played, Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, Bernard King's 60 points were not enough for the Knicks, who fell by 120-114. So it goes for talent-weak clubs that have one big scorer. (Television - Sports Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660, at 7:30 P.M., and WPAT, 930; WFAS, 1230; WGBB, 1240; all at 7:20 P.M.)

title: UTAH MINE FIRE IS STILL OUT OF CONTROL
description: Burning coal and a dangerous buildup of gases will prevent workers from sealing off critical areas of the Utah mine where 27 miners died until Saturday at the earliest, a spokesman for the mining company said today.

title:
WAYS OF REPAIRING THE ISRAELI ECONOMY;
AMERICAN INCENTIVES
description: In recent weeks, Israel has asked the United States for nearly $5 billion in new military and economic aid - an additional $800 million for fiscal 1985 (on top of the $2.6 billion already granted) plus a total of $4.1 billion for fiscal 1986. The Reagan Administration has firmly refused the emergency aid request pending evidence of further Israeli belt-tightening. Although the news was greeted with some disappointment in Israel, economists should see the logic of the new American approach and the long-term advantages for Israel's economy.

title: BIRDFINDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Plan for Beached Freighter
description: A Venezuelan freighter, aground in the back yard of an oceanfront mansion, will be hauled away ''in the next few weeks,'' a state official said Wednesday. Elton Gissendanner, director of the Florida Department of Natural Resources, said that equipment would arrive this week to begin work on the Mercedes I, which grounded in a Thanksgiving storm.

title: TOYS 'R' US SALES DATA HURT STOCK
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc., the giant toy specialty retail chain, yesterday announced record sales for the Christmas selling season. But apparently because sales failed to meet its own sales plan, the company's stock plunged on the New York Stock Exchange, dragging down the stocks of other toy companies as well.

title: Musical-Comedy Tunes
description: ''Tate to Tate,'' an evening of show tunes starring the arranger-composer Neal Tate and his wife, the soprano Marzetta Jones-Tate, will be presented at the Billie Holiday Theater, 1368 Fulton Street, Brooklyn (636- 0919 ), on Sunday night at 8. Staged by Alan Weeks, a co-star of ''The Tap Dance Kid,'' the program will feature numbers from six Broadway shows. Tickets are $7.

title: MITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $270,000, or 14 cents a share, from the forgiveness of previously deferred income tax which was partly offset by expenses booked to bring the company's Preston Engravers Inc. unit into conformity with its accounting policy.

title: CENTRAL SOYA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SOVIET JEWS IN ISRAEL SPLIT ON U.S. RADIO PLAN
description: A United States request for permission to set up a transmitter in Israel to relay Voice of America broadcasts to the Soviet Union has set off a debate here among Soviet Jewish emigres.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of editing errors, an article in Sports Pages yesterday about the Holiday Festival basketball tournament misstated the poll ranking of the St. John's team and misidentified the tournament's organizer. St. John's is ranked fifth in the poll of writers but eighth in the coaches' poll, and the organizer is the Eastern College Athletic Conference.

title: 2 Killed in Fire
description: Two employees of Kutsher's Country Club in the Catskills were killed this morning in a fire at the staff quarters, the state police said.

title: Long-Ago Swat Is Long Forgiven
description: Nick Lopardo's enthusiasm was unbridled. ''That's wonderful news! You made my day!'' the senior vice president at Equitable Life said yesterday when told that Jim Garrett, who had coached him at Susquehanna University, had been hired to direct the fortunes of Columbia University's football team.

title: STILL MORE TROUBLE
description: First Olden Polynice, then Chris Washburn. And now a third college basketball star this season has run into some off-the-court problems.

title: CORRECTION
description: The About New York column on Dec. 12 about single women's search for compatible men omitted the sponsorship of a survey of unmarried people. The survey, by Princeton University researchers, was initiated by Money magazine.

title: THE RESPONSIBLE AND PREDATORY PRESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect Is Shot; Officer Suspended
description: A police officer was suspended yesterday because he violated department guidelines in shooting a youth who fled after the officer caught him trying to jump a turnstile at a BMT elevated station in Queens, according to the police.

title: Military Contracts
description: Subsidiaries of the Lockheed Corporation received contracts totaling $329.2 million from the Air Force and Navy for 18 C-130H aircraft, Trident missile materials and facilities and improvements on S-3A aircraft. In addition, units of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation got contracts of $168.4 million for ammunition, KC-10 aircraft materials and the development of a jet flight training system.

title: Heileman's Offer For Pabst Blocked
description: A United States District Court judge today temporarily blocked the G. Heileman Brewing Company's proposed $70 million purchase of the Pabst Brewing Company on the ground that the acquisition might violate Federal antitrust laws.

title: THE TECHNIQUE OF TERROR
description: CAIRO Terrorism has been an instrument

title: Gee! Haw! Mush!
description: One of the big public festivities being planned for Jan. 21 is the Presidential Inaugural Parade, the 50th such event since sup porters of George Washington trooped behind him in tribute in 1789.

title: Ollie A. Randall, 94; Advocate for the Aged
description: Ollie A. Randall, a lifelong advocate of increased care and rights for the elderly, died Wednesday at Allen's Nursing Home in West Kingston, R.I. She was 94 years old.

title: DONOVAN'S LAWYERS CHARGE MISCONDUCT BY PROSECUTORS
description: Charging misconduct and bias by Bronx prosecutors, defense lawyers yesterday filed a motion for dismissal of fraud charges against Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan and his nine co-defendants.

title: BIG BEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24

WAYS OF REPAIRING THE ISRAELI ECONOMY;
HIGH-TECH EXPANSION
description: Israel's national unity Government faces the Herculean task of arresting the spiraling trends of the country's ailing economy. Yet Israel must be wary of the severe economic austerity measures being strongly recommended now at home and abroad. The country's economic future must lie in expansion, not curtailment of what has already been achieved.

title: THE RESPONSIBLE AND PREDATORY PRESS
description: To the Editor: Defense Secretary Weinberger is right. The Washington Post was both ''irresponsible'' and arrogant in pub

title: AUCTIONS
description: WHILE most auction houses are closed this holiday season, it is business as usual at the Robert W. Skinner galleries in Bolton, Mass. Nancy R. Skinner, president, decided to hold the post-Christmas sales planned by her husband, the founder of the 22-year-old auction house, who died Aug. 12 at the age of 51.

title: ACTOR WOULDN'T QUIT; NOW HE'S 'PACIFIC' STAR
description: KEVIN GRAY is a perfect example of why young actors ignore the advice of experienced elders. He was advised to get out of the business. He didn't. He's now one of three leading men in the revival of ''Pacific Overtures'' and his portrayal of Kayama Yesaemon, a Japanese samurai, has been critically acclaimed as ''commanding.''

title: Strike at Bookbinders Ends
description: A bitter, two-month strike against the Old Original Bookbinders, one of Philadelphia's best-known eating establishments, ended Wednesday night with the return of 150 waiters, waitresses and other workers. About 90 members of Local 301 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union walked out Oct. 19 in a dispute over health benefits, and about 60 bartenders and kitchen workers, members of Local 274 of the same union, walked out in support of the waiters. Raymond Turchi, president of Local 301, said today that ''management had thrown in the towel'' after losing about $1 million.

title: City Federal Seeks Units in 24 States
description: City Federal Savings and Loan Association, New Jersey's largest thrift institution, said it was seeking permission to open 54 branches in two dozen states. Under the proposal submitted to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, City Federal seeks to open deposit-gathering branches in existing loan offices, a spokesman, Michael Rust, said.

title: PERSONAL DIAGNOSTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $275,000 for payment to a former underwriter in connection with a stock offering. Results for the latest periods include results of Lydo Precisions Products Inc., acquired Feb. 10.

title: Chileans Deport Priest And Free 3 Others
description: A Roman Catholic priest born in Chicago was deported by Chile's military Government tonight for distributing Christmas cards that asked for a ''New Year without torture,'' church officials said. The Government set free an Irish priest and two Chilean nuns who had also been arrested Monday.

title: DEFENDING THE SILOS
description: To the Editor:

title: ARGENTINE COURT APPROVES TRIALS
description: The Supreme Court ruled tonight that civilian judges can try nine former leaders of the armed forces who are accused of violating human rights during Argentina's years of military rule.

title: Interactive Data
description: Chase Manhattan Bank's Interactive Data Corporation and the Western Union Corporation said they had signed a letter of intent for Interactive to acquire Telestat Systems Inc., a Western Union subsidiary.

title: REAGAN CALLS SOVIET AFGHAN MOVE 'DAY OF INFAMY'
description: President Reagan, marking five years since Soviet forces joined the fighting in Afghanistan, said today that the event was ''a day of infamy'' reminiscent of Pearl Harbor.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: NEW YORK SUES TO BLOCK GRANT TO JERSEY CITY
description: New York City filed a lawsuit yesterday seeking to block a Federal grant of $9 million to Jersey City pending enforcement of a promise to preserve 1,200 jobs in Manhattan.

title: REFUGEE INFLUX STRAINS SUDAN'S FRAGILE FABRIC
description: The United States said it was sending emergency aid by sea and air to the Sudan. Page A6.

title: The Dangers of 'Self-Defense'
description: Many New Yorkers now seem to believe that because the police and courts can't guarantee public safety, citizens should carry weapons in the street and subway. How else to interpret the flood of public ''support'' for the unknown subway passenger who shot down four teen-agers who apparently tried to extort money from him?

title: Dissidents Reported Detained in Pakistan
description: The military authorities detained more than 30 dissidents in Northwest Frontier Province today, an opposition party said.

title: NICARAGUA' WEST: KING COTTON AND SOVIET HEALERS
description: The white puffs of cotton are hanging heavy on their stems, and tall buds are shooting from the tops of ripe sugar-cane stalks in this rich farming region of northwestern Nicaragua. ''Take a look at these crops, my friend,'' said Luis Manuel Saballos, whose fertilizer and pesticide business depends on the farm economy, as he visited the area for a preview of the harvest. ''That's our economy. This is where we grow our dollars.''

title: LOUISIANA KILLER IS ELECTRCUTED
description: An unrepentant Robert Lee Willie was executed today in Louisiana's electric chair for the rape and murder of an 18-year-old woman who was attacked as she walked home from a discoth eque.

title: BOSTON'S DECADE OF DESEGRAGATION LEAVES EXPERTS DISPUTING EFFECTS
description: Ten years after a Federal judge ordered busing of public school students here to achieve racial integration, Boston's classrooms have changed dramatically in terms of what is being taught, who is being taught and who is doing the teaching. But whether the quality of education has improved remains in dispute.

title: Montgomery & Stire Names Vice President
description: Remember Emilie Griffin, the copywriter at Compton Advertising who was recruited to start a Children's Advertising Unit for the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus?

title: RULING IN COVERT-AID CASE WORRIES U.S. OFFICIALS
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials say they are concerned about a recent ruling by a Federal judge that could force the Central Intelligence Agency to release numerous classified documents describing the agency's involvement with Nicaraguan rebels.

title: KOCH ASKS INQUIRY INTO SUBWAY FIRES
description: The number of fires in New York City's subways rose sharply during a recent Federal inspection, and Mayor Koch has asked the Fire Department to investigate the possibility of arson.

title: A GENERATION DISCOVERS THE BLACK DRESS
description: The dress, perhaps more properly, the

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Sympathy in the Park
description: Walking across City Hall Park en

title: 4th-Quarter Loss Seen By Colgate $114 Million Charge Is Set
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company said yesterday that it would take an after-tax charge of $114 million against fourth-quarter earnings to cover the cost of restructuring certain manufacturing operations in the United States and abroad.

title: Economic Scene; 3 Messages Of Challenge
description: What were the most challenging economic messages of 1984? Here are our nominations:

title: A Second Chance
description: Nine track-and-field athletes who missed last summer's Los Angeles Olympics because of the Soviet boycott, are scheduled to compete in the United States this winter in the 14- meet indoor series that culminates in the USA Mobil Championships Feb. 22 at Madison Square Garden. The nine include Irina Podyalovskaya, the world champion at 800 meters, Nadezhda Ralldugina, the world champion at 1500 meters, and Konstantin Volkov, a leading pole-vaulter.

title: VEGA BIOTECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
10,000 Italians at a Funeral For Train Bombing Victims
description: Some 10,000 Italians, many demanding justice, attended an emotional funeral today for the victims of the terrorist train bombing that killed at least 15 Christmas travelers.

title: Presidents in Color
description: The National Archives has discovered that two very disparate

title: PUBLISHING: A BEST SELLER FOR CONNELL
description: FOR the second consecutive week, Evan S. Connell's ''Son of the Morning Star'' is on The New York Times nonfiction best-seller list. The book, a biography of George Armstrong Custer, set against the history of the Plains Indian wars, is the first best seller in the four-year history of North Point Press, which has published 102 titles.

title: IIS INTELLIGENT INFORMAION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCOVILL: STRENGTH IN DIVERSITY
description: Scovill Inc., which is now on center stage in Wall Street's latest takeover drama, was not always such a sought- after property.

title: Chase Manhattan Bank Chooses Scali, McCabe
description: Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that it had chosen Scali, McCabe, Sloves as its agency for consumer business in the New York area as well as the bank's wholesale business here and abroad.

title: HEADACHES MOUNT AFTER BELL BREAKUP
description: A myriad of problems have greatly complicated the move to deregulate the nation's telephone industry and rely more heavily on market forces. The effort has been vastly complicated by the breakup of the Bell System a year ago.

title: HUBBARD REAL ESTATE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
School Aides Disciplined Over Strip-Searches
description: A teacher's aide was dismissed and a physical education instructor suspended today for allowing a strip- search of 10 middle school students, school officials said.

title: Required Reading; Congress and Cannibals
description: A sampling of quotations from ''A Guide to the 99th Congress,'' a 1985 datebook, calendar and Congressional reference manual just published by the LTV Corporation, an aerospace and energy company:

title: KEVLIN MICROWAVE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Princeton Hires Coach
description: Columbia is not the only Ivy League school with a new football coach. Princeton yesterday appointed 41- year-old Ron Rogerson , who for the last four seasons had been head coach at Maine, where he compiled a 23-23-3 record. He replaces Frank Navarro, who resigned Nov. 19 after a third straight losing season. . . . Five days before he takes his Southern California team against Ohio State in the Rose Bowl, Coach Ted Tollner of the Trojans received a one-year extension of his contract through 1988.

title: Bill on Pollution Gains in Jersey
description: The State Assembly, meeting for less than an hour today, approved bills that would increase fines against companies violating air-pollution laws and that clear the way for the sale of Freehold Raceway, which burned down last May.

title: POSTCARDS FROM 1984
description: The Winter Games and the Summer Games

title: Ex-Chairman Of BTK Sued
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged the former chairman of BTK Industries with improperly inflating the company's sales and earnings for parts of 1982 and 1983.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: C.R. Bard Inc., Murray Hill, N.J., a manufacturer of health care products, has named John F. Cvinar vice president and general manager of the company's USCI division in Billerica, Mass.

title: No Headline
description: Van Allen Bradley, a rare-book dealer who was literary editor of The Chicago Daily News for 23 years, died Tuesday. He was 71 years old.

title: Charlie Brown Honored
description: A tribute to the cartoon character Charlie Brown continues this weekend with screenings of an animated feature and an interview with his creators, at the Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A NUMBER of films have been cited as sleepers this season, and it has yet to be seen which of them will emerge from the pack, and which will remain fast asleep. So far, among the season's most heralded films in this sub- blockbuster category, ''The Flamingo Kid'' looks like the strongest. Over the five-day Christmas weekend, it grossed $2,015,076 in 531 theaters. That put ''The Flamingo Kid'' well ahead of its fellow sleeper ''Starman,'' which earned $3,477,196 in 1,271 theaters. Another sleeper, ''Birdy,'' is playing in only three theaters (in New York, Los Angeles and Toronto) and grossed $15,148 at Cinema I in Manhattan.

title: PRIVATE CONTROL OF CONRAIL IS SWITCH TO RIGHT TRACK
description: To the Editor: Professor Neuschel's letter is filled with phony statistics and illogical economic interpretations. He attacks the pay and benefits that railroad workers have accrued over years of loyal, devoted service.

title: F.T.C. Cites Tractor Hazard
description: International Harvester broke the law by failing to warn consumers that its tractors posed a safety hazard, the Federal Trade Commission ruled today.

title: TRI-COUNTRY SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BROADWAY
description: IT would be nice to begin the New Year with

title: RESCH HELPS DEVILS END SLIDE
description: When Glenn (Chico) Resch is as sharp as he was in goal tonight, it is difficult for the Devils to lose, especially when they play a weak team like Toronto.

title: Market Place ; Experts Pick 2 Stocks for '85
description: If you had to pick two stocks as favorite investments for 1985, which would you select?

title: Living, Dying and the Law This week a Long Island man was finally taken off the respirator that, as one doctor put it, ''had been merely ventilating a dead body.'' Shutting off his life-support system, a misnomer in this case, was possible only because the man's family had obtained a court order. Without one, the hospital was afraid of incurring legal liability or criminal prosecution.
description: It is this kind of tragic dilemma that Governor Cuomo's newly appointed commission on ''life and the law'' is trying to resolve. The commission's agenda, some of which is similar to that studied last year by a Presidential commission on medical ethics, is ambitious, and its recommendations are bound to provoke more controversy.

title: ARGENTINA SEEN NEAR BANK PACT
description: Argentina and its 320 creditor banks are close to agreement on a $20 billion financing package, banking and monetary sources said today, virtually assuring approval by the International Monetary Fund of a program to help the country pay its bills.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Washington on Wednesday about a program to expand the broadcasting abilities of the Voice of America gave an incorrect location for a Voice transmitter on the East Coast. It is in Greenville, N.C.

title: INDIA IS HOLDING 5TH SIKH IN INDIRA GANDHI KILLING
description: A Sikh, the fifth suspected of involvement in the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, was flown here today from the Philippines for questioning.

title: Give or Take a Yen
description: About a week ago the Embassy of Japan issued a very glossy, information-filled press kit in advance of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's visit next Wednesday with President Reagan in Los Angeles.

title: Japan Payments Gap
description: Japan's balance of payments swung to a deficit of $2.03 billion in November, from a surplus of $1.08 billion in November 1983, the Finance Ministry said today. On a seasonally adjusted basis, Japan's balance of payments deficit narrowed to $680 million in November, from $737 million in October.

title: ALGAE DISCOVERED AT RECORD DEPTHS IN OCEAN
description: Two botanists exploring the ocean floor in a research submarine have discovered an abundant form of plant life growing deeper and in less light than any previously known, the Smithsonian Institution announced yesterday.

title: GENTLE MAN OF THE TRACK
description: When it comes to devising nicknames, promoters of wrestling matches will have to settle for place money. Backstretch workers at race tracks are masters of the art.

title: Action on Deak
description: Financial Secretary John

title: Montana Utility Rates
description: The Montana Public Service Commission today granted the Montana Power Company a $21.4 million interim electric rate increase. The increase included about $8.5 million for a portion of the company's investment in the controversial Colstrip 3 power plant.

title: BEATRICE COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $19 million.

title: Indiana Utility Loses Rate Bid INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 27
description: The Indiana Court of

title: ARTIFICIAL COMET QUICKLY GROWS 25,000-MILE TAIL
description: The first artificial comet was launched from a satellite 60,000 miles over the Pacific early yesterday in solar wind so great that it sprouted a tail 10,000 miles long in 10 minutes.

title: WHAT'S AT THE CABARETS: FROM SHORT TO GILLESPIE
description: IF Bobby Short can be used as a

title: Japanese Brewer
description: The Milwaukee Brewers have signed one of Japan's best-known pitchers, Yutaka Enatsu , to a one- year contract.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Interest Rates Firm In Light Trading;  Economic Data Awaited
description: Interest rates were mostly unchanged in the bond market yesterday after jumping on Wednesday. Activity almost dried up in lethargic end-of-the-year trading.

title: Younkers Layoffs
description: Younkers Inc., a department store chain that lost $1.8 million in the third quarter on revenues of $41.6 million, said it would lay off 200 employees to cut costs. The layoffs represent 5 percent of the chain's 4,000 full-time employees at 29 stores in Iowa, Illinois, Nebraska, South Dakota and Minnesota. The company's president, William Friedman, said Younkers was also closing its store in Ottumwa, a south central Iowa city hurt ''severely'' by the troubled farm economy.

title: Vacationing Reagans Plan to See Children
description: President Reagan is expected to spend time with his children on his California vacation, which may include a fence-mending session with his son Michael.

title: MILITANTS DEFY ORDER TO YIELD CHURCH CONTROL
description: With faces marked by both sorrow and anger, members of the Trinity Lutheran Church, a congregation once held together by friendship and a common faith, were staring at one another today across a gulf grown wider than the street between them.

title: 2 Buildings to Make Way For Holocaust Museum
description: Two historic buildings that resemble the barracks of Nazi death camps will be torn down next year instead of being used to house a Holocaust museum, the group planning the memorial said today. The Federal Government donated the buildings to the group in 1981.

title: U.S. HELPS SUDAN COPE WITH ETHIOPIAN REFUGEES
description: The United States said today that it was giving priority to emergency airlifts and sealifts to the Sudan to help it cope with a new wave of refugees from northern Ethiopia who are crossing the border on foot by the tens of thousands to escape famine.

title: William Weleck Jr., Executive Of Realty Company in Jersey
description: William W. Weleck Jr., a real-estate executive who assembled many large tracts of land in New Jersey, including the site of the Meadowlands sports complex, died of a heart attack Monday while visiting in Phoenix. He was 74 years old and lived in Mahwah, N.J.

title: FOOD-AD RULE MAY LAPSE
description: The Federal Trade Commission is thinking of dropping a requirement that grocery stores have available for sale all the items advertised. The commission says the rule may be costing consumers more than it saves them.

title: WHERE NEW YORKERS WILL RUN, GIGGLE, GASP AND ROAR
description: NEW YORKERS will be celebrating New Year's Eve in myriad ways, including running in loops, gazing upward, giggling, listening, gasping and roaring. The running, five miles of it, will start at the stroke of 1985 in Central Park, from Tavern on the Green, near West 67th Street, which is also where it will end. The annual race has attracted 3,000 participants in past years, some in tuxedos, others dressed as the Empire State Building, for instance, or a rotten apple, or a chain gang (with several people linked).

title: HBO Buys Fight
description: Home Box Office, the subscription cable-television network, has bought another fight from Don King, the boxing promoter who is under indictment for tax evasion. According to Ross Greenburg, a producer at HBO, the network will televise a bout between Larry Holmes, the International Boxing Federation heavyweight champion who has threatened that his next fight will be his last, and David Bey, also undefeated.

title: Friday SURREALISTIC CINEMA
description: The Thalia Theater, at 95th Street and Broadway, likes to greet the new year with a salute to the bizarre. Its ninth annual Surrealistic Film Festival today and tomorrow (identical programs) includes two short features made by Hans Richter in collaboration with other Surrealists. In ''8 x 8'' (1957), kings, queens and other players act out some of life's episodes on a chessboard; the painter Max Ernst pursues his wife through lower Manhattan; the sculptor Alexander Calder constructs mobiles and sets them in motion, and the writer Jean Cocteau plays the role of a pawn who becomes a queen. Richter's ''Dadascope'' (1961) was made with Man Ray, Jean Arp and Kurt Schwitters. Three shorts are also on the program. Screenings at 2, 4:30, 7 and 9:30 P.M. Admission: $4.50 ($2.50 for children and over-65's before 5 P.M.) Information: 222-3370. MUSICAL THRONES

title: Alaska Pipeline Trust Settlement
description: The Justice Department and one of the owners of the Alaska oil pipeline announced a tentative settlement of charges of excessively high shipping rates. The proposed settlement with the Arco Pipe Line Company, a unit of the Atlantic Richfield Company of Los Angeles, was also endorsed by the State of Alaska.

title: Monica E. McHenney Wed to Peter Kessler
description: Monica Elaine McHenney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond McHenney of Parma, Mich., was married yesterday to Peter Bernard Kessler, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard H. Kessler of New York and Sarasota, Fla. Michael Kruger, the bride's brother- in-law and a Universal Life Church minister, performed the ceremony at the Sarasota home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Saudis Devalue Riyal
description: Saudi Arabia devalued its currency today for the seventh time in 1984, adjusting the riyal's parity to 3.58 to the dollar, from 3.56 riyals. The riyal has been devalued 2.3 percent since the year began. Analysts say the devaluation would better position the Saudi economy in a climate of slow or no growth and declining oil revenue.

title: ZIYAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Polynice Surges for 25
description: Olden Polynice came off the bench to score 25 points and the freshman reserve Derrick Simms added 10 to lead Virginia to a 66-54 victory over Penn State tonight in the first round of the Sugar Bowl Classic.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: A.H. Belo Corp. Names President
description: Robert W. Decherd, the executive vice president of the A.H. Belo Corporation, was elected president. He will remain chief operating officer of the company, which owns The Dallas Morning News and seven community newspapers in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, as well as five television stations and four radio stations.

title: Don't Phone Home
description: For most consumers, the American Telephone and Telegraph

title: Harris Bankcorp
description: Harris Bankcorp said it had signed a letter of intent to buy all of the stock of the First National Bank and Trust Company of Barrington for $32 million.

title: SINGAPORE SAYS IT PLANS TO LEAVE UNESCO
description: Singapore's Ambassador to France said today that his country had informed the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization that it plans to leave the agency at the end of 1985.

title: SCREEN ACTOR INCREASES GIFT TO NEEDIEST
description: Peter Falk, the screen and television actor who has contributed to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund annually since 1980, has increased his donation to $3,000 this year because he believes, apparently with many others, that there is ''a much larger number of needy people in New York.''

title: TWO LISTS FOR BOSTON LATIN
description: One public school where court intervention has led to greater integration without an appreciable loss of white students is at the Boston Latin School, founded in 1635.

title: CITICORP SEEKS BROAD SECURITIES ROLE
description: In what could be an important test of the powers of banks, Citicorp said yesterday that it had filed for permission from the Federal Reserve Board to underwrite corporate bonds, commercial paper, mortgage-related securities and municipal-revenue bonds.

title: REBUFF TO MERRILL IN TOKYO CRITICIZED
description: The rejection of Merrill Lynch's bid for a seat on the Tokyo Stock Exchange has prompted strong criticism here.

title: THE HARD JOB REMAINS
description: Just before President Johnson appointed him to the Supreme

title: CONGRESS'S KEEPER OF THE CONSTITUTION
description: When members of Congress have questions about the Constitution, they call Johnny H. Killian, their resident expert on the great document written 197 years ago.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 28, 1984 International The trial of four Polish security officers for the abduction and slaying on Oct. 19 of a pro-Solidarity priest began in Torun. One of the defendants testified that he had been assured the kidnapping had been authorized by his superiors, even if it resulted in the Priest's death. The trial marked the first time a Communist country publicly prosecuted security police in the murder of a dissident. (A1:6.)

title: WHILE CORKS POP ON A SHEIK'S YACHT, RUSSIAN ARISTOCRATS SWIRL IN SOHO
description: AT 10 seconds to midnight on New Year's Eve, the stewards aboard a yacht chartered by an Arab sheik will aim their cannon-sized bottles of champagne out across the dark waves of New York harbor.

title: Big-Band Sound
description: The 10-piece Widespread Jazz Orchestra will perform at Birdland West, 225 West Broadway (431-1810), tonightand the jazz drummer, composer and arranger Errol Parker, leading a ''tentet,'' will offer big band jazz there tomorrow night.

title: Money Funds
description: Up $200 Million Assets of the nation's money

title: YOUNG PEOPLE AND DRINKING AT HOLIDAY PARTIES
description: This is the time of year, with college-age children home for the holidays, that telephone bills climb to new heights and student parties and reunions, often enlivened by alcoholic beverages, proliferate. Parents are concerned about how to keep a cup of Christmas cheer down to just that.

title: Swaziland to Upgrade Tie to South Africa
description: South Africa and Swaziland agreed today to exchange trade representatives, the two nations' first exchange of permanent diplomatic envoys.

title: Yankees Sign Whitson
description: In signing a five-year, $4.4 million contract with the Yankees yesterday, Ed Whitson became the latest member of this year's free-agent crop to demonstrate the wisdom of producing the right record at the right time.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; All's Fine in Queens but . . .
description: Borough President Donald R.

title: BEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Video Recorder
US JVC Announces Management Changes
description: The American division of the Victor Company of Japan, the US JVC Corporation, has announced several changes in its top management. The parent company, a producer of audio- visual equipment, is 50 percent owned by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, which markets under the names Panasonic, Quasar and Technics.

title: PATIENT MAY REFUSE LIFE-SUPPORT CARE, COURT ON COAST SAYS
description: In a case that has become a focus of the national ''right to die'' movement, a state appeals court ruled today that a man who was suffering from five usually fatal diseases had a constitutional right to refuse medical treatment.

title: Debt
description: * Federal Farm Credit Banks said its $792 million in new bonds due July 1, 1995, will carry an 8.40 percent interest rate and its $796 million bond due Oct. 1, 1985, will yield 8.80 percent, through the Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corp.

title: DANCE: AT OPEN EYE
description: THE THEATER OF THE OPEN EYE has often favored themes concerned with ritual, myth and literary sources in its dance presentations. But Muna Tseng, who is the coordinator of the fourth annual Holiday Dance Festival at the Open Eye, 316 East 88th Street, seems to be reaching out for a more eclectic view of dance this year. Certainly this is the impression gained by the inclusion of choreographers who are not Open Eye regulars, such as Stuart Pimsler, who was on the opening bill Wednesday night with Miss Tseng's company.

title: AT BUDGET TIME, PROBLEMS BESET CHICAGO MAYOR
description: Mayor Harold Washington has encountered one problem after another since October, when he proposed a $1.9 billion ''austerity'' budget for 1985.

title: YOUNG WRITERS HAVE SUICIDE AND NUCLEAR WAR ON THEIR MINDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Auburn Triumphs In Liberty Bowl
description: Auburn's Bo Jackson deflated an Arkansas rally with a 40-yard touchdown run in the fourth quarter as the Tigers downed Arkansas, 21-15, tonight in the 26th annual Liberty Bowl game.

title: APPLIED CIRCUIT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. OPPOSES RELEASE OF WIRETAPS ON F.B.I. AGENT ACCUSED AS A SPY
description: Documents detailing court-ordered wiretaps of a man accused of spying for the Soviet Union should not be released, ''to protect the security of this nation,'' Federal prosecutors said in papers made public Wednesday.

title: GREATWEST HOSPITALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $785,000 for the quarter and $367,000 for the year. c-Net income including an extraordinary credit of $152,000 and a gain of $261,000 from discontinued operations. d-Including an extraordinary credit of $796,000 and a gain of $2,993,000 from discontinued operations.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: CONSISTENCY of style is not the first thing one notices at an exhibition of Jonathan Borofsky's artworks. At his show at the Whitney Museum of American Art, which runs through March 10 (review on page C27), he displays works that include a blue dog drawn directly on the museum wall, a Ping-Pong table painted in camouflage colors, and a steel sculpture of a man riddled with what appear to be bullet holes.

title: SALSA, BLUES AND ROCK FEATURED AT CLUBS
description: ON an average New Year's Eve, New York has so much music that, stretched end to end, it could probably fill the next six months. This year, with New Year's Eve on a Monday, the city's clubs and dance halls have gone into overdrive. It is a long, celebratory weekend, offering not just the usual rowdiness and elegance of New Year's Eve - when admission prices tend to pop higher than champagne corks - but also a chance for the more impecunious to start the party early.

title: SFE TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-Net income.

title: Comings and Goings
description: For the sixth time, the diver Greg Louganis has been nominated for the Sullivan Award, given by the Amateur Athletic Union to the nation's best amateur athlete of the year. The other nominees are the marathoner Joan Benoit , the sprinter Valerie Brisco-Hooks , the gymnasts Bart Conner and Mary Lou Retton , the equestrian Joe Fargis , the wrestler Steven Fraser , the swimmer Rowdy Gaines , the Alpine skier Bill Johnson and the synchronized swimmer Tracie Ruiz . . . . Darryl Sutter, the captain of the Chicago Black Hawks, will be lost to the club for at least two months because of a broken ankle suffered in Wednesday night's loss to the St. Louis Blues.

title: SOLAR AGE INDUSTRIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest quarter reflect the acquisition of Delafran Industries. Year-ago results are pro forma.

title: 9.1% Rise in Home Resales
description: Resales of single-family homes, bolstered by falling interest rates, climbed 9.1 percent in November, the first increase since April, a real estate trade group said today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 10.75-11.25 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ART: 'MODERN MASKS,' AN ASSEMBLY OF SCULPTURES, ON DISPLAY
description: ''MODERN MASKS,'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, 42d Street and Park Avenue, through Feb. 7, surveys an increasingly populated territory. There are probably as many masks, or intimations of masks in current painting and sculpture as there were in the years of Cubism and German Expressionism. They have surfaced during an artistic moment just as soaked in ''primitivism,'' as the early 20th century and one even more charged by conflicting currents of extreme rawness and extreme self- consciousness.

title: Small Plane Breaks Up In Flight, Killing Six
description: Five bodies were recovered today from the wreckage of a single-engine plane that apparently broke up in flight, and a sheriff's posse on horseback searched rugged terrain for a sixth victim.

title: Bridge:Follow the Odds, but Expect Fate to Give Some Surprises
description: Go with the percentages, but remember that the fates will occasionally give you surprises. Options traders who are also bridge experts find this philosophy appropriate in both pursuits, and perhaps as a result, are consistent winners.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: AS you enter the restaurant, past the giant wooden piglet holding a menu card at the front door, into the pink barnboard-lined dining room with a frieze of illuminated pigs all around, past tables of voracious customers chowing down like farmhands at sunset and sipping tea from mugs sculptured like pigs' snouts, oinking and giggling, you begin to question the wisdom of coming to a place called Pig Heaven for a serious Chinese meal.

title: Melissa Ashlock Bride in Harrison
description: The marriage of Melissa Ann Ashlock, the daughter of Mrs. Raymond Ashlock and the late Mr. Ashlock of Godfrey, Ill., to Stephen Joseph Rosenfeld, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Isadore Rosenfeld of Harrison, N.Y., took place yesterday. Acting Justice Burton Sherman of New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony of the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: GOVERNMENT ASSAULTS ON THE REALM OF IDEAS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THEY seemed to be around the Grand Hyatt Hotel in endless numbers the other evening, the young women in cocktail dresses, the young men in dinner clothes set off by bright red bow ties and cummerbunds. More than 1,200 of them gathered for the 28th annual Gold and Silver Ball.

title: Diner's Journal
description: IT began as a novelty several years ago. Restaurant bars around town started serving

title: JACK WARDEN STARRING IN 'CRAZY LIKE A FOX'
description: DOING nicely in the ratings on Sundays with Angela Lansbury as a detective in ''Murder, She Wrote,'' CBS has decided to imitate itself and add another detective series to the night's lineup. ''Crazy Like a Fox,'' having its premiere this Sunday at 9 on Channel 2, dips into the old formula of pairing an older man with a younger one. In this case, they are father and son, played for assorted comic effects by Jack Warden and John Rubinstein.

title: MONFORT OF COLORADO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
Chinese Granaries Full
description: China's granaries are overflowing after a record harvest, the Government said today. Niu Ruofeng, director of the agricultural economics institute, said that Chinese farmers grew more than 400 million metric tons of grain this year, up 12.5 million tons from a bumper crop in 1983 and more than state grain stores can accommodate. A metric ton is equal to 2,204.6 pounds.

title: GOLDEN WEST HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
description: b-Including tax credits of $54,000 for the quarter and $5,000 for the 6 months.

title: Precautions Planned in Va. For Unloading of Chemical
description: Extra safeguards are planned to insure that a shipment of methyl isocylanate - the gas that killed some 2,500 people in Bhopal, India - is safely unloaded and transported to Georgia.

title: Shift Planned At Greatwest
description: Greatwest Hospitals Inc. said it had decided to divest itself of its hospitals and hospital-related operations to concentrate on prepaid health plans.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;  Art-Deco Press Cards
description: Quite contrary to reality, a stereotype persists of the reporter as hard-bitten, tough-talking and male.

title: PRIVATE CONTROL ON CONRAIL IS SWITCH TO RIGHT TRACK
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMBODIAN REBELS IN COUNTERATTACK
description: Cambodian guerrillas carried today counterattacked Vietnamese forces that overran the Rithisen rebel camp near the Thai border on Wednesday, Thai military authorities and guerrilla sources said.

title: SUDBURY HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $556,000 for the quarter and $948,000 for the 6 months. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $27,000. d-Net loss.

title: SUIT ON SCHOOLING BLOCKED BY COURT
description: A divided Court of Appeals yesterday rejected claims of ''educational malpractice'' filed by a man misdiagnosed as retarded when he was a boy. The court ruled he could not collect damages from New York City and the child- care agency that treated him.

title: Vice President at ITT Starting a Business
description: John Lowden, 63-year-old corporate vice president and deputy director-corporate relations and advertising of the ITT Corporation, announced yesterday that he was taking early retirement and was establishing Old Lyme Consulting Unlimited in Chappaqua, N.Y., his hometown.

title: Reply by Steinbrenner
description: George Steinbrenner says that Marge Schott, the new majority

title: JAPAN FOILS PLOT TO GIVE SOVIET SECRET U.S. DEVICE
description: Japanese customs agents acting on information from United States officials have thwarted a plot to smuggle an American submarine-detection device to the Soviet Union, officials said today.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Venomous Feud Over Weimar
description: The venomous attacks of some senior historians upon the inaccuracies or alleged ''fabrications'' of one of their juniors seems to confirm an old saying: Battles fought in academia are so vicious because the stakes are so small.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about arbitrage losses misidentified the Federal agency that blocked the Gulf Oil Corporation's attempt in 1982 to acquire the Cities Service Company. It was the Federal Trade Commission.

title: JAZZ: GUITAR AND BASS DUO
description: THE guitarist Gene Bertoncini and the bassist Michael Moore have been playing as a duo on Sundays since September at Zinno, 126 West 13th Street, a series that has enabled them to develop a varied repertory of pieces that fudge the lines between jazz and classical approaches to their instruments.

title: SEOUL PUSHES U.S. TRADE TIES
description: Faced with increasing resentment of this country's economic success, South Korea's Government economists have mapped a plan to stress cooperation rather than confrontation with the United States.

title: Generals Sign Blinka
description: The Generals, gearing up for the start of training camp in a few weeks, signed six players yesterday, including Stan Blinka, the veteran linebacker formerly with the Jets. Blinka, now 27, spent five seasons with the Jets after having been picked by them in the 1979 draft but was traded to Denver early this year and released by the Broncos before the start of the season.

title: JORDAN SCORES 45 AS BULLS BEAT CAVALIERS
description: Michael Jordon tied his season-high 45 points to lead the Chicago Bulls to a 112-108 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers. The triumph was the third in a row for the Bulls.

title: POLITICAL SATIRE REIGNS AT THE BALLROOM THEATER
description: Is the type of satirical revues that Chicago's Second City troupe helped popularize 25 years ago enjoying a resurgence? If the political cabaret ''Issue? I Don't Even Know You!'' becomes a fixture at the Ballroom Theater, the answer could be yes. The hourlong spoof, which is a showcase for the talents of a number of promising New York actor-writers, pokes sharp fun at 1980's conformism, the Reagans, Pope John Paul II and political image-making.

title: 'MEMOIRS'
description: ''LIQUID SKY'' paved the way for sinister, stylized New Wave melodrama, of which Bachar Chbib's ''Memoirs'' is an energetic if somewhat less witty example. According to production notes, the Montreal-based Mr. Chbib made the film for $47,000, which is certainly impressive. He wrote it in two weeks, which suggests more coherence than the screenplay actually has.

title: WAGS STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: THE CITY ; 2 Pharmacists Accused of Fraud
description: Twelve pharmacists in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens have been charged with defrauding the Medicaid program by illegally substituting less expensive generic drugs for brand-name medicines and charging Medicaid the higher cost, state officials said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, DECEMBER 28, 1984
description: International

title: DOLPHIN PUNTER EXCEEDS
description: Reggie Roby doesn't know how high is up, or how far forward a football can travel. But his search for the perfect punt obsesses him, waking and sleeping.

title: BLUEWATER OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
More Poles Jump Ship In a West German Port
description: The West German frontier police here said today that another group of Polish tourists failed to return home from a shopping excursion at Christmas, bringing the number who have jumped ship to over 1,000.

title: Advertising ; Change At Family Circle
description: Family Circle magazine is investigating the possibility of

title: GIANTS SHOW CONFIDENCE IN THEIR RUNNING GAME
description: Rob Carpenter likes to run with the ball. He likes to block. He likes to catch passes. Most of all, he likes to win, and he does not particularly care how the Giants beat the 49ers in their playoff game Saturday in San Francisco - by running or by passing - as long as they win.

title: ISLANDERS LOSE IN OVERTIME
description: Respect. For so long, over the course of four championship seasons, the Islanders commanded it from everyone. But not anymore.

title: Beatrice Says Net Was Off by 7.3% in 3d Quarter
description: The Beatrice Companies today reported a decline of 7.3 percent in net income, to $127 million, in its fiscal third quarter ended Nov. 30. Sales for the period were $3.75 billion, up 52.4 percent.

title: ART: SCULPTORS' DRAWINGS ON VIEW
description: -born Seagram company started its art collection more than 30 years ago by commissioning local artists to paint 26 Canadian cities. Now totaling some 2,000 objects, the Seagram holdings encompass antique glass and photography, together with paintings, sculpture, drawings, prints and tapestries of the 20th century. The moving spirit behind the collection has been Phyllis Lambert, the daughter of the company's founder, Samuel Bronfman. Mrs. Lambert is responsible for the choice of Mies van der Rohe as architect for the New York headquarters. Situated at 375 Park Avenue between 52d and 53d Streets, the building houses an art gallery on the fourth floor that is now presenting a show of sculptors' drawings selected from the company's collection.

title: Italy Tourist Revenue
description: Tourists spent $7.8 billion in Italy in 1984, up 7 percent from $7.3 billion in 1983, the National Federation of Tourist Offices said today. The federation predicted that earnings from tourism would be $8.6 billion next year, based on the belief that reduced inflation would make this Mediterranean nation more attractive to foreign vacationers. Inflation, which was above 16 percent two years ago, is now slightly below 10 percent.

title: OPEC PLAN IS DELAYED BY NIGERIA
description: All of the OPEC members except Nigeria agreed today to a radical plan to audit the oil pricing and production of the group's members. The plan is a desperate effort to stop the decline of prices.

title: BRIEFS
description: BSN Corp., Dallas, said it was engaged in negotiations to acquire Riddell Sports, a Chicago-based manufacturer of football helmets, for about $7 million.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: HITLER AND THE FINAL SOLUTION.

title: ST. JOHN'S GAINS WITH N.C. STATE
description: Playing strongly for the second consecutive game in Madison Square Garden, St. John's shot out to a quick lead, then held off a second-half rally last night and defeated Old Dominion, 77-66, in the first game of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival.

title: 2 ALVARADO INQUIRIES FIND NO CRIMES
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney's office said yesterday that it had not found evidence to warrant criminal prosecution of Anthony J. Alvarado, who resigned as New York City Schools Chancellor last May amid charges of professional misconduct stemming largely from his financial affairs.

title: A.T.&T. Hires Chief Lobbyist WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -
description: The American Telephone and

title: CHESS: A RECORD IS BROKEN AND ANOTHER IS EXTENDED
description: The 35th game of the world chess championship in Moscow on Wednesday broke one record and extended another: the match is now the longest such series in the modern era, and the record number of draws for such contests has been increased to 29.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Into the Icy Abyss
description: ''Ill bet you're not going swimming

title: Arizona State Given Penalty
description: The Pacific-10 Conference has placed Arizona State on two years' probation and imposed penalties on three of the university's sports programs, including the forfeiture of a conference baseball title, because of N.C.A.A. rules violations, the conference announced today.

title: Osborne's Challenge
description: Tom Osborne , Nebraska's football coach, yesterday challenged Booker Brown to a lie-detector test over the former player's accusations that in 1972, when Osborne was the Cornhuskers' offensive coordinator, he tried to recruit Brown with such rule- breaking inducements as cash and a date with a female student as well as free airplane tickets and hotel bookings for Brown's mother. ''I'm amazed that 11 or 12 years later, all of a sudden the guy has a rush of conscience and such amazing recall,'' Osborne said from New Orleans, where his team is preparing to play Louisiana State in the Sugar Bowl next Tuesday night.

title: Alcoa Drops Plan
description: The Aluminum Company of America said it had ended a plan to build and operate an aluminum smelter with the province of Manitoba after reassessing its future investments in new primary aluminum capacity. The 200,000-metric-ton- a-year smelter, which would have been located in the province, was to have been equally owned and financed by Alcoa and Manitoba. Alcoa said ''current and planned world primary aluminum capacity is adequate to meet the growth rates we foresee in metal demand.''

title: Medicare Freeze Considered
description: President Reagan acknowledged today that his Administration was considering a freeze on Medicare payments to hospitals and doctors.

title: Soviet Leader Appears At Kremlin Ceremony
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, who was absent from the funeral of Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov on Monday, appeared today at a Kremlin ceremony at which he presented medals to prominent writers.

title: 4 POLISH OFFICERS ARE PUT ON TRIAL IN PRIEST'S SLAYING
description: Four security police officers went on trial here today for the abduction and slaying of a pro-Solidarity priest. One of the defendants testified that he was assured in advance that the kidnapping had been authorized by his superiors.

title: THE CITY ; ostage Is Killed In Failed Robbery
description: An employee of a Chelsea variety store was shot and killed yesterday as the police captured two gunmen holding three hostages at the scene of a robbery, the police reported. One of the gunmen also was shot.

title: HAWKINS CHEMICAL INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Rotation at the New York Fed
description: Though just three blocks from Wall Street, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York is no ordinary bank. It is the principal operating arm of the national bank of the United States, constantly trading in Government securities and occasionally currencies to give force to monetary policy - either stimulus or restraint.

title: EATON VANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ADVERTISING
description: People

title: Dining Out Guide: Wholesome Restaurants
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AMSTERDAM'S BAR & ROTISSERIE, 428

title: HOUSING REINVESTMENT FUND WILL BE EXAMINED BY GOLDIN
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that he would audit a city program that requires housing developers to reinvest part of their profits to help restore poor neighborhoods.

title: Coast Cable Sale
description: The Times-Mirror Company and Knight -Ridder Newspapers Inc. said they had agreed in principle to sell their jointly owned Long Beach, Calif., cable television system to Simmons Communications. The companies did not disclose terms of the agreement. They said the sale would not have a significant impact on the earnings of either company and was subject to approval by governmental bodies.

title: JENNINGS BEGINS TO HEAR FOOTSTEPS
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about bank failures misstated the number of failures in Texas this year. There have been six.

title: SHIFT FROM 212 TO 718 CODE PAINS 3 BOROUGHS
description: It has been called everything from an ''insult'' to a ''punishment from God,'' and the months since it was announced have brought threats of secession and revenge. People scoffed at the ''dowdy numbers'' and pouted like spoiled children about how Manhattan gets ''everything it wants.''

title: ATTACK COSTS, NOT DOCTOR-PATIENT RELATIONSHIP
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: WRITING ON THE WALL You don't have to be able to read it to admire the handwriting on show at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue at 71st Street (288-6400), and at the Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street (756-0824). It is a writing that many Westerners study as art even though they remain illiterate when it comes to deciphering it.

title: Ticket Bonus
description: In an attempt to sell out the Peach Bowl football game in Atlanta next Monday, the game's officials are offering a $10,000 bonus to the person who buys the last available ticket. ''We're making this special offer in an effort to take us over the top,'' said Don Elliot Heald, the president of the Peach Bowl, in which Purdue will oppose Virginia.

title: FATAL SHOOTING ON WEST SIDE JARS AN UNEASY BALANCE IN A CHANGING NEIGHBORHOOD
description: Within 48 hours of the fatal shooting of Dario Vasallo on Christmas night, winter's first snow had turned West 88th Street into a picture postcard of brownstone doorways and arching tree limbs highlighted in white.

title: High and Dry
description: The most surprised indoor swimmer in the Washington area in

title: 26 Hurt in Chain Collision
description: Twenty-six people were hospitalized early this morning after a chain collision of 90 to 100 vehicles that skidded on ice on Interstate 95. Most of the automobiles were driven by young people from Massachusetts who were leaving a rock concert in Providence, R.I., the authorities said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture grouping in Business Day yesterday, with an article on telephone deregulation, reversed two identifications. Mark S. Fowler was at the center and Edward Hipp at the right.

title: METROMAIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
JAZZ: MAL WALDRON QUINTET
description: The spirit and sound of Thelonious Monk hover in the background of the Mal Waldron Quintet as it plays at the Village Vanguard where it is extending the customary one-week engagement to remain through New Year's Eve.

title: Store Sales Lagging on Castro St. Merchants Cite Fear of AIDS
description: A few miles from this city's banking and financial center, the Castro Street shopping area has long been a flourishing outpost of quality shops, bookstores and restaurants that cater to homosexuals. Many of its businesses are run by homosexuals.

title: Fumes in Store Force Evacuation
description: Nearly 40 people were treated for respiratory problems after noxious fumes forced the evacuation of a Caldor department store in this Ocean County community today, officials said. Police Sgt. Thomas McKnelis said 38 people were taken to hospitals operated by the Northern Ocean Hospital System, where a spokesman said they complained of light-headedness, numbness and headaches.

title: COMMERCIAL METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FLANIGAN'S ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
Jets Shake Up Staff; Gardi, 2 Others Out
