description: Throughout this summer and fall, just as in the three previous years, Joe Gardi and Coach Joe Walton commuted together from their Suffolk County homes to the Jet training camp in Hempstead, L.I. But at some point their highway discussions as to how Gardi should run the defense began to grow increasingly animated.

title: Oil Sand in Montana
description: MSR Exploration Ltd. said its Weiss No. 1 well in Montana had found a 22-foot deposit of oil-saturated sand that produced between 65 and 90 barrels daily in recent tests. The company said a 10- well development program was under way on the 3,000-acre block.

title: Escape Report Cites Opening in Window
description: Five inmates were able to escape from the Niantic state prison for women two weeks ago because too much space was left between the bars on a window when workers removed a fan last fall, a prison official said today.

title: Carl Levy, 50, Ex-Union Chief; Le Ne D Co
description: Carl Levy, president of the Metropolitan News Company and former president of the newspaper deliverers union, died Wednesday at Massapequa General Hospital in Seaford, L.I. He was 50 years old and lived in Seaford.

title: OKLAHOMA ST. RALLY WINS GATOR BOWL
description: Barry Hanna, an Oklahoma State tight end, carried two defenders into the end zone while scoring on a 25-yard pass with only 1 minute 4 seconds left tonight to give the Cowboys a 21-14 Gator Bowl victory over South Carolina.

title: IONA TOPPLES WILLIAM AND MARY
description: Rory Grimes scored 24 points and directed a disciplined offense tonight as Iona beat William & Mary, 68-55, in the opening round of the Connecticut Mutual Classic college basketball tournament.

title: TEXTILE LAW ORDERS A U.S. LABEL
description: All clothing and household fabrics made in this country are now required to carry a label saying so.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1984 International A sweeping victory for Rajiv Gandhi and his Congress Party was indicated in returns from parliamentary elections in India. It appeared that Mr. Gandhi, who succeeded his slain mother Indira as Prime Minister two months ago, had achieved a popular victory unparalleled since the Nehru era of the 1950's and 1960's. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: U.S.-Jamaica Loan Pact
description: Jamaica and the United States signed a $65 million loan today that Prime Minister Edward P.G. Seaga said was aimed at supporting the island's balance of payments and financing Government projects. The loan is part of package of $145 million in loans being granted to Jamaica in the current United States fiscal year.

title: Uncommon Debt Relief
description: Far from the madding politicos'

title: DAYS OF THE WOLF
description: I have tried to become interested in

title: NOVEMBER TRADE GAP WIDER
description: The United States had a $9.9 billion trade deficit in November, a rise from $9.2 billion in October, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Bridge:Even in Time of Computers, The Way to Errors Remains
description: Computer scoring is now normal in major tournaments and serves to eliminate arithmetical errors. But there is still a possibility that an official has misread a score slip or misfingered when entering a result.

title: Skiing Technique Stirs a Dispute
description: Ove Aunli's victory in 1 hour 18 minutes in a 30-kilometer World Cup cross-country race at Davos, Switzerland, early this month spurred heated debate in Nordic skiing circles - not because of the Norwegian's zippy time, but because he had raced on unwaxed skis.

title:
PATENTS;
Dry Etching of Metals By Gas and Laser Beam
description: Methods of dry etching metals by use of gas and a laser beam were patented this week for the International Business Machines Corporation, Armonk, N.Y. Patents 4,490,210 and 4,490,211 were granted to Lee Chen and other inventors.

title: A CHANGE IN SELLING ABROAD
description: After suffering all year from the strong dollar, which made their products more expensive abroad, exporters on Jan. 1 will lose one incentive program and gain another, less favorable one.

title: PANTRY PRIDE INC reports earnings for 16 wks to Nov 17
description: b-Including a tax credit of $354,000, a Chapter 11 debt reduction of $275,000 and a net gain of $218,000 from the termination of a pension plan. c-Including a net gain from discontinued operations of $255,000 and a tax credit of $1,460,000.

title: Baby Left in Ditch; Parents Sought
description: The parents of a newborn girl who was left in a drainage ditch here Monday are being sought, the police said today.

title: U.N. Aide Says West Was Slow With Food
description: A senior African United Nations official accused Western nations today of not reacting promptly enough to appeals for emergency aid for Ethiopia and other famine-stricken countries of Africa.

title: SOVIET TO MODERNIZE CHINESE INDUSTRIES
description: China and the Soviet Union signed an agreement today under which the Russians will assist in modernizing several dozen industrial plants and other projects that were built with Soviet help in the 1950's.

title: U.S. POPULATION ROSE BY 4.2% IN LAST FOUR YEARS
description: The population of the United States grew by 9.6 million from 1980 to mid- 1984, the Census Bureau reported today, and most of the growth was still in the South and West.

title: U.S. CHARGES BALTIMORE INN WITH DISCRIMINATION
description: The Justice Department charged in a lawsuit today that a Ramada Inn in Baltimore has discriminated against blacks seeking to use the hotel's bar.

title: MUTE GIRL SUDDENLY REGAINS SPEECH
description: An 11- year-old girl, left mute and paralyzed by carbon monoxide poisoning almost a year ago, regained her speech just in time to wish her startled family and therapists a Merry Christmas.

title: Tomorrow's Famine
description: Two weeks ago, The Times ran a photograph of two Ethiopian women and a child combing the hills for edible grass. The women resembled stick figures, and the child's body seemed too small to support his head. Chances are they're dead by now: in Bati, where they were, 120 people die every day.

title: Military Contracts
description: The Navy awarded contracts of $250 million to the Raytheon Company and $207.4 million to the General Dynamics Corporation, both for Sparrow missile guidance and control equipment, the Defense Department said. The Lockheed Corporation won a $101 million contract from the Air Force for C-130 aircraft modernization kits, the department said. The Air Force also awarded $66 million to the General Electric Company for backscatter radar systems and $43.3 million to United Technologies for work on F100 engines.

title: Minister's Supporters Told to Explain Defiance
description: Defiant supporters of a jailed minister were ordered today to explain in court why they have refused to relinquish control of their church.

title: Stocks Slightly Higher In a Lackluster Session
description: The stock market failed to respond to some encouraging economic news yesterday, trading lower in the morning and finishing barely ahead.

title: Montana Power Reduces Dividend
description: The Montana Power Company said today that its board had agreed to reduce payment of the quarterly dividend to 50 cents a share from 70 cents.

title: BRIEFS
description: * California Real Estate Investment Trust, San Francisco, said it had sold its Singer Co. Building in Sunnyvale, Calif., for $1.45 million in cash.

title: GEORGETOWN DOWNS TENN. STATE
description: Patrick Ewing pumped in 21 points and Bill Martin scored 13 in a row in a first-half stretch as Georgetown defeated Tennessee State, 74-64, at Roberto Clemente Coliseum tonight in the first round of the Copa Navidad Tournament.

title: DRUG REGION IN PERU BOOMING AGAIN
description: Less than half a mile from the headquarters of Peru's special antidrug police unit, sales of pickup trucks are booming, new bars and restaurants are opening daily and dollars are in such abundance that they fetch less than the official exchange rate.

title: WOLFPACK TO TEST ST. JOHN'S
description: It's fitting and perhaps even fortunate for St. John's that its final test before the Big East season begins will come against North Carolina State.

title: Ambulance Crews Are Suspended
description: Mayor Leonard S. Paoletta of Bridgeport has closed the city's Emergency Medical Services, suspended the staff and ordered that city ambulance services be provided by a private company.

title: AEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Argentine House Backs Beagle Channel Treaty
description: The House of Deputies voted 127 to 74 today to ratify a Vatican-mediated treaty with Chile designed to end a century-old dispute over territory in the Beagle Channel.

title: CROWN AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Their Plate Was Full
description: Two women went to lunch at the

title: Against the Odds
description: Dave Kragthorpe , the 51-year-old athletic director at Utah State, was named head football coach at Oregon State yesterday.

title: EXTRADITION SHOULD BE LEFT IN JUDICIOUS HANDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Man in Spy Case Denies Charges
description: A man accused of spying for Czechoslovakia while working for the C.I.A. was arraigned yesterday on Federal espionage charges.

title: INTEGRATED CIRCUITS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $170,930 for the quarter and $667,500 for the year and a loss of $435,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations for the quarter and year. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $145,385 for the quarter and $469,981 for the year.

title: Curtis Karnow Weds Marilyn J. Englander
description: Marilyn Jean Englander, a candidate for a Ph.D. degree in anthropology at the University of California at Santa Barbara, was married yesterday to Curtis Edward Karnow, a lawyer with Landels, Ripley & Diamond in San Francisco. Federal Judge Louis H. Pollack of the Eastern District of Pennsylvania performed the ceremony in his chambers in Philadelphia.

title: WHAT KILLED MRS. BUMPURS
description: If society maintained a closer alliance between its theory and its practice, the police officer who killed Eleanor Bumpurs eight weeks ago in the Bronx by now would have been proclaimed a hero worker of the state. Mayor Koch might have given a fine speech at the honorary dinner, and the Real Estate Board of New York could have bestowed a commemorative medal.

title: GIANTS FORMULA REQUIRES CONTROL
description: By all rights, the 49ers, with the best regular-season record (15-1) in the National Football League, should beat the Giants handily Saturday in their playoff game at Candlestick Park. But the Giants think otherwise, and they think they have a formula to win.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 42.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Washington Bullets, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The absence of the Knicks' ailing big men has been a major factor in the season series against Washington, which has won all three previous encounters. The Knicks tried double-teaming Jeff Ruland in the second of those games, but the tactic didn't work: He responded with a triple double-digit effort - 22 points, 12 rebounds and 10 assists. (Television - MSG Network, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WPAT, 930; WFAS, 1230; WGBB, 1240; all at 7:20 P.M.)

title: DANCE: ROBERT SMALL PERFORMS TWO SOLOS
description: Robert Small is a gifted dancer, and the two solos he performed on Thursday at Theater of the Open Eye displayed him at his best. Mr. Small's ''Musings,'' set to music by Maureen Wiely, presented three aspects of that skill. His control and buoyancy were impressive in the first section, which had him turning along a circling path. The second dance was all arabesques and extensions with the extended foot nuzzling into position when it returned to earth, giving Mr. Small the look of a protractor with articulated points. Balances and a slow, easy fall into the ground were the material of the third and closing section, a depiction of easy poise and stylized ease.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mary Decker will compete in the women's division of the Wanamaker Mile at the Millrose Games, to be held Jan. 25 at Madison Square Garden. . . . Andres Gomez of Ecuador has withdrawn from the Volvo Masters tennis tournament because of an injury to his left shoulder. He was replaced in the 12-men singles field by Aaron Krickstein, the 17-year-old from Michigan. . . . Michel Platini of France, who plays for Juventus in the Italian League, has been named Europe's top soccer player for the second consecutive year in a poll of sportswriters conducted annually by France Football magazine.

title: REAGAN CAUTIOUS ON EXPECTATIONS FOR ARMS TALKS
description: President Reagan sounded a cautious note today about arms talks scheduled for next month with the Soviet Union, saying there was a need to ''temper our expectations with realism.''

title: Jordan Dooms 15 For Selling to Israelis
description: The Jordanian Government has approved death sentences for 15 people convicted of selling their property on the Israeli-occupied West Bank to Israelis, the official Jordanian press agency reported today.

title: CABARET: DR. BUZZARD'S BAND
description: Dr. Buzzard's Original Savannah Band, the theatrical Latin-soul-disco group from the South Bronx, has all but disintegrated. When this innovative band was formed by Stony Browder Jr., the composer and band leader; August Darnell, the lyricist and bassist, and the sassy vocalist Cory Daye in the mid-1970's, it forged an inventive fusion of traditional swing, disco, Cab Calloway and West Indian music.

title: Armin Landeck, Printmaker; EmployedArchitecturalStyle
description: Armin Landeck, a printmaker known for his cityscapes, died of heart failure Wednesday in Torrington, Conn. He was 79 years old and lived in Cornwall, Conn.

title: AMERICAN RECREATION CENERS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Democracy on the Diamond
description: Even the title of Meir Z. Ribalow's

title:
PATENTS;
Rear-View Car Mirror Widens Driver's Vision
description: Milan Pribis of Elmhurst, Queens, a mechanical designer with aviation experience, received a patent this week for rear-view equipment that he thinks will greatly benefit the motorist. What patent 4,490,013 terms an ''elongated panoramic mirror deflector'' is to be mounted above the windshield. The mirror is about as wide as the windshield and is expected to give the driver a broad view of what is being passed.

title: U.S. Steel Sale
description: The United States Steel Corporation said it had sold substantially all of the marine assets of its Ohio Barge Line Inc. and Mon-Valley Transportation Company subsidiaries to Ingram Industries for undisclosed terms. The units carry cargoes on the Monongahela, Ohio and Mississippi Rivers.

title: Times Square as Obstacle Course
description: The law's delay was deemed by Hamlet a fairly good reason for self-destruction, even before urban renewal. But as the sponsors of Westway and any number of projects have learned, it is a particularly powerful weapon in the cacophony of New York. It has become a lot easier to buckle up for a debilitating fight with government than to knuckle down for sober negotiation with it.

title: Ahmanson's
description: Bank Unit Bid LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28

title: A NEW MORALITY PLAY
description: New York City has a new morality play for the holiday season. Three days before Christmas, a subway rider who was apparently being harassed for money by some 18- and 19-year-olds carrying sharpened screwdrivers in their jacket pockets pulled a .38-caliber revolver from his waistband and fired bullets into four of them. All four are now hospitalized; one is paralyzed from the waist down. The gunman fled - after reportedly telling a conductor, ''They tried to rip me off'' - and is being sought by the police.

title: Ben Zevin Dies at 88; Leader Of World Publishing Company
description: Ben David Zevin, who came to the United States from the Ukraine and rose to head the World Publishing Company, once a leading producer of the King James Bible, died here Thursday. He was 88 years old.

title: JAPAN RESISTING U.S. LAWYERS
description: As far as Japan is concerned, it has acceded to more than enough United States trade demands over the years, from importing beef and oranges to restricting its auto exports. But the Japanese are sending clear signals that one commodity urged on them by Washington is something they would rather do without: American lawyers.

title: Books of The Times; The Reward of Virtue
description: -Interest, and the

title:
Patents ;
'Smear' Is Cut for TV Cameras
description: WASHINGTON

title: A FEW RESPONSIBILITIES LESS IS ALL THE BOARD OF ESTIMATES NEEDS
description: To the Editor:

title: PREMIER RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Webb Casino Sale
description: The Del E. Webb Corporation said it had completed the sale of interests in three Nevada casino-hotels to an investor group for $80.4 million. Webb said it had retained a long-term management contract and operating sublease at the three properties - the Mint in Las Vegas, the Nevada Club in Laughlin and the High Sierra at Lake Tahoe.

title: EYE LINER BY TATTOO: NEW PROCESS DEBATED
description: A new microsurgical technique - which some physicians describe as a possible health hazard - is being used to tattoo tiny dots of dark pigment permanently along the rims of the eyelids to augment or replace eye liner. It is being offered to growing numbers of women in the offices of plastic surgeons, dermatological surgeons and ophthalmologists across the country.

title: Jackson Reports 311 Threats
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that one of the lows of his unsuccessful campaign for the Presidency was the 311 threats against his life recorded by the Secret Service.

title: Letter-Writer Takes Responsibility for Bombs
description: An anonymous letter-writer has asserted that she was responsible for bombing three abortion clinics and has threatened additional violence if the facilities reopen.

title: Drawings by Matisse
description: More than 50 drawings by Henri Matisse, never before displayed in public, are among 150 works in an exhibition that opens Feb. 28 at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street.

title: Federal Reserve All data in millions of dollars
description: LatestPreviousYearWeekWeekAgo Monetary Aggregates M-1*as of Dec. 17 215,800 R 216,000 n.a. title: Shell Dutch Terminal
description: The Royal Dutch/ Shell Group of Companies will build a $31 million oil terminal in this Dutch port city, a company spokesman said today.

title: 5 DEATHS SPUR A STATE STUDY OF THE POLICE
description: Governor Cuomo has ordered a study of the use of deadly force by police departments.

title: Art by the Elderly
description: Hundreds of artworks created by the elderly around the theme of life styles are on view at the Art Gallery of the Board of Jewish Education of Greater New York, 426 West 58th Street. The exhibition, which includes tapestries, collages and graphics, is on display through Jan. 6. Weekend hours are Sunday, 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Information: 245-8200.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 10.75-11.25 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: AmericanBalletThe ater Reports Surplus for '84
description: American Ballet Theater has announced that it closed fiscal year 1984 with a record income of $15,188,086.

title: Cause for Joy
description: The holiday season has brought special joy to the Reinhardt family of Littleton, Colo. Their son, Ed, suffered a critical head injury in a college football game last fall and lingered in a coma, punctuated by several brain operations, until his condition markedly improved in recent weeks.

title: FOOD FOLLIES OF 1984
description: Keeping up with the latest eating trends is no easy matter, especially when some foods have a life span of no more than 20 minutes. Whatever, for example, happened to rabbit, which we were all assured was the hot new food of the 80's? Did it peak too soon?

title: Michigan Town Lifts Order To Boil All Drinking Water
description: An order to boil drinking water was lifted today after tests found that the water supply in this Michigan town had not been contaminated when the system ran dry Tuesday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1984
description: The Economy

title: CITY BALLET: 'THE NUTCRACKER'
description: During the New York City Ballet's long run of ''The Nutcracker,'' many dancers get chances to play many parts, and recent performances at the New York State Theater featured newcomers in several roles.

title: MANY DONATE TO THE NEEDIEST AS A MEMORIAL TO LOVED ONES
description: With the holiday season evoking warm recollections of family and friends, many donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are giving in memory of loved ones whose lives reflected concern and compassion for the poor.

title: REAGAN MEETS SON AND HIS FAMILY IN 3-HOUR REUNION IN LOS ANGELES
description: President Reagan today held a fence-mending meeting with his son Michael, who said as he went in that he planned to tell the President he loved him.

title: Change in Plans
description: LaVell Edwards's Brigham Young football team is on the verge of being voted national champions for 1984, with much of its success attributable to the air attack Edwards has honed so well.

title: GAYELORD HAUSER, 89, AUTHOR: PROPONENT OF NATURAL FOODS
description: Benjamin Gayelord Hauser, an advocate of good health through natural foods and a popular figure in Hollywood and European society, died at his home in North Hollywood, Calif., Wednesday, a family member said. Mr. Hauser, who had been suffering from pneumonia, was 89 years old.

title: STAGE: 'ACT AND THE ACTOR' BY CHIN
description: The class in symbology of the cinema is now in session. Tonight's topic is ''Ideology in Romantic Stereotypes,'' a consideration of genre movies from screwball comedies to film noir. The professor, the man who in his own words will deconstruct these structures, is Daryl Chin, playwright, filmophile and author of ''Act and the Actor.''

title: States Will End Year With Budget Surpluses
description: The 50 states will end the fiscal year 1984 with surpluses totaling $5.8 billion, nearly three times the total for the previous fiscal period, the National Governors' Association reported today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Bridge With a History
description: The Kennedy Memorial Bridge is

title: COURT REINSTATES RAPE CHARGES IN BROOKLYN CASE
description: Reversing a lower-court judge, a state appeals court has reinstated charges that a man raped four women and tried to rape a fifth in a series of assaults in low-income housing projects in Brooklyn in 1981.

title: JAPAN SEEKS A 6.9% RISE IN ITS MILITARY SPENDING
description: Government leaders have agreed on a 1985 budget that would increase Japan's military spending by 6.9 percent above this year's level.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES ; Y.A. AT HOME AND ABROAD
description: Y.A. Tittle was recently in New Caledonia, a

title: OFFICIALS ATTACK MEDICARE FREEZE
description: Officials in the health care industry have warned that extending the freeze on payments for health services under Medicare could reduce the quality of care for the nation's 30 million elderly and disabled Social Security beneficiaries.

title: INDEX THAT SHOWS ECONOMIC TRENDS UP A STRONG 1.3%
description: The index of leading economic indicators, the gauge the Government uses to try to foresee turns in the economy, rose a strong 1.3 percent in November, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: POLICIES ON RETURN OF PRESENTS
description: At a counter in Saks Fifth Avenue

title: OFFICERS STOPPING ROBBERY DIDN'T KNOW OF 3 HOSTAGES
description: The police officers who shot at suspects in a store robbery Thursday in which a hostage died did not know a hostage had been taken, the police said yesterday.

title: SoHo New Year
description: Bruce Roberts, the singer and songwriter who has written hits for Barbra Streisand and Donna Summer, among others, will perform on New Year's Eve at the SoHo restaurant Gordon's, 38 MacDougal Street (475- 7500). There is one sitting, beginning at 6:30 P.M., with a $100 cover charge that includes a seven-course Italian dinner and unlimited champagne.

title: Corcom Plans Employee Cuts
description: Corcom Inc. said it wascutting its worldwide work orce by about 21 percent, to 1,400, and imposing a salary freeze for employees in the United States, effective Tuesday.

title: KING SCORES 39 BUT KNICKS LOSE
description: Forget the first 45 minutes 35 seconds of the revitalized Nets' 100-97 triumph over the Knicks' one-man attack tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: VIETNAMESE SHELL CAMBODIAN CENTER
description: Vietnamese forces shelled the perimeter of the main headquarters of Cambodian guerrillas today in the fourth straight day of fighting, the Thai military authorities reported.

title: IN NEW DELHI, FIREWORKS AND ROSES
description: As returns from India's parliamentary elections poured in, hundreds of young supporters of Rajiv Gandhi danced for joy tonight on a broad, tree-lined avenue near the Prime Minister's official residence.

title: G.M. Raises Car Prices By an Average of $296
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it would increase the base price of most of its passenger cars by 2 percent effective Jan. 2.

title: 'BEVERLY HILLS COP' WINS AT CHRISTMAS BOX OFFICE
description: For the last three weeks, nearly one of every three people buying a movie ticket has gone to see the 23- year-old comedian Eddie Murphy, wearing scuffed sneakers and a Detroit funk sweatshirt, make monkeys out of the slick denizens of Beverly Hills. He is starring in Paramount's ''Beverly Hills Cop,'' which has earned $64.5 million in 23 days.

title: Ward Offers Legal Services SCHAUMBURG, Ill., Dec 28
description: (Reuters) - Montgomery

title: I.M.F. APPROVES $20 BILLION AID FOR ARGENTINA
description: The International Monetary Fund today approved a $20 billion aid and austerity program to help Argentina pay its bills. The move ended more than a year of uncertainty over the financial status of the developing world's third-largest debtor.

title: KNOX, SHULA DISMISS RIVALRY
description: Chuck Knox and Don Shula both insist that the playoff game Saturday between the Seattle Seahawks and the Miami Dolphins is not a game between the coaches.

title: Rozema to Texas
description: Dave Rozema, whose eight-year career with the Detroit Tigers was marred by repeated injuries, has agreed to a two-year contract with Texas, becoming the third free agent to sign with the Rangers this winter. Terms of the deal were not disclosed by either side, but Dallas newspapers reported that the 28-year-old Rozema would receive a total of $500,000 to $600,000.

title: Out for the Evening, Up With the Garbage
description: Donald Miele heard strange sounds coming from the compactor unit of his garbage truck today, so he flagged down a passing deputy sheriff.

title: A POINT MAN CONVERSATIVES CAN BACK
description: William H. Gray 3d represents Pennsylvania's Second Congressional District, which spans the Schuylkill and includes most of the black neighborhoods in North Philadelphia and West Philadelphia.

title: GEORGE III DIDN'T DO IT
description: To the Editor:

title: LOUISIANA KILLER IS PUT TO DEATH
description: With a wink to the nun who helped him through his last hours, Robert Lee Willie went to his death in the electric chair today for raping and murdering an 18-year-old woman on the night before she was to enter the Army.

title: FANON-COURRIER USA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: KOCH REFUSES TO SET CITY HOLIDAY TO MARK THE BIRTHDAY OF DR. KING
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would not create a city holiday in 1985 to mark the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: INDIANS DISCIPLINED OVER PLANT SAFETY
description: The state government suspended several officials and accepted the resignation of its Labor Minister today in connection with failures to act on safety problems at the Union Carbide factory here where a poison gas leak killed at least 2,000 people on Dec. 3.

title:
PATENTS;
Wrist Monitor of Heart Calculates Pulse Rate
description: A heart monitor that can be worn on the wrist has been invented by Iosif Baumberg of Brooklyn.

title: Your Money ; I.R.A. Switch Is Not Simple
description: The turn of the year marks a new season for

title: HOW ELECTIONS WORK IN INDIA
description: Voting in an Indian general election takes place much as it does in Britain, after which India's parliamentary system of government is modeled.

title: SAM PECKINPAH, MOVIE DIRECTOR, DIES
description: Sam Peckinpah, the maverick movie director best known for his westerns and graphic uses of violence on film, died yesterday at Centinela Hospital Medical Center in Inglewood, a Los Angeles suburb. He was 59 years old.

title: OPEC TO AUDIT ITS PRICES AND OUTPUT
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed today to set up a five- member committee to oversee an auditing of the group's oil pricing and production. It will be headed by Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi Arabian oil minister.

title: Alpha Capital, Westamerica Tie
description: The Alpha Capital Company has increased its stake in the Westamerica Bancorporation of Santa Rafael, Calif., to 222,060 common shares, or 9.5 percent of the bank holding company's shares outstanding. According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Alpha purchased the shares for investment purposes only, and has ''no present intent to acquire control or otherwise affect control'' of Westamerica.

title: SIKES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SEABOARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 17
description: Results for the latest periods include results from chicken producing and processing businesses purchased in 1984.

title: Panel Rules Hinckley Victims Cannot Sue His Psychiatrist
description: Three men wounded by John W. Hinckley Jr. in his attempt to kill President Reagan cannot sue a psychiatrist for $14 million in damages, a Federal appeals court has ruled.

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page picture caption from United Press International on Thursday, about the Vietnamese attack on a rebel camp in Cambodia, misidentified the body of water the refugees were crossing. It was an antitank ditch.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: Boeing Unit Gets Energy Contract
description: The Department of Energy said it had selected a Boeing Company subsidiary, Boeing Petroleum Services Inc. of Seattle, to manage, operate and maintain the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

title: STEEL LIMIT APPROVED BY E.E.C.
description: The European Economic Community today accepted an accord with the United States to limit exports of Common Market steel tubes and pipes to 7.6 percent of the United States market, a Common Market commission spokesman said.

title: INTERNATIONAL INTRIGUE MAKES MIAMI THE NEW 'CASABLANCA'
description: In darkened corners of quiet cafes, they plan the overthrow of a government or seal a big drug transaction. Some speak of spy operations or transferring huge sums of money.

title: Two Royal Families Vacation in Colorado
description: King Juan Carlos of Spain and King Constantine II, the exiled ruler of Greece, are spending the week with their families on a skiing holiday near this resort in the Rocky Mountains.

title: Saints Consider Moving Away
description: The New Orleans Saints said today that they were seriously considering offers from out-of-state interests who wanted to buy the team and move it away from Louisiana.

title: Thumbs Down
description: Gord Lane, the Islander defenseman, suffered sprains of both thumbs in the 5-4 overtime loss to the Washington Capitals Thursday night and will be out for 10 days to two weeks. The Islanders left yesterday for a three-game trip, starting in St. Louis tonight, and may promote Gord Dineen, a defenseman, who is with the Springfield team in the American Hockey League. . . . Jan Ludvig of the Devils, whose chest was injured in the 4-1 victory Thursday night over the Toronto Maple Leafs, is expected to play tonight against the Buffalo Sabres because the X-rays were negative. . . . The Rangers said that there was a chance that Mark Pavelich will return for tonight's game against the Canadiens in Montreal. He suffered a broken leg Oct. 13 against the Minnesota North Stars in Bloomington, Minn.

title: BANKERS TRUST SEEKS FED BACKING FOR COMMERCIAL PAPER UNIT
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation plans to ask the Federal Reserve Board if it can transfer the bank's commercial paper activities into a non-bank subsidiary, a bank spokesman said yesterday. The move appears to be an attempt to establish a backup defense in case Bankers Trust loses a longstanding legal battle over its commercial paper role.

title: Vietnam Dissolves Its Subjects
description: Vietnam has earned its reputation as the Prussia of Southeast Asia. After humbling French and American armies, it conquered Laos and Cambodia, then turned ferociously on its subject peoples. This Christmas week, Vietnam mounted a fresh offensive against Cambodian rebels, driving 63,000 more civilians across the border into Thailand.

title: ASBESTOS COMPANIES SUED BY SCHOOLS
description: New York City and the Board of Education yesterday filed a $250 million lawsuit against more than 60 manufacturers and distributors of asbestos found in city schools.

title: Unidynamics Shift
description: The Unidynamics Corporation said it had formed four business units as part of a reorganization of its operations and realignment of its operating management. It said the new businesses are Unidynamics Engineered Materials, Stamford; Unidynamics Defense Systems and Merchandising Systems, St. Louis, and Unidynamics Automation Systems, Troy, Mich. The new units combine nine major and four smaller divisions, according to the company, which has interests in military goods and commercial vending devices.

title: Swaziland Rounding Up South African Guerrillas
description: The police have begun rounding up the last 23 African National Congress guerrillas still in Swaziland, a police spokesman said today.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Prices of Bonds Move Lower;  Money Off $200 Million
description: Bond prices drifted slightly lower again yesterday in the quiet year-end market, as interest rates edged higher for a third consecutive session.

title: A SMALL CITY IN SOUTH JERSEY WELCOMES THE WORLD'S TRADE
description: More than 50 miles up the Delaware River from the Atlantic Ocean, a port has opened in this small southwestern New Jersey city, the first new port of entry in the Northeast in 50 years.

title: ALCOHOL BUT ONE CAUSE OF LIVER CIRRHOSIS
description: To the Editor:

title: GOVERNING PARTY POSTS BIG VICTORY IN INDIAN ELECTION
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and his Congress Party scored a smashing triumph and appeared headed today for one of the biggest election victories since India became independent.

title: SMOKERS GET A RAW DEAL
description: The civil rights act, the voting rights act and a host of antidiscrimination laws notwithstanding, millions of Americans are still forced to sit in the back of planes, trains and buses. Many more are subject to segregation in public places. Some are even denied housing and employment: victims of an alarming - yet socially acceptable - public hostility.

title: 36TH CHESS GAME ADJOURNED
description: The 36th game of the world chess championship match between Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov was adjourned today on the 41st move with Kasparov, playing White, holding a pawn advantage.

title: TOLL-FREE LINES TEEM WITH INSTANT REPLIES
description: In a room with salmon-colored walls and natural wood tables, Carmen Pimentel is one of 25 people answering the constantly ringing phone. ''Clairol Hotline'' she says, then waits for questions from anywhere in the country.

title: TV: 'SUPREME COURT,' ABC NEWS DOCUMENTARY
description: The Supreme Court of the United States,'' an ABC News ''Closeup'' documentary, looks on our highest tribunal with mild alarm. The Court seems to be shifting its concern from individual liberty to majority and institutional rights. Is liberty in peril? The documentary doesn't really answer the question, and that's just as well. The Supreme Court has been arousing alarm for almost 200 years, and mild alarm is almost a corollary of an intelligent examination. It means we are interested. The documentary will be seen today on Channel 7 at 10 P.M.

title: 3 Family Members DieinUpstateFire
description: A married couple and their 2-year-old daughter were killed early today when a fire destroyed the home they had been visiting for the holidays, the police said. Three relatives were injured.

title: SHULTZ SAID TO DROP RECOMMENDATION ON NEXT ENVOY TO HONDURAS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has dropped efforts to have a senior State Department aide named as the next Ambassador to Honduras, department officials said today.

title: Westchester Joins In Free-Fare Offer
description: Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said today that rides on county buses will be free on New Year's Eve.

title: A SCANDAL IN BONN CASTS A SOFT SHADOW ON MADRID
description: Spaniards call it the Flick case, and it can be viewed as a corruption scandal, cynical politics, overzealousness by the press or just a big national joke.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;  'Arc' Under Scrutiny
description: ''Tilted Arc,'' a monumental and

title: Candelaria's Tragedy
description: John Candelaria, the Pittsburgh Pirate pitcher, is ''taking hard'' the near-drowning of his 18-month-old son, who is now in a coma at a hospital in Tampa, Fla.

title: U.S. Shoe Adds
description: The United States Shoe Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the brand name Nettleton for men's footware and certain other assets of the A.E. Nettleton Company. Terms were not disclosed. It said the Nettleton brand footwear would be manufactured by its men's division in Beloit, Wis.

title: ; HOW SIR IKE AND HIS KNIGHTS SLEW THE DRAGON CALLED MCCARTHY
description: To the Editor:

title: Stake in Broken Hill
description: The Adelaide Steamship Company has become the sixth-largest shareholder in the Broken Hill Proprietary Company, a Broken Hill spokesman said. Adelaide holds 15.7 million shares worth about $80 million (Australian), as of Thursday, she said. The holding represents about 1.7 percent of Broken Hill's shares outstanding and is worth about $66 million in United States currency.

title: NEW LAWS RECOGNIZING MARITAL RAPE AS A CRIME
description: Deborah was making a call from a pay telephone when a man held a knife to her throat and demanded money. When she got home the same man was waiting. He raped her at gunpoint.

title: Letter: On Warfare ; A Nuclear Theory That Can't Be Tested
description: To the Editor:

title: Rock at the Ritz
description: General Public, the English rock group, will appear at the Ritz, 11th Street between Third and Fourth Avenues (254-2800), tomorrow at 10 P.M. Tickets are $12.50.

title: I.B.M.-Korea Link
description: The Finance Ministry has approved a plan by a unit of the International Business Machines Corporation to set up a company in South Korea next year, ministry officials said. They said the unit, I.B.M. World Trade Americas/Far East Corporation, would make and sell personal computers and parts. I.B.M. wants to invest $15.4 million in establishing the I.B.M. Korea System Corporation, the officials said. They gave no further details.

title: A Hand or Two Clapping
description: A week has passed without repetition of the booing of ''Field, Chair and Mountain,'' the new David Gordon ballet that is part of the American Ballet Theater program at the Kennedy Center. At the closing curtain of the ballet's world premiere, on Dec. 20, there was some booing.

title: Philippines Pact on Debt
description: Institutional and governmental creditors of the Philippines have agreed on the rescheduling of principal and interest on debts falling due between Jan. 1, 1985, and June 30, 1986, sources in the central bank and Finance Ministry said today.

title: No Bail Required for Boy In Father's Slaying
description: A 17-year-old boy accused of killing his father with a hatchet was released today in the custody of relatives after a judge said he was impressed by community support for the teen-ager.

title: LET'S TURN SUBWAY SEATS INTO CONDOS
description: In his recent offer to finance a new sports stadium in Flushing by selling seats as ''condominiums,'' Donald J. Trump, the real estate developer, unwittingly outlined a revolutionary plan to rescue our failing public transportation system. The lukewarm reception accorded this plan by city officials unwilling to provide free land, access roads and electric power for the enterprise is apparently forcing Mr. Trump to take his generosity elsewhere. But his pioneering approach to the needs of the urban community deserves wider application.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Killing people is wrong. That's why you've put me to death.

title: A June Wedding Is Being Planned By Callie Madeira
description: Mrs. Rufus C. Finch Jr. of New York and Harry R. Madeira of Northeast Harbor, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carolyn Coxe Madeira to Henry George Brauer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Earle W. Brauer of New York and Westport, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: THE REALITIES OF CENTRAL AMERICA
description: James Chace speculates that if Arturo Cruz had participated in the recent elections, he might have won 40 percent of the vote, and the Sandinistas ''might have been hard pressed to come up with a decent majority.'' Mr. Chace bases his hypothesis on ''the presence of many workers and peasants at his (Cruz's) campaign rallies,'' but he fails to mention that many workers and peasants also disrupted these rallies because they viewed Cruz as Washington's puppet. More importantly, Mr. Chace neglects to mention that Nicaragua's largest economic group (of peasants, artisans and cooperative members, comprising about 60 percent of the adult population) has benefited greatly from the Sandinistas' policies and, therefore, had every reason to vote for the Sandinista National Liberation Front, known as the F.S.L.N. Finally, Mr. Chace presents the Sandinistas as isolated from European Socialist parties; for example, he calls the French ''profoundly unhappy with the generally Leninist direction of the revolution.''

title: Free Train Rides Tomorrow Night
description: For the second year, the Metro- North Commuter Railroad will give free rides on New Year's Eve between Connecticut and New York.

title: KOCH AT ODDS WITH PROFESSOR OVER STUDY OF POVERTY IN CITY
description: A dispute has broken out between Mayor Koch and a university professor who wrote a recent study of poverty in New York City.

title: HAZARDOUS CHEMICAL, REJECTED BY BRAZIL, IS UNLOADED IN VIRGINIA
description: Thirteen tons of methyl isocyanate, the chemical that killed more than 2,000 people in India early this month, was unloaded in port here today amid special safety precautions and put on two trucks headed for a Union Carbide Corporation plant in Georgia.

The Murphys originally wanted to take in one child, but when social workers came to them with a brother and sister - Jimmy, who was then 6 years old, and Angela, who was 3 - they agreed.

Mr. Douglas is appealing the perjury conviction and has denied contributing to the failure of the company ''and the hardships caused by the event.''

Attention among Soviet and Chinese officials here focused less on the economic and technical agreements reached during the nine-day visit of First Deputy Prime Minister Ivan V. Arkhipov than on the warm atmosphere that prevailed throughout his stay.

SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
ALL IN ALL, IT WAS A GOOD YEAR

title: Commuter Compliment For Metro-North
description: On Sunday I read, ''Real Reason I Drive to Work'' by John Chervokas (Opinion Page, Dec. 9). The following Tuesday, I took my first ride on the new marvel, called the ''electrified'' Metro-North. Truly, I cannot quite come to grips with Mr. Chervokas's complaint that he gave up using the railroad because the ticket does not carry enough cachet!

description: A Choice of Evils'' recently appeared in its fourth edition. He teaches at Stanford University. TALES OF A LONG NIGHT

description: KINDERGARTNERS in the Rye Neck School District are listening closely these days as teachers describe early-American settlement and year- end traditions. At round tables in their classrooms, 4- and 5-year-olds have pasted paper feathers to turkey bodies and colored in pictures of New World feasts.

description: When the National Forest Service tried to push a logging road into the center of one of the biggest remaining stands of virgin forest in Oregon's Cascade Mountains, members of the Cathedral Forest Action Group draped themselves over the waiting boxes of dynamite and threw themselves in front of the oncoming trucks.

description: Nostalgia, laced lightly with fantasy, dominated in the antiques and 20th-century decorative arts that were shown in museums and galleries and sought by collectors during 1984. When the wares in question were also rare or of the finest quality, connoisseurs pursued them with even greater determination - and paid prices that reflected this preference.

title: OPEC MakesAnother StabAt Unity
description: Without discipline a cartel is nothing. So the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries seemed to say last week when they agreed to form a special panel that would monitor compliance with the oil cartel's efforts to limit production and maintain price levels in a world glutted by oil.

title: LIBEL SUITS CURB AN EVER-MORE-POWERFUL PRESS

title: Ellen Kelley Wed To James Peace

Peace of Purchase, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Manhattanville College Chapel in Purchase. The Rev. Robert J. Robbins performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Suffolk College 'Bonus' Disputed
description: I'm glad that in the article ''Suffolk College Financially Abandoned? No Indeed'' (Opinion Page, Dec. 9), Frank R. Jones, Deputy County Executive of Suffolk County, affirms that Suffolk County has an excellent community college and that the faculty and staff of the college are dedicated to their profession. However, Mr. Jones's words of praise are no real comfort to the faculty, which has been working without a contract since September and has been demoralized by Suffolk County's offer of a 1 to 2 percent ''bonus'' in exchange for the traditional 4 to 5 percent salary increment and concessions regarding seniority rights, sick leave, etc.

title:
FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
Fake in Houston
description: A regular visitor to the reptile house of the Houston Zoo noticed last September that the coral snake wasn't moving. Indeed, it hadn't moved for days.

title: Campus-Politics View Is Termed Simplistic
description: In the journalistic frenzy to write the story that young people are turning conservative, important facts are being obscured or ignored.

title: The Role Of Today's Navy Pilot
description: As a former Navy dive- bomber pilot, I read Michael Berryhill's article, ''The Leading Edge: The Role of Today's Navy Pilot'' (Nov. 25), with interest.

title: TOWN SET TO REPEAT MONTH WITHOUT TV
description: SOME of the residents of Farmington are planning to spend January without television, just as they did during a widely publicized experiment last January.

title: FROM FACTORY LINE TO OPERA PRIZE
description: PHILIP BOLOGNA'S goal in life is not exactly modest: He wants to be an ''international opera star of renown.'' And now, at the age of 32, the tenor, who appears in concert at Guild Hall in East Hampton today, could be on his way toward approaching those heights.

CONNECTICUT OPINION;
AROUND EVERY WRIST, TIME MARCHES ON
description: MY daughter, Lisa, is the only person I know who does not own a watch. Every Christmas, I offer to give her one. Watches, however, are not a priority item with her.

title: TO HIS PUBLISHER Dear Jay (James Laughlin, of New Directions): Unless I am mistaken, which is likely enough, you may have taken my remarks on money in my last letter as a kind of hint, naturally enough. But I merely meant to report on what preoccupied me, which is the only way I can write letters, and I sincerely yearn for the day when our friendship is so pure that all my royalties can be assigned to some charitable cause such as a society for making it clear to the American people that (General) MacArthur is an unspeakable ham. I have decided not to be a bank clerk, after all, since I would probably be paralyzed by the conflict between my desire to steal money and my fear of doing so. It was pleasant to learn that you expected our correspondence to be read in the international salons and boudoirs of the future. Do you think they will be able to distinguish between the obfuscations, mystifications, efforts at humor, and plain statements of facts? Will they recognize my prime feelings as a correspondent - the catacomb from which I write to you, seeking to secure some word from the real world, or at least news of the Far West - and sigh with compassion? Or will they just think that I am nasty, an over-eager clown, gauche, awkward and bookish? Will they understand that I am always direct, open, friendly, simple and candid to the point of na"ivete until the ways of the fiendish world infuriate me and I am forced to be devious, suspicious, calculating, not that it does me any good anyway? And for that matter what will they make of your complex character? . . . Yours, Delmore New York City May 8, 1951 -
description: From ''Letters of Delmore Schwartz.''

title: ST. JOHN'S CAPTURES FESTIVAL
description: Through most of its first eight basketball games this season, St. John's carried the weight of national recognition like a man with bogus credentials, treading softly for fear of being exposed. Suspicions from without combined with nagging doubts from within to create an unspoken feeling among the Redmen that before the Big East Conference season began, they needed proof that they were one of the country's elite teams.

title: MEETING NEAR POLE TO TAKE UP ANTARCTICA'S FUTURE
description: Two planes laden with diplomats and scientists from about 30 countries and a variety of specialized agencies are to glide down at a remote research station near the South Pole Jan. 7, where a special workshop is to be held on the future of Antarctica.

title: VAN NORSTRAND SEEKS 'A GOOD TONE'
description: When the 1985 session of the General Assembly convenes Jan. 9, both houses will be controlled by the Republicans for the first time in a decade. R. E. Van Norstrand of Darien, the Republican minority leader of the House of Representatives for the last six years, will be Speaker of the House. Following are excerpts from an interview with Richard L. Madden of The New York Times in which Mr. Van Norstrand discussed the changes at the State Capitol:

title: Kathryn Lynn Barrett Marries Jules F. Simon
description: Kathryn Lynn Barrett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Stevens Barrett of Williamsburg, Va., was married there yesterday to Jules Ferber Simon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Everett Simon of Plainview, L.I. The Rev. Jack B. Scott of St. John's Episcopal Church in Olney, Md., performed the ceremony at Bruton Parish.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: WHOSE LITTLE BOY ARE YOU? A Memoir of the Broun Family, by Heywood Hale Broun. (St. Martin's/ Marek, $6.95.) One of the author's parents, Ruth Hale, was the nation's first female movie critic; the other, Heywood Broun, a famous columnist and founder of the Newspaper Guild. As parents they were casual and ''progressive;'' for their son, Heywood Hale Broun, the CBS-TV correspondent, they were a trial. Barbara Schulgasser wrote here last year that ''Whose Little Boy Are You?'' ''is a painfully honest book'' in which Mr. Broun ''recalls his childhood with the urgency of one who still feels the hurt.'' THE SEASON: A Candid Look at Broadway, by William Goldman. (Limelight, $8.95.) For his examination of the Broadway season of 1967-68. William Goldman saw every new show and interviewed critics, playwrights, producers and ticket brokers; he even commissioned a customer survey. Harold Clurman said here in 1969 that ''The Season'' ''performs a hatchet job on Broadway. It is a frank book; it names names. . . . William Goldman's book will be read with relish by everybody in the business and by many others who follow its trade.''

title:
ANTIQUES;
ITEMS MADE BEFORE 1840 ON VIEW
description: FOR the avid collector, good news anytime is that a show of fine, authentic New England antiques is coming up. Just such a show is promised by 50 well- known dealers who will exhibit this weekend at the Third Annual January Antiques Show to be held in the State Armory in Stratford.

title: CREWS PUSH TO SEAL OFF FIRE INSIDE UTAH MINE
description: Crews worked late today to finish sealing off the burning Utah coal mine that held the bodies of 27 workers.

title: Man Gives Up After Freeing 3-Year-Old He Held Hostage
description: A man with a knife held a 3-year-old boy hostage nearly four hours yesterday in a Harlem apartment before releasing the boy unharmed and giving himself up to the police.

title: Bouncing Back With Television
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: EMPLOYEE-OWNED COMPANIES AND THEIR FATES
description: In June 1980, with considerable hope and much fanfare, Rath Packing Company, an old meat packer based in Waterloo, Iowa, was reorganized as an employee- owned company. Proponents of employee ownership saw the plan as a remarkable experiment in workplace democracy, one that might help combat a wave of plant closings and counter industrial stagnation.

title: PUBLIC TV'S GAMBLES OFTEN PAID OFF HANDSOMELY
description: Consider television as an instrument of information, enlightenment and knowledge. Consider its people as journalists, thinkers and teachers. Some of them do good work. Nonfiction television, an area roughly made up of, but scarcely confined to, news, documentary and opinion, had triumphs in 1984. In particular, there were rich, plummy and intelligent series. Say right off, meanwhile, that these were public-television series. The great justification for public television, indeed the only one worth talking about, is that it can offer an alternative to the networks. It can gamble, making excellence its own reward. This in itself will not uphold Western civilization, but in the continuing battle against the Vandals it will claim a small place. Intelligent television never hurts.

title:
DINING OUT;
CRITIC'S CHOICES FOR THE BEST OF 1984
description: AS 1984 comes to an end, once again we submit our yearly evaluation of the area's restaurants, and the news is good. Several old favorites have become even better, and some excellent new places have opened their doors. We would not hesitate spending an evening at any of these.

title: KAUFMAN DEFENDS USING LAWS' INTENT
description: In a strong defense of a judge's right to exercise broad leeway in interpreting legislation, Judge Irving R. Kaufman argues in a law-review article that judges must seek the law's ''underlying aim'' and write decisions that reflect the values of their communities.

(Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) A fictionalized life of Salvatore Giuliano, the Sicilian bandit-hero of the 1940's. *3 311 LOVE AND WAR, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) The Civil War rages in this saga of a Pennsylvania family and a South Carolina family, begun in ''North and South.'' *4

description: ''THE Primacy of Just Seeing,'' at the Thorpe Intermedia Gallery in Sparkill, Rockland County (Route 340), gets off to a wobbly start in the form of a statement by its curator, Bill Hochhausen. The sculptor responsible for the new bus shelter in nearby Thorpe Village, Mr. Hochhausen is, not unnaturally, interested in perception; particularly, he says, in its function as a ''separable/inseparable and unique element in the content of art.''

description: IN sports, 1984 produced some of those memorable

title: Sailing Daily From New Jersey Getting to work in Manhattan from New Jersey starts out being a job in itself and it's getting harder. Traffic has increased sharply, reflecting the growing white-collar job market. The result: Bridge and tunnel crossings routinely involve 35- minute delays and the PATH trains are packed. People are struggling to find new remedies and, eureka, have discovered an old one. The ferryboat.
description: Until the era of the automobile, main access between New York and New Jersey was by water. Regular ferry service from Hoboken began in 1774, and, at one time, there were 11 ferry crossing points below 24th Street alone.

title: Requiem for a Nation
description: Orwell's year ends with all his imagined horrors realized in Afghanistan. Five years ago, the Soviet Union undertook a ''limited and temporary'' intervention at the ''invitation'' of a beleaguered Marxist ruler. He was then murdered by his supposed comrades, and a docile successor was implanted. The war thus spawned in lies, and waged in stealth, has now run longer than Stalin's war with Hitler.

title: 17 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 17 food establishments last week for violating the city's health code.

title: HEADLINERS;
description: Nonpracticing Preacher Frances Warner used to counsel children in North Dakota on the dangers of drug abuse until she admitted using peyote, a powerful hallucinogen derived from cactus. She and her husband were arrested last July after 5,000 peyote buttons and peyote tea were found in their home.

title:
INVESTING;
SORTING OUT INVESTMENT NEWSLETTERS
description: PUBLISHING investment newsletters has become big business, with several hundred weekly, bi-weekly and monthly letters offering investors a bewildering variety of advice. Some pick stocks. Many forecast swings in the market averages. Others counsel readers on preserving life, limb and Krugerrands in the next great crash.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: NEW HAVEN
description: WHEN Herbert Pearce, a North Haven realty broker, makes his pitch these days, he often talks about the boom towns an hour away on the Connecticut Turnpike. ''The bloom is off the rose in Fairfield County,'' he says. ''Availability is limited, costs are very high, the cost of support services is very high, and the traffic situation'' - and here his voice drops to signify understatement - ''is not completely desirable.''

title: Houston Passer Prefers Obscurity
description: Gerald Landry may be one of the most overlooked quarterbacks in the history of modern bowl games. He is ''the other quarterback'' for the Cotton Bowl game, when Houston plays Boston College, which is led by Doug Flutie, on New Year's Day.

title: R. S. McEniry Is Wed To Elizabeth Johnson
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Courtney Johnson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Lee Johnson Jr. of St. Louis, to Roger Scott McEniry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray W. McEniry of Scarsdale, N.Y., took place yesterday. The Rev. Donald Howland performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Ladue Chapel in St. Louis.

title: AID FOR THE AGED
description: To the Editor:

title: Bishops Urge Governor ToRiseWelfare
description: The state's Roman Catholic bishops have asked Governor Cuomo to seek an increase in welfare payments to the poor.

title: 'IT'S HOW WE GOT WHERE WE ARE'
description: When James Duff was attending junior college in Hurst, Tex., he and 94 classmates took part in a sociology poll. There were four questions to answer - who would you most like to work with on a project, who would you least like to work with, who would you most like to see out of class and who would you least like to see. The result stunned both teacher and students. Mr. Duff had placed first in all four categories.

title: 49ERS: A FAST START BUT NO RUNAWAY
description: With two flicks of his wrist in the first seven minutes today, Joe Montana gave the San Francisco 49ers all the points they would need. He threw a 21-yard touchdown pass to the wide receiver Dwight Clark and a 9-yard touchdown pass to the tight end Russ Francis to put the Giants in a 14-0 hole, and the Giants never climbed out.

title: SUFFOLK COLLEGE 'BONUS' DISPUTED

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
NEW YEAR'S FOR YOUTHS
description: The New Year will be toasted in with apple juice, not champagne, at the Y.M.C.A. of Port Chester/ Rye Brook. The Y, at 400 Westchester Avenue, will hold an overnight New Year's Eve party for children ages 6 through 12.

title: 2 DANCERS REJECT STATE ARTS COUNCIL AID
description: -year history of the State Council on the Arts, two recipients of grants have rejected their awards. Julie Maloney of West Caldwell, founder and director of the Julie Maloney Dance Company, has returned a $2,000 general operating support grant, and Lillo Way of Montclair, founder and director of the Lillo Way Dance Company, has given back a $1,000 choreography fellowship.

title: SHOWROOM CARS IN BIG TIME

Except for the addition of safety equipment, no modifications were to be made to the cars, and the purchase price of the eligible economy sedans was limited to $2,000.

title: ENVIRONMENTALISTS TAKE ON NEW LOOK
description: THE environmental movement that gained force in Suffolk County during the first half of the decade is evolving in new directions, according to people who have been active in it.

title:
ANTIQUES;

description: MIDDLETOWN ANTIQUE slot and vending machines and arcade games have been finding a growing market among collectors in recent years, and, with recently liberalized laws in New Jersey, some of these vintage devices are beginning to find their way into homes as absorbing novelties and colorful conversation pieces.

title: SABRES TOP DEVILS AS BARRASSO STARS
description: Despite some excellent goaltending from Glenn (Chico) Resch for the second consecutive game, the Devils lost, 2-1, to the Buffalo Sabres tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: ; Vietnamese AttackCambodian Camps    ect Few $
description: Six years after invading Cambodia and establishing a friendly Government in Pnom Penh, Vietnamese forces seemed intent last week on delivering a knockout blow against rebel forces holding out in camps along the border with Thailand.

description: Members of the new Parliament took their seats Friday as Grenada returned to democratic rule for the first time since a 1979 coup.

title: DESIRE TO SHARE INSPIRES GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: A desire to share - whether it is a sharing of material goods or of the riches of health, happiness and family love - often inspires contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
ANS PLANS MEDAL CONTEST FOR STATUE OF LIBERTY
description: The American Numismatic Society is conducting a design competition for a new medal marking the centennial of the Statue of Liberty. The medal is envisioned as the first in a series of ANS issues commemorating major public events.

title: A MASTER AT USING METAL IN SCULPTURE WITH IMAGINATION

His art has worn rather well with time. It has enough of the technological, the primitivistic, the spiritual and the monumental - to different degrees in different pieces - to allow it to seem significant, even to advocates of newer developments in sculpture.

title: THE COUSINS
description: Kathleen Teltsch is a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times. THE SECLUDED ROCKEFELler estate in the Pocantico Hills of New York, overlooking the Hudson River, offers an idyllic and very private setting for the homecomings of the family's younger members. They met there two weeks ago, and also last June, when the rhododendron and laurel were in bloom. The trees in full leaf provided a shield, preventing outsiders from glimpsing the tennis matches, the softball game or the children tumbling on the greensward. A vehicle constantly patrolled the perimeter of the grounds.

title: ; Rajiv GandhiWins a LandslideVictory in India $
description: TSixty-five years ago, a rich and aristocratic Indian lawyer named Motilal Nehru renounced the grandeur of his Western-style life to join Mohandas K. In the subsequent years, he gave to the nation not only his devotion, including terms in British colonial jails, but also his family - his son, Jawaharlal, became the first Prime Minister of independent India and then his granddaughter, Indira Gandhi, held the job for most of the last two decades.

title: 1. DEAL WITH FEARS
description: The arms race in both the United States and the Soviet Union is driven by a profound fear that the other nation will acquire the ability to gain an advantage from a first strike and then exploit that advantage politically. Efforts to control the nuclear competition might be more successful if the two nations discussed the reasons behind their first- strike fears and sought to make it impossible for either side to gain any sort of advantage from launching first.

title: IN SHORT
description: By Sheila Bosworth. (Simon & Schuster, $15.95.)By Norma Klein. (Viking, $16.95.)By Norma Levinson. (Simon & Schuster, $15.95.) By Maurice Valency. (Schocken, $15.95.) By P. F. Kluge. (Freundlich Books, $15.95.) ''Season for War'' is a historical novel about 200 black soldiers who remain in the military after the Civil War. These ''buffalo soldiers'' - so called by newspaper reporters of the 1880's because of ''their bison-like carriage'' - go west to the Arizona Territory. They fight and eventually defeat the Apache nation and then herd the Indians to a reservation in Florida. Later they drift to Manila and Samar, where they fight Filipinos in the Spanish-American War. The plot that girds this action, however, involves three white Hoosiers who become involved in a love triangle. There is Henry Lawson, the rugged captain who leads the black soldiers, a war hero who has the sophistication of a boy playing king of the mountain; Edwin Carter Morrison, a war correspondent for The New York Sun whose stories have made this foolish captain into a hero; and Lucy Lawson, Henry's wife as well as Edwin's lover, a kind of kitsch Lady Macbeth who throws dinner parties on the prairie while urging the two men to promote their careers. But since P. J. Kluge's real concerns seem to be the victims of American imperialism at the close of the 19th century and the part the press played in making America's ''Manifest Destiny'' an accepted myth, these three characters for the most part emerge as merely representations of the silly, macho hero, the sensational, dishonest journalist and the repressed wife.

title: HIS OLD ROOM ON THE GROUND FLOOR She ran to her old mahogany dresser, poked around in it, and found in a drawer a gold chain with a black stone cross in it. She pressed it to her, kissed it, fell to her knees again, and begged for help. Scarcely breathing, she listened at the door, the chain still in her hand. Men's slow, heavy steps, a maid's voice: ''Down this hall and then left to the open door.'' A muffled sound; they had set the stretcher down. Whispered words now; they were carrying him to his bed. From him, nothing. The heavy steps again in the hall. The maid's voice: ''I'll get Mrs. Allison.'' Alice pressed the chain to her lips, stuck it back in its place, and opened the door. ''Mrs. Allison,'' the maid called. In the peaceful house Edward lay in his old room on the ground floor. A door opened onto the garden. He could see the rose bushes, the yellow, red, and white roses, the wilted ones, the tulip bed, the carnations, the constantly changing sky, and, beyond, hills with chestnut trees. Complete peace. Here a man could become well again. He put up with things for a few days. His mother was overjoyed to have him home. She sat at his bedside for hours at a time and held his hand. He remained reticent and often sent her away (he had a nurse) - didn't she have anything to attend to in the house? ''Let me be, Edward. Believe me, I have nothing to do. Allow me this pleasure.'' -
description: From ''Tales of a Long Night.''

title: LEADING INDICATORS SHOW A NEW SURGE
description: The economy is back on track, according to most economists, who hailed the 1.3 percent November increase in the index of leading economic indicators as proof. The increase came after a drop of five- tenths of 1 percent in October, and was much larger than had been expected. Helped by building permits and the money supply, the rise in the index reassured Administration officials, who have been denying predictions of a new recession. Still, there appears to be little chance that the economy's growth in the coming months will match that of the boom period that began 1984.

title: VAN GOGH HEADED THE LIST OF HEROES
description: One of the good things about the New York art world is that it has no Oscars, no Tonys and no Emmys. And quite right, too. Prizes have no place in the arts. Who wants the Nobel Prize, except for the money, when they remember who else has had it? Who would want the Goncourt Prize for the novel in Paris, if it were not for the six-figure sales that go with it? Nice as it may be to win the Leeds Prize for the piano or the Tchaikovsky Prize for the violin, how far does it really get you? How many prizes did Picasso win? Art is art - a long, slow haul - and Matisse was neither better nor worse for having won the Carnegie International Prize in Pittsburgh when he was pushing 60.

title: Playing the Peace Game The war game has been partially superseded by economics, the ''peace game,'' in the pursuit of national interest. If the United States is to strengthen its power . . . it must be prepared to play . . . through trade, aid, foreign investment, exchange of technology, measures to strengthen and stabilize the international monetary system - and its own economy. At the end of World War II, it was recognized that for the United States to achieve its international goals of rebuilding the world economy and preserving a secure structure of peace, high employment and economic growth would have to be maintained at home - to create the needed conditions for America's world role, to provide the resources needed by others, and to maintain an open and growing market for the goods of other countries. The world economic and financial crisis today requires a comparable effort on the part of the United States to keep its economy operating at a high level of employment, while curbing the inflation and high interest rates that have worsened the problems of others. International inflation stems from national sources, and the United States has been as great a culprit as any nation in breeding these evils. What is needed is the political courage, in the broad public interest, to curb the special- interest pressures that unbalance the budget, distort and waste national resources, including the arms race but by no means limited to the arms race.

title: FROM DADDO WITH LOVE
description: In his day, Rudyard Kipling was much esteemed for his way with a patriotic poem. But anyone familiar with ''The Jungle Book'' and ''Just So Stories'' will know that he derived endless pleasure, and inspiration, from children. Kipling was uncomfortable in the limelight, and his most treasured role was that of father to his three children - two of whom died tragically young. In ''O BELOVED KIDS'': Rudyard Kipling's Letters to His Children (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $16.95), Kipling's correspondence - selected and edited by Elliot L. Gilbert, the author of ''Kipling and the Critics'' and ''The Good Kipling'' - illuminates nine years (1906-1915) in the lives of two of those children, Elsie and John. Styling himself variously as ''Pater,'' ''Daddo'' and ''Thy Parent,'' Kipling cajoled, entertained and edified his ''Babes'' in hundreds of warm- hearted, totally unpatronizing letters filled with jolly sketches, puns and limericks. When John went away to school, his father prompted him, with imagination and good humor, on everything from hygiene to spelling. Kipling enlivened his letters with comforting news from home and compelling (albeit jingoistic) travelogues. Kipling's private life emerges as touchingly quotidian. He and his wife, Carrie (who is forever ailing and recuperating in these letters), spent the time between jaunts abroad tending their garden, walking the terriers, chatting with villagers, motoring about Sussex and, of course, writing letters. Contented in middle age and with the bulk of his achievements behind him, Kipling seemed happy to dedicate himself to the nurturing of his offspring.

title: PETER KIHSS, REPORTER FOR 49 YEARS, IS DEAD AT 72
description: Peter Kihss, a reporter for The New York Times and other news organizations for nearly half a century until his retirement in 1982, died of a heart attack Friday night at his home in Jamaica Estates, Queens. He was 72 years old.

title: Bears Plan to Vary Defense
description: The Chicago Bears, the underdogs by a touchdown in the playoff game against Washington Sunday, will try to crowd the Redskins into a corner with their defense, which was the best in the National Football League this year.

title: WHEN RULES NEED UPDATING
description: OFFICERS of cooperatives and condominiums frequently find after several years that their governing documents - the bylaws, house rules and proprietary leases - are out of step with current needs and may need amending.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: FROM BACH TO BERG IN HOLLAND, SKIING EAST OF THE ALPS
description: Netherlands Celebrates Great Music At 11 A.M. on New Year's Day, with church carillons throughout the country pealing out the music of Bach and Handel, the Netherlands will proclaim Musica '85.

title: Cordero Nears Title
description: Angel Cordero Jr., who has done it six times already, has all but wrapped up another New York riding championship.

description: To the Editor:

title: ; A Year of FailureFor Many Banks     in In
description: The bankers of the land aren't likely to recall 1984 as a good year. According to a tabulation released last week, 79 banks failed this year, many of them Sun Belt institutions that made bad bets on farm and real estate loans.

title: Scott Outruns Janicki In Fiesta Bowl by :004
description: Steve Scott, one of America's top milers, won the Fiesta Bowl 10-kilometer race for the second straight year, this time by 4 seconds from Don Janicki of Tucson today.

title: COOKE, ABOUT TO RETIRE, LOOKS BACK IN SATISFACTION
description: The courts of New York State are more efficient and respected than they were when he took the post six years ago, but important reforms remain to be carried out, the state's outgoing Chief Judge, Lawrence H. Cooke, said today.

title: TO THE TREASURY, SOME PERKS ARE RIPE FOR PLUCKING
description: If the Treasury Department's plan to restructure the nation's tax system becomes law, workers will have to pay taxes not only on their wages and salaries but also on the value of some of their fringe benefits. For many workers, that would not make much difference. They get little in the way of fringe benefits other than medical insurance or pension plans. But an increasing number, especially those who work for large, unionized manufacturing companies, are getting a quarter of their compensation or more in tax-free benefits such as employer-paid baby-sitting, dental care, legal fees and commuting costs. For them, such a change could mean a big bite out of their paychecks.

title: RECORD-HIGH TEMPERATURES PROVIDE BRIEF TASTE OF SPRING
description: The forsythia buds were opening at the New York Botanical Garden, and the azaleas in Central Park were showing pink at their tips. The bears in the Flushing Meadow Zoo were stumbling out of their winter stupor, and the llamas at the Children's Zoo in Central Park were romping near the fence.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW PLANTS PREPARE FOR THE COLD
description: ONE has to wonder what the results of the springlike temperatures of the past few weeks will be. Will plants be ready for real winter temperatures, or will they again get caught by a sudden drop in temperature, as they were last year?
