ART;
THE MAKING OF A GIFTED REALIST
description: TRENTON MEL LEIPZIG is a gifted realist painter, and how he got his gift is revealed in a retrospective of his work at the City Museum here through Jan. 27. Evidently, his high level of performance did not come easily.

title: THE LITTLE-KNOWN WORLD OF THE VIGILANTE
description: It was an ugly incident on an IRT express train, but it took an unexpected twist that seemed to strike a perversely satisfying chord among many New York subway riders.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: NEW JERSEY'S ''Broadcaster of the Year'' gets up at 6:30 every morning to take a brisk walk and send her six children, including triplets, off to school from their home in Morris Township. And she doesn't consider herself a ''star.''

title: OPERETTA: 'GONDOLIERS' BY GILBERT & SULLIVAN
description: Since the lamentable demise of the D'Oyly Carte company, its premiere comic baritone, John Reed, has had to find other employment. He still manages to sing Gilbert & Sullivan parts in Britain, occasionally. But most of his activity now seems to be in that hotbed of Anglophilism, the prodigal colonies of the United States of America. Mr. Reed serves as stage director of the Colorado Music Festival in Boulder and appears in comic roles - mostly Gilbert & Sullivan, of course - hither and yon.

title: BETTING ON THE VERDICT
description: The contingency-fee system makes winning everything. Rex Carr states that this system allows poor people to be represented, but he won't touch a case unless there is a deep pocket from which the damages can be paid.

title:
TWO VIEWS ON ARMS NEGOTIATIONS;
2. REASON FOR DESPAIR
description: All signs indicate that the Reagan Administration is moving in earnest to resume negotiations with the Russians on controlling nuclear weapons. This should be cause for hope. Yet judging by the agreements reached in the past two decades, the arms control cure may in the end be worse than the nuclear weapons disease. In the past, at least, each ''successful'' negotiation has in fact increased the nuclear threat.

title: CANCER DEATH: POLLUTION BLAMED IN SUIT
description: BRIDGEWATER A LOCAL citizens' group and the family of a deceased resident of this Somerset County community contend that chemical pollution of their wells by the Fisher Scientific Company contributed to, or was responsible for, at least three deaths and five cases of an immune-system disease all within a neighborhood of little more than a square mile.

title:
CAMERA ;
EXPERIMENTS IN SELF-PORTRAITURE
description: Lou Jacobs is a freelance photographer and writer. How often do photographers take advantage of built-in self-timers? By pressing a lever or button, shutter action can be delayed for 10 to 12 seconds. Most 35mm cameras have this feature which enables photographers to get into the pictures.

title: Jennifer Hocking Is the Bride of James E. Abbott
description: Jennifer Ann Hocking, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Hocking of New York, was married yesterday to James Edward Abbott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Abbott of Centerport, L.I. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, assisted by the Rev. Scott Pearce Hocking, an American Baptist minister, who is the bride's brother.

title: PADDLING DOWN THE ZAMBEZI
description: There was quiche and salad for lunch on the first day and an elephant shared the spot, deep in the Kariba Gorge of the Zambezi River, defoliating a tree as the travelers took their sustenance 15 yards away.

title: JAPAN SEARCHES FOR WAYS TO SQUARE ITS U.S. ACCOUNTS
description: Only a few months ago, officials from the United States and Japan marvelled at how well they were getting along under the leadership of President Reagan and Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone. In recent weeks, however, they have begun to talk about how relations between the two countries are, in fact, blemished by economic mistrust.

title: THE KREMLIN DEALS WITH A VACANCY FROM WITHIN
description: MOSCOW HE has little glamour and not much political power, and seems to have spent his career as a manager rather than as a man of ideas. He is unassertive enough to have stayed in the same job for the past 17 years, and too old to hold his new post for many years to come.

title: SCHOOL RECYCLED
description: Last year the Town of Mamaroneck had to decide whether to upgrade the old Mamaroneck Union Free and High School Building at 740 West Post Road, which housed offices and a center for the elderly, to meet new code standards.

title: DOLPHINS WIN, 31-10
description: The season ended today for the Giants, not in a playoff victory but not in shame, either. They were outplayed and outhit by the 49ers, they dissipated too many scoring opportunities and they lost, 21-10.

description: Anne Cameron Read Thomas, a daughter of Anne M. Thomas of Locust Valley, L.I., and James A. Thomas Jr. of Becket, Mass., was married at her mother's home yesterday to G. Anthony Siesfeld, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald A. Siesfeld of Pelham Manor and Averill Park, N.Y. The Rev. Nannene Goudy, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

BUSINESS FORUM;
THE BIGGEST ENEMY IS MOUNTING DEBT

title: ;  International
description: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1984 Preparations for the arms talks with the Soviet Union have produced a consensus among White House officials, they said, that the United States will not agree to limit research for a long- range defense against missiles. This apparent agreement, contained in papers being flown to California for President Reagan's perusal, was made known by officials who sought to end confusion over the Administraion's position. They said the Administration is prepared to be more flexible on procedural issues, which are the ostensible reason for the meeting between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko in Geneva on Jan. 7 and 8. (Page 1, Column 6.) Soviet and Chinese officials asserted that an important watershed had been passed in their long struggle to re-establish a good-neighborly relationship. The remarks were made as China's most important Soviet visitor in 15 years, Ivan V. Arkhipov, the First Deputy Prime Minister, departed for home. But the easing of relations is not as far-reaching as that achieved by China and the United States and will not be for many years, officials on both sides say. (1:4.)

description: Both Tom Osborne, the head football coach of Nebraska, and Booker Brown, who contends that Osborne violated N.C.A.A rules in trying to recruit him 12 years ago, have solidified their opposite positions on the issue by passing lie-detector tests. Three hundred of these instruments have recently been purchased by the county to help the county and local police find and arrest drunk drivers.

description: Stephen Schlesinger is co-author of ''Bitter Fruit: The Untold Story of the American Coup in Guatemala'' and serves on the staff of Governor Cuomo. SALVADOR WITNESS

title: A LANDSCAPE ENGULFED BY BLIGHT Outside, the hills still loomed grayly through a mist of smoke and dirt and fog. A city rolled by and Danny was struck initially by how many aerials there were - hundreds and hundreds really, prodding the sky any which way - then by a subtler apprehension of the whole electrical network, the telephone poles and power lines, the huge humming ugly infra-system that usually dissolves from one's sight, and finally by a freshened perception of the ugliness of this whole Japanese countryside. There, right before his eyes, a steam shovel was tucking into another hillside. ''It's like New Jersey, south of Manhattan,'' Greg had prophesied of this terrain west of Kobe. But more accurately what this was was a hideous parody of all those old
description: sumie landscapes he'd seen with Carrie in the museums. A delicate mist- hung mountain landscape opening to unveil, faintly, in the distance - what? A corrugated shed, a power line, a smokestack, a derrick, a traffic-congested street, a larger-than- man-sized replica of a bowling pin. . . Here it was, spread out before him, the absolute refutation of that pervasive Japanese conviction - which he'd so much wanted all year long to believe with them - that all things could be assimilated into their remarkable land while leaving its soul intact.

title: JERSEY WEDDING FOR MISS MENCKE
description: Alice Mary Mencke, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Bernhard Mencke of New Vernon, N.J., was married there yesterday to Robert Quin Montgomery, the son of S. Phelps Montgomery of New York and Mrs. John C. Giordano Jr. of Red Bank, N.J. Msgr. John F. Corr performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King.

title: Are Actors 'Cattle'? A few years prior to my arrival in Hollywood, I had been quoted as saying that all actors are cattle. I'm not sure in what context I might have made that statement. It may have been made in the early days of talkies in England, when we used actors who were simultaneously performing in stage plays. When they had a matinee, they'd leave the set, I felt, much too early for a matinee, and I suspected they were allowing themselves plenty of time for a very leisurely lunch. And this meant we had to shoot our scenes at breakneck speed so that the actors could get out on time. I couldn't help feeling that if they'd been really conscientious, they'd have swallowed their sandwich in the cab, on the way to the theater. . . . Another reason for resentment is that I'd sometimes hear two actresses talking in a restaurant. One would say to the other, ''What are you doing now, dear?'' and the other one would say, ''Oh, I'm filming,'' in the same tone of voice as if she were saying, ''Oh, I'm slumming.'' And this raises a grievance I have against those people who come into our industry by way of the theater or as writers and who work in our medium for the money only. I think the worst culprits are the writers, particularly those who are here in Hollywood. . . . Some playwrights sign three-month contracts just in order to spend their winters in California. By the way, how did we get on this subject? -
description: Alfred Hitchcock in ''Hitchcock.''

title: MEDICINE, LAW AND THE AMERICAN WAY OF DEATH
description: Dr. William A. Greene, a Rochester psychiatrist, recalls sitting in a medical school class in 1936 and listening as the professor warned about coming advances in medicines and machines. The mere prolongation of human life, the professor said, would create a whole new set of medical, moral and ethical dilemmas. The elderly, freed by antibiotics from the fatal threat of pneumonia, would be saved to die later of far more painful maladies still eluding cure. And doctors, who once had no choice but to accept a patient's death, would acquire awesome powers over when that final moment arrived.

title: SILVER AND GOLD Playing GamesNext week, the Treasury will destroy the dies used to make souvenir gold and silver coins for the Los Angeles Olympics. The coins, like the Games, were a roaring success, netting $65 million to help develop young Americans for future Games. Now let's hope the Games don't go the way of the dies. That gloomy thought derives from the disappointing results of the International Olympic Committee's recent meeting on anti-boycott strategy. Three consecutive boycotts, led by black Africans in 1976, America in 1980 and Russia this year, have diluted three consecutive Olympics. The I.O.C. confirmed its feeble reputation by deciding to do virtually nothing. Boycott possibilities remain serious. The I.O.C. chairman, Juan Antonio Samaranch, has reported receiving veiled threats that Russia, Poland and Cuba might boycott the 1988 games in South Korea.
description: The executive committee wanted to penalize boycotters by excluding them from at least two future Games, a penalty with real teeth in it.

title: NOT THE SAME OLD RICE
description: RICE IS BOTH ONE OF THE MOST basic of the world's foods and one of the most versatile. In our travels around the globe, we have always been fascinated by the different ways it is cooked. In Japan, recipes commonly call for washing the rice an hour before it is to be cooked and then letting it drain in the open air. In China, it is sometimes rinsed in several changes of water and cooked for one and one-half hours. In the American South, recipes for Creole rice often call for cooking it in a vast amount of water before draining and buttering. In my kitchen, except for special so-called ''foreign'' meals, the rice is rarely washed, but it is cooked in one and one-half times its volume of liquid for exactly 17 minutes.

title: THE BEST MAY BE A HARBINGER OF BRIGHTER DAYS
description: Thinking back on the 1984 theatrical year, a theatergoer may well find himself wanting to weep. And not, as you might suppose, simply because the New York theater is in sad shape. For all that's askew on our stages right now - assuming the stages are even occupied in the first place - the past 12 months have produced wounding and jubilant flesh-and-blood images that just won't depart.

title: Elmore Leonard's Rogue's Gallery
description: Something odd has happened to Birmingham, Mich. Once an unprepossessing satellite 15 miles north of Detroit, Birmingham has become an upscale suburban nexus - its broad main street a collection of trendy boutiques and gourmet takeout places that would be out of place in Detroit, its outlying highways a repository for ad agencies and financial service firms. All of a sudden, it is chic.

title: BUMPER CROP OF FREE AGENTS DUE IN 1985
description: The free-agent market, which languished for three weeks after the draft, heated up in a hurry, and in precisely one month clubs signed the 11 most attractive free agents for a total of $49 million. So now what?

title: HEADLINERS;
description: Knesset Clamps Down One of the reasons Rabbi Meir Kahane left the United States to live in Israel was, apparently, to explain personally to native Arabs why they should leave his adopted country. Not surprisingly, many Israeli Arabs have taken offense at his suggestions.

title: WOMEN WALKED OFF WITH NEARLY ALL OF THE HONORS
description: This was the year of the woman in music. As I look back at the events of 1984 that I remember most vividly, I find female performers dominating to a shocking degree. As a loyal male, I refuse to draw sweeping sociological or artistic conclusions from this landslide, but there it is, a phenomenon that must be faced. Let me document the situation as I see it through my admittedly restricted peephole into the recent past.

title: VOLUNTEERS HELP INJURED ANIMALS RETURN TO THE WILD
description: THE warm light of late afternoon filters gently through the woods near Silver Lake Park in Harrison. Inside a cozy house nestled beneath the trees, Dona Lakin and Glen Tracy ruminate upon the special beauty ofthe county and the abuses they fear may change it forever. For Miss Lakin and Mr. Tracy, this is no idle conversation. Westchester's natural environment is the focus of their lives, and they are working to bring a greater awareness of its problems to the people of the county.

title: LOOKING BACK ON 1984: WHAT THEY'LL REMEMBER MOST
description: AS the year drew to a close, the Long Island Weekly section asked a random selection of Long Islanders what they will most remember about 1984 on the Island. Here are their replies: Robin Horsley of Bellport, a teacher: ''When I look back, I am constantly amazed at Long Island's resilience. Despite incessant battering by developers, county and state 'improvements' and careless people, she manages to shine through her parks, her beaches and her ambience. Long Island is a survivor.'' Harriet Lesser of Woodmere, a writer: ''In 1984, Long Island was called upon to pay its environ mental dues. For the first time, garbage literally became a burning issue. Legislators and medical authorities were inundated with complaints about water pollution. In Nassau County, which has one of the highest cancer rates in the nation, the public finally began to assert itself - as evidenced by the protest over the Oceanside landfill. It had been going on for at least a decade. But the voices of the people were not heard until this year. In 1984, we saw the beginning of the people's revolt against pollution.''

title: COALITION TO PRESS FOR SEAT-BELT LAW
description: WHEN the state legislature convenes next month, Dr. Kenneth Dardick and members of his group intend to press the lawmakers to adopt a mandatory seat-belt law.

title: What's in It for Them
description: Is patriarchy hiding behind the skirts of women's romance fiction? According to ''Reading the Romance'' by Janice A. Radway, such books ''confirm the validity of the traditional female role in the patriarchal society.'' The fact that their enormous popularity has occurred since 1960, alongside the raised consciousness of feminism, may be due to more than improved marketing techniques.

title: Egypt Will Release Coptic Church's Leader
description: The spiritual leader of Egypt's Copts, who has been in exile at a remote desert monastery since 1981, will be freed in time to conduct a Christmas service on Jan. 7, a church official said today.

description: Sorting out the year's best classical records is a little like making plausible critical distinctions among snowflakes while being buried by an avalanche. Still, before we begin the actual selection process, a few generalizations about the year in records can be offered.

title: JERSEY HOSTS KEEPING DRUNKS FROM DRIVING

description: The Mobil Corporation yesterday announced the resignation of Stephen L. Pistner, president and chief executive officer of its financially troubled subsidiary, Montgomery Ward & Company, one of the country's largest retailers.

title: IS SHOREHAM NEARING A POINT OF NO RETURN?
description: SUPPORTERS and opponents of the Long Island Lighting Company's Shoreham Nuclear Power Station are now arguing about a new part of the reactor: its point of no return.

title: HEARTY MEALS FOR WINTER
description: HEARTY peasant meals that can be served in one large platter are perfect for winter entertaining. description: When the House and Senate open the 99th session of Congress Thursday, legislative leaders say the biggest issue they will face is the Federal budget deficit - the same big issue they have faced each of the last four years.

title: No Headline
description: The Year of the Prisoner Bartlett's isn't sure that Burke ever uttered the famous line credited to him: ''The only thing necessary for the triumph of evil is for good men to do nothing.'' But the exhortation is timeless. Decent impulses are diffuse; evil is willed and specific. This is bitterly understood by political prisoners who are torn from normal life for the crime of belief, and vanish into that limbo where persons become abstractions.

description: Guerrillas eluded tight security to bombard Kabul, the Afghan capital, with rockets on at least five successive nights last week, Western diplomats here said today.

title: FLUTIE SHOWS GRACE UNDER A NEW BLITZ
description: THE playing field is where he is most at home, where he is known as No. 22, the starting quarterback, or simply Doug because he is not even the only Flutie on the Boston College football team. On the playing field, he is one of the guys, undistinguished in a sea of maroon-and-gold-clad players, most of them bigger and more imposing than he. On the playing field, the only ones who want a piece of Doug Flutie are the players on the opposing team.

title: THE UNLOVABLE PRESS (2)
description: BOSTON Mayor Koch of New York is a rumbustious politician, admired and detested with equal fervor. So it was something of a surprise when he said in a speech last month that he had never been involved in a libel suit. He was often aggrieved at the press, but he never sued - and he had no complaints. Why?

title: SUSPECT HELD IN CLINIC ATTACKS
description: Federal agents arrested Matthew John Goldsby of Cantonment today and charged him with bombings at three abortion clinics Christmas Day and a bombing at one of the clinics on June 25.

title: GIANTS ARE UPBEAT IN THEIR FAREWELLS
description: It is as much a ritual of football as the tailgate picnic, the coin toss and the halftime entertainment, though hardly as visible or glamorous. It is the annual chore of cleaning out the lockers when the season is over, and the Giants went through it today at Giants Stadium.

title: A NEW LOOK FOR AMERICAN HERITAGE
description: Our beat is anything that ever happened in America,'' Bruce Catton declared in 1954, the year he was named editor of the newly established American Heritage. That credo has not changed in the intervening 30 years, but much else about the American Heritage Publishing Company has.

title: CAMBODIANS SAY HANOI SUFFERED 100 CASUALTIES
description: Cambodian non-Communist guerrillas, fighting Vietnamese troops in the heart of an overrun rebel camp, said today that they had killed or wounded about 100 of Hanoi's soldiers but had sustained serious losses of their own.

title: Theresa Rakov Clowns Through Her Songs
description: Show business whimsy in the spirit of ''Little Me'' is the forte of the promising singer-comedienne Theresa Rakov. In collaboration with her song and dialogue writer, Tim Grundmann, Miss Rakov has created a fictional show-business ''never-was'' named Terri, who sings and narrates an autobiography that she cheerfully characterizes as ''a field trip through the sewers of life.''

title: Budd Is First In Return
description: Zola Budd, the 18-year-old South African who competed in the Los Angeles Olympics for Britain after it had quickly granted her citizenship based on her grandfather's birth there, returned to international competition today with a victory in the Silvester road race.

Jane Elizabeth Dennison, Doctoral Candidate, Wed
description: The Presbyterian Church in Lawrenceville, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Jane Elizabeth Dennison, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James E. Dennison of Lambertville, N.J., to Wai-Kwong Kwok, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kam Yuk Kwok of Kobe, Japan.

title: Blount on Africa
description: ''More Americans need to go abroad,'' Mel Blount says. ''They would appreciate this country more.''

title: A LATE CHRISTMAS BUYING SPREE BUOYS RETAILERS
description: A last-minute shopping surge that began just before Christmas continued through the final days of 1984, as shoppers, conditioned by pre-Christmas markdowns, returned to look for greater bargains. Retailers said the push helped them post a 7 to 20 percent sales gain for December - versus December 1983 - in an otherwise disappointing Christmas season.

title: Pregnant Woman Slain; Baby Dies
description: A woman eight months' pregnant was stabbed to death in the hallway of a Harlem apartment building Saturday, the police said.

title: Arafat, in Jordan, Blames Syria for Killing
description: The chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat, arrived here from Southern Yemen today, a day after the assassination of a senior P.L.O. official, and he accused Syria of being behind the killing.

title: HERE, TEACHING TOOLS ARE STUDENTS' HANDS
description: The keyboard of an old Ivers & Pond piano lay across a bench and the parts of the cabinet stood on end as Gary Ford completed the job of stripping the wood and adding a red mahagony stain.

title: No Headline
description: A Token but Sober Gift A hearty New Year's toast to New York's Mayor Koch, City Council President Bellamy and Governor Cuomo for insisting on free transit fares tonight and tomorrow morning. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority had resisted the idea as too expensive.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''People will enjoy a high living standard, enjoy a good material and cultural life. Is this bad?'' - Deng Xiaoping, China's paramount leader.

title: COLUMBIA FACES THREAT OF STRIKE OVER UNION VOTE
description: The union seeking to become the bargaining agent for clerical and technical workers at Columbia University is threatening to call a strike when classes resume in mid-January unless the university recognizes it and agrees to begin contract negotiations.

title: Boy Kills Friend In Bronx Shooting
description: A Bronx teen-ager shot and killed a friend Saturday, apparently while playing with a handgun in his bedroom, the police said yesterday.

description: Great deceptive plays have to be made quickly and nonchalantly, and even for great players that is difficult. But if they have thought about the position, the right play may pop up, years later, when the opportunity arises.

description: Leontyne Price, the great soprano who has held center stage of the Metropolitan Opera for almost a quarter of a century, will leave her operatic career Thursday night ''to steal a little time'' for herself.

description: Hilary Hinds, a fellow at Columbia University's East Asian Institute, and Junichi Kitasei, a New York producer for Asahi Television of Japan, were married yesterday in the chapel at the Church Center for the United Nations. The Rev. Jack Haney, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.

description: Tyler Larter scored three goals and had two assists today to lead Team Atlantic, a Maritime all-star under-17 squad, to a 9-4 triumph over the visiting Soviet national midget team.

description: Gunmen abducted three foreign journalists from a restaurant, robbed them and threatened to kill them before releasing them several hours later, the journalists said today.

description: b-Including a tax credit of $117,600.

title: Red Rover, Dead Rover
description: Many trappings of the holidays, such as stringed popcorn, tree ornaments, mistletoe, artificial snow and poinsettia plants, are hazards for dogs, cats and other household pets.

title: MISSOURI UPSETS NORTH CAROLINA, 81-76
description: Missouri converted 15 free throws over the final 2 minutes 45 seconds with Dan Bingenheimer making five over the last 42 seconds, to upset North Carolina, 81-76, for the title of the Hawaii Pacific College Invitational.

title: Brette Popper Is Bride Of Paul Brian Spraos
description: Brette Erica Popper, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anton R. Popper of Rio Rancho, N.M., was married yesterday to Paul Byron Spraos, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Spraos of London. Acting Justice Beverly S. Cohen of State Supreme Court officiated at the Manhattan home of the bride's aunt and uncle, Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Cooper.

title: DIVORCE 101: COLUMBIA PIONEERING IN FAMILY LAW
description: David Allen, a physician, and his wife, Lynne, are getting a divorce after 15 years of marriage. Lynne claims that David's affair with his laboratory assistant caused the breakup, while David feels that Lynne's devotion to her new career in real estate is responsible.

title: WOMEN IN 1984: STEPS FORWARD AND BACK
description: Women, who have long had role models on the road to equality, acquired their share of heroes this year: The first woman to run for the vice presidency on the ticket of a major party. The first American woman to walk in space. A team of American female athletes who ran, swam, cycled, somersaulted, dribbled basketballs and otherwise competed to win 62 gold medals in the Summer Olympics.

title: Iraqi Planes Said to Raid Town and Village in Iran
description: Iraqi aircraft raided an Iranian town and a village in a valley near the southern front of the Persian Gulf war today, killing at least 14 people and wounding nearly 100, the official Iranian press agency reported.

description: Local advocates for the unemployed say they are weary of having to explain that they are not part of the group whose members have occupied a church in defiance of a court order.

description: The Rev. Joseph H. Bond, rector emeritus of St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Sayville, L.I., died of kidney failure Friday at his home in Sayville. He was 95 years old.

description: The Tandy Corporation today will introduce a long-expected successor to its Model 100 briefcase-sized computer, which pioneered the market for lap machines before being sur- passed by more powerful competi- tors.

description: Really they had wanted to hoist Mark Pavelich to their shoulders, so joyous were the Rangers to have him back. ''We'll hug him and we'll tell him what he did for us tonight,'' said James Patrick, ''but we'll also keep the game in persective.''

title: DRIVER BADLY BEATEN AT SCENE
description: A woman was hit by a car in Harlem and killed early yesterday, and the driver was badly beaten after a witness followed him from the scene and persuaded him to return, the police said.

title: MILITARY 'ACCIDENTS'?
description: A report that a secret helicopter unit of the 101st Airborne Division repeatedly makes covert forays into ''hostile regions'' of Central America ''to aid pro-American forces'' surfaced recently. Earlier this month, the Knight-Ridder newspapers reported that families of Americans killed in such actions were told their sons or husbands had died in accidents in places far from Central America, like South Fox Island, in northeastern Lake Michigan. Whether true or not (there has been no confirmation) this report is painfully familiar to me.

title: PERSONAL EXPERIENCE LEADS MANY DONORS TO AID THE NEEDIEST
description: Concern for a sick or disabled relative or friend often moves contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to ask that their donations be used to ease the distress of someone similarly afflicted.

title: IN CHINA, UPWARD MOBILITY
description: China's economic reforms have captured the attention of businessmen, diplomats and politicians, but a less publicized restructuring of society is likely to have an even greater impact on modernization efforts.

title: Scratching Heads Together
description: More than 2,000 philosophers were

title: NAKOSONE TO MEET REAGAN THIS WEEK
description: President Reagan will meet with Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone in Los Angeles on Wednesday but it is unlikely that he will make specific demands for Japan to narrow its trade deficit with the United States, according to Administration officials.

title: RABBIS COMBINE JEWISH LITURGIES IN PRAYER BOOK FOR MILITARY
description: The armed forces have just printed a new prayer book for Jewish military personnel that incorporates the Orthodox, Conservative and Reform liturgies into one unified service.

title: SUIT BY HOMELESS SEEKS ORANGE COUNTY SHELTERS
description: Seven homeless men and women have sued Orange County in an attempt to force the county to provide emergency shelters for all its homeless people.

title: Music at the Maestro Led by Larry Woodard
description: The musical fare at the Maestro, a restaurant across Broadway from Lincoln Center at 58 West 65th Street, is a reflection of the musical variety to be found at the center. It is built around Larry Woodard, a pianist and singer and one of the owners of the room, who can slither through ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' in the Fats Waller mannner (he even looks like Mr. Waller when he sings it), move on to an operatic aria and fall back to a medley of sentimental songs.

title: ANALYSTS CITE OPEC SPLIT ON SHIFT IN PRICING
description: The failure of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to reach a unanimous agreement on a crucial pricing arrangement will probably mean a further decline in world oil prices in the face of shrinking demand, analysts said today.

title: MAKING JOYFUL NOISE, TONS OF IT
description: As midnight nears on Monday, some people will pop champagne corks, some will blow into noisemakers, some will set off firecrackers, some will simply bang pots and pans together. But a group of Washingtonians will be ringing out the old year and ringing in the new, literally and loudly.

title: UNESCO HEAD DENOUNCES U.S. DELEGATE
description: The director general of Unesco, Amadou Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal, has strongly criticized Jean Gerard, the departing American representative to the agency, calling her ignorant and ''a politician.''

title: HOW COLOR BLIND IS BRAZIL? A CHALLENGE BY BLACKS
description: First, young men started nailing up posters proclaiming Black Mother's Day. Then a black Father Christmas appeared. When Antonio dos Santos and some 3,000 followers insisted on wearing African robes in the carnival parade, there were quiet visits from the police.

title: NEW WAY TO DISPOSE OF HUDSON PCB'S TESTED
description: A new method of disposing of hazardous sediments of PCB's in the Hudson River is being tested by a private company in Waukegan, Ill., in cooperation with the state.

title: MONTGOMERY WARD'S CHIEF RESIGNS
description: Stephen L. Pistner is resigning as president and chief executive of the Montgomery Ward division of the Mobil Corporation, and has accepted a position with another company that represents ''a real course change for me,'' he said yesterday.

title: Michigan Player Wins Tournament
description: Luke Jensen of Grand Rapids, Mich., seeded No. 2, defeated Thomas Muster of Austria, 6-1, 6-0, in the boys 18-year division final of the Rolex International Junior Championships today at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1984 International 40 of China's top military men retired in what appeared to be the most important shake-up in China's General Staff in years. The retirements, which resulted from insistent prodding, appear to mark a major step forward in Deng Xiaoping's drive to rid the aging officer corps of veterans who have resisted his campaign to get the four-million member armed forces out of politics and into a more modern approach to warfare. (Page 1, Column 6.) Angola's almost hidden civil war has left countless dead, 20,000 amputees and aggravated malnourishment for one-third of the people of the once-fertile highlands. The rebels are led by Jonas Savimbi, of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, Unita, a pro-Western group. Opposing him is Angola's Marxist Government, led by the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola. (1:5.)

title: BARNWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: West 72d Street Loses a Pet Store
description: This pet story is not so upbeat.

title: INDIA STATE PLANS TO FILE U.S. SUITS ON GAS LEAK
description: The state government of Madhya Pradesh said today that it would file suit in the United States on behalf of the victims of the poison gas leak from the Union Carbide plant here that killed more than 2,000 people.

title: Fire Destroys Lighthouse
description: A fire termed suspicious destroyed the Port Mahon Lighthouse here Saturday night.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. , Cincinnati, has named Michael Steinberg, executive vice president of its Bloomingdale's unit, to be president of its Dallas-based Sanger Harris division.

title: ISLANDERS ARE WARNED: IMPROVE OR ELSE
description: Before the night began, Bill Torrey said he would probably make more moves. He had called up Gord Dineen and Ron Handy from the minors earlier in the day. And, after Saturday night's 5-1 victory over the St. Louis Blues, the Islander general manager was more convinced that further changes had to be made.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: REFLECTIVES New York's two loftiest perches are high enough for looking back even more than a year, which is what some people like to do on New Year's Eve. The Empire State Building and the World Trade Center offer overall vistas for tourists, but for locals they can provide platforms for contemplative reflection, in a lofty perspective that reduces the rush of people in streets below to the petty meanderings of ants. Or one may appreciate, from far above city noise and grime, the wonders created by man. If poetry fails, there is always the spectacle that, on a clear day, reaches as far as Connecticut, across the Hackensak plain to outer New Jersey, and even Pennsylvania.

title: Doctors Seek Candidate For Next Artificial Heart
description: Dr. William C. DeVries, head of the team that performed the world's second artificial heart implant on William J. Schroeder in November, said heart patients would be interviewed this week in a screening process for the next artificial heart implant, The Los Angeles Times reported today.

title: BELOW CHAMBERS ST., AN URBAN FRONTIER IS WILD NO MORE
description: In the old days, the days before the supermarket, before the dry cleaners, before the liquor store, before the descent of the Yuppies, Kathleen Gupta could hear crickets from her apartment window at the tip of lower Manhattan. Listening to the incessant chirping, a sound that seemed somehow misplaced at the edge of the concrete canyons of Wall Street, Mrs. Gupta and her neighbors in Gateway Plaza felt like the city's last pioneers.

title: Florida Officials Protest Air Force Project in Park
description: Air Force plans to build a space shuttle tracking station in a state park known for its deer, alligators and natural beauty have prompted protests from officials.

title: Union Special Gives New Titles to 2 Officers
description: The Union Special Corporation said that J. Grant Beadle has been elected chairman of the industrial sewing machine maker and Carlo A. Kaiser has been appointed president.

title: UNIVERSAL MONEY CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. SAID TO PLAN CENSURE OF POLAND ON RIGHTS
description: The Reagan Administration plans to issue a report contending that Poland has broadened its suppression of individual rights since the 1981 declaration of martial law, a senior State Department official said today.

title: KOCH APPROACH TO RACIAL ISSUES DRAWS CRITICISM
description: Mayor Koch's relationship with the city's minority groups was again the focus of criticism yesterday, as a city union leader accused the Mayor of ''pandering'' to white voters and a potential rival of the Mayor said Mr. Koch intended to wage ''a racial campaign'' for re-election.

title: Boy, 3, Fatally Beaten; His Father Is Arrested
description: A 3-year-old boy was beaten to death by his father in the East New York section of Brooklyn yesterday after the child spilled some water, and his father burst into a rage, the police said.

title: 40 HIGH OFFICERS RETIRE IN CHINA IN ARMY SHAKE-UP
description: In what appeared to be the most important shake- up in China's General Staff in years, 40 officers at corps level or above - equivalent to at least three-star generals in the United States - have responded to insistent prodding and have retired.

title: 1 DEAD AND 45 HURT IN RIOT IN MEXICO
description: One man died and 45 people were reported hurt today after supporters of a defeated mayoral candidate went on a nighttime rampage in this city near the Texas border. The violence continued until dawn, when the Mexican Army moved in.

description: Taxis never seem so scarce as on

description: Monday

title: MONDAY SPORTS Football
description: Texas Christian (8-3) vs. West Virginia (7-4), Bluebonnet Bowl, at Houston. T.C.U. impressive this season in turning around its 1-8-2 record of last year.

title: BOOM FOR PARTY DISK JOCKEYS
description: While many people spend much of December celebrating, winding down a long year of work with a round of parties and family gatherings, the holiday season is the climax of the business year for Jun Mescallado. His workload triples, and he increases his fees, making a big push before toting up the year's results.

title: ANGOLA'S CIVIL WAR REDUCES A FERTILE DISTRICT TO HUNGER
description: Nine years ago, Jonas Savimbi made this city the capital of his short-lived Democratic Republic of Angola. Today he is trying to strangle it.

description: because of the New Year's holiday. The Treasury Department

description: Preparations for the Reagan

title: NO FRANCO, JUST FRANK
description: The names on their uniforms have changed, but the Pittsburgh Steelers haven't. Once again they are in the American Conference championship game, two victories away from their fifth Super Bowl championship.

title: BEARS AND STEELERS WIN TO ADVANCE TO TITLE GAMES
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers made life miserable for John Elway the first time they saw him. And not much changed today.

title: Rousseau Retrospective
description: A major retrospective of the artist Henri Rousseau will open on Feb. 21 at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street. The exhibition features masterpieces from permanent collections at the Modern and the Reunion des Musees Nationaux de France, as well as several private collections.

title: Bad Transmissions Killed 77, Auto Safety Group Asserts
description: An automobile safety group said today that 77 people had been killed because of a problem with Ford transmissions in the four years since a compromise between the Government and Ford headed off a large-scale recall.

title: WORLD'S STOCK EXCHANGES EXPERIENCE A DIFFICULT YEAR
description: It has been a difficult year for most major stock exchanges, with Toronto and New York losing ground and minor gains on other exchanges offset by inflation and depreciation of their currencies.

title: MUSIC: NEW YORK STRING ORCHESTRA
description: For the last 15 years Alexander Schneider has spent the winter holidays leading the New York String Orchestra Seminar, an 11-day workshop for students and young professionals between the ages of 15 and 22. The course culminates in a pair of Carnegie Hall concerts; this year's second, given Saturday evening, was one more testament to the work of a musician whose dedication to seeking out and developing string talent in this country has been tireless.

title: STUBBORN PROBLEMS AT WOLLMAN RINK GIVE SKATERS SCANT HOPE FOR SEASON
description: For the fifth season in a row, the hiss of blades on ice, the screams of children venturing out on shaky ankles and the waltzes lilting above the circling skaters have been absent from the Wollman Memorial Rink in Central Park.

title: UNIVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including net gains on the sale of facilities of $7,489,000, or $1.35 a share. Year-ago results have been restated to include only operations retained by the corporation after a March 1, 1984 distribution of its manufacturing activities to its shareholders.

title: ANALYSTS CITE MANY FACTORS FOR SWINGS
description: The credit markets at year-end would seem familiar to a bond investor who has been hibernating for the past year. Interest rates have come down, but economists and analysts are predicting higher rates for the year ahead, just as they did a year ago, and are citing many of the same reasons they did at the end of 1983.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: When Dan Marino of the Miami Dolphins threw his 37th touchdown pass of the season earlier this month, he broke the record he shared with George Blanda and Y. A. Tittle. How much success did Blanda's and Tittle's teams have in the seasons each threw for 36 touchdowns?

title: COMPUTER TERMINAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: OFFIC POOL, 1985
description: WASHINGTON Here, for the high rollers of punditry, is the office pool in Cassandra's Casino. Nobody ever gets more than four correct, but when you hit on a big one, all the predictions that went awry are washed away.

title: Ohio County Concerned By Animal Mutilations
description: Dozens of cats, dogs and chickens have been mutilated in what the police think may be the work of a satanic cult.

title: SALOMON TOP '84 UNDERWRITER
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. easily dominated the business of bringing new debt and equity issues to market in 1984. The investment bank acted as lead underwriter for 186 issues totaling $21.2 billion, a record 25.8 percent of the market.

title: HARRIS & PAULSON INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
RICHARDSON GETTING BETTER, AND HE'LL TELL YOU SO
description: Micheal Ray Richardson was dribbling down the side of the court at Byrne Meadowlands Arena Wednesday night against the Detroit Pistons' Brooke Steppe. As the two crossed midcourt, Richardson looked Steppe directly in the eye and said, ''I'm going by you right now.''

title: Celebrating to Music Around the World
description: For music, New Year's Eve is the

title: TV OPERA: 'MANON' FOR BBC
description: Metromedia Television has established a tradition of venturing somewhat out of the ordinary during the December holidays, and this year's elegant package, being presented tonight at 7:30 on WNEW/Channel 5, contains Giacomo Pucccini's ''Manon Lescaut.'' The production was recorded for the BBC at the Royal Opera at Covent Garden, London, in May of 1983.

title: CONCERT: CLASSIC CHAMBER ORCHESTRA
description: In yet another attempt to melt away nationalistic divisions of style and sensibility, the Classic Chamber Orchestra visited Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday night. The conductor and the repertory were Spanish, the players American.

title: BRUINS STOP JETS
description: Dave Donnelly's first-period goal sparked the Boston Bruins' comeback from an early 2-0 deficit as they downed the Winnipeg Jets, 5-3, tonight.

title: No Headline
description: Hold High the High-Tech Torch Last summer, a relay team of runners, each running one mile, carried the Olympic torch from New York to Los Angeles through 33 states. Last week, a commercial airliner carried the Statue of Liberty's torch from New York to the Tournament of Roses at Los Angeles without touching the soil in between.

title: The Rev. Jose M. Viana, 48, Leader of Cursillo Movement
description: The Rev. Jose M. Viana, a Roman Catholic priest and a leader of the Cursillo movement for spiritual renewal, died of heart failure Dec. 24 while on vacation in his native town of Pamplona, Spain. He was 48 years old and lived at St. Joseph's Center at 523 West 142d Street in Manhattan.

title: STATE BEGINNING ITS ENFORCEMENT OF SEAT BELT USE
description: Compliance with New York's seat belt law, the subject of long legislative debates over public safety and personal choice, becomes mandatory at midnight tonight, making New York the first state in the country with fines for drivers and front-seat passengers who fail to buckle their seat belts.

title: Wallace Hospitalized To Treat Exhaustion
description: Mike Wallace, the CBS News correspondent, was admitted to Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan yesterday morning suffering from exhaustion, a CBS spokesman said. The hospital listed Mr. Wallace's condition as stable and said he was being treated by his personal physician.

title: Hedley Woodhouse;Was Leading Jockey
description: Hedley Woodhouse, a jockey who rode 103 stakes winners and won 2,642 races, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Franklin Square, L.I. He was 64 years old.

title: Dr. Geri Ann Kleinman Wed to Dr. James Kibrick
description: Dr. Geri Ann Kleinman, a dentist, and Dr. James Kibrick, a radiologist, were married yesterday at the Scanticon Hotel in Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Irving Schreier performed the ceremony.

title: AMERICAN FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
FANS FLOCK TO DALLAS
description: A recreational vehicle with Massachusetts license plates pulled into the visitors' information stop just west of Texarkana on Interstate 30 Friday afternoon. Five Boston College students spilled out to stretch legs and take a breather before making the final leg on their 1,800-mile trip from Boston to Dallas.

title: Books of The Times; NAMED APARTMENTS
description: LIVING IT UP: A Guide to the Named

title: BURLINGTON COAT FACTORY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MARRIAGE OF FRIEND: MIXED BLESSING
description: IT can be the best of times and the

title: SAN DIEGO DOWNS COSMOS IN SHOOTOUT
description: The Cosmos have improved slightly since Ray Klivecka replaced Eddie Firmani as coach three weeks ago, but not enough to move out of last place in the Eastern Division of the Major Indoor Soccer League.

title: L.I. Man, 77, Killed by Train
description: A man was killed today when he was struck by a Long Island Rail Road train as he tried to cross the tracks, the Suffolk County police said. A police spokesman, Officer Joseph Grimes, said the man, Gustav Siering, a 77- year-old resident at a local home for the elderly, apparently walked around the crossing guard at the L.I.R.R. tracks and was hit by a westbound train at about 10 A.M.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Florida Thrift Unit Names Chairman
description: Morris N. Broad, 49 years old, has been elected chairman and chief executive of the American Savings and Loan Association of Florida.

title: Kathleen Tormey Wed To Timothy Thornton
description: Kathleen Marie Tormey, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Bernard Tormey of Garden City and Quogue, L.I., was married yesterday to Timothy Hobart Thornton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Reid Thornton of Shaker Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Joseph Kelly performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City.

title: BURGER URGES CONGRESS TO HELP CUT COURT LOAD
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger today renewed his call to Congress for help with the Supreme Court's caseload.

title: Pain Reliever
description: An inventive, 63-year-old suburban Philadelphia man has helped Gerald Ford walk without pain and Jimmy Carter run without pain. In fact, for 40 years G. E. (Moose) Detty has tried to make life less painful for many.

title: Tax-Exempt Pattern Varies In the tax-exempt market, the pattern of rates was different from that in the Treasury sector, mostly because state and local governments unleashed a flood of new issues in the last quarter of the year.
description: In October and November, for example, yields on long- term tax-exempt bonds rose even though Treasury yields were falling. The Bond Buyer Index of long-term revenue bonds rose to 10.62 percent on Nov. 29, from 10.56 percent on Aug. 30, while 30-year Treasury bond yields fell to 11.42 percent, from 12.57 percent.

title: EX-ENVOY TO U.S.
description: Nobuhiko Ushiba, a leading Japanese diplomat, international trade negotiator and former Ambassador to the United States, died today of a liver ailment at a Tokyo hospital. He was 75 years old.

title: SIZING UP OF VISITORS FROM AFAR
description: Warm weather and winning football may not chase away all of south Florida's problems, but they have combined to make this holiday season one of the best in recent years.

title: HOW TO COMBAT DRUNKENNESS
description: Almost everyone believes that the tough Scandinavian approach to drunken driving is the answer to an old and worrisome problem that is accentuated each New Year's Eve. I think they are wrong. In the long run, a broad effort to educate the public on how to control drunkenness would be far more effective.

title: Dr. Leonard C. Feldstein Dies; Taught Philosophy of Science
description: Dr. Leonard Charles Feldstein, a professor of philosophy at Fordham University and a psychoanalyst, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Redding, Conn. He was 62 years old.

title: Diane Dixon Wins 800 in 2:11.78
description: Diane Dixon, preparing for the World Games in Paris next month, won the 800-meter run in 2 minutes 11.78 seconds, and Tatiana Smolin high- jumped 5 feet 6 inches, the best in the country by a schoolgirl this season, in the Metropolitan Athletics Congress indoor track and field meet today at Princeton.

title: Bucks Beat Celtics For 8th in Row
description: Terry Cummings sparked a 10-0 spurt early in the fourth quarter that carried the Milwaukee Bucks to a 114-98 triumph over the Boston Celtics tonight, their eighth in a row.

title: Economic Calendar Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.
description: Monday

title: Airlines Back In the Black
description: The world's airline industry, back in the black for the first time since 1978, is expected to reap a collective net profit of about $800 million this year, the International Air Transport Association's retiring chief executive said. In his farewell year-end message, the association's Director General, Knut Hammarskjold, said Friday that the association's 134 member airlines could also expect positive results in 1985 and 1986, ''assuming the economic recovery is sustained.'' Mr. Hammarskjold said substantially better financial performances were needed bymember airlines faced with expenses that he estimated might total as much as $200 billion over the next 10 years to buy new equipment and cope with world traffic growth. Mr. Hammarskjold will be succeeded by Gunter Eser, an executive with Lufthansa, the West German flag airline.

title: TERRORISTS WON'T TALK TO THE 'GREAT SATAN'
description: To the Editor:
